reviews.review: Architectural Marvel. If you are in Siem Reap to visit Angkor Wat, do not miss out on some of the other stunning temples and angkors in the area. If possible get a guide who can tell you about these places like our guide Mr. Phally from Indichina Odyssey tours did for us. Bayon Temple is another must see but it is better if you know more about when and why it was built. Enjoy
Better than Angkor Wat. One of the best and most iconic temples near Siem Reap. Try to visit it off season to get a better impression and beat the touist masses.

The most interesting temple in the Angkor reservation. This is a large temple, whose distinguishing feature is massive faces carved into the walls and turrets. In my opinion this is the most beautiful temple in the reservation, even more than the Angkor Wat

The smiling temple. It is definitely one of the prettiest and unique temples among so many temples in angkor archeological park. The structures with the mysterious smiling face are absolutely stunning. Bayon temples is standing out than other temples as this is the only one with the beautiful features. It also has less stairs to climb so it is easily acesssible and beautiful!
Amazing. This is the second temple we visited and it was just as amazing as Angkor Wat. Take your time to explore and of course take plenty of photo's. Loved It.
Amazing. This is my first visit to Bayon ... and i was amazed by the architecture and it is truly amazing to visit Bayon Temple .... The view is fantastic and I totally fall in love with Bayon ......

Unbelievable I kissed a buddha. Not really but our tour guide took us to a popular site where you can blow a kiss and look like you are getting piggy with a Buddha in the background. The four faces sculptures and opportunities for sweeping photographs make this a must see temple visit.

Unique experience. This temple is just amazing, with its numerous faces, all with different expressions on their faces. It is so large that it takes up to an hour to explore and is just one of the Angkor complex.

Must see. We arrived at the Bayon Temple around 3pm. Most of the heavy crowds had passed and it was most pleasant just wondering around. This temple had the most intricate carvings and beautiful intact walls etc... great entrance as you enter also... take note of the statues on the bridge ... most interesting

You'll Rarely Visit a Place Quite Like This. Not much more I can say beyond the pictures other have posted other than the fact that you will rarely every set foot in such an enchanting place. We were caught in a rainstorm while visiting in mid-June 2015 and that did not detract one bit from our personal tour. In fact - it perhaps added to the visit, like a scene from an adventure movie of the 1930s - 1950s or Indiana Jones today. I could've stayed at The Bayon for hours longer than I was able to. There's something very calming about it.
Absolutely thrilling. Try to be here when it is not too much people. These ruins are truly amazing and one of the "mandatory" views, so expect a lot of people.

Amazing, monkeys were a bonus! . We thought it was better than Angkor Wat. Really worth stopping To check out!
We did get to see some resident monkeys whilst walking around. They fought amongst each other but posted for photos for us :)

BAYON TEMPLE MIGHT EVEN BE MORE SHOCKING (BEAUTY), THAN ANGKOR WAT. When you visit Angkor Wat - you should be prepared to see 100 beautiful (and even more beautiful) sights in a limited time.Our superb guide (Sopheara Pheav) tried to squeeze as many "attractions" in the available 2 days, as possible.(So we might have seen 10% of it...)Bayon Temple was indeed one of the greatest experience we have got there.
Happy Buddhas. A peaceful place to wander around just be careful of the small monkeys. The Buddha faces make you smile. Great photos everywhere. Love this temple.
Another beautiful temple. Must go and see. this temple is usually a second temple on the tour after Angkor Wat. It can have many tourists but it is very nice and interesting to see.

Amazing. All the temples in the Angkor area are just truly amazing. All very different and with their own story and architecture. I have bad knees so found it difficult to go climbing all over them but I was happy enough to look from the bottom or wherever I could reach. We did the 3 most famous temples, Angkor Wat, Bayon & Ta Prohm and small ones around and that was enough for us as it them got hot and and we were tired as we had been up since 4.30am! Do go see it as they are pretty spectacular. I liked Bayon the most as there was no one trying to sell you something and you it truly did have a have spiritual feeling around the temple. Watch out for the monkeys, although they stayed well away from us.
Beautiful Temple. Best temple in terms of carvings. It was a bit crowded so was quite difficult to take pictures. But the faces have been carved with so much detail, its quite unbelievable.
Beautiful. Go early in the morning to have it all to yourself. It is spectacular and awe inspiring. Must visit!
Can get busy visit early morning or afternoon. Fantastic temple with great photo opportunities and historic value, a guide will advise the best areas to visit and photo opportunities

Bayon Temple Restoration. One of the best temples in the Ankor complex. Though not as famous as Ankor Wat, this is a must see with its 54 towers if you come to Siem Reap. This site is undergoing restoration so if you come, there will an opportunity to learn how the restoration process is being applied to all Khmer temples. There is also a Bayon information center which is a joint UNESCO Japanese Government venture which includes more information on temple and ceramics unearthed at the site.
Great Temple. This was my favourite temple to visit. A truly wonderful experience. I would definitely recommend this temple.

Gorgeous site. MUST. I'm in love. Seriously. This one is different from the others. With lots of 4 faced towers. Woman are not allowed in shorts, just bring a sarong. I highly recommend wearing workout clothes. Flip flops are ok but you are not taking your shoes , so wear whatever you are comfortable with. Bring a hat also. And of course your camera or selfie stick and cell phone.
A little ruined. This is not the best ruins/temple to visit but as you are in the area you must check it out anyway. Its not as much fixed as Angkor Wat. However its interesting.
2nd visited. Didn't notice any changes, except increase of tour group visiting small circle. Crowd at the top of temple, difficult to shoot photos without people as background.
Must visit . If you're going to any temples it needs to be at least Angkor Wat, Ta Phrom and Bayon temple. They were all so different and therefore able to hold your interest.
Many faces. There are some great views from all angles around this temple and even with lots of tourists there is space to get some good photos. Have one taken with you "kissing" a statue.

Part of the entire Angkor Wat tours. Bayon temple is part of the archaeological site tours and located a distance from the main complex of Angkor Wat. The entrance fee is USD 20 for a day visit excluding guide to visit the Angkor Wat,Bayon temple and Ta Phrom but it is definitely worth it. The food stall near Bayon temple charged exorbitantly and a favorite recommendation for the tuk tuk drivers. I guessed they get to eat for free when they bring tourist there but you have little choice as there is no restaurant nearby and unless you decide to skip lunch

Aware of Scam. Not to say it's a scam but they did something which is not from their sincere heart. We went to visit one of the temples in Angkor Wat (the one shown in photo) and suddenly he police there start to explain the story of the temple and offer to help us take some photos. Without any precaution we accepted the offer and end up the police ask for tip. Thus we just paid since he really assisted us to take photo and explained the story.Well it's nothing wrong with this but I feel cheated This is an awesome historical heritage and we feel that this should not happens here. Overall, this place is still worth for visit at least once in your life time.

Definitely a must see. Part of the small circuitHurry and arrive before February 2017 as park entrance fee almost doubles $20 to $37Park fee includes entrance to all sites and can be bought in 1,3,7 days increments

Take a guide. This temple has the best carvings and BAS reliefs which are best discovered with the help of a guide who will explain it in detail. Very hot area though so make sure you pack plenty of water, sunscreen and a hat.
Temples. A very interesting day out. You will need good walking shoes and plenty of water. A fan is always a good idea also

A place worth visiting . Bought a one day ticket of USD20/person to visit the Angkor Wat which need about 03 hour and then 02 hour of Bayon Temple and another 02 hour to Ta Prom. The schedule is good for the whole morning and if you are not tire, you can still visit the rest of the attraction with the One Day pass. We book the Tuk Tuk for the day that cost us USD25
Enigmatic smiles. Struck by the huge stone face sculptures keeping watch over each of the 4 compass points. Felt a sense of peace and serenity despite the crowds at the attraction.
Amazing Faces. You can spend hours here however realistically 1 hour will be enough. Not a hard climb so fit for all ages and fitness abilities.Great picture opportunityAnd a good temple to visit

Centrepiece of the larger angkor wat complex. This is located in a separate area of the huge angkor wat complex.It's main features are the carving of the faces.Should bring a guide as they would be able to explain the history and intricacies of the structures and features
Full of picture worthy spots. This place is just full of history and architecture, definitely full of instagram worthy spots that'll show the beauty of the the Bayon Temple.

Stunning. Bayon's was the official state temple of Buddhist King Jayavarman VII and is a stunning example of Khmer engineering and craftsmanship.Bayon's famous for it's columns with carvings of serene faces depicted on each of their 4 sides, but there's a lot more to this temple with hidden shaded alleys, tight staircases and raised ceremonial platforms and courtyards. Possibly the most architecturally unusual temple in the Angkor Wat area and my favourite by a mile.Although smaller than some of the other Wat's with it's intensity of detail it's worthy of further investigation and I'd recommend spending in the region of an hour and a half of your time to fully appreciate it's majesty.
Beautiful temple and the others in Angkor thom area. This take you breath you away. You could spend my hours to discovery as the a lot of temples in this area.
Touch with History. I really wanted to visit this place and i did!!! If you have change to visit to Siem Reap, you must go there!!!

Amazing structure, evokes strong feelings. One of the biggest draws of Angkor Thom. An extremely evoking set of faces of Avalokiteshwara. To think that these faces have witnessed so much in the last millennium.

Mystical . 4 haeded structure - the most prominent feature of the temple created a mystical effect. Certainly very unique and different from Angkor Wat temple.
The only thing that put us of is the rush. There were long ques for taking photographs and that too one could hardly eliminate others from frame as it was jam-packed with tourists.
very interesting and detailed.. Rather enjoyed this temple, the stone carvings were so interesting and intricate, hard to believe this was all accomplished by hand!
Stunning. The four aspects of Buddhism are depicted at this temple. Not for those who may have difficulty climbing steep steps.
Gorgeous . Another amazing temple!! Do all the temples with a guide and an aircon driver!!! This particular temple is quite quick to look around and definitely to be on your to do list.
The best Temple. This is my favourite temple! Such detail has fone into both the initial building and the restoration, words cannot describe this amazing place.
One of my favoites. All have their individual qualities but this one has an amazing energy to it as well. Center of most of them so if your bike riding you get to pass it a few times...

Make it your own! . Seeing temples is mandatory in Cambodia. They can be very crowded with tourist buses, yelling children, and rude people. But do not let this deter you!Anyone can walk down the middle of these amazing places with the masses and get caught up with selfie sticks, group photos, and disrespectful tourists. If you can handle this, go for it. My wife and I chose to walk the dirt paths around the extoerior portions, entering the locations we wanted, and gathering the beauty of the entire grounds. We could not have been happier wandering on our own. I would also HIGHLY recommend going to the national museum before hand to gather the history of the temples and be your own tour guide :-)

Highlight of our visit to Siem Reap. We visited many temples during our three days in Siem Reap and Bayon Temple was definitely my favorite. Located within Ankor Thom, it is stunning. Just about all of it is accessible and it is way less crowded than Ankor Wat.
This is a must . Traditionally people go to Ankor Wat.You should also visit Bayon Temple.Great site.We didn't have a guide during this part
spectacular . very interesting site. I enjoyed all the smiling Buddhas. I went with a local guide to better explain the history and to find me the best vantages for pictures
Worth every minute. Less crowded and probably more interesting than Angkor wat-great photo ops also but wear good walking boots and insecticide as the mozzies are very persistent

The face temple and it's iconic towers. A must to visit in Angkor Tom, The Bayon Temple located at the center of the site, has been built by the famous King Jayavarman VII which symbolises the transition from Hinduism to Buddhism. Pay attention to the carving on the wall, as they narrate the everyday life and wars that happened during the 12th century. Get lost in this temple to discover hidden "treasures" Little advice: busy during dry season, little less during wet season. Don't forget to cover your shoulders and knees when entering the temple.
Tomn Raider. Nice view on top! With a lesser audience than the Angkor, I prefered this one since you can really appreciate its beauty.
Beautiful. Amazing to climb to the top and walk around the main central room with its 12th doors. With its smiling stone faces on the many towers, it gives a sens a deep serenity.

Meh. A bunch of old rocks. Just kidding!. Of the "Big Three" temples, Bayon is probably my favorite. Absolutely mind blowing (they all are really). If you have time, I recommend not trying to do all the temples in one day. It's just too much. One of the most magical places on earth.
Unique. The biggest temple inside Angkor Thom complex. Has a unique architecture with four faces statues. One of the must see temples in Seim Reap.
Enigmatic faces. This is probably my favourite part of all the temples in the Angkor complex. The faces are timeless and enigmatic.
Enjoyed this very much. The deteriorating faces and small passageways had me channeling my inner Indy and enjoying this one quite a bit.

So interesting . The temple has much to offer. Our guide gave us an informative tour. The temples in this area are a must see. Cover up - no exposed shoulders or knees.Lots of hawkers selling food and wares

Truly Remarkable Temple Of Ancient Time. There are 4 entrances to Bayon Temple. Alighted at the south gate. There is a pond there. An ideal spot to picture the ancient temple with its reflection on water. 30 metres from the temple entrance will be the day pass checkpoint. Ahead will be many steep steps to conquer to the top where you find many "Smiling Buddha Faces" engraved on the stone. It's simply 360 degrees, everywhere. Really unique. One of the few temples that I really marvel the craftsmanship of the ancient times. Walking up there is alike a maze, I walked down the wrong exit ended up in the north gate. Unable to identify fortunately called the driver and asked a local tourist guide to converse with the exact location. He came and picked us shortly. Saw wild monkeys roaming around.
Huge faces and. Bayon temple was my favorite temple to visit. Very amazing temple with lots of faces. Great decorated Khmer temple.
My favourite!. What a beautiful temple! This is my absolute favourite! Make sure you climb to the top for some great photos of the 216 Buddha faces!!

Good place to shoot some pictures . Easier to access and much more compact than Angkor Wat.
Good for making some pictures but very touristic and super crowded.
Good place to stop by but for us as not-temple-enthusiastic just a nice place to see and not comparable to the massive Angkor Wat complex.
Great carvings!. We loved the carvings in this temple. Lots of photo opportunities. Some steep stairs but they are worth the climb.

It's a temple. You already bought your ticket, go see them all. My tuk tuk driver was really cool and would park and wait so I could spend as much or as little time as I wanted. It's an old temple so it's a lot of walking on uneven terrain.
Amazing Temple. This temple is worth a visit, it goes back to old times and very unique especially at sunset. Not to be missed!
Amazing temple . This temple has so many faces carved on you can not even count in one shot correctly. Don't miss this temple.
The Buddha face. The most impressive temple in Angkor area, i recommended to visit early or late afternoon then will be less people and you will amaze all the hundred of faces of the Buddha !
Love this temple. My absolute favourite of the temples at the Angkor complex. If you only see a couple of temples see this one. Don't go past it.
Beautiful temple. Take your time to look at all the Buddhas. A very beautiful temple, visit in the late afternoon when there are not so many tourists.

Amazing. For me this was the highlight of the Angkor wat complex. From a distance it seems like a heep of dark rubble but at close range the sculptures were most impressive. We were there in the early afternoon with not that many people visiting. I would really like to come back.
Famous Angkor smile. Famous, worth to spent time and look every smile. The art on the wall is great, too. It is better to go earlier in the morning or in the evening, or it would be too hot.

Cooler than Ankor Wat!. The temples surrounding Bayon temple is definitely more interesting than Ankor Wat in my opinion. Lots of places to explore and definitely the highlight of my trip.
Just a note: some children might try to offer to take pictures after leading you to a location. Never give your phones to them unless you never want to see it again.

Holiday. Booked a short break with my girlfriend and mate , flew in from Koi Samui , just a fantastic piece of history , grabbed a tuk tuk for a couple of days and went round most of the temples , just brilliant . If you gonna do it do it in a tuk tuk , great way to see what's going on
Always the best place to visit. I go there many time and never getting bored. Feeling relax whenever i go there and if someone who love sunny activity,you can visit in the afternoon.

While in Cambodia.... I would highly recommend taht you see Bayon Temple while visiting the greater archaeological park. Admittedly, the entire experience of visiting the park can be somewhat physically demanding - so if you don't want to explore (or can't,) at least try and get a few pictures of this great temple. Much like the Great Pyramids of Egypt, the Angkor site (and Bayon Temple) provide a look in to the past - and one cannot help but be amazed by the engineering marvels of the structure - as well as let the imagination run wild with the thoughts of a civilization long-lost living at the site. A must-see while in Cambodia.
Tomb rider temple. Very different but beautiful temple. Interesting design and suitable for all age visit. Preferable to visit during early morning to avoid hot burning sun.
Amazing. One shouldn't miss it if you are at Angkor Wat. It ia another spectacular architecture of hindu temple.
amazing!!. worth the many hours of walking, taking lots of photos, people watching, 13 hours weren't enough - need to go back

One of my favourite temples. This temple really took my breath away. Smiling faces everywhere you looked and such a rich history. We walked around with our guide for 1/2 hour and took many fantastic pictures. This is the temple where you take the photo of yourself nose to nose with the smiling face. It truly was beautiful and fascinating here.
Must visit when in Siem Reap. Great architecture, hard to believe that it was built by a civilisation with possibly limited tools. A must do when in Siem Reap
Sightseeing. Bayous Temple is beautiful and has a lot of religious and historical background. This and the other temples should be added to the wonders of the world.
Interesting temple but the overall scale of Angkor Thom is more impressive. Nice temple but its position in and the history of the palace of Angkor Thom is much more interesting
Nice temple. One of the many temples in Angkor area. So nice to see so many thing. In different angles you can find special engravings.

Captivating. I am so very glad i was able to hire Angkor Visitor (Praim hear) for my personal guide. I would have missed most of the fascinating details of this intricate world heritage site. Very worth seeig and ecperiencing.

Magical. Bayon Temple is a testament to the imaginative and the wonderful. You can easily close your eyes and when you open them you are 700 years in the past, facing the power of the Cambodian kings.

My Favorite Temple in Cambodia. We arrived after seeing Angkor Wat, it thought this temple was better. It is more broken down and smaller, however, for meet had more feeling to it. You get in on the same ticket to Angkor Wat. It was hot and humid when we were there, building to rain. The temple looks like it has weathered a storm, the steps are uneven and the wooden stairs installed are narrow. There wasn't so many tourist here, however, due to size, I found I was frequently impeded but slow walkers on the narrow stairs, or people who were slow to take a picture, or need quite a few pictures. However, I connect more with this temple than Angkor Wat.
Beautiful . Quite a small temple and tends to get overrun by hordes of tourists. Surrounded by lovely trees. The giant stone faces create a surreal ambience. Great restoration job.

Must see this . Absolutely beautiful and amazing history, wear sunscreen and closed comfy shoes. As with Angkor Wat be respectful and wear appropriate clothing. Cover knees and shoulders. Get an aircon car and guide. I am not the guide type but we had our own for 3 of us and it was well worth it.
Must Visit. History place with amazing old building. Should bring a umbrella or hat due to UV and hot weather in Cambodia which this place is not many shelter be provided.
The many faces temple. Every nook and canny are not spared from carvings. Even the genius path of reaching the different parts of this temple is amazing!

Loved Bayon. Loved this temple - with all the smiling faces - very beautiful.
Not too big to get around and see it all in short space of time, but not great if there is a big crowd (hard to move around some tighter spaces).
Monkeys were at this temple also.

Go to all of them!. Angkor Wat and the surrounding ruins take between 30 - 90 minutes and all are highly recommended with a healthy dose of sun screen. The ruins and the surrounding jungle is mesmerizing and it was hard to believe I was privileged enough to get to spend time here. We only had two full days here and that wasn't enough. Having our wonderful tuk tuk drive, Savin, from Miracle Resort made our trip a lot easier. Spend the few dollars and visit this must see!
Beautiful temple worth the time to see. This is one of the better temples and a must do to add to your bucket list. Take your time and don't rush your visit.

Amazing. This was one of our favourite temples. We visited Bayon after Angkor Wat and really enjoyed it. The faces in the stonework are amazing. It was also better in terms of crowds, much less crowded than Angkor Wat.Well worth a visit.
The most awesome ruin. This takes your breath away. You could spend many hours climbing around this fantastic ruin discovering new faces. It was the highlight of our visit

Mind bending. . It doesn't photograph as well as you'd hope and it can be overrun with bad mannered tour groups. Best to get there early and just enjoy walking in and around it and soaking up the mind bending views. A great way to start is a 15 minute elephant ride around the temple. A bit touristy but cool nonetheless. $20 per person for the pleasure.

Absolutely breathtaking . There is many tour guides waiting to help. However I had done a great deal of research before hand so we decided to do a self guided tour. This way we were able to do it at our own pace. The temples were breathtaking and well worth a look. This was my second time visiting and i still saw new things so i would recommend taking a great deal of time to explore so that you don't miss anything.

It was very good day to visit this place it is beautiful and amazing it is very good experience to go there. . and is beautifulamazing it is very good experience to go there. I will be back again to visit with same group.
Wow. Fabulous time at the temple great place. So much to explore and so many great photo opportunities. Lots of climbing great views and architecture. Well worth a visit the complex Is wonderful
it's cambodia. temples are everywhere in siem reap, this is just another one of those temples, but they are all great for walks...beware...long walks so children may get tired and bored
Smaller than Angkor Wat but worth the visit. The carvings in this temple are wonderful. As it is smaller than Angkor Wat, it isn't as demanding to visit but equally lovely.

Faces @ Bayon Temple . Visited Bayon Temple on 22 September 2016 along with two friends and the experience was worth it. The faces are enchanting and tourists in large number taking photos posing like kissing faces bring smile on your face. It was a hot sultry weather but the fresh coconut water purchased from a kiosk outside the temple, reenergized us.

Another must see temple . It's one of the temples which is a must see, great walking around it and some beautiful colours in the corridors. Lots of people there, just be aware there are crowds and it's difficult to get photos with no one else in them!

Magnificent!. We spent a whole day walking around this place but couldn't reach every corner. It was huge and impressive! However, there were too many shops and food stalls nearby that may damage the relic if it's not well-preserved.
Still a must-try experience when going to Siem Riep.
Wonderful experience . Greatest temple to visit amazing structure. Baton trees were unreal how they are just embedded in the temple
Many faces. The temple of thousand faces of King Jayawarman VII. We really can see his face everywhere we turn around. A little kind of narcisist of him? I don't know. :D
Our favorite temple!. We loved Bayon the most! The faces on the temple is really pretty and makes the temple stand out. Don't miss this one out!

Lesser known than Angkor but definitely a must see. A beautiful Buddhist Temple with beautiful, smiling , benign faces carved on it . So life- like , the faces are peaceful . One could sit and watch them for long.
Majestic. We viewed this with our tour guide without going into the temple. Completely blew me away. So many different aspects to view. Would definitely recommend.

Amazing place to visit. This is my favourite temple to visit. Very unique temple with lots of faces. Great arts.
I only don't like the smell inside the tunnel. Bring face mask if you want to. And wear proper shoes.

Huge!!!!. The Bayon is a massive place full of rooms, corridors and levels!
I could have easily spent the whole day wandering around!!!

The photos say it all. Stunning and spectacular place to visit. The temple is the most awesome sight and well worth a visit. Really you cannot visit Siem Reap and not visit the temples. There are some great travel guides around as well that are very affordable and provide you with a great day out sightseeing with all the background history included. Definately a must!
Uniquely Architecture!!!. It was amazing time to visit temples especially Angkor Thom at sunrise and beautiful atmosphere.. Highly recommended!!!
The most impressive of them all. In my opinion this was the most interesting and impressive temple of the whole Angkor Wat complex. All the faces incorporated in the structure look very cool!

Many faces of the god. The towers all have or had four identical faces looking down and it us said that one can see you where ever you are in the temple. A beaufifum place but it does get a bit crowded. Take plenty of water with you.

My favorite in the complex. This was my favorite temple in the whole complex. Make sure you bring your camera because you have a lot of photo opportunities with the faces.
This temple should take you about 2-3 hours.
This temple will be crowded even during low season. Make sure you bring water and that you camera has enough battery and memory.

Many faces temple!!. That how you remembered this temple, with 54 faces which represent the kingdom area back then this truly one of my favourite temple. The temple is not big, close by from terrace of elephant, however it's more interesting for me compare to other temple (including angkor wat). The carving and the fascinating of many faces really make this is a unique temple. Must visit even if you skip the other temple.

Amazing. we were really impressed with this temple. It's smaller than Angkor Wat but the spirit here feel deeper and more interesting us.We had an assistance from a little local boy. He help us to find the s secret corner to take a nice PhotoSadly is, we didn't spend to hire the tour guide to understand more about history of this temple.But finally, i believe that Bayon Temple is the place that you need to visit in Siem Riep
amazing place. i collect really unforgettable memories in Cambodia, and of them is tha Bayon temple. Amazing place to be a 'real tomb raider'.. :)
One of the best. Definitely one of the best temples in Angkor. The Buddha faces are incredible. Try to avoid very hot days
Our visit to Bayon temple. We have gone on group tour to this place.All the temples have smiling faces in 4 directions.I presumed it must be Bramha statue.

Giant faces!. Just an incredible place, with all the giant smiling faces, this temple couldn't help but make you smile! The history and stories behind the temple were very interesting, and since we were there during "off season', we had plenty of time and space to enjoy all the sites.
Thousand Faces. Much erosion compared to ten years ago but still amazing. Children are allowed up the stairs unlike Baphoun and Angkor Wat. Lots of doorways and windows with amazing details.
Beautiful attraction . Really nice looking temple near Angkor wat. Part of the complex or temples. Inclusive of the passes you get. Had a lovely time enjoying the beautifully built temple.
fantastic Building. Bayon temple is very nice building.It's charming temple for come to kiss with the face of the 54 top.

Favourite temple. If I had to rank the small number of temples I have visited in Cambodia (there are thousands!), I think I would rate this my favourite. Nice and small and easy to scramble around. The detail in the facial carvings are amazing! Worth a visit. Is part of the Angkor Thom complex.

Mindblowing. I always say you should read a little bit about where you visit before you go, my advice would be to know the history of the Khmer empire and the history of what you are looking at as it is incredible how powerful they were and personally the best architecture I've ever seen, it's breathtaking.

The faces are from a Hollywood movie. The faces on the temple give this area something spooky. The temples are very old and the deterioration of the stone also adds to the effect.There doesn't seem to be any form of preservation as many tourists were able to climb some of the buildings, there were no notices or guards prohibiting these actions.

Memorable trip to Cambodia. Amarzing... happy trip...enjoyable...
Comfortable Transport...
Excellent guider...
Humble driver...
Friendly local people..

Our favorite!!. Bayon temple was our favorite of all the temples. It was very crowded but so breathtaking, Make sure to get a guide to ensure you don't miss out on the rich history riddled throughout these stunning sandstone walls!!!!

Just amazing, I had to come back to see it again.. The first time I was here was in December 2011. I knew one day I would come back, and I did in August 2016. The complex is huge. Make sure you have a tour guide or you will miss so much interesting information. Also have a car of tuk-tuk driver. The price goes up starting in January 2017, so if you want to see this incredible site, go sooner than later. The price jumps to $37.00 USD. Get the 3 day pass. But do NOT let the price hike stop you from enjoying this amazing temple.Make sure you take some water with you. Along with a hat and sun screen. There are no vendors inside the complex. Outside, food and drinks are available. Don't miss the wooden stair case that takes you up into the temple. Great and unique photos of the complex are possible.

This is another view of Siem Reaps exquisite temples. . This was the third temple that we visited in one day while in Siem Reap. But, it is different. The Bayon Temple has many peaks and stupas. There are many stones on the ground waiting for completed restoration, but the powers to be will take many years before it is completed. This temple is not to be attempted by those that are handicapped due to the many steps and uneven paths. All of these main temples need to be visited to learn the true history of this area.
Beautiful Bayon . Early morning visit to Bayon made my day awesome, entrance of Bayon is beautiful with rock sculptures, best place for taking photos of historical monuments, must visit place..

The Temple of many faces!. Really amazing temple, climb to the top and enjoy looking at the sights. My group had three adults and three children under five. It was good for the kiddies but just be sure to be holding their hands, steep steps and lots of crowds!
Bayon templee. There are no words. Except to say dont miss. Drink and take lots of water as it is sooooooo hotWear sound footwear take a littke travel brolly. Cooler than wearing a hat. I loved it

Bayon temple. Was a lovely temple to visit, a little crowded and hard to navigate but worth the look. The history of the structure is interesting and from different points this temple is fascinating to look at.
Love your faces. This surprising compact temple unlike any I've seen in Cambodia. Originally 50 smiling faces today we are left with 37 no less fascinating.
Everyone cant help but love the Buddhas faces. Saw Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, Ta Prohm and Bayon Temple.Glorious. See them all. Bayon is extra charming!
Smiling Temple. We Saw this temple as the third on our tour. When you look at it from the outside, it looks Amazing! So beautiful and ancient. Inside there's smiling Buddha faces on all the towers.

beautiful temple and monkeys everywhere!. We did not have this listed as a must-see before we got here, but our tour guide added it to the list and we are so glad he did! It was not nearly as crowded as many of the other temples we visited during our trip, the temple itself is breathtaking, and there are monkeys everywhere that just add to the uniqueness. Such a cool stop!
Bayon takes your breath away . The Bayon temple just takes your breath away the contrast of the finely carved power heads with the bluest skies gives you the most stunning back drop.

The Famous Bayon Temple. The "Mona Lisa of Southeast Asia. Bayon is known for its huge stone faces of the bodhisattva Avalokiteshvara, with one facing outward and keeping watch at each compass point. The curious smiling image, thought by many to be a portrait of Jayavarman himself, has been dubbed by some the "Mona Lisa of Southeast Asia."
visit bayon. best place for visit in cambodia so many temples best security & good hospility all facilities there
Misterious temple. No wonder they made the movie here (Tomb raider).The force of nature was destroying the human civilization.
Amazing place. I loved this temple There are carved faces ever where you look one of my favourite temples in this area
My favorite temple!. This is my favorite temple in Angkor Wat complex! The walls are intricately designed and the stones carved with heads are fascinating.

Stunning (like all the temples!). like all, gets very busy but worth the trip, absolutely amazing. we used our great tuk tuk driver Mr Million and had an English speaking guide for the day who really provided amazing inforamtion

The most beautiful temple in the complex. Far more interesting and beautiful than Angkor Wat. The heads, the carvings in the walls, the peaceful trees surrounding it... everything about this temple was brilliant. There were lots of people everywhere but the temple has enough twists and turns that it never seemed crowded.

Pinnacle of Khmer Empire. This building was very interesting because of the design. There were so many pillars to signify each province the Khmer empire ruled over. The pillars were decorated with the face of a smiling buddha which brought calm and peace. The walls were covered with carvings of historic battles of the Khmer empire. This is a truly interesting building after studying its history.
Bayon Temple. Not to be missed either after Angkor Wat. Its situated near Angkor Wat. Since we had bicycles, we cycled.
Go and visit. Not so preserved as Angkor Wat, this temple, close to the most famous, and a century newer than the other, is a must see as well. Enjoy.

A BIG hit with my 5 year old daughter. GREAT experience.. This was my 4th or 5th visit to Siem Reap and the ruins. I never get bored of it. However it was the first visit with one of my daughters, my eldest ( 5 years old), May 2016. It was a truly great experience and Bayon Temple was her 2nd favourite temple after Ta Promh. She had no problem walking around it and was amazed at all those big faces, still talks about it. There is at least one set of steep ladders that requires special attention for little ones (& adults to be honest) but if they are steady on their feet it's not a problem with someone behind them. Lots of water and a few refreshment towels for little ones is handy - you can buy drinks everywhere mostly.

By far my favourite temple out of the whole of Angkor.. After spending the majority of the day exploring a bunch of the further out temples as well as the "big 3" the Bayon is by far my favourite, its nowhere near as crowded as Angkor Wat and its just great to climb around on. The carvings of faces are amazing and it seemed to be home to a bunch of monkeys when we visited.

The second one in the complex - I love it!. Very beautiful and special to see the difference of faces! Angkor Thom consists of 8 temples. I prefer Bayon and Bapoun. It is very large to move among the temples. You also can rice fields.
must see this place. this temple is absolutely stunning and a must visit by all travellers , like all the temples you will not be disappointed you went there and you wont stop talking about it

A really beautiful temple in angkor. The temple is surrounded with towers with many faces of Buddha on them. Many of the towers lay in ruin from being pulled down many years ago but what remains is stunning. A must in angkor
Deserves to be #2. Located at the heart of AT, this temple has a lot going on in and around it. The stone carvings up high in the temple are particularly good. Don't rush this one.

Beautiful Temple. This was my second favourite (after Ta Prohm) temple. My tour guide timed it perfectly so there were very few people. Your guide (book with Happy Angkor Wat Tour!) will likely know the best time to avoid the crowds.
Fascinating architecture & look back into history. Complimentary temples to those at Angkor Wat add more to the visit with even more carvings & religious artifacts.

One of fhe best buildings of Angkor. If you unfortunately don't have much time and can visit only 3 temples in Angkor, for sure Bayon should be among it.
Take your time, and pay attention to every detail. The Bas reliefs on the walls, the faces, everything. It is going to surprise you.

Wow. You can take some wonderful pictures in this location. Go to second/third level for great pics. Nothing interesting in the ground/first level.
Steps to the second level is narrow and steep............

Amazing Buddha faces. Very nice place to visit.The Buddha faces are seen on the towers,
With smiling Buddha .
Magnificent and very elegant to see.
The temple is run down over the years,but the Faces still look good.
Amazing!. Possibly one of the most amazing man made structures i have ever seen, to seen this ancient city still relatively undiscovered is mind blowing.

Another fascinating temple. Although incredibly hot weather this is worth the walk and the heat.
Tons of photo opportunities and fabulous memories
Amazing. It is amazing. Unique experince that one shouldn't miss. At every corner, on every stone you will see a detail...
Great temples. Probably one of my favorite set of temples in Seam Reap. In times filled with tourists, so go early in the morning. Great photo opportunities here.
Amazing. I was so impressed with the existence of this temple and the magnificent architecture. It is must place to visit and you can have beautiful scenery for your photographic.
My favorite.. This was my favorite temple of all that we visited. It was so beautiful and great pics to be taken here. I def would not skip this one!

So many faces . This was our 2nd temple we went to on the day. It was amazing and spectacular. All the 54 giant faces were all staring at us, we actually got confused with the exit and couldn't find the right way out for a while
You could really feel the mystery inside the temple

Impressed. Really impressed with this historical place ,feel like back in time and wish to visit there again.
When I was there its rain season then its not too hot though a bit wet but everywhere are so green and so nice.
The temple of the smiling faces. Everywhere you look, around the corner, through a window or a doorway you see these smiling stone faces. It's mysterious, it's beautiful. Don't miss this.

Terrific. Unfortunately it was raining quite heavily on our visit but this, perhaps enhanced things as water was cascading down every crack, valley and rock in this temple.
Lovely as are all the others

My favourite temple. I wish we had more time to spend at this temple, but unfortunately our time was rather limited (we did 3 temples in one day, including Angkor Wat). The many faces make for a most interesting facade. Our guide managed to capture the most creative photographs - with us appearing to rub noses with the Buddha. Magical indeed. This temple is beautiful beyond compare, my favourite one on the day

Temple with smiling stone faces. Bayon Temple is spectacular! It is the main temple in Angkor Thom and the most special things are the smiling faces. It's better to go with a guide because they know places to take pictures and things to see. Don't recommend to go with children.

very enjoyable. we enjoyed this temple the most the trees are amazing growing out of the temple we went in the low season but it was still quite busy with Chinese tourists everywhere beware the children begging all around here but they disappear when a policeman appears !
Amazing Stone Work. Loved the many faces of Bayon and the photographic opportunities they presented. We actually went back for a second visit to capture the Temple at a different time of day.
A must see. Go see this temple! It really is stunning in real life and every corner there is something else to amaze you.

Faces carved in stone. Visited here as part of the temple tour of Cambodia.Quieter and more serene than Angkor Wat.Faces carved in stone and the temple area is quiet which allows for relection away from the crowds.Not a lot of effort to get here after visiting Angkor Wat.The approach across the bridge, with lines of carved statues as you approach the entrance, is also worth checking out.Definitely worth asking your transport to take you here for a look.
Love the different faces. The faces were truly fascinating spent awhile here, looking and taking in the experience these ruins hold so much history , make sure you have time to enjoy
One of the most mysterious temple. This is one of my favorite temple in Angkor. The mysterious smile on all the faces is really intriguing.

More than just Angkor Wat. I came to Cambodia only knowing Angkor Wat. By the time I got in to Siem Reap, I realized that the entire complex was much, much, larger. Bayon is one of the "satellite" ruins that you're likely to visit on the same day as the main attraction.You won't want to miss a magical photo op of the Buddha at the center of the entire complex. The candlelit Buddha is nothing short of magical. Be respectful - take off your shoes and be quiet, as it is likely that locals and travelers alike will be praying there.Most likely, you'll be visiting other places in the Angkor complex on the same day. I'd strongly advise visitors to bring at least one spare battery, as there will be almost nowhere you can charge your equipment.

A Favourite - Must See. I preferred this temple to Angkor Wat. They are both magnificent in scale and grandeur - the many faces at the Bayon however lend an air of peace to this temple that is not lacking at Angkor Wat, but is more pronounced at the Bayon.You must see this temple, avoid the beaten tourist path and there are some wonderful angles to take beautiful photos at - but don't forget to also breathe and marvel at these wonders.

Let's "face" it, this is pretty great. Really unusual, even for the Angkor area. It is a don't miss! The Bas reliefs were the highlight after one has absorbed the structure and the 4-faced carving style

My favourite.. I found this Temple the most enjoyable. Maybe it was the smiling Buddha's that made me smile back. Was lucky with the weather although may be a bit too humid. My guide informed that next year the day passes will be $37, we paid $40 for a 3 day pass obviously the guides are not too pleased about the price hike as that could mean less business for them.Worth visiting several more with a 3 day pass otherwise it's too much in one day.
Great temple to toue. Not as big as Angkor Wat but a beautiful temple.We enjoyed walking the temple.It does involve a lot of walking and climbing but it is worth the effort

Great of Cambodia temple.. It is imazing temple of cambodia, great architecture from accent time very beautiful face of Buddha on the top of temple tower, It really unbelievable that the old people can build this imazing temple. We really love it a lots.

Best of the lot in Cambodia. If you are on short trip to Cambodia and do not have enough time to visit all temples, never forgot to miss this one. One of the best architectural marvels that will keep you enthralled. Takes around 1-2 hour to enjoy the beauty of it. Best suited for photographers and architecture lovers. You can try some funny photographs as well like Nose to Nose

Marvelous. The Bayon is one of the mayor attractions of Angkor Historical Park near Siem Reap. It is also one you can't miss when you come from the direction of Siem Reap. Take your time to have a good look at. It's marvelous to see at sunrise

Reminded me of Tomb Raider.. It's so magnificent the moment you reach this temple or pass by. It's good to take panoramic photo right in front of the temple as when you get close up to the heads and faces, it's getting more challenging to shoot the panoramic photo as the sun also make it difficult to capture clear photo noon time or rainy days.
My favorite temple. Bayon Temple was my favorite of all of those we visited. The towers of faces and the climbing were fantastic. It was, by far, the most interesting.
Our Favorite Temple. This temple was our favorite amongst the many that we saw while in Siem Reap. It's a MUST SEE! Be sure to bring water and sunscreen/hat as it's super hot!
Bayon. See this just for its beautiful carvings on the walls. A lot of groups tour this and the spaces are narrow, so it can get crowded.

Buda faces everywhere!. Bayon is the temple of faces, the Buda faces sculpted all around u temple's coluns intrigues you about how they could do it so many centuries ago.
In my opinion this is one of the most beautiful temples inside the Angkor Wat complex.
Place to vist. Bayon Temple was a lovely vist had lots of old ruins , great place to vist.lots of stalls for cloths and drinks.

A jump in the past. We took the "small" tour (7h :-O ) of the archeological area, Angkor Watt, Ta Prohm and the Bayon, and this temple WIN! It has a magical atmosphere, with all those stone faces, that it took our hearts.
AMAZING

Just beautiful!. Bayon is most probably most recognizable temple because those faces are really everywhere - on signs, hotels, t-shirts and so on.So when you arrive there you recognize them, but nothing will prepare you to massiveness of those sculptures. Bayon is absolutely a must see temple!
Interesting. Enjoyed walking around but not as majestic as Angkor Wat - a good look will take more than an hour so have water with you.
Part of our Angkor itinerary. Smaller than Angkor but still worth the tour, not far distance wise only a short time, progress being made on restoring.

Loved it! Be sure to get close-up photos of the faces. This place looks like a movie set. It was awesome. People seem to think all the temples are alike, but this one definitely stands alone, as it's the only one with all the faces carved on the outside. And the faces are so large. Be sure to get a good angle with the sunlight to get good photos that show the details in the faces.

ABSOLUTELY YES. One of the most beautiful and inspiring places I've ever seen, besides the beauty of the temples, the history and all handmade sculptures that surround you, come completely enthralled by the spectacle of green around the temples, although there are many visitors, you breathe an air of peace and the feeling of strength and power that there was in the time it was built ....A must see
Cambodian Holiday. Great place to visit,to photograph and to enjoy.Should be part of most organised tours.Enjoy the culture.

My favourite temple. Of all the temples in the Angkor Wat campus, this classic temple is my favorite. It's fairly compact and not spread out too wide like the angkor wat temple, though it does involve a bit of a climb. But once you're at the upper level, you're surrounded by all these stone carved faces and it makes for quite a sight! I was there off season, but the place was still quite crowded in the middle of the afternoon. Can't imagine what it might be like in peak season.
Well worth a visit. Really interesting place to visit, very crowded do try to get ahead of the tour busses. Read up on the history
Awesome place. The temple is different and impressive. It is easy to access and walk around, and to the top. The surrounding view is remarkable.
Unique Temple. The Bayon Temple is one of the unique temple around angkor wat area. The Buddha face built around the temple looks very interesting and great. Do not miss this!

Start Temples here or go later in day. I'd start here at Bayon so to be one step ahead of the tour groups as they all start at Angkor then move to Bayon. Start at Bayon or start at the end of the tmples and work back to work agains the tour groups.
Awesome. The history and structure of these temples are incredible. Having a guide is a good idea. There are many other temples around this area just follow the crowds if you don't have a guide.

2nd best of all the temples. Bayon is rated 2nd best on my list of temples, Angkor Wat is the 1st. What I love about Bayon is the faces in stone, which seem to look at you from any direction you are. And the climbing around that allows you to see how people last time move around for their prayers. I think it is the most 'interactive' of all temples.

Amazing. Amazing. Fulfilled all my expectations. Tourist friendly, but not too “touristy”. I recommend you go as early as possible in the morning to avoid heat and crowds - it's a pretty compact attraction.

Amazing Bayon Temple. I went on a temple tour which included Bayon. It is very impressive and not too difficult to walk around and up to the top. All the Temples were amazing, but we preferred Ta Prohm.

awesome heads. this temple is good break between the ankhor wat and the tomb raider temple! It has interesting enigmatic heads staring out into the abyss. Avoid this place during midday because it's hot hot hot.

Mesmerizing. Be prepared to be flabbergasted by the numerous carvings that cover Bayon Temple. From the famous faces that you see decorating the tops of the various pagodas, to the numerous finely carved bas reliefs, this temple should not be missed.

Don't forget this place if you are visiting Angkor Wat. It is not far away.. This is a beautiful temple to visit and not always as crowded as Angkor Wat. Try to go in the morning before it gets too hot.

Incredible creativity of thousand years ago. Khmer Smile is definately one of most incredible history heritages in the world. 49 buddies faces 49 smile faces. No matter how the world has changed over past thousands of years, these smiles have never ever been changed. They just look at this world quietly. A good place to find the inner peace.

Amazing, a must visit for everyone!. Of all the temple areas in Siem Reap, Bayon made the most impact on me. I'm not quite sure if it's because it was the first temple complex we visited but it is defnitely awe inspiring nonetheless. Its ruined spires are majestic, it just sends the imagination on overdrive thinking about the great culture that once inhabited this land.

Stunning in its intricacy of craftmanship. The Bayon Temple is absolutely stunning, it is currently being renovated by overseas archaeologists so part of it is inaccessible however well worth a visit.

Awesome to the core. . If you are taking a 20$ ticket to the amgkor , then this should be second in your list. The renovation work is not really upto the mark , with many pieces missing and it looks as though it could fall any moment. But for its history, this is a must visit. Go for it. Be careful when you climb the steps , they are really really small!

One of many. As the other temples, magnificent, proudly stands among trees and rocks and testifies about many historical and cultural events. It is a mountain temple representing Mount Meru, the center of the universe in Hindu and Buddhist cosmology.Bayon was a Buddhist temple, other Gods were also worshipped. Separate shrines were dedicated to Vishnu and Shiva, while countless other deities were worshipped.

Great place of historical importance, but damaged a lot. Great place to visit to see how ancestors of this place lived and prayed 1000's of years ago, great piece of work unimaginable these days. But the assembly and restoration is not that great and the stones are simply heaped up at many places.

Be careful with the stairs.... Jam-packed with tourists. Every carving was handmade and the history is unique. The trees sprouting in the temple itself are amazing. Temple stairs could be steep and dangerous.

Must see. This unique buddhist temple is simply outstanding and everybody who can should visit it.
Hard to believe that man created this in such an area hundreds of years ago.

Beautiful Temple. The Temple with many faces . One of the best place to take pictures and this should be in your itinerary together with Baphoun, Phimeanakas , Thommanon and Elephant Terrace since this temples are just walking distance from one place to another.

Amazing Architecture. This is a beautiful temple to visit the architecture is truly amazing, with so many faces and photo opportunities around every corner. A guide is essential to understand the meaning behind this amazing temple. it is my number 2 favourite behind Ta Prohm.
Beautiful. . What an interesting temple and definitely on the top temple sites to see. A guide is most helpful. This was one of my daughters favorite temples.
One of the best temples in Siem Reap. Don't miss this beautiful temple of faces on your visit to Siem Reap! Make sure to capture a picture giving Buddha a kiss.

breathtaking. The Bayon's most distinctive feature is the multitude of serene and smiling stone faces on the many towers which jut out from the upper terrace and cluster around its central peak. The temple is known also for two impressive sets of bas-reliefs, which present an unusual combination of mythological, historical, and mundane scenes
Wonderful. I went go there with my family last weekend I love setting and can saw many animals special elephants in there.
The Temple of the Faces. Such an amazing accomplishment. Truly ornate and fun to walk around. We were able to duck into a tower during a summer down pour. This is a don't miss site.

Good visit. An amazing time spent at the temple. Though the late morning period tends to see a lot of tourists groups. I counted about 150 people or so. Was very lucky that my tour guide provided from saem siem reap hotel was very helpful and brought me around off the beaten track to give me an opportunity to view the ruins in peace.
Lovely Scenic!. Amazing architecture.. lots of photos scenic and mind boggling rock.. We enjoyed the visit very much.. though was extremely hot.. but it's worth to Visit.

Beautiful old temple. A lovely old temple that attracts many visitors, especially to view the many towers that have carved faces on Buddha on all 4 sides. Well worth a look, this temple has had minimal restoration; there's been a bit of work to protect the worn steps and also to ensure that tourists are safe. You need to have purchased an Angkor area ticket - buy the $40US for 3 days (can be used over 7 days).
Amazing. Amazing temple to visit, it is very beautiful and the scenery is lovely. If you can get a guide then it's even better.
Our first visit. We did the tour of this temple with APT and to have a guide explain all the features of this temple made it come alive

A must see for any travellers to Cambodia. The ancient structures are incredible. I live for these kinds of travelling adventures. Cambodia was high on my list of places to visit in the world and the ancient temples of Siem Reap will not disappoint.
Another beautiful Temple. Breathtaking site. I suggest wearing shoes that tie or closed toe, as the ground is uneven.Beware of large groups of people taking pictures.
great see. see it all NOW before it gets ruined by LOTS more people. Its needs more looking after, as changed from my last trip.
Another must. Aside from the Angkor Wat, this is also a must. The carved faces were just simply fantastic. A guide helped us a lot in understanding and appreciating most of the temples
Must see. We actually liked this temple a bit more the Angkor Wat. It was a beautiful structure and we had a lot of fun exploring this temple and the magical faces.

Best temples at Angkor! . Personally I loved this place more than Angkor wat. Possibly due to the lower numbers of tourists. The Buddha head images are incredible and well preserved and restored. You are able to amble around the temples complex and it almost feels like a maze. The front has incredible carvings. Highly recommend this one but it's usually included on most people's visits.

If 6 stars could be given it would be a 7 star!. If you are looking for magic, genuine magic, it's here to be found in the Bayon temple. The faces smile at you from every direction. Angkor Wat might be the largest and most famous temple, the Bayon is probably the most exotic.
marvellous. when you go to Siem Reip you must see all the temples as each is different. This was one of them and worth a visit

Probably my favourite temple. Magic temple. Give time to wander around, dont rush in any of the temples. The whole area is worth visiting more than once. Angkor is one of the most beautiful places in the world but also morw visited, so avoid rush hours

Temple of the Thousand Faces. One of my favorite temples in Siem Reap. Most of the faces are still easy to see and you can take pictures with some of the most-well-preserved ones. Spend at least an hr here!

Best of the Best. Cambodia, and Siem Reap in particular have amazing temples to visit, it is the main reason for many people coming to this part of the world. Banyon Temple is the most outstanding site in Siem Reap. The more famous Angkor Wat temple is of course outstanding but this temple is in a place of it’s own. The architecture is probably unique in the world and the dozens of faces built in to the towers are awesome to see. Again like Angkor Wat the trick is to get there as early as possible in the morning, around 08:30 would be ideal, before the crowds arrive at mid-day.

Small but great. The temple was really narrow and had tiny passages and tall steps. It may make you tired but really awesome to see around the temple. Even though a lot of it has been destroyed it still remains beautiful.
Favorite Temple. Faces everywhere were really great. This was my favorite temple I viewed while touring the area. Incredible to walk amongst the history. A Must See!

This was truly fascinating. Spent a day with a tuk tuk visiting Angkor, Bayon and TaProhm. It is amazing to see the carved faces and the remnants of a once Hindu temple. There's something in the huge faces of buddha that makes one feel instantly peaceful.

Famous for the head sculptures. The view is good. If not for the not-so-many visitors, you are going appreciate this site more. Better read on its history so you can appreciate the importance of this temple.
Bayon Temple. ithink its a beautiful temple, just climbing litlle bit to the top of temple and you can enjoy the view.

Lovely. Beautiful temple, a lot smaller and quieter than Angkor Wat. The faces are truly unique, I would have liked to have learnt about them but there are no information boards so your only choice is to hire a tour guide.
faces. Located in the heart of the huge archeological city of Angkor Thom, these face towers appeared more approachable than the grandeur of Angkor Wat. An amazing part of the world.

The temple of the faces - another must-see when in Angkor. Bayon, the architectural masterpiece build by King Jayavarman VII some 800 years ago, still thrills with the hundreds (261 to be exact) of the King's faces on every single dome of the temple.In the old days, the faces were smooth and colorful, now they are of rough and stained rock, but still breathtaking.Of course, the crowds ruin the experience. If on a private tour (highly recommended!), try asking your guide when to visit the temple to avoid the most dense crowds.A tip: while not as famous as the Angkor Wat reflections in the moat, Bayon can also be photographed in similar way. While walking or driving around the temple, look for places where it reflects in the shallow moat - you will find a few.

So Impressive!!!!!!!. I loved this temple, it was truly mind blowing!!, The carvings and faces were amazing. It so hard to even begin to imagine how they built these structures so long ago and what the must have looked like back then. There was quite a bit of restoration being done out the front and the guys doing it clearly had some skill with the intricate markings and carvings. We walked up to the top and WOW what a view, very steep stairs going up!!! You could spend quite a bit of time at this one. Loved it!!!

Lots of steps!. The prettiest of all the temples, but lots and lots of steps some are quite steep and a little hard to climb.I'd recommend climbing to the top temp,e view point as its amazing how far out you can see
the best. for me the best temple in Angkor complex. Hypnotising is to sit inside the temple and look at this "pearl" in quiet and peace.

the major temple. Bayon is after Angkor Wat the second major temple complex in Siem Reap. It offers a nice reflection in the surrounding shallow lake and an lot of steps to climb. In this temple your guide will show you all the spots where you can shoot a tricky picture, like kissing a huge statue or participating in a ceremony with a carved figure. Pay attention to the heights and the steep steps if you have young children as you should never leave them unattended. Quite frankly better visit without kids if you wanna savior the ruins in peace.
One of our favourite ones. We enjoyed this temple so much. It is not so busy then Aangkor Wat and has a lot to see and to find on your ownWe love to travel and this is so beautiful to experience.

Beautifully Crafted. Great experience walking through the temples and climbing those tough stairs. Was quite tiring after walking miles around Angkor temple, followed by this one. It would be nice if we can keep enough time to visit these places since I had just one day stay @ Cambodia, had to complete these temples within a day. Next will surely plan for a longer stay.
Bayon temple . Bayon has the most finest hand craft and artefacts there are in abundance at this ancient angkor architectural .Such a phenomenal art centre in siam reap

Impressive Carved Faces Temple. This temple is quite far from Angkor Wat, where you need to travel pass through a bridge and Angkor Thom city gate before reached at the Bayon temple. There are several rehabilitation and reconstruction works during our visit there, but with proper safety measure taken. Impressed with how the earlier people made this temple and had so many carving faces decorating their temple. As Khmer's temples configuration had almost same configuration, don't be confused where you should exit and met you driver, or your bicycle.
Very good but busy.. Nicely restored part of the Angkor Thom complex. Very good detail remains on many of the carvings. Another one to definitly one to visit and hope for less crowds than I had.
Temples. Amazing with all the faces , a must see ! Take plenty of water and a hat , mystical and interesting, not far from Angkor wat

Incredible Bayon. Really lives up to its reputation. Fascinating details everywhere; superb wide angle shots. I did it both as part of an excellent photo tour (tour@angkor-wat-photography.com) and later on my own. Don't miss it.

Favourite of the temples. With the stone carved faces on the perimeter towers facing in all directions and the higher vantage point together with the fact that it was more crowd free than the others this rates as my favourite of the Angkor temples.
Visit. Once again best to goo early morning not to many people and heat not to hot after 1pm it gets very hot 35 degrees and to many people but a must visit.

Loved this temple.....beautiful. We visited quite a few temples in Siem Reap but the faces here were just beautiful. We managed to get here very early (best time to see it) - so the sun was just coming up - the bridge just before you reach it is amazing as well - we caught the mist and the fisherman in our pictures.

Maybe our Favorite. We came for Angkor Wat but we left astounded by Bayon. I genuinely didn't know much about the other temples but Bayon and all of the 4 faced pillars are an absolute must see. Try to go early to avoid the crushing tourist crowds!
Stunning. As is Angkor Wat, this is also one of the miracles of centuries ago. Please do not miss a visit to this unbelievable building.
Don't miss it!. The place that you can feel like the Bayon face was smiling to you every where. You will amazed from the Bayon face that was built many thousand years ago.
Woo another amazing temple. This is another must on the journey around the temples. It is famous for the more than11,000 figures with the outer wall depicting every day life in 12 C cambodia
An ancient marvel. Absolutely amazing!! Beautiful temple.. One of my favorite in Siem Reap.. A great temple to spend time in. Don't miss this one...
2nd to Angkor. Open and big temple. Is over crowded with tourists. Go to the side wall less crowded and can take great pictures. Ready to sweat.

Four faces..... After visiting several temples they can all start to blur together but Bayon is an exception. The four faces on the towers are quite different from any other temples and make Bayon a special place. I thought the faces were very mystical.

Beyond belief - history inscribed . One of 3 temples we visited with Insider Journeys - it left us spell bound . Extraordinary- architecture words can't describe this experience - not to be missed . Worth every cent - needs an hour or 2

Like an Ancient Labyrinth, never felt so good being lost.. This place, minus the crowd and horrible Chinese tourist from China who smoke and pretty much violating the temple despite all the warning sign.This is a good place to get lost and slowly explore the amazing labyrinth and countless of pathways. The giant stone faces. Near to Angkor Vat, stands the Bayon temple. After Vishnou's place, here comes the Bouddha's place. Again, take some time. Walk, sit, look at it from outside, from inside. This place is worth staying there for hours, if you have an umbrella against the sun AND the rain.

Bucket list. As per my other reviews of Siem Reap this is a must see for some time in your life. You will compare it to the best things you have seen. Bit daunting physically if you are not too fit but great close up or from a distance.

Bayon temple. A marvellous experience suitable for all age groups.Take a local guide as they are all well trained in the history.Take plenty of bottled water, ask to be taken to the Mine Museum a small local fund raising area full of interesting and enlightening information about the land mines in the area.Home to a number of land mine orphans. Along the road near here little stalls selling a marvellous array of local produce,handcrafts,fruit, including strange looking mushrooms.
Amazing. Amazing place to visit, the entire Siem Reap experience is definitely recommended, make sure you dress properly.

Oldest temple, 11th century. The serene faces looking over the kingdom will surely take you back in time. Get off the beaten path, due your own exploring in and around the temples. Plan for at least 2 days.

There are apparently 216 of them over 54 towers plus there is something like a kilometre of bas-reliefs (carvings: the best of which in my opinion are on the outer wall of the first level)...those numbers alone give you an idea of the size of it.To do it properly I would recommend giving it 90 minutes to 2 hours.Outside the Bayon you can ride Elephants. Surprisingly, all the buddha faces are similar in carving.

Angkor Thom. The Bayon is a well-known and richly decorated Khmer temple at Angkor in Cambodia. Built in the late 12th or early 13th century as the official state temple of the Mahayana Buddhist King Jayavarman VII, the Bayon stands at the centre of Jayavarman's capital, Angkor Thom. Following Jayavarman's death, it was modified and augmented by later Hindu and Theravada Buddhist kings in accordance with their own religious preferences. The Bayon's most distinctive feature is the multitude of serene and smiling stone faces on the many towers which jut out from the upper terrace and cluster around its central peak.

Overwhelming... After spending more than few hours I went to Bayon temple, accompanied by my guide. It's also from 12th century and is considered as State temple of Jayavarman VII and his successors. As there is no surrounding wall it can be entered from anyside but my guide took me to from the side of long terrace,called E side, with steps and guardian lions and naga balustrades on either side. It's an unique structure with a mass of face-towers to make you feel a stone mountain of ascending peaks. It appears it orginally had 49+ towers but presently only 37 are standing. The initial impact of such towers is overwhelming and quite impressive. The temple undergone many changes from worship of Hindu pantheon of Gods to Buddhism. The temple is composed of two galleried enclosures, almost square, but also on three different levels.Corner pavilions, chapels and gopuras reflect the complex architecture that stood vagaries of history.The towers got four and some three faces with a wonderful view of changing colours with the reflection of Sunlight with the background of trees particularly at upper terrace. The Bas-relief,inner and outer, require at least few hours to relish the intricacies of artistic carvings that deal with historical subjects from battles to daily life.Fine devatas striking adorn the walls of central massif including Siva,Vishnu and also Buddha.Few hours walk with guide explaining the importance of each corner took me to all together different world. Please devote atleast three to four hours, wear a cap and carry a water bottle as heat in the afternoon make you sweat a lot. Not to be missed by any traveller to understand the glory of Khmer art and architecture. Same ticket for Angkor Wat is valid for this temple.

overwhelming. it is incredible how a temple like this can be built in the past with no machinery or complex tools. the sheer size and magnificence of the place left many people in awe. a must for all tourist who are visiting the angkor temples
Best temple in the world. I went to beyou temple on July evening time with my family I saw big smiling face and four face look so nice spent my time for dinner at front temple lovely food😍👍👍👍👍
Amazing faces. The temple has a amazing faces of Buddha, take time to see the different faces. It's a must to visit even though it becomes very busy at times.

I love this temple and all the faces carved into it. Smiling Buddhas at every corner, the faces within the building walls are insane! It is not often that the reality surpasses your expectations, just take your time to walk slowly and examine the details.

History and cultural. Bayon is a Buddhist temple it built for waship for top government and king in 12 century, attraction for this temple is a big face of status, hight temple, good carving on the wall of temple show up about religion, activities of people life, war and some gambling with other county, it good for photos especially in the afternoon time,

Huge area, very crowded . Visited the Bayom area around noon. Impressive as well, but very hot, very crowded place with almost no shade. As the visitor circle which you have to walk is quite long here, make sure you have enough water and your hat with you. Toilets are also only at the very end of the circle behind the car park and most drivers drop you off at the first temple which is quite a walk back.We liked it there and think it is an impressive place, but enjoyed other temples more!
A must like Angkor. we did that temple at the same day when we went to Angkor and it's also very impressive and a landmark when. It's a must when you get into Siem Reap

This temple was simply amazing. A dream come true! Of all the temples visited in Siem Reap this was my favourite. Bayon Temple is a gem of a place especially if you arrive around mid day, by then the morning crowds have left. Excellent photo opportunity, you have to choose the right guide and he will know the best spots.

Tourists beware of tourists. Even in the "low season", I couldn't stand the crowds here when I rolled up in the afternoon - after two minutes in the heat jostling and bustling and listening to very strident Chines tourist guides, I made my excuses and left, planning an early morning strike the next day. I got there shortly after 0730 opening time and at first believed my cunning plan might just work: from the outside, Bayon looked tranquil but as soon as I got into the heart of the place, the sheer volume of people again took all the pleasure out of it. A shame, as the massive great heads that are its most striking characteristic are wonderful structures snd still faintly evocative even in all the twenty-first century bedlam. But after 10 abortive minutes, I decided to skip them and the bas reliefs and was just glad to be out of there. The nearby Baphuon temple plus the Royal Palace plus the gardens and woods linking them just contained a sane sprinkling of fellow-tourists. It's so worth going to Angkor Thom just for those, and for the wonderful array of sculpted figures on the maze-like inside wall beneath the mound that was once the site of the "Leper King". Then you re-emerge into the maelstrom of the main circuit but it's ok- you've had your fix.

Fantastic. The Bayon Temple was pretty amazing, it's included on your Angkor Wat Park ticket. It's a bit more of a ruin, which made it even more fascinating! It was pretty crowded, but it's not huge so you don't have to spend forever walking around it.

Quiet in the morning. My favourite temple. Not too crowded in the early morning, not too big and no tiring stairs to climb. Yippee! Bring some pens to give to kids trying to sell you souvenirs instead of giving them money.

Bayon Temple. Also a must see.
Unfortunately our tour guide wasn't as good on this tour as the others but wow! We just wanted to see all of these beautiful sites and glad that they've been found under the overgrown vegitation for us to see. The imprints, figures, stories and Buddha's in the stone are awesome.

Do you ever get the feeling someone's watching you.... My favourite temple and I did both the Grand and Outer tours. Despite being very busy I loved the style and layers present. It just seemed different compared to the others.

Lots of Buddha Faces. Roam around the temple to see the different faces of buddha. There's a spot as well with faces being at the same level. While another can be used as kissing buddha illusion picture.
Stunning. Felt very emotional seeing this. It was awe inspiring. Amazing faces. I didn't believe the size before I went there.

Beautiful temples, simple stunning. Amazing carvings and beautiful temple grounds. There were some impressive views from the upper part of the interior that are not to be missed. Its quite an experience to have all the Buddha faces looking at you!
Stunning. Incredible and exceeds 'Temple of Doom' expectations. We arrived at noon so were scrambling around in the intense heat and humidity. Watch out for the faces carved in the rock

Great Stop. Like everyone has said, this is the best place after Ankgor Wat. It is hard to imagine how well these carvings are preserved. Besides the obvious reasons, this stop has a very cool elephant ride. Get there at 8:00 so you don't have to wait in line.
Please go and see. This temple is also incredible to see, especially if you are spending the day sight seeing temples. This one is worth a visit.

Beautiful . The Bayon Temple is part of the Angkor Thom temple which is part of the small temple circuit which your hotel will offer you. It will cost you 20 us in a tuk til or 30 in a car. It will take all day. Brace yourself for how hot it gets here. Drink water, bring sun screen and a hat and also an umbrella- the sun is strong.
