Also consider bringing electrolytes packs from home to replenish minerals you will loose because of sweat. Also you can take an elephant ride around this temple for $20 us. Look for the monkeys that hang out around this temple. Also get ready for the steep stair cases. Don't wear flip flops.

You'd be amazed with these wonderful temples. I advise taking the steps to the top of the temple to see it in it's full glory! Be sure to dress appropriately so as not to offend the local people. Try to go early as it can be quiet hot towards the middle of the day.

A must visit temple!. Of all the temple in the Angkor Complex, this is a must visit temple as it is not only a uniquely designed temple but one that sets the foundation to your understanding of the other temple. The temple was commissioned in late 12th century by Mahayana Buddhist King Jayavarman VII. This man went on to commission a few of the other well known temples including Ta Phrom. Remembering the faces (of Bodhisattva Avalokiteshvara, the deity in Buddhism) would come in handy for your future circuit, as you would see it in the other temples the king commissioned.However, the temple itself is unique with the faces looking at you from all direction.Take a pic with your nose touching one of the noses and take a picture of the temple from across the left lake at the entrance, you get a beautiful reflection of the temple in the water.

Lots of faces . Not the biggest, nor most spectacular, it's still the second most important one around. Famous for lots of big stone faces, it's definitely must see when visiting archeological complex.
Don't miss the smaller temples. While Angkor Wat is the prime destination I found that the smaller temples were more interesting and less congested with tourists.

Incredible. Amazing temple reflecting King Jayavarman. Absolutely amazing to see the faces carved into the magnificent temple. must see during your temple visits. Thanks Active Asia for making our tours so easy and smooth
worth visiting .. one of the temple complexes to be visited in Angkor / the gigantic towers with faces every side is unique. though most of the structures are ruined its worth visiting /
Amazing place to visit. An amazing place to see, as are all of the temples of Cambodia. Definitely worth a visit but make sure you have a guide to explain the history as it is very interesting.

One of The Best Temples!. Bayon Temple surely did not disappoint! After our sunrise at Angkor Wat Temple, we headed straight to Angkor Thom and saw this magnificent temple that boasts plenty of intricate faces of the Gods/Kings. Once you reach the top of the temple, you'd be able to see the faces up close as well as having a great view of the surroundings. But be careful, the plank stairs are quite steep! In addition, when we went there (that was around 7:30am), there were already too many tourists so you'd have to fall in line to go up or down the stairs as well as wait for your turn to get a good shot of the temple.
Impressive faces. Impressive faces. Worth making the visit here. You could get a nose-nose picture if you find the right face/angle to do so. A good one for photographers

Bay on your way other temples . What a place, amazing faces carved out of stone. Totally different from Angkor Wat but better as it's quieter and feels more grounded in the jungle. It's hot so take water and there aren't many toilets.
Amazing bayon. Temple was amazing very interesting with 4 face of the god .It was inside angkor thom city have many temple .

Beautiful, fun, less hype-d. Bayon is less hyped than Angkor Wat and therefor maybe a better experience to us.The many faces and other bas reliefs are more fun to discover and the site is not so big, more do-able. It actually also has a moad in front that allows for beautiful reflection pics and despite the busy-ness, we were able to shoot a few pics with no other people in them, fun.
Stunning. no words that can explain the feelings that you get when you are there. Rainning days I do not recommend.If you can go in tne morning I think is better !

Temple of Many Faces. Combine a visit to this temple after Angkor Wat. Hop back on your bike and cycle 3k to the entrance. Use your Lonely Planet or hire a guide to help you decipher the bas reliefs on the outer walls before wandering amongst the faces starting down at you in the inner temple.Plenty of small vendors outside to provide coffee, waters, snacks and proper covering if you need.

So many faces. The temple is under construction, but although it may spoil a picture or two, it doesn't ruin the experience. It has many stairs and so many corners and faces to see. Quite a cool temple!
Must-see. The Bayon Temple was by far the favorite of the many we explored around Siem Reap. Highly recommend hiring a guide to make sense of the many cultural references found at the site.

Loved it.. We visited Bayon after Angkor Wat. Bayon was so unique and gorgeous. It's really impressive when you walk through. We were caught inside a temple for about an hour because of the rain (be prepared bring a poncho and umbrella! ) and I just looked at the faces and tried to discover everything there was to see. Take a moment and really look at the detail.
A must to go place.. This place is unique compared to the other temples. It has smiling Buddha on it towers and has 200 plus statues of it. It will definitely get u smiling too!
Beautiful. One of the better temples in my opinion and some lovely views and pictures from it, saw a lot of temples over the 2 days in Siem Reap all in about 27 and this one would pop in the top 5

Stunning Temple. This is a truely impressive temple. Can be crowded, but not hard to find a quiet place to sit look at the structures and reflect. The beautiful faces seem to follow your movements and make you feel relaxed and at ease. Really worth the walking and climbing.

Amazing temple. This temple is the 2nd best temples to visit in Siam Reap. It has a distinct feature which stands out from the rest. Do read up before visiting or alternatively hire a national park guide. This is definitely a great place for panaromic shots. Drink lots of water if you are here during July period.
Nice . It's probably not quite as nice as Angkor Wat, but it's close. And the way the trees how on and thru the stone is pretty cool
Amazing temple!!!. It used to be a big city of Cambodia if i am not wrong. The construction is big and the design was fabulous!
Great architecture. If you can do it in low season then do so. There was a couple of bus tours there and it was a bit crowded.

My favorite temple in Angkor. All the heads in the bayon temple is so spectacular, and it is really hard to imagine how they made these sculptures by hand. If you want some nice pictures, there are great possibilities here.

Do Not Miss this unique Temple!. Banyon has tree roots that grow into the stone. It is so awesome. Many of the roots are over one story high. Walking has to be done with caution but can be done. Do NOT recommend walking through if you have problems with balance or stepping over rocks. There are very limited pathways. Go with a guide.
Beautiful temple with plenty of faces. The best time to visit is early morning. There are plenty photo opportunity but you must beat the crowd.

Iconic Smiling Buddhas. Arrive early and get a guide! There's some stairs involved if you want to explore the upper levels. One of the iconic photos from Siem Reap. A must do. But it gets crowded by about 9am.
Tomb raider temple. Next best thing to being with Angelina Jolie!!! It's mesmerising!! Take your time. And do visit all four gates, esp the gate of the dead

favorite temple. This was by far my favourite temple. There's something special about it, it's magnificent from the beginning till the end. I wasn't expecting much, I'm not much of a tourist and usually get annoyed at temples and ruins, well not this place it's so beautiful I can only imagine how it looked when it was built and it's still so nicely preserved. Amazing, so happy I went to this one!!

My favourite temple!! . I loved this place!! I guess I liked t most because it was quieter than Angkor Wat but also because the many cool smiling faces. Fantastic place to take pictures and interesting history.

Big face of Buddha temple.. I don't how to say with this temple because the old people they can made this temple so amazing with great big face of Budhha more than 200 face at the same time.
This is a temple we liked.

The many faces of Bayon. Awesome temple, had a great feel to it. I think you can get much closer to the great carved faces than you could at Angor Wat and the enclosed spaces really make you feel a part of the place.

Brilliant Bayon. A great temple. Magnificent. Loved the many faces of King Jayavarman VII.
We visited in July which is the low season and it was very crowded.

A great place to put on your bucket list.. This is a very nice place to go and see. It is very old and it part Asian and part Indian. To see what people bulit many , many years ago is quite impressive. The art work of this Temple 5 star.
Definitely our favourite! . The complex is amazing. We love it as soon as we entered the complex. So much details to the workmanship. Just spectacular. Must visit.
Magical place!. The temple of smiling faces, one of the most beautiful temples in Siem Reap area. An absolute must-see!
Beautiful. Lovely temple that has a distinctly different character to the others in the area. Not quite a show stopper like Angkor wat but definitely worth a visit

Loved this place - one of my favourites.. Actually one of the better locations in my opinion, I loved the fact there were just so many photo opportunities, because there are so many decorated walls, as well as nooks and crannies.
Certainly for me Bayon and the rest of Angkor Thom is preferable to Angkor Wat in terms of things to see and explore.

Weekend trip . Bayon temple is one of old city before Angkor Wat temple.
The sand stone temple look great of Khmer empire.
Bayon is amazing temple of Cambodia.
Let visit Cambodia for your experience life.
banyon temple. Simply amazing! Must see! Incredible carving. One of the best temples in the Angkor Wat complex. It gets busy in the morning. Probably better to go in the afternoon.

Absolutely WONDERFUL. No words can describe my experience in this place. Is unique, full of details, and lots of energy. Was powerful be in there and incredible how much can you learn just looking the constructions and the carvings on the walls all around the temples. Absolutely beautiful.
Another Must See. Great and in a smaller scale than Angkor Wat. The closeness to the Budha faces is worth the visit, easy to walk and not challenging.
Amazing ruins. You see many more things up close. I also had the benefit of a great guide. Bayon's architecture and story are great. I liked the 'smaller temples' more than Ankor Watt.
Magic place very old. This temple is very special because you can see how they built piece by piece. Is very good for spending more than one hour there
Not to be missed. Bayon temple is almost as impressive as Angkor Wat but a lot less crowded which means that there is much more opportunity to have a good at all the amazing details

Worth a visit. Right from the snake -pulled by the Asuras and the Devas on either side of the road leading to the Bayon Temple and the huge towering 4 heads of Brahma.54 in all...it was truly a sublime experience. Intriguing displacement of Shiva lingas replaced by Buddha statues.. inticate carvings of day to dayliving that even finds place in todays lifestyle ...almost a thousand years later...is so surrealistic!Enjoyed it immensely
Another long hot day. I suggest doing these over a couple days, the weather was extremely hot and there are so many steep steps on all the temples
What an experience.. We arrived quite early so not too crowded or hot. Just a fabulous experience that you really cant describe; you have to live it.

Amazing!. Loved our visit to Angkor Thom. In our opinion we thought it actually better than Angkor Wat. There are so many ways to go and a photographic opportunity at every turn. As with all the temples if you can drag yourself out of bed early to be there as it opens then this is the best time to visit, it's quieter, easier to take photos and less hot. Make sure you take plenty of water as climbing the steps and negotiating the flag stones is quite an effort and in the heat quite exhausting. Make sure you have sensible comfortable shoes. Also (and I can't remember if it was here or another temple) make sure you're suitably dressed as they will turn you away if youre not. I wanted to see the lepta to terraces a and the terrace of the Leper King both within walking distance from the main temple. Whereas the temple itself is amazing I am glad the two terraces were within this complex and I didn't go just to see them as I would have been somewhat disappointed on seeing the terraces. Don't get me wrong they are beautifully carved and worth seeing but as part of the complex and not on their own.

Best of the temple sites we visited . This is a great site with the opportunity to take breath taking photos.Quite a large site but far less steps to climb than it's big brother Angkor Wat. Much more decorative also.

Pretty but not that interesting. The place was probably bigger up too much, but I expected it to be a bit more maybe.. most pictures were also ruined by unused cranes and scaffolding. Obviously worth a visit but we were done within 30 mins
Another beautiful sight. This place is amazing. Faces and more carved faces everywhere you look. Just beautiful, a must see!! Well with the trip!

Unexplainable sculptures..."the serenity of the stone faces". Oh! Look at that...that's what I said to myself everytime I changed my position to see the unexplainable beauty of this temple... While Angkor main temple makes its position for the greatest engineering, this temple gets 10 out of 10 for the best of its sculptures in the planet...Bayon was the last state temple to be built at Angkor, unlike other Angkor temple which were built as Hindu temple and then converted to Buddhism, Bayon is the only Angkorian state temple to be built primarily as a Mahayana Buddhist shrine dedicated to the Budda and letter reverted to Hinduism...I would suggest you to click some awesome moments during sunrise and sunset while most tourists are busy in clicking Angkor main temple....Truly, a lifetime experience!

Must see. Aside from Angkor Wat, this is one of the most majestic temples. It also shows the emergence of Buddhism and conflict as the subsequent king removed many Buddha statutes and changed the towers faces to appear Hindu. Just beautiful.

Amazing - spend at least 1/2 day here. Try to get here at 5-5.30am, (really!) as the hordes will be at Angkor Wat for the sunrise and you will have this to yourself (well, mostly) just as beautiful and has a mystical air about it at this time of the day. The grounds are big, with a gated wall around it.

best of the Ankor temples. Expected Ankor Wat to blow me away - and it did. Bayon was more spectacular. The scale of the undertaking and the carving of the heads is awe inspiring. Loved the ambience . If you visit Siem Reap - make sure this is on your list
Fantastic place . Definitely to be missed when in Siam Reap;Incredible sculptures of four faced Buddhas; just wondered how long would they last withstanding the deterioration of the weather ?
The many faces temple. So cool to see! It was hot while we walked around so make sure to take plenty of water. The art work on this temple is amazing.
The Angkor temple complex. Make sure you already have your ticket handy, because they will ask you for your ticket at every temple's entrance.
Incredible detailed carvings. Mostly in a state of disrepair however quite acceptable to appreciate the style of building and architecture of the time.
A style of its own. Perhaps the most interesting temple (visually). Everywhere something to see, a different face, a different view. Great.

The Speechless of the Speechless. Angkor is the incomparable temple region and Bayon is my favourite. The four-face towers are smiling to you whichever angle you look at them and make you calm and content.

Another unmissable experience. Bayon was the third and last temple we visited in one day and, although we were getting a little weary and hot, I am so glad we made the effort .. Another stunning place .. beautiful carvibgs on a huge scale .. There are some very steep steps ..but the views are awesome. Fabulous photo opportunity to catch Bayon reflected in the pool... Don't miss it
So beautiful!. This was one of my favorite temples! It was significantly less crowded and absolutely beautiful. Highly recommend this one!
Great!. Larger than Angkor Wat, this place is close by and provides a lot of opportunities to explore the grounds and eat local food.

Elephants. The only thing I can recommend here is having an elephant ride take you round! Have a photo taken for $1 and enjoy the jealous looks. It's difficult to get a ride outside to go in, easier once you are inside. You also get the opportunity to stroke and have a photo taken. Unfortunately that was the highlight for me and the only thing I can really remember! Try to keep your bearings, we went the wrong direction to get to the tuk tuk park, so that turned into a very long walk, and a slight panic as the park is big and your trying to find your tuk tuk in amongst hundreds of vehicles.

Our 2nd favorite (after Ta Prohm). The only Buddhist (from time of construction) temple in the park. Truly amazing! Be sure to carry a bottle of water with you everywhere and have $1 bills for souvenirs.
The best temple by far. Dont what ever you do miss Bayon. Most photogenic for sure and would be my choice to visit first. Take your time and enjoy the mystique about this whole place

Stunning. This was our first temple visited in the complex and one of my favourites. We had a guide who was well worth the money, he told us the full history and knew all the best areas to take pictures. A really atmospheric place to visit.
fantastic tour.. amazed to see how it was built many centuries ago. it was tiring but worth the visit. i would love to go there again.
Stunning. Absolutely beautiful work on all of the stones. Even restored, you still get the depth of how amazing this place was and is.
Not to miss!. Very interesting and unique temple. Don't miss the battle scenes carved into the lower level surrounding the temple.

Amazing piece of history preserved. Was totally awestruck by this structure and its history. Definitely a must visit when in Cambodia. Spend about at least 30mins here if not more. Go through the intricate carvings that tell stories. It's worth the heat.

Bayon Temple, center of Angkor Thom. The temple of 200 smiling faces, one of the most spectacular in the Angkor complex. The faces said to be of Jayavarman himself is quite ornate and impressive. It is in the center of Angkor Thom, the largest city in the world at that time.

Beautiful! . This was my favorite temple of Angkor Wat area! It was steaming hot, so very good to early in the morning! Also, there was a tour guy that gave some serious history on the place and showed me where to get the best photos. He was just a student asking for tips for his time. Unfortunately, my husband had already gone down because daughter was sick so I didn't have any money to give him. He was gracious about it. So PLEASE if you are approached and he gives you great information tip a little extra for me!

Awesome inspiring . The engineering and sheer architectural wonder that is the Bay on Temple.Wow, the 39 remaining towers are truly amazing to behold. The history behind this temple is quite something (too much to mention here.)Go along and marvel in its splendour. Many photo opportunities. The towers with the heads showing a diamond shape on the forehead; is the 3rd eye of Lord Shiva. Enjoy this temple...

Climb.. Climb till you succeed. Similar to Angkor Wat.. The Bayon temple has many levels... Each level gives you a different view of surroundings.. You would think that the view is same from level 1 or level 3 but believe me.. Its NOT! Tip: Do this at around 3pm, it is less crowded. Carry a bottle of water to replenish yourself at the top!

Even Better Than Angkor Wat, IMHO. I wasn't familiar with Bayon before I visited Siem Reap, but I found this temple to be even more interesting and more beautiful than Angkor Wat (although it's awesome too). Walking through the temple is a little like exploring a maze, with something new and exciting around every corner.

Amazing architecture; incredibly crowded. Unlike many if not most of the other temples in the Angkor Wat complex we visited, this one was so crowded that I was tripping over other tourists the whole time, and had to wait to take pictures at a given spot or of a particular carving. However, part of the reason it's so crowded is that the huge carved heads are just so iconic. They're also beautiful. The shapes of the towers, which are intended to be reminiscent of ancient holy mountains, are covered with carvings. Although the details may be a little fuzzy around some edges, and while the cracks and lichen are apparent even in the best preserved samples, the carvings are just amazing. The overall architecture of the site was interesting- stairs up and down, up and down, around each corner, a few up to go in any door or window opening, then a few down again. It's such an interesting style, although certainly tiring to traverse. I enjoyed my visit immensely.

Great heads of Buddha... Integral part of the Angkor archeological park within the precincts of the ancient city of Angkor Thom. With its magnificent heads of Buddha a must visit for any body in the area. Just make sure you try to get there when it's least crowded as crowds are totally unavoidable. The visit here is combined with Baphuon , terrace of the Leper King and Elephant terrace. Wear good shoes as it's a Pretty big complex and have arleast 2 hours in your itinerary for this. As you exit the temple, outside you will find Chinese juice sellers. Don't buy from them . Very over priced. Just walk a few steps behind the van to the non conspicuous Cambodian small shops to drink coconut water.
Bayan is known as the Magic temple. During our visited our tour guide Mr.Thearith told me much interesting history about the Bayan but the most important that I knew is the Magic Temple.

The faces of Cambodian. The first thing when we arrived here it was a big wow for us, as we did not know we are coming to this place after finished the angkor wat trail. It is not far from angkor wat and our tuk tuk driver said this is a must come place.And i agreed, this is a must come site where you can see faces up in the tower. Its actually parameterized by a square box and any entrance can be an exit, hence you can see the faces one by one. Their expressions are different and you wont believe this statues are made from so many years back.. tons of tourist including me question how do they carve these and how do they make it so perfect that each gap.id nicely sealed with different type and size of rubbles.On some side of the temple, there are some rubbles that fall down and please do not keep it, it is very meaningful to everyone, but it ia even more meaningful for the cambodians.Be extremely careful with your steps as the staircase is very steep, this place is not for kids and oldman.

Why Are You Even Asking? Go!. This was the 2nd temple I visited on my 1-day Angkor tour, after seeing Angkor Wat. Many of the architectural features of Bayon are very different from those of Angkor Wat and it's worth seeing, if only for that reason. Angkor Wat was built by a Hindu king, while Bayon was built by a Buddhist king. There are still lots of architectural details preserved in both and it's mind-blowing to think of people with basic tools doing such intricate carvings into stone. I'm pretty sure you won't regret spending an hour or 2 at this temple.

Unique structure. Numerous smiling Buddha face. This is one of the attraction at Angkor Thom one should not miss out. It would let you ponder how those large artistic structures have been in those per-industrial days without any assistance of crane and other such lifting equipment

Don't leave the Temples of Angkor without visiting this Temple.. The main temple, Angkor Watt, is a must see and the largest of all the Temples. However, I think this temple was the most beautiful and amazing with all it's many faces. All I can say is WOW.

Very impressive . All the temples at Angkor are great to see however this is one of the best. It is hard to imagine this whole area was home to a thriving civilisation around a thousand years ago when you compare to modern day Cambodia. Once you are in the area just try and see as much as possible of every temple; you won't regret it.

Wow . So different from angkor wat and other temples. Incredibly beautiful and interesting. Suggest visiting at this time of year, crowds sre down and the rain generally holds off until the afternoon. We hired a car and guide which provides nice respite from the heat

Interesting Temple. Enjoyed my trip to this temple. I went to Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm in the same day. This was an amazing temple, but I enjoyed the other temples a bit more. It was worth it to visit, but I would not skip either of the others to visit this temple instead.

The temple is great to explore and has so much history. Bayon is not overly large so it is quite easy to see around. Very interesting bas relief as you enter depicting a variety of historical and mythological scenes. The Bayon's distinctive feature is the massive stone faces of Buddha on the many towers. As you walk through, don't forget to turn around and view where you've been for sometimes surprising angles.

Same Same but Different - Worth a Visit!. Although similar to Angkor Wat - it is also quite different. The large faces, deep carvings, and many stories told in the carvings (explained by our private tour guide) this is a temple well worth the visit. Although try to beat the crowds if possible - it gets a little hectic and sometimes difficult not to have strangers in your photo. Do try to get a photo kissing the Buddha...

Smiling temple got me smiling . Yep the smiling temple. It's amazing how every corner you turn you can still see the middle tower surrounded by other smiling little towers and it looks like you are standing at the same place all the time!!! A must visit in siem reap
Bayon Temple. A temple with smiling faces. There are lots of very nice stone carvings too. A place you should never miss. Excellent.

A must see. Visited Bayon Temple after Angkor Wat and was amazed at how few tourists there were. Was on a tour group of 16, and would guess there was ~30-40 people total at the temple. The temple has a number of beautiful Buddha faces on large pillars and the architecture looked very different than Angkor Wat. Lots of opportunity for great photos (there were staff taking pictures for tourists with the Buddha faces at great angles) and exploring the temple.

Temple of many faces - fabulous. I loved this temple. Visited it late morning so pretty busy and hot. Very interesting with loads of pictures carved into the stone. My second favourite after Ta Prohm.
Wondering . Went for the morning with two 5 year olds. Walked around the temple. Took photos, got blessed and just enjoyed the history. Great trip

Child friendly for climbing. Great Temple with lots of photo ops. Was great for the kids to be able to explore up top, which they were not allowed to do due to steep climbs at Angkor Wat, and a couple of other temples we visited
A huge temple to walk. A nice temple. Spend about few hours here. Lots of rebuilding is on going at the moment. Overall is a great temple to visit.
Amzing. This is most beautiful and interesting place you must see. Many faces many feels, don't know long it take to made this. You should come here in sunset, nice view from other side of the lake

Beautiful. One of our visits on the list. My partners must see place. On his bucket list. They usually don't allow vehicles close to the complex but we managed to get one of the motorcycles to take my partner who could not walk closer to the temple.

Stunning architecture and history. From each of the towers, there are large carved faces that appear to be watching over everyone. The details of wall carvings and head statues are absolutely well made. Truly mesmerising and what is most staggering is that no cement was used. Very easy to wander around and start to see the uniqueness of all the faces.
One of my favorite temples. I traveled twice to Cambodia to visit the temples and Bayon is high on the list of my favorite temples. You have to experiece it for yourself and you will not regret it.
One of the best Temples in the area. Loved that this temple still has all the Buddha faces depicted and have not been defaced like in most other Temples. Made it real special.

The magic of the Bayan temple. This temple is straight out a tomb raider game . The wonderful stone features loom out the morning mist and is quite unlike anywhere I have been before. Despite the crowds you can still take a few moments to marvel at the spectacle before you
Tremendous temple!!!. What a beautiful temple!!! It is very surprising to see what talented people have achieved centuries ago.

Magnificent temple. Amazing temple and it's like a maze once you go inside. The details of wall carvings and head statues are absolutely well made and makes you wonder how did the past Khmer people made it. When i went there last Nov 2015 some part of the temple are under restoration but I still managed to take good pictures. After you visit Angkot Wat be sure to visit Bayon Temple next because its worth it.

Outstanding!. Truly mesmerising and what is most staggering is that no cement was used, the lime and sandstone were transported great distances, carved and then placed in situ. As with Angkor Wat a must when in Siem Reap. As you will note from other posts we had a private car and guide - it did make life so much easier ($155. Although we paid another $20 each for the day pass). Not a cheap day but it is worth every cent - truly one of the outstanding sights of the world.
Must-see. Amazing place to visit - stunning architecture and history. A must see part of the large Ankor Wat complex.
great temple. Bayon is big one temple have 4 face stand on the top of temple so very nice .On wall of temple had a lot picture it was show about history .

Many watchful eyes!. This temple has a very mysterious aura, as from each of the towers, there are large, carved faces that appear to be watching over everyone in each of the cardinal directions. It is splendid, and you really get a sort of spooky sensation of being watched over from everywhere. Bayon is in the center of the Angkor Thom complex. Book a tuk tuk driver for a day or half day and have him take you to Bayon and allow you as many stops as you like to see the other smaller temples, and serene but majestic views throughout.

So many faces..... Not crowded by my definition. Very easy to wander around and start to see the uniqueness of all the faces. Spent half a day here and loved every second. Could have spent more! There was a small structure that you can climb up not attached to the building proper. (It's on the left after you enter) Trust me, you want to take the 'easy' way up. Both sides are steep steps that require climbing with both hands ans feet. Excellent view. The whole temple has a mysterious feel and tons of great photo ops; worth lugging a proper camera to.
Quiet and moving place.. A great place to sit and watch the world go by. It is beautiful and peaceful and a wonderful location to take in the amazing craftsmanship of the Khmer people.

54 Towers and many, many smiling faces. The Bayon Temple is in the middle of Ankor Thom and very impressive with its many towers with each 4 faces to each direction. Take the time to see all the galleries, amazing reliefs with crocodiles hunting fish and all other types of animals and scenes from daily life.
So many different faces. The Bayon Temple is absolutely astonishing! Each and every face of Buddha is different with it's own expression.
one of my favorites!. A great place to watch the sunrise. Highly recommend this temple, walk around the whole thing to really see it!
Amazing Faces. You would first of all wonder the beautiful smiling faces on the Temple trying to express good ness.....Amazing
Spectacular - my favorite temple!. Be sure not to miss Bayon Temple - absolutely amazing with all the faces. Even though it poured rain when we visited, it was my favourite!

Gorgeous. . Crowded. But gorgeous, I can never get enough of Bayon and the beauty surrounding. The grass in the front will have caribou grazing some parts of the year, other parts of the year there are pink flowers in the motes that only come certain times if the year. As the seasons change, so does the look outside Bayon. You will never be disappointed, no matter the climate

Amazing, plentitude of stone towers with 4 peaceful Budha faces each. Not to be missed in your trip to Siem reap. One gets surrounded by huge Buddha faces all around. That too in a thousand year old temple. Sit relaxed for some time instead of running to the next attraction. Absorb the ambience.Truely amazing.
Great Temple!! . Love the temple! It's less well-preserved than Angkor Wat, but the faces of Avalokiteshvara are nice here~ their faces seem to come so close to you~~

Amazing. Another must place to see on any trip out to Angkor Wat Archaeological Park. So much work went into building this temple that a visit is due to appreciate this complex structure. Even in its ruins, which is slowly being rebuild, a good couple of hours walking and climbing around leaves you in awe.

So Different. For people visiting the temples of Ankor Wat this one is a "must do" This is mainly because the statues and carvings are not only Bhudist but many are Hindu and therefore it is so different to most of the other popular temples. So many carvings that it can become a little overbearing but nonetheless it is a must visit temple and you will not be disappointed

Well worth the effort.... This temple of the many faces is a fantastic example of early Khmer architecture and is still used for religious ceremony today. Make sure you have a photo 'kissing' the large stone face.

Beautiful faces (literally). Moment you enter this place, you will observe lot of faces looking in all directions. Sculptures depicted Buddha in these temples. Its looks are magnificent. There are good spots to click pictures.
Temple of Faces. This is another unique temple you can find in Siem Reap. It was fascinating to see the faces of Buddha carved all over the temple.

LET'S FACE IT. This temple is one not to be missed and is famous for the 216 smiling faces decorating the 54 towers. Unless you're an archeologist you will get a bit bored after you've seen your 81st face. However that does not detract from the thoughts you have that this place was built hundreds of years ago with hand tools only and no power tools or heavy lift machinery. Be amazed; I was.

Face of Gods overlooking the great city.. Bayon temple was having 50 towers with 200 smiling faces on the top, out of which 37 towers now exist. The faces are said to be of the Hindu God Brahma overlooking the great city of Angkor Thom as a guardian. This temple was also built by king Jayavarman the 7th.

What a wonderful place...... Go and enjoy all the carvings, especially the huge heads. Another wonderful temple, popular with tourist and worth visiting. Fairly well in tact and compact so you can see alot in a short time. Don't forget your camera if you go there.
One of my favourites. . No doubt it ranks high on TA. Really amazing architecture in ancient time. Be prepared to climb the stones up, but you will be rewarded.

Amazing temple. This is one of my favourite temples. Best to visit early to avoid the hordes of people. Wooden steps have been put up to help people move around the temple safely. This does take away from the beauty of the temple however probably necessary to protect. There are other temples that are less visited and just as beautiful.

Go early!. This was one of the most impressive temples in Angkor Wat. I would recommend going there early (right when it opens) to avoid all the large tour groups. The pathways to walk are narrow so if you would like to avoid people in your picture, I would hire a tour guide and beat the crowd.

Same day visit as Angkor Wat . Well Worth the short trip from Angkor Wat wonderful temple with faces looking at each cardinal point.
I would recommend going with a guide although Tuk Tuk drivers may be able to do a basic tour if you pay them a bit more.
amazing. amazing need to see pictures dont do it any justice would highly reccomend a visit to see for yourself

Visit this place. If you're in Siem Reap, how can you contemplate not visiting this place??? Ok, if you're looking at this review, obviously you are going to. So, just look at the pictures, look at the faces, and pack your stuff, get a guide, and just go. Enjoy!!

The Bayon Temple is great. We went here after sunrise at Angkor wat and spent about an hour. Loved the carvings of everyday life and the faces, the shrine etc. Beautiful and one of the better temples to see, can get quite crowded though.
Great trip. Amazing carvings, so much to see here. Take a good camera and you will come home with some great pictures.
Large group. Again, a beautiful temple with awesome history. Bring a guide and lots of water and give yourself at least 2 hours to tour.

A temple of character . Bayon Temple offers an intricate scene of endless carvings along the temple walls. To snap the best pictures it is suggested to go in the morning, though this temple doesn't get too busy, it is best to visit then as it is quiet and cool. The temple also has a steep climb to the top of three levels where a panoramic view is seen of the Siem Riep jungle, truly beautiful and worth the climb if you have second thoughts on doing so!

A must do!!. We were tired as this was the last temple of the day. But man, this was a jaw dropping experience. Detailed art work on the walls of the temple.A guide will be able to explain lot of history if you are not familiar with the hindu culture, regardless get a guide for the "mini tour" as they call it.

Another amazing city. Smaller than Angkor Wat but in some ways more impressive. You can see the Bayon temple at its centre. You'll probably enter through the south gate with the four heads pointing in each direction.
Superb. In the centre of Ankhor Thom and superb. It has scale, beauty, interest. Everything an educated tourist could want. Superb
IMMERSE ONESELF IN THE PAST. The photographic opportunities are endless. The array of temple structures are incredible. It is truly amazing how the structures still exist today

Breathtaking face carvings. My favourite of all the temples. Allow a good 2 hours to investigate, and not be rushed by the other tourists. Worth venturing up and up all the steep stairs to the top for better views and close up to the face carvings.
The many faced god-king. Surreal temple that exudes powerful energy. Visit at any time. Rain ruins photo ops, but it cleanses the temple of the inevitable crowds.

Our favourite temple. Of all the wonders in its locality, this was our favourite. Go early to avoid the crowds (who will be waiting for sunrise at Angkor Wat).
The faces (basically 1,000 year old faces) were better in real life than pictures in the guidebooks.
A must see

Interesting!!!. Firstly, apon arrive Do NOT accept any offers from the taxi driver who drove you as tour prices are cheap at your hotel! You will lose more money with tourist price. We got a tour for 15 dollars for 1 whole tuk tuk rather than 15 dollars each. This tuk tuk tour started from 5 am to watch the sun rise and he drove us all around showing all temples around Angkor wat.This temple is one place to go to! The only down side is that due to reconstruction you can see the old and new stones. It is very good that this is happening but the difference make it look alittle bit off, taking that old and jungle like feeling.I would highly recommend on getting the early morning tour which starts from 5am- yes this is an early start but as soon as it turn 8 o clock the place is so packed with tourist that it's difficult to take any pictures. Also starting early mean that your less exposed to the hot sun after 12. Be warned there are 2 prices for EVERYTHING. First price is tourist price which is twice or even more than the original such as water costing 1 dollar rather than 50 cent and also the second price, the fair price which you my ask the locals for. Also the cost to enter this temple is 20 dollar which gives you the ability to see all temple.

Fantastic temple. This is another must-do on your Siem Reap tour. All of the temples in this area are magnificent and they are all different.I recommend you use a local guide like Affinity Angkor who made sure we had a fantastic tour.
Another Fascinating Temple. Amazing place, well worth visiting. Temples are quite far apart, so pays to take a tuk tuk. A guide is another suggestion as it's good to get the history of the place.
amazing face temple. Bayon was stay inside Angkor thom city the big one ,Have face it very nice and beautiful .i very love this temple .

Incredible mesmerizing temple of many Buddhist faces. I was stunned by this exceptional temple composed of many towers, each with four smiling Buddha facing NSEW. There's a wondrous mystical quality to standing in the middle of all these towering ruins, being mesmerized by all the giant Buddha faces smiling down at you from all directions. Bayon Temple in Angkor Thom was by far the favorite part of my trip to Siem Reap, Cambodia. Incredible! I was awestruck.
Masterpiece. Bayon has lesson of life, lesson of rock and it is a charming place to travel back to the past. A truly wonder of Khmer culture.

Well worth a visit . Took a bike to this site. We had a guide who explained its history. We loved exploring the temple. The carvings at the entrance were amazing and in fantastic condition. Walking around the tip was great and we took some brilliant photos.

Truly breathtaking!. Cant help marvelling at how magnificent the temple structures are! My favourite temple among all I've visited. Swept away by the intricate sculptures of many faces belonging to great Khmer kings some say. Others believed the they are sculptures of the bodhisattva of compassion.
Nonetheless this temple provides many amazing photo spots for tourists.

Every where you look up, you will see the face of Buddha. We visited near the end of the day, and the crowds were less. You can get very close to the Buddha faces, photo opportunities of an era passed... A must see when you are in Siem Reap.

King Safety Driver. Sowang took myself and three others on a tour of Angkor Wat and the surrounding sites today and I cannot express how incredible of an experience we had. He is knowledgeable about the Angkor Wat well as Siem Reap. He is very polite and has a seemingly endless supply of patience and sincerity. One personal note from myself would be that I had wanted to purchase some paintings from the market and he went out of his way to negotiate on my behalf and I was able to get two amazing paintings for the locals' price. His driving skills as a tuk tuk driver are superb and I would absolutely recommend him if you are seeking an unforgettable experience at Angkor Wat. Thank you Sowang, for giving me an unforgettable experience that I will cherish for the rest of my life.

This one must be visit on a sunset. Bayon is a large and impressive structure, the temple has a lot of intricate and detailed carvings, and the carvings of the faces are huge! You would really be amazed how all these were preserved up to this time.. Its a place where every angle you turn is a lovely shoot.

The faces of temple . At the center of the city is Jayavarman's state temple.Big face of them this is a major of all and central of Angkor thom. The point is under construction if they have a completed I don't believed that this is a temple but is is a god's land.You can see the details of carve at every rocks.
LOOOOVVVEEEE IT. Absolutely a must place to go in Siem reap. You cant stop smiling at the faces carved on that temple. Beautiful!!
Of course 5-sar. An amazing feat of human architecture. Again, worth all the hassles of traveling to this challenging area with challenging weather.

Magnificent place. Wonderful layout, amazing carvings. It is more enjoyable if you prepare a little beforehand. National Geographic, the museum in the city, good general guides all will let you understand it better.

The smiling Budha. This temple is actually famous for taking picture with our nose touching the buddha statue. There is 4 spot to do so. If you have no idea where the spot is, just look for the long Q and wait in line. FYI, this is a must take photo in cambodia!

The large four faced Buddhas are amazing. Spent a half day at the Bayon Temple which was lovely. All the towers with the intricately carved faces on each of the four sides was breathtaking. Probably the most important temple in Angkor Thom. Wonderfull and breathtaking.

do not miss seeing this temple. Possibly one of the most fascinating of the temples in the region., Jungle growth over sections of the temple inspires the antiquity of the place. Numerous chambers and passages to explore.

The smiling Buddhas are just captivating and unforgettable. Amazing Buddhist temple (in ruins) to visit. The faces of Buddha are just unforgettable. Garudas are there all over. The intricate sculpture will bewilder you.

Nice architecture . It's very amazing I don't know how did they built the face at the temple.If you have not much time to stay in SR I recommend you to get a small tour from Tuk Tuk taxi for 15$ and they will take you to the Angkor thom area that included Angkor wat, Bayon, Ta Prohm and 2-3 temples. And the Bayon is one of the highlights that you should visit
Perhaps my favourite?. This place is very cool. Doesn't look much from afar but when you get in it - fascinating. Possibly my favourite of all the temples in this area.

Serene. Hot, busy and dangerous stairs but everywhere you look are the faces of Bayon. Would be an amazing place to sit and soak up the atmosphere if it were not so busy. I think it would be good to visit this one at sunrise rather than Ankhor Wat to escape the crowds. Much smaller than Ankgor Wat and we seemed to arrive at the same time as everyone else leaving there! Sad to see the elephants carrying tourists here!

Eerily Interesting. The many faces on the temple is what makes this place a must-see. Be ready for steep staircases to forgotten rooms- don't climb up what you can't get down. The size of this place is amazing as well as the intricate details of symmetry.
Strange faces. You going to love this place as the temple have strange faces craved on the stones. There is a high place to climb on but you have to be very careful as the steps are almost 90 degree.

Spectacular. Really no need for my review here-----its all been said. But, if you thrive on imaginary time travel, this is the place for you. Standing in the midst of this splendor will send your mind reeling back a 1000 years.

The history, go and visit. We had a local guide for this part, we didn't realize we had a guide until the end when the donation sheet came out so we learned the hard way. But it was worth it and he did know his stuff which helped one to understand more. A lot of children hang out so be careful when they keep looking for the sponsorship and wanting to guide you.

Amazing. The sense you get when you go here is unbelievable. It's rare to be able to get o close to such ancient ruins and really feel the history. Bayon is one of the larger temples and part of Angkor Thom, therefore one of the more crowded. Expect many people milling around aimlessly usually in front of where you're pointing the camera.Great day out!

Get there when it opens. . We arrive about 5 minutes before the temple opened at 7:30am, and this was the right move. Not too many crowds and the light was beautiful! Bayon is definitely the low key winner of the Angkor temples. It is very well preserved and super beautiful in a kind of creepy and mysterious way. A must see!!!

Stunning!. A really worthwhile temple to visit. It is quite small (in comparison to other temples nearby) and you notice the volume of visiting tourists. Best to get there as early as possible to fully appreciate its beauty.
Beautiful. Fantastic site where you can see the multiple faces of buddha that have been built towering into the sky.

Must-see but overrun by tourists. Of the temples, this one was my least favorite. It may partially be my own fault because we went later than we should have but there were just too many tourists there. They should limit the number of people allowed in at once.

really interesting temple. went here with an excellent guide Mao form happy angor tours and his detailed knowledge and explanations really made the experience. The temple has many faces and a lot of history an symbolgy. There is a lot of climbing involved but the "many faces of bayon" was one of my highlights of the siam reap trip
My favorite. 216 faces smile at you as you explore this cool temple. Any tour will bring you here, so enjoy your day.

Love it. For all those who want to visit this complex be sure have a good guide book or book yourself a tour guide because if you don't know anything about Bayon Temple then all that you will see there are just pile of stones carved with faces. Do your own research before arriving in Siem Reap so you could appreciate the temples. I will not recommend any guide but all hotels and guest houses in Siem Reap could arrange that for you. This complex is mostly open air so it is best if you wear light clothes and bring an umbrella to protect you from the midday sun and the rain.This is also where you can ride on top of an elephant and have a tour around the surrounds of Bayon.

Amazing place. We visited a lot of the temples in Angkor Wat and Bayon is one of the more special ones - perhaps it's the lovely stone faces. You really do need to see them up close. Wonderful experience.

The best temple at the Angkor archaeological park. This is definitely worth a long visit while at Angkor. It's definitely one of the more crowded temples, but there is a reason for it. Bayon forms one part of the much larger Angkor Thom, which was really the highlight of the Angkor park.

This is a temple that you can't escape. Beautiful setting temple within a big city walls. These ruins are all that all that they are said to be - mysterious, intricate, and impressive. A guide is a necessity if you want to learn more about the area and to guide you through the maze of walkways.

Second favorite on main circuit. I really like this temple. It's has a nice ruin feeling to it without being swallowed by the jungle. It's hard to photograph because there is not a whole lot of contrast in all the stone. Make sure you go to the Buddhist shrine in the middle. It is only lit up with candles and there is a small hole in the top of the spire. There are also bats fluttering around in it!
Great temple . Along with Ankor Wat the most impressive temple of Ankor. The massive faces on this temple makes it very different from Ankor Wat.

A wonderful experience. Another masterpiece of the smiling faces of Buddha. The faces give this particular temple a very memorable character. Some of the stairs are a little steep so be careful. Wonderful experience.
The Many face Gods. All I could think of while visiting this temple was all the faces and the many face gods in Game of Thrones. We saw a monkey trying to steal the donation box and it was hilarious.
Smiling Faces Temple. Yes...like the title, we can find all smiling face statue. If you find a good spot, you can shoot a photo nose to nose with the smiling statue.

My favourite. We actual spent more time here than we did at Angor Wat.This is a spectacular temple across a large area.We went to this temple first and this allowed us to avoid the crowds. It made for some excellent photos.I would certainly recommend a guide for this temple.

Inspiring. This was the second temple we visited during our Angkor Wat tour. The temple is beautiful and inspiring. Everywhere you look, there is a new face on the walls that you didn't see before. Definitely give yourself at least an hour to explore. There are so many hidden passages and special spots that will give you phenomenal views. I definitely recommend wearing tennis shoes here. Its much easier to make it up and down the narrow, uneven steps.

Transition from Hinduism to Buddhism. This site is interesting since it provides an insight into how people made the transition from Hinduism to Buddhism. The massive reclining Buddha statue must have looked so impressive when it was built.
Ancient. This Temple was interesting and I got lost a couple of times but it had plenty going for it , enjoyed the tour.
The most beautiful temple in Angkor Site. No words to describe how beautiful is this place. Take your time to enjoy all the faces around you. Definitely, a must-go place.

Great day at the temples. The Bayon Temple was super amazing, learning about the history of the temple was awesome. Getting an early start to see the temples helped to beat the crowds and the heat - enjoy

Must see. Really beautiful. A lot to see, I suggest you organise a knowledgable guide in your language who will explain all the segnificance of each structure or you will not understand the meaning and the real history of this forgoton Culture. Very prett place. I can only immagine how beautiful it would have looked in its glory days.This is a must see site.
Serene faces. This temple is all about reliefs and faces that are smiling. Walk through the temple and enjoy the serenity. Get creative with photography by clicking pictures with faces....

Absolutely Amazing. Just had the most amazing of days exploring some of the fantastic temples but the Bayon Temple with all the different faces was superb. Worth clambering around the ruins to get some really good photo opportunities.
Temple of the faces. Bayon is a definite must see! The massive stone faces are spectacular and sets it apart from a lot of the other temples. Make sure to get your "Bayon Kiss photo"
Most beautiful in Siem Reap. Amazing temple: a little ruined, but still beautiful sculptures, walls, details on the walls. Must see!

Smile of Angkor!. Amazing historical site. Temple towers are sculptured with King Jayavarman's captivating face on four sides. The smile and the charm on the face, in spite of the corrosion and disfigurement are meditative. A must see!

Iconic Temple. Soaring heat but worth taking time to wander around Bayon Temple. Felt quite surreal with the sounds from nearby monks chanting. The multiple faces of this temple complex are instantly recognisable to most travellers and are definitely one of my highlights of my short trip to Cambodia.

Cant get more picturesque than this. its like the mount Rushmore of Cambodia, every where you look you have the face of the king staring down at you. The temple site is well preserved and while you keep marvelling at how they would have built this place up a 1000 years back the photo ops are superb and abundant for a tourist

The best in Siem Reap. This was my favorite temple in the complex. It was so intricate and beautiful. It was extremely hot and there are several things to look at in the area, so get there as early as possible. I'm going back to spend sunrise here on Friday!

Beautiful. Near a small pond, with lotus growing , lies this temple that is much much smaller than its mammoth counterpart-Angkor Wat but as pretty with Buddha statues facing in 3 directions. Again, maintenance is poor and it smells of pigeon poop but for the short visit that you make, you can ignore that and soak in the serenity and the calm of this place. Its a must visit if you have come to see the Angkor Wat.

Peaceful bliss in early morning. My favorite place to visit of all the Angkors, and a small part of Angkor Thom. Especially peaceful in the early morning or in the rain, with the smiling faces aging well.

amazing and a must. awesome experience. the ruins of this temple are an incredible experience that must be enjoyed when in Siem Reap. We were lucku enough to have our own private guide but it is quite possible to do it on your own also.
Quite impressive!!!. There are a lot of temples to see in and around Angkor. Of which, this should be in the must-see list. The architecture is really impressive- huge stone faces!!

Fantastic. I feel to rate this experience better than Angkor Wat. The history, built after Angkor Wat, is amazing being Buddhist and not Hindu, has a different history. We hired a guide which was invaluable as he was able to put meaning to the carvings and the pagodas. Another must see when in Siem Reap.

Bayon is great. I found Bayon to be the most impressive, more so than Angor Wat. It has some really beautiful statues, temples and areas and simply feels less touristy in its setup for visitors. Recommended
Which one was this?. There's so many temples here I'm starting to lose track! This one was very nifty with its multiple faces and stuff..... Get down and have a look see people!!
Magnificent . A must I rate it better than angkor take some extra time .please read up on history to appreciate better
Very interesting temple. This temple was very interesting and large- took a couple of hours to see. One of our favorites in the area!
Ancient treasure in the jungle. Great ancient treasures being revealed to the world. Unfortunately it was raining when I was there that I could not visit much and take pictures.
Amazing. Another great choice and a must see while in Siem Reap. Intricate and unique carvings make it well worth your time.

Majestic and awe inspiring. . It was an honour to be able to see the Bayon. After seeing so many photographs we were worried they would make seeing the Bayon underwhelming, the reality was still stunning. Much harder to traverse than other temples, it's well worth the physical effort. Not great for the little one who spent most of the time in the sling.

Definitely one of our favorite temples around Siem Reap. Interesting temple with intricate carvings. It was raining the day we went to this temple but even that couldn't dampen our enthusiasm to explore this wonderful site. The walls and gates around it are also very beautiful.
better than Angkor Wat. this temple was amazing just loved the architecture and all of the faces on every pillar cant miss this one

Excellent temple. I preferred the Bayon Temple over Angkor Wat, but to be honest they're all great.
Get there early.....
Fantastic!. Great first visit. It was panoramic and majestic. It was surreal to see an age-old temple survive until now.
Even better the Angkor Wat. This temple was even cooler than Angkor Wat in my opinion and a lot less crowded. Don't miss it when you're in Siem Reap!

Epic end day. After did the big tour of the Angkor temple, we arrive at Bayon, and oh my! What a surprise ! The temple is huge, kind of a maze, very beautiful and close to another big one that I don't remember the name.
Anyway, a beautiful temple, for sure.
Great temple. This is again a great temple and easy to fit them all in with just one day. Temples cost $20 and best to just get a tuk tuk for $16 to take you to all of them.

One of my favourite temples. I enjoyed this temple for the lesser of the crowd and I believe it has more to offer on the eye. I found walking around it enjoyable and spent a little more time here than previous temples. You can get a great picture from the centre column looking at the three heads.
Interesting.... . Truly amazing. A bit of climb and no real shelter. Went immediately after lunch so was scorching. So avoid mid day for this.

Stunning status and architecture. Serenity, beauty, optimism are all conveyed in this temple. Here you will see many Buddha heads with smiling faces. Personally found this more impressive than angkor wat.

Magnificent!. Loved the Bayon Temple...to me it was up there with Angkar Wat.
Those faces - truly amazing, what a structure.
Only disappointment was the crowd.
Another great temple. Wonderful to see the carvings all over. It gives you a sense of peace and tranquility. So peaceful and so much work still to restore.

Sense of being watched all the time!. The Bayon temple is in the centre of Angkor Tom, the new city. Start your visit to Angkor Tom by visiting the Bayon Temple. The architecture is one of its kind with stacked stone carved to depict the face of the Buddha and the uncanny resemblance to the King. The highest level of the temple brings you to these head which are constantly staring at you! You will feel watched the entire time.A must visit when you are at Angkor Tom
Her majesty. Most expansive set of temples in the region and worth every moment of exhaustion& thirst. Come with plenty of water, you'll need it
Amazing!. Such a beautiful temple! The faces are fantastic. Also saw a monkey and a cat hanging out together!!

Breathtakingly beautiful. The bayon is absolutely beautiful. The carvings and the way the faces depict different smiles is something that you can appreciate only if you see it for real. Its the most beautiful temple of Cambodia that I liked and will be very special to me

My favourite of all the temples. I remember my first backpacking trip, trying to tick off as many sites on our list in as fast a time possible. That was over 20 years ago and I've moved to the quality not quantity school of thought. We were there in May, travelling as a group of 3 adults and a 4 year-old. We rented a car one day which did a tour of 5 temples (I think). My 4 year-old was at the "not another temple" stage but the 2nd one, but he still enjoyed this one. I was a bit like him as the heat was relentless and draining. If I had to choose one temple to go to, this would be it. The multidimensional temples, the 360 view, everything about it made this my favourite site of them all.

Our favorite temple. This is me and my friend's favorite temple. It has intricate carvings of faces and has a lot of nooks and dark corridors. It is smaller than Angkor Wat so it's less tiring. Bring a lot of water and towels because it is very hot in Cambodia during midday.
Best place for sunrise. Went here for sunrise. There were 2 or 3 other people. The bats make seclusion make the experience more exciting. Very peaceful sunrise without the million other tourists.

Faces with different experience. One wonders if the king who built this temple was like a selfie obsessed guy who wants more and more of his faces to be carved and placed on each dome of the temple. It was not clear whether the face depicted Buddha or the king!Mystic feel to the place..must visit. It is a small temple so is easier to walk and see around. One can sit and relax for some time to let the place soak you.
Amazing temple that will keep you guessing.. This temple was our favorite in the Angkor Wat complex, a must see for everyone visiting Angkor Wat.

A place that is extremely impressive!. The scale of the temple is incredible. Great reliefs exist on the lower levels and the big towers show brilliant faces. Photographers dream... and I'm not a photographer.
A Trip Back in Time. This is a great place to take photos and to explore one of the great ancient ruin of Angkor. Wear comfortable shoes as the visit will require a lot of walking to see all of it.

Fascinating temple with the most magnificent carvings. My favourite from the moment you see the front gate and the large stone heads looking down on you. I am not sure if without the guide we would have enjoyed as much. A real highlight of our visit with its many beautiful and mysterious faces.

Pat of Angkor Wat visit. We visited the Bayon Temple as part of our day pass to the Angkor Wat site. Another beautiful temple. It can be a little annoying when you are trying to walk around and are continually stopped by the 'selfie' takers!! And the thoughtless who sit themselves down and block an other wise 'perfect' photo opportunity but on the whole it was not as crowded as I expected and the climb up to the top and walk around offered great views and was well worth it. The stairs are incredibly steep.. So not for the faint hearted!
Bayon temple.. Excellent work of carvings. A must visit in Siem reap.Need to be prepared to walk for hours to enjoy the scenery.

Bayon temple. Part of Angkor Thom - the most interesting of the Angkor Wat temples - definitely worth a visit. Possibly the most photogenic. Of course the famous tree in the Indiana Jones movie has to be seen in Ta Phrom - which is a few kilometers from Angkor Thom - all of the trees there compete with the temples for splendour.
Worth a visit . Bayone temple is just as beautiful as angkor wat. You could spend hours walking around it. ( if you can stand the heat)

Amazing Temple within Angkor Thom. Angkor Thom is a city/temple complex with many great sites, but Bayon is by far the best one. It has a mix of old unrestored Angkor temple feel, some colonial French restoration, and the more modern subtle stuff. When you climb up to the top level though, you are surrounded by the giant smiling Buddha faces. It's an incredible site and different from all the other temples in Siem Reap. Don't forget to visit the ancient Buddha statue at the top!

Great site to start the temple tour. We spent about 2 hours at this temple. Some parts of this temple is very well preserved. the entry gates are spectacular. We had an excellent guide in Pin Vannak, who gave us a good run down about this temple.
Coolest tempel in the Angkor Wat park. It not really the size of this temple that makes a amazing, but all the faces an the design of it. Dont miss this temple!
Favorite Temple. This was our favourite temple. The faces and dark stone contrasted by the gorgeous yellow butterflies was incredible.
Loved the buddah faces!. Couldn't believe the architecture. Can't imagine how they were able to produce such amazing places with ancient tools.
Stunning!. Bayon Temple was one of my favorite temples I have visited over the years. There are so many beautiful carvings, it is just wonderful to view. A great spot for photography!!
Bayon Temple . Really cool temple. It was my favorite out of the major three temples. Remember to wear proper dress to cover yourselves but it does get very hot.
Amazing. It is hard to describe it because it is absolutely amazing. . Don´t forget to wear long skirts or you cannot enter the temple.
Maganda at masaya. Pictorials are worthwhile here. Don't go without water the walking distance is longer than other temples. Bring umbrella and dress nice and decent please.

Amazing Architechure. What a lovely place right in the heart of Angkor Thom the old capital of Cambodia. A hidden treasure amongst the lovely lush green jungle. Really lovely figurines - mesmerized by how they were all carved and built in the old times. Easy access with Tuk Tuk or car. Spend an hour half will be good, not many steps.

Amazing. What a amazing place it blows your mind to think how they built these places.
A must visit while your in Siem Reap.

Faces on Stone . This was our 2nd temple. I loved the atmosphere and the temple. It was probably the only temple we visited that was crowded so if you're going during busy season then good luck. We were here during a slow time. But the carvings and faces are impressive and this is a great one to see.
Fascinating site to visit!. It's amazing with so much history. The ancient Angkor city is so interesting. I would be back to visit with my family.
spellbinding sight!. The Bayon has many stories to tell. Entering the Bayon you feel welcomed and protected by these smiling faces looking down at you. Amazed and dazzled by its beauty.
Peace of history . Interesting temple. All those faces looking at you. Enjoyed coming here. Missed out on the elephants. This place is much more crowded as a lot smaller than angkor wat

The Kissing Eskimo. One of the best temples to visit while in Siem Reap. While traveling towards the temple, stay on alert for monkeys playing with each other. The temple itself is interesting. There's a 'mural' depicting various stories. There are several windows to take pictures as though you're looking out on a cool summer evening. And, the wonderful heads that you can get creative white taking pictures, such as the Eskimo kiss.
Hard to believe, beautiful to see. Incredible site. The carvings that still exist, views everywhere. This ancient place is amazing to behold.

Our favourite for our first day. Our favorite! Had an early start at 7am starting at Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm. Bayon was after lunch with a drive around the temple before going in. Not crowded maybe due to the heat.

amazing temple but very crowded :(. I expected the crowds of tourists but it was a bit disappointing seeing the beautiful temple overrun with people. Never the less this was an absolutely amazing site. The area surrounding the temple is scattered with monkeys (very cute but keep your distance!).This was one of my favourite sites in Siem Reap. The architecture was just mind blowing, a bunch of blocks stacked up precariously to the sky have survived all this time. It really is an amazing place, I just wish I could've seen it when it wasn't so busy!

Bayon...must visit!. the bayon was the last temple we visited in the day but considering the ruins in which the other temples were...this was one of the better temples in Angkor wat. partly the reason being this was a Buddhist temple unlike the other Hindu temples...The 900 year old's beauty has been ravaged by nature with the archetype 4 headed face broken/covered in moss. it is incredible that they transported/cut/arranged the faces in such symmetry.
Epic. Epic Scenery! Not too much in this world compare. History right in front of you. Your pictures will never be able to capture the true unbelievable mystic of this place. Amazing, just amazing.
Smiling faces that make you smile...... The Bayon Temple is ancient history at its finest. The Lotus shaped smiling faces are simply stunning.
My favourite temple. Best to go right at the beginning of the day before the tour groups start arriving. Lots of great photo op spots and stories carved into the walls.

Keep an eye on your kids. . This place is like taking a walk through a fevered mind. Imagine multiple levels of wending labyrinthine stone passages, rooms and nooks, stacked in a seemingly (but not at all) random fashion and decked out with carvings and hundreds of insanely serene faces. Even with the place loaded with tourists you can get some great photos and find lesser visited areas.As it turned out I had the opportunity to pass through and explore each and every room and facet of Bayon. Our capable, adventurous ten year old daughter wandered off, quickly becoming disoriented and lost - without water, around noon on a 38 degree day. It took me two hours of searching to find her. Many important lessons learned there and some dark thoughts thankfully dispelled. The limited staff on-site were very helpful and patient.This is another temple I'd suggest visiting with a guide as it is one thing to take it on face value but would be far more rewarding with the accompanying stories and histories.
Smile Teomple. Great smiles and friendly temple. The temple gives very great befinfit you me as I visited. I feel historic spirit with good smiel!

3 days not enough !!!. If going to see Angkor Wat, allow yourself as much time as you can afford. After all you've traveled all this way.We visited in june, to avoid the crowds, but got the heat!There's not really a bad time to visit I hear. Hire a guide! If you think you can do it solo, think again! You'll need background info to fully understand everything about this amazing place.

A Must See Visit. Bayon Temple was our last temple visit after a long day and well worth the stop. The faces carved in the stone evoke such emotion and serenity. The magnificence of this man made temple is evident every where you look as you walk through.

Absolutely amazing and our absolute favorite in Angkor. The faces carved in this temple are fascinating, to think that this was built centuries ago is quite a feat. This is one of those things that needs to be seen with your own eyes.
Must See. Part of Angkor World Heritage. Unlike many other temples, this one is Buddhism. Amazed by all the scriptures of Buddha faces, especially that it was built so many years ago.
Great Experience. Definitely I will come back to Siem Reap to visit again and this time... I will take the 3 day pass.
Awesome. Pouring with rain while walking around, it actually added to the beauty of the monument. Very surreal, and probably one my favourite of the temples.
Temple. It was worth the time to see one more temple it's so old & a lot of history beautiful carvings that have remained in good condition
By far my favourite temple in the area!. Bayon was my favourite temple in the area, with less tourists and fantastic architecture. The temple is surrounded by faces which is awesome for photos.
More photogenic than Angkor Wat. Bayon was very enjoyable to walk through, explore and take photos of all the faces. Also very grand and worth committing the time to.

Bayon Temple is great. I like baton temple very much because it looks like mountain in the jungle. It is bigger than other temple and what I like the most is the towers with Avaloketesvarak smiling face.

Smiling Buddhas!. Terrific experience.. The Buddhas and so many of them and how they were carved out and when is truly mind boggling. A different flavour from Angkor Wat. Loved being here.. Not to be missed..

More Interesting that Angkor Wat. We found this temple also simply stunning. More interesting that Angkor Wat due to the many faces which are carved into the stone - and with little explanation as to why. An interesting look around and an essential stop as part of the Siem Reap temple tour.
Beautiful relics of history. Bayon temple built in 12-13 century showcase the most beautiful stone faced sculptures, blending two great religions Hinduism & Buddhism.
ancient ruins. spent a lovely hot day here ..a must see attraction .it does get bust but is worth while take water with u and a good pair of walking shoes

Another piece of amazing architecture. In its semi ruined state, it is very evocative and mysterious. In some ways, more impressive than Angkor Wat. The amount of restoration gone into this project is amazing .
Love the History + Architecture. Make sure the guide explains the history behind the faces of each Buddha pillar. Definitely a must visit!
Best Temple!. This was our favorite spot in Siem Reap. The towers of faces are just really cool and well preserved. It's a great spot for perspective pictures too!

Smaller temple, but awe-inspiring! . I loved this temple, the architecture of the Bayon heads is simply amazing.
It was pouring down with rain when we visited in May which was a real shame.
As we only had time for a one day temple pass, we chose to walk through the temple in the rain - still worth it!!

awesome. Really beautiful and good to see active restoration happening, a must go to, great for children, if you have a tall child remember to take their passport, we were questioned at least 6 times about our ten year Olds age.
Stunning. If you only have time to visit a few temples, make sure you include this one. There are a few others worth seeing nearby as well, so it's a good location for those with limited time.
Awesome. My favorite temple. Sunset time was best with long shadows. So cool. I liked it more than Angkor wat. A bit crowded but you can deal with it.

Very impressive temple. You must visit this very impressive temple. Is close to Angkor Wat, and although Angkor Wat is one of the new worldwonders, the Bayon Temple is more than worth a visit with its several Boeddha faces. Only frustration was the Chinese tourists running in front of your camera all the time.

Just wow!!!. Great view! I enjoyed walking around as it is not as big as angkor wat. I am really amazed on how it was built years ago and be able to preserve it so that the new generation can still see how rich Khmer culture is.
Unreal. This temple is amazing! Definitely hire a tour guide so you can get the most out of the experience and really appreciate what you've come so far to see.

Beautiful. This temple was less crowded than Angkor Wat, and we loved walking around to see the faces and other carvings. We spent a good hour in here, and we would go back in a heartbeat! Wear your hiking shoes, though!

My favorite of all the Angkor temples. This visit begins with the beautiful bridge and gate entrance, with the carved demons and saints lying opposite sides. Take your time and avoid the crowds to appreciate all they intricate carvings. The complex is amazing, and the corridors are long and impressive, with the doorways getting smaller as one approaches the center. This temple can be navigated in an hour.
Brilliant . Fascinating and worth the time to explore. Be sure to stop and take it all in. A camera will give you a record but it is not the same as just sitting, looking and reflecting.
Amazing. You really have to visit all the temples in Cambodia. You have to take the whole tour after seing Angkor Wat and then visit the rest. Absolutely amazing.
Well worth visiting. This temple should be included in your visit, amazing to see, easily included in the 'small circuit' visit of the temples.
A must to see. An amazing construction given the detail and engineering feat in a time before technology was as sophisticated as today..

Lovely. As are all the sites in the park they are wonderful and awe inspiring. I think Bayon is the most spectacular with all the faces staring at you from all directions. It is a must see temple in Angkor Wat

Just incredable. The place is in my opinion breath-taking. How did they build this all those years ago? Some of the detail would be difficult to achieve now with all of our technology so must be seen to be appreciated.
Epic. This temple is unlike any of the other temples we saw in Siem Reap. It has 50+ towers, almost all with faces on them. It is incredibly impressive and a must see!
the most interesting temple IMO. The rich history of this place made me glued to it. Or maybe it was our Tour Gide's way of telling it. Nevertheless, this is one temple you shouldn't miss.

So much to see. I was expecting a temple with only a few carvings of faces. There are so many you dont know where to look. A lot of what is there is only a fraction of what was carved into the stone but it gives you an idea of how much time and effort it took to make these temples.If you go take a good pair of shoes as the stones can be slippery when it rains and depending on the amount of rain there can be large pools of water.Dont forget your water bottle.

This is my favorite site. There is so much history to take in. Standing on the steps I can feel what a king are from a warrior background. This part of Cambodia is steeped in history and spirituality. I love Cambodia and the people.
