amazing place, but there are lots of temples there to see that are all just as good. baon is one of the more famous sites in ankor what and it quite imposing, i did like it, but probably preferred some of the smaller less visited temples for a bit more differentiation
Impressive and magical. What an amazing place. Way more quiet and magical then the Angkor Watt this temple has surprised around every corner.
Wow. All the templates are amazing. It is hard to chose one over the other. The beauty of nature, the artwork and the butterflies is an overwhelming

Another beautiful memory. Take back all of those many faces with you, captured in photos or in your memory.... take beautiful pictures, one's you could post of Facebook and earn those lovely comments!!

Magnificient temple in complete ruins. You can make out what an incredible temple this must have been few hundred years ago. Temple is in complete ruins. Still a close observation of stone carvings can talk a lot about history and civilisation

My favorite. This is my favorite of all the temples: 50+ towers with 4 faces each; beautiful design. Came back to see it a few times; my kids felt like Indiana Jones exploring an ancient temple. We did sneak in some history lessons too, while they were open to it.Hope you'll read a little or use a guide; there is so much more to experience here than just a few photos.

Another Big Temple Complex Not as many Tourists as Angkor Wat. This is also a big temple complex, you need 1-2 hrs minimum to see it, it is also several storied, & you end up climbing a lot of stairs some of which are quite steep. Bring umbrella as you will be walking a lot & plenty of water as no water available inside the temple.

Amazing. Absolutely mind blowing in someway better than Angkor Wat, everywhere you walk the photos appear to be brilliant. The art work throughout the ruins is extraordinary. Weaving through the ruins spectacular faces appear. Such a photographic and magnificent place to visit.

You'll want to know more!. After seeing the magnificence of the Bayon temple, you will definitely want to know more about it.. so another visit after reading about it will definitely give you a deeper perspective :-)
Another amazing temple. Amazing place. Each temple is different with its own story. So spiritual. Cant say enough about this incredible place.
4 Faces temples !. Bayon is the second temples that i see in my trip. their 4 face with nice smile.and totally of the face is 54. you could know about it.
Huge temple. Interesting and huge temple, you can get lost wandering the many sections, unfortunately had a torrential downpour right in the middle of this visit.

When walking through Bayon it's like a maze. Beautiful Temple, intricate carvings, and elephants. The faces from stones are marvelous, the level of detail of the carvings in the stone walls and on the pillars are truly impressive.
While you're at Angkor, swing over to Bayon. Part of Angkor Thom, Bayon is bit more crumbling and not as ornate, but in its own way, as beautiful and breathtaking as Angkor Wat.

Amazing. As with Ankor Wat and Ankor Thom this is an amazingly impressive site and one I would once again recommend. My review is simular to the previously mentioned. the Statues and amazing architecture is mind blowing.

Amazing. Our visit to Bayon was the day after exploring Angkor Wat. We got there early becsuse my friend wanted to take an elephant ride (which was ok but not my thing). The Bayon ruins are a amazing, we hired a guide for the entire day ($40 USD) and he have us a great explanation of the archeological sites including this one. There are opportunities for incredible pictures and just exploring around the ruins is a unique experience.
Love the Faces. This is one of my favourites when we visited - I couldn't stop taking photos of all the faces. Can't imagine when these were built, all by hand.

One of many special temples. We first went to temples without guide just map and books but I think a guide is better and the second day used one and was very happy with the quality of knowledge and command of English

Angkor Wat + Bayon Temple = Total Angkor Archaeological Park Experience. Though it is a great fulfillment to explore all of it. Yes! It is really true that if to choose the easiest way to experience the Angkor Archaeological Park the Formula is Angkor Wat + Bayon Temple = Total Angkor Archaeological Park Experience Bayon is the temple with many faces located inside the Angkor Thom. Exploring the area is quite shorter compared to the other temples. Tourists and Travelers are permitted to go upstairs and get closer to the Bayon Stone-Made Faces (Nose to Nose Picture is optional).
Temple visits. Aweinspiring. History in abundance without being boring. A place to spend hours. This place would be open to all ages, families and couples.
Culture Reveal. Very very nice. I don't take good photos but it is a delight just to see this temple. If you see a postcard it looks exactly like that. Be prepared to climb though.

Better than Ankor Wat.. This temple is smaller than Ankor Wat but I personally think it is much better and is totally amazing to visit. The walk in is much shorter and it does not take as long to walk around but it is more spectacular than Ankor.
Another great tample. Like all temples from this complex Bayon is amazing mystery. Visiting Angkor is a long day so make sure you have comfortable shoes, clothes, plenty of water and camera.
incredible. Humans do things like large stones carved into the shape the story.There are many stories to be studied
Nice big 4 face . Bayon very nice had 4 face was stay in side angkor thom ancient city .nearly temple have elephant ricing it good and fun but pay 20 usd /person around bayon temple .

Bayon struck me as the most beautiful among all temples. Bayon is my favorite amongst the temples I visited, a spectacular temple with stunning carved faces that are everywhere you look. The beauty of the many faces will never get old, smiling their mysterious,sensuous smiles from every direction...

Looking At Beauty. The faces in the temple are so serene and happy it is really a joy to see. The building is fantastic and the photo shoots nose to nose with the Buddha are not to be missed.A lovely temple well worth visiting

If you're going to Angkor Wat, you might as well come here too. Right next door to Angkor Wat, this is another significant temple in its own right. Angkor Thom has the famous "faces" all over the temple, and has a history all in itself. Hire a guide and car to take you to both Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, and Ta Prom.

Amazing Vivid and Serene Stone Sculptures. Bayon Temple is definitely one of my favorite temples in Angkor Wat. This is a good place to come early! When all others have gone to admire the sunrise in Angkor Wat, Bayon will be quite empty. Pay attention to your footing as there are some loose rocks around, but it still quite child friendly place to visit.

Top 3 temple in Siem Reap. Best known for its smiling Buddhas atop about 40 spires (4 on each spire facing all directions), is a sight to take in..no words can describe the beauty. Visited this place in May when it was pouring, and was completely spell bound by the grace and beauty of this temple. The outer wall has amazing stone carvings depicting the daily life of the peoples of that time, and the grandeur of the king's court. A must visit. My guide also gave a brilliant idea of taking a picture of the temple as a reflection in a water body- stunning, unforgettable!
Bayon temple at Angkor Wat. It is an absolute must to visit the Bayon temple. This ancient Khmer temple is very authentic and almost completely untouched. Very impressive.
its in a very bad shape. restoration work is in progress but still worth a visit, you can also take an elephant ride around it.

Beautiful Bayon!. Loved Bayon temple! Simply beautiful! Catch it during sunset, and it's even more impressive! The different faces of the temple really stood the test of time, and most parts are still intact.
Buddha everywhere. This is a unique temple with the face carvings on the domes. Must see attraction. very different from all the other temples in the area

A lot of tourists, and be mindful of signs!. They seemed to be doing some reconstruction or preservation when we were there, so be mindful of the signs to determine which areas are safe to enter and which aren't. It's like a maze inside, so you might get a bit lost, but signs would tell you the "way of visit" so you'd be able to find an exit eventually. Go upstairs. That's where the best parts are :)
A must visit in Siem Reap!. A must visit in Siem Reap Angkor Wat tour. One of a kind temple. Best time to go is in the late afternoon.
Is someone looking at you. The face sculptures were amazing.. I believe there was 162 faces in total through out the place.. Allow about 1 hour to see this.

Stone Faces. There are so many things to explore in Siem Reap but for us, Bayon is impossible to miss. I have hundreds of photos at this site, especially for the stone faces overlooking the jungle.Again, our guide did a good job to show us the meaning of the carved stone painting.
My favorite!. Of all the temple in this area, this is by far my favorite. Angkor Wat is so impressive, but the smiling faces here are delightful!

I loved this!!. A photographers dream location. You can get some truly amazing photos of the giant stone faces carved into the amazing tower structures. Because there are 4 faces carved into most of the towers, each facing one of the cardinal points, you can get a photo with a profile view of one face and a front on view of another face in the same shot.

Visit at sunset recommended. Very busy during the day but not so at sunset. If you buy a ticket at 5pm for one day only. You get to see the sunset in the evening and then you get the whole next day free. Take time to wander to areas where there are no crowds, silence is golden, you feel the peace and serenity, loved it

Close to Angkor and is amazing. If you are going to Angkor Wat, go in the morning the head here. The temple is in an ancient city that housed a million in the height. Temple is quieter than Angkor. They have some elephant rides for 20$. Dont know if it is worth it.

Temple of faces . This was my favorite of all the temples we saw. We got there at about 7am and it was totally empty. There are faces everywhere and the morning light made this totally breathtaking. A must see!

Beautifully carved temple. This temple was the second stop on my day trip around the Angkor complex and I found the carvings a tad more interesting than Angkor Wat. I spent almost the same amount of time here than at AW, though it's much smaller. Only problem was that it was really busy. I must have arrived at the same time as Chinese tour groups and it became difficult to navigate the narrow corridors and get around the ruins, not to mention it was impossible to take a photo without one of these tourists in it :)
17/6/16. Nice place but Cambodia is very hot. 36deg cWe hire a taxi driver for 3 days US$105. Took us on the grand circuit Plus dinner aamd floating market and Beng Melea. Plus took us to airport

See my comments on Angkor Wat. See my comments on Angkor Wat. If you intend to visit many or most of the temples within the Angkor Archaeological Park (and there are many), have a plan, spread your visit over two or three days or more if you are able, a local driver/guide can help with this.

Dazzling Reflecting Pools In Rainy Season!!!. Spectacular! Get your tuktuk driver to pull under the shade on the north side, where you can capture the reflection of the entire tower in moats of water during rainy season! Out of this world!!!

Wow! Must see. Our stop after AW...and so much to see! Loved all the face carvings...really magical! A must see! As we only had one day i am really blad we chose to see it! Wasnt crowded and we got lots of photo ops!

Stunning Temple, with a surprise around every corner. The Bayon was for me the creme de la creme of the restored Angkor temples. The temple awed from every angle and was really interesting to wander through. Make sure you circle round the perimeter as some of my best photos were taken by squeezing into the corners of the inner walls.
Engineering spectacular. I always wonder just how these temples were constructed and how they are still standing with al the humidity and tourists all over them.

MUST SEE. We took a tour with HAT tours (which we loved) and this was our final stop. We were blown away. Unlike anything I've seen and I would highly recommend it to anyone and everyone! The 4-faced Buddhas and kings are amazing. I'd recommend going with a guide (or good book) because the history really adds to the experience

Angkor Thom - The Many Faces: Sympathy, Compassion, Charity, Equaminity. This temple is my favorite of all of the temples in Siem Reap. This temple has the many faces of the Buddha engraved in all of the stones up above.To achieve zen, inner peace, love for one another, and self love, we must try to achieve all four facets of the faces represented on these stones.Sit in a meditative position and think about all of the things for which we are thankful.Tip: Take lots of water. Wear a hat. Wear sunscreen. It is very hot.Tip 2: Take a tuk-tuk tour. The distance between the temples is expansive. (we considered doing the tour on rented bicycles for our family of 5. We were glad that we hired a tuk-tuk for the day instead. The heat from the sun is quite unbearable.)

Another gem. Of course not as popular as Angkor Wat but the beauty matches it. Less crowded than the other main temples a few large steps so be careful walking around some of the faces still have so much detail over these hundreds of years it's so amazing.

Nice architecture, but the smell... It is worth going for thr architecture, but the smell of outhouse makes it unbearable for more than 10-20 minutes. Also, the crowds are huger here than Angkor Wat, for some reason.

Another not to be missed part of Angkor visit. All the temples are amazing and Bayon is no exception in it's beauty and interesting history. We had a guide for the day of our tour and the explanations behind all the temples is great in understanding the history.

A great place for photos!. This is the temple ruins that has a lot of faces. Not only that, but the details on the ruins is stunning & there is so many chances for great photography. Only thing that it being a ruin, some steps are hard to climb, steep & unsafe.
Mesmerising place. Amazing place to visit, go early morning to avoid to many others on your photos and to miss the intense humidity in the middle of the day.

to scam or not 2 scam. a great place. we had a fantastic day. but watch your pockets, and also the speach. as the locals etc. inc the young will pick up on your accent. but otherwise a fantastic day. if very hot please make shure of a hat and sun cream. yes gents. even you. we where sun burnt very quickly.

Less Crowded and more peaceful than Angkor Wat. I have to admit that Bayon Temple, in my opinion, was much better than Angkor Wat. Angkor Wat is beautiful for pictures, especially at sunset, but overall loud, crowded, and less intricate once inside. THe Bayon Temple is entered through a beautiful archway/bridge on the roadway. The Bayon Temple itself has myriad (48) faces on the pagodas. There were originally around 52 or 54 and is therefore amazingly intact. This area was less popular than Siem Riep and it was easy to feel at peace and take a leisurely stroll around the area. At the top, you can take a photo with your nose seemingly touching the nose of the smiling faces or you can just appreciate the many carvings. You will see people dancing, which if you take enough pictures and combine them in a video will seem to actually dance before your eyes. You can also clearly see the depiction of the Khmer (cambodians) defeating their enemies, the Char (probably not spelling that correctly) and celebrating their victory.

Very impressive temple & stone etchings. We went here following our visit to Angkor Wat. The carvings on the bridge over the moat before you enter the temple are spectacular in their own right.Inside the temple layout in exactly north to south & eat to west. There are literally hundreds of huge stone faces with different expressions, including the smiling buddha.Again we had a tour guide with us and he gave us lots of information about the history of the temple and in particular the incredibly detailed wall carvings / etchings depicting the many battles which had taken place over the centuries, who had taken part, who had won etc.After we completed the 'formal' tour we wandered around ourselves, lots of photo opportunities here although many of the tour bus groups seemed intent on using the stone faces or windows as the backdrop or frame for selfies!I think a visit to Bayon Temple is a must - you need to see this in person to truly appreciate the spectacle, history & culture.
Happy Faces. Beautiful, happy faces. Walked through with a private guide. Well worth the money. More interesting to me than Angkor Wat. Built 100 years later.

Breathtaking, but crowded. This was perhaps the most fascinating temple of them all - countless serene stone faces looking to the distance is something you really have to see for yourself. It was like stepping into a movie or a game. Only thing making the experience not-so-magical was the enormous hordes of tourists that clearly all wanted to take a picture with a selfie-stick in front of the giant smiling face. In the upper terrace, you could not properly move or even see the carvings if you wouldn't line up to take a picture with someone in front of them. We visited around noon hoping that the heat would bring a little space to see the temple, but no. The temple is super-popular photo-op so I think it's crowded all the time.On the positive side, the perfect-selfie-hunting crowd usually goes along the path that goes straight through the temple and up to the upper terrace. If you take a side-road, you can have a little adventure inside the temple's inner and outer gallery. It's amazing, there's no-one on sight, you can hear the jungle, have a little Indiana Jones- moment - and still see the many faces of Lokeshvara from down below.
Not the main temple but a great one to visit exactly for that reason. Definitely need to do Angkor Wat, but the outlying temples are just as amazing and not nearly as crowded
Amazing carved faces. The faces carved in stone are really fascinating. There are many small places you can go to explore. This temple is a must see.

3rd favorite temple. This has got to be my third favorite temple. Take the time to travel off the beaten path and visit Preah Khan and Boeng Mealea. You'll feel like an explorer and get an insight into how things might have looked when nature and architecture were one.

Unique and complex face towers . About 37 face towers with about 2-4 faces on each point. It is both overwhelming and enchanting with its maze-like design. All around, if one will look at the walls, there were sculptured scenes, mostly of war and I saw some looked like images of daily life like woman taking care of a child, trading peddlers, monkeys in a tree. I had goose bumps all over but I'm so thankful I got to this place. Even just this Bayon tower within Angkor Thom City is enough reason to visit Siem Riep! A wonderful experience for anyone who is interested in culture and remnants of old civilization.
Great day ☺. Beautiful temple with many photo opportunities. We spent time there walking around with our guide Mr Sophanna explaining all of the history.

Khmer smile. Khmer smile is all around this magnificent temple. A good idea before exploring the many picturesque shooting spots in the heat is taking plenty of electrolyte fluid prior. Wonder if there is a better way to see elephant presence other than carrying tourist around.

Impressive, hot, unstable. This was our least favorite of the temples. It was impressive to see but if you have kids I'd skip it. It's also very unstable and your footing can be missed easily. We had our 3 yr old daughter, who did great at all of the other temples, but I wouldn't take her back.

I hope to see maintenance to this beautiful place. 10 years ago, i came to Bayon Temple. And there were sayings about maintaining the temple. It will be really sad to know that many millions of tourists visit Cambodia each year and there are no one protecting this old temple. I hope we all can do our part by preserving what was left during the Angkor period.

Another wat. Although the ways are very impressive, I felt this was very good . We were lucky enough to be helped by a gentleman who had lived at the Wat for years and he showed us sites that were not usually seen by visitors.

too many temples, you will feel tire. Let me tell, i spent 3days to circle Angkor wat and near by site with only 6 dollar and a 3 days ticket!! it's a vast area, Angkor wat is just one of the well known archaeology site. if you have time, take it slowly with bicycle, the rent was just 2dollar per day, with bicycle you will definitely see more than those with tour group. It's for reason that they sell 3 days pass ticket, because you really need that much time to visit all of the site. it's a must do trip in Siem Reap, and the different is how you do it. by the way there is a war museum during the way to Angkor Wat, shop by if you have time, see some real war stuff !!ps, well prepare when you ride bicycle, to get there you need to ride to the highway for about 45 minutes.

Make sure Bayon is on your temple list!. Bayon ranks an equal first to the much loved Angkor Wat on my list! The unique face carvings are incredible - I've never seen anything like that before. Best in the afternoon light.
Bayon Temple. A small piece of the Angkor Thom complex and undergoing a deal of restoration but well worth a visit
the largest temple in angkor wat. the largest temple in angkor wat. you will get lost in here because it has 4 different entrances.exits
Great. All temples if you do in one day begin to look the same..so spread it out over three days and discover at a good pace

Amazing structure . It great to see the contributions from other nations to restore and rebuilt the temples.Whilst there's still lots to do nevertheless you can still walk and see the marvel of the past.Worth the stroll and absorb the layouts and the structure. Simply amazing!
Mystical!!. This is Buddha in all it's splendor. Beautiful carvings and a really unique temple to see. Don't miss it when you visit Siem Reap!
must visit temple beside angkor wat. it was awesome and wonderful temple that can be found in siem reap. it not big like angkor wat. but the four face of bhuddha is so beautiful.
Best of Angkor. This was my favorite temple we visited in Angkor. We went directly after watching sunrise at Angkor Wat and exploring there. This was great way to beat most of the crowds to Bayon!

Wonder monuments to humankind. The Bayon Temple complex were built out of pure faith - and makes us not lose the faith in humanity. I would do the research online and skip the boring guides. Being from South India and quite familiar with the South Indian temple architecture, it was pretty shocking when the guides say that the inscriptions on the temples are Sanskrit or even Tamil.Few tips:1. If you are staying longer, get the 3day pass as you will want to go again2. It's hot - even in winter3. Tuk tuks charge $15 for the whole city tour and pretty reasonable4. Wear light proper clothing to the temples
Many Smiling Faces of Buddha. Just like Angkor Wat, there are a lot of bas relief you can find at the 1st terrace. Full of interest stories.
Fantastic. Really interesting amazing , really hot though so take plenty of water also lady's you need to cover up legs shoulders you will not be allowed to enter otherwise.

So many faces to photograph!. We loved this site. It's really not shady, but it's well worth an hour of your time if for nothing else....just to photograph. It's amazing to the workmanship that went into carving all the faces so high off the ground. Go see it!

A wonderful wonder of the world! Don't miss it. Having visited Cambodia as a change from going all the way to Europe I didn't really take too much time to research Siem Reap. The temples looked interesting and I had not been there before so hey why not! Wow, the temples of the Angkor Wat complex were breath taking and just remarkable as to how they were formed and the history associated with them is amazing. Sunset at Angkor Wat is definately something for the bucket list. It was very hot and tiring exploring the temples but such an amazing place in the world. We loved the smiley faces and entry gates to Bayon temple
Great to visit . There are many temples around this area.... but Bayon Temple You can not miss. Huge big Temple with the famous Buddha that smiles. Really have to see this one.
Beautiful faces. The temple has beautiful faces carved all over it. We visited on a stinking hot day but we walked at a gentle pace and took in the beauty on offer.

The best architecture construction in the Angkor Thom. This is is very beautiful complex in the jungle. For me was very curious to see a carving on the old sandstone, mythical figures, heads, sapsaras. I have made a wish in this temple, there is some special spirit and I`d like to return.
Pretty nice. Of course this temple is in the shadows of it's bigger brother but it's still worth the visit! Amazing how people ages ago built this.
Another beautiful temple. . Actually no review needed for this temple. Only need to say it's beautiful, and really worth an visit. Rent a tuc tuc and drive around within this amazing temple complex.

Great temple lots to see but is under a bit of renovation. Lovely temple under much needed renocation but still a great attraction to see, was included in our tour and our guide was amazing explaining all the meanings of the carvings in the sandstone. Helped we had been to National museum day before as well. Such amazing history
My favourite temple.. The temple is not too big and a lot of shades ..lol ... Great place for photographers and excellent stone carvings. I can easily spend 2 hours here with my camera.
Bayon Temple. As with Angkor Wat, it is a must see. This entire complex is a UNESCO protected world heritage site. There are many different temples and Bayon is one of the best to see.

My favorite temple in Siem Reap. This was my favorite temple. I loved the feel of the ruins here and history. So many great angles and hidden spots for fantastic pictures. There are 3 levels that you can walk up to so make sure you make your way up to the top. Also make sure to climb to the top of one of the outer temple sections to get a great view of the whole temple from a top down viewpoint.

Bayon is the most beautiful of all the temples I saw at the Angkor Site. Bayon has the most detail and was overall the most awe inspiring of all the temples I saw. There is an elephant riding concession there. They will give you a ride around the temple on and elephant and take your photo in front of one of the temples. It is an 8x12 professional photo, a wonderful keepsake of the experience here.

Come visit the Buddha. Be prepared to mesmerised by the sheer sight of this temple. It would be a never ending experience. Again avoid visiting during the lunch hours or peak time of the day. You need at least a good Hour to spend once on the main deck.

My favorite Temple out of all of them.. What a great experience. Walking around this temple and seeing all the details and the huge faces scarves in to the stones was something out of a movie set, except THIS was is the real deal. I couldn't stop taking pictures here, just amazing. Don't pass this one up, you'll be sorry.
Legends of Nara and Naari. Ask your guide to elaborate the legend of Nara Naari and the monks. A good story trail to follow. Writings on the walls.
My favorite temple. Awesome place! This is the one that we liked the most! Amazing pictures! Totally recommended. Try to go in the morning to avoid the sun and really hot weather!

A must see. This is part of the Angkor Thom city and is a lovely place to visit. It is regularly visited by monks so you need to wear clothes that cover your shoulders and knees otherwise you won't be allowed entrance. The faces are everywhere and are spectacular to see in real life, much better than the photos because you can't appreciate the scale or quality of the carvings. A must See!

Amazing Temple in Angkor Thom. The Bayon Temple is located in the old city of Angkor Thom, quite close to Angkor Wat. It is much smaller than Angkor Wat, and by comparison is much quicker to visit. Look out for the many carved smiling faces on the remains of the towers. There was restoration work going on when we were there, with several areas fenced off. It seemed somehow odd seeing a large modern mobile crane standing next to the temple. We went there in the afternoon, having visited Angkor Wat in the morning, however, it does get very hot in the afternoon, so make sure you take a bottle of water with you.
Beautiful! . Beautiful temple with the four-face Buddha statues to admire! You should not miss this temple if you visit Siem Reap!

Every visit sees a different tail. I have been coming to Cambodia since 2011 and the first time was an incredible experience with so much AWE and WOW seeing so many different temples and areas around Angkor.However on our recent visit we were quite shocked at the state of ruins and only in 5 years the amount of restricted access we had... i.e. most of the temple roofs had collapsed and were closed off to the public.I really hope and wish the officials at Bayon temple do more than publish they are reconstructing and maintaining Bayon Temple as all we can see is an attempt to keep tourists coming....the reconstruction efforts are pretty embarrassing and are noticed by most tourists of trying to replace ancient stone with modern concrete....come on your not only conning the tourists but yourselfs.RecommendationGo and visit Bayon Temple and take photos just in case you visit again like we have and compare the photos with previous visits. Give yourself a voice and inform the officials to do more and maintain such a wonder of the world.

bayon with thousand faces. angkor wat is the main site. there are other few temples in this area. bayon is famous for its faces, smiling faces:)nearby you can ride an elephant to explore the surrounding.

Great architechture and great time exploring. One of the best temples in the Angkor temple complex... you can get a one day pass for 20US that covers all the temple.. you need to have cash and they will take a picture.. most economical way is to take a tak tak.. but it is not far from the Siem reap town .. this temple is one of the best temples I have seen as this has atleast five layer and all the temple peak is covered with budha faces.. one of the least busy temples and you can see wild life on the way like monkey, deer ad elephants
Cycle it. We cycled the Angkor Wat compound and got five temples including this one in over the course of five hours. Cycle it. Worth the push in the heat.

Bayon. Absolutely loved this temple. Thought it had more to it to see compared to Angkor Wat. It was beautiful especially some parts of the temple which was covered in ageing tree branches. It was huge but very hot. We had to go around quickly with a little one. The only thought is that although it says at the back of the ticket you have to cover your shoulders and knees, we saw many in mini shorts in the temple. If you need to buy trousers, you could do so for cheaper at the temple entrance or market. Overall, worth the experience

It's like falling stacks of rock.. i. Visited this after Angkor Wat.ii. Fun fact, this is a Buddhist Wat while Angkor Wat was a Hinduism Wat.o Special.o Lots of Buddha faces. Great place to take photos of you kissing the Buddhas. ;)- A teenage boy 'volunteered' to take the Buddha-kissing photos for me. Be anticipating him asking you for money after all the 'service'.o It is very educating to see how people in the older days build their building. This one looks like they simply stack stones of different hardness gradually from bottom up. Therefore, you see alot of fallen stones.x Lots of people. x It is a let down compared to Angkor Wat. (But you're comparing Buddhist Wat and Hindu Wat built by two different kings. So, comparison not valid. =P )

A very cool temple with faces. I came here straight after watching the sunrise at Angkor Wat and managed to dodge the tourists before they came and also avoided the heat before the temperature slowly increased to unbearable. I spent an hour exploring Bayon and admiring the many faces on the temple. definitely a must visit when in Siem reap

Too much of a good thing. We really did enjoy going round Bayon Temple but by the time we did this one, having done so many other temples, we had had enough! We were all templed out!. Had we started with this one we would have thought how wonderful, so don't be put off! Enjoy them all, whatever order you decide to see them in!!

Transported to another time. There is something powerful about this temple. Labyrinthine passages in the lower levels, glimpsed views up towards towering structures. Once on the upper levels you are surrounded by the multi-faced Buddha structures that seem to look deep inside you.This temple, beyond all others, felt to us like we were in another world, rather than just looking round a ruin. It's a popular site, so expect a few more bodies, but done closer to lunch time it can be less packed and better for those picture perfect snaps.

Beautyfull carved sculptures. The Bayon temple is one of the most beautyfull spots of the archeological parc of Angkor Vat , you can spend one of more hours to visit it in detail .Try to go in the afternoon when the sun is not to fierce and when there are not so much visitors.
Less busy. A bit less busy than Angkor Wat but again a great visit. Go early to avoid less crowds and better cooler weather. Great from exploring
The best one. I don't understand why Angkor Wat is considered the main attraction, bayon is way more beautiful, ok is not as big but I didn't know anything about it and I was astonished by it
Mesmerizing. This is the word that comes to my mind when I re-collect the temple. A must -see in the checklist of temples to visit in the area.
Beautiful temple. Prasat Bayon is a temple to not be missed. At the center of Angkor Thom, well known for all Buddha faces

This temple has an outstanding history. Lots of four-face smiling with this temple. It is as amazing and marvelous as the main temple. We visited this very popular temple at the end of the day when the crowds has gone to enjoy it in peace and quite.

Enchanting faces of Bayon. This is probably the most amazing of all the temples with Avalokitesvara looking down upon you from every angle. It is a rather unique place even in Cambodia and is not to be missed on any visit there. These days you can even access inside much of the complex.

My favourite of the lot. I visted Bayon Temple with a private guide and driver on our morning tour of the temples. It was a very hot day and I recommend you go early. The temple was breathtaking from the moment you entered the old city to the moment we left. The carved smiling faces were enchanting and we enjoyed walking through and exploring the temple. Do yourself a favour and do not miss this one!!!

One of the best temples in Siem Reap. The carved smiling Buddha faces on each tower are unforgettable! A must see after angor wat. A word of caution-steps are steep and there are not always handrails.
Bayon Temple. Bayon Temple is my favourite out of the rest of the temple ruins. The site is beautiful. Do stand at the entrance of the temple and admire it. Simply breathtaking!
Temple of a hundred faces. This temple was by far my favorite of all that we visited. Very crowded but worth squeezing yourself through.

Highlight together with Angkor Wat. Take time to see earlier, lesser temples on the previous days and leave Angkor Wat and Angkor Tom (Bayon) for the end. Spending only one day visiting the temples would be a sacrilege.
Tour. This is a must see lots of interesting things to see our guide Mr Nak was extremely knowledgeable. Would recommend him to anyone.

Miracle Angkor Thom. I'd love how Cambodia goverment site train for Siem Reap people to service tourists. They know basic English and they serve by their friendly, kind. I came to Cambodian 2 times and all the times I go to Angkor

Amazing place. Even though it was about 38 degrees, we enjoyed walking around and seeing the sites. It was great to walk inside and amongst the walls of the temple. The trees growing through was amazing. Take plenty of water with you as it is a bit of a walk to get to the temple and there isn't anywhere inside to buy water.The stall sellers outside the walls of the temple are annoying and won't leave you along.

Amazing carvings, fantastic photo opps and more. Each temple in this region has something special to offer. The carvings at Bayon are amazing and it's incredible to wander around and see them from all different angles. These temples are vast so please allow yourself an appropriate amount of time at each one. To really get the feel of Bayon you need to walk around the entire temple. There is so much history here it would pay to get yourself a guide to enrich your visit. Just fabulous. You won't be disappointed.
BEAUTIFUL. One of the more stunning sights at Angkor. Worth checking out to any traveller in Cambodia, bring a camera, its beautiful.
One of the best of Angkor. From all temples we visited in Angkor - that one was the best. Not as crowded as Angor Thom and really in great conditions. YOu have to visit it!

Ruined but Amazing Achitechure. Although the temple are much ruined, you could imagine how wonderful when it was built. We almost can't believe that the temple was built in a time when machines were not available. Anyway, I'm a bit sad to see it getting old. Thousands of beautiful faces are still there. Make a visit at least to appreciate this amazing piece of work.

Cool place. This temple has been on of my favorite...there are numerous outlooks and different faces on each side if you creative you can get some real nice pictures. I would definitely put this on top of your list to visit if you have a few hours on this town.
Bayon Temple is the best . Very nice temple ever !! I spent my time in this temple around 3hour with my wife and take a lot of nice photo. I give Rank #2 in the best temple in Siem reap
My favorite temple . This temple was magical. The carvings of the faves and the stories that accompany them were fascinating. Very large temple with hours of sites to see.

you would think its just another temple... But then you walk closer, and you start crawling through all the small halls and doors.. and you discover beautiful faces.. the temple has the feel of a labyrinth.. precarious corners, steep angels.. stairs and alleys going everywhere... but none the less.. the symmetry is beatifull and the faces looking over you at all times.. evokes an otherwordly experience that is the least to say sometimes creepy and sometimes otherworldly.

Happy Faces!. This was the last temple we visited before we had to leave for the airport so it was, unfortunately, a fairly quick visit. By the time we got there, I was kind of "templed out" and so wasn't sure if I cared about seeing this one. However, it was spectacular! The "happy faces", as my guide called them, were everywhere. The intricate carvings were incredible and the temple was very fun to walk around to see. Do not miss this one, no matter how tired you are!
Amazing Amazing. What can one say Magnificent Architecture and still standingMind blowingImages not all of Bayon Temple

Amazing . By far my favourite. We visited this at the end of the day, however it became overcast and it was raining. I'm so glad it did. Made the place look magical Our tour guide Munny was full of knowledge and an excellent photographer
Amazing carving, Buddhas everywhere!. This is one of the most amazing temples in Angkor. The intricate carving is so beautiful, with so many Buddhas everywhere one goes.Simply Amazing!

Beautiful and Fascinating. There's a lot of temples around the Angkor complex but this is without a doubt one of the more beautiful and fascinating temples. The carved faces, the ambiance, feel and overall grandeur of the temple is enough to keep one busy for hours on end. For those who want to really get in-depth with the history and background then I'd highly recommend to hire a guide, they can show you the most efficient way to get around the Angkor complex and what each temple has to offer. However I personally choose to buy one of the very popular guide books (Lone**Pla***) and just relied on that so I was able to explore on my own time and my own pace. Used a tuk-tuk to get a more "authentic" local feel but I'm sure going around via an air conditioned van would be a lot more comfortable. FRIENDLY TIP: there's several types of passes for the Angkor Wat complex ranging from 1day all the way up to 1 week so don't feel pressured to finish everything within one day (time permitting that is).

Fun Experience with Temples and Elephants. My family and I visited this temple in the morning to beat some of the crowds and heat. We took a loop around the temple by elephant which was unique and worth it. We toured as part of a group of nine which was no problem. This was the end of the dry season so it was very dry and dusty. Good footgear was important.

Incredible Temple with Incredible Tour Guide!. Stunning temple intricately carved with faces - a must see! Had a incredible tour guide HAN HIEK from Pin Vannak Tours. Highly recommend this tour guide to detail the amazing history of Bayon Temple (as well as all the other Angkor temples in Siem Reap)
Our Favorite of Them All. if you only have time to see a couple of the ruins, make sure this is one of them. All four of us voted this as our favorite.
Among the most beautiful temples . . .. Bayon is notable for the vast number of large carved faces on the temple towers .. . spectacular and well worth a visit . .

The best temple in Siem Reap. For me, this is the best temple of all the siem reap Angkor complex. Very intriguing with all those khmer people faces sculped in the stones. Fantastic ambience and atmosphere. It is located right inside Angkor Thom south gate and it is worth a 2+ hours visit to see all the details. I visited this temple two times, one at sunset and the other one in the morning light, when it was hoter and also more crowded.a good tip is to Hire an english speaking guide to explain all the multiple details and stories about the place.To avoid large groups of tourists, go in the afternoon after 3;30 pm. The closing time is 5:30 p.m and there will be enough time to see everything in a slower pace.Considering the interior details, the whole experience and the architecture, Bayon and Banteay Srei were the two best visits for me.

I didn't get the chance to see the inside of the temple. We just passed by because we were rushing to go to Ang Kor Wat before it closes therefore we only managed to see the outside of this temple. I will definitely return
Another place you cant miss. After a 2 hour walk around Angkor wat, we were brought to the Bayon temple. Also another 'must-see' place after Angkor wat.

Simply the best.. Personnaly I prefer bayon to angkor vat. Going to the top takes a little bit of effort but it is worth it. In high season you have difficulty moving around. I dont know if the structure can hold more than a thousand people. The design of the temple is unique but a lot smaller than angkor vat. The bouddha faces are fantastic. A wonderful souvenir.

So many temples so little time! . So there are just so very many temples to see!! But Bayon is just beautiful! If you can afford a guide for the few extra $$ i would recommend it to hear about Cambodian culture and mythology and explanations behind the carvings and the temples. Wear sturdy sneakers as some of the steps are quite small and uneven and possibly bring a hand held fan. It gets quite warm.

Magical. We visited many temples while in Siem Reap and Bayon was our favorite, truly magical and quieter than other sites!
Highly recommend having a private tour guide if you can, especially wjth you ger children so that you can go at a slower pace.

One of my favourites . This temple is so amazing.. the maze like design is so intriguing. Even if it is crowded visit this place, it's worth it. I am sure u will never see anything like this elsewhere. I just loved being here so much so that I visited this place twice. The second time we checked out the sculptures around the temple which are very interesting. This is a must visit. Only problem was loads n loads of tourist buses with large crowds arriving in the morning. It was relatively empty when we went around 3pm the second time.

Fascinating architecture. This temple has far more architectural complexity than Angkor Wat. Though way smaller its quite a fascinating piece of work to see the 4 headed Buddha with different expressions. Also dont miss the King's Buddha. It is a small monastery inside and a prayer hall

Extraordinary . This was one of my favourite temples. The face carvings are phenomenal. I liked that they were smiling too. There were lots of people, but plenty of photo opportunities and places to be without too big of a crowd. We were on a private tour, and our guide was amazing. So knowledgeable. Definitely worth a visit if you're interested in temples and in the Angkor area.

Favorite Temple at Angkor!. The second stop on the short temple circuit if you start with Angkor Wat. Not as big but extremely intricate and fun to explore! More like a maze than Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm so you can easily spend an hour or more here. Went at around 7-7:30am after being at Angkor Wat for sunrise and it wasn't that busy yet.

Wow. We did a tour of the three main temples and this one was amazing. The faces in the towers emerge from the stone with so much feeling. The more you look from a distance the more you see. It is well worth getting a guided tour of the three main temples, as they can show you all the reliefs on the walls and give some structure to what you are seeing.

A must go to temple!. You might just be interested in angkor wat but bayon temple is definitly a place to visit,its majestic towers and architectural beauty is a mystery for me. I even believed in aliens just because of this temples wondering how they made such incredible structure in limited technology.A must visit and its actualy very near to the temples; here are some tips for your visit!1.First what we did was buy ticket in a goverment controlled establishment (you a have a choice of a 1day 2day or 3day pass for all the temples included) we got the 1day pass for $20 and visited 6 temples.If you are not that into walking i would suggest to just visit bayon and angkor or just split the temples in different days for there will be alot of walking! 2.SLEEVLESS,SHORTS,SLIPPERS,SHADES AND SCARFS ARE NOT ALLOWED although sandals may be considered.but most importantly make sure to be comfortable to enjoy ur visit. 3.Just to be sure dont forget to check the weather,temples dont have roofs and there are only few convered area so if it is gonna rain i suggest you bring you rain coats or umbrella.

One of the must see temples in the complex. After being in Angkor Wat I didn't expect more, but it was impressive. The temple's carved faces are amazing and in very good conditions for photos. Loved the history, good idea to hire a guide.

Top 5 temple in Angkor. A bit more crowded than some of the lesser known temples, but worth dealing with the masses. Along with Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm, Banteay Srei, and maybe Preah Rup, the Bayon has cemented itself in my top 5 temples of Angkor.

Just as good as Angkor Wat, if not better!. This was quite possibly my favourite temple in Siem Reap. It's amazing, you'll see. Lots of cool photos to take... it'd be worth going here at 6am to avoid crowds.
Favourite temple . We didn't see a heap of temples but this one was my favourite. It's super intricate and detailed. Full of people but worth it.

Don't Pass This Up. Compared to Angkor Wat, this is a tiny temple. But compared to Angkor Wat, all temples are tiny! Go here around sunset to feel the vibes from all of the huge faces carved into the temple walls and spires. Each face is different and there are a bunch of them. Go with an experienced guide to get the most out of this great place!

Our favorite part of Angkor Wat. Angkor Wat is a large complex of dozens of temples. You probably won't have time to see them all, so picking out a few keys ones I think is important. Bayon was the second one we saw but I think it's the one we liked the most. All the temples are stunning and the history is overwhelming, but Bayon had the right mixture of interesting architecture and not too many tourists (unlike the main temple that was jam packed).
Another amazing attraction. Again amazing engineering and detail make this another facinating attraction. Highly recommended. It is worth visiting all the temples and understanding the history.

My favourite of Angkor Thom!. This was absolutely my favourite of all the temples! Arhitecture blows away, plus if you have a guide to tell you the stories what tells the wall drawings... its amazing!

Another beautiful angkor temple. One of the most famous and photographed Angkor temples, next to Angkor Wat. The temple is well-known for the 2000++ large faces carved on its tall stone towers. The faces on all 4 sides of the towers give this temple a majestic character. The smiling faces on the towers is widely known as the "Angkor smile". Recommend to spend at least 2 hours to view the 3 levels of the temple.

Exceptional and mysterious. The temple, which is known as Bayon has Buddha faces everywhere you look. It's mind blowing how the temple was made and all the faces carved into the stone. Everywhere you turn, there is one smiling at you!

The Many-faced Temple. This temple looked like a simple towered temple from afar. But going around, the carved faces of divinities were amazing. There are many pillars, windows and carvings to see. Go up to the third level for a better appreciation of the temple.
Beautiful. If you are in Siem Riep, then it is a must to visit this temple. Though not much is left, but you can still make out a beautiful temple it must have been in those ancient days.

The temple of many faces. We went there as a family and beside it was too crowded and too hot, we enjoy the place. This temple is part of the budhist period and it's easy to realize that. Nice atmosphere if you find a place for you alone.

Favorite temple!. The giant heads and other mystifying things of this temple amaze me.
When you look at the view from above, you just smile.

Incredible temple, my favourite in Angkor Thom!. I was blown away by this temple. All the faces are so cool! Do a bit of reading about it before you go in so that you can appreciate it more (there are no signs or descriptions anywhere on the site). It's not nearly as busy as Angkor Wat, which is a bit surprising to me because I actually enjoyed it more. This means that with a bit of patience, you can get loads of photos without other tourists in the background!Within walking distance are a few other cool things to see, like Baphuon (you need to be appropriately dressed to get inside this temple) and the elephant and leper king terraces. If you're as terrible with directions as I am, I highly recommend taking a map! Our tuk tuk driver dropped us off there for two hours and we got a little confused.
Beautiful!. I loved this temple. It is of course much smaller than Angkor Wat but the serene faces of the Buddha at Angkor Thom are stunning.
Part of the Angkor complex. Another picturesque addition to the temple tour, visited before Angkor Wat and is a must see part of the tour

Breathtakingly beautiful . We went in May and the weather was warm but dry. We got there early- pre 8am and it was quiet and so peaceful. We stayed for 3.5 hours and could have been there longer. $12USD in a tuktuk for a half day.

amazing temple one off my bucket list ticked for sure.. Auer inspiring and to think that this stunning piece of architecture is over 2000 years old and still standing proud and mainly solid looking, wish I had taken a balloon trip now to view it from above as this would have got rid of the begging children continually and annoyingly trying to sell postcards and trinkets.

Probably the best of them all. I visited all the temples around the Ankor Wat area and definitely recommend to visit this temple. Apart from the Ankor Wat, the top of the Bayon template is the most interesting.

Incredible experience. The most amazing carvings and how terrifying that the scenes of torture were recreated during the reign of the Khumar Rouge. The killing fields and genacid actually happened in my lifetime and I was completely ignorant until I visited this region.

Avoid the crowds by.... Bayon is a wonderful temple, and I've been fortunate enough to explore it on many occasions. There are some fantastic carvings on the outer walls, and of course, the views from the top of the temple are extraordinary.Bayon, however, is another temple that can get overrun with tourists, so the trick is to arrive there either before or after most tour buses are there. Ask your local guide about these times, but it seems to me that most tour buses arrive at the temple between 9 a.m. and 11 a.m. If you explore Bayon over the lunch hour, you'll see fewer tourists. If you can endure the heat of the day (and Bayon does get very hot), arriving at 2 p.m. or 3 p.m. will greatly improve your chances of avoiding large groups. A late afternoon visit would also be good.My best advise is to talk extensively with your local guide about the timing of your visits to Angkor Wat, Bayon, Ta Prohm, etc. If you can create a schedule that allows you to arrive at these temples before or after the big groups do, you'll have a better experience.On a general note, Bayon is a can't miss temple. It's amazing. -- John Shors, bestselling author of Temple of a Thousand Faces: A Novel of Angkor Wat

Don't miss Bayon. I was getting a bit 'templed out' to be honest after 3 days but was so glad that we went to Bayon. It is mesmerising - all the faces looking at you and thinking about the history of it all. Our wonderful guide knew all the best spots for cool photos opportunites too

Amazing. Personally I liked it much better than Angkor Wat. Both are nice but here there is less crowd and the same beauty.
Absolutely a must to spend some time here as well.

Buddhist symbolism. Noted as the most recent of all the Kymer temples it is situated in the centre of the city Angkor Thom. It is richly decorated with figures depicting historical and mythological themes. The most significant feature of this temple is the striking figures of Buddha carved in the upper towers of the temple. Legend has it these are modelled on the features of King Jayawarman VII who had commissioned the temple Well worth a visit to compare with Angkor Wat and see this unique example of the Kymer baroque architecture.

Bayon. The Bayon Temple has a total of 49 towers, each tower has 4 smiling face resembling Jayavarman VII.This temple has 3 levels and are connected via steep steps therefore sports shoes are recommendedIn the temple you will notice the presence of both Buddha (Buddhism) sculptures and Linga (Hinduism) Sculptures . The guide explained that the temple was originally built by Jayavarman VII as a Buddhist temple, After Jayavarman VII death, due to conversion of religion to Hinduism the Buddha sculpture are replaced with Linga which is a sign representing the Hindu god Shiva.The Linga sculptures were sculpted over the the Buddhist sculpture on the walls of the temple.Angkor Wat Temples Pass is required for entry.Stayed at the temple for about an hour.

Even so, a visit to any of the temples while in Siem Reap is a must, and take in more than just one of them.

Temple of four faces. Bayon is the most popular temple alongside with Angkor Wat. Bayon is located at the center of Angkor Thom complex. The many wonderful faces of Buddha. To visit the Bayon Temple we entered Angkor Thom through the South Gate. As we approached the entrance we hopped off the tuk tuk and walked along the bridge lined with 54 stone figures of gods (left hand side) and 54 figures of demons (right hand side). We then passed under the impressive stone entrance tower topped by four heads of Buddha.This was one of our favourite temples. It’s impossible not to enjoy all of the smiling faces carved into stone looking at you as you make your way around this Buddhist temple. The temple is surrounded by trees and earlier in the morning there were not as many people which added to the serene feeling of the site. There were also lots of corridors to explore with intricate carvings depicting warfare, everyday life and mythological scenes. We spent about an hour wandering around this wonderful site.We went through with a guide, driven by a tuk tuk driver, as this was included in our accommodation package and organised by our hotel. We found having a guide was invaluable as it not only helped us navigate the large site, but also put things into relevant historical and religious perspectives for us. To visit any of the Angkor Wat temples you need to have an Angkor Pass, available in 1, 3 or 7 day passes. This gives you access to the temples for any of those number of days in a given week, or month if you have a 7 day pass, they don’t have to be used on consecutive days. We went with a 3 day pass for $40. When you go to the main entrance to get your pass your photo is taken and printed on the pass, which you must present on each visit to a temple.We had visited Angkor Wat beforehand and exited Angkor Thom through the East Gate to go to Ta Prohm Temple afterwards on the same day as they were included in our full day tour, however although it was beneficial going through these sites with the knowledge of a guide, due to the heat and the magnitude of what we were viewing if we could do it again we would leave these sites for a separate visit and take more time with each.We enjoyed travelling between the temples by tuk tuk, it was a unique way of travel for us and we also appreciated the cool breezes as we travelled.It gets hot visiting the temples, especially in May, so taking lots of water and wearing a hat and sunscreen are a must. Also a good insect repellent to avoid mosquito bites is advisable. Fair bit of walking over uneven ground so recommend comfy shoes.
lovely. A place one must see. I was amazed to see this architectural wonder. It was built in 12th century. Restoration work is on now.

"Oh, the many faces!". The faces of Bayon Temple have been etched into my childhood mind since I was knee-high to a goat! You will take some of the most professional looking pictures EVER! Bayon Temple doesn't have bad angles. Trust me, you'll have more than enough to fill up your office walls, and frame some for Christmas gifts! It's amazing how time has done little to whittle the faces away. The parts that HAVE crumbled, crumbled in just the right way. However, I suggest the same thing for all Cambodian temples: eucalyptus oil mixed with lotion to ward off mosquitoes, comfy shoes, a good camera, a bottle of water, a hand towel for wiping away sweat, time, a smile and a curious nature to wonder the stone hallways of the ancients.

An amazing place. The architecture is fantastic. I loved all the faces. Also did the elephant ride around the perimeter. Need good sturdy shoes for all the climbing up and down steps.

The best temple . In my own opinion this temple is the best. Buda is happy and his Happiness you can feel it. If you go there tray to go early in the morning before 7 am almost empty and better weather. At this time you may mediate alone. Hope you enjoy as much I did . Come and visit is awesomely be there

Angkor of Faces!. Opposite of Angkor Wat, where there is a long leading path to the main temple, Bayon is pretty straight forward. The tuktuk will take you to the entrance, with a few step away, you will be inside and able to see beautiful architect with fascinating Budda's faces where different shapes of stones put together to create masterpieces. Try to get to the top, its amazing how symmetrical element is vital and create such magnificent site!

Best Temple!. Bayon Temple was by far my favorite in Cambodia. As you approach the temple, you immediately notice the smiling faces of the King staring down at you. There are 216 of these carvings in the walls and towers at Bayon, which make this temple very unique. It was fun to explore the many hallways of the site and climb the steep staircases to different levels of the temple. This temple is a must see when visiting the temples of Angkor.

One of the top temples. This one is not to be missed. Watch out for the crowds and pay attention to the "one way" flow of the up/down stairs to the center of the temple. Amazing restoration has taken place.

" FACES "Their Everywhere". This temple could be your favorite , I have taken many groups to this Temple and it is one of the favorites of many of our friends. Make sure you have your camera, also sometimes there are Apsara dancers to take your photo with.
Amazing . Loved it. So beautiful and interesting. I took some amazing pictures. Could of spent hours looking around and studying the faces.

Amazing temple. It is unbelievable that many Western tourists seem not to appreciate to see many Asian tourists come to contemplate the temples! I want to say that these Asian tourists have more right to be here not knowing they reside very far. It's annoying to see Western man believed that everything is naturally acquired him and not to others. Asian seriously begin to tour, maybe it will help the average white man to understand that he does not represent the planet and other people have as much right as him to move it.

Faces!. Make sure to stop here on a tour as this is where all the faces come from. The faces are unique to this temple and should not be missed.All of the temples are amazing. Consider doing a tour of several all at once. Bring lots of water and sunscreen. It's hot.

I enjoyed this more than Angkor Wat. Found it more enjoyable walking around. Really liked the faces everywhere. Didn't know what to expect but thoroughly enjoyed my time spent here & could easily have spent a lot longer here.

Another amazing temple!!!. The style of this temple is quite different from Angkor Wat. It consists several four-smiling-face tower. The wall-carves tells interesting stories as well. A good view from the top towers. Must-have.
Absolute favorite after Angkor Wat. The faces are fascinating. The smiling faces overlooking from every direction are uplifting. Loved it!

More Beautiful than Angkor Wat. The Bayon Temple, central to the Angkor Thom Temple is more beautiful than Angkor Wat. The work that went into it is breath taking. Again, the Bus loads of screaming tourists who climb all over the temple are shocking, however there are many spots you can quietly appreciated this one from. Please don't ride the elephants.

Intricate interesting Maze! . We were dropped off by our tuk tuk driver on one side and yTold he would meet us on the other side. They check your ticket at every temple and offered us a guide. We had just spent money on a book about the temples so we decided. Walking through I heard guides speaking a wide range of languages, very cool! It was early May and extremely hot, like sweaty through your shirt, poor water on your head hot. Even with the heat we were so interested in the temple, it is not as well kept add Angkor Watt, but this adds to its intrigue. If you want to do the temples close to Siem Reap I recommend going with a tuk tuk tour (most hotels offer them for around $15 for the day), all the driver to do the circle in reverse (end with Angkor Watt, we seemed to miss the crowds this way) , and bring lots of water! Also I should note tickets into the Angkor Archaeological Park are $20/person for 1 day and $40/person for 3 days.

The Active Temple of worship here.. This is one of 3 must see temples that can be included in your tour with a driver in ac car, which I suggest. The many faces are interesting to see as well as all the figures leading up to it on the road here. Its just special to learn how important these places are in this culture.
Its same. I think baayoo its a same feel like angkow wat, there is nothing different when i came here. But you can take one day trip for angkor wat, bayoon, angkor thom and etc,

Beautiful but.... They carved stones are indeed stunning. But there are too many tourists that it ruins the peaceful mood and also prevent you from fully admire the beauty (since they keep pushing you for pictures)

Great historical and architectural value. Great historical and architectural value - you will need to spend a whole day. Put on sunscreen, wear a hat, good walking shoes, cool clothing and a sturdy fan.
Amazing temple!. This is my favorite one! Very beautiful and exotic! I was really impressed by the architecture, the specificity compared to other temples being the buddha heads everywhere. A must!

The faces of Angkor in all their glory!!!. Bayon Temple is at the center of the Angkor Thom Complex and is believed to represent the intersection of heaven and earth. According to our guide the four faces on each tower represented the 4 main religions of the time (indicating a remarkable level of tolerance which we could probably learn from today). There were originally 51 towers (of which 37 remain) which represented the 51 provinces in the Khymer Empire.A really interesting and fascinating visit which simply commands respect!
The faces are breathtaking. There are lots of temples in siem reap, but Bayon is the one that you will never forget. It is way more beautiful to see it with your own eyes than in photos.
Another Amazing Temple. Another Amazing Temple and again close to Siem Reap, Cambodia. The temple is well worth a visit and can be easily reached.

Beautiful Buddha faces in the many towers of the temple. What makes this temple special is the many Buddha's that are engraved in the towers of this temple. Very impressive and making this temple stand out amongst some of the others. Although to be fair, many other temples have things on their own that make them special
Enjoyable . For me not stunning but great to see and definitely something that should be seen. I found it better than Ankor Wat. Really a maze to see everything.
Smiling faces. less crowded than angkor wat. go earlier to avoid crowds and big sun. Love this place! a lot of smiling faces.

Stunning temple, a must!. Bayon Temple dates from the 12th Century and was built as the official state temple of the Mahayana Buddhist King Jayavarman VII, the Bayon Temple stands at the centre of Jayavarman's capital, Angkor Thom. Our guide brought us here as part of the day tour we had booked and if you are coming to see Angkor Wat then Bayon Temple nearby is a must.Bayon temple is most famous for the 216 carved faces (especially the famous picture of the three faces) and beautiful relief's, and is very different in style to Angkor Wat, its famous neighbour, and the overall complex is larger in size.Bayon Temple was hidden by the jungle for generations but has been heavily restored by an international effort.The overall architecture is utterly stunning and the views are sensational. The climb is punishing but well worth it!Bring a lot of water, wipes etc as Bayon Temple can be brutally hot and involves a lot of climbing (the stairs are incredibly steep in places). Bayon Temple is generally much calmer and more peaceful than Angkor Wat.

One of the many highlights in Angkor. It's the Wandering Yank here. Mrs. Yank and I spent 3 delightful days in Siem Reap, and visited Angkor each of those days. Bayon was one of the more memorable (and unfortunately, also crowded) temples. The 216 faces on the 54 towers certainly give it an eerie feel, as though one is always being watched. But be warned - the morning crowd, even in the hot season, means you'll constantly be walking around people taking selfies and photos of their fellow travelers.But still 2 thumbs up!

Always a smile for you. Bayon Temple knocks you off your feet due to its immensity. Yes, nature and looters have taken a toll on this wonderful temple. I didn't get around to nor did i have time to count the 54 towers and we know the smiling buddha faces on each of the four sides of each tower are no longer all there. Never did find out how many of the original 216 are still present but Bayon Temple is still a sight to behold. There does appear to be one particular buddha face that everyone likes to or will have their photo taken next to because it is at the right level and is the right size. It is fun to check out as many areas of the temple as time allows. There are areas to sit and get some shade and there are some regions with steep steps to climb. It is also easy to get separated from your party if you or they venture off. Another must-see in Angkor Thom.
Bayon Temple is a must visit !. Togethewr with Angkor Wat, this is a must visit site for anyone coming to Siem Reap Cambodia. I think its obvious and I do not need to explain further.
Most impressive temple around. The Budha faces temple making for great instagram pictures even with the numerous other people doing the same thing
Lovely. Stunning and generally not as crowded as Angkor Wat. A reasonably large complex with some steep climbs so allow time to explore. Go early to avoid the other tourists and the heat!

Bayon is best. If you are short on time and are visiting Siem Reap then Bayon is probably the equal of Ankor Wat but for different reasons. It's various parts are more accessible and the gateways are awesome.
Unforgettable experience. Amazing place and more peaceful then main temple. Go there early to avoid crouds. Love the towers with many faces-when you look closely you can see subtle diffrences.

Tattoo. Khymer for Bayon is tattoo.If Angkor was a downer for me The once beautiful Bayon was sheer precarious rubble.Again we walk through badly preserved areas.There does not seem to be any pride to upkeep these glorious temples.

Simply The Best. If you want to see an amazing Temple (10th century) then this is the one. It has not been renovated and yet is in very good condition. Jaw dropping faces (4 on each of the 54 spires) . . . This was one of the highlights of our month long stay in S E Asia.

Fun adventure . This place is alot of fun to explore and has some beautiful carvings if your interested in that kind if thing, I'd highly recommend visiting here with friends and making some amazing memories :-)
Must see. . Cambodian Mona Lisa. If you're here and don't see Bayon, you've missed out. The faces are incredible and it's right by the Angkor Wat!

Best temple in the entire complex. What a sight!!! My favorite temple for sure in the entire complex. Great to hide away and catch your breath. Get your kiss pic, sure but the greatest part Bayon is finding a cool corner or hidden spot, sitting back and taking in the sights of Bayon and reminiscing over.
very cool. this temple is massive and lovely to see how it had been converted from hinduism into Buddhism over the years, it is currently a buddhist temple

Amazing. As mentioned in the comment Angkor Wat, impressive ancient construction.
You can enjoy an elephant ride around the grounds.
Need urgent conservation works.

Amazing face sculptures. Hundreds of gigantic faces with many different expressions. Your tour guide will tell you what it all means. It was incredibly hot and humid when we were there and the stories were lost on us. Lots of great photo opportunities.

Breathtaking!. This is one of the premier tourist attractions in the world, & pictures do not do it justice. I was awestruck by the magnificence of this temple, the size & scale of it was beyond my imagination.
Put this one on your bucket list - it is as good as it gets!

Spectacular. This is one of places you have got to visit! I recommend visiting early morning to get the most out of your visit and definitely do some reading up on the history so you know more about the place rather than just turning up with no background knowledge. Hiring a guide is worth every dollar as you will get a lot more information about the individual temple complexes this way. Don't forget your camera!

Not so hidden Gem!. I absolutely loved this temple! The more you see of it the more you love it! Part of the day ticket to the major Angkor complex this is a nice spot to explore after the sunrise at Angkor Watt for a hour or two.Stunning architecture that really puzzles the mind at how they where able to build such massive structures with the most minute attention to details. Remember to bring a camera:This temple allows for a lot of photo opportunities and great selfies.There are lots of vendors around selling water snacks.

My Favorite . It can be busy and that can limit the chance for great shotsI would suggest coming in the late afternoon for the sun setting on the facesBut without doubt this is one of the temples that people associate with Cambodia

The best of the 3 major temples. We enjoyed this site as was both internal and external walking. Internally through little passageways, small framed entrances etc. our guide said he played hide and seek there as a child. Not as large as Angkor.
amazing temple. I loved it. Their architecture is amazing. when you first see it you get amazed. great place to take pictures.
Holidays. Bayon Temple is another site not to be missed. A lot of history is inscruptured on the walls. The history is alive.Great site to go and explore.

Awestruck - get your camera ready. A must do - this is the best temple to get trigger happy on your camera because it photographs way better than you see it, trust us. And wear good walking/sports shoes because it's still a bit messy due to ongoing restoration works. Totally worth it though.
WOW. If you don't mind the crowds or the heat it would be truly amazing. We didn't spend too long there as too many people but definitely worth a stop.
Fantastic, like being on a set of Indianna Jones. Great temple, lots to see. You will need plenty of water as its so hot while going round these temples.
Loved it!!!!. Cant say anymore than "I loved it"!!!! Highly recommend a visit, a bit of walking but thats apart of it....taking it all in.

Temple of Faces - Make sure you visit when in Siem Reap!. The Bayon Temple is another must-see temple when you visit Siem Reap. While there are "faces" everywhere, it's truly amazing to see just how much detail there is with all of the sculptures throughout this temple. It's a very peaceful setting. This temple is not nearly as grand as Angkor Wat, but it's another must see temple when in the area. When in Siem Reap, be sure to visit Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm & Bayon Temple. It's the perfect Siem Reap trifecta! Each temple is incredible and special in its own way. Be sure to add Bayon Temple to your Siem Reap itinerary.
Great Experience. Its near Angkorvat temple and really great experience to visit these temples. standing tall from last 1000 years

Beautiful . This was our second stop on the Angkor Wat small circuit. Managed to get there just as they opened it at 730. Small crowds ment quiet during the exploring which is always nice. Cute kittens running around as well and super friendly.
One of my favourite temples. The faces on this temple are unbelievable, definitely one of my favourite temples. Make sure you see this one on your tour!

Could be great but for the CROWDS. I think this could, and should be a really great archaeological site, but it's very hard to feel the history, the age, or the significance of this temple with amusement park like crowds milling about. This is a more compact temple than Angkor Wat, so the crowding is even worse. At some parts there were shuffle-your-feet lines to go down the stairs, or for prime photo spots. Really wish there were some sort of crowd control system in place. As it is right now, it feels like a people mill.
Favourite. Many of The other temples get the glory, but this one is a real gem. Not to be missed or passed over.

Amazing!. This temple is the temple of many faces! (sounds like game of thrones) it feels errie but at the same time you can understand why, such a peaceful place which can not be missed out on your journey in siem reap.

Just ok. I'm not crazy about stone temples...but this one is ok in that you don't have too walk too far to get to it (unlike angkor wat). A guide would be nice to explain the stone relief decorating the walls.

Magnificent. I am at a loss of words. I can't describe the magnitude of this place. I am almost sad because nothing (or almost nothing) I will see could ever get close to how breathtakingly amazing this place is. Beautiful, magnificent, colossal are poor words to describe it.Just go see it.
Top 10 site.. Excellent site with plenty of photo opportunities. Can be busy and hot. Steep steps for a good view all around, not easy.

Incedible. This is another incredible temple and certainly a must see.
The carvings and setting are amazing.
The place feels relaxing and we would love to have spent more time there but we're restricted on time
For martial art lovers there are also inscriptions about Bokatar
Highly recommended along with Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm

A crowded visit. The temple is very crowded because of its small size
so be prepared for crowds. You may see 5 to 8 elephants which
are available for rides nearby.
beautiful and repectful. this is one of the temple in whole area of Angkor Wat, and this is a place should NOT skip from the list of Angkor Wat
Amazing . Liked this better than Angkor Wat... The faces are beautiful! Make sure you have a shoulder cover to go to angkor thom, a scarf won't work.
Stunning!. Beautiful place... we went end of March VERY HOT! got a tour guide ..well worth it! explains a lot of history there..

more energy!. this area was a little quieter. I really inJOYed the spirit energies... I can see sense & feel stuff like that! might have to go back on my own without a guide to take it a little slower.... it was so hot too
Stunning and zen. Lovely temple...very peaceful. Really loved it. Buddha faces looking at you from every corner. Very special...highly recommend it. Don't miss it!
Gobsmacking. Gobsmacking! This was quite special and must be added to anyone's itinerary. I am sorry it was the last place we visited as I could have spent more time there easily.

Another Great Sight. you can see this temple at the same time you see Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm.Again the structure and history are amazing and well worth seeing.A tuk tuk can get you there cheaply but you do need the temple pass.A 3 day pass at $40 per person is the most efficient way to go.
