a visual treat. the temple with the human faces, Bayon is an architectural marvel. the south gate has a large four faced carving of the king. the temple enclosure consisted of 54 towers totalling 216 faces, every tower having 4 faces. there are bas reliefs on the southern wall depicting the daily lives of the people. it is fun exploring and figuring out these reliefs.we visited Bayon twice, once with the guide and the next morning on our own because we felt that a single visit didnt do justice to the temple.

Stunning. You can play in the jungle pretending you are Lara Croft or explore every inch of the bas-reliefs. Don't forget to go upstairs to have the full view of the composition surrounded by canals. One of the wonders of this world...Stunning
Smiling Faces. Another fascinating temple where smiling faces are all over the place! It must have been such an intriguing look thousands of years ago.

Wow. The structure is in ruin but what's still standing is fantastic. The volume of relief carvings and the story on the largest wall are amazing. The construction of the towers and carved heads took very skilled craftsman. While not as popular as Angkor Wat it's still every bit as inspiring.

Breath-taking Buddha faces by the dozens!. This is by far my favourite Angkorian structure, simply for the magnitude, and the dozens of towers with the iconic 4 directional Buddha faces atop them. It's an architectural wonder and a treat to walk around and imagine it's early glory! Highly recommended!
Favourite Temple. My favourite of all the temples due to the faces. Definitely needed our private tour guide that day as we learnt so much about this temple and the history of Cambodia.
THE BEST ...MUST-SEE. The best preserved of all the temples. Magnificent size and tons of detail in artistry on walls inside and out.
Amazing. loved this temple, it was a real relic of the past, again like all the temples lunch time is the quietest to be there

A very special experience.. I love to experience what architecture, particularly religious architecture, can make you feel. Bayon Temple is really special. I kept wondering what life must have been like living and working in those meticulously designed and crafted spaces. I think it must have been wonderful. Dozens of beneficent faces look down from all directions as you make your way into their immediate presence. Wow... One version of heaven on earth. Too much to take in on the first visit, calls me to return.

Don't miss this one!. The Angkor Thom complex is incredible. The Bayon temple frieze is beautifully detailed. Take time to appreciate the narratives, how the different people are portrayed through their hairstyles, the depiction of everyday life, and the beauty of the carving. The giant faces are, of course, amazing but I mention the frieze because you can't miss being beguiled by the faces!

One of my favorite temple. I've been to Siem Reap twice and still, this is my 2nd favorite temple next to Angkor Wat. it is somewhat unique because the design of the temple is mostly known of its smiling faces. Just make sure to bring water and bandana because it usually gets really hot in here. there is restaurant within the area where we actually ate our lunch, you just have to take quite a long walk going there, touristy prices tho.This temple is also near temple of the lepper king and elephant terrace.

Calming Temple. This ended up being my favorite of all the temples we saw in Siem Reap. The Buddha faces carved all over the temple had a lovely calming effect on me and each face has a different expression. It's a fairly small temple, but seems larger with every step bringing you around a corner with a new group of faces to admire.

Wow. Amazing place. Possibly most favourite place out of all the temples! Well preserved and has a real wow factor about it. Up until visiting Bayon wasn't that taken by other temples when you compared them with others I have visited like chitchen iza and machu pichu. This one is definitely worth a half day visit!

Beautiful. Loved the bayon temple! Beautiful architecture and creeping tunnels and hallways, and very well-preserved! It's always piping hot though, so bring water and food as well, to not be the victim of low blood sugar!

A real Gem. Most tourists to Cambodia head to Angkor Watt which is indeed a fabulous destination. However the Bayon Temple in Angkor Thom gives the visitor a realistic glimpse of what life would have been like in this ancient kingdom. Access is much easier than Angkor Watt, fewer visitors, and easy walking for most people including children
Wow!. Love the smiling faces and the walls!! I really recommend to visit this place. I enjoy this site even more that Angkor Wat. The place is chaming and is a special experience
Favorite temple in Angkor Wat. Loved this place. Amazing faces coming out of the ground in temple form, each way you look, there is wonder around the corner. A must when at Angkor Wat.
Huge heads of stone. Worthwhile getting to this part of Angkor, amazing carvings of stone. Heads with different expressions.

An interesting temple full of faces. One of the many temples and attraction in Angkor Thom. This was supposedly the Mahayana Buddhist official state temple built by Jayavarman VII and which features multiple smiling faces and a couple of impressive bas-reliefs.

Iconic temple with lots of Yellow Monkeys. This was one of the more difficult & dangerous temples to navigate. There are wooden stairs to climb into, but no hand railings. This made the climb in hard, but I managed to run around in the 100 degree F. heat, late April 2016. The surprise came on the back side where there was hundreds of yellow monkeys running around & very friendly looking for food handouts. They were cute and a great surprise after the difficult navigation in the temple.

They're watching you!. An iconic stop that is recognized worldwide yet worth visiting on your own. Aim for the beginning of the day or later in the afternoon to avoid heat and crowds. While in the midst of the stoic faces you'll have great photo angles and opportunity to contemplate about what life may have been in the past.
Awesome Temple. This is another amazing temple a must see, again will need water and good walking shoes the day we went there were a lot of tourists, and very warm

Beautiful! . The faces in the stone are enchanting... my favorite temple! For photographers, visit during the golden hour for some great shots. We saw a monkey climbing the walls of the temple. This temple looks like King Louie's palace in The Jungle Book. Watch your step though. .. I got quite a bruise from falling on the steps.
Fun photo opportunities. An interesting temple for sure but I most recall the fun photo opportunities, Check out the attached picture.
SMILING TO THE WORLD. Has to be seen. Unique. Unbelievable ...a lot of walking but it is worth. will advise it absolutely . My favorite ...
Faces. Could spend ages going around this temple. The 216 faces carved in stone. Great history here on Khymer culture.
A must visit!. It is one of the finest temples in the Ankor complex. Each and every wall speaks volumes about the architecture. Plan it so well that you have enough time to look at everything
Amazing place to visit. How were these temples done so long ago?? A mystery to everyone...the carvings are amazing, the faces enormous, just stand back in ore!!
Tour organized by hotel. This amazing temples is just MUST SEE, this 4 faces temples are amazing and thanks our experienced guide who explained all perfeclty

Hands down, my favorite temple in Siem Reap!. I went to Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm, Phnom Bakheng, and to the Bayon complex (which includes the Bayon temple, along with a number of other structures like the Elephant Terrace!!!!). Bayon Temple was HANDS DOWN my favorite of all of them. My friend and I went at 6 in the morning. The thing is, it doesn't open until 7:30. So we were just walking around the perimeter when someone--a student--invited us into the temple and offered to show us around. So, yes, we basically got a private tour, which made it very magical. We could really experience the space, absorb the energy, take in the angles, and feel the Buddha all around us. It was quite moving and even emotional at moments. If you go, try to go early to take in the majesty of the structure, and also leave enough time to visit some of the other sites in the complex!

Know the story to make the most of the carvings. It's a very well documented site. This, my second time here, was more educational than the first as we travelled with Khmer guide "Jed" who pointed out the small detail of life in the legends depicted in the rich carvings on the temple walls. It surprises me that these very intricate and historic carvings are so exposed to the elements. One would hope they will get at least a sheltering roof over them one day like the apartments at Ephesus.
Very interesting temple, amazing detail.. Good temple to see the incredible engineering work of the original builders, and the restoration efforts of today.

Smiling Faces Everywhere!. I visited Bayon Temple early on morning and it was my favorite temple I visited at the Angkor Wat complex. The faces carved into the temple are beautiful and amazing. Well worth the effort to visit.
A stunning temple. Although smaller than Angkor Wat, Bayon Temple is well worth a visit. There is quite a lot of climbing involved in a visit here but the views are well worth the effort.

Beautiful temple. It is truly a beautiful temple and a breathtaking experience to visit it. Less touristy than Angkor Wat thus more intimate and relaxed. Face-sculpted stones one of their kind. Definitely a must see if you're in Cambodia. Have water handy and dine in one of the nearby Cambodian open-air restaurants.
Wonderful history. Follow a tour guide round who knows all the spots to get nose to nose pictures with the statues for some fun memories!
Lots to see. There is a lot to see here. You could spend half a day in this area. Beautiful temples. Bring plenty of water, lots of steps and walking.

Majestic. This was my favourite and for me the most majestic of all the temples we visited. It is so beautiful with all of the heads facing the 4 corners of the world. Imagine it it its heyday, it must have been truly Magnificent
cool place to visit. really loved Bayon Temple, its a throw back in time, would be nice to get here really early before the crowds ascend upon you.
so much history. Interesting from a historical, religious and cultural perspective. Do some background reading before you go.

Beautiful Bayon. Another mind blowing temple. So much to see and explore here. Quite a bit of climbing and lots of walking in and out of the darkened corridors. Some restoration work going on when we visited but only added to the interest.

Breathtaking and beautiful!!. This was actually my favorite of all the temples we visited in Siem Reap! It's huge, beautifully ancient, and the face carvings everywhere make it stand out as one of the most unique! Do not miss this if you're in the area!
A great place,don't miss it!. We visited here last March.,It's a temple with towers in the form of smiling Buddhas.Highly recommend to visit..

One more you must see.. There is a group of temples that you must see and this is another. They are all different and built by different Kmer kings with different religious influences - Hindu and or Buddhist. Differing symbolisms and artefacts.
Our guide explained this all and having visited the museum the day before helped.

Not to be missed!. After Angkor Wat, you should definitely head over to Angkor Thom to the Bayon Temple. It's so unique and just mind-blowing. The temple is more compact than Angkor Wat so just be prepared to feel the crowd considerably more.

One of the best tempkes. Our guides said to us that one temple not to miss is the bayon temple with the many faces and he was right!
The place is just so amazing with all the different faces and the details that goes to it.
If you can only visit a handful of temples - don't miss this one.
Buddhas every where.. 39 temples complex with 4 buddhas head on each temple ruin. Through each crevice or space, you can see a buddha's head. its worth seeing once.

My favourite!. I have to say, I found my spot there. I recommend to get lost inside the temple and walk through the rooms... And of course, I read about the cambodian culture and how the apsaras (beautiful dancers semi naked carved on the walls) are related to the whole history of the country... I could feel the magic! Take your time to follow the carving on the principal entrance wall, it tells their story!
temples.. really interesting. the faces were amazing. how did they make these? take plenty of water. walk slowly.
Amazing place. This is a must visit temple in Siem Reap. This place is filled with history. Make sure to have a guide to learn all the history behind this place.

Beautiful Temples. Visit the Angkor Wat first and then the other temples. Good temple to visit. We visited the other temples first and then Angkor Wat, but by then we were tired and had to really force ourselves to walk, even though we ended up spending nearly 4 hours at Angkor Wat.
Beautiful. Getting up close and personal in this temple is pretty special.the faces are a beautiful sight to behold.

Amazing Architectural Treasure . A super attraction this is part of the temple complex at it is high point.You get amazed looking at the structures and how it has sustained for so thousands years and yet it is a marvel to watch even in its status of ruins.The creators must have been engineering geniuses.Recommend months of the year to visit is Nov to Feb, we were in April it was very hot and humid, but it was low season and less visitors hence could see the place with space and serenity.If you are in visiting this place during summer , recommended time is between 7 am to 10 am.Do wear comfortable shoes lot of walking to be done, carry sun protection cream, water to avoid dehydration. Cap and shades.You need to pay 20 $ for a one day pass for the entire temple attraction there is also 2 days and up to 1 month entry pass with different charge
Small but worth seeing. This temple is small but won't take long to look around. It's worth seeing. The carvings and history behind it is interesting. Make sure you have a good tour guide.

The faces scalped all building Bayon temple Thom. Place an icon of super architecture.every faces are identical.. One of the great historical place remain in Cambodia.yes its very beautiful buildings at thom(top end)has four faces of sides. At the site every building faces are identical & detailed crafting. very proud to say ancient craftsman's cravings are great full.not so large temple but nice historical place to visit.worth to spend time over there. You must get pass to enter seim reap Historical squire cost 20 US Dollar. But its worth.

With smiley faces. The buildings are all close to each other. There will be 4-sided smiley faces on top of every building. When you are inside the area, you will feels like you are surrounding with happiness. It's an awesome place for me.
My favourite one!. This is the temple I liked the most...It is not full of tourists so that you can appreciate it in a better way
Great Temple. Its amazing how they preserve this massive area. Bayon Temple is one of the must see or things to do in Siem Reap. Make sure you hire a guide to give you a bit of history.
Worth the walk. The history has to be heard.Very interesting. Go with a guide. Do in morning as it was very hot. Worth doing.

Simply magnificent. Many different dark halls, carved faces, and beautiful crumbling rocks here. This is a must-visit as long as you are not too physically frail, as it is a little strenuous with large steps to climb and lots of uneven ground. Best to visit in the early morning to beat the relentless heat and the large tour groups.
hard to put into words. This is another temple on the Angkor Wat site, again its amazing to think this was built so long ago with so much detail. As you are out you should check this out.
Faces of Bayon. Very popular spot due to the faces carved in the building. It can be very hot during the day. Best to visit early in the morning.

Legends of the Hidden Temple. Visited Bayon Temple, among many others on a 2-3 day excursion, while at Angkor. Bayon was one of the more difficult to climb and hike but was well worth it. There was significant sun but plenty of opportunities for shade; this was important to us because it was extremely hot. There were dozens of faces, ranging from beautifully intact to barely recognizable. If you're of the generation to know what I'm talking about, this has to be what Ole Mac from Legends of the Hidden Temple is created from. Anyway, this is certainly a temple worth visiting while at Angkor.
Magnificent. This is one of many temples we visited. Smiling carved faces everywhere. Very hot and very busy. Lots of photo opportunities.
Get lost beneath dozens of stone faces . One of our favourite temples in the whole Angkor site. Spent hours getting lost in the maze of ruins overlooked by huge imposing stone faces. Unforgettable.

Amazing scupted faces on al the stones. - Nice Temple to visit as it is not too big, takes about one hour to view- The faces so accurately sculpted in all the big building stones and fitting so precisely together is a marvelous manifestation of the skills of people in the 13th century.
More Ancient splendour . Again the ancient worlds treasures continue to amaze us. As before all of these sites require a bit of stamina and grit if visiting in the hotter months.

Breathtaking. Amazing wall cravings with lots of history. The many crumbling rocks are not easy to climb if you have artritis, or if you are frail. The numerous craved Budha faces on the buildings were amazing. I just wish tourists will stop damazing this site by taking (stealing) pieces of momento rocks/stones, touching the buidling, or even building their own little shrines outside (saw a few of thes: despicable).

the highlight of my visit to Cambodia. I've always wanted to come to siem reap, Cambodia to visit both Angkor war and Angkor thom. Both places are beautiful and the monuments/temples are just amazing. Even the fact that mother nature has destroyed some of the structures everything works in perfect harmony. Make sure you do these temples with a guided tour, the history is very interesting!

Bayon Temple!!!!. This is my favorite of the Angkor sites and is truly amazing .The temple is one of the most striking and unique temples in the whole of the Angkor archaeological park, the building features hundreds of smiling faces around an imposing central tower.
Beautiful temple. I visited Bayon Temple as well as Ta Phrom and Angkor Wat when visiting Siem Riep. Bayon Temple was my highlight of the day, with beautiful faces carved into the rock faces.
Bayon temple was best temple have 4 face. Bayon big temple have 4 face stay in side Angkor Thom city .Round a lot big tree and have a lot caving on the wall of them it was history khmer impair
Stunning. Lovely Temple and well worth visiting - can be included in the pass for Anghor Wat. Loved the four faces on all the pillars.

Another awesome temple. Spending USD20 to visit all these temples were worth it. It is one of it's kind. don't forget to take your picture with the carved Buddha the epic 'nose to nose' on top of the temple. The stairs are very steep so you must hold on the the hand rail. If it rains it may get slippery. Wear comfortable shoes because the floor is uneven. The corridors can be a little bit dark and also tight to walk especially with tourists flocking into this temple.
Amazing!. The best time to visit this place is between 4:30 to 6:00 p.m when the golden sunset make everything more magnificient.

The best of the temples. . From the front it looks amazing and unique, but once you get up close, its even better. There are Many different passages and sculptures to admire here, and although it can be busy and crowded in the centre, its well worth going to.
Ancient. Another beautiful temple anyone must visit in Siem Reap. Wonderful stories & architectural of its own. A must see indeed!!

A less frantic visit during the busy Khmer New Year. This is a terrific stop for a quick explore as the scale is much smaller than Angkor. The difference is that this temple is purely Buddhist and that many of the statues and carvings are in much better condition. It is a perfect site for visitors with small children as it is small enough for them to explore without losing concentration. It is a real gem of a site and well worth the visit. we did it after Angkor Wat and wasn't too demanding as there is a little more shade around to take respite

Giant Faces Of Bayon. Bayon is one among the main temples to be visited..its almost in ruined stage but thanks to the Angkor Archaeological park restoration... For maintaining the sit...Bayon temple is situated in the Angkor Thom Complex...and can be reached by tuk tuk....the temple has intricate carvings of Khmer traditions and deities and Gods..and Faces of Kings and Bhudda....care must be taken while climbing the temple steps as it s very steep and some places are utter dark..when you reach the top floor the giant faces can be seen very closer...Bayon architecture s outstanding and an epitome for the Marvel creation...
Favorite among the temples. Loved the many faces. Love the smaller area but has many nooks and crannies. This temple has bats also. :D
SUMMER TOUR. I was amazed by the smiling Buddha's surrounding the temple and because of this I realized that Cambodia is really a nice destination to go during summer time.

My favorite temple.. Bayon was my favorite temple in all the Angkor area. There is no other place that will make you feel like you are just discovering the ruins and the adventure feel is exceptional. Loved it!

Wonderful Place!. Incredible Beautiful Temple! ))
Geat place for Amazing pics and photo shooting!
54 faces of the King as simbol of 54 provinces of Ancient Khmer at that time!

Wonderful place full of history.. Another site you should not miss if you go to Siem Reap.Wander around the ruins, see the reconstruction work that is going on. The area is full of old temples and other interesting ruins.If you work in health and safety you will probably hate it, there are very few barriers or fences, although there are steps in the harder to get to places.You would have to keep children under control as there are too many potential dangers. If you have problems with mobility not the place to go.
Beautiful. I love the architectural design of this temple. It looks so majestic and amazingly beautiful with intricate details.

Another Wonderful Temple. We went early in the morning as the temperature is quite hot during the peak hours of the day. We had a very nice Khmer guide named Sein that explained things about the temples history. It is definitely one of the most awe-inspiring places we've ever been. It's well worth the 7.5 hour bus journey from Phnom Penh.
Faces everywhere. This temple was my favourite of all the temples. Perfect photos every time you raised your camera and a surprising lack of other people at the time we went.our guide did well.
A marvel. There are four faces on each side of each tower. The devotion it must have taken to carve these in stone takes your breath away.
Smaller but good to start. Big faces temple and the best way to start discovering the park. Go in early morning and avoid lunch time as it will be very hot.

The many faces of Bayon. We had read about Bayon and wanted to visit as part of our temples day and it didn't disappoint! Absolutely fascinating and very different to Angkor Wat. We managed to get some incredible photos even though it was very busy. You will most likely be approached by an unofficial 'guide'. It's very cleverly done and begins with someone asking where you are from and offering to show you the best places to take photos. The back story is always about wanting to practice English to get to University and that they teach underprivileged children in their spare time. They certainly know their way around but, if you choose to follow, be prepared to have to pay in the knowledge that his back story may not be entirely true! We saw the information sheet, that he gave us to read about the school, being shown by many other unofficial 'guides' at several of the temples.
Bayon Temple visit. Arrived at 2pm and it was very quiet. Amazing faces built into the walls. Lovely temple that is the centrepiece to Angkor Thom.
Beautiful . This is my favourite temple of all in this area. I visited a couple of times. My last visit was in April which is not the best time in terms of weather. It was incredibly hot.

Temple with 4 faces . Amazing temple and another must visits when you in Angkor complex.
Need about 1-2 hours to admire the place. Amazing amazing

Another amazing piece of architecture. Another temple that you have to see up close to truly appreciate the work put into these places. It's an honor to be able to walk through and touch these pieces of history

Distinctive temple with four faces of Buddha. The temple of Bayon, located not far from Angkor ‎Wat is home to more than 50 towers each with the four faces of Buddha.
Although not as large or ‎magnificent as Angkor Wat, Bayon's multiple temples are quite distinctive and the close proximity to Angkor Wat allows the visitor to include a visit both on the same day .

A Favourite. This temple with its many faces was a favourite of our family. We visited this first thing in the morning (at 6:30) to beat the crowds and the heat. We went with a guide and it was worth it. He pointed out so many things along the long carved wall at the beginning that we would have missed otherwise.
Worth the time... This is the temple with 200 (or so) faces. Its worth a visit, most guided day tours take you there after Angkor Wat, or you can explore on your own.
different. Steps and steps - need a good guide - after Angkor Wat worth visiting for a smaller temple with interesting twists.
Stunning . Collision of history and nature, I spent a few hours here. It is crowded, but worth it. Be mindful in this space, explore, and open your eyes.

As good as Angkor Wat. This is obviously somewhat smaller than Angkor Wat, but nonetheless, just as interesting, and probably prettier, and certainly less.crowded. We had a guide, and we would have missed so much if we had done it on our own. 45 minutes is all that is required to have a thorough visit here.
Too crowded and a temple too far. A favourite to visit after sunrise at Anghor Watt and it is a temple too far. Our advice is to visit this as a separate half day trip to get the most out of it.

A must see if you have seen the silver fig "strangling" the temple entrance.. A lot of walking but fascinating to see how the jungle had taken over the temples. Very uneven terrain but well worth the trip.

Four different views to the world.. This is the site where the temples have Budda faces facing in NSWE directions. It is unbelievable to see and definitely worth the visit. Great site to wander around.
A must visit. To be in this area and not visit this site would be crazy. A wonderful place with faces looking out at your from history

Amazing place. Before visiting any of the holy sites and palaces in Siem Reap, we recommend going first to the National Museum to get a good overview of the history, religion and culture that provides the backdrop to appreciating the sights more.

One of my favourite temples to see. Wear trainers as steps are steep and health and safety a bit lacking ! However, this temple is stunning. Loved the beauty in the Buddha faces. We had a guide with us which is totally worth it as you then learn the known history behind all the temples. We managed 3 temples in one day - Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm and this one. We had a tuk tuk driver with a cool box full of water for us which you need in these temperatures. Take an umbrella as this is so useful for giving you a bit of shade from the sun. You buy your ticket to enter the temple area before you go in a brand new building just on the outskirts. All the hotels will tell you how to do this.

More impressive than Angkor Wat !. We love all the galleries of bas-reliefs and intricate carved stones. .It is surrounded by forested areas and amazing tall trees. You can take a walk through a maze of walk ways to enjoy this incredible site.

Spectacular Place to visit. This is Magnificent Bayon Temple has Intricate stone carving I have seen. Spectacular Place to visit. I was fortunate to visit Bayon Temple during the end of January when the weather was not too hot. The entrance to this temple is grand and there is always a story for each stone carvings mostly related to Hindu religion. During my visit there were not too many tourists and so it was easy for me to go around taking photographs. If you visit this place you will find out it will be one of your most memorable site.

look stone in the eyes. One of the main temples. Climbing, and walking between huge stone faces is a particular experience. Try to find a moment without too much people otherwise it is difficult to circulate. May be in the late afternoon when shadows plays with profiles?
No words . Every temple you see you think wow there can't be any more beautiful...and then you get to the next one.The work and detail is just other worldly
Fantastic. Fascinating place and in many ways more interesting and fun to visit than Angkor Wat, though you must do both. Far less crowded buy great photo opportunities with all the faces.

Our favourite of the temples. What an amazing place! Having walked around Angkor Wat for 4 hours the previous day in the beating sun I was not quite as enthused at the thought of a whole day's guided tour of the so called 'lesser' temples.However this place totally blew me away. It's hard to describe the intricacies of the site, just make sure if there's one temple you must visit it's this one.

Great photo opportunities of this Smiling Faces Temple. Apart from Angkor Wat, Bayon temple is another 'must see' temple as the giant smiling faces offer the most spectacular and unique examples of the Angkorian architecture.There a lots of steps to climb and at a certain area, tourist with proper attire (blouse/shirt with no expose shoulder and knee length pants/skirt) are only allow to go in. Lots of walking so it's good to wear a good pair of sports shoes rather than sandal as the ground area is full of red sand and dust due to its very hot and dry weather.
Human faces etched on stone. Very interesting sculpture of human faces etched by human hands on huge stones as part of the temple.

awesome. I loved this temple more that Ankor Watt. Much smaller so not so many tourists and it has a really awesome atmosphere. It was wonderful to wander along the small corridors and see the amazingly preserved bass reliefs

Favorite temple. Our whole family loved this temple. There were so many unique perspectives there. Our guide from Angkor Sam Tours showed us all of the great photo ops, and we took the touristy nose to nose pictures with the faces. :-) A very unique temple!

My favourite by far. The faces of Budah have presence and give this place an energy all of its own.. So as you arrive this place feels different. Its set right within the trees and kind of feels compact even though it's still huge. You climb into the grounds it just feels beautiful, then up quite steep stairs to the top of the tower. Surrounded by all the Buddha faces this temple has an energy and presence unlike the others. Time again, given the compact nature, the temple felt quite crowded so I would have probably tackled this a little earlier in the day. But I would never miss this one... must see in my eyes!

Almost ruined but worth it. Great views. We walked and explore the whole temple. Most statues were almost ruined, sadly.What I uave read and saw in National Georgraphic were true. Those stones were crafted block by block and become a perfect piece.Awesome!
I want to visit again on a SUNRISE or SUNSET! PLEASE !. It was a very nice ruins, I hope they could conserve it properly for all the future generations to witness its wonder. Nice one Siem Reap!

Amazing Faces and Photographic Opportunity. Great temple to visit as well preserved and there is room to move with heaps of photo opportunities, challenging steps to the top - so take care. I watched others take the climb. Elephants will take you around this area - however at 42 degrees this would seem inhumane.
Excellent. Some great sculptures of the Bayon Heads. It is both an intriguing and charismatic place to visit. A great experience.

Best temple there! . One of the most unique temples at the Angkor complex! Really cool 360 degree face carvings and makes for great photos! Only tip I have is to go really early so that you can get pictures and enjoy the architecture without tons or tourists in the background.
must visit. really worth a visit we visited as part of a cycle tour it was a hot day so remember your hat and water, go with a guide otherwise you will not get enough out of the visit

Words can't describe it. One of the most marvelous places you will ever go to. The place is serene and quiet. Even with all the crowds around, you will feel as if you are at a beach meditating. Bayon is included in all the tours you will take for Angkor Wat. Do not miss this one.

AMAZING! I recommend doing it last (see tip if not doing guided tour). This is my favorite of the Angkor sites and is truly amazing (not that the others aren't, each in their own unique way). Though I've seen it recommended to start with Bayon, I have done it both ways and preferred the entire Angkor experience seeing this site last (doing Angkor Wat first when having a 3 day pass). If you do not get a guided tour, the cool thing to see and do here is to aline oneself with the various faces and if you are traveling with someone else to get them to do a shot of your nose lining up (touching tip to tip) with that of one of the carvings (both you and the carving in profile view). They make for some very cool pictures.

The bayon temple. The bayon temple in Angkor thom was an incredible experience. The temple is one of the most striking and unique temples in the whole of the Angkor archaeological park, the building features hundreds of smiling faces around an imposing central tower. The temple's history was very interesting with the temple being very mysterious in it's use and symbolism. Bayon is definitely a must do If you are in the area, highly recommended.
Such beauty.... As part of the Angkor complex, this is a different style, definitely worth a long walk around, explore all it has to offer!
Wonderful. A must see, it's part of the angkorwat experience. Rest of the details same as mentioned in my Angkorwat experience

Spectacular!. Bayon Temple is a fascinating temple with many faces on each stupa, apparently of the same King! What a vain man he must have been, although he did appear to be quite a happy chap! It is a must see when in Siem Reap, Bayon is smaller than Angkor Wat but completely different. The huge carved stone faces are incredibly beautiful and intricate for their size.

Our guides favorite spot. Again our guide was AWESOME! This was our first stop and he clearly loved it the most. We got lucky and there was one elephant left and we were able to ride an elephant into the temple site. Felt like Indiana Jones! The faces in this temple are incredible. Our guide taught us so much and pointed out so many neat features. We spent half the day there and it was worth it! Of course I think our guide was a big reason why.

Incredible faces!. Bayon Temple in the Angkor Archaeological Park is wondrous!There are LOADS of steps so it's not suitable for anyone who isn't sure-footed, possibly including very young children. There are various places where you can stand to see many different profiles of the massive stone-carved faces at the same time, and a couple of places where you can stand to pose and appear "nose to nose" with one of the faces. Elephant rides are available outside the temple, but the elephants look to be in poor condition with obvious elephant hook sores on them. Various locals I spoke to said they didn't endorse tourists riding the elephants because of the cruel methods used to "train" the animals. Take water - all those steps in the sun makes for a VERY hot day, but well worth it!

Very Interesting place, and amazing view. Only there are way too many tourist now. Would definitely recommend to go and walk around, but if possible, do a early or late trip there, so that you can avoid the crowd. I walked around for about half an hour, but once you get up there where all the "Heads" are, there were SO many people there, making it hard to move around with the limited space, and not to mention viewing it in more detail or taking a decent pictures. But overall, a very interesting place with great history, but pick your time to visit carefully.

Rise and Shine. Get up early and get there early - around 7am. There will be few people around and what little wild life there is in the area, will be out. It's nice getting lost in the small rooms at the bottom of the Wat and good photo opportunities up top, when the crowds are still at their hotels eating breakfast. Bayon is on what the locals call the "short route". You should be able to hire a TukTuk for 1/2 day for about $12USD. We were able to see Bayon and surrounding temples, as well as Ta Prohm before 12 noon, when the temp becomes unbearable.

Interesting temple to check out. Worth checking this temple out, rich history. Worth getting a tour, there was someone there leading brief tours for donations. The tours are worth while unless you are already knowledgeable about the temples. They provide a bit of clarity to what you may not be able to understand on your own.
Another amazing sight!. Again visited with our guide who explained everything about the history of this temple.It was extremely hot that day but our guide made sure we stayed out of the heat
Fantastic. Once again I visited the Bayon Temple. The same mystic presence, as the first time. A must visit place on your tour of Siem Reap. Great for photographers.
So many faces!. We loved this temple. At first we thought the faces carved into the stone were the same, but they weren't?! My favorite!

Surreal. I felt a little like I was in a movie set, after seeing so many documentaries on the Cambodian temples, it was surreal being there. This was probably the most crowded temple I had attended, but it did not diminish the experience. If you are able to visit the shrine on the second/third level inside, do so, it sent me back hundreds of years ago. Beautiful.
Fab detail. Again go on a dry day but get there early to avoid crowds and heat. Lots of detail on the architecture and also quite shady.
Don't Stop With Just Angkor. Angkor Wat was great but the Bayon Temple was spectacular and not to be missed. There are so many temples in Siem Reap but we were overwhelmed by the beauty of Bayon.

On a par with Ankhor Wot. There are hundreds of faces carved into the towers of this temple, each with different features. The entrance to the complex is also guarded by an avenue of heads on both sides of the road also all different.
Fabulous. Lots of temples to see, however each one is different in its own way. Don't miss the royal enclosure and famous Terraces of the Elephants and the Leper King. Set in lovely surroundings.
Wonders of Angkor Wat. One of the wonders of the world you must go out of your way to visit for the whole family, a real eye opener & experience.

Interesting site -. This temple is worth seeing if only because it's quite different from other temples and really quite interesting, especially when you get to the top and are surrounded by several peaks of four faces!
Stunning!. One of the best temples at Angkor, get a guide which will help understand the history. It was extremely hot in March so take plenty of water as you can't buy it easily.
Picture perfect. This place is AMAZING and a definite stop on any temple itinerary. The faces are mezmerizing and will leave you in awe.

Best in early morning. We went at 7am when it first opens and had the place to ourselves. Little to no crowds while everyone was at Angkor Wat. If you want a peaceful experience, the morning is the best time.

At first glance a, not impressive, but get closer and wow!. Looking from the road, this site is large but not as impressive as expected. However as you get close you can see the many towers , with faces carved on each. The carvings are all ancient done but seem to done in a pattern so that you can get many in the same picture. It is an amazing site, much larger than it looks and would be my second favourite temple in the Angkor Wat area.On the way back to the road and the car, look up in the tree and you may see a monkey as we did.A guide will help you to better understand the site , its meanings , and bring you nose to nose with the face carvings.An attraction pass for all temples is $20 US per day, but to get an early start get your pass late in the day before and you can use it for sunset and also the next day

One of my Favorites. Bayon Temple was the first temple we visited on our trip! Even after seeing 8 temples total, I would say this one stood out as one of my favorites, if not my absolute favorite. It's hard to compare them, honestly, but Bayon was just striking. There are incredible carvings of faces throughout the temple; it's a bit maze-like, stay with your group! We had a small mishap where we split up, and it was a bit difficult to find each other (even though it's not terribly large).Do not skip this temple! You will regret it. As with all of the temples, if you visit when it is hot, do not forget water, sunscreen, etc. The heat is powerful, especially if you're not used to it.
Fantastic!. The temple is unbelievable and so grand. You also can see some monkeys taking a walk around the ruins. Just beautiful.

beautiful. In awe of the site. Beautiful location and lots of exploring to be done. Wear comfy shoes and dress appropriately as otherwise you wont get in to all the temples on the site. Watch out for mozzies.

Amazing. Wish we'd had more time.. Saw some elephant rides. First temple we saw and it did not disappoint. Wow and Wow. It was 40 degrees on the day we were there. Very hot. Take water and wear loose clothing.
amazing. it is one of the most amazing temples in cambodia. After the angor wat, you should visit bayon temple but be attention for the rainy days
Beautiful place hidden areas.. I felt like Indiana Jones, you are able to walk around in and find hidden rooms and areas.Very easy to find and a good location to get to other sights.
A beautiful temple. This temple was very busy by the time we got here but you could still get photos without any other tourists in them. A great one to visit on your tours.
The centre of Angkor Thom and wonderful. The whole site is huge and Bayon in its centre is lovely. A must see for its multiple Buddha faces. A tour guide add an extra dimension and understanding.
Amazing. This is my favorite temple. Even though Angkor Wat is the biggest, the architecture of the Bayon temple is unique and therefore should not be missed.

Amazing Heads. The craftsmanship and imagery at Bayon makes it one of the standouts of the Angkor complex. The juxtaposition of the heads against the surrounding forest/jungle transports you to another place in time.
Unbelievable . Fantastic historical sites they have to be seen to take in the wonder. Carvings are amazing & all done by hand centuries ago. This was my favourite of the temples.
Smile of Khmel. Quite different to Ankgor Wat, with many interesting face carvings. But less well preserved. Having a guide will make the visit more interesting.
Nice place to visit besides Angkor Wat. Other than Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm, this is also an interesting site to visit with lots of budda faces and also elephant rides on site.

Fantastic Faces. This temple was fantastic. The skills that were needed to carve the faces on so many columns is beyond belief. This is a temple that has been partially renovated so is very different from Wat. Went around lunchtime and it was not that crowded so that was a bonus. The huge Budda statue across the road was wonderful and was decorated as there had been a festival the day before. Saw a lot of elephants walking along, what a shame they weren't in their natural habitat. Also saw a stupid woman feeding the monkeys despite all the signs.

Great historical structure remains ruined. The temple is in dilapidated status. Still the remains shows the greatness of the architecture. It is better to visit during morning or evening hours to have better view / picture of the temple.
Love the 4 headed statues. You cant get up close with it. Pretty much outter wall only to take pics. Nothing much to see here but the 4 headed statues
Great temple!. The temple is what we nerver felling about before. Huge temple we never been befor. Amazing head of budda. Temple that we must visit in life. Beautiful @!

Go Late In The Day. Lots of tourists go here, but if you go later in the day, there won't be quite so many of them AND the light will be great for catching great photos of the faces. Stand in the right place and they'll be kissing.....

Mind Blowing. There is so much to see and to photograph that you must leave at least two hours to do the job. If you leave early you will be disappointed. The carvings are magnificent. You will not put your camera down..
Impressive temple. Worth a visit when at Ankor Thom. Huge temple. Easy to climb but probably most impressive from the entrance looking at the massive structure

Awesome Bayon Faces !. Wonderful ! Lofty ideas, superb architecture and noble thinking. I just wonder and think of those great architects who constructed it. Perhaps more refined than the Moai 's of Rapa Nui ( Easter Island ).
A Buddhist Temple. another attractive place to visit besides the Angkor Wat. fascinating carvings on the wall at the entrance as well as ancient carvings on the pillars inside.
Even better than Angkor Wat. Even though Angkor Wat is a truly spectacular site, Bayon impressed me even more with its rugged beauty surounded by the jungle - almost too beautiful to grasp.

Stunning. After seeing Angkor Wat, we saw a few more temples. Thankfully, Bayon was one that we chose to see. We were greeted by monkeys on the way, which was fun, but when you get to the temple itself, it truly is breath-taking. Much quieter than Angkor Wat but much more intimate. We had a guide, which was helpful, but it would have been enjoyable without him, regardless. It isn't the most shaded temple on the site, so I would recommend you to invest in a hand fan!

Gets busy early!. After visiting Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm, wee found the Bayon Temple very busy with many tour groups having just arrived (just after 8.30am), we drove past an hour earlier and it was empty so arrive early for a quieter experience.At both of the other temples we visited, we found there to be a significant amount of restoration work being under taken which somewhat ruins the picturesque images of the temples, at the Bayon however, there was none of this. Also there appear to be less regulations at the Bayon with more areas you can climb to get different perspective.
Beautiful . The four faces are really cool. Enjoy this temple while you have the temple pass. Kids 11 and under see free if you have their passport.

Stunning. I think this was my favourite of the temples. Built by Jayavarman 7th it was originally for Buddha.It is in the centre of the Angkor Thom city and represents the intersection of heaven and earth. There are wonderful carved heads many with an enigmatic smile. It is hot and there are a few steep steps so take some water.
great temple.. This is a great temple we liked. We saw many temples in siem reap but we love this than other we had lots pictures with this temple.
Buddha - The Many Faces. First temple we visited in the Angkor complex and it is mind-blowing. The scale and complexity together with the beauty make this a must see.

Day trip. It just liked in the Tomb Raider the film. I was quite excited, pretending I'm Lora;) Such beautiful place should be properly protected! I've asked our driver that why on earth your guys could ever leave these kinds of grand architecture behind. He told me that there were wars between Thais and Khmers. The city was changing hands few times and they moved the capital to the current one and left Siam Reap in jungles' mercy. My childhood question was answered and I love peace more!
Nice sight. After visiting half a dozen of these ruins, beginning to feel the same.Still, had the feeling of grandeur walking through if you imagine of its original structure at its hayday.

Great Temple!. Quite a lot of climbing to do here. We agreed for a tour at the temple itself from a government guide for $11USD after much haggling. However the guide overshot the time and kept asking for $18USD as we took about 1.5 hours. The tour wasn't that superb, not really worth the money.Try navigating the temples yourself, a much better time on the whole I would say.

Beyond amazing!. Each Temple in Siem Reap has different characteristics. I must say this is one of the top 3. It will take maybe an hour to explore. I love it! I am so happy I get to experience this place as it is really a fantastic place.

Great architecture. Great views, amazing pictures could be taken.
Big place and will be very entertaining. Lots of faces

Bayon. Bayon Temple at Angkor Thom is an absolute 'must see' when visiting the complex at Angkor Wat. During peak season very busy and you will always have 'company' in your photos. It is great that the site is interactive and fairly safe walkways help you through. Hot, tiring and don't forget the water!!

Faces watching you. This is the famous temple where the towers have enigmatic faces on each of four sides. It can be very busy so try and go early in the day to be sure to take memorable photos without being jostled by selfie sticks. A very peaceful place despite its many visitors.
A Must See!. Bayon was one of my favorite temple out of the 14 I visited in 3 days (within Angkor Park)! 52 towers (216 faces) amazingly awesome!
just amazing. different to angkor wat but just as breath taking - a must to see, do the sunrise tour as these temples got very hot
Its worth. I prefer to be around Angkor Wat, but there are other interesting temples to visit..its worth to rent a bike e see all of then..

Striking images. This is the temple with the faces and visiting, especially to the top level, is one of the most remarkable experiences I've had in the world. There is so much character to this temple. Because the faces are so large and life-like, it's almost like meeting someone from 1,000 years ago in person.
The best!!. A wonderful site. Make sure that you make the effort to climb the rather steep stairs to go to the upper level when you can walk among the carved heads.

Wow!. Amazing, you have to see this to believe it.. I liked the ambience of This temple. Need to be firm but kind with local market types pushing you to buy books, hats etc etc. nearby toilets were spotless.
Crazy busy. Beautiful site, but barely any space to stand or move. We came back a few times, but each time was busy. If you go before 9am you'll need torches if it is overcast.

kissing Budha. This Temple is famous with kissing Budha picture..all tourists try to take very good angle to do so..it's quite interesting to see ;-) for me, i'd prefer to take picture from the outside of the Temple..
Very different from Angkor Wat. I had a personal tour guide who was very helpful in explaining the history of the temple. She also helped me take pictures of the area with me in them.
Faces of da previous kings on da towers. :). One of my faves in Angkor Wat. A must go if you are into da Khmer Culture and history. Great places for photography as well.
Like being Indiana Jones. Take good hiking boots as you'll be climbing over rocks and rumble which adds to the overall awesomeness of this site and the beauty it bestows upon you forever!

Inspiring. This is another one of the great temples at Angkor. The sensation you get from being around the 54 smiling Bayon faces is very inspiring. Also a great photo opportunity. If you like photos, make sure to change out lenses (utrawide, marco) while touring this temple.
First stop. Best to see this temple first, it shows more of the growth that covered the Angkor Wat area. Be sure to approach from the east gate to see the trees first.

Jungle Temple in March. We visited Ankor Watt, Ankor Thom and Bayon Temple in one day, what can I say that hasn't been said 1000's of times before AMAZING. Being late March and very hot humid and a little dusty didn't dampen our enthusiasm, if you can handle the heat the advantage is there are many less tourist so easier to get around, see everything and get photo's without a million random sin them. We arranged our tours through Exo Travel and while this may have cost a bit more than getting a Tuk Tuk and a local guide, we would highly recommend their services, the information provided by our guide Mr Som was informative and entertaining, not only about the structures but also about Cambodian history within this part of Asia and where and how all of these Temples were placed within this history. One of the best things was having a driver that met you at the end of each tour with a cold towel and an ice cold bottle of water. Another bonus with local knowledge was the guidance about how to avoid getting harassed by some of the locals. Do your self a favour and pay a bit extra you'll be glad you did..

A MUST SEE, together with Angkor Wat and Ta Phrom. Bayon Temple, the Temple with all the faces, is a must see when you are travelling in Angkor Wat. You can get really close to the sculptures and enjoy a wonderful view.
Amazing. Another beautiful temple that is so rich with history! Amazing architecture! Another must see if in Siem Reap!

In reasonable condition but that's about it.. Looked good from the outside, while a fair jumble of fallen down lumps of rock on the inside and the odd Monkey crawling around, who was posing for the cameras but get to close and he tried to take whatever from you!
Another great temple. Not to be missed, this was our favourite of all the temples and we were in awe of all the huge carved faces. A photographer's dream
Truly amazing. This was one of my favourite Temples. So much history. Guide from IOT was very knowledgeable on the entire tour, this temple and many others(Joe).
Another awesome. History abounds. Go early in the day the crowds and heat get thick. Go with a good guide it makes all the difference. Don't miss this temple.
Beautiful. This temple was very busy but still very beautiful to see . Angkor has so much to offer :) it's a must see place
Our favorite temple!!. Don't miss this!! We rented bicycles to tour this and Angkor Wat!! We'd like to return during the rainy season!!

So glad our guide encouraged this stop.. We were a bit hot and tired, but after a rest, great lunch of Amok with fish curry (yum!), iced coffee and lemon tea we went on. So cool, many great photo ops recommended by our awesome tour guide Mr. Teav Kimsan.
Incredible. A photographer's dream. So much to see and so much history attached. Made me want to do more research on my return home.
Majestic temple. Although much smaller in size than say Angkor Wat, the architecture is just as stunning especially up close

The most recent of the temples. This most recent of the temples is still nearly a century old. The carvings and bas reliefs are spectacular! The view from the upper level is certainly worth the climb. Every temple near Seim Reap is different for the others.
So much detail. Less well preserved than Angkor Wat but still worth a visit to see the magnificent friezes around the walls.

Bayon Temple aka Smiling Temple. Bayon temple is known as the smiling temple because the Budha faces are all smiling which is pretty unique. Great place to stop over for a couple of hours for some photos etc. There isnt as much to see as at Ankor Wat.
Speechless.. It was so beautiful. Sad that it was our last stop to visit among the temples and we were very tired but this place is a must see. AMAZING!!
This one is equally as amazing as Angkor Wat. Another large site not to be missed. The carvings are amazing and it is located quite close to Siem Reip.
Breathtakingly beautiful. A must visit temple with great opportunities for good photos against a clear blue sky. Spend time walking around to admire the carvings.

You'll be smiling here too!. This was tied for my favorite temple along with Ta Phrom. The faces are incredible and there are so many spots where you can see a line of smiles. We were lucky enough to see a team of Japanese restorationists with a 3D imaging robot, which was pretty cool. Definitely a must see!
Dom & Judy traveling around Cambodia. What a great trip I would like to go back in the wet season when things are green what a great place so large I enjoyed it more than Machup Picchu

So many faces carved. Bayon temple seems from afar nothing more than a huge collection of stones. How closer you are how more it gains to its shaped. The first temple we visited on our first day in Angkor. Bayon, after Angkor Wat one of the larger Angkor temples. The structure was created in the twelfth century and is a must-see for everyone. Bayon and around is remarkable that is not surrounded by a wall, but by open arcadesThe most characteristic of this famous temple is the multitude of towers with the faces looking in the four directions. Due to its exuberant carving this temple is considered one of the most important of Angkor. There are two entrance and exit. Try to start a side and go clockwise.
Took my breath away. This was by far my most favourite temple. I absolutely LOVED it. It's just incredible to see the detail up close. Get a guide, it is well worth the history lesson.

Spoilt for delights. Another fantastic example of some amazing sculptural architecture though if we'd arrived at a less busy time we might have been able to enjoy it more. Like most sights around here timing is crucial in your enjoyment away from the masses.
history vist. As this one was best to do first for all the crowds stop at the ANGKOR WAT FIRST, you get a easy walk and inspection as you follow the elephant terrace, & terrace of the Leper King

Interesting Structures. Amazing structures. Must see but preferably on your on pace to absorb the history. There is nothing more astonishing to absorb. Sad how some of the structures are falling but reconstruction is upheld.
My favorite temple in Siem Reap. Gorgeous! Go early to beat the crowded. This was by far my favorite Temple in Siem Reap. Hire a guide, the rich history needs to be explained.

Interesting Site. Very interesting site. We loved going through it!
A monkey outside this temple accosted me for a drink of my smoothie! Surprising, yet interesting interaction. And no, he didn't get it!

Good place to find a quiet corner for meditation and rest after the main event.. Built in a different era, it is significant for the huge faces carved into the laterite which was used as building blocks, with a rougher exterior finish.

Amazing. The unique feature of this temple is the large stone faces everywhere. There were also some amazing reliefs around the outside walls depicting various scenes from everyday life. I had always wanted to go to Angkor wat and had not appreciated the number and variety of other temples. It is an amazing site and can only be fully appreciated in person. We had a private guide who we had through booking our holiday with TrailFinders, but there are plenty of official guides you could book with over there and it does add a lot to the tour, so is worth doing. We did all of the main sites in 1 day, but you could easily spread this across 2 or 3 days if you wanted to take it a bit slower and wander around some of the smaller sites. This is one day that will stay with me for a long time.
crowded but worth a visit. beautiful temple buildings. Crowded when I was there late morning. Only needs about 30 mins for a visit.

Bayon - Temple heads. Bayon was our second day around the AW complex, & to my surprise was completely different to AW itself.The beatific smiles & scale of the heads gives the whole place a more human atmosphere somehow?This is the place NOT to miss if you come to AW.

A Mysterious Place with a lot of Tourists. It's nice to just look and be amazed by all the structures and faces there. There were a lot of loud people when we were there though so it kind of lessened the "mystery" of the place.
Amazing!!. My family and I love this place. We had a great time. Every visit we had around here was worth it. I really recommend this place.
Another amazing temple. Not all the temples are the same, so you must visit them all. They are so amazing. Take your time and enjoy them all. Don't ry to do it all in one day.

Amazing Buddhist temple!. This was my favorite. The energy here, and the Buddhist faces everywhere were beautiful. A lot of walk ways to explore before moving to the top where there's a central point with a sitting Buddha. Everywhere you look are Buddha faces looking back at you. But, beautifully doing so, not at all spooky. Such peace and quiet as well.

Majestic Temple within Angkor Thom. The majestic temple complex with the smiling Buddha faces cannot be missed.
Make this part of your itinerary when you visit Angkor

Mysterious. An impressive long bridge with statues leads over the moat to this magnificent temple, with giant faces on every tower, at every angle, representing Buddha? the Khmer king who built it? No-one is sure.
Worth visiting. Another stop on our visit to the temples of Angkor. The faces add a certain personality. Very different from Angkor Wat but equally as spectacular. This was my husband's favourite.

Absolutely fascinating. Walking around in amazement at how old these temples are and what the people before you would have experienced. Found the history amazing and the sights fascinating. Would highly recommend a walk around

One of the 3 most beautiful temple of Ankor Wat. Its one of the 3 most bneautiful temples of Ankor Wat ...If you dont have much time, this one you have to see and you cxan take many spectacular pics ...

The Peoples Temple. Smile and smile again: there are 216 smiling Buddha-like carved faces, all the same on the towers. Some say they bear a great likeness to the king who built it for his people in the city of Angkor Thom. The carvings in the portico at the entrance are good. One gets a feel as one goes around and up that the place was more homely than its neighbour Angkor Wat. On the "roof" pose for your photo beneath the smiling faces and do smile!
Mythical, grand, beauty. One if many temples in this part of the world, Bayon is smaller but has an awesome ancient look to it. This temple is certainly worth to be included on your list!

A magical place. No question ALL of the temples in the Angkor complex are amazing, but for me there was something just a little bit more special about Bayon. Perhaps it was being there at the end of the day, with golden hour light and less crowds? Perhaps it's smiling buddhas at every turn you make?Whatever the reason, I just found it to feel a little more "warm & Fuzzy" than the other temples and found it to be very peaceful and picturesque. I would definitely recommend going in the last 90 minutes of the day, as I was told that the big Chinese tour groups generally go in the mornings.

Spectacular details out & inside the temple. We hired a guide for three days to visit all the temples. A three day pass cost $ 40.00 US. The whole complex at Anchor Thom is worth visiting especially with a guide. It gives you a way better inside look and storyfromt this ancient temple and complex.
Fantastic. Another favorite place in Siem Reap. It is amazing what people hundreds of years ago were able to build. It's a must!

Impressive. This is one of my favorites due to the enigmatic faces that look at you from ever possible angle; some are on top of huge towers and some are jsut in front of you; face to face. Also the structur of the temple is impressive with still 50 of the original 54 towers remaining.
Really quite extraordinary. Bucket list ticked.. As part of the tour of Angkor Wat, best time to go is very early in the morning before the crowds and before the heat.
My second favourite!. Terrific scene! Amazing craved faces! Not much time to spend there, but it is a must! Massive faces, all over! Great for photos!
Smile of Angkor. I personally like this temple more that the Angkor wat. The smiling faces curved in the stones made this temple will make you smile ............. :-)

Bayon temple. Bayon temple was probably my favourite temple, in saying that I had waited over 35 years to visit Angkor wat , bayon temple is a smaller temple , and with a good informative guide you get a better look into the history, and the way life was lived over 600 hundred years ago, when talking with the local people, this temple seamed to be there favourite, so I will always go with local knowledge.

One of my favorite stops in the archeological park. Bayon temple is really cool. It's more ornate than the others we visited. It has a lot of towers and corners to explore despite a relatively compact size. Get a good guide and spend some time being enchanted by Bayon.
Busy but impressive. Another site you have to see if in Siem Reap. Quite a lot of steep steps to climb so beware if your balance is not so good.

Compact temple to visit and appreciate Hindu creation story and history. We visited this temple last, which by then we had a good idea of the chronology of events and the Khmer history. All of those stories (mythical and historical) could be gleaned from the carvings on its wall. The temple is compact (not as big as Angkor Wat) yet offers a lot of story to uncover. Our advice is to visit the Angkor National Museum before going to this temple.
Fascinating. It is a fascinating place to visit, there are lots of temples in the area and you can get "templed out" but this is one of the best.

AMAZING. Bayon Temple is another amazing temple in the Angkor. This is quite small and can be covered in about an hour or so for admiring and photographing the face towers and intricate stone carving depicting Hindu religion.The crowd is less here. A must see historical place

Beautiful temple complex: in its natural state.. This temple complex is wonderful in its natural state. When I arrived on mid-March 2016 morning, there was a traffic jam to get through the main entrance gate. Cars and tuk-tuks and motorcycles were trying to get in. In addition there were many people on foot taking pictures of the same iconic images on the entrance gate.So, in order to comply with tripadvisor.com guidelines, I will temper my opinions reluctantly: The "selfie" culture, along with the annoying "YOLO" ethic has interfered with the quiet, authentic experience of travel to Angkor---as well as many other places on this earth!Bayon is beautiful! I had to wait in line to walk through the interior passages because people were taking photos of every angle and edifice of the site. Not happy!Bayon is great! "The Bucket list" is tiresome. This ethic, promoting the idea that travel is something you do to brag about and check of places is quite tiresome.The faces of Bayon are the primary attraction and I think are now becoming the face of the Angkor experience, rather than the main Angkor site and the sunrise over the towers. (BTW, the sunrise over Angkor is underwhelming and not "the most amazing thing ever", or even a "must do" as many reviewers note. If you don't feel like getting up early on your vacation, don't do it.)

My favorite amongst the temples I visited. The Bayon temple struck me as the most beautiful among all temples. The faces of Buddha were made perfectly. Monkeys and tourists alike are visiting the temple. Best photos can be taken here.
The best place for visit. I like this temple, not too big but many things to see, not far from Angkor Wat only 10 minutes driving.
Must visit. If angkor wat is first on your list, Bayon should be the second. The 200+ Buddha faces seemed to be watching you as you tour this temple. Amazed!
Must see place. This temple is one of tge best during our three day temple trip. Need not climb very high and have lots of photo spots.

Beautiful temple - faces on the walls. Just when you think you've seen enough temples, there is Bayon Temple. With beautiful faces on the walls of the temple, it is not only a marvel but beautiful to walk around. It was worth the visit for the stunning photos we took.
Prepare to climb. Beautiful and peaceful temple. Pretty steep climb, but worth it to go to the top. Ensure you have a good guide for the Angkor temples.
Another great tsmple. This temple was built in a different century and style to Angkor Wat. The differences are fascinating but you will need a good guide to fully appreciate the temple
Must see!. This was, by far, my favorite temple to see. Seeing all the carved faces was amazing! We even brought home a gold-plated picture of a Bayon face from Angkor Artisans.

Amazing. Another amazing temple. This one is quite small and extremely popular, with hundreds of "faces" and some great views ... Is one is part of the Angkor Thom complex and one of our favourites. Maybe try and visit early before the crowds arrive

Loved the temple except for the crowds. I know it's a pretty facile thing to say but the crowds of people make it truly hard to love this temple. Because the corridors and paths are so small and intimate, having to constantly weave your way around everyone else substantially detracts from the experience. However in a vacuum this temple was easily my favourite from the Ankgor Wat/Thom area for exactly the same reason - the small and cosy corridors leading to fantastic angles and surprises around every corner.

Ancient Ruins in Angkor Thom. This impressive set of ruins sits in the middle of Angkor Thom. Not as well preserved as Angkor Wat but certainly worth the visit. It gives you a better feeling of the massive size of the temple area near Siem Reap.
wow. One of 3 favourite temples for me. Very beautiful, its must see besides angkor wat, ta prohm. Just incredible

My favorite temple out of three visited. This was our second temple visited with Grasshopper bike tour. The design of this temple, the details on the walls, the faces on the towers, the maze... everything there was breath-taking! We were just a bit sad to "run" through the temple with our guide. We would have stayed there much longer.
Awesome !. Allow about 45mins to wander around the temple. Beware though, there are a lot of very steep stirs. If your short of time I would recommend seeing bayon temple and Angor Wat!

Great but crowded . The place is impressive. As other Angkor site it is ruins but still is impressive so it lets us imagine how great it must have been a thousand years ago when all the stones, statues and wooden parts were there ! Sadly it is crowded with tourist so finding the right spot for a picture is a real challenge except if you are a photoshop tourist eraser expert !

This should be at the top of your list with Angkor Wat. We visited twice during our 7 day stay and got lots of great pics each time. One of the most recognizable temples, it has the many iconic Buddha faces carved on its towers.
Super nice. Take a bike and enjoy the temples. It's easy and gives you all the freedom you need. I really enjoyed the view!

Awesome. Bayon Temple is a mini Angkor Wat, but expect to spend 2 to 3 hours exploring the different passages; admiring and photographing the face towers; and marvelling at the intricate stone relief depicting war and everyday scenes of the Khmer kingdom. The giant faces which are said to point in cardinal directions warrant lengthy photo sessions at different angles. If you take a walk around the temple you will see a body of water from which the temple (with its reflection) can be photographed with swans in the foreground. Bayon Temple is truly an unforgettable experience.

Like Easter island temple. The Temples really impressed me cos for me it was the first time to see a four-faced God (according to my tour guide it's not Buddha face). My tour guide explained to me that no one can be sure what God that was whose face was assembled and carved out on blocks of rocks put together. This attraction was crowded with tour groups but it was a worthwhile must visit if you are in Siem reap. Reminds me of the giant head statues of Easter island.
Awe Inspiring. A very different experience than Angkor Wat, but just as incredible. Bayon looks like a pile of rocks from a distance, but up close it is breath taking.

My favourite of the big three. I rated this better than Angkor Wat. I found the carvings on the wall more interesting and clearer to make out especially those depicting everyday life of the time. Chinese gamblers, women giving birth, a turtle biting someone. It seemed the carvers had a sense of playfulness about them. The huge faces were also inspiring and the view early on of the the layers of the temple rising to the tower was breathtaking. It is also less strenuous then Angkor Wat, for those who have some mobility issues or who suffer unbearably in 40 Celsius heat that is fairly typical for this time of the year. My recommendation is that if you have a choice, December is a better time to visit with the rainy season closing and the temperatures much better. In late March the whole place is brown, dusty and very hot, typical weather according to our guide.
A must see!. I really enjoyed Bayon Temple more than Angkor Wat because it is smaller and not as overwhelming. But the architectural work is just as stunning and historically rich. Worth the visit!

Rivals Angkor Wat. We actually both agreed at the end of our visit that the Bayon was our favourite out of all the temples we saw. Absolutely incredible detail and scale, I could never get bored of wandering around.

Second temple to see. Drivers prefer to drive you there right after they pick you up from Angkor. In some ways I found this temple more interesting and with more impressive roof tops and ways to walk. Definitely a must see, don't miss it for nothing.

Family visit. It is a wonderful temple in the world. I have been there for every year with my family. Around the main temple there are other small places the visitors must see or we can ride the elephant walking around the temple.
Temple full of faces. Such a beautiful temple. ..has around 56 towers and a 108 faces... God they are impressiveA must see.. worth the trip to Cambodia
Incredible temple complex. This is a beautiful site, my personal favorite. This temple has numerous ancient faces gazing down on you; faces are both large and small.

dont have words to describe it. i have never ever seen something like that. i went with my husband and we got very surprised!we knew it was going to be wonderful but it was much more of that!!!! we will be back. Come early, from 10 am its full of touristS!

Fantastic and very big. Unbelievable how the people could build a temple like this and many others in the 11th and 12th century. Even though it was very hot it was a great and interesting place to visit with a very knowledgeable tour guide.

Temple of Smiles. I am impressed by this place. I failed to count the faces but I think this is a very interesting place. There is something mysterious on how the faces because probably they have a 'I-know-a-secret-you-do-not-know' smile. I will always remember Bayon when I am asked about Siem Reap. Another thing that I can remember is the four swans enjoying and playing at the pond surrounding this area. If you see them, say hi to them from me.

Even more impressive than Angkor Wat. I visited many temples in the area but Bayon was by far the most stunning. Especially at the end of the afternoon the colours and forms of the towers get a magic touch.
Amazing. Came upon the section of the Temples on our tour of Angkor Wat and Thom, beautiful sculpture, which fascinates the mind. Well worth the visiting this part of the site
Amazing. What a treat to see the level of detail achieved so many years ago. Bring plenty of water and enjoy.

Beautiful temple with many faces. I highly recommend that you visit this temple if you only have an opportunity to see one other one apart from Angkor Wat - try to squeeze it in! You will see many faces looking at you from different parts of the temple - it's not to be missed.
Another impressive Temple. All of these Temples are mind blowing and you just need the time to take it all in and explore and take photos

A visit to Cambodia. Very good place to visit depicting various large sculptures of Buddha. I went there with my family during the day , it was very hot. completely worth to go if you plan in winters.
Stunning . The temple is full of different faces and its faces actually has its meaning on it. I would advise for a traveller to somehow take a lot of pictures in here.

Another must go place in Siem Reao. Like many of the other temples, full of history and great architecture, cannot leave Siem Reap without coming here. Big structures that have deteriorated over time, but still maintain that great look and design that make it a great experience.

Sunrise & sunset are mesmerising. breath-taking beauty during sunrise. if you have love for historical architecture then you you love this place and time will pass in a blink while exploring the whole temple

You cannot imagine such brilliantly executed craft and beauty . Unimaginable!
Such well preserved and significant architecture.
Our adult family group visited in a van with a driver on the short tour from Siem Reap. Could have spent days there but enjoyed a representative sample of the three temples.
Very humbling to have been able to experience such an amazing place
Fascinating . Thoroughly enjoyed the experience, the Bayon Temple was really enjoyable. Really interesting with amazing carvings.
Beautiful. I really didnt reliase how big the ruins are, and how much of an area they cover, be prepared to walk a lot and to be awestruck.

Bayon temple . Love the place. A must see. Come very early before the tourists arrive and the weather is not hot.
Bus loads of tourists come around 8 am and sometimes become unruly and noisy

Really Cool Palace Complex. A visit to this site reveals Chinese and Khmer influences, as well as changes in religious attitudes and allegiances. Large faces on the stones were altered to have closed eyes, reflecting the change from Vedic influences to Buddhist.

Much Better Than Angkor Wat. The faces were amazing, and in much better condition in my mind than Angkor Wat. Be sure to be here for early morning or sunset for best pictures. The contrast is not very good for photos during the high sun.
Same Same but different. A further temple, but different to the others. You can see the different epoch of the Khmer culture.

Magnificent architecture . Another beauty of Cambodia past. It was in high 38 c and not being the fittest i found that after seeing Angkor Wat and this temple I had had enough but did go on to see a 3rd
