A place for elephant rides. I recommend you guys to visit Bayon Temple ;) We went here at noon time so the sun was strikingly hot. Good thing there were bunch of vendors selling icecreams and fruit shakes outside the temple. I bought 2 icecreams for $1, cheap right? Here you could see a lot of buddha's face carved on stones. There was a place where you could offer fruits or stuff you like and light an incenso. When we arrived here, there were tourists riding an elephant. Though we really like to try one we couldn't cause we didn't have much time. I'm not sure how much it cost but I think the ride lasts for 30 mins or so. Outside the temple were small stalls selling souvenirs, etc.
Must see if in Siam Reap. A definite must see in Siam Reap, a city that I fell in love with. Make sure you pay close attention to all the faces around the temples.
Perfect!. There is nothing else to say! It's ahhhhhhmazing. Oh! The bathrooms are really far away - down past the elephant terraces, so plan accordingly!
Fun place to get some fun pix. Go early to avoid the big crowds; make sure you carry water too as it's a very large place to walk around

Fascinating. The level of detail of the Buddha images on the temple are amazing. Plus, the history of the temple is incredible as well. Best toured with a guide to fully understand the building, but still equally inspiring simply to walk around the massive structure and admire its intricacy and elegance.

Must visit to the the Angkor Wat area.. The Bayon area is really easy to visit with plenty of areas to walk through and explore. We visited here first to avoid the early morning crowd at Angkor Wat.
Take your time, explore, reflect and people watch. This is really an impressive place. Plenty of food and drink options available across the road. Elephant rides, too.

A must go. This place is just down the road from Angkor Wat. I believed it's also called the Temple of Thousand Faces. Each of the face here has a different expression of smile. A must go. There's a spot here where you can take picture that align your face with the statue and it seem your nose are touching. Look for the spot when you are here.

Giant, Gentle, Smiling Buddhas Everywhere. Bayon Temple is not as big as Angkor Wat but it has many more smiling buddha faces throughout the temple, and not little ones either, but great big ones.This temple was part of my day tour with a guide. I was very happy to have him showing us around this temple because, like many of the temples in Cambodia, there are elements from both Hindu and Buddhist eras. For example, there was a whole wall that once had held a row of bas-relief buddhas that had been hacked off some time in the past leaving only the flowery outline that surrounds most buddha carvings. But the best part to me was visiting the top level which has buddha faces carved into each tower, 200+ I was told, many of them several meters high. The other good thing about this temple is that none of it was under renovation so were were able to explore everywhere. This is a great place if you want some really great pictures of giant Buddha faces to take home and remind you of your adventures in Siem Reap

Give yourself plenty of time here!. I love Angkor Thom and Bayon and having visited here before I knew to schedule half a day to see everything. WE visited right after seeing sunrise at Angkor Wat and I think this was a great time to visit as it was not busy at all and the morning light made the temple magical

So good I went back for a second look. The Bayon temple was part of a Mega temple tour package but unfortunately, it didn't afford me enough time to marvel at this splendour, so I purchased another day pass on the next day and went back to visit it. I spent 2 hours climbing in an out of this ruin and with the lack of crowds, I had some sections to myself. The temple of faces is definitely worth the visit.
AMAZING. Our favorite of all the temples, spent hours exploring even came back on our second day for another look. Keep a look out for the monkeys that live here.
Faces. This is a temple that you will see the pronounced Khmer lips. You see them on every buddha head and you see them on great scale here.

Peaceful and beautiful. They are working at restoring parts of this temple. The restoration is amazingly precise and you won't know what is old and what is new. Having a walking issue, we went in the back gate and got to see a whole lot on the flat. There were some musicians and ample quiet compared to Ankor Wat.

The highlight of Angkor Thom. Like all of the major sights in the Siem Reap area, Bayon gets exceptionally busy. Unlike Angkor Wat it's also not really big enough to deal with it that well. That being said, it is one of the real must-see temples of the world, with its huge number of haunting faces carved into the rock. Photos of it in the right light can be amazing.

It's like a maze!. I was with my brother and we decided to part ways, I didn't see him for 45 minutes! It was hard to find the exit! Lots of turns and stairs but everything about this place was beautiful. Several carvings were of course, replaced by more modern carvings. I actually enjoyed this temple more than the Angkor Wat temple.

Unreal. Angkor Thom as with all the other temples in Cambodia, are totally unreal. it just doesn't seem possible that at the beginning of the 20th century they were overgrown and lost to the world. Thankfully they are now out in the open for all to see and appreciate, and appreciate them we did. I had seen photos of sculpted heads, but nothing prepared me for the size of these heads - the 4 stones used to make up the face alone are massive. Angkor Thom stayed in my mind as I renamed it Ankle Thom when I slipped and twisted my ankle between the ancient stones What amazed me was when a group of people came to help, They brought me water, and a girl massaged tiger balm into my ankle which made it feel better almost immediately - fantastic people. I loved the place and the people.

Boggling buddhas. Another fascinating temple: astonishing to see so many smiling buddhas at every turn. Look at the friezes, apparently you can tell the power of a general by the number of umbrellas held over him. There are very few inscriptions but look for a particular meditation corner where the name of the important person who meditated there is written.
Highly recommend going here. This is another temple that was part of our private tour and it was simply beautiful. Every aspect of it was unique. We thoroughly enjoyed our tour.
Complex and breathtaking. Bayon is only marginally less impressive than Angkor Wat, the towers with their identical faces are one of the great places in the world

Loved the faces. This is part of Angkor Thom complex. In my opinion Bayan is what makes Angkor Thom so interesting to see. The faces carved into the temple give it a much different feel than any of the other temples.

Near to Angkor Wat, but quite different.. Another very old temple in the Siem Reap vicinity, but quite different from its more famous neighbour, Angkor Wat. This temple features many columns with faces carved onto the four sides. Probably a bit less well-preserved due to the speed of its construction about 1000 years ago, but still plenty of it standing and well worth a look.

Probably the best of the temples. This was the first stop on our tour of the area temples and for me was probably one of the best. It is a very complex temple with some time damage, but once you get into the internal complex it is superb.
Take time to just wander and observe.

Our favourite temple!. A lot of the temples at Angkor have wow factor but Bayon just blows you away. Fabulous faces of Buddha on all the towers. Awesome views as you climb to higher areas. Don't forget to do your tourist shot, nose to nose with Buddha!
Great history and littel secrets. Same as Angkor Wat. You just got to do it. It's practically next door so how could you not. Simply Amazing
Better than Wat. Way better than Angler Wat, awesome edifices and carvings, make plans to spend some time here with your camera or sketch pad

Thought you had seen it all? Well not quite.. It would be easy to think that each of the many temples in the wider Angkor area were all the same - but Bayon offers many different aspects of the beliefs and history of that period.
Incredible!. Amazing, again make sure you have plenty of water a compass and a tuk tuk driver, thank you Mr Chinn!

Our favourite.... Just loved the faces and do not miss the bridge with the figures lining it - that was a wow moment, but be careful as the figures are more intact/ restored at one of the entrances than the other so be sure to check out both.
Wonderful to walk around in!. Didn't bother with a guide here as we had gotten information from the guide we had at Angkor Wat. Amazing these ruins have lasted so long!

Bayon Temple. The ride on the tuk-tuk to the temple area was a wonderful ride through the countryside outside Siem Reap which gave us a good understanding of life outside the city. We enjoyed visiting the temple area and wandering through the myriad of centuries old ruins, characteristic of an earlier civilization. A rich, historical experience.
Amazing architecture.. Hugh temple with so many open rooms to peek in and out, to walk around and climb at some point. Try to make it to the top to see view around

So different to the other temples.. This was possibly my favourite site with it plethora of smiling faces. Also,the carvings on the walls are so well preserved and tell such a vivid set of stories. A must for anyone visiting the Ankgor sites.

Spectacular . Like being in a dream, a totally mind blowing place. I waited many years to see this place and I wasn't disappointed. I took about a thousand photos. Only marred by loudly shouting giant groups of Chinese tourists but there are lots of quiet spots to escape them. Top tip -come as early as you can!
Temple with many faces!. Just right to go around especially when its hot. Interesting. Face of King Javayarman VII all over showing contentment, wisdom & harmony.

Amazing place - Must See. This is one of the place that you must not miss.This is one of the Khmer temple and has many smiling stone faces on the many towers. Haven't counted them all but I believe there are 216 gigantic faces on 75 temple's towers.The temple gets very busy and one has to try and avoid big tourists group to enjoy the place.

Loved it - worth a visit!. Great location and wonderful photo opportunity. Differently worth a look - they claim there corocodiles on the water. You do see the odd local swimming in the water so who knows. The history behind this place is also amazing.
the famos temple. the bayon temples are a part of the temples in siem reap - dont miss the Gallery and a trip on the top of the temple.
stunning place!. I loved it so much!! Prefer this place over Angkor Wat for sure. Again crowds but thats the way it must be I think ;) Going up and down might be challenging for kids and old people!
its very interesting. its amazing place to visit if you like historical,if you need to know more about this place must hire a private tour to explain

AMAZING - one of my dreams fullfilled!. This is definitely one of the most beautiful temples on the archeological temple site of Angkor Wat. It's big, lots of details, just really beautiful. It is a must-see for sure!
Fantastic. Fantastic place! Wear good walking shoes though and take a bottle of water. However, be prepared for the many groups of tourists going through. I would also recommend going with a guide.

Incredible!. For me, this place was in many ways more special than Angkor Wat. I was really moved by the beauty and magnitude of this place! Also the fact that the main Buddha head sculptures are more in your face, allows you to really appreciate them in better detail. Probably my favourite of the "Big 3 or 4"!

It's a ruin but it's beautiful!. The place is really destroyed but there is something beautiful in the caos. You see the faces carveds in the rocks is interesting! You can see all the faces are similar but at the same time You can see they are differents. The differences are really subtle. You should go up stairs!

Amazing Site!. This was an amazing temple! To think people actually carved this gorgeous stone temple thousands of years ago is mind boggling. It was very hot and dusty. If you have trouble with walking or balance this would be tortuous for you. Take water!
Amazing!. Amazing experience to be here. Certainly suggest a tour guide to make this visit more meaningful and worthwhile.
Interesting carvings and great atmosphere. Still undergoing reconstruction and good to explore. Less crowded than Angkor Wat. The stone carvings are very detailed.

small temple but great for a visit. The traffic can be bad in the morning, I'd suggest take tuktuk to Bayon in the morning as my tuktuk driver just drive thru while the van and tourist bus is still in the traffic jam.The reason of the jam is because there is only one way to go in via the South gate, and the gate is very small with only one lane.The temple is really small but pack of tourist in the morning, go slightly late can avoid the crowd but not good lighting for photo shoot.
Another large temple. This temple more important to Cambodian people than the more famous Angkor Wat. We were getting tired so did not climb to higher leval

Another temple. Another part of this massive historical site. Must do. So many stories. Make sure you get a guide or Tuk Tuk driver who can tell you the stories well. We had Mr Pealy. Great driver & service with a welcomed esky :-)
To be done after visiting Angkor wat. Very impressive. This temple is not that far from Angkor wat. It shows the 4 expressions of a same Buddha face.
This is one not to miss. This temple is unique because of the 4 faces on each of the 54 original towers. I believe about 20 have fallen but it was very interesting and well restored.
Amazing. You think all the temple complexes would be the same, but with an excellent guide with superb knowledge, you really enjoy seeing them all. Another great attraction.
Amazing detail. Fascinating temple with the most magnificent carvings telling the entire story of the period . The Buddha face carvings are intriguing. Equally as interesting as Angkor Wat.
Faces of the Buddha: in all directions!. Experience an ancient site where the Buddha smiles serenely from dozens of stone towers. Best times are before 9 am or around sunset.

Bayon is my favorite temple!. What an amazing religious temple in Cambodia!
The multitude of smiling stone faces on the towers make the temple so unique.
The bas reliefs show some historical and mythological events. Simply remarkable!
I've been there twice… and i could have stayed there for days!

Beautiful temple, surrounding area serene. The temple is beautiful. The walls depict not only deities, Kings and battles but also scenes from everyday life of the kmer people, making the visit doubly interesting. The surrounding area is full of trees and was not loud when I visited. A minus is that one can only take a mini bus because the gate to the site is too narrow.

Templing, as I called it.... I have waited a long to time to get to these temples. It's been on my list forever; I should have been here sooner. Unreal and surreal to be in the presence of these glorious temples. All I can say is GO.
The most mysterious temple of Angkor. Bayon is the most mysterious with all of stone heads over there. Quite different of any other temples in Angkor Tom.

Most ornate carvings and not lots of climbing. Very nice intricately carved very photographable temple. There are however hundreds and hundreds of thoughtless mooks there later in the day with their selfie sticks and loud talking in Mandarin/Cantonese.

The faces are amazing!!. Loved the Bayon Temple. Easy to get to by tuk tuk, the whole temple was awesome but the face pillars up the top were just majestic!! You are very close to them so can see details of the carvings very well. We walked around them for ages taking in their beauty. It takes quite a while to see enough of the temple to fully appreciate its intricate carvings , pillars & rooms. A must-not-miss place to see while in Cambodia!

A real highlight with its many beautiful and mysterious faces.. An absolute must to visit and be sure to have plenty of time to walk around and discovering all these amazing faces carved in stone. Best time to visit is between 6-9 am, 12-2 pm and 4-7 pm when there are fewer tourists and guided groups.

Superb. This is smaller than Angkor Wat but equally impressive. A beautiful building with amazingly detailed carved friezes of life at the time of construction, almost 1000 years ago. It's hot - but so worth the visit.
Visit to Bayon Temple. The temple reflects the effort done in past to make such monuments. Each stone, door, carvings are beautiful. Lot of effort though needs for restoration of temple.
part of Angkor Thom. There's a lot to see after entering Angkor Thom. Bayon Temple was my fav, all the huge faces (a fraction of what was originally built)

State temple of Buddhist King Jayavarman VII. We visited the Bayon Temple located in the Angkor Thom complex during November, 2015, as part of a group tour. This was the official state temple of the Mahayana Buddhist King Jayavarman VII, sometime in the late 12th century. This is actually a collection of several temples integrated into one by connecting corridors. It is presently in ruins and in need of restoration.
A must go place. When in Siem Reap, this is one of the must go temples. Less shade around the temple, but the structures are unique and still well defined.
Beautiful. Absolute beauty.... It's really nice just to wander around and get lost in this amazing temple! We stayed for a couple of hours just exploring! Must do in Cambodia!
Breath takig. Don't leave without a visit. Lose yourself in the narrow passages and history of this magnificent temple

Another awesome temple . Yet again,another magnificent temple in the Angkor complex. Brilliant sculptures, amazing structures and attention to detail is second to none. As I mentioned in a review about the Angkor wat temple, words cannot describe, you have to be there to truly appreciate the complexity of the tombs

My favourite spot of all the temples I have seen. We saw many temples in Siem Reap over our 3 day trip. Bayon is my favorite for picture taking. We were there in the second week of March and it was very hot (37C) as the dry season has started. It was still worth it but I may consider coming here from November to February next time when it is less hot.

More than I had expected.. I went early for interesting lighting. Going late should work as well. There are so many towers and angles to see them from. The stairs are excellent but if you can't do stairs the outside is beautiful too.
Another temple complex in Angkor Wat. To understand the immensity of Angkor Wat also go to temples a bit further afar. Some people bike, most hire a tuktuk - that feeds the local families.

Unbelievable experience in the jungle. Amazing structures that speak to a bygone era. Cannot be missed, really among the best of the best. The 216 faces of the king, the faces of the Buddha, who knows?

Great. As beautifull as Angkor Wat......... Just... Beautiful.... Just amazing.....
Worth a visit..... Be ready, gets very hot durring noon...

Smiling Faces. I really enjoyed my visit to Bayon. The huge smiling faces and the passageways were the most memorable features for me.Having a tour guide with me proved to be useful. He was able to take me to the best spots for viewing and photos, whilst explaining the history of the temple.A visit to Bayon can be combined with other temples in the Angkor complex and achieved on the same day.

Great Temple. It was a really good idea to come to this temple before Angkor Wat. This temple, according to the guide, was the centre of the capital of Cambodia in ancient times. With almost 1000 years history you cannot but feel that you are treading upon something legendary.The smiling budhas are everywhere and you can feel the energy of the temple as it used to be.

Quite extraordinary temple.. This temple at the heart of Angkor Thom is extraordinary. The towers and passageways are covered with bass-reliefs and statues which bring an ancient civilisation to life. You need a guide to get the most of your visit, there are few facilities once you start, no signs or explanations. It is meltingly hot, so a half day of Bayon and the rest of Angkor Wat, then a break for a long lunch.

underrated. an underrated temple based on the crowd during my visit there recently. some refurbishment/restoration work was undergoing when i was there, hopefully will add more glory to this temple which can be mistaken as a pile of glorified rocks from afar.
A must place to go.. The Temple is still has so many apsara face on the top of the stupa. The detail of craving are still visible.

More Beautiful than Angkor Wat. We visited Bayon temple on a group tour with other nationalities. I've read in Tripadvisor before that Bayon is more beautiful. It is indeed. The facade itself is prettier than Angkor Wat. My tour group agrees too. We've also climbed up to the top and it is indeed more beautiful. Stones used were indeed of poorer quality than Angkor Wat, hence mostly accounting for its premature destruction

It should be called ruins of Bayon. The entire Bayon temple is in tatters. Most of the part is inaccessible but still it is the most facinating temple in the complex. It is also the largest structure with many parts to be seen. Visit duration should be atleast 2 hours

Really amazing temple. This was really awesome to see first hand. The level of craftsmanship in the carvings was just awe inspiring. I would highly recommend having a guide to take you through the temples so that they can share all of the local history and the meanings behind some of the carvings. It really enhanced my trip and the way I felt about the ruins.

An absolute gem.. This is my favourite temple in Siem Reap. Hands down. Wherever you lay your eyes upon there are smiling faces staring at you. Faces who have been smiling for centuries, even during the darkest times of Cambodia, and will smile forever after. It's a place of peace and you feel it. Walking around and see the smiling faces everywhere is just overwhelming beauty. I fell in love with it.
Interesting. This was the first temple we saw in ANgkor. It is impressive to see but very crowded, Go early when it is still not that hot. Go with a small group and a local guide.
Amazing place must see if hr in Siem Peap. We went to wach the sunrise over the lake which was stunning,would reccomend going to the temples early in the day as gets so hot.

Highlight of our trip. I loved this temple among all the temples in siem reap. The architecture is simply breathtaking. The grandeur, the precision and the entire ambience is simply breath taking. My husband and I spent a lot of time at this place

Beautiful carvings. There are so many stunning carvings into the building and they are beautiful so make sure your camera is fully charged, the entrance to o is unusual and lots of monkeys at that point. Highly recommended.
Simply stunning. One of the best temple from 10 or more temples that we visited in the Angkor complex. Would be a shame to miss this temple when visiting Angkor.
Smiling Face Temple. Awesome architecture. More shades than other temples coz of the trees. Less cheap buys compared to Pub street but still cheap.
New York after Trump becomes president. After visiting numerous ruins in this area, they all start to look alike! Nice but .....where is the magic?

Mysterious temple complex. We visited the temple at 6 in the morning and it was a very good decision. There were only 5-6 tourists then and we were able to appreciate the beauty of the place. The temple consists of numerous structures with carved faces- we couldnt get answers to questions about why they were built in that manner. Probably a guide would have helped. Would need at least an hour to completely cover the complex.

Exquisite Temple. This amazing temple was my favourite... I was awestruck by the magnificent workmanship involved in creating this masterpiece... words simply cant describe this temple.. you have to go & see it for yourself

A favorite Temple complex. seemingly compact with many huge facial carvings, it is a must see on the Angkor tour. My Wife and I had a personal tuk-yuk driver and several guidebooks - in other words we were self-guided!

Not the best of the Temples . After visiting Anghor Wat this was a bit of a let down straight after.
It's become quite fallen down but I do realise it's old but in comparison to all the others visited while visiting Siem Rheap this was my least favourite.

Absolutely Incredible!. What more to say? One of my 10 wonders of the world.
Compares to Luxor and Machu Picchu.
Makes a special trip to Angkor Wat area worth doing.

Amazing Temple Complex. The Bayon temple lies quite close to the more famous part of Angkor Wat. It's a short ride away. You'll find elephants here to ride if you like - I'm 50/50 on it being animal cruelty to do so. As long as more than three people aren't on the elephant, I think it not cruel. Anyway, the complex is great. It should take you bout 30-40 minutes to get through if you're a semi-avid photographer. Definitely a must hit if you're within the confines of the Angkor Wat park.

Amazing Place. If you are seeing Angkor wat then is will be a waste not to see Bayon temple or vise versa in fact there are several sites in the same area which I would put them in the must see category. If your want a really nice vacation plan Then stay at Sofitel Angkor ( a magnificent place) for 3 nights(at least) and buy the 3 day pass for $40 and explore the entire area. You will love it as my wife and I did.
Temple of many faces . This temple is nice to explore and get lost in- definitely recommend a visit. The stone carvings are preserved well and very detailed.
Fabulous Temple!!!!!. Don't miss this temple if you are at Siem Reap. We do love the construction concept, the histories on the carved stone and the surrounded jungles.

not to be missed. The temple is completely photogenic. The most impressive thing is probably the stone faces. I got so many photos there and very supprise how the accient Khmer can built such a masterpiece.AT the time we reached it, we encounter not so mahy tourists, so if you go, try to be around 8 am. Siem reap is very hot at noon.
Once on top it's like an escape room. Must visit while in the Angkor Wat complex. Good to even ride around and look from outside. Reminded me of Tombraider for some reason.

Excellent Knowlegde Experience. Went there to see the sunrise and i think it was one of the most beautiful experience. Also, me & my friend took a tour guide with us and he explained variety of things. It was an interesting, mystical and beautiful place full of knowledge. I highly recommend this place for a visit.

Another amazing site. This is another amazing temple. We went with our Cambodian guide who I would highly recommend as we were told the history of the temple. There are stone carvings depicting life during that time and our guide was able to explain the meanings and stories behind all the stone pictures. Very interesting and almost incomprehensible, the detail of the stone work and the size of the stone used to build these temples so many years ago wit no machinery just elephant and man.
Very cool temple. Awesome temple with most of it large structures covered in hand carved faces. Quite an intricate temple with lots to see and explore. Go see it.
Very impressive. We went here on the same day as we toured Ta Prohm and Angkor Wat. I felt that it was just as impressive as Angkor Wat but on a smaller scale

Great temple with the option to be more hands-on and explore/climb. We enjoyed Bayon temple, more so than Angkor Wat. The temple is more manageable to explore, and you can be very hands-on and climb the various stone stairs to the upper levels/tiers. The smiling faces are great (and a nice opportunity for touristy “nose-to-nose” photos). Though the reliefs are less detailed they are still beautiful, and you can see how much labor and hard work went into creating both the faces and carvings.
Fabulous. These temples are all astonishing. Each one is different but they are all amazing. I did a tour with Angkor Wat Photography and was so glad I had done.

After a while, one Temple looks much like another but this one is 'worth visting'. Much smaller than Angkor Wat, this temple is much easier to navigate around - especially if you visit 'early' before the tourist crowds.It's quite sad to see the structure in such as 'sorry state' and so little being done to protect it (for future generations) - much becuase of the fact that the soft sandstone is crumbling at a horrific rate.Wear 'sensible' walking shoes as the terrain is VERY uneven and often difficult to manage (if not flexibly mobile).

Lots more unusual features than the other temples. This temple complex offers some very different features than Angkor Wat or the other major temple complexes. This one has terraces (Leper King or Elephant Terraces) with some fantastic, intricately carved walls. It also has a couple of tours across from the terraces where acrobats used to attach ropes between the towers and entertain the king.Definitely a complex worth visiting.
Magnificent Angkor temples. The Angkor temples should be on everyone's bucket list. Absolutely awesome! Siem Reap and the Cambodian people are truly magical.
The Many Faces of the Khmer deities.. Enjoyed the trip with the many faces of the Khmer deities. Intricately carved stones. Had a good shot doing a nose to nose with some of the faces.
Funny smiley faces and great architectures. Bayon was quite crowded. If possible, maybe you'd better to go there in the morning. Still we enjoyed its decorative architectures and smiley faces!

Hands on an ancient Buddhist landmark. I can say that I honestly enjoyed exploring Bayon temple more than Angkor Wat. It's smaller and felt more manageable. It's more climbable and lends itself to snapping lots of creative photos. The reliefs are not nearly as detailed as Angkor Wat, so a guide is not as much of a necessity here.
Intricate details. Going during lunch was a great idea as it was less people. Enjoyed the detailed wall coverings depicting what life was like a thousand years ago.
Incredible!. Bayon amazed me as much as Angkor Wat, it is huge and the faces are everywhere! I went in the afternoon which made for nice photos with the late sun hitting the faces at angles.
Best of the temples. Best of the 3 main temples in my opinion. Beautiful carvings and stonemasonry. Lots of stairs and can get quite hot and busy in the middle of the day.

Must see. I personally loved Bayon. For me the style was distinctive and the style and era was evident in the ruins.
I recommend, if you are not doing any of the tours I suggest this as one of the four temples to see.

The Temple of smiling faces of the God. Several gigantic smiling faces of the god. It must have took them ages to carved the detail on this pile of rocks. Imagine if there were one mistake, wouldn’t they have to redo the whole thing again?Restoration work is ongoing but they allow you to climb all over the temple to get to the central tower. The giant stone faces are extremely to details and makes me wonder with awe. It's definitely not something you see everyday.

See the faces and ride the elephants!. The temple is very detailed and a must for your trip. We had a nice young man give us a guided tour and show us the best faces to photograph. Another activity available is an elephant ride around the temple. It was fun. Bring tip money, comfortable shoes, and sunscreen.
Gorgeous. Buy a 7 day pass. Rent a driver with a car with AC take your time. Do 2-3 each day...ankor wat split in 2 days. To hot for snack. Lots of water. Extra camera battery. Big sun hat. Thats it.
Amazing Temple. This temple is stunning and a must see when you visit the Angkor area. Beautiful Khmer architecture. There are many 4 faces of the Buddha and is well preserved.
A glimpse of the truly beautiful past!. Just a must alongside the main Angkor Wat complex, go enjoy the fine details that this old and rich culture created!

Excellent ruins & detail. Over three days in Ankor, this became our favourite temple. Though still in ruins in many parts, that added to th mystical character of the structure. Spent ages here because it's got so much to photograph.

Stunning temple . Visited Baton in the morning after watching the sunrise at Angkor Wat. Beautiful 12th century temple featuring huge faces. The central part can get extremely busy with tour groups but we wandered around the lower tiers and tunnels which was a bit less scenic but still interesting. This is my second time to Bayon, having previously visited in 2009 and it's still one of my favourite temples

Loved it!. Since I love temples and their history and well, mostly because of their unique structures, I would certainly recommend to go to this temple if you happen to be in Cambodia. If you have a travel guide, listen to him/her (which I didn't do because I was already in awe of the place), if not, have some research before going. This is actually a must visit place in Siem Reap. One thing tho, it was very very very very hot when we came so make sure to bring water while you go around the area.
The best temple in the complex. I just loved all the Buddha faces, and the amazing carvings. Interesting to see the contrast between the earlier Hindu temples and the later Buddhist one.
Stunning. This was the first of the temples within the Angkor temple complex that I visited and it was simply stunning, with magnificent friezes and carvings.

Our favourite. We loved this temple. Our favourite of them all. It was a little busy which made it difficult to move around as it was a lot smaller than the others. Great photos from across the road looking back towards it. Definitely not one to miss

Beautiful place...can get crowded later in the day.. Beautiful Temple. Best way to see this is to come early in the morning. Sun rise from this temple is stunning. The early morning sun reflecting on those carvings...words just can't describe how amazing of an experience that is. Around 8am Temple starts to get crowded. 10am....forget it. It should take about 2-3hrs to see the temple and that's taking your time. You only need a guide if you want to learn the history behind the temple. Otherwise it's easy to navigate.

You'll want to take pics of everything!. The first temple we went to, but looking back, it was one of our favourites, as every part of it has yet another fascinating pagoda, carving or relief that you'll be dying to take a photo of or with. A must-see for sure.

Interesting - a lot of history. I would recommend hiring a local guide to see all the archeological sites as they have a lot if knowledge to impart regarding the history. It can be hot during the middle of the day. Early morning is the coolest. Some walking and climbing involved.

Bayon temple. When I went it was going through some serious reconstruction so it was a little difficult to get around. However it is good to see that they are trying to repair the temples in a culturally sensitive way.

Unbelievable. Smaller than Angkor Vat but I think more surprising as the buildings were more concentrated and steeper.
Please, respect the Temples. Too many people do stupid things just for a picture...

A glimpse of the Khmer Empire. The Bayon Temple is a Buddhist Temple that receives so many visitors in a day. After my tour to this spot, I understood much better about the Khmer empire and Indo China. Sometimes, men try to create their history in their own way but these old ancient wall carvings don't tell lies. The whole building is truly an artwork. Though, I feel that visiting this place with a tour guide is much better as you will then only be able to understand the history better. Otherwise, you should visit the National Museum first before coming here. Also if you are sensitive to dust, remember to bring a mask as this place can be dusty when it is windy.
Great City in Khmer. see them, the reason why we come.First day tour must see:Angkor Wat and Roluos group.Angkor Wat-Angkor Thom- and cafe break at Angkor Cafe(front of Angkor Wat

Great visit after a short "Temple Run". We went to Bayon after Angkor Wat. Each temple had a distinct charm and a wonderful history. In the case of Bayon, I found the fact that it was a Buddhist temple converted to a Hindu temple quite interesting. Most interesting was that of a stone carving of Buddha that was "tweaked" by adding facial hair, and various accessories/ornaments to make it look like a Hindu god.
The most beautiful of all temples. In my opinion the most beautiful temple of all. The trees wraping around the old ruins. You wont find this picture anywhere in the world.
Amazing. Part of the trip to the temples a must!You may do it a first site on the daily tripTake a guide or use a book to understand it

Mysterious. . Arrived at this site pre-dawn and was one of 4 people at the site beating the crowds and the heat that would follow. There are some wonderful images to capture here as it is very authentic and not in the process of restoration. Collapsed walls, overgrowth and walkways make the site worth photographing. Had 2 1/2 hours in peace before the tour groups began to arrive and by then I had been all over the site.

Like walking into the past. After visiting the busy Angkow Wat, Bayon was a breath of fresh air from the crowd and rabid camera clicking and shoulder to shoulder exodus of human bodies. (Okay got carried away there but come on Angkor Wat was really jammed-packed when I was there)What I love most besides the obvious lesser crowd is the intricate design on every wall and pillar. I can say it is a feast for the senses for those history and art junky!

The best of the bunch. You can't help but smile and admire everything this temple has to offer. The second most popular of the group but my personal favourite. A place where you can take photo after photo and sit down to take it all in. Beautiful!

grand in scale. Details of the workmanship is amazing and to wonder how these were actually built. We took an elephant ride around the perimeter of Bayon and it was worth the experience. We stopped at various places to take photos. Visually you certainly get a different perspective up high. not as crowded as Angor or Ta Prohm.
My Favorite Temple of them all. Gives you a majestic view, looks very peaceful. Definitely worth a visit. It's like a maze inside. The faces are definitely worth taking a picture. :)
Amazing Temples everywhere. Amazing!! Enough said, that hasn't been said before. The sheer size and scale of some of it, and you can climb it too
Excellent. Probably the best for us can go by tuk tuk after Angkor Wat as close. Again no need for a guide just buy the book take water and if possible a good camera or well charged phone
Smiling faces all around. A must visit on the temple circuit in Siem reap. Early morning is best as it is can be very crowded. Bayon temple is designed to make you smile.
Stunning. My favourite temple in the Angkor Wat complex. Serene Buddha faces watch over you as you explore the Bayon' s nooks and crannies.

Temple with hundreds of faces. One my favourite Angkor temples, the faces on the Bayon temple follow you as you wander around these ruins. We coincided with a large group of Buddhist monks, spectacular to see the orange robes flowing in & out of the towers

Awesome Temple. You will me mesmerized with the amount of detailed carving any puzzled with the engineering works required to hoist each heavy stone on top of others to create this masterpiece. A great place to visit.
Amazing. Very large temple area, beautiful but we got lost and missed a large amount. Hard to follow the map as there are no directions or signs. Just impressive!!
Beautiful. One of the better preserved temples. Plan on spending a long tine visiting slowly. Many others to explore.
Must-see part of the Angkor Wat complex. When seeing Angkor Wat, this is part of the ticket you buy to enter the national park which encompasses Angkor Wat and various other temples. .
not your average temple. neat spot. lots of fun to explore for any age. our children loved it. we will be back to explore more!!

So Classic!. This Temple is stunning! I took so many photos of walking inside the temple and the relics shown on the temple walls. If you ever plan to visit the temples, please do not forget to take your camera with you, especially visiting this Bayon Temple!

Eerie and enormous, an extraordinary place. Bayon is the centrepiece of Angkhor Thom and is quite extraordinary in the morning light, before the crowds arrive. The ghostly faces looking out in every direction gradually illuminate. Great photo opportunities abound.
Wonderful despite the crowds. This is a marvelous temple. Go with a sense of humor and patience due to the crowds, but do not miss.

The most beautiful temple in Angkor Thom.. The Bayon is the most beautiful temple in Angkor Thom. Amazing temple with great history. The faces carvings are the best of all the temples. Better to visit in the morning.
Go just after sunrise to beat the crowds. This was my favorite temple – the most unique. Arrive just after sunrise and have the place mostly to yourself.

Big and beautiful.... This temple is outstanding with four female faces on top of very temple. The faces have been done on stones and are remarkably similar.For movie lovers, these faces have been used in the movie "Tomb Raider". Remember the stone lady that comes alive and tries to kill Lara Croft. You can do a little bit of star stalking here. Just watch the movie before going to the temple.As with other temples in Angkor, arrive to the attraction as early as possible. A hat and a water bottle is a must for the visit.

Temple in Angkor Thom. Found this temple actually more interesting to explore than the large Angkor Wat. There are so many people at Angkor Wat itself that it is hard to really enjoy. Bayonet Temple is smaller, quieter and you are not rushed or harried by other visitors.
Easily My Favorite Temple. There is something so stunning about this temple. I have visited twice and will for sure be back again. There are wonderful photo opportunities here as well.

As Compassionate as Avolokitesvara. The statues actually depict King Jayavarman VII whose kingship was one of compassionate service to his subjects in the manner of Avolokitesvara, the Buddha of compassion. The Bayon Temple is within the Angkor Thom complex. We visited the Ta Phohm, the Preah Khan. The former was built to honour the King's mother and the latter in honour of his father. We visited the Angkor Complex in February. It was very hot and we recommend that visitors take lots and lots of water. You will certainly need.
Amazing temple to see. Again this is somewhere to see at least once in a lifetime. Be prepared to walk and go early to avoid the crowds. When we went it was hazy so photography was not so good.
Amazing. Amazing temple with great history, we were sorry we didn't have a beter camera with us. The Climber to the top is not to be underestimated when being pregnant or in bad physical shape.

Group Tour of Angkor Thom and Bayon Temple . As part of our group Tour in Cambodia with World Expeditions, we biked to Angkor Thom and then walked through the Bayon Temple in the center of the city. Our tour guide was very informative and helped provide the information needed to truly appreciate both the architecture and the history of the city and it's people from when this used to be the capital of Cambodia when the country was much bigger than it is now and housed over a million people. The 58 spires of the Temple represented the various regions at that time. The walls are carved and etched telling stories of life from that era. This would be difficult to tour if you have mobility issues. You also have to keep an eye on smaller children as there are no safety rails. Otherwise this temple is worth seeing as you can get quite high up and close to truly appreciate the architecture.

So awesome . This sight is great and we really loved the smiling Buddha heads. There is one Buddha inside who has a bigger smile then the others there are some great places to take photos here and should not be missed. But it is very crowded as are the other sights. So maybe it's best to arrive here very early. Or on a weekday in the peak off season
vey beautiful to see. The Bayon is the most beautiful tempel in Angkor Thom. It is a must to explore them. You can come there at any moment of the day, it is always a good time

Bayon smile :). I have been there in the afternoon. It was very hot; however, there were a lot of interesting things such as looking a sculpture called Bayon smile and making amazing photos of nose to nose of you and the sculptured face.
Another great Temple. go see them all, pack light sunscreen hat umbrella water don't buy a book for more than $5 runners or comfy shoes, go early

Don't miss this temple. This is a little different Angkor Wat in a refreshing way. The temple has had much shifting of its foundation as well as spung trees growing up in the ruins. It makes for great picture opportunities.

Mysterious faces but not the charm of the others. Temple dedicated to the 3 main Gods. The faces carvings are probably the best of all the temples, but the site is busy and lacks a little bit of the magic you have elsewhere.

One of the best in Angkor. Absolutely stunning! Make sure you go and check it out!!
Doesn't get 5 stars just because it's too crowded! Visiting it was actually a bit stressful. If you go at about midday it's supposed to be a bit more quiet (probably because the heath at that time of the day is unbearable)

Favourite Temple!. Only advice is to go late afternoon to avoid tour group crowds. I went during the Chinese New Year and it was crowded....we headed back around 4pm and it was almost empty...same thing goes for other more popular temples...
Amazing Temple. How could human being built such wonderful temple at that time? It is a human being heritage indeed. Well done!

Bayon Temple is the Best!. For me, this is the best temple filled with four faces on each building top. Good photo can get it here due to this ancient building and color standing. Try to get there before the big group of tour coming, otherwise, narrow walk way will pack and may need to wait for giving way and pushing each other. Take times to get best short of photo and so on.
Amazing and impressive temple!!!. I liked this temple a lot! it is much more mystical and charming than others. these smiling faces looking through centures!!! i think that it is MUST SEE spot!!
Probaly liked this more than Angkor Wat. Not sure why but more face carvings and seemed more intimate, they all have something different to offer.

Must do!. Best Temple! I loved faces and also the fact that you can go all around as you like, climbing up some risky parts of the temple! Early in the morning there are less tourist so is the best time to see (maybe just go sunrise to Angkor and then come here).

Best Buddhist temple in Angkor.. Built and dedicated to the Wheel turning monarch King Jayavarman VII, this Buddhist temple is a must see and we enjoyed this piece of ancient history far more than Angkor Wat. The faces of the Buddha are still with us.

SO YOU FORGOT TO SEE BAYON ??? WELL -DONT TELL ANYONE -AND GO BACK !!. Together with Agkor War these 2 temples make up the 8 th wonder of the world !The many huge Buddha faces (said to resemble the founding king) can be seen together with the treeroot-encompassing of Ta Promon numerous pictures round the world.They also festured in the Indiana Jones movie.Bring a guide and good shoes.You are in for an experience of your lifetime-like Macchu Pitcchu,The Great Pyramids,Luxor or even the top of Mt. Kilimanjaro

My favourite temple. All the temples are awesome. This one has a lot of photo opportunities and the reliefs are in quite good condition. It is smaller than the the others so people do not stay around for long so there is good opportunity to have a 'tourist-free" photo.

Another Must see when you are in Siem Reap, Cambodia. This temple is another must see when you are in Siem Reap. Beautiful sculptures, a elegant gate approaching the temple complex. Its sad to see that it is in ruins but good to see that restoration and maintenance is in good hands. Wonder how beautiful it was during its glory days

Definitely worth it. Once you have paid for the driver, guide and entry ticket for the Temples complex, it is definitely worth going to more temples than just the famous Angkor Wat. If you nevertheless don't want to spend the whole day at the temples and would like to see only 1 or 2 more, I would highly recommend this one. It seems to be the best preserved one. Besides you could easily find a spot to take a picture with several Buddha faces - our best was 5 faces at a time :)Approaching the tempel you could also see an exhibition on how tempels are being restored and how they were built back then. For the ones without a guide this is also the right place to get more background information about gods and religious fights.

Great to visit even if you're sick of temples. One thing that can happen when you're in the Angkor Wat area is temple fatigue. Spending hours a day at various ancient sites can get tiring. You may be sick of walking through old stone buildings regardless of how fascinating they are, but do not miss Bayon. It's part of the huge (larger than Angkor Wat) Angkor Thom temple complex, and it's a beautiful walk/drive in. Once you get there, you can see giant heads made of stone blocks - very eerie. As with Angkor Wat, it's a popular place, so it might be good to visit Bayon on a weekday and in the heat of the day (if you can tolerate it) so as to avoid so many tourists. You won't regret it!
Fascinating. It is difficult to compare all the different temples in Ankhor- they are all fascinating in their own way, and the Bayon Temple is no exception.

Fifty four towers of inscrutable Buddhas. I saw four temples on the complex over two days - Bayon was my favourite. Almost theatrical in appearance it had huge atmosphere with the four expressions of each Buddha giving a tongue-in-cheek feel to the whole experience. Do not miss this site!
Absolutely amazing!. Going to historical sights such as these puts perspective into our everyday lives, just beautiful! Wear comfortable shoes, there is a bit of walking involved.
Another amazing Temple. Took lots of snaps here, love looking at them again and again.Listen to your guide, or get a guide as he will point out and tell you things you could miss.
awesome. Bayon, while somewhat in a ruin, still retains the splendor and grandeur of bygone days. The ability to walk through the ruins is most facinating

surreal place. lots of temples in this area so after angkor wat and angkor thom I was about to quit ..thanks to my tuktuk driver i dod not miss this one and Ta Prohm which add another dimension to the whole expeirence
Amazing temple!. In my top of Angkor sites ... love this place. The walls are presenting beautiful stories. The heads are so mysterious.
Amazing temple!. In my top of Angkor sites ... love this place. The walls are presenting beautiful stories. The heads are so mysterious.

Mind blowing facade!. The experience of seeing the Bayon temples is indescribable in words! The massive smiling faces peering down on you can give you goosebumps if you are here alone in the evening and it definitely is a special place to visit. Gives you an insight into an ancient era where kings were no less than gods. What is also interesting is the entrance gates each of which shows the churning of the ocean with massive nagas. Great place for interesting pictures :)
Visited Bayon Again. A great Wat to visit if you are tired as it is relatively small but has 216 different faces. One of my favorites in Angkor Wat

Intensely busy, but super interesting . When walking through Bayon it's like a maze. There are pathways which go in multiple directions and it can be confusing if trying to get around. Not helping this much is the hundreds of tourists walking all over everything. You can hardly get through the crowd let alone take a picture without someone walking through it.The hundreds of stone faces which bring the crowds are pretty amazing. Makes you wonder all the things they've witnessed, bet becoming a tourist attraction for hundreds of people per day wasn't something they thought they'd see.Altogether, definitely an awesome place to visit, and we would recommend it. Just maybe in the offseason so you can avoid the crowds.

A Must See in Siem Reap. "Bayon is known for its huge stone faces of the bodhisattva Avalokiteshvara, with one facing outward and keeping watch at each compass point." The Walk to the temple then seeing the large stone faces was amazing. Just knowing that every stone carving is done by hand and the time and labor it took. Then trying in your mind to see it as it must have been with all the inlayed gold, copper and precious stones.

Smile of Angkor - my undying Confidence. i am tour guide in Viet Nam and Campodia. I share to my customers culture information about Viet Nam and Campodia, guide them visit a lot of temple, they will have experiences for their trip
My favorite temple. Bayon temple is a unique temple. Worth visit the temple not too far from other temple. I spend more time in bayon temple than Angkor Wat. Less people more unique and beautiful.

Best in Angkor. Absolutely amazing and our absolute favorite in Angkor. We hired a taxi for the day and did Ta Prohm, Bayon Temple and Angkor Wat in one day. For us it was more than enough since our schedule was tight. It was hot and crowded everywhere and we were so glad we had a taxi and did not ride on a tuk tuk. The distances between the temples is pretty big and those tuk tuk riders looked miserable and hot.

Beautiful piece of history . This temple is absolutely stunning. Beautiful in the sense that the artwork of the walls of the temple describe the history of this wonderful place. There are many 4 faces of the Buddha. Some are rather interesting. The grounds are rather well kept and it is rather impressive regardless of what is surrounding nearby
Most deserved to visit. Khmers Smile is definitely the reason to be there. Incredible carvings in Bayon and I took a lot of beautiful photos here.

Worth it!. By the time we got here it was hot but definitely worth the visit.
Lots of climbing steps here as well so these attractions not for feint hearted!
My favorite temple of Siam Reap. The faces carved in this temple are fascinating. I've never seen anything like them. This was, by far, the most fun temple.

Another amazing temple!. Not the same as Angkor Wat, but amazing just the same...not as taxing physically! Would suggest, doing early mornings or late afternoon for temples as it does get quite warm in the middle of the day!
The faces - oh the faces. Absolutely mind boggeling. To think that this was built centuries ago is quite a feat. we loved the grinning faces
A Sight to Behold!!!. Admirable ancient sculptures and engravings that have withstood the test of time. A must see after the early morning tour of Angkor Wat.

More detailed than Angkor Wat. Really nice temple. Great detail on face carvings. We were lucky to see several of the temple elephants leaving across the entry bridge which is also nice to see with all the statues. Definitely worth seeing as part of your overall tour.

Beautiful Temple, Intricate carvings, and Elephants. One of the main temples to visit in the Angkor area, we entered via a less crowded entrance crossing paths with fellow tourists riding Elephants. Similar to Angkor Wat - this temple also had beautiful carvings on the outside walls detailing a conflict between the Khmer and the Cham. Once we got inside, the layout revolved around several towers, which housed Buddhist shrines within them. Unfortunately due to the sheer amount of tourists there we didn't want to spend so long inside and left within the hour. If I were to do this attraction again, I would come during the low rainy season - as my guide pointed out there would be less tourists and a layer of moss amongst the ruins, adding to the wow factor.
Lovely Buddhas. Lovely temple with Buddha faces wherever you look - ideal contrast to Angkor Wat both in size and style
Very Interesting. Go early!. Bayon is quite extraordinary. Lots of amazing history etched onto the walls. Go early, while everyone's at Angkor Wat, to avoid the mob.

Unique. We basically visited every major temple in Siem Reap and this is one of the ones that stood out to me with the facades covered by the large faces - they made it standout from other temples so definitely worth a stop! We got some really striking photos
If you go to Angkor Wat then you should come here. Not as much to see as Angkor Wat but you are in the same area and have the same pass you might as well visit.
Amazing temple. Like Angkor wat, this is a must see in Siem Reap, must be visited. If possible, take two mornings to visit all the temples, or wats
Vast Buddah heads. Wonderfully quiet after Ankor Wat. loved the Buddah heads looking out in all directions, less grand but more atmospheric than Ankor Wat.
The main temple of Angkor Thom. I was amazed that this temple is so old! Hard to imagine they were people living here hundreds years ago....

Temple day. This is a truly amazing temple, take plenty of water a comfy pair of shoes and maybe a hand help fan as it gets very hot. Take a TukTuk driver with you as there's so much walking involved.
Stunning. Absolutely incredible. One of my favourite temples in the whole Angkor complex. The photo-crazy asian crowds ruined the experience but the temple is a must see.

Take time to explore. Some people see one temple seen them all. Not so true at Angkor. Make the effort to walk in, slowly, and have a wander, look deep into the carvings and you may appreciate the differences and uniqueness of all the temples. This one is particularly good for me, even though it can be crowded it is possible to feel like you are back in time. In saying all that, a 10-15 stop is possible to get an appreciation, we aren't all into taking our time, got a holiday to enjoy.....

Amazing temple ruins. Bayon was definitely one of my favorite temples. The massive Buddha heads are intimidating and peaceful at the same time. This is definitely not a temple to be missed when you're visiting.

Rock that smiles. This temple is very close to many other temples, but what makes it different is the smiling faces that are carved into the stone. The rock can be slippery so wear shoes with some sort of grip, a hat is a good idea a tons of water. The elephant ride is available right outside, the temple is smaller than Angkor Wat, so you won't spend too much time walking around, tops 2 hours. My tutus driver took 15 minutes from my hotel and charged my 10 dollars to drive me to this temple plus all the other temples in the vicinity, yup pretty cheap, he waited outside while I walked around, tip these guys because they are freakin awesome and kind. This temple will make your pictures post card worthy, this was by far my favorite, don't forget to visit!! Xo!

Beautiful Carvings. I had seen photos, but was blown away by the actual temple. Carvings are really amazing.Way too crowded, though. Guides are mixed -- some almost pushed us aside to get their groups through. And, having studied Hindu mythology, many of the guides were either inaccurate or passed over the Hindu part; choose your guide carefully!Again, some parts were inaccessible because of the crowds. The wait to climb the stairs, for example, was over an hour.

The best temple in the complex. This was by far our favourite stand out temple from all of the main ones people visit.
Go in the morning as everyone is at the more famous Angkor Wat for sunrise, you'll avoid the crowds this way.

What else is there to offer? . Definitely a Temple you don't want to miss. Pros: - Part of the Tuk Tuk small tour (Tuk Tuk all day for 10-15$). Very informative driver that new some side places to be dropped off for better access- Beautiful design and a lot more walking space / climbing that isn't available at Angkor Wat - A lot more detailed walls and faces within the stones that make great pictures opportunities (look for some side walls that are a bit more secluded that have some amazing cravings on them. Usually there is more space to get pictures without other people being within the pictures. - Less kids and people trying to sell you stuff as you walk in.Cons - Can be a problem with people that have difficulties climbing places as this one (in my view) more labour intensive.- (Not really a con - but just be aware) temple has a lot more residence bats, birds and giant moths. So always make sure not to put your hand in dark places etc.

Could spend hours there exploring angles for photo taking. I like this better than Angkor Wat. From a photo perspective, there is much more to take, especially from various angles and with various lenses. We went there twice, once in the morning and once at sunset. Could spend even more time there.
Serenity at Sunset. Re-visited Bayon Temple before sunset for the sunset and to avoid the crowds. The serene faces are great to photograph in the absence of large tourist forces.

Smily faces. Very nice temple with nice pictures to be done with the large smiling faces on the tours. It was a bit crowded when we visited, so i m sure it would have been even greater with less people.

Crowded, steaming hot, but worth the faces. This was personally my favourite temple in the Angkor Wat complex. Aesthetically that is! I loved the expression on the many faces that face all four angles on the sides of each tower in BayonThere was also a smaller tower with a platform on top that you could climb to, just outside the main complex. It was a very steep climb! with some steps barely 20cm long - so more of a ladder, but lots of funWithin the main temple it was very hot and jam packed full of people. Bayon has the least amount of free space to move around in it is fair to say. A Chinese woman even tripped and fell over onto me which the guards thought was funny.Don't miss Bayon! But prepare for the heat and pushing past other tourists inside
SUPER!. Amazing. Just like the movies. But better. Super reccomend. Make sure you bring water with you as it does get warm but completely worth it ! *****

Grandiose too. We visited the temple in the middle of the day. Maybe it is better to do it morning or late afternoon, as the heat is quite intense.But it was amazing to see it - easy to understand that it took approximately 50 years to restore this great place. Worth to experience.

My favourite. A beautiful temple with 200 faces of the Buddha, seen at every turn, through every doorway and window. Very well preserved and stunningly beautiful. An easy tuk tuk ride from Siem Reap, well worth it!
Must see . It is a good place to visit. Astonished to see the construction in the ancient times, when there was no facilities available.
Stunning stone faces. Smaller than Angkor Wat and not a lot of carvings compared to the other temples. But the stone faces are very stunning.
I bought the T shirt !. A great temple from all views according to my camera ! Do not miss it...a couple of viewings would be worth. And get the T shirt !!
Movie site!. Just another fantastic ruin to enjoy, do not miss while touring Ankor Wat. I loved riding in the Tuk,Tuk while visiting the entire area.

Very unique temple made up of many four-faced towers. Just like the giant four faced enemy from Tomb raider, you will face many at this interesting site. Our tuk tuk driver explained that each tower represented a province of the old Khmer Empire. The walkways are narrow and with lots to see, but can get annoying if you are caught amidst the noisy tourist groups. Try to pick a less busy time to go.

An excellent place to wander around. Sun screen, hat and pleanty of drinking water a must when visititing this temple complex. Take your time as when we visited in February it was hot and humid and made for a tiring but very rewarding day.

Blue skies and Bayon temple. It's hard to pick which temple is the best. They are all different and I'm happy that I visited all of them. Bayon is not to be missed. This is a unique temple and I believe it was one of the later constructed temples. It's interesting to compare the architecture of all the different temples. If you're young and able, rent a bike and see them all on your own time.

This temple,is a major architectural building feat. 216 faces of the King and through time of Buddha. The work that went into Bayon is awe inspiring. If you do t feel tingles from visiting this temple and the stories it has to tell you are seriously not getting the temples at all.

Nearly as amazing as Angkor Wat...until you see Angkor Wat. Bayon is surprisingly gorgeous, expansive, historical and amazing. It was completly off our radar but the tour company had it as our first stop (via tuktuk) on the was to Angkor Wat. We were all blown away... someone could have told me it was the only site in Siem Reap and I would have been happy. The moat, entrance and long path to the temple was gorgeous... the shopkeepers were friendly and didn't harass too much. The monkeys bothered no one and folks took rides on elephants (I understand some people disagree with this sort of tourism so wanted to mention it does occur here). Bayon itself is massive and there's currentlysome construction work occurring but nothing major. There were lots of tourists but the flow moved and there were tons of amazing photo opopportunities. We highly suggest Bayon if you have time... it's absolutely incredible, until you compare it to Angkor Wat itself.

Someone is watching. The scale and intricacy of the carvings here are nothing short of stunning. At any point there are the implacable faces of more than one carved face looking down on you. Favourite temple in the area.

Bayon Temple. Part of a 4 temple tour this was our second stop after Angkor Wat. If you have a driver this is a good place to be dropped off to start. From here you can walk around the nearby Temples and even the Elephant Terrace. I would recommend you have an ID holder on a lanyard to hold you day ticket as you will be constantly asked to show proof of ticket purchase. There is some climbing involved, but you can also navigate around on lower levels if required. We allocated 40 minutes for this attraction and spent every minute exploring.
Smiling Temple. A very nice visit to the "smiling faces" temple. There are many angles for unique pictures (make sure you follow the tour guide instructions).

Bayon Temple. Most impressive of the Angkor Thom complex. Visually stunning with all the peaceful smiling stone faces carved on the towers. This temple also has amazing carved bas reliefs on the outer walls that depicts everyday scenes in an Khmer village and some mythological elements included. Wonderful complex to explore.

Very interesting temple. Another 12th century temple to the God Budda in the Ankor Wat area. Smaller than Ankor Wat but well preserved. There is a wonderful carved mural with the history but you need a guide to decipher it for you. We were on a guided tour so had own bus/escort. Easy walking and you only need 1 to 2 hours to see everything. Good photo opportunities.
Almost as good as Angkor Wat. Very impressive temple - inside Angkor Thom. Smaller than Angkor Wat but almost as impressive. Little bit of a climb to the top levels.
Various Buddha faces. Perfect place for photography!Many Buddha faces. The best place in the Ang Kor Wat campus. Do climb to the top and take pics with the dancing Divas!

Magical . A truly majestic place- we spent a good hour going around. We walked around at about 12pm and it wasn't too hot, there is a fair bit of shade. The temple looks very similar from all sides. When we were leaving to find our tuktuk driver we got lost- we just couldn't figure out where we'd gone in! It did give us another opportunity to walk around the outside though!

great details. great details and size I had a teen age young man give me a tour he spoke English and and explained things to me , be aware of kids asking for money for their school I think is a scam..

A must see. The Bayon temple is a must see when you visit the Angkor area.Even if you only have a single day, make sure to include this one on your shortlist.This complex alone can easily take the entire day if you allow it.It's a wonderfully preserved example of ancient Khmer architecture.But the most stunning are the extremely detailed and well preserved wall decorations, showing mythical stories, daily life, the kings, the wars with the Cham.. I found the wall decorations even more amazing than the 4 heads on most towers the complex is typically more known for.Make sure you start the visit early in the morning. That way you not only are able to avoid the hot sun during the late morning until mid afternoon, but you will also avoid the masses of people ( they are usually all at Angkor Wat for the sunrise and the climbing of the third level). If possible, hire an experienced guide to tell you about the decorations and everything else you see.
interesting to visit as it has a lot of history. Very interesting historical temple. It seems to be a Hindu temple but also has some sort of Bhudist inter twining.

Best part of Angkor Thom. We have visited Bayon temple at 12.00-13.00 . It was not crowded and the light was fine to take good pictures. It is a marvelous temple , much different to others. It is astonishing, an experience which is a pity to loose if one happens to be in this part of the world.

my favorite . This temple is probably my favorite of the bunch. There's just something about all those faces that are completely amazing and breathtaking. It's also a bonus that the crowds seem to be way less here than at Angkor Way.

My favourite from the moment you see the front gate and the large stone heads looking down on you. What a city the detail and scale is very impressive the area is like going to some magic world where they lived with amazing stone art every where they say the elephant terrace well add a Buddha terrace with many pieces of carved stone to make up this beautiful place .It is one I am going to go back to and see the sunrise and finish one of my days there as well to catch a sunset . What a amazing city .
One of the very best temples to visit. I was even more impressed with Bayon than Angkor Wat. An absolute must visit temple. Go early or late to avoid the crowds as its always very busy.

Nice temple not too busy. It was probably the second best temple my husband and ai visited during our day trip.It was not too busy and still in pretty good shape.We enjoyed the history of it given by our guide. I am not sure if without the guide we would have enjoyed as much.One day around the temples was enough for us but Bayon was one of the 2 to visit. Enjoy!
Wake up early and go before sunrise . Wake up early and go before sunrise. It's a little creepy in the dark but once the sun rises, it's great before tourists start funneling in.
Beautiful. Bayon is one of the few temples that you should visit our of the numerous temples in Angkor archaeological park. Lot of walking but the view is beautiful and carving is very interesting.

Another beautiful temple. This temple has been restored and is so beautiful. It is hard to say anything new about these temples that have not already been said. This was one of the top 3 temples in the area for me. If you only have 1 day I would see this one after Angkor Wat.

A great chance to see and feel heritage!. The tour around Bayon Temple is great! You get to come face-to-face with what is left of the 54-tower temple (for the 54 provinces of Cambodia at the time when the temple was built).

A must to visit!. I have been to Bayon Twice and i still loved it! It is constantly crowded and I recommend that you visit during the late afternoon in which the crowd might be less. Wear comfortable shoes as there are climbing involved and allow yourself at least an hour there to fully appreciate the beauty.

First stop. This was our first stop of the day and already quite busy. There was a small amount of construction work going on but that didn't take away from the magic. Really enjoyed exploring this one and even though it is busy you can always find a secluded spot to explore yourself as most tour groups stick to a pre determined path. Climb to the top its worth it.
multifaceted. There are supposed to be 216 unique faces carved into 54 spires, no duplications. At certain angles you can have a picture taken looking like you are nose to nose with statue.
This is the second temple that you should visit. While the temples start to blur a little after seeing several, this one is probably the second must see temple. Beautiful stone work
Amazing. I was wowed by this temple, its beautiful walls and history. If you want to learn more go with a guide to these areas.

Very Impressive in Size and Scope. The Bayon Temple is an extremely impressive place, overshadowed by Angkor Wat, yet in many respects as extraordinary. The restoration provides many insights and photo opportunities- especially impressive are the multiple faces on the many towers.
Be prepared for large crowds and hot days
My favourite!. Bayon is my favourite of all the temples we visited. The huge carvings of faces are striking. There are some very detailed smaller carvings depicting scenes of everyday life.

Bewitching. Bayon Temple was actually the first port of call after watching sunrise at Angkor Wat, and the craftsmanship on display is totally mesmerising, difficult to comprehend the achievement of those artisans thousands of years ago. Huge faces peer down at you from all sides, awesome, totally awesome!

Temple of faces. I did a solo tour of Bayon, my third stop after the sunrise at Angkor Wat and Victory gate. The temple is small relative to the others and I enjoyed an elephant ride around it. It was currently under construction as they try to rebuild many of the ruins. This is the place to go to get a great photo of a stone face. I gave this 4 stars as I feel Angkor Wat is extremely impressive and huge and by the end of the day you get a little "templed out" and you need to choose your temples a bit. I would definitely stop here, and enjoy an elephant ride for $20.
all smiles.. Another brilliant temple. Cannot emphasise enough the need to have a good guide in order to get the maximum out of the visit.
Great attraction. Good with a knowledgeable guide.Fairly easy access throughout.Suitable for children and those over 55.

Stunning building - the one with the faces. This is one of the most photogenic of the Angkor complex temples. The faces of Khmer kings adorn the main columns and look out to the four points of the compass. Even better at dusk with the low sun across the reliefs.

Wonderful building. My wife and I visited the Bayon Temple in the afternoon and we enjoyed going around with few other tourists. The buildings and carvings are magnificent. Just be careful about people who show you where to take a good photo as they expect payment, usually $1.

A repeat visit to Bayon Temple. After my first, second ... and third ... visits to Angkor Wat, I have now found myself a repeat visitor. I just find it inspiring, relaxing, stimulating, and a bit like time travel. So buy the repeat pass ticket, as you'll surely visit more than once during your stay in Siem Reap.

LOST my TUK TUK Driver HERE!. I love this temple due to the presence of smiling/laughing faces on the walls/columns of the temple. There are steps to climb which I avoided by going towards the right side after the entrance. I admired the beauty of the temple and presence of less crowd, took lots of pictures,and watched two monkeys wAlking towards me.I "lost" my tuk tuk driver here due to miscommunication re meeting place. Happy travels!

Very impressive. Probably one of the most impressive temples there are. Right up there with Angkor Wat. This is an incredible structure that will impress! It is extremely busy no matter what time of day you get there so as long as you can block out the amount of tourists there are there you will really enjoy it. If you have a really good look round this temple it will take you about 2 hours Dress wise men are OK in tops and shorts, ladies you will still get away with strap top and shorts this isn't a temple you have to cover up for but would definitely suggest you get sturdy shoes. Trainers in dry season were absolutely fine.
Nicer than Angkor Wat. This temple undeservedly gets much less attention than Angkor Wat. I liked it much more, beautiful stone carvings, less people. Spend as much time here as you can.
One of the most beautiful temples in the region. This place was awe-inspiring and simply beautiful. Also, one of my personal favourites. Can get some lovely shots and is a true discovery!!

Temple of the smiling faces. The Bayon Temple also known as Prasat Bayon and is a Budhist temple and famous for its smiling stone faces on the many towers. This temple is located in the centre of the city of Angkor Thom and was built late 12th Century or early 13th Century. We really enjoyed walking around this magnificent structure and it’s a must visit.Temple is very popular and very busy.
My favorite of all the Temples. The expression of the faces of the various people the temples were built to honor are awe inspiring. Magnificent!

Historical adventure. We hired a taxi for the day, $30, to take us to Ankor Thom And the Bayon Temple.What a master piece of engineering they are, the cars thesis of the complex beggars belief.If you come make sure you see the area which was used in the film Tomb Raider, the tree growth is staggering.
So nice. Beautiful place to visit. Lucky to be there without too many tourists... Beautiful faces and beautiful faces. :) One of my favorite temples!
One of my favourite sites I have seen. This was my favourite temple in Angkor Thom. We spent a lot of time here taking some incredible photos.

Baylon at 4:30pm. This is my favorite temple in the Siem Reap region. Going late in the afternoon is much better than the theoretically cool morning visit I did last year. The complexity of this temple does not come through in photos no matter how good the photographer is.
Probably my favorite . Bayon temple isn't as popular as Angkor Wat but it should be. All the amazing detail carved into the faces make them unique works of art. An absolute must see in Siem Reap!

Visit to Bayon Temple. This temple has 37 towers with each tower having four faces of Buddha. The faces are gigantic and adorn all the four directions. Many of the faces are in reasonably good shape and the temple itself is in good shape.It is said that the image of Buddha is made to resemble the face of the king Jayavarman VII.
