Justifiably popular. You can see why people love this temple. It could be taken straight from a scene in Indiana Jones and is a magnificent cluster of ruined towers with massive carved faces. Like all of the major temples it is very crowded but I can't see how you can avoid that.
Our favorite temple. This special temple has so much attention to detail. Make sure to go through all the nooks and cranys for photo ops
2nd place that i love. when i was there, this temple is full of people but probably you can go here on the afternoon so it will avoid the crowd and you can take photo easier.

Better than Angkor Wat. Maybe it's an expectations thing, but I was really impressed with Bayon, more so than even Angkor Wat.
Although more decayed than Angkor Wat, Bayon gave visitors a stronger sense of history and closer experience with the imposing statues and bas reliefs.
Best of the Temples. We found this the best of the Temples we visited. There is a real sense of the wealth and affluence of past centuries.
Worth visiting. You can get a bit overwhelmed by temples in the Ankor area, but it's good to see different styles and have the differences explained by a good guide.
Budy. Such a vast temple I would recommend visiting before the crowds, so busy and easy to get lost!bwell worth a visit

No. 1 Temple. I felt this was by far the best temple for its architecture. It's hard to believe how they could build foundations to support the weight of these temples that could last centuries and transport the rock required to build these structure's. Get a Tuk Tuk (shop around for price), and a ticket for 3 days because there's so many temple ruins to see and have a hat and sunscreen. Angkor Wat is amazing but I felt the Bayon Temple was far more spectacular. The touts are relentless at all the temples so get used to saying no. Remember they have to make a living too. If you want to buy souvenir's remember if you show interest then walk away the price will drop, e.g. A painting I liked at $250 dropped in price the further I got away down to $90. A must see

Fantastic experience. After visiting Angkor Wat we went to Bayon Temple and found it even more impressive. The faces were just unbelievable and our guide helped us to take such unusual photos. So impressive, very quiet and just before sunset so the stones took on a different shade. The carvings and way it was built is incredible.

Very impressive. Gigantic stone faces and beautiful (some newly restored) bas-reliefs are truly magnificent!! Some of the bas-reliefs are very similar to those of Angkor Wat, like, the ones depicting marching Khmer army and, of course, you can find dancing apsaras here as well.You can easily spend a couple of hours around the temple

Wonderful Experience. This was the first temple we visited in Cambodia and we all loved it! The faces are amazing and every time you turn, you get a different perspective. This is definitely a must-see for anyone visiting Cambodia. We were there approaching sunset and it was beautiful.
Bramha here Bramha there. This is a fantastic temple with more than fifty faces of Bramha on all sides of the temple. This is a siva temple.
Beautiful Temple. Bayon temple is located in Angkor Thom. It is a beautiful temple and is a must see if in Siem reap. A lot is rebuilt but is fascinating. My children were amazed with all the faces.

Amazing ancient place. It was a great couple hours exploring the nooks and crannies of the temple. Amazing art/architecture. The site was a little uneven under foot but with care you could climb and descend to truly get a perspective of the construction and ancient uses. Elephant rides available if you like that sort of thing. Remember your hat and water. It's hot and dry
One of my favourite temples on the tour!. The structures are amazing, the faces in the rock and the sheer size of everything is extremely impressive.
Stunning!. This temple was a favourite! The faces in each tower are just amazing. Each one with its own expression and personality. Every turn presents a new photo opportunity. Simply stunning
Amazing!. Beautiful and amazing masterpieces of nature! Definitely worth the visit! A treat for nature lovers. Great addition to the beautiful Angkor Wat visit.

Sina. The most popular sandstone temple in angkorthom
amazing of Buddha smiling all of the tower, it's look like the paradise. Everything was perfectly. When you are arriving at this temple you will unbelievable.
During the rainy season, when the moat full of water it make visitors most interesting.

Bayon Temple is a shining example of Siam Reap and Cambodian Culture and History. Bayon temple with its many faces is a photographers dream, capture at sunrise or sunset to catch the light and stark shadows as it hits.Travelling around the many temples you really need to set aside an hour or two to enjoy this spectacle, explore and take photos.Siam Reap and Cambodia are a magical place and this is a shining example of its history and heritage.A must see.Remember your sun-cream, water and a hat, it can get pretty hot, especially when making a day of it.

Unique Jewel in Angkor Thom. After a day (or certainly two) of touring temples in Angkor Wat park, they all start to seem similar...except this one. With it's dozens of smiling faces, Bayon is definitely a temple that you know when you see it. It's fairly easy to get around and the uniqueness of the many faces provide plenty of interesting photo spots. I can be toured in less than an hour, or a little more if you want a slow pace and time to study it's many angles and vistas. Even if you only have one day to tour, make sure you visit Bayon!

The best of the best. I have been to Angkor 6 times, and Bayon is always my highlight. It is impossible to visit this place and not walk away with awe and amazement, while also having an infusion of pure joy! The faces light up something in your soul!
Beautiful Temple. Absolutely amazing, the only thing I would say about visiting any temples in Angkor Wat is to avoid Chinese New Year. During this period the temples can be quite crowded.

Favorite temple of our Angkor tour. While not MY personal favorite temple of our Angkor tour (my favorites were the tiny, out of the way, almost private temples. The crowds were a bit much for me at the popular temples.) it did rate highly. For my husband, on the other hand, it was his favorite temple of the many we saw. There are so many faces, every where you turn. It is incredible how many you can find in simply one picture. Definitely worth the stop, and worth the crowds.

Beautiful Temple! Iconic Buddhas heads!. This temple is located in Angkor Thom. A lovely scenic drive leads you up to this temple. Climbing up to the main area and you will find the iconic Buddhas heads. Images of these heads can be seen in photos and paintings all over Siem Reap. With some help from your guide, find the right spot to sit to take a fun photo that makes you look like you are nose to nose with the Buddha. It is a more buddhist design with sets its apart from Angkor Wat which has more Hindu influences.

great temple+ elephant ride. this is must see temple in the area.also there is an elephtant ride option if you are cool with it. it was 20 usd per person (including kids.)elephant ride takes about 15 minutes and includes a tour around bayon.most of the tours start the day from bayon and end the day with angkor before sunset photo madness.as a result bayon and other temples in small tour are crowded in the morning and noon.a small tip; if you spare more than one day (you must) angko area; bayon, ta phrom etc will be less busy after 15:00 pm.

Temple in Angkor Thom . Bayon temple is the temple in the center of Angkor Thom and is mostly rebuilt but it's still stunning. The rebuild attemps to keep the original work in mind. The rock carving is very detailed and the time it must have taken is mind blowing. Make sure you stop at the gates of Angkor Thom to take pictures as they are just as stunning as the temple itself.
Fascinating. We appreciated the help of our guide to gain an understanding of the history and artistic elements. Very much enjoyed out time there. Wear good shoes and wear sunscreen!

Better than Angkor Wat. This is the most spectacular temple to visit. Unbelievable carvings. Smiling faces everywhere.
The highlight on a visit to the temples.

Interesting, introductory temple to the Angkor Wat areas. Bayon Temple was the first temples we visited. It's an interesting temple and an introductory one to the complex around. It's famous for the big faces (and if your guide is good, you can take some creative pictures). Many tourists but well worth a visit.

Another temple.. After Angkor Wat, this temple began to look familiar. I know to some of you reading this might think it is sacrilege to say what I said, but to me it was another temple with long corridors, steep steps made of similar rock material that is badly worn through time with carved images that tells a story aeons ago. If you are a lover of the by gone eras, you would love this whole place.

The brother of Angkor Wat and worth a visit too. Its difficult to compare the Bayon temple with the famous brother Angkor Wat. Bot are worth a visit and Bayan might be even more impressive from some views. Being in Siem Reap you must have seen both.

Crossed Off the Bucket List. I had an awesome day at Angkor National Park and this was one of the sights to see!As mostly every single temple, this one too was quite crowded, but truly there is no way to avoid it. (And we got to the park at sunrise!) I really enjoyed this temple due to it's beauty and architecture, but also because there was more freedom here.At Angkor Wat and other temples, there seemed to be many wooden boards to help up stairs and whatnot. This temple there were actual opportunities to (very carefully) scale the steep and slippery steps, but that added to the fun and adventure of it all.
Spectacular briefing . Its impressive surrounding guides your point of view to the first temple foreigners often get in touch here. Go there and enjoy the pictures

Very busy and hard to get photos without the masses in, but still worth a visit.. I visited in late afternoon and it was very, very busy. The faces are impressive and I did enjoy my visit, but I personally preferred Baphuon temple just across the road because I got a sense of calm and enjoyed the view more and the climb up put many people off so my photos were better :-)Ultimately, all the temples are amazing, see as many as you can and then come back again the next day. Siem Reap is pretty close to my favourite in S.E. Asia.
Lovely place. You can get templed out if you aren't careful but this was a lovely temple & one worth going to. Quite busy so a morning is probably best.

Same but Different from Ankor Wat. Different style of temple. Typical tours include Ankor Wat, Bayon Temple and Ta Prohm, which could be done within 0.5 to 1 day. Alternatively, get a 3-day pass for a leisurely pace. The grounds are flat and good for cycling too.
Nice temple. It was a good temple. Fairly small but this allowed you to see more of the intricate carvings up close. Not as good as Angkor Wat, but our group really liked the ride out to Bayon.

The Bayon Temple is the most important building in the Angkor Thom complex. It is busy on the way to the Bayon Temple from the gate to the Angkor Thom area. Cars, minivans, tuk-tuks and even elephants transport the tourists to the Bayon Temple. This large temple complex is more than 8 centuries old. What I focused on were the extensive stone carvings in the temple. These carvings are well preserved. Furthermore, large faces are carved in several temple "towers", one tower has four faces, one for every main point of the compass. I have added several pictures; they say more than a thousand words, as the saying goes. Bayon Temple is one of the important sights in the Siem Reap surroundings.

Hundreds of enigmatically smiling faces. Amazing bas reliefs show what daily life in Cambodia was like 900 years ago as well as portraying a battle on the great lake. Although this is very ruined you can form an idea of it original vast scale
One of the most beautiful. My favorite temple in tge area.Great to go, been there twice!Dont miss the highest floor and take a good view of all yhe different faces!
Impressive!. The towers are massive and set off well by the massive mammal arriving - the elephant which approached so silently to my left, I nearly got trampled by it!
bayon temple. fantastic work and great master piece with clearly depicting changing of the religion from hindu to buddhism

My favourite temple. Very very VERY beautiful temple. Definitely my favourite. I'll recommend it. And I don't know if i was lucky but it was not surrounded by big group ofChinese people when we get there. So we did really nice pics
Must visit it. Looking at the more than 200 faces of Buddha in the evening was an inspiring experience. Every world traveler should visit it
Stunning temple with many faces!. A fascinating visit into the past with some many passages you rarely bump into another tourist. Good exploring to be done!
amazing architecture. the whole place is ful of wonderful buildings and love to see all the details, no place like this in other country
Well preserved!. Its an amazing place for any traveler looking to tick off their bucket list. Allocate minimum 2 days to go around the temples. There's a lot to see!

wonderful. the photos speak for them selves
just a wonderful experience
I've wanted to visit here for so long it did not disappoint.

Ancient Faces. Visited in the afternoon once the crowds have dissipated. Every smiling face is different. Around every corner is another smiling face. The bas-reliefs depicting mythological and historical scenes are amazing in their detail.

Spectacular but Very Crowded. Bayon was definately a nighlight. The carved faces weres amazing - brooding and watchful. Even with crowds you could get some photos. And crowds there were...everywhere with their selfie sticks. The area up the stairs is the best, but i t is a confined space and therefore can be shoulder to shoulder with people. Keep this in mind when visiting.

A must-visit while in Siem Reap. Built in the late 12th century by the Buddhist King Jayavarman, this is the temple with the huge serene faces. This place is intricately decorated with dancing apsaras and also features huge bas reliefs that denote what life was like during this period of the Khmer empire. This temple complex is relatively compact. Unless you go super early or super late, you won't have much space to yourself, especially on the upper terraces.

#2 highlight at Angkor. The massive Budda faces, seemingly lurking at you from every direction and around every corner and endless inscriptons in this temple maze made Bayon the second most interesting of the Khmer temples. A guide is a must to understand the relative history of each different temple and how Hinduism versus Buddhusm carved the stories of these massive and unfortunately crumbling culture gems!
Beautiful Bayon. Mystical experience at this spellbinding temple. It is just mesmerising and in my opinion the highlight of the entire amazing area.

Bring your paitence and water. We got here around 9am-9.30am and it was busy. It is a lot smaller than the likes of Angkor Wat and so you certainly notice the crowd, as people are climbing over and on everything, just to try and get around one another. It was also very hot on this day, so be sure to take water, we saw one lady pass out, but thankfully she was part of a tour group and so help was on hand for her quickly.The temple itself it quite interesting, you will want a tour guide, or to have read into a bit previously to get the real value out of it. I would go back for a second look, at a less crowded time.
Face value . Great temple, once you're inside. Smaller and busier than Angkor Wat, we found it also more impressive, because of the famous faces. Great stuff.

Same but different.. Almost anyone knows about Angkor Wat and, justifiably, wants to visit if/when they are in the area. However, few could name any of the other significant archeological sites in the same general area.Bayon Temple, Angkor Thom, and Ta Prohm are just three of many and, like Angkor Wat could be considered "must-see", too.They are all located in the Angkor Archeological Park and, although sharing similarities, have significant historical and/or architectural differences. A US $40.00 pass gives unlimited entry to all the sites in the park for a 1 week period.

Truly amazing. When we went to visit Bayon Temple we were just amazing. The temples in Cambodia one is nicer than the other. You can feel the history in each of them. I would highly recommend going to this temple. It's great to see that they are still persevered after so many years.

Impressive architecture and smiling faces. This temple stand out from the rest and I would say on par with Angkor wat because of the interesting features. And I do feel like in a maze unless other temple with straight forward design .

Absolutely amazing!. Throughout all of our temple visits I was amazing at the level of access you have everywhere and this temple was no exception. You could go pretty much anywhere you wanted. Prepare to spend at least an hour if you want to see the whole temple and view the wall of carvings.Strongly recommend a licensed guide as ours was very well versed on both the history of the temples as well as the best way to see everything.

Amazing Temple. What an experience seeing the rising sun over the temple and the reflect in the pond, it's magical. The' library' with it's wall carvings are just unimaginable how life was in those days over a thousand years ago!
Great. Te smily Buda faces are like the main attraction, all in stone and it has some kind of hidden chambers that will connect to other parts of the temple, it like a fun maze.Highly recommended

Go for the end of the day. One of my favorite temples.We went there at 4pm when the lights were very bright and orange (the stones of this temple are very dark naturally). The temple was almost empty!

Another amazing temple complex in Siem Reap. These places make you wonder how the people moved such massive amounts of stone and fit them together so perfectly. You have to see it just to realize what humans are capable of when they put their minds to it. Besides it is beautiful
Looking in all directions!. I loved the faces in stone.It was fascinating to see them and compare the intricate carving in each.

Well worth it. This was one of 3 temples (Ta Prohm and Angkor Wat) we visited with our 2 teenage sons. We only spent about 40 minutes there (2 teenagers!) but it was magnificent to see. Climb to the top to see all the faces and enjoy the atmosphere and marvel at what this magnificent civilisation achieved - a great unforgettable experience for all of us.

Charming temple visit. Looking at the buildings and many stone faces of the temple made me take a deep thought about how such a beautiful temple was made. There was high quality architecture, design, engineering and construction skills a very long time ago.

So different from Angkor Wat. Angkor Wat is huge and this temple is in the centre of Angkor Thom. It is so different in style and construction, it was hard to conceive it was built by the same people. A lot of the temple has fallen down but restoration in ongoing and it still is magnificent. There is not much I can say about it that hasn't already been said, visit it and feel what was once an alive, active city and temple.Walking around this behind on the rest of the Angkor Thom grounds area is a day in itself. This is one of the do not miss sights while you are there.
Well worth spending a few hours here. If you have the time, make a point of visiting this temple, it certainly makes you think, and simply wonder at the years gone by!

So nice had to go twice. . The first time we went it was super early in the morning. So nice and so incredibly quiet with hardly anyone there. The second time we went was right before lunch, terrible mistake... The place turns into an absolute zoo, complete with the group of people following the man with the waist mounted voice speaker and the flag that looks like to belongs on the back of a dune buggy. It really is a remarkable and unique place. The faces make the temple much more personal and totally took me back to watching the Legend Of the Hidden Temple game show from the 90's. Hard to believe humans were capable of making such a beautiful structure so long ago... Or maybe it was aliens.... *queue twilight zone music*
A must see. As well as Angkor Wat, this temple is also a must see.Very huge area, bring some time with you. Little side note, in one of the temples was a Tomb Raider movie shot. ;)

Fantastic!!. When my tuk tuk driver drove past this I couldn't believe it. Great condition, but can get very busy so patience is a must. It was great fun to 've able to climb on some of the structures to get birds eye views and great pic.

Excellent temple. Without doubt Bayon is the most attractive temple after the main Angkr wat temple, the details of bas-relifs are stunning and you need a expert guide to tell you about them. in the morning (when i visit) it was crowd and unfortunately i didn't have time to go back again in the afternoon, however, the temple is also very photogenic.

My favorite of all the temples . Baton temple to me was the most interesting. The designs of the building was beautiful and there were a lot less people to encounter than the main Angkor Wat temple. I spent the most time here and got some beautiful pictures. I'd highly recommend visiting Bayon temple if you haven't got much time and have to be selective which temples you see.
Beautiful!. Well maintained. Restoration work is as close as it can possibly get to the original.All the smiling faces of the kings are so beautiful and clearly visible.

Impressive. At the centre of Angkor Thom. Has over 50 tower which are decorated by over 200 smiling faces. Everywhere you look you are greeted by another smiling face. Bayon is decorated with over 1km of bas-reliefs that have more than 11,000 figures. The carvings on the outer wall depict life in the 12th? century Cambodia.

Different from any other temple I've seen before. The buddha faces all over the temple do set it apart from any of the intricately carved temples or the grand Birla Mandirs you might see in India. Always a good idea to read the wiki page before visiting so you get a good sense of history of the place. A guide would also be good to learn about Bayon.

Outsatanding. The temples are a thoroughly worth seeing! I Fantastically part of a full day that included all temples & when we arrived The Bayon Temple was virtually empty. It was very tranquil & something I'll never forget!! A must see : )
Worth the visit. This is one of the main temples in the area and really worth to visit. It's less 'organised' than other temples but that makes it so appealing.

Guide was good value. This is the only temple we had a guide for. It was good to get an official guide and he gave us a good general background history to the whole temple area including Angkor Wat. 2 hrs tour for $25USD, bargain. The book The Angkor Guidebook is an excellent read and has great before and after photos. If you can, buy it from your hotel when you arrive and try to read up before venturing to the temples.

Stunning temple (older than Angkor Wat)... great to see in the morning. We saw the Bayon Temple in the morning (leaving the big crowds to see Angkor Wat then) and the timing was great. It was less crowded. Another incredible site in the large Angkor Thom complex.

Amazing detail... at every turn. Visited this place on my last day in late after noon as the sun was setting. Perfect time. This has some of the most amazing detail of all the temples. It's one you should not miss.
Simply amazing. The place is so beautiful, so overwhelming, that one is speechless. For those who have been to Mexico, a bit similar to the Olmec heads
Faces. One of the great ruins on the moated island of Angkor Thom. This is where you'll see the most stone faces in the one spot. Simply beautiful.
Maybe better as Angkor Wat. You must see faces of Bayon - it is so fantastic experience. For me one of best in Angkor. Many people here, but I feel I was alone.

Loved it. There was a lot to see at the Bayon temple. With a good guidebook, you can be here for quite a while. Do bring your own snacks or water with you. For lunch inside Angkor Thom was more expensive than at Angkor Wat, it is advisable to eat at the stalls opposite Bakheng which was not too far away.
Bayon Temple. Same like Angkor Wat. Must see and beautiful. Usually it's included in visit to Angkor Wat. Not much to say, one of most beautiful temples in the park.
Beautiful Bayon. Another temple that never to be missed. I found this temple a bit similar to Angkor temple.i went in the afternoon, less crowd.
A good place to end your day.. Visit in the late afternoon for the least amount of tourist traffic. Most of the large tour groups go here in the morning so it's virtually empty in the evening.
My favourite. This was my best one as with a guide showed where to get some cool pictures. Loved kissing a Buddha and seeing lots if different ones.lots of places to look.

Very impressive and inspiring. First impression of this Temple is not that great but once you step in and discover it by your own eyes it thrills you right away and you cant stop looking around to see all the small and huge nice areas in that area. I personally like that Temple the most of all the once we visit in that day.
Another archetecural wonder!. You have to have an Angkor Wat ticket to visit this place. And, it's a must to see, too. How they did what all they did for the when they did it all is INCREDIBLE.
Stunning. Just wonder around and look at all the different stone carved faces. Amazing place to spend a couple of hours.
Best temple at angkor. The faces make it just facinating make sure you get a photo with your nose touching one of the faces

Beautiful old Temple. Large temple complex, currently being restored by the French?? Temple is interesting with lots to see - unfortunately has lots of steep steps. Very scary for those of us with fear of heights or balance issues!! Although once up the stairs very flat promenade around the top of the temple - go views across Siem Reap and great for photos.

You can't help but smile too. Bayon is a lot of people's favourite. This was the second temple we saw after the spacious and grand Angkor Wat. I was excited to see the reliefs and sculptures but the hoards of noisy tourists really ruined it for me. As you make your way up the temple, it gets squashy with the amount of people and being hot as it is just made me irritated and annoyed. For this reason I would recommend seeing this earlier in the morning of late in the afternoon as unlike other temples, there are no trees for shade. But commenting on the architecture and structure, Bayon is a curious maze, a lot of fun to wander through and make your own discoveries. I even went back for a second visit on our last day, because there's always sometime else to see.The reliefs are awesome, the detail that has gone into them are amazing. And the fact that it is telling a story just makes it more astounding. I would recommend buying a book and reading up on the scenes depicted so that it can be better appreciated. Chams verus Khmer, scenes of everyday life. There's so much to take in. The smiling faces are eerie yet evoke a sense of peace. There are many opportunities for the typical corny tourist photos here! Bayon is not as grand nor as simple as other temples, it sort of in between, on its own, unique, eclectic, full of quirky details. But it's definitely just as memorable as the Angkor Wat.
Spectacular. One of the most impressive temple structures but because of that very full all the time. Best to be there early

Absolutely stunning. This is a vast temple known for its smiling faces - about 200 of them. The detail is incredible. Plenty to photograph, particularly early morning when the light is good and you can really pick out the decoration. Early morning is also fairly quiet in comparison with the rest of the day.
Beautiful, calm and spiritual. It was wonderful to walk through this temple area. We were lucky enought o be there without tonnes of tourists, thanks to our guide. Just breathtaking.

wonderful experience. Experienced that one with the 20min elephant ride ahead of going through the temple. Amazing! Well worth the visit and the elephants looked in great condition and the people handling them were very friendly.

Superb architecture and sculpture. A marvel of Khmer architecture, the temple is in good condition. The many towers still have the thousands of detailed carvings intact. The huge smiling faces of Avalokiteshvara are noteworthy.

One of the best in the temple circuit. Deffo one of the best temples in the whole of angkor much better than Angkor wat in my opinion. Truly deserves a lot of time and reading of the guide book to understand how much detail has gone in to everything. Deffo do Bayon if your short of time.

My favorite temple . Bayon is fantastic. Not as crowded as Angkor Wat. Massive grounds to explore & you can climb very high on the temples without the long queues of Angkor Wat. The stairs are very steep - so take your time & climb carefully.
Eerie.. Big brother, or at least big Buddha is watching you! Magnificent but a bit spooky. Not to be missed and of course wonderful photo opportunities.

Beautiful!. Very very beautiful temple. Has one part where the statue's smile is particular pleasant. You can't miss it because there will be alot of tourists there taking photos with it. Conveniently at photo taking level too. Be prepared for alot of walking and stair climbing though. Recommend a good pair of walking shoes.

My number two Attraction in Angkor. This is a must see in Angkor. Preferable visiting time before noon or evening depending upon how you want your photography. I personally was awe stuck with the numerous large faces carved on the towers. Most of the Temple is in Ruins , but we go to Angkor to see these ruins . Dont we?

Most unique temple. This is one-of-a-kind temple with huge faces carved on the towers. Makes for good photographic options. We visited this temple right after catching the sunrise at Angkor Wat. There were very few people in the complex at that hour. The early morning rays falling on the carvings made for good photography. We spent a good 2 hours in peace here and left just as the large tour groups began to arrive in buses. Since it is a small complex it gets crowded very quickly. Highly recommend to visit early in the morning

A MUST SEE during your lifetime. Angkor Wat is a marvel. How these Kymer people ever built these structures is impossible to imagine. To think that millions of people lived here then left because of famine. What ever you do, go there before sunrise and watch the sun rise over the ruins. To sit there on the rocks and imagine it being built had me in awe
Amazing . Fantastic place to visit. Awe-inspiring from the outside and a labyrinth when inside with every turn opening to new amazing discoveries. A must see.
Impressive!. This temple is amazing! Probably my favourite as the detail is incredible. Definitely worth a visit if going to Angkor Wat!
One of the temples to visit.... So many things and temples to visit in the area... take one at a time. Visit in the morning when not too hot.

A Must-See in Angkor Complex. The faces that are carved into the temples are amazing. It's an otherworldly feeling to have hundreds of faces surrounding you and it's a magnificent aesthetic. There are plenty of excellent photo opportunities in this temple! The wall carvings are stunning as well. Make sure you have a tour guide (your hotel can hook you up) because they will tell you all about the history and the stories in the carvings. This was really cool and I have never seen anything like it. If you only have time to see a few temples, make sure this one is on your list as it is unique. Don't miss out on the view from the back after you exit--it is impressive!

The best is to take an off-track biketour of Angkor Thom with the social enterprise Khmer for Khmer Organisation (KKO).. You will see villages and temples that are not accessible by tuk-tuk or taxi. KKO is a terrific off-track bike tour social enterprise.

Stunning temple - one of the "Must Sees" for the Angkor Complex. This is one of the best preserved temples (and arguably one of the most famous) on the Angkor Wat site, and is made up of 54 crafted central towers, each decorated with four opposing faces representing King Jayavarman VII. Bayon’s stone galleries display very famous bas-reliefs incorporating over 11,000 figures (took this on word, as I didn't count them), with the detail quite astonishing in places..and still intact. Again, a very popular site to visit and it did get quite crowded...especially the stupidly steep steps to get to the top (but again a very worthwhile visit)
My 3rd favourite in Angkor area. Nice temple along the way through the Angkor area. You should really stop by and take a look. Very easily accessible by bicycle.

not my favourite but great engravings. Bayon temple has fabulous towers each with the four smiling faces and great engravings with many details. Unfortunately it is also very crowded, so unless you visit it very early in the morning or at sunset, you'll be packed with many other tourists.

Has to be seen to be believed!. Just wonderful, really one of the most beautiful amazing places in the world, if you can go, you should. Not too much climbing of stairs despite this being one of the taller temple complexes and those their are have fairly steep but sturdy staircases.
My favourite of all the temples. These temples are amazing and stories that are on the walls are fantastic. A lot of stairs and quite steep. Love the four faces of Buddha.

Another fantastic temple near Angkor Wat main temple . Another very impressive temple to view, very close to Angkor Wat and accessible already if you have the 1-day or 3-day pass.
Lots of walking around, more open air than Angkor Wat.

Be fit . This is an extraordinary temple with towers which have massive smiling Buddha faces on each side of the towels over 400 massive just massive. Quite a lot of climbing over ruins wtc so go early in the day before it is too hot.

Magnificent!. This is a magnificent temple. It gets more incredible as you rise to the top. Greeted by the budha faces, an incredulous smile appeared on my own face and didnt leave me till I got home.

Not our favorite of the temples but the engraving is impressive. This is large and there are many towers but I prefer the other temples in the complex. Make sure you look closely at the engraved walls as they tell a story and you can learn what the people valued.
Interesting and unique. The 4 faces on each monument are mostly damaged but still worth a trip. Medium sized temple so can go round it in 1 hour.

My Favourite temple. Bayon is so different the Angkor Wat. For a far, it looks like ruin that is not been restored, But as you walk closer and closer, you will start seeing the details and the many towers and many smiling faces. I was mesmerized by this temple, we went in early morning right after the sunrise, So there were just practically me, my friend, and another 2 girls, We had the temple for ourselves for a good 30 minutes before the crowd started showing up.
Coolest temple ruins I have seen so far. Spectacular, enchanting, mesmerizing. Absolutely do not miss. Fits as a perfect semblance of ancient mystique and wonder.

Beautiful carvings. One of the more beautiful temples in the complex. The carvings are exceptional, and very distinct. Love the wall carvings too - all of them have survived the centuries without pillage
Impressive sculptures. As shown in most photos the remarkable aspect of the temple are the dozens of huge stone faces on the towers. Much smaller and less crowded with tourists.

Beautiful unique temple. 216 faces of Budda. There are several interesting gates to the city on the way with other interesting bits of architecture such as the dancing towers. There are rough walk ways and some step steps so if you've got bad knees beware. No matter where you turn there is a Budda looking at you. Worth a trip.

Worth a visit . All the temples in the complex are incredible wonders, and Bayon is no exception. My advice is to space your temple visits out over two days, especially during the wet season (hot, humid) as it is easy to become worn out after seeing two, and you want to be fresh to experience each one to to the maximum. Hire a guide for the best experience, the Khmer guides are highly informative and exceptionally friendly, and will show you small interesting intricate elements of the temples you might otherwise miss.
amazing. very amazing!!!! I dnt know how they made this temple. The sculpture are so detailed. It is really worth the visit.

By far the second best after angkor wat. The temple is an example of symmetrical architecture. The huge larger than life smiling yet calm faces of Vishnu or Buddha however you interpret attracts all. Each face structure is unique in construction yet looks same. When seen together, it is very iconic. This is to say that God is everywhere. A place to visit for sure.
Number two tourist attraction. Number two tourist attraction in Siem Reap. Very impressive architecture. A great experience to explore and photograph. Also crowded but for good reason.

Beautiful. The Bayon temple is the gem of Angkor Thom with its beautifully carved faces. If you go with a guide they will undoubtedly take your photograph seemingly nose to nose with one of the heads!

Must!. Bayon is a must, I could talk here for pages and pages about it, bottom line is if you are visiting the temples, Bayon has to be on that list. Take your time, avoid the crowds and pick your own route. It is 360 degrees of stunning!

Bayon is a must see. Bayon, another very popular temple (thus a little crowded) is still a must see. The carving and sheer magnitude are breathtaking. Hike to the top for sure for a great view of the faces up close and good panoramics of the surrounding area.

I am looking at you!. Crazy and smiling faces look at you from every angle in this maze-like temple. Walking around these enormous stone faces is an experience not to be missed, and the architecture of Bayon is unique and wonderful. Cerainly a must-see when visiting the Angkor temples
Wow. Such an amazing temple with so much detail. We loved this temple and its many turns and surprises. We also took an elephant ride, which was really cool. You will not be dissapointed.
Beautiful!. Arguably one of our favorite temples here. Highly suggest going with a tour guide. Tons & tons of history here

nice place for history lovers. Nice place! R. Kippling written about in in his "Jungle book" in the end of 19th century. Real impressive place in jungle from ferry tale story. No dislikes, liked everything.
My fav. The best looking in my opinion along with Ta Phrom . look for Mao in front of Tanei Boutique Villa. Excellent tuktuk guy
Favorite temple in all of the Angkor complex. Amazing experience, that I will always treasure. Be careful to avoid the crowds. We found mid-afternoon to be the quietest.

Very nice. Beautiful statues/sculptures of smiling Buddha faces.
Amazing site to visit that is centuries old. Fantastic.
Siem Reap Angkor Complex - Bayon Temple. Unforgettable with wonderful journey in Cambodia, Bayon temple - a beautiful temple, cultural known of temples

A 'must-see' in Cambodia; beautifully sculpted faces. Enough of the original construction remains to provide a glimpse of how stunning this place must have been during its glory days. Wear good walking shoes and a hat; bring a camera.
Our favourite. The whole area here is quieter and more diverse than the Angkor Wat (though it doesn't have the spectacular temples) - best explored just after sunrise when cooler and quieter.

Impressive.. All great temples close to each other, and all of them very impressive. Wondering how they managed to build theese great monuments almost 900 years ago. Buy a 3 day ticket to all the temples priced 40 USD, and take a Tuk Tuk and enjoy.

simply stunning. So much to see at this site, make sure you don't miss it. The climb to the top of one of the towers is well worth it too. As with all the sites at Siem Reap try to time it to miss the crowds. We did the day before Ankor and arrived at circa 8am and was almost empty
The best of the temple city. Unreal, better than Giza. Bucket list material. Go here first around 8 am is plenty early. Then circle back to Angkor Wat to avoid the crowds.

Bayon Temple impressions . The entrance as well as the temple itself are quite impressive. However, because the temple was neglected for a long time a lot of it is in ruins and is in urgent need of restoration. Further, the Cambodians have stolen the heads of many of the statues. This information was given to us by our local guide.Because of lengthy neglect, trees have grown everywhere, some even in and over the walls. The roots of the trees, which are very thick by now, travel along the walls, over the walls and sometimes through the walls. Our guide concentrated more on this than the temple itself. Indeed these formations are interesting even though they have nothing to do with the original temple.
The most impressive in our view. The faces are incredible and we really enjoyed this temple. Bit less busy and some amazing carvings.

So so, but great. After Angkor war, you tour guide will bring you to Bayon temple. Well nothing special but the ruins are amazing. The elephant ride is expensive comparing it to Thailand. So it's up to you. Still the same, bring your own water bottle.

My favourite temple. I enjoyed this more than Angkor Wat. I just really liked the 216 heads. We arrived at maybe 9:30am and it was pretty busy, my friend and I were behind a Chinese tour group on our way round, however I thoroughly enjoyed my visit. There is construction work going on there on one side (the side we arrived at) at the moment (January '16) but that didn't do anything to detract from the amazement. Give yourself about 1.5 hours here.

Outstanding and a must see.. The second of the temples we visited after Angkor Wat, access around the temples is not suitable for people with any disability as it requires climbing a lot of steps. The Buddha images carved into the ancient rocks are outstanding and one of my favourite sights of Cambodia. You can also get an elephant back ride around the perimeter of the complex.

Many Faces. Bayon is well worth seeing, with 54 towers decorated with 200 huge, smiling faces. There is a face on each side of each tower, so wherever you look, you are staring back at a hugh face. We were able to get some great pictures here.

We didn't spend as much time here as there were restoration works happening.. It's worth seeing because it's different from Angkor Wat. It is in a state of more disrepair so there are areas that aren't accesslble.

Visit it carefully.... A goldmine . Bayon was the state temple of Jayavarman VII, a powerful ruler in the late 13th century. The temple sat at the center of Angkor Thom, a walled city that served as the capital of the Khmer Empire. Four of the city's five gates sat on axis with the temple, and the walls of the city substituted for the enclosure walls normally found at Khmer temples. The walls sit at such a distance from the temple that the temple seems to rise abruptly from the ground like an artificial mountain. In fact, the temple was intended to evoke the form of Mt. Meru—the cosmic mountain at the center of the world in Buddhist cosmology. In keeping with this cosmic symbolism, the plan of the temple is based on a 'yantra', a symbol used by Tantric Buddhists as the basis of mandala diagrams that represent the layout of the universe. The temple honored not just one deity, but a host of gods found throughout the Khmer empire. Its central shrine held an image of Jayavarman VII, who perhaps imagined himself as a god-King ruling in the name of the Buddha.The temple is best known today for the gigantic face sculptures that adorn its thirty-seven surviving towers. Facing in four directions on each tower, the faces are thought to represent Lokeshvara, a Buddhist deity that projected benevolence outward to the four directions.

The most impressive temple with beautiful bas relief. This place is a must!We went there twice and spent around 6 hours there.It has so much to offer if you are interested in history and archaeology.Get the Ancient Angkor book or any other Angkor boom, and get lost in the story of carvings in the outer and inner walls, and then climp up to see the enigmatic faces.It might be a bit busy in morning, but if you go there around lunch time or after, it's great. There are lots of shades, so you can enjoy the breeze from time to time.The elephant terrace, lepper king terrace are only 5-10 minutes walk to the north of Bayon temple.There are plenty of restaurants around elephant terrace ( 5 minutes from bayon)But be careful as you might get sick.The weird thing about these restaurants is that they all have different number above them, but their menu is exactly the same, make sure you bargain for the food when they approach you to get you on their restaurant. You can get a food around 2-3$ nstead of the written price (6-8$)! I've never bargained for food, so it sounded odd to me. We got a coconut chicken for only 2 bucks, but gladly we had hand sanitizer to clean the spoons, and got drinks in a can.

The face carvings are a true work of art. Soooooo much detail in all the carvings. Continually amazed by all the temples. What I love is the lack of health and safety - common sense not to fall off the edges - we should adopt a bit more of that attitude in the west!

Happy faces temple. Like most temples in Siem Reap, it was crawling with people so it is a little difficult to get good pictures and enjoy the tranquil beauty of the area. This temple was very nice because it had unique faces on many of the temple pillers. Definitely worth seeing

Good Temple. Bayon, Angkor Wat, and Angkor Thom are the headlining temples in the main circuit many tourists see when visiting the park. Bayon is definitely a difficult one to miss and you should spend time at it. It's definitely very different from all other temples in the park with the faces jutting out of the rock face.However if I had to rank the three main temples I would put Bayon last on the list. Albeit remember you are comparing them to absolutely phenomenal temples. Make sure you just make enough time to visit all three of them - you won't regret it. Visiting the temples at the park can be a long exhausting day, but it's why you came to Siem Reap so take the time and hire a tuk-tuk to take you around for all day! Don't pay more than $20 for a driver to take you around all day - you can probably get one for about $15. Be nice to him though because they are really caring people.
Wow . This one we visited in the morning when the temperature was very pleasant! Bit tricky to walk around,need good walking shoes. Not very suitable for disabled people!
spellbinding. Of all the temples in which we were - like the most. We have it back for re- examination . I recommend.

Most beautiful of the temples. I found Bayon the most beautiful of the temples in Siem Reap. It's the most famous together with Angkor Wat but I enjoyed that it's much less crowded and The structure and statues even more interesting.
Great!. If you enjoy historical, cultural and religious sites, don't miss this. Either take a guide book or guide with you, though, as there is nothing that explains what went on where.

One of the must visit temples. Bayon is unique for all the "faces" stones. But I got bored too quickly. I think the temple is one of the most sacred, you will see some statues. But besides the faces statues making for some really nice photos there is nothing much in there. I got out pretty quickly. Still worth visiting but didn't spend that much time there.

Stunning temple with amazing detail. All the temples around the Angkor area are amazing...no one is better than the other as they are all different in style and art work. The Bayon temple will blow you away.

Top 2 of 3. This temple has an outstanding history and delightful, enigmatic characters that you just can't help but be drawn to. Think it's definitely No 2 in the 1) Angkor Wat, 2) Bayon, 3) Ta Prohm listings for a day's visit to the temples.

Great historical site. Bayon is one of my favourite temples in Angkor area. Lots of four-face smiling with this temple. It is in the heart of Angkor Thom city with lots of temple sites around it. You can go to see this temple in the morning to avoid crowded people. And it is also the time for photograph.
Bayon temple. For me simply the most impressive temple in Siam reep. This temple is in a much better shape than the rest of the temples.
Bringing together all as one. Each of the entrances is exactly the same because this is the place were everyone is equal and the same. The preciseness of the images is incredible.

So Many Smiling Faces!. Or are those faces mocking? Do a little research or hire a guide.
This temple is more compact than Angkor Wat, so less physically challenging. Even so, it is just as interesting in its own ways.

One of the best. The Bayon in my opinion is more impressive than all the other temples; this is a totally subjective opinion :-). Like most other temples try and visit very early before the Chinese and Japanese mass tourist trips arrive. They tend to arrive at midday so its worth getting up early, also the heat of the day really builds by 12.30pm so another good reason to arrive early. By the way be aware of photo scammers at this temple. We experienced it twice one was a chap casually dressed who said he would take a photograph of my wife and I, he then lead us to another "perfect spot" to take another photograph etc. aftering taking a few snaps he then requested that we pay him 10$ for his services! If this wasn't bad enough we had a policeman...yes a policeman try and pull the same stunt when we visited a second time!

Great Bayon Temple. It was a great chance to visit this fabulous temple. The stone carving on the wall describes all the histories of Khmer empire at that time. Our Guide (Pon) was great enough to share us about the history of this temple. Come and visit this temple if you are in Siem Reap. Most recommended.
Loved it. I may have enjoyed this more than Angkor Wat. It was amazing to see and walk through. We even took an elephant ride around the temple. Beautiful!
Just brilliant. Almost as impressive as Angkor Wat, great carvings, so glad we had such a knowledgeable guide to help us understand the carvings

Better than Angkor Wat.. Bayon temple and the Angkor Tom area were our favourite temples of Angkor, over grown, wild and relatively uncrowded. You really feel like an explorer as you walk through the dark tumbled down chambers of Bayon or up the steps to the peak of Baphuon.We also got a tuk tuk driver to take us on a tour of some of the smaller temples from here for $18. We were offered 2 tours, the big and the small, we took in the big tour which takes in a lot of very cool temples, but we wished we had taken the small tour which included the most overgrown temple.Beware: there are muggers operating in the more secluded jungle temples.
its look like the real face,. after walking in tired just relax in the shadow, to listen cicada very nice sounds, very large space of terrace of elephant,

AMAZING TEMPLE. The amazing Cambodian temple! The left side of the temple where that people chose to end the walking is the best place to relax and to see this temple more longer. I would visit again and again to this temple.
Great to visit.. One of THE Temples to see at Angkor Wat. Wonderful carving but try to avoid the crowds. But don't confuse it with the Bayon inside Angkor Wat, this is a few kilometres away.

Spectacular sight, more impact than Angkor Wat we felt. The history here is amazing, you need to be fairly sure footed though. The ground is uneven and you will need to climb up to appreciate it fully.

What a beauty . We went here as our 3rd and final stop around the temples and what a way to end.
The faces are still visible and look incredible. We spent about an hour here as you can climb up quite high but the crowds grew and grew in seconds so get there early.
Temple Run!. After seeing the Angkot Wat, Bayon Temple was our second destination if I can remember correctly. Overall, the ruins are a fascinating sight to see.
Quiet and lovely to visit. Loved the smiling Buddhas and the whole temple was just a delight.Did it in about 2 hours and this was long enough. Some restoration work on its way but did not detract.

A Definite MUST SEE. I can't say enough good things about this place. Out of all the places we visited this moved me the most. I can't explain why. Maybe it was the beauty of the carved faces or the layout of the temple but I enjoyed every minute I was there.Visited in the afternoon so it was a little warm but not too many tourists groups. The are plenty of places to take some really amazing pictures around the temple and inside of it. Do not miss the opportunity to take the juxtapose pic face to face with a carving. (check the photo section to see what I'm talking about)This is a MUST SEE attraction in Siem Reap.
Stunning!. Another temple not to be missed. There are many photo opts here. Since there is so much to see, I visited Bayon on a separate day from Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm.
Fantastic. The complex is fantastic with Buddha heads everywhere. It isn't as large as some of the other temples, but the architecture is quite amazing.

Spectacular. With 54 towers taking on the shape of a pyramid you get a spectacular view of the temple as you approach from the South Gate. The many stone faces appear foreboding warning you that you are about to enter a very special place. Once inside the complex you discover the many reliefs depicting the numerous Khmer conflicts to both defend and expand the Empire. It helps to have a knowledgeable guide to relate the history of Bayon.We were fortunate to have one of the best, Pin Vannik, who shared the history and facts of Bayon which made for a much more interesting visit.

stunning. this is a site everyone has seen in publications and movies and travel articles. The architecture and relief faces were spiritual. But get there early. when the bus tours arrive your photo opportunities will disappear and your ability to view & appreciate the place will be seriously diminished.

Amazing!. Bayon Temple is a must see if you to to Siem Reap, it is easy to get lost in the temple, so easier to follow the crowds.
The stonework and faces chiselled in to the stone is amazing!
A must see.

One of the best . Bayon temple is really amazing. Once you get to the top you can walk around the central tower which is surrounded by several towers, each one with four giant Bhudda faces, one on each side. On the way down we explored a lot of the narrow hallways on the lower level. Very cool, especially since most visitors (there weren't that many there to begin with) don't bother with this part of the temple. We almost felt like Indiana Jones.
Temple. Bayon temple is quite nice temple but the stone drop & damage very serious, almost 40% fall down aldy. But the structure still there, the graphic on the wall still can see very clearly.

One of two favorites in Angkor Wat. Bayon doesn't seem too different from a distance, but once we actually enter the complex, you see exactly how much character it has. The faces are huge and varied, and depending on the angle of the sun, there are so many opportunities for good photos. Bayon is also good in that you can walk around various places inside the smaller buildings, not just around the perimeter. This adds to the sense of adventure as you explore and see new stuff around every turn and corner. Highly recommened!
Amazing. It is all I can say about all the Angkor temples. Amazing. Just take a guide and hear the stories. Just incredible
Unexpected. Loverly faces watching you from all angles. Try and avoid the crowds though. Large tour groups monopolised some of the photo ops!!!

Amazing!. This was my favourite temple despite the crowds. The structures are fantastic and so well preserved. Everywhere you turned there was a different face to admire - my camera was definitely in overdrive here!

The ladies temple. The king built this beauty for his mother - it's feminine and known as the smile temple - not to be missed . You can visit this while doing Angkor Tom - all the temples in and the entrance at Angkor Tom are wellbeing s visit ... Take your time here and preferable do this seperately to the Angkor Wat visit .
Beautiful temple! . Another remarkable temple in the ankor wat area Siem reap, the skill and work that has gone into this structure is amazing!! Do not miss this!!

Amazing Architecture. The architecture of the temple domes is outstanding. The huge faces os Buddha on all sides of the top domes are impressivly huge. The temple is in ruins but is really worth a visit

amazing. The heads are really cool. I'm sure the view from the top was amazing, but sadly due to my ankle i was unable to go up the steep steps to the very top. The different faces are really interesting. Bayon was being renovated while I was there so a part of it was not accessible.
A must visit. Another fantastic temple in the Angkot Tom complex a must see if your in the area great carvings all around temple

Temple. This was the second temple of our own guided tour. It was really big, and there were again, a lot of tourists. It is still worth checking out though. I was getting templed out at this point.. but not complaining :) Bring sunscreen, because it gets quite sunny.

A beautiful place. So beautiful so interesting
Wonderfully carved faces not to be missed I especially loved the bridge leading up to it with its huge serpents and carved figures pulling on the snake on both sides
The faces...everywhere. Along with Angkor Wat this is a must see in Siem Reap. An amazing site that will keep your interest for hours. I highly recommend this if you find yourself in Cambodia.
hidden gem. stunning carvings make this a must see on your trip to the area - well worth a visit along with the other main temples
Great. All around you are faces, you can take your picture with your nose touching of the temple faces nose

Magnificent. We stopped here for about 1hr at 11am. It was far too hot and we suffered a lot. The temple is beautiful with all the faces looking at you. I really liked it here and it wasn't too busy, but it was too hot
Smaller site but interesting. I really liked the massive carvings, these ancient people were really artisans. Crowded but still possible to get a wonderful feel of the past.

love at first sight. in my opinion the best of the temples. one of the few Buddhist temples and has a great feel to it. inside the top head is a little shrine where i found peace from the outside never ending crowd.

Breathtaking!!!!. Go during late afternoon sun for wonderous colors on the stones. This is an amazing temple that is not to be missed during a brief stay in Siem Reap. Definitely in the Top 3 temples outside of Angkor Wat.
great atmosphere. Not as majestic as Ankor Wat but had more atmosphere.Try to go early morning or evening as the lighting is fantastic for photos.
Great. Much less restored and more primitive than Angkor. It is a great site and relatively easy to navigate. Don't miss it.

Another must see. This is another must see temple near Siem Reap. Be prepared for climbing many steep stairs but the views are extraordinary. It would be helpful to go to the national museum in Siem Reap before going just to have bit better understanding of what you are seeing - or have a good guide.

If you're tired of the same ol same ol, come here. A lot of the temples started to look the same by the time we got around to Bayon, so we were excited that it was different from most of the other ones. It was really busy when we were there (around 11am), so I would recommend going much earlier.

This is must for once in my lifetime.. How could those people construct all these amazing structures in Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom areas? Besides their enormous sizes, those carvings in sandstone are so neat.

Beautiful. Is one of the most important temples, so it is a must see. Most tours include the visit. It was one of my favorite, with the faces, thetowers and the arquitecture.
There were a lot of people because it was 10am, so you should go early in the morning. Here you also have to climb some steps, so be prepared!

Pretty. Pretty hot.. I went to the Angkor Village without a map so I was delighted when I saw Bayon by accident. It was such a beautiful temple but it was just too hot and crowded to go around. There were also too many people going around the temple at 13:30. Really? Avoid Bayon during those hours. Always go very early or late.

Visit in late afternoon. This place just had the most magical atmosphere of any of the Angkor temples. Loved the monkeys roaming around. Drive around the outside and stop for a lovely mirror image of the temple in the water surrounding the temple.

The temple of thousand faces!. This temple could be one of the most iconic throughout Angkor Thom complex, it is filled with faces, everyone of each has different expressions. Try to count all the faces... You will fail!
Loved this temple. I could not stop taking photos of all the faces carved on this wonderful temple. It should be a Must See on your list.
fantastic. dont miss this site full of history and as i said in my last review use a guide or you will be dis appointed

Everything you expect . As with Angkor Wat it's hard to say anything new. If you've read other reviews and guidebooks, you get exactly what you expect. Very interesting, and definitely worth including in your temples tour. But as I said in my review of Angkor Wat, whilst the temples are wonderful, you should make sure you get out and do other tours to villages, the river etc and see a little more of Cambodia, if Siem Reap is to be your only stop in this lovely country. Contact Q Travel for information on tours from Siem Reap

So beautiful...those smiling stone faces !. Bayon temple was built in 1190AD by Jayavarman VII, one of the Khmer Empire’s greatest kings, and it was the only state temple built primarily as a Buddhist temple dedicated to Buddha. The temple stood in the exact center of Angkor Thom, and represent the intersection of heaven and earth. Bayon is famous for it's huge stone smiling faces at each tower, and many believe these are the portraits of Jayavarman himself. Bayon is one of my favourite and also a must see temple in Angkor Thom. Originally there were 56 towers where each with four stone faces of its own, and currently less than 40 remain.

Temple. Really interesting place to visit.so much history and locals r very proud of their heritage.was extremely hot on the day but our guide made sure we had cold water at all times.can take as long as u like as their is so much to see and take in.lots of stairs though.sunscreen and walking shoes a must.
Not to be missed. Along with Ta Prohm one of the top two sites. In my opinion, much better than Angkor Wat. The giant Buddha heads are amazing.
Must see!. While most people go to Angkor Wat itself, some of the smaller temples are as good or even better and Baynon is one of these. Do not miss!!

Beautiful!. I enjoyed this one almost as much as Angkor Wat. There is a serenity to the presence of yhe huge Buddha faces. It is not as busy and much easier to walk around.Am I the only one who thought some of the wall carvings reminded me of the Bayeaux Tapestry? Samd vintage!

My favorite temple. Though it is a tough choice, this was my favorite of all Angkor temples. The symbolism and architecture, are remarkable, I had a feeling of accomplishment whilst visiting, always in awe at the magic of this place; a dream come true

Temple with the many faces. This is one of the must see temples in Angkor Wat. Originally with 49 towers with stone faces depicting Khmer King Jayavarman VII on each side, currently less than 40 remain. Around the temple walls are reliefs that depict Khmerian wars and daily life, having a guide would be good to get an explanation to understand the historical context.
Don't Miss It!. Great temple option with the impressive head sculptures. See this and others outside of the Angkor Wat site to get away from the big crowds.
Impressive!. I would like to say it's better than Angkor...actually, for me it was. See it at sunset, catch that dimming light over the Buddha's smiling faces and you will see why..
The best temple. That was amazing, the best temple to see in my opinion. I couldn't leave, that was such a great moment!

It's amazing but come early. We woke up at 5 am, went to see sunrise in Ankor Wat, then headed for Ta Prom, then did two other temples and only arrived to Bayon at about 9.30 - 10 am. It was already too late and the temple was packed with people. I suggest you do it 2nd or 3rd. aim for 8 am ish.

Faces of Buddha. This temple shows the many faces of Buddha and within the walls the history of Buddha is shared. It is hard to believe that the huge carved statues within and around the temple were created and placed before the invention of machines. One can only imagine the dedication and determination of the people who built the temple.

Amazing faces. we visited this temple as part of a tour to Angkor Wat archeo site. Bayon it's amazing! all that faces are incredible and you won't see them so often in the other temples so take enough pics!

went here on the same tour as angkor wat this is another amazing place cant wait to return. went here in november a very hot day amazing scenery cant wait to return as soon as possible as such an an amazing area
Recommended. The bayon temple was spacious and beautiful. It was less crowded than Angkor Wat but it had its own crowd too. Be prepared to climb stairs too, and uneven steps!
My first Angkor temple. I actually liked this better than Angkor Wat. Be cautious on the uneven surfaces - I fell down here. But it's a great place for photography and just a quiet sit.
One of my favorite temples!. I loved this temple! The architecture is amazing and I felt like I was in the jungle book when I was in here. It gets a little crowded at the top but still fun to enjoy
Our Favourite Temple. After being 'templed out' throughout Siem Reap, a visit to Bayon was a breath of fresh air. Highly enjoyable

Bayon was love at first smile. The most unique of them all Bayon is a work of art. I honestly couldn't leave the place. The bridges leading to Bayon took my breath away although they are not considered an attraction. I stopped the driver, walked them and took everything in. Each face is unique and they are all together holding the naga. I wish all bridges were constructed with such care and beauty. What I would give to see this place at the height of it's glory.
Faces temple. Also on your must visit list in Siem Reap, temple with faces in architecture, you can walk through the temple ruins.

In the midst of religious confusion- a master piece is in ruins. flicking between Hinduism (shaivism and Vaishnavism) and Buddhism - the Khmer kings have created a wonderful temple but ruined by their shallow understanding of both the Religions - this attitude has steadily flown to generations after generations where now most people are not sure what these great monuments stand for.
Loved it... You've got to see this array of 3D jigsaw faces made in huge rocks. It was probably our favourite ruin of all the ones we visited.

Arrive early or late. If you arrive early – go for the top directly and spend time with the wonderful bas reliefs after. This way you can beat some of the early tour crowds as well. In the afternoon (after 1600), the light is very good for photos and the crowds are gone. Good photo spots are in the SW corner on the third level. The famous “Smile of Angkor” is in the NE corner – go for this one first to beat the crowds. The intended entrance from east is currently blocked of due to renovations. Some noise and some machines block this area right now. Bring some kind of guide (book or living) to tell the story on the bas relief which is really fascinating and holds a lot of funny and interesting details that you otherwise most likely will miss.
Simply amazing.. A world treasure. If you love history and historic world sites, this temple and the others around Angkor Wat should be on your must-see list.
Felt like Indiana Jones. Great temple, very classic, and a bit off the beaten path. Here you will find trees entangled with the temples and the etchings on the stones are just incredible.

More attractive than Angkor Wat. While Angkor Wat is an international magnet, as a photographer I found the much smaller Bayon Temple to be more picturesque. In fact, I went to this temple twice--first time in the morning and second time in the afternoon. The sight of hundreds of smiling sculpted faces is unforgettable. It was unfortunate, however, that many parts of the faces had been chipped off or replaced by new ones, whose colours did not match the original.

Spectacular!. The Bayon Temple is the second structure that meets after Angkor Wat. If the latter surprised by the size and grandeur, the Bayon is astonishing for its diversity. Very well preserved temple with many interesting and smiling faces around. The atmosphere is calm and silence. Wear good walking shoe, be extra cautious when climbing the steps up and down and drink well. Another wonderful spot for photo taking if arrive early.

The temple of faces. This is a huge temple! You can take good pictures in and outside. I enjoyed jumping over the temple ruins. Though we only stayed for a short time as it is part of our big and small temple trip.

The best temple . This one was my favourite out of the main temples. Not too strenuous and less crowds. Take comfy shoes, water and camera. I'm had a tuk tuk drive me round all the temples for 15 dollars the whole day. Do that it's loads easier and saves your feet. Def go.
Best in the late afternoon . We came at 4pm and it was nearly empty besides and some monkeys. The temple itself is visually striking as there are so many smiley faces on the rocks. Would go again.

Don't hurry too fast through this temple.. If you go up too fast you will miss the exquisitely carved walls full of amazing details. Slow down on your tour. Stop at the stairs on your way up and go left. Explore the walls. They have the most astounding art on them. Don't follow the crowds. While the heads are wonderful, you'll get there in plenty of time. Don't miss the ceiling to floor artwork carved in stone. Unbelievable.
Bayon Temple. Other then the Angkor Wat temple, this is the temple to visit.If you visit this 2 temples all the others will pale by comparison.Not to be missed when you are in Siem Reap.
Whole day temple tour. If you're an admirer of Tom raider temple and Angkor Wat, this will be an average temple for you. But hey! It's worth to visit them!

Temple of faces in all direction. What a spectacular temple. I fell in love with this place as soon as I set my eyes on it. I have never seen such beauty and creation. Definitely another must do with family and friends. Please go early to avoid the afternoon heat and people. These trips are enjoyable during the cool early mornings

An Impressive Temple, but not Angkor Wat . We visited Bayon Temple before Angkor Wat, which was good because it's pretty impressive at first glance, but would have been less so had we first seen Angkor Wat. The site is spectacular, but does not seem to be as well maintained as Angkor Wat. If you're interested in riding around the grounds on an elephant, you can do that here (although we did not). Elephant rides are not an option at Angkor Wat. Definitely worth a visit when in nearby Siem Reap.
Beautiful . This is an amazing temple with its multiple towers adorned with beautiful faces and its fascinating wall carvings. Very picturesque and one of the best temples.
My favourite temple. There is just something about this temple that stands out from the others. I love all the different faces, and there is a special aura in this place

Imagine its original splendor. This is an incredibly elaborate temple which must have been spectacular in its day. The remains speak of enormous ingenuity, workmanship, vision and art that is barely paralleled anywhere in the world. Intricate carvings on the outer walls, the numerous towers and the splendid faces allow for compelling viewing.It is worth doing your research before visiting to ensure that you get the most out of the experience.

One of my favorite tempels. Bacon is next to Ta Prohm, one of my favorite temples. Walk around and explore the temple by yourself. Go around and see the places where not much tourist are coming. Most tourist directly go up to see the big heads but you get a different perspective if you walk around first and see the heads from different angles.

Awesome!. To think that these temples have survived for almost 1000 years is amazing enough. But how did they build these monuments, and make these carvings?! Really incredible. You must have a good guide to explain the intricacies of all the buildings. Guides in Siem Reap are licensed, and recognizable by their pale orange shirts and badges. Try to find one with really good English, and that you can relate to.
The many faces temple. One of the most beautiful. Smaller than Angkor Vat but with these beautiful faces looking in all the directions, it is a must see.

I love Bayon!. Bayon temple is so fascinating. At every part of the temple it feels like someone is looking at you. This place is one of kind. Make sure to get a good guide because not only are you helping in their livelihood but the knowledge that they impart is really interesting. Our Guide was very informative but not boring because he mentions the highlights. (Angkor Vision Tour). Bayon is really remarkable dont miss out visiting this place.

Best Temple!. This was one of my favorite temples! The beautiful carved faces in the towers were amazing. The temple was huge with many staircases and rooms to explore. Definitely plan to see this one.

Make sure you visit this temple!. This is a wonderful place to visit. Smiley Buda temple, how Brem Sopheap, our amazing guide called it, has different faces and heights that give abundance of photo opportunities. It is highly recommended for first-time visitors to have a knowledgable guide to take you through and point out all these photo possibilities. And as I said before, our guide was so good at that!
Wonderful to behold:). Finally!!! I get to see for myself what National Geographic and all those countless articles and photo spreads talk about. Incredible! Impressive!

My Favourite Temple. In this Temple I found myself feeling uplifted and a sense that I was "getting it"... that I was engaging with the ancestors who had built this place. The whole area is magical and if you're someone thinking about visiting, I would say DO IT.

Beautiful temple and largely intact. Make sure you get a close look at the lovely cobra balustrades that run around the building and the elephant walk. There is a lot of walking and it is very hot. Probably not ideal for mobility impaired or disabled tourists. Make sure you take plenty of water.
Surreal . It's hard to take it all in and register exactly what's in front of you. History overload - awesome. Managed to find a few sneaky corners to get some pics without other tourists too.
Heritage site. Another Hindu temple with rich history..restoring work going on.. be prepared to walk a lot..start early to bit the heat..

Amazing site, very crowded. Lots to see in this area, the ruins are beautiful. Watch out for begging children in unexpected corridors and try to keep patience as the hundreds of other tourists disregard 'no climbing' and 'no touching' signs.

Amazing Temple with very big area,. Start the tour at 08:00, leave from the hotel and we have to buy the temple pass for three days for $40.00. with along crowd people and we had waiting over half an hour. a short while we arrive the Bayon temple and the driver will wait us at other side of temple around parking area.we spend around two hours to see all the temples like Bapuon, terrace of elephant.
Favourite . This is our favorite temple with 54 towers and 216 faces , there is some fantastic photo opportunities, but you will have to get in earlier as it gets very busy.
Nice!. Every structure of it is amazing! Though we've been in a lot of temples it was definitely has a different aura when you go inside.

Amazing Temple - A Must See!!. I was in Siem Reap for 2 days, so we dedicated one whole day to temples. We visited Bayon within Angkor Thom first. I would say this is one of my favorite temple! I felt like I was Indiana Jones exploring some forbidden ancient temples! The carvings on the walls were incredibly intricate and beautiful. There are over 50 large beautiful Buddha carvings on steeples and around the temple. Only downside is that there is quite a bit of climbing involved though and steep steps, so it maybe difficult for elderly or those traveling with children. But if you are in Cambodia, I would say the Bayon (inside Angkor Thom) is a must see for temples. Especially if you are short on time like us, this temple would be in the top 3. Fortunately, we had a great Tuk Tuk driver who spoke fluent English and gave us good background and history about the temples as well including the Bayon Temple. If anyone is interested, we highly recommend him. His name is Thary and you can contact him at his email: somthary.greensp@gmail.com

Monkeys were a bonus, but don't miss the bas-reliefs.. The highlight for me was not the climb to the top and view, magnificent though it was, but the wonderful pictures carved in sandstone in the corridors. This reminded me of the Bayeux tapestry in complexity and story-telling.

54 Towers with 216 Faces of Wonders!. The Bayon Temple right in the center of Angkor Thom is a wonderful place to explore. It's various towers of different faces and heights give abundance of photo opportunities. It is highly recommended for first-time visitors to have a knowledgable guide to take you through and point out all these photo possibilities. Our present world of camera on cellphone with selfie stick, Bayon Temple is definitely the temple of choice. However patient and respect of other fellow visitors is a must specially in popular photo spots. In order to cover the whole temple, allow minimum of an hour if not more. Navigating through the steps here is relatively easy in comparing with other Angkor temples.

For Sure my favourite temple. We arrived here after spending the morning at Angkor Wat and for me, this was for sure the most interesting. The carvings are magnificent and it is a great place if you like photography. I am not a great picture taker when on holiday as I tend to live in the moment, however I was clicking away on my camera.
