Please make sure you visit this temple, it is a short tuk tuk ride from Angkor Wat and you can easily spend a day here as there are other temples to see like Elephant Terrace.

So many aspects, so many faces of Buddha . Love this place went there twice. Beautiful-est if you can get there very early. Find peace here! Compact and seemly easily to navigate, however you can get lost if you want. Awesome example at this time of just what goes into restoration, gives you an unlucky get as to what the French did early on.
Just Amazing. Bayon Temple along with Angkor Wat should be on everyone's must see list in a lifetime. The scale of the entire site is mindblowing.
Great!. It is just as fantastic as all the sour rounding sites. Magical! It's definitely one got the diary, have taken lots of pictures.

So unique . I visited all the main temples of Angkor and then some smaller ones and Bayon is the most unique by far. Get a cheap guide outside he will give you some amazing history and background of the temple. It will make it that much better trust me.

My favourite temple in Siem Reap. The smile of Ta Prom, the monkeys on the way to the temple, the elephant ride, the ruins of the temple, the guy who sold his artwork in the temple all are special features of the temple for me. It is not so large which can be easily covered in a short space of time before it got too hot. Love this temple. My kids still remember the elephant ride till now.

My Favorite . It can be busy and that can limit the chance for great shotsI would suggest coming in the late afternoon for the sun setting on the facesBut without doubt this is one of the temples that people associate with Cambodia
Loved the trees around. Beautiful temple. Different faces seen from each of the 4 gates. Even more so we loved the old trees around the temple
Great!. Bayon is the first temple I visited and I find it very amusing. Please from different parts of the world are everywhere in this temple.
Great!. Dont miss this temple during your trip in siem reap! I spend half day there in the morning because from 6-7am in more quiet and best weather to explore this beautiful temple!

Smiling faces all over.. This is my favourite temple as everywhere you will see the smiling faces stone. You need to walk up and down at this place so having a pair of good and comfortable shoes is important.

Awesome. Enjoyed the the place. It was an amazing experience. Very interesting. Loved the different structures. Only issue was there was a lot of people so at times it was difficult to view all the structure and truly enjoy the surrounding. I should had gotten a guide. It would have allowed for more info.
Charming statues, quirky temple. Although like many here, this temple is overrun with tourists, they are worth battling to enjoy these amazing carved faces, good walking shoes a must here!

Beautiful temple. There are so many temples in the area and each is beautiful. Do go see this one. I enjoyed walking around and photographing each temple, there are so many angles, details, and views to capture.
Don't miss it!. The faces smiling down on you (over 200 of them) will stay in your memory. The history of this beautifully restored site is fascinating. The entire Angkor Thom complex is amazing.

Reconstruction is interesting.. Reconstruction happening at the side. It's interesting to see the stone masons at work.
Compact but distinctive temple which is gun to wander through.
Ancient Temple. Be prepared to walk alot. Hugh build up. Very old and fallind structure being proped up. Some of the path are not even. Wear comfortable shoes.

Beautiful temple - but again ... overcrowded. Bayon is a must see when you are in the area of course. The temple is huge. Beautiful. The huge crowds diminished the experience inside the temple. But outside we had a few quiet moments looking at the monkeys and the people rushing by. Take your time. Try to relax.
Excellent . Every temple is different and they never get boring. I thought getting a 3 day pass I would get bored but I didn't. The Bayon is a bit of a walk but it was a lovely stroll.

Puzzling faces. My least favourite of the three temples I visited. Close to the road with the chaos of hundreds of tuk tuks and lack of signage. Corridors were jammed with Chinese tourists with selfie sticks.
cravings are spectacular. the carving here are amazing you could lose hours looking at them all. its easily as impressive as Angor Wat.

Most enjoyable. Bayon temple was our favourite it's nice to see some restoration taking place to preserve this unique area you will need to take plenty of water along as its not really readily available
One of the wonders of the world. Amazed at the way it is constructed almost 1000 years ago every rock was brought here from hundreds of kilometres away.

Although Angkor Wat is the more iconic, this is a temple with huge power and presence.. The second most famous of the Angkor temples, but with a unique power. The carved stone faces have a brooding, mysterious quality which, once seen, will never be forgotten.

fantastic temple. All the temples at Angkor Wat are good to visit but this one was one of my favourite. The faces are fascinating. Look closely at the lovely carvings. Take plenty of water with you and be prepared for crowds of people.

Towering Faces. Although most renowned for Angkor Wat, the Bayon Temple in Angkor Thom is smaller but every bit as impressive with the carved heads on every tower. It is mystical, soothing and stunning.

Amazing. Words are unable to describe this amazing place. Comparable with the antiquities of Egypt.
Still occasionally used for devotional purposes.
Beautiful, other worldly, uplifting

Even better than Angkor Wat. I have to say it - this place beats Angkor Wat !! I really enjoyed it here -very unique and so much to see.
Mighty recommend you come as early as you can to try and avoid the tour groups.

Breathtaking ! . This was by far our favourite of the temples in the Angkor Complex. The entire temple was carved in place, which is to say stone blocks were positioned and carved after construction. The detail of the carvings and the many faces of Bayon are fascinating. It's a very special place and quite magical! We felt fortunate to have had the chance to fully explore the many levels of Bayon as no doubt, in the future, access will become more restricted. A guide is strongly recommended to make the most of your visit.

Amazing. Amazing temple, extremely crowded with your groups. Avoid crowds, visit early, at lunch, late afternoon when tour groups leave.We traveled by a/c car and guide because 93 degrees! We recommend Lam Sinal on facebook: originaltuktukcambodia. He also has a tuktuk.

Fantastic architecture!. We think this temple is more spectaculare than the main temple - Angkor Wat.
The fantastic faces of Buddha everywhere at the temple-towers made this temple one to remember.
The stonewalls were carved With pictograms and stories. Our guide presentented them in a very understandable way.
Nothing Can Prepare You. I was looking forward to seeing the Bayon for so long. It far exceeded expectations. So spiritual and moving!
The best. Bayon temple was really amazing. It was my favourite of all the temple ruins. You've gotta climb around a bit on some stones so bring proper shoes.

smiling buddha temple. the temple features the faces of smiling buddhas on the towers. I remember being very tired and just sitting on top of the temple while admiring the view, and the crowds that posed for a photo with the smiling buddhas on the facade.
Mesmerizing Beauty. Having Mooni share the stories inscribed on the walls was fascinating, we were mesmerized with all the faces smiling at us wherever we walked

Stunning. One of the most amazing temples - in a bid to beat the Angkor Wat crowds we arrived for sunrise but the temple is not supposed to open until 7am - we did have a wander in the dark before being met by security who escorted us out for safety - apparently it used to be open but there has been some damage caused by tourists wandering in the dark - you can understand why it's not open when you visitStill recommend if time permits a 7am start here before the tours arrive for a truly spectacular experience
A Marvel in Stone!. The Bayon Temple complex with its stonewall carvings around the peripheral walls and innumerable stone temple carvings are a marvel in stone.
wonderful place. fantastic temple...we are very lucky !!! is much more than everybody can imagine.even with the rain, it was a wonderful trip

Better than Ankor wat. We arrived early morning before the crowds of tourists and it was worth getting up early. Impressive temple and local cafe's and shops not so overpriced as other areas. Can be difficult to get good photos due to the crowds so arrive early
Spectacular!. The symmetry they've achieved with innumerable faces carved onto huge blocks of stone is absolutely incredible! Go early in the morning or towards sunset to avoid huge tourist crowds.
See in early light. People rush to see Ankor Wat in the Sunrise, but my recommendation would be to get here early instead/as well. The faces in the early light are just wonderful.
Adventure . Lots of walking amd climbing of the stairs. Bring lots of water, shades and a put on a pairs a good walking shoes . Amazing

An ethereal place. Unlike Angkor Wat, the titular Angkor attraction near Siem Reap, the Bayon Temple is a less monumental, far more intimate and poignant experience. Arriving by tuk-tuk from Siem Reap, the first glimpse is of the South Gate of Angkor Thom, which appears on the road as if stepping out of the surrounding jungle, with a tower adorned by 4 faces of Jayavarman VII. The Bayon temple itself has the most surviving faces on towers of any of the temples, and a special resultant feeling of being watched by the ancients during a visit. Indeed, this feeling is so pervasive here, that a special connection seems to exude from the surviving stones if you can spend some time in relative quiet contemplation. Contemporary with the Magna Carta in England, the Bayon (and the entire Angkor complex) instantiates the existence of great civilizations and accomplishments outside that of western-centric familiarity.Tour groups abound here, since the Bayon is one of the temples on the "short tour" as well as the "grand tour", but if you time your visit right (early morning or around noon) and avoid the tour group "rush hours", a special experience can still be had even in high tourist season.

Essential viewing in Siem Reap. Bayon Temple is one of the most important places to visit when going around the temples of Siem Reap.The temple is packed with interesting features. Bas-relief carving - still in very good condition today - depict interesting historical events. The upper level of the temple consists of many towers with four faces of the compassionate Buddha; the faces look in four directions.Although very attractive even today - 800 or so years after being built - it is interesting to imagine what it was like when built. A long time ago a Chinese visitor described the temple in it's heyday. It was decorated in gold and silver leaf and was magnificent to view.
Love, Love Love. It was almost unreal. A mystical place.The King crafted his face in the temple facing many directions. It was hard to take pictures because there were too many tourists.
One of the temples. . This temple was great, but the crowd was a bit annoying, way too many people for my taste. I would like to do this one again early morning.
Beautiful!. Look for those carvings on walls and Apsaras....magical. Try and get a guide to really understand the history of all these temples otherwise it becomes 'just another temple'.

Besutiful. This is a beautiful temple. Very calming and easy to climb around. The faces are mesmerising and there are lots of great photo opportunities. This is quite a large temple and spreads over a large area so you don't really notice the crowds. It was by far my favourite.
The faces of Bayon. This was the second Temple we visited (before Angkor Wat). If you visit in the mornings the elephants will take you on a walk around the temple complex ($US20)
Favourite temple near Siem Reap. While Angkor Wat is the icon of the Angkor Archeological Park, and it is truly magnificent, we enjoyed exploring Bayon more. The large four faced Buddhas are amazing.

Gorgeous, just remember what entrance you came in!. Bayon is one of my favourite temples, it is amazing seeing it up close. My only advice to people would be to remember what entrance you came through, otherwise you will be walking for awhile to find your transport!

Bayon my love of Angkor Wat.. Faces.
Happy Serious Mad Blessing or cursing. Just for these go and let it be. hurry One of these nearing years you won't be able to touch & walk through these mankind masterpieces anymore.

A must see temple in Siem Reap area. A very interesting Hindu temple with the face of a Khmer king sculpted on four sides of each temple edifice. This site is a must see item on the itinerary of a tourist trip to Siem Reap.

My favourite temple. I simply loved this temple. All the towers with the intricately carved faces on each of the four sides was breathtaking. We ride the elephants around the perimeter of this temple and that was an amazing experience also. Definitely something to cross of your bucket list if you ever get the opportunity.
Half day visit. Spent a half day at the Bayon Temple which was lovely. Lots of visitors as to be expected but plenty of space for all. Elephant Terrace nearby also interesting to see.
Amazing. One of the top attractions in Siem Reap area. Probably the most important temple in Angkor Thom. Amazing architecture, Extraordinary designs. DO NOT MISS.

Magnificent . Bayon was probably my favorite of all the temples we visited. Walking among "the faces" was an incredible experience! It was VERY crowded and a bit difficult to navigate. I would have been very disoriented but for our wonderful guide, Mr Bros!

Worth a visit. make this one of the three temples in the complex that you visit, or save it for another day. It is very tiring climbing all the steps in the heat (except for young people perhaps)
We are both 71 and found it OK

My favorite temple!. When I stepped on this place all I could say was, "how did they do this?" This place was just surreal. I loved the faces and just by looking at each detail you would know that it was no easy feat finishing this great architecture.
Visited October 2014
very evocative religiously and historically. part of the Cambodia required viewing lists, very evocative of past glories historically, as well as the pre-Buddhist Hindu past of the nation.
Wonderfull and breathtaking. Breathtaking in double sense, you have to climb to understand the full magnificence of this great and most important historical place,

Favorite Temple in Siem Reap. With 54 towers each featuring 4 Buddha's there is a lot to see here. Stories told in pictures, structures to climb on, nooks and crannies to investigate, simply amazing. We recommend a guide - well worth the money!

Daily life carved in stone. The Bayon is best visited twice. Once to be astounded by its glory and once to take time to admire the details of the bas reliefs. Those depicting battles are similar to other temples, but the daily life scenes of women cooking, men fishing, people relaxing in rest houses or women giving birth in government built maternity hospitals are truly unique.
Amazing!. This was my second stop after Angkor Wat. Different, but equally interesting. Less crowded. Plenty of things to see, bats.
Must see. This is a must see place ... Go early super hot and can get crowded especially with the Chinese who stop at every wall to take pictures of themselves posing for a long time !
My favourite temple. For me, this was my favourite temple and the only one I had any real interest in. If you visit Siem reap this one is a must!

One of my favorites. Out of all of the Angkor Temples, I would say this one one of my favorites. It's much more beautiful in person and not many photos can do it justice. The workers there were so friendly too. Also, this is a Heritage Site, please cover your back, shoulders, midriff. A french woman came here in a bikini top and got angry when she was asked to cover up. This isn't just a Cambodia thing, all National Heritage sites (even in France, Italy, etc.) ask you to cover up. Please have some respect. There's a nice little praying area in this temple if you want to pray your respects.
Amazing!. This building is so beautiful! Really spectacular! We had such a great time exploring around! A must do while in Cambodia!

Smiling for You. This smiling temple is awaiting you to visit. I believe that this was one of my favorites, second to Angkor Wat. How the faces have survived is a testament to those who built it. The correct guide can really make this place come to life!

Must visit. Its another amazing temple thats stands as a testament to the craftmanship of the Khemer. Generally, tourist tend to do Angkor Wat, Bayon and Promh Ta together (all three located in the same loop). You can ride your bike there (8KMS FROM Siem Reap city) or take a tuk tuk for $10.
Breathtaking Buddhist temple. With an effigy of Buddha facing in all compass directions this temple has the WOW factor. The attention to detail is stunning! Easier walking than other temples.
Spectacular!. Wow! I think this was even more impressive than ANGKOR WAT. We saw this on a bicycle tour with Grasshopper Tours. Highly recommended

Went there for some travel photography this time. The Bayon is not normally recommended for a sunset visit as the surrounding trees block any views of the sun at the horizon. However, I went there one evening and thought that the trees bathed in the brief golden glow of the evening sun were lovely and provided a great background for photos of the face-towers. It was near closing time too and much easier for photography as I found that some shots I took that evening were very difficult to capture again with the crowds of visitors the next day in the late morning.
Faces that amaze. Small temple, three levels, lots of climbing, lots of places to rest, photographers paradise, great for kids.

Very nice . Travelers: My family of 6. My husband and I with 4 boys. 17, 14, 12 and 9.We were there on the 19th. First Angkor Wat and after lunch we went to the Bayon temple.The kids thoroughly enjoyed it. More so than Angkor Wat. They had field day with the pictures and selfies!!It was fun for them to climb up and get some great pictures.

One of the must see' temples at Angkor. This temple is worth visiting especially for photographers. Plan on lots of walking and make sure to take plenty of water, wear good shoes. We got a tuk tuk driver for the day and that was helpful.
Unbelievable. One of the temples in Angkor, less crowds than at Angkor Wat, but is a must visit site. Well preserved.

Very beautiful. This temple is a little different from the rest because it has all the three different Buddhist influence; the Mahayana, the Hindu and the Theravada. Hence, the style of carvings changes as you move around the ruins. Another uniqueness of this temple is at the top level where large carvings of the Buddha faces remained intact, which makes this place an amazing location for photography. This temple is among those at the Angkor region, so plan your time in order not to clash with the tour buses. Tour buses usually pour in from 9am till about just before lunch time. Highly recommended, it's beautiful.

Very beautiful, filled with face carvings. The temple is beautiful and unique. At the front of the temples there are monkeys around but they are not aggressive. If you get there early morning or late afternoon there is less crowd and will be easier to take photos. When there are buses of tourist it makes the place rowdy and difficult for photo opportunities.
Crowded but a must see.. One of the many highlights in my three days of temple exploring. Unique tower face carvings set the site apart from many of the other majestic temples in the vicinity.

Definitely Must Do Bucket List. I really enjoyed visiting Bayon temple . It is different to Angkor Wat and has its own character. Go early in the morning to avoid heat of noon day sun. you need to have a current Angkor Wat 3 day pass with you at all times
Tip : sunscreen, sunhat, water, suitable footwear, knee length trousers. Camera and selfie stick
Amazing Temple in cambodia. I love this temple and I would like to recommend to tourist to visit cambodia angkor Wat Tepmpe. See you here again soon

Part of the Angkor tour. Great place to visit but a guide will inform you about what you are looking at
Go with a guide or you will miss too much
Our Favorite Temple. Definitely worth a visit! Our favorite temple in Siem Reap. We ended up with great photos from this temple.
Amazing. The wonders makes me want to do archeology. The grandure and extend if the complex is incredible. Would do it again would want to see it when all the water ways are full.
Stunning. Well worth the climbing and the heat. Some has been restored, but you can see how it used to be. The many faces are largely intact.

Monolithic faces . Wow! Wow! Wow! Extraordinary. Built in the late 12thC. Take your joggers or proper hiking sandals. Don't go in the middle of the summer here. It'd be too hot. Its 30+ in winter. So much to see, so many photos on the whole Angkor complex I ran my battery down. Must see.

Kiss a Buddha!. Very cool temple that I fear you can no longer see very early and therefore will have to battle the crowds. I suggest getting a private tour guide that can help guide you through this important temple at the optimal time (and get you the optimal photo ops). I was lucky enough to get the best tour guide in Cambodia (maybe the world) in Kamsan Sreng. http://www.tripadvisor.com/Attraction_Review-g297390-d5567760-Reviews-Best_Angkor_Guide_Day_Tours-Siem_Reap_Siem_Reap_Province.html

In All Majesty. I think this is the most beautiful temple in Angkor Thom, if not the most beautiful of all the temples in Angkor Wat. Bayon Temple is well-known for the many heads of forgotten deities adorning the many towers of the temple. The smiling stone faces on top of the towers make you smile back in awe and appreciation for the beauty and majesty that they represent.
Favourite temple! . We got a 3 day ticket and out of all the temples we saw this one was my favourite. Definitely a must see when you are in siem reap

When visiting Angkor Wat, essential to experience Bayon temple complex. With smiling Buddha faces greeting you throughout Bayon, it is perhaps the most enjoyable of all Angkor Wat temples. Our Cambodian guide admitted that Bayon Temple is his personal favorite. Be prepared to share with many visitors, even in off season.

Amazing history. Our personal guide from Buffalo Tours Cambodia was excellent. Could not speak more highly about his professional attitude. Spoke very good English. He took us to all the important sites and pointed out the best locations to take photos. It was easy walking and the weather during our tour was very comfortable.
amazing - another highlight of the temples here. again, what can one say but the temple here is amazig and just blows one away.... the faces looking down are just spectacular

Go!. This is an amazing temple. You have to go to this temple when you visit Angkor Wat. How great your experience is may be affected by the number of people there. Consider going at a time other than high season.
The Faces of Kambodia. I strongly recommend to take more time and watch this temple properly. It looks obvious from the first sight, but there are many little hidden corners with amazing bas-relief.
Beautiful and interesting . We loved this temple and spent a long time walking round with our guide and took so many photos! A great temple to visit for a couple of hours

Pretty outside, mysterious inside. The entire temple architecture is like a palace. Spending quite some time here because this temple is big to explore, have many photo opportunities here, inside is like maze and is good when you comes to some nice little carving on the stone. Looking at the God's face (4 faces) make ones feel clean since it's a temple. I like this place as we get to capture this complicated yet amazing creature whenever we go.
This is a must see plaze. This is a must see, if you are in Siem Reap. It take about two hour to see the most importent. Use one day if you want more. You pay 20 $ for one day, all tempels.

Must see when you go to visit Angkor Thom. Very nice ancient temple and highly recommend to see when you plan to visit Angkor Wat-Angkor Thom. The carving wall surrounded the temple tells the story of Kmer history, very amazing.
WOW! Just WOW!. A place that is extremely impressive! it's really a nice experience to get up close and personal to these temples!

Fantastic photos!. Loved this one the best! Fantastic photo opportunities, amazing temple. Take your time and enjoy! Look for the nose to nose photo opportunity.. Brilliant! I think it's was one of our favourite temples.
Spectacular. It is not easy to choose a favorite among the many temples in Angkor, but Bayon would probably be my one. Its size and structure make it very enjoyable for visitors.

Third temple visit. We were taken to this temple after visiting Ta trong and the lady temple. It was different in that the faces carved into the rocks really stood out. Again the carvings are amazing and you never get tired looking at them. The scale of the temple is incredible.
Amazing Temple in the world. No regards to visiting Bayon Temple, especially during the sunset, the temple just like turning golden.
Happy face. Loved this place. Photographers dream...and I'm not a photographer. Fascinating place, took some of my best pics ever. Not too crowded even for December/January.

Must see Iconic ruins. this lichen encrusted basalt ruin is best visited at sunset, when it is cooler out and the mobs of tour buses go to a small hill for sunset in many of the organized tour companies.As you will approach from a distance, pay attention to the spires and see what you can see... soon you will start to see eyes staring back above full lips and peaceful gazes from dozens of 2 meter tall faces (208 to be exact) that surround the spires on all levels of this ruin.HOT TIP: go at sunset and you will have this place to yourself.

FACES FACES FACES. This is one of the many amazing Temples of Angkor and Wonders of the World. This temple was one of my favourite as each step (almost) had a different face to look at. I loved the engraved faces all over this temple. It made it unique and stand out from the others I went to. Would definitely recommend seeing this one if you're short on time and can only go to a few of them.

Beautiful but crumbling - Hurry and visit!. Mine and my boyfriend's favourite temple out of all of them. This temple is small but packs a punch. Great reliefs exist on the lower levels and the big towers show brilliant faces. Go early in the morning when there are less tourists and their guides. There is a little altar for Buddhists to pay respects in the middle so have some change ready.Enjoy!
My favorite temple. This was my favorite place to visit in the area. We also ride elephants around the temple, which as a little expensive but worth it.

Probably myFavorite Angkor Site. It is hard to pick favorites, but if pressed I think Bayon would win my vote for favorite site. It is just spectacular. The faces, the carvings, the massive scale and how accessible it is to visitors. Plan to spend a bit longer than you expect here.
Beautiful, peaceful. This temple is so unique that it has to be one of the top three temples to visit while in Siem Reap. The 400+ Buddha faces are beautiful and breathtaking!
My favourite. Of all the temples in this area, this was my favourite, the stone work is amazing, considering it was carved centuries ago.
Up there as a favourite temple!. If you dont have much time up your sleeve exploring Angkor, this is definitely one to see! Amazing pictures, amazing vibe- you will not regret

The Best Temple in Siem Reap. There are many nice temples in Siem Reap. But a lot of them are covered by trees. What made Bayon Temple different is that I can have a clear view of the whole architectural structure, design, stone crafts and details of the temple. The crafting on the stones not only tells the story of the royals but common people's daily lives so we know a lot more about the history of Khmer dynasty. Many of the 200+ Buddha faces are still very vivid that I can relate how they were like hundreds of years ago. Thank for for all the people who made this happened throughout the years.

Still one of the most picturesque... despite the crowd. The temple is perfectly symmetrical, so visitors may get disorientated quite easily. Tips on how to know where one is: remember which gate one entered first (north, east, west or south)… ancient Khmers are real rationalists when it comes to building, everything is done in precise right angles. Personally, I find Bayon Temple to be the best temple for families with toddlers: easily accessible, lesser difference of terrain heights and huge steps… to accommodate the younger visitors. And not to forget the elephant rides (a real joy) and monkeys, though one should not be too close nor irritate the later.To avoid visits in the afternoon though… too many visitors and no shelter from the hot sun.
Small temple but worth the visit.. A very unique temple in the Angkor complex.. you'll find a big Buddha head since the 1st time you entering the temple gate. Mysterious yet fascinating!
Temple tour. Smaller, less walking, elephant tours available, rather rugged walking over stone steps but fewer people

Buddhist Mt. Rushmore. Perhaps even more breathtaking than Angkor Wat, four faces of Buddha adorn the towering columns. Inside is filled with detailed skilled carvings. The entrance bridge alone, a bridge of sculpture over a river, (evil spirits on one side, good on the other) is a masterpiece. Don't miss this!

One of the 'must see' temples at Angkor. We visited this temple late in the day when there were very few visitors. More so than Angkor Wat, it's quite easy to get disoriented once inside the warren of narrow corridors and staircases and all the more appealing for that. The main distinctive feature of this temple is the huge carved faces on each of the towers.
2nd temple. If you want to see some of the temples and not all. This is definitly one you should visit. Make your way up the stairs for best pictures

216 Buddhas smiling at you.. Bayon Temple has a slight resemblance to Borobudor in Jogjakarta. In the latter, the Buddhas are encased in the bell and the temple more circular. Bayon on the other hand has all the Buddhas smiling at you all round as you explore the temple. Enjoy the serenity when there.

as pretty as Angkor Wat. Bayon during sunset is magnificent, the colors change when illuminated by the setting sun.... something to behold! The structures are surprisingly still standing and almost whole even after hundreds of years
fabulous. this is another temple that should not be missed the carvings are so well preserved and all the faces are different

The statues are very impressive!. This temple is the most spectacular. It has several levels and very steep staircases. But the climb to the top is well worth the effort. To get a close-up view of the enigmatic faces is so special.

Photographers Delight. This temple is worth visiting especially for photographers. Plan on lots of walking and make sure to take plenty of water, wear good shoes. We got a tuk tuk driver for the day and that was helpful.
The "Faces" Temple. More intimate in scale than Angkor Wat, Bayon dazzled with details. Be sure to have your photo taken "kissing the Buddha".

Best temple in Siem Reap. . In my opinion this was the most beautiful temple we visited during our stay in Cambodia. A temple with many faces...unique in this area. If you like to take pictures...you will find hundreds of spots here....really breathtaking!

As well known as Angkor Wat. Another iconic heritage site which all visitors to Siem Reap must see together with Angkor Wat.Much work has been done to restore its past history and glory. See it during sunset time and the temple colours change into gold!!!

Stunning, huge carved smiling faces. The carved faces of Bayon are one of the current wonders of the world. There are more than 200 faces in the area. It is a wonderful place for photographs as there are so many angles and framings possible. One traveller commented, " How could you not be happy among so many smiles?"

Favourite attraction in Siem Reap. Everyone who visit Siem Reap goes to see Angkor Wat no doubt, but Bayon Temple will always be my favourite. There's something magical about it. Being within the temple among the 200 smiling faces, one has to wonder about how great the ancient Khmer Kingdom must have been and how the place was built, at the same time feel a chill running through their body with the mystical atmosphere. There's also something serene about the place that makes you reflect on life - how small you are compared to the universe. All of these just in one place. My favourite interpretation of the temple given by our guide was that the the faces represent the King Jayavarman VII looking after all of his people in the Khmer Kingdom.

incredible.... There are two main reasons to visit Bayon. First the bas relief carvings around the base and second the face towers of the main temple. Either would justify world heritage status. What i really liked was you could get right up to them both. Wandering around the face towers in a really magical kind of ancient 'big brother' is watching experience. Apparently there are 37 face towers each with 4 sides, but not all towers have 4 faces. Incredibly in this day and age it is still disputed how many faces there actually are!. Buy the book from the guys in the car park and it details the dispute (the book is just one dollar - but actually costs seven dollars when you agree to buy one!). As well as book sellers there are also water and soft drink vendors (50c for a small bottle of water, 1 dollar for a coke) and numerous monkey troupes around the entrances. Best visited as a walk through from one side over the top to the other side, and then a trip around the bas reliefs. We spent about 90 minutes and didn't see it all.
Amazing labrinth. Cannot get enough of this temple - something magical about the faces! A photographers paradise - give yourself enough time to explore as there are many aspects to take in.

very nice. If u r short on time, you must see Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm and Bayon temples!It has a lot of striking faces, made popular by the numerous visitors from worldwide.Built 200 years after Angkor Wat, is different in architecture.Guide may not be required here.

Well worth it. Words are wasted, you'll know why when you get there. Do it after the Angkor sunrise and then carry on to the elephant walk, but be sure to go the back way for a couple of little roles on way.
Yet another site to wonder its grandeor. One of the temples worth visiting and admiring of its detail of work. Stone artisans did great in immortalizng their work on stone.

Second favorite, or maybe first!. Loved this temple more than Angkor Wat. It's tied for first place in Cambodia with Ta Prohm. The Buddha heads are AMAZING. They all have different faces and are so interesting. Recommend bringing a guide for interesting information and also because they can take you places you may not find on your own. HIGHLY recommend.

An item on my bucket list. Been touring in southeast Asia since 1997 and finally decided to visit Angkor Wat. Due in large part to a promotion found on the Travelzoo.com site for Navutu Dreams Resort in Siem Reap. Quite happy for the entire experience!
Magic. One of my favorites. This one has the 4 sided faces. We went in the afternoon and found it had very few people. Make sure to leave plenty of time to take it all in.

Wow. If you come to Cambodia; you must come and see this! As an arhcaeologist and photographer I could appreciate this master piece differtly than your avarage tourist. I highly recomend it. My only regret is not having enoguh to indulge my self and process what i was looking at. I joined a day tour and you get an avarage of an hour to see it. If you have more by alleans stay longer or come back the next day.Entrance for a day to see the temples are $20

Wonderful albeit humiliating.... The Bayon temple is a part of Angkor Wat. It\s wonderful but also a bit humiliating at the same time: It makes one realize what little progress manhood has made in the past 1000+ years.
Smile of Cambodia . 54 stunning statues that shows the smile of Cambodia. There's a wall that features the story of Cambodian with nice carvings.
Amazing. Don't let the heat of the day stop you from seeing this temple it worth the walk but take your time to absorb the history.

Most memorable experience. One of my favourite temples to visit. Amazing architecture and the 216 faces are just incredible.
Expect there to be a lot of people!

Worth Seeing. I think the cultural information about this temple is probably more compelling than the remaining structure. Still, really beautiful faces and worth a visit if you're already seeing Angkor Wat.

Different and amazing . Although built around the same time frame as Angor watt this temple is very different both in the architectural elements and what the visitor can see. It is currently going extensive renovation and we saw teams working on putting some of the structure back together, quite fascinating.

my wife's favourate temple. A must see with all the smiling faces - definitely include t on any tour
don't need a guide for this one just wonder about and remember to look up!

Better than Expected!. All of the ancient sites in Siem Reap are worth seeing. Bayon features the stone carvings of the four heads facing north, south , east, and west. Viewing this makes one appreciate how hard it was to build 1000 years ago and then to reconstruct in modern times
Worth it -. Glad we saw this prior to Angkor Wat. The various smiling faces are worth seeing and overall the temple is unique in many ways.
Cool faces on the temple. Look out for the faces that make up the temple wall. Beautiful views and definitely a very unique temple in the archaeological park that is worth visiting.
My favourite one. It has been one of my favourite temple in Siem Reap. Not very big but very nice. I've been loving the 4 faces story.

Better visited early. We visited after sun rise trip to Angkor Wat, seemed that many others were doing the same so very busy, we were group of 12 so difficult for guide to get us together to hear his commentary, would be better in small groups

Huge Faces. This temple is in the process of being reconstructed. There are areas that are roped off, but the prime photograph spots are open to the public. It is amazing to see the differences in construction style between Bayon and Angkor. The huge carvings of faces are the most striking difference.
A busy temple. Fabulous temple undergoing some reconstruction. Extremely busy though fun as you can access it by elephant ride!

Another amazing temple. The area around Siem Reap is so rich with temples and this is another spectacular example. We had 3 days in Siem Reap and Angkor Thom was the first site we visited and we were so impressed with all the serene faces of the Bayon temple, built in the late 12th or early 13th century. We didn't have a guide but enjoyed exploring the various levels that are accessible at the complex. We spent an hour or two there.
The best temple!!!!. Out of all the Angkor Temples, this was my favourite!!! It isn't the biggest but definetly mind blowing!!
Small and not really that special. Yes... there are lots of faces... but so? The architecture is so-so... and not really worth spending more than half an hour or so. IMHO.
Mirror?. It's definitely worth a visit if you have the ticket for the temples. The doorways look like mirrors and it's generally a beautiful place. We liked it more than the Angkor wat

Beautiful sunrise. We visited this temple on our first day to avoid the madness at Angkor Wat. It was a beautiful morning, we wandered up there in the early half light taking in the silhouettes of the temples towers. Take a headtorch as it is very dark before the dawn and the stairs are steep and can be slippery. It was a very peaceful and atmospheric sunrise with only about 8-10 other people up there.
VERY SPECIAL. This is the place with "four faces" towers! Amazing details and finish of the stone carvings! Probably the most special temple in Siem Reap!

Highlight of the Angkor Wat Experience!. Bayon Temple was just amazing as we took our time and climbed all around for several hours. We had a wonderful guide, Ratanak Eath. Highly recommend using his services. He showed us great spots for excellent pictures and just made this whoe experience special.
Amazing temple. Another amazing temple to visit. we visited on a day when thousands of monks had arrived for a special event. This added to the magic and ambience of our visit. highly recommended.
beautiful, fragile, Bayon. this temple is a special place at Angkor Wat - go early, be quiet, take lots of photos and give yourself a magical memory

The Temple with the Smiley Faces ;-). Bayon is the temple with all the many smiley faces. By the time I reached Bayon at 9am, my legs/knees were hurting so bad. I had taken a hard fall in Angkor Wat whilst climbing the narrow and steep steps :-( So sadly, I couldn't walk much.I only managed to skirt around the outer parts of Bayon.I'll be back!Important Reminder:Be prepared to walk and walk...and walk! Thankfully with the private car/driver, I didn't have to walk that much ;-) My driver drove all the way inside the complex to pick me up when I told my private guide my legs hurt. P.S. Check out one of the pics I posted regarding the dress code when visiting the temples.

Avoid crowds, visit after 4PM. If you want to truly enjoy your visit at Bayon, try to avoid crowds, the best time would be either early morning or after 4PM when most of crowds will be at Angkor or other places.I found Bayon little bit more interesting than Angkor itself because it offers more sites to explore.

Beautiful example of Khmer Temples. Bayon Temple was stellar example of a temple that has been and continues to be maintained.If you have folks in your group that are not good with stairs, I would avoid this one. It has several levels and not much room to move due to popularity.The architecture is incredible and it is worth the investment to have a guide give historical context.
A trip true time. three Colors, the blue of the sky, the green of the Gras, and the Grey of the Temple, a place for inspiration Needs a Tour Guide to understand the behind story
Bayon Temple. Spectacularly stunning architecture and a must see when visiting Cambodia. It's feels mystical and is a very special place.
Enjoyed It. Seeing the many faces of Buddha carved on the temple is the most memorable. It is important to see this temple and understand its difference from Angkor Wat..

All about faces!. Bayon is not the Tomb Raider temple, as that is Ta Prohm. Bayon is the temple of faces which sits inside of the Angkor Thom area. It is super popular with good reason. It's so cool! It sits just a bit south of the promenade and palace area and will have you making faces of delight.
Better than Angkor Wat. We went to this attraction late in the afternoon and found this site to far more interesting and accessible than Angkor Wat.

After Angkor, my favourite temple. This temple is amazing. It's inside the Angkor Thom complex and is crawling with visitors but it is a must to visit. If you stand behind the lake/pond to the left of the temple, you can get wonderful shots of the temple and the towers reflected in the water. The towers are made up of stone faces on each side and are just amazing. There were cambodian ladies in full dress inside the temple that you could pay the obligatory dollar to have your picture taken with. Absolutely stunning temple.
Most outstanding of the temples. This temple was amazing. The magnitude of the area was over whelming. There is so much awe in this place.
Misterious. The temple us amazing. It hiddes sone mistery. The carving are in a very well state and you will be impressed once you are there.
Many different types of buddha faces. This temple is amazing as you can see over 200 types of buddha faces in it. One of the most famous face what the local people called is Smile of Cambodia.
Visit at 4pm. Was so happy to go at 4pm until close. Probably only 100 people or less in the whole place. Best plafe for photos of all the Siem Reap temples.
Another temple. Though probably the most interesting of the very famous ones. It is absolutely worth going, even if you are sick of temples as one is.

Fascinating tree growth. Left undisturbed trees and plants have taken over. It's not the ruined temples that are of interest but the amazing trees and their roots, like snakes slithering their way through cracks and crannies.
Bayon Temple . Nice one! Had a photo taken especially the Tomb raider tree. But had to rest becoz its really hot. Hubby enjoyed the whole temple.

Bayon Temple. not too far from Angkor Wat, located in the center of large ground. Our tour guide Vannak took us there in the morning with less tourist (guess they are at Angkor Wat). Some walking, definitely worth visiting.
An amazing place!. It's unimaginable that the ancient people could have built and lived in this amazing place! One of the top 5 or 6 highlights of Cambodia. Don't miss it !!
Mesmerising and awe inspiring. After Anka Wat this temple is stunning. The thrill was taking a tide send the temple...the best way to see this attraction.

Great Temple. This temple is as beautiful as Angkor Wat temple, but we found it more interesting. We had a great guy who took us to every corner of the temple and pointed out all the stories and history in the carvings on the wall. Great experience!

My favourite . I liked this temple a lot, it's one of my favourites. When you climb the temple you get very close to the faces. For nice views of the temple take a walk around it. It's very beautiful and the faces are very fascinating.

Interesting to see the many Buddah faces. Saw this with a guide as part of a small tour (Grasshopper). Would recommend as it imparts lots of knowkedge that gives context to what you are seeing.
Awesome photo opportunities of course!

Magnificent! Unique! Gorgeous. One of the top monument we ever visited, unique, grandioso!!! It takes you away in the past by its sheer beauty and force.
I will go back
Our favourite of the Angkor temples. While Angkor Wat gets most of the attention, for our group, Bayon was a more interesting temple. Both have their own

A profound experience. I found the Bayon to be a profound experience. Standing under the serene and knowing faces gives the temple a tranquillity that Angkor Wat doesn't have. The achievement by the ancient builders is truly amazing and not just from the construction side - to impart such a sense from stone is brilliant.From a practical side - its the same as all the Angkor complex - the morning has more people but less heat and the afternoon has less people but more heat. Your choice.
Must go . Loved loved Loved this place a must see when visiting Siem Reap ! Take an umbrellA for some time our of the hot sun.A must place to visit !

The Many Faces of Buddha. This was one of our favorite temples in Siem Reap. Each tower has four faces of Buddha on it and most are smiling. This temple is a true work of art. As with all the other temples in the area, I recommend bringing plenty of water, bug spray, and sunscreen/a hat if you are fair skinned. It is also less crowded if you go first thing in the morning or when the sun is the hottest.
One of the best things I've ever seen. This temple is just astonishing. It has layers of surprises, and you cannot beat the picture-taking opportunities. It was highlight of the temple complex.

Grace in stone. These huge stone faces are sublime. Soft expressions, graceful in their own way. And the carvings around the walls of the base of the temple are the best I have seen. Well preserved and tell their own stories.

Fantastic. This is such a wonderful place and the stone work is amazing - definately a must visit attrraction - worth allocating several days to really be able to explore this and other temples - you wont regret it :))

Best Temple in Angkor. If you can avoid the coaches that turn up, this is a great place. Take photos at the front, by the small new temple as you get the reflection in the water too. No shade on site. Take your time avoiding the crowds, as they are usually on a quick turn around so you can let them race ahead. Carved heads are all different, so lots to see. Watch your step as very uneven and steep surfaces. Nice loos here - they call them "happy houses" and these ones were clean and monitored.

Multifaces of a temple. Out of the many temples around Siem Reap, it was the most impressive for me. I forgot about Angkor Wat when I caught sight of the faces. I keep thinking how to describe it, but impossible. The faces somehow brought the majestic temple alive. Enigmatic smiles... ah, I give up. Go and see for yourself.
architecture marvel.... such an architecture marvel, so fine sculptures, can easily spend a day, need to do a lot of walking and so need good pair of shoes...

Best Temple in Cambodia. Rich history, delicate designs on each temple, the grandeur feel and magnificent views. Beware of tourist guides who will just approach you out of nowhere, they are nice but they will expect at least USD10 after the "semi-tour" that they will offer. Plus side is when you are traveling alone, someone will take nice pictures of you.
Must see. The bayon temple was so beautiful and not that overcrouded as angkor wat. Please dont buy postcards or magnets from children.

Amazing temple. great location to get all the possible pics - especially with the different faces on each side of the temple - lots of people again. but that should not stop you from taking as many pics as you can - another must do in Siem reap

Outstanding historical structure. Whilst not as famous as Angkor Wat, this complex of temples which is in the heart of the Angkor Thom ancient city is of equal interest and well worth a couple of hours strolling around. This is where you see the many towers with multiple stone faces.

Multiple faces at Bayon. Bayon is one of the must see temples. it is amazing to see the faces in person. Helpful to go with a guide that can explain the meaning and history of the temple. It can be quite crowded and hot. Pack water and your patience. It's very much worth seeing.

Bayon Temple, Angkor Thom. Do catch hold on the most smiling Buddha out of 36 or so Buddha face statues :) :)
The outer galleries distinctly shows the lives of the soldiers back then, the lifestyle of the people and many more. The peaceful smile of the Buddhas makes it a calm and incredible experience.

Legend Temple to Visit. It is a must visit when you are in Siem Reap , spare 2-3 hours at least to get better understanding about the culture , philosophy and bit of historical side. Grab your sun-block , umbrella & bring a bottle of water to avoid dehydration during hot daytime
Not to miss. If you have to select a few temples to visit in Siem Reap, this one has to be one your list - impressive !

By far the best temple in the Angkor temple complex. Be sure to go to Bayon early in the morning. We went directly after sunrise at Angkor Wat so there were only 5 other people there. Bayon is hands down the best temple in the Angkor complex. It's beauty is overwhelming. On the ride up to the temple there were monkeys everywhere (we even saw some in the temple itself-- be careful though, they were pretty ferocious). Pictures do not do Bayon justice. It's definitely a must-see in person.

Another iconic temple. This temple is only a kilometer or two from Angkor Wat head north and you'll find it. It's the temple with many faces, and the lion "kissing" a face. A few stairs to ascend to get to where the main attraction is, being the many faces carved.
Nice temple. Bayon Temple is one of the best temple inside Angkor Wat. This place is one of must visit place in Angkor Wat.

worth spending quality time here. We visited bayon temple early in the morning, before the large groups of tourists came along. It was such a great outing for the family (we have 2 teenage kids). Amazing history, great stories (please engage a good guide). Some useful tips: go early in the morning to avoid both large groups as well as the heat

Unbelievable architecture covered in tourists. Without doubt a stunning example of a temple... Just such a shame there are loud, large tour parties every corner you turn. I think I would pay more to have restricted numbers. The temples just on from Bayon near the elephant terrace is more peaceful and I would recommend you stop there too.

All temples are worth to visit. We had the chance that it was very quiet during our visit, which makes it more comfortable and interesting. Visitors normally start with Angkor Wat and continue with Angkor Thom: try to do the opposite!

Many Faces of Bayon!. Bayon, part of the larger Angkor Thom temple complex is one for everyone's must see list when visiting the Angkor temples. It's a unique place, differing from the architecture of Wat and Ta Prohm.

Full of smiling faces. This temple is part of the Angkor Wat Archeological Park and is characterized by numerous smiling faces on the towers of the complex. Like the other sites it is very popular so be prepared for crowds. There are spots where you can have a friend photograph you appearing to be nose-to-nose with a smiling Buddha. Lots of fun.

one of our favorite. Richly decorated the temple was our favorite. Built in the late 12th century, it was the official temple of the Buddhist King. The Bayon stands at the centre. with a later touch of Hindu according to their religious choices.The multitude of serene and smiling stone faces made us take photo after photo. Some pass time disguise people were there to have their photo taken in the decor. The temple has also a combination of mythological and mundane scenes. Don't miss this one
Lovely at twilight. An interesting temple, we had the luck of seeing it at 6pm without the crowds and again later in the day with many others!Lots of steep stairs
The lost city of angkor. Ancientangkor#bayon#Manmade#hugefaces#rajarajas#kingjeyavarmanVII#One of my favorite temple around the world..Must visit once in a life
Bayon, and its many faces. Immensely enjoyed the views here at Bayon. Remnants of a civilization of the past tells you a lot about what happened here in this part of Cambodia

Beautiful temple to get amazing photos. We visited this temple in June (when it is very less crowded due to off-season). This is a must visit place if you are going to Siem Reap. The temple is beautiful and the faces are unlike you might have seen before. You can get amazing photos of the grey stone temple against the contrasting blue sky. There are also many spots within the temple where you can click very good portraits.

Simply Amazing. Another great temple to visit. The ruins are beautiful. I think it's better than Angkor Wat because there's certainly something special about Bayon Temple, like the feeling lilttle bit magical in the air when you approach the steps that lead into the temple complex.

Amazing in its Singularity. Still decently preserved and I only wish people were not allowed to walk on it anymore. It will further destruction. Great picture site for sure. We bicycled here with our six person tour group and made a 45 minute stop to explore. Worth it!
Fascinating to visit. Went here after sunrise at Angkor Wat, totally different but well worth the visit. Smaller and more crowded but don't miss it.

Amazing. seriously gorgeous , be prepared do cover your shoulders and knees both menand women. Bring water and do be prepared for rain, wear rain proof shoes or a pair you don't care about. An experience you won't forget. Get there early , before the crowds.

Astonishing work of Art. After Angkor complex I visited this temple as part of temple tour. This temple is part of larger temple complex spread in hectares of land. Buddha faces carved in stones are unbelievable as it makes you think of the passion of sponsor and creators. Wear your sport shoes and take a walk to nearby pyramids. DO TAKE WATER along with you as water vendors are available in certain locations and while walking in the jungle one tends to move away from strategic locations. Do not miss this attraction while you are in Siem Reap
Amazing Architecture. A really terrific place to visit. It is almost a fantasy world. Easy to see a little of the impact it had on the people who built it.

Must see temple!. Bayon is definitely in my top 3 favorite temples in the area. It really is unique with all the giant smiling stone faces greeting you as you climb to the top level. There was a nice breeze up there, and it makes you want to linger a little longer. Be sure to get a souvenir picture of yourself nose to nose with a stone face. You can even take your shoes off and walk inside the center of the structure.
Mandatory. Well, another temple one cannot miss when visiting Angkor! It really old and restoration impressive.
the buddha is watching over you. Lovely temple, needs a bit of crowd control like all other temples around. Part of the small tour that one can do in half a day.

Why was it built and developed?. Part of Angkor Thom, Bayon is being carefully restored and after Angkor Wat, is one of the most impressive sites. Read some history to gain maximum benefit from a visit.

Must Visit, Great Faces. Lots to see here. Unique faces, sculptures, and a lot fewer tourists. You'll spend about an hour walking around, looking at the amazing architecture, and see how meticulous the details are on the faces. Absolutely spectacular!
Better than ankor watt. I think this was better than ankor wat. Lots to see a bit crowded on parts but very interesting. A guide helps to understand the carvings etc

Awe-inspiring Angkor Thom. There's certainly something special about Bayon temple, you can feel it in the air when you approach the steps that lead into the temple complex.The detail in the carvings and the ancient faces carved into stone gives Bayon it's uniqueness, unlike any of the other temples in the Siem Reap area.Get's horrendously crowded with large tour groups, so if you're travelling solo or with a small group of friends, then get here before sunrise so you can have the place pretty much to yourself while everyone else is nearby at Angkor Wat watching the sunrise.

Perhaps better than Ankor Wat for Drama and Architecture. I personally prefer Bayon than Ankor Wat. The labyrinthine architecture, the escalation of drama as you ascent the towers and central dome, i can feel the chills. I can almost imagine the grandeur of old times. Must Visit.

Faces from the past. This temple is restored but also in the process of restoration. It is famous for the smiling faces, and is one of the top 3 Angkor sites. You can walk the outside as well as climb inside to the top.
Yep all good. Here with friends nice and cool but wouldn't want to be here in the hotter months , amazing from start to finish
Amazing. Just cant stop being amazed about these places, temple after temple. Beware of the angry horse walking aroud the temple. Tries to bite if you go near.
My favorite temple. I like this better than Angkor Wat. Although not as big as Angkor Wat, the details of this temple are amazing. You can easily spend a couple of hours admiring this work of art.

Bayon Temple (celestial palace) deserving of its praise.... Well preserved and steeped in history with it's famous sculpted faces. This temple has many photo opportunities (holding a face in the palm of your hand, kissing a face, etc.) so I would recommend bringing a water, sun screen, a hat and a camera, but make sure you look after you possessions as I did see a monkey picking through careless tourists bag to steal their water. To miss the crowds I would recommend visiting either in the early morning or late afternoon where you can explore the temple more freely, but I would also recommend a guide to supply further details about the history of this temple.
Jaw dropping wonder!. Can only marvel - how was this done so many centuries ago! Simply amazing. Tip : some prior knowledge is helpful. Need to wear good walking shoes
Peaceful and serene. I thoroughly enjoyed visiting Bayon. So many smiling faces that were sculptured throughout the temple. Feels like a happy place!

My favorite. Without any thoughts, I easily rank this as number 1 of all the temples in siem reap (in terms of beauty of the architecture) ... extremely crowded place, would suggest to keep trying at different times during the day as one might get lucky with less people in it.
Bayon is MUST SEE Top 3 Temple in Siem Riep. Also my guide and mine’s favorite temple. The central location, size, buddha faces and unique yet tranquil grandeur were all present here.
Loved Bayon....an amazing place!. Another great temple to explore!.. Good shoes, water and if you tuk tuk out, just get your driver to suggest where to go if your short on time.

Best temple of the lot. We got here late in the day and the sun was just right, illuminating the faces just perfectly for some atmospheric photography and experiences. It wasn't too busy either and at time we has sections of the complex to ourselves. It is difficult to describe just how amazing this place was, it phenomenon only to be experienced in the flesh. if i had the choice, I'd go back to this temple time and time again and wouldn't bother with the more contrived tourist mele that Wat presents.

Glorious temple in the centre of the Angkor Thom area. I was a little confused at the outset, but the Bayon Temple is the "most" famous one in the Angkor Thom complex.It is famous for the large faces throughout the temple. You can do some fun photoshots, pretending to take photos kissing one of the gigantic faces. There were quite a few monkeys running around the temple when we were there.

Our favorite temple. Really lovely. We had a great guide who spent a lot of time pointing out things of interest that we would have otherwise missed so highly recommend a guide to get the most out of the temples.
Wonderful!!. This was our favourite temple!! My kids loved exploring and climbing through all the tunnels and pathways...

Don't miss this! Do Angkor and Taphrom and this at the minimum. The famous views of the 4 Buddha faces are outstanding in morning light. I came back after the Angkor Wat sunrise visit to look at it again.

Ancient Bayon. Bayon Temple is a great place for a honeymoon. Although I have been married 37 years. I love the architecture of how it was put together, the tree's that hold some of the buildings together, also a film location for "Tomb Raider" just a lot of history.
My favorite temple. I enjoyed Bayon temple the most of the four temples I saw.it is so so unique. The faces are magnificent

One of our favourites. This temple isnt as busy as Angkor Wat, but we found it more interesting.Not as busy, and much more accessible too. Take a guide, who will point out all the stories and history in the carvings, ands will really bring it all to life for you.
Lovely temple!. Climb away they don't care how you explore here! Lovely intrinsic temple! My teenaged kids loved it!

MY FAVORITE SITE. Set aside at least 2 hours for this site. The stairs to the top are steep but, the view is worth the climb. Watch out for the monkeys.They will take any food that you have. I loved Angkor Wat but the Bayon Temple was my favorite. Early morning when the monkeys first come out is the best time to visit.

Fabulous - possibly our favourite.... Mystical and atmospheric - almost maze like as you wander up, down and around the floors, under the gaze of the many stone faces. All of us, parents and kids ranging between 14 and 18, loved this temple - our top tip would be to go between 6 and 8 a.m as it does get busy after that, and the crowds really detract from your enjoyment of Bayon as it's smaller and more compact than some of the temples.
Divine. Love the faces. The base of the temple is wirth exploring. I recommend the elephant ride around the temple for $20. It is a great experience.

The Climb. The steep climb up to see the revered Buddhist statures is worth it. There is a separate lineup that is regulated by tourist police to ensure not too many people are on top so anticipate a wait during peak tourist season. Keep in mind that coverups for shoulders and shorts are required when going into the 4 shrines with standing, lying and sitting Buddhas.
Don't miss it!. Easily combined with the major temples, good shades to rest and amazing atmosphere for those who wish to get in the mood of the ruins's vibes. Recommended 100%
The best temples in Siem Reap. These are the best temples in Siem Reap with the 100 smiling faces. So much to look at with three levels to the temple.
Loved this temple. Loved this temple for the peaceful faces on the temple turrets. Again we travelled during peak time and there were too people there. One of my favourite ones.
temple. the faces look down from above and have do for 800 yrs. King celebrating himself - who else. Elephants used to move blocks of stone cut to fit.
The best temple in angkor. From our point of view the most interesting temple in the whole Angkor area. It is kind of small compare to Angor Wat but all the faces make it of very interesting look

Temple with lots of Budha's faces . I like this temple more than Angkor Wat. If you wanna see the faces of Buddha, you should visit this place. You can also find the Buddha relief in the wall. It's a Buddhist temple nor like Angkor Wat which is a Hindus temple.

Busy in high season but you can still find places to escape the crowds. I liked the fact that this temple had a bit of everything, for me the thing i remember and liked about this place was the historic carvings all around the external walls of the history of Siem Reap, and you can see the depiction of the chinese who came to help the locals fight against their enemies. These are in great condition compared to other parts of the site.I did like the towers but it was quite crowded ( i did go christmas eve) so preferred the external walk which was much quieter.Would highly recommend, but think it's on everyones to do list visiting angkor wat.
Temple with humongous heads and faces. One of the must see temples in Siem Reap. A tour guide again is recommended to visit the place to explain the history of it.
The best of all the large temples!! . So gorgeous, awe inspiring and the best of the large temples. This was our last one on our large temple tour and it blew us away.

Brilliant. Visited Dec 2015. Stunning site that is imho a must do. Do take time to look around inside and see the bass reliefs.We also came across a shaft, on the South west side I think where shining a torch downwards revealed circling bats, 20-30 of them.One of the goods things here photo wise is that there are always some faces illuminated by the sun as they are on all four sides of most towers.
My favourite. To see giant Buddhas carved into the rocks just amazing. Could have spent hours here. Not the easiest of walking but well worth the effort. Less crowds also on the day.
A great and old temple. Located in angkor wat complex this was voted the favourite temple by my groupIt is indeed fascinating.Go ahead and explore it

beauty bayon. the bayon is a must see in siem reap. not to far from angkor wat temple. a tour guide again is recommended to visit the place. the many buddha faces are incredible. there is quite a bit to see. the entrance and exit on both sides to the temple are a must see also with the 51 emperors.

Incredible.. An absolute must if you are visiting the Angkor Archaeological Park, it's spectacular. It gets quite busy so try to get there early. There are official tour guides available - but we found that our tuk-tuk driver from our resort knew just as much!

Get lost in the Smiling Buddhas!. We enjoyed spending time circling through this temple, gazing at and mystically interpreting the reliefs, and counting all the smiling Buddhas that greeted us as we traveled as high up as we could.
Beautiful Bayon!. Bayon temple is simply amazing!! It is really interesting to see the faces of the king! The carvings are amazing. Better done early (before 8AM) in order to avoid the crowds.

Amazing!. Got lucky with the quick queue for tickets and got a great driver from the hotel!Anyway, the temple complex was amazing and was not that crowded.Well worth it! Felt like Indiana Jones! An amazing experience!!!

Better than Angkor Wat!. This temple probably does not get the notoriety of Angkor Wat, but we liked it better. We loved seeing all the towers with the four faces on it. We also liked being able to climb a couple of the inner temples to get a better view of the overall temple.

Fantastic. This Temple is well worth visiting- it was my favourite out of all of the ones we went to. It is much smaller than Angkor Wat and all built up on one area which makes for lots of ducking and climbing (which I love). There are many faces embedded in the temple which are just fantastic. Only con is that it was very busy but this is unavoidable, just get up nice and early to do your sightseeing! Don't miss out!
A must. Amazing places to visit. Kids loved running around and seeing all of the amazing archways, statues and hidden wonders.

The faces of smiling buddhas everywhere. This temple is the most memorable temple for all of us. I commented casually that I would like my mum to take a kissing picture with the buddha and a male tourist guard who was nearby actually approached me to assist me in the photo taking without asking for any gratuity. He even helped me to take another few pictures when we bumped into him again and he did it out of his own goodwill. This is contrary to my experience at another temple (Preah Khan) when the tourist guards help to take pictures and later blatantly ask for tips which I was shocked at their straightforward attitude towards all the tourists. If you do bump into a male tourist guard at Bayon, do approach him to ask him for help in taking pictures and if you do not have a spare change for tips, just thank him for his help and his smile is very genuine and untainted, just like the smiling buddha.

My most favorite temple in the Angkor Wat complex. My then 3-year old son and I went to the temples as my gift to ourselves before we left for good after staying in Siem Reap for 4 months. I've heard so many great feedback from the travellers and couchsurfers we've hosted who visited the temples. Most of them, if not all, have said that Bayon was their favorite. When we visited ourselves, my friends were never wrong about the temple. It was a really sweet treat for me and my son with how different the temple looked from all other temples. The different levels between the rocks and interior itself were really beautiful. My son enjoyed going in and around the temple pretending that it was his room. He and I played comparing of our rooms from each other. It was indeed the most fun time we had during that visit in the different temples. I could spend the whole day reading a book to myself while being in a relaxing place like Bayon.
My favourite temple!. Definitely worth visiting. We did a day tour of this, bayon and Angkor, and was definitely worth getting there early to avoid the crowds and tour buses!

Rated average because of similarity and aspect. The issue is that most temples here look exactly the same,except maybe the main one and the Tomb Raider one (Ta Phrom, which is by far the best). Also, since Cambodia is quite corrupt, none of the money collected via entrance fees actually makes it towards restoration of the temples, so the temples here look far worse than Borobudur in Indonesia for example.
Beautiful Bayon. Stunning visually, a must see when visiting Anka Wat. An awesome structure with many things to look at and admire.

The Best Photo Spot for Late Afternoon. This is far and away the best place for photos in the late afternoon. The sun lights up the many faces at different times and creates some wonderful contrasts. For my personal perspective, this was the best temple in the immediate area. If you are outside Siem Reap, go to Banteay Srey.

Not to be missed!. I really enjoyed climbing up the temple and finding myself face to face with those giant heads which seem to look at you from any corner. Only downside is the tourist crowd, so try to avoid the peak hours. Unfortunately my tuk tuk driver didn't help much with it.
Intricate carvings and features. Interesting visit due to the intricate stone faces carved onto the temple walls. Would recommend including this temple in your temple hopping itinerary.
Stunning. Well worth visiting. The smiling Buddha faces are wonderful. A different feel to some of the other temples. Lovely.

Beautiful smiling Buddha faces await you!. Make sure that you make your way down to Angkor Thom and visit the Bayon temple. It is perhaps the most underrated of the Angkor temples but simply should not be missed. One of the must sees!

Bayond Believable. Another temple situated within the Angkor Complex. I visited at just before sunset. This temple is well situated and particularly photogenic if there is a full moon. I turned up on the full moon (by chance) and.........nothing. Lol. It didn't change anything though. This temple is close too Elephant Terrace etc. Great as part of your Angkor Daytrip.

A World Wonder. This was a site to behold. A treasure and a World Wonder. Make sure that you wear comfortable enclosed footwear with padding. Doesn't have to be hikers, but footwear must be comfortable and wear nice padded socks. Lots of climbing when visiting this and other temples. The pictures that you will take will be awesome!

a must see temple. you cannot say that you visited Angkor Watt if you missed this temple.
it is a must see temple, historical and great art of the old days of Cambodian history.
Crowds is always there. Be watched with the scammer that might be around you
My favorite . This temple was one of my favorite it had amazing statues and carvings I recommend going early in the morning to beat the crowds and heat
Memorable architecture.. A bit different than the other temples, Bayon offers unique sites and a bit different architecture as you weave through arrow straight halls.
Tomb raider. This temple is amazing with the tree roots growing over the stone work. Part of tomb raider was filmed here in one of the rooms with a large root taking over the walls.

Awe-inspiring!. The was a smaller temple than Ankor Wat but, it was absolutely beautiful. the ancient carvings are stunning to look at. A beautiful example of how two religions can co-exist in harmony.

Known for its huge stone faces that smile at you from every angle!. Built in the 12th century and left to the elements it is great to see sections being restored much of it sponsored by countries such as Japan and France.
Once in a lifetime experience... truly amazing. Simply the best, at least for me. You will need at least one hour to see it. Absolute a must to see.
As good as AW. Bayon is as good as Angkor Wat. The actual size is bigger. It is a must see. If you want to avoid crowds, visit some of the small temples.

Bayon. A must see. Breath taking views. Be prepared for steep climbs & jostling with tourist crowds. If you are visiting please keep the place clean, too much of litter there which is a little sad to see.

Great. I have visited bayon annually for the last 6 years. Over this time it has become more and more restrictive where you can go. This time there was a lot of restoration going on. I know it is a necessity but it does that away from the experience.
My favorite one. Simply the best, at least for me. You will need at least one hour to see it. Absolute a must to see.

"Bayon My Favorite Temple". There are about 200 temples in Siem Reap but Bayon is very charming and my first favorite temple. Bayon has so many Buddha faces about 134 faces are remaining today and about 216 faces in original time. Bayon is the great architecture building from around 13th century and all the different pieces of sandstone look like they have done a great job with the recycle of sandstone. Love it so much!!!

My favourite. This is a masterpiece. So many corners and corridors and big faces of Buddha. I found one vantage point to see 6 Buddha faces at the same time. We visited this temple twice. It is very interesting and tickles your imagination. Unmissable. Late afternoon gives the best light for phographs.

All of the faces!. If you skip sunrise at Angkor, you'll have the place to yourself. Easy climbing except the library, that had the narrowest steps. Don't miss this one. Buddha faces everywhere. There was a "guide" hanging out and he helped me up the library and showed me around, and all of the great spots to take photos, I gave him five bucks when I had my fill of Bayon.

The Next Highlight of Cambodia after the Angkor Wat. It's the second biggest Wat after Angkor Wat. Magnificient in its own right, a sight of beautyStand at the right spot, tilt camera from down to uoward angle, you can get to "kiss the buddha heads"
Part of the must do here. Bit of stair climbing, there was a student of the English school to offer to show you around for a donation to the school
Breathtakeing. The most beautiful temple I've never seen in my life. Those smiling faces just made me feel free, calm and peace. I could just look at this them for days.
Can be visited. If you have time after visiting the the famous ones you can go to Bayon. It is attractive but nothing different from the others.

Interesting place. Came to this place on a nice cloudy morning. the pictures on the wall are interesting, they have records of the daily life of the people that live during the Khmer empire. We had a guide to explain the place and its better you get a guide to help you navigate around the area and understand the history. Must do: a) find the smiling face of the bayon lady statue b) take a picture at the unique spot where your nose can connect to the bayon statue.

Bayon temple is a must after Angkor Wat Temple. if you spend either a half day or a full day tour, Bayon temple is a second must visit temple after Angkor Wat temple. this temple is very big and with a lot of big smiley faces as you can see in the photo.

Ever get the feeling someone is watching you?. This is the place to get that feeling that wherever you go your being watched. The faces in the temples are visible from all angles and this is a very interesting place to visit.

Captivating. Climbing through the temple ruins of Bayon with my kids is a memory that none of us will soon forget. This elaborate and impressive stone structure is haunting and beautiful; everything you would expect from Angkor experience.
