The first temple I visited and it took my breath away. Part of the full Angkor Wat tour that I did and this temple was the first we visited. Just totally took my breath away and you have to be there to really appreciate the scale of it.

Beautiful. One of the most famous and popular temples of Siem Reap, this temple is famous for the many smiling faces of Buddha. We visited on a sunny day and the photographs turned out really beautiful, with blue skies and the serene Buddha faces!

Captivating Enormous Heads draw attention from afar!. The enormous heads of Avalokiteshwara in the Bayon temple of Angkor Thom are imposing and enigmatic. The ancient ruins of this city, with four main gates, so many inner courtyards and temples is like a maze, and as you explore, you may come out somewhere else!

Beautiful. All the temples are beautiful. This one has alot of stairs!! I really enjoyed the path in and then around the back walking through the forest a little bit seeing the trees grow around the rocks.
Bayon Temple. Awe inspiring ruins with many steps to climb. Great photography opportunities. Can get a bit hot--take water with you.

Faces of Bayon. i may say one of my favorites! the structure of the whole temple was really amazing! the faces of bodhisattva Avalokiteshvara is all over the temple and perfectly sculptured! well as it was thousand of years ago due to the ruins still it remains historically preserved.

Friends & Family trip - Tuktukking around the Siem Reap temples. It would be unthinkable to come to Siem Reap and not see the temples! We started out early this morning, with two tuktuks, and the plan was to make the trip around the 'big' loop, with short stops at each temple. Follow up visits are permissible under the ticketing arrangements, so this plan worked out nicely and avoids 'ruin fatigue'. The temples are visually arresting, and if you can slip through the band of vendors unharassed- definitely the better. The roadside eateries along the way offer welcome iced tea and very good coffee. Tip - make sure you establish an RV point with your tuktuk driver for each temple spot, as some exit points are on the other side. Drivers have also been known to abandon passengers who bargain too heavily.Camera wise: would recommend something wide (eg. 14-24) and stopping down to F4, WB on shady to get the warmth of the blocks inside the ruins and under the trees.

Hidden surprise!. This is by far the best temple ruin among the others in Siem Reap.We were lucky that just a couple of hours before we came to this temple, it had rained. The place looked heavenly with lush greenery everywhere and the wet atmosphere and post rain smell adding to the feel of the site! You then enter into the temple with around 500 face statues surrounding you! DO not miss this at any cost!Tip: Visit this towards the later part of the day (closer to the evening) to feel the beauty of this place. In the scortching sun, it may not impress you as much as it would towards the cooler evening time.

Beautiful freezes, one of the top three temples in the park. Visited this temple late morning just before lunch. It is a magestic site, with walls decorated with exquisite freezes. It is divided into three tiers, with the top absolutely packed with tourists. It must be a beautiful place to be at sunset though.

spectacular!. this temple is simply of monumental proportions! the face of bayon carved onto monoliths is simply out of this world!a good time to visit would be 4:00 pm in the evening, just before sunset. i went here as part of the walking tour conducted by Sam in Siem Reap.

Amazing sculptures. From the outside I thought they were just ruins of temple towers. But when I walked close to the towers, a face of the Buddha is on each side of the temple tower. However, too much maintaing or even renovation have to be done.
Very accessible and big. Nice temple very accessible. very wild and big. can climb as well. very impressed, need time to be able to look all round.

Heart of Angkor Thom. The Bayon Temple is the central part of the ruined city of Angkor Thom. It's huge towers with the inscrutable faces staring down are very arresting. The well documented bas reliefs are worth a look. Like all the sites it gets very busy. Go early if you can.
Faces. Be prepare to climb just a few steps, the faces turns golden during sunset, and most tourist will be gone by then, so visit in the afternoon.
top of the 'kor. in the vast vast angkor, you see fell-down rocks and you see mega trees. Well this one is none of that but my favorite, for all the faces carved in each direction. Impressive.

Not that exciting. This was our least favorite of the three we went to. It is another massive temple- it's a lot of walking and to me, not worth it. If you're into the history of it, yes, this place is so cool and so special.

Almost better than Ankor Wat. After taking a guided tour through the main temple yesterday we branches off on our own today to see Bayon and it was fantastic. Less well preserved than Ankor Wat, but just as beautiful! There are even monkeys living in the ruins. You could spend all day wandering around but we were in and out in about an hour and a half. Well worth a visit.

History In Front Of You. Built almost 1000 years ago, this is truly a unique place to visit. We had a guide go through the area with us, which I believe helped make the visit more interesting and worth while. Make sure the guide of you choice will provide water, the area can get very hot through the day.
Absolute must see. This is where you find the 216 smiling faces. It's absolutely magnificent from far and the detailed work differentiating all the faces from close up is impressive.

Another great temple!. This place is just one of the many amazing temples in the area and is well worth a visit! Bring water and a hat cause it can get damn hot around there. You'll need to buy a pass at the ticket office to see this as well as the other temples.

another great Temple. I had gone here as part of the Angkor watt tour that i had arranged and again was blown away by the temple and the wonder of this it is not as large as the other but certainly worth looking and allow about 40 minutes to wonder through

Even Methusaleh Would Feel Young Here. I've done a few reviews, but sometimes the words just aren't enough to describe an "experience" like this. Simply amazing, and no surprise that seeing this place is on so many people's bucket list.Take your time, sit and soak in the feeling of the place, and enjoy.

Fabulous place. Saw this as part of a guided tour. Amazing ruins of what must have been an amazing capital. Wear good walking shoes, loose clothes & be prepared to walk a lot! It's a must see place but make sure you go with an official guide to get the most out of the visit.

Unique temple with many faces. The Bayon temple is located at the centre of Angkor Thom. It's uniqueness lies in the fact that there are many faces sculpted into walls, on pillars, and at the top of towers. Worth a visit.
History & climbing. Loved it...kids loved as they could climb and explore. We were there quite early not so many people. Watch out for the monkeys if you have food.

Amazing Bayon Temple. Bayon Temple was one of the highlights of our trip in Siem Reap. The temple grounds are a veritable treasure-trove of sites and architecture to climb around. And climb is exactly what you can do. Bring some good climbing shoes, because the steps can be a bit tricky, particularly if it is wet out. We took time to wander slowly around the grounds as our guide (Mr. Sun) told us stories of the many faces that make up Bayon.

Watch the big stone faces. I like Bayon especially because of the big stone faces giving this place a mystic atmosphere. Come here late afternoon when the crowds rush for sun set to have the place on your own.

Very Nice. This is a wonderful place to visit. You are able to wander among such old ruins without many people,To be able to touch many of the carving is amazing . Not sure how long this will be so. I think in time all will be fenced off.
Neat place. Can get crowded but we went in afternoon. I like the face to face picture you can take with one of the faces. This is one of my favorite temples.

One of its kind!. Unmissable series of gigantic, meditative 216 faces. Unique in the way the rocks are arranged without being cemented together and then carved into compassionate expressive faces, is quite incredible. A must-see.

Favourite temple. The temple with the four faces or bayon temple is one of my favourite temples in Cambodia. This temple site is not overly crowded like ankgor wat. The architecture and restoration of the temple makes it an amazing temple to visit.
Faces. As good as Angkor WatLoved the intricately built stones faces, a photographers heaven on earthGreat place to spend an hour or 2

Piece of art!. Don't know what other people think of this wonder, but for me, it was really a wonder of the world. It might not look gorgeous, luxurious or sth, it looked old, damaged, but its structure and composition was amazing, even in little details crafted on those bricks! I just loved wandering around and wondering how the ancients had lived

Interesting temple with intricate carvings. This temple is worth a visit because of the intricate carvings and different types of stone used to build it. It is easy to traverse and there are opportunities to do some close-up photography for the carvings and intricate stone work. This is the only temple dedicated exclusively to a female, which may be of interest.

Great temple. It was raining the day we went to this temple but even that couldn't dampen our enthusiasm to explore this wonderful site. It stands in the exact centre of the city of Angkor Thom and it is a collection of 54 towers decorated with 216 enormous faces of Avalokiteshvara. Once again we noticed that by adding 5+4 we got the magical number 9 and also by adding 2 +1+ 6 we got 9. This number seems to feature a lot in the temples. Apparently the best time to visit this places is early in the morning or late in the afternoon but we were there mid morning and it was still fantastic. The carvings on the outer wall are really interesting because they show 11000 figures going about their everyday life in 12th century Cambodia. There are pictures of a naval battle, people checking heads for something, possibly lice, hunters and people cooking a pig while others appear to be carrying water. These are very clear to see.Well worth a visit even if it is raining but I would recommend that you wear good walking shoes because it can be a bit slippery when wet. Jenine
Amazing temple. This temple of faces was my favourite! Just amazing, can sit and enjoy for hours. Try to get there early
amaze. a must do when you travel here. just don't do much if you not fit enough. there is a few big temple to visit after
Plan before the crowds come. We went her around 11:00 am and it was packed with tourists. One need to ask around what times there are less people.
A temple in Angkor. There are many temples in Angkor, this is only one, but filled with history. Be sure to see as many as you can.

My favorite!. This was my favorite temple in Siem reap!We went there mid-afternoon, so it wasn't as crowded and the lighting was perfect for pictures!The walls and gates around it are also very beautiful. Must see!!!

More and More to See. Besides the obvious Angkor Wat this site must be seen as well. There are multiple site en route to this site but this shall certainly be memorable. There is some reconstruction going on here but that won't deter you from a worthwhile visit on the site. The crowds can be horrendous but take your time and enjoy the sights - marvellous place to visit.
One of our favorites. Definitely one of our favorite temples around Siem Reap so don't miss it. Each temple was unique but this one was even more spectacular than the others.
Well worth it. Spent 1 and a half hours there. Taking pictures n exploring the place. Gotta be extra careful of uneven terrain though

MUST GO temple in Angkor Thom. it's amazing that you see a lot of sculpture in the whole temple.
some tour guide will suggest you to make funny photo but I rather not to do that. it's really amazing place for your to visit in Angkor Thom

Challenging site!. Hubby loves this the most. He enjoys climbing the towers to view the entire site. The stairs were so steep and some were incomplete. Thinking back, it is amazing how we climbed up there and then climbed down again. Thoroughly enjoyed the site. The smiling face Buddha is really nice. The sculptures are mesmerizing. There is a group of people who wore traditional costume, waiting for tourists to take pictures with them for a fee. This site is very crowded too. Need an hour to explore the place.

Amazing smile. The temple is not as big as Angkor Wat. However the smile on the top of every pagoda is amazing. I suggest you visit in the early morning or late afternoon. Because the strong sunshine may make your photo not very beautiful.
Faces are worth the visit. This is likely part of any tour as it should be. The faces are large and interesting. Great for photos.

Highlight of the Khmer architecture!. The four-faced smiling Budhhas were distinctively different from the other temple architectures around the area and was definitely the highlight for me. I would highly recommend them!
Unique Experience for Life. Simply extraordinary. Feel like Tomb Raider, or Indiana Jones. Try not to plunder any artifacts, take only photos and keep only memories.
Remarkable Carvings. One of the best, smiling faces and carvings on the temple was one of the best in Cambodia. Highly recommend in the afternoon for less crowds.
worth taking a look. Relatively well preserved, definetly interesting and not comparable with other temples. Very photogenic.

Bayon Temple. Interesting temple with lots of nooks and crannies but not completely reconstructed yet. Lots of Buddhist monks visit this site so it may have great significance (sorry don't know its history). Definitely worth including on your temple list.

Vivid in its beauty. The sprawling grounds were more relaxing than some of the other temples - partly because we visited earlier and partly because it's not quite as famous. Don't let that distract from it though, by far one of the most amazing religious sites I've been too.
Part of the trio. Yes. Beautiful! different from Angkor Wat main. This one you walk in the complex of temples ending in the elephant terrace. Bring water!
Complex and beautiful temple. Bayon is the remarkable temple in Angkor Thom. The temple is really complex with many carvings. The story of the temple is also very interesting

One of my favorites. I thought seeing this temple after Angkor Wat I would be disappointed but this temple was my favorite after Angkor Wat. It has a multitude of faces (some say 54) carved on its many towers - facing north, south, east, west. Each side represents one of these: Charity , Compassion, Sympathy and Equanimity. As I walked through this temple, every turn, every corner presented a different view - and a different picture. I never tired of looking at this amazingly intricate carvings. Don't miss this!

Buddhist temple in a sea of Hindu temples around the area. Bayon is an amazing temple complex; it is the one you recognize from all the photos with the faces. It can be difficult to get photos here without other tourists but the beauty of this temple is second to none! In my opinion the best pictures here can be taken near mid-day. You will want to take photos from almost every angle and if the sun is low it will ruin your shots one way or the other. I highly recommend taking the photos with the temple's reflection in the pond from the back side.
Great architecture. Despite being just blocks of stones placed but it was built as a beautiful temple with all entrances are well placed and symmetrical.

Worth A Visit.. Make sure you go here if you are going to Angkor Wat. Some tour guides will ask you what you want to fit in to your day as it would be really hard to see it all at once. You can visit this place a couple of times if you have the week pass.

To see in a lifetime. This goes for every other temple in the complexe but the Bayon Temple will remain with me for a while. We visited late in the day and there were few people around and it was just magnificent to walk around. Loved every minute of it!

Fantastical temple with excellent preserved murals. Squarish temple complex in the center of Angkor Thom, many of its parts in ruins but a few dozen towers standing/restored with giant faces of King Jayavarman VII. The outer gallery has a long mural with carvings in excellent condition, showing scenes from ancient daily life, along with naval battle scenes between the Khmer and the Chams. Moving up to the top level, there are many good spots for photos with the huge faces. We got here by private tour van.
Must See!. One of the nicer temples in Cambodia. A must see! Also once you climb up the stairs and go to the back part, their are some ladies that will show you which face you can take a photo with.

More intimate compared to Angkor Wat. I personally prefer Bayon over Angkor Wat as it is a much smaller compound, and it is easier for my young family to cover this temple. The famous stone faces are truly a sight to behold and when you personally go face to face with them you will marvel how much effort the stone masons took to crave out a face using multiple blocks of sandstone. As mentioned in my previous post, there is an entrance fee payable before entering the temple compound and I will recommend not to go do the temple tour too late. Chartering a tuktuk will be highly recommended and will save you a lot of money compared to those pricey deals offered by the hotel concierge. 5/5.
Very nice temple in the Angkor Archaelogical Park. One of the temples in Angkor Arhcaelogical Park, Very impressive, regarding how old the temples are!

Good place for photo taking. - recommend to visit on the morning.
- walk with a group
- do not simply allow freelance tour guide (they cost me USD 20 after negotiation for a short photo taking session)
- there are lot's of hidden view that you need to explore yourself.
- wear sport shoe, no slipper
- shades, cap, water is needed
sun set trip. watching the sunset from up here, wow. the day i was there some one was making a documentary and filming it, but wow! can't say any more
Our absolute favorite temple. For us this beat even Ankor Wat. Absolutely stunning temple. Gorgeous surroundings. So many photo opportunities. Carvings everywhere you look.

Probably my favourite temple!. Just loved walking through this site and looking at the engravings and the amazing smiling buddha heads. Couldn't believe that tourists are allowed do climb over most of the temples. I'm sure this will be stopped soon enough but i'm glad we were able to get up close to these incredible temples while we could.

Fascinating temple. This is one of the best temples in Siem Reap. The enormous stone heads are memorable and it appears everyone is different. We approached via the South Gate with the Naga walkway and the guardians on either side of the moat. It was mid-December - still the high season and it was really really crowded and patience is needed to view the architecture and to get those photographs. If possible, I would've opted for the off season as the sheer number of people, especially the large tour groups detracted from the visit.

Absolutely beautiful Temple. We went to the Bayon Temple twice. It is fabulous! There are four faces on each of the face towers, some of them in the likeness of the King. There were originally 49 towers, there are 37 still standing. The mass of face towers together give the impression of a stone mountain with various peaks. It is beautiful both close up and from the ground. Really loved the larger face carvings and the bas-reliefs. It had a feeling of "Picnic at Hanging Rock" about it as you ascended the maze like temple. Very atmospheric! Plan to spend an hour here and go early to beat the crowds.

This place made me want to change religion. Both myself and my wife were just mesmerized by this temple and i have to say, more so than Angkor Wat. Sometimes you visit a place and feel like you belong and I've travelled many places internationally but never felt more connected or belonging than I did here. Have a guide take you around and explain what it all means and then go around again in your own time and take it all in. Still puts a lump in my throat watching my beautiful wife in tears by just feeling in harmony with her surroundings. Amazing, amazing, amazing...
Great Historic temple. Great history and well worth the visit , just wander around get a local guide if possible they will show the points of interest and take some unique photographs for you.

Kid Friendly Temple of Fun. This Temple is amazing! Its more interactive than the others: you can build small towers out of rocks (the higher they are = the more luck you're given, don't knock them over) and there is a section of temple near the front that you can climb on and take photos, while at the other temples this is seen as disrespectful, here we were encouraged to take part. Super kid friendly!

Beautiful ruins. Surprisingly the Bayon is in more ruins than the Angkor wat even though it was built later. But such beautiful ruins you will not have seen . It's part of the huge Angkor Thom which is a town in itself. Don't miss

Prettiest Temple among other temple. This is my favorite temple during the temple visit. It will be helpful with guide to explain and tell the story on the wall craved. Lot of climbing need to be done as it have around 3 level of different view.

My favourite spot in all of Angkor!. This place blew my mind. The details were amazing. Don't do just Angkor Wat without visiting Bayon at Angkor Thom!! We went at about 3pm and there was hardly anyone else there, really refreshing after the rush of people at Angkor Wat. Overall Bayon was a beautifully detailed temple and so glad we got to experience it.
so much to see. we managed 4 to the temples at the site, each as magical as the other. make sure you have a guide, water and hat!

Must see!. This was one of our favourite temples! A must see temple full of atmosphere. The carvings of all the faces are amazing at any time of the day, but it is more atmospheric early in the morning.

Other worldly. Bayon Temple was one of the highlights of our time in Siem Reap. When you first look at Bayon, you don't appreciate what lies ahead of you. The temple grounds are a veritable treasure-trove of sites and architecture to climb around. And climb is exactly what you can do. Bring some good climbing shoes, because the steps can be a bit tricky, particularly if it is wet out. We took time to wander slowly around the grounds as our guide told us stories of the many faces that make up Bayon. One of the features of Bayon is that you can get right up close to the best parts. It is a magical place that should not be rushed.
Favorite temple in the Angkor Wat complex. This temple is so cool. It's part of the 3 that most people go to see, but it's worth returning to, there are so many details to explore.

face on face. Another iconic must do. Perhaps it is because my visit here was timed different from the last whatever being the case my affinity towards this venue expanded exponentially this time aroundThe only hindrance if any were the number of people. It was crowded and it was not far from feeling like you were in amongst the many in a famous department store summer sale.

No Fear of height required!. Besides the fact that is part of the small circle of Angkor wat and it is just AMAZING! This temple has the steepest stair cases I've climbed - machu pichu included. At least these stairs were made of wood and has rails but still. For the young at body not at heart. ForOlder people- you can definitely do it but take your time.

great detail, in really good condition. The views/design seem to change from every angle. I really enjoy just walking around and getting lost inside of all of the passageways and courtyards. Well worth a trip (but I'd suggest stopping at Angkor Wat for sunrise first).

Excellent temple. It was great to wander round a number of temples during our guided tour, and amazing to think how much effort went into creating these magnificent structures. Well worth the effort to wander round in the heat.

Mesmerising!. The temples across the Angkor ruins offers a great visual experience and offers a view into the interesting past of the Khmer kings. But this particular temple, with those large faces sculpted(said to no. close to 200) all through the towers of the temple is a visual treat. I would rate it higher than the Angkor Wat!

One of my favorite temples!. Bayon Temple was one of my favorite temples in Angkor Wat complex. Each temple in Siem Reap has an characteristic architecture and Bayon has faces on its towers and walls everywhere. You can climb up the stairs and find a really nice part of the temple with narrow paths surrounded by walls and towers with the faces on it, some of them are crying some of them are smiling as I've heard the guide speaking to some other group. You can have a nice shot from what they call "library" but the stair is really steep! Forgot to mention that this place is crowded too. If I'm not mistaken Bayon Temple makes part of the small tour and of course you need the ticket to get inside.

My favorite by far. . Visited Bayon three times. Twice in one day on my last day. The beauty of the many faces will never get old. I can't wait to come back experience this temple again. I'll never forget this place.
Impressive smiley heads. Took some great shots here. It's quite spread out so don't miss the other temple which is a couple of mins walk away.

Hands down my fav temple. Yes it's crowded, yes it's touristy, but it is magical. There are many corners to explore, and it's so full of history, good and bad. Take your time, explore at your own pace, and be sure to take a picture in front of the small lakes. The reflection is very nice. Taking a tour guide will certainly help you appreciate this amazing temple. Unlike a museum, there is nothing to tell you what you're looking at. And why spend your time with your nose in a book. Plus, you're helping support the locals by doing so. I really felt my time was enriched by going with a guide. I just loved the way the Bayon looked, and felt. Children were at play, dogs were lazing in the sun, and a true sense of Cambodia was reaching towards the skies.
The most beautiful temple!. This is super atmospheric place! So many faces are looking at you ;) Perfect place for trippy experience)

Extraordinary. This place is amazing, so many smiling faces at every turn, one of of favourite places at the Angkor temples.We went with our guide Rany who has a superb knowledge of the temples and took us around explaining the significance of temples.Everywhere you turn there is another smiling face, the climb to the top was worth it as the views are stunning, our guide knew all the areas for great photo opportunities and we got some great pictures we would never have got had he not been with us.

Beautiful. Got to do a tour at this temple early in the morning. It was perfect because it was almost empty. If you go later in the day, crowds might be annoying because it is a bit small upstairs and pictures can be hard to get.
My favorite temple. My favorite temple in Siem Reap. Love the faces.It is huge and crowded, you might want to time your visit to avoid crowds.

My Favorite of all the Angkor Temples. I can spend hours just wandering around these amazing ruins. Of all that Angkor has to offer I LOVE the Bayon the most. This is my fourth trip to the Angkor ruins ...my favorite ruins in the world. I made the most of my three day pass this year, spending three full days exploring not only the major sites, but the less visited ones as well. If you're a photographer you'll find yourself taking a ton of pics. A must see place in the world!

Must do must see. This is all within the Angkor wat complex so make sure you check this one out. There are over 100 temples but Bayon Temple is listed as one of the main ones to see, and you will know why when you see It for your self.Just amazing. Had a great time. Would suggest bringing lots of water and a packed lunch to keep going as the whole complex is huge.Date visited: 1 Dec 2015

200 faces staring at you. This temple has you wondering if each face has a slight different style because of the artist or due to differing rates of erosion over time, either way which ever direction you turn there is one that is looking at you. I love how you can roam around the faces after climbing to the top, this is a magical temple and a must see.
jaw dropping visuals for your mind. its amazing to touch and feel and climb on something so gorgeous and part of human antiquity. good trip at least once in your life almost a musttc
Wonderful. Amazing architect and it's nice to know a little history behind this tempel which can be read before visiting it or by hiring a tour guide.

The centre of Angkor Wat. One of the relatively complete historical buildings still standing. The sculptures of smiling faces are clear and it is really unbelievable that all smiling faces are actually different.

Don't overlook this one!. Whilst in Siem Reap - don't only focus on Angkor Wat - check this one out - absolutely stunning and worth a visit. Again some gigantic faces greet you as you arrive - take some time to sit and poner at how this was built and what the significance of this temple was and indeed is to the people of Cambodia. Try not to spend the day racing through the temples of Siem Reap - sit, take stock - leave your camera aside for a while. Embrace and Enjoy.

Broken faces. High structure and many stone faces but most are broken and not too recognizable. The steps are steep and one can always find spots to rest. Not advised for the marginal health or infirm.

Amazing must see but consider something else first. Not sure I can add much to what has already been written. This is a MUST SEE. Go early morning or late afternoon to reduce exposure to heat. Also, paying $40 for 3 days vs $20/day is available so if you will be in the area for more than two days pay for the extended pass. Lastly, you might want to check out the Angkor Museum first before going into the temples. It provides an incredible overview.

Must see. Loved the history and mythology, an amazing structure still standing. Try and pick cool days if that's possible!! Paid for a tour guide, worth the money unless you do lots of research beforehand.
Yet another site not to be missed. Fantastic, did all the major sites in one day. It was tiring but very worth it as long as you have a guide with you
Wonderful, great setting. A pleasure to visit very peaceful not too Crowded. Beautiful setting. Help understand the complex.history of this area. Easy to walk about the well maintained grounds.
Another temple to take your breath away. If you love archaeology or just came to see the ancient temples, this one should definitely be included into your tour. Gorgeous masonry!
Awesome Temple!!!. Bayon Temple is definitely one of the 'must visit' place in Siem Reap!!! Beautiful ruins and amazing carvings. Just breath-taking in my opinion!!!

You can't not go.. Most of the people here have already said it: it is a must visit. Go around crumbling towers and narrow corridors and discover it for yourself. There is a place of worship in the middle tower, but unless you are a Buddhist there isn't much to see. Make sure you spent some time on the outside wall carvings.

Come when it's quiet too many tour groups ruin the place. We visited twice as we were too exhausted the first day to see it all but enjoyed walking around the passageways underneath the temple in the shade. Sadly the second day it was jam packed with tours, tons of them all looking at the same things and getting in the way of anybody without a guide. It ruined the ambience and feeling. At the top of the temple you can see lots of stone heads but try to come at a quiet time if you can. We wish we didn't come back the second day.Be prepared for fake guides that charge you, sellers calling you to buy things and book sellers. But that's at every popular attraction. Please don't give money to the children they are working for someone the money won't go to them and they will go out and do the same thing the next day. Remember to promote good tourism in the country. Also you can get elephant rides here we weren't too sure on the welfare of these elephants you may want to enquire or research before getting a ride.

the true beauty. After watching sunrise at Angkor Wat (impressive) we moved onto Bayon which is simply stunning and in our opinion actually more impressive then Angkor Wat. We went very early in the morning and practically had Bayon to ourselves .... favorite temple visit. Just beautiful

beautiful place. beautiful temple, one of my favorite. go early in the morning to avoid the crowd, it is a very small temple, try to go before 9 am. It is also cooler. There is an elephant ride that takes you around the temple, again go early, the ride usually starts around 8:30, be first in line.
Must see!!!. This temple isn't talked about enough! It's gorgeous and there is so much to explore! What an amazing experience! Highly recommended!

Excelent. All the ruins of Angkor are beautiful. Amazing.For me one of hthe wordl wonders.Really love it! I recommend. An advice, bring water and sunscreen. The complexes are very large and it's very hot.
Amazing. Breathtaking. Many tourists, but what do you expect. Well worth the tour as part of a wider tour seeing Angkor Thom and Ta Prohm.

Amazing!. You should not go to Angkor Wat without visiting Bayon. The road leading to the South Gate is incredible with devas lined up on one side and asuras on the other. No two faces are exactly the same and they set the stage for what remains to be seen beyond the gate. The temple is complex, beautiful, and well worth the visit. Take your time here as there are so many images to photograph and contemplate.
Beautiful ruins. A spectacular temple. Beautiful ruins that should be at the top of your itinerary for the thousands of acres of temples and ruins in Angkor Wat.

Incredible. I went there three times too and just sat and meditated as it was so peaceful. The hundreds of carved farces are just so incredibly beautiful. The atmosphere breathtaking, I loved it and will be back one day.

A must see temple.. Allow plenty of time for this temple and be sure to wear good shoes for climbing and exploring.This is one of the main temples and is truly spectacular in both size, contruction and history. Allow a full day for this temple and some of its smaller surrounding temples.

Best of the Ankor Sights. Very interesting temple with not too many Chinese tourists prancing around taking photos of themselves. Most of them cannot have gained any insight into the importance of the Ankor complexSuper carvings and a rich history.....if you have only one day in Ankor make sure Bayon is on your list.

Baton temple visit. My second day visit to the temple route after Angkor Wat. The place is big and nice, it was relatively in better shape as Angkor Wat compare to the smaller temples along the route.

Something different from the rest. Another amazing temple within the Angkor complex. The features were slightly different from the others, much less crowded than Angkor Wat (or maybe we were just earlier than the rest of the crowd). Had a good time admiring the facial carvings on the walls.

Our guide's favorite temple in the Angkor complex. Bayon has more Buddha heads than I can remember. It is simply amazing. Be sure to book a good guide for all these temples. Mr. Mey Try was ours and he is not only an excellent guide, he is a very wonderful human being with a happy attitude in spite of his country's civil strife of the past and how it affected him personally. Email: entry_58@yahoo.com and tell him Darrell and Patti sent you.

Stunning!. Even more stunning than Angkor Wat is the Bayon Temple at Angkor Thom, with its 216 smiling Buddahs. Take the time to look at all the squares inches of this place and exit through the back for an incredible view of the building. Do not miss this one!
Ancient wonder..... Like most of the temples in the area closest to Siem Reap, these ruins are amazing...be sure to wear good shoes for climbing stairs and walking on uneven ground...
Second Temple on our visit. Approached this temple from the south gate, just stunning. Could spend the whole day just walking around this one temple.

Pay all in US dollars. We were very surprised that local currency is almost not used. All paid in US dollars even the excursion to he temples $20US per person. That is a lot of money considering the large number of tourist that attend every day. The temple ruins were interesting.

Bayon Stuns everyone. Some rate it higher than Angkor Wat.
Well!!
The mamoth life-like faces do stun everybody but i feel both are very different and make an equal impression as the size and styles vary.
I rate it right on top sharing its stature with Angkor Wat.
Must visit early morning.

No way to avoid superlatives in describing this palce. see my review of Angkor Wat and substitute Bayon for all references to Angkor Wat. I exhausted 2 camera batteries in just this one temple. Everything seemed familiar to us as we had overtime seen so much about Bayon. But nothing, nothing sets you up for the surprise, the particular joy and feeling you get when walking around Bayon. Every turn of a corner, every portal you pass through gives you a buzz. All the faces magically appear and the awe inspiring vista just goes on and on. A good choice of guide proves invaluable.

Great area, 'boutique' temple. Angkor Wat and Ta Phrom get most of the attention, and rightfully so, but smaller, less significant temples such as this one are still remarkable. The rock carvings are really impressive and it's easy to lose track of time just wandering around admiring.

Don't miss out the faces. Not the nicest looking temple but surely one of the most interesting one. A closer look & you will find faces looking at all 4 directions on each tower, & there are so many of them. Kinda creepy but nevertheless interesting. Requires climbing steep stairs to get to the top so be prepared. I was amazed how the workers brought the stones up such heights.Might've looked nice earlier in the morning with milder lighting, but the good thing about going there at noon was there were fewer people up there so it was easier for me to take pictures without other tourists.Don't miss out the wall carvings at the base around the temple.A must-see if you come to Angkor. One of the signature temples in the region.
My favorite. This is my favorite temple because of the beautiful scenery and the dramatic eerie buddha stones creates mixed emotions.
Still my favorite temple in the area . Really enjoy this one more than the others. I find it so interesting. And continue to find new things to explore there on this second trip here.

Maybe the best one?!. I really enjoyed this temple. It was a little quieter than the others and I was fascinated by its cluttered beauty. The faces were captivating as well as the worn away sculpture that decorates it. Definitely worth a visit.

Beautiful Beautiful Bayon!!. This would have to have been one of the highlights of our trip to Cambodia! This incredible temple is situated in the heart of Angkor Thom. There are 216 gigantic faces and when you look at them a feeling of serenity comes over you. They are just amazing! There is a huge gallery of bas-reliefs that are incredibly detailed and tell of the life back then. Very interesting to study. Truly a must see temple
Temple of faces. Another popular temple due to its prominent stone faces found on every face of each tower. Very crowded but definitely mesmerising and worthwhile.
Stunning View. It was a large temple and a very nice for taking lots of picture specially if you could get a complete picture of it as your background,

Temple with massive stone faces. We entered Angkor Thom via South Gate and visited Bayon Temple which was at the centre of Angkor Thom. Bayon Temple was significant for the massive stone faces that stood on the top of a number of towers. We climbed up to the central tower to have a closer look at the massive stone faces, all faces showed a calm expression.
Bayon Temple. Take the time to visit all parts, sit, wait, see. Try to visit early in the morning, during the day allways crowded

Amazing carvings- worth the trip for sure. great temple, pretty large and loads of amazing carvings. Kids liked this one. Access by steps, you need to be quite fit to get around this. recommend the trip.
Same same but different. Was a nice place to visit but very much similar to all the other temples around the area, didn't spend too much time here.
Cultural overload!. Go as early as possible during the day to avoid the hordes of tourists angling for photos. Beautiful site.
Smiling in the Rain. Umbrellas, slippery stepping stones, and rain drops on my camera lens did not dampen the spirit of those smiling faces. Bayon Temple is extraordinary, even in the pouring rain.
soo pretty.... part of the best of the temples... go go go.. make sure you tke water and drink lots..because it was very warm
Amazing. Lots of amazing heads, 216 in total . great piece of architecture and lots of pictures to take also wonderful history behind it

Fascinating for Tibetan Buddhists. There is a new theory that The Bayon and the temples of that period were as a result of mass initiations and state Tantric Buddhism. If you are a Tibetan Buddhist, you don't need to read that: you can see it as soon as you look at the Bayon, just as you can with the Shwe Dagon pagoda or the stupa of Mihintale in Sri Lanka - even if the figures of Tara in The Bayon are too different from the versions that we know to recognise without a guidebook. With a doorstep and a new shrine every few feet, it's tiring to walk around some parts, but even if there are many tourists crowding the top, the lower levels and galleries are very quiet. I'm not going to buy into any theory of who the smiling faces represent, as I have my own ideas, but to understand this temple would take a deep background in both Khmer archaeology and Tantric Buddhism, and I'm not sure if anybody in the world has this. Architecturally, The Bayon is crowded and seems rather chaotic. It's hard to take in although it's not especially large. If you look carefully, you can see the remains of post holes and holes that supported tiles: then you realise that the bare stone is only the skeleton of walls that once supported richly decorated tiles of wood, ceramic, bronze, gold, and silver, and you can imagine its glory. This was a mandala in stone, not a place for people to visit to do practice but a magical centre and geomantic blessing for the civilisation, still as living as are the equivalents that are being built today. Whereas the Hindu temples of Angkor have, like Hindi temples everywhere, murals of gods, this, as a Buddhist temple, has images of daily life, from the lowest to highest. The caretakers there are also fascinating to talk to and very helpful. When I offered my pass, which was so drenched in sweat that it was falling apart, they exclaimed in concern and asked to hang onto it and dry it out. By the time I came out they had done this, very carefully, and put the pass in plastic for me. One guide could tell what country visitors were from with only a brief glance, which I tested by asking them - that included people like Argentinians and Mexicans. The caretakers get a very low wage and are there from their commitment and feeling for the past. A lot of them are meditators and very spiritual. I fell in love with the gentle Cambodian people.Temples that are less visited have a stronger feeling of spirituality. But The Bayon is still one of the greatest architectural marvels of the world, and I feel enriched just for having visited it.

A more domestic sized Angkor wat. We liked this smaller but equally enthralling temple, beautifully carved and easy to explore. This is a good first place to get in temple mood before tackling Angkor Wat.

be here early. with hundreds of tourist everyday it is better to be here early to have a good picture of it. it was really an experience to witness this temple in person. the faces of Buddha are really intricate carved in sandstone.
Bayon Review. Like Angkor Wat, absolutely amazing and just next door. Inhabited by a troupe of monkeys. You cannot help wonder how it is that civilistions on 3 continents all built pyramids.
1000 face of budha. This also called 1000 faces of buddha temple, great temple, every place in Angkor wat is beautiful, but during the summer, the heat weather may become problem for western visitor

Ancient Grandness. Must see with a professional guide to give you a guide tour in your native language to understand its history. Sadly, Bayon temple in deteriorating in its age to understand its grandness. Go now to visit!!

Awesome . A very mystical temple in the middle of a giant roundabout. It's much larger than it looks in photographs. There are so many huge and impressive temples in the area so don't just focus on Angkor Wat

So many big trees. Sad to see trees and their roots have begun destroying the temples.My phone went flat so no pics :(But also im pretty sure this is the temple where the live action tomb raider was shot.However there are so many temples so i really cant remember.Also be vary of tourists as they love and i mean love, blocking up paths making them inaccessible to people just wanting to continue exploring :)Also probably bring hiking boots, i did and it was so much easier. Lots of harsh terrain and rocks.I saw people in thongs :/

Too busy. This is a lovely temple to visit but is just too busy. There are so many people you actually have to queue just to move around. Even at 7am there are so many people. It was my least favourite temple of the dozen or so we visited just because you couldn't enjoy it because of the crowds.

Visit the other temples in the area for an otherworldly experience. My cousin and I climbed about this temple (which is lovely) but once we got a bit off the main track and out into more of the complex, things became even more interesting. Some of my most favorite photographs from the trip were taken from the other temples and forests around the area.

Fantastic faces. This is always one of my favourite temples. The faces bring it to life.
Earlier in the day is less crowded.

Must visit for Sunrise. Most people go to Angkor Wat for sunrise, but if you can try to reach the Bayon temple by sunrise. The sight of the first rays of sun hitting the 'enigmatic' faces of Avalokiteshwara brings in the awe that stays with most of us even after the trip to the Angkor archaeological site. The Bayon temple, by itself, is mostly in ruins with some areas under renovation. Its a heaven for archaeology and architectural history buffs. We spent about an hour here as we were in the Angkor Complex for a day and had a lot to cover. Do wear light cotton clothes. It is advisable to carry a raincoat if you are going around the rainy season. Shades and a hat/ scarf to cover yourself would be highly recommended if you are going to be cycling/ biking. Carry ample amounts of water and light snacks with you.
Stunning!. I loved this place. So picturesque and unique. The area is not that big either, so it is manageable.

The always smiling faces. It is really difficult to chose which of the smiling faces is the most beautiful, for they all are...and have survived centuries of weather and jungle invasions, wars, the Khmer Rouge and millions of tourists! This temple is small and delightful, make sure you are fit for there are many steps!
Bayon Temple. Rain was letting up. Impressive-educational-For some it was very spiritual. I was more impressed with the grandeur of it all.
Smiling Faces!. This was one of our favorite temples! We loved climbing and exploring and finding all of the smiling faces that are carved into the stone.

Must See but not an Easy Stroll. It is awesome and left just as it was. It is accessible but not to wheelchairs or even people with walkers. I saw people with canes, but it was tough going. Crowds and a bit of rain.
Bayon Temple. Its the Khmer temple with the face of Buddhist King Jayavarman. There are a lot of steep steps to climb if you want to have a good view from the top. But its worth it.

Angkor Thom/Bayon. I hired a local personal guide and air conditioned car for our 3 days in Siem Reap. Bayon is the central temple in the Angor Thom complex. It should always be on your list to see. We visited IKKT Silk Factory, a temple and enjoyed an Apsara performance/dinner our first day. On day 2, we toured Angor Wat & Angor Thom, and attended the Phare Circus that evening, day 3 - Tha Phrom, Bantea Srei, and the Landmine Museum, with sunset on a nearby temple pagoda.
The Faces Temple. Also known as the faces temple. It is a comparatively smaller temple. Will not take more than an hour or two to look around the temple.
Amazing temple. Definitely a worth visit... I love how many smiley faces around the temple and the beautiful carving around it. It's so nice to explore inside the area

beautiful Bayon. we came to Bayon in the afternoon. Bayon is very beautiful, with many relief in the wall telling about the history. Many photograph can take there with natural lighting. It's so beautiful. We going with children, and they enjoy too.The stair going up is reasionable, even for children.

Don't Miss This!. This is one of the highlights of Angkor Thom! After Ta Prohm, I would rank this place second. The smiling faces are really something to see. It's a large structure and I think there's definitely a positive vibe with all the smiles around!:-) Since each stone was placed individually by elephants or men, the precision of the carvings is astounding. Don't miss this one!

Awesome!. Simply amazing! It is one of the best and my favourite among the eleven temples that I had visited during my 2 day tour of the temples. Saw it on the first day and went back again on my second day. Would definitely go back if I am ever in Seam Reap again!

Impressive faces.. The faces are the highlight here and very cool to see. I think under an hour to visit this temple is plenty of time. Having a guide is good to make sure you have the background story and history of it.

Put it on the list. Definitely worth a visit if you are visiting the temples in the complex. Smaller and less crowded than AW and lots of smiley, smiley faces. Don’t forget to get a photo of your side profile rubbing noses with the carved faces.
Bayon Temple. Fun area to explore and take photos. Really in aw of all of the temples in Angkor Wat / Anglor Thom area !
Interesting ruins. Be prepared for ruins rather than a well-preserved structure. Much of it is still being restored. I found the four-faced structures here very unique.
temple of smiles - loved it!. Makes anyone happy to see so many smiling faces in one building. Steep stairs to the top but worth climbing.

This is my favorite place on earth. This place is amazing.... It's the temple of smiles..... It takes you back to a time has since forgotten. But with the right guide Mam Somondy. you will relive the experience.
Great temple to view sunrise over Angkor Wat. Enjoyed this temple very early in the morning. The view is spectacular. It is a shame that restoration scaffolding obstructs the view for photos.
Multi - faced. This is a single large continuous complex. the bas relief depiction of war and procession is still well preserved. there is buddha temple just outside the Bayon temple.
Better than Angkor Wat. Personally I enjoyed this temple most. It's carvings are fantastic. Even a giant sleeping Buddha built into the walls..

Bayon Temple:Serenity. The Bayon Temple is a well-known and richly decorated Khmer temple at Angkor in Cambodia. Built in the late 12th or early 13th century as the official state temple of the Mahayana Buddhist King Jayavarman VII, the Bayon stands at the centre of Jayavarman's capital, Angkor Thom.Following Jayavarman's death, it was modified and augmented by later Hindu and Theravada Buddhist kings in accordance with their own religious preferences.

So cool. Another really awesome temple in angkor! A pass is required to enter. I got a 3 day pass for approximately 25$usd which is good for multiple temples and sites. I recommend visiting any time as it has more trees and shade than other temples you would want to visit early morning before the midday heat.

the most beautiful from all the temples. I visited angkor wat and in my opinion bayon is much more beautiful and with more details . The ticket to visit all the temples costs 20usd a day and to have a tuk tuk for the whole day driving you through all the temples costs about 20usd , 25usd if you wanna watch the sunrise!

Favorite of all the Temples. We had a blast exploring the many faces of Bayon! Climbing up steep staircases, entering hidden rooms and exploring the Bayon Temple make for hours of fun and exploration.

I will never forget this experience.... I went to the Bayon in the late afternoon. There were not so many people at that time. I walked along the corridors and came out. Then, I found a place to sit and wait for my friends. It was at the corner of the street across the Bayon. With so few people and cars passing by, I had a chance to be by myself. When I sat and looked at the faces, I felt not only the amazement inside but also the serenity in the faces which has affected me till now. I will never forget this tranquil experience.

Lots of atmosphere at the end of the day just beofre dusk. This is an magical temple with huge carved smiling Buddha faces where ever you look. Our local guide from All Points East small group tours had the best idea- we visited this very popular temple at the end of the day when the crowds has gone to enjoy it in peace and quite .

Is Amazing. If your are a art and cultural lover is a must to pay a visit to this temple.simply beautiful sculpture.p/s if you don't bring a guide along with get yourself a guide book or you will miss a lot of history, architecture and the cultural.

Beautiful historic site. Among the temples at Angkor thom I would rate the bayon temple as one of the best. The exterior is bit dilapidated but the main attraction are the 54 towers representing 54 provinces of the Cambodian Kingdom with Buddha faces carved on all 4 sides of each. A must visit site

Bayon Temple. This temple is huge! It was an amazing walk.... many photo oppurtunities not to be missed out. Be creative and you could look like the gods! I suggest you wear comfortable shoes... i wore a light long sleeve top and 3/4 leggings to meet the required dress code. A highly recomended temple to go visit after the Angkor Wat....
4 faces Buddha . One of the temple I visited during my Angkor trip. This temple is slightly different from the rest because it cherish 4 faces Buddha. The temple is big and quite well maintained too.
Another amazing site. Although not as large as Angkor Wat this temple was just as fascinating. The workmanship for its time is unbelievable.
Tempke. Great and amazing temple as world heritage. It is good to to see in first hand to get Cambodia life style experience. People and Tuk Tuk driver are friendly people.

Oh the faces...so impressive. . This temple is just inside the Angkor Thom complex and is simply amazing. While many may overlook this temple's appeal. This temple has endless corridors to explore and some of the stories etched into the various temple walls are amazing. Of all the temples visited, this was my favorite. Words cannot describe this place so all I can say is, visit it!

Temples . 12 km of wonder .amazing sites it takes 2 hour to complete .go to small temple as well its worth seeing .request your driver for it because most of them dont like going there but it is the best. Specially the one near the fligh of the Gibbons which is a must do. Well enjoy cause I did.
A sense of history. The Bayon is supposedly the resident city of the king and other upper class residents. It is not as high compared to Angkor Wat, since Angkor Wat is actually a temple.
Nice Temple. This is another unique temple at Siem Reap. Very distinct and having amazing art to view. Must visit.
I give this place the 3rd beautiful temple of Angkor Wat!!. This place is full of Bayon smiles. You'll see the beautiful ancient architecture with a long history.

Visit to Bayon Temple. A great place to visit.
My husband always wanted to ride on an elephant and it's one of the attractions at this temple. One of the must see attractions in Siem Reap. The eating stalls close to the temple also serve excellent Kmer food, like Fish Amok, Pineapple Fried Rice and Stir fried Morning Glory.

An Architectural marvel!!. though small, it has much more details in architecture and the Angkor wat. try to visit early in the morning as it can get very crowded after 9 (so crowded that you cannot walk without bumping into other tourists).

Same same but amazing none the less. All these temples offer something different if you look hard enough.. Understand the history of them and you understand the little differences better. Well worth the visit.. Cooler months would be better and if you do go in Sep get a car not a tuk tuk.. Aircon was NEEDED each day.
do not miss this one!. A worthwhile visit, but use a guide as they share information that makes each temple worth visiting!

Mysterious and impressive. Bayon temple is very very in usual. It's the one with the faces on the pillars. It's also huge. You can walk around it and view the faces and sections of the large building from lots of different angles and passageways. I think it's my favourite part of the Angkor site, just because it's like something from a film and those faces give a mysterious and slightly spooky air to the temple.

Awesome place. A lot of temples in Siem Reap and Bayon is one of my favorites. A must visit if you're in Angkor. They are great and should not be missed. The detail on the faces carved into the stones is unbelievable.
Ancient history visited. Good to visit before Angkor Wat as it gives you a foretaste. Ancient lives and ancient achievements always worth checking out.

Wow, this temple is a must see!. The iconic faces of Bayon are more beautiful than you can ever imagine. This temple is a must see! It is possible to see Bayon, Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom and Ta Prohm comfortably in one day. Bring a hat or an umbrella though as it is very very hot in the sun!
perhaps the most interesting and educational of the Angkor lot. perhaps the most interesting and the most educational temple in the Angkor lot, not as crowded, also

The Jewel of Angkor Thom. Bayon is the major temple in the area know as Angkor Thom, and it is absolutely stunning. It is here that one fins the towers with the enigmatic faces of the king as the deity Lokesvara. There is something amazing around every corner, so plan to spen a couple of hours here!

Unreal . Go early, as it gets crowded and there are some small corridors. Absolutely brilliant temple. So unique, with so much history. I recommend hiring a guide for the day to get the full experience.
stunning. we went there at the end of our day tour. Bayon looked stunning in dawn light. Lesser people and golden yellow light gave us an opportunity to click some wonderful pics.

Fabulous. This was one of my favourite temples, although one of the busiest that we toured. The condition of the temple is excellent with many opportunities for photos - to capture the multiple smiling faces. At this temple, there happened to be a small troop of monkeys that were extremely friendly. Our guide encouraged us to interact with the monkeys, and it was the most fun. At one time I had 4 juvinille monkeys on my back. It was the BEST!
2nd fav temple. It drizzled when we got here which was good as it took the heat away. Easily done in 30mins. I wore slippers which was a big mistake
Worth a visit. Go early (the park opens at 5). Very busy with tourists and by mid morning the temperature has risen. Beautiful temple with amazing history

Romantic air of mystery. It is sights like this temple that make one fall in love with Cambodia. The tumbledown nature of the temple adds to the allure. Take water, it's exhausting and thirsty work exploring.

Beautful and famed temple. Most peoples obvious reason for travel to Siem Reap is Angor Watt, and other temples. The temples are magnificent, only letdown are the sheer amount of tourists visiting, making it rather crowdy. However worth a visit, and should be on every "before I die" to do list.

Under restoration, loses a bit of charm. Another excellent temple, but with all the restoration, it loses a bit of the charm... again too many tourists spoil the temple. Be prepared to get sunburnt, not much cover since most of the roof fell in.

Beautiful statues. Again, something what you just can't describe! You need to see also this place with you own eyes. One thing when you go to see these temples: if possible, try to go to see these in one day. You will have time to go to four/five most important temples, it's more cheaper and believe me, if you split these for two or three days, it will be more difficult than to go through in one day.
amazing place to visit. The scale of the temples is an amazing site. Our guide knew all the best places for photos and helped capture memories that will last a lifetime
Interesting Piles of Stones. Can be circled in 5 or 10 minutes. Notice stones piled up. i wonder what it means. And there are good wall reliefs.

Banyan Temple. This temple was built in the 13th Century and as with the other temples in the area it is a photographer's dream. There is so much history and the architecture is beautiful. Throughout the temple are some 216 gigantic Buddhist face sculptures attached to the many towers on the grounds.

Early morning, no crowds. Our guide took us here early in the morning, so we could wander around before the tours buses arrived in almost isolation.
Weird place, with all the faces looking at you - all different with that enigmatic smile. However, so peaceful early in the morning... worth getting up for!
G R E A T !. An amazing Temple! Many adjacent temples. Tip .. Visit Bayon first, then exit to Phmeanakas Temple, then on to the Elephant Terrace & continue to the Leper King Temple.
Don't miss. go early, avoid crowds; We traveled in November, the beginning of the "in-season". toward the end of the month is the water festival. Huge crowds. take lots of water.

My favorite of the Angkor temples. 216 enigmatic faces smiling serenely into eternity - absolutely nothing like it anywhere else. Late afternoon is a great time to visit - fewer crowds, softer light for photography

So many faces!. Bayon is amazing in it's skill and the size of the temple It was disappointing to see so many areas incomplete as changing religions or political spectrum left lots of the temple unfinished.

Many questions..Fantastic experience. Visiting these wonderful monuments causes one to reflect on the life of those who built, lived and nourished the culture that existed here.
Could have spent hours marveling at the skills used to erect such a structure.

Sunset smiles. We went to the Bayon around sunset (one hour and a half before closing time) and it was incredible. Most visitors of Angor Wat go to certain sunset points and the Bayon isn't one of them. The place was deserted, which added to the mystery. The lowering sun on all those faces was magical!
My favourite temple. This is my favourite of the temples I visited. Gorgeous stone work. Nothing else like it anywhere I've been 😊

Smiley faces . Angkor Wat is beautiful and big but Bayon Temple in its way being smaller is a real eye catcher with all its different and smiley carved faces. My favorite, but that s my honest opinion. If you have time you can do an elephant tour from SouthGate to Bayon .There are also 3 Bouddha temples around Bayon. Very nice and tranquille moment. Continue to Baphuon temple and Terrace of Elephants and visit small water pounds in between temples.

The most awesome temple we saw on the site. This temple is definitely worth visiting. Way more impressive than Angkor Wat if you ask me. The faces that are on the towers are awesome and it's a perfect place to take awesome pictures!

Must see. A lot of temples in Siem Reap and Bayon is one of my favorites. Best to see early morning when the sun is hardly out yet. Amazing temple and glad to see that they are renovating and maintaining the temple.

This complex is huge an awesome. What an exciting temple to visit. Massive piece of architecture. Beautiful carvings, lots of rooms and archways. The carved faces are everywhere. Spent a lot of time with my camera there. It was crowded but it did t matter as there is so much to see and do there. Well worth the visit .
The best bit of Angkor Thom. A quite remarkable temple with amazing buddha head profiles; because Angkor Thom is a much bigger site than Angkor Wat it absorb people well and doesn't feel crowded

A beatiful 54 towers temple. Amazing temple with 54 towers of Buda heads facing all 4 cardinal points, stairs to climb, some fascinating corners for that great photo. It does not matter if you do not have that expensive camera and lenses, your cell phone will be enough for that special photo to take home. It is always sunny so be sure to take sunblock and enough head coverage, also carry water with you because once inside there is nothing else. Be sure not to miss this temple. It is included in the " short tour" that most tour companies. offer
Amazing again. Like Ankor Wat, this has to be seen and you can only admire the achievements to build such a structure.
Wow. Wow! Has to be seen to be believed. An Amazing place even when packed with tourists. The massive faces staring out at every turn.
Amazing place!. It´s an unforgetable experience to be stand-up at the Bayon temple terrace and look at all the beautiful faces. It´s a must go place in Siem Reap.

Beautiful Temple that is Mostly Restored. A little bit of renovation was ongoing during my visit, but it did not detract from the temple. I took an elephant ride around the Bayon, but I don't recommend it for $30 US. It did provide a different view of the temple, but most of the temple should experienced from within. After a rain shower, most people left, and the temple was much less crowded. Well worth a visit and doable with Angkor Wat in the same day if you are pressed for time.
GOOD to SEE. i thing it is the biggest temple in Anghor thom . Nice architecture ,only it was overcrowded with tourist . We spend almost 1:30-2 hours to see the temple
One of several great sites. While not Angkor Wat this is worth the effort. I'd recommend 2 days for hitting all the major Wats. Hydrate!
Astounding. Not to be missed! . This was super cool. 54 towers of Buddha heads, each with different expression. I could spend hours here. Just fascinating and beautiful.
Thrilling. No visit would be complete without visiting all the temples of Angkor Watt, best to travel early morning or late afternoon.
Cool Faces....but no Angkor Wat. Well worth the visit given the impressive faces. Be careful as non-approved tour guides will try to give you an informal tour without your asking.

Mesmerising. This is a temple like no other that I have seen and I come from the land of temples India !! We were awestruck at the first sight of the carved rock faces. There were so many of these smiling faces popping up all over the place. Try out some fun pictures where at certain angles , you can get yourself clicked with your nose tip touching that of the rock face. A cheesy thing but trust me the, the pictures will make you smile later :) Ask any of the friendly guards to do this for you - they know exactly what to do !!The heat is over bearing even at 4 pm. So dress comfortably in loose cottons. Avoid denims at all cost !!
cool. if you like this kind of thing - its pretty amazing how they built this and it lay hidden for so long

Smiley Faces. As you take a photo of the temple, you'll find smiley faces looking at you. It's quite rare to see temples with this type of design. This is usually a quick stop for me, but nevertheless a must visit. As always, I would recommend you to go through the side pathways to avoid the crowd and really get the feel for the temple and imagine yourself in the decades long long ago. It's like a maze. In fact, it is easy to get lost as the four sides of this temple look pretty much alike. So better get your bearings before you head inside, otherwise, just head out and go around the temple from the outside.There is also a wall of drawings just before you head indoors and there's a long long story to tell. If you're interested, make sure you get a guide. In fact, when I first visited this place, the guide told us that their version is already a very short summary. In reality, It takes 10 days to tell the whole story! ;-)
one of Khmer heritage temple. beautiful place , where we can see Khmer heritage temple during 14th century. the river around this are make this place make this place mystically beautiful

Simply the Great, Great and Great.. What a imagination and Sculptural miracle. The Big Heads at the shikharas with very simplicity and high aesthetic value... Amazed...The expressions the Khmer artisans carved on the group of big rock blocks is marvelous. Really unique artwork among the temples so far i have travelled. I visited this monument in Oct. 2015 but i suggest you to visit in winter and dry season so that you can have good sunlight and relatively less humid and good climate.

wow. tourists should not be allowed to climb up or walk inside the temple. it is deteriorating and is hazardous to both - tourists and the temple conservation efforts. despite of the no entry signs, tourists find ways to climb up and get into the no-entry zone and click pictures. if this continues, the temple is not going to last for a decade or so or if a natural disaster strikes during visiting times, human casualty will be inevitable!
My favourite Temple. I always thought angkor wat was one temple. How wrong was I. And bayon, is my favourite. Just a wonderful feeling. You must visit if you are here.

Another Amazing place in Siem Reap. This is another amazing place in Siem Reap. This place looks small compared to Angkor Wat but once you step in,this is a treasure trove. The place has amazing details. It rained the time I got there and after that I had some stunning details.

Uncountable Buddha's faces. This is totally different from the Angkor Wat as Bayon is about Buddishm while Angkor Wat is about Hindusm. The faces are uncountable. The views are magnificent. However one of the sections are under restoration.Please beware of locals within the Bayon as they will try to guide you for taking photo. After that will show you a piece of paper and said that his school needs some donations. One of them even said that he is an English teacher in the school known as "Save our Associations". When we got tricked and wrote our donation amount below his expectation, he tried to press us with higher amount. We also found out that most of the donations amount were at least 20 usd. He just ran away after he get the donation. Shortly after this, we saw that some of his members were chased away. But I failed to locate him. This wasn't the fault of local police officers because there are many doors and entrances in the temple as they can hide easily. This also happens in other temples and please beware.
fantastic. As with Angkor Wat , this is very close and easily done on the same day. This whole area is a must if you have a loving foe ancient buidings
Face in the temple. Really cool temple with faces and many carvings on the wall. In the morning at 6 there was almost no other people.

Spectacular Carvings. This temple is smaller that Ankgor Wat but, in my view, better. The face carvings are spectacular. Well worth a visit. Check that your camera is fully charged as there are numerous great photo opportunities.

2nd Best Things to Do in Siem Reap. Right after Angkor Wat, this is the temple you must visit in Siem Reap. I am not inclined into Buddhist history so I could only appreciate it at a superficial level. But the photography opportunities it provides makes it a must visit for everyone.Pro-tip: Go right before lunch time as it's not really that crowded at that time.

Better than Angkor Wat. I said it. Yes this was the most impressive temple i visited. And i visited this after Angkor Wat. The detail was immense and it was a pure surprize to see a temple like this. During my visit it was under restoration too which was a pleasant sight to see :)
Interesting Temple. Many many faces. Quite interesting. Remember to take a "nose to nose" shot with some of the faces. Only a few of the faces can give you a good effect.
A splendid site.. The building is possibly not quite as highly crafted as others in the whole complex but it's towers with Buddha's facing in the 4 directions are a must see. So much to photograph.
Aesthetically pleasing!. Really easy on the eye. Not too far from the others. Take a tuktuk for the day, it's not particularly big but impressive both outside and in!

A must visit. Located close to Ankor Wat this stunning temple follows on brilliantly from the stunning Ankor Wat. Here you will find superb carvings around the temple and elephants walking around the outside of the temple. Take your time and soak it up.

Steeped in Khmer history and mythology.. You really must have a guide to take you through the ruins so you can truly understand the history behind the carvings. Otherwise you're just looking blankly at another monument.

Beautiful Bayon. Bayon is a very large temple and is said to be most people's favourite. We visited this temple whilst on a three day visit to Siem Reap. We were expertly guided by Sim Sophath and driven there by our tour guide/driver John Sochheat.The temple has stairs leading to an upper level, and depicts columns featuring a face on each side. There are many many columns and each face has a different expression which makes this temple very interesting. Sim explained that the higher the column and the faces, the more likely they would be to have been defaced in previous wars because the higher you are, the more important you are. This was very evident as we walked around.We enjoyed visiting Bayon very much and would certainly advise people visiting the temples to add it to their list. They would not be disappointed.Lyn and David, Brisbane, Australia.

You're being watched ;). We visited Bayon Temple on our 2nd day of our Angkor tour. The detailing of the carvings and architecture was so beautiful. Everywhere you look, there's a face starring at you. It was really fascinating at the engineering behind it and how well preserved it is.

Second Stop!. Start here before proceeding to Baphuon, Terrace of the Elephants, Phimeanakas, Royal Palace, Terrace of the Leper King and the rest of the Angkor Thom. After you visited the inside of Bayon, come out through one of the exit to have a 360 degree walk around the external of Bayon. You would have a nicer view with lesser tourists! Again, where good hiking boots!

Beautiful architecture, Incredible history. Like the other temples in the region, this is a truly remarkable site. How these temples were constructed in the first place is mind-blowing, but the fact that they still stand, some 1000+ years later...wow. Just, WOW. As with all the other temples, be sure to have your pass on you, otherwise you'll be turned away. With regard to rain, I wouldn't sweat it too much. The rain we experienced lasted a short period of time - and was actually quite refreshing! If you are someone who can't handle getting a little wet, bring a light rain jacket in your pack - just to be safe. Chances are you'll just schlepp it around the whole time, but if it makes you feel better, so be it.

My Favorite Temple. Bayon in shoulder or off season is terrific. Less crowds than Angkor Wat or near by Ta Prohm, but still massive. So much to explore, so much to see, so much to photograph. Oddly enough the food in the back of Angkor Thom is surprisingly the same price or lower than in Siem Reap as is the shopping. However the pay to pee bathrooms are pretty rancid-- so come ready to practice your hover skills.
Best preserved that we saw. As with all of the temples, Bayon is spectacular, but the detailing of the wall carvings is unequaled. Well worth a visit.
Interesting landscape. Temple tours a must. the history and structure great for photo taking. Apply sunblock for all temple visit

Not quite a tomb raider. Again, a must see on your tour to the Angkor. Fantastic architecture, magnificent scenery and you can see how nature is reclaiming the site. Plenty to see - take your time and enjoy and soak up the site er sights....
Bayon in Angkor Thom.. Fantastic and jaw-dropping archeological site. A must together with the other temples in the Angkor Thom complex. Beautiful and Inspirational...

Wonderful...if you're a traveler this has to go on your bucket list.. All the temples are incredible and being this whole area gives you such a feeling of such a different time.. this one should not be missed and you can climb all around it. It really makes you wonder how all these incredible temples were built then. Make sure you buy the 3 Day pass for the temples for $40.00 and we had our hotel arranged our driver and guide who were excellent..

Great Place. I loved visiting the complex, it was immense but it was a bit hot although I went in November. There's a lot of walking involved but the site is worth seeing most definitely. Also, beware of going too late in the afternoon as it rained cats and dogs all of a sudden and we were struck in the temple for 30 minutes before the rain calmed down.
Love The Faces!. The carvings are really something to see in this temple. A lot of Khmer history. All those faces are incredible.

Puts a smile on your Face :). This is inside the terrace of Elephants, and has a long elevated walkway towards the temple itself. It's smaller compared to the other temples, but what sets it apart is that there are smiling ?Buddha's? faces on the top of pagodas looking at all directions. It is also one of the few temples that has a renovated stairs so you can go all the way to the top to see up close those faces. Very, Very beautiful.
Stunning architecture. bayon popularly known as 1000 face temple is as the name itself says is a stunning work and example of khmer architecture.

Wonderful isn't enough to describe it. I'd say the best sightseeing in the temple area. To be fair, we didn't spend as much time in the other temples (which are also stunning), but Bayon simple deserve to be experienced. Take your time to go through the three levels, it will take roughly one hour, and you won't regret it. If I visited this place when I was 10 years old, I'd have probably cried to stay the whole day.
