Mesmerizing Site and History. Being there in the areas of Bayon Temple and all the temples within Angkor Wat compound really brings a totally different feeling as if you are in a different era or world altogether. The serenity of the place at times makes you wonder how they were built then.
another amazing temple in Siem Reap. temples are just temples -- wrong -- this one is beautiful and another one not to miss in Siem Reap -- everyone needs to see this

Bayon . Another great photo opportunity. These temples are truly spectacular and a definite for those who visit siem reap
Price for a day at the temples is $20 however it would be hard to visit a lot of temples in one day so I suggest you purchase a three day ticket which can be used over a7 day period $40 each
Rivaling Angkor Wat. This country is just fill of wonders. While lacking the scale of Angkor Wat (or the maintenance) this place is almost as impressive and well worth a visit.

It is amazing when you think about it. Close to the other attractions and well worth the visit
You can climb all over it and there is a budha face t every turn

Must see.. Really enjoyed the architecture at Bayon, especially the prominent faces. As with all the temples around the Angkor complex it can be difficult to move around in the crowds. Best times to go are early mornings and brave the heat during lunch and early afternoons.
One of the many temples visited. We saw so many interesting temples in all different stages of repair. Some had been left to show how they were discovered.

Stunning. The best of all the angkor wat temples. Just awesome. Cannot miss this one.
Try to go early or at times other than the crowds. Or low season
Broken ruins remain. Not as majestic as Angkor Wat or Thom but nevertheless very beautiful. Do visit if you like taking pictures. The temple ruins are truly splendid at dusk.
A marvelous sight. The iconic face-towers of the Bayon temple will definitely leave you speechless! Be prepared to climb some mean steps, but it's well worth the effort.
hidden history. This trip was life changing. The temples are so amazing and old! The story of discovery and the history here is just mind boggling.

Architecture marvel.. Intrigue with architecture complexity of this temple. Our guide was excellent where he took certain area of to avoid th big crowds There were many vendors ascending upon you selling their tourist scares, embossed paintings and other wares,
Absolute must in Angkor complex. Absolute must, preferably at dawn or sunset, with magnificent bas reliefs, numerous smiling Buddhas and great views from the top.
Awesome site. This is one of my favorite sites to visit in Angkor Wat, there is so much to take in, plan to visit it early in the morning to avoid the crowd and the heat.

Another must see in Siem Reap. After touring Angkor Wat, we came to the Bayon Temple. It is distinctive in its contract to Angkor Wat as it was constructed as a Buddhist Temple, almost a century after Angkor Wat. The towers abound with the four faces of Buddha throughout the complex. We had a wonderful guide who showed me all of the best locations to take photos. Having a local guide definitely enhances the visit.

Part of of tour to Angkor Wat. It is usual to visit all of these complexes in one trip but be prepared to do lots of walking and climbing to properly explore the site and have amazing views. Try to pick a good time to avoid the crowds

Must see places before you die.. Bayon temple is so beautiful and just a magnificent place to see, from its construction to the beautiful art designs all over the temple. I wish I could've of seen it in its time and era.

History to remember. Visited this place on July 2011. Magnificent architecture. Every corner of the temple tells a story. An attraction not to miss when visiting Siem Reap. But need to bring bottled water to quench the thirst as it was so hot in this place. We came to this place with a tour guide so gained knowledge on the history of this temple.

Must see!. A must visit if you're in Angkor. What makes this location different from the others in the area is the statues of the faces. They are great and should not be missed. First we visited when the rain was pouring and after being in the area for around 6 hours. Weren't that impressed then. Then went back the next day when the sun was shining. It was gorgeous. I'd suggest visiting early in the morning as light conditions are best at that time for taking pictures. Also in the morning hours, most people would likely tend to be at main Angkor Wat area. Enjoy!

Beautiful carvings. This is one of the popular temples in Siem Reap as shown by the large crowds of tourists that it attracted during our visitBayon temple was the first temple we visited and it sure set the bar for all the other temples. It was simply beautiful with its face carvings and the bas reliefs. A must see. Pictures do not do it justice. Suggest to get a tour guide to explain to you the carvings and bas relief. We had a blast hearing about the guide's explanations about the carvings.
Love Bayon Temple. I was a very beautiful temple! It's big, rocky, high and very complex architecture built by the Khmer empire. Imagine how beautiful it was in the early year of building!

Excellent illustration of the Buddhist era. I was told that each of the towers represented the provinces of that time and based on how well those provinces were advanced they got 2-4 faces on their representative towers. Originally supposed to be 170+ faces but not only about 130+ faces are still visible. You will see that each of the faces has distinct features and there is only one where the smile is very perceptible. Must see. Loved it.

The smaller Cousin of Ankor Wat. This temple is a surprise part of the tour. The details of the Temple is simply mind blowing. It's a kings tribute to his empire that was dedicated to the gods. Each four faced pagoda represents each province in the empire. 53 in total. You have to be there to understand and feel the expanse of this ancient historical site.
Great Thing. This is the most stunning place in Siam Riep for me. It is like nowhere else in the world. It looks scary at first but then I enjoyed walking from place to place.
Amazing . Make sure not to miss this temple. Beautiful. Had a private guide that explained everything to me, totally recommend it.

Extraordinary. A lot has been made of Angkor Wat and rightly so, but to me, the Bayon really embodies the alien, mystical sensation of the complex. The smiling faces that you see at every turn can give you the willies after awhile, but lends the place a certain uniqueness, even for someone from Asia like myself. A must see if you happen to be in Siem Reap.
Love it. Everything in this place is magnificent. It's a must on your bucket list. Bring cold water and towel. Lots of walking
Not bad. Not a bad temple as part of the entire range of temples around Siem Reap - the carved faces are interesting
Great architecture of Khmer people. Beautiful work of art. Temple has a very fascinating story and structure. Enjoyed every single corner of this temple

Stunning and mesmerizing!. Of all the many temples in Angkor, I enjoyed this one the most. I went back a couple of times and once found it almost empty of visitors. Hard to describe, but seeing the carved faces all around you is something unique and special.
Awsome. Hired a tuk tuk for the day, toured many of the temples and must say the temples were quite something. Even got up at 4 to see sunrise-well worth it .
Amazing part of History. Like all the Temples spend the extra money and grab a guide the history they can inform you of is makes visiting these monuments all the more special
Spooky but beautiful. I visited this site first thing in the morning and had it virtually to myself which is to be recommended.

Beautiful architecture and carvings. The carvings on the sides of the temple depict the daily lives of the Cambodians from fishing, boating, hunting and are a wonder to watch. Bayon is not as big as Angkor Wat but the stone heads at the top of the temples are beautiful to see. However this is also a favorite to many tourists so it can get crowded at the top. We took the elephant ride from the South Gate to Bayon which was fun but there is also another elephant ride around Bayon temple. An elephant ride costs 20 dollars.
Fantastic . Amazing piece of architecture, pure precision and skill went into carving the hundreds of faces into the temple. While smaller than Angkor it is still worth a visit

My favourite. I have found this the most magical place. The temple features over 200 massive stone faces that look in all directions, and are thought to be portraits of King Jayavarman himself or a combination of the king and Buddha.

So many nooks. This temple would have been my favorite if I had visited at sunrise while the crowds were occupied elsewhere. Unfortunately my friends and I showed up when half of Cambodia's population was in Bayon (or so it felt). But even with people everywhere, we could still find nooks and crannies where we were all alone (for a moment). This temple is well worth exploration time, and if you can find a time when other people aren't around, then it is perfection!

Amazing place. Wonderful to take your time & look around. A little different from some of the others & a bonus if you can be there at a time when the bus tours arnt there! Loved wandering around such an ancient place.
Great structures. This is a must see attraction on your visit to Angkor Wat. The detail on the faces carved into the stones is unbelievable.
a surprising temple. This temple is a little less known than Angkor Wat but is one of the "Must see" temple when you are visiting this area. The giant face sculptures are just astonishing.
Bucket List Place to visit. Much easier walking compared to Angkor Wat but can get slippery in the rain. It better to hire a car as its a bit far on the tuk tuk.

AMAZING!. This was just stunning. The architecture and details found here were stunning. All the columns had 4 faces of the buddha and the expressions were varied. Recommend to visit on the same day you are doing Angkor Wat. ANCIENT & STUNNING!

Beautiful Bayon. Of the 6 temples we visited, this was my favourite-- the Buddah heads are so peaceful and there is such a sense of serenity at Bayon. We went with a private guide and would highly recommend this option-- we learned so much and our guide made the trip for us plus they show you where to take all the best photos.

Around the corner from Angkor Wat. Even for someone like me who isn´t actually too much into history, architecture, temples ("Have you seen one you have seen them all"-attitude), I really enjoyed spending 30-45 minutes at Bayon.I think 2 hours are enough if you just want to get a feel for the place and "soak up the atmosphere".Well worth a visit especially since it is just around the corner from Angkor Wat.
Best temple. This was my favourite of all the temples we visited. Was not too busy and we were able to really get in and look at all the areas.
Amazing sunset. This one must be visit on a sunset. The images got golden with the sun. Looks like you are in a spaceship ready to take off. Amazing.
Just simply incredible. The most amazing thing is to see all the carved in stone murals of daily Khmer life in the 9-10th century AD

The Bayon - temple with carved faces!. I visited this temple just after Ta Prohm and it was nice to see a much bigger temple. Some of the best photos I took of this temple were just outside by the water, where I could get a photo of the temple with its reflection.The temple has a lot of intricate and detailed carvings, and the carvings of the faces are huge! There are again plenty of photo opportunities at this temple.Everyone in the Siem Reap area should see this temple.

Nice Temple ruin. As each temple is different in Angkor each has its own character and each one is worth to visit. Bayon is a large and impressive structure - great wall carvings show the normal life if kmer people - from cooking to market scenes, hunting and war.
Don't get lost. It's like a little maze and when you try to exit all the exits look the same. We couldn't find our group but that's half the fun of it! Amazing place

A Man-Made Wonder of the World.. No words will be able to justify the experience of enjoying the Past History of the Khmer Kingdom.
All I can say is that it's Enchanting.
Photo Op place. Lovely place with the blue skies and smiles. Its a place where every angle you turn is a lovely shoot. Slightly crowded place though. Very hard to find a slot with not much crowd.

Worth the visit. This is about 45-60 minutes outside of Siam Reap. It is worth the visit and it is much smaller and can be explored easily. Passing through the country side made it even more interesting. We saw water buffalo and the local life.

Awesome carvings and scrulptures!. Of all the temples I visited in Cambodia, I like Bayon next to Bantey Srei. Bayon temple has great carvings and well-defined sculptures to this date. You would really be amazed how all these were preserved up to this time. Cambodia can be a little too hot from lunch until early afternoon so if you want to explore the place longer do it early in the day or late afternoon.

Faces faces everywhere. Such intricate and detailed carvings of smiling faces. Its enough to bring a smile to your face especially when you are weary from temple visiting. There's also a good spot of a nose to nose photo with a statue.
Great Temple. Really interesting local Temple, built by the greatest leader in Angkor history. Was getting crowded when we visited, which impaired our enjoyment. Pick your spots to avoid the crowds.
Come see the smiles. The smiling statues are amazing....and there weren't too many tourists trooping thru the ruins. A beautiful place, don't miss it
Magnificent !!. Magnificent !! Imagine how human could build such beautiful building. A must visit places even you are not temples crazy people :)

Unreal!. Words can't begin to describe, and none of my photos will do it justice. This is one of those things that needs to be seen with your own eyes. We did a Grasshopper pushbike tour and thoroughly enjoyed it as it covered a few different temples and riding the wall of one temple. If you get a good guide they'll explain the history of the temples which is amazing to hear - especially for an Aussie when we come from such a comparatively young country.

Nice historical site and well preserve . Unlike Angkor Wat that overly crowded with both tourists and hawkers, Bayon at Angkor Thom is well organized and beautiful in wall carving from Stone. It is one of the best show case of Khmer Empire
Go up and take a pic kissing one of the smiling faces!. After a few temples everything looks the same but this temple is unique by a hundred of smiling faces that greets you as soon as you enter.
As beautiful as Angkor Wat. It is my second favourite temple in Angkor complex. The faces from stones are marvelous. In the early morning it wasn't very crowdy.

A favourite. Bayon is a favourite. Having visited three times and still can't get enough. The feel of it, the sight of all those faces and the giant smiles make you wish you could stay. Spiritual, peaceful bliss. Not as many tourists make this a more peaceful vist

Prettier than Angkor Wat!. This is my favorite temple of all of them. They are all breathtaking and stunning but this one was prettier in detail. There was so much to take in I had to put the camera down and just stand there in awe. The carved Buddha heads and the dark color was beautiful. The entrance is spectacular, and lined with huge statues still standing. Please don't skip this one. Most of the photos I've liked the most from the day were from Bayon Temple.

bayon temple. This is beautiful temple well worth a visit.Temple of faces some wonderful photos of the carvings again we had a guide to tell us the history .the faces were featured on a BBC documentary.Take plenty of water!

Unbelievable beauty!. The temple is relatively small compared to Angkor Wat, but its certainly worth a visit. The level of detail of the carvings in the stone walls and on the pillars are truly impressive. It truly makes us more amazed of the fact that the temples were built 100s of years ago. Be sure to explore the surrounding temples and take a lot of pictures.
Nose to Nose. This is my favorite temple. Got alot of photos and had my nose to nose photo. You should not miss the place.

Bayon temples: marvelous. Personally I think this is THE best temple in Siem Reap. Make sure you spend some time here and discover hidden details in the temple. P.s just in case someone is wondering: YES - sleeveless shirts and shorts are allowed in the temples and necessary in the summer months!!!

Impressive. I went to the Bayon temple with my father in law who is an architect which only made the visit more special. This was also my 4 year old sons favorite temple. CLimbing around and looking at the faces in the stones around the temple. It felt like an adventure for him. We also rode an elephant around there and do that early as the elephants go nap around 10AM.
More temples. One of the multiple temples in the Angkor Thom complex, this one is well worth a poke around and explore.

Faces Faces Everywhere. A wonderful Temple where you feel never alone (a.) du to the tourists and b.) due to the many faces watching you)
Amazing works of art just built up all around you.
Wonderful!
Wonderful temple. All temples we been almost two days Bayon is the temple liked than other temples. I lover the faces on the temple and great temple for pictures.

My favourite - the centre of Angkor Thom. After visiting the museum the previous day I was keen to see the huge and serene carved faces of the Buddahs, and this is the place to see them.... Right at the centre of Angkor Thom and for me the best of Siem ReapWe purchased our ticket ($20 for one day) at 5pm the previous day and used it to go for a sunset visit (to Angkor Wat) and saved the early morning queue before a full day of 'templing'
The hotel staff were great. Centrally located a very comfortable hotel with excellent staff the car and driver made available by hotel was extremilly helpfull
Impressive . This is one of my favorite temple in Cambodia It's just so impressive how they created this Make sure to take a guide when exploring the temples
Many faces. Great to see how this has been restored and you can once again see the faces. much of the rest is in ruins.

Wonderous!. The smiling Buddha faces are slightly creepy! One of the most famous Temples of Angkor Wat, it tends tends to get very crowded. Makes one wonder about the amazing skills of the artists and architects of ancient times

Excellent temple with beautiful faces. Definitely visit this temple. The faces are highly memorable, and the story behind the temple is also interesting. It's not large, but it's also excellent for photos.

The very best of Siem Reap!. To me ..this was the best one...better than Angkor Wat. Be sure to wear a hat and take cold water and comfy shoes. There is a lot of climbing of stairs but its all doable and def worth it. You cannot possibly take a bad photo here.

Astounding!. The scale of this temple is incredible. It's truly a joy to explore and ponder those giant stone faces. You really feel like Indiana Jones :) Avoid peak times to enjoy a less crowded adventure. A must see!
Everything you expected and more. Stunning status and architecture. How did those people so many years ago carry those heavy materials to Bayon.
The Buddah Headed temple. Very nice temple. Here you will see many Buddha heads with smiling faces. We were very entertained at this temple and were so happy we visited.

Like something out of an Indiana Jones movie...and a heart breaker.. This was the first temple we visited at the Angkor park. It's amazing! Massive stone structures, just beaming with ancient history and wonder! Monkeys are all over the place too... as long as you don't feed them, you're fine. What was not 'fine' about our first experience with our first temple at Angkor was walking right into one of the first scams we learned first hand. ***Beware of good english speaking 'locals' that approach you and ask "Hello, where are you from?" This is the opening line to a blind sided scam. They tell you they are volunteering for their school, walk you around, tell you about the place, maybe take a pic for you (like this guy did for us) and then about 15 min later, they ask you for a 'donation' to their school. They even show you a piece of paper, with people's name on it and the dollar amount they donate - all in the same handwriting, all the same amount. This was when we just looked at each other in disbelief that this guy had been dragging us along, thinking that he was really doing good, being generous and kind hearted...nope. Just trying to scam you out of $5, 10 or 20 dollars. You think it goes to a school? Nope! When we told him we didn't have any money to donate, he started getting really forceful with saying "Any thing, I'll take a dollar. How about Baht? I'll take Baht." That's when we were like "You'll take Baht? You mean your school right? You're volunteering right?" He didn't like us trying to tell him how to run his little scam operation. All through out Angkor we encountered this...I'm kind of surprised I'm not reading more reviews about this...as they are literally everywhere! I would say if you are strong willed, can just turn a blind eye and deaf ear to it all, it's still worth going to enjoy the wonder of the temples.

My Style!. My most loved sanctuary - it is an astounding structure and the grinning buddhas are simply delightful. The sanctuary is under some modifying in the blink of an eye yet this does not influence the excellence and magnificence of the sanctuary. Visit with a manual for get the best comprehension of the development and iconography.
Go face to face. It seemed smaller than some of the other temples but enough wonderful photo opportunities to sink a battleship. Amazing cross religion temple

Faces for the ages. Ancient building are impressive, but the human face takes you back in time like nothing else. Serenity, beauty, optimism are all conveyed in this temple. It also shows that happiness transcends time, position, and power. Good spot for recharging your resources.
a must see. Like all say, fit this one in. The temple is amazing. So much feeling and character and lots to look around. Personally found this more impressive than angkor wat.
Recommended. One of the best temples best visited during morning hours.Tip:Afternoons can be hot and humid carry water and umbrella....
splendid at sunset. different from Angkor Wat, definitely worth seeing especially in the afternoon or just before sunset when the light adds to its beauty

The coolest of all the temples!. This temple was my favorite of all the ones you get access to with the angkor pass. It is slightly less crowded an unique among all the rest with the faces and other drawings carved into every inch of the wall.
THE BEST one. It was my favorite off all temples.. really less croweded and with an atmosphere totally amazing! LOVE IT! Go there!

Part of the Angkor complex. Visit during your Angkor tour.mit is just s impressive.
Allow about 2 hours to see this attraction
This is an easier climb than Angkor

Temple with the FACES. Another stunning temple, completely different to Angkor Wat.
These ruins feature The huge Faces carved on 4 sides and lead to places like the elephant terrace and leper terrace.

You may think you are being looked at.... Faces surround you on a visit here. It's reckoned there are over 40 towers still standing and they each tend to have at least two faces carved at them, smiling at you, Mona Lisa like. We did venture inside, but as it was late afternoon and was quite dark. The murals carved on the outside are detailed and are worth studying. We stayed for the sunset, but it was a cloudy day and mad little difference.

Breathtaking - my favourite!. My favourite temple - it is an amazing structure and the smiling buddhas are just beautiful. The temple is under some rebuilding presently but this does not affect the beauty and splendour of the temple. Visit with a guide to get the best understanding of the construction and iconography.

my favourite temple. angkor wat may be the heart of cambodia but my heart was stolen by bayon. after sunrise at angkor wat, we headed straight down to bayon and reached at around 7am. it was a perfect time as crowds were minimal and we saw less than 10 people walking around This probably added to the magical atmosphere at bayon! we took all the pictures, avoided all the crowds and went off to our next temple as happy troopers. if u really want to enjoy your visit to a particular temple, it's worth waking up to avoid the tour groups and also the hot sun!

Another Fantastic MUST SEE. This temple is best visited after Angkor Wat. It is not far away, but as you study this temple it is nice to have the reference of Angkor Wat in your mind. The 54 original stone faces cause one to reflect on our own humanity, which has not changed so much in 1000 years.
One of the most important temples in Cambodia. This temple in addition of Ankor What is un must seen if you are in Cambodia. I recommend to visit it, better with guide.

Great place to visit, "Buddha gazing down on you.". The Bayon in my opinion is the best temple in Angkor Thom. The smiling faces of Buddha is different and amazing opportunity for some great pictures and another lifetime goal achieved. A must see and you need a guide and get there early as well.

Another amazing temple!. Again, a hot day, lots of fluids required to sustain one's energy and hydration. Need to be able to scramble over uneven ground and rocks. Would be difficult for anyone wih walking issues.
Amazing. From Angkor Wat to Bayon Temple it's a sight to behold. All that history to absorb and even the monkeys were cute!

The temple of faces. A worthy side trip from Angkor. We stopped here after the main temple at Angkor and we loved it. It was under some construction when we went (Sept 2015) but was still worth the visit. Its a very small area and yet we all managed to get lost. A wonderful experience. The faces give this particular temple a very memorable character. Definitely recommended.
Love this like going back in time.. We spent a beautiful day visiting these temples, I loved every moment of it would loved to be there on my own.

Faces and faces and faces. Another masterpiece of the smiling faces of Buddha. There are hundreds of them... Many destroyed or stolen by art thieves or during the civil war. Reminiscent of our past generation and their beliefs

Another great place close to Angkor Wat. If you are going to Angkor Wat, take the time to also stop here. Very nice and great time for pictures. Some of the stairs are a little steep so be careful. Wonderful experience.

Iconic mountains with faces. Other than perhaps the 'tree in the courtyard' Ta Prohm location, Bayon's faces are the most iconic spot at Angkor. It looks like mountains above the temple with faces you can't take your eyes off of. They look great in photos, but believe me they are even more impressive in person. One of the great spots at Angkor.

The Temple Where The Compassionate Buddhas Are Found. The stairs are very steep, compare to a ship's stairway, but it is the only way to get a good look at the smiling Buddhas that adorn the temple. If you past this up you're visit to Angkor Wat is incomplete.

The Temple of Many Faces. This was probably one of the best temples I had seen on my 2 week trip of 4 countries with enough temples to last me a lifetime. This one was very different in the feel and the look. The faces were the immediate difference and for some reason it gave the whole temple a different feel. This was the last one of our trip in Cambodia and it truly felt like the best had been saved for last. While I loved Angkor Wat and the size and magnificence, Bayon was a completely different feel and love that I will never forget.
Disappointing. We wish there was more information at the site on the site. It was far more interesting than Angkor Wat, but we really did not know what to look for.
Stunning!. We actually liked the Bayon temples more than Angkor Wat! what a absolutely stunning place. Go early to miss the crowds.
My favorite temple. Another must see in Siem Reap - can be combined with Angor Wat. Love all the faces! Great exploring.

Totes worth it for the selfie op. Okay maybe the selfie isn't so easy and you might have to ask your guide to take the picture at exactly the right spot, so that you too can seem to be kissing the eternally smiling statue at the temple. If you're pressed for time, then obviously you can just power through as part of a group, but this really needs time. It's a fairly easy walk around the building and up and down some darn steep but well-maintained stairs and the effort is worthwhile to see the finely carved sculptures.

Temple of the smiling Buddha's . The Bayon is the highlight of Angkor Thom. The site is adorned with numerous smiling faces of Buddha gazing down on you from above. Some of the towers appear to be actually defying the laws of gravity. A must see during your Angkor tour.

Fascinating! . We visited 13 of the Angkor temples and this was definitely one of our favourites, the huge, serene Buddha faces are mesmerising. When you climb up to the top level of the temple and get up close to them they are even more impressive. A must see.

Early morning start. As we already had our ticket from the previous day, we decided to visit this temple at 6am before the crowds arrived. It was worth it, as we had the place to ourselves initially, and were able to take lots of really nice pictures. On leaving we found monkeys were scurrying around and found them entertaining.Recommend you visit early and enjoy the peace.
The best. love, love love it! by far the best temple in the Angkor Wat complex, the real Indiana Jones experience!
Fantastic sightseeing. We had always put off going to this place and Angkor Wat as we assumed it would be too hard to get to but we are very glad we made the effort. Great experience.

Exceptional and mysterious. An absolute must see. Exceptional and mysterious. Leave yourself plenty of time to view these ruins. In many ways just as impressive as Angkor Wat but on a smaller scale. Go early to avoid the crowds. I would consider this a must see while in Cambodia. Multiple levels to explore. You could spend the entire day here and we did. Don't miss this or you will regret it. Entry tickets are included with the purchase of Angkor Wat tickets.
Holiday . Fantastic views, history, details in the architecture are amazing. Not to expensive and great value for money a must see
Khmer Culture highligt. Great Experience to get to know the Khmer culture and the structure of its religious society of yester years.
My favouite. Angkor gets the press, this is the best temple. I wandered around lost it the mystic for hours. This is a truely an amazing temple structure
Exquisite and beautiful!. One of the most beautiful temple comlexes in Siem Reap. The majestic beauty cannot be expressed in words. See it to believe it.

What a Fantastic Place. We have been with my 3 friends at Siem reap. Bayon was great temple at our visiting. Especially using bicycle is very easy , fun and cheap choice. Because temples are surronded at very wide location. I am still not sure, but Tomb Raider or Indiana Jones were produced at this temples.

Unforgettable!. While Angkor is the most popular temple in Siem Reap, Bayon leaves an impression. The temple, which is known as Bayon (meaning face in the local language), has Buddha faces everywhere you look. One of the best spots to get a panorama of the temple is from the waterbody just outside the exit. It's not surprising that this was the chosen site for Tomb Raider starring Angelina Jolie. The setting is exotic and mysterious. Well worth a visit.
Amazing!. Bayon temple is one of my favorite temples in Siem Reap.The best time to visit is in the morning so you can ride and feed the elephants.
Amazing. Just incredible to see something so ancient. It's great to see they are trying to preserve as much as they can. Essential to use a local guide as you learn more that doing it solo

Great experience raiding tombs. Took 3 boys (9, 8 and 3) looking for Lara Croft. Although we didnt find her we all really enjoyed Bayon. Its involves a bit more exploring than some of the other temples and i think for that reason the kids enjoyed it. Its also not too far from central Siem Reap. Really good experience.
pictures tell it all. another wonderful place to walk around, again i feel very luckily that i could visit bayon up close with my family

Smiling Faces of Bodhisatva. I wanted to visit this temple because I was fascinated by the huge smiling faces of Bodhisatva here. There were originally 216 faces. Now less than 100 are left. Worth visiting and yes, a great picture spot!

Amazing temple :). The carving is so incredible! Imagine there were no power tools and they were able to create such masterpiece made of stone. Be sure to explore the surrounding temples and take a lot of pictures. Also bring a towel, hat or cap and arm yourselves with water canteen because it's too hot and tiring.

Unforgettable. A visit to the temples is Siem Reap is a must. The spleandour and impressiveness of the structures are inspiring. The level of detail of the carvings in the stone walls and on the pillars are truly impressive. It truly makes one more amazed if you think of the fact that the temples were built 100s of years ago. It is recommended to get a guide (or, if you prefer, a book on the temples - there are many available in Siem Reap, even at the temples, just haggle a bit on the price if you buy at the temple!) as there is a lot of history you wont know about by just walking around and looking at the impressive structures. Set aside atleast 2 days to see enough of the temples. For a different view, go for a helicopter trip over the temples, a great experience!

The smiling Buddha temple. It was a part of my Angkor wat visit and is situated in the middle Of Angkor Thom and has 54 faces of smiling Buddha in total at the bayon temple. A beautiful temple of Buddha.

Cycling tour: visit to the temple . We visited the temple as part of our one day cycling tour. This was the second stop on our route.We arrived by travelling through the countryside and forest areas on our bikes.Another fantastic historical site! Well worth a visit if you are only going to see a few of the temples in the area.

This is why you come here. Although we stayed in the beautiful Hyatt hotel which our entire family enjoyed, the temples are why you come to anchor wat. We had hired a guide before We came and I am so glad we did.the ticket Re is a zoo, but he took care of that and the area is so much larger than I ever realized. He took us to the important temples and the picture spots....he was also. Great photographer. We had asked for someone who spoke English and he did speak very well.

Angkor Wat and surrounding temples. Amazing. A once in a lifetime must see. The history is unbelievable.Carvings in each and every part of the building are unfathomable. Unbelievable beauty. Easy to walk around and one is not bothered by lines or people telling you what to do every 5 minutes and what to touch and not to touch. Very easy to sightsee around without many restrictions.
Amazing temple. I was very excited to see it. Great temple with so many many faces tower. This temple has three floor. It is not too far from south gate. Amazing!!!

Up close and personal with history. This is my favorite of the 3 'touristy' temples in Siem Reap.At times it can be very busy with people posing for selfies and the main photo spots, but if you can escape the crowds, it's amazing how close you can get to the Ancient temple. Not everyone knows that Bayon is actually older than Angkor Wat. It is worth doing your homework to appreciate all of the architecture. Overall it's very impressive.

Don't miss. Bayon temple is in Angkor Wat area. You have to use the pass to access it. It has a great view with an incredible face carving. You may feel someone stare at you all time. Visiting it in the morning is recommended because the front placed in east.
Gorgeous Temple. under the guide and showing by Angkor cab we have a thorough visit all the temples in Bayon. The trip was nice and unforgettable

Most amazing carvings. We thoroughly enjoyed this temple. We found the carvings out of this world.Before doing all the temples recommend you visit the museum in siem rep, it is located near the river.Try to visit the temples early in the morning, it gets very hot and humid in the afternoon.We had a private tuk tuk, paid usd 20 for the dayAlso recommend you do not see all the temples in one day, unless you are young, superfit and do not mind the heat.By purchasing a 3 day pass valid for 7 days, you get one day free. Cost is usd40 for a 3 day pass. Enjoy

Smiling Faces – a must see !!. The temple is relatively small compared to Angkor Wat, but its certainly worth a visit. We visited the temple for a morning sunrise and it was magnificent. Suggestion, as you arrive at the temple aim to go straight to the top terrace where all the smiling face structures are – once you have taken your photos with the surreal structures you can work your way to the lower levels which are also worth exploring. Once you have explored this temple it is possible to explore Angkor Thom on the same day, they are located in very close proximity (refer to map) FYI – its worth reading the relevant chapter in the Angkor Wat guide
Wow!. Continuing our journey of the temples this was another to tick off the list and again well worth the visit

Counting the faces. A fairly busy temple area and the only place that we needed to compete for space or photo opportunities , Might have been the day or the weather but only place we came across with "pushy" vendors around the site.

Need lots of time here. There is so much to see in this area that you can't see it all. But don't miss this temple.The carved faces are amazing. If the walk from the entrance to the temple is too much in the heat, take an elephant ride.
Little shade. Wonderful place. Just make sure to bring water, hats or umbrellas as Bayon offers little shade compared to other sites.
The Second must see following Angkor Wat. Not so big as the Angkor Wat, but its complexity and splendidness do add to its charming. The first thing to see after entering the Angkor Thom area.
Spectacular. One of the most important and beautiful temples in Angkor site that should not be missed. A bit crowded on the day we visited.

Worth to go, don't miss this temple. I visited many temples in two days, but this one is very impressive! It's huge and beautiful, Over 200 large faces give this temple its majestic character. You can find the "Angkor Smiles" here.

Incredible. What a view, if people say they are not impressed by this I don't know what will or maybe they are confusing it with something else. Its not ankor wat size but its sure is impressing with the 200+ carved buddha faces. Theres monkeys to :-)

Tour as part of the Angkor Complex Temples. It is recemmneded that you tour the Bayon Temple the same time that you tour the rest of the Angkor Temples. One suggestion is to use Mr. Pech Mony, Mony Tour Guides, as your tour guide. Trust me you will thank me later!
My Favorite Temple. Anchor Wat was incredible but the Bayon was my favorite. So much meaning - takes your breathe away. Do with Angkor Thom and Ta Prom.

Exit/entrance. This is one of the many temples that we went to during my tuktuk tour of the Angkor Wat and the many temples. Being here brought back so many nights of just reading about their history. It was overwhelming. The place is beautiful. The ruins were just amazing.By the way, bring your water when you go here. It could get super hot.
The faces!. Love love love this temple. First visit was very busy, went back the day after for sunrise. Love the detail of the faces. Very special place.
No words to discribe. One of the best temples. I felt that old atmosphere. Wanted to go back again and again. Something magnificent there
Details of carvings. More accessible and easier walking access with a lot of face carvings but go with a guide to understand the stories.

A wonderful temple with smiling buddha. The smiling buddhas impressed you! It is not the same as the Angkor Wat but definitely should not miss this special temple. You will also wonder how the people at that time managed to build in such details!
Different.. This site was different to the others mainly due to the many carved faces on the columns. Certainly worth a visit.
Don't miss this!. Too many visitors to Siem Reap seem to think that Angkor Wat is pretty much all there is. Make sure that you take the time to see Bayon and Angkor Thom too, at the very least.
Next stop. Smaller and more compact than Ankgor Wat this has the smiling faces on the towers and the decorated friezes depicting many aspects of daily life.

I like Bayon Temple very much!. I like Bayon Temple very much! The photo and temple is nice!Take note: the security police they wanna help you to take photo and will ask tips from you after took photo and using your own camera or phone. Normally they ask USD1 TO USD5.

Such a beautiful temple!. I love photography and this place didn't disappoint at all. The faces are so detailed and it truly is an incredible place to spend some time exploring. My favourite of all the temples. Definitely should give it a wander when doing the temples around Siem Reap.

My Favourite Temple. Whilst I had always longed to visit Ankor Wat the Bayon Temple wasn't on my radar, if like me you like to capture your visit on photos, I doubt that you will ever visit a more photogenic spot in the world. I read that from a distance it looks nothing, but when you get on the second level with in excess of 200 perfect faces all 2m+ high you will know what I mean, it is absolutely stunning. Trying to line up as many faces in one shot is your biggest challenge!
Smiling Buddah.. Fascinating temple where the face of Buddah watches your every move. Many interesting stories told in the bas-reliefs.
Challenging Site. Another must-visit place. Climbing up to see all ancient stuff in the hot sun was challenging...but it was worth it. Don't forget to drop by this place!

4 Faces in one Temple. You can find 4 faces of Cambodia ancient god in each of the tower in this temple. Now its on restiration project to make sure all the faces is remain well-consructed. You can take picture in front of the temple beside the big tree.

Mesmerising gothic towers. Littered with coldly smiling faces (216 of them) looking down at you from every single angle.There is a beautiful walkway to it, great for photo shoot.Don't miss the reclining Buddha on the back that was recreated a few years ago.
Unforgettable smile. Not big temple like Angkor Wat but very worthwhile to visit. Buddha's smile under sunshine brought peach and wisdom.

Early morning visit is best.. See this before you see Angkor Wat. Easy to get around and worth the visit. Suggestion is to do this one, Angkor Thom and then Angkor Wat. (Keeps the biggest complex for last).
Interesting temple. While smaller than Angor Wat, it is still impressive. In fact, we enjoyed the smaller temples more than Angor Wat in some ways. They were certainly less crowded.

Fascinating!. Was truly interesting visitng this place in the middle of the walled city Angkor Thom. Its a ancient temple containg towers with large face carvings! Must see place in Siem Reap along with Angkow Wat and La Prohm

Amazing. Amazing if you get a chance to go it's a must spectacular A Buddhist temple with all these amazing heads just wonderful very impressive I'm glad we do it in the morning early as it gets very hot and it's gonna get Hotter The best way to do this temples is a tuk tuk otherwise there's just too much walking you could never do it unless you have a lot of time
Truly amazing. Another fabulous example of Khmer history. You can only imagine what it was like in its heyday! Majestic!
Great to see. Went to this Temple after Angkor Wat, though smaller great to see. Can't imagine how hard the people would have worked to build these places.

Part of Angkor Thom - great history here. The Bayon Temple is in the Middle of Angkor Thom and is well worth an hour's visit. We went around midday to avoid the crowds but it was quite hot. Fascinating history shown on the carved frieze at the front. Lots of interesting faces carved into the rocks. Not on the scale of Angkor Wat but not to be missed either.
The 4 faces temple. A wonderful place to visit. Extremely amazing to witness to great accomplishment. You all should come to visit.

Impressive! . I travel for work and have visited zillions of temples all over the world, mostly in South-East Asia. I went to Temple Park without much understanding of its history so I could judge the temples for their visual aspects rather than admiring hem for their stories. This one was visually spectacular.

Bayon temple- don't miss this!. Everyone knows and visits Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm, since Indaiana Jones and Lara Croft have been there, but The Bayon Temple is different. Lots of smiling face-statues all around. This gives You the good mood!

A different kind of temple. Bayon was the 3rd temple we visited and it was a different kind of temple because it is called the smiling face temple as some would say and I agree. Among the temples we visited this site is something different because of the big smiling faces that you can see around the Bayon Temple. We are in awe with this temple. A must see temple when you do your temple tour.
Nice Buddha monument / Temple. Worth going to this place with guide else the place is not suitable...access to the temple for the old people would be difficult.

Just beautiful!. We visited after watching the sunrise at Angkor Wat and I must say it was maybe slightly to early, due to the sun still being behind it. Maybe better to visit after 2pm. It was a beautiful place and - unpopular opinion - I loved it more than Angkor Wat. Such interesting and faces everywhere you look. Definitely see this one!
A must visit ancient temple. A unique temple which has a lot of faces carved onto it. Definitely worth the sweat to explore the place.
Magical site in the heart of the jungle. I never tire of visiting the Angkor ruins - there is so much to see and the experience is different each time. Hire a tuk-tuk and spend half a day exploring.

Impressive Cultural Site. Along with Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm you will want to see this cultural site. It is huge on the map but the tuk-tuk will take you to the center where you can view the Temple grounds.

The Gods are around you..... FEEL THEM.. Bayon temple is one of my favourites in Angkor Wat. The moment you step inside the bayon temple is a different world altogether......can't explain....You have to feel it.

A highlight of the temple complex!. you will be amazed by the dedication and hard work that would have been needed to build this temple and it is easy to picture in your n=mind what it would have been like when new. Do not miss this when visiting the temple complex.
The temple of Faces. really one of the better temples to explore and alot of the architectural integrity still in tact. Plenty of photo ops with all the faces. Really had a blast at Bayon.

Tremendous temple!. Well known as great city in ancient Khmer and it's established by King Jayavarman VII in 12th century and Bayon temple was known as the centre of the city. you'll see some local people with Khmer traditional costume offering to take picture with them, 1 Dollar for it!. As usual, water is a must bring when you want to explore the whole temple.Overall, Bayon Temple is one of the most impressive temple i ever seen with tremendous ancient architecture.

One of my favorite temples in Angkor. Bayon inside Angkor Tom is one of my favorite temples in Angkor. Last time we visited the place early morning in the rainy season and had the place just for ourselves, which was really special. The numerous faces carved in stone blocks look the same at the first glance, but when you start to look at them more closely you realise they are all different. The large murals describing every day life and some historical insidents are fashinating as well.
The best Temple in the complex!. It is an amazing sight- each and every face is beautifully carved into giant masterpieces.By far the best temple in the complex

No words can describe this. There are not many words to describe Bayon Temple. Yes the climb is tough but it is worth the effort. King Number 7 has done it again ! How can us of the present time understand how they managed to build these.

It shows me a smile of Cambodian. This hotel is looked smiley and friendly, isn't it? And Cambodian is looked more smiley and friendly. This temple is one a mong my top favorite temples. Will be back and recommended/

One of my favourites!. Quite crowded in the afternoon, try to be early! Take a "nose-to-nose" pic with one of the faces, makes a great photo. Paid (an overprice) $30 for a tuk-tuk from sunrise to sunset and had time to see the following (with time left over, so if you're on a budget one day is enough and you don't have to rush to be able to see all of this): angkor wat (sunrise and the entire temple), banteay kdei, sras srang, pre rup, ta prom, ta keo, chau say thevoda, thommanom, preah khan, angkor thom, bayon and phnom bakheng (sunset, more of a view point). Doing it in that order also seemed like a smart plan as we were almost all alone everywhere (except sunrise and sunset and some people at ta prom). So don't listen to "you can't do it in one day", at least not if you are young and healthy and can climb the stairs quite easily. Don't forget to bring clothes that cover your knees and shoulders when walking in some part of the temples. I advise you to bring it though and take it off in between in order not to faint because of overheating...
Awesome! . By far the most enjoyable temple visited. The giant faces are awe inspiring. We were there before the crowds and had it to ourselves
makes you feel like indiana jones. this is one of the highlights of the angkor complex but go early to avoid the crowds. most people come after seeing angkok wat

Has the best feeling of all. Full of happy faces, Bayon is outstanding. Unfortunately it is crumbling faster than Angkor Wat and the lower quality workmanship and materials shows. I hope that they restore it before it is too late
Part of a guided tour. Great temple, not easily accessible for those with difficulty walking around, plenty of little areas and lots of Buddhas heads to see. Another great photo stop

My favourite!. Counting the 216 faces, 4 on each of the 54 towers, facing the four points of the compass, can keep you quite busy but there are always many others taking photos of their friends seated on all of the convenient ledges. This does tend to spoil the atmosphere there but if you are mentally ready it is OK. It is not to be missed though and the carvings on the lower levels are amazing as well as the serene faces staring out at the jungle.

Magnificient temple and outstanding architecture. This particular temple is about a mile from Angkor Wat and a magnificent drive to get there. The stone faces are outstanding and have tremendous character and peace. Many folks rate this ahead of the magnificent Angkor Wat.

A must! The temple of the faces. The one thing that my friends and I noticed was each temple was very unique in and of itself, even if you do all the temples in one to two days or even 1 to 3 days you will not get bored. There's so much to see, so much detail, and an intense amount of history involving Buddhism and Hinduism. At Bayon you can climb into the temple and for you instagramers and selfie takers--- you'll find all sorts of open terraces and windows to take gteat pictures. Recommend going early in the morning to avoid high volumes of tourists and Chinese tour buses.Note1: Take a bike! They're $1usd and most come with locks, not that you really need them. Some routes/circuits are 10-12km, but you obviously don't have to follow the recommended three day tours. Biking allowed us to observe daily life in the rural areas outside the temples as well as Siem Reap as a whole.Note 2: do not go ticketless! They will fine you. Grab tickets en route to the temple roads, on your right approx. 3km before arriving at a fork in the road. Angkor is to the left of the fork. Note 3: Money is changed in USD, Cambodia uses the reil as change, like cents. Note4: snack stands and beverages available near Angkor Wat - restaurants too, and vendors line up near other temples. Prices slightly elevated but it's not ridiculous inflation.

Love this Temple. The faces at this temple where amazing. Loved really taking a good look and seeing them up close and personal. The only bummer is that the site is currently being repaired so there were cranes everywhere and a lot of noise, made it a little less spiritual and relaxing, but boy did I love it!

Largest Buddha heads. Must visit places after Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom .... These places have large Buddha heads ... most are in pathetic condition due to wear and tear over the time during to weather. Must place visit.

Faces, Faces, Everywhere. One of the most interesting temples in Siem Reap.. The massive faces of Bayon Temple make it one of the most visually stunning of the temples I visited while in Siem Reap. The temple has an interesting history of religious changes, and the inscriptions on the wall are intricate and still well maintained.
Big face Bayon. I love Bayon temple because of Big Faces every corner. We will visit again next time. Good time to see this temple is early morning

Best bayon . A must place to wish on earth...
Simply magnificent
A new great experience..
Bayon showcase a 216 bayon faces in the temple that makes yr head turn around 360 degrees
What a great place to be... Bayon

Lots of faces. This temple was pretty cool, you could go up in it a bit more than Angkor Wat (we went early and the higher part was only open with special reservation until after 740). Easy to get good pictures here, fairly crowded though. Definitely worth a stop for the architecture
Put this on the list. Make sure you stop here. It's amazing and won't take a lot of your time. The smiling Buddha faces are so cool.

Impressive temple of the smiling Buddhas. This is one of the many temples of Angkor, and one that's worth a visit. There are impressive figures on the road driving to the temple, and an equally impressive wall around the temple area. The temple itself has been greatly restored, and there are endless photo opportunities as you climb the various parts of the temple. Be warned, though, that the stairs are very steep and very shallow, so it can be physically challenging to climb, and I wouldn't want to try them in the rain. You can get a picture of yourself nose-to-nose with one of the giant Buddha heads (if your guide doesn't suggest it, one of the guides wandering around the temple will). There are elephant rides around the temple grounds, if you're into that sort of thing. Bayon is not as well-known nor as frequently photographed as Angkor Wat or Ta Prohm, but still well worth a visit.
The temple with the 'big heads'. Fantastic and unlike any western architecture. Highly recommended as part of Angkor Wat visit. Take plenty of photographs and water!

Well maintained. great historic site, structures were well maintained. some chambers though had this funny smell. ladders were also too steep for older tourists. saw monks taking selfies which is against the temple rules

Humbled. 200 gigantic stone faces huge curious smiling facing all sides is amazing and majestic to look at. Humbled in the presence of math, science and architecture of the generation way way before us.
AMAZING AMAZING. Besides Angkor wat, Bayon is marvelous thing. You can't say no. You don't believe human being invented that amazing temple a thousand years ago.. Come and reckon it.
Outstanding temple. Definitely one not to be missed. Incredible experience, not as busy as Angkor Wat, but just as hot. Early morning visit is advised.
The best of the temples. 54 faces of complete serenity surround you, smiling their ,mysterious, sensuous smiles from every direction. Fabulously well preserved, awe inspiring.

The many faces of Buddha. This was out final stop on the Temple tour and it was definitely worth it. So many of the Buddha's faces are so well defined and as with so many of the temples you can explore pretty much the whole site. If you only do a selection of the temples, make sure this one is on your list
So different. Wow, this was great seeing all the figs taking over the temple, shame but it adds atmosphere, being able to walk in something that is over 1000 years old is truly mind boggling.

More than two faced!. A spectacular temple with stunning carved faces that are everywhere you look. The Bayon face has become famous and instantly recognizable and is no less disappointing when seen in person. Not to be missed.
Many faces. This is temple has wonderful examples of carvings depicting real life - 1000 year old photos! Take lots of photos because there are faces even where you don't realise.

Better than Angkor Wat. We loved it. Less crowded than the main temple at Anchor Wat and just as spectacular. Do not miss this. There was some renovation work going on at the front but once you get in it is serene and quiet. The layout (many towers, covered walkways, rooms) means it is easy to feel like you are away from the crowd. Beautiful carvings and temple towers. Not all standing but that really adds to the atmosphere of a very special and ancient place.

Amazing. We used the word amazing so many times in Cambodia but you need to say it, the temples are just that the structures themselves and the history behind the are incredible we did a organised trip which covered all of major sites and would recommend this way of seeing them all
Faces. Spent a day with a tuk tuk visiting as many temples as we could fit in. This temple was amazing . Faces everywhere.
Amazing. It is amazing to see the carved faces and the remnants of a once beautiful building. As with other temples in the area it is good to see other countries investing in the rebuilding

Must see after Angkor. This is the only temple where Shiva linga was in a full form. As all other updates about tourist group. Avoid china tour groups, trust me, you will know when you encounter. Great pictures and to my awe craftsmanship. The back of the temple is still going through phases of restoration. Steep stairs to be aware and try to give way to others after you take your pictures in certain spots. It get crampy upstairs.

Don't just visit Angkor Wat. Whilst Angkor Wat is the largest and best known temple there are many others that are fascinating too. An early visit to some of the surrounding temples such as Bayon avoids most of the large tour groups and if you hire a local tuk tuk he'll happily take you around and wait between temples.
Don't miss. Besides Angkor Wat, this was my favorite temple, of the ten that we visited.The photographic opportunities were superb!

Absolutely beautiful!. Totally worth the journey all the way to Bayon. Try and go when the huge tour groups (particularly from China) aren't around as they can be very loud and quite obnoxious and will ruin the peaceful surrounding atmosphere.

Smile of Cambodia :). I have been in Cambodia for 3 days and i have noticed that everyone in Cambodia is so friendly. They always have a smile on their face that makes day so fresh. Of course, this temple may be a symbol of Cambodian smile!

A stunning start to a beautiful morning. We started very early in the morning and there were less crowds around so you could take in the views peacefully. We had a great guide with us from Selective Asia (an agency who booked our honeymoon for us) who talked us through the history. It's definitely on the must do list.

Beautiful Temle Ruins with Amazing Details. Aftr visiting the crowded Angor Wat main temple, it felt very peaceful at the Bayon Temple. There were hardly any people and it made it possible to take in all the amazing details of the temple. The Stone carvings are simply fantstic, in particular the face carvings. Do not miss out the Bayon Temple when in the Angor Archaeological Park.
STUNNING STUNNING STUNNING!!. What a place...the title really says it all. On a par with the Egyptian temples with regards to how they were made, giant stones upon stones, and carved, breathtaking!

Smaller than Angkor Wat. Easy to walk around this temple and less crowded than Angkor Wat. Lots of the part of the temple are accessible, although they are doing restoration work, which in itself is interesting especially compared to Australian Health and Safety standards. The steps are very steep to access higher areas.
Very different from Angkor. Modern camera's have face recognition technology, it recognises the faces carved in stone roughly 1000 years ago, great carving skills

Don't miss this!. Don't fall for the scams when people offer to tour you around inside. You can access everywhere without them and it's better to just wander around, take loads of photos, and move on at your convenience. These places are like playgrounds for adults, so be prepared to take silly photos, climb around to get a good shot, and make unforgettable memories!

Amazing. this is not as well preserved as Angkor wat, but its still amazing for its 49 towers, each with 4 faces on it...Dont forget to bring an extra $20 per preson to ride the elephants around teh temple....
Beautiful. You can't come here and skip this unique and beautiful temple! Try to avoid the mass of turists making the tour on the opposite direction or enjoy it during lunch time!

Beautiful and unique temple. Amazing temple. Kids loved looking at the different faces carved into the temple walls and towers. Only downside was the crowds. We had difficulty getting through certain areas because of the crowds and tight spaces. But Definitely worth a trip - even with the crowds.
Siem Reap sightseeing. Magnificent! The temples are huge. Stone carvings are everywhere on the walls. The stone-carved faces are still intact. this is definitely one of every photographer's havens.

Well worth a visit. I am writing this not because I have anything particularly unique or insightful to say but so it remains high up on the list of places to visit (if you are like me and came to Siem Reap not knowing what to prioritise and use the top 10 things to do in Siem Reap list....). This is part of the Angkor Thom complex so you can do this and several other places of interest at the same time.
Wow. One of the most impressive temples I've ever seen A special atmosphere and strange recommends that you visit!
Great but lots of stairs. It was hot so bring plenty of water as the stairs are a killer. great views from up high. Allow about an hour here.

My favorite temple. Of all the temples/structures in the area, this one is my absolute favorite. Its definitely got character. There's something in the huge faces of buddha that makes one feel instantly peaceful. Easy to do unlike Angkor Wat where one needs to spend a lot of time walking. Bayon is a smaller building and relatively quicker to see. A must see!
cultural experience. The carvings are amazing. Get a guide - we used a guy called Cheak Chuom . He was excellent - chuomcheak@ymail.com.

AMAZING temple!. All the temples in Siem Reap are amazing, but if I had to choose one, this was my favorite. I visited during the lunch hour and although it was uncomfortably hot, it was not as crowded. There were still people there but if you want to avoid the larger crowds, come visit during lunch.
Temple of Faces Bayon Temple. Temple of Faces was well worth the visit. Not to miss. All the sights are best when you have a guide to give you the details and history. The beauty comes alive.
Beware bogus guides speaking unintelligible English!. Very easy to get lost completely surrounded by huge towers consisting of many faceted enigmatic faces.
Favourite temple in Siem Reap. Even though Angkor Wat is the most famous temple in Siem Reap, Bayon temple was my favourite and I would recommend visiting it.
Angkor Thom. Not as huge as Angkor Wot, but very cool to see all of the faces carved into the rocks. This was truly fascinating.
Face off!. One of my favourite temples, lots of opportunities for photos. Amazing workmanship to create this temple. A must see if going to Angkor Wat. Only a short 5-10min cycle from Angkor Wat.

Temples. You can spend so much time admiring the skill it would have taken to build these temples years ago and the sacrifice that would have been made to make it.
Allow plenty of time.
Awesome. Lovely place but go early. IT gets crowded and really really hot and humid. Wear good walking shoes and light clothing.
Meaning . I been many temple but Angkor Thom the best and number one , really beautiful and perfect , but very sad Buddha no arm no head I don't know why people's ....;

The temple of 'Faces'. Words probably can not do justice. I was amazed with the carving, and the capacity to make those sculptures.Here you need to see, hear and feel. Better to see once than hear a hundred times.
Angkor Thom. World Heritage listing, and very, very interesting.The history of the place and the cultural aspects are amazing.
2nd to see 😝. If you get tuktuk he can take you along the small circuit for 15usd, so if you have 4 people to split the price with then it works out real cheap
Second nice temple. Nice temple with a lot of heds sculpters, do not miss it as it uniq compare to othets. Take a rain coat or umberalla for rainy days
Educational Experience in Cambodia. Very educational trip. Full of history. Rich in culture. Excellent way to learn about ancient Cambodia
like the smile. like the smile very much,amazing, and we are very suprise for the king doing this like that, very fantasity
Unspeakable beauty in stone. Words fail me. How can the stone faces and smiles retain their softness and beatitude after all these years? Beautiful.

Very unique temple design. I like this temple more than Angkor Wat for some reason. Maybe it's not as crowded but with all the towers and how each tower have it's own face might be the reason. It's just looks very insetting with how all the faces make the temple.
Must be seen. Bridge entering the temple sets the scene.The bas relief carvings are worth seeing if nothing else.Whole experience means much more if you have a local guide.
Great Teples and histories behind. Cambodia is wonderful and its my own country. Bayon Temple is one of the most beautiful Temples in Kingdom of wonder.
Elephant Ride around the Temple. The temple is being remodeled but it doesn't take away the breathtaking ambiance of the temple. Try an elephant ride for $20 USD around the Bayon Temple site.
So many faces!. Beautiful temple! Take a time to sit and relax. Somewhere you will take your best photo, face to face.

Holiday to Vietnam & Cambodia with friends. Very nice temple on the outskirts of Seam Reap. Easy to walk around the area.
Slightly different from other temples.
Waw, Faces in rocks. very nice temple, don't miss this one ! can be very hot there but a beautiful place with faces in the rocks of the temple

Good place for temple shots. The contrast of old and refurbished stone faces make good shots, with few artificial structures or trees to get in the way of shots. Not a very big place so you won't need to walk much. There's a short climb involved to get to the main area though, and it's exposed so the heat might get to you - most tours should reach this place at around noon.

The famous "Faces of Buddha" Temple. The temple is unique in its own way. I lost count of how many Buddha faces inside the temple. The Buddha faces and the architecture also reminded me of Borobudur temple in Indonesia. It was not the largest temple in Cambodia. However, the number of structures within the small area make it more impressive.However, what made me curious the most is the architecture. If you look inside any towers that have the Buddha face on it, you would see it is just a big stone stacked in pyramid position and lean against each other to stabilize it, without any mortar. To think that such a big monument can survive more than 9 centuries with just basic physics law is just mind blowing.This is one of the big three temples so do not miss the opportunity to visit the Bayon temple.
Different temple. A smaller temple, it is nonetheless very striking with the numerous stone faces. One can spend a whole day trying to line up the faces for some amazing photos.

One of my favorite. This is one of my favorite from the Angkor Wat Complex. I love the stone carvings and very authentic ancient feel. Everywhere is picture perfect. My only warning is that beware of khmer students or anyone who will talk to you and would present to take your photo. They will be asking for donation. which is initially fine but then they would demand a certain amount which i find off already. I guess they target solo travellers.
A sight to see!. Don't miss one of the must-see temples in Angkor area. You should get overwhelmed a lot of huge Buddha faces (I cannot count them).
Survivor Cambodia's one team is Bayon. This and Angkor Thom were spectacular. Don't miss them. Unfortunately, I hadn't heard of them, only Angkor Wat.

Also very interesting and amaizing. Very intetesting and amaizing how much work was done here.
All the faces, the stairs and huge complex that was quiet difficult to build.
A must see!
Unique in itself . Bayon is a must to see. If you are an avid photographer, you will love the shadows cast by the stonework.

Definetly stop there. A great temple to walk around and explore it.
There are everywhere carved faces and many good spots to take some nice pics.
In my view the temple is cooler as Angkor Watt but less famous.

The Temple of faces.. When you see the pictures of this temple, I was reminded of the movie Tomb Raider. I was expecting a much larger place. The compound itself isn't covered with a roof per say, and what is covered up at the very top smells very strongly of bat droppings. The smell is so strong that going inside takes your breath away and not in a good sense. The Temple itself is still very impressive and I would highly recommend a visit.

Beautiful Temple. Make sure to climb and walk all around this temple. There are interesting things around every corner. The four faced sculptures dominate, but there are some amazing carved reliefs in the temple walls. Make sure if you are visiting this temple to check out the Angkor Thom complex, which is right nearby. There is on going restoration work currently, but it is interesting to watch the workers. I would recommend getting to this temple early to beat the crowds. All temples can be accessed with the Temple pass and I would recommend the three day pass.

Boring. Looks better in the curios and photos than actually viewed. Smaller than most other temples with the four-sided face sculpture dominating everywhere. There's a strong smell of man pee around some of the structures...velly exotic!

Lower than expected. A bot of disappointment after all the build up. Looks like a zerox machine rush job. Historically great and worth the visit. Remember to get your nose stock against the nose photot

I recommend the Elephant ride. Enough must have been said in other reviews about this amazing place. My tip is to consider the elephant ride round the outside of the temple. I did this and jumped into the full tourist experience paying the hustler for several photographs and also buying multiple pineapples to feed the Elephants. It may seem expensive by Cambodian standards but when will you get another chance? The ride itself feels very safe once you get the hang of it and I never felt in any danger
Worth a visit. This temple has the 4 faces of the special Kings of Cambodia who advanced the country and people. There are many depictions of them in temples other than Angkor Wat.
Bayon Temple is interesting.. Bayon Temple is interesting.Make me wonder how they do this temple .Big rock beautiful face and Huge.

One to tick off your bucket list,. Took a private Tuk Tuk, organised with the Hotel. An amazing experience, a must see in Siem Reap. Unfortunately only had 4hours , one really needs to have a couple of days as the Angkor Archaeological Park stretches over 400 sq km.
Great temple. Great temple, I really suggest you to visit it if you are around Siem Reap.Get a good mountain bike if you don't want to struggle
One of the true wonders of the ancient world. So amazing, we loved Bayon. Walked around it for hours and still kept coming back. A must on anyone's list thinking of visiting asia

Stunning. As with the other temples here Bayon is unique in design. All the major temples here are well worth the trip to Cambodia alone. Thank god these temples were rescued from the jungle, it would have been a great loss to humanity if there were not here to be seen.

An awesome sight not to be missed. Mind blowing that we are lucky enough to see these ancient buildings. Ask a local or guide to take your photo ''rubbing noses with the king''.(sort of a Leaning Tower of Pisa trick).Took so many photos and climbed most of the steps.

One of the most interesting. This is one of the most interesting and beautiful of the temple complexes in Cambodia. Be sure to visit it when you are there. There is far more to see in the Siem Reap area than Angkor Wat.
Lovely. Culture and history. A place to relax and to learn, will be back again and wish you could experience this too. I once wonder how this was made but now U have chance to know more pls come more
Sounds better then it is. Since its part of the archeological park, it's worth a look, but not much here. There are a few elephants made of rocks, but not much of a story to go with this place either

The real deal. It is one thing to look at a nat geo or see the photos . The experience of climbing on these walls, feeling them , looking at the large faces from all angles... Well , there is simply nothing like it. I wish i was not in high season and there were less people. Obviously i'm not the only one in the world who wanted the same experience . Wow ! It is stunning.

there should be a maximum occupancy. you can't go to everything at sunrise but this amazing monument was so overcrowded with the many busloads of tourists we had to evacuate. When trying to take a picture, others taking selfies would have no care as to ruining your photo op. Our experience was ruined by the masses.

A Photographer's Dream. Amazing temple which you simply can't stop photographing. The Buddha faces are unique for temples in the complex, and yet fit in perfectly with the style. Around every corner is another amazing view of the faces, and a chance to take yet another great photo. Go early if you want to beat the crowds that inevitably come to this temple. A "must see" when you come to Siem Reap.

Captivating. This temple is part of Angkor Thom and it is indeed of good size, unique architecture and beautiful to capture within and from the outside. There are many different facets to it inside and outside and we thoroughly enjoyed exploring its interesting structure and photo taking even without being professionals. If you want to learn anything about the temples beyond what you see with your naked eye, you must go with a licensed guide. Do not miss! We easily spent an hour here on our own.

Gorgeous Temple!. This temple is well known for it’s tremendous stone faces and incredible bas-relief carvings. The massive carved heads each have four carved stone faces oriented to the cardinal points. They are one of the most recognisable images of the cambodian temples and the classic Khmer art. Don’t miss the extraordinary bas-relief carving which depict scenes of the real life historical sea battle between the Khmer and the Cham, as well as everyday events such as market scenes, cockfighting and chess game.

A-mazing Temple - an absolute must-see, after Angkor Wat. A temple with lots of character, the Bayon is part of the Angkor Thom complex. It sits in the middle of a 'square roundabout' – there are no walls surround this temple.It is visually stunning, with the faces and the towers. But don't stop just there, there are nooks and crannies downstairs, below the faces. Unlike the 'temple-mountains' around Angkor (the ones that rise up to over 20 metres, with steep steps), the Bayon isn't built high and therefore no steep climbs. Well, ok, just a little one, of about 10 steps.It is a photographer's paradise, so take a spare battery! You can cover this temple in less than an hour, and during rainy season, take a brolly or raincoat as there is no cover.A real must-see of a temple, it won't disappoint!

Beautiful temple - must-see. Set aside the Tomb Raider hype, this is really an amazing temple. It's incredibly beautiful, with those fabulous trees with their long "fingers" looping through the stones. A must-see.
Must See. Along with ANGKOR WAT, a must see complex. Get a Guide & walk the complex, learn the history, it's fascinating Check under ruin blocks for black scorpions, green snakes, & giant spiders
A must see.. Outstanding; the temple is a must see. Fantastic experience. A world heritage site that should be seen by all.
Second best temple in the Angkor Complex.. Wonderful temple, almost as good as Angkor Wat. It's part of Angkor Thom, a complex of several temples. Bayon must not to be missed!
My favourite. . Favourite temple, love the faces, lots to explore like it better than Angkor Wat, try to get a photo with you and a face nose to nose

200 faces of gods and kinds carved on stone. This temple had 200 (?) faces of gods and kings carved into the stone walls. If I'm not mistaken, this one had the most heads of Buddha, and you can take a picture "nose to nose" with one of them (our guide told us that, haha!) What I liked about the sculptures was that it had scenes depicting everyday life at the time, instead of the usual Creation stories.We also rode an elephant (I was really conflicted about this, because I'd heard of some inhumane treatment toward elephants,) and although it was such a novel experience for 15 USD, I felt sad about the 57-year old elephant afterward (even after I'd grilled it's trainer about his lifestyle.)

One of the Top 2 Temples in the Park. At the exact center of the ancient city of Angkor Thom this an amazing Buddhist temple with each tower featuring a smiling face of Buddha (seems to be in Nirvana). Reserve at least 2 hours to explore it fully. In the wet season the lakes on one side offer excellent photo vantage points.

Ancient wonderland. Huge faces are carved on all four sides of the temple towers. They have different expressions. We came as part of a tour visiting many of the different sites. It's best to have a guide to tell you about each temple. One entrance fee lets you see Angkor Wat, this site, Ta Prohm, Wat Thom... Take plenty of water. Hawkers sell drinks and souvenirs at each car park.
