Angkor Temple. Again another great experience, where it will be gone in few decades to come..Experience it while you can

Cambodia 2015. Outstanding place to visit. A must for young al old visiting Cambodia and Siem Reap. I went as part of a tour group. You will need transportation to get to the location, the tour is a walking tour throughout the area. I suggest you to hit the restrooms before you get inside, since it may take you a couple of hours before you end it. Bring your water bottle. And, after the tour, in the path back to the exit you can try the pineapple, or mango in stick offered by vendors, which was refreshing, and delicious, after the long walk.

Amazing 216 faces!. Must see in Angkor Complex beside Angkor Wat, this place will raise your curiousity to look for the 216 faces carved on the stones. We enjoyed touring around though bit tired and drained due to hot weather, so ensure to bring water and hat. If you're not into historical artifact and arts - this is not your ideal place, but I suggest to give it a try .

Nice place, but beware of plain clothes pretend-to-be tour guides. I love this place because of the sculptures and Buddha faces which are pretty unique and big. It's like walking in a maze that you need to find your own way and at the same time trying to hunt for stuffs (e.g. carvings, sculptures, nose-to-nose with a Buddha sculptures, and etc.). Before you leave the temple, do not forget to take a reflection picture of the temple beside the lake. It will look awesome!The only downside I dislike is the unlicensed pretend-to-be tour guide. Try to avoid locals who OFFER TOUR GUIDE around the temple who do not wear the "tour-guide" uniform (pinkish uniform) - normally they will just wear in plain clothes. They don't really know the history of the temple. All they know is to bring you around the temple and point to the sculptures that worth picture taking. At the end they will ask for donation. I find it is totally unworthy to pay for nothing. Please do not fall into the trap although they are kind enough to show you places to take picture. If you want to know the history of the temple, you should hire the real tour guide.
must see. Take your time to explore, there is a lot to this temple: Inner gallery, Upper terrace with some 200 faces, and the central tower and sanctuary.
Amazing. Amazing compared to the other temples ..The day i visited, one too many people around.. it was very hard to take photos.. make sure you go early in the morning
My favourite temple. This temple inside Angkor Thom was my favourite, it has a nice atmosphere that Angkor Wat doesn't have.

dipping the body into the world of the fantasy. The Bayon was built nearly 100 years after Angkor Wat. The basic structure and earliest part of the temple ate not known. Since it was located at the centre of a royal city it seems possible that the Bayon would have originally been a temple-mountain conforming to the symbolism of a microcosm of Mount Meru. The middle part of the temple was extended during the second phase of building. The Bayon of today belong to the third and last phase of the art style.The architectural scale and composition of the Bayon exude grandness in every aspects. Its elements juxtapose each other to create balance and harmony.You visit the space that is this mystery by all means, and how about dipping the body into the world of the fantasy for a while?

Wow. Unbelievable feat of engineering.. As impressive as the pyramids of Giza..
Spent around 2 hours here but could of spent a whole lot more..
Sunscreen and a hat a must
6*...

Bayon temple with Rany and Angkor wat services. Visited Bayon temple with Angkor wat services and Rany our tour guide was very professional and passionate on the history of the temple he also made sure we were shown the best spots to take photos and we did the temples in an order for times of least crowds where possible
Beautiful. Beautiful temple. A lot of people but worth spending time exploring lower and upper levels. Don't forget to bring water it is hot.

Mystery ad Magic. The enigmatic faces staring out into the surrounding forest are captivating and inspire a sense of wonder at how they were constructed and by whom. Chose a time in the early morning or late in the evening to get some tourist free periods when you can simply stand in awe at the mystery and magic of this ancient site.

Ok tour. This Temple was not as exciting as the others that we saw on this day. Still a work in progress. They are trying to restore it. This tour would be OK if you haven't been to the others before.

Stunning. Cambodia is a beautiful country and you have the change to visit definitely change your life. Is amazing place. The only thing I don't like it is all the vendors every step you do they are next to you try to offer you a souvenir. They are very persistent. The prices are not very cheap if you compare for example with Thailand. Bring a lot of water and if you need buy more, tell your guide if he can buy it for you because the stores have 2 prices one for locals and the other for tourist and the price is 1-10...
Baton temple. Better than anyone could describe, you see the photos but to stand and inside the temples and see just how wonderful the carvings are is fantastic

The Face Temple. The second stop in the first day tour is the Bayon Temple or the face temple, it is as amazing and marvelous as the main temple. And Bayon was originally built as a respect to the Buddhism unlike all the other Angkor temples was built for the Hindu gods then transferred to the Buddhism.

Explore!. This temple is one of the best we saw. You can walk through the corridors, and marvel with the changes the city went, particularly the temples. The details in the carvings are impressive, as the whole complex is full of them, take your time to appreciate the view and the work that went into developing such an amazing place.
Introduction to the Kingdom of Cambodia. Here do not need words. Here we need to see, hear and feel. There is a good Russian proverb, better to see once than hear a hundred times.
Love the Huge Funny Faces. Beautiful place seeing hundreds of these huge faces carved in stone. Checked this one off my Bucket List.

Tranquil and misterious. I've seen those smiling faces in many photos and holidays brochures, but watching them at Bayon temple was unique.... Certainly I was amazed with the carving, and the capacity to make those sculptures. Get around there with time, bring a book and relax.This place get's a lot of visitors too, and it might be a good place in the afternoon when everyone goes to the Angkor Wat for the sunset

Amazing place. It is incredible, you can walk around 54 big old buddha faces that are 2 meters tall. Beautiful natural environment with enormous trees and monkeys are giving to this temple a magic feeling. Probably the best site in Angkor area.

Amazing!!. This was the first temple we saw while in Siem Reap. It was amazing. Thankfully our guide was very knowledgeable about the temple so we learnt a lot about it as well, which made the visit even more enjoyable.

Stunning Stunning Stunning!. A Must see. Mind bending and otherworldly, you really feel like you may have step into another world. Safe to say what Angkor Wat has in scale, this has is sheer "wow!" factor!

Smiling Buddha! . The temple ruins were a sight to behold. The 30 odd smiling Buddha towers that are still standing reflect the architectural excellence of the period. We climbed up the extremely narrow steps to 'the library' that offers a nice overview of the entire place. Our camera shutters were clicking non stop and there are many niches and corners to capture beautiful shots of yourself standing next to a smiling face of Buddha or Brahma. With four faces overlooking in each direction on every tower, and given that it was Hinduism that flourishes when the temples were built, it is more likely to be Brahma. The carvings on the temple walls reflect the lives of the people then and the wars they fought. Some of the carvings show the war general blinding the enemy soldier with his spear! Another must see spot!
Amazing four face from Bayon Temple.... Have you ever seen here before? Don't miss this place you will be get more experience about our rich history and civillization...
Amazing. Beautiful surroundings! I went in a low season, so it rained a bit but there were days when there was hardly anybody there - just me and the ruins - so the experience was truly amazing!

One of my favorite temples in Siem Reap. I loved the faces - everywhere you looked there were faces - 216 in total. I also loved the photo opportunities both from within and from outside - very photogenic. Our guide showed us one particular face where if you stand just right and the photographer stands just right, it looks like you are kissing one of the huge faces that is physically very far away - very cool illusion. Some very cool opportunities for reflection photos in the water in front of the temple. Keep an eye for monkeys as they're prevalent in the area. It is very hot and humid so dress appropriately and have adequate supply of water. A must temple to visit when in the area!!

Mysterious, surreal and mesmerizing. I went to Angkor Wat in August, a lot of walking in hot weather so good shoes and plenty of water are a must. Bayon was incredible because of its mystery. There are hundreds of carved stone faces looking down at you and I couldn't really figure out what the represent- satisfaction, annoyance, sadness or happiness. It is a unique and unusal part of the AW complex- a definite must see!The temple is situated in a jungle in the Angkor Wat complex so it is quite far from the main entrance. I was cycling which is a convenient way to move around. You can also take one of many many tuk tuks available there.

Totally mesmerising!!!! . This temple has got to be one of the most spectacular temples I have ever seen. The faces on the towers are fabulous and the design so perfect. Worth visiting early to avoid the crowds and heat. The photos from the front are best from the left hand corner of the moat (as you look t it) to get the best reflections and if you are lucky you may get an elephant in the photo too!!! You must visit. It is impossible to describe. Enjoy.
Beautiful and Unique Bayon Temple. Unique must visit temple. Four fascinating faces on every pillar,drainage system and alley ways to explore.Watch your head, some low archways.

Classic face reliefs on this temple. You can see from everyone else's photos what this temple is all about.Our tuk-tuk driver dropped us at one side and collected us from the other. We spent about an hour here, including a period just sitting in the shade and soaking up the views. Not as well preserved as Angor Wat, but maybe that's part of the charm - that an about 10% of the visitor numbers too!

Unbelievable structures. It is best to include this temple at the same time as you visit Angkor Wat as you can get a day pass to a number of temples. Recommen visiting Bayon Temple in the morning when cooler.

Not to be missed, but early start required. Incredible - but get there early to avoid the crowds. We went in the middle of the day as part of a day trip around Angkor, and could hardly move for tourists. So we went back at 5.30 am, to be first in when it opened, and it was a million times better. Apart from the peace and quiet, the morning sun coming up on the heads is not-to-be-missed.

Amazing architecture. Four faced Buddha! Great thing the temples are slowly being restored to preserve the carvings and for the new generations to see and visit! Awesome view! Touching the carvings are prohibited for preservation purposes.
You Will Be Amazed. My favourite Temple in Siem, words will never explain this stunning wonder and the intricate beauty that has been created!Take your time, you will be amazed

Amazing place - Stone faced towers. One of the best temples of the Khmer architecture styles - 4 faced towers bring in the uniqueness, each having different expression. It is one of the most visited sites around
Under construction when we visited. Very lovely. Construction was going on out the front. More relaxed than Angkor Wat, but still beautiful.

Ruins of a plundered beauty. Probably the least 'rebuilt' of all the ruins in the area. Still very charming and beautiful. Pay close attention to the walls and how the blocks are put together to appreciate the intricacy of the work here. Although, pretty much everyone starts their tour here so you will probably end up here when all the tourists with their selfie sticks in random directions are blocking your view. Try going early morning to beat the rush. Or else, the main temple level gets jam-packed and people posing for photographs will delay your stay here even if you are trying to explore the carvings, etc. But a must see spot nonetheless

Moss covered temple with Buddha faces on 4 directions. Unlike Angkor Wat, that need 15 good minutes to walk inside from the gate, Bayon Temple is near the main road. Most of the stones covered in moss which enhanced ancient look of this temple.
Serenity!. Walk around, touch every stone & look and admire every piece than sit down close your eyes let's the environment take you to 18th century! The best peaceful feeling ever!

Must do while in Cambodia. Excellent place to visit and must do while in Cambodia. I know Cambodia is remembered mostly by pol pot however Angkor wat is slowly starting to get the tourists in and so it should.

Mystical and Beautiful. Each Temple in the Angkor Wat area has it's distinct character. This one is full of magnificent, huge heads that are sculpted in the rock. It is mystical and scenic and a must see.

My favourite temple. Something about Bayon Temple was very different to the others we had seen such as Angkor Wat and the Royal Palace. The faces carved into the stone were amazing and each one had a particular expression like the face of compassion. We didn't have a guide or guide book but I would have loved to learn more about the temple; recommend bringing one. The stones were mottled grey, black and green giving Bayon a beautiful appearance. If you're visiting Angkor Wat it's definitely worth going to see Bayon and the rest of Angkor Thom as well.
Smiling Faces. The Smiling Faces on the Towers were most fascinating. A True Marvel constructed some 1,000 years ago. Definitely worth a visit
best temple in siem reap. This is the coolest temple I saw in my visit to Siem Reap, and the highlight of Angkor Thom. All the 'tops' of the template have various heads which give it an eerie feel.
Amazing little wonder. Must visit; it was even better than Angkor Wat in some aspects. Get a local tour guide (won't cost much) and try to be there as early as you can to avoid crowd and heat.

Mighty Faces. Here you will see hundreds odd similar faces. These are made of sculpted small stones arranged one over the other to make a face. All these faces almost look the same. Unfortunately, lot of them are damaged and vandalised. You can spend hours together to going through these ancient sculptures. There are structures which a re arranged in multiples. A MUST VISIT PLACE.
Grand Ancient Temple. A place full of Bodhisatva carvings and statues. A must see in Siem Reap. You will get the best out of this if accompanied by a recognized guide.
A must see temple. its a must see temple in siem reap, better to go in early day or evening. as there is no shade around to beat the sun. a lot of nice place to take some good hdr photo.

The Smile of The Khmer. The happiest temple I have ever seen where you can see all the smiling buddha faces here. The smile looks clearer under the hot sun in noon. The peak hours is in noon. Many tourists will be up there and taking a nice photo might be tough as tourists are everywhere.

A must see.. A must see if visiting cambodia. Organised through sofitel angkor. Great guide and driver. Make sure your camera is charged and has plenty of memory for all the great photos you will take.
Bayon temple . Amazing. The walled royal city is the home of bayon temple with its huge stone faces and incredible carvings
Don't miss this. Amongst the many other sites in the area to visit, don't miss this one to get a real feel for the place.

The Bayon Temple. An amazing temple with so many statues it is impossible to count how many there were. Everyone of them is so intricately carved, so majestic it makes any tourist feel a sense of awe.

Nose to Nose. Dont miss the place when you climb up, where if you stand in a special way, it will look like your nose is touching the nose of the statue that is perched 20 feet above and 20 -30 feet tall. I loved the smiling giant statue. Reminded me of Cambodia a s whole. The land of smiles, everyone is greeting you with one!

A beautiful, compact jewel in a jungle of green. This was relatively small but still needs a good 2 hours. We walked through the middle and then back around the outside anticlockwise. Was extraordinary, the way the jungle has wrapped its tentacles around this site and is trying to pull it down into a sea of green is amazing.

A unique face masterpiece. It's a unique face temple with face of the lord in all directions.Though only few faces are clear and distinct to.identify.You can relax on the top of the Temple with nice breeze flowing near sunset time.
Amazing but busy. Absolutely beautiful, but unfortunately quite busy. I reached around noon after sunrise, ta prohm and other temples.

Smiles to lighten up your Angkor temple visits. Just seeing the smiling faces of the tower gives Bayon temple an entirely different tone. I can't help but smile as well. A must-see in Siem Reap. I just loved exploring the insides of the temple.

Absolutely marvelous . . . don't miss Angkor Thom and Bayon Temple.. Really fantastic doable Temple in a series at Angkor Thom, which unlike Angkor Wat, was an enclosed royal city. The many enigmatic stone faced temple, based on lotus flower design, was powerful, moving, and one of the highlights of this series of temples.

Superb. Favorite temple among many travellers, it is indeed a wonderful place to visit. Although most of the temples are quite unique (at least seeing the most important ones through small and grand circuits), Bayon has a special flavor given by the four-headed smiling faces towers everywhere. Just by walking through them gives you a very peculiar feeling of the greatness of the accomplishment there. If you were able to go to the museum before and enriched yourself with some information, so much the better. Otherwise, stroll around this majestic temple and just enjoy it.

best experience in bayon temples. love the environment inside the temple. the famous temple afta angjor wat n ta phrom. when u enter the temple..just showed ur 1day tour pass to the guard. weather was good yet gloomy n raining.

Wonders of the World. All the temples we visited in Angkor were amazing. The carvings at Bayon were intricate and detailed. Have visited twice now and although I had my 4 children in tow this time and we chose one of the hottest days to do the temples, they too enjoyed our time visiting this ancient ruin.

Temple with diverse heritage. You need a well versed tour guide to explain the carvings on the walls. They tell a story and if you're familiar with Cambodian/Khmer history as well as India, China and Siam; that will help. Of course the Mahabharata leaves an imprint. Be sure to read up ahead so that it all makes sense. Needless to say, it was overcrowded for some good reason on the day we were there. Cameras were clicking and people were posing all over the place. We had to wait to click some good shots in the popular designations. What surprised me was the fact that it was supposed to be ancient ruins but we spotted blocks of building materials being assembled. The local markets too had artefacts that looked a ancient. Authenticity has to be verified here; unlike Angkor Wat. A hat is advised to shield you from the brunt of the sun. Dress code is what you decide. The local girls dress rather conservatively and are soft spoken. The men are almost always polite and helpful. However, the onus is on you to be vigilant at all times with your belongings. Cambodian boasts of low violent crime rates. This temple is inactive with perhaps one or two places with active shrines. You may want to get blessings from the Buddhist priest or bypass this altogether. The atmosphere is one of a tourist spot rather than a place of worship. Cambodia thrives on tourism and the government takes the initiative to maintain good washrooms and cleanliness almost everywhere- give and take the agricultural mentality of the heart of Cambodia.
Holiday. A great experience and a must-do if you are visiting Cambodia, we thoroughly enjoyed the visit and highly recommend it to others.
Beauty !. The most amazing of all ... Highlight of the day !! Got lucky to be there by quiet time .. It is crazy to see all those buddha faces, what a work done thousand years ago ...

Amazing.... This temple was packed when I went this time, which made it noisy and difficult to take good photos without heads in the way...so maybe go early in the day.As with all the temples in the area there are many many photo opportunities

Bayon Temple. This is the main temple in Angkor Thom. The carvings on the first level are far more detailed than those of Angkor Wat and the carvings of everyday life in the Khmer kingdom are insightful.
Ancient temple. My favourite temple amongst many at the Angkor wat complex. The many smiling faces promised many blessings.
go early. great temple but really early or really late is best to avoid the crowds. nice views from the sides away from the main temple

A place of wonder. I have now visited this site twice. The last time in December 2014. I am going back in December this year. Three visits over the top? I suggest not. There is always something new to discover. You cannot in this wonderful place in in one go. The ticketing system for the Angkor site allows flexibility to enable more than one visit. It is stunning. I had always thought of "ruins" as boring but this has changed my mind. Stunning, beautiful, amazing. Go

Another temple. This is quite a big temple. I prefer the other two, personally. However, the entrance seemed inviting and we decided to pay a visit. There are 4 gates, east, west, north, south. Some gates are not so nice anymore because the statues are ruined/ broken. Conservation and restoration work was going on here, even for other temples. There's not much shade and it can be very hot on sunny days. It's more interesting if you know its history.
Bayon - a historic discovery. This is really really ancient and have survive time immemorial. This is a good discovery and for any visitor to envisage the greatness of mankind in ancient days.
amazing. probably our all round favourite temple complex.. the faces are just amazing- it really mustnt be missed
Amazing!!. One-of- a kind in the world! It seems impossible they had the knowledge to build such a wonderful temples in the middle of the jungle.

Unbelievable!. The baton temple is in my opinion the most impressive of the temples in siem reap! The sheer size and detail of this temple has to be seen to be believed! It is certainly a must see when in Cambodia!

Top choice of temples. The most unique temple in my opinion! Watch the carvings on the wall closely as you can discover great detail of the Khmer lifestyle during King Jayavaman VII's reign. Wherever you stand in the temple, you are surrounded by towers with face carvings. Stunning!

Just Do It. I managed to get all the temples in on a four day flying visit to Cambodia with Wendy Wu Tours. Wonderful, if you have the chance to do it, just do it. It was on my bucket list and now that is ticket off. I would love to come back and do them at my own pace but truely awe inspiring.
its amazing. one of the great temple in angkor wat..so many relief and statue that so artistic..you cant miss this part.

Amazing. This place is so amazing... I really love this! You will enjoy the beauty of the scenery. You'll be amazed that there is such a kind of place. You will imagined how they did come up to this. I'll surely recommend this and I will definitely back here. You will really emjoy the nostalgic of this place.

Wonderful faces to photograph. It was wonderful to revisit Bayon aftera 9 year absence.....better than we remembered although much busier. For any keen photographer it is a must see....take your time to look for the best vantage points looking also for the unusual. Some stairs to negotiate.

Take the time, be patienct and soak it in.. This temple is particular is worth getting a great explanation for. There are 54 faces. When the region shifted from Buddhism back to Hinduism, the initial reaction was to deface them - later they recast it as a Hindu god. Astounding
Grand and Magical !. Our guide Mean Chanra almost made us visualize the history ! This is grand ! A must visit place if you love history and can see beyond broken old structures.

Interesting temple with the striking facess carved in stone. Interesting temple with the Bodhisattva faces carved on its towers. Visited it in the afternoon after visiting the Angkor Wat in the morning. Though a bit hot and humid, the experience was worth it.

Nice place. Good place to visit and know about Hindu god shiva.
Government need to take care of the place very well it's too old and need good maintenance beautiful and very nicely buildup can't imaging thousands of years ago without any technology how nice and perfectly designed buildings are there...!!
Heads heads heads. I always tiught of Angkor wat as the mother of all temples, but somehow I liked this better. With all it faces. It is a diffent and special temple. Do not miss it ehen visiting :)

a must, the most beatiful building in Angkor complex. Probably the most beautiful and interesting part of the Angkor grounds. This used to be a palace and it is decorated with heads of Buddha (who incidentally looks a lot like the king, who build the place).Best to come during lunch hour, when there are fewere people, it is much nicer to explore then and take pictures. A must, even if You have just once day.
Another amazing temple.. An amazing temple, a sight to behold. Make sure you have your cameras at the ready because you will need it to photograph the intricacies in the stone.

Must-see temple in Siem Reap. This is one of the great temple visits in the Siem Reap area - not to be missed. Multiple fantastic carved head portraits of one of the ancient kings that have served as a model for later Buddha images.

A must see. Ausume these big faces in the temples were placed here with elephants helping & pully systems what hard work it must have been for the Cambodians that helped build this temple. Our guide told us they placed all the stones there first then went about chiseling all the faces out. Definitely amazing our guide also told us it took 38 years to build all the temples. ..

My favorite of the major stops around Angkor Wat. Bayon is a breathtaking remnant of the ancient Khmer empire, with its many four-faced statues. Feels like an Indiana Jones set (and in some ways cooler than Lara Croft's Ta Prohm) and fun to explore. A good guide, like my regular tuk-tuk guy Phoen, makes it even better.Offers a dazzling number of photo opportunities. Not to be missed.

Mesmerizing!. I found Bayon temple to be more mesmserizing than the Angkor Wat. Those faces carved in stone carry what a magical smile... Do not miss this site!An excellent opportunity for photography. For better light, go there around 4:30pm when the light is softer and try HDR photography if the sky is cloudy.

I've of the best. Take a guide.. This temple is fascinating and really beautified it was not as crowded as the other big temples. THe engineering is fascinating and it is worth having a guide if you can afford one.

Bayon won over Angkor Wat for me. So so beautiful! The structures of 4 faces were lovely, wished i could have gotten a tour guide to understand it more, but i got myself a book to learn more about it.Do take your time to roam about Bayon, it is amazing! Do not miss this if you are visiting the Angkor Archaeology Park.Again, you would need a pass for this20USD for 1 day40 USD for 3 days passRemember:- Pants/ skirts over the knees- no sleeveless outfits- bring a cap/ umbrella- be careful where you walk (the ground is uneven)- drink LOTS of water

400 faces. What a wonder to see all the faces. So fascinating. 400 faces and none are the same. This temple opens early. Go here one morning for a different sunrise pic. That's what I plant to do next time.

Stop By Despite the Heat. There are many temples in Siem Reap and they are all interesting. The Bayon Temple may pale in comparison to the huge Angkor Wat but the Bayon Temple has its own charm and unique characteristics that makes it worth stopping by for a visit despite the heat.

My favourite in Angkor Park. Bayon is a standout in an incredible area renowned for the quality of its temples and ruins. The reason is simple: its hundreds of mystical faces staring out across the green landscape. You won't see this anywhere else, and its haunting beauty and timeless power will stay with you. A definite must.
Bayon is my fave. Bayon is my favorite temple because1. it is easy to get around and see2. the 4 faced stupas3. the small overall size4. the most unique in the Angkor areaBut beware the crowds

The temple of smiles ;). A short drive from Angkor Wat is the imposing Angkor Thom complex. Built by a different king some 70 years after the construction of Angkor Wat, it houses several temples - the most notable of which is Bayon Temple, located right at the center.Smiling Buddhas are found on all 4-sides of each pagoda or tower. There are numerous pagodas across Bayon Temple and a central tower located in the center.Another recommended temple within the cluster of Angkor World Heritage sites to visit during your trip to Siem Reap!

Temple with faces. It was nice to visit. The temple is very unique with all the faces on the very top. It has many spots for good photos. Unfortunately when i was there, there're some sort of diplomatic guest who concquered all the place on top with guides and some security members. I coulnd't really enjoy the sacredness of the temple because of the crowds.
amazing!. Love this temple so much, unique craving, smiling Buddha face around make me feel so peaceful, wish to visit again in future....
Wonderful place to visit.. Lot of history... amazing stories.... beautiful carvings. For people who like to visit old places...ruins... this is one place you should surely visit.
atmospheric. Well worth a long visit, take water, good walking shoes as you won't want to stop exploring and simply sitting queitly imbuing the atmosphere.
Don't miss it. Amazing and extensive. Don't miss this when you are visiting the temples. There are few people exploring and you have a sense of discovering the place yourself.

Amazing. The most beautiful structure within the Angkor complex with beautiful wall carvings throughout. Definitely send me goosebumps with its magnificient beauty yet the smiles on each faces gives calmess and tranquility.
Everyone loves this temple.. Everyone loves this temple wandering around all the faces. Go early because it gets too crowded later in the day!!

Highly recommend. I visited during the hottest part of the day but was able to walk around and explore a bit and took some amazing pictures. I recommend bringing an umbrella and water, if you come during the noon hour. The best part was that I did not have to pay to any temple visit since I was born in Cambodia and I just had to show them my passport. Yay! Walked around and explored on my own the beauty of this temple that's been around for ages. There's still visible carvings and the Buddha faces are well maintained. I had a driver that took my friends and I around to the temples but did not get a guide. I recommend a guide so that you can learn about the history of this place because you can spend a lot of time here, if you wanted to.

Awesome!. The Bayon Temple, inside Angkor Thom is really astonishing. The faces create a mystical, almost creepy feeling that really intrigues you. I felt as though I really gained insight into the people who once inhabited this great site. The work that is being done to preserve it, is also very well done.
The elephant ride. I will never forget the elephant trekking around the impressive Bayon Khmer Temple. Our guide, Mr. John was really helpful and the mahout funny and entertaining the elephant.

Majestic Bayon. The first in the circle of temples we met and for me the best. Full of atmosphere majesty, it is definitely worth the visit and the money. Perhaps visit the temples over three days to really savour the visit and the relics.

Monkeys!!!. Beat part about this temple were the many monkeys surrounding it running about. They were quite happy for me to get within 30cm of them for pictures. Great selfie. Seen other people feeding them and giving them bottles of juice which they seemed to enjoy. The temple itself was great. Nice view from the top and the giant faces were good to look at.

Best in the coolest part of the day. So many photo opps! There are a ton of buddha faces. I would have enjoyed it more in the morning as there isn't a lot of shade and we were there in the hottest part of the day. Make sure you're there when there aren't many tourists. It definitely impacts the experience. The tour guides know best but I would think first thing in the morning would be safe.

Definitily worth a visit. All the temples are worth a visit. i just felt like if i was in a scene of a indiana jones film . Buy the ticket for 3 days ( 40 us dolars ). Hire in advance a tuk tuk driver for 2 or 3 days ( depending on how much time you want to spend in the temples complex ) so that you move from one spot to the other at your own pace and convenience because if you´re travelling during the summer believe me you will feel knackered . we got our driver arranged by our hotel for 2 days for 20 us dollars.

Go early. We went early after watching sunrise at angkor wat and before the crowd. The temple is well preserved in most places with Budda faces visible on the walls. The carvings on the pillars are interesting.

Worth a look. Really interesting... very different type of temple for angkor wat but a lot smaller. Beware of people trying to be your tour guide. Unless you would like a tour guide.Try to do it before midday so it's not too hot.

Bayon is my favourite. Bayon is gorgeous. There are so much to do and see inside of the Bayon temples. Getting a guide would make the stories so much more interesting. Some construction work is going on to restore the temple, but it's not very loud and disturbing. One thing to be cautious about: the unagreed guide. If a Cambodian comes up to you and start explaining about the history, please be wary. There is definitely no free lunch in the world. Try to have an agreed price with him or if you don't need a guide, just reject him. However, some of these guides are very knowledgable, albeit a little difficult to understand with the Cambodian accent. I enjoyed the experience with the guide I had as he was knowledgable and patient with my silly questions. I didn't know that he was charging, so by the end of the guide, he just ask me to tip him with whatever amount.

Smiling Buddha Temple. Bayon Temple was very impressive as it housed so many people back in the day and the temple itself is wonderful to visit and see the history. Certainly worth spending 2 hours looking at the carvings and architecture.

Terrific temple!. Amazing - my daughter loved this temple more than any other of the angkor wat complex. Elephant ride round the temple a real highlight! Brilliant for climbing steep steps and clambering around.,
Only lucky people will have opportunity to visit.. Difficult or impossible to imagine how this beautiful temple was constructed with out the support of the technology support.
BAYON = BOSS!. The highlight of my day by far. Not since Petra has my mind been blown like this. A truely magnificent structure!!

Temple with the smiley faces!. I was here last August 29 with my girlfriend and tour guide Mr. Lonh! The view was really nice but when we got here, it was so crowded. So I didn't enjoy it as much as the other temples. But the views were amazing! Don't miss this place when you're in Siem Reap!
54 faces. Bayon is colated in siem reap inside the Angkor Thom area, after our visit Angkor Wat i am here angkor thom is one of the big temple in siem reap Cambodia. dont missed.
huge smiling faces. stunning temple area, featuring huge smiling faces. A must see as part of a tour of the Angkor Wat temple complex
great experience. be prepared to walk and climb some stairs to to top ear you can take pics with the four face statues... wear proper shoes for lots of walking

Four faced Buddhas. There is hardly a place where you cannot find the four sides Budha faces. Who conceived it? How did they make it - so many faces of so many different sizes! And so many of them are still standing strong unaffected by time and weather.

Bright ideas place. This is a world heritage site is not to be missed. Its the only place in all the temples that you will visit in Anchor with face sculpture in the rock. Those buddha faces are great and you really feel how special this place is by being there. Have some water and get ready to climb some steps, it might be a good idea to a massage after to get all the lactic acid lout of your body.

Don't miss this temple. This temple is very iconic and beautiful. I spent a long time admiring its architecture and design.. if you can only visit a few temples in the park.. you definitely shouldn't miss this one

A very special temple in Siem Reap. This temple is not as well conserved as others but it has something special. It is sad to see how so much has been destroyed by religious disputes but it is indeed a lesson of mistakes we shouldn't repeat.
Special Place. The world heritage that the best of the world. You should not believe whom if you still not go there which see by yourself

Not to be missed !. Within the archeological complex of Angkor Thom this temple is, rightly so, one of the most famous. Not to be missed because of the fascination of the Buddha faces present on all the walls of the temples.
Temples to not miss.. This was one of our favourite temples. It is the temple with the faces. If you were going to just see a few temples then this one is not to be missed.
Worth doing, but prepare for a long day out.. Stunning, but be prepared for a good long walk as they are huge and very spread out. A must for all is the Elephant Ride!!

Steals The Show. Travelling to Cambodia and Siem Reap fulifilled a dream that seemed almost surreal when actually there. I had always imagined that the wonders of Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm would undoubtedly shape the enduring images and memories that I would take away with me. That these two temples would be the most memorable seemed almost inevitable. Bayon snuck in through the back door and stole the show.
Very accessible. Great - very accessible. Great climbing if you have kids - lots of fun. Ride the elephants from the entramce to the Bayon
over 200 faces. hard to believe but the 200 some faces were not boring, in fact the lighting and setting gave many of them a distinctive and different feeling --enjoyed more than Angkor Watt
Excellent English Speaking Tour Guide. Highly recommend Mr Panha as private tour guide if your intend to visit Angkor Wat -Siem Reap. His h/p contact +85581438199

Easy to navigate, hard to forget. If time is limited, do make this one of the temples a must-see. Its square configuration on just a few levels, this gives a great insight into the many faces set in greenery to intricate frescos carefully restored and gorgeous windows to frame your memories. Be warned there is a steep ladder up to the highest level. Just remember to bring a compass to check which direction to exit as they all look similar. Stunning sight

The Most Beautiful Temple In The World, PERIOD........ This is my favorite temple. Myself and my fiancée both agree that this is the magic temple of Siem Reap, Cambodia. It is just amazing how they could have carved all those images in the stone, so perfectly without the technology we have now. It is truly a surreal experience to have been their and see first hand the beauty of the Bayon Temple.......All I can say is we fell in love with Cambodia.......
Stunning!. Beautiful place, a must see when you are in Cambodia. Lots of stairs and walking around, have few hours to explore the area.
Fab Temple (but busy). This temple is quite compact and, unfortunately, very busy. Having said that, its interesting and has some fantastic carvings.
Must Bayon!. Amazing wonder of architecture. But I am hoping that in future there will be voice guided tours for better understanding.
Must do of temples!. Very interesting - the best of the temples! Easy to get around and lots to look at - a must on your list of temples

Amazing architecture. It was a fantastic site, full of complete, partially reconstructed, and remaining pieces of the Bayon Temple. The multi-faced towers were incredible, as was the view...you can't help but feel like you're an explorer discovering it for the first time... Not to be missed!
my second favourite. Get lost in this monument maze. The colors and the faces are hypnotic. Enjoy going up and down. Go early in the morning to avoid crowd

Face it. This is an amazing place - the temple is absolutely outstanding and in great condition. Try and see it when it is a bit quieter so you can enjoy the ambience and significance of these ruins in the middle of the Khmer empire.

Beautiful Temple with renovations underway. This temple is near the forest where many monkeys live. This was one of the few places I saw the monkeys. What was really nice is there are still some large statues inside the temple. Many of the temples have had them removed to museums. They are currently working on renovating or rebuilding parts of this place so you can see what they have to do to reconstruct it. Without a guide or a guidebook it is hard to tell the difference from other temples, but they are all a little different.

Amazing site, what an experience!. This is a site that travelers should not miss in Siem Reap. The huge wall faces was spectacular and gave a spiritual vibe even to non-Hindu and Buddhist like myself. It's great that they were able to preserve this world heritage site because the new generation can appreciate its splendor.

Well worth a visit. This temple was fantastic we visited all the main temples in Angkor and they were all amazing. We had a guide whose knowledge was unbelievable and he told us so many interesting facts about this wonderful area. Lots of brilliant photo opportunities here again. Gets very busy as do all of the most popular temples.
Amazing. This was my favourite temple at the Angkor complex. The stone heads are so impressive because of their detail and size! Can hardly imagine how they must've built it.
Our favourite temple!. We just loved this temple! It's so impressive and also a fair bit quieter than some of the other temples so it was nicer to roam around. A must-visit!

Four face Temple - Stunningly beautiful, mesmerising!. What a magnificent temple, with it's four face Buddha towers, all 54 of them apparently, I didn't count them. I found this temple mesmerising as where ever you looked the Buddha smiling faces seemed to be looking right back at you.You could spend all day taking pictures from various angles and different positions within the temple and walk away with some amazing pictures. It's very hot walking around this site in the midday sun, take plenty of water and sunscreen. Be careful when walking around this temple many uneven surfaces, steps, rocks to avoid. This temple certainly gives Angkor Wat a run for it's money. I think this temple is more captivating because of the many smiling Buddha faces and such a stunning piece of work. How on earth did they built this temple all those years ago is beyond me. A must see whilst in Cambodia, I totally understand why this is a world heritage site and one of the top tourists site in the world, definitely warrants that status.

Crowded, but worth it - bring water and sunscreen!. Bayon Temple is remarkable... it's hard to believe how long these temples have been around. This being said, it's a busy attraction. Bring sufficient water and sunscreen to prevent heat stroke.

Unbelievable...theres nothing like in around the world. Some of the most impressive and extend temple complex. The figures and the surroundings are gorgeous. The only down part, just in my personal opinion, they offer some elephant rides, but they have injuries and look so sad....personally , they are beautiful but not well maintained. I didn´t want to promote the poor elephants to be hurt

Spectacular - A must see. We visited the Bayon temple with our guide Pheat Sinath from hanuman Travel and this I think out of all the temples is my favourite, it is stunningly detailed and utterly unbelievable that people could create this temple so long ago, there must be hundreds if not thousands of faces of Jay 7 in this temple and all of them hand carved are almost identical I would have gladly wandered around here all day.Our guide was fantastic and truly knowledgeable even knowing the best parts of the temple to go to to get the best photo.A truly wonderful temple shown to us by a truly wonderful guide.
Amazing Crafts!. This is a different type of temple.I was amazed by the crafted pictures on it's walls.Hope that the fixing can make it more beautiful.
breathtaking !. again lucky to have been there on a day when NOT noisy and hectic tour Group tourists invade the place and spit on the floor as they do at home... grrrr
Interesting temples. 1 of the more interesting temples with 4 face Buddha. There are 54 towers as there were 54 provinces before. Now in Cambodia there are only 34 provinces.
Nice temple. Four face temple , i been here many time in my life but i feel i still love and want to go there again and again . we can take a lovely photo here too

Beautiful and Stunning. A must see, this whole area is pretty spectacular! Evening photography is magnificent. There are several temples to visit....see them either early morning or late evening around sunset.

Awesome!!. This magnificent temple features giant buddha faces and the history behind its architecture is simply awesome. Always listen to your tour guide! Prepare yourself to tons of photos for it would be sad if you didn't bring any cameras so they should handy all the time. Also prepare to get burned so bring your sunscreen!

Must visit. Bayon Temple is really beautiful and a highly recommended place to visit.
I can spend the whole day taking a picture and looking at the Buddha faces.

Bayon and Angkor Thom easily rival Angkor Wat for spendor.. How could human beings of so long ago create these monuments? It boggles the imagination. Get to the highest points that your health allows, to take it all in.

Look in the past. My Favourite of all the temples to visit, the elephant ride around the time to explore and see the past history today is truly amazing and think that it will be here long after I am gone is a testament to the late Khmer empire

Extraordinary . This place will blow your mind! You can use a guide, if you don't have one people at the temples will offer to take you on a tour for a donation. If your into history would recommend a guide. We didn't do a tour, instead went through at our own pace and flicked through the guide book we had purchased when we arrived (payed $8usd, you could bargain way harder if you wanted to, but hey its their living!) Plan to spend least an hour here if not 2.

The four faces. Amazing, no wonder it's world heretige listed and one of the top tourist attractions in the world. There are a lot of steps to get to the very top so remember this as it's also very hot.
Bayon Temple. Bayon Temple is really beautiful and a highly recommended to visit this those 4 face Buddha head are really a must see
My favorite temple. There are 54 faces of the Buddha carved in massive lotus bud towers that will leave you awestruck. In addition, the story carvings on the walls are spectacular.

Incredible. This is the temple with all the faces on it. It's a great experience. Nearby there were monkeys as well, and our tuk-tuk pulled over and we were able to feed them, which was fun. This temple is included in the $20 USD fee to visit Angkor Wat and the other temples on the grounds.

One of my favorite temples in Siem Reap. We made this temple one of the first stops before the crowds came. It was a great idea to explore the grounds while it was early morning. The stone faces are a magnificent sight from the entrance but are even better when you climb up the stairs to get up close.

The Faces the Amazing temple. How could they build bayon? I don't believe is that amazing until i am here. I really have no idea how they can build this temple. It was so amazing and i can't describe my feeling at all.

Temple a Shrine to Buddha. Khmer Stone temple partially in ruins, incredible construction. Take a photo 'touching noses' with one of the many faces of the Buddha. Very hot in the wet season, carrying water is a must.

The temple with all the faces. Such an amazing place... One of the best sights in Siem Reap!
You can really feel all the history when passing all of the faces in the temple !
Hypnotic. Go around 5 PM to explore the inside and around 6PM to meditate with the loudest, most mesmerising crickets singing.
FABULOUS.. Amazing historical ruins, gradually being restored and the age is stunning. But unless you are fairly fit and not overweight, this site can be quite arduous.

Absolutely loved this templ with the 4 sided smiling faces!. This is a must see for sure. I think I enjoyed it more than Angkor Wat for the unique 4 sided columns with smiling faces. It was unreal and magical.
Those Buddha faces!!!!!. You get there and you can hardly see them... and then you climb the steps and you start to see one, then two, then three, then four, ....... pure magic.

Ban the selfie-sticks, please...... The centerpiece of Angkor Thom, a truly amazing temple. The giant heads are amazing. Very crowded the day I went with lots and lots of tour bus visitors. Aside from the crowds and hundreds of selfie-sticks, very enjoyable.

Go when its quiet. My favorite of the temples we visited I went twice,but go when you can appreciate the carvings at a slow place,and a guide really helps to point out the details 7am was great quiet and not yet too hot

A temple of many faces. I was amazed that almost every part of the temple is where you can see the face on the stones. A lot of corridors and rooms and a lot of people.
To know more of our trip, visit my blog at http://katmeifucan.blogspot.com/2015/08/sunrise-at-angkor-wat-complex.html

A might place to visit. It is really amazing to see Bayon Temple and the architecture of the old times Khmer people. You can make a visit of 3 to 5 temples only in one day as there are a lot of interest part and story to learn.
A must see. Amazing to see how your perspective on this temple changes the higher up you go. What looks like a pile of rocks from far away gradually becomes hundreds of beatific faces. Incredible.

Beautiful and amazing temple!. I was blown away upon seeing the amazing Bayon Temple. It was surreal to see those beautifully carved faces on the temple. It was extremely hot on the day we visited Bayon. We rode the elephant on our way there to add to the experience. Bayon is definitely one of my favorite temples. It was truly an experience to remember.
Must visit. This is an amazing temple and our favorite. We really enjoyed climbing all the steep stairs. Best to go there early morning to avoid the crowds.

My favorite.. Absolutely stunning temple. Pictures here are phenomenal. It is a must see - just make sure to stay hydrated. There is work currently being done on this temple, but hopefully that will end sooner than later.
Love the structure. Love the structure. The carving was stll quite visible. Prepare to climb and you can rest on the way.

Forest of Smiling Faces and Excellent Bas Relief. Amiable smiling faces left on my mind. There we walked between mountains of face towers, each with one smiling face on one direction. And they are all different.On the lower ground you can see many many beautiful bas relief describing daily life and war. Hmm, war is a major theme all over places. But the figures here are more cute and sweet.http://hkindependent-traveller-croatia.blogspot.hk/2015/01/bayon.html

Bayon classic touch of Angkor. Quite alot numbers of images architect in this temple, but climb up stairs bit scary as so steep and small path. Khmer architecture, as contrasted with the classical style of Angkor Wat
Kiss Buddha. Not the best kept, and not the most atmospheric of Angkor temples by a country mile. Go just to take the "kissing Buddha" photo anyway.
Worth a visit. Nice, words and photos cannot describe. need to see for yourself the actual site. Unfortunately a couple of sections had collapsed.
Great temple!. Beauitful temple, visited this in the early morning to make some great shots when no one is around. These turned out great with the rising sun and beautiful faces on the temple.

Amazing Temple. Traveling to Bayon Temple is impressive and beautiful as it was. I was awed at the first sight of this temple with a "thousand" faces. The quality of the work on this temple is superb and we loved exploring the place since it was not as crowded.
Bayon Temple. The temples in Siem Reap are truly fascinating. You can clearly see the faces the sides of the temple.

Do not miss the Bayon. Do not miss the Bayon!Whatever time you go there will be the world ... so you have to accept it (be zen). See/examine the reliefs without being pushed, it is impossible, this being is war and famous Khmer warriors are brave; I like the crocodile grabs an evil man...Apart from that, a king, a few men in prayer but they are rare.Climb, you will not regret it.And take time there.
Unique . Even after two days of exploring the temples, the many-faced Bayon offered something new. It's 'personality' is unique and exploring the maze of passages is fantastic. A must see.
Mysterious temple. The temple has lot of face sculptures with a mysterious smile. Feel lost in the old kingdom with ancient architecture and atmosphere.

Witness of the past. I loved to visit that temple and the stone faces are very inspiring. I recommend to see this place in the early morning, than it is less crowded and hot. You can almost enjoy the special atmosphere in total tranquility if you make it as an early bird. Make sure you bought the ticket before at the ticket station.

Great spot for photos. Bayon is a temple representing of living together between Buddhism and Hedonism, if you clam up, you will find a great spot of for photo taking which your face can be seen directly to the Budhha face as well.

Atmospheric and incredible.. This was one of my favourites, although extremely hard to choose between them as they are all so different. The heads make for an imposing atmosphere and I loved the twisty turny passages inside.
Amazing Temple. Amazing Temple with its face sculptures. One of my favourites of all the temples in Siem Reap. Would recommend you have this temple on your to visit list.

Visit for sunrise. Visit at sunrise while the maddening crowds are in Angkor Wat you can survey the ruin in total tranquility. The sunrise will not be visible but you'll likely be alone with only the sound of the birds in this haunting ruin.

Awe inspiring epiphany. This was the most amazing architectural wonder to experience. Everywhere you looked was an epiphany, awe inspiring and unforgettable. By the end of the day my body ached with exhaustion both mental and physical. A very enriching experience well worth the adventure.
AMAZING. Just one word AMAZING, This beautiful temple complex will leave you breathless, there are no word that can describe the beauty and the atmosphere of this magical place.
Must See. I think the architecture was so advance and modern for the time frame that they were built in. A must visit place in Cambodia
Many Faces. Really interesting place, loved the many faces around the temple, if your in Siem Reap this is a must visit

Best in my Trip in Siem Reap. All the temples i saw in my full 3 days vacation in Siem Reap Bayon temple is a temple i more like than other we visit. We had nice pictures with this temple especially our guide took our pictures kissing Buddha face like other tourist made and posted on worldwide this is what we expected before we come for our vacation in Cambodia.Very high recommend this temple.

Stunning. Probably my favourite amongs the Angkor temples. Built late in the 12th century, the towers with massive Buddha faces on each side are imposing and stunning. Our trip that day wasn't meant to stop for this temple but the Tuk Tuk driver unexpectedly took us there. As we approached, I was blown away by its beauty. It's a must see!

The temple with a thousand faces. The first thing I noticed of Bayon temple are the faces. Almost everywhere I looked, there was this face, big and small. From the outside, the temple looks so majestic. I wondered how glorious it was before.Bayon Temple is smaller than Angkor Wat. I could see that they did try to restore the temple back to its former glory, and I must say, they did a great job. Upon entering the temple, I kind of got scared because the stairs are so steep, and the landings are quite narrow. I had to face sideways to avoid slipping.Again, for some reason there were parts of the temple that smelled like someone peed. There were also some tourists who climbed off-limits area and looked like they don't care as long as they were able to take pictures.

The most magical of them all!. Okay, the many faces looking down at you at Bayon Temple are very nice, too. But as one tends to know them already from those t-shirts and postcards, they eventually did not cause this feeling of visiting something really special.But what made this place truly outstanding to me were the interior small rooms at the top filled with a Buddha statute and magical light effects coming from the smoke of the incense sticks and the chimney-like structure with bats flying through the sun rays coming in from a small hole at the top. Although I am not the spiritual type of person, I found this very very SPECIAL. Just wondered when Dr Jones would walk around the corner.

The best. Wow, amazing view . Wow, I really like it. A super place to visit, strongly recommended . Second time there and I will go again. Just looking at it, you really feel the history, a majestic location

My favourite Temple in Siem Reap. What a wonderful place......go and enjoy all the carvings, especially the huge heads........ please stay to where you are allowed, clear signs tell you. Perfect to spend an hour or two just marvelling at how these beautiful carvings have lasted in such a wonderful condition.
Best experience from Angkor.. For me was Bayon more intenzive then the main Angkor Wat temple. Amazing, great, big, not so crowdy.
Lovely temple. Another wonderful temple, popular with tourist and worth visiting. Use walking shoes and take water with you plus a torch for dark areas to avoid falling down steps inside
My favourite temple. Probably the best of the temple complex. Fairly well in tact and compact so you can see alot in a short time, something important in the hot weather.

Smiling faces. Don't forget your camera if you go there. This is a wonderful temple which has many King's faces who smile and look at us everywhere. Raining season, be careful with your step as the floor is slippery. Careful with your head as many of the walkways have low ceiling.

Beatiful!. This temple really wowed our family. The quality of the craftsmanship, the archticture and the reconstruction are all very impressive. It is definitely a must on the temple trail as it was a tie for #1 in our family with Ta Prohm. It is packed, but really worth it. You can make some of the best photography here.

Marvels of the Past. The whole complex is stunning and one only wonders how these big stones and monuments were moved from the quarry site to the temple site without the machinery that are at our disposal nowadays. Had a great afternoon ...

So beautiful and interesting place. Bayon temple was part of our visit in Cambodia's temples and we are so happy that we had the chance to see it.This temple stands in the center of Angkor Thom and is consisted of various towers with enormous face sculptures which are truly very stunning.In the lower parts of the temple you can see carvings that represent mythological and historical scenes.Be aware! Wear comfortable shoes!

The unique temple.. Love the structures of the 4 face bayon temple.. everywhere is beautiful. The temple is so huge that I get lost finding the exit to meet my tuk tuk driver.. overall I love this temple so much!

my favourite don't miss it!. This temple was absolutely my favourite in the all archeological site. We spend here more than an hour looking at all faces, all different and beautiful. The only problem is that this temple is included in the "small tour" at the end, so you problably will be a little tired. I strongly suggest to plan the all tour and not to let the guide or the tuk tuk do it for you. This temple worth all your energy in the morning, I suggest to start from these the second day of your visit!

The faces, they're staring at me. This and Angkor Watt were the highlights of the area - if you look closely enough you can find the face that is shown on the local currency - not that you see much of it, as everything in the country seems to be priced in US Dollars. This was the second stop on my day tour which began at 3am.
Awesome. One of most interesting places to visit in Siem Reap. Should be on everyone's list of 'to do' things in Cambodia.

900 years ago, man built more amazing stuff!. Bayon Temple is a must-see, but no worries - it's impossible to miss, as your tuk tuk driver (if you've hired one) will definitely take you there on your Angkor Wat & Angkor Thom tour. If you are cycling or hopping on a motorbike, it's hard to miss as well - Bayon is the epicentre of the ancient temple city of Angkor Thom. The bas relief status of Buddha's faces are the main attractions here, of course - if photography is an interest of yours, there are plenty of chances for some interesting angles of mythical stone faces carved out 900 years ago. Just avoid the tripod, as you might get told off by park wardens. There are multiple entrances to the temple, try and walk the perimeter of it once before you enter so you can decide which entrance to take - usually the less touristy one appeals better.
A khmer architectural style. The bayon is a well known and richly decorated Khmer temple at Angkor wat in Cambodia. built in th e late 12th or early 13th century.must visited place .
1000 years of 3D faces made of stones. It is so nice to explore the tempe, checking out the details and the 3D faces Stunning and breathtaking! :-)
Temple of faces.. Nice temple in ruins. Amazing to see a structure build so beautifully in an era without sophisticated tools.
Lovely face!. We visited this temple and really like it! We like the big face of Bayon. Don't miss this temple when you visit Siem Reap, Cambodia.
Majestic Bayon. Best place to take photos at 5pm with the sunset shooting through the stone carvings. Magical moment :)

Excellent Detail on Carvings. The detail on the carvings within the temple, allowed your imagination to take over and visualize what it must have looked like in the past. You see pictures all the time but seeing the scale of these epic buildings for real is something special.
One of my favourite. Beautiful temple that feels a little different from the others. I found my own peaceful little pot and sat down to daydream about the dreams of the smiling faces.

Smile...your at Bayon. A truly unique sight, the Bayon temple blows your mind. The architecture is unique with the smiling faces all around the temple complex. I recommend you take about an hour and a half and at least one bottle of water! It is very hot during mid/late afternoon there. Definitely do this temple... It will make you feel relaxed and help you find your inner peace! :-)
Beautiful. The faces provided an added level of spirituality to this particular ruin. Some smiling, some in deep contemplation.
Temples everywhere!. Visiting any temple in the Cambodian jungle is an absolute delight, and our guide took us to several!
Mythical. One of my favorite sites in Angkor. No image can prepare you for the the amazing architecture of the Bayon. Bayon needs to be on everyone's bucket list.

Another fabulous Siem Reap Temple!. Another beautiful temple within Siem Reap! I thoroughly enjoyed walking around and seeing this, I especially enjoyed when I had breaks of shade as the sun was blistering! Must include this one on your Siem Reap trip!
Stunning palace and temple complex. Yet another amazing temple and palace complex which is a must see on any trip to the Ankor complex. Truly stunning!
Must see. Its another temple and its a must see.......i like these places in Siem Reap the most......its a must see!
Buddha faces everywhere!. Love, love, love, love! The Buddha faces are phenomenal! Don't miss this lovely place ... it is a photographers dream!

Lovely Temple. This temple is a little different than the other temples with the faces showing on all sides of the towers. You can get some great photos here as its not as crowded asAngkor Wat. It's definitely worth a visit as part of an Angkor Wat tour

Faces..everywhere Faces!. Fantastic faces, everyone with a different expression. In some ways we found Ta Prohm and Bayon Temple better then Angor Wat. Maybe it's because they are smaller and not so overwhelming in size. If we can just get rid of the "selfie sticks", every time you try to take a picture somebody sticks in in front of your camera.

Amazing. This is a weird and wonderful place with trees growing out of the buildings. Such a shame as they are destroying them although there is extensive repairs/conservation taking place. This is a four sided carving of a Buddhas head. The paths are uneven and care is needed when walking about.

Good site for photography. This temple is very much worth a visit. Very beatiful temple with a unique appearance. It has many towers with 4 faces: brahma, vishnu, shiva and buddha.
The relic is still intact though some portions are only ruins.
Faces Temple. Another amazing temple, with massive stone carvings of faces. Built in 11th century. A must-see temple

Awe inspiring. Truly a masterpiece made by complete craftsmen. It is such an awe inspiring place just the size layout structures etc. no words can describe this place a must see. The land is flat so no real difficult areas to walk through unless you go up the temples. I'm sure in the future you will no longer be aloud to walk around the temples one day it will be closed for pedestrians to just walk around so go see it now.

The Best Temple in Siem Reap!. This was by far my favourite temple out of all the temples we saw. The faces are all still well perserved, and local monkeys climbing around the grounds add to the atmosphere.

Morning visit to Bayon. After a very early morning at Angkor Wat, breakfast I visited the Bayon Temple. Bayon is not huge like Angkor Wat but it's the faces that take your breath away. Imagining what they would have been like when originally built make you think deeply. while many of the towers have collapsed the remaining ones impress.

Second stop on my trip. I went to the sunrise at Angor Wat and immediately left for Bayon to outrun the hordes of tourists. It was impressive. The temple is quite small and we had it all to ourselves at 6:30 in the morning. It is beautiful and well restored. Worth to leave Angkor Wat for later if the trade off is gettings this and the whole Angkor Thom complex to yourself.

Incredible Bayon. This was my personal favourite temple. Looking at the temple and the faces carved in each tower, one would wonder how is that even possible to do it in the 12th century. A must see. Built by King Jayavarman VII, the faces on the towers still remains a mystery as some claim the face represents Jayavarman VII while others claim it is the face of Buddha.

A must visit spectacular wonder. The Bayon is a well-known and richly decorated Khmer temple at Angkor in Cambodia. Built in the late 12th or early 13th century. The face sculpture is amazing and you will need to spend a few hours there. Recommended to go early to avoid the hot sun. Get a good guide if you are interested on details of history. A must destination at least once in a life time.

Worth a visit!. Worth a visit! Remember to cover shoulders and wear something down to the knee. Also, may be worth getting a three day ticket to the Angkor temple complex the day before (one day ticket is USD $20 and three days $40). It'll save you the trouble of queueing especially if you want to do the sunrise trip to Angkor Wat followed by Bayon temple and others.
Amazing. This is a must see on the list of temples. Breathtaking and spiritual. How these were built approximately 1200 BC and still intact is a wonder unto itself.

Unique, many faced temple. This is a large temple, but not even close to the scale of Angkor Wat. Still, one could easily spend many hours here exploring or trying to find all of the different faces. It's definitely on the list of must-see temples in the area, so even if you have only short time for a visit, simply do so. The only real tip I have to share is if you are interested in seeing monkeys, head to this temple an hour or so before sunset. We did that on 3 different days and were surrounded by monkeys everywhere.

Whoa!. A spectacular must see for history, art , culture and architecture buffs.The scale and complexity is really awe inspiring. You can't help but be transported back to how grand this temple must have looked in its era.

Flowers, grasses, stones, naturalistic view of scenery. Also another temple among the AngKor Wat grand tour . Visiting these during the dry season is better. Do prepare the necessities like sunglasses , caps or hats. Many of the stones bricks or walls have carvings on them. do look and admire them a while if possible

Magnificient temple. Wonderful temple.Loved the temple and the views. If you can make it to the top of the temple, it is an awesome experience. Great scenery. but bit humid and crowded with tourists from all over the world. Don't ever miss it

Smaller than Angkor Wat. This Temple is easier to get around than Angkor Wat and a lot cooler as the government has not cut down all the trees as in Angkhor. It is in the forest and a favourite of the local guides as it is not as busy.

Enigmatic temple. Temple of 54 towers with 216 faces of Buddha/King is simply amazing. Restoration work is going on. Very sad to see only some parts of the temple, rest all came down. I couldn't imagine how beautiful the temple would be if it was in its original complete shape.

A highlight of our trip to Siem Reap. I loved Bayon it is so atmospheric and brings home the wonderful faces that on cannot see elsewhere, of all the temples we saw in three days Bayon was one of the very very best.
Very cool temple. Very cool temple with faces built into the temple. Once again females need to cover their shoulders and knees to access some parts of this temple.

200+ faces from any direction !. Over 200+ faces of King Jayavardhan VII, overlooking the then city of Siem Reap. Its magnificent how this temple was built out at different levels.Make a trip right up to the top to get a close view of the faces and a view from the top. The climb and return can get a little exhausting, if you have already had a long day across other temples.

breath taking. The photos don't do the faces on the building justice the most spiritual place we visited out of all the temples we loved it buying a three day pass means you can take your time to see the temples in detail

Huge and Wonderful. The jewel of Ankgor Thom is the Bayon Temple. Its situated on a huge platform and the temple strusture consists of several individual temples. Each has huge faces of Budhha on its dome in all sides. The corridors have wonderful structures like Roman Catholic churches. Architecture is simply wonder and grandeur of the whole thing makes you wonder about the architectural superiority of encient people.
Very cool. It's so hard to say any one temple was our favourite. This one is unique and very cool. The faces were amazing. Glad we did this.
My favourite temple. This is by far my favourite out of the temples in the inner circuit. I prefer it even to Angkor Wat. A must-see!

Favorite of the Temples. This is the favorite of the local temple, Angkor Watt is big, Ta Prahm is the overgrown temple, but the shear magnitude of towers with the faces of the Buddha is spectacular...even if the face is really that of Waterman 7

Tiring but worth the visit. Bayon was our second temple that we visited in a day and yet we felt the pinch to our body already! Same as Angkor Wat, (and the rest of the temples,actually) there are tunnels that leads you in and out of the temples bringing you to different parts of the temple. The buddha faces were sighted almost everywhere in much parts of the temple making it quite an interesting activity for me and hubby in trying to get some pretty angles for a good picture!
Once is enough. I was here a second time. Same. Unless you're researching, one visit is good enough. You see one ruins, you see them all. Right next to Angkor Thom.

Magnificent temple. One of my favorites temples in Angkor Complex. The principal hall it´s amazing and you can see the monkeys through the side, they´re friendly and you can play with them (but be careful), because they love to play. You can admire and feel the sunrise...
So many faces. Perfect. ..absolutely beautiful You actually get to walk on a hundreds of year old building its insane
This is my favorite. All those beautiful face of Budha make a visit to this temple worthwhile. For me this temple had something more than the others

Temple of Faces. This is a must see if you travel to Angkor. You cannot fail to be impressed by the massive stone faces, with their serene expressions,on the many towers which protrude, out from the upper terrace and surrounds a central peak. This place gets busy so get there early and to enjoy the experience get a guide.
Faces!. Amazing temple with >200 carvings of a benevolent face looking in all directions. Beautiful views once you get up close to the faces, a must-see in the Angkor area.
religiuos. although it was low season (late July, meant to be monsoonal), no rain but rather hot, good structure with some steep ascent within.
Best in Angkor Thom. You already feel amaze from far distance when you seen this temple. All monument got 4 faces and it look manificent.

Serenity!. Without a doubt my most favourite temple - as long as there is no one else around. Beautiful faces of Buddha throughout the temple, and some steeps stairs that lead to a secret library. During peak tourist season you can hardly walk through this temple and you get hit by selfie sticks, so choose a time when there are only a handful (early morning, low season).

Bayon or the temple of Bhudda faces...fascinating!. One of my favorites site in Angkor...really a beauty! You can feel peace and harmony in this temple. Angkor Wat is impressive by its size but Bayon has something different !
Awesome. Truly awesome. But it would be preferable to have a guide so that he or she can explai the history. A guide through the hotel cost US$45. But its possible to get a guide for $30 to $35.

Can be very crowded with group tours. The temple building can be very congested with people, with almost no or little room to move around. At some stairways, it's unilateral flow can be frustrating when seeking the exit to the car park.

Stunning. Be aware its big and its hot. We used a local guide to get the most out of our visit. Take plenty of water with you. Famous for having the 4 heads, One of my more favoured temples in the region.
My favourite temple. probably my most favourite temple. It's architecture style is different from AW. Lots of big faces :) it was very interesting and ... the photos with these big faces are fun

Beautiful carvings and well looked after elephants. Another fantastic temple with some amazing carvings, lots of restoration work being done at the moment.Went on a trip around the temple by elephant also, really good to see a resident vet checking the animals constantly and making sure they had plenty of food. I have seen some animals in horrendous condition all over the world and can hand on heart say these where really well looked after.

Incredible. This place is mind blowing. My only complaint is that there are so many tourists blatantly touching the bas reliefs and taking inappropriate selfies. How is no one watching it more carefully? Amazing place, a must see in Angkor.

trully stunning. There are 2 ways to visit these places.DIY with tut-tut taking you there or with a proper guide in a cosy van The temple complex (part of Angkor Thom) is huge and probably best visit with a good guide to maximise the time. Bayon's distinctive stone faces on the stone towers are probably the most recognised 'faces' in Siem Reap. The structures' architecture are strikingly different compared to Angkor Wat. Bring an umbrella or poncho and a good hat plus plenty of drinking water and allocate a good 2 hours For photo-buff, do visit early in the morning or late in the evening for better lighting and colors and less crowd. Though Bayon temple is no longer an active temple, there are still a few altars scattered around the huge complex dedicated to Lord Buddha. Hence practice some respect to the holy site

Favourite Temple. This was my favourite temple. We had visited the national museum the day before where we read and watched short videos that explained lots about the carvings. This made the visit to the temple really meaningful.would recommend doing this.
Ancient Hindu / Buddhist Temple. Based on ancient Indian architecture.Does not look similar as in photos as restoration work is still on.Internally nothing much to see like engravings, etc.

One of the best places in Siem Reap. The Bayon temple also known as the Faces temple is amazing. The carvings are staggering. The many towers make it for congested walkways but it is still worth all the effort. Do get to the highest point. There are photo opportunities scattered all over the temple. One of the most beautiful places in the world indeed.
Stunning. An amazing temple with the iconic faces of Buddha watching over the old Khmer kingdom. I've visited it in the sunshine and in an absolute rain deluge - both were magical experiences.
I love the Buddha image's. Must seen after Angkor Wat. Enter from the North gate and go right. GREAT PICTURE together with Buddha. .
Interesting architecture. Well worth à visit with à good guide. Very warm, bring sunscreen, lost of water and good walking shoes
