My favourite temple. This was my favorite temple. Maybe because we had an amazing guide who explained all of the carvings to us (Asia Private Guide Service). But it was great seeing a glimpse into life back then through them! Go early to avoid crowds as this one is the best and you will want to explore in peace.
Great views from the top. Most interesting . Angkor Thom was very impresive as well, easy to get around the temple , great photo shots

Bayon Temple. It's easy to get lost in this maze of a temple. Despite the signage on telling you which way to go. It can be difficult to find the way you came in on finding your way out. There is no cell phone reception out here, so it's impossible to call your tuktuk driver if you can't find the way you came out. It's huge and the smiling faces are nice. But the people on hand are not helpful in finding your way. They also lack in their English skills so don't expect to be able to ask them for any kinds of assistance.

One of the most unique temples in Sieam Reap, if not the world.. This is definitely one of the most important and most beautiful places to visit in Siem Reap.The huge, imposing faces on the temple towers are a sight to behold.The sheer size of the temple complex and the beautiful carving and scultures inside show how rich the erstwhile Khmer culture was.

Bayon Review and the Elephants. Bayon is just enough removed from Angkor Wat to not be so congested. As we are massive elephant conservation people at The Elephant Story, we were interested in the elephant cultural aspects of this temple. Elephants are symbol for strength in both Hinduism and Buddhism so they support and guard the gate entrance. After all, they were used to build all of the temples around Angkor Wat. Go to the elephant terrace and you will see bas reliefs of elephant carrying riders to hunt deer in the 12th century.

A must visit! And dont forget the elephant feeding/ ride.. This place is incredible- there is soo much intricate detail everywhere you look! It is hard to fathom how it could have been built- the time and resources it would have took, and to still be standing today. Especially when considering all of the testing times that the architecture has had to withstand.The elephant ride around the temple prior to the guided tour really topped the whole experience off. P.S try and count how many smiling Buddha faces there are.

So good. Another wonderful temple to see. The four sided faces are interesting, actually all of it is just amazing. Take good walking shoes as you have many a step to go up and walk around. Lots of water too as the humidity was extremely high when we visited. Not unbearable just hot.

Go early in the day.. What can I say. Totally beyond words. It's about feeling, mere words describe the beauty age of this temple.Can I recommend going as early as possible, it's very hot and humid this time of year. I had left winter in Australua and the humidity really hit me. Take a guide! Worth every cent!
One of the Finest Temple. The Bayin temple is one of my favourite temple. It is extremely beautiful and different than other temples at Angkor Park. It is a must see.
Years after, it's still known due to Tomb Raider movie. It's nice to experience temple run for yourselves. They did an awesome job to preserve such ancient structure.

Beautiful temple to explore. The 54 sly smiles of the Bayon temple faces are an amazing sight to see. So mysterious and endearing at the same time. My favourite spot in the Angkor Wat loop. Remember it rains at 4:15pm so bring a raincoat or visit in the morning!! :)

!!!!!!!. In all of Angkor, this one was probably my favorite! Wat is great but Bayon is so unique!!!
The detail is so amazing. I can't say enough good things about it.
Simply beautiful and a must see!

Espectacular. When you look it at the first time don't imagine how it is really. For me its one of the best temples. That faces smiling at you every where. You discover more and more faces when you look it.
Cool faces!. Loved this cool temple! So glad to see the many faces and explore the grounds. Climb around where you can

Bayon Temple: Make it Early in the Cool of Morning; Take your Time, Take a Guide.. Of all the sites within Angkor Thom, this one is the most crowded. It is flanked by the elephant circus of rides, and is swarming with people. Its ruins are beautiful, carvings amazing, but again, as with all the temples in the park, get there early (or after 4 pm) if you want to see it in peace, and take your time. I reached this temple in the thick of Noon, which made it hot and teeming with tourists. I was not able to give it its due. This one is well worth spending over an hour at, and hiring a guide to take you through. There is much to see and ponder and about the glories of Jayavarman VII's rule.

The Faces of the Lord Buddha Surround You. Here is another temple in the form of a mandala, yet this one takes on a pyramid shape and consists of 54 towers bearing more than 200 enigmatic faces looking north, south, east, and west. This magnificent structure lies in the heart of Angkor Thom and is entered through eight gates surmounted by towers. At one time, these gates were linked by covered galleries. These are slowly being restored. The galleries are lined with splendid bas reliefs depicting battles in intricate detail, dancers, and other images in wonderful condition.This temple was originally dedicated to the Hindu Vishnu, and an image of him survives in one of the galleries. We made offerings at one of the Buddha images in one of the upper towers. Many pilgrims were doing the same. It takes some time to wander around this complex temple, but the architecture brings a sense of awe to most visitors. A visit is well worth the trouble.

I Am and You Are Too. Oh Bayon... Bayon, with your myriad Buddha visages. The memory of walking with your Giants is still fresh and haunting. Contemplating the lives who's devotion, strength and faith gave birth to you is something today we are not only searching for, but truly need! Collectivity in heart, mind & soul across even just small village could potentially change life on planet earth...imagine if was humankind as one!
Stunning and peaceful. Visit in person to see the amazing architecture and beautifully carved faces that pictures cannot begin to capture.
Love the Bayon Temple. I got so many great photos at this temple. Loved the Victory Gate, the king's entrance. Temple ruins at their best.

An architectural marvel . One of the most famous temples in Siem Reap and rightly so. Go early and take your time to see the place. The inscription on walls are beautiful so are the faces.. As you climb up make sure to observe the subtle change in smiles..
Super beautiful architecture!. Amazing temple one near AngKor Wat, one of many many temples however it is advisable to go here if you are in the area don't miss out!

One of my favourite temples. 37 towers with giant smiling stone faces in all 4 directions? Yes please! This temple is like nothing on earth. I loved it. My partner and I liked it so much we visited it a second time before leaving Siem Reap. Much better than Angkor Wat.
Good faces every where. Great faces of Bayon temples attract many tourists. I really like Bayon. The faces look so big and so nice (smile).

Simply amazing. The Bayon is breathtaking. Beautiful temples intricately carved into gods, buddhas & kings. It is my favorite temple in Angkor. The carved heads depicting four faces are seren & peaceful. A must visit.

Best time for photos / Best Angkor guide. An absolutely amazing temple, beautiful in the mid to late afternoon when golden sunlight shines on the ancient faces. Make sure you see the well deep inside the temple. I only found it when I went back with a guide. Speaking of Need a guide? I know THE guy! Charmony - ph 092820529 amazing knowledge of Khmer and temple history as well as Buddhist and Hindu mythology. He will take you places you'd never find by yourself (I tried without a guide the day before I hired him, the difference is night and day!) Kind and friendly with Good English and also he's a great photographer that knows where and how to take the best photos (even with professional cameras) !

Artistic Temple. This temple is unique in the sense of artistic flavor. Original structure is same as other temples but this one has many towers with human face curved. . We found both Hindu deity ,Shiva and Buddha sculpture .Well costumed Apsaras (heavenly Dancers) can be found with whom one can take picture ( on payment) .Its nice and enjoyable.

Incredible. Among all the temples in this area the Bayon was definitely my favourite. The architecture is simply incredible, mostly because each face on the top of the temple is highlighted by the sun at a certain time throughout the day, creating a mysterious atmosphere and a true wow effect. I was so captivated that I could not leave the temple!

Bayon Heads. Interesting temple, the huge faces are well worth seeing, as with all temples, get a guide! - as you have travelled 1000's of miles, paying $40 a day is cheap and you get the history. Take an elephant ride too, they go around the temple and it's great fun.you can see this temple in half a day.

Most well-designed temple in Siem Reap. Favorite tempel in Siem Reap! Just feel like this was designed by the best architect in Cambodia. Very cool-looking, and some nice architecture. A tour guide is a must at any temple!
amazing architecture. just go and experience this utterly amazing place. we went in low season but it was still fairly busy and getting up early in the morning for sunrise is recommended

on par with Ankor Wat. This is the "smiling Buddha" temple with tons of stone-carved smiling Buddhas facing every while way. On par with Ankor Wat in terms of amazing sites. Definitely worth a visit especially with a guide.

Best of all, different and cool. This was the best of all the temples. Loved all the faces. Beautiful. Got great photos. Was fun getting lost in all the little tunnels. Inside was really nice and cool. Pretty stunning all up. Bonus to see some baby monkeys too.

Iconic. This is one of the most iconic temples in the world! Outside this temple, there is actually a display which demonstrates how they believe this ancient civilisation cut the stone to make the many faces and walls of this temple. very interesting. This temple has the best photo opportunities, and everywhere you turn you are looking at the majestic faces. It is really incredible. The temple goes very high giving a great view of the park.From here, walk across the road to Baphuon temple. An incredible (very high, very steep) temple that has a lovely walkway and entrance. We came here to rest under the trees out of the heat before walking up to the top of the temple. The back half of the temple appears to show a reclining buddha as well.
Bayon Tempple. Intricate carvings in the walls will not leave you disappointed. Close to Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom. Would recommend a visit.

Mesmerizing monument. There is so much history to this place! You feel so tiny when you see this huge creations from our ancestors.Make sure you have ample time to look around. It could take you at least an hour to cover this monument.There are some local eateries around but make sure you carry a lot of bottled water especially in the summer as this place can get really warm.I went there twice during my stay, just couldn't get enough!

Majestic Temple . The entire square of Bayon encloses a number of different temples. The front gate leads into a thick maze of temple ruins. Mostly you have to climb up to get a great view of the grounds. Outside of the first temple you will find various other temples to explore. Our Tuk Tuk driver provided a map which was helpful. Our two other favorite structures in that square was the Elephant Terrace and the Leper King Terrace. Elephant Terrace had a beautiful view as you walked along the road while still atop the temple. Leper King Terrace provides a free place to pray with incense and it is much more peaceful than other options around town. A word of caution: You will find that there will be children moving through the halls fishing to get you to tour with them. After showing you some places they will ask for money. The one that stopped us was equipped with a letter that discussed a "school" of sorts that teaches impoverished youth to give these tours. The letter, however, was not well edited amd spoke in sort of broken English so it made us question the validity of the script. We gave the child a couple dollars for his time (and because it's so hard to say no to children- and they know it). Many children, however, collect money becuase peiple are more apt to givr to them and will unfortunately have to turn any profits over to their parents/guardians who probably will not use it for the well being of their children. At one temple we offered the children filtered water and gum instead of money and they were just as happy if not happier than receiving our money.

As amazing as I thought it would be. These Temples are the main reason for staying in Siem Reap. They are truly awe inspiring. T faces carved into the Bayon Temple are incredible. This is one of those occasions when a local guide is worth their weight in gold, fascinating.

Faces Galore! Bayon - every sculptor's dream. 3 hours well spent!!. The sheer number of faces beaming at you as well as the ones hidden in plain sight is nothing less than a riddle. The carvings on the walls are exquisite and have a lot of stories to tell. People who are really interested in the history would definitely go into overdrive mode. We visited the temple early in the morning at around 7 am and had the whole temple to ourselves....as this is when majority of the crowd is at the Main Angkor Wat temple. If you prefer solitude while experiencing the artistry, go early in the morning. The view from the top is something else. And u wont realise how time flies up there.

Incredible experience - a must see. By far my favorite temple - even better than Angkor Wat. If youre in the area, you must put this on your list to visit. There's an ethereal sense as you walk among the hundreds of faces looking down upon you. The partially restored ruins are absolutely beautiful. A must-see.
So wonderul.. This was one of my favourite temples. Such a wonderful place and I'm planning on visiting again soon.

Impressive - be ready to be captivated by the smile of Bayon. A definite must see in Angkor Thom area. Very unique and the only temple I have seen in my life with such architectural design. Can be explored on your own if you have read/researched about it beforehand. Hiring a guide would be another alternative you can take, they help you appreciate the temple more with the stories that they tell about the carvings and they can help you take good photos as they know the picture perfect spots in the temple.

A must see in Angkor temples area. This temple is not that far from Angkor Wat temple which is the biggest and one of the most impressive temples to visit, especially at sunrise. The Bayon temple is very special as there are dozens of faces sculpted in stone still in an impressive condition. Ideal place to take some amazing pictures. Not to be missed at any price!
Don't Miss. Well worth seeing this temples from the 7-9 century & how it has stood taste of time. Lots of walking but worth it.
awesome!. Gorgeous. Haven't seen anything like that before! Better to take a guide or read extensively about it so you know whats happened and you appreciate it more
great!. this was my favorite temple. Not a lot of tourists at the top, and looks good from any angle. steps might be uneven.

Wait for reconstruction to be finished first. Go after the 'renovations' have been done. It was a lot quieter than its neighbour Angkor Wat. I would have liked this a lot better had the rehabilitation of this ancient area been complete. But still nothing to complain about as it was still a site to see.
Amazing. Four Faces of Buddha - awesome temple for exlporing. A definite must see of the Angkor complex. Hire a guide to explain all the carvings along the walls - they tell quite a story!
Bayon temple simple yet majestic.. Amazing ruins. Please protect them before its gone! Can see that the authorities are doing their best to re-construct the ruins.
Unique place. Amazing structure. The site is well preserved. Dress modestly. Lovely place to reflect and meditate.

Amazing historic site. Our tour guide explained that there are more than 10 faces in Bayon Temple and they mostly differ from each other. Some are the "smiling" face and one of them is the "kissing" statue.

Moment of silence . Absolutely breathtaking. A bit too many people for my liking but you should expect that. However we did manage to find a quiet spot for a few minutes to just sit and soak it all in.

Happy Temple!. A beautiful temple with vast amounts of detail! Hire a guide to help time your visit to avoid throngs of people--it will make all that much more magical! There are ruins, restorations and nature to be seen here!

Temple with serene stone faces. This temple was constructed during the reign of King Jayavarman VII. The most distinctive feature of the temple is the multitude of massive, serene stone faces that graces its many towers..
More than just ruins. Superb historical monuments. We enjoyed going around and taking in the architectural style of the period. The statues of Buddha in stone carvings are something to admire.
Faces at Bayon Temple. Amazing monument with huge faces built into the rocks. The small shrine in the middle is very atmospheric. A great monument to the Angkor civilisation.
best temple. crowded in the morning, but that is when the sun is best for photography. still great in the afternoon though
Bayon .... Brilliant. it was so fascinating , i love the temples an hearing the history of them - every one is beautiful in it's own way

Amazing Temple. Bayon is a must see. Amazing Buddhist architecture built on a magnificent scale. It is still in very good condition and is very impressive . If you go to Siam Reap it is a one of the best preserved and most awesome temples that you must visit .

An absolute MUST see. I wasn't sure if this smiley temple I was told about - to be honest I was so tired from 'templing'. sooo glad I didn't miss this one!!! Fantastic! Go and have zero regrets - tourists are only issue - too many, but hey, you'll be one!

Amazing. This place has amazing carving the faces are unbelievable it's not as big as Angkor Wat but just as impressive. Don't miss it. There is lots of spots for photos inside doorways and windows but there is one spot that if you stand in the right place it looks like you are nose to nose with the god statues. Keep an eye out for it. You will see the guides using it

216 faces of an ancient civilisation. These 12th century Khmer temples are stunning. There are 216 faces carved into about 50 stone towers, with a face looking east, west, north and south on each tower. My guide Believes the faces are a combination of the face of the Cambodian Khmer king Jayavarman VII who built the temples, and Buddhist bodhisattva of compassion. The international efforts to restore the temples has been very successful, and continues. If only those countries who stole the treasures would return them to the Cambodians, where they belong. It is a beautiful site, and at the time we went, quite peaceful. There are also many wall carvings of wars with the Vietnamese Chams, as well as carvings of everyday life. Go with a guide if you want to know the background to the carvings and some historical perspective.
Amazing tour through the ruins.. Local tour guide took us on an amazing 6 hour tour through the ruines of Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom and Bayon. Recommended !

Do it in early morning ?. We got a wonderful time as we reached the place around 7.00am there were only few other people and we enjoyed the bird songs as well the temple like it is unspoilt !Temples and sculptures are just amazing here !

One of the Highlights. OK, after a while you run out of things to say about this area. But the Bayon temple is one of the highlights of the area. It's incredible that you're allowed to climb over these nearly 1000 year old ruins. Absolutely one of the 3 must-see's in this area.
Great Temple. This is one of the most fascinating temples. A bit crowded during the morning. Might be better to visit in the afternoon.
Favorite Temple of Siem Reap. Incredible! Fantastic views all around which makes for great pictures. Very easy to explore on your own.
Must See. This is one of the best temples to see especially at sunset. Buy a three day pass & try to see all of the outlying temples as most are less busy then Angkor Wat but equally inspiring
Beautiful!. Personally the most beautiful of the temples in Angkor. If you have time and energy, do the the tour with a bike. And definitely hire a professional guide. Worth the money.
Must see Great photo op. Incredible temple with some super photo opportunities. We walked in the back entrance which was a cool experience.
Amazing. A magic experience that will transport you to the world of spirituality. Easy to feel how buda's presence can be around you

Must-see temple with beautiful Buddha faces. This is one of the must-see temples in the Angkor Wat area. The general Angkor Wat admission ticket covers admission for this temple as well. Consider getting the three-day pass if you'll be in Siem Reap for a few days.

Great faces. The best highlight in Cambodia is Bayon. I love the smiling faces every corner. It is best to see during sunset time because no tourists at all. And color is mixed up between gold and green.
Must see. An interesting temple with lots of images of king Jayavarman 7th. Worth a look whilst in the area as part of the historical sites.

Interesting Faces. This temple has the added interest of the various faces carved in the huge stones. It is best to go early in the day to avoid the crowds and get some great pictures. Fascinating architecture and carvings. Wear good shoes as the stones and stairs can be slippery.
Not to be missed. A great place to walk around and taking in the wonders of a long lost temple. Do not miss this place inside the Angkor Thom. Awesome!

Disappointing. Maybe it was the fact that we had just visited near bye Angkor Wat but I found this historic site disappointing or it could be because parts of it were restricted due to ongoing restoration work. The whole site which is much smaller than Angkor felt very claustrophobic and after 30 minutes was ready to move on
Unmissable!. Such an amazing temple made from sandstone. The faces are in great condition and although it is always very busy you can always find a few spots to get away from the madness.
Well worth doing.. Ive been every temple and piece of ruin. I thought this would be another same same - it was not, its totally fantastic.

Another Siem Reap Gem. Although not nearly as large as Angkor Wat, Bayon Temple is just as impressive. It is simply amazing to see the beauty and the craftmanship at every holy site. We were fortunate to have a wonderful guide, Sky, through all our temple tours who explained the culture and history at every site. Do not miss any of the temples in Siem Reap.

Company outing in Angkor. Ancient architecture made from the sand stone. So many King faces all round the top of the castle. However, a lot of traveller and tour group so some narrow area is very hard to walk through the tour group and have to wait them finish their photograph activity .

Experience enhanced with a tour guide. Like Angkor Wat our visit to Bayon was made so much more interesting by having a tour guide like Sovan Say to tell us about the culture and explaining the history.
Stupendous temple. So many temples to see and all so impressive. Impressed by the variety of architecture and the building materials used.

Take many photos!. Very easy to get around, go early to avoid crowds and take a small towel from your hotel to wipe away your perspiration as you tour the area. Very many touts in the area, take a stern approach and just keep walking, unless you wish to be followed for a bit.

Added Interest!. Once again the amazing sandstone structures as in Angkor Wat. But this place has the added interest for the tourist of elephant feeding and rides. These animals walk people right around the temple giving a bird's eye view of the whole structure from an extremely good vantage point!

Fascinating enigmatic faces. This temple stands out , very unique for or more sided lira ides with faces very interesting, very crowded but still worth the effort we tried to go very early in the morning or later in the afternoon nice light to take pictures

A site like no others. Be amazed by the architecture of Bayon Temple... a temple of many faces. Aside from the face towers, Bayon is also adorned with intricate bas reliefs depicting Khmer’s traditional symbols and daily life. A work of art indeed...
Wings of history. Really awesome and well-preserved place! You can really feel the wings of history! I highly recommend a visit.

A lot to explore. A large temple with a lot to see.
It has plenty of nooks and crannies.
Loved the rooms with the little rocks that obviously visitor had put up.

Many Faces are watching you.. This temple has multiple face carved into the rocks, unfortunately when we visiting they were doing work on the front of the temple and certain areas were blocked off, but once inside we could view the beautiful carvings and the huge four sided faces looking down at us, very,very steep stairs to climb to the higher levels but once this is mastered then you have wonderful views around the temple.. Elephant rides are available here also.

Go early. I recommend going early, while everyone else is basking in the beauty of having seen sunrise at Angkor Wat, head to this one and experience it by yourself, it was amazing and so much better than the first afternoon trip we made to it.
Best temple. Among all the temples in the Angkor Wat, I like this the most. The face of the Buddha in every place was unique. It was less crowded when we went there. It was more serene and calmer.
bayon. Great atmosphere in this temple especially the lack of carving.s gave it a clean simplicity walking around the lower terrace was especially good

A must visit. This temple is a must visit in Siem Reap!
The intricate carving of apsara dance and the history of how people live back then is absolutely stunning and awesome.
Bayon Temple. Another Temple worth visiting for its unique towers with four faces of the Buddha facing different directions.
Majestic. Superb structure, beautiful photo opportunities. Quite a spectacular sight. One of the must dos! Sunscreen and good shoes are a definite!

Ancient Technolgical marvel. A marvelous architecture with out mortar / cement , but not maintained well by the local government. The pieces of sculpture are precisely cut and inserted with out cement which locks with out falling off.See the sculptures closely you will realize it  Wow what a wonder . A real wonderful idea of those days. No words to explainA place MUST SEE and admire
One of Cambodian icons. It's part of the Angkor Thom complex and one of the most recognizable icons in Cambodia. The faces on the temple wall are really stunning and not to be missed.
very nice. Must see the old days architectures and explore it. this is one of the part of angkor kingdom one of the must see spots
Very fun temple. This temple was second only to Angkor Wat in terms of our preferences. The smiling, peaceful faces are really interesting.

Prasat Bayon Temple. When in Siem Reap your guide will take you to probably the 2nd most visited temple which is the Prasat Bayon Temple.It is a short ride from Angkor WatThis again is a supurb structure with many carvings on the walls.You should also try the elephant ride which take the tourist around the Temple once. Remember to take your camera for those high up pics.
Wow temple to visit . It was such a hot day when we visited this beautiful temple , which was very crowded too. Lots of narrow paths & you are guaranteed to take lovely photos here.
Great temple. The huge stone faces of the bodhisattva Avalokiteshvara are amazing, well sculptured but still need more maintenance.
Fantastic smiling faces!. Do not miss out the smaller temples, they are really worth a look, especially this one. The smiling faces are great, and the temple has lots of different areas to explore

Lots of history and beautiful carvings. This temple has 54 carved face statues for the 54 provinces of Cambodia when it was built. There was a lot of history here; definitely take a tour guide so they can explain all the carvings! They tell beautiful stories of Cambodian religion and folklore.

Amazing. Complex architecture and great sensation just being in this place.
Big temple with many points of interest. Great for photography
Amazing!. The temples in the the Siem Reap area truly are a wonder of the world. I have been twice and will return in the future.

One of my favourite temples in Siem Reap. This temple must be included in your list to visit. The architecture of the temple is simply breathtaking. It is definitely one of the top temples to visit in Angkor.

My favourite Angkor Temple. This temple has rich carvings on a scale that is smaller and more intimate than Angkor Wat. The towers with Bhudda images on each face are amazing. It's a shame that the temple was vandalised in previous times when Hinduism was practised.

Great to see. A really nice temple, but lots of building work going on, so not so easy for getting good photos. Make sure you walk across the other side to the forest for great photo opportunities with the troops of monkeys.

Awesome. It was awesome. All this old stones and the incredible amount of work it must have been. And after all this years it is still so amazing to see.You should be able to walk a lot, the have small stairs and uneven cobblestoneways. But you really have to see it.It is phantastic.

awesomeness. We loved this temple almost more...I say ALMOST more than Angkor Wat...it is more intriguing and more of an Indiana Jones experience...it is HUGE in area mass so allow at least a few hours there before you kove onto all the other temles that surround it
Amazing. This is the amazing temple in Angkor Thom compound with many other beautiful temples. The four faces towers are stunning and the carving describes of Cambodian local life in Angkor era.
Amazing stone carvings. I love the four face Buddha, the incredible work of stone carvings. A must see place when visiting Siem Riep.

impressive temple ruins. you should combine all these temple ruins within 3 days for 40$ per person within one week...you do not need to do that one after the other day you can make a break in between

Stunning Temples. First thing that will come up on my mind how they started working on these temples. The temples are all beautiful and Khmer people are trying to preserve their national heritage.The place is well maintained and clean, some instances that we can’t avoid too crowded. Make sure to have the signature pose in The nose to Nose in Bayon temple... ill share the picture.. i cant stop starring on those faces engraved on the walls.Tip. Make sure to bring bottled water and empty your bladder it’s hard to look for washrooms.

My personal favourite of all the temples. The temple is amazing and the stone faces carved on the towers are absolutely stunning, not to mention the carvings on the walls. We decided to hire one of the guides on the spot and didn't regret it. He explained everything in a very interesting way and kept us entertained for about two hours for 15 USD. He even gave us tips to take some fun photos on the site. Happy memories!
AMAZING!. This was by far one of my favourite temples. The faces are something you must see!! There were not that many other tourists when we visited, which made the experience even more enjoyable

The Temple of Faces. Another great temple to visit. My group and I had fun exploring. If you don't mind being silly in photos, you can come up with many good poses with the faces to laugh about. It is very beautiful and full of culture. Lots of walking throughout the temple but worth it.
Amazing Temple . One of the best temples in Angkor. There were many 4 faces Buddha in the temple. Very unique and breathe taking!

The nose!. don't forget to get your profile picture taken by the guide which will touch the nose of the buddha statue ! Almost fully in ruins, but with lovely inscriptions. My favourite one was about the fish, the boat men and the warriors.
Go early. If you want to get an awesome photo without the crowds skip the sunrise at Angkor watt and go here first! The photos look awesome

Bayon review . Bayon was the last of the historic temples we visited. It is impressive but I think we were too tired to appreciate it fully. Our personal guide Kim made it special though by pointing out the intricate carvings and what they symbolise to the Khemer.
Just got to see this!. One of the main temples to see. Completely different to the others - faces throughout...different expressions, so many. huge.

amazing. discover the kmer civilisation through the magic architecture and be among thounsand of ppl who everyday share the same joy and get fascinated ; beleiv me you will have a good day and you will never forget it all your life; siem reap is more interesting than phnom penh or sihanokville .

Unforgetable. One of the more striking temples, although younger than Angkor Wat, this temple has over 200+ faces of Buddha carved into it, not something you will easily forget. Each face is quite special, and creates for some excellent photo opportunities. If you stand just right you can line up to be nose to nose with the faces. There is a lot of history also carved into the temple, about the ancient people and their way of live. Hands down one of the most striking and remarkable temples, and my favorite.

amazing Bayon. Bayon to me was the Second best after Angkor Wat, its probably the staring faces ewerywhere ,that really got to me, and i felt humble and quiet - unfortunately some of the cultures arriving on the tour buses did not feel the same...nevertheless, amazing experience, if you have to pick 3 places in the area, you must do Bayon

A MUST SEE, but be careful with small children. An absolute MUST SEE! Be careful when taking small children (ours are 2, 4, 6, & 8). Before I knew it, my 8 year old was trying to climb incredibly steep stone steps to the top of one of the structures. Scary, but well worth it! There are plenty of other areas to climb that have wooden steps which are much more manageable for young ones. Soooo worth it! All of those giant faces! Wow! Easily our favorite temple.
Cultural essence. Temple after Temple in Siem Reap reveals the historical and cultural essence of a civilization gone but not forgotten. The images are mystical!

Bayon Temple is known for its many, many stone faces. If you are only spending a limited amount of time in Siem Reap, and can only tour for a day, make this temple, along with Angkor Wat, the gates of Angkor Tom, Ta Prohm, and maybe Banteay Srey the temples you visit. Basically, if you stick with TripAdvisor ratings for things to do in Siem Reap you won't go wrong.

Definitely a first or second favorite. Go as early as possible to avoid the rush and enjoy the serenity! Some great photo ops at this place. The shear number of smiling faces will amaze and delight. Entrance cost included in Wat Pass.

This is the place where you see all the carved faces. Lots of good walking through shady paths and, once inside the temple there are corridors after corridors of exhibits. We didn't bother with a guide and loved every minute.

Don't miss this one. Think this was one of the temples in the Ankor region I liked most.
We had a local guide and he really brought the place to life for us.
Definitely worth getting a guide or guidebook so you get the most from the visit.

Great SiVery Crowded, & Elephant rides (horrible!. This temple, with its Buddha faces, is one amazing place to visit in Siem Reap. The only down part is it's a bit smaller than Angkor Wat which makes it seem a bit claustrophobic. Also there are Elephant rides. Which are horrible for the animals, no matter what you're told. PLEASE DO NOT RIDE & ENCOURAGE ANIMAL TOURISM.

Beautiful temple!!. I really like the Bayon temple. The face carvings and the elephant ride around it was really exciting! The carvings and the greenery that surround the temple makes for a beautiful site!

A must see for everyone. My family and I visited Bayon temple in Jul 15. I recommend hiring a tuk tuk for the day, about $15 USD. The site is currently under reconstruction however most areas were accessible. I hired a tour guide for $5 USD and it was money well spent. There is just so much history in that area.

Four-faces of peaceful god-like self resemblance. This temple is famous for its many faces (216), all in sets of four, which are a mixture of Buddhism and Hinduism. Though the temple was built as the last state temple in Angkor as a Mahayana Buddhist shrine, some scholars believe that the shrine may be paying more homage to the founding/creating King Jayavarman VII than Buddha himself, as there seems to be a keen resemblance between the 216 faces and the god-like king with the name meaning victorious warrior. Don't get swept up by the grandeur of this temple, though. It also serves a nice backdrop for playful pictures. A great photographer and guide can be found here: www.angkorbesttourguide.comContact Narin via email: narinviptours@gmail.comHis knowledge and humor are unmatched, and he also provides a keen eye for great photography spots!Also, don't forget to explore Victory Gate as you exit the city (Angkor Thom). You can even do a 3-minute trek to the top of the gate, admiring more pre-zen-like faces.

The temple of the big heads and more!. This is 1 of the 3 temples of Angkor Wat that are a must see. The large heads along make this site worth visiting but make certain to to check out the relief work on the lower levels of the temple. Get there early, more and more tourists are visiting (even in the "low" season) and making it more difficult to visit and much more difficult if your serious about photographing where you visit.

My favorite temple. Of all the temples I visited this was my highlight. The detail work is amazing and it is a great temple for photography. Other major temples visited: Ta Phrom, Preah Khan, Angkor Wat, Ta Som.

Another great monument. Really worth a visit as are most of the temples in the area, but to be sure when you go to Cambodia. the one monument starts to blur into another monument and many of them seem quite like "de javu."

Must see. The one and only.. This is a special one . With so many 4 faces budha. A good place for photography. A lot of uneven steps to climb. But they are not too high and steep. A lot of climbing up and down though. A very special architecture not to be missed. Get a tourist guide to explain of read up before you go.

Impressive architecture and carving- 4 faced stupas. All the temples are constructed according to the same basic principles but they vary considerably in style, execution and atmosphere. I quickly realised that Angkor Wat as a destination encompasses a number of different temple complexes each with their own name and unique quality. Allow plenty of time to explore. And read up or you will miss gems. We hired a car and guide and therefore got the history, the religious context and the navigation to major sights with the flexibility of being able to linger longer at some places or ask to see more than just the major attractions. These place had great serenity and I would definitely recommend having it on your itinerary. Allow plenty of time and watch out for those groups all having a photo nose to nose with a statue!

#3 Temple. The place looks pretty much like rubble, but it is not. There are so many top places to take snaps @ Angkor, this is #3. My Opinion. Which is saying a whole lot. The Buddhas seemingly hidden in the crumbling stone, peeking, jump out at you. You can spend hours here if you like taking that "different" snap. I have been to Bayon 6 times. It is never the same. Kind of like the USA Grand Canyon.

My Favourite. Angkor Wat is stunning but Bayon is truly awesome.Get there early or late to avoid the crowds so that you can get up close to view the carvings and literal rock faces. And to secure the best photo positions.Don't miss it.
The Faces of Budha @ Bayan. This temple was indeed my favorite. With 58 stupas times 4 gentle faces, it's so calming to be there and wander.

Beautiful! A must see. Make sure this is on your list of temples to see. Plan to see this one right after Angkor Wat. And make sure you have a guide with you who can explain the religious meanings behind the faces. Awesome stuff! Just a word of advise, this temple has lots of levels and stairs. Not recommended for someone with mobility issues.

Crumbling, interesting ruin.. A great visit to the temple- wandering around here was stunning. There are so many corridors, rooms, carvings and intreting views. Again do not go mid morning as there will be hoards of tour groups and the place becomes almost unnavigable with so many people- also ruins your photos as impossibe to get a shot without lots of people in them.

Totally loved it. Amazing architecture of 54 pillars with 4 faces of Buddha on each pillar. It simply is amazing. Do carry adequate water, cap, umbrella, walking shoes. No roof and can get hot. I recommend visit with guide so you can get to learn a lot more about the place.
Awesome place not to miss. I found it amazing!.After visiting Angkor Watt this was the second spot to visit and as it was raining a lot only a few people visiting it.
Amazing place. Almost all the temple is amazing, if you can go earlier after watch the sunrise otherwise it become too crowded
worth to visit. we liked it more than angkor wat, interesting and impressive temple, go there in the morning and watch your steps
Not to miss on a trip to Angkor. One of the best temples around, with the huge amount of history and stories attached to this temple you cannot miss this one on your trip to Angkor.
Bayon Temple!. Love this temple - huge stone faces! Very interesting how this was done considering it was 12th century! I am amazed! This is the temple you should include in your tour!
Incredible - Must see. One of my favorite temples in all of Angkor - and one of my favorite places in the whole world. A definite must see. Even looking back at pictures I can't believe it's real.
Beautiful Architecture. The Banyon Temple is stunning with it's many faces. The architecture is truly unique and worth a visit.

Don't miss the place with the faces. While much of Angor is impressive the giant faces facing the four cardinal directions are breathtaking. Be sure to see them all up close as many are unfortunately in varying states of erosion. Once can only imagine what they looked like when covered with gold and other guilded materials. The entire Angor experience is a once-in-a-lifetime experience.
my favorite temple!. The faces are unique compared to the other temples and it feels like you are going through a maze. Amazing.

Bayon Temple Tour. Very interesting tour and site. Site of the large Buddha heads that have four faces on each tower. Tour requires a lot of steps to climb. Very intricate carvings that have survived the ravages of time. Should be in pretty good physical shape to take this temple on.
One of the best temples. Probably better than Angkor Wat and less busy!! Going early is a must in order to beat the rushes. Gorgeous temple and really interesting history
Worthy for exploration. The striking feature in Bayon temple is the smiling head on the gopura. One wonders as to how the head which is itself made of multiple stones is made to smile.

Welcoming Smile. From a distance, I felt the temple welcoming me and my husband to not only get near and around it but most of all to "discover its beauty within". Am glad we spent a good time walking in and through this amazing structure. Impressive architecture !

Unique for its many smiling faces. This temple is unique for 54 towers with more than 200 hundred smiling faces of the manifestations of the Buddha. There are several sections to this temple and small and big steps get you into some narrow areas. The temple is truly beautiful with its many statues. This temple is part of the Angkor Thom complex
Amazing. it's really touch my heart about this temple, we must visit, I love so much, it shows us a lot a cambodia living standard in history. I seem I was there .

Most complex temple in Angkor. Full of smiling Buddha's faces all over the temple. It is pretty amazing. The complexity of the architecture and the facts that it was built in the 12th centuries will make go WOW ! How did anyone do that without a designing software ?!

My third trip to Siem Rap and the temples never fail to excite and impress. Bayon was our third temple of the morning. We had already done Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm and my husband and I were a little weary at this point. (I was thinking back to the hotel for a swim/lunch/rest and my husband was templed out). Our fantastic guide Ramon (we thoroughly recommend him) gently persuaded us to do a quick trip through Bayon (my husband hadn't been before) and we were really glad we did. Everyone should get a "face to face" photo - which looks like you are nose to nose with one of the temple faces, and it's very different to Ta Prohm and Angkor Wat. I think if you are staying a few days and can pace yourself with the temples - not try and do too many in one day - you will get more out of it and enjoy it more.
Very interesting. Great to have a wander around, the faces are still very obvious. Lots of people though. And currently doing restoration works.
Marvelous ruins. History comes alive when you walk through these ancient ruins, you can imagine what it was befre the jungle started to reclaim it.

Best temple of the park!. We really liked this temple because it completely differs from all the other structures in the area. In Ayutthaya in Thailand as well as Sukkothai you can find temples that resemble the rest of Angkor park, even though Angkor is by far the biggest assemblage; however nothing looks anywhere near this one. It's unique and the many faces of the king looking at you from all sides really makes the experience worth the time!

Must see the smiling Buddha temple. Smiling faces all around you and a very unique architecture make this temple a special one.Bayon is one of the most stunning temples within the Ankor temple complex. Perfect for a unique photo shot of an smiling Buddha. The somewhat round temple amazed me and is very different from anything else in Siem Reap.You must see this once in your lifetime!!
Worth the visit. Worth the visit of the temple. Would recommend when you have a day pass to visit all of them. Also walk from it to the elephants terrace to see the heads of them.

Amazing Face Towers. This is one of the main temples to visit and it's easy to see why. It is different from the other temples with stunning face towers all over. Really impressive. But it also means this place is very crowded with tourists. Shockingly I saw a Chinese tourist who lit up a ciggie, and got reprimanded by the guard. Do behave when you are visiting a sacred place. If you only have a one-day pass, please make sure you visit Bayon.

Our first glimpse to the Angkor past. We visited this temple toward the end of the day on our first day in Siem Reap. Although small, the many carvings were in-tact and we were able to gain an appreciation of what was to come over the next three days of our stay.

One of my Favourite Temples. This is one of the most stunning temples but you must take the time to look at the relief carvings around the base as well as all of the faces on all of the columns. When you compare the faces you will see that they are different. Having your photo taken with the Apsara dancers at the top level makes a nice souvenir. Unfortunately this temple becomes quite crowded at times and some of the tourists are not considerate of others.
I would do it again. Yet another unique site. Some might not classify this as one of the better ones, I most certainly do
Stunning. This old temple are amazingly built from the stone. I cannot imagine how people in the age can built such a beutiful building. The tower are made like 4 faces seing anywhere. Amaxing

Legendary!. Not for those who can't climb. This holy site house many scenic views. If you combine the different angles and different weather conditions, will get an infinite possibilities of shots that makes this place a truly awe inspiring place. One word: breathtaking.
Incredible. I visited with my 4 sons, and they spent hours exploring Bayon. Simply amazing and their favourite temple at Angkor. Loved it.

Surreal!. One of the best temples I have ever seen. Very interesting sculptures. Very unlike others. Aside from Angkor Wat and , possibly Angkor Thon, this one you definitely have to visit if you have limited time at Siem Reap.

Tree's Tree's and more Tree's. This temple was for sure my favorite. I am a tree lover and to see the ancient tree's that have grown up all throughout the temple is amazing. The temple itself is being restored after damage from Pol Pot Era but it is still a beautiful temple.
Fantastic. Wonderful and inspiring place. It is truely amazing. i will definitely back. One of the best places I have ever been to.
Awesome. We viewed many temples in the Anghor Wat. The Bayon Temple is quite popular... vast, exotic, and intriguing. A must see!

Love the temples. It is just amazing to see these temples and think about how long ago they were built. I really enjoyed the sight and appreciate the amount of work everyone has put into reconstruction. A very interesting and amazing piece of history.
Impressing. It is one of the "must see" temples at Angkor. On the other hand, every tuk-tuk driver will show you it, simply as a part of even basic sightseeing.

Elephants at Bayon. Of course Bayon is amazing (although be aware the money for the park goes to a Vietnamese company not a Cambodian company?). It is one place that should be in everyone's bucket list alongside Angkor Wat. I have been lucky enough to visit twice and I am still seeing new and amazing things. You can ride an elephant through the gates of Angkor Thom to the Bayon Temple. These elephants are rescued from heavy logging work. I suggest you visit the Angkor museum before you go to the temples, as you will have a much better understanding of what you are seeing. Remember both Angkor Thom (where Bayon is sited) and Angkor Wat are still religious sites so be respectful in your dress and behavior. We were very lucky to have Mr Panha from Siem Reap Angkor Car and Tuk Tuk Service as our driver during our ten days in Siem Reap. He provided us with both an air-conditioned comfortable car for those sites further away and fun tuk tuk for sites near Siem Reap such as Bayon. As two women travelling alone in Cambodia, it was good to have Panha as we know he is honest, trustworthy and reliable. He has a chilly bin full of free bottled water with ice in both the car and tuk tuk. Mr Panhan does not do Angkor Archaeological park guiding but he can guide you at Mt Koulen etc. There are plenty of guides waiting at the park. But if you want a safe driver and English speaking guide Mr Panha is your man contact him on (+855) 12 86 45 81, (+855) 975085708 or E-mail and face book panhachhouk@yahoo. He will drive you to see the sunrise at Angkor at 5am and to the Phare circus at 8pm no matter what you need he’s there. He will help you get tickets for all of the attractions including the Angkor Archaeological Park including the Bayon Temple which is also where the Terrace of the Lepper king and Elephant Terrace. If you want to travel responsibly try this idea. On your way into Cambodia you are unlikely to have your full quota of kgs of luggage. Most airlines offer 30kgs but most people take nearly empty suitcases into the country and fill them while they are there. Don’t take a half empty suitcase into Cambodia, fill it up with children’s books, educational toys (no battery operated toys), toothbrushes, soap, shoes, technology items and other useful things. The items don’t need to be new, just in good working condition. Please don’t take lollies or sugary stuff and don’t offer religious items, Cambodians have a diversity of religions available to them, let them choose. You can ask your hotel to distribute the items or take them to the Children’s Sanctuary. If you are lucky enough to have Mr Panha as your driver, then he will know where the most need is and help you get your items to the right place. You don’t have to go along if you don’t want to, just hand the stuff over and then you can fill your suitcase with amazing t-shirts and other souvenirs. If you want to go when there is hardly anyone there try the off-season May to August its very hot (up to 38C or 105F) and can be very dry or very wet but there are no tourists and less pressure to buy souvenirs as there are less sellers. Fewer tourists means better photos. You can expect to see troops of Macaques on the way into Angkor Thom and bats in the darker areas of Bayon, you may smell the bats before you see them. Beware there are young people at the temple asking you to donate to their school, you should beware public education in Cambodia is basically free until high school, although costly private education is available. If you want to donate money for a school, go to the school and donate, don't give to people in the street or at temple sites. Also the young woman in town asking for money to buy milk for her baby, actually sells the milk back to the shop and use the money for herself. Be careful she can get aggressive, do not support this activity there are plenty of really needy people, usually those with no limbs due to land mines, be careful and pick who you help.

The Serenity of Buddha & the Majesty of an Ancient Ruin. The Bayon Temple, within the borders of the ancient city of Angkor Thom, is one of the most majestic temples in the Siem Reap area of Cambodia. My husband and I just got back from a 10 day trip that focused only on this area. We visited many temples, sometimes several a day. Bayon is one of my top 5 temples in the area - vying for first place with Angkor Wat and Banatay Srei. The huge faces peer down from heights at every angle - showering you with serenity. They are beautiful works of art that present the peaceful air of a Buddha. The architecture is incredible for it's day, and the carvings are magnificent - especially considering that they were likely done in situ. I can just picture the master carvers perched on rickety scaffolding chipping away at the huge stone blocks, high in the air, to create these masterpieces. It is a lovely place to spend some time meditating or just contemplating your place in this world. The faces also adorn all of the gates into Angkor Thom, giving you their loving looks as soon as the gates come into view. Currently, you can climb several levels and get up close and personal with may of the faces. This opportunity probably won't last much longer as time and tourists are taking their toll on these ruins. While the faces are superb, the temple itself is majestic, and all of the other carvings are not to be missed, especially the large wall murals. We did the temple, then went back and took an elephant ride around the perimeter - a totally different perspective of this beautiful masterpiece. Depending on the time of year, the best time to see this temple will vary. Check with a tour guide or your hotel for advice. It is better to visit when the crowds are smaller. Go soon - Bayon, as well as all of the other temples in the area, is a sight not to be missed. Add it to your bucket list.
as good as Angkor Wat. the day should be completed to visit this place after Angkor Wat. this history beyond the architecture of this building has more to find out

best historical architecture and monument. Angkor Watt it self is one of the best historical architecture and monument of temple so far. once your there, all the temple around there are a must to give a visit. they have their own character and unique.
Best temple in the Angkor Thom area!. It's really a great temple with all its faces on the many towers. Be prepared to climb some stairs to get to the top but it's worth it.
Hot, but so worth it!. Visited in May so it was hot and humid, but worth all the sweat and time. Make sure you don't rush through it so you have time to ponder all the details.

Almost as good as Angkor Wat. Amazing temple only a few kilometres away from Angkor Wat.Unbelievable design and architecture for its time, loved all the Buddha heads and site is well preserved.Most certainly in the top few temples to visit in Cambodia, would highly recommend doing Bayon Temple.

Buddha faces everywhere. This was my favourite temple in Siem Reap. The beautiful faces are everywhere you look, and you can't help but be calmed by the overwhelming sense of peace throughout the temple.

Vast archeological site. This seems to be a collection of temples each one interesting in its own right. Not as impressive as Ankor Wat but should be visited as part of a tour of the region. A day pass to visit all temples cost $20 or $40 for a three day pass,

Very Nice Temple. This the temple i like more than other temples we trip almost two days. Most more interesting with faces of Buddha it so imazing temple i never saw around the world.
We come see it again.

something different. The carving is something different from the other Wat. Do dropby to visit the place. Be careful of some of the steps shall you be going up some of the higher points, e.g. the library.
Another beautiful temple. This one was my husband's favourite, be sure to check it out. But be prepared for the rubble as they are still working on reconstructing the venue.
Magnificent temple carvings.. A different experience to Angkor Wat, much smaller but you are more in touch with the magnificent carved stonework.
Awesome. Just beautiful. Worth the effort. Take water with you as it is all thirsty work. Make sure you take your camera and remember to look at the Temples from different angles.
Truly a beautiful temple. I was surprised by the carvings throughout this temple and the strategic positioning of the carvings. Do not miss the site of this amazing temple.

The Beautiful 12th Century Temple in Battambang. Banan temple is the best one which was built during the time of Angkor Wat, 12th century, located on the Banan mountain range. Come to check it out by yourself to know how beautiful it will be!

My Favorite of the Angkor Temples. This was the last temple we visited on the first of three days at Angkor. It was my absolute favorite - it was breathtaking! It is in better repair than many of the others, and it has the most character. The faces were mesmerizing, and I went back on my last day to wander around the nooks and crannies, and just soak up the essence. Also, if you go here later in the day/evening (around 5.30/6pm) you get the AMAZING experience of seeing hundreds of wild monkeys! Bring some fruit for them - just be careful, as they aren't scared of humans and may get aggressive. But it was so cool watching them - definitely one of the highlights of my trip.

Amazing, my favourite temple. There is something wonderfully indescribable about this place . it's just very spiritual and the faces are amazing, surreal and will make u smile, get a guide, so you can understand where 216 places came from on the 54 towers. Each has four faces it's just amazing no words can really describe it. This was my favourite temple, above Angkor wat . U walkthrough and soak it up and check out all the carvings which tell the story of the chuning of the milk and wars, childbirth, etc. allow an hour or more , take your water of course its hot and there's not much shade.

The face that launch a thousand tourists. This temple had lots of carved stone faces. The whole site is big and walls adorned with detailed carvings. I can say this temple is the second most crowded temple after Angkor Wat! This temple is big in the outside but when you get in, passages were small (asian-size) The site, like Angkor Wat, is very marvelous also. Tip: you can visit this after angkor wat!

Outstanding Must See. The Bayon temple was our group's consensus second favorite temple in the greater Siem Reap area. Ta Prohm barely took the crown followed by Bayon, then Angkor Wat and Beng Mealea. We went in the afternoon around 3 PM and there were very few other visitors. Clearly a can't miss.

worth the trek. we'd booked a private tuk tuk for the day to do the smaller of the two tours, it was great to see, the down side is that there is no information telling you about what you are seeing, no notices or guides, not much about the history. We had a guide at Angkor Wat who told us that you don't need a guide to visit the other places and temples, I disagree, if you travel all that way to Cambodia why wouldn't you want to understand about it? Very peaceful place full of mystery.

I love this temple!. I came to this temple after watching sunrise in Angkor wat. I felt warm when I entered the temple where you're welcomed by many Buddhas' smiling face. Must try the nose pointing pose with the Buddha's statues there and enjoy the serenity in the temple.

Many faces - facinatng. This is a must do temple. Different to most other temples due to its many huge faces made of solid rock. The shape of the temple is also quite different to most other temples found in the area. Less crowded than Angkor Wat. Do not miss.

The Many of Faces of Bayon. One of the true symbols of the Angkor complex is the Bayon Temple. The large stone faces with their inscrutable smiles. This site is a must see and I'm sure you'll see it. It's on most programs and guided tours. Probably all guided tours as otherwise I'd image you'd say "where were those faces?" And the answer here at the Bayon. So go face to face with the faces. Truly a one of a kind experience.

Love the gigantic faces!. It's unique massive faces of King JayavarmanVII and beautiful wall carvings too! If you have the time and if you enjoy elephant rides, you can take the elephant rides for USD20 for 15-20 minutes around Bayon temple. There you can get better view around it or you may take the elephant ride outside of Bayon temple which is around a small jungle.

Amazing amazing amazing!!. Bayon is a must do when checking out the temples at Siem Reap. An easy site to see after doing the sunrise view of Angkor Wat. I am still amazed at the sites in this beautiful country!
Happy. A very happy place to be - with lots of smiling faces looking over you. Lots of history and lots of people everywhere.

Special, A must visit. One of a kind temple, many faces and the outer walls are filled with great and details carvings of the various stories being told from their time. Went about 1.30 p.m. before the crowds came in.

Much better than Angkor Wat. This temple is great to explore with the numerous (216) Buddha faces and levels. It is part of the Angkor Thom area and it was the best place we visited while in Siem Reap.

You've got to see those serene Bayon faces!. The Bayon temple is at the center of the Angkor Thom complex. Its unique feature are the numerous faces of the buddha facing the four directions. It's apparently built by the buddhist angkorian king who built 300+ other temples. The Bayon faces apparently reflect his own. Tag along a guide for tips on great foto spots. One of my fave temples for sure!

Majestic Bayon. Truly majestic....imagine such art can be done in the ancient times without technology. The whole temple area totally takes the breath away and completely awesome. A definite must for all travelers to visit this ancient site.

Worth checking out the bas-reliefs.. 54 towers, 216 heads, very impressive . Some of the areas are under restoration. The area was quiet in regrads to locals selling things and also not many tourists at 130pm, so freedom to move easily around and take people free photos.

When in Ankor Wat do visit. History and ruins make a great destination. Tickets for the temple area need to be purchased first at an entry gate. Get there early as the queue builds up. Our guide whom we had booked from our hotel was able to give us a good insight into the temple. We loved the faces on the stone work. You need patience to take photos, as everyone else is also wanting to be photographed in front of a smiling face. Ability to climb over stone masonry and up steps which are uneven is necessary. Suggest going early to avoid the hottest part of the day.

MAGICAL, A Must see, do not miss it. This is a magical place, all the Buddha faces looking at the horizon, the construction and the overall landscape is fabulous, one of our Top 3 in Siem Reap. Try to go early in the morning or in the afternoon. Just magnificent.

Fantastic!. The Bayon was my favourite out of Angkor Wat , Ta Prohm and the Bayon. Make sure you go upstairs to be surrounded by the faces. Wear comfortable shoes, a hat and sunscreen and bring some water.
Magnificient. This was the best place I have ever been. I just love the way you see faces of Buddha no matter what direction you are looking at. Just incredible.
Stunning. One of my favorites simply because all the Buddha heads are just so beautiful. Take your time and look and appreciate all the carvings. These are spectacular places.

Beyond Bayon. This is the temple of many faces. If you can, either hire one of the many guides available there or listen to the various guides as you walk the grounds alone for the good picture and viewing spots. It can be crowded but take your time here.
My favorite Siem Reap temple. The architecture is amazing! The heads look spectacular. I had a great time visiting this temple. Please wear sunscreen and a hat!!
Stone faces. This is my favorite temple, the serenity of the stone faces is unforgettable. It is mind blowing that these withstood time and the elements.
great. A great must see, plenty of places to eat and drink nearby, the whole area is studded with various temples all of which give an insight into Cambodia's past
Bayon. Bayon is not to be missed.....spectacular.... going during popular or rainy season will allow you to take pictures with water reflection.

Stunning temple. Although not as famous as the main temple at Angkor Wat, Bayon is truly spectacular. The carvings on seemingly every wall of the temple vary in scale from vast to the delicate. The symmetry is stunning given the lack of computer aids ! Look through the various doorways and arches and through each one you will see an image.Superb .

My favourite Temple. That's a big call... the favourite of all the temples. Reality is they all have unique characteristics that make them all cool. The Buddha heads and bas-relief work here is amazing. I'm stunned that they allow people to walk around and over these temples, and in the future they may not. Get there asap before this changes.

Amazing place.. If you visit Sime reap you must visit this amazing temple. People generally call it as multiface temple as we can see faces in all angles. A nice place to try funny poses with your camera.
So many faces!. Was really cool to see all the carvings of faces. Definitely worth a visit, especially since you'll most likely have this included in the circuit tour of all the temples anyway.

A magical monument. It is a mystic monument and to just gaze at it from a distance will transport you to different world. There are some very good picture spots outside the temple premise that provides perfect background for photography. Ask your tour guide for the same.

Crowded, but cold. Go at lunch time.. Quite a few people there, even at low season. However, the way the temple is built offers a good air flow and some much needed shade. Go here between 10-13 to get out of the burning sun. Not as many people at lunch time.It's beautiful, and the faces look serene. Remember to cover up (shoulders and knees) or you won't get in.

Fascinating. The faces and architecture is amazing. On a very hot day
, we found it peaceful and cool within the many buildings. There are at least 22 Hugh blocks positioned for each facial feature - out of this world .

What a way to "house" your gods. Testament to the power of religion, this masterpiece of engineering and construction is something to behold. Watching the repair work currently being undertaken, one is reminded their were no such luxuries as power, engines, highly efficient power tools etc. in the times Bayon was built.With a knowledgable guide - or a good guide book - take time to soak up all that thisplace has to offer.HINT - go early in the morning before the heat kicks in!!
Get your camera ready for this stunner!. This was my favourite ruins, a jaw dropping site with the most amazing faces cut into the temples. Loved it! A photographers paradise!

Beautiful place to visit. Well worth the visit, could return again and again, such a peaceful place, well kept, many tourist buses in pm so go in the am. Lots of steps so those who are challenged with steps may find the higher areas difficult to access. If a guide attaches themselves they will require payment
Very cool. This temple for me has it all with the massive faces in the towers as well as the interesting stella on the walls. It was great.

I prefer it to Ankgor Wat. 54 towers , 261 faces and some brilliant reliefs , anybody doing the temple tour ( inner circuit ) must do Bayon , went there late morning in July , no tour groups , some small guided groups , a couple of annoying " students " wanting to be guides ( but very gentle compared with most of Asia ) just and amazing place looking at smiling faces

Marvellous. When you see Bayon for the first time, one thing you strikingly notice is that its uniqueness. It is unlike any other famous Khmer temple. It has these "Face Towers" on top of its halls. Those carved faces have serene expressions. The intricacies of the carving are quite amazing. It is simply a not to miss place.

A face at every turn. This temple is incredibly beautiful with such detail. We visited it just after 9am before the heat settled in. The faces lure you in. Such detail. This one is so different and my favourite. Photos turn put so well even if you are hopeless at taking them. We spent a lot of time here. A very spiritual feeling. We hired a car from the Golden Temple residence where we were staying. This was a good idea even though it cost $US40.00. We were able to see the sunrise over Angkor Wat and return for breakfast to the hotel and be back just after 9am for the Bayon.

Many, many stone faces to study.. Bayon Temple was our second temple of our tour after Ta Promh, the work that has gone into this place is awe inspiring. I was really taken with the many stone faces of the bodhisattva Avalokiteshvara and got some fantastic photos that we will be putting onto canvas, simply spectacular.

Awesome place to visit. An awesome place to visit. Many years of history, especially the architecture. They were so far more advanced than we think. Allow yourself a minimum of 3 days to explore all the temples in the area. My advice, have a day off between visits, its a lot to take in.

Highlight of our temple exploration. It's really hard to find the words to describe this wonderful place. Go for sunrise and have it all to yourself while the masses chatter away at Angkor Wat. Climb to the top level and commune with the looming faces. Wait for them to open their eyes, because you'll become convinced they will.

My favorite temple during my Cambodia trip!. Within the walls there are stories to tell of the Khmer empire, their whole lifestyle carved within the walls. What is even more amazing is the -- faces carved all over the top part of the temple! It is simply amazing that there are over 200 smiling faces carved and I am still in disbelief that I was actually here!

Stunning temple, very photogenic. We got some 200 photos about Bayon with stone faces and this is one of our best shots in Asia.
The temple has something that attract us very very much

A learned experience of Bayon Temple. My experience at the Bayon Temple was so overwhelming with the vast historical architecture and the stories of Cambodia past life written and drawn through out the stones and carvings on the walls. I learned more than a 1000 time more than I would ever find in a book or magazine of the truth in Cambodia history. You have several options to come to the temple ether by elephant or by TukTuk...I was able to do both and have a different perspective in each.... In walking among the ruins of the Temple, you feel the life essence of the past and the difference of the present by seeing the various indention of the stone walk ways where countless lives moved and lived and many stories lined the walls....In riding the elephant around the Temple grounds, you actually get a feel of the every day ease of commerce that was lived in the past and see the grand size of the structures of the area... I learned so much in my stay in Siem Reap that it added a new perspective on my growth in life that I for ever can give thanks to this experience..........

Wow-Wee. The Bayon Temple is ALL good. You can snap photos here all day and always finds great new targets and angles. You can spend an hour or four hours. I have done both. You never get tired of discovering, stunning new things. For me, I know there is yet more to uncover.
Most beautiful temple. The many faces that adorn the temple is really beautiful. It was a shame that when I was there, there were simply too many people.
A must see. It is a must visit. It's quite a unique temple and different from others you see in Siem Reap. The faces on top of the temple are worth your time.

the world most famous smile. watch the very special smyle of the remainig sculpture of Bayon Temple, this same smile can be found among Cambodian girls population the bayon smile made cambodia famous you can find aswell in vietnam mekong delta population (Kampuchea Khrom) it is believed that the famour head represent the king god him self ! visit the ruins at late afternoon to try to avoid the crowd and selfie crazy girls

Better than Angkor Wat temple. Bayon temple is very close by. I liked this temple more than the Angkor Wat temple for its architecture. There are many many smiling Buddha heads in this temple and this adds to the awe and mysteriousness of the temple. There are stories carved on to the wall which reflect great craftsmanship. The guide may also show you bullet marks on the temple walls by the Vietnam soldiers. There are many hindu mythological stories, but if you are already familiar with the same, I still to see this temple cause the similing Buddhas are really fun to take pics with!
It was incredible. The Bayon is massive and simply incredible to behold - definitely should be on your lists of temples to visit if you're on limited time.
A must see temple when in Siem Reap. A mesmerizing site indeed.It is a glaring example of how Hinduism flourished in South East Asia centuries back
interesting. a interesting temple it has a heap of stone faces around the temple we had a guide that explained all about it and the story is quite interesting.
Beautiful Temple. Bayon is one of my favourite temples, very nice but the crane doing the renovations was a bit of a distraction. Nonetheless, the temple was well preserved.
My favourite temple. The temples at Angkor Wat are amazing but this was the best and most interesting one for me. It was wonderful to explore with my son.

On of my favorite temples. Bayon was one of my favorite temples around Angkor Wat.
It's a nice place to take some unique pictures and walk trough the ruins.
As everywhere there are as well big chinese tourist groups but as they are rushing trough the temples just wait two minutes and they will run away;)
It's just amazing. Picture just can't do justice to the amazing view of Bayon Temple. It is a MUST to visit if you appreciate art, architecture and history.

An under rated temple. While low on hype about the various temples, Bayon scores over all others by its sheer sculptures and peace it brings with. It is usually less crowded and you can enjoy the place very peacefully.
Great ruins. This is a must for a photograph. The temple is being restored, but there are still lots to see, including the tree roots eating into the temple.
Ancient faces. This is one of my three must sees. The picture is from Ta Prom. It is an amazing place. You need to get a tour guide or read up on it. Rich in Budda history and more.

A highlight of our trip. A must see while in Cambodia. We were there in April and it was not to crowded. Is best to have a private guide to answer all your questions. Ground uneven wear appropriate footwear. There is do much information available for this temple. I advise you to read up before going. It is like going back in a time capsule.
Happy temple. I just love the 4 faces smiling Buddha that scattered in all part of the temple building, it cheers you up. So this is another must visit temple in Angkor wat complex.

Fun to explore. Great to climb around and explore, especially with all the giant carved faces smiling at you. The only negatives were the searing heat and humidity - should have gotten up earlier! One other unfortunate thing about this temple and the others in the area are the unofficial "students" who attempt to befriend you and then ask for donations for "guiding" you through the site. Not sure why the authorities allow this but your money can go to a much better cause.

Interesting Stone Faces. A place not to be missed lots of beautiful interesting faces in this area in Chinese you will see their happy sad sorrow and angry faces unlike Angkor Wat and Ta Phrom lots of restoration work need to be done there.

Move onto here from Angkor Wat. It is ideal for you to head here early after the sunrise at Angkor Wat, since hordes of tourists will make their way here after the sunrise. If you bike here quickly, you will have the entire temple to yourself and a few others. When I was heading back to Siem Reap, this temple was surrounded by literally hundreds of tourists.Lesson: come early.

Put this on your bucket list!!!. Such a small country ripped apart through history. Touring Cambodia is a wonderful, interesting and fascinating experience. I thoroughly recommend the Tour operators Travel Marvel of Victoria Australia.

Beautiful architecture. I personally liked Bayon temple more than Angkor Wat. Very intricate work on rocks and feels enchanting. I would have loved to stay longer if not for the scorching heat. Best time to visit Cambodia is between November to February.

Iconic temple in Angkor Thom. This was definitely one of my favorites from the day I spent here. There are great photo-ops to be found, and you might just happen to see some monkeys hanging around as well. Try to hit this temple early, as it is one of the most popular in Angkor Thom, and can get pretty crowded with tourists later in the day. I was very lucky to have my own guide who was quite knowledgeable on the history of every temple, which further enriched my experience.
