Interesting stonework. This was one of the better and more interesting complexes of temples, easy to access, but with few cafes or rest stops around.
Just Amazing!. Of course it's crowded, but it's huge, so you don't really feel the crush of the crowd. Phany took us around to see the highlights. Of course you have to see this!
By far my favorite. This is by far my favorite temple in the angkor wat area. it's a little less crowded than angkor wat itself, but it's just as magical.

ONCE IN A LIFETIME TRIP….... This was absolutely a trip of a lifetime…The amazing fact that the temples are still standing and your able to travel through them is wonderful. I loved everything about the history of the temples. We viewed four temples in one day, along with, seeing the floating village

Baron...a temple to turn heads. Wow! Breathtaking and a wonderful energy to the place made even more special with the coincided visit of many monks in their beautiful orange robes. Truly a place of great spiritual importance and a must for every travellers "to do list".

Part of Angkor Complex. These temples defies the imagination and have to be seen to be believed, there are so many of them. We spent a day with a tuk tuk driver who spoke good English and gave us a lot of information. He was based at our guest house.
More beautiful than Angkor Wat!. It is more beautiful than Angkor Wat! It is very peaceful and the faces are really nice. It is very good for photos.

different not same. Close to siem reap Visitors centre simple and with a lot of information
Dislike too long and regular skils in Engkish in visitors centre
like open air activity with friendly staff
better with a Guide to get all the tips

Preferred this over Angkor Wat.... I liked this temple complex a little more than Angkor Wat, I found the carving to be more vivid and more towards what I was expecting to see from Siem Reap in terms of ruins. Got some great photo's here!

Favorite Temple - Very cool (3-6 faces in every picture). Loved this temple. We thought it was the best of the ~10 or so that we saw. The many faces of Buddha watch you from every angle. Go early to beat the crowds. We got a multi day pass to the temples and did not regret it. We went for a couple of hours each morning by tuk tuk. We beat the crowds and were back in time for lunch. This was a great way to experience Siam Reap.

Avoid weekends. This is the main temple at the centre of Angkor Thom, and is really quite a sight with all the carved faces. I strongly recommend visiting this temple during weekdays to avoid the crowds and picture posers. After Bayon you can carry on around the rest of Angkor Thom, it's hot work walking around, parasol recommended!

Absolutely gorgeous!. Bayon Temple is a must visit when you're in Cambodia, especially if you are a photographer. So many beautiful details to admire and capture through your own eyes and your camera. Would recommend visiting early in the morning straight after seeing the sunrise at Angkor Wat.

A rival to Angkor Wat. We hired bikes in town and rode around ourselves. Be prepared to hand over photo id. I DID NOT leave my passport left my drivers license instead. Even though it was very ho,t we paced ourselves, took plenty of water and food. We do ride bikes back in Queensland Australia so are used to it being hot. We did Angkor Wat one day, then the rest of the small circle the next day including Bayon. It reveals Angkor Wat! You do not need to take a tour or guide, just read up before you go and take Lonely Planet's Cambodia travel guide. It has heaps of info.

very high light of my trip. One of the most beautiful and mind-blowing things I've ever seen.i went with about 10 people on tour but a hair people went back to the hotel because of heat.i am from japan so i got used to humid weather so it was not that bad.you must see it if you travel cambodia.

khmer smile. the most attractive place for me on this trip.
you can see the whole temple full of khmer smile.
recommended visiting time : b4 8am

the most impressive of Angkor's. between the Angkhor temples , this one os the most impressive, with all it's stone faces and despite it's relatively minor size.
it's situated in the same area of Angkhor complex, possible to get there only by local tuktuk, couldnt' pass with our own motorcycles.
Impressive temple but way too crowded. Impressive temple but unfortunately way too crowded to explore or take pictures or just sit around and enjoy.

Holiday. Normally we dont visit temples any more having visited Seim Reap once a year for the last six years,thought we would try this one last time.
Very easy to get around ,take water,not very crowded,no pressure from Hawkers

faces on temples. huge temples with faces! majestic. just so amazing. after passing by the gates with guards pulling the snake, the terraces of the elephants and the leper king, it is just worth to visit the bayon lastly in the ankor thom.

Amazing place. We was suprised by the beauty of this temple with a big face og Boudha looking at you, together with Angkor wat, Bantay Sreay and Ta prom, they are most beautiful places to discover in Siemreap
My favourite of all the temples. If you think that Angkor Wat is amazing, just wait until you see this place. Truly remarkable, steeped in history, and the surroundings are just beautiful.

The most detailed temple in Angkor. Bayon is the jewel temple in Angkor. This temple is a very detailed temple where you will be astonished as soon as you see it. Avoid the kids who will help you explain the history, or help you select places for picture taking because at the end, they will ask you for moeny for their "services."

Awe-struck. This was my favorite temple of them all. The detail in the faces is amazing, it must have been something to behold in its time. If you don't see this temple, you are missing out big time.It is much cooler in the small rooms up on the highest level. So it is a nice reprieve from the relentless Cambodian heat and you don't need to climb too many stairs like at Baphuon or the Crematorium.

Great Experience. This was the first temple we visited during our trip 2 days ago. We went in riding an elephant for $20 per person. The tour guide said the are not too many elephants so some tourist don't get to ride at all (we got lucky!). Our tour guide Hiek explained the carvings on the walls and what the temple was all about. There were also monkeys freely and confidently walking around everywhere, one of which walked towards me and I got scared a bit, but it just looked and walked away. Definitely a must to visit this place and take a lot of photos!

Breath taking. Truly humbling to have laid eyes on. Whilst it is incredibly busy and one of the main temples all the tourists want to visit it is worth it and you would kick yourself for missing it out.
A day to remember. The architecture is amazing, we also had an elephant ride to this amazing site, and the sun was shinning.

Most myterious. What a most mysterious faces we have had ever seen before visiting Cambodia! over 216 huge smiling faces carved on sandstone, appearing all over the Bayon temple. Everywhere we are looking, the faces are watching at us like gods watch our daily life ...who are they? god or Buddha or Khmer king Jayavaman 7.....strongly reccommended to hire a guide!

Face's of life. Dont miss this huge face accross all four corner..Yes, all four corners huge human structured face where amazing n breathtaking..Selfy is must!!!! Also another ancient master piece whereby im not sure who is that face actually. Sure one day will find out!!
Sightseeing. One of The most beautiful, fascinating and enchanting temples in Angkor Wat complex. It's a must see. Those faces are well preserved and there's so many of them. A masterpiece!

Self guided temple. The temple of faces was grand & magnificent. Easily accessible temple. Monkey about & less hawkers than the other temples. Pop over the road & be sure to visit the terrace of the elephants...wowsers those ancient Khmers were such visionaries. Truly breathtaking.

Place of many faces. This lived up to expectation. It's a great place to get some great photos and see this very famous temple with so many faces. They are doing a lot of renovation on the sight and is a bit awkward to get around the narrow passages, plus you are meant to only go in one direction, so when there are a lot of people, it can be a bit hard to get around. Still would make it a place to go, maybe better later in the afternoon, especially in the summer period, as there are a lot less people there.If this review is helpful, please tick below:

The Faces Look at You. Bayon Temple has hundreds of faces looking down upon you. Depending on who you ask, the Bayon Temple faces could be that of the Buddha, of the Bodhisatwa or the King. But they all look at you, peaceful and calm. Definitely a place to visit

Just as incredible as Angkor Wat . As part of our Angkor tour my girlfriend and I visited Angkor Thom, a large area with The Bayon in the centre. Angkor Wat is incredibly impressive from a distance but when inside after a while the walls, turrets, towers and archways start to look alike. Not Bayon temple, which is - in our humble opinion - more interesting than Angkor Wat up close. 54 towers each with 4 large smiling faces staring down at visitors, this temple is fantastical and surreal and photogenic.It's part of the city of Angkor and can be visited on a 1 day tour in combination with Angkor Wat and Ta Phrom.

A Must See. An amazing temple that the large faces stare at you from so many angles. The stillness of the area was truly amazing as we sat and contemplated how these were built. A must when visiting Siem Reap.

As beautiful as Angkor, but different. This temple is absolutely stunning. The towers have huge faces of Buddha that make for a most impressive effect even from a distance, but truly monumental from close up. Experts believe they are portraits of the builder, king Jayavarman VII the greatest king of Cambodia and one of the world's most amazing rulers, who was also a great builder of temples and hospitals.Climbing up to the terraces to see the monumental sculptures closer is very much recommended.

Faces in stone. Dont miss this one. The many faces of mostly the same king stare stonily ahead, ignoring you, but you cannot ignore them. Imagine the work involved, and the narcissism of the creator who decided to make this stone memorial to himself! Quite many photo ops here, but some tricky steps.

Fantastic and breathtaking. In the middle of the massive complex of Ta Prohm lies the wonder that is the Bayon, one of the most interesting and unique temples you'll ever encounter.Walk around it, climb inside it and let the hundreds of heads carved within the walls we your witnesses. 100% recomended
amazing. beautiful place a must visit!!! went on my own just hired a tuk tuk for the day cost me 15 USD hired a tour guide for 7usd just to learn the history worth it

Not only Faces !. Not only Faces ! But also some interesting stories on its bas-reliefs.In my country, Thailand, there's a festival called "Loi Kratong", which means floating an artificial flowers into the river as for thank you the river.Surprisingly, I found the bas-relief about the festival on Bayon's south-east corner wall !I realized finally, the festival might has its origin here, in Bayon.

I love it.. My all favorite temple in Angkor Wat.Visit as the sun rises, before the hordes of tourist cause the "bayon eclipse"In the early morning the tranquility and majesty of the temple will transport yo into a different time, different world. Thousand years old masterpiece is all yours to explore.

Must Visit!. This place has the face of Cambodia! Great photos to capture and many things to learn. This temple is an important stop in Siem Reap series of temples. So dont miss it. Total time required to see this temple - 60-90 mins. Tip - either go in the morning or in the evening to get better views of the surroundings and the faces look better.
Tour trip. Whew it was hot but worth the trip. The strange faces need to be seen to be believed. However a good guide will add relevance and context. Hawkers can be persistent.
All "Templed Out"? think again..... Another great place to visit in low season to avoid the masses that will be there in high season. Try June if you can.

Beautiful Architecture . Highlights of Bayon temple is the four faces Buddha craft. The view from 1st gallery was awesome and it took me 3hours plus to complete the whole complex. It's also walking distance to Baphoun Temple and ancient King Palace and Tarace of the Elephant.

AMAZING!!!. We liked Bayon Temple so much we went two days in a row. We arrived about 7:30am the first day (Sunday) and already it was busy but went at sunrise the second day (Monday) and had the place to ourselves for an hour. This beautiful, amazing place all to ourselves!! It is worth getting up at sunrise, it really is!!The temples, the ruins, the grounds, everything is magnificent. You need to be able to climb steep stairs if you want to go to certain areas but if you can't you can still wander the grounds and gaze up at Bayon. And all the Buddha faces just make you smile. A trip I will never forget.

For religious and cultural history buffs. A magnificent example of Khmer worship and culture. The panels and architecture are amazing. See it early in the morning to avoid the tour bus operator crowds.
Fascinating temple. Another fascinating and interesting temple from the ancient people. the steps up to the upper hall are super steep.
Meditation jewel. Those temples with mistery and amazing caves to visit. Meditate if you have the time and tere are not so many tourists around.

Lots to See, as Great as Angkor Wat!. The Bayon Temple is one of my favourite temples. It has lots to see and explore, and many spots which are picture-worthy. This is a must visit for everyone. Bayon temple is only 5 km away from Angkor Wat. The best part about visiting this place is to go on a day where the skies are clear and a magnificient blue. That made such a beautiful photo backdrop for us. Should also get a local guide to tell you more about its history. The history of these Angkor temples is both stunning and beautiful.

Another Amazing relics of the yesteryear. Bayon temple site beauty is beyond descriptions. The peace and serenity from the smiling faces make you forget about the heat and perspiration that is so uncomfortable. My only regret is that I have to share these nice moments with tons of tourists and the beautiful experience become unpleasant when they raised their loud voices.

Beautiful temple, plus the gates are very impressive. Bayon temple is part of the walled Bayon complex. This was a walled city and at a time the capitol of the Khmer empire.Very impressive and beautiful to see.

Even Better than Angkor Wat. Angkor Wat is amazing, but for me the outstanding temple in Siem Reap is Bayon.The gates are spectacular, but when Bayon reveals itself it takes your breath away. We took an elephant ride around Bayon - I didn't do research into this beforehand, but I hope the elephants aren't mistreated. Cost $20 a head and you can also take an elephant ride up the hill to Bayon.Could've spent hours exploring Bayon itself, but rushed it a bit as thought we should see other temples nearby, but they weren't a patch on Bayon and it was energy sapping going there and looking around (Baphuon in particular!).

Amazingly Incredible. There is an elephant tour (up to 3 people) around this structure ($20pp). I have been to many spectacular places around the world, and the best way to convey this one is that Angkor is one of the few that are more awesome than the publicity photos and descriptions.This is a two day adventure, at a minimum, just to see the "main" ruins. Be prepared to walk, climb, and be amazed. The first day we went with a guide and driver to see the "inner loop" ruins ($70). The second day we went via Tuk Tuk and traveled the "outer loop" at our own pace. This worked well for us.Musts: loose clothing, hat, walking shoes, sunglasses, bug spray, sunscreen, water and snacks.

Favorite Temple of the Day. The "temple of smiles" was probably my favorite because it was quieter than Angor itself. Our guide made it great, and I loved the stories & details he pointed out. Neat to see reconstruction going on nearby, really cool temple, check it out.

Memorable trip. All temples very amazing ,beautiful scenery..
What I didn't like was the food as I am a vegetarian was difficult for me in my group

Seeing is believing. We've all seen photos or paintings in fashionable furniture shops. But to actually see the Buddha stone carvings is another thing. It makes me feel insignificant & humble. Do get a good tour guide as there are various entry & exit points. Take the wrong one & you can be very lost. Well worth the visit.
Loved the carvings. I really enjoyed the carvings on the front of this temple that depicts everyday life in Cambodia centuries ago - offers a real sense of history and context.

Crowded even during low season. I honestly do not know how crowded this gets in High Season, but, in low season, it was still crowded.
However, this is an absolute Must-See. The faces are amazing and the relief carvings are incredible. Bring a tour guide to get a better understanding on the carving's multicultural history.

Awestruck. I have been to the Bayon temple many times over the past 7 years and it always impresses me. Every time I go I see something new and learn more about this amazing structure. 200 giant Buddha faces plus more.

Amazing Place. We went here as the area opened about 6.00am. It was still dark when we arrived, but created amazing shadows for photographs and we had the place to ourselves. If you have the time I would recommend trying to get to all of the different temples early before the influx of tourists. It definitely makes for a nicer experience and allows for a more relaxed way to view such a beautiful place
Great Temple. Another great temple. Thanks to our guide for figuring all this out. I had 16 college students with me and he kept everybody in a good mood and happy. Even in 100 degree heat.

Amazing. You cannot go to Siem Reap and not see this temple. The scale of this structure and the serenity in every face was unreal.Whilst the whole area is overrun by tourists it's not impossible to find a quite spot to sit and take it all in.Hire a guide if you want to actually understand what you are looking at. They are trained and well worth the money.We went bank for a second day without one and regretted it.
as, solna. It is one of the tmeples you mus tviist, thos enigamatic faces , still remaining to be seen. So many treasures in such a small arean. what a powerful empire it must have been !

Ancient temple. The temple probably dated as early as the 12th century is being resurrected. So many statues of Buddha. You can go all the way up and see the human creation of the ancient world when there were no machines, computers etc.

One of the most amazing temple in Angkor Complex. This Bayon temple is a nicely decorated Khmer temple in the Angkor Thom complex. Said that is was built in the late 12th or early 13th century as the official state temple of the Mahayana.Since then ,this temple was modified as a Hindu temple and Theravada Buddhist Temple by the late Kings.We visit this temple during our Angkor Wat Tour ,and we really thankful for our guide ,who described the history behind every temple we visited. You must show your entry permit to the temple guards, before entering the temple.We observed that the structure and the decorations are very different than the main Angkor Wat temple , and thus the distinctive uniqueness of this temple made it worth to be visited.

Watch your camera's facial recognition go crazy!! Highlight of Angkor Wat. This was one of my highlights of the Angkor Wat Temple complex. The breath taking detail and all of the levels and areas to explore. It's relatively small compared to a lot of the temples so you don't feel like you're missing anything. Facial recognition really picks out so many faces - it does on many temples but non come close to Bayon for quantity.

elephant ride. you can take an elephant ride to the temple. The elephants are at the south gate and they take you to right in front of the temple. The only thing is you don't get to ride the elephant by yourself, you have a guide. Intricate sandstone carvings on what they call a "mountain" temple, because it is more than 1 story.
To see to believe. How could nature be so wonderful. A must see. Grab a local driver and head to the sights. Great value.

Amazing! Probably nothing else like this in the world.. Amazing! Really my favorite temple, which I liked more than Angkor Wat. It's more intense due to having the amazing looking face carvings all in one place, and so many of them. No one would visit Angkor Wat without seeing here though because it's right beside Angkor Wat.

Just Another Piece of Treasure. Another walk that brings back, the reflection of great history and architecture, each corner gives a pieces of treasure to tell and a life time experience to go through.

<3 SIMPLY AMAZING AND BREATHTAKING . More than 1000 years of history well preserved, the faces in the walls (or columns) are all perfect. There are a lot of work going on there to keep all the temples as closest as possible to how looked originally. AMAZING
Small temple but good one. the temple is relatively small compared to angkor wat... yet it is nice and the building is very detailed status ...
Wow!. Within the Angkor Thom complex, the Bayon Temple is wonderful. In many ways, this particular is the highlight of any visit to the Siem Reap complexes.

WOW. Bayon temple is one of must see in the Angor region, A temple with towers depicting four faces was one of the last state temples built by Jayavaraman VII. Most of the temple are in ruins one can see both shiva and buddha images inside the temple. During my visit some restorations were going on.

Buddha bonanza. 54 Budha heads carved into towers, some great photo opportunities for example by having your face or your travel companion mirroring a Budha in a face to face pose; also there are some nice window shot ops for couples.

A Trip Through Time. Amazing stone work from a millennia ago. It is truly inspiring to walk among the ruins and think about the ancient civilization that toiled so hard to build this spectacular temple.
DEFINITELY WORTH A VISIT. Another place that shouldn't be missed. There are so many interesting places in this area that they all deserve a visit
Favourite. Amazing temple, post card shots everywhere, rich in history and despite the heat and the steep stairs, it was an amazing place to visit.
Amazing. Well worth the climb, just be careful, very uneven, but worth it.Loved all the carved faces, glad to see the restoration going on.

The highlight of my life. Wav spending the day ay Bayon, it's indescribable really, you have to experience this for your self. It's tranquil, spiritual, mystical and interesting. The only bad thin was that I did not spend enough time here.... I will be back soon.

A Must See in Angkor. This may be the most famous temple in Angkor after Angkor Wat. Who hasn't seen photos of these huge stone faces?Seeing them in person is truly awesome.In addition to the faces, there is an a surrounding gallery of interesting carvings revealing details of 12th century Cambodian life. Some rural areas in Cambodia still use similar buildings and vehicles.The only drawback is that Angkor has become a number one tourist destination with the crowds to match.The best time to visit is early in the morning before the group tours arrive. Reading something about it ahead of time makes the visit more worthwhile
I like this place better than angkor wat. The faces are surreal. Make sure you visit all thee levels. Then hang out in the cave underneath the tallest cone. There's an area for prayer there.
Four Faces Temple. The Bayon was quite old and impress me with the history of this Four faces. Elephant ride is available after tour inside the temple.
Less crowded and prettier than Angkor Wat. Before you get "templed out" it is worth seeing this one. Less famous, so less crowded and smaller. Spectacular in its own way. Monkeys are cheeky and bold.

Faces, faces, faces everywhere!. One of the most visited temples and for good reason - the faces are all over the place!! You can always see one from a different angle at a different distance. Amazing.

Incredible!. We visited Bayon in the heat of the day, but it was worth it because there were way less people and were able to spend more time looking over the many carvings. These ruins are all that all that they are said to be - mysterious, intricate, and impressive. This site is a must see!
nice to see. This is a temple that you can't escape because you will see the four face temple that no where else in the world.

The Faces temple. Our guide showed us around and took some very unique photos with the heads for us. A guide is a necessity if you want to learn more about the area and to guide you through the maze of walkways.
Nice Temple within. Beautiful setting temple within a big city walls. Wish I could go back in time to see, but I could I imagine how busy it really was.

Awesome!. The temple is awesome! Though it was already rundown and dangerous, it was beautiful with its distinct architectural design. To know more about the temple, there are guides you can hire within the vicinity. To have a better understanding, I suggest that you visit the Angkor National Museum first. My visit there was a lot informative and spine-tingling on how amazing the temples at Siem Reap.*you might want to try visiting the Philippines. Read more at joylenesdayout.blogspot.com
A fantastic temple. The enigmatic faces will stay with you for a long time. Well worth visting at lunch time when many vistors return to their hotels for lunch.

Every visit to the Bayon is a magical experience.. I have visited and photographed the Bayon quite a few times over the last ten years and it is always the place that I want to visit first and look forward to spending time in. On my last visit I was sitting at the top level and just waiting for the light to change and for the fairly large group of tourists to leave, so I could shoot one of my favorite faces. Since I had my camera on a tripod a few people asked me if they were blocking my shot, which was very nice but I was really in no hurry. I also took some photos of the Buddha that had been recently restored and placed inside the highest interior chamber. Reluctantly I moved on after a few hours to continue my journey, but I will return.
Beautiful Architecture. Great place to visit but beware of the children begging. If you succumb to one you get them all hanging around you which can be really detrimental to your visit.

Very busy, good early in the morning. Before reaching Bayon, take some time to Walk up to the old city gate, have a overview of the river, status alone the bridge. At Banyon, Take the elephant tour, it's fun, and don't forget to visit the nearby small towers.
Special. The architecture of this temple felt different than the rest. There were a lot of four faced Buddhas statue heads. It was actually my favourite temple in the Angkor Park.

Touring Bayon with Kim Rieng. Finding a personal guide to the temples of Siem Reap is the key to having an unforgettable experience. Kim Rieng, kimrieng9@gmail.com is that guide. I was fortunate to spend four days touring many of the temples of Siem Reap with Kim but he was especially helpful in showing me the excellent murals of warriors and everyday people at the Bayon temple.He even returned with me for a second hot day of climbing the stairs and studying the amazing multi-headed statues at the top. Always ready with historical and cultural information, Kim made sure to point out special details and photographic angles for my consideration. After 20 years of guiding, Kim has gathered a vast amount of information and a special understanding of how to tailor a tour towards your individual needs and interests. I highly recommend spending several days with Kim Rieng for an enjoyable learning experience.

My favourite temple.. The Bayon equally stands in its own right as a magnificient piece of architecture. 54 towers decorated with 216 coldly smiling , enormous faces staring out over the Khymer empire. As you walk around, a dozen or more of the heads are visible at any one time - full face or in profile, almost level with your eyes or staring down from up high. They are mesmerising and you end up photographing everything. The crowds are less here than at Angkor Wat as you wander around so it feels far more comfortable. There are steep steps to climb to reach each level but no more than twenty on each staircase. Easily managed. The friezes on the lower levels describe everyday life occurring at this time and are a fascinating insight. Renovation is being done to the temple and it was a living reminder to watch craftsmen carry out age old techniques in the twenty first century. The Bayon still is a wonderful monument.
Great place for photos and wandering. Busy by lunchtime and the shadows were flat so photos were less atmospheric so perhaps go earlier or later than we did.

Return visit - didn't disappoint. A certain sense of calm at this site. Love the place - not overcrowded with tourists. Visiting during june when the temperature is highest (36 degrees C) and with less tourist is very different to October when the temperature us much more bearable

Amazing Site, better than Angkor Wat. This is our favourite temple, having been to Siem Reap before we did not want to see all the temples again but we did want to spend time here. We arranged a tuk tuk from our hotel to take us out and we spent 2 hours walking around the outside and through the inside of this amazing place. The faces carved into this place is amazing. They are still restoring parts of it. Allow plenty of time, it truely is worth it. Not as many people as at Angkor Wat and I believe this is more spectacular.

Gorgeous!. Many world which can't describe but from my own is Amazing. I like this amazing mysterious temple.I Like the most about beautiful Khmer carving indie or even outside. Completely amazing and unbelievable. TBH- the gate is amazing and huge and best customer service have been provided. Best experience that I have got and this where you should experience in your life time when you visit Cambodia.
Awe-inspiring. I started my tours of the Angkor temples here earlier, 7:30 am. The crowds had not overrun the temple. I enjoyed the skill, craftsmanship and energy required for its construction.

Great Face Temple. I am very impress by the many face sculptures at this temple. The face represent Hindu gods. This is a must visit temple in Angkor area. Wonder how could they build a huge temple in 11th century? This is a great monument of the world
Amazing sight to behold. This is an unbelievable archaeological site! No one should pass this up. All the pictures do not do it justice
Fantastic. One temple you must add to your list. A little quieter than Angkor Wat but still took us around 2 hours to visit.
Awesome. An incredible temple and complex, amazing ruins, one could spend days wandering around it. Faces galore.
Amazing Temples. It is a must and it is just impressing. Settled between all these other wonders in architecture. Do to think you've seen it by visiting only once.

Don't miss it. If you are visiting Angkor Archaeological Park and you have limited time you must ensure this temple is on your list. It is an amazing site, especially when you start to look at the various carvings. Don't forget to look up and see the amazing faces carved in to the buildings. You can make your own way there but it is worth hiring a tuk tuk driver (we did this through our hotel), for your time here as they can be really helpful in identifying the best bits to see. We would also advise reading up on the place before you go as this helps bring it to life and you can then avoid what can be expensive guides. We went in May and it is very hot at this time of the year; you shouldn't let this put you off unless you have problems with heat. The plus side of this time of year is that the crowds are much smaller. Visit and enjoy!

Fabulous introduction to the temples. Huge temple, loved all the faces, and spent a good hour exploring before moving on to other temples and structures at Angkor Thom. Extremely hot when we visited at 8.30am at the end of May but the benefit was the crowds were not too busy and we managed to capture some quiet moments to soak in the essence of this amazing structure.

Dreamy. I have been playing Temple Run and watching Legend of the Hidden Temple (Nickelodeon) for a long time, this place just gave me overwhelming nostalgia. The carvings on the walls are superb and unbelievable. Seeing the "faces" on the 2nd story was much more incredible. Definitely my favorite temple on the Angkor Thom area.
Birthday celebration. was my great experience here have so much fun with my friend and my birthday was excellent going on here
Probably the coolest one. The faces are very cool. Don't do the elephant ride its a waste of money and at $20 per person it was probably the most expensive thing I did that day.

Superb!. This place is amazing, take your time to see all the temple, the level of details that it was constructed is incredible, try to visit it early that will be better for you because your pictures will be free of people
Freaking cool. Temple with so many faces. Worth seeing. Each temple has its unique features and the faces on the towers in each direction are very cool and each one is different from the next

You can do this without a guide. One of the great temples of Angkor but you do not necessarily need a guide to visit here. Sure it will help but if you like moving at your own pace, you can explore and learn with a locally purchased guide book.

Our favorite temple. This temple was by far our favorite! There was no construction going on like there was at a lot of the other temples, and it felt so untouched and fun to explore. It is small enough that there isn't a crazy number of other tourists there like Angkor Wat, and big enough that if there are others you can go explore different areas on your own. One piece of advice, unless you like to hear all the little tidbits of information about it, we just took a tuktuk and enjoyed the experience and didn't feel that we "missed out" by not going on a tour, but I suppose that also depends on what kind of traveller you are. We just sometimes prefer exploring and discovering on our own:)
Beautiful. Go early to avoid heat and crowds. Park at one end of the complex and walk around to the other temples. Avoid the hawkers- they have all the same stuff you can get at the markets.

It's Beyond WORDS !!! One of the BEST !!!. It simply is a Breathtaking , unique and mesmerizing experience !! We spent about 2 hrs there , but i want to go back once again !! No doubt Angkor wat and Angkor Thom have their own beauty , but Bayon Tempel has a different pull, I was quite intrigued by the beauty and serenity of these 900 year old carvings . There actually are no words to describe the Majestic Beauty of this temple. You can spend hours n hours just looking at the beautiful Buddha Faces. Some say as it was made by Hindu king , its the face of Brahma , everyone has a different story .Please take enough water with you ...and be ready for lots of crowd :(And also go there with enough time on your hands and with a guide.PS- From one specific angle you can sit at a window ledge and pose as if holding the statue in ur palms - ask the security guards if you want to have some quirky pics :)

Didn't know about it. Hadnt heard of this place till i got on the tour and it was a very nice find, easily spend 3-4 hours here taking pics and learning about the place. again wish i had got a guide as there is a lot to learn and some hidden gems i only found by accident.

Surprising. I didnt know about this till i got there, but spent a fair few hours walking around here, and could have spent more if i wasnt travelling with others. There is so much history i do wish i had taken a guide for this temple. Great for photography

The temple with 216 gigantic faces. Was our daughter's favourite. Went at the end of the day, not as warm and less crowded. Great photo opportunities! Visited quite a few temples in the area but this one is amongst the 3 top ones that you should visit. The other two Angkor Wat obviously and Ta Phohm.

A must see!. One of the best temples in Angkor Thom.The best way of visiting is go with a guide or you will miss the story behind and a lot of photo points.But if you don't have a guide, you will always be approached by corporate police or locals, they are actually guides to hire.They are not just friendly citizens but expect to be paid after a temple or a few temples.If you don't want their service, just smile and keep walking on.
Go Bayon. This is why you need to buy the three day pass for $40 to the whole structure of the temple complexes.

a must-see destination. Those who love history will love this place, however, as it's outdoor, the weather can be very hot & humid that it will drain your energy. Bring lot of water & wet towel with you
One of the most amazing things I have ever seen. My second favourite temple - absolutely stunning! Not to be missed and you should plan at least an hour (better two) in this one

Something Special. Yes, Angkor Wat is the jewel in the crown, but this place is something special. Very hot when we went but all those lovely serene faces staring wisely into the distance is just brilliant. Enjoyed very much

What do the four faces of the Buddha statue mean?. This temple is breathtaking. I was curious to understand what the four faces mean. Different meanins depending on who you ask. One comment was when praying the front view is for business and wealth, left hand side wisdom, back view is health and the right hand side is for relationships. Another view and one I liked was the four faces represent simplicity, compassion, equanimity and wisdom.The faces are mesmerising. The temple is small compared to Angkor Wat. It is also a bit sad to see it covered, and I include myself among them, hordes of tourists. There is little management of the site with a few guards and a one way system to avoid jams on the staircases you climb up to get a closer look at the four faces. Be prepared for crowds, we visited in the low season and it was packed. There also is work taking place on the site. I expect in a few years time a quota restricting the number of tourists visiting Bayon Temple. Otherwise it will be slowly destroyed by peoples admiration of it. I remember years ago wandering around the Acropolis in Athens with unfettered access. Returning a few years ago there are now restrictions in place to prevent people going up to the columns or wandering around it. Still magnificent to visit. Saying all that Bayon Temple is a beautiful temple and should be on your to do list when visiting Angkor Wat Archeological Park.If you found the review useful I always appreciate a helpful vote.
A Must-See!!. A Buddhist temple with more than 200 gigantic stone faces on ~37 towers. There is no bad angle so anywhere you stand the photo will be awesome!

Attraction at Bayon Temple. It's a wonderful place,having mesmerising experience.many of the travellers including us were taking photographs through mobile bringing close our face to the giant sculpture.we have touched our nose to the figures which are very very attractive and innocent.We strongly recommend to visit Bayon Temple and take a full round to the entire area.The view of the surrounding area also looks nice from this place.Do not miss,and be a part of Face of Any one of them to take back in memory.

Beautiful Bayon. Quite amazing how clearly visible those faces are, beautiful smiling faces looking down at you. We had hired a guide for the entire day to accompany us to all sites and it was money well spent.

Dreamy. This is a WOW place. The carvings in the rocks of the buddha are mind blowing. It's a little small and tight but so worth going to see. I could sit there for hours and hours. It's so peaceful and relaxing. If I were a monk... and I've thought about it :) I would live here. Yeah you should go and be wowed!

Small but beautiful. Compared to Angkor wat, the Bayon Temple is smaller but with more temple towers. The giant stone faces are extremely to details and makes me wonder with awe. It's definitely not something you see everyday.
Recommend . Part of the Angker Wat tour highly recommended make sure you get a god Tuk Tuk driver tour guide if wanted I Tuk Tuk driver had enough knowledge for us
Love the faces. Bayon is mesmerizing. I never tire of the faces. Bas reliefs of everyday life are fascinating. A must-see.
Fabulous!. Words are difficult to find to describe this wonder of architecture and cultural history. Unmissable!

See to believe. Some 216 faces smiling (Rather large faces at that) at you from different angles makes you feel very happy. One could see undeniable Indian Influence in the complete structure. It is a place one must see to believe

Towering Faces. This temple with the huge faces is enigmatic and incredible to think how ancient they are. Its one of my fave temples. The outer walls have carvings of khmer life/battles. There are some steep steps to climb and the place gets crowded which can be distracting. It was very hot in April, best later in afternoon or morning.

Beautiful and amezing temple. so amezing building 1000 years ago
Must to see them After 4.00 pm , its better
Not hot and beautiful sunshine
Interesting, extensive restoration work required. Enjoyed the visit here but far more restoration work is required. Very hard on the knees with steps etc. to manage
Beautiful. A very popular and busy temple of all of them but an absolute must visit! Try to take a sunrise tour of the temples so that you're there before it starts getting overcrowded!

Most impressing place I've ever seen. This review might be biased as I've been reading about Cambodia and Khmer civilization since I was young. But the fact is Bayon Temple is much more impressing than is shown in the books or on Internet. You definitely shouldn't miss it if you have an opportunity to visit Siem Riep.

Bayon Temple is a stunning sight. We really, really enjoyed our visit to Angkor Thom, and Bayon temple in particular. Bayon is part of the city of Angkor Thom and is the jewel in the crown on this site. A multitude of 4 sided depictions of Jayavarman VII's head (obviously a narcissist!) rear up splendidly and are still in great condition. His serene face epitomised, for us, the mystery and fascination of the ancient Khmer Empire. It was one of the only sites for us where the volume of people didn't matter much as you were largely gazing skywards at these imposing faces on lofty towers!

A face to remember.. As part of the famed Angkor Wat region, the Bayon Temple features carved facial figures on huge blocks of stone, dragged by elephants through the Cambodian jungles up to 40 miles distant, over 800 years ago.
My third choice, impressive. Another area not to be missed - impressive, great for photos and to realize what an ancient culture was able to come up !

Fave temple in Cambodia. When you see Angkor Thom from the outside it looks rather impressive. However, once you trek up the stairs and you come face to face with the hundreds of smiling faces, you realize that impressive doesn't even begin to describe it! the faces will make you feel happy, spooked out and in awe all at once. Beautiful!
Amazing!. I been to Angkor Temple twice then, this year planning to return again. Angkor Temple is a place where I always to return.

Mysterious face. Huge stone carving faces and indescribable smiling faces made Bayon , One of the most mysterious religious and wonderful monuments in the complex city of Angkor ever built by human beings.
It was absolutely our favorite temples of Angkor... Highly reccommended!

Amazing. I really enjoyed the temple grounds with the faces etched on the four sides of some of the structures. This is definitely one of my favorite places. Although it is extremely hot but as long as you are prepared with an umbrella and water it is a great experience. We went early in the morning and it was not top crowded.
Great Stuff. another amazing temple in the Angkor Wat set of temples. Take plenty of water as it is a hot walk. Feel time pass around you.
Do the sunrise here. Beautiful and quiet during the sunrise when most folks go to Angkor Wat. Explore all the outside walls also, really beautiful reliefs

Stunning.. Stunning and must visit, top 5 of the temples to do. You have to purchase a 1 day pass for the temples for US$25 that gets you entry into all the temples for the day or US$40 for a 3 day pass. Well worth the fee.
Bayon Temple. Very interesting history. Loved all the faces, rubbed noses with a couple in a photograph. Trekked from Siem Reap to Angkor Thom.

Interesting. It is not a huge temple, like Angkor Wat, but it is a good introduction into the history of temples, one get's an idea of what the temples you might also see will look like. It offers a unique experience when you are surrounded with statues looking at four sides of the world, all over the place. There are, of course, people praying inside, burning scent sticks and offering string bracelets. Participate in this tradition; burn a scent, wear a string :)

Symmetrical structure. A tip to cover this temple quickly. It is a perfectly symmetrical structure. Although there are 216 faces, they look exactly the same. Depending upon the time of the day, just pick a few faces which have enough light falling on them, click them and thats it!!

Very impressive bayon temple. This temple was my favourite out of the three I visited as it was so hot 45 degrees but was mid April very impressed by the big faces on the stone work a real piece of sculpture there must of bin over 20 big faces on this temple definitely one not to miss

Better than Angkor Wat. It's hard to believe but it's true. This smaller temple complex was amazing. Amazing enough that I want to see it again. Elephants roam the grounds and the carvings are very memorable.

Great, complex temple. I can imagine what this would have been like when the temple was first completed - people in awe of the many Buddha faces carved into the stone towers - not to be missed, if only for the nose touching Buddha photos..

Favorite place. Amazing place, My favorite temple of all. Wonderful, peaceful faces looking out in every direction. This is something really special, even in Ankor with all its temples. If you can, avoid the Chinese new year in February, it's crowded, lots of people visits the temples this period. Visit in Febraury 2008
incredible . Those faces inside the stones...absolutely amazing! very beautiful and totally worth the visit! you should go in the morning though or months which are not too hot... ;)

Bayon <aka> Temple of Faces made my jaw-dropped. Angkor Wat has been on my bucket list for quite a long time but I never knew about Bayon before I actually arrived at the place. When I got there and saw Bayon Temple, I was stoned by its amazing architectural outlook. This is a must-visit place when you are going to Angkor Temples. Want to know more about the trip to Angkor temples, you can check out @ http://www.heypt.com/#!Visiting-Siem-Reap-Angkor-Wat-Other-Temples-in-Angkor-Region/c1kiu/55688e3d0cf2adc1ad677703
Iconic!. 216 buddah faces are carved out and shown in this smaller temple. It is nothing less than remarkable. I think this will be my favorite temple in Siem Reap. Just go and see for yourself :-)
Buddha faces at every turn. 216 Buddha faces with different smiles on 54 towers. Simply superb. Only a few minutes drive from Angkor wat.

Get there early. Go to this place first, as soon as the park opens. It is very overcrowded otherwise. Tons of tour busses coming non stop unloading hundreds of tourists all waiting to take selfies in front of the temple before moving on. Breathtaking and hauntingly beautiful temple.

So many smiling faces.... And i dont only mean the ones on the towers... This was one of my favorite temples we went to the three days we spent here. The number of towers with their 4 smiling faces were so amazing. It is hard to not have a smile on your face when no matter where you look you see about a dozen smiling faces carved into the stone. The walls of this temple also have intricate wall carvings. On the top level i just sat in a shady nook and took a few minutes to feel the place and even with the other tourists it was so peaceful. This is a do not miss if you come here, do not just go to Angkor Wat.
Outstanding. There are so many temples that we were very glad to have an experienced guide in Siem Reep. Although hot, it was not too hot in December or too crowded.

Magnificient!!. Words fail you. The sheer scale of the temple with the gigantic Buddhist faces ... takes your breath away. Wiki tells you that there are 216 of them. The labour that went into this construction is mind-boggling. Hit the temple early in the morning to get the right light for photographs. And be warned, the steps are very steep!

Best temple in Asia!. I think this place should be more popular than Angkor wat. It's really amazing. We've been all around SE Asia on our travels and this is the most gobsmacking temple we've seen. It's huge with amazing carvings etc. Definitely worth a good visit.
Impressive. So much to see so take so take your time. The heat is an issue but you eventually get used to it. The temple is so intricate you can only imagine the time it took to create.

Unforgettable. Everybody has seen pictures of the great faces which are the peculiarity of this temple but being there, walking on the stones, touching them is another thing. Try to go there early in the morning, before the assault of the tourists.

All Khmer roads lead to Bayon. All Khmer roads lead to Bayon. That is true within the capital city of the Khmer Empire, Angkor Thom and at its heart is Bayon. The last temple to be built in Angkor before the fall of the Khmer empire, its distinctive characteristics is the four-sided stone faces adorning the towers. The feeling I get when I venture into the temple compound is like entering a maze city. It’s small and compact within, and the twist and turns do make you feel like Indiana Jones excavating your next adventure.Ascending to its summit, I found that Bayon seem compact, claustrophobic even. It doesn’t have the wide spaces such as Angkor Wat, and it’s also a smaller temple compared to its more famed brethren. But there are more hidden corners, unknown pathways, dark hallways that make the experience somewhat more thrilling. Almost as if you’re exploring a road less travelled.Taking a last look at Bayon before heading out. One thing to be careful about while in Angkor is temple fatigue. The heat and exhaustion can set in pretty quickly if you try to see too much too soon. I would suggest pacing and explore over several days. Early mornings and late evenings are more bearable and the light is better as well. Mid day from about 10-4 are hot, and extremely bright and you’ll likely get washout photos instead. I think a better way to explore Angkor is to head out to temples like Bayon at sunrise where the crowd is much more focused on Angkor Wat. Rest through mid-day heat and return to Angkor Wat in the late evening. The heat was simply punishing.
A truely unique temple. The face towers are not to be missed, this temple can be combined with nearby temples. We were a little disappointed that the upper level was not accessible.

Conservation work.. When i arrived there. There are still few section close for conservation works. But i can say this is my second favourite temple behind Angkor Wat. Just be careful with people looks like they want to help you and give you some free informations and then they will force you to donate some money.

Angkor Thom. Each of the sites in the Angkor Archaealogy Park is different, so don't restrict your time to just one. It is good to buy a ticket for two or three days. Go early in the morning to avoid large crowds and this time of day is more peaceful and adds more to the atmosphere. The detail in the stone work is so intricate and carried out over 1000 years ago. An overall very memorable experience.

Love the faces. When I was there there was a lot of reconstruction, so that took away quite some of the temple's charm. Otherwise, the faces are really cool and impressive but the stairs are very tiny and super steep. It's quite a small temple but well worth a visit!
Spectacular. In its decayed state this temple still conjures up images of the grandeur of the Khmer empire. The bas reliefs are some of the most beautiful to be found anywhere.
Let your imagination take over. Just explore every knook and cranny and imagine what it was like in it's hay day. Do not be intimidated by all the steps you have to climb.

Thomb raider door. Yeahhh...believe it or not, have you ever seen Thomb raider movie,there is a fantastic door in movie so well that fantastic door is on Bayon,you need To go....In Bayon you have To care your money and no speak with the teens there ,becausea they talk To you as your friends,they play like a guide tourist to you but they will require you money minimum 10 dollars and if you dont give them money ,they wouldnt let you go away of Bayon ...
Another breathtaking view!. As part of the Angkor Group temples you will be able to visit this Bayon Temple in one way altogether.. explore the world heritage site by Unesco!

A Must See!!. This is one temple I will considier a must see! Angkor Thom itself is a gorgeous place, and the temples within the Angkor Thom are so beautiful!I saw the Bayon from afar, when the tuk tuk driver dropped us. I was awed by the sight, of the building, with faces of Lokeshevara peering at us from all angles. It became even more awesome as we walked closer, and stepped into the building. Not too sure if it was the spiritual atmosphere, but I felt a sense of good light in this temple. There are several levels to go too, using steep wooden steps to climb, and at each level, the beauty evolves. We spent the most time at the top tier, where the faces can be seen most closely and clearly. We see some tourists posing for pictures, pretending that their noses are touching that of the sculpture's nose. Do bring lots of water for your visit, as the weather is real hot, and to get good views, one must stand outdoors. Also wear really good fitting shoes, as climbing is needed.

Incredible!. We thoroughly enjoyed our visit to this ancient Hindu Temple in Siem Reap. We had a great English-speaking guide with us, who pointed out the history and significance of the most important carvings. Great place for photos. Totally unspoiled. Don't miss a visit to this Temple if in the area of Siem Reap. We got to see elephants and monkeys on the way into the Temple. Note of advice....bring plenty of water to drink.

Bayon Beauty. I've been wanting to visit these temples for such a long time. Not disappointed. Take a guided tour to visit the temples Angkor Wat, Bayon and Ta Prohm. It really is worth the extra dollars to have a guide, help you imagine the temples in all their beauty.

Beautiful Buddha Heads. Crowded place as it's one of the top 3 main sites for the temples of Angkor along with Angkor Wat & Ta Prohm. There are elephant rides possible nearby. The site is under construction on one side of it, and they have added wooden stairs to climb the structure to the top, which is easier these days to use and less dangerous, but somewhat take away from the beauty of the place had it not been preserved.Still once on top of the site, you can fully enjoy the beautiful sculptures of buddha faces all around... It is truly magnificent.A gem but alas it is packed filled with tourists these days...
Great.. Take your time and take lots of water if travelling in Summer as it can get really hot in Cambodia. Wear good shoes as many of the temples here are REALLY big.

An amazing place of history. We came here after Angkor Wat and in my mind is better, it thats it not until you get up close you actually see the making of the stone and etching to communicate back in there time..

Almost calming... but so many people..... I fell in love with this temple and the beautiful face of the Mona Lisa of southeast Asia. The Bayon Temple represents the gateway between Heaven and Earth according to the Buddhists who occupy the area - maybe that's why when you are in a space by yourself I felt incredibly calm. It is rather beautiful - but I really wanted to tell some of the rather rude tourists to stop scrapping the walls and get out (mainly because I wanted it all to myself!).
Amazing. you'll just love to see the creations from ages where there were no technologies. Enjoyed every inch of it. Awesome place to take pictures

Hidden treasure. OK - not that hidden obviously. But when I went to the Angkor Thom the only historical building I was expecting was Angkor Wat. I had no idea that Bayon Temple existed (I hang my head at my history education) and how incredible it was to look at. Also how large it is. Make sure you prepare for a full half day with sunscreen, hat and lots of water. Oh - and if you can ride the elephants around the temple. The drivers aren't cruel to the elephants and it's a great perspective.

Amazing But Be Aware. This is a truly spiritual place. Visually you will be blown away by the craftsmanship of the numerous faces and wall carvings. But ... be prepared for the bus loads of selfie stick toting, high heel wearing selfish, thoughtless Mainland Chinese tourists. They tend to put a major dampener on your zen temple experience and mess your chi. Try to get there as early as possible to avoid the mad chaotic rush of the Mainland Chinese hoard. If not, be prepared to be standing around while they take numerous selfies and actions shots while you are trying to enjoy the sanctity of the temple.
Better than Angkor Wat. I believe this is better than Angkor Wat in terms of architecture. Go around the place. Tourists disrespecting notices - no entry yet I see some going over barricades.

My Favorite Temple in Cambodia.. Visiting as many temples as possible in such a short time can get a little overwhelming, specially in May (the hottest month of the year in Cambodia) when the temperatures easily reach the 98º. I was pleasantly surprised by the beauty of this temple. I even forgot about the heat for a moment. The walls of carved stone are so beautifully filled with details and the stunning Buddha Heads with their smiles invite you to a perfect Zen moment. This was without a doubt one of my favorite temples so far!Couple tips: 1. Arrange price with your Tuk Tuk or Taxi in advance. I found that more than once they were trying to take advantage of me. 2. Wear a Hat: it was a lifesaver for my sensitive skin 3. Try to visit in the morning hours or after 3 or 4 when the sun is less intense. Enjoy the view!
Smiles everywhere. Having that many happy faces looking back @ you does make you want to smile.For me the most interesting part is the way the trees have grown thru everything. Well worth the visit.
Truly Majestic :-). over 2000 large faces carved in this amazing temple you can't help but smile when you see them ;-) i hope you enjoy!!!!

Only one in the world .. Then on to Angkor Thom where you will visit the Bayon temple with its 54 Buddha head statues. And to finalize your journey, visit the famous Ta Prohm temple, featured in the movie Tomb Raider, and walk among the overgrown trees and gigantic roots that have become part of it throughout the years.

Favorite. The Bayon temple was by far our favorite of all the ones in the Angkor Thom complex. It was very interesting with the story carved in the stone around it (and even better when the guide explained it all to you). They offer elephant rides around this temple, which was probably the most awesome 10-15 minutes of our entire trip. Also, the four faces of kindness are carved into each pillar- compassion, charity, amnesty and forgiveness. Overall way more impressive than Angkor Wat!

And Always Smiling. Beside Ta Prohm the Bayon is my favorite temple in the Angkor Park. It is the central temple of Angkor Thom which is situated only a short ride to the north of Angkor Wat. A high stone wall (8 m) and a wide moat surround Angkor Thom. There are five entrance gates, the south gate probably gets the most traffic because it admits all the visitors coming from Angkor Wat. The bridge leading up to the gate is quite impressive, it is bordered on either side by a row of gods (devas) or demons (asuras) pulling on a snake, a representation of a Hindu myth of the Churning of the Milk. The gate itself is around 25 meters high with the first smiling faces which you will find everywhere in the Bayon temple and are unique to it. Modern scholars are still debating the identity of the faces, some think they represent Buddha, some King Jayavaram VII and others the Hindu god Brahma. Inside the walls the area is densly wooded with very tall and beautiful trees. The Bayon temple itself is quite compact but with around 40 towers still standing and rouphly 150 smiling faces it is awe-inspiring. It is built three-tiered and features also two galleries with extensive bas-reliefs. They depict scenes from the mythology but also scenes from daily life. You feel you are in a maze with narrow walkways, dimly lit low passages and many corners. And always, after every corner you find more smiling faces. Over the years I have been to the Bayon now three times, but it never lost its original fascination. Definitely a must for every visitor. A tip for photographers: if you visit the temple in the late afternoon (around 4 pm) the light is just perfect and the temple less crowded. In the mornings it is sometimes very misty and the whole sunrise crowd from Angkor Wat falls in like a locust swarm.

What an amazing place. I loved this temple. All those smiling faces looking out in all directions. The Kapok trees growing through and over the buildings give the place a very spooky feeling. I think it must've been absolutely amazing at the time of the people who inhabited the area.
Amazing. Go early, very early. An amazing structure needs to be seem in person to be appreciated. Don't think I need to say much more
Factatics!. This temple is really neat and lots of imagination. I like the Cambodian smile. This tell you a lots of history behind.

Go at lunchtime. An absolutely amazing temple, we went just after 8 and it was absolutely packed with chinese and korean tourists on tour buses. We went back at about 12:30pm and it was aalmost empty so that seems like the time to go!

One of my favourites. One of my favourite temples in the Angkor complex! Awesome photo opps here and a really fun area to climb around and explore. Try to go early though as it was really crowded when we went and I felt like I was always in the way of someone's photo.

Great Bayon. If you have only one day to visit temples in Siem Reap then make sure that Bayon is one of them. For me it is most amazing temple, those carved stone faces-that is something to see. I think I spend around 2-3 h walking around and taking pictures and you cant go wrong- anywhere you look is great photo opportunity.
Amazing temple. I think the Bayon temple is my favorite. I love all the faces. It looks very cool and photographs well.

My favorite among all the temples. Lots of picturesque areas and interesting architecture. I feel there's a bit more character with this temple than with the Angkor Wat, although the beauty of Angkor Wat is its grandeur and the preservation of details of the temple. If you have a short time only, don't miss out on Bayon Temple and the surrounding Angkor Thom area.
Weird temple. The weird temple of Bayon in inside the Angkor Thom. A very interesting temple with excellent carvings. a must do in the Angkor complex.

One of the best temples. Nice temple. Different from Angkor Wat. It's a temple with a lot of faces, facing all four directions. A guide will explain you everything. We had a guide named Mok Vireak. He was really good. His Yahoo-mail is mokvireak001 if you want to book him.

Do not miss this temple on your visit!!!. Fantastic photo opportunities! Massive structure! One of our favorites. Definitely a do not miss! We saw this on our last day and what a memorable thing that was! There were not very many people in May so I suggest going during that time, just before the rainy season. We went May 11-13. Hope that helps you in your scheduling!
Amazing!. After Angkor Wat itself, this is the most fascinating. All those huge faces carved in stone looking in every cardinal point. It really is amazing!

Exciting place. Bayon was an another of Siem Reaps treasures. The whole temple has smiling faces of Avlokiteshwar on the towers. 4 faces - one facing each direction. Unique aspect of the temples in Siem Reap is that carving was done after placing the stone blocks one over the another. So the lines are clearly visible on the faces. Its an amazing site to see smiling faces all around you. The walls of the temple depict the time and life in Siem Reap at that time - war, crocodiles, kings, monkeys etc.Must visit surreal placeDon't forget to take the nose to nose photo with Avlokiteshwar
Stunning. Perfect temple for those with mobility problems to visit, much smaller than Angkor Wat. Also seemed cooler with more trees about.
The temple of a thousand (Buddha) faces. This is my most favorite temple, by far !!!!Just wish I had this temple to myself , even for a few minutes...

Fantastic Temple. The temples with the many faces are straight out of a Sinbad movie. There are lots of stairs so think carefully about the visit if you have any mobility issues.I was very impressed with the fantastic architecture and would recommend it for a visit

My Favorite. Traveled January this year, of all the temples I've seen in a day pass. I personally love, or awe Bayon Temple. It is a feel good place, smiling faces on top of an anciet building. The walls were articulately made centuries ago. Wow. Bayon lover here. Take note, prepare A NEW DOLLAR BILL for payment. THEY WONT ACCEPT AN OLD DOLLAR BILL which is a change in one of my market shopping. I almost could not see this place because of an old dollar bill, good thing my fiancee got another new bill at hand.BE SURE NOT TO ACCEPT ANY OLD DOLLAR BILLS WHILE YOU ARE TRAVELLING CAMBODIA.

Amazing . I've now been twice and it is an amazing place. There are a huge number of faces within the stone and also other things to look at. They were doing some renovations during our visit and it might be a bit harder to get around if you have trouble walking / climbing stairs etc.
A unique temple. One of the unique temples in the Angkor area worth visiting. Recommend taking photographs with Apsaras in the temple area.
Amazing Temple in the World. I was really surprised with this temple! How it was build! It is amazing. There are many statues around the towers that I would not count.

Staggering!. The Bayon is majestic! Some 54 towers, each with carved faces on the four cardinal points. To the untrained eye, all faces appeared different!. And most of the faces are remarkably well preserved. The Bayon is built on 3 levels, so once again there are numerous stairs to negotiate. Oh, and beware of some low doorways.The Bayon was originally Buddhist, but this then changed to Hindu gods and then back again. Each tower had contained Buddha statues brought there by priests from the various provinces, but over time, these were removed.There are also masses of bas-reliefs carved into the various temple walls. The patterns and scenes depicted are remarkable.The Bayon is most definitely well worth a visit.
Incredible structures. Magnificent buildings erected long before modern time, before nails and mortar. Go and be awe inspired. A must see.

One of my favorites. After visiting many temples they begin to blend together. This stands out for me. Be prepared to walk and climb, in hot humid weather. Take your time and drink lots of water. My tuk-tuk driver would bring a cooler with bottles of water.

Fantastic place.. This was the 3rd temple of our guides day itinerary. We had Tep Nat, tep_nat_2007@yahoo.com for $35 for the day, would recommend. He will set you a 1,2 or 3 itinerary. And he has a tuk tuk driver for $18 so you don't have to hire your own like we did doh.  This temple is the one with the famous faces on, 4 each side, 54 provencies represented here so 216 faces in the temple. Tep knows all the best photo opportunities. Glad I went here. Please find my 2 other reviews on the Angkor Wat and Bayon. Do them all in one day is best. No need to do 2 or 3 days even as you will only be seeing lesser smaller temples. Just do the big 3 and don't go for temple fatigue !

Majestic Ancient Ruins. This ancient temple is a definite must see. Giant stone faces scatter the ruins of this once glorified temple. The moss covered faces and half smiling smirks create a truly eerie surrounding. There are plenty of creative photo opportunities while you are here exploring as well.

The best for me. This site has everything mystery carvings small door ways and some pretty cool views gives you a real jungle temple feel. Mind your head on low door ways and watch your footing on loose stones
Preferred to Angkor Wat. . I thought the faces made for a more impressive display than the other temples. Not sure why, jump out your tuk tuk and tour the temples in this little area. I got lost.

Very busy!. Personally, I didn't enjoy bayon as much as I'd hoped. It was super busy, with kids trying to sell you stuff everywhere. Nearly impossible to get pictures with no people in! It is a must see, but it wasn't my favourite
Fantastic. I have been here twice, and will continue to return. You get more each time. This is 1000 years ago. Nothing in Europe comes near, including the cathedrals.

Tuk Tuk ride aroud. i would prefer the tuk tuk ride around the temple than riding in a car. I have also tried cycling and i also suggest tourist to do the same. you may see more and enjoy more. by the way, dont feed the monkeys.

Beautiful Buddhist Temple. We had a sunrise tour of Angkor Wat and surrounding temples. Would recommend doing a morning tour as it can get very hot later on in the day. Our tour guide was amazing, providing us with an in depth history of these temples. It is absolutely amazing that mankind built such a huge and detailed structure without the modern technology available today. Highly recommended, and would be a shame to miss if you visit Siem Reap.

Smiling face Temple. Build by the greatest King of Khmer Empire. This huge temple are filled with soo many similing face figure, which many Khmer people belief that it was the face of King Jayavarman VII. You can see some bas-relief on the outer wall of the temple, its telling us some story about Khmer. And on the inside we can see so many Apsara dancer bas-relief. Great Temple, beautiful. Must visit
Beautiful. Visited this site while also visiting Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom. Great photo opportunities, but expect crowds, heat and humidity. A must see when in Siem Rep.

A must visit. Definitely a place to visit. The temple structures are fascinating. Its best to get there when its not busy because many of the passages cross each other where you get four sided (faced) structures and you seem to be bumping into people or waiting for them to pass. Its unique with all its faces carved into the rock and therefore presents plenty of opportunities for taking pictures.
Be there early!. If you want to enjoy the site at its maximum, come early and enjoy the perfect sun rays on the Buddha heads with an almost empty spot!o
A Must when in Cambodia. This and Angkor Wat are, in my opinion, the two must spectacular of the temples visited. Take your time here there is plenty to see and enjoy.
Intricate!. Intricate, beautiful! I loved it, refreshing compared to the other temples! Which were actually not bad too, just that this was better!

Big temple with great carvings you must see. Bayon temple is a large temple and has many different and interesting features to see especially the well preserved wall carvings. To understand these carvings I emphasise in all my trip advisor postings for Siem Reap is My advice is please get a Tour guide or organise a tour as it is essential to understand the history to this amazing place & temple. We used an excellent & best english (American accent) guide- Vannak (vannakguide@gmail.com), extremely knowledged.This tour was organised thru (the best) Odyssey Indochina Tours with a air conditioned car driver and guide- knowledge of history, language, customs and area including food.You will appreciate Bayon Temple and others with a guide that will point out and explain things which you cant read about or see.
Wonderful place. Bayon temple was our high light during our visit to Siem Reap. We love this temple so much. We spent so much time to visit this temple.

unique temple top. it's less crowded than Angkor Wat, but still famous site. There are a lot of smiling Buddha faces on top and sure a lot of fun and very impressive. The smiling Buddha faces roof top is unique for Bayon's signature. You sure cannot miss this site if you are visitng the temple area.

Awesome Temple of Faces!. Go and enjoy the grandure of this amazing Temple! When we went we hired a great tuk tuk driver and guide! Here are their detailsOur driver was Mr Sopha! We highly recommend him.He was reliable, trustworthy and always there for us.His contact details are: khievsopha07@gmail.com.We also hired a tour guide to take us to the major temples! His name is Votha his email is: ongvotha@hotmail His English was very good, he is very knowledgable about the History of his country and also very passionate about the temples of Siem Reap.He also took some wonderfully cleaver photos of us during the day at the temples.If you decide to book them, let him know that Julie and Chuck from Australia recommended him please

Impressive!. Definitely one of the more impressive temple structures on the Angkor Wat grounds. It's best to head here first before the throngs of tourists attack it if you want to get some good photos. Those faces carved into the rocks are mind-blowing.

Spectacular temple.. Angkor Wat is the largest and most famous of the temples at Siem Reap but Bayon Temple rivals it for physical splendor. Here you find the huge, omnipresent, carved faces of the Buddha, gazing serenely, from every direction. Many are at great heights and you can climb up to stare back at them, though it's no contest. Bayon's vertical features are spectacular. Every surface is festooned with carvings. A photographer's heaven.

One of the most beautiful. Even though this temple is one of the busiest, it is for sure one of my favourites. I'm a tour leader and come back to the Angkor Temples a couple of times a year. This one is fascinating with all the carvings and faces.
amazing architecture. its a must visit place in siem reap after angkor wat. The statues and complex are so beautifully carved.

The "Face of God". We been there many timese and each time we were so excited to visit Angkor wat . The real bonus is that you can mingling every corner of the temple Up and Down and if you visit Ta Prom "OMG " it's amazing SO real you can Reach and Touch "The Faces of Gods " In my opinion This is a Truly ****** 6 Stars . Don't take my Word for it Go and see for yourself . I will be there again next year Now start to saving Up . Many thanks to "Angkor Wat"

Most Unique. The temple of Bayon is one of the most unique temples I have ever been so far in SEA. The unique four-faced Buddha carved and etched on as the temples is magnificent. If you would be seeing only a few temples in the Angkor complex, make sure not to give this one a miss.

The One and Only. The first glance of the Bayon Temple was absolutely amazing! It was like something out of another world. I just loved all the beautifully carved out faces all over the temple complex. It is difficult to understand how the people did this kind of architecture centuries ago without all the equipment and tools that one gets nowadays. The chisel work is astonishing especially the beautiful faces with subtle smiles of the lips as if they are looking down on all the tourists walking by and if they want to say "we have a secret that only we know about". I could not get enough of taking photos and felt a little bit sorry to leave as if there stayed a lot of unanswered questions behind. The Bayon Temple is a must visit attraction for any tourist visiting Siem Reap.

Highlight of Siem Reap. Ang kor wat is the most famous temple in this province. However, my favorite was definitely the Bayon temple. The handicraft is absolutely exquisite and intricate. It's a temple with tons of four-faced Buddhas.If your budget allows, do try to get a day guide around the Ang Kor Wat area. The history adds to the mystique and beauty of the various temples. A guide will really help you appreciate the area much more! The locals' love for the area is contagious and will make you fall in love with their history.It got really hot in the area when I went (March 2015), so bring lots of water. Also, I'll suggest covered shoes :) Shorts and sleeveless shirts are not allowed in their premises, so do come fully covered in light clothing (WEATHER IS HOT).

Best temple and all to ourselves!. Hands down favorite temple of the area. Want to experience this place alone and not with 1000 other people?First, we went to the sunrise at Angkor Wat. Rather than staying to explore Angkor Wat, around 6:30am we left and went to Bayon, only 5 minutes away by tuk tuk. While thousands stay after sunrise and explore Angkor Wat, we had Bayon to ourselves! You can stay ahead of everyone else on the little or big circuit and double back to Angkor Wat in the late afternoon. You'll likely need to ask your guide or tuk tuk to do this as they'll recommend otherwise putting you on the normal route with many others.Enjoy!

Hot. So hot.. Far smaller than Angkor Wat, and in a far bigger state of ruin, though there are some restoration works in process at the moment - make sure you have good shoes for climbing over rocks and
On the small circle tour. Loved it , so different from Angkor watt , allow time to just take it in and get there early if you can , as the crowds can take the edge of its glory
Interesting history. Our tour guide started our first day of tour here at the Bayon temple. We were lready so amaged with the 4 faced wall and the evila and good statues guarding the entrance.
Unique. Although the whole complex is original per se Bayon has something unique...hard to define exacly in a objective way although...

Incredible. The structure and meaning of this temple really amazed me. It is just so great to have been able to experience all that is there and learn even more why Cambodia is what it is and learn so much about their people and customs and history.
