Natural and beautiful . This temple with its overgrown feel make the whole experience even better. Go early to avoid the crowds and spend your time walking through with trees that simple grow out of the walls hundreds of years old. A true natural wonder
A face for all. Great to get away from the crowds of Angkor Wat and take in the detail somewhat uninterrupted. The stone faces are asthetically pleasing and are accessible for all.
Unforgettable. The sight of the stonefaces, and the changing light and shaddows over them during the day, is really something to use a day for.

Must do - stunning set of Buddha faces in the midst of the jungle. Must do temple during your visit to Siem Reap. I would rate it higher than Banteisrei and Ta Prom. Supposed to have 216 smiling Buddhas looking at you. Best visited in the evening - when you leave the temple in the evening you realise what an untouched wilderness the temple is still in - no electricity, no street lighting - just forest all around . Stunning temple.

Impressive!. When I reached Bayon, I was just thinking to myself, "Yet another temple..." However when I looked closer, I saw the different Buddha faces on all the towers, on ALL 4 sides of the towers. I was i-m-p-r-e-s-s-e-d! I end up enjoy this temple more than Angkor Wat.
Awesome temple. One of the must see temples in the complex. The faces are astounding and speak from out of time. If you have the opportunity, visiting all of the temples is the way to go.

My favorite of the temples at Angkor. The smiling faces of Bayon will forever be etched in my mind. It is amazing how many there are and the detail of this temple in my mind is as good as the vastness of Angkor Wat itself.
Visit. the lovely stone face carvings are spectacular and the scale of this temple must be seen to be believed. Be wary it's hard work exploring this temple.
good. -many points to take photo. beautiful photo. -please wear a suitable footwear.a good temple to visit. But nothing compare to the Angkor Wat.
Wonderful!!. Bayon was really worth a visit! After being in Angkor Wat I didn't expect more, but it was impressive

BAYON is a must see. BAYON should be included in a package if you come to SIEM REP, CAMBODIA to view centuries old man made temples.. Unique in its own right, with many faces of BUDDA . We suggest you hire a guide and private car, especially if you, like us are an older couple, Remember, SIEM REP is in between the Tropic of Cancer and the Equator, so it is very hot and humid. We came in late APRIL, early May which is still the dry season--- a good time to come before the rainy season.Guides and car are not expensive and well worth it. Get a 3 day pass to see many temples and sites for USD $$ 40 per person. We did several temples in 2 days. A three day pass is the same cost as a two day one.
Beautiful. Another awesome temple that is a must to visit..make sure u definitely wear comfortable shoes and bring your camera, phone, you will not want to miss the pictures for sure.

I don't think you can find a bad temple in Cambodia. We visited many temples and all are beautiful. I don't think you could pick a bad one. The interesting thing is that other than the largest temples (Angkor Wat) there is no one there to guard them. And yet there is no grafiti, no problem people, nothing to make you feel threatened at all. There are a lot of children begging/sellling small trinkets at many of them. The people of Cambodia are sweet and honest and very kind to tourists.
Liked the faces. Not a huge attraction like Angkor Wat, interesting carvings.Easily seen in an hour. Man trying to impress his gods.

Gem. Like all the other temples this is not for the mobility impaired. You do have to climb around a lot which can take it out of you in the heat. Nevertheless the experience is sufficiently great to be worth it.

amazing temple!!!. this is the fantastic temple that i do love!!
have a day for tour and finish at there.
amazing temple, lovely place. will come here again!!!!

My favorite temple. Having a look at all those towers with Buddha faces that represented the provinces of the kingdom at that time is a breath taking moment. Take the chance to do the "silly" picture of kissing one of the faces :)
Very nice temple. I love this place because of the antique spot. The temple is full of 4 kinds of face expressions the Hindu's God. I think I'm going to miss this place more and more.
Amazing temple in the jungle1. It's hard to describe about this temple! It is so amazing! I love the big tree which is grown with the temple!
Amazing. This temple is breath taking!! It's mind blowing how the temple was made and all the faces carved into the stone.

Vast, with 216 enigmatic smiling faces. This temple is in the exact centre of Angkor Thom city. It is vast, with 216 enigmatic smiling faces and huge sculptured decoration on the walls. Easy to imagine the Khmer kings watching huge processions of elephants during their public ceremonies.
Definitely worth visiting.
Very large, great architecture. Wonderful place, beautiful surroundings with monkeys running around. Good preservation and some interesting murals throughout. Take planty of water and a hat!
Stunning. Incredible temple facades! unlike anything I've ever seen before-- and it's vastness and larger than life presence is daunting.

Breathtaking. This place is simply breathtaking and I am not sure that anything else I say can do justice to how beautiful this place is. Seeing these giant heads from another time laid out in perfect symmetry was one of my favourite experiences in Cambodia.

Stone Faces Everywhere. Bayon temple is an amazing temple to see. Since the temple’s most distinct feature is the multitude of serene and massive stone faces on the many towers. It’s really hard to capture a decent photo in this type of location wherein it was jam-packed with numerous tourists. But, I got some good ones.

Incredible temple to explore.. I thoroughly enjoyed this temple, all the faces were amazing! It was a little less crowded than Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm but just as impressive if not more so. Everywhere i looked, a face was smiling back like we were old friends. One of the stair cases was so steep, it was more of a stone ladder and I was glad to be wearing shoes with a decent grip.

Another amazing temple!. Like Angkor Wat, you can marvel on how this temple was built. The Bayon faces were all over the place, carved on the sand stone. It's amazing how religion and engineering go hand in hand. No worries for the fee because this is included in the price you paid for Angkor Wat and so are the other temples in Angkor Thom.

Mind Blowing. Take your time to check out this amazing temple. All the temples are amazing but this one has a special appeal. As with all the temples be prepared for Chinese tour groups and young children trying to sell souvenirs

Late afternoon visit. My daughter and I went to visit the Bayon Temple about 4.30pm one afternoon. We had had a busy morning exploring the other temples and then had a siesta before embarking on this one. I think it was a sensible choice to come this late as there were very few other visitors. We came on another day around late morning and the Bayon was absolutely packed. My daughter and I thought the huge faces carved into the stone were beautifully serene. Its a reasonably large temple but we managed to see most of it in the hour before the temple closed. It was certainly very hot and dry but I think that's to be expected at this time of the year in Siem Reap.

Majestic. One of the main Angkor temples. We went about 4.00 pm and was not much crowded, but extremely hot. There is a very steep stair climb at some sections and nice views from the top. The carvings are fabulous and their story is great. A guide with knowledge is a must.
Another fabulous temple to see. Loved being in Siem Reap and seeing all the temples. Nothing I disliked at all, except maybe the general heat and humidity but that was everywhere.

By far the most awesome temple in Angkor. Reaching this site as early or as late you can before closing time you have the Bayon all for yourself and at this point it's Worth pulling your camera out of your bag. The structure is massive and impressive but most of all are those gigantic stone faces with an enigmatic inner smile the sight you will remember for ever.

A Hidden Jewel. We visited this temple during the Cambodian New Year and it was a real oasis. While the world and his wife were at the bigger temples, we were able to truly soak up the atmosphere of Bayon. There is a fair amount of climbing but well worth the effort.

This should be number 1. Come to Bayon temple today on small circuit tour. Any hotel you stay in at Siem Reap will probably offer a temple tour service as mine did. Of the three we visited on day one which were Angkor Wat, Bayon and Ta Prohm (commonly known as the tomb raider site). I would still say this is my favorite so far for the fact that every part is lovely not just a one shot photo.
A must see. Excellent temple - beautiful art work, great experience and fully loved this. Its highly recommended to anyone travelling in SE Asia.

So incredible I felt like I wanted to cry. This temple really resonated with me. I don't know why, however, as I walked around the temple I felt like I wanted to cry. I still can't believe you are allowed to walk around incredible and ancient temples like these. I feel very privileged.

Go early!. While everyone went inside to tour Angkor Wat after sunrise, my tuk tuk driver and I started out for the other temples. I seriously had Bayon all to myself. It was the perfect way to climb around and take all the photos you wanted. I stayed ahead of most of the crowds the rest of the day, while they hit Bayon, I was already at the next one.Beautiful place, highly recommend stopping.
Try an elephant ride. The elephant ride around the temple is well worth it. It was part of our all-inclusive tour so not sure of price but it is a once in a lifetime experience!

My favorite of the temples. As I walked up to the temple, I could make out a few of the different faces of Buddha, but I wasn't expecting there to be so many! It seemed that at every turn there was another face - incredible how they were able to build and carve the massive place. Although definitely not as big and massive as Angkor Wat, this was definitely my favorite of the bunch.
mind blowing. what a great place, very interesting but be aware that it gets very very hot so take plenty of water and a sun hat.

Bayon,- The State Temple of Jayvarman VII. The Bayon is a compact temple and easy to enter at many places.The inner enclosure is confusing with its narrow chambers, stairways and corridors but it is a pleasure to explore it all - even if there are many visitors daytime.The bas-reliefs are a fascinating experience to see.In addition to Angkor Wat, this temple is a must to see. (Well, all other temples are worth a visit as well but one get saturated with impressions after a while.......)
Big Temple. Great to see the temple, this was the first we saw so it was impressive to see all the carvings in the gallery. It was pretty busy though.
Awesome!!. What a fantastic place, the many faces was truly amazing! Beautiful and fascinating all at the same time.

Unique temple. This one was an unexpected treat. When you pull up, you think you're visiting a mound of rubble but as you get closer, you see the structure is full of faces. Bayon Temple was built by the Buddhist King Jayavarma in the late 12th or early 13th Century and the facade is in remarkable shape. There are dozens of faces.One trick to try is touch your nose to the nose of one of the faces, but you're actually standing several metres away from the face (see my photos).

the Lady Temple. further in and much smaller than the other temples. Really beautiful, The trees surrounding the temple are really huge and extremely old. Though they have grown over some parts of the temple, seems to be so natural, the blend of man made architecture marvels with nature.

Rumbling beauty. Bayon is the central temple in Angkor Thom. When I write central, I don’t mean only the location, but the importance and the impression as well.From a distance it somehow looks like a glorious cathedral after a serious bombing in the Second World War. You have to get closer, and get in to realise its eternal beauty.It became famous not only for the 216 Buddha faces with their Mona Lisa smile, but the beautiful bas-reliefs on the exterior walls of the lower level.Personally I preferred the wonderfully carved bas- reliefs, since I found to see these countless Buddha faces in every direction a bit disturbing.Surrounded by the jungle it is a bit dark and I felt this temple despite its undoubted beauty somehow sinister.

Best in the soft morning light!. We liked Bayon Temple that much we went to visit it twice. The second time was in the soft morning light, it is better than during the day when the sun is very bright. So, admire the faces in the morning but do not look up to the faces all the time. Also look around you as well and see some nice details. The best temple in Seam Reap!

Great temple.. Great temple. Spend some hours there and explore massive stone faces on the many towers. It is very nice early in the morning.. usually not many tourists at that time. Also by the noon is good time, but be prepared for heat.

Even with iphone got great pics. The tree growing in the center is unbelievable. A guard took me behind the scenes to see the offerings in the middle of the temple. Felt very special and honored...lit incense and left a cigarette and water for the Buddha
Best. For my money the most interesting temple, enough standing to be interesting, and of a comprehensible size, it is a very atmospheric place.
Huge an overwhelming. But definately a Must See in Ankor Wat!. Amazing temple, but too much dirt and garbage lying among. Takes the top off the experience. Still worth a visit though!
Another majestic architecutre with stone faces(face temple). Stunning stone faces temple with many photogenic spots for photo shoot especially the nose-to-nose pose spot.

My favorite of the Temples. Left me awestruck. I kept imagining how powerful and smart the ancient king was to build this place. It commands your attention. You will never for get this place, it wont let you.

Faces of the Buddha. Everyone loves Bayon temple because of the serenity of the faces of the Buddha, which sooth the weary soul of the visitors (mostly because of the heat... hydrate!!) Watch the walls for the Apsaras here and there. Words from our guide: "rebuilding the temples is like a jigsaw puzzle, they have to mark every piece and put them together" and you will witness by the amount of rubble laying around.

Stunning. For me, this is the crown jewel of the Angkor small circuit. Hypnotizing faces all around you, exciting layout of the whole temple and something like a connection-with-the-universe feeling. Great vibe, highly recommended.

One of my favorite temples. After Angkor Wat, Bayon Temple is my favorite. This is the temple with many stone faces. You could take pictures where you would appear to be going nose-to-nose with these stone faces. This complex is very photogenic.
Smiling Faces everywhere. Stunning workmanship, you can see those smiling faces everywhere you turn in this temple. Marvellous

Bayon belief. A beautiful temple that has 4 faces of Buddha on each spire.The weathering by wind, rain & sun has done nothing to diminish the splendor.A day pass with your photo on it costs US $20.00, it entitles you to visit the entire park.Bring lots of water because it is hot. Watch out for the steps as they are steep & do cross over doorways.
Misterious. The most enigmatic temple of Angkor. We cycle there and was a beautiful ride despite the high temperature.

See this soon. What an impressive structure! I say see this soon because it is falling apart right now. There is a restoration and preservation project going on right now but I'm afraid they won't be able to keep up with it. Much of it is shored up to keep it together. The interesting part of Bayon is the massive trees that are growing in the structures and the roots that are both holding the structures together and in other places destroying the structures. Be prepared for the heat, a physically challenging day and dealing with a lot of rude tourists. It is still a magnificent attraction.

The Happy Temple. This is a fabulous Temple to visit. It was the last one we visited at the end of a long day and so worth summoning up the energy for more stairs (but not at all too demanding). There are faces carved in everywhere and it is to my mind it is such a happy friendly temple. There are a couple of places where you can pose and get someone to take a photo of you 'nose to nose' with a sculpted face. Just for fun! A must to include in your itinerary.

Smiling faces everywhere! Welcome to Bayon. Another Iconic Place in Angkor complex. Smiling Faces everywhere, magic and moldy smell in every place. Got some of the best shots of my life. This places has been featured in so many movies and so many years that you can consider it a symbol of that Old World.

So Unique and Different. All of these temples have their own history and stories of life,,, don't miss it.. It's amazing how they could of transported all these huge blocks to shape and build with precision,,, the architecture is just amazing..
One of our favorites. This is an iconic temple. The giant face carvings are simply breathtaking. Bring a camera, sunscreen, and a towel. Be prepared for intense heat but stunning views

second must see in Angkor complex. brilliant place, fantastic scenery, another massive place with plenty good views and walks. again I recommend morning visit as it's too hot during the day (visited late march) busy too

Inside Angkor Thom. Interesting as it shows carved stone faces of the ancient King. You can climb steep stairs to view them more closely. It starts off your visit to Angkor Thom and whets your appetite for more!
Worth a look. Bayon Temple not as popular as Angkor Wat but unique in its own way. Went with Happy Angkor Tour - Private car with tour guide "Mr Em". Fantastic person!
Very Hot Bayon. A very hot day, detracted from the enjoyment. Like Angkor Wat. We did too much standing and listening and not enough moving around. This may be an older person's problem.

Amazing & Unique. Bayon Temple is quite amazing & unique with many massive well preserved stone faces of Buddha on many towers jutting out from the terraces. One of the most beautiful temple in Siam Reap. Our tour guide explained that the temple was built in the late 12th or early 13th century as the official temple of the Mahayana Buddhist King. Good photo spot. One of the must-see attraction in Siem Reap. Highly recommended.
Favorite Temple. This was definitely one of my faves. Definitely a bit more interesting than others but we did it first so was pretty awestruck.
Alone at Bayon. we arrived in the evening, just before closing. Great experience because nobody else was at the temple. Looking at the eerie Buddha's in the evening sun is superb.

Astounding. This place will blow your mind...it is just incredible. One of the most amazing places I've ever seen. It makes you realise that very sophisticated societies existed long before us...utterly fascinating.

Unique. Bayon is just so much different from its surrounding temples like Angkor Wat or Ta Prohm. I love the architecture and symmetry with the big stone faces popping out of the temple like spines. Smaller than Angkor Wat you can still get lost in Bayon with its unique structure of hallways and terraces.
Spiritual, mystical, inspiring, must see.... It is hard not to leave this place in a good "uplifted" mood after seeing so many smiling faces. This is a must see if you are visiting the national park.

Mystical temple. Too close to Angkor Wat to miss. I actually liked this temple better because of the spiritual, mystical aura that this temple gives off. Wear good walking shoes and mind where you step.
Beautiful. Very different to the other temples - the colour and detailed work is amazing - well worth the travel and visit

Amazing. this temple is amazing, you literally can get lost in the huge complex, ready your camera with lots of juice in it. A lot of stunning picture, can be little crowded after 10.00 AM. Try going here earlier after Angkor Wat to avoid the mass crowds.

Impressive. Walking through the temples you can't help being amazed.This one has the various different Buddha faces.We came here just after watching the sunrise at Angkor Wat and advise you do so as well. We had it just to ourselves (and a handful of other travellers). Then all of a sudden at the end the place was swamped with coach loads of Chinese tourists!
Fascinating. Possibly my favorite of the Angkor temples - happy faces everywhere. We did this as our final temple of the day - crowds weren't horrible, but the heat was. Probably best early morning.
Great temple. Great temple, but get there really early, before the crowds and/or heat. One of my favorites. Great pics. Make sure you climb to top.

Majestic. What a unique temple!!! The stunning 4 smiley Buddha faces (all different Buddha faces) surrounding the temple. One of the most beautiful temples in Siam Reap. Engage a tour guide who can tell you where to take beautiful photos and explain the history of the temple. It is indeed intriging.
Amazing. This temple is stunning! I couldn't even imagine how mighty khmers were!Climbimg all the way up is highly recommended!

Bayon temple is best before 8am. If you can get there before tour groups arrive, you will find this place impressive. Light sunshine on Bayon can make great photos. Avoid 8am - 3pm due to huge crowds and you will not get good photos. Being here in hot season can be challenging.
Quirky. Seems to have been designed by some one with a sense of humour and had a 'feel happy' attitude shown by the number of happy, smiley faces dotted around all over the place.

Impressive. One of my favorite temples in Siem Reap. The 200+ huge face carvings are the highlight of this temple. As for all temples you want to go as early as possible. Especially if you are a photo afficionado and want pictures with little to no people.

4 Faceted temple. Very interesting statue with 4 faces. Way smaller than Angkor Wat so the experience was not as intense, plus you already tired by the time you reach this temple after 3 hours raiding Angkor wat
Great lighting at sunset. We visited just about an hour and half before sunset and had great lighting for our tour and lots of good picture opportunities.
Worth doing. I enjoyed my time exploring the Bayon, however I preferred exploring Angkor Wat and the surrounding area. I would spend more time in Angkor Wat next time.

The most magnificient Angkor Thom temple. If you want to truly enjoy the history of the temple GET A TOUR GUIDE. We did the mistake of going in with our lonely planet but the temple is huge and the information does not do justice to the magnificence of it. We got a tour guide with us the next day and were lucky to visit the temple for the second time where we let him guide us through the history while we gaped and clicked away.

Favorite Temple in Siem Reap - Just Magical!. Bayon is so magical - enjoy a variety of wonderful photo opportunities and stand in awe at the expressions of the carved faces. I've been to Siem Reap 8 times and always make it a point to see Bayon - even if just a "drive by" - its my favorite!
Wonderful. Beautiful.... we did it as part of a tour of the other sites.I would recommend a visit - we took lots of pictures.

Amazing. Simply stunning ! It's amazing , really is Pls go!! Take pics , ul remember it for everIt's tiring - lots of steps and walking , so u have to be fit to see the temples - wear shoes, carry water, hat n sunscreen !!

Faces from an Age ago. Great temple site for pictures. The stone face carvings are amazing. You'll take many pictures here. With the dark complexion of the stones though, you'll be adjusting angles as the sunlight can blot out the details midmorning-midday. One of the must-sees in the region.As with other temple sites in the Siem Reap region, not wheelchair or stroller friendly. You'll need/want to bring water, sunscreen, a hat, and the camera.
Brilliant, brilliant, brilliant!. Bayon Temple was definitely everything I thought it would be. Definitely my favourite temple and well worth a visit.

The Face of the Past. We arrived at Bayon at sun rise. We walked around the bottom of the site, before heading up the stairs to the top. The highlight of this ruin is the top for sure, and is the place to be for amazing photos. The first half hour up top we were all alone and it was incredible. As the sun rose and shaped and changed the shadows on the faces, there was a perfect photo op every few feet. As the time went on and more people arrived, the views were less stunning and you often had to wait to take your photos. We wasted an hour at the bottom looking around, where we could have done it at the end. If you go early and I recommend you do, head to the top right away, it's a magic spot before the crowds show up.
stones watching you... The many stone faces looking at you from everywhere and it every direction . You cannot escape from them.

Temple of serene stone faces. This temple was constructed in the late 12th and early 13th centuries AD during the reign of King Jayavarman VII. The most distinctive feature of this temple is the multitude of massive, serene stone faces that grace its many towers.

Amazing. Equally beautiful as angkor wat...siem reap being 2015's top 2 of 25 destinations in the world has a reason. Its wonderful, amazing, grand ancient temples. However, be prepared because it very hot, crowded and requires alot of walking. You really need sunblock and a big hat to lessen the heat on your face. We walked about 1km from parking to the bayon temple under the sun. But worth it. Every scribble, decors, statue are very intricate that it will always keep you in awe on how they were able to do that durng ancient times. Upclose, the temple looks like piles of big rocks. Each rock is solid. Some of thesebig rocks have fallen adding more to its historic feel. Trully amazing. Yeah its crowded, but hey, its a top destination, so better expect that, right?
Part of the half day tour. So hot, but saw the main two temples in the morning. Well worth it. Very happy we did not sign up for the full day considering the heat.
Worth a look. They are so proud of Laura Croft i have to rent the movie. Give yourself time to get absorbed in this area. We were here for 2.5 days and could have used a lot more time

Equally impressive, much less crowded than Angkor Wat. Actually, i prefer Bayon more than Angkor wat because it has less crowded and you can explore the temple at peace and a relax pace. Although not as grand and huge as Angkor Wat, the beautiful and features matches that of Angkor equally. Bayon also presents better photo opportunities because there are less people and you can take photos with background that does not have people.
Faces everywhere. All of the complex is just unbelievable and in special Angkor Wat and Bayon Temple. Take your time to enjoy and appreciate every rock, every face, everything...
Stunning. Could have spent a good couple of days here. So full of history, so beautiful, captivating, incredible.
Has to be seen to be appreciated. This is just an amazing structure. make sure you buy a 3 day pass to Angkor Wat as a minimum because once you go once you will want to return

Nice. Nice, you can see the sunset, but be prepared to see a lot (LOTTTTTT) of tourist,...
Too bad, ...
NB : Don't arrived too late or you will not be allowed to go..

Faces! . Once there, I'm greeted with giant stone faces that are simply magnificent.
It feels like a better place than the often cited Angkor Wat.
Many photo opportunities. Many other tourists are seen taking pictures with their faces oriented in the direction of one of the four faces.

Spiritual and amazing. Loved Bayon. It encompasses all of what ancient Cambodia was all about. There is some serious history here, but you don't need to know it to enjoy the amazingly beautiful structure, even 800-1000 years after it was built.
so good. it is wonderful of cambodia and people friendly ,easy to eat somethings,or shopping ,the traffic not noises

4 faces temple. This temple stood out is because of the 4 faces of Buddha of each shrine. The detailed craftsmanship is to be applauded and appreciated. I was impressed with face of Buddha crafted on top of each of the 5 gateways.

best to go at sunset. Absolutely breathtaking. We visited Bayon around 4pm so it wasn't too hot and we had more energy to climb to the top and appreciate the view. Our guide, TONG HANN +855-0-89986497, is the best!!!! He will even show you secret picture taking spots around the different temples!!!!
probably one of the most beautiful temples. If you visit Angkor Wat you'll def see this one, it's beautiful, if seen it in the rain season too and i was even more impressive.

Visit Bayon temple! This is also a must!. Temples are the main attraction in Siem Reap and aside from Angkor Wat you have to definitely go here and check out the amazing structures and the smiling faces. You can actually hire a tuktuk driver for around $20 for the whole day and drive you to these great places. This is one of the must be temples in Siem Reap as its also very beautiful and less people than Angkor Wat.

More appealing than Angkor Wat. I had gone to Angkor wat temples early morning & Bayon the very same evening. I couldnt help but feel that Bayon temple is so better than the Angkor wat temple. I enjoyed my 1.5 hours here walking in and out through the caves and posing with the super cool pillars!

Better than Angkor Wat?. I actually enjoyed walking around Bayon Temple more than the main site at Angkor Wat. Fewer people, and in some ways a more interesting site with all those smiling rock faces.

Amazing!. One of our favorite temples in Siem Reap! I loved the different faces of the temples. The temple also offers a lot of photo opportunities, for those photo junkies!It is also near other temples like the Royal Palace so you can visit those other temples. But be ready for some serious walking. It was quite tiring. I suggest you bring a bottle of water with you as it can be quite hot and humid in Siem Reap and I didn't see anyone selling drinks around the temple.

Early morning trip busy but cool.. We went here after sunrise at Angkor wat and spent about an hour. We had a guide who explained some of the bas relief walls to us in great detail this helped our enjoyment of the temple.

My favourite. of all the temples. Loved the carvings of everyday life and the faces, the shrine etc and it wasn't overwhelming. Would have appreciated some signage as to the where the exits were though as we kept going round and round and got quite lost.

Fabulous. All of the temples are amazing I particularly enjoyed this too. Must do! Put on in the bucket list. All are included in the park pass and there are places to stop and get drinks and also market stalls along the way as well as restaurant which we ate in khmer restaurant delicious fresh and lovely people I particularly like the children. You can get 10 postcards for $1.
Beautiful and one of the better temples to see. There are a few must see temples when in Siem Reap and this is one of them. Can get quite crowded though.

Bayon Temple - Siem Reap, Cambodia. The Bayon Temple is great. It is a bit a walk all of the temples. It has faces in the stone. It is very hot in Cambodia so be sure to bring water with you. Instagram: @tommiesox

Our Favorite Temple. This temple is not to be missed. You may want to see it a second time. It is the one with the stone faces and big heads. We hired a guide and he was very helpful and advised us of the history and also pointed us to the best photo opportunities. We visited midday and although very hot, we had the place mostly to ourselves as we braved the heat. There is a small outer gate you drive through before you get to the main part of the temple with four of the large heads on the top facing each direction. Everyone stops to take photos facing the gate, but if you stop and climb to the top of the hill beside the gate, there's a great place for photos. The stone face will "photo bomb" any photo you take of yourself without other tourists in your photo.
Amazing architecture! Worth the visit. I can never imagine how they can build the temple with many faces. Spectacular architecture. But be prepared for the crowds.

Place of Fantasy. Leave this until your last day. There are three levels and you must get to level 3 to see the best of the surviving carvings. There are many faces that were the "king's eyes" some of which are hard to make out but there was one for every province of the Khmer empire. I think this is the biggest temple but not necessarily in terms of enclosed grounds.
I found this the best temple of them all. Thistemple is a bit compact and offers a wide selection of great constructions. This is a real not miss.

A gift from the gods. Truly a wonderful spectacle I will never forget it a place of sheer majestic beauty. What a world when mere mortals build such wonders. A must see in your lifetime. Awe inspiring and unforgetable

Great temple but the most crowded one!. Bayon is such a fun temple, so many interesting things to see and pictures to take. It is quite different to the others and definitely worth a visit.
However being relatively small and so popular, it gets extremely crowded and with the incredibly high temperature of April the visit can become really uncomfortable.

Mad architecture, good stories. Not as well-preserved as Angkor Wat, but important a it was the first major Buddhist temple in the complex, built at the end of 12th C in the centre of the two mile square of Angkor Thom City, which had a population of over 1 million even back then. There are some major renovation works under way, and it can get quite crowded.

Fantastic!. I could never get templed out! Well worth visiting but be prepared for crowds. Walk around as well as on - the stones are impressive & the atmosphere is wonderful, even despite the crowds.
Ancient Architecture. Wonderful for history & art lovers , stone carvings spread over different levels with wide majestic architecture...to be seen to be believed...

Our Favorite Temple. The Smiling Buddhas Are the Best. This is our favorite temple of all that we visited during our stay in Siem Reap. The south Gate welcomes visitors with over twenty statues on each side of the bridge.. Gods on one side, demons on the other. Walking through the entrance leaves you breathless. As you make your way to the temple you can't help but wonder what this place looked like in its glory days. Bayon Temple is a happy place because every tower has a smiling Buddha face in each direction. Over 148 smiling Buddhas set a joyous tone at this temple. We left two additional smiles at Bright and beautiful Bayon. A Must see during your visit to Siem Reap.

Climb up the temple to see the Giant Stone Faces. This is a very nice temple. Restoration work is ongoing but they allow you to climb all over the temple to get to the central tower. There are over 200 giant stone faces carved into this temple and they are a site to see.Make sure you get into the heart of the temple to get a few photo ops - well worth the climb/effort to get to them.

Words are insufficient..... Yes you have seen many photos, but it really is more amazing to stand in the flesh. A wonderful couple of hours spent photographing, looking and climbing through the ruins. So many twists and turns with wonderful discoveries wherever you turn.
One of my favourites. So nice, it's amazing to just be there and see what was build some 1000 years ago.This was one of my favorite sites to visit.
Get there before 6 a.m. No people early on. The East Gate is awesome. Try to be in line for the climb to the top before 7.30 a.m.

My favourite temple of the bunch!. The sight of this temple with all its faces truly took my breath away! We hired a tuk tuk for the day who took us from our hotel to Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom and Ta Prohm and back for $15. We're planning on taking our bicycles, but it was extremely hot and big distances to travel so we ended up happy that we didn't. Be aware of friendly strangers wanting to "tell you the stories of the temple", they will (over)charge you for it, this country is not nicknamed "Scambodia" for no reason. But out of the places we saw, this one was without hesitation my favourite. I highly recommend going here!
Buddhist Temple. Every where you look up, you will see the face of Buddha! The other major attraction in Siem Reap is the Angkor Wat which is a Hindu Temple.
Good Temple. Not as restored as Angkor Wat but very good to see. Lots of steps and rough ground. No toilets. Take plenty of water !!

Great carvings!. At the center of Angkor Thom, Bayon is unique and beautiful. We visited near the end of the day, and the crowds were less. Don't miss the wall carvings around the exterior of the temple. They tell such great tails from famous historical events, to the people's everyday lives.
Nice temple like a mystery old building. Like this thousand year old temple very much (and many other temple nearby). A full day of exploring and exciting!...
faces.... one of my personal favorite... i admired how the ancestors carved out those faces especially those that are located in elevated areas..
Impossing Sentinels from the Past. Trees that appeared to have been poured over ancient ruins. Photo opportunities of an era passed. Be prepared for lots of walking.

a complex complex. I like this one better than the Angkor Wat. You can get very close to the Buddha faces. The guide took us there at around lunch time in order to avoid the crowd. However, the sun was the strongest at that time. Still, it was worthy.

Must see this place. we must see this temple at Sunset. Bayon is known for its huge stone faces of the bodhisattva Avalokiteshvara, with one facing outward and keeping watch at each compass point. The curious smiling image, thought by many to be a portrait of Jayavarman himself, has been dubbed by some the "Mona Lisa of Southeast Asia." There are 51 smaller towers surrounding Bayon, each with four faces of its own.

Ancient artefact. Bayon Temple is the first of the ancient temples in that Angkor Thom complex, and it is fascinating and beautiful, a labyrinth of passage ways, corridors and incredible motifs line the walls and of course you have the Heads. A must see when you are in Siem Reap.
Must see!. Despite the crowds, don't miss this one! Incredible faces in stone make for a mystical experience.......

Magnificent, beyond description.. If there is one thing you do, this should be it. We went at 8AM on our second day and it was very crowded. Lots of Chinese tour buses were there at the same time. It got very loud, but I think that is just to be expected. When we passed the temple again later in the day, there was nobody there... it may be best done during mid-morning rather than first thing.
MUST GO. Big Temple with the smiling gods. Massive stone faces on the many towers upper terrace and cluster around its central peak

An amazing experience. It would be hard to imagine how amazing it is. The temple walls have been engraved with the stories of every day life, including wars and fighting to simple meals being serve. There are scenes of fishermen in boats and the fish in the sea below them and the simple tasks of the servants. You feel that you have had a glimpse of their lives.
Faces. Faces where you look, take time to take there smile deep into your heart. Look for a suitable time to avoid the mass tourisme

our favorite. This one was more interesting to our kids as it has many faces all over it. So that added another element of entertainment (necessary after seeing so many temples over a few days in challenging heat).
Mind blowing..... Absolute must on your visit....I personally enjoyed Bayon Temple more than Angkor Wat. Do watch the many uTube coverage available about Angkor Wat and more BEFORE going.
Magic place. Bayon temple is part of a much bigger temple area. An absolute must to see. It has extraordinary architecture which is a testimony to Cambodia's past greatness.

Remarkable. If you're in Cambodia to see Angkor Wat you must also make this part of your tour. Being less popular we were able to wander round and take photos unaware of other visitors. Not just the level or architectural genius and land and water management, the decorative work - faces everywhere - in this ancient building is truly amazing.

The best tenple. The best temple
In Angkor absolutely majestic and amazing the faces carved into stone are memorizing and you can climb down underneath it all through a series of tunnels a must see !!!
simply stunning. as with the majority of reviews all I can say is wow!!!! the sheer awe I was in when I visited will be tough to beat.

I'll "BaYon"est...best temple next to Angkor Wat~. This temple had the best smiling buddhas! What was most impressive was the main wall with the beautifully etched story of what was taking place at the time of construction. Not sure if it would have been as interesting if we hadn't had our guide. His explanations made it come to life. Was a bit hot, so I recommend going in the morning.
Impressive. again too many people tramping all over the place, guides waving flags at you, and a one way system that is not clear.
Lost glory. This temple is part of of the large Angkor Wat complex and adds its own bit of pathos to the monuments therein.
Beautiful piece of heaven..... A quiet and beautiful place you must experience that takes you within yourself, peaceful, tranquil and hauntingly beautiful.

Smiling Buddhas or Avalokiteshvaras. After Ta Prohm my second favourite temple of Angkor park. The faces carved in the dark sandstone leave you speechless. And at the entrance there's a huge wall full of interesting murals depicting battles and everyday life at that time. Just imagine what an impact such a place had for a peasant in the 11th century... Leaving your village for the first time to pay respect at the king's temple, walking on one of the paths into town - Ankgor Thom, and then coming face to face(s) with the 56 Buddhas of Bayon.It would made you an even bigger believer in God's almighty power and a humble follower of the mighty king. The temple is a photographers paradise.

I vote #1 for the Bayon Temple in Angkor Thom. We visited Siem Reap during a very good river cruise and land trip with Gate 1 Travel through Vietnam, Cambodia and Bangkok. For me the highlights of Siem Reap's temple complex was the Bayon Temple in Angkor Thom, the trees of Ta Prohm, and Angkor Wat, in that order. While Angkor Wat typically gets all the raves (and much is certainly deserved), I thought the smaller Bayon Temple had more interesting sights; the stone faces and relief carvings for example. Part of it was also still not reconstructed unlike Angkor Wat which, to me, made it more interesting and allowed some imagination to play with the pieces.
Amazing. Make sure to book a guide and go first thing in the morning to avoid the very high temperatures from noon on.It is absolutely outstanding!
more. This temple is the womans temple , was worth the visit , we got some great pics and not so many tourists .
Not to be missed!. Another of the area's treasures, the Bayon Temple is not to be missed. Having a guide is essential to add depth to the experience.
Beautiful. One of the most beautiful temple. A bit less tourist than Angkor Vat. Just go very early in the morning if want to have a chance to avoid the crowd

You'll have it to yourself at sunrise. We've visited Siem Reap many times, and long ago we learned the secret that you should make time to visit Bayon at sunrise. As the sky lightens, so do the many faces on the temple. It's magical. Better yet--you have the entire temple to yourself. This time, there was only one other couple there, and we got to see the temple light up and come to life without worrying about others in our photos or in our quiet space. It was just us and the cicadas. You don't see the typical "sunrise" of the actual event over the temple--but you do experience the day coming to light and life in serenity and in a stunning historical setting. It's a must do.

Incredible architecture. Another beautiful temple in Siem Reap ,one feels serenity here with the huge carvings of Budda staring out at you from this temple from all angles.There is a lot of restoration going on here but it is still a definite to visit.

Not to be missed!. If you are going to see Bayon, make a stop at the Jasa office in town/ Bayon Information center. The guided tour at the information center is $2. We had to make two different trips as their posted hours are unreliable, but the information and the knowledge we left with was well worth the hassle. Also you can purchase a book "Temples for Gods Bayon" at the center as well with a lot of great information. When visiting the temple itself go early in the morning and watch the morning sun light up the smiling faces.

Must Do. OMG this temple was everything you have read about and more, I recommend that decent footwear is worn and not flip flops. To get the best out of this and other temples hire a private tour guide, Our tour guide Rany made sure we did not miss a thing

Mind blowing. Go and see it yourself.. It is hot and there is lots of walking and uneven steps.The details and size and age ... I cannot find words to describe the experience of standing there, walking over those stones and trying to absorb the culture and history.Beautiful site.

A BEAUTIFUL SITE. Although more of an active archeological site than some temples this does not detract from the spectacle as site has been st up to balance conservation and tourism. Prasat Bayon offers some of the very best examples of base relief carvings, which can be found on the outer walls. On the higher levels you will see its famous array of carved heads and faces that adorned the towers and walls. Some steep steps are involved but the quality of the hard wood stairs is very good.

Highly recommended. This is most impressive part of the Angkor Thom complex. We visited in the late morning which meant it was hot but not very busy. Great place to take your time to explore. The stone faces are unique. Highly recommended.

Beautiful and Inspiring!. Bayon temple is nicknamed "Four face Buddha" temple. It has the serene feeling and interesting elements to it. You can pick from the window and see the face of the Buddha right behind it, as if it's framed. Excellent architecture and lots of attention to details to make! Loving it!

Has to be seen to be believed. The sheer scale of the faces is mind blowing. Walk around inside the many small rooms and you can imagine what it must have been like to be here in its prime. the stairs are a bit of a challenge however its worth it once you get to the top

The best. This is by far the best temple in the Angkor Thom complex. We spent about 2 hours climbing through the ruins and marveling over the architecture, but easily could have spent more time. We had a tour guide who made sure we saw the main sights. The place transports you back in time. The crowds were manageable, but grew throughout the day. Wear sensible shoes - saw tourists struggling to navigate the ruins.
Great temple. Definitely one to see in the morning and if you arrive around 7.30am you can pay to take an elephant ride to the temple... a definite must!!

Great temple to visit. Do not miss it. This is one of the few temple that worth the visit of the Angkor area. Really nice and interesting from several point of view. Great opportunity to take different pictures. To avoid during the weekend.
Lovely temple - face of Cambodia. we had a great trip around all temples. Bayon is the most popular one in movies as it has the stone faces. must visit among all temples.
Breathtaking.. This is just a 'small' part of the huge Angkor Thom complex, but is still worth a good hour wandering around and climbing the temple.

a gem!. Be sure not to miss this temple. It's actually really vast and I spent half day in that area, visiting the elephant terrace as well as the other temples which form Angkor Thom. Angkor Thom is a beautiful complex that will take your breath away, just like Angkor wat will!I went one afternoon in march. It was hot but still manageable. The other benefit is that it wasn't over - crowded, which is always a bonus in the temples!
simply beautiful. the most outstanding and unique sculpture! loved every moment in Bayon..Had a great time throughout the visit.. An excellent place for photography!
Fantastic temple. Amazing temple made us feel like we were stepping back in time. Fantastic photo ops especially of the large faces.
Fascinating. This is part of the overall Angkor complex and is intriguing in its own right. The four faces of Buddha wherever you look is a masterpiece. An experience.

AWESOME!. First you notice a couple of faces, then another and another. Try to count them all. A memorable spot. The only down side here were the large number of tourists more interested in taking their pictures in front of faces than actually "being present" in the temple.
Buddha will smile on you!. Well preserved with stunning bas relief and massive sculptures, its multiple spires suggestive of an ancient Gaudi creative spirit.
Must see. This temple is not too big to explore any time of the day and was less crowded than the huge Angor Wat.
Stunning creature!. The temple is like a maze, walk around the temple the you will find a good photo spot. Climb up to the root top and snap better picture of the Bayon temple.

Beautiful old relic. If you have limited time, make sure you put this temple on the to do list. This buddhist temple was built around 1190AD in the shape of a square and was built 100 years after Angkor Wat. There are over 200 faces carved into towers and lots of passages and steps which makes it difficult to work out where you are in the complex. It's like getting lost in a maze but everywhere you turn someone is smiling at you!!!

Bayon Temple. Same as ANKOR interesting history but was crowded. Facinating to walk around and our guide knew his stuff. We gor there after ANKOR so the heat was high as was the humididty so dress accordingly
A must see. One of the top 3 temples to see, I would recommend this on any trip to Angkor Wat.Bring sunscreen and go early unless you can deal with the heat and the steep stairs in the mid-day sun!

A Must..... By far the most amazing temple in the Angkor Complex!We have visited many times, at all times of the day, during all seasons!It is a spectacular and spiritual place... and one of the best!We have been here alone and with the many.. Either way, it is amazing and a photographers dream...Remember take a moment, put the camera down and take in the awesomeness!

I loved the buddha faces. Arriving there is impressive, although I wish I could have done it by walk (our tour guide had decided it was too hot and too long to walk). We were there on a very busy day, but very interesting to see that even today the temple is one of the major attractions among locals and that they come and pray in and around the temple during that period.

Awe inspiring giant carved faces. Originally consisted of hundreds of giant smiling stone faces; four faces being carved into each side of 50 stupas or towers. Here there is access to all three tiers and you can get some creative photos from the third tier especially early in the morning. There are some interesting bas reliefs depicting Kyhmer history. Can be visited separately or as part of the Angkor Thom complex which is included in the Angkor Archaeological site one, three or seven day ticket.Take plenty of water and sensible walking shoes. Shoulders and legs should be covered or you might not be allowed entry to the temples. Can get busy and noisy with tourists but with a bit of patience you will find a quite space. Hire a guide to ensure you get the best out of the history and design – you can’t possibly get this from a guidebook.
my favourite. I love that place Each year I return for the history and the atmosphere and all those wonderful statues
Fascinating!. One of my favorites!It was so amusing seeing a multitude of enormous stone faces. Visit in the afternoon to skip the crowd.
Amazing. Go early and do the opposite tour - start anywhere but Angkor Wat and you will be able to miss the crowds
Amazing. Like others,we loved this Temple ,particularly the Smiling Buddhas,lots to see,great photo opportunities,careful when walking as the walkways,flooring are uneven.

A Must See When Visiting Cambodia. A must see on a visit to Cambodia! If you are a history buff and love photography this is somewhere you must visit. Take an English speaking guide with you and enjoy the truly amazing way this structures were created without model technology.

Smiling Buddha. This temple, Bayon Temple, is really nice and smiling! Like cambodian people. They smile!It is a good idea to arrive late in the afternoon, less crowdy and less hot and the monkeys are all around the temple. Such an expirience to share the visit with the monkeys!

To be seen. Again, like the others worth the visit, agian might be best to pick a time later in the day, less tour buses around and gives you the oppotuinity to view without the hassell if the tours rushing by. Worth having a tour guide fir the first trip and then go back on your own.

Temple of The Faces. Probably my favourite temple in the Angkor Complex. Visited at sunset which was perfect lighting for photos of the Smiling Buddhas. The history is that this was once a Hindu Temple that was converted to Buddhism after wars and reoccupation by the Khmer people after the Siamese invasion. Hence, there are both Hindu and Buddhist influences in the temple architecture. Highly recommended for history/photography buffs.
my Favorite. The temples of Angkor Wat are all beautiful but the Bayon is my personal favorite - the symbiosis of nature and the monument is just breathtaking.
Must see!. This temple is one of the more popular, so it will be busy. Even so, it is a must see. Absolutely amazing!

A Must See. In terms of design and creativity I think this is my favorite temple. At the entrance of the temple are giants walls that depict the Khmer fighting off invaders. Throughout the temple are huge Buddha heads that watch over the visitors and in the middle is a tall tower.

A site to be seen for sure!. This amazing complex of over 50 towers holds over 2000 faces of gigantic carved Buddhas, each one just a little different from the other. The ancient construction is a marvel to walk around. We walked from Buddha to Buddha just mesmerized by their size and grandeur. DEFINITELY get a guide to explain the history and significance of it all!

Crazy crowded with tour buses. Hit Bayon at sunrise and you will miss the busloads of Korean tourists. Bayon should begin to put a limit on how many people can be in the temple at one time. it was so crowded you could barely move, let alone snap some photos. Skip Ankor Wat sunrise and go to Bayon and Angkor Thom.

Another interesting temple. this was our second temple of the day and of our Cambodian visit. Smaller and plainer than Ankor Thom, but equally charming. You really have to think about the age of the temples and the people who used to build them, live in them, pray in the. Definitely worth a visit.

Spoilt by rude Chinese tourist . Brilliant history and nice to see but it be a lot better if it wasn't full of rude Chinese tourists shouting spitting and pushing you out the way for a photo, they Really did put a dampner on this beautiful place

An awe inspiring temple with massive Buddha faces. Bayon temple is the second temple Complex we visited after Angkor Wat. It is totally different from Angkor temples in style,design and structure The area is more compact and condition of the structures are good as it is maintained by Japanese experts.There are 2000 giant Buddha heads at the top of 54 towers. Four faces on each tower are believed to be of Lord Buddha and signifies the omnipresence of the king. It was believed to be built by King Jayavarmana7 in late 12th century,about 100 years after Angkor Wat. It is learnt from an inscription that it was the central temple of worship in the capital city of Angkor Thom.The deity is Bodisatwa Avolokiteswara. However, some Hindu influence is also seen at places. Two big bas reliefs are also seen here.The columns are decorated with the figures of 3 dancing apsaras.All massive stone heads look alike with broad forehead, lowered eyelids, thick lips and wild nose.There were less number of tourists in this temple unlike Angkor Wat and Ta Phrom. Unlike other two temples, there is no entry fee here A calm tranquillity prevails here that filled me with awe and respect for those who built these impressive creations so many years ago with primitive tools and implements

Fascinating and picturesque. My favourite of all the temples in the Siem Reap area. The carved faces are amazing and in its original state this site must have been truly stunning. Very busy and difficult to photograph without strangers in view but we were tourists too so can't complain. So much information imparted by our knowledgeable guide. I would recommend brief research beforehand and then follow up on what interests you afterwards.

Unbelievable. A must for the bucket list!!. Examine the amazing architecture and sculpture... Go early tourists are out and about before dawn and as the weather is very hot you will find that by mid afternoon you have had enough.

Definite Must See. If only for the Buddha/King faces. A guide is of great use here to explain the significance of the monuments plus circumvent the large tour groups who seem to flock here. Lovely site within an amazing archaeological park.

It is very peaceful in the morning time . Bayon Temple is the spectacular central temple of the ancient city of Angkor Thom. The complex is located just to the north of the famous Angkor Wat.This is an amazing place.One of the first places we visited and the carvings are amazing site to see. Well worth the look.

Beautiful, not as grand as expected. When the visited the Baton Templed there was little conservation going on, and tons of people. The faces are very interesting, didn't take us long to walk through this temple. Lots of monkeys outside.

Classic Photos of Cambodia. Whenever you see pictures of Cambodia, this is where the pictures of massive stone faces on the towers. Most photos do not show the size of these stone faces, they are huge. Do not miss Bayon Temple.According to scholars, King Jayavarman VII bears a strong resemblance to the face towers of the Bayon. If that's true he was extremely narcissistic, but he certainly will amaze us for eternity. Come with a private guide, or on your own because you will not have enough time to get good pictures if you take a group tour. Your $20 day pass will allow entrance to all temples.
A must see!!!. An awe inspiring temple that just has to be visited. Try to get the early, as in 07.00 to beat the crowds and just soak it all in. Stunningly beautiful!

I really like this for all the carved faces. This is a favourite of mine in Cambodia, as it is so unique, I have not seen anything like this anywhere. There are currently 148 giant faces on 37 stupas, all with different expression. You can get creative with photography here and get great shots.

must see. visited same day as ankor wat, as it was afternoon it was very hot so take water, you also find guides who for a fee will take you round, found that quite worthwhile , will cost you us$6-10, fantastic place
wonderful. excellent temple, lots of history, markings in abundance. obviously lots of uneven surfaces so not great for the unsteady person but well worth a visit.
Loved it!. The architecture is amazing. We loved the huge faces. Try to see as many temples as you can, because they all have something that makes them special.
An experience. Put your walking shoes on. This is an amazing place,hire a guide there is so much history only they know. found it to be fascinating and absolutely beautiful.

I loved just being there, puts a smile on your face.. The temples are so picturesque and there's much to explore.The happy figure puts a smile on your face too! You'll have a wonderful time here.Join me in my adventure!http://www.monicawong.com/2015/03/projectmcambodia-siem-reap.html
Carvings amazing.. One of the first places we visited and a fantastic site to see, the carvings are amazing when you think how long ago they where completed.
speechless. Need I say more? I was awe struck and this is not the first time I am visiting the place. Ancient architecture, Brilliant memorabilia,

Really beautiful and unique temple with happy faces. Go early in the morning around 7am to enjoy the temple by yourself. It is very peaceful and zen at that time. Since the temple is very small, once the crowds come in, it is impossible to fully enjoy the temple and take good pictures.
What a temple. Splendid temple with carved faces. Outstanding architecture and really really unique. A must visit temple.

Save the best one for last. We saw the Bayon as the last temple and that was perhaps a good choice, since we were already a bit temple-tired, but this one was so spcial that we regained our energy. The temple is at the centre of the big city Angkor Thom and is more compact than the huge Angkor Wat, but still very impressive. Most striking of course the some 200 faces which are said to all look like the temple's builder emperor Jayavarman VII. Also very impressive are the extensive carvings at the Bayon.

Almost Bayon belief!. Bayon temple is the gem of Angkor Thom. It stands stoically in the exact center of the ancient Khmer capital, dating back to the 12th century. Bayon is famous for its 4-faced towers, with huge smiling stone faces dubbed by some as the "Mona Lisa of South East Asia". At one point, the temple was host to 49 such towers; now sadly, only 37 remain with apparent signs of deterioration. The number of faces is approximately 200, but since some are only partially preserved there can be no definitive count. Why this is my favourite site in Siem Reap, despite Angkor Wat being a more architectural marvel, is because of the surreal ambiance it seems to exude. One feels as if transported into a seemingly unreal bygone era; or like being cast on a movie set, especially when the area is glazed by the setting sun. The apparent look of meditation (maybe compassion) cast on the unfazed sandstone faces, with eyes closed, create an atmosphere of repose, when the crowds are gone and all one hears are the birds singing on their way home to their nests.
Worth visiting..bit crazy if too busy!. everything except the crowds...can't help them.. Great photo opportunities ... The architecture is great...

Mystical ancient temple - see my TIPS!. We visited this incredible ancient temple that is being painstakingly restored on the same day that we visited Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm. It had a mysterious and magical feel to it, particularly because of the ancient stone faces. We went late morning after first visiting Angkor Wat. I think no matter what time you go, it will be busy with tourists. We spent about an hour and a half strolling through the ruins and then afterwards walked to the Baphuon, which is nearby. TIPS:Visit the Bayon as part of a visit to the overall Angkor complex.Car and driver for the day is around USD 30. It's useful hiring a car/driver as it gets very hot and the air-conditioned car is a welcome place to rest in between temple visits. One day entrance fees to the Angkor complex is USD 20 per person. Multi-day passes are also available. Watch out for the monkeys. Don't clamber over the temple ruins - stay on the paths. This is a temple under restoration. No need to take shoes off at the temple.Wear a hat (there is little shade at the top of the temple) and take water - it gets really hot.
Smiling Faces Temple. Loved every bit of it. Take your time to take it in. Well worth the look. It will take a couple of hours to go through, the history present will blow you away.

Well worth visiting. Easily recognisable from the many smiley faces carved on the huge rocks at the top level of the temple site, but do not miss the carvings telling the story of every day life in the early centuries at ground level around the walls. Go with a guide so he can point out all the interesting features. Definitely worth a visit as still in good condition now although major attempts are ongoing to preserve the heritage.

Temple great but watch out for dangers!. Bayon was the first temple we visited and we were ready for three days of this activity. Sadly, we got no further than Day 1. At the end of our visit to bacon my wife was descending a wooden staircase when she slipped and broke her leg! we were lucky in that the private tour we were on wished us off to the International Hospital for treatment (not cheap.....over a $1000). What was interesting was to learn later that such accidents are fairly common..the ground is uneven, the steps are covered with a film of sand and hence very slippy....so, if doing this visit...take care!

Yes it's another temple with a big history. This is worth going to discover how the religions Hindu and Buddhism go hand in hand. The stone faces of the statues watching as you move around give an erie feeling. But the history and mythology is gripping for any listener.

See it before the forest reclaims it. Iconic temple which is being reclaimed by the jungle.
Every old tree that falls takes out another piece of wall.
The faces on the towers are wonderful, particularly considering how old they are and still in good nick

One of the best - a 'must see'. Bayon is a very impressive temple providing a great example of how the jungle is now inter-twined with the temples. Some good photo opportunities if you walk around and best shot from the jungle or across the small water area. In pretty good condition and provides a good view of the effort and complexity in building a temple like this. Another for the 'must see' list.

be there at 5pm on a rainy day. for great pictures most of you don't think about, put your raincoat on on a rainy day and start taking mirror pictures in the water and cloud pictures in sky. great and so different from all these sunny pictures. i, ve been there so many times the last 20 years, never get bored.

Amazing temple, still being renovated. The heads in this temple are haunting, the temple itself is a must-see and beautifully arranged.Not as tiring as Angkor Wat, it's much easier to get to the top of this temple and walk around the amazing architecture.
A "Must See". If you are visiting Siem Reap, you must want to see the temples. Fascinating even if the weather is unbearably hot in February. Go in November/December instead!

The serene faces of Bayon watch you.. This is an amazing site. The tranquil faces of Bayon temple watch you as you explore the ruins of this enormous structure. It never ceases to amaze me as to the amount of access you are given to these historical ruins. It seems that as long as its safe enough you can go there!  Stairs ( like ladders!) climb high into sky up to the parapets around the top of the temples or descend down into the passage ways and rooms below. You will definitely get a workout at this site. Remember to wear your joggers or good walking shoes and to dress appropriately so you are not denied access into the sacred areas. Women must have legs and shoulders/neck area covered. There are some more ruins and interesting areas along a marked track that wanders through the bush surrounding the major temples too and it is very peaceful (& cooler) walking along the track. There are a few vendors selling water and fruit at the end of the track or around the parking area too so you can always grab a bite to eat before you head off to you next stop.

You won't see anything else like this. What a marvelous idea to leave the trees on these temples instead of removing them. It's good to have the restored temples at Angkor Wat; however, to see the condition in which all of these temples were found is even more remarkable.

le regard du roi mystérieux. Huge ! one of the most beautiful ruins of the world in an exceptional site. Bayon is an amazing temple with the same face looking at you wherever you will be in the temple. .Angkor archeological site-Buy a 3-day pass to take time to see well the major temples- Take a daily tuck-tuck in SIem Reap to go to the site, then you will have it to go to a temple from another. and MARVEL...

Enchanting!. Mindblowing architecture! It intrigues me so much that I couldn't help being amazed at it. Lovely place not to be missed. And beware, steep stairs everywhere. And visiting the bus relief carvings is a must here!
Beautiful serene temple.. Consirering how many people were visiting, the tranquility was surreal. You could hear the birds in the tree tops, and feel the peace.

Favorite Temple. This was my favorite temple in Cambodia. I really loved the face carvings in the stone. We went here around 10:30 am and it was pretty crowded. If i returned, I might go here first thing in the morning to get better photos. Even with the crowds, there were a lot of great photo opps! Be ready to climb up the ladder/staircase for this one - it's not too bad compared to the steep stairs with no rails at other temples.
Mind blowing. Probably the best temple in the siem reap region, the construction and detail of the heads on the temple pillars is fascinating.
Beautiful Carvings. Feels Lifelike. Very fascinating faces all over the temple. Definitely should be added to your itinerary if you are visiting Siem Reap for the temples.
Mystical. Head carvings great . Loved the the first time. And husband loved this time. Mystical and great photographic subjects

Possibly the most impressive temple at Angkor. The Bayon was very cool to see. It gets quite crowded though, if you go around sunrise it's probably quieter. It was still very impressive and enjoyable, even with the crowds.

Well Worth Visiting. I really enjoyed Bayon Temple. It has a lot less tourists then Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm. I found it very eerie but also thoroughly fascinating with the ancient faces and various levels and tiny rooms of the temple. Amazing condition considering how old the temple is.

Impressive, don't miss it. The Khmer Temple was built in 1190; it is a fantastic site to learn about the history of their civilization; it is also called the Temple of the Thousand Faces and if you are curios you will find spots were you can take a photo with up to 12 faces. Ask your tour guide to show the Smiling Image, considered by many the portrait of the Jayavarman VII, a Buddhist King. The walls present historical events through their bas-relief scenes. Don't forget your hat.
Worth a walk over.. Stay together you can get lost in this one with the faces. Not too arduous compared to some. Take water as not one selling anything around that we found
Mind Blowing. Bayon is with Angkor Thom and the site is very well preserved and when we visited not to busy enabling us to take our time and really take in the fantastic acheivement this was.
Bayon Temple. Loved this temple the faces are amazing! We has an elephant ride around the temple was great to it from a different perspective.

Steep steps amazing views. Went to the Bayon temple on part of our tour . The stone carvings are amazing, it's a place of beauty and not as busy as some of the other temples . It great to climb the steps for some amazing views well worth a visit .

Personal favourite of all the temples at Angkor. This temple is best visited in the morning whilst everybody else is at Angkor Wat; this way you can avoid the large tour groups that ruin the experience of visiting the temples. Large stone faces stare at you wherever you are in the Bayon.

My favorite temple in Siam Reap. More interesting than Angkor Wat. We wandered all around and took so many photos. The kings face carved everywhere just adds to the photos. Unfortunately it was a bit crowded when we got there around 11 am.

Serene. Bayon is my favourite temple of Angkor - smaller than Angkor Wat it offers more individual space for exploraion and contemplation. The big faces of Buddha exude such serentity, I could spend hours looking at them.
Beautiful !. i love the feelings when i was at Bayon. Lucky to be here, to witness one of the world oldest temple on earth.

Multi Facets Beauty. This is one of the last Buddhist temple to be built by the king and later on, there was the influence of Hinduism in the temple. There are hundreds of faces of different dimensions being sculptured in the temple with solid granite boulders.The beauty of the temple is the originality being maintained without any alteration or or upgrading. It is worth visiting this temple, especially for photographers.

Even better than Angkor.... Bayon is more mysterious, surprising and inviting. It's (OK: nearly) intimate but huge, too. 54 towers, 216 faces in stone, hundreds of perspectives. One could possibly spend days finding more an more details of a long forgotten culture.

It is hot so dress appropriately. There are countless chambers, rooms and levels, countless Buddha statues and carvings. Bring lots of extra batteries because there is just so much you will want to remember.

stunning. do not miss this temple on you ankor trip. the stone-carved faces are really impressive and the temple is not so flat as others. it is fun to explore the temple and climb the steep steps. after visiting the temple you should walk on to some other temples nearby and to the terrace of elephants. but these others are not so much worth seeing but the walk is beautiful

Excellent attraction. This was the first temple we visited and to see all the work that ???.... the 7th put into this place was amazing. I did not like the elephant rides that were going on around the place but I guess that's part and parcel of commercial tourism.
Fascinating!. My favorite temple in Angkor! Inside Agkor Thom, the Bayon is enigmatic and huge Buddha faces are looking around. Accessible by bike, tuk tuk, motorbike ... Nice Temple into the Jungle!

Must See!. This was a beautiful Temple. I would recommend going in the morning as it is very hot. History buffs will be fascinated with this. Many carvings with wonderful stories behind them. Our guide was fabulous with a continuing stream of the history. Hats, sunglasses and water is a MUST! We will definitely visit here again if we get back to this part of the world. To enough time to see everything!

Awesome Bayon. Travelers that would visit Siem Reap should make sure to visit the Bayon Temple! This is one of my favorite temples that would make you want to research its historical background. Check out all the faces! :)

Best temple!. This is my second trip to Siem Reap and too Angkor temples, among those Bayon Temple is still my favorites! You can really takes loads of nice picture in this temple. Remember to go there earlier to avoid the crowds! I am really amazed how they build such a wonderful temple! A must visit!

face lifting!! with smile. numerous towers, each has 4 faces to 4 directions, and only one is smiling, and a lot of visitors stand in line to take photos with the smille. one of the nicest impressivr temples

Tomb raiding. There are no pictures that do this place justice you just have to go and see it for yourself. The trees are encompassing the buildings or are the trees holding up the buildings .We went twice just to take advantage of the morning and late afternoon light. Be patient and you will be able to get that picture without a crowd of people.
take loads of time visiting all the temples!. take loads of time visiting all the temples! most amazing few days ever and i want to return very soon please! thnank you siem reap

Glory of 12th century. Very interesting and absolutely amazing structure. One should not miss it. It represents the intersection of Earth and Heaven with huge smiling faces of Bhodhisatva. This is also called Monalisa of south east Asia.

My favourite. Of the 5 temples we've seen on our tour (including the iconic Angkor Wat) this one was by far my favourite. We could get up close to see the four faces of Buddha, and it was exactly what I was expecting from a temple. Get there early to avoid the crowds and the heat.
Temples of Angkor. Truly amazing, the temples, the people, the craftsmanship all features of this amazing area. You need to be faily agile, but well worth the effort.

The faces. Similar to the other temples, but with faces. The sides of the towers have the most serine faces on them. Still crowded like the others , but wonderfully done. One of the must see temples in the area.

So impressive!. Interesting, amazing and definitely on the must do list! Yes, the Angkor Temples are overrun with tourists, but this was the least busy of the sites we visited. We did the elephant ride around the Bayon Temple and really enjoyed it. Great views from up on the elephant!
A gem of a temple. This was the first temple we visited (we did 12 all together) and very impressive it is too, especially if approached from the south gate
8am busy busy busy. . I could not imagine doing this temple once it started to heat up. Its very tight compared to the other temples, so gets busy very quickly. Go early to avoid the heat and crowds.

The complex face towers are the highlight here!. People think there might have been 54 face tours with 216 faces, but right now, 37 are standing. There are also exceptional bas reliefs of daily life and Kymer history. Stones are made of soil, lime, sand, red soil, and clay compacted by hand. There are many apsara - the traditional Kymer female dancers. This is a beautiful temple. We visited fairly early in the morning, but much to our disappointment, it was already overrun by great numbers of tourists. This, however, is an unfair negative assessment since we were a couple of the tourists! We did find it difficult to take pictures without dozens of other people being included!

Bayon Temple - how blessed this place felt. Of all the temples, this was the most captivating with so many of the Buddha faces preserved.Truly a magical place, which was the favourite one to see in all its splendour!!

Best temple in the complex. It was very beautiful and special temple...All the carvings, architecture - it was awesome...Wish i can come back again one day!!! All the words and pictures cannot describe its real beauty - just visit Bayon yourself!!

Great tour bring your walking shoes. We did a one day $20 tour with our hotel tuk tuk driver. Enjoyed every temple. Some are under conservation construction and offer guides etc. But apart from Ankor Wat where we got a guide we did the rest ourselves.Bring water and comfy shoes
A sight to behold. Another great piece of Cambodian history. Lots of walking as with temples but 100 percent worth the time.
Lots of history. The temple was very interesting and worth seeing. This temple is well-known and richly decorated Khmer temple at Angkor in Cambodia. Worth a trip.
