Amazing ancient wonder. After spending the morning and early afternoon at Angkor Wat, we visited the Bayon Temple. We thoroughly enjoyed it. We found it to be even more beautiful and impressive than Angkor Wat. By the time we got to the Bayon Temple, the heat was intense, but there weren't many people. You may want to visit Bayon first, and then go to Angkor Wat. We hired a private guide to take us to these temples, which really added to our enjoyment of these ancient wonders.
Very nice Temple. The faces are very nice and make a unique temple in comparison to others in the area. Simply loved it. Don't forget to take your camera. Highly recommended.

Incredible faces of Bayon. Set at the heart of Angkor Thom the Bayon Temple is an imposing edifice that once had 59 columns with each having four faces. Not for those with mobility difficulties but for two reasonably fit 66 year olds not a problem. A must visit for anyone going to Siem Reap.

Unbelievable. What can you say, the whole reason we came ½ way around the world. Amazing!! Bring water a camera and take your time. Don't try to see everything in one day. With the all the Faces this place rates higher than Angkor Wat for me.

Don't miss this temple . One of the most buetiful temples. Not as big as others. This is actually an advantage. You will remember the stonedfaces forever.Best time to visit around 8 am. Crowds of tourists are still at Ankor Wat at the time, beautiful light for photographs.Very recommended.

My favorite!. Maybe it's because we went late in the day and it was not crowded with the sun low behind it. The carved faces and views from the top - a must see! Plan ahead for a restroom as it is over near the market by the Elephant Wall. If you ask a policeman where it is, they might just give you a ride on their moto! Lots ofuneven stairs if you want to go to the top - but the site from the ground is still amazing and worth the visit!

Favorite temple at Angkor. We timed our trip to Bagan perfectly in the afternoon and were able to avoid the crowds. This place was absolutely beautiful and the carved faces on each pillar are still in great shape. If you're exploring the temples, make time for Bagan you won't regret it!
Fascinating and part of the tour. Just impressive, there is plenty of information on the Internet and a good idea to look at that in advance.
Don't skip it!. A must-see. Stunning Budha faces all around you, reminding you of what our ancestors did to praise the divine in them.

One of my favourite temples in Siem Reap. Bayon Temple is a must see while in Siem Reap, this was one of my favourite temples even though it was full of other tourists! The many carved faces are an impressive sight to see!

my favourite. I came over all emotional at the sight of the faces, loved it.
Get there as early as you can bare though

Stunning Beauty. Although the LP said morning is the best time to visit Bayon temple, we were brought there in the late afternoon by our guide and it was awesome! The sun light in dry season added a beautiful touch to all the peaceful smiles and the place was not even crowded. We were able to have a quiet enjoyment of Jayavarman VII sculptured faces.

BAYON TEMPLE. Visit the Bayon Temple in the morning and allow a few hours in this area as there are two more temples within walking distance. I recommend arriving as early as possible as it does get hotter later in the day... there's lots of steep narrow steps so sensible footwear a must. Grabbing a guide book on the Angkor temples and doing some reading will help you to understand the history of these amazing structures.
Amazing. One of the most beautiful temples. The faces are simply exquisite. It was not as crowded as Angkor Wat which was a plus. I could have stayed there all day
Beautiful.. This may be the best of the many temples around Siem Reap for pictures. It is still undergoing major reconstruction. The temple is known for its many faces.
What a gem!. The most impressive after angkor wat.A must !Together with the surroundings, needs a whole afternoon visit.

one of my fav. it is one of the top 3 temples in Angkor Wat and they will surely take you there if you do the tour. It done not look like much from down but climb up as high as you can and its fantastic. The Buddha faces which is the overall design is fantastic.
amazing. I've never been such a beautiful place. Talk about the stones. Everyone should see this. A dream come true.

Excellent but too crowded. I came there in February which is the Lunar new year. Things were excellent. The weather at this time was hot but acceptable (in comparison with summer which is around 40 degree). From the gate, you can go to Bayon temple by bus (for around 20 people, mainly tour) or tuk-tuk, by bike, etc. But I prefer going there (and all the places in Angkor) by tuk tuk since you can catch the whole beautiful view of Angkor. This place is super beautiful and breathtaking. There are 54 monuments which represents 54 provinces of Cambodia in the past and things on the rock are still remained through time. The only thing that distracted me from enjoying the Temple is people. Too crowded! I suggested you shouldn't go there in the peak time of tourism (February and summer) cause you can't enjoy that much.

Top 3 Temple. We spent 4 days in Siem Reap and saw just about every temple (well at least the ones on the map). Rather than reviewing all of them, I decided to just review my top 3, and Bayon was one of them. I really liked the faces of this temple and just the overall design. Check this one out for sure (but see as many as you can!)
Beautiful colours. An amazing temple that just seems to go on and on. Can get very busy, but is incredible during late afternoon sunshine. Climb as high as you can.

visit in September. We travelled at the beginning of September, less visitors so you can move around easier but still do early morning or late afternoon, the light on the buildings and statutes is great for showing up the reliefs.The complex is excellent and do explore all around not just into the main part, take some time to look at the complex as a whole it is worth the effort.
Must do!. Must do whilst in Siem Reap. Quite busy, so be prepared to queue and wait. Take some water with you as it gets very warm whilst walking around.

Our favorite temple. We stayed 1 week in Siem reap, the Bayon Temple was our favorite templeWe did not know where to look first it is simply amazing.Make sure you have enough time to visit give it at least 1,5 hours.

You are being watched!. Everyone raves about Angkor Wat, for obvious reasons, but Bayon is a true gem! You will likely find less of a crowd (particularly at sunrise/sunset when everyone is at AW). If you figure out how to get your camera to take a back lit shot, (or go when the lighting is right) you will get some cool "head shots." If you are using an iPhone, touch the screen and a little sun will pop up and you can counter act the back lighting.

Great location. Great location to discover, early birds will enjoy the silence. My favourite place so beautiful, a physical impression of old stones and old trees very well arranged by nature. I like the Bayon periode and enjoy to own some beautiful sculptures.

So many faces!. This temple is known for the many faces of Buddha looking in all 4 directions. The walk ways in between are a bit tight and this location got crowded very quickly. You have to look out to not get poked into the eye by some Korean tourist's selfie stick. There was a also a group of locals dressed up in historical garb for taking pictures (if historically accurate, shouldn't the ladies be topless? ;) ) .. of course for a fee.
Favourite Temple. Definitely my favourite temple in Siem Reap. The faces are amazing (though repetitive) and the temple is a true wonder.Absolutely loved it.

The best.. By far the most charming of all of the temples, however measures really must be taken to stop hoardes of people weilding selfie sticks climbing all over these beautiful stones grinning inanely into a phone and showing no respect at all for the heritage of the site. It was hot and dusty but the sheer beauty overcame all,

Great to see at least once in your life.. The carved smiling faces in the temple are all around. This place is unique and very cool to see. There are a lot of different carvings of smiling faces on this temple. You have to be careful when you are walking around because you are technically walking in a place where this is more of an actual archaeological site then a museum set up so you can be walking on very unlevel rocks, etc.. This is a bucket list attraction for sure.
A Magical Place. A truly magical place and I think the best temple I visited on my trip. If you like history and historical places then a visit here is an absolute must.

Make sure its on your temple list. This was my favorite of all the temples, the stone buddha faced towers are stunning. there are lots of levels, passage ways and rooms to explore. I managed to find an area toward the right of the main entrance in the lower passage ways where no one else was. I had a rare chance to feel like i was the only one in the temple i took a seat and just relaxed and took it all in, Fantastic place

Enchanting. Bayon was one of my favorite temples that I went to when visiting Siem Reap. The faces were magnetizing and I took photo after photo. We were there in the afternoon which means it was hot. It also meant that we avoided most of the big tour groups and were able to get some great shots. Highly recommend!

Cultural Heritage. This is our last stop on our temple tour. Outside the Bayon Temple, there are huge Buddhas, where you can light incense sticks and you will have to give donations and the lady will give you a bracelet. Inside the temple, you will go up quite steep stairs and you will notice that the structures had bayon carvings on almost each one of them. I was amazed because they all look exactly alike to think that ancient Cambodians used their bare hands to carve these.

yes!!. We had a private guide who took us on bikes, from Angkor Thom to the Bayon, Elephant terrace...it was really fun, we stopped many times for pictures, explanations, and our teen daughters liked it too.

One of the best temples to see in the area, but go early or late!. To me this was one of the most fascinating of all the temples in the area. There is a lot to see and its best to do this early or late in the day to avoid the throngs of selfie wielding coach loads! As mentipned on other posts, tell your tuk tuk driver what order you want to see temples, not the other way around. Top tip is to see Angkor Wat at sunrise, spend some time there then head straight here. It's a nice peaceful place with plenty to see, if you the it right!

Faces and Elephants!. Be sure to walk through and go on to the elephant terrace for something a little different. The myriad of faces staring out at you makes this temple very interesting, look out for the smiling faces :)
Great place. one of the best place in Angkor with a lot of statues and carving on stones with wonderful atmosphere
Favourite temple in Angkor Park. This temple with its many Buddha faces were my favourite. Make sure its on your itinerary when visiting the park. Great photo opportunities.

kissing the buddha. must do: to kiss one of the buddhas. the architecture carved on the stones are very detailed. the temple staircases are very narrow and straight. please wear flats, shoes, flip flops or sandals.

Older than ankor-wat but just as impressive. As with Ankor wat - you should bring a guide to get the full experience here, they have vast knowledge of the history of the place, and though the sights are impressive enough, having the history of it told to you as you experience it is well worth the relatively small sum you pay the guide.Well worth a look, but I would not spend the whole day here.

Center of Angkor Thom. Bayon forms the center of the great Angkor Thom temple, built by King Jayavarman in the late 11 th or early 12 th century. One I portent point about this temple is, it's lower level has all historical and mythological facts depicted, while the upper level has huge four faced stone images. They call it Buddha or Bidhisattva. After Jayavarman's death, temple was modified according to the wishes of the Buddhist kings. This has a magnificent look and was the State Temple of Jayavarman.

Be sure to ride the elephants. While this temple is not as impressive as Angkor Wat, there are elephants ready to take you around the entire temple - it's a great way to see it and worth the small price. Then check out the ruins - but be careful of uneven steps and limited handrails. It's pretty cool to walk around these ancient structures.

the sum of its parts is amazing. Giant Buddha faces, an elephant temple, stunning gates, and many minor temples. This space really is beautiful. In the morning (sunrise) it is rammed. If you start a bit later you will be able to see the temples from the tourists. Also good walking shoes are necessary. The paths are clear but it is easy to miss step at the temples. Take water, lots of it, the dust, sun, air, etc will dry you out. There is a lot of ongoing work around the temples - keeping them up and re discovering lost bits. Definitely worth seeing, it has a grandeur that is different to Angkor Wat, though its scale is just as grand. Also don't take any stones or move things - these sites really do need to be better protected.

Must do!. We are a family of 3 (2 adults and a 10 year old kid). We got an overall of 5 days in the Angkor Archeological Part.First of all, be ready for a very warm and humid weather and second be ready for many steps up and down.In the first day we got to visit Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom with all the temples within, so at the end your visit will probably not be only to Bayon as in the same visit your guide will take you at least to: Bayon, Baphoun, and the Elephant and Leper King Terraces.You will need easy 3 hours and if you can spare more time, there are plenty of opportunities for photos all around, I would suggest to spend some time at the gates as you can get a clear shot as at Bayon there are too many structures together so you will need much better skills with the camera for good pictures.

Get there early & ignore your tuktuk driver. Bayon was by far the most impressive, however it gets busy so it's worth going early - ignore the tuktuk drivers as they will map out the route they want to take but you can customise it to your own requirements.I found Bayon to be the best of the lot during my time in SR.

Very awesome. After sweating it out elbow to elbow at Angkor Wat, we went to Bayon Temple. What a huge contrast in the two places... And experiences. Bayon Temple is simply amazing... A tight labyrinth of intricate stone faces with a lot of exploration in (relative to Angor Wat) a little bit of space. Way less dense in terms of visitors, too. Go to Angor Wat and check it off your list, but makes sure Bayon Temple is next... It's so close it would be a shame to miss.
Bayon Temple. Brilliant, amazing, beautiful! Like all the other temples, just find a spot, sit down, admire and enjoy!
Amazing!!. Having to read about Bayon is a totally different experience than visiting the place yourself. It was a hot afternoon when we reached bayon temple.

Smiling faces my favourite. One of my favorite temples. What makes it interesting is the smiling carving faces on the temple and the architecture and artistry of carvings on the walls and pillars that depict Buddhism. All around the temple is just rich of carvings and stone structure that is so fine and detailed you have to wonder how it was made long time ago.The place has not much of shade so bring along water, caps and hats as it would be very hot if you are planning to visit it in the afternoon.

Essential part of the Angkor experience. The second of the big temples but with a different feel to Angkor Wat and maintains the great Angkor experience. Again this can get very crowded with tour parties, a visit later in the day is worth the effort to avoid the crowds.
Magnificent. Incredible place. You need to get close to the walls and observe carefully the 100's of faces is every direction. It is truly a captivating place.

My favorite in Siem Reap. This amazing temple has two major themes - the Huge king face carved in the sands stones all over the building and the daily Kemer life seances carved around the first floor. Don't miss it.
Just AMAZING to see. The Temples are just awesome to see. No words to describe the beauty of the place. Just pics... A must do!

Angkor Thom. This is the best part of the Angkor Thom area. Don't miss it. It's the most interesting part because it is about the life of the king and priests. Great carvings, too. Get there early. It gets hot by noon.

Walking among ruins. I am still amazed that we are allowed to walk around this amazing structure, touch the ancient reliefs and climb up and down the "rubble" of eroding sandstone. I imagine it will become like Stonehenge, where tourists are no longer permitted to sit on the stones or even to walk up among them. I hope it does, as it will preserve the structure far more than thousands of tourists pounding on its surface daily. The Bayon Temple was an unforgettable experience.
Impressing. The towers with the many faces of BuddhaThe sculptural walls with clearly told stories, all very well preserved

Here's looking at you.. While not as large as Angkor Wat, it is tremendously interesting and mysterious. The many faces carved into the towers, each with it's own expression, are magnificent. I couldn't help but imagine how spectacular and intimidating it must have been when the facades were intact. Take the time to stop at the entrance and look down the long approach road, imagining yourself to be seeing this temple for the first time as you walk up that road a thousand years ago.

Excellent; watching archaeologists at work on restoration, even better. Beautiful & stunning. Large parts are at present under restoration - interesting to watch modern day cranes do what elephants did 1500 years ago. Stunning carvings. All easily accessible & close to where TukTuk does the drop off / pick up. After Angkor Wat itself this is my next favourite temple in this area.

Serene smiling faces !. Just breathtaking as each face is carved on huge stones, similar in appearance of the Khmer architecture, sporting a huge smile that is incredibly beautiful and serene. The pathways are narrow and one has to wait to take pictures if the temples inside. Some part of the temple premises are closed down with the Japanese doing renovation work to restore many of the statues. Requires a couple of hours to do justice to this beautiful structure built around the 13 century. Lots of mobile stalls selling ice cream and fruits to pause and recharge before the long walks along the parapet of the walls of the temple.
Enchanting!. The most playful of all the temples - our favorite!! Though much smaller than Angkor Wat itself, this temple and it's faces were absolutely delightful!

1 of the 3 Best in the Angkor Wat Area. Bayon Temple is one of the 3 best temples in the Angkor Wat area. There's the largest temples Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm temple with the beautiful trees, and Bayon temple with the best faces of Buddha in the whole complex. As you enter the temple area, you pass over these large bridges and beneath these huge gates, each capped with a giant face of Buddha. Inside the temple is covered with giant lotus blossoms and faces of Buddha. My only recommendation for the whole temple area is to drink lots of water and design your own tour schedule. Most of the tours tend to start at the same temple and follow the same route, so you will be stuck following around LARGE tour groups and unable to snap any good photos.
Faces galore. A very interesting place to visit. The faces on the temple are magnificent; can't help but wonder how perfect they must have been over 800 years ago when they were built.
The best of the best. In my view this temple complex outdoes Angkor Wat even if the latter is better known. Don't miss it on a visit to Siem Reap

Go in the afternoon. It's hot here, so so hot and humid. There's lots of kids to sell you water though but man it's hot. Afternoon time we found was better for visiting as it either wasn't as hot or we tolerated the heat better. Go by tuk tuk not car. More fun, cheaper and you regulate your temperature better, the bayon is amazing. It's all amazing but this place is so mysterious. Our second time here and just as good.
Beautiful but.... Beautiful, but extremely crowded. Very frustrating when there are large groups of tourists there, as it is hard to pass through and get any pics without loads of people.

One of a kind. It's a beautiful temple, in ruins though but intricately preserved. You would love the tour to the entire complex. We spent about a full day at the Angkor Wat complex, starting from the south gate and ending at the north gate. By dusk, the entire place was lit up by yellow sunlight. It was just phenomenal.
Great temple. Awesome temple to explore, just to many constructions at the moment. Really helpful to do it with a guide and I would suggest looking around the temple at the other information.

Massive smiling stone faces. The Bayon temple is the central attraction of Angkor Thom. It is famous for the hundreds - estimated to be over 200 - of serene and massive smiling faces carved out of stones which make up the many towers of the temple. Bayon is also known also for two richly intricate sets of bas-reliefs, which many say are a combination of varying mythological and historical scenes. So don't miss these bas-reliefs. This temple is truly a must-see. It represents a period in history, which tells the story of the rich culture and architecture - very similar to baroque - of that period of time. We had a guide with us, so we were able to get a lot of information on the stories behind many of the carvings and bas-reliefs. This site gets to be very busy, so a late afternoon or early morning visit is recommended especially during the hot months of the year (March to August). Some visitors take the tuk-tuk to get here, but joining a tour would be preferable. The temple was built in a compact way so it is not as expansive or grand like the Angkor Wat. But be prepared to do some climbing and walking.

Our Favourite. This was by far the most impressive of all the sights we saw in Cambodia. For us it overshadowed even Angkor Wat. Skip the dawn rush for Angkor and cycle past the crowds to the completely deserted Bayon temple for an unforgettable experience. The place gets very crowded later in the morning so this gives you time to explore at leisure.

Best temple in Ankor. The views you can get of this temple from simply walking around the surrounding road are genuinely staggering. With its hundreds of quietly serene stone faces, and its sheer scale, you can't help but stand and stare, jaw on the floor. Inside the temple is a maze with tunnels and nooks and crannies, and close up views of the stone faces. However as with a lot of these temples the best view is from afar. As with all the temples, be careful with your day of visit. Weekdays are noticeably quiter than weekends.
Put this one on your list. You have to put this site on your places to visit. Even when its crowded you can still enjoy the ruins..
Spend some time here. Just amazing so much history - so not rush take your time and definitely hire a guide you will learn so much more about the history etc

Wonderful Architecture. I thought this was on par with Angkor wat. The architecture is beautiful, every corner you turn is something different!So Mich history to learn in one place, it's worth taking a guide to talk you through it all!Not as busy as Angkor wat which is a big bonus!

Angkor Thom Many Faces. It is quite an impressive temple complex especially when one takes a closer look at the four faces of a Hindu king carved out of stones as part of the temple's many towers. The temple was set in beautiful landscape and although much of the temple has crumbled, the symmetrical shape of the vast temple is mind boggling considering the technology present during the realm of the ancient Khmer kingdom. As for photography, I reckon the best time is in the afternoon when the Bayon reflects colours of amber and gold due the intense light from the sun on a good day. You can expect postcard quality photography as a result of natural colours from the surrounding greens. Don't bother with the free-lance photographers in and around the temple complex. The quality of photography has been compromised with tourist's money.
Amazing architecture. The architecture was beautiful. It is better to visit any of the temples early in the day as not so enjoyable when there are thousands of visitors.

A Fascinating Angkorian Temple Experience. The Angkor Thom Temple was a vast area, so we were taken to the middle where the Bayon temple is located. Our Tuk-Tuk driver told us this was the most significant part and we weren’t disappointed. The temple contains 54 towers and 216 huge stone faces of Avalokiteshvara (the Buddha of compassion), with various myths saying that they also look like the King himself. Walking around in the temple is slightly unnatural – wherever you go, whatever you see there is always a huge stone face looking down at you with a strange smile. Legends suggest it was a reminder to his subjects that the king was always watching them.What we adored about the temples was the rustic and atmospheric feel, the intricate details of the carvings and the rich history of the Angkorian temples. The stones are placed at such precision and complex interlocking shapes, that it is impossible to fit even a single piece of paper between them. Whether you have one week or one day in Siem Reap, I would definitely recommend coming to Angkor Wat and seeing the famous Angkorian temples. Unlike other modern temples in Thailand and other parts of Cambodia, these aged temples offer more dramatic and atmospheric views. Many people told us we would need a minimum of three days for the temples which would cost $60 (per person) and around $60 (for a Tuk-Tuk driver for three days). We were able to see most of the large temples, stop off at the smaller ones and even had time for ice cream and lunch before the sun set over the temples in just one day. The day ticket is only $20 (per person) and if you arrive around 7:00am, you will have more than enough time to visit the temples including Angkor Wat. There are absolutely loads of temples though, so if these are your thing then a multi-pass deal might be for you.If arriving to Siem Reap by bus, avoid at all costs the locals who almost pounce on you at the bus station. Their prices are extortionate compared to the services your hotel will offer. One local tried selling to us, thinking I didn’t understand the exchange rate. When calculating this in my head I told him no and he got very aggressive and shouted something in Khmer as we left the station. Their selling tactics are very hard sell – they don’t give you time to think and before you know it you’re reaching for your wallet. Speaking to many travellers on our journey we have heard many similar stories.

breath-taking. There were so many carvings that it was hard to know where to look first. Whatever you do, make sure you walk to the top and look more closely at them. Incredible archaeological treasure. I'd have stayed longer but my tour group needed to leave. Don't miss it!

Better than Angkor Wat. I actually enjoyed my visit to Bayon Temple more than Angkor Wat. Yes, Angkor Wat is a wonder of the world, but it is so crowded that visiting it can be less than enjoyable. I went to Bayon Temple mid afternoon at the suggestion of my guide. Sure enough, the temple was practically deserted compared to the crowds at Angkor Wat. The carvings are extraordinary, and the complex is huge.
Spectacular Bayon. I loved this place. A beautiful setting, awe-inspiring building and fascinating history. Get a good guide to tell you the full history of the place
SO INTERESTING!. Such a beautiful place - so many lthings to learn about history! I advise to take a guide - this helps a lot to really understand things.

One of the best. Bayon is one of my favorite places and I have been here quite a few times. It is in the centre of the city of Angkor Thom and was built in the late 12th century. There are over 200 large carved faces believed to be King Jayarvarman V11 on 54 towers. These beautiful faces reflect the famous "Smile of Angkor".The Bas reliefs on the southern walls contain real life scenes from the sea battle between the Khmers and the Cham plus there are also many carvings of everyday life. Beautiful place.

Top tips for visiting Bayon Temple, Siem Reap, Cambodia. - Yes it is stunning just like everyone says. Totally agreed but i gonna give you some tips on what to prepare for the trp- Which temple to visit? There are tonnes of temples around but tell ya, after a while you will get so sick of all the temples. Choose only 3 temples. Angkor Wat, Tombraider's temple and Bayon Temple. Look i cannot even figure out which temple is which so i guess everyone single one looks the same anyway. Leave the rest out and dont even bother going to the sunrise. Who pays to watch the sunrise and sunset in this world? Go figure! There are free sunset and sunrise back home, dude!- Bring lots of water and forget about a hat. Bring an umbrella. Oh boy, Cambodia is hot..truly hot. Hotter than Bangkok. I can tell you i have never been in such hot country in my life, Cambodia hits the spot. Also if you could bring a fan or those electric fan, by all means, bring one. Put some sunscreen on,- Not a lot of people mentioned that you will need American dollars wherever you go. It is all about american dollars here. The entrance fee was charged in American dollars, street sellers charge you USD$3-$5 for a Cambodia t-shirt. Make sure you have enough American dollars. - Food...yeap pretty much you dont need them. You need water the whole time. The weather gets so hot that you cannot even bring yourself to eat. You will only want water the whole time. - Wear a really really good pair of walking shoes. This is the one thing that everyone should know. It does look like there are lots of good pavement to walk but when you want to climb up those stairs to the top of the temple, you need good pair of shoes.- Be prepared to be harassed by street sellers the whole time. They get on to your face so close that you cant do anything about it. Just turn them down politely. If you think my reviews have been helpful to you, please click 'Yes' for 'Was this review helpful?'

Temple of faces.. Really beautiful impressive temple. One of my top 3 in Siem Reap. Make sure you explore the temples by Tuk Tuk, 15us dollar for the day. Definitely the best way to get between the temples.

the smile of Angkor. they said if you are in the angkor thom, you cannot escape from the smile of bayon. The temple is quite small ( not as the review and picture in the guide book which the temple look so huge) However, it still beautiful and difference from the other temple around.

Amazing. The sheer size makes it awesome, the fact that there are so many details make it amazing. One hint, make sure to bring an umbrella, makes all the walking far easier as it will help you stay cool under the sun, and given that it rains a lot will also be helpful then.

Astounding. This is the temple that has been photographed the most with it's tree roots that twist and turn around the structures and stones.Again a very spooky but exciting place with it's short stone door ways and hall ways. I loved this place.
Magnificent!. Even the enormous crowds of people do not spoil the beauty of the place! Much smaller than Angkor Wat but still is an absolute must-see.

Wonderful!. The amazing detail and the most magical feel to the place. Took many photos and spent hours here! Our guide was very helpful and told us a lot of history about this Temple and Ankor Thom!An uplifting experience! A must for all visitors to Cambodia!

Thirty seven towers. the giant stone faces of Bayon are one of the most recognisable images connected with kymer art and architecture.There are 37 standing towers , most with four carved faces. the Bayon was Jayavarman VII's state temple and represents the pinnacle of his massive building campaign.there is extensive carvings revealing everyday scenes of life, including market scenes and chess games !!go early to avoid the crowds and be amazed !

One of the temple not to miss. Nice to visit in the morning when sun is not hot. Big temple. Lots of tourist come here. Just scary to climb up n go down steep n narrow stairs. But it's Fabulous sculptures n stone carvings on the walls. Don't miss this wonderful temple

We visited Angkor Wat, Banteay Srei, Bayon, Ta Prohm, .... This temple stands out as a result of the magnificent work done by its designers and architects. Huge faces look at you from almost everywhere...
Mystic faces. The faces at the Bayon temple will haunt you for the rest of your life. But get there very early in the morning to avoid the crowds

Best of the Temples. Bayon Temple is my favorite out of all of the Cambodian Temples. The architecture is amazing and very photogenic and it has a peaceful/spiritual feel. I could spent days exploring Bayon.

Captivating. We could not agree within our family which was the most impressive: Angkor Wat or the much lesser known Bayon. This temple stands out for its magic, inscrutable faces, and the rich illustrations of Khmer history captured on its walls. There are about 3/4 of a mile of carvings on the walls of Bayon, and we enjoyed them all the more because we had a competent, English-speaking guide with us. Highly recommended!
Might be better than Angkor Wat. In my opinion this temple might surpass Angkor Wat in terms of intricacy and detailing (though of course not in size). A must see.

breathtaking. the bayon is the latest of the many temples in the area, and the most beautiful one. walking through all the smiling stone-faces makes you think you're in a dream. undescribable impressions - simply go see it.

Amazing and yet .... ... another frenzy of the photomentalists. You could imagine that even with this beautiful, astonishing work or art being crowded, it would be possible to experience an essence of its intended meaning, were it not for the madness of the crowds of people behaving with extraordinary levels of disrespect. Huge tour groups of Chinese tourists shouting and screaming at one another, posing for innumerable photos, and even, pushing people - me in this case - out of the way. Just horrible, horrible behavior that ruins it for everyone, though they seem completely oblivious to how they are being perceived. I did this after seeing Angkor, and were I to go again, I'd go here first before the crowds arrive as it has a very special aura to the place (or at least I imagine it would given the chance). There are also a series of interesting temples in the vicinity that are far less crowded, but well worth a visit to at least experience something closer to what was intended.
Spectacular Sight. A must visit! Truly remarkable to stand inside and realise how old and historically rich it is. It can get hot so take water and make sure you have plenty of space on you camera

Yet another outstanding building. After the WAT, the THOM and Terrace of the Elephants we had expected to be somewhat underwhelmed by the remainder of the area, this was not to be and the Bayon Temple lived up to the standards set by the major attractions

Magical place. Very interesting temple with massive stone faces and second important monumental temple in the area after Angkor Wat. Bayon also was considering as the last stone temple ever built in the period of the Khmer empire. They told me that Bayon has a meaning in Khmer the Magic. The best possible description. Temple is amazing and a must see!

Gorgeous Temple. Another place that will astound the senses with the ruins containing so many architectural details. The walls are covered with amazing relief figures and the temple ruins are beautifully preserved. A must see.
well worth a visit. this is the temple that was used in some Hollywood blockbusters. the trees are amazing how they have grown through the temple
amazing. More impressive than any pictures!! Unbelievable site, totally awe inspiring. Should not be missed by anyone.
Face Towers. Amazing! Interesting! If I would visit Siem Reap again, I would definitely go back to this stunning place.

Amazing . This is an amazing temple. I could imagine its greatness during its prime. One of the most remarkable historical site not to be missed. If you can only afford time to do one temple in Siem Reap, this should be the one.

Easy Access.. This is easily accessible and if you spend one hour you will have sufficient time to enjoy all the outstanding features. It is also less crowded than all of the more popular and larger Temples
Interesting Temple. The temple that has 4-side face. Very interesting and easy to take pictures as not too crowded. Tourist need not walk too far as the van can stop by the road side

Amazing. Another amazing temple to explore. A bit difficult to get around if your not solid on your feet. This temple may even be more interesting than Angkor Wat because of some of the natural stuff.

Squeezed another Temple in!. Gosh, it's hot and we got out taxi to take us to this on, I'm glad he did take us, it was a bit busy but well, well worth the effort!Our driver told us about how all the Budda heads are facing a certain way, as that how the were placed all these years ago, quite impressive. Makes you think how did they have the skills.Usual running of the gauntlet of people/young kids who would not leave you alone but as the kids from Grange Hill said in the 80's.........JUST SAY NO!Anyhoo, I was well worth it and not to be missed. ;)

The best temple. Having marvelled at Angkor Wat we thought we'd it couldn't be beat, so were really amazed when we visited Bayon Temple. We were lucky that we missed the tour groups and were left in peace to wander around this temple with all the many faces. Not as iconic as it's near neighbour, so go and visit before this changes, you won't be disappointed

Another Interesting Temple With Its Own Unique Feel & History. So much choice, so little time is a feeling often described whilst in Siem Reap and this temple is another must visit. It certainly has its own unique feel and is another temple in the Siem Reap area that deserves a visit.

Perhaps the best Siem Reap temple after Angor Wat. Perhaps the best of the Siem Reap temples is Bayon, with it's fascinating collection of carved faces.For photosCopy and paste this URL into your browser: https://fineeating.wordpress.com/2015/02/09/temples-of-a-siem-reap-bayon/
Bayon Temple and Elephant Terraces. Only glimpses of the greatness of this area. The area was teeming with tourists when we visited, so there was only a short time for quick pix

Felt like the Cambodian version of "The Name of the Rose". This temple was my husband's favorite and my second, after Angkor Wat. It's impressive, very high and covered with very complex carvings, besides the giant faces it's famous for.Walking up and downs and entering so many rooms, I felt like I was in a Cambodian version of the library describe in "The Name of The Rose" - each room and corridor has a meaning, that most of us are unable to understand. And it's so easy to get confused with all the rooms! Differently from other temples, this one does not follow a square shape, so you'll find curve here and there.Certainly worth a long visit.
Amazing!. It was high season, too crowded. There should be more security to take caer of the temples. They are amazing, but people dont respect treasures

If you're templed out, check out this one!. This was my favorite in the whole area. It was the general consensus amongst me and a couple of travel companions. I'm not going to waste time trying to describe this one. Just go. I thought it left Angkor Wat in the dust. You won't be disappointed. I promise.
Thumbs up!. I wish that it was in a better condition. Could imagine how fantastic it was in its heyday. Awesome to see how the devotees took the efforts to build such a structure.

best of all the temples. This is my favorite of all the temple's at the angkor wat area. If you have several days, would recommend this being your first stop of the day since most people will be at angkor wat for sunrise. Believe the other reviews.

Had the most amazing time here . A wonderful experience here
Go early to miss the crowds and heat . One of the great wonders i have ever seen . Book a good guide

a great temple at Angkor Thom. its a great temple with Buda faces and reliefs at the outside walls !
watch my video which i recorded with action cam at 2015 february ...
Bayon Temple
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xNP38OG2iTs&feature=youtu.be
The Best Of The Bunch. This is the famous temple with the giant faces. It is my favorite one. Go early morning for bright light, or about 4:30 for really spectacular light before sunset.

Another Amazing Temple.. Bayon temple is definitely not a case of 'seen one temple, seen them all'. This was the last of 5 temples we visited with our tour guide and it still blew us away. The amount of detail in the stone carvings, the sheer number of faces, everything was magnificent. Even if you are feeling bored with visiting many temples do not miss this one, along with Angkor Wat and Teah Prom, this is a must see. Again, see these temples with a tour guide as they add so much more to the experience!
Excellent!. Wow is the word! If you visit Angkor Wat, you can't miss this place either. It is truly marvellous! The beauty of the place has to be seen to be believed!
Iconic. This temple is the famous one , different to the others , facing a different way , best to go early as many tourists , but it is spectacular .
you must not miss this. read about it in the guide books. I would recommend it to anyone visiting here. Absolutely stunning temple.

The best of the Angkor Wat cluster of temples. This is the temple of the four smiling faces: each tower is surmounted by four smiling faces, each looking out to one of the cardinal points - there are hundreds of them. Good time to visit is late afternoon because the low sun turns the temple's stonework into reddish colours.Like Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm, the other main temples in this cluster, Bayon is extremely busy with tourists for most of the day. So, if you have plenty of time in Siem Reap, take a guide and driver out for a long drive to the Koh Ker group of temples and Beng Mealea - hardly any tourists go this far so, suddenly, you can enjoy the tranquility of temples without the shrieks of other tourists only interested in taking selfies with the now ubiquitous selfie stick. Allow at least 10 hours for this trip and budget about US$140 for the car, guide and driver.

Beautiful but crowded. This is one very beautiful temple - if you have several days in Siem Reap - go see it earlier in the morning before the hordes of tourists arrive so you can truly appreciate the site.

Personal Favorite. Upon entering this temple, you're greeted by all the smiling faces of Buddha. This temple is gorgeous and a true marvel of the rich Cambodian history. It was much less packed with tourists here than at other temples, which made exploring much more fun and accessible. The inticate carvings around the temple are beautiful and well maintained. I will never forget this moment in my life. I enjoyed the Bayon temple in Angkor Thom much more than Angkor Wat, and is my personal favorite memory of Siem Reap.

fabulous temple- my favourite. impressive temple, with lots of huge stone -carved faces. awesome. mysterious feeling . loved it!
best place for amazing photos!
go early in the morning and have lot of water with u!
Must visit. If you love temples, this is a must to visit. Lots of Buddha faces. Excellent for photography. Simply amazing and
One of the most striking sites!. Beautiful because of its location in a cleared area. The base relief carvings are beautiful here. Get a guide to explain their story!

Amazing Temple near Siem Reap. Although there are so many temples in this enormous UNESCO World Heritage complex they are all different and unique. It's difficult to choose which one to prioritise so it's worth some serious research with a map to get the most out of your visit. Don't try to visit more than three or, at most, four temples in a day though because there's a lot of walking and climbing involved.
Beautiful ruin. This temple there were great carvings. This was interesting because, built by the king's nephew, it was originally Hindu and and later turned Buddhist.
Amazing and beautiful. Go early to this fabulous temple - its very popular and the crowds later in the day make it difficult to get around easily.
Smiling faces. Beautiful temple, lots of smiling Buddha faces. A must see. Very well maintained temple. Great location for taking excellent photographs.

the temple of many faces. I liked Bayon because each of the many towers in the temple have four faces of the Buddah looking in each direction. Its a very nice temple, fairly easy to walk around on and one of the temples that is rather undamaged.

Sculptures of heads, lots of steps, avoid the rush. We went late afternoon as the sun was setting. This is a tremendously impressive building, with lots of huge stone faces, intricate carvings, and steps. Awesome.

The most beautiful place in Suem Reap. Bayon Temple Angkor Thom - ExcellentIn my opinion this temple complex is just THE most beautiful place in the whole of Siem Reap if not the world. The enigmatic smiles and calm that they emit will pleasantly haunt you for months if not years to come. Take time to just sit on the top level and wait for crowds to disperse to get time to yourself and the beautiful sculptures.
ancient temple. its location is good, but very sad to learn most original artifacts gone only new one attached made by Cambodian artists
The photogenic temple. Roots and temples hugging each other, picturesque and exotic. Felt good to walk around and feel the place

must see. I was amazed to see the huge faces carved in stone which form the sides of the temple.The alignment of stones to form the faces is unbelievable. The structures are falling apart and could be dangerous if you are not careful.

Bayon Temple Siam Reap Cambodia. Incredible place, well worth a visit. Amazing to see what these people did with primitive tools over a thousand years ago. the ruins are being restored, but most of the structure is still standing

A must see!. I stood and marveled at these temples and tried to imagine the culture and the passion…that it took to build these temples. I wonder what happen to this culture. Go early to beat the heat and the tours. Gets very busy later in the day. Bring plenty of water. This site is massive.

Simply Amazing. Out of all the temples, this is the one I enjoyed the most. Beautifully crafted and amazingly made. Definitely worth a visit. The temple is rather spacious which is a plus point in view that the temples are incredibly touristy therefore some areas are perpetually packed with people.
Loved it!

Most interesting of the temples. Part of the Angkor Thom area, Bayon is the 'faces' temple. Tall towers with great carved faces looking at you from all angles. This temple gets crowded, so early touring is the best.
Ya gotta!. This was my favorite of the 8-9 temples I visited. I liked all the smiling heads. It's a must see :-)

Brilliant Day out. This was included in our day tour of all the temples in the area, which is highly reccomended. When you hire a Tuk Tuk for the day the guy will take you to get the temple pass which will cost you $20 for the day. This will let you into all of the temples. The Bayon temple didnt really look as impressive as Angkor Wat but once inside it was amazing. Lots of climbing but well worth it.
Beautiful. Loved it. Just wish I would have spent a little more time there. Could have gone back, but there is just so much to see in the area!

Beautiful. One of the most beautiful temples in the area. Well worth a visit.
The carvings are spectacular. Our group spent over two hours wandering from sight to sight.
Temples. We really enjoyed our visit to the various Temples. We had a 3 day pass, which made it more leisurely
Bayon. Part of the must see group in this area. One of the more important temples to visit which reflects the splendour of a past Khmer civilisation

Amazing faces. This temple is a definite must see. Wonderful carvings of faces every time you turn each corner. Great photo opportunities with all the windows everywhere. The faces are amazing. Lots of walking and climbing. Loved it.

well preserved ... Probably the most complete temple that gives you a true sense of the
Complexity and dedication of those that built the temples. Impressive in every way.
Stunning. Go early in the morning and try to avoid the tour bus groups. Read up on the history of the place and why this temple was so important.

Buddha heads galore!. Beautiful and one of the top 3. Unfortunately we went around noon when it was flooded with Asian tourists. Our tour guide said best time for quiet time was early, say after the sunrise.
Another temple. This was one of many temples we visited with out guide, we became confused by the sheer number and specialities of each. Attractive and not at all crowded.
Bayon Temple. The giant faces on the Khymer towers in this temple in Angkor Thom are truly incredible. As with the park in general, be prepared for a lot of walking and climbing.

Not to be missed. This temple of numerous faces should not be missed. It is a must see on your temple trekking itinerary. Elephant rides are offered around this temple. On the day that I was visiting this temple, dancers in costume were hanging around for photos. It was all very touristy, but alas enjoyable. Don't skip this one!

Fantastic Architecture. The Bayon Temple is certainly worth seeing. There are terrific photo opportunities and you will admire the architecture and skill of workmen nigh on a thousand years ago. A must visit on the tour of the Angkor Wat area.

our first and last of the trip.. our family started here and were bowled over. so many wonderful corridors and levels. unfortunately it was terribly crowded with very loud, pushy tourist groups. don't stand close to the edges.

Big heads!. This is the temple with all the big heads inside of Angkor Thom, which is the largest part of the complex. This is the first stop on the "Half Marathon" course. Whether you have a guide or not, this complex is impressive.
This area is definitely not stroller or wheel chair friendly. Be ready to walk/climb.
Great place. Great architectural well preserved place with huge history behind it. Wonderful place to visit. Without visit these places your visit to Cambodia is not fulfilled.

A fun elephant ride.... The temple is very impressive with its many carved faces and sculptural reliefs. You can also enjoy a guided ride on an elephant around the outskirts of the temple for some great photo shots.
Amazing. One of the best spots in Angkor! Better if you read before go there! The place looks good,try to go early, to not be so crowded.
Our first temple group.. Very impressive group of temples. Be prepared to climb some pretty steep and large steps. Pretty hot and not much shade.
Bayon temple. Amazing attraction, one of the more interesting temples to see and well worth going to see when in Siem Reip

Bayon is amazing and fabulous. Fantastic trip with a good tuk tuk driver...you can't go wrong amazing photo opportunity... The most picturesque and the least crowds allowing more time to savour the site.

Loved this temple. Although not as well known as Angkor Wat, enjoyed this temple more because of large face carving that are visible throughout temple. Went around 9 in morning, and experienced large (somewhat pushy) crowds. Walkway well marked but some areas have narrow passageways. If on tour you may have to change busses due to narrow openings for passenger traffic. Beautiful carvings and can still view many of the faces of the temple. Beware of all the persistent locals wanting to sell Cambodian travel books and photos.

My favourite temple out of them all. All the wonderful heads all over the place. There are so many different ones to see along with little shrines with lovely windows overlooking more beautiful faces.
Out of all the temples and shrines we saw this was by far our favourite

Smiling faces & elephant rides. Lots of bas reliefs, you an climb within temple. Elephant rides around temple offer great
photo perspectives of full temple.

very bumpy elephant ride. At the Bayon Temple is an elephant ride only until 10.30am we were told. Three of us rode on the elephant, but I think maybe 2 people would be better. FYI It costs $20 per person, not per elephant and you walk around the whole Bayon Temple. The temple itself was amazing although appropriate footwear is recommended, as walking around isn't easy with steep steps and uneven surfaces everywhere. This is the temple with lots of smiling buddha faces. The carving on the walls are amazing, be sure to have a tour guide with you to tell you some of the stories from the pictures - some are very interest and can give you a lot of insight into the history and culture. It's much harder to appreciate walking around on your own.

Same but different. Although Angkor Wat and Bayon Temple are somewhat the same, they are different at the same time. The carvings on the structures were different and it was interesting. Definitely worth a visit!

Outstanding experience. The whole experience was wonderful, we had a private tour guide, Kok Chhen to take us and explain about the temples visited. This was very helpful as he knew the best times to go and gave us a commentary on each temple to get the most out of our experience.
Great to wonder around. Lots of people didn't spoil our enjoyment wandering around these magnificent carving. If you're visiting SR, then you are sure to come here!!!
Easier than Ankor Wat. This is small temple with lots of smiling Buddha faces. After spending the morning at Angor Wat this was a piece of cake.

Nice temple. This was a really interesting temple in which you coud easily spend hours.Great for photographs but recommend early morning or late afternoon as the sun can be quite bearing with the steps.Lots of good photos to be had of stone face
No disabled access. The architecture was stunning, but as with many of the temples there al lot of steep stairs with no rails, you just have to rely on the goodness of others to help you down them.

One of my fave temples in Seam Reap. I like how these magnificent sculptures remains beautiful up to this day, I admire the ancient khmer's creativity and skills to create a very intricate design on stones and temples. A must see.
4 Faces. This temple impresses with its detailed 4 faces of Giant Buddhas. At the back see if you can spot the reclining Buddha in the stone. Interesting mix of Hindu & Buddhist temple overlays

Get a grip, people, how can you not be overwhelmed?. Ummm...if you come to Cambodia you MUST see this temple. Read about it....do research...we spent over 5 hours there between 2 visits....just the physical trekking over rocks to see amazing things is wonderful but the totality...in awe...words cannot do justice...
Mesemerising. Excellent architecture . Imagine the prosperity 700 yrs back. Beautiful , what more can you say .love history and visit .Beautiful
I always feel like someone is watching me. Visit in the afternoon for fewer crowds. Be prepared to climb some stairs. Read up on the place so you know what you're looking at

Incredible. 52 towers with a smiling face with bold jaw and a stern forehead of Buddha. Gives you a mysterious feeling of why and in what environment these towers were put up. Go early because the sun does make it hot and there is a good amount of walking and climbing involved.
My favourite. Among the all temples in Angkor Park this is my favourite! Those four faces are everywhere and the majority are well preserved.
Bayon fantastic!. one of the 3 best temples to visit as there are more than 300!. You could spend weeks going around them all!

My Favorite Temple. Out of all the amazing archaeological sites at Angkor, Bayon was my favorite. The temple is in great condition and all of the four directional heads look really interesting when viewed from different perspectives. The relief murals told an interesting history too; I was happy to have a guide at this site to explain them to me. The crowds weren't too bad when we visited in the late afternoon. If I could only see one temple in the area I'd pick Bayon!
Favourite Temple. Awesome...not to be missed.Take your guide from Angkor Wat to this temple so you gain all the history and know the best spots to take the photos. Worth a few extra dollars.

woweeee. This was just a once in a lifetime experience. We used Angkor sam daytour- our guide, Sam, did am excellent job of finding the places where we were away from crowds of tourists. wonderful experience!!

Favourite temple of all!. When I arrived at Bayon, I was truly in awe, my mouth left hanging opened. I personally felt it was more impressive than Angkor Wat, maybe because of the idealistic image I had painted in my mind from all the rave about it. Bayon is especially beautiful when visited after the sun has fully risen where the sky is incredibly blue. Its just a pity that you can never have a quiet moment to yourself in this incredible temple swarmed with tourists at anytime of the day. The towering faces of the temple are simply spectacular!
Memorable. This is a place that needs many visits if you are a photographer and seek good sunlight on the carvings

How the world was. Bayon temple and Angkor thom just shows us how the world was many centuries back. The experience just takes you back to the times of great kingdoms and amazing history. The temple itself has many faces of Buddha which still carry the expressions someone conceived and sculptured so many years back. A must visit

Amazing. As you approach this temple you can't believe your eyes. When you climb you become even more amazed and I have the photos to prove it. You have to be fairly fit and we have to say a very big thank you to our guide, Mr Sary. We would never have managed it without him. This was a fantastic experience.

Awesome. Definitely worth hiring a tour guide though to help explain the history, identify carvings and to know the best photo opportunities of the various temples. If you have limited time definately include Bayon in your itinerary
Awesome. Wow!! This temple is great. The human being face stone. It temple no many people visit so we can enjoy over look around. My tour guide said that this temple is the symbol of smile.

One of the best sites.. Impressive site but swarmed with noisy tourists. The scuptures are brilliant. The smiles are mesmerizing. We went back for a second time in the early afternoon when there were less people.
Spectacular. Smaller than Angkor Wat, but no less amazing. Best part- fewer crowds. Go early while the tour buses decend on Angkor Wat, bring lots of water and sunscreen, it gets very Hot.

The Bayon is unbelievable. If you must see at least one temple, you could either tick off the most famous of all the Khmer temples, Angkor Wat, or see the contender for its place, which i think is the better of the two (note; there are hundreds of temples in the region). Bayon is of course famous for its faces that surround all the stupas.
Not for the paranoid. Amazing structure with many faces in the towers , no matter where you look there is a Buddha type face staring at you.
Worth a visit. Once again brilliant history and amazing architecture from an ancient past. Man made with hand tools, local stone carted in from afar awe inspiring to see what primative man created.

Fantastic Temple. Avoid the crowds particularly in the morning.
Fewer visitors end afternoon ...we went twice...and will return to Bayon at next occasion!
One of the must sees. This temple is a must see in Siem Riep. The faces are very impressive and the temple is quite well kept.

the best among all the temple. the big bhudda faces architectural! is just the amazing scene that you shouldn't missed. though, the place is always packed with tourists. but you will get the happy faces vibe from this temple.

Stunning !. This was my favourite temple. There was so many different viewpoints and we were so lucky that our fabulous guide, An Rachna from siemreapguideservices.com' was able to take us around so that we could get some great photos and also to help me get up and down some of the steeper stepsLOL :)) he also knew the best ways to enter the temples so that we missed a few of the very many tour buses! We would highly recommend An and the company if you are looking for a tour guide with great English and a lovely sense of humour ! I do think he struggled with our broad scottish accents though LOL:)) we are used to that!
Great visit. Great showcase of the architecture of the Khmer Empire. Various carving on the wall shows histories as well as daily lives of the people during the Khmer period.
Worth visiting. I found visiting as many temples as possible interesting. They are all a bit different and you get to look at the area a bit more as you travel around.

Unique Temple with multiple FACED sculptures. LIKE : Its an awesome wonder how during ancient era they could build such beautiful faced temples... Look out for a photo spot where you can take a picture that looks like your nose tip touches the nose tip of the face sculpture.DISLIKE : Nothing except keep yourself energized for a lot of walking and climbing

Timing is everything..... We bought the seven day pass and stayed in Siem Reap for 8 days and nights in January 2015. Hire a tuk-tuk driver in Siem Reap anywhere near the pub street or market and keep your wits about you. A tuk-tuk driver will drive you to the furthest wats from Siem Reap, wait for an hour or so, and then drive you to another wat or back to town for about 8 bucks. If your hotel calls the tuk-tuk, expect to pay $20 or $15. If you flag a Tuk-tuk at the market, expect to be asked for $15 and settle for $8 or $10. If you show up at the same time as a bunch of tour buses from Korea, just tell the driver to head for another nearby wat and come back later. If you see a gaggle of middle-aged women dressed like multi-coloured incarnations of Sailor Moon, run, don't walk.

The Rocks Are Watching You. This temple in the middle of the walled Angkor Thom area features sandstone block entry gates and multiple towers, each with faces carved into the stacked rocks of the structures facing the four cardinal points of the compass. Each doorway lintel and vertical support is decorated with intricately carved sandstone, and most walls and corners are also decorated with carved full length figures, many well-preserved, some damaged by bullets as a reminder of the horrific recent past.

Beautiful. Nice place with so much to see. Really enjoyed our visit and worth getting a guide to tell you a bit of history.If you don't mind the heat you can get a 'tuk-tuk - apparently this is called something else in Cambodia but I cant remember; or you can ride a bike there. Really nice views. Def worth a visit.
amazing. Like all the temples this one is another amazing one. Leave it to one of the last to not spoil the others

A must visit together with the main attraction Angkor Wat. One of the three main priority sites to see in Siem Reap together with Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom. The whole complex is smaller than Angkor Wat but on the whole just as impressive. I somehow get the impression the sculptures/ carvings /facades of buildings are more intricate and less worn-out by weather and time as compared to Angkor Wat. Much better to hire a guide for a tour of these historical sites than wandering around the complex yourself. There is just so much history and information in every spot among the ruins. In certain areas there are certain things only a guide knows which even a guide book will not help.
must see. Definitely a must see, the smilling faces are amazing. Lots of turists, better to go earlier if you can.

Amazing huge face carvings. This is seriously like something out of Indiana Jones. The upper level containing the stone unique faces is beautiful. The size and uniqueness of each will surely blow your mind.

Nice but crowded. By the time we hit Bayon it was like 2 or 3pm and there were 2 large groups around the sametime, luckily guide brought us a long fairly quickly and avioded gettng stuck behind large groups.

Impressive. Not as magical as Angkor Wat of course but they are so different. You can go there in early afternoon as some picture spots ( large stone faces) will not be lit up if you arrive after 2pm.Our No 2 site in Siem Reap.

Breathtaking. Of all the temples we visited, this is our absolute favorite! Everything about this temple is breathtaking. There are more tourists here than any other temples we've visited during our time there.
worth seeing. This Temple is special and should be on your agenda to see. If you only plan to see a ew temples my advice would be to make this one of them

MASTER PIECE-Excellent architecture. In the heart of Angkor thom , we can see this wonderful monument which was once State temple of JAYAVARMAN VII,symbolic center of the universe and empire whiere narrative bas reliefs of daily life of khmer history are depicted. NOT TO BE MISSED, JUST NEAR THE ANGKOR WAT.
Beautiful Bayon. A must! My 3 daughters (aged 8 and 9) absolutely loved it here. The faces are beautiful. My eldest said it 'was like being in Narnia'!
Excellent. Amazing huge face carvings. Narrow walkways make it a little difficult to enjoy the central area, so find somewhere quiet and sit down for a while to avoid the tour groups.

Whose face is that?. Indescribable - always crowded but what a treat - if you can arrive early and beat the tour coaches you'll have a chance to get some great photos. The stories in the Bas-reliefs around the outside are fantastic and there are tiny details of all parts of daily life as well as the armies and navies and warring expeditions of the Khmer kings. Worth the time
WOW - must see. The whole temple complex is a lifetime experience. Lots of vendors around the temples but hey, these people are poor and trying to earn a buck.

Just Brilliant. Brilliant! Faces faces everywhere … I have never seen something like this before in life truly fantastic and a great place to click some most memorable pics. The areas around are great for a good walk. Pack your feed and go for a picnic. Totally recommended. Iconic site of Cambodia.
Great spot. The experience in Bayon Temple was fantastic. The statues and sculptures were all masterpieces which tells a lot of the glory of this great nation.

Temples. Bayon Temple along with all the Temples in the Angkor area are simply amazing, The skill, hard work and general toil that has gone into the construction of these places is breathtaking. All those years ago there was no modern machines etc and when you stand in front of these archaeological marvels you are simply speechless.
One of the best of the temples in Siem Reap. I personally like this temple. It's a must see after Angkor Wat. Don't forget to take a photo facing your nose to Bayon's.

One of the great temples of Angkor. The Bayon Temple is one of the highlights of Angkor and should not be missed!Its amazing how those "stone faces" look you just from everywhere while you are in the temple... Great place to stay one hour or more...

My favourite temple in Angkor area. There's something fascinating about a king who wants his face replicated 216 times in a temple, even if it's a big lack of understatement! Visit it at sunset, because these faces become golden.

Best temple in Siem Reap area. Awesome temple in the Angkor Thom complex, stunning views of "faces" on display. Use a guide (cheap) to show you were to take the best pictures within the site. My favorite temple site in the area.

Stunning. Went here just before lunch. It was just stunning, I know everyone visits for Angkor but we found this place just as impressive. It was busier than any of the other temples we visited. But our tour guide had the order of temples perfected. Angkor for sunrise, then head over to Ta Prohm, then here and then Angkor for the Arvo. Best seen with a tour guide who can talk you through it all.
Beautiful Temple. One of the highlights of Angkor Thom. It can get crowded, but its worth the visit. They might also have some people in traditional Khmer costumes their for photo opportunities.
Feel you are being watched. It was spectacular setting. There is also an area where the tuk tuks park and there is a shed with lots of eating places. There's also a wc.
Amazing!. My second favourite temple after Angkor Wat. Must see! The faces on the temples were amazing. What more can I say.....these temples are one of the seven natural wonders in the world.

My favourite out of the three we saw. We visited this place after lunch and it was not as busy as we had thought. Amazing temple, loved all the faces that were carved on the stones.Our guide was amazing and spoke great English and had a good sense of humour.

Bayon temple is excellent. See it before it all falls down. Great history and wonderful sight to behold. Lots and lots of tourists jostling for the best position for photos. This site is just brilliant and worth the trip

Absolutely stunning. I always though the images in Lara croft were digitally altered (especially the tress and roots). Well it is not! The tress are wonderful, so are the statues and the temple. Amazing walk around the grounds... It is shocking that people can still access these! Visit before it is closed to the public!

Amazing site. You cannot go to Angkor Wat area withou visiting Angkor Thom and Bayon temple to see the many faces of Vishnu, really the emperor, carved into towers of stone over 200 times. I felt like Indiana Jones.
Most impressive temple in Siem Reap. Really nice, loved the four-faced Buddha towers. First temple I visited in Siem Reap and still my favourite.
WOW, just wow. The temple is incredible, go there after 4pm so you skip the big crowds. The place just took our breath away, it is spiritually uplifting and just amazing!
Wonderful Temple.. I loved the way the ancients were able to cut stone and carry it to the temple site to create such historic places

Beautiful and peaceful. This Temple was quite magnificent, surrounded by lush vegetation which at times overtook parts of the temple. I found a lovely lady who was making prayer strings and was able to purchase one for a small donation and she blessed me and boy did I feel this blessing! Bayon Temple was one of the highlights of our 5 days in Siem Reap, do not miss it.

Huge Heads and Great Photos!. If you're on your own, be sure to look out for small tour groups and their special knowledge of different photo opportunities! Our tour guide made use of perspectives to make it look like we were kissing one of the heads!This temple is beautiful and there is so much history here!
Awesome temple!. I loved this temple, so interesting and beautiful. It's well worth a visit and should not be missed. There's reason why all tours stop here because it's so cool.

Quite Possibly My Favorite Temple We Visited. We visited Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm, Pre Rup, Banteay Samre and Banteay Srei, and I am quite positive the Bayon Temple was my favorite. While it doesn't match the Angkor Wat in sheer size, I loved the multitude of Buddha faces. The temple had so much character. Its' antiquity, size, and structure were awe inspiring and majestic. We couldn't pick a favorite face. We loved them all! As we walked closer to the towers, we were able to see how intricate and unique the details were on each face. No two faces were the same (and there were 216 in its' glory days!!!) While I am unsure on how many stood proud, they appeared countless and each one was extraordinary.Remember that temple attire is required, which means no bare shoulder and at least no bare knees (I wore lightweight pants to be safe). It's hott! Really hott!! Wearing a hat or bringing an umbrella for shade might not be the worst idea. The temples are incredible though, so the heat is worth putting up with. If possible, hire a private guide so you can tour the temple at your own pace and you're not stuck at the pace and whim of others in a large crowd. Our guide's name was Dy with ICS Travel and he was absolutely phenomenal. He provided us with such fabulous insight and shared his knowledge with us with such charisma. I would truly recommend both Dy and ICS Travel.

So many people. SO MANY PEOPLE. And people that get really angry if you're in their shot. Sorry that I can't escape you shot when there are 1000s of other people also looking at this temple!It's the people that ruin this temple, not the temple. It was very beautiful and an impressive feat of ancient architecture.

Must go. We visited Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm and Bayon, and our favourite is Bayon. It has so much character and is so uniquely different from the other 2 temples that we visited. It's impressive to see so many carved faces and in relatively good condition. We went there at about 4pm, just one and a half hours before closing time at 5.30pm and it was not very crowded. It was also a good time to take nice pictures of the setting sun shining on the carved faces, turning them to a beautiful warm amber. There are a few stairs to climb, the steepest being to the highest level. As most of these temples are still used by the locals as places of worship, it would be respectful to dress appropriately. Knees and shoulders should be covered. I saw a few women wearing dresses and skirts. Although they were below the knee, it's best to remember that some of the stairs can be quite steep. Not only could they hinder your climbing, they could also leave little to the imagination for those climbing behind you.
Looks like a movie set!. This is definitely a must see. The temple looks like a giant movie set and looks unreal! Lots of great pictures to take!

Must see temple complex. Part of the main complex of Angkor Thom, you really shouldnt miss this amazing Temple! 216 smiling faces and I was in awe... there are a lot of tourists so it can get annoying trying to get your perfect photo also trying to take in the whole temple itself, it can be tough but its a really must see - one of my favourites

Eery and majestic. This was an amazing feat of building and conception. Ancient, eery, majestic, religious, awe inspiring. A favorite among tourists however so expect not to be alone. With patience you can get there between the tour groups. Later in the pm brought some great shadows.

so many Budha faces. A beautiful temple worth travelling to Cambodia for, superb architecture and lot of history. In my opinion, the jewel in the Angkor temples. Can't match the Angkor Wat for sheer size, but does for everything else

Best of all the Temples I visited. I went to Angkor Wat first then Ta Prohm and just as I was having enough Temples for the day we came upon the Bayon. It's more beautiful and interesting! The towers had intricate details of faces stunningly carved. It's great for photo shoots.

Temple visit. Lots to see and photograph. Too many people - visit early in the morning or late afternoon, however for ardent photographers the afternoon light or earl morning light is good. Two visits are probably necessary to see everything!!
Buddhas Everywhere. Incredibly well preserved temple with buddha heads all over. This was one of my favorite temples in the Angkor Park!

Gigantic stone faces. We explored this ruin early in the morning and avoided most of the crowds. This was a wonderful ruin with many nooks and crannies, stairs to climb, and the amazing stone faces. We were able to walk from there to other nearby sites.

One of the three 'must see's'. Although this isn't a large as Angkor Wat, I would still recommend you visit this site. It has loads of stunning architecture and is extremely impressive, inside and out. If you're thinking of visiting the various temples around Angkor I would recommend you do Angkor Wat in the early morning, Ta Prohm in midday and Bayon in the afternoon. This way you'll hopefully avoid the crowded areas and also avoid the worst of the scorching sun, as this is more shaded the Angkor Wat?
Go early to avoid crowds. One of the iconic and most interesting temples in the complex. All the smiling heads are interesting in juxtaposition.
Photos Spot!. Stay there longer for more awesome pictures! Get Sun to take for you because he knows which spot to take great pictures! :)
Smiling Faces. Another impressive temple with massive smiling faces in stone unfortunately too many people while we were there so not able to fully enjoy it
The best!. simply the best! so great so fantastic so amazing...what can i write more? it will be good for you to arrive early or late to be alone

My favorite temple in Sien Reap. This temple is quite wonderfully atmospheric. Be careful where you walk in the central circular building, since there are some dark places with drop offs. Take a torch and investigate the circular passageways. Beware of bats.

Not to be missed. This was our favorite site, and we visited 8 in total. The many smiling Bhuda faces throughout the complex were remarkable. Overall we were left with a feeling of wonderment when we left.
Amazing. One of my favorite temples in Siem reap with the sun setting on made this temple absolutly magical it was a lot less busy than the other most popular ones

Best Temple in Angkor Complex. My personal opinion, the best temple in Angkor with majestic views and touristic options to explore.
Optional elephant ride is an OK addition
Loved Bayon Temple the Best. this was our favorite..full of character..not as crowded at Angkor Wat. Great photo ops here. This was our last stop of the day.
The Buddha temple. It's breathtaking to see the chiseled 4- sided Buddha faces from all the angles, watching over you. One can feel the divine vibe while exploring this temple

My most favorite temple. In a minute I was passing through the gate, I felt like stepping into a different world where is so magical, peaceful, and relaxing. Seeing this amazing temples while being on a Tuk Tuk from the distance, I was blown away. I love the carving where the story is told which took me for like 2 hours in just this amazing temple

Smiling Buddha faces galore . One of my favourite temples at the park. I love all the smiling Buddha faces, they are just so beautiful. It's fascinating to reminisce amongst the ruins as to how these amazing temples were constructed. Highly recommend visiting this temple when in the archaeological park. Due to it being one of the main temples there are quite a lot of people viewing it, but if you go around the 11:30~12pm mark there are fewer people around due to it be very hot and also being lunchtime.

Wonderful!. I really liked this temple. It's in better condition than some of the others and is quite magnificent to behold, with all the faces pearing down at you.
