When I was there (early afternoon) it wasn't very busy, which made it all the more special for me. It also allowed me to take photos without lots of tourists in the shot.
Trees among the walls are amazing!. You may think you will see/watch more of same ruins, but Bayon actually worth a visit. Bayon and Ta Promh are definitely the two to see.
Very Lively!. Nice place to visit for historic moment. Nicely carved statues with clean environment. Many souvenirs shop.
Great Morning. Big and serene. I wished this was not our first stop on my first day. I would have loved to spend more time here

Enigmatic icon. Perhaps the most beautiful and intriguing temple in Angkor, but crucially important to time your visit to avoid the tour groups - go really early or late. The Bayon with a few visitors is a totally different experience to when it is crawling with them.
Wow. Love the faces carved everywhere. Sometimes we felt like the buildings were put together like "Jenga" pieces. The skill and artistry here is amazing.

Better than Angkor Wat. The faces on the upper tiers of this temple make it supremely picturesque. Sit down and enjoy the scene. We went back for a second look, exploring on our own after we had finished with our guide on a previous day. Simply stunning.
Very Cool. It was amazing to see the amount of detail and all the faces that were carved. This is definitely worth the visit after Angkor Wat.

Need sign posts. The temples need signs to tell us where to go and the historical context. Where do all the money go? It's $20 per day. We paid $40 per head for multiple-day tickets. I expect better signposts and explanations.

Best seen at dusk. We visited early evening and there was only a handful of other tourists there. The light enhanced the setting, it was very atmospheric and is one of the best temples to visit. Angkor Watt is impressive for its size but Bayon and Ta Promh are definitely the two to see.
Go Early, Early, Early. It is a beautiful temple but go early. By 10:00 a.m. the crowds are unbearable. Skip Angkor Wat at sunrise and do this instead you'll enjoy it more.
Incredible! Have never seen anything like this. Loved everything. Faces are magical. Make sure you are physically fit. Lots of climbing. This was one of my favorite temples
The faces...!. It is a cute little temple compared to Wat. Be there at sun set or sun rise. You need to see the statutes when they are hit by the sun.
Stunning. This was by far our favourite temple area. Much smaller than Angkor Wat but the carvings were very pretty and the surrounding area not as hectic whilst we were there.
do not miss this temple. certainly a great achievement of ancient architecture. Faces of Budha are so close and imposing. A favorite photo spot where you can be face to face with Budha.

Bayon beautiful late afternoon. Bayon was the last temple I visited in Siem Reap and one of my favorites. We visited late afternoon which with the light was lovely and less people although still reasonably busy. The faces are fascinating in the different light and internally kids will love the small labyrinth like spaces to explore. If you have only s brief amount of time this would be in my top three. Best seen first or last part of tour
Amazingly beautiful !. Another one of the temples that is a must-visit when coming to Cambodia. Absolutely beautiful with all the Buddhas.

Another Wow!. Very impressed … these Cambodian stonemasons knew how to build with stone. A must see temple with the serene faces on the temple spires. Incredible detail. Keep plenty of water handy and prepare for lots of stairs and steps (some are very steep). I'm dying to know how they managed to get such large pieces of stone carvings to the temple top?

Beautiful Temple. We arrived there in the morning with my family on December.The Temple is so beautiful outside and inside.The wall carving were still intact and the faces on top were beautiful.This temple is a must to go as it is beside the road.

Much better than angkorwat . This temple was big and beautiful and puts angkor wat to shame. If you get your park pass (20us for 1 day or 40 for 3 days) generally the tuk tuk driver will take you to this as well as all the others. We got a tuk tuk driver for 20 US dollars for the day.

Bayootiful. The temple in the middle of Angkor Thom is spectacular with its huge face temples with the face of the Bodhisattava Avalokiteshwara. So calm and serene. Do spend some time here just sitting and enjoying the ambiance.

See it and wonder. How could Jayavarman VII build it and around 40 others in his reign? Incredible but true. A treasure of ancient history.
See it and wonder how did they do that?

Best to go early to Bayon. This was on our list of must see temples and though there were hoards of other tourists there it was still magnificent. A few steps to climb but nothing like Angkor Wat or some of the other temples.
Mesmerizing. One of the best places I have visited in this planet. The location and the weather make it a very 'adventure-like' experience.
Our favourite temple.. Loved the 54 columns with the amazing faces. The kids loved this the best and so did we..Its largely in tact and felt less crowded than Angkor Wat.
Bayon temple visit. As for Angkor Wat, very well preserved and excellent to visit, Not quite as crowded. As a Temple it was better to visit than Angkor Wat.

Great. Just amazing. The design and engineering of the temples is just phenomenal. None of the temples are handicap friendly and it is difficult to navigate them if you have any sort of physical inconvenience. I have two artificial knees, fairly new ones at that, and there were many times when the high steps took me out of the ballgame.

Wow - this place is awesome. Visited this place as part of a photo tour, unfortunately it was raining but it was still an awesome place to visit. Be warned however that the stone gets very slippery when wet. Got some great photos and loved the atmosphere.
MAJESTIC. An absolute must to do. Aday trip is more than enough in the searing heat. But the splendour of the temples more than makes up for it.
Loved the faces. Loved the faces and the size. Visited around 7am and not that many people were there. Maybe 3 people in each section where we were.
My favourite. This was my favourite of all the sites. The faces in relief were just incredible. Give yourself enough time to do it justice.
Just impressive. All the towers and intricate details make this stunning. See (and clime) the Baphuon, enjoy the reddish Phimeanakas and of course visit Bayon temple.

Bayon Temple Climb. I loved the climb at the top. Had a cute " nose to nose" photo too with Buddha.
So serene and I felt a smooth swirl of air upon reaching the top.

Nice Buddha faces. We visited in the morning and the light shining on the huge stone carvings of smiling Buddha faces was an interesting view. On each of the four sides of all the towers there are smiling Buddha faces, some better preserved than others but all basically the same. No one knows why these faces were carved, so it's definitely an interesting place to visit. It's nice to visit when there are less tourists so you can get better pictures.
Great and Huge. It gives a very good first impression of the complex. We were very excited to explore the temple, even when we visited this at noon....

Not like the movie. I was hoping more of the Tomb Raider scene when she was inside the temple but there is nothing like that. It's really falling apart...literally. There is extensive repairs and restoration going on which is good. It is a great place with lot of historic value and history.

Bayon temple is architecture of 9th century construction of volcanic lava stone supporting walls and granite interior. Temples are internally connected and each has different historic fact of religious beliefsFaces reflect the different gods face carved out

Impressive temple labyrinth. This is one impressive structure. Although falling apart, but one can see its hey days. Quite easy to lose sense of direction there as every corner looks just like another one.This is definitely one of the more interesting sites spread across a vast area. The other being Ta Keo (the ruin with nature taking back from civilization).
Amazing Place if you go Early. An amazing sight to see all the massive smirking stone faces, just go early when the light for photo's is kind and tourist numbers are manageable
Majestic. Has a large number of pillars and is an imposing sight. Was among my top three, the others being Banteay Srei and Ta Phrom

Sunrise. Be sure to get up early....take a tuck tuck from town and arrive at Bayon for sunrise. Approximately 6am. It's the best time as it's fascinating to watch the sunrise over the temple, highlighting the textures and colours. You get a short time only before the hoards of tourists arrive. Once this happens it is a nightmare. This temple has undergone renovation work over the last couple of years, in fact it is ongoing. A portion is roped off as are many other temples at Angkor. Hopefully the new work will weather in because at present it looks like new concrete and stand out badly. Take a torch if you intend to go for sunrise as it's still dark when you get dropped off.

Amazing and huge stone faces. I like the curious smiling images..For those who have limited time, enter the Bayon at the east, turn left at the first gallery and follow the arrow marked on the plan...We have our tour guide who is really assists us on every history of the temple..

Mind blowing experience. These are old archeological ruins which showcased the ancient Hindu civilization in this part of the world.
Though far away from India the Hindu & Buddhist culture flourished in this part of the world.

My favourite. Well preserved with interesting architecture and designs. Yes it's crowded but this is to be expected with popular tourist attractions! Make sure you cover your shoulders and knees to guarantee entry. Some of the stair climbs can be a little difficult because they're steep with narrow tread.

go there from 1 pm to 3 pm best time to see the temple when everyone having lunch. what a amazing idea ? the temple was build by using the used stone that left over from other temple to build it ... all of the faces on each tower was amazing
cant say enough about this one
Smiling Faces. A charming temple with smiling faces. Bayon Temple is a smaller area to cover so it felt much more manageable and thus memorable.

Just loved this temple. Such a peaceful, beautiful place. The smiling carved faces have a serenity that just gives one a such a happy feeling. Like Angkor Wat, one has to watch where you are walking due to the uneven surface. Only 'problem' here, I couldn't stop taking photos of all the faces!!

Our favorite temple at Angkor Wat by far.... This was our favorite temple by far....Famous for its gothic towers embellished with over 200 giant smiling heads of Avalokiteshvara … and intricate carvings at every turn – it was absolutely fabulous :-) There were even brief moments of respite from the crowds where one could find solitude to sit, take a deep breath and imagine what might have taken place in this temple centuries ago.Do not miss Bayon! :-)
Captivating. This temple is captivating, from the idea of building towers of faces which look to every direction of Angkor Thom, to the intricate carving of the walls
great temple - well preserverd. ..one of the not to be missed temple; driver stays with the car or tuktuk, while you visit. Many simple great dissher
a must-see temple. The temple is famous for the "Khmer Smile". A place to gain inner peace while seeing the smiling faces of Budda.Don't miss the sculptures on the walls.

One of the must see temples. If you only have a little time this is one you have to make sure you see. Get one of the local guides to show you where to get the great pictures. With a little creativity you can get a nose to nose picture with the giant stone heads. A memory you will keep forever.

Must see at Siem Reap. While everyone talks of Angkor Wat, i enjoyed the Bayon Temple more. It was bigger and I liked wandering the passages and corridors and getting lost inside!
Don't stay too long, though. After a while, it all seems to be the same. Make sure you bring water too. Pretty humid there.
My favorite. The 200+ placidly smiling faces of Jayavarman VII in the four cardinal directions will remain with you forever.

Our first look at Angkor history. Part of the Angkor experience.
This gave us our first taste of the Angkor period temples. It's amazing how they carved every piece of stone.

My favorite temple. This temple was amazing, I couldn't stop taking pictures. I do wish our driver had stopped at the gate so we could get pictures there but it was pretty crowded. They also have elephant rides. There is a place in the temple you cannot go if your knees and shoulders are not covered. I highly recommend going to this temple
Just lovely. Another fabulous temple in the Angkor complex. Every one is worth a visit and this one is very popular. Go early or late to avoid the worst of the crowds.

Go early!. We went to sunrise at Angkor Wat then went straight to the Bayon Temple, highly recommend doing that, there were about 5 other people there when we arrived making it so serene and contemplative. Once we left about an hour later there were over a hundred people which slightly ruined the serenity!

Bayon is a must see. Bayon is one of the must see temples in Siem Reap. It is famous for the more than 200 smiling faces adorning the many towers of the temple. I also like the wall carving showing the battle between the ancient Khmer and their enemies. Unfortunately it is very crowded so you should go there early. You can take an elephant ride in from the outside which is not that interesting. However I highly recommend the elephant ride around the temple. You can get a good view of the temple and if you have someone who walk along with the elephant you can get some fantastic photos of your family/friends on the elephant with the temple as the background!!!
Our favorite temple. We went back on our last day to visit Bayon again on our own. It is definitely most spectacular of the temples. Amazing big faces. We loved it.

Buddha faces wherever you look?. The face of a Buddha is a picture of calmness & tranquility & this place sums up that feeling. We visited late afternoon when the crowds had dispersed somewhat & the light was still good for photography.Again our private guide was a real source of information & brought the place alive.

Amazing temple. We were amazed with this temple and the great views when you get to the top of the temple via some very steep steps. You just wonder how they could have people built this al those centuries ago.
Beautiful but overcrowded. Probably one of the most beautiful temple in Angkor, but unfortunately overcrowded with groups. So you have to queue just to walk.
My favorite temple. The faces on Bayon Temple were amazing as was the story of Bayon. Highly recommend seeing this sight.
It feels like the first time. This is my second visit in 8 years, but still it feels like the first time I came here. The temple did not cease to amaze me. I find this more charming than Angkor wat

Well worth the trouble of the climb. Visiting this involves a non trivial climb, but once you are up there, you feel vindicated for having made the effort. The giant faces wear such a serene expression from up close that you find your tiredness melting away.

Breathtaking!!!. This temple is absolutely breathtaking, the reliefs are absolutely amazing... A must visit!!!
Restoration work is going on at this temple, but don't let that deter you, once inside you will amazed & moved at the sheer scale & beauty of this place ... Truly amazing & for me better than Angkor!!!

196 faces!. The many faced towers of the Bayon temple are part of the Angkor Thom complex. We visited this at the end of the afternoon and the light was interesting showing many different facets to the 4 faces on every one of the 49 towers. It was certainly very hot at the top so interesting to wnder the narrow tunnels and dark rooms too before meeting our guide again so he could explain the stories depicted on the friezes around the lower walls surrounding the temple. Although not as huge as Angkor Wat, this temple was worth the visit, especially as towards the end of the day it was less crowded.

Not to be missed!. A most unique temple with its 54 Face-Towers of 216 faces of Avalokiteshvara (bodhisattva embodying the compassion of Buddha), that bears more than a passing resemblance to Jayavarman VII (the greatest Khmer king) himself. The massive faces are imposing and serene at the same time. Very atmospheric.  There are three levels. As the central tower area is not large, the crowds make it feel all the more cramped. I was there at 8 am but many visitors were already there. After 9 am, the temple got very crowded with tour groups. The exit area was thankfully not crowded at all at 10 am and you can get a nice panorama photo.  The floor of central tower area is no longer level, and my guide suggests that at some point in the future, the area must be cordoned off for major reinforcement work. Better view it now!

My favorite temple. This is the fist time I visits Siem Reap and I felt in love with the Angkor temples. Bayon is my favorite temple. I visited this temple 4 times during my 5 days staying in Siem Reap. I love the peaceful face of God-kings. And 3.30-5pm is good time to watch the face under the light of sunset

Sadly beautiful.... When I visit these great ruins, I go there to imagine what it must have been like during their glory days. In reality, it is sad to see the damages resulted from the conflicts and the neglects.
Better than Angkor Wat.. Angkor Wat is great for sunrise, but in the daylight itself, visit Bayon, which is far superior in complexity, scale and variety.
Wow.... Its more famous brother 'Angkor Wat' gets a lot of the press but this is equally as stunning, the history behind these temples is amazing

Incredible!. Bayon temple is stunning and absolutely incredible. The multiple faces are a mysterious and eerie sight at times.
Restoration work is in progress at the temple. Would recommend spending at least 2 hours here.
Carry umbrellas or hats as it can get very hot.

Fussy. J man 7 was energetic! Only came to throne at 55 but built so much. For me This Temple shows his fixation with appeasement of his God. A Buddhist but with 2 successive sister religious fanatic wives. This Temple is incredible but too intense for me.
Wow. Wonderful site. We hired a private guide and he was a huge help. Make sure you go back to the site in the evening - the light is wonderful.
Must see. If you visit the Angkor temple area then the Bayon Temple with it's huge stone faces is a must! imposing edifice.

Went with a guide, made a big difference. Our guide showed us a bunch of cool look angles to see how certain faces on the temple lined up, which turned into great photos. He gave us some additional education on the bas relief, etc. The temple itself deserves its high rating, it's very cool. Probably need about 1 hour at this temple.

Quite a remarkable temple. Packed with tourists so when you visit this temple (on the same day as Angkor Wat) just make sure you obtain a guide that is savvy enough to take you around the back side. When you enter from the opposite end of the main entrance into the complex you will see plenty of ruins with minimal tourist traffic (at least comparatively speaking) - i.e. the Northwest side of Prasat Bayon.
Interesting but not as busy as Angkor War. This is a really cool place to explore with many unique photo opportunities. It's not as busy as Angkor Wat.

They're always watching. The temple known for the many smiling faces, it feels as though they're always watching, kind of spooky. This was my 3rd favourite temple. Lots of restoration work which currently obscures some great photos.

Probably my favourite Temple at Angkor. After visiting Angkor, who is probably the largest complex in the whole Archaeological Park, it is nice to take a look around Bayon, who was large itself, but has more of a ruinous feeling to it.When I stepped inside, I just felt like my childhood hero, Indiana Jones, finding my way around the sometimes dark passageways in the temple building.

Temple and Terrace of the Elephants. We visited this historic site as part of a tour and found it extremely interesting. This site was an original temple site in the Angkor area and well worth a visit.

My favourite temple in Angkor. Bayon clearly was my favourite temple in the complex. The huge towers with the 4 Shiva faces carved on each side is epic. Considering there are 49 such towers. Make sure you stop by to see the wall carvings of scenes from the daily life of a cambodian citizen; they've also got extensive carvings of wars between the Cham from Vietnam and the local tribes.

Beautiful temple.... Bayon is a beautiful temple and largely intact. Make sure you get a close look att he lovely cobra balustrades that run around the building and the elephant walk. There is a lot of walking and it is very hot. Probably not ideal for mobility impaired or disabled tourists. Make sure you take (and drink) plenty of water
very nice. one of the top spots! a need to go. Did a tour with local companies, compare the prices, there a much different!
Best out of the lot. This was our favorite temple out of all the ones we visited. The stone faces were so well preserved. Plenty of little 'rooms' to explore and plenty of great pic opportunities.
The best of a great bunch. This was my family's favourite, spooky and other-worldly. You can really get lost in it, without the madness of Angkor Wat.
Thought this the best out of main three. All those faces, with great photo opportunities. Nice reflection in pool outside. The wall with carved history is amazing
Favourite temple. My favourite temple in Angkor - you can spend lots of time exploring the maze of rooms and passages and looking at the giant faces that make this temple so unique.
Breathtaking. My favorite of the temples, this had huge faces built out of stones that is simply breathtaking. Try starting here, instead of Angkor Wat, to minimize the crowds.

Fascinating faces. The temple with the giant all seeing faces and many nice wall inscriptions. Many tourists on a relatively limited area makes a bit stressful and takes some of the mystique away. Beeing renovated with aid from Japan.
No One Would Miss This. Fantastic Temple. Yet you'd better choose a less busy hour to visit (early morning like 730am, perhaps?)

Jewel of the trip. By far our favorite Ruins site to visit while in Siem Reap. Amazingly detailed, complex and scenic. My kids, age 4 and 5, loved it. Really gave you a feel of what these people accomplished and how long ago. Mystical and Mysterious. It was a giant maze of laterite and silhouette. Bring your best camera, cover your shoulders and knees and explore!

The most interesting temple amongst all.. Beautiful smiling Buddha faces on this temple makes the atmosphere just so peaceful and interesting even at its current ruined condition. Just think about how beautiful it would have been when it was at its prime condition. Just amazing!

Highlight of Angkor. Apart from Ankor Wat itself, the Bayon Temple is the highlight of a visit to this world heritage historical park.Most people would be familiar with the Bayon from travel photographs of the gigantic four-sided Buddha heads that are the main feature. It is now commonly believed that these sculptures were modeled on King Jayavarman VII, once of the greatest kinds of the Khmer Empire.
Magnificent architecture. The temple is full of history and stories. There are also other sites that are worth to visit in that area.

What an amazing place!. The history, the sculpture and the spiritual feeling was something we won’t forget. We also went to the museum the day after which I would recommend it gives us a real understanding and more depth information of the temple.

massive carved faces. This is the temple to visit for carved faces, which adorn all sides of the many temple towers. Just explore the temple and its ruins and take in the sights and magnificent carvings.
Interesting. Considering its history, this site was very interesting- but there is limit how much you can be impressed by ruins!

Magnificent!. Come here quite a while ago but it's still one of the most fascinating places i've been to. i really love the old architectures, extremely unique in the world. the faces of the "towers" likely represent the thousand-year-old mysterious smiles that give people feelings which are hardly described. would love to come back here and explore more of it just by myself.

I kissed the king and I liked it!. Finally I get to visit the spectacular central temple of the ancient city of Angkor Thom! Bayon temple is one of the must visit place when you're in Siem Reap. I love it how you can snap a lot of picture by kissing or nosing the statue as long as you could find the correct angle.. Is a very fun place to snap!

Our 3rd choice after ta phrom and angkor wat. Each column decorated with faces of buddha facing 4 directions. Similar in architecture to angkor wat. Can be visited in half hour if you can figure out which exit to take
amazing temple. If you only have time to visit a few of the temples in the area around Siem Reap, Bayon Temple should without a doubt be on the top of your list.

My 6th visit. I love this Temple.All about the light and time of day when you visit. It get very busy and can get hot. Go early!HInt....Remember where you are dropped off you can get turned around here and loose your Tuk-Tuk driver.Please stay away form the Cruel Elephant rides near this Temple.They are so sad, and miss treated.Worked all day chained all night.

Fascinating but too tiring. Like Angkor Wat, this temple comes together in the $20 ticketGood to walkabout if you are fit.Same structure and after a while one may feel overloaded.No English explanation.
My favourite. This was my fav temple on Cambodia.Is magnificient! The only less positive aspect is the lack of care with it. Besides that, a trully amazing place.

Magnificent Bayon. A highly recommended place to go to. I had always wondered where all those mug shots of big buddha heads on temple tops came from. Got my answer from Bayon! A beautiful temple that boasts of some amazing architecture and many Buddha heads adorning the temple towers. An inspiring place for beautiful photo opportunities!
Worth A Visit. It can get crowded quickly, but is worth a visit. There are beautiful carvings and it is a fascinating temple. It's very impressive and should be on your itinerary!
Beautiful . We got here late morning and it was pretty busy with the tour buses that had rolled in too but it's still a beautiful place to explore and see, lots of smiley faces of the Buddha's.

Wow!. We arrived in the late afternoon. The site was very crowded. Since I was exhausted, I planned on taking a few pictures from the outside before returning to the van. But, I was drawn in to the site. So glad I took the time to explore this temple.The faces are amazing up close. Very intricate. Everywhere you look is another amazing image. The site was fun to explore and definitely worth the visit. We easily spent 40 minutes at this temple.

The Search for Enlightenment Part 3. Bayon. Bayon is the “Faces” temple which stands at the center of Angkor thom. There are about 216 serene looking massive stone faces in the upper terrace. This faces might be a representation of the Khmer king Jayavarman VII. This temple is compact and it can be difficult passing through corridors with other tourists. Take time to view its 2 galleries. The first one depicts everyday life and the second one depicts mythological events.Amazing how the stone Faces were built and how they have been preserved to withstand centuries.

Bayon buddhist temple. Elaborately decorated with carvings and pictures, Bayon temple was built by King Jayavarman VII in late 12-13th century in part of the Angkor Thom temple complex. Gigantic 216 faces were believed to be depiction of the King's face himself.

Too many tourist. I went on a Thursday, and the place is overcrowding with tourist. This made taking photos a challenge and moving around the compound difficult. Guides are available to explain the area, but I choose to walk on my own. Entry of all Angkor heritage needs the ticket.
The temple of smiling faces. Go there in the morning or afternoon, when the sun lights up the smiling faces, and you will see much more details and beautiful colors.

Mind boggling. Such an amazing site! Got to the temples early (started 5am) so not too busy, as we were leaving it started to get very busy so worth the early start. We also went via push bike so earlier the cooler :)
Intricate carvings.. Out of all the places we visited on our tour, Bayon had some of the most intricate and interesting carvings. Faces, everywhere.

Phenomenal siem reap experience . The carvings and faces everywhere make you feel like you've been sent back to a different era. The ruins are so stunning that it's hard to imagine it in all its glory. If you're going to visit only 2-3 temples or ruins whilst in siem reap then this should be one of them.

large and impressive. lots of carvings, large faces on the towers. one of the largest ruins in the Angkor Wat park. there were quite a lot of people here but we managed to get the odd photo without any tourists in it

Amazing sculptures. If you opt for a smaller temple with so much details in it, this would be the best place. With sculptures on the walls and the faces of the buddha's everywhere, it was quite a show! We had the most beautiful pictures taken here since the skies decided to be awesomely blue with clouds on it the momemt we arrived. It was hot but this place was amazing!

Makes for amazing pictures. The faces at the temple are really unique. The fact that visitors get to climb up the temple and really get a close look at the design allows for some wonderful pictures and amazing memories.

The 4 heads of Buddah. This is a small temple and can get very crowded. It is very stark but the carvings and the stories they tell are fabulous. A guide with this knowledge is a must, otherwise you will miss out on the facinating stories that are depicted.
My Favourite Temple!. I loved the Bayon temple most! There were lots of pretty sculptures and my tour guide helped me point out the iconic and beautiful ones. A MUST visit!
Amazing Temple. Beautilful carved faces on each tower . A Must see ! Try to go there during lunch time to avoid the large crowds of tourists .

My favorite temple in Siem Reap. My friend and I did a tour of the multiple temples of Siem Reap, and we both agreed that this was our favorite one. The Buddha faces found throughout the temple evoke smiles and feelings of tranquility. Very beautiful and well worth a visit here. We had a guide who told us some history behind the temple, which was wonderful. Be sure to get a picture kissing a buddha face!

A Favourite. My Favourite when we visit so much character and if visiting at the right time maybe lucky enough to catch an Apsara dance with girls in costume.Every corner you turn there is another face looking at you, so beautiful.
TEMPLE VISIT. Walking up to this Temple makes you feel very peaceful; there is a wonderful and interesting forest surrounding this Temple. Lots of ancient history surrounds this area and you feel it.
Beautiful carvings and rich history. Great start here on my first day in siem reap, every corner is photo-worthy! I Skipped the sunset on the hill cause there are too many people

A must visit. Try to pick a time that will not be that crowded, it will be best seen with less crowd - probably early in the morning or later in the evening before cloising times... Highly recommend visiting this place with Hour Sokkung tour Guide

Amazing if not for the large number of tourists. This is an amazing place to be except that it gets packed with tourists - all trying to get their perfect pictures. Oddly, I could hear sounds of squeaking (I think it was rats) whenever I was inside the temple (possibly up in some ceiling). Doesn't of course in any way affect the experience. It's a labyrinth and takes a bit of time to completely explore and definitely worth it!

Awesome!. It's quite a smaller temple compared to angkor Wat both it's really worth a visit. I enjoyed taking pictures the architectural design of the temple is so intricate. I love to come back again.

True faces. Bayon represents the soul of all entire arqueological sites of Angkor Vat. This giant heads, with mulktiple faces and the impressive bas-reliefs, gave him a unique importance. Due to the dimensions of the temple, please avoid touristic excursions for better comtemplate this human wonderful place.

Very nice place. Lots of buddha faces all over the temple. Very nice to take a photo by the water edge (some water remaining on the grounds surrounding the temple) that give the right reflection for a perfect picture. Short climb up a not too steep stair to go up. Can be a labyrinth if you are lost up there but never mind, you can always get back out at another exit.

Stunning. An amazing experience to climb around this temple, it is also under going some major work, but this does nothing to detract from what an amazing temple it is.One of the major temples and very worthwhile seeing.This was my second visit.

The Temple of Faces (as they call it). The temple is looks like a labyrinth and is different from all the temples in the area. All summits has budha face. This temple isnt that big compared to others and is very easy to roam around. Its currently being rehabilitated.

Don't Lose Your Head. Well, the Bayon has lost a number of the huge Buddha heads that once adorned its 54 towers, 4 heads per tower, but still retains a great many of them, and is totally magnificent.

Wonderful sightseeing place. Its a must go for all visitors to cambodia! Photos taken at the site turned out nice with backgrounds of stone scruptures and faces. There are some nice angles to take, capturing a few faces at 1 go :)
Hindu & Buddhist Temple. The temple encompasses Hindu & Buddhist work and makes it into one. Its beautiful and well maintained. Lot of opportunities to take selfies and pics. Don't miss it.
impressive. take your time to send time in bayon temple. this is the one with giant Faces, our guide said it is better to start the daily tour with bayon...

More time to see. This is part of the short tour, which sounds like the easiest but its the longest. Be sure to buy the 3 day or 7 day pass, same price $40. That way if the heat or walking get to you, you can re-visit. This place covered a lot of ground and I didnt get to see it all. Also, I regret not getting a tour guide for this one.

Good, but I have seen better. Some relatively unknown temples in India are much more beautiful and have more intricate carvings. Was a bit disappointed, must be because I saw the best first. One such is the temple near Aurangabad, called the kailasnath temple, hewn out of a single rock. Definitely a must see. Another one is a Jain temple in mount Abu called dilwada. It is the best I have seen , so far.

Very nice. I really liked it because there was much more room to look around at Bayon and the faces and carvings were amazing- like nothing I had never seen before. Just make sure to remain culturally sensitive and especially to cover your shoulders. Taking your hat off in temples is also respectful. Make sure you wear sunscreen if you get easily burnt!

Well-worth the crowds. Restoration work is done splendidly and the view from the top is breathtaking. The reliefs on the walls that depict the history of the Khmer empire are in excellent condition. From the upper terrace of the temple, it is hard for one to not be awestruck by the gigantic faces and the amount of work that has gone into its construction, maintenance and restoration.

Wow factor was the Tranquility. Fascinating fine work, one of the most impressive temple in the world. Was able to connect with this place and spend time watch the temple with disbelief. Much is done and still in progress with restoration and much appreciate the funding of other foreign countries and the effort put it. Delicate work is carried out while it's historical values and worth not compromise. A must visit site.
stunning. my favourite of all, simply amazing, intricate carvings and complex, compact place that takes you by surprise at every turn
Tranquil!. Compared to Angkor Wat this was realy quiet and tranquil with equal wow factor if somewhat smaller. Well worth going too.
Big. Couldn't gain access as had my shoulders uncovered, so wear a t-shirt... Other than that, you can walk around it and explore the nearby temples

The most impressive temple at Angkor Wat. We found the quality of the decorative carvings at Bayon to be the most fascinating of all the ten temples we visited at Angkor Wat. The intricate work was excellent and the trees that grew over and on the structures made it even more fascinating. The restoration work funded by many foreign Governments and undertaken by Cambodians under supervision of foreign experts is impressive

Beautiful temple. To enjoy an elephant ride around the complex make sure to avoid the break times for the elephants. They stop rides early in the afternoon. Don't forget change to buy pineapples to feed the elephants :) and tip your elephant guide!

Favourite temple at siem reap!. Stunning, magical, and absurdly beautiful. The building distinct style is unusual and picturesque. The plan is well ordered and symmetrical altought the setting looks briliantly chaotic. The multitude of tranquil and massive stone faces soaring gracefully from the terrace testifying the king's triumph. Coming here was a bliss for me. Altough cramped and chock-full with people. Coming after sunrise / before sunset will be the good decision to avoid the crowds.

Temple of many faces. All temples are beautiful in Siem Reap but Bayon somehow has got that extra charm. The temple of many faces - hundred faces look in all directions. Important place to visit when near Angkor.

Favourite temple. Best to go in the morning before the sun gets really hot. Bayon's third level is its greatest charm - its possible to get pretty up close and personal with the lovely enigmatic stone faces. Fans of perspective photography can look out for the spot where the two faces appear to kiss. As the third level of the temple is pretty exposed without cover, it can get very hot if one were to visit in the afternoon. Suggest to do Angkor Wat in the afternoon as that temple has covered corridors

The Best i like it.. It really enjoined what i saw this temple our family reallly like lots this temple more than other we saw. We had great memorial with this temple lots. We hope will come back again.

Beautiful cultural and historical site. This place is really beautiful. Lots of tourists though, still less crowded than Ta Phrom. Beware of local young men who are trying to direct you. They will ask you to follow them as they show you around as guides. They are harmless but of course expect a fee. If you do need their service, just say no and go on your own way.

Terrific. I keep getting this and Angkor Thom mixed up. And the images that people post are also mixed up. You must see both. The sculpture is wonderful and the Buddha faces are said to be a mixture of Buddha and the king who built it.
Lots and lots of people. Go early early early if you can.Reliefs of daily life on first level magnificient.Buddha faces all 4 directions on every tower awesome.

Special face. We love the smiling four faces of the tower of the temple and we were on the right time at the end of the day so it was fantastic time without many people. So we could take it easy with a quiet atmosphere.

Visit as often as you can. I would suggest everyone to take few visits to this gorgeous temple. Sunrise, sunset, lunch time, when hordes of tourists are returning to town for lunch.Take your time and try to find the most pleasant "face" and the best angle to photograph it. And don't forget to see the murals that extend around the temple. Pure storytelling.

Really cool. So many lovely Buddha faces! This temple was fascinating I really enjoyed my time here. There are a couple hundred faces and all are unique. Really interesting to see, and lots of great photo opportunities here.

The Temple of the Faces. When you see photos of the ancient Cambodian Temple with the depiction of the large "Buddha-style" faces on the temple spires, Bayon Temple is what you have seen. As part of Angkor, it was among the last of the state temples built here. It is well-worth trying to plan to visit here at a time when the crowds are smaller, as you can explore many, many hidden places here.

Excellent. Part of the Angkor Wat experience. Very impressive. The same applies to my review of Angkor Tom. Allow yourself twice as much time as you think you need to explore the whole complex at Angkor Wat.

Another great temple at Siem Reap. I'm not sure how much people would get out of visiting some of the temples if they didn't have a guide with them. Our guide was great at explaining the differences between each temple which made them all come alive. This one has faces on each of the four sides as shown in the picture and each face is subtly different. If you don't know this you can miss the detail so make sure to check them out for yourself.
Favorite Temple. This was my favorite temple on our private tour because of the history and beautiful architecture. I found myself lost through the little hallways.
Watch your step. Messy, difficult with loads of narrow stairs and poor footing. Need to hire a guide. Its often crowded and slow to move about.

The temple of the big heads. This temple is the second most famous to visit in Central Angkor Thom, to reach and also leave this area you have to cross the gates which are like bridges with sculptures on both sides, near this temple you also can visit the elephant terrace, Baphoun and other small temples.

Beautiful and mesmerizing. Stunning is the only word I could say on this Bayon temple. Unfortunately, I was there during the peak hour and I sincerely regret it. I kept bumping to many tourists so wasn't able to spend quality and quiet time there with my camera. Worth the visit and try to avoid the crowds but guess it's impossible.
The best place to visit. It was great to visit the place as we visited in the afternoon by the recommendation from the villa we stay. We have enjoyed our visit very much.

Add this to your tour.. You will only need around 45 minutes to walk around this temple. It is one of the biggest and it is nice to see. After this temple, you can easily walk towards the elephant wall and there is a more interesting temple over there.

One of the must see. Probably one of my favorite temples there. Love all the faces and intricate art work. Also is generally less crowded if you leave the early morning rush of anchor wat a bit early.

Really great artic. Bayon should be the one. The giant stone face image of Bayon save in my brain for ever which connected with khmer art and architecture. There are about 37 standing towers and look very nice in the evening. The interesting of carving of unique and revealing scenes of everyday life that are interspersed among the battle scenes, including scenes, cockfighting chess games and childbirth.
One of my favourite temples. Very impressive temple. Much smaller than Angkor Wat but one not to miss. Get there early if you can to enjoy without the crowds
壮观. the beautiful architecture is definitely a plus but it is a little crowded. a little tough for photo taking. the inside is cooling. great escape from the heat outside
Worth a visit. very enjoyable - one big drawback - the noise of visitors on motor bikes really ruined the serenity of the place

Peaceful during sunrise. We went there as early as 5.30am to wait for the sunrise. There was nobody except me and my husband. You can feel the whole temple is belonged to you. While the first sunlight ray shone on the pagoda, the golden light appeared on the "smiling buddha", the scenery was so touching. More and more "faces" were smiling at you. This is the best time to visit Bayon.
My favourite temple in Siem Reap. Angkor Wat is special for what it represents and for its size but Bayon is the site that made me sigh - for reasons I cannot explain.
fantastic. a must to visit when you have a chance to go to Cambodia. this old temple covered by trees. easy to travel here as well
The temple with many faces. another great architecture of the cambodia. try to get a good weather day to explore it as many are exposed to mother nature
As good. The bayon is as spectacular as Angkor wat if not more so. Less crowded, less chinese shutterbugs. A better temple all round.
One of the wonders of the world. Even with the large number of tour groups at about 9am, the Bayon temple is one of the wonders of the world.

Tomb Raiders. There are no murals here, but you can see the big trees enveloping over the huge stones as if they are telling the stories of how nature has taken over this sacred ground. The aged architecture and amazing huge trees are a great place for you to relax.
Extraordinary!. A fascinating temple with the faces on the towers. It is smaller than some of the other temples and therefore easier to comprehend. We worth a visit.

Must visit. A good archeological site. Great photo opportunity. Amazing to see that this place was built in the middle of no where in 9th century. It should take you about 90 to 120 mins depending how your interest.
Staggering. Great visit. Keep hold of your ticket we left ours in the car and had to find an illicit way inside!
Photoriffic!. This is my second time here and it still amazes me to feel the past Kingdom's greatness immortalised in these stone faces!

best temple experience. Angkor Wat gets the press, but Angkor Thom (Bayon Temple) is THE BEST. Bring your camera. See some of the other temples too - undeniably great experiences - but do NOT miss this one.

Siem Reap must see. I personally love bayon temple because it has a good spirited vibe when you sit at a quiet place and find your own peace. We went in the early morning so that it is quieter but we realized the direction of the sun affects the shadow and lighting of the faces. Hence we tried revisiting later in the afternoon (very hot) and we took better pictures. The downside is the crowd increased ++ in the pm.Be ware of some people who offers you incense or guide to you because they want tips at the end of it.

Magical. The Bayon Temple is one of the most magical places in the world. Even while overrun with other tourists it is clearly a testament to human creativity and skill. Plan to go more than once at different times of day.

Faces every where. Very interesting bas relief as you enter depicting a variety of historical and mythological scenes. Look closely and you will be amazed at what you see!Lots of up and down climbing here, although some wooden steps are no last time i was here.You are never far from a face- big peaceful calm faces every where you turn- always someone watching you!.Amazing architecture and building for Khmer times . Temple was originally Buddhist and later some Hindu additions as . Only thing which spoiled this visit was that in the centre was a group of people dressed up in Khmer king costumes charging to have your photo taken with them - Tacky... and more respect should be shown for a temple as beautiful and historical as this.
Sexy Face. They have full lips that smiles coyly.It might be difficult, but try to find an empty space through the maze, and step back into ancient time.
Fabulous temple. My favourite of the temples at Angkor. I strongly recommend visiting before 11am if you can - it was very quiet then but soon after got much busier with tour groups arriving.
A must see!!. Part of Angkor Thom - the number & variety of archaeological treasures can be difficult to absorb in one day. Liked every thing!

Amazing, Outstanding, Must See!. Another part of the UNESCO World Heritage sites at Angkor Thom/Wat is the Bayon temple and you really should include this in a 3 day package.The Bayon Temple is a well-known and richly decorated Khmer temple at Siem Reap, Kampuchea. The name Siem Reap means "the defeat of Siam" as the Khmer Empire became so powerful at the height of it's construction, they defeated the Siamese (which became Thailand). Built in the late 12th or early 13th century as the official state temple of the Mahayana Buddhist King Jayavarman VII, the Bayon stands at the center of Jayavarman's immense capital, Angkor Thom. Following Jayavarman's death, it was modified and augmented by later Hindu and Theravada Buddhist kings in accordance with their own religious preferences. Amazingly over a million people are though to have been living in this area at the time of its construction and peak of the Khmer Empire. The Bayon's most distinctive feature is the multitude of serene and massive stone faces on the many towers which jut out from the upper terrace and cluster around its central peak. The temple is known also for two amazing sets of bas-reliefs, which present an unusual combination of mythological, historical, and everyday-life scenes. We spent a few hours just admiring this Temple in all its beauty, the only spoiler was the incessant cries of the sales children who are used by their controllers to pester the tourists with postcards and other trinkets for sale. I doubt that very much money makes it back to the children themselves and it is a sad reflection on the society that allows these peddlers to continue to use young children in such a way.
impressive. like the all site of Angkor, but those heads are fabullous. the site in the middle of the nature. i made many great pictures. Hope you will enjoy as i enjoy it.

Amazing!. This was the last temple we visited on our tour and was the highlight of our day. I could have spent hours at this temple. The trees growing up through the walls and around the grounds are beautiful.
Pretty awsome. I liked this more than Angkor Wat - over 200 faces of Buddah on huge towers makes it an amazing site. Try to get there around lunchtime when the crowds are thinning out.
Amazing. Huge and amazing. You must visit here if you come to Siem Reap. Lots of faces and details to investigate. Check this up and you won't disappoint.

Excellent and part of Angkor Tom. We hired the tuk tuk that picked us up from the airport , If you are comfortable walking then he will take you to Angor Wat , Angor Tom ( Bayon Temple ) , Ta Prom and Banteay Srei all in one day , so you can complete them in a day pass ( $20 per day ) and the next day you can do Beng Mealea the next day . The tuk tuk rental for the first day was $39 and I think it is $ 40 to visit Beng Mealea . The price list for tuk tuk will be in the room or the font desk can provide it., if you are solo you have the option to take the mini bus etc .. check with the front desk.The name if my driver was Toluah and his number is 0886644479. I stayed close to Pub Street
fabulous!. nothing to dislike..just enjoy the temple..need to have a guide if you want to know more about the history etc.

Top attraction in the world heritage site. Bayon is very awsome temple with a big smile of world heritage site, All of the tourist coming to visit Cambodia, You mush see this temple.I would urge visitors to start here first. I really enjoyed this temple and wish I would have started here earlier in the day when the sun wasn't so hot. After having already seen Angkor Wat and Phnon Bakheng, I was hot and sweaty. I probably was not as focused as I was viewing.

Want to feel like Lara Croft?. We got there at 540. Shared Bayon with only one other couple as the sun rose. The sunrise itself was nothing special but the feeling of being in the weirdest place imaginable as slowly the faces appeared... Fantastic. After we had visited two other temples we passed Banyon on our return. The buses , Tuk tuks walking tours cyclists jammed the road. Go early very early

Incredible Architecture. My 2nd visit to Bayon Temple after 10 year still very impressive for how it built. This architecture definitely represent Hindo religion civilization in ancient time that inspire people to to put lots of effort to build this huge temple. This beutiful temple is different style from many other temple in Cambodia which one of the place must visit if you go to Angor Wat. There was some renovation to keep this place stand strong for people to visit and admire the Art of old cool Architecture. Nidnoi
Must See. The ruins around Siem Reap have been on our bucket list for years and we're glad we got to see this one.
One of my favourites. This is an amazing temple, which is obvious as soon as you arrive. It is awe inspiring and well worth a visit

Definitely worth a visit. Amazing site to visit, it is fantastic. However, unfortunately not recommended for people with mobility difficulties. The site is vast and one has to go from one place to another to appreciate it all.

The culmination of Angkor civilisation. Through a plump, serenly smiling face of Buddha done in likeness of Jayaraman VII, the face of ancient Cambodia's most celebrated King's benevolent gaze greets you in Angkor Thom area. It is as if he wanted to watch over all of Kambujadesa (ancient name of Cambodia) from the soaring spires of the Bayon building complex for eternity.This is the most evocative of monuments in the Angkor area. Must visit!
Cycle trip. I loved this temple and all the faces carved into it. Don't miss this one on your visit to Angkor Wat!

A Slice of Life. It can be easy too become "templed-out". It all is beautiful and overwhelming. It helps to identify something about each temple to set it apart from the others. This one was one of my favorites because of the bas reliefs depicting daily life. It is a window to the past.

My jewel of the Angkor temples. I do not why, but since visiting Bayon 10 days ago i can't take it out of mind. Is it the haunting feeling you get when see it from the entrance, the delicate art work describing daily life in Angkor of those days. I do not know, but visit here was "worth the price of admission".

Smiling Buddhas at every corner. The smiling buddhas are incredibly peaceful. After so many centuries and greeting visitors with warmth. Totally amazing how the stones have stood the test of time! Spend more time here.
Simply in awe. This was an amazing temple, possibly one of our favourites! The faces within the building walls are insane! To think these were carved centuries ago is a wonder! Must see!
Amazing!!!!. I love Bayon - it easily has to be one of my favourite of all the temples! A workout - yes. But amazing views ... it's just awe-inspiring being up there! LOVE BAYON.

By far my favourite temple . Out of all of the temples of Angkor that I visited during my stay in Siem reap (and I did visit a lot), bayon was by far my favourite. It was so much fun being about to explore it, and even though there was a lot of people there it definitely wasn't as over run with people as Angkor Wat was when I visited it a few hours earlier at sunrise. All the carvings are magnificent and very well preserved. The temple is undergoing some maintenance at the moment too, so it is reassuring to know that it should stay beautiful for people to enjoy for a long time to come.

Truly magnificent. It is not often that the reality surpasses your expectations - but this is one such place. It is absolutely beautiful. Recommendation - get there early, as a real problem is being trapped by one of the many packs of tour groups whose main aim seems to be to take selfies/group photos in front of anything. Despite this the site is a must to see.

Great relief carvings. The carvings go right round the four sides, and are intricate in detail and extremely well preserved. A guide will point out the specials and explain the stories. Otherwise, just take the time to walk slowly and examine the detail.
Great photos. The trees amongst the ruins were extremely interesting! It's hard to believe how the roots could have grown so much through the ruins without uprooting everything.

I remember the face of Buddha. I can say one thing for this place-Picture Perfect. The artisan who built and carved the face of Buddha must have been geniuses at that time. You can see and feel the details and imagine the time they have invested to this place. I took numerous shots as I was really amazed by this place. We still used the tuktuk as this place is away from the Angkor Wat. A lot of restoration works were going on and structural supports are in place in some areas of the temple. If you have so much time-don't rush this temples as you really enjoy it when you take your time. Don't forget to take your selfie.

The Temple of many faces. This is one of many temples in the Siem Reap area. This is a must see (after Angkor Wat) as the beauty in the different faces (over 200 and each one if different). This temple leaves you breathless. I recommend a local guide to explain what you are looking - the history is fascinating and I cannot wait to go back and see more.
Photo-friendly. Selfies, group photos, candid, or staged, you can get the best pictures at many corners of this temple. We had a long session of "kissing the Buddha" picture-taking here.

One of my favourites. Highly recommend getting there early as I imagine it would get quite busy later in the morning. The corridors and entrances are smaller than the likes of Angkor Wat which makes every little turn something new. Went crazy with the camera with all the face carvings. Another stunning temple.
Nice visit as part of a tour. Bayon is not overly large so it is quite easy to see around it which I did as part of the short circuit tour. Lots of building work going on but reasonably photogenic.
Bayon Temple. The temple is great to explore and has so much history. Great photos. Restoration is happening to maintain as much of the structure as possible.
Temple of Faces!!. Massive temple structure built with faces of the king jayavarman. there must be atleast 200+ faces of the king. treat for people who love history,architecture and civilisation.

Favourite temple. My favorite temple for sure. Was very busy, but there every corner you turn there is something incredible to see, so its easy to get the photos you want. Our tour guide was fantastic too, we had a great laugh and he gave us loads of inside information. We are backpackers, so he was also within backpacker budget and cheaper than hiring a tuk tuk driver. He was actually a friend of the person who ran the orphanage we worked at. He can be contacted via sok hope foundation at g mail dot com. I'd also highly recommend visiting the orphanage and if you have the time, volunteer there! (both can be done by contacting Sok)

How did they build them!!. This is my second trip to Siem Reap doing everything the second time around and yet I am as amazed and filled with awe as I was the first time I visited. My lastest count - 20 towers.

Huge Buddha faces. We visited this site for about two hours which enabled us to take our time viewing and photographing large faces as well as smaller carvings. As you walk through, don't forget to turn around and view where you've been for sometimes surprising angles.

Nice place, good environmental surrounding,. It's amazing place that we visited. not just only Bayon Temple of Cambodia that we visit, but also the other temples such as Angkor Wat, Taprom, Tonle Sap lakes and friendly people that we met and experienced with them. It's amazing, and thank to Asia Explorer Travel that provided us an excellent services at a reasonable price. we will come back again with our other friends thru your agent.

Number 2 behind Angkor wat.... Angkor Wat is the obvious number one for Siem Reap...but this is the #2...the temple is awesome and if you get the right light the photos are stunning. The surrounding area is a pretty walk and a great display of the jungle swallowing an ancient civilisation.

Insightful tour. The weather can be unbearable so please do bring a cap & wear light. Other than that it was an eye opening tour about the intricacy of the architecture & the story behind their cultural elements carved in the ancient monument.

Our favorite Temple. Bayon is our favorite temple and we went to many during our 5 day trip in Siem Reap. There's something to the smiling faces that just makes you feel welcomed and calm. A must see in Angkor.
Well done Khmer . Part of my small highlight tour of angkor was bayon. As 2nd big temple after angkor wat itself bayon impressed me even more. The four faces which encounter you are just amazing.

Best Temple. I would urge visitors to start here first. I really enjoyed this temple and wish I would have started here earlier in the day when the sun wasn't so hot. After having already seen Angkor Wat and Phnon Bakheng, I was hot and sweaty. I probably was not as focused as I was viewing.

A Must Visit!. Be sure to visit this at the right time of the day. We were here around 12nn which was super hot. So our pictures of the whole place was not so nice. We passed by in the afternoon again just to get a nice picture maybe around 4pm. :) A must visit :)
Bayon Temple. Must see. Go with a guide to hear the history to appreciate the art and architecture. Contructed late 12th Century it's massive buildings are beyond belief.

A must watch among 1000 Angkor temples. The Bayon's distinctive feature is the massive stone faces of Buddha on the many towers which jut out from the upper terrace and cluster around its central peak. Its worthy of visit among thousands of other temples for its sheer khmer architecture style and fusion of Hindu and buddhist stories hidden behind its walls . Don't be too miser to save your money on tour guide :)
Angkor Divine vision of Khmer kings- Devrajas. Once a life time visit place.Visit as early as possible...the heritage is detoriating & restoration adds artificial flavor.
Average. Compared to others like Ta prohm and Angkor. I found this temple very average and should have skipped for something else

One of our favorties...went twice. Managed to visit at sunrise with only about 6 other people here. Amazing to watch the sunrise on the many faces. This was second visit to this temple. First we visited in late afternoon with full sun ( and full tour buses lol) amazing at any time
My favourite!. This temple is breathtakingly beautiful and my favourite of all the temples we visited during our stay there. You could spend hours taking in all the different vistas. Don't miss this.
Temples temples temples. Well worth a visit, but get the 3 day pass for better value.Watch out for dodgy tourist guys at temples and children hassling to sell you something.

most photographed spot in Cambodia.. One of the most photographed temple of the Angkor Wat complex. Has many bayon-three faced god-stone carved kind of stupas. Beautiful, wonderful, hard to imagine this was build a thousand years ago. Beware of the very hot weather.

There's more to explore. This is my favorite among the Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom temples. I did not expect to like it as much as I do, but I would come back here again.Don't be content with following the tour path, which mostly goes through the upper levels near the giant faces. You can explore a bit more in the lower levels and around the outer walls. Finding your way through the maze of corridors in the lower levels is exciting.Tip: Most tourists go with a tour schedule, which is either starts at 5:00 AM for sunrise or 8:00 AM for those too lazy to get up early. Both starts at Angkor Wat, and more tourists start at 5:00 AM. It will take them some time to explore Angkor Wat and move on to the other temples. So after seeing the sunrise at Angkor Wat (around 5:45-6:00 AM), go directly to Bayon and the other Angkor Thom temples. This is the best way to get ahead of the other tourists and avoid crowds. They will catch up with you at around 9:00 AM, but by then you will be moving on to Ta Prohm.

Best temple in Siem Reap. When I was planning my Cambodia visit, I came across number of blogs mentioning that Bayon was better than Angkor Wat, I always wondered what made it so beautiful ... But I now can say that I too loved Bayon Temple over Angkor Wat.. Angkor surely is the biggest temple and beautiful early morning, but its something about Bayon Temple which makes it my favourite..I liked the character of the temple, the Bayons smiling at you.. Loved it.;

Elephant Rides. Beautiful temple - you can ride an elephant around the outside of this temple which is great when you have small kids as there is a lot of walking - about $10 per adult. Under 5 free I think. One of my top 3 temples!

Mystery. This is the largest among temples in Siem Reap and the most mysterious one. Carved faces smiling back at you and you're left with nothing but the expression of awe. Hold on to your friends, you might get lost! =)

Mystical. Spectacular visual sight. The temple has such an intricate layout, reminds one of the Incas and all their hypothesized wisdom. The architect/s have made an amazing array of stone faces throughout the temple and the symmetry is mind boggling. Must see and experience!
Great. Amazing how these towers were built, the detail work, the carvings! You can spend hours walking around. Write up doesn't do it justice

Must See!. Just look at the pictures online and you will know to go. I hired a private guide with a private driver for two days. I am a female solo traveler who hates tour buses. I loved this Temple and took many amazing photos. Take time to look at the carvings in the stone. So many hidden treasures.
Bayon Temple - Wonderful experience. Magnificent place that smell history everywhere you look around, brought to life by great guide. Truly should not miss from the bucket list.
Awesome temple. The fifty-four columns (which represent the original provinces) each have four faces carved into them. lt can be pleasantly spooky
Most picturesque temple in Siem Reap. Just point your camera in any direction and you get a great shot here...highlight of my Angkor Wat visit

Mystery civilisation of the Khmer Empire. Absolutely brilliant trip! Bayon, Angkor Wat and the other two temples visited are spectacular. It was really eerie. Our guide was superb and really knew her stuff, giving us a very in-depth history of the era and construction of the temples. She also gave us plenty of time to take photos, even suggesting some interesting shots like trying to make your face line up with the faces on the towers of Bayon Temple so it looks like you're kissing which was great fun. Well worth the visit and I would recommend this trip to anyone.

A must see - sublime, amazing, collosal. Bayon has 54 pillars. Each pillar has on each side the face of Avalokiteshavera (looking rather like the god-king himself). Built in the early 13th century. So 4 faces per pillar!! Now that's a super PR job indeed, inspiring awe and fear all around. Big brother watching before term was coined! Yes it is packed with tourists. So what? It's totally mesmerizing. A must see among the Angkor temples. It's truly unique. The huge faces are offset by delicate carvings. Still going strong today! A must see indeed.
My Favorite Temple!. Wonderful temple with huge sculpted faces throughout. It was a little crowded, so I'd recommend getting there early in the morning or late in the afternoon.

The Most Important Buddhist Temple in the Complex!. Many might prefer this to Angkor Wat! I love this way how the faces appear at every corner when you are inside the temple. More importantly, it was built by the most prominant ancient Cambodian king, Jayavaraman VII!

Spectacular lotus temple, A must see!. Dating from the 12th century, Bayon Temple is the spectacular central temple of the ancient city of Angkor Thom. It was built in very beautiful lotus shape as it is a Buddhist temple. Bayon Temple is surrounded by two long walls bearing an extraordinary collection of bas-relief scenes of legendary, showing daily life of Khmer people during that period such as weighting goods/fish at market, popular boxing sport, cooking, birth giving... and historic events. In all, there are are total of more than 11,000 carved figures over 1.2km of wall. Just unthinkable how they did that!You will feel warmly welcome by approx. 200 huge stone smiling faces as you entered the site.There will be a lot of walking and climbing during the exploration so be sure you wear comfortable shoes with appropriate dress code as it is a sacred place. A must in a life time...Soooo amazing!

Go except on weekends. Bayon Temple is a good place to learn the country's culture through the carved murals in some of the temple's walls. You can also find the famous face sculptures inside which you usually see in post cards and posters. But schedule your trip to go on weekdays. If you go on a weekend, expect to see a lot of people buzzing around as if you're in a 99% discount store.

Go early. Worth seeing but was much more pleasant early on when not full of people. Looked very claustrophobic when went past in the afternoon. This is one of the "top2" temples. Most people seem to go to Angkor Wat first and then here.

One of the 5 temples to visit at Siem Reap. Bayon is the capital of Ankor Thom complex, very beautiful and with a baroque style opposite to Ankor Wat that is more Classical. It has a part made by the hindu kings and one made by buddha kings, so it is very interesting to see al the scenes and reliefs that narrate the history of the Ankor Kingdom and the giant faces are also impressive.

A must-do when in Siem Reap. A visit to see the amazing 'many faces of Bayon' should be included on any tour of the temples of Angkor. Buy a 3-day temple pass, as I can assure you, one day exploring all that Angkor has to offer will not be enough!

Stunning!. I was really awe struck by this temple complex - ever since the visit i have been trying to imagine what it might have looked like in its hay day, but its just unimaginable. This is by far the best temple in the whole complex of Ankor Thom.pictures cannot do this place justice and seeing it for real was an experience I will never forget.

A maze of temple. The Bayon temple relics and architecture is a bit different with Angkor Wat and Ta Phrom, apparently this temple was special because it has been passed on from one king era to another: surviving Pagaism, Hinduism and Buddhism. Its a bit hard to navigate myself around Bayon without getting lost, its almost like a maze! But all in all, I was amazed with the complexity of the temple and how they built it.
Great to see. Loved seeing this icon - photos a little harder to get due to crowds but the best turn taking and polite behaviour from all that I have ever experienced in a popular attraction
super crowded. Too crowded, cant take pictures as too many people. NOISY :(. Weather 33 C, sweating as run 2km/hours :))
Interesting site. Bit more of the same as seen in Ankor Wat and Ankor Tom. Only the history of the site makes a difference.
One of many temples. I loved the history behind the construction. There were many steps at all of these temples and the hot weather made it a bit difficult. Still amazing!!

" Love at first sight ". My wife and I came to see this magnificent temple during our 3rd and final day in Siem Reap. It was late in the afternoon and the sky above the area was swollen gray. We hurriedly took to the stairs with the intention of making it to the top tier when all of a sudden the rain fell. Good we found a dry nook on the western portion of the ruins where 3 Cambodian ladies were taking shelter. We found out later that they were there to do some janitorial services. My wife offered them some candies and their conversations started. There was a small window-like opening to my right where I could see the road and the tuktuks and cars passing by from afar and I figured the nook must've been a part of an ancient room. I was in that state of daydreaming when the rain finally stopped. I was so enamored with this temple that on our way back to the hotel, I made it a point to drop by a roadside art shop to buy an oil painting of the Bayon. The painting now hangs in our home as a special memento of that "love at first sight".

Incredible!. This temple is mesmerizing and amazing. Yes, it would be even better with the sun setting and no people but fabulous any time of day and with or without people. A must see for the area.... I already want to go back.

Top 3! Go see it!. Next to Angkor Wat and the Ta Phrom, this one fascinated us deeply! So different, so tiny and curvy walkways, so steep, so many faces in the walls, an absolutely impressive building. Stop by and stun! There are few spots, where you can see all three sides of some column, meaning that you can three faces on one single pillar at the same time from one spot.

Unique and truly impressive. Bayon was the first temple we saw in Angkor. It was early in the morning shortly before the sunrise, so there was only a couple of other tourists. Maybe that was the reason we liked it most. Massive head carvings look magnificent in the morning light - a real gem for any photographer. Temple territory is not too big, so I can imagine visiting it while crowds are already there is not so great. So skipping sunrise at Angkor Wat and going directly to Bayon would be your best bet if you want to enjoy the Angkor Tom inner temples (including Bayon) in peace and quiet.

Bats and Faces. This is a really stunning temple, set within Angkor Thom, and has a fantastic look as the sun sets. The shrine at the top has a narrow shaft above it with bats sleeping (and occasionally flapping). And the faces carved into every side of the temple are amazing, and thoroughly beautiful. We had a great time exploring this temple, especially the quiet bits away from most of the other tourists (around the East side). Don't forget to see the rest of Angkor Thom while you're here!

Fascinating - amazing carvings - '216 faces of Budda' - looks fantastic.. Spent some hours gong through and over this temple with our private guide. He was terrific in pointing out many things: history and purpose and some great fun photo shots! eg getting 2 budda faces lined up to be kissing; 3 faces in the one shot; multiple towers in line and so on!Just pure history - amazing how they built it and the carvings.....Make sure you get a 3 day pass so you can come back and explore the other amazing temples in the area! Do half day excursions to each - don't try to do them all in one day. Go have a swim in the afternoon!
Amazing and impressive. The temples of Siem Reap don't really need a review - they are all amazing. This temple is especially beautiful when it it lit up for celebrating new year.

Wonderful. People have been asking - what was your favourite temple. Hard to answer but if I am allowed 2 I would easily say Bayon and Angkor Wat. Well preserved faces and easy to explore on your own. Then walk along to the Elephant Terraces and Leper King which are also beautiful. As with the others was pretty crowded by 9am so go early or late!

Granduer of Bayon at sun down. As you enter the South Gate, you will come face to face with the ubiquitous Bayon temple. So very magnificent. Love to visit at dusk when the sun is about to set, the golden color shining on Bayon is amazing, mystical with no crowds. Just you and the mighty Bayon. Perfect.
Bayon Temple with the fabulous faces. This temple has a great feeling of strength and power. I enjoyed the amazing achitecture and sculptures.

Absolutely beautiful. The beautiful Bayon Temple with faces everywhere is the one of the most beautiful temple in Siem Reap. Although not as grand as the Angkor Wat, Bayon is more known for its sculpture, more specifically the face.Just standing in the middle of the temple, you feel as if every face is watching you. Just too good to be missed.

Fantastic. One of the many must sees in the area, this place is stunning with many faces looking at you from all angles - in stone of course! (as well as quite a few tourists!). It has an interesting history so either a guide or guidebook might be worth it for you.

Amazing. Amazing and impressive building. We visited there on our Day 1 of the 3 day pass, so still have enough energy to explore around for great pictures. Better to go early to avoid the crowd and heat.

Unique temple with faces. Go early in the morning to avoid the too much sun. It is a unique temple with peaceful buddha faces. Great wonder. Don't miss this one even though it's small and everyone kind of all over the places. But worth it.

Choose your best time to visit. As I arrived here quite late (10am), the temple was full of tourist. However the scenery was still very stunning. I think it would be better if I could visit it in sunset.

The Best of the Temples. Although Angkor Wat is the largest (and most crowded), this delightful temple is so ornate and features an amazing array of faces looking down at you, each of them completely different. We visited around lunchtime while the large tour groups were absent.A truly remarkable feat of engineering!

Thrilling view of the ancient world. Whilst far more ruined than Angkor Wat, this Temple exudes charm and fascination in equal measure. The multi-face turrets, allegedly depicting Avolokiteshvara, a Buddhist God, adorn the Temple. It is said that Jayavarman 7th the architect of Bayon, bore similarities to the God image and wished them to exult his Kingdom. Much restoration work is on-going at present to open up some of the outer Temples and gateways together with the inner singular alters. Another quite remarkable structure of the ancient world.
One of the best. One of the best of a very good bunch. Interesting carvings and worth wandering around the whole Angkor Thom area.
Amazing!Not to be missed. The ambiance and much quieter than Angkor Wat. The details and figures are just gorgeous! One could stand there for hours looking at those amazing smiling faces...
Another amazing temple. So different from Angkor Thom and Angkor Wat but just as impressive. The jungle is literally taking over this temple.
stunning. Fabulous despite the heat and the crowds. Wonderful ruin of a temple with so much to see. Very atmospheric
Must see!. If you're interested in archeology, architecture all Cambodian temples are "must see". It's all about history of this place!

great photo opportunties. We watched one of the local photographers and copied him taking pictures so we got some really good quirky shots. Nose to nose with one of the carving profiles and lining up the three faces of Bayon with your own at the end.We lit some incense at the temple and reflected on a wonderful trip
wow. you have to go see :-) truely a wonder of the world, and its been there since the dawn of time. Lots of other tourists, but what can you expect with something as spectacular as Bayon.

Better Than Angkor Wat!. I dare say. However, Angkor Wat is more iconic than Bayon. It was awesome to get lost inside the temple, but at the time that my friends and I explored it, there were less tourists, and that made the experience better.
