In the jungle... All the temple's of Siem Reap are within distance of each other. This is one excample of a good well kept temple... I do not recommend that you take a bycyle to peddle between them... the heat.. to die for...

Great way to pass time. I found the Bayon Temple really fascinating. It's a great way to explore the ruins and take your time looking around. While the heat does make you feel less energetic, at the end of the day it's worthwhile. I had a guide who showed us around the area - one thing I found interesting is the well (located somewhere where there is no light) that is supposedly ~16m deep but has been filled half with water.

Love this Temple!. This temple, while not too big like Angkor Wat, has a lot of large Buddha heads to take photos with. Also amazing is the way the carvings depict the battle between Cambodia and Vietnam.

Unbelievable. Overwhelming but beautiful. The earlier the better for visiting. The crowds are enormous. Easier to navigate in sneakers as there is a lot of walking and climbing on uneven ground. Drinks etc available.
Middle of the middle. The most center of the central temples. The carvings are amazing, and so is the temple itself. Don´t miss the nice buddha heads in the facades

Quick dash round before sunset. I only briefly got to see bayon temple just before sunset and in my opinion is is far more impressive than ankor wat. From a distance it looks like a pile of rubble but up close the Buddha heads are impressive. At the moment it is partially lit at night as Japanese archaeologists are doing work. Worth a visit.

Second best temple in the area after Angkor war. See this one at the end of the day when the sun is going down, the light on the stones is wonderful and you walk right up the top/close to the best carvings and with an amazing view over the countryside.

Another Temple another "must see". The temple closes at 17:30 and we arrived a few hours before, the crowds seemed to disperse fairly quickly and this allowed us to enjoy the site in relatively quiet surroundings. This is a lovely temple surrounded by trees which adds to the mystical feel.

Probably the best face of Angkor. Maybe the little brother to Angkor, but the ability to climb the stairs and roam around stone corridors. Maybe find a quiet corner to Sit and look the 4 ways that JV the 7th peers makes this place magical for me.

In the shadow of Angkor Wat but arguably the better of the two. The Buddhist bas-relief work at the Bayon is fascinating and arguably better than the Mahabharata at Angkor Wat. Certainly worth a few hours' patient wandering to take it all in.
The many faces of Eve. great temple to start with-The temple of the smiling faces. Easily accessible and a good intro to the temple complex

Small but fascinating.. Not as big or as grand as Angkor Wat - however this temple is very beautiful with the 200 or so faces of Buddha well preserved. Just look out for unofficial tour guides (normally disheveled looking children) who will show you to the library (a steep climb to a secluded spot) and then ask for donations to their "save our school" foundation. I told them my wallet was back in the car and only had $5 on me - which seemed to annoy them a bit. Aside from this minor inconvenience the temple was lovely and the scenery was great.
Great Place!!. Amazing place! Worth to visit! Very interesting and great to take few good photos!! Very crowdy place!

exquisite. Bayon temple is one of the most popular Buddhist temple among the many temples in Angkor Wat. The majestic king's head made into a magnificent structure of the temple is testimonial to the architectural prowess of the Khmer empire.

i love this temple. Wow, Bayon temple was so fantastic, ancient. I visited thid temples twice in 3 days because i loved it so much. I loved all the faces and the amazing pictures all each walls of the temples. I will strongly everyone to see this temple.

One of the most beautiful ones. If i had only one day for temple-runs, I would include this one. As a part of Angkor Thom, Bayon is near to other stunning temples. Also the area is close to Angkor Wat, the big one from the flag.
Best temple. I liked the architectural design in this temple. It was well preserved and all efforts are being done to conserve the ruins.
Must See. This temple is smaller than Angkor Wat but even more interesting because of the 216 Buddha faces and the easy access to the different parts of the temple.
Visit to angkor thom city. The efforts that must have gone in to put this together in such olden days ! Unfortunately several portions are damaged due to passage of time and human actions.
200+ smiling Buddhas. These faces are just awesome; wherever you're standing you can see 5-6 or more. And they're just big.

No words to describe it. The temple is just beautiful and it is one of the most important in the complex of the temples. As the complex is big you may choose to visit some and not all of them, but this one you can not miss!

The Best Bas-reliefs. Although well known for its stone face towers Bayon’s bas-reliefs on the outer gallery wall were the most artful thing I could relate to all day. With the sun making its way down after 5pm throwing light on the wall my guide took me on a history lesson of Cambodia showing what life was like in the market place, family, fishing, the election of a new general through fighting and playing chess and even a guy wooing a girl by kissing her hand. With artwork this detailed who needs movies, however you will need the knowledge of a local guide to explain them.
One of the Main Sites to see. This one is quite amazing in the growth of the trees and the fame from the movies.. your guide will make sure you see it.
Amazing. All temples are incredible, but this one in particular is amazing. Not easy to visit as there are many stairs and some people might find it difficult.

What's not to love?. Absolutely my favorite temple in a city of amazing temples. From the crowds, I was not alone in my opinion. We visited twice and both times I was awestruck by the serenity of the smiles. Do expect crowds - on our first visit we were enveloped by massive groups of tourists (the horribly rude kind, unfortunately) and on our second visit we were stuck in a traffic jam for more than twenty minutes attempting to leave the complex. Doesn't matter, though. I'd return again in a heartbeat.

Great temple-too many people. This temple is amazing but because its quite narrow to walk around I found the hordes of people all taking photos (rather than experiencing the temple) a bit much. Good one to visit really early- like sunrise.
Breath taking. It's like travelling back to medieval age. You can never go wrong visiting to Cambodia. Temples especially Bayon must visit at least once in a lifetime.
Favorite temple. This was our favorite temple. The Buddha faces are amazing and so detailed. Need a guide to help you understand all the significance, but even without a must see!

So amazing! . This was the last temple we visited on a day where we had been to nearly 6! So I don't think I appreciated it as much as I could of, as it was sooo hot and there's many stairs! But it was so beautiful and has many smiling faces which makes it amazing! Proper foot wear is advised as the steps are so steep and small it could be dangerous! We loved it here, we just took our time and wandered around :D
Wonderful temple. We went at 3:30pm. Wasn't too crowded although a few tour groups were still around. It was worth it! Magnificent place
Unmissable. Do not miss visiting this temple during your stay to appreciate how every temple can be different. While it may have similarities to Angkor Wat the scale and details are very different.

Simply beautiful....regardless of crowds and restoration work. My favourite of all the temples. The carvings are absolutely stunning. There was quite a bit of restoration work going on but that didn't bother me....I'm sure future visitors will enjoy the results! Expect crowds at most times of day. The only thing that made me uneasy was the elephant rides nearby, as South East Asia is very well known for badly treated animals being used for the tourist trade.

Amazing ruin. Words cant express how great this temple it just go and see it. There was quite a lot of restoration going on when i was there and large equipment blocking a panoramic view. This is an ongoing part of Angkor as they try to maintain the ruins.

Another pleasant surprise. I must admit that I was not well prepared for visiting all "must see-s" around SR. I haven't done "my homework" how I should have done it and that left lot of space for surprises of various kinds: good and pleasant ones as well as bad and disappointing ones.Bayon Temple was very, very pleasant one! Impressive to every last detail, enchanting structure - not to be missed!

Beautiful Ruins. The temple is good but they are in ruins and yes they are currently under conservation but yet they look pretty unstable. The heads on the temple are yet surprisingly beautiful. One can only imagine the grandeur these temples would have had when they were newly built. Its located right as you get into the main complex of Angkor Thom.

Beautiful. It was very beautiful, and, in spite of its age, the temple is still in great condition (conservation has been ongoing since the beginning of the 20th century). If your childhood was with nickelodeon, this one will keep you reminiscing the legend of the hidden temples!

Out of this world . Although smaller them the other 2 temples it's still amazing and full of detail. What s place. You must go and see this. We did 3 temples in 1 day and the sunset the previous evening. An experience I will never forget.

Stunning, just amazing. It's really hard to explain how detailed and grand this place is. All of the 216 smiling buddha faces are amazing despite being at various states of wearing away and its incredible to imagine what this place may have looked like hundred of years ago. There are so many photo opportunities and its great fun to walk around and enjoy the temple and all of its carving.
Amazing temple. Amazing. Love the faces :) Be prepared to bring along an umbrella, definitely helps on hot sunny days (be in morning or afternoon).

Brings you back. Got there early in the morning with just another group aside from us. It was very tranquil and so peaceful. Entering the temple is just like a maze of its own with doors leading to another. It is very nice to plan your visit ahead so that you can ask the driver to bring you to the Bayon with lesser tourists so that you can enjoy the place much better for your own. It is just walking distance to other parts of the Angkor Complex so you can really enjoy the place.

My favorite of the temples.. It's beautiful! 216 faces carved into the building.... Go and do sunrise at Angkor Wat and then get to Bayon for 6:30am. My friends and I were the only ones there and played hide and seek whilst enjoying just how stunningly unique this place is. Just gorgeous.

Beautiful, and worth every bit of the hype!. The smiling faces of the Bayon Buddha are one of the most popular and well known sights of Siem Reap. And yet, when you go there, nothing prepares you for the scale and the beauty of these faces.Apart from the Buddha faces, the temple also has stunning carvings depicting day to day life of villagers and fisherfolk in Cambodia as well as carvings about war and hunting. A must visit if you are in Siem Reap!
amazing!!. The best one !! Is better if you go in early morning without a lot of tourist for take a pictures alone
Breath Taking. This was my favorite temple. In spite of the crowds it seemed so serene. The faces are awe inspiring.
A blast from the past. The complex is just gonna bring you back to the past and imagine the grandeur living in that period. 1 day is not going to be enough. Spare more time!

Many Faces of the Buddha. A bit disappoint, because I think the Bayon could be bigger. Inside this temple is very steep, tightly and smell bad. In the top pagoda, there is a buddha statue with old woman lights up a joss stick for you to make a pray and donate. I was very scare!!!

Bigger than Ben Hur. This place is huge and being on several levels with various galleries, you really need a guide to explain all the bits and history. Fantastic carvings and bas-reliefs, despite their 800yr age. Great place for trick photos using the big heads as backdrops.

Incredible. Being there among those smiling faces it's an incredible experience! I highly recommend going there! Usually it's crowded with hundreds of people but if you go really early in the morning it's OK. Also have in mind that there is an elephant riding there. For like 25$ (if I remember correctly) you can make half-an-hour ride to the temple or around it. The only bad thing about this that they beat the poor elephants on their heads so that they walk the right direction. This was a bit awful for me and I barely stood it. But except that everything is just fine.Also be careful just before the entrance to this temple because there are monkeys there, which can steal your bag, keys, camera, ect. One of them has also bitten me, so you really have to be extremely careful not to tease those little creatures.

Very Enjoyable. From Siem Reap you can take a tuk-tuk round the temple circuit for $15 or so (Angkor Wat, Bayon and Ta Prohm). Your tuk-tuk driver will take you to get a ticket for the temples first. A 1-day ticket ($20) was enough for us. We had enough time at all the temples and at the end of the day, were 'temples' out. If you want to take a more leisurely pace then you can buy a 3-day ticket ($60 so no saving other than queue time) or you can come back and buy another 1-day ticket (the way to go if you don't want to do temples consecutively). The temperature in Cambodia gets very hot very quickly (by 930 it is brutally hot) so make sure you use plenty of sunscreen and take a hat. The biggest challenge in the temples is the tourists...blocking paths and walkways in search of the perfect photo opportunity (especially true at Ta Prohm). In the heat you can get very annoyed with the boorish behaviour very quickly
The best!. Quiet, gorgeous and worth the trek! The smiling faces were beautiful and it was so cool to climb all over this one. Our favourite temple.
Awesome Smiling faces all around you. In side this you can look in any direction and you see a smiling faceNice to see so much timeless smiles around youMakes you happy automagically
Wow. Really big with many many tourists visiting and gets really hot in the afternoon. You should visit in the morning with a guide explaining the story behind it. Beautiful.

Go at sunrise or sunset. The Bayon Gate is half of the fun, so do yourself a favor and get there morning or late in the day. Chances are you will see monkeys between the gate and the temple, and the light at that time of day will make the 216 faces come alive.
Worth to visit. Don't missed. One of highlight in Siem Reap. Never expect the civilisation is nearly a thousand years.

a bit crowded, but well worth the experience. Hot and humid, wear a hat, take plenty of water, but enjoy a remarkable site. Purchase a multiple day ticekt because you won't be able to see everything in the are in one day.

Spend Time Here....... My second stop of the day, truly stepping back in history. Take the time to understand the history of the city inscribed on the stone walls of the first level. Wander around the complex, climb to the top, imagine what it was in its day - ignore the people jostling about. Bayon temple is one of the three top attractions - the other two are Ta Prom and Angkor Wat. You should ensure that your knees and shoulders are covered when visiting the temples as a sign of respect.

Love the faces. After Ta Prohm, this is the most photogenic of the temples in Angkor, with the many giant faces carved into the upper towers of the temple. We loved wandering around here and got some great shots.

Amazing site. This was my favourite site of Angkor and so interesting, the different angles and aspects of the faces were amazing. The sunlight in the hottest part of the day between 11am -1pm made the photos a bit bright so it would be good to visit early morning.

Simply Mesmerising. Bayon Temple is my favourite temple among the temples in Angkor Wat Archeological Park. We were told by our tour guide that the best time to visit is in the morning. Nonetheless, we were there in the afternoon under the scorching sun. The giant stone faces of Bayon were so intriguing. The faces were on all four sides of the tower. It is amazing, as every angle you look at, you will see the smiling faces of Buddha.Definitely a worthy visit despite the heat.
So beautiful. The faces on the temples are so beautiful and intricate. One of the most interesting temples and fairly well maintained.

Great temple. this was the first temple we visited, it was very large and busy but a great one for sure. The temples around it offered a great variety and perspective at what life may have been like in that time.We also did the elephant ride here, it was definitely touristy but fun :)
Interesting. Amazing if you like architecture. The Bayon Temple is up lots of steps you need to be agile to enjoy the trip around all the temples

Incredible Site of Khmer Era. Bayon Temple is located in Angkor Thom not far from Angkor Wat.It's take 15 mins via taxi.The hi-light of this place is Bayon smiling faces.it's around 54 faces.
You can walk and going up to the temple easily to see the Bayon face closer.

Bayon temple visit. This was my second visit to this holy temple of faces and architectural building and I was amazed that the second visit opened new vistas for me that I had missed on my former visit in Oct 2013.My second visit in Oct 2014 there were busloads of Chinese visitors but as they stay for a short time only just be patient and then the Temple is all yours to enjoy and there are one way steps and passages so you wont be forced into tight spots so enjoy this temple as number one on my list of temples.
Stones tell you stories of the Good and the Evil. Beautiful Carvings------ the Majestic bridge entrance, and the serenity of the river moat . These things are unforgettable.
The 4 faces of Budda. Amazing huge temple. Managed to avoid crowds by going very early which meant we could explore pretty much on our own. our guide gave us excellent background information
Unreal Place - amazing. 100% one of the best places I have visited, so interesting and the construction is so amazing. Definitley a once in a lifetime, not to be missed experience!
Peacefully Busy. Yes, a really busy place, bustling with tourists, yet the enormous stone carvings have a peaceful grin that makes it all worth while.
Another place not to miss. good walking areas around temple and many taking photos.fantastic places and carvings.A must see when in the area

A place where you can sit in piece. The place you will be clicking away with many photos, get there early as very busy. Pay the $20 USD but it will be well worth the visit. Get a tuk tuk there and enjoy the day.
Amazing. That's it. Amazing. The temple is just awe inspiring. The trees coming through the temple grounds are crazy and I like that they have left it natural
Awesome. An incredible experience that opens a persons eyes to civilizations past. How people could imagine and construct something so grande and beautiful roughly 1000 years ago is amazing.
run out of words!. go first early in the morning. to avoid large volume of crowds. Its good for taking photos in this time as soft light illuminates those stone faces.

Centuries Old And Still Feels Alive!. This is one of the largest and most impressive temples in the Angkor Thom section of the 'Angkor Wat' complex. It was the first temple we visited and we really loved it. It's got 54 individual pillars with buddha heads looking over you and many of pathways throughout the temple. The engravings are amazing too, you'll have trouble finding a piece of rock that hasn't been worked on!

Our favorite temple, don't miss it!. This temple was the favorite site/temple by the entire family. I think it was all of the faces carved into the temple that intrigued us so much. The size of the temple is easy to navigate. Enjoy the great photo opportunities at the Bayon.

History at its very best. Built around 1190 AD by King Jayavarman VII, Bayon is a Buddhist temple but it incorporates elements of Hindu cosmology.Angkor Thom was built as a square, the sides of which run exactly north to south and east to west. Standing in the exact center of the walled city, Bayon Temple represents the intersection of heaven and earth. Unfortunately its overrun by tourist which not all respect the history and in need of better protection in order to keep in shape for future years to come.

Favourite of them all. My wife and I came here as a part of our own tour that we did of the Angkor Wat Archeological Park. I thought this was the best temple of all. It has such character with the faces and is somewhere you can get lost very easily. While it's not the most intact temple, what is standing is amazing. There was a lot of restoration work going on at the time we visited too so it may end up all in one piece again. This temple is a must in Siem Reap. It also deserves top spot on TripAdvisor. Our tuk tuk driver and hotel both said also it's the best place for sunset!

Favorite temple. I would say, this is my favorite temple from all the temples I saw in Siem Reap. Nice, HIstorical and the intricacy of carvings and how it was made was what made the whole SIem Reap experience memorable.
Awesome. Just plain great so large $20 to see all the temples but you will need a full day you could cycle their but I recommend you pay for tour guide

Amazing!. One of the Angkors that you have to visit when in Siem Reap. We went early and we had awesome photo opportunities without the crowd. So if you want to take photos, I would suggest going about 9 in the morning.

Beautiful, intricate, unique. This temple is beautiful! Large and structurally complex with dozens of beautiful Buddh a faces, this is very much worth going to. This temple is the only one in the area (country?) that includes both Buddhist and Hindu traditions, with many Hindu carvings around a temple adorned with Buddha faces. A truly unique religious structure.

Don't miss it!. Loved the temple and elephant ride! Beautiful temple with a lot of interesting history
A must see while in Siem Reap.
Temple with faces!. An interesting temple, with larger than life sized carvings of the then king all through the temple. The royal touch to the temple is very prominent.
Smiles on different directions. A tour guide told me that Bayon originally had 56 towers but now only a few remains. Those faces have their own unique smiles. Amazing

Gorgeous. We came here after Angkor Wat and it wasn't as crowded as it could have been. I hear sunrise/sunset here is worth seeing, there are massive crowded doing sunrise at Angkor Wat so this may be a good alternative if you don't want to share the moment with 100+ picture-happy people.
I do like the temple. Bayon Temple always give me a heartbreaking feeling. I love it. Amazing Architecture. YOu can also take a tour by elephant and you have pay for some amount.
Amazing. Fabulous place to visit, unbelievable to think that until fairly recently this was covered in jungle
Vaoov. My personal favourite.Really like it.Something like 3D puzzle.Mind boggling...look from different angles and you will see the same thing.

Amazing!. I saw Bayon on my second day in Siem Reap. The first day, we visited 5+ temples or so (the grand circuit), and in the morning of the second day, I had first seen Angkor Wat. Then I went to Bayon. I think Bayon is definitely the most grand, most impressive, and most breath-taking temple of them all, far surpassing Angkor Wat. I wondered why Angkor Wat was so frequently mentioned and commonly known, while Bayon is not, and the answer I got was that the Cambodian government heavily promoted Angkor Wat, but not Bayon. I think Bayon is the true gem of Siem Reap. The #1 attraction, #1 temple of Siem Reap. While I found all the temples to be quite impressive and amazing, my favorite is Bayon because it is so distinct, different, and easily recognizable. It has many towers, and each tower has a large, smiling face on each of the four sides. They really make this temple stand out from the rest. The temple itself is also very large and magnificent. This is definitely the most awesome and memorable temple of them all, and my favorite.

Our Favorite. This temple was our favorite of the many we saw while in Siem Reap. However, get there early, before the tour busses arrive. We got there at 9:00am and even then our experience was spoiled by the huge number of tourists, especially Chinese and Japanese, who we found were more rude than most, and quite pushy, especially by the bus load.

Ancient temple with many faces. Bayon temple is different from other temples in Siem Reap with its many faces all over the temple. We enjoyed the mythical atmosphere climbing in and out through stone stairs and door ways. A very beautiful site.
The faces of the past. Ancient faces everywhere make this one of the best temples to see...our guide took us very early and it was very exciting before the crowds!

Bayon Temple. Worth the effort. A bit difficult if you have mobility issues (as my husband does) but if you have your own guide $35 for approx 6 hrs and your own driver also $35, they will be able to get much closer to the temples for you.

Twelve years on.. It is twelve years since I visted and the temple is still amazing. Our guide tried to get us round avoiding the crowds of Chinese & South Korean's who insist on pushing and shoving past you and expect you to get out of their way when the stop and pose for stupid "Selfie" photos of them in every doorway and window. I am sure they are not really interested in the places they visit only their photos. All said a must to visit.
nice. We temple-hopped so sometimes I don't remember the name of the temples where we went. But I remembered this one because it's the temple with the face depicted in them. Nice :)
“Must see” before Angkor Wat. Good: Famous faces that the unnitiated might associate with Angkor Wat.Fair: Same three-tiered structure as Angkor Wat, so lots of stairs to climb.Bad: Crowds.

Contrast from Angkor Wat amazing. having seen Angkor Wat which was mind blowing, then going across a magical bridge filled with stone carved images of people and entering through a stone carved entrance you finally come to Ben Than, the images that have been made from stone depicting Buddha are truly amazing and every angle has a photo opportunity... My top tip.. Take a large memory card and back up batteries.
Amazing. Must visit , amazing and wonderful temple with massive face . I really loved this temple so much , I will definitely come back in Siem Reap .
Great temple to visit. Bayon temple is one of my favorite temples around the complex. The best way to explore this temple is early in the morning.

Stunning. One of my favourite sites in the Angkor Thom complex. Even the stifling heat and humidity didn't prevent us from exploring this temple from top to bottom. Don't go to Siem Reap without visiting the complex, Angkor Wat is just a small part of what SR has to offer.
Wonderful Buddhist architecture. We visited Bayon late afternoon around 4pm and had the temple to ourselves.The faces are unique to this temple. This is a must see!
Stunning. This was our first introduction to the Angkor Temple area and it didn't disappoint. While there were large crowds, there was still plenty of opportunity to take some good photos.

Must see!. Can tick this from my "to do" list and I recommend hiring a tuktuk for approximately 10-15 dollars day that will take you around,and bring plenty of water when it gets unbearably hot among the stones.

don't go to Siem Reap and ONLY go to Angkor Wat. The Bayon is incredible and otherworldly. The enigmatic faces confront you at every turn, and the bas reliefs are gorgeous. I've seen pictures from the Bayon incorrectly labeled as Angkor Wat, so my mantra is the title -- you will miss SO much beauty if you only plan a visit to Angkor Wat. You should also see, at a minimum, the Bayon, Banteay Srei and Ta Prohm. The crowds were a little lighter at the Bayon, and there is also an option to take an elephant ride around the temple.
Amazing. It is really the piece the resistance inside Angkor Thom - the four faced buddhas are very unnerving and magnificent!

Amazing temple - spoilt by crowds. The temple and the other temples in the complex are stunning. Amazing to see.However, get there early. We arrived about 10am and the whole experience was spoilt by the huge number of visitors, some of whom were pretty rude and inconsiderate.

Crowded but worth it. Very crowded and brutally hot when I went (lesson = go early), as others mentioned there is scaffolding etc throughout various sections. The whole place is run in an interesting fashion. Essentially you can pretty much climb up or on to anything here which for such an historic site I find unusual. There is a very steep stair climb at one section which is fun and gives good views over the site. There are so many temples throughout the park that after a while they tend to blend into one another, therefore pace yourself and enjoy as this is one one of the biggest and most popular of them all.

Beautiful. As all temples are around Siem Reap, Bayon is beautiful. It is awe-inspiring, though I enjoyed it less as I had been to Angkor Wat first and been dumbstruck by the size and history of the place. Definitely worth a visit though.

Angkor Thom. Bayon. A perfect introduction to the Archeological Temples. Manageable without need to scale great heights and full of interesting details. A good guide on a private tour is a must for older travellers and ours was a brilliant photographer too.

cute faces. beautiful temple. the temple is not like Angkor wat. it is different because of the faces. it is very crowded. Chinese people are everywhere but it is worth the visit. and... go in the morning, way too hot in the afternoon

There are no words to describe. Overwhelming and fantastic. A once in a lifetime experience. Arrive early, at 6:00 am or before in order to experience the peaceful quality of this place and to avoid the HOARDS of trourists, many of them pushy and rude.

The Best Kept Secret. While Angkor Wat & Angkor Thom (Tomb Raider) get most of the attention my favorite is Bayon by far. The faces of the temple are so well preserved it is astonishing and unbelievable. I love how you can climb in an out of the different ledges and passes...it feels timeless. This is also great because it is a relatively short visit and great to do after Angkor Wat as they are nearby and usually you feel super tired after that excursion as it can be more than two hours. One thing to be weary of are the people who have made offerings in front of Buddhas. They usually have a $20 bill in a plate and ask for an "offering". Unfortunately this money does not go to pagodas just to their pockets. Don't get alarmed just respectfully decline to donate.

Totally worth it. Very crowded, but totally worth it. You can't miss it. I suggest to start the day (very early) visiting this temple and then continue walking towards the other ones in the same area, as it will be less crowded. Spent around one hour for visiting this temple, and a little bit more than 2 hours for the whole area (Elephant Terrace and sorroundings)
My fav!. We went here just before sunset and the sun was hitting all the different faces of the temple beautifully! I even saw monks taking selfies
the best temple. I like this temple that decoration with tower and all tower have smiling face that open to the four direction and best time to visit early in the morning.
Beautiful. One of my favourite among all the temples on the red line route. It is famous for the four face Buddha status.
Amazing. What is amazing temple was massive face and great in the world , this is all the best memories I will never forget .

Beautiful at night time. I won't repeat what most people have experienced. I once saw Bayon at 2:00 a.m. on Cambodian new year in April 2013 when it was all light up in beautiful blue and yellow tints around the whole temple and my friend and I were only one of four people in the whole temple exploring. It was magical at night. We then waited until 2:12 a.m. for the Cambodian people to open the ceremony at Bayon temple to welcome what they believe were angels to prepare for Cambodian new year. We were probably one of the few non-Cambodians in the crowd so it felt like a truly local experience. But around Bayon area you can get a monk water blessing where they will wish you good fortune and luck as they pour water on you.

Would be better without the crane and construction site!. Bayon as with almost every temple we visited (including Angkor Wat) over 3 full days, had some sort of blue tarpaulin, crane, construction site, huge white sign, etc. at the site. I visited here in April 2004 and remember a crane here and there but not in the number of 2014. As a photographer, it was extremely disappointing, with some of the best vantage points ruined. No thought or time management whatsoever in restoration work.I firmly believe that Cambodia should close all the Angkor sites for a month of the year for restoration work, then pack all the construction work up; just as Machu Picchu is closed for a month of the year. However, this will never happen in Cambodia as the mighty dollar is more important than truly treasuring this amazing area. With over 2 million tourists each year to Angkor Wat, sadly, you can see why it will never be closed!

Beautiful, breath-taking. While visiting the temples in Angkor, am just constantly amazed by the intricate architectural and art work of all the temples. Simply amazing and breath-taking. Please and you must must must, visit the Angkor Wat temples when in Siem Reap.

Find a quiet time if you can. It was too busy to really enjoy Bayon when we were there, a couple of coach loads descended around the same time which was a shame as Bayon is fascinating. The carved heads watching you as you wander seem to need quiet contemplation to really appreciate the beauty of this complex space. I aim to try to find a quiet time and try again.
just excellent. the place to see, just be carefull can be crowed quickly in the morning for the sunrise but really great to be there

Amazing. This site is different from Angkor Wat and also amazing with huge faces carved in the stone. Once again you are in awe of the work carried out building these temples and how they have remained for so long. Awesome!
great. The history, the craftsmanship of the carvings that tell you a story. Truly amazing, these temples are great reminders of the greatness of the Khmer empire.
Super temple. Very nice ancient architecture in the middle of the jungle. Unbelievable, it is one of the must visit place in the world.

Unbievable. We enjoyed our visit here very much. The temple is unbelievable as human masterpiece. With its four face tpwers and bas relief on gallery is amazing especially in the afternoon time with less people in the morning.
Go Early. This is a wonderful Temple. It get's crowded so go early and avoid the crowd. Remember to wear light clothing and take an Umbrella.
Love the ruins. You'd be amazed with these wonderful temples. How they were built before the modern construction machineries and equipment.
Impressive. This is very different from Angkor Wat - you will want to see both. Be sure to dress appropriately so as not to offend the local people - cover your shoulders and your knees.

Sister to Ankor Wat. Great place to visit, better at sunset, slightly quieter if you want to get photo's without others coach parties being in the way or obliviously spoiling your treasured shot.
Enjoy
Awesome temple. I love this temple. It is so impressive and can't help but admire the beauty of it. Took so many pictures to document our tour.

Its the one with four faces. It is equally as amazing as Angkor. Its has its own story to tell and own design to show off.
Again, you will need to be wearing appropriate clothing to get to the top which you would want to miss.
Fabulous.. Just amazing!! Well worth the visit. Try to go early as it can be quiet hot towards the middle of the day.

Late evening visit. We finished out mini tour here and loved it. We had the place to ourselves at around 5pm and it was our favourite of the temples. I advise taking the steps to the top of the temple to see it in it's full glory!
Preferred temple. All temples are unique and this one gives the best example. Easy to access and best to go with a guide to make the most of the visit

Beautiful temple.. Such a beautiful temple , with the face of the Buddha in every corner. I feel this temple is much more magnificent than the Angkor Watt it self , especially for the Buddha face everywhere.
Among the stones. The sense of history and looking back to times gone by. lack of any toilets let alone western toilets can be problematic
My favourite temple. Mysterious faces everywhere you look. Also amazing reliefs. Go direct after the sunrise to this place to be there on your own without the busses of Asian travellers.
Jaw dropping. The temples of Siem Reap are a must see for any traveller. Beautiful beyond belief, words cannot do them justice. I found it more impressive than Angor Wat at times.
Be patient. it is packed... but it worth to try to isolate yourself from the crazynes, enjoy the place and get good photo shots.

Indiana Jones and the temple of dome. If you let your imagination run wild just for a will and you have seen the movie Indiana Jones and the temple of dome it is a very exciting place to visit If you are in good shape to climb up and down those stairs and check out the wonderful hand carvings in the walls, the statues all over the place I am sure you will enjoy your day in Angkor Wat .The place its self is huge ,you need a good days walking maybe more.If you have the time to stay in the town Siem Reap and take a day extra day to visit Angkor .The town its self is quaint lost of little people selling all kinds of stuff, the restaurants are okay ,nothing to write home about.I took a walk just outside the town towards a pig farm following me were 30 little people trying to sell me a long stick for a dollar buy one and keep the peace From my hotel room I had a patio with a beautiful view of the town and the valley below This is really a wonderful place to visit. Pictures to follow .(sorry dyslexic)

Visually busy. This is a pretty crazy temple, hard to take it all in. So much detail in a small area. Must have been amazing when it was new. Quite a few people there, hard to frame a picture with just the rocks. Still worth it though, try to spend time looking at the details and zone the other tourists out.
what lies within. Worth the visit - and as always probably better in the cooler (morning) part of the day. More detailed carvings here.

Not to be missed. This is one of the most beautiful temples in the Angkor complex with huge carvings of Buddha faces on the temple facade. From afar the intricacy of the carvings is difficult to notice but once you climb the flight of stairs and reach the inner precinct of the temple, you can see the the details and the beautiful expression on each face. Don't miss this one at any cost.
Tree & temple, power of nature. "maybe neglected temple" being wrapped and conquered by banyon trees. The trees are much bigger and taller. One of a kind and is a must see.

So cool and photo opertunities at every bend. Its really warm and don't forget to take good walking shoes, but great to exploreSo many hidden walkways and temples, amazing place. Be ware of students trying to play guide and ask for money...
Must see.. This Temple is a must see. You must stop here in your touring of Angkor Wat. I want to return to Angkor and see more, but I would see this again on a return visit.
Interesting and Impress. It is huge and carvings is meaningful. A good places for archeology. The carvings picture and the life and workforce during ancient empire of Cambodia.

Unbelievable Experience. Like all of the temples and architectural wonders that make up the whole Angkor experience, the Bayon temple sits in quiet serenity and reminds you that people walked here before...

Come and prove it yourself. I was here today and it was very tiring climbing up and down the stairs (especially after visiting every corner of Angkor Wat). But it's totally worth it!Come and prove it yourself!

smiling faces of bodhisattava and 51 small towers surrounded to bayon temple.incorporate element of hindu cosmology. beautiful place and views.liked different smiling faces and 51 tower surrounding bayon and it incorporate element of hindu cosmology
One of the best kept secrets in the world. My main purpose of visiting Siem Reap was to see the Angkor Wat. Bayon, though, is more stunning with its giant face statues, some of them look alive (!!)
Probably Great, but our view was obscured. A fair portion was under restoration scafolding so we moved on quickly. But not before a tourist cop sold me his badge...

A must do!. Simply my favourite temple in Angkor.
A must do! Just beautiful and majestic. This is the famous temple appearing in Tomb Raider.
Beautiful. I really liked and enjoyed seem Bayon Temple. Remember to take an umbrella for sun protection and water.
An ancient wonder for sure. Like all the Angkor temples this one was uniquely special. Many towers with huge faces. Great photo opportunities. Big area to wonder.

Don't miss this place!!. This place is so amazing and one of my favorite. The structure was amazing and beautiful. Don't forget your hat because it so hot there. Walk around and go to the top see at the bayon face and guess what is it that smile? :D

One of my favourites!. If your visiting the temples defiantly don't give this one a miss,
It's beautiful, you can ride round on elephant back (which we didn't as we think it's cruel!)
one of the musts. I went there in the rain. Dark and wet. I felt like those faces on the pagodas were watching me everywhere I went. :) Love it.
Great Temple. Liked the faces carved at temple top, its must visit when u in siem reap, i am sure you will love the great architecture.
Very Nice Place. Nice historical place to visit. Be prepare to walk on uneven surface, remember to wear a good shoe and enjoy the hot sun shine.

Magnificent!!. Its one the best places I have visited. Really historic. Amazing structure with faces on the pillars. A $20 per day ticket for all the temples around Angkor is worth spending. Slightly tougher with young children, but overall worth visiting.

Magnificient. Bayon Temple is one of the major temples in the Ankor Wat area and well worth a visit.Lots of climbing steep stairs so you need to be fit and healthy.It's unbelievable how this structure was build and such a magnificient piece of architecture.Tope 3 temples in my opinion you MUST see are: Bantaey Srei, Ta Phrom, Bayon and Ankor Wat

Best Temple in the Angkor Area. Absolutely gorgeous. The four face towers are so imposing and unique. One of my favourite historical sites in the world! It's a busy site so get there as early as possible to avoid the horde of tourists visiting this site daily.
Very interesting. It was very interesting to see this temple. Try and go early to beat the heat and crowds. I would recommend going with a guide.
Amazing faces. Angkor was the best sacrified place I have ever seen in my life. I don't have to recommend it. Bayon is one of the most important "wat" to see there.

Great Place. Make sure you have a guide with you. We had Dany from AboutAsia and what a wonderful experience he provided in making Bayon come alive for us. Get a great tour guide to truly explore this magnificent place.

Very comfortable stay. I like the place, very clean, good facilities, friendly and helpful staff, I feel safe staying there. Thanks to the staff there.The place is near to Pub Street, very convenient place

Just incredible. First things first. Get there early or it will be over run with tourists, but what do you expect.As with all the temples in the Angkor area, this place took my breath away. The engineering that went into this and all the temples for that matter is awe inspiring. Just couldn't stop taking photos!We were lucky enough to have a local guide show us round the whole complex which I would thoroughly recommend. It's ok gawping and taking photos, but the background information gained the guide was invaluable

Captivating faces. After the huge Ankor Wat complex, the compactness of Bayon comes as a relief. All the better for concentrating on those fascinating faces on the towers. There are over 50 towers, each has four faces on it. What faces! Serene, with a enigmatic smile to compete with Mona Lisa's and all captivating. Everywhere you turn, there is one smiling at you!
The best one. I was in Cambodia looking for Angkor Wat but Bayon was incredible! When I arrived there I couldn't believe my eyes
The south gate and the north gate are top!!!. 2 days are just enough to do the small tour and the large one. I did the first in 2013 and the second this year :-) So much emotion !

Beautiful. This is also a must. The faces are very nice and make a unique temple in comparison to others in the area.
You can about crowds starting your tour and following the "alternate way" that is shown in several maps posted along de area.
Incredible. Enjoyed the visit especially the carving on the agllery of the temple and all the faces of the towers but the little bit crowded
Quite amazing. Very nice Temple. Must visit. Unique architecture. Simply loved it. Don't forget to take your camera. Highly recommended.
Beautiful place. Liked it all, it was hot, but this is SE Asia! Great examples of the four faced pillars here. Close to the other temples too!
fascinating visit. The bas reliefs carved into the stone tell stories of mythology, daily life and religion. Fascinating. The carved faces also give the place a creepy/mystical atmosphere!

Must see. Get a quality guide for $30 per day to help you make decisions on which of the 54 temples to visit. Bayon Temple is large and requires help to understand what you are seeing. It is a must see.

My favourite temple. I have visited the temples around Siem Reap twice over a 5 year period, and both of these times Bayon has been my clear favourite.It's strikingly different to any other temple, and the detail in the sculpting of the faces is really quite amazing when you consider the tools that must have been used.If you are visiting Siem Reap make sure you visit this temple, its truly beautiful.

It gets better as you ascend.. Some parts of the temple are under construction, but do ascend to the higher grounds. The view is such better. Also, there will be "temple guardians" aka guide that you will need to pay once they voluntarily join you and explain the history (without you asking).

Wow!. There are many smiling faces in this temple. So beautiful and unique because very green surrounding temple, many trees with nice maintain. All the faces look like Buddha with happy faces, and welcome to everybody there.I really happy to visit Cambodia especially to see this temple. You shouldn't miss this place if you miss something in your life.

What the jungle gave up. The temple was amazing, I particularly liked the wall carvings which told a story. The heads carved out of stone were also stunning.
I didn't like the fact that some steps were quite steep and there were no handrails on some of them.

Hauntingly beautiful even in ruins. Another one of the most famous temples in Siem Reap, some heads of the towers here are in very good condition, despite the vandalism that this temple was subjected to by Cambodia's invaders. It's not as hot here as compared to Angkor Wat because of the denser trees present. But overall, the weather is still very warm at this time so don't forget to rehydrate and a comfy, cooling piece of garment is recommended.

Amazing enigmatic faces. Great place to take some great pictures. Can be hot so take lots of water with you. The locals sitting in the temples will try to give you a small red bracelet to wear. Take note this is not for free they expect some money for the bracelet.

get a guide. Nothing to dislike time visit to avoid the crowds, especially the Chinese who do not seem to be able to comply with the local rules regarding litter, smoking, and being respectful of the temples.
Best of the lot. Bayon, in my opinion, is the best of all the temples in the area. Incredible face carvings. We came back the next day.
A Must See of the Angkor temples. Amazing how there are about 200 faces carved in the towers and that you can still see them many hundred years later

Really great and quite eerie. Liked Bayon a lot. I reckon its on par with the Angkor Wat temple, although I felt that the Ta Phrom temple was slightly better.It is quite eerie seeing all the faces peering out into the jungle but its a great monument and make sure you take loads of photos, the ones you see don't do it justice! Watch out for some of the stairs as well, we went when it was very wet...little dodgy at times!!

The most impressive for me.. I take with me, sealed these amazing four sided faces.nThis a truly one of a kind place.Not to be missed. Try very early morning and cash in your pockets as it cost $20 per person to go in.

My favorite temple. This was my favorite temple. There are so many temples you can see in Angkor Wat and they can all start looking the same. It's a great template to wander around and look at all the faces. It's definitely worth a visit.
Amazing!. Bayon is very unique temple in Cambodia. There are many smiling faces and really happy face. Greatest place in the world.

Temple with the giant heads of the Buddha. Interesting temple, but I think I would have been fine just seeing Angkor, that was well worth it, this was fine, but I was getting tired since it was so hot and muggy outside and all of these temples start looking the same to me.

Loved it. Beautiful temple, less visited than Angkor Wat. We went here by bike from Siem Reap and loved the tranquility and all the faces which are featured. I would recommend visting this temple and Ta Prohm over Angkor Wat. We visited all temples by bike, coming from Siem Reap, and would reccomend this to everyone who is able to ride a bike in a hot and humid environment.
Amazing. This temple is huge with lots of corridors and doorways to explore, the carved faces and wall friezes are fabulous!

One of the temples worth a visit. Very impressive. After five weeks in Vietnam and Thailand we were pretty "templed out" so only did one day of temple visiting when we were in Siem Reap, fortunately this was one we visited, We got here early so it was not too crowded. Much of the massive restoration project has been completed so the full glory of the place can be appreciated. If you don't use a guide, try and listen to someone else's explain the carvings in the stone walls.
Amazing Temple. Amazed at the detail of this temple. So much to discover with the help of a knowledgeable guide. Could not stop taking photos.
Amazing. Get there early, and go to this one first. The crowds tend to arrive later. Spend time and take in every site, step and stone!
Temple to start with. We started here and this temple is very impressive... Very big area to explore (basic climbing skills recommended)... Do not miss out to visit this one when in Ankhor!

Good for history and achitecture buffs, a photographer's heaven.... Good for history and architecture buffs, a photographer's heaven...Highly recommended...Good to have a guide here to explain the scriptures on the walls of the perimeter surround it.

Amazing. What is there not to like about Bayon temple?! Nada. You can't complain about the heat, just bring the necessary sun protection & drink lots of water, unless you want to tell mr.sun to stop shining

My second favourite temple on the Angkor complex and a must visit. You will need to buy a ticket to visit the temples of Angkor from the one and only onsite main ticket office. A ticket is valid for entry to all temples on the complex, you cannot buy a ticket just for one temple. A one day ticket is $20, a three day is $40, and a 7 day is $60. The ticket will have your photo on it so it is non transferable.Outside your hotel negotiate with a tuk-tuk driver to hire him for a day for $20-$25. He will take you around all the temples you want. Pay him at the end of the day. He will wait for you outside each temple.My favourite temple is 'Ta Prohm' (Tomb Raider Temple) where the trees grow through the temple. This is my second favourite temple.As per other comments this temple is the one with many heads and makes for some stunning photos. Over the course of time this temple is doing well and is standing strong, although there is some restoration work going work.Depending on personal choice you can hire a guide to explain to you everything, or you can take a guide book with you and read about it as you stand there, or you can just find somewhere nice to stand or sit and enjoy it for what it is.Even if you have just one day this is a must visit temple
Bayon - unique and unforgettable. Bayon is the 'face' temple - a 'must see' in Angkor - if you don't have much time, make time for this one.

You wont enjoy the scene if its too crowded. I was really amazed on the stone faces with different facial expression. In fact, it was our first destination of our tour. Make sure you come here at around 7 am to avoid too much people.
Excellent Temple. We loved wandering through this temple and would highly recommend it as one of the must see temples.
Awesome and inspiring. What a temple!! Awesome, magnificent, inspiring, stunning, etc. No amount of superlatives is superfluous. Another temple definitely worth a second visit.

The temple with the many faces. We immediately went here after witnessing the sunrise in Angkor Wat to avoid the crowds. Bayon seems to be in better shape than a lot of the other temples and the faces on the walls were really very interesting.
Great temple. interesting and really neat! Definitely recommend seeing when in siem reap. We enjoyed seeing the different faces all over the temple. We had an english speaking guide which was helpful
Highly Recommend. Stunning temple part of the Angkor Wat temple complex.. amazing! Definately a must see on the bucket list!
On the must do list. Very impressive and a must whilst in the area. Easy to reach from Siem Reap, Need to spend a half day here

Absolute classic but in shambles. The architecture style is remarkably unique, polylithic sculptures( if I may call it so) Images carved out from stacks of stones..The symetry of the four faces on four sides of the stone stacks is amazing.. But they are all tottering..and very less effort seems to be in place to preserve them..Lots of miscellneous stones found spread all over the place ..Again her, there is no inscriptions explaining the story behind these breathtaking monuments
Just beautiful.... Mesmerized by the temples in Siem Reap! Would love to see it again in the future. It felt magical being able to walk around this UNESCO Heritage site.

Favourite Temple. This place was my favourite temple in the park which should tell you something! It looks amazing from the outside and there are so many places for great photos. There are around 300 smiling buddhas around the outside and it is just an amazing place to be!Beautiful and breathtaking - this is the place to focus the most of your time in the park!
Amazing!. Loved it, it's a must see! A little crowded, and not for anyone with mobility issues, but a definite otherwise.
Unbelievable!!. Gorgeous and atmospheric. Definitely get to this one. Loads of really cool stories around the wall. Get a guide to translate them for you.
It's the peaceful place.. I do like everything! Everything is perfect for me! The sculptures look so so real, the art on the walls, It's just perfect! I know a lot of beautiful Khmer cultures.
Fabulous temple, smiling Buddha faces. Nice places to visit and take pictures at Bayon temple. Bayon temple would be the temple you should not miss.
Temple of the 214 Buddha faces. Impressive temples with over 50 towers that had 4 faces of Buddha on 4 sides. One of my favorites in the Archaeological Park.

One of the highlights of Angkor Thom. We wandered around the Bayon Temple for a little over one hour taking many photos. We thoroughly enjoyed it. It is hard to believe that so many people lived in the area nearly one thousand years ago and then abandoned it.

This place needs saving. Bayon is another architectural marvel just a short ride away from Angkor wat. This is a Buddhist temple with Buddha sculpted in 215 different expressions. The temple is very small compared to Angkor wat and the is crowded beyond belief all the time. It's very difficult to walk around to see the temple and a lot of tourists climb around to go around and finish their trip. This is very bad for the already crumbling temple. I hope the Government can close down this temple for restoration or at least regulate the number of tourists who visit this monument until it is fully restored. This place seriously needs Saving..

Budha watches over. One of the places I visited during my recent visit in Cambodia. Beautiful as any other historical buildings in Cambodia. Each tower has four faces of Budha facing four directions. There is a significant meaning for this, by looking at each direction Budha protects the countries in that direction as mentioned by our tour guide. Must visit place in Cambodia I would add..Cheese....
Must see!. This temple is a must on your trip to Angkor. Great carvings. I recommend a guide to see all of the temples.
Majestuous Bayon. You can visit and revisit Ankor's temples you have always so places to discover, some marvels to look -
beautiful temple. it is a historical architecture and has beautiful architecture. It is amazing to see that intricacy of the architecture.
Smaller than Angkor Wat. After Angkor Wat, Bayon would be the temple that you should not miss. Get a guide to walk you through the story of the place, especially the story on the bas relief.
stunning. such a beautiful temple! amazing carvings and a great place to explore! Took lots of pictures and really enjoyed our time here
Must see. The most amazing temple in Siem Ream. At every turn, you come face to face to with elaborately carved faces. A must see!
Beautiful!. What can I say, the marvelous architecture, intricate carvings and design. The stories etched into stone. I am a huge history buff and this place is like a playground to me!

All the Beauties in the World... A must visit in Angkor, blow-minding architecture. Be lost in its maze-like small coridors, while admiring the reliefs. Make sure that you climb up to upper terrace to be awed by the 'thousand' faces every time you turn your head. Magnificent!!
Panggah
Jogja, Indonesia

The best of Angkor. As the trees clear the wonderful face towers of the Bayon temple come into view. This is easily the best temple yet. The carvings on the outer and inner gallery walls are spectacular and it takes three separate visits today to see everything. I spent more than two hours walking around the long galleries trying to take in all the drama unfolding, from the various battle scenes and processions to the forests, lakes and rivers full of fish. Climbing up to the open third level the feeling changes dramatically, replacing the delicate carved reliefs below are the huge, calmly smiling face towers.
beautiful. All the temples in the Angor Wat complex are beautiful. It is worth exploring and appreciate the details.
Beyond. expensive entrance....not enough place for those who wish to rest. Elderly folks cant do much walking and climbing but there is nowhere for them to wait for others who wants to see more.
Serene Faces. My favorite temple! The faces are fascinating, a must see. The carvings tell stories of ancient battles. I could spend all day there.
A must. Ankorian temples have long been on my bucket list. I was not disappointed. The scale and magnificence of the architecture knows no bounds
Huge!. In the heart of Angkor Thom. Amazingly beautiful. Carvings everywhere. One of my fav temple to visit. Please be reminded not all temples are near a washroom.

Blew my mind!!!. I loved this place you must go, See for yourself Amazing to see I could not believe you can climb all over the temple. The intricate details of the carvings ate fantastic, I can only imagine what these must have looked like when they were first built.
Amazing. the carvings in the rock here are incredible. We had an elephant ride round this temple which added to its atmosphere

My favorite Temple!. My travel guide had such an interesting way of telling us the stories at this Temple that it enhanced our experience. All the smiling faces dating from such a long time ago makes you wonder what are they smiling about. A must to visit!

Great temple to visit, our favourite. We could not help but take photos of every corner and every wall of this temple. There is just so much to see and appreciate and as a result, this is our favourite temple from the Angkor Wat complex. Best to go early in the morning or late afternoon as there is little shade.
Favourite temple. The most impressive of Angkor's temples in my opinion - but it gets crowded. Try to get here at sunrise, when everyone else is at Angkor Wat!

Best of Siem Reap.. Without doubt it was the high point in Siem Reap. its a small temple undergoing much restoration, but it strikes u very well.
Must go and more than that must be preserved for the next generations...

Fantastic temple. All jaw-dropping stuff. Very busy. Just incredible. I hope that the Cambodian authorities look after all these temples so that they continue to cause many jaws to drop in the future!
Worth all the travelling.. The guides are full of fascinating information and the history that you pick up on site makes you want to do follow up studying back at home.
awesome. This temple was so beautiful. A definite must see and not far from the city center at all. It was about 20 minutes from our hotel and was right next to Angkor Wat.
Well worth the visit. Liked exploring the exterior and interior which is fascinating. Seeing all the human faces on the walls is amazing.

Joint best temple of the entire trip. I must admit, I hadn't even heard of Bayon before arriving in Cambodia although I had SEEN it. I think I'd assumed all temple photos were of Angkor Wat!Whereas Angkor Wat is huge, with well preserved religious carvings and impresses - and exhausts - with it's sheer scale, Bayon is by comparison smaller, easier to relate to and for me at least, much more photogenic.The carvings here relate to daily life rather than mythological events and it's fun looking at the walls and trying to make sense of what's going on. From people playing chess, to farming, you can wander around and continually find little motifs that take a couple of seconds to understand but leave you with a smile when you've figured it out. Spotting Buddha faces is also a good pastime and it's really hard to not keep snapping photos of their serene smiles.So whereas Angkor Wat is the temple that gets all the attention, for me Bayon was better preserved in some places and much more fun to visit. Ta Prohm is also superb, like Bayon, and is the flipside - a temple that HASN'T survived and has been overwhelmed by nature. Definitely make sure you do both.There are no facilities, like with the majority of temples, and nowhere to get food/drink unless you head to the stalls outside Angkor Wat (a good 10 mins drive away). Bring some water with you. On the plus side there are no souvenir-selling annoyances either as they loiter around the bigger name places.For a good photo, after it has been raining, check out each of the four corners of the temple from the surrounding road. You can often get a pretty cool reflection of the temple in the waters nearby.You can also get elephant rides for $15pp from the shops just outside the Angkor complex south gate to Bayon (or back), or an alternate shorter ride around Bayon. The elephants looked to be well cared for and it was nice to be able to stroke them after our ride. Massively touristy but there's something about riding an elephant that's always a bit special.Definitely a highlight of the region
Not for the aged or infirm. Lower level easy enough to negotiate but the steep steps are not for everyone. The temple is lovely and very interesting
A must !. This was my second visit to the Bayon. It is part of the tale of how impressive must have been the Khmer Empire, a thousand years ago.
Must visit. Excellent place to wander around and soak in the beauty of the ruins. Situated in the middle of a large green patch, the whole place has a calming effect on the mind.

Suggestion, go in the morning. Very pretty temple! My suggestion would be to go in the morning.. A lot of tourists go back to their hotels for breakfast after sunrise. Instead of that, I would recommend to go see the temples so there would be less people around.
Amazing. The feeling I get in a place like this is what makes life so wonderful!Extraordinary, let yourself get involved, relax, enjoy! VIsit early in the day or after 4pm.
photographer's delight. quite in ruins. a temple to watch from a distance and appreciate. faces everywhere. very photogenic ruins. lots of nooks and corners to explore.
Smiling. It is a peaceful temple looking at the smiling faces of the Buddha. The pathway can be narrow especially if there are many visitors.

Great exploring. This is one of our favorite Temples. You can roam around the ruins and discover all sorts of different things. Of course you need to take your picture with the face but figure out first where it is. Great time

Impressive. I visited Angkor in 2010. In Angkor, I am impressed by The Bayon most. 216 faces on the temple's towers were sculptured on massive stones. Most of faces still keep their sharp curves. When I wandered around, I saw some Apsaras, all were young girls and very friendly. They were preparing for the next performance. Everything here made a feel of peace and ancient. A must-see place!

Don't miss it. Our favourite of the temples- this is iconic and a absolute marvel to scramble over. The image will live longn in your mind let alone the 100s of photos you will not be able to resist taking

Go early and take your time. The tombs/ statues were enormous and you'll really feel like you've entered a different world upon seeing it. We were there early in the morning (about 630am) and were amongst the very few people there. Majority of the crowd would be at Angkor Wat during this time. At first it felt eerie, but after the sun rises and we started exploring, it was really peaceful and surreal. Take some time to read up about the whole Angkor Archeological Park and their history before exploring and you'll kinda understand why the Bayon Temple is built the way it is. Why the workmanship is considered crude compared to the works in Angkor Wat.Don't forget to bring sturdy shoes/ sneaker, mosquito repellants, hats and lots of drinking water. Snacks and small breakfast is good too so that you can maintain your energy while climbing. Just remember not to litter. And take your time. The jewels are hidden in the carvings.
The top has an amazing view. Loved this temple, recommend you do in the morning with a guide, so much more interesting to be listening and looking rather than reading as you go.
hot but amazing. This temple is fantastic. The images care incredible. Take lots of water for the visit. Be prepared for the crowds. You can go all over the temples no restrictions.

Incredible. The temples in Angkor in general are amazing and what I like best about them is that you can walk right inside these ancient ruins. We visited in late September and it was hot...as you will spend lengthy periods wlking around wear a good sun screen and flat sandals or shoes as the going is rough underfoot.

Serene!!. this is the starting point of the small circuit tour and the start blows your mind off.It is a well preserved temple, the giant carved faces each different from other gets you spell bounded. I would recommend people to carry a small torch as that will help you explore some magnificent corners of the temple.Turn on: Beauty, cleanliness, well managed, proper Signage.turn off: None
216 faces!. This temple is full of peaceful, smiling faces. 216 in all. I spent about 45 min wandering around. Take a photo nose to nose with one of the 216!
Wonderful. Unbelievable and fantastic place, I like to visit this temple especially at the late afternoon as it is quiet from the crowded people during the morning

Temple complex.. Strange feeling to see the tree roots trying to strangle all the buildings. Had a wonderful ride on a lovely elephant around the Temple complex. These animals are loved, - - - - are treated gently and it's great to see.

Giant faces. Bayon was a wee bit less impressive than the photos make it out to be. That's because with the naked eye one cannot discern the detail as is possible with a telescopic lens. But that doesn't make it any less grand

great. Get a GUIDE! Worth it do NOT do it alone! Loved the fact that the guides are Gvt TRAINED in their history and can go back to the 1st Century. We had Buffalo Tours' guide Nimol and he and his staff were 5 star! Point to make....do NOT go to Cambodia if you want to be a tight! The people are extremely poor so have a dose of western humility! A wonderful country steeped in history!

Very impressed . The site and the story of the temple and Palace is impressive. We visited the restoration works and a professional explanation from the architect that is responsible for the work. If you think about the history of this place you understand that the history is not change all the time there is a conflict between the poor people and the reach. This site is a must visiting this region. Thanks to Ann tours that arrange it. Do they miss the elefan ride

One of my favourite temples. Could have spent a lot longer here just looking at the various images of buddha - stunning. Visited in the afternoon, crowds weren't too bad and our private guide knew best spot for the photos.
Another fabulous temple. Brilliant, another one to go to within the Angkor area, the carved faces are stunning. So much to see you eventually run out of time, allow plenty

Stunning. This temple is amazing and is a must see when in Cambodia. Takes your breath away and is brilliant for taking great photos. Very hot even in the shade. Dress in cool, comfortable clothes and bring a hat.

Best Temple. This is by far the best site. You should also bring a book about Bayon and wander around. The site itself is small but you'll find a wealth of images and stone work to keep you occupied for hours.

Great to visit but VERY NOISY. The place was crawling with over excited PRC tourists scuttling around because they MUST stand in front of EVERY "face" so that they appear in EVERY picture they shoot, and then try to get into EVERY picture of YOU shoot too... Dream on but you can burn any hopes of finding any spiritual feel - not in the company of constant irritation (and that's when I understand their language...) Still... no reason to not visit. The Bayon is in fact a must-see in Angkor! Do some reading first before you go. It helps.
Amazing. Another amazing attraction, I loved all the faces here, there were some great photo opportunity everywhere, a must at the park

Stupendous!. An amazing archeological site! Perhaps best to start the grand tour of Angkor with this site. Going early helps by beating the crowds, and maybe the heat as well, but anyways you're going to get both to some degree when you're visiting Siem Reap!
The site itself is beautiful, keep at least and hour plus to see this site.
Worth an elephant ride around to get some great views of this temple.. Fascinating to go through with a guide who explains the carvings and history. Definitely worth seeing.
My Favorite!. The faces of bliss are amazing. Don't leave without going here!! Do it! I like it best at sunset (hire Mr. How to drive you in his tuktuk).

Amazing. An amazing temple with so many towers, but it was so busy that there was not really chance to appreciate much of it and very few opportunities to take photos. I would suggest getting here very early-temples are open from 5.30am I think. Possibly go here for sunrise rather than joining the crowds at Angkor Wat

Worth of time. I think Banyon was more than exciting than Angkor Wat. You should visit there by the elephant. Very historic and green..
You can take very exciting photo shots.
Must visit if you were in Siem Reap.

a must-see temple.. I have liked everything. I guess it is one of the most popular Temples in Angkor Thom, we were lucky, cause it was a low season and it was not crowded at all, so we could peacefully enjoy the temple almost on our own.
day at Bayon. The historical nature and cultural aspects - not to be missed. Make sure you do it with a guide. Too much to be missed without one,

A real window into the past. No knowledge of the Khmer language is needed to see how the Angkor Khmer lived nearly a thousand years ago, to just look at the carvings and see their whole life and society is breathtaking.It is almost beyond belief how far advanced this people were in their skill in making nature work for them and controlling it to create the most advanced civilisation on the planet in its time.It does get crowded but you just have to be patient and give yourself plenty of time, certainly more than a couple of hours

54 faces of History staring back at you - superb temple. This was the last of the temples of the tour - and was a great way to end the morning. The kings faces just follow you - and the majority are well preserved. Our guide knew exactly where to stand to get this great picture of my hubby and a stone face to be nose to nose.

Incredible carvings. I loved the temples! Found them to be very fascinating with the building of them to the craftmanship of the carvings and how they are still so good after centuries of weather and more recently, war. Could have spent days going through the temples.
Superb temple with amazing smiling faces. You've gotta see this one. More than worth the hype. Try to see how many smiling faces you can get in one photo. This was my favorite temple in Cambodia.
Temple of Faces. The temple of the faces, could just keep taking photos all day, give yourself 2-3hrs to do it justice. Can get very crowded, varies on the day.
Unbelieveable. What a fabulous temple. All of the ones we visited had something special about them but Bayon was a favourite as it is just so haunting with all the faces. You must see it.

Beautiful Peaceful Wonderful. By far my favourite temple complex. The temples are stunning but it is the walk through the jungle and the quiet, serene atmosphere that makes this perfect. I will treasure the memories and will come back time after time.
Beautiful but more advance state of disrepair. This temple is beautiful but in a greater state of decay than some others and the repair work being undertaken looks a bit odd
Beautiful. Wonderful temple. A lot of climbing up stairs wear Sun screen. There are elephant rides around the temple for $20 early in the day

Majestic Stone Faces greet you. All the towers have gigantic stone faced carvings.Doorways, windows with amazing work of art & architecture.Need at least 1 hour at this site for appreciating this awesome temple. This temple too has lot of vendors pestering to buy souvenirs, specially children . Buy from 1 girl, within minutes another girl will appear start requesting to buy from her and at lesser price ! We had a girl who followed us to our tuk tuk & finally I had to give in & buy fridge magnets from her too.

Smiling faces.. This is a wonderful temple which has many King's faces who smile and look at us everywhere. Please take your good camera with you if you go there. I will have a great chance to take a lot of photos.

My favorite temple of Angkor!. This is most amazing temple I have ever seen in my life, probably I have not seen other beautiful temples but I must say that you must not miss to visit this beautiful and mysterious temple in your life.The whole temple is full with four face Buddha tower and I seriously don't understand how Khmer people built it perfectly 1000 years ago. The whole Bayon temple tour just makes you feel that you are in the Indiana Jones or Tomb Raider movie. If you wanna know more about the history origins of the temple you might need to pay a little bit to a tour guide to tell you more about the Bayon story, it is really worth it!
Another great temple. I went here on my second day at the temple complex. I really enjoyed the trip and was able to get some great pictures.

The best temple, and the only one worth seeing. It's The best temple, and the only one worth seeing.
This is the only temple with the four-sided faces.
Looks cool and special.
Worth coming with a tour guide to a tour in the temples area,
I felt like it added a lot to our visit there. And wasn't expensive - 40$ A guide for the 2 of us.
Bayon Temple. The Towers with Bhudda faces on four sides are very beautiful and very sacred. You feel honoured to be at this placd
One of the Best Temples in Siem Reap. Awesome Temple. Make sure you pay a little extra to get a personal guide, worth it to find out more about the history.

Outstanding!. An absolutely awe inspiring temple. So much so that we went for a second visit 2 days after our first visit.The whole place makes you question just how anyone could do all the building work, carvings etc. It really does make you respect what's in front of you and also baffles you when you think it was built approximately 900 years ago.An absolute must visit!!!
Many faces temple. Good photo shooting place but have a lot of barricades to avoid people damaging the facades. Need more restoration work to preserve it.
Faces everywhere watching you. Masterpiece. One of the finest temples in sieam reap. To understand the history, cravings, take a guide.
Ancient temple. climp up to staircase are quite dangerous. The temple are very quiet no much people praying. No much tourists around.
One of the Best Temples in Siem Reap Area. Smiling Buddhas - lot of them and plenty of great photo ops. A must see when in Siem Reap. Elephant ride around the perimeter is great for the kids
Temple with faces. This is a pyramid style temple with lots of levels. Very interesting with wall engravings and faces sculpted into the rocks.
Smiling faces. I liked this more than angkor wat. I don't know if it is because of the more jungle location or all the smiling faces looking in all directions.
Interesting place!. Visited this temple and it was worth the visit! I would recommend to visit most of the temples as it was worth it.

Awe inspiring. The remains of a grand design and it retains the majesty of thought and deeds. Take time and immerse yourself in the beauty and vastness of Bayon temple complex. Enjoy the clean and friendly eating houses when needed. It is not a place for rushing. Your trip should last at least three days.
