Massive heads. My favourite temple and the size of the faces is incredible. I was in awe of the builders and their vision. Photo opportunities are everywhere but their are a couple of locals who for a couple of bucks can show you where to be some classics. Take your time as it can be a bit exhausting and take plenty of water.
Awesome Antiquity. Go to this one first while the rest of the crowd are hanging around Angkor looking for the sunrise picture. A truly magical atmosphere.
One of the wonders of the world. walk around the outside to see the bas reliefs before you go up to see the magnificent "faces" We went twice since the normal tour wasn't enough

Spectacular Temple. The Bayon Temple really is spectacular. After visiting Angkor Wat you would expect that the next thing on the list would be a disappointment but this is not. Only a few miles from Angkor Wat, this temple is in the Angkor Complex. The Bayon Temple is famous for its 51 towers with four faces on them. But you should also visit the dancing gallery and see the wall carvings. The ornate carvings depict what life was like in e 12th century with the Cambodian people fighting and playing along side the Chinese. Once you get into the temple it seems like every nook has a view towards one of the many faces of Bayon. As with many of the temples, some destruction has happened. Buddhas have been removed to be replace with Shiva lingas when the Hindus came into power. There are some steep stairs here and if rainy can be slippery.
Again - awesome!. You have to see for yourself. It is just too amazing to put in to words what this is like - expect to see loads and loads of tourists though.

One of the three must see temples.. This was an amazing labyrinth of face carvings resulting in some wonderful pictures. We didn't have a guide for this one, so if you want the history, get a guide. Restoration work being done, but it didn't really impact our visit. The rain helped.....keep the tourist numbers down.
Stunning. A stunning temple, visited this as part of a 3 day tour and could have stayed for hours, even though it was incredibly hot
Awesome. Between this and Angkor Wat, the two most accessible large temples for a day outing of Siem Reap. Very touristy but if you get there at early morning hours you should be good.

Unbelievable. Almost 20 years I plan to visit this temple I really don't know how much I can say how can Cambodia's people can built this this temple, even I hire a guise to tell me the reason why the temple has been built. I really wanted to spend h hold life to study about this. I really recommend to everyone must come to siem ream and learn more about history of Cambodia
Awesome. This is a very interesting temple. It has face carvings everywhere and is very beautiful. We enjoyed our visit here very much.

Carvings were excellent. One of my top three places in Angkor Wat - the others being Preah Khan and Ta Prohm. Loved the head and wall relief carvings. IF YOU HAVE LIMITED TIME (or don't want to spend $40 on a two-day pass), just visit these three and maybe Angkor Wat itself if time permits.

Temple of faces...one of the best for exploring & pictures. The Bayon Temple, newer than many of the others, is surrounded by dozens of faces which are fun to explore and also can make for incredible pictures. I am amazed that over all the years, the faces are still in such great shape. Another great thing about this temple is that there aren't as many stairs to climb and by the end of the day, this was very welcome. Another secret and if you are there with a good guide, he/she can tell you...there is a pond out back (or maybe smaller/bigger depending on the rain) and similar to Angkor Wat, you can get a great reflective picture of the temple in water.

restoration still in progress. Maybe we pick the wrong time to visit. There must be hundreds of group of tourists crowding the small area of Bayon that is already restored. And tourists does what tourists did, taking pictures, everywhere they think they can. Even when it's almost impossible to even walk without bumping into another person's shoulder.The temple is still so far from finishing its restoration. The stairs were steep and dangerous, I wouldn't recommend this place for families with small children.
must see. nice elephant rides, interesting place to see, details of sculptures. not much tourists in september

Important part of the Temple tours.. It's hard to pick which temple you should spend more time in as there are so many things to see.I suggest either a guide or a bit of research so the significance can be appreciated.

Face it, this is a awesome place. Bayon was the first of our temples to visit in 2 full days in Siem Reap. It was also my 50th birthday so was even more special, especially with the elephant ride first thing in the morning. This temple of many faces was always going to be special...and it didn't disappoint. Very popular even in August when it was very very hot (even for Adelaide, South Australia standards!). So many photo opportunities, faces everywhere, and doorways and detail. This one is an absolute must see in Siem Reap, almost if not our favourite temple.

Worth the Visit. Bayon is one of the temples in Angkor Thom that is worth visiting. Climbing up to the terrace and seeing some Stone Faces peaking at you is the best experience of the place. There are labyrinths with windows for you to take a peak of what is there to come! When we reached the top terrace...there were plenty of tourist. So best enjoy the way up! We were also lucky to see some Cambodians dressed in costumes posing for tourists to take pictures with.
Amazing!. Really amazing experience. To appreciate the giant heads in their majesty, go in the early morning or sunset to avoid the huge crowds.
Superb!. An amazing site to visit in Siem Reap - time stops there... Just wow! Try to visit early in the morning or just before the sunset for better photos.
beutiful. wait when the monk is passing nearby and capture them with the temple in the background. Looks lively.
Temple of all the buddha faces. unique monument in the temples. Advice: Bring hat and lots of water because it can be very hot during the day
Well worth a visit. Another spectacular temple in the Angkor region, a worthy addition to your itinerary. Distinctly different carved features to Angkor Wat.
Beautiful faces. This temple blew us away. You could spend the whole day here staring in wonder at the faces in the temple.
Temple of Faces. This uniquely decorated temple is a must. Lots to see, lots to poke around and discover. Even in the slow season this is a crowded sight, but worth it.
Cool faces. One of the highlights of our Siem reap trip. The faces on Bayon temple are stunning and the setting in the jungle is awesome. It´s really a memory to treasure

My favourite temple!. I absolutely loved this temple! So many beautiful carvings of Buddha and no 2 are alike! Loads of great picture opportunities and it's not so jammed crowded as the other 2 popular temples.

Just rocks, but amazing rocks. The temples, the trees....For me these are just rocks and trees.Rocks of thousands years of history.Rocks showing the past glorious era of an ancient empire.Rocks that meant a lot for human history research.But, I don't care about all this. Amazing. Amazing sculptures. Beautiful temple. Great gate and bridge and grounds. Part of a large set up of temples in the complex and very awesome. Almost liked it better than Angkor Wat (but really its just different!)

Scenic and fun exploring. Second best temple at Angkor. Steep steps and small doors, more face statues than you can count! Still very touristic and gets really warm after 9am, which makes it a bit less than perfect.
Amazing Khmer artisanship. Simply not to be missed. It is one of the preeminent Khmer architectural wonders and you must visit it when in Siem Reap.

Bayon Bagus. Compact and pretty when on top of this Buddhist temple. There are a lot of photo spots of the faces from the stone statues. Very unique look and feel and a gorgeous view of the greenery around the temple.

Highlight of the Angkor archaeological park. Angkor Wat is still the most famous temple inside the archaeological park, but in my opinion not the most beautiful. That honor is reserved for the Bayon Tempel inside Angkor Thom. You can't hardly imagine how this tempel should be looked like when it was in use. Originally there where 49 towers but there are only 37 left. There are no words to express the complexity of the structure. The towers with the faces on the top and the winding lanes underneath it are really impressive. When you look to the temple from the outside it's not as hugh as other ones, but you will find the beauty of it inside. The inner and outer bas-reliefs tell you a lot of stories.Highlights:- The complex of face towers- The winding lanes inside- The bas-reliefs with stories from different Khmer periods
Another amazing temple. Definitely put this one in your itinerary for your temple tours. Fascinating to see and wander around for an hour or two in.
amazing. the temples in siem reap are just amazing i loved every minute. they have water and stuff at the sites
Grand. This is the grandest temple i have visited in Siem Reap. Those huge Buddha faces are amazing. I was in awe of this magnificent creations of mankind in the past.

One of the most spectacular places in Angkor. Have been in Bayon Temple twice and both times have been amazed of the architecture of the place. Probably, one of three best places to visit in Angkor with Ta Prohm and Angkor Wat.

Amazing Must See Temple. Breathtaking, inspirational and beautiful. It's great to see the history so well preserved. This was my favorite temple to visit next to Ankor Wat. I highly recommend you see this if you are visiting Siem Reap. Passes are very affordable.

sprawling and majestic. Bayon is the major temple in the Angkor Thom temple complex. It is sprawling and has intricate wall art and towers. We came here right after catching the sunrise at the Angkor Wat.
Bayon Temple. There are a few temples in the Siem Reap area for you to visit, the Bayon Temple is a most! With the help of Unesco, the temple is being restored and is a popular tourist attraction.

Great Place. Great place to see, a lot of smiling faces, big temples with a lot of sculpture.
I will definitely return and visit this temple again.
2-days tours of siem reap. fantastic details of the buddha face. and the numbers of the 4 sided face was amazing. the history is unbelievably

Beautiful temple. We visited this temple in the afternoon and were lucky that there wasn't too many tourists around.
The place is very special. The faces are very impressive. The bas-reliefs are in excellent condition and a testimony of the everyday life of the people of Angkor.
Bayon Tempel - a must see. Visiting the Bayon Tempel is a must see when you visit the Temples of Angkor Wat. Seeing all the faces from every corner was a great experience.

spectacular Temple. wandered all over it and to say it was overwhelming and worth the visit
for my daughter it was also being able to pat elephants and see wild monkeys nearby was a bonus
My Favorite!. I love this temple the most. so many hand carved Buddha statues still intact. The tour guides are most helpful and even take photos for you
beautiful area. climbs to top and temple was closed for repairs.. beautiful area here i walk all the time i was here..
Buddha magic. Wonderful architecture but spoiled by behaviour of many tourists who do not respect this as a temple!
Banyon. Ancient architecture is WOW. Raining season, be careful with your step as the floor is slippery. Careful with your head as many of the walkways have low ceiling .
Best for photography. Easily my favourite temple in the Angkor region. Angkor Wat is big but the Bayon Temple was amazing. Get there early to avoid crowds

Smiles of Angkor. Just adore the carving, history, mystery & the inviting smiles.

Always be respectful & take a shawl and not too short shorts for the ladies.
otherwise early morn is beautiful but it closes 530pm so no sunset pics unfortunately

For me the best of the temples.. Angkor Wat is, of course, the main attraction but for me, this temple was just amazing with all of those faces looking down at you. It really is picture-set perfect. If only we could get large Chinese tourist groups and their guides to be a little less noisy and behave in a slightly less obtrusive manner. This is great temple. Bayon Temple is best for the tourism around the word to visit in South Asia.Prasat Bayon or as we normally know it, the Bayon temple is one of the most spectacular central temple of the Angkor city of Cambodia. It was built around the early 13th century by the Mahayana Buddhist king Jayavarman VII. Later after the king’s death, the temple was modified by the following Hindu and Buddhist kings as per their preferences. The most interesting fact about the temple is that when its foundation was laid, the main religious figure was a statue of Buddha which was more than 3m tall and was located in the central tower. But, when the following Hindu kings modified it, the statue was removed and broken into pieces. In 1933 during the restoration work, the pieces were taken out from a well, were placed back together and are displayed in a small pavilion at the Angkor.
terrific to visit. One of the top 5 temples in Siem Reap. Well worth the visit. Must walk up to the top tower for the view over the area.

WOW!! Use the absolute best of them all!. Angkor Wat is the most famous but this one is the most interesting labyrinth with every turn exploring a different view of the ruins all under the glance of the enigmatic, mischievous smiling rocks pillars. Truly fascinating that you must spend time here.
the secret kmer's smile make me peace and linger. the secret kmer's smile make me peace and linger,this tample is still repairing,I definitely will come to visit again!
The trip is full of knowledge. Our first project is more humane humanity. I was extremely impressed with this specific temple... it was a very emotional experience and easy to get there by bike...

Very wonderful place. I have been visiting this place. it is very beautiful and wonderful for anyone who comes here.My message to anyone who comes to every temple in this country should be obstinate in all the local people who force you to buy the goods they sell.I see a lot of people, especially from western countries, many buy stuff from them had. tips I can give is to avoid them, 1 do not stare at them 2 do not produce any words particularly "How much is it" to them 3 continue your journey carefully I know many people from western countries have a good heart. However, here you have to be strict to those who force you to buy their goods.

Simply Mind Blowing. The trip was just amazing. If you are a historically inclined traveler, just do not miss this. This is best visited during dusk or early in the morning as during mid day it tend to get very hot. Also photo op is best just before dusk for the lighting.
The best Wat in the Angkor Wat. I was extremely impressed with this specific temple... it was a very emotional experience and easy to get there by bike...

Beautiful Temples. We spend around 30 minutes at Bayon Temple after visiting Angkor Wat and other temples in the Angkor Complex around Siem Reap. Many people spend a little more time there. Overall, the temple is beautiful, full of four face Buddha towers. I wish to have more time to stay there and learn more about the history of the temple.

The best of the best.. According to other reviews I read before I went here the Bayon Temple, this is undoubtedly the most beautiful and evocative of all the archaeological site of Angkor Wat, the peculiarity of this imposing structure is undoubtedly the large faces carved on the rock, a feeling really strange. The temple is perfectly preserved, unlike many others now in ruin and decline.

Incredible. After Angkor Wat I went to Bayon. That is another amazing temple. From the distance you see a great structure but when you walk closer, you began to see all the Buda's faces. Take your time to have a walk aorund.
Goosebumps.. Amazing place. The only downside were the throngs of crowd here all pushing and shoving to get the best angle for their photos.

Spectacular. When I thought that I was "templed out" here in Siem Reap, I see something that's of a similar era but so different! We tend to just think about the Angkor Wat but in fact there are many, many other temples to see here in Siem Reap that are equally if not more spectacular and this is one of them!

Great Sight of Angkor. It was such a great sight as both Buddha & Hindu elements were present at this temple. Originally built for King Jayavarnam VII, a Buddist. Later modified by Jayavarman VIII when Khmer reverted to Hindu.
The huge and many faces built with different expressions on them were truly and simply great work.

Fantastic Adventure. Imagine: in the jungle. Surrounded of green arms. In front of you two elephants are slowly walking across a bridge. And you behind them enter the historic site. The trees are out the houses roof, and the walls are all violented from jungle. Wonderful place planty of magic.

Words Can't Do Justice. Bayon is my absolute favorite of all the Khmer sites I have visited. There's something magical, spiritual and just beautiful about this place. You can find a tranquil space and ponder the mysteries of this thousand year old structure, or you can walk and climb all over the temple, which is lots of fun. Also one of the best photography locations in Siem Reap/Angkor.

Must See of all the temples in Siem Reap. Loved this temple the most because of the unique four-headed statue for the top. Loved the relief on the walls too.
Smiling Bhudda Wonder. I felt as if i was in some magical place. Loved the nooks and hallways and the all the beautiful picture spots that the guide brought us too.
I love it. I love historical places, specially architectural site and love restoration company working on it, this haw people have to preserve historical objects

Elephant ride around the temple. An elephant ride was a lovely way to look around the outside of this beautiful temple. Plan your visit carefully to avoid the most crowded times of day. If you have a tuk tuk driver for the day you can organise the order in which you visit each temple.

Faces everywhere!. As with all of the temples in this region the stone work and preservation is remarkable. I particular loved the different levels of this temple and the fantastic views through all of the faces. Wherever you looked there were faces and the sun hitting them at different levels is really a sight to behold. In the wet season there is also an amazing photo opportunity outside this temple. Find yourself a corner outside the moat and you will be able to photograph the temple with a perfect reflection in the water. Just stunning!

Favourite of all the temples. You'll take hundreds of photos ..... very well preserved.
No way you can go to Cambodia and miss this.
Great temple. It was really great temple that have a lot of tower with for smiling face. even it have so many people go to see that temple but it still nice with the photo and visiting.
Fascinating. Bayon Temple is one of the most interesting places in Angkor. It is rich of history and has fascinating sculptures. Really a place not to miss during your stay in Siam Reap.

One happy face after another. This temple is the one I wanted to visit the most. And if you wait until the tour bus leaves you can have the complex to yourself. It is a maze of large faces of stonework that keep you interested to see them all. It can also be seen in as little as a couple of hours. Not to be missed.

Amazing temple!. Temple with many faces. From the main entrance the temple looks dull and boring but believe me, once u started to explore you will change your mind. The best of all the temple so far. Each temple tower have faces of bayon. Best time will be in afternoon. Not much people around. The temple seems like belongs to you since not much crowd.

Just amazing!. What a great place! This and all of the historic sites locally are wonderful. The size and magnitude of this site will amaze. This is one of the must see bucket list items you do not want to miss.

Great exploring. Bayon is beautiful! Temple of the heads as I'm sure your guide book will tell you. There are also lots of little passages and nooks that you can duck into and explore. (We waited out some rain in one.) It is one of the more popular temples so go early to enjoy before the crowds show up.

Bayon - is it a best temple in Angkor?. Yes it is. All Angkor is amazing. This temple will stay with you. See it. We saw probably a few of all the temples there. This one was probably the most magnificent. You probably know the photos of those beautiful stone faces,

Exceptional...go early. Too crowded but a must. Avoid elephant rides which is a rip off . Take good shoes as climbing on the temples can be perilous in flip flop (which I did and survived but grazed my skin). have some loose change for women asking $1 for good luck by altar on top of temples...on your guard for boys acting as "self proclaimed" guide and asking afterwards for donation to bogus school...!

It is best viewed from afar where the faces are more prominent. One part of the temple is being rehabilitated. We went here first to avoid the flock of the tourists after they visit Angkor Wat. The place is very quiet and peaceful. Bayon is really one of my favorites.
Loved it. This is the first temple i visited and loved it. Very different from all ths others. Enjoy walking around and inside the corridors.

Best in Angkor Archeological Compound. This was my favorite temple in the Angkor Wat Archeological compound. I love the four face pillars in light of sunset. This temple has an amazing energy, especially with the active Buddhist monastery right next door. While we were there at dusk, the monks were chanting Buddhist mantras at the foot of a large Buddha statue, and we could hear the chanting as we walked clockwise through this ancient heritage site. The faces of the pyres look out in the cardinal directions, and have a peaceful look on their sandstone faces. Though not the most extravagantly carved temple of the archeological compound, energetically this was the most moving place of our whole visit to Siem Reap.

You're being looked at!. A fantastic temple to visit. The enormous faces carved in the stone are in varying conditions but most are very good considering the age of Bayon. Definitely should be on your list of temples to visit in Siem Reap!

Stunning. My favourite part of Angkor. One of my most memorable travel experience! You think of Cambodia and you dream Angkor watt and Bayon, tomb raider movie certainly has made it more popular, Architecturally not much has left and efforts to restore it are not enough and honestly Indian organisation of ASI hasn't done good work, further , honestly Bayon looks far more impressive with roots jutting out of architectural remains , whole feel is different, can't be expressed in words, you gotta see it to believe it.

As Awe Inspiring as Angkor Wat. The shear size of this palace is astounding, not to mention the 216(?) perfectly carved faces looking down on you at any point in the temple. There are main touristy areas to look at, but if you make enough left turns, this place is easy to get purposefully lost in, and see areas not usually seen by the general public.
Better than the other temples!. Theres something fascinating to see at every step in Bayon temple. Go here also if you want great pictures.

Temple of the Faces.. Located very centrally amongst the many temples, this one stands our for the art carved throughout. A main feature are the many faces, and if you have a good guide some of the right camera angles and lighting can give you great opportunities to capture them. It can get a little crowded and with narrow walk ways sometimes you feel herded along, so I would go earlier rather than later.

Come here and enjoy all seen!. It's all history and stands to broaden their horizons and get a lot of impressions! Only here you will understand how important it is for these people - this culture and why they relate to life ...

Our favourite. Out of all the amazing temples we saw in our one-day trip to Angkor Wat, this was by far our favourite. The temple is breath taking and just an incredible structure. We've seen many temples during our travels and this definitely takes the cake. Do not miss this!

Epitomises Angkor. Angkor Thom has many splendid structures, The Bayon Temple is just awe inspiring. Make sure you pose for the "kissing Buddah" photo. Wish we had got more photos of the bridge with tug-of-war and of the gateway so make sure you go crazy! Negatives would be it is rather busy (obviously) and there are lots of hawker children (common around here, and actually less here than elsewhere).

Super Hot - Wear leggins. It was great. Lots to see. Do yourself a favour - pack knee length sports pants or leggins and wear them to the temple no matter how hot it is. We didn't know this so like everyone else, we all bought $3 happy pants at the markets one size fits all because you can't wear shorts above knee length to the temples. Look for the better quality ones that come in different sizes - they are there look for them they are $5 and come in L and XL sizes because all the seams split at the crutch on the cheap ones and you end up with massive chaffing. It's hot anyway and with the heat radiating off the stone plus all the climbing and walking you will be glad you wore leggins or paid the extra $2 for the larger pants. It was a great day ad we all loved the temples but by the end of it we were all walking a little tenderly.
Bayon Temple. Of all the temples seen, this is my first choice, very special with all these faces looking at you. An amazing and magical place!
Great. We love this temple even more than Angkor Wat. It is an amazing example of the great work of Khmer architecture, very intricate.

One of the best. One of the coolest temple ruins in Angkor, a definite must. The 50-something big Buddha faces looking at you from every angle. Magical on a misty day but be there early as it is one of the most popular temples.
Of course. It is on of the temple to visit around here fir sure, but so much other oner too........It is Angkor Wat after all !! All are magnificient !

Amazing, a must see!. This was my favourite of the temples in Siem Reap. The faces are absolutely amazing. While walking around you feel like you are walking in a maze, which I loved. It is not as spread out and open as the other temples, giving it a more intimate feel. There is limited shade, so you are mostly in the hot sun. I recommend bringing lots of water! Women can wear shorts, you do not need to have your knees covered, as you do on the top level of Ankor Wat.

huge.... Huge, interesting, a mix of religions,and the statues...pardon me...but a bit like Legoland. Coming from India where sculpture / carvings are fine and intricate, and generally from one stone, the sight of humongous heads..part Buddha part Brahma...made of blocks carved individually and put together was interesting. No 'like' or 'dislike'..it was a different type of temple, different culture, different type of sculpture. The reliefs on the panels illustrating every day life of locals was superb. Detailed and finely done..

Dramatic architectural display of Khmer flair. While Angkor Wat serves as the iconic image of Cambodia, it is a huge complex that can be rather overwhelming. On the other hand, while no less dramatic, the Bayon Temple is smaller and more manageable. In that sense, I like to think of the Bayon as the Musee d'Orsay to the Angkor Wat's Louvre.The main attraction of the Bayon are the towers bearing over 200 carved faces of a smiling, compassionate Buddha. The towers are located on the third level of the complex, and are reached via steep stairs. But don't neglect the reliefs on the first level - if you come with a guide, he will bring you through the most important ones. Many are scenes of battles between the Khmers and the Chams (or Chinese - they're the ones wearing headdress), with the Khmers eventually victorious. Other interesting scenes are that from a river and a circus. We were told that because the temple faces east, a visit at sunrise was the thing to do. However, we visited in the late afternoon when the crowds weren't as crazy.

The secret of jungle.. that's a good place ever, it's simply perfect with a natural made. Bayon Temple is the best place that's was so beautiful i never seen before. it's spend around 15 minute from middle of city by Tuk Tuk.

Very cool. The enigmatic faces of Bayon was one of my favorite parts of our Cambodian trip. This temple is less spread out than Angkor Wat and also less crowded. It's sort of like a maze, which really gives you the adventurous feel. I will say though that shade is minimal, so plan your time here during a cool part of the day.

Stunning Temple. Very busy but you will see why when you get there. Incredible architecture and monuments. Be careful though as the locals will start to talk to you about the temples and then expect payment. Even the security guards / policemen!
Must-see. Amazing to see the scale, grandeur and beauty of this place. It is incomparable and is one of the most photogenic places one is ever likely to see.
Stunning. The Bayon Temple is THE most beautiful site of Siem Reap. If you have a day, go here first, if you have 3 days, go to this place thrice!! It is that amazing!

Mesmerizing!. There are many temples to visit in Cambodia especially around Angkor Wat, and the Bayon Temple is one of the most beautiful/interesting one, do not miss it! The best way to visit is either by bike or hire a tuk tuk driver for a day, which is really cheap and he can drive you around to visit all the temples you want to see.

Awesome size, awesome atmosphere. If I could only have visited one temple, this would have been it. Massive scale, fewer people and very atmospheric. Try to go early or late but even when it is busy you should still get some quiet time if you are patient.

impressive. The bayon temple was one of the more striking impressive temples in the Angkor Thom complex, if you are visiting the Angkor Wat park you will go here as a matter of course but it is well worth the effort to go up to the top.
Beautiful. as part of a Temple Pass 3 day tour, the Bayon has photogenic qualities in the morning, afternoon and evening!
Under stone scrutiny. More than 200 giant faces watch silently as you walk round the temple. A surreal highlight, magnificent.

You're being watched, can't escape!. Divinity everywhere if I have to put it in two words. Really impressive how the almost identical have been carved and laid out watching you from all angles. Best to go early in the day as it is in the open and heat can get in the way of the experience.

The faces gave it a mythical feel. Nicest temple of the lot.. The most unique. Enjoyed a tranquil walk within the compound. Great for photos!
Was there about 8+am and it wasn't too crowded.
Much more than I expected!. I thought it was just ONE face- the whole thing was covered and fun to climb through. It was sunny when I went too so it was even more brilliant!
it's really imagine excellent experience,. There was every thing was so well organize and excellent. good quality i got better experience than other place in my life.

Impressive. Another solid part of the Angkor experience. The complex is huge and this temple does not disappoint. Only had one day around the area but made sure I went to Bayon, very easy to cycle to from the main town.

Love the faces!. A very beautiful temple with loads of faces. We had a nice tourguide who could explain the meanings of some statues and walls and tell us stories about it.
We learned a lot about Jayavarman VII which was very interesting.
It's one of the best temples there so don't miss it!

Preserved Beauty.. Stunningly build, temple of many smiling faces and 4 faced Buddha's head was the first temple destination. With rich history and beautiful towers surrounding the temple complex, it's one of the many temples in Angkhor Thom (the capital of the Angkhor kingdom) that one should not miss. Hire a local guide and the experience will be elevated. Amazing. Also great to see that many NGOs helping to preserve and restore these amazing ancient ruins. Thank you.

Amazing place!. My family and I have booked a private Siem Reap tour with Odyssey Tours, this is really an amazing site in the world! you can touch the ancient history by the stone, and i was so movied when I was seated in the step of the temple! Don't miss it!
Amazing!!. One of my favourite temple!!It remember me the famous Disney cartoon Moogli&jungle bookOne of the most beautifull and famous Angkor temple

Smiling faces to lift the spirits. Beautiful place with lots of photo ops. It was the last stop on our trip so we were quite tired.The group of loud Chinese tourists were very irritating barging into us while we were taking photos, basically being pests.Despite all of this, the smiling statues somehow managed to lift our spirits (especially after the group were herded away) somehow saying see it's not so bad after all.
Stunning!. An amazing place, one temple we had to come back to as it really took our interest. I spent a few hours here and the history is amazing. Don't miss it!

My favourite temple of all. This temple is amazingly huge with all the smiling buddha faces. We cycled our way from town to Angkor Wat, followed by Bayon, Royal Palace, Leper King Terrace, Elephant Terrace. recommend to visit Bayon early in the morning (e.g. right after sunrise, or during the late afternoon before heading to Bakheng hill for sunset) only during then you'll see the faces at Bayon glowing under the sunlight. Time for best shots. Don't miss those bas-relief.. most of it tells u the story of the life of civilian during the ancient days.. interesting.
faces every where. loved this place. It is a small temple but is known for its many faces. Had a great time here as a prelude to Anghor Wat

Great temple, probably the best.. Like most say, get a guide to enhance your experience, most of the stone carvings are well preserved. Two day temple experiences can be arranged at reasonable prices and the entrance fees are 20 dollars for one day and 40 for three. Don't get me wrong, the other temples are beautiful too but this was my favourite!Not sure why anyone would give less than 5 stars unless your indianna Jones!

The entire circuit was magnificent, Bayon is no exception. We visited Bayon as part of our sunrise visit to Angkor Wat. It was certainly incredible, don't skip it when you go to look. Be sure to bring plenty of water!

Breathtaking. I spent 5 days in Siem Reap. Three of them were spent discovering the different temples. Bayon is amazing as were a lot of the smaller temples which are all part of Angkor Thom. For me these temples were better than Angkor Wat although I did go back to Angkor Wat for the sunrise which was well worth it. As the temples are so far apart it is best to hire a tuk tuk driver over your time there. Great value and extremely knowledgeable. You let them know what kinds of these you want to see and they will take you. Our last stop was at the oldest temple in Siem Reao. We were the only people there. When we said we had finished with the temples our driver talked us into going there. So glad he did. It was one of my favourites. Also buy yourself either a 3 day or 1 week pass.
Temple of a different kind. Was a different type of temple to see however in the middle of summer, its just too hot. I wouldnt spend more than half an hour here.
Amazing wall carving. We love the faces but the wall carving is amazing too. We can learn what life was like, so intricate.

beautiful!. beautiful temple with great history.it would be a waste if u are to explore the temple without a guide as there are stories behind almost every carvings and statues. clean and well kept. must visit!!

Best temple in Angkor Wat. The Bayon Temple is really worth visiting as there are so many details which reveal themselves to the visitor depending on how they are positioned towards the many elements. It is also a compact temple and not too big which is nice as it is so hot and humid.
Charming temple. This temple is really beautiful, with the carvings amazingly well-preserved and restored. One of the most beautiful temples we saw.

amanzing. I love all the temples I saw in Siem Reap. This one has some scenes of battle that I did not see in the other one. The architectural of these temples take your breath away.
I was able to take some cute pictures where you can be nose to nose with one of this great sculpture.

Faces temple. Situated in the centre of Angkor Thom, Bayon temple represents the intersection of heaven and earth.The temple is best known for its smiling faces. Best to go early in the early morning to avoid crowds that throng in later and also to avoid the heat. Spend some time in the quiet and solitude of the morning to enjoy this temple.
My favorite. This was my favorite temple it´s so magic to see the faces! Yoy have to get it no see them even closer.

My favorite temple in Siem Reap. I love this temple! It was absolutely the more gorgeous and unique temple I ever visited. As I was walking away I kept turning around to see it because I wanted to capture a mental picture and remember it forever.

Between heaven and earth. In the center of Angkor Thom stands the Bayon temple also called the temple of the faces. Walking along the Bas relief galleries you see the carved scenes of simple everyday life. Also an episode of the Mahabharata.
From every side of the towers it seems like the faces are watching you. That makes me feel humble.
Unbelievably beautiful. One of the nicest temples in Angkor if not the best. Better visited in the afternoon yo avoid some of the crowds. Very magical
Stunning!!!. Amazing! Large old ruin, perfect picture opportunity! Beautiful architecture and history. A must see when visiting all the temples.

Picture-worthy Temple. Bayon was one of our favorites to see. The stone faces were awesome. After making the loop of the smaller temples, and several of them undergoing construction, it was nice to see something different.

My favourite Temple. This temple is much nicer than Angkor Wat itself. The stone faces were a highlight on our Cambodia Trip and should not be missed. You will end up taking lots of pictures here, because these are the things you wanna show your friends at home and which you saw in the movies. On the way to the temples, take your camera out of your bag and let the sun warm it up a bit, as you will have a foggy lens otherwise because of the temperature difference from your aircon room to the outside.... :-)

Beautiful temple . Our taxi driver picked us up at five and drove us around the temples of Angkor in his air-conditioned car. This was the best way to smash out the temples as we were on such a tight time schedule. Bayon temple was stunning and well worth a look. Glad we did it.
Must See. This was probably my favorite temple to visit. The giant stone faces and bas-reliefs are simply stunning!
budda stuff. It is obvious after a while that Bhudda was not real but the artists make money making art junk that if the people don't buy it they have bad luck... truth is not fear based.

More impressive than Angkor. This temple was definitely my favourite of all. The beauty of it is timeless, the gorgeous faces made of stone make you feel welcome and the fact that you can actually walk through it is simply amazing. Needs so much more attention than Angkor.

Awesome in every meaning of the word!. This huge temple and it's surrounding terraces offer so much! This was our first temple and we loved it. Having already visited the Cham museum in Vietnam and the national museum in phnom penh, we had already had a few lessons on the incarnations of Vishnu, the meaning begind the Naga and how Buddhism and Hinduism are linked in Cambodian culture. Nothing prepares you for how cool this all looks on a massive scale though!! It really felt like you were seeing glimpses of what must have been a powerful, creative and vibrant civilisation. It's wonderful to also be able to walk on, touch and see almost everything with little limitation or prohibitive signage.

The towers with the faces looking in 4 directions are still magical. I returned 20 years after my first visit to the Bayon as part of a family tour. While obviously many more people were visiting this time, the temple has still a timeless beauty and is one of my favourites within the Angkor park.

go see. go seebest temple we have seenyou really need to get a guide when visiting the temples as there is so much history to learn about.you wouldnt get the whole picture about the temples without a guide

Must visit. Although the Bayon temple seems to be more crumbling than Angkor Wat, the stone faces make it very memorable. It seems amazing to think of people ideating and executing something like this several hundred years ago.We didn't use a guide so we just wandered in and out of the temple. We later visited the Angkor National Museum and learnt quite a lot about the temple and the ruler who built it and the significance of the faces. It is a good idea to visit the museum first and then the temples.
Amazing.. It's a piece of 900 year old art - what's not to like? Avoid the crowds and get there early. The bas reliefs have defied the elements and are in incredibly good condition.

My favourite temple!. This temple has great carvings, intricate architecture, and a fantastic atmosphere. It was quiet when we arrived around 12:30-1pm, and we really enjoyed every minute of it. There's a reason it's one of the most famous!
Absolutely Amazing. Beautiful temple and one of the highlights for your trip. Amazing place to walk around to see all the Buddhas. But it is very busy with all the tourists.
Beautiful. Spent most of our time at Angkor Wat main temple with a guide but walked around this temple too. Amazing must see.
Amazing temple. This temple was one of the highlights of the trip. I just love all the faces of the Buddha. Went here in low season and it wasn't too crowded.

Amazing !!!. The most beautiful temple that i can seen in my life !!
I remained 10 minutes to contemplate the mouth opened with shivers which traveled my body.
Great place. Amazing place to walk around. Allow at least an hour to enjoy what it has to offer. The lower level ruins are interesting as well.

Fascinating!. I loved how the entire place was shrouded in so much history and mysticism.
When I was there, I couldn't help but think what it would be like to live during the time when Bayon was first constructed.

Excellent. Like many of the other temples, I couldn't help but think 'How did they manage to make such amazing temples?' The faces of the Bayon Temple are wonderful and something which you will keep with you forever.
Eerie. You approach this temple knowing that it's known for its faces but when you first see it, it has an eerie quality to it that I found captivating. Loved it

Smaller than I expected . You have to see these if in Siem Reap - only second to Angkor Wat for me! It's just different and a must do if only doing a day (couldn't be bothered to do more than a days worth!)
Very similar to the rest of the temples.. Quite nice with the similar shapes and concepts among the temple around the Angkor area. But still Angkor Wat is the main attraction.

A must on the temple tour. Bayon is highly recommended to visit, the last stone temple built (according to the guide). With the hundreds of buddha faces it creates a great atmosphere and effect. Everywhere you turn you will see a face and it is a great place to shoot some photos. Make sure you don't miss it.

Volcanic temple?. From a distance,looked like it was a ash stone rubbish after a volcanic eruption.
Closer, it is magnificent, especially the heads of Buddha and the carvings

Amazing Architecture. The best in Angkorwat...it is captivating...each wall in the temple has a story to tell.You really need a good tour guide to tell about the details of Bayon.We were lucky that Mr.Vanny was our tour guide.
Amazing. Very interesting site ...amazing to think how long this has stood for!.Wanted to do an elephant ride round site too but they finished running just as we went to book.
Start here. Start the big cycle tour with this temple - it's less crowded in the morning and more impressive than Angkor Wat in my opinion.
Faces in stone that talk. The faces look so real and are huge. The architects were superb. The entire edifice is be seen to be believed. Photos do no justice.
Mysterious Smiling Face. You can see the smiling face everywhere with TV or internet, but it's a different feeling, when it just in front of you. Really worth visiting.
Faces. Bayon Temple looks a bit of a mash up on approach, but as you spend time at the higher levels the many faces become highly evocative and provide a unique atmosphere.
Fantastic temple. Must visit temple. Great photo opportunities of the Buddha heads. We visited with Cambodia cycling one day tour. They were great! Quite a lot of steep stirs to climb.
Temples. Very interesting to see the difference between various temples. Worth having a guide who knows the history too.

Majestic Temple. Bayon is probably the most beautiful and magnificent temples in Cambodia or the world! You will feel the powerful spiritual ambiance once you step into the temple perimeter. The beautiful architecture and not to mention the many majestic calming Buddha faces are not something you could see anywhere else on this planet. Explore around...be amazed!

worth a visit. nice temple well worth a look. we travelled in august so out of the peak period, less crowds, ladies should take a long sleeved blouse or thin cardi as you wont be allowed into some of the temples bare shouldered.

Pretty Faces on Temple. Seeing those smiling faces on the walls here are just mesmerizing, I've been wanting to see these faces with my own eyes for years, and now I'm finally here, just.. undescribeable
Phenomenal. It is amazing, but 4 million other visitors are aware. Best times are before 9am where the day trippers in huge buses roll in.
Brilliant, exceptional.. The real highlight of Angkor Thom. Just awesome really. A face is in view wherever you stand, the Eye of Sauren?
good. It might be the only one or two should-go places in Angkor Thom. But I was there, it rained heavily. But the smile of Angkor was still impressive to see.
Beautiful. Amazing history and gorgeous, meditative space. We took a bike tour of the temples and were able to see little-traversed areas of this beautiful temple, while hearing about its history.
Lots of stairs to see great carvings. It is not easy as many may think, but if you are nimble and agile, you can take some great pictures and be intimate with this temple.

Here's looking at you!. What an amazing Temple! Everywhere you look a Buddah is looking back at you . The whole aura of the place was peaceful and joyful, the carvings were incredible. Certainly not aTemple to miss out on.
Amazing!. Incredible place with faces everywhere! I really enjoy it. You can ride a elephant around the temple for just $15 and feed the elephants with bananas for just $1.
definately a temple not to miss!. everything! beautiful carvings and buddha faces which are well preserved and very pictoresque in the Angor Thom complex

Amazing place!!!. Pro:
Fantastic architecture, grand and certainly full of history.
A shutter bug's haven.
There is alot of restoration going on, so that limits access to alot of places.
Impressive. No words to discribe the beauty of this place. It's really one of my favourite temples. Went there early to avoid the massive crowd. Spend time to really enjoy this magical place.

Inspired!. After Banteay Srey, Bayon was by far my favorite among the temples. The awe and sense of mystery it evokes cannot be compared to any other monument. It is startling how much of the temple has been restored to its original structure.
A must visit for all who come to Siem Reap!

A little different from Angkor Wat. Bayon temple has a great number of large faces which makes it a little different from some of the other temples and interesting to see. I would recommend a visit to here.

Go in the morning. I remember reading a fellow tripadvior's review about going to Bayon at sunset and enjoying the peace of the faces alone..and that was exactly what I had set out to do. I got here at around 6, when the sun had just rises, and quietly sat there/ took pictures, for about an hour. The environment was pure magic. Everywhere you peeked you would see a face. I loved it so much that I came here for two sunrises. -Try to get here before 9am, after that, its asian tourist world. -Also heard the sunset here is amazing.
Amazing. This is a brilliant. We went first thing in the morning before any other tourist arrived and it was great. Surreal atmosphere without anyone else here.
Serenely eerie. Very nice. Have to definitely visit when in siem reap. Cannot describe in words one has to experience personally.
Fabulous. Visited Bayon as part of tour of Ankor temples - stunning place would love to go back again Good time to go is August as off peak and not so many tourists
Do not miss.. Hire a guide. Makes all the difference. The tuk tuk drivers aren't really guides. Hire a pro. It will make a huge difference.
an iconic temple. larger than i thought it would be but amazing to walk through. shame they were reconstructing parts so could not enter some areas, but still awe inspiring.

Interesting, but crowded. This is one of the bigger temples in the archeological park, so is really, REALLY crowded. There's a lot to see (move away from the main groups that are following a kind of set path) and it's worth spending some time at, but I found it a bit difficult to see because of the sheer volume of people. There's currently renovation work happening to one side of it. Keep an eye out for the faces at this temple - everywhere you look, the one particular style of face is looking at you.
Amazing. Beautiful structures, smiling buddha in all directions. huge and Magnificent, intricate patterns.overall an great experience.
Amazing. The temples are a must see, you will not be disappointed. We obtained a one day pass to see the temples and felt that this was adequate for us.

wowwww. How can you review one of the wonders of the world? You in fact are going to travel half the way around the world to see this. It is just awesome. My recommendation is to take your time, do not get blustered by the large tourist groups. And see some of the many other wonderful temples of the Ankor area. I also recommend a local guide/driver combination. We have traveled the world using a guidebook and jumping into buses, tranis or an occasional taxi. but here it makes sense to have someone that adjusts to your schedule as you jump from temple to temple. Plus, by westerners' standards, in it is very affordable. Plus, if you come in August you will have to sort ouut the weather (it rains, hard, every day, usually in the afternoon, sometimes for one hour or more).
Like a film set. Like the setting with trees and creepers appearing to grow out of the stones. Dislike the crowds - people walking in front when trying to take photographs.

Temples in Siem Reap. You need a 3 day pass $40 to see most of the Temples. A Tuk Tuk is good value they wait for you at each temple and cost about $15 day. Unless you usually ride a bike, it is pretty far between temples and pretty hot.

Must see. Definitely one of the top temples to see in Siem Reap. Highly recommend getting a guide or going on a guided cycle tour through Grasshopper Adventure (as I did) best way to explore all the temples!
Fascinating. A really interesting area, full of Cambodian history and the amazing quality of there stonework. reasonably easy to get around.
All the faces. So many faces, so much history! Take your time to explore, mind the helpful though they do want your money!

Amazing.. Surprising... CC ( 2014.07.26 ) This temple was very impressive and amazing view. Though it was very hot weather, view of this temple was very beautiful. I and my son visited there with much expectation, and we were satisfied with gorgeous view. Very impressive to us..

One of the better buildings at Angkor. One of the better buildings at Angkor. Ruins and temples of the style expected for visiting Cambodia. Definitely go. Vendors selling water and Cokes for US $1, with a few kids asking for money around. Suggest you bring ten ones, try a fresh coconut.
Simply breathtaking. The Privilege Floor where we were staying organised a guide for us and he was brilliant and helped explain the background and structure to Bayon.
Most beautiful temple of Siem Reap. Must See when you visit the site of Angkor, very well preserved. An fantastic experience. Visit this temple you wont regret it.

Incredible. I visited in July 2014, the craving of Buddha faces into solid stone is incredible. The Temple is much small scale than Angkor Wat. There are so many temples in the area but love the Bayon temple because of its scale and these smiling Buddha faces, it's so peaceful in there and it's less walking to do as well. Please do visit if you have a chance, it worth every penny you spent.

Huge and impressive. Bayon was unique in the way that it looked huge from the outside. It was also one of the very few Buddhist temples built. The Buddha' faces carved on top of the temples were very beautiful. We climbed to the top level and the architectures were wonder for avid photographers!! This temple took us 2.5 hours to finish looking around and we were pretty quick! The small attractions surrounding such as Baphuon temple, The Palace of the Leper King, Elephant Terrace etc were worth visiting too! Be prepared to spend 4 to 5 hours at this area if you want to appreciate the places.

This is the smallest temple but by far my favourite. We went early and the light was beautiful it it was quiet and serene. I truly found this place mesmerizing. It has a lot of soul and is right in the middle of the jungle.
Magnificent temple. This is a small-ish temple...but is trully magnificent. The carvings are just splendid. I really enjoyed browsing this temple

best timple. Bayon temple it is very nice temple , it have a lot of caving all the wall and in side Bayon temple have 54 pick and in side Bayon temple you can see small temple too ,it far siem reap town about 10km .it is very smile temple i like it .

Beautiful. This was one of my favourite temples. It is small, and very interesting. There are a lot of steps and it could be hard for some people to reach the top, but if you can the view is beautiful.

Intriguing and memorable. This is one of the most intriguing of the Angkor temples. Interesting four-faced towers. The bas-reliefs of the outer gallery show daily life of the time. Interesting and memorable.

Surreal site. Bayon stands out and is unique compared to other temples. The complex is much larger than first meets the eye and can be explored in 3 dimensions with all its steps and tunnels.Worth getting a guide and going in the early hours of the morning to beat the heat and crowds as it is very exposed to the elements and gets crowded easy.Remember to see the elephant terrace which is another temple like structure nearby and the wall/tunnel of faces.
fantastic. amazing, in the best temples in angkor! one of de Word Wonferfulli never has been nothing like this
This was an incredible temple. Exactly as I had read about it. It was a weird structure with beautiful carvings but just so eerie and wonderful.

Favourite Ang Kor among all. Love the BAYON the most among all. Loved everything about it. Made me felt soooooo happy to be in there. The stones and faces were the most beautiful thing I saw all trip. :) It was where the "dancing hall" was

There is more than just Angkor Wat. Away from the hustle and bustle of Angkor Wat this is a nice place to visit. There aren't too many tourists and you can get very close up to all the structures.A good place to take a few snapshots without the interference of people who can get in the way.

Brilliant Example Of Khmer Architecture and its intricacy. As with all of the amazing sites in Cambodia going with a guide makes this worth it 10x over, knowing all of the little stories and background to the carvings is well worth whatever you pay. Great Spot
awesome history. So interesting to see. Crowds are large so go early . read a little before going it helps with understanding . amazing history .
So detailed. This temple has some of the most beautiful carvings. Well worth the visit to see them and learn about the local culture for the period in which it was built.

One of the top ten places to see before you die. You have to be a Shakespeare to do Bayon justice. Just normal words do not suffice to describe the majesty, the grandeur of Bayon. Either get a good guide or a good guide book, because there is a lot to see and Bayon hides its beauty and its secrets from the casual onlookers. Most people will just climb to the top and pose with the faces, But there is so much more. Explore the lower levels, both inside and outside. There are numerous beautiful bas-reliefs of scenes from history and mythology. There are many tunnel like walkways and passages all around the lower part of the temple, explore them and you will be pleasantly surprised. And of course, there are the 200 odd faces of Jayavarman. Either go to Bayon first thing in the morning or at the end, it takes about two to two and half hours to properly explore the place.

Love this temple!. We visited this temple twice! We loved all the faces.Instead of going to Angkor Wat for sunrise, we chose Bayon.It was an amazing experience. We arrived around 5.30, finding the monks chanting next the the moat. Very atmospheric!Also we were the only people in the temple at Sunrise! Make this your sunrise destination.
so amazing Thom. amazing to have a peace afternoon pondering things
owesome Khemer architecture. Beautiful and well preserved ancient architecture.a bit of read up before the trip will certainly help to enhance the entire experience
216 Smiling Buddhas. This was one of the highlights of Ankor Thom. The towers are amazing and all the carved Buddha faces are breathtaking. Really enjoyed this temple.

One of Many, but it Stands out. There are so many temples to see in the area, but this is a staple and should not be missed. It is of Buddhist construction built in the late 1100s C.E., but there seems to be a bit of a mix of architectural styles at play here. The lower level reliefs should not be missed.
Absoulutely divine!. I've visited Angkor Thom twice before and I have to say, this is by far my most favorite among the other temples.

Amazing but bring water. This was my second favourite ruin. I used a Tuk Tuk to bring me around and was so glad I did. In the heat after walking for hours I wanted to be able to sit back and have someone drive me around while still appreciating where I was. I brought one bottle of water and wish I'd brought 2 there are places ot buy water at the end of the ruin but not where the ruins are so bring some!
Symmetry. If you like Buddhas th en visit this temple bad see the Buddhas faces carved on all sides so times 4 - amazingly beautiful . Well worth a visit
Nice Temple Known for faces facing each direction. Part of the Angkor Wat Complex. This is a must see temple. This temple is not huge and can be seen in less than an hour.
Pretty interesting place!. Loved the architecture, and the view of the temple from outsideGot lost inside and came out through the wrong exit!

Bas relief carvings and budda smiles. Stunning, beautiful facades that tell stories of ancient times welcome you into the inner layers and towers of the main temple. You can see many motifs carved into posts and panels while viewing giant, smiling buddha faces on all four sides of the enormous towers. This is a must see.

Perhaps the most impressive of all. A favourite. The Bayon is endlessly fascinating. There is so much to see. On our first visit we were utterly captivated by the countless enigmatic faces - so photogenic, especially when the light is just right. On that subject, go early or late in the day, when there are clear blue skies to maximise your photography. But there's a great danger of becoming so tied up in the elevated faces, that you miss the amazing bas-reliefs in the stunning Southern Gallery. These are not to be missed! Just make sure you leave enough time - and don't miss having a good look at the temple from the South...

love at first sight. Incredible faces of buddha. It seems to me that it was outshined by Angkor Wat’s beauty. Have that 3- 4 shots $1 striking photo ops with Apsara people dressed in a traditional Khmer costumes. It wasn't that bad. Love the structures, its mesmerizing. The temple is really amazing. Definitely a Must see!More photos here: http://www.lamyerda.com/asia/temple-of-faces-bayon-angkor-thom/
Just go!. Loved this temple. The kids liked the elephants eating pineapples and the ride around the temple grounds.

START HERE (if you aren't beginning at sunrise). Holy Cow, great photo ops! Everywhere you turn, there is a face. We probably spent longer there than we should, but you really can stop and stare at a wall for an hour with carvings and faces and bas-reliefs. There is so much to look at! Our tuk-tuk drivers dropped us off here after entering the South Gate, which kickstarts your excitement into full blast! I recommend starting here, as shade can be provided inside if you need to get relief from the sun. But I recommend you start somewhere else if you would like to start at sunrise. Go to Angkor Wat with the 500+ people who are also wanting a good sunrise picture!

Go early. Our excellent guide took us to this complex first as it gets overcrowded, it's well worth the early start, everywhere you look there are faces looking at you , great insight to the culture of these people , if you are lucky your guide will know the right place for the photo where you can pose & it looks as if you are nose to nose with one of the faces. Take water & look where you walk as places can be uneven. All of the temple complexes are a must see. It is worth while getting a knowledgable guide they know where to go when to go & of course lots of history of the area, as they have lived through the conflict they have some very interesting family stories
My favorite. It was a blue cloud day and I spent it with some rays of sunshine and faces of Bayon. Stunning. My favorite temple in Siem Reap.
Well preserved and beautiful.. Like most of the temples around, this one was particularly impressive. We went in the start of the rainy season. Be careful, some stones are slippery!

Don't miss this!. The Bayon is a well-known and richly decorated Khmer temple at Angkor in Cambodia. Its most distinctive feature is the multitude of serene and massive stone faces. You can also spot Cambodians dressed as Apsaras over here. Look for the spots where you can take the tourist-y nose bump pictures :-P

Awesome sight. The sight of the temple itself was amazing. Was slightly letdown by the fact that major repair & restoration works are in process when I was there but don't let that stop you from going. It's a worthwhile visit to the place.
The best in Angkor Thom. The best! Beautifully preserved, sophisticated temple, unique Buddha faces in the façade of the towers, evocating, magic!

Amazing. First stop on our Angkor Wat complex tour. What a sight. Incredible carvings depicting Khmer way of life and major events in history. The main draw of course is the faces carved in the rocks, which are plentiful. My wife and I did a few of the rather challenging climbs up to the top of different parts of the temple, which was really fun. Great experience.
One of the highlights of siem reap. Definitely put this on your list of must sees when visiting siem reap. We went when it was crowded; try to go earlier in the day if possible.

No.1 place to visit in Angkor. We got the hotel to arrange a private car to take us around Angkor for $45USD for one day. You will most likely find a tuktuk who will do it for you for much cheaper.You must buy your admission ticket to Angkor when you get there (if you are doing a tour by yourself) and the cost is $20USD for one day, you can buy 3 and 5 day passes as well. These tickets are checked at each destination by staff in blue shirts. So do not lose your ticket.Bayon is an incredible temple to discover. Lots of places to go up and down and a lot of things for you to hold onto and marvel at.

Not just another face in huge crowd. This was the last temple that we visited and it was so refreshing to see a temple that has it's own character. The faces are the stars of the show at the Bayon Temple and from every vantage point you will see them. You can get some awesome photos with the faces, but the crowds can be rather off putting but well worth you being patient.
Banyon - Spectacular. The faces and the carvings were spectacular and the atmosphere was much more calm than at Angkor Wat
all good. very impressed with this temple. great for taking pictures on a clear day. best to visit in the early morning

Magnificent, mindblowing.... This is a must see, take a moto or bicycles if you can, so you can go slow and marinate in this. Photos are intriguing, but do not even begin to do these temples justice. Go!What I didn't like and the mistake I made was to eat at the temple. Check the prices carefully, I paid 16 dollars for 2 people for something I could have had for 6 dollars in town.
Special Temple, love the architecture. Love this temple. It is slightly different from the temples that I have went to. It is beautiful. Everybody should at least visit this temple once.

fabulous history. a bit of a climb. here's an excerpt from my blog, The Mediocre Wanderer: The first on our adventure was the Bayon temple. Expect to climb steep wooden steps, and rough, uneven sandstone blocks. We entered it through it's east gate, where the short walk from the tuktuk parking area is probably the easiest path you'll walk on in the entire structure.Built 100 years after Angkor Wat, it's the next most amazing temple to see after the former, with it's 2000 faces carved on solid rock and 54 towers rising to the sky. It is a Buddhist temple, with pillars, surrounded by 4 faces, representing the omnipresent god. Bas reliefs at the first 2 areas tell of the battles, of a history built upon the blood of it's enemies, and it's people. Personally, it's my favorite temple.
Must see place. You need at least 3 days for the main temple places and this is one of them. Have comfy shoes and your camera ready.

Amazingly beautiful. Gorgeous area, rode an elephant, so much detail on every service and majestic overall. Beware of people offering to guide or take pictures. Consider booking a tour before hand or just explore on your own.
The greatest Temple of All. Very impressive temple among all Angkor Wat temples. Crowded even during raining season, but a must-see temple and take your time to soak it all in!

Temple of the temples - huge and magnificent. One of the countless temples in Cambodia. But it’s the #1 temple in terms of history and the awesome stone works left behind by the ancients for us. Build by King Jayavarman VII, this gem of ancient architecture have stood the test of time. Most distinctive feature of this temple is the massive stone faces. We end up going twice in 3 days to Bayon Temple for the serenity and to admire it. :)Tip : Before you go and visit the temples, take a trip to Angkor National Museum and spend 2-3 hours there to explore and find out more about the temples and who build them and when. Museum entry is 15$ and don’t forget to get the audio commentary in English, its worth the additional 3$ you spend. To enter inside the Angkor temple complex (which consist of the hundreds of big and small temples) you need to buy a pass. It’s USD 20$ for 1 days and USD 40$ for 3 days. If you have time and keen on exploring the temples, I would recommend to take the 3 days pass and you could take your own time to see the place and explore it on your own terms.
An Amazing Experience. A temple that can't be missed when in Siem Reap. More atmospheric compared to Angkor Wat. A tour guide is very much recommended to enhance the overall experience.

The faces at bayon are awesome. Many are man sized and make for great photographs.. This spot is a must see. It is second only to Angkor Watt. If you go to the temples, then see at least Angkor Watt, Bayon and Ta Prom. The giant faces make for great photographs and the location is on the small circuit tour.

Stunning. So outrageously cool that it seems surreal.. Do not waste your precious hard-earned (who likes waking up at 4:15 a.m.??!!) sunrise time battling the crowds at Ankor Wat. Ask your tuk-tuk to take you to Bayon for sunrise. They will argue with you: "But....Bayon??!!...you mean Ankor Wat, right? No-one, nobody, wants to go to Bayon for sunrise! Too many trees! Are you sure???", but you should persevere and get him to take you all the way to Bayon. He's right on all accounts- trees block the eastern horizon and there is NOBODY there (we only saw 2 other people on Bayon up until ~8:00). BUT THAT'S WHY IT'S SO COOL! The blue hour comes and all of the gorgeous, enormous faces of Bayon are bathed in ethereal blue light. You can snap away at the gorgeous facades free of the clutter of people, and enjoy the serene whistle of the Cambodian cicadas.
Loved this temple. The carved faces were just stunning. The Buddha faces are just fascinating. Very beautiful despite being pretty crowded.

Siem Reap Temples. get there early to escape the crowds and heat otherwise fascinating and fabulous experience.Lots of steps tp climb and hard to dodge all the photographers.So much history though and hard to believe the skill taken to build and carve these temples
A beautiful place. It's a beautiful place. You should go to this temple first. You can take the photo beautifully in the morning.
wonderful atmospheric. worth going to see faces of Buddha on temples and is a highlight of our visit. Worth going towould try and go when not too many there as can be crowded esp in weekends

Bayon temple. When in Siem Reap one must visit the temples..... Out of them all this one was my favourite. It can get very busy and walking around can get tricky with lots of tourists taking photos and bustling for the best advantage points
Amazing faces. Go early - as with every temple!! Love the faces and the fact that you can get close to them. We were here at 8am. By 9 when we left it was much much busier.
Very crowded but interesting. The temple is a must see. However, there were a lot of visitors at the temple. We visited in the mid-morning.

Brilliant Bayon. Its iconic and best in morning or late afternoon light,
Don't leave it too late to get here or you spend all your time trying to get a photo without another visitors head in the shot

Amazing. What an amazing place to visit. I loved all the temples. The only down side was people trying to sell you Books about the Temples the whole time. They are over priced.
Take lots of water with you as it was extremely hot

rubbing noses with the big wigs. A brilliant piece of architecture. Every turn reveals another set of faces with a different emotion. My favorite temple because of its unique character. the Apsara group who allow you to take pictures with them are also fantastic.
Girlie trip. Fourth trip and still takes my breath away ! My teenage daughter and I spent four days seeing the temples. Stunning !
Bayon Visit. Great stuff with old scupture of old temple from Hindu religion from 5 century,with huge structures and pillars
The most interesting temple.. We went later in the afternoon when few people were there. Fascinating to stroll thru and look at the tree trunks and the tree roots. Take plenty of photos

Perhaps the most magnificent of temples in Siem Reap!. We visited Angkor Wat, Banteay Srei, Bayon, Ta Prohm amongst others. But this temple stands out as a result of the magnificent work done by its designers and architects. Huge faces look at you from almost everywhere. This is where the true genius of that era comes out!
Buddha galore. Good to have guide who could paint picture of life in 12th century Angkor. The carved murals on the front face do a great job of explaining this.

Amazing. We figured how to get here when there was no one else here (yes just us and the Bayon Temple!) A truly beautiful temple with a magical feel. This was the first temple we visited for the day and only spent an hour but you could spend more time if you felt the need.
Must do!. Amazing! My favourite of all the temples we saw! The giant faces on the walls and the grandeur of the building make this place an absolute must do in the temple circuit.

Must see. Bayon is a must see. Smaller than Angkor Wat but for me much more intriquing, all those faces. You will need to see a few to appreciate it, but it's amazing. How, how long and how many people to achieve this wonder? Make sure you get your photo taken kissing one, your tour guide will show you where and how. There are so many Temples to see and each has a different story. If you have the time see them all, $60 for a 3 day pass spaced over 7 days is the way to go, and use a guide they know there stuff. Therea Suy is an excellent guide you won't go wrong with.(google him).

Temple of many faces. Twas the last temple to visit on that day but i was so energized that I still managed to get around the temple just fine. it was a very intersting magnificent structure. i was just awed by the history of this place and the many faces that covered the towers. our tour guide from sun same tours "sophome" allowede us to get to know the temple more.

Beautiful temple. Bayon was amazing. I would have liked to be there with less tourists around. The access to iconic stone faces and photo opportunities were really good. Photographers will love this place.

Beautiful temple..... U shld visit this temple after Angkorwat. Its also like that only but better. The ancient culture and and their way of building this temple makes u think of their strength back then in the 13th century wen they built it. its unbelievable....

My favourite Temple. It's just magical and it's quite a big complex so you feel like you're getting more for your money.
