I prefer the latter so I can spread it out over the week therefore not getting "temple fatique".

One of my favorite temples. The faces were so incredibly serene. Though tourists were swarming all over it, it was still fun to see and soak in the amazing large sculpted faces. The picture windows that peeked around every corner were also fun for a photo enthusiast such as I.

best temple. Bayon it very nice temple in siem reap angkor , it far from siem reap town abort 12km . it had a lot caving on the wall and in side .
Bayon it is very very smile temple in siem reap ,in side Bayon we can see small small too.

An absolute marvel!. This was my most favorite temple I visited in Siem Riep! Here’s a big tip: visit this temple early in the morning! We arrived here by 6am and we had the entire place to ourselves! There was nobody here and it was very peaceful and enjoyable! It was truly a treat. The temple is very unique with its stone faces carved everywhere. The stone faces are different and you’ll get some fantastic pictures. The early morning sun casts a golden light on some faces which make the pictures even more special. The craftsmanship is exquisite and you will really appreciate what it took to build this temple. This temple is breathtaking!
Preserved well with beautiful little nooks and crannies. Beautiful detailing still to see even after 100's of years. Well worth a visit! So impressed with stone etchings and detailing.

Bayon Wonders. It was worthwhile for us to wait in our vehicle for 20 mins than decided to walk tru the monsoon rain wearing raincoat and umbrella to storm the Bayon Temple.....than the rain stop at the long gallery ..What a a beautiful site and sightts after climbing to the top".. Our tour guide took some lovely good pixs here in the Bayon with the interesting 4-Faced Buddhas looking at us in all directions!...and walking tru the narrow gallery and rooms was fascinating..I think it's good to engage a tour guide so that we can be brief well on the history and stories of the Khmer kingdom..plus a comfortable Lexus 4-Wheel adds the comfort driving tru the monsoon rain in the afternoon..our Guide Mr.Charrya is a good choreographer and photographer too apart from speaking good English........it was a lovely experience for me and my hubby.....
Wonderfull. very beautiful temple many faces of Buddha..and about 54towers even you can take a pic with nose to now at the tower!
Must-see. One of my favorite temples in Siem Reap!!! Mysterious and grand. Can't imagine how the Khmers built this temple. Definitely a must-see landmark!
Super interesting. Go early since the causeway gets really crowded and the temple itself has narrow walkways. The faces are unique and wonderful!
The smile of God. Stunning place! Enjoy to photo all the smile faces of Bayon. Better to go in morning to avoiding hot weather and tourist.

A temple like no other. When i asked my friend who is a frequent Siem reap traveller for suggestions on what temples to visit on this trip, Bayon is among the top 3 choices.And i was not disappointed when i set foot on the grounds of the Bayon temple ruins.It was indeed a temple like no other in siem reap.My jaw dropped,admiring the impressive architecture and ornate carvings that depicted Khmer civilization and culture.This temple is the evidence of the degree of civilization of the Khmers of yore.The temple walls speak of their everyday life, religious beliefs,as well as the myths and legends and the concepts of good and evil.Truly amazing!In doing this temple or any other temple ruins in siem reap, a competent and accredited guide is very helpful.It is worth their professional fee as they will really elucidate on the temple's history and background.Though tipping is not necessary,it will be most appreciated by these gentle people.A good pair of walking/comfy rubber shoes and bottled water are a must. The tuktuk driver usually have a chest of cold bottled water ready to refresh the temple visitor for free. A camera/camcorder is an item a temple visitor must not forget in order to document the sights/sounds of the Bayon temple ruins.

A must do. I am pretty sure that every traveler going to Cambodia knows that this is a must do on your trip! Please don't be silly and climb on the old stones as conservation efforts are already huge!
Spectacular!!. Absolutely amazing to see. This temple completely blew me away. You have to see this if you are in Cambodia.
Incredible. I couldn't imagine how cambodian people built this. It is very impressive man made. It's a paradise for me. I spent hours looking for beautiful stone carving. It's worth paying a visit.
brilliant. loved how beautiful and amazing the place was, the history is incredible so accessible and reasonably priced

best temple. Bayon temple best and have a lot of caving in the Bayon temple and on the wall .bayon temple far from siem reap town bout 12 km . Bayon temple have gate 4 and have pick 54 . it is have only one cabodai .
A must see in Siem Reap. This was one of my favorite temples in Siem Reap. Its just amazing and beautiful. We spent some time there and were in awe of the stone carvings of faces.

Worth a visit. The Bayon temple is worth seeing. The carvings are superb and me husband and I loved the architecture. The elephant ride around the temple is a great experience and the photographs taken from that level are excellent.

amazing. amazing how people in those days built such temples and the engravings and carvings are so lifelike. do spend some time there with a guide to explain to you the history behind it.

Must see in Siem Reap. Huge structures with beautiful buddha faces. According to the tour guide, this is the only temple with bas-relief showing the daily lives of khmer people. It was meaningful and beautiful.
The best time to visit Bayon is in the morning. There are also elephants that one could ride around the circumference of the temple.

Amazing. A must see if you are visiting the area. The stone carvings are the most obvious things but as you walk through the temple check out the walls. There are some amazingly intricate stone relief carvings.
Bayon. A fantastic temple. Maybe my favorite among all the temples in Siem Reap. It's easy to spend many hours just at this temple.
unforgettable. The temple with the stony-looking face that appears at every corner and remains impressive every time it's seen. Evidently, it's difficult to avoid the crowds.

More wow factor in Siem Reap. So many temples to be explored - this one truly impressive. Was good to have a guide to tell the history and explain the significance of site. A very hot and humid time of year to visit - take water! A definite must visit when in Siem reap

good temple. Bayon temple is very nice temple in siem reap angkor wat good smil good stone please all to get ther . goo to see BAYON .
Faces are wonderful. I like Bayon temple and it is my favorite. I see elephant terace, royal palace, Ba phoun temple and Leperking terrace

Stunning. This was my last stop on a whole day tour. It was hot and humid and I thought I'd had enough but you can't help but be drawn in by this beautiful place. A must see, along with Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm

Temple of Faces. This was one of my faves, I love all the faces carved in the stone - our guide told us the many faces are all different faces of the king. We got some beautiful photos and the hindu stories are a lot of fun to hear about. If you look closely at the wall carvings you can see the different cultures - the faces of the chinese and the cambodians are very distinct. The chinese have beards and the cambodians have the long ears - fun for the kids and a nice walk through the temple. Stop by the information center and let the kids learn about how the temples were built, and they can use the wooden lever and see how the ancient people lifted the stones. Cool Place.

Fantastic!! A must see!!. By far, my most favourite temple there is in Siem Reap. I am completely beyond amazed with the detailing that went into building this structure considering the fact that there were no electrical tools and machinery back then. The faces stick in your memory forever. I went to Cambodia in July, which is considered low season. Still, there were crowds as I feel that Cambodia is becoming a booming tourist attraction - especially over these past couple of years. However, I went pretty early and there were less crowds. You do have the opportunity to climb the stairs up certain areas, which is also nice because you can see how everything looks from the top. There were locals dressed traditional Cambodian garments at the top of one area who let you take photos with them. It did take away a little bit from the "natural" beauty surrounding us. I really hope the bad traces of tourism doesn't make its way into these temples and in a couple years, I pray to God that there isn't some Starbucks at the very top. Fee: There is a $20/day pass if you go for 2 or 3 days. For one day, I think it's $30/day. Personally, I think that two days is enough for you to see the major temples (and some smaller ones as well).
Must see! Very interesting . Very interesting temple. There are heaps of photo opportunities. And a few stalls around for cold drinks. Would go again!
Magical. Went there for the sunrise - for 1 hour it was just me and all the faces. Sublimely magical! Get there before the big tours arrive, they completely spoil it.

A Picturesque Marvel of Cambodia. Hands down to this temple. The moment I saw Bayon, my jaw dropped to the ground. The astounding inscriptions on the stones would make you want to time travel back at the time the temple was being built. This is my favorite temple compared to other temples. I suggest you should visit this temple in the early hour of sunrise to avoid the crowd. Visiting Bayon at this time, would give you the luxury of time for appreciation and serenity. No noisy crowd would disturb you in adoring the magnificent details of Bayon. Upon reflecting, I was moved by the patience, dedication, and sacrfice of the workers and builders of this temple. Bayon's smiling faces are the marks of my Siem Reap memories.
Wonderful temple. There're 49 tower and each tower got 4smilling face.that was build by king JayavaramanVII was build the end of 12th cenaury and early 13th cenaury.also dedicated to bhuddism.

dancers brought color. I loved the enigmatic stone faces at Bayon, but not the hoards. Earlier or later might work better. One of my favourite. All those temples in Siem Riep, This is one of my favourite ever. I couldn't imagine how could human did this heavy rocks and transforming it into a face. The best one of the all!. This one is definitely my favourite and probably the one I had the least time at as we were heading off to a very disappointing sunset viewing from Phnom Bakheng as it was too cloudy. Spend as much time as you can here.

Fantastic Temple. The temple was very interesting. My husband and three kids aged 12, 11, & 8 also really enjoyed it. It was very hot the day we went so I recommend taking a wet face washer so you can cool yourself down. There are also a lot of uneven surfaces so good walking shoes would be of benefit. We had a private guide and driver from Water Buffalo tours. I would highly recommend using a guide otherwise you do not know the significance of what you are looking at.

Amazing . Loved Bayon.

Extra Charge but Worth It. This temple is fairly well preserved and has some of the best stone carvings in the area.
The tour guide will charge you extra to visit the temple, but pay the surcharge and go.

I Love Bayon temple. really resonates with me, not my first visit, but my favourite. This time I was able to come back to enjoy it again and loved it as much as the first time. There is something truly fascinating and special about this place
Awesome. Wear comfy shoes. Worth paying for a guide and take lots of water"..... Tuck tuck is a great way to go....
Majestic. Wonderful! Very impressive. Watched on-line documentaries of the ruins at our hotel, making the tour come alive.

Bayon Temple - Gigantic Smiling Faces of Buddha. Bayon Temple is a very interesting temple since it is a landmark for Buddhism and its various myths. Noteworthy is the huge smiling face of Buddha carved out of sandstone facing the north, south and west. As you go through the ruins, you will be transported to a heaven on earth with all the portals reflecting happiness and contentment. Many claim it is the portrait of KingJayavarman VII, who built the temple towards the end of the 11th century. The temple, however, is now the center of a massive restoration efforts by Japanese and French government and one can see the diggings and the gathering of pieces of relics within the grounds of the temple. The bas reliefs found inside the hallways of Bayon temple speaks of stories of old such as the churning of milk and asparas, the celestial dancers. They then became the symbol for beauty and the theme of traditional native dance.

amazing. What an amazing place the history, the sculpture and the spiritual feeling was something we won’t forget. We also went to the museum the day after which I would recommend it gives us a real understanding and more depth information of the temple.

Don't miss this one!. We loved Bayon, including the 100% touristy elephant ride around the perimeter. It's a great deal of fun to climb all over and find the faces. Our guide did a great job of guiding us to the most fun picture spots, too. We were also glad to see that fairly extensive preservation efforts are underway. The international community is pitching in to ensure that this treasure remains available for future generations to appreciate.

Wonderful place. Cant say about this place...amazeeeeeed place ever,4faces of Buddha and ancient temple. Oh my lovely god,how fascinating and wonderful place.Please,i want to stay more in this place.....siem reap beautiful....

visit to Bayon. it was aewsome as is every other temple in siem reap would highly recomend you use a guide all temples are so vast and so rich in history you could miss so much. and also fall pray to rogue guides who prey on unsuspecting visitors they will try and follow you round explaining and leading you on a mini tour and then request you pay them. The temple with mystic faces.. My favourite of all the angkorian temples. A must for lovers of sculpture. Beautiful. It was so beautiful. Amazing. It's hard to express how I feel about it. I just thought that it was really amazing, that's all.

a dream come true. it has been an overdue trip for me to Siem Reap.... i really was so excited to see the temples particularly Bayon temple as i am so fascinated with its features ( hundreds of faces)..... so when the time came for me to visit Bayon i was a bit sad because at the middle of our trip the rain pour.... but i never gave up... so on the fourth day of our tour i really cancelled some spots that we were suppose to vist and ask our guide if we could just go back to Bayon.... and i was so lucky the sun was so bright that day.... i really enjoyed the marvelous carvings and given the chance... i would surelly go back someday..... a visit to Siem Reap will be incomplete if you dont go to Bayon..... trust me.... and i will be worth remembering
Awesome. Excellent photo shoots. Choose the right guide and he will know the exact spots. This temple is one you can't miss

My favourite temple. Of all the temples visited in siem reap this was my favourite. It is smaller than angkor wat but it is also less crowded... The four faced towers are simply beautifull and the relief is imho also better looking than the one in angkor wat.
Usual. Crowded, touristy - like all other temples of the Angkor Wat. You can't feel anything. But you can come after 5 pm, when guard is not there any more and stay until dark.

Beat the Crowds. Bayon Temple is a Gem of a place especially if you beat the crowds. Plan to arrive around mid day, by then the morning crowds have left. Its all about planning. OK everyone wants to see the sun rise at Siem Reap and these crowds move onto Bayon, but if you head to another temple afterwards and then arrive at Bayon around mid day, the morning crowds would of moved on.

Wonder abound. Arriving at Bayon Temple was greeted with wonderment , across the road from the main entrance you could see the Elephant rides and Mahouts, waiting to take you for the experience of a lifetime, riding the elephants through the surrounds of the Park .Bayon is exquisite in size and sheer beauty of it all, was a sight & temple so worth while seeing .

Bayon Temple. This temple was simply amazing! A must visit. It is a wonder how people in the olden days were able to bring in such big boulders of stones and arrange them and than carve those beautiful big faces on four sides of each temple's top. The carvings on the walls, door entrances and pillars are done with such great precision. Simply amazing.

A must see by your own eyes.. Bayon temple is one of the temple around the Angkor Wat area which have its own uniqueness on the build which was told to be influence by the face of Buddha. It's a good experience to see the detail and message and history that told all along the build of this temple.

Beautiful Views. One of the few temples where you can appreciate the views of Angkor Wot. The sunset is supposed to be amazing from here but we had monsoon rain which prevented this. However, worth the visit and please wear comfortable shoes (trainers) as the steps are steep and in some cases, small. Also, Angkor Wot main temple does not allow visitors into the site if you are wearing shorts above the knees or vests i.e. sleeveless t-shirts. Shoulders must be covered.

The King's Face. In the Temple you will see the King's face intricately sculpted in the stones. Be prepared to marvel and delight at the serene scenery. Don't miss the place where you can take a photo that will fulfill your girls dream "To Kiss a Prince" but it's better than that, because its your highness most royal KING that will fulfill one of your sweet fantasy.
Ancient history. Another 'must see' when visiting Cambodia. Our guide was excellent and explained the background for the building of the temple.

Incredible. Incredible structure. Really worth a visit. Kept teenagers occupied for an hour.our guide batman planned our schedule for the day. You need about an hour to walk through and get some photos. It was very steamy when we went. Be sure to bring water. I like to get a guide for a few dollars to learn about what you are seeing.
Amazing. This was one of the best temples in siem reap. We went right before sunset and it was truly majestic. It was less crowded later in the day and photos turned out absolutely stunning.

One of my favourite temple. I loved this temple because of the unique structure. I liked being photoed where I face the face with the statue. It is a great place to wonder and get lost. Makes us wonder how did people make such fine artitecture

Amazing. I visited this temple early on in my trip, it was extraordinary! It was a great introduction to all that Angkor Wat has to offer and I thoroughly enjoyed my visit. There were many photo opportunities and it was nice to soak in the rich cambodian culture. This is a must see!

The Smile of Khmer :). We spent almost 3 hours in Bayon. It just simply amazing and breathtaking! We took a lot of pictures with the smiling Buddha.There was one man wearing the police cap taught us to snap the interesting pictures with the smiling Buddha.Nose-2-nose / face-2-face / 3 faces in the row. It is one of my favorite temples!!!
Amazing. So much culture and history! Make sure you bring water and hat! not much shades going over there. We went there around noon, maybe that´s why and not much people too.
Nice. Saw this in the rain so probably was not seen in the best conditions but still very impressive and amazing

A hidden gem. Not necessarily the first temple you'd visit, but well worth it. Our tuktuk driver informed us that Bayon is the region and so includes both Angkor Thom and Bauphon so I'm taking this to be true and both are well worth a look. Angkor Thom is more haphazard than Angkor Wat but this gives a definite element of excitement but Bauphon is a hidden gem. Far from the most well known, it's more open than the others and is the only temple (I think) you can climb to the top of, which is not only exciting but affords great views. Certainly worth a visit.
One Of The Top 3. We got lots of amazing photos here. Go early to avoid the heat and the people. This was one of our three favourite.

Our pick of the Wats we saw. We liked the variety, and the scale of it. Angkor Wat is impressive of course, but this one grabbed us more. A nice interesting wander around different buildings. More personal feeling.

Beautiful. I love this temple. I got to visit this on my first day at Siem Reap. The smiling sandstone faces above was worth the climb. One word: Beautiful. The best part, it wasn't that high a climb. Add to that, there's just so much material for amateur photographers (yep, just me and my faithful digicam) such as myself. I wish I could have stayed longer and given the chance, I'm definitely coming back.If you wish to see photos of this place, check out my blog post at http://thirtyandme.wordpress.com/2014/06/29/tomb-raider-for-a-day/

Ahhhh Siem Reap. I have made a visit for the last five years to Siem Reap Im hooked on Siem Reap and Cambodia!!!Ankor thom is one of my Fav. Go when there is less people Early am or lunch time.Hints, hire the same driver for everyday,Cost is about 20 us a day.Get a 3 day pass.Make sure u know where the pick up is after u visit each temple or u will get lost!!!You enter one way exit another.The people of Cambodia r very kind and honest no problems with drivers.The tuk-tuk is the way to golots of fun!!!Make sure u visit the lake near by very interesting lots of fishing villages and a floodedforest as well.Take a birding trip well worth the money!!loved it!!Please!!! do not take a Elephant rides its is heartbreaking.No food water all day Asian Elephants backs are full of bones not ment to be ridden.This is abuse in its fullest form.So many end up with broken backs,hips and they are still working AT different camps.They r kept chained up at night work all day.Go to a rescue park instead!!!

Smiling faces temple :). Our guide called this the Smiling Faces temple, an excellent reference! We took the first hour with an archeological guide who gave us the history of building materials and the attention being paid to its restoration. We then were able to walk through a large restoration site and see first hand the restoration process. We then had a second guide who was intimately familiar with many unknown tidbits: Look for the turtle biting the soldier and his female campaign laughing!
Impressive. Impressive place..how it was built and carved out from the stones, nice pictures we got from there and good preservation of the place

Best of the Lot. To my mind Bayon Temple outshines Angkor Wat, the buildings are phenomenal and you stand at gape at this architectural marvel. You are able to scurry around inside and climb where you really shouldn't. The sense of adventure adds to the experience. A photographers delight an amazing shot around ever corner. Not to be missed.
Faces. We visited Bayon twice while in Siem Reap. At dawn, we were virtually alone to watch as the early morning light lit the faces. An amazing experience.

Beautiful temple. This is the central temple in the walled city of Angkor Thom. Don't miss this temple. It's huge and beautiful. We went here in the morning (around 9am). We were lucky it was sunny. However, there were a lot of tourists already. Perhaps an earlier visit has lesser tourists.There's an on-going restoration of this temple. There's crane and other construction equipment. Somehow they look awful in pictures. But you can try the other sides of the temple for better photo ops.You can have an elephant ride around Bayon temple. I believe this is only where you can ride an elephant.

Magnificent temple. All are very beautiful temples in siem reap with lots of walking and climbing but worth it.
Too bad June is raining reason so couldn't see sunrise nor sunset.
Traveling from Oct to Jan was advised by local.
Beyond my expectations. While I knew a little about this complex, I was overwhelmed by the magnitude and the beauty. Around each corner was something new and wonderful.
Early Morning Visit. Check out Bayon earlier in the day to avoid crowds flowing from Angkor Wat. Take your time to explore every corner of this ruin.

Face to face. Can get up and close to the faces in the temple
Was very busy by 9am. Try to do sunrise at Angkor Wat, then Bayon temple and then back to Angkor Wat just in time for the climb to the 'Temple of Heaven'

Main attraction. Easily the main attraction of Angkor Wat. We managed to do a sunrise tour. Great display of the sun rising above Angkor Wat before heading out to see the other temples. Can be crowded at times and there are plenty of people offering their souvenirs to you

Superb!! BUT avoid Chinese Group Tour in Late Morn!!. I visited Angkor Wat at 8 Am before came here Bayon at around 9 AM ; Temple itself small than i pictureque in my mind; Many werido Apsara Faces carving at all each Khmer pagoda; Look like they stared to you in all direction; It will be very daytime delightful with happy visited UNLESS IF I NOT HAD BAD LUCK visit same time the CHINESE GROUP TOUR CAME!!! it like DISASTER!! from quiter place it turn out to be a ruined places by all middle women and men ages of chinese group runing around climbing up temple ; yelling ;shouting ;spitting; no picture queue line ; This was nightmare for me!!!
good face of king. i travel there many time and spend good time at bayon face during sunset , feel amazing, Recommend sen set time ,
Beautifully Ruined. It's a beautiful ruin located near Angkor Wat. It's not as big as Angkor but its majestic and historically significant image is definitely worth witnessing.
Beautiful!. Loved this little temple, the second one I visited after Angkor Wat and was pleasantly surprised. Definitely one of my favourite ones in Cambodia. Best to be covered early in the morning.
Amazing. Much better in real life than in pictures.If you visit Siem Reap and angkor area i know you will not miss this temple, so just enjoy it!

Angkorpiece of Angkor Thom. TA shows this as the #1 attraction in the area as opposed to Angkor Thom, which weighs in at about #6. Fan-driven but makes no sense, since the Bayon is the central temple of Angkor Thom, and the whole ensemble works together as an integrated microcosm.Comparative ratings of UNESCO World Heritage Sites should be irrelevant. The Bayon is far more chaotic than the central complex of Angkor Wat--not only is it built over a pre-existing cruciform floor-plan, but apparently Jayavarman VII kept changing his mind. At this scale, that must have driven his architects bonkers. While artistically this is deplorable, for the casual Indiana Jones wannabes, it's great fun. While it sure isn't harmonious, it's a heck of a labyrinth! That emerald scarab's gotta be round here somewhere!The selling point is the enigmatic smiling Buddhas. Don't kid yourself about J-7's devotion. I ascribe to the notion that all those smug Buddha faces are his own egotistical images--though the sculptors glossed over his leprosy. And as the model of the mother of Buddha--the Perfection of Wisdom-- his own Mum!Some parts of the Bayon are intrinsically unsafe, such as virtually vertical ancient stone stairways with extraordinarily narrow treads and highly uneven surfaces. Use safety sense, particularly if it's raining.

Excellent!Majestic! ANGKOR WAT COMPLEX.. Truly remarkable temple. Great photo op! Ta Phrom Temple is the true "Indiana James " experience. Massive Angkor Wat is the Vatican of the Kingdom. Night market in old town Siem Reap was fun and great dining with Lek Krong my guide!
Great temple. Bayon is a very huge temple that took us around two hours to walk around in. It is walking distance to Baphuon, the Elephant Terrace and other temples

Amazing Bayon!. Bayon's architecture was amazing. The faces on the walls, the mere size of the structure, the magical way the whole structure feels. A must-visit when you are in Angkor, and don't miss the surrounding areas too!

Bayon is My Favorite. I've been touring all of the temples in Siem Reap for 5 days now and Bayon is by far my favorite. It is just so grand and beautiful. While it's hard to take a picture that really expresses how impressive it is, you also cannot take a bad picture in the place. Everything is beautiful. I've already been there twice and might go back again.

This was also lots of fun. We visited many temples during our trip to Siem Reap. Bayon Temple was definitely our favourite. It was beautiful and our tour guide was able to show us many of the popular places to take photos. Very interesting and lots to see. While there, we also took an elephant ride around the temple.
OUTSTANDING. Take the kids here - they will be so inspired. Truly one of the wonders of the world - we preferred actually to Angkor Wat, so did the kids.

That's a whole lotta faces. Bayon Temple is located right smack dab in the middle of Angkor Tom. It's known for its many, many stone faces. If you are only spending a limited amount of time in Siem Reap, and can only tour for a day, make this temple, along with Angkor Wat, the gates of Angkor Tom, Ta Prohm, and maybe Banteay Srey the temples you visit. Basically, if you stick with tripadvisor ratings for "things to do in Siem Reap", you won't go wrong.My advice for this temple and all temples in Siem Reap is to get a good guide. You will get so much more out of the experience.
Beautiful Bayon. Beautiful Bayon is a must see... so calm and peaceful. You will appreciate it best when there are very few tourists around. Full of history and works of art!

Great Complicated Compex. This complex was much more compact and concentrated than Angkor Wat. There was much more to see and the maze like pathways made it much more engaging of a site.This is definitely on the list of temples to visit in addition to Angkor Wat

Fantastic Temple. What a great place to visit the many faces were interesting as they were all a bit different. The walls are craved with so many scenes of ordinary life and great battles. They are amazing. You should wear good shoes to visit as you really need to watch your step on the stones and stairs. This temple is a good place to visit.
a sight to behold. nothing to dislike,so much to see would need three weeks but by that time you would be sick of temples

In one word....BREATHTAKING !!!!. This place is a place of rest and relaxation....for many people over century's .... Now it's fantastic to be able to be part of that but expect too be part of several thousand that visit the same day as you...it is brilliant but the numbers that visit here are rising by the day every day , and every year ...get here now the world arrives to take a look.. A good tip come here very early in your day or very late in your day and you will encounter less people... But truly Fantastic doesn't even bring it into words :-).... Go take look and smile .....
Breathtaking. There's no words to describe how beautiful this temple was. It's one of the most beautiful temples around there. Just... go there

ONE OF THE BEST. Have fun spotting the many faces on the walls! Really amazing and beautiful temple. Only thing that bothered me was the crowd- because it's so famous, many tourist groups arrive there and make so much noise and treat the place like a photoshoot location. Perhaps go to this temple later in the afternoon when the crowd is gone and you can have some peace and quiet and admire its beauty. Most people go to this temple after sunrise at Angkor wat so mornings would be most crowded.

Being Indie. This is seriously like something out of Indiana Jones. While the Angkor Wat vicinity is touristy you manage to escape people to feel like you are an adventurer in a long forgotten temple with dark passageways to turn a corner to see an unforgettable breathtaking stone carving. Be sure to check out the lower level. The upper level containing the stone unique faces is equally as beautiful. The size and uniqueness of each will surely blow your mind.
Beautiful temple. The Temple is one of the nicest temples of Angkor Wat. You should go during the sunset as the faces light up in the warm light of the sunset.
Fascinating. This temple is very near Ankor Wat and well worth a visit. The large faces of Buddha seem to look at you from everywhere.

So much to explore. Angkor Wat is teeming with almost as many temples as tourists - and this one is one of the unmissable ones!! At first glance you might not realise the gem you are about to visit but as you start to wind your way through the narrow spaces to emerge on top to view the world from this ancient site, you realise that this is one of the most spectacular sites in the world.
Wow. Just amazing. We loved everything about Bayon. Take your walking shoes to the entire complex! It really helps to be able to walk around and get different perspectives on the faces
Breathtaking. Another iconic symbol of Cambodia and it really didn't disappoint. The many faces are fascinating and allow for many photo ops. Wasn't busy for me when I went a couple of days ago.

Breathtaking Temple. I bought a 3 day ticket(40USD) and cycled my way around Angkor area which is rented from my hotel. I recommend any cyclist to start cycling at 4.30am so that you can reach Angkor Wat around 5.15am for the sunrise(Its around 9KM distance). Everyone wanted to catch the sunrise, so it will be crowded at Angkor Wat. Hence, after taking a few pictures for the sunrise, i cycled deeper towards the Bayon Temple. This temple is around 2KM away from Angkor Wat, just straight ahead following the road to more temples. Before reaching the temple, you will cross a bridge, which at the side it was decorated with lots of statues. The gateway at the end of the bridge is a good place for photo too!From what i read, the temple was in ruines when discovered, hence you expect to see most parts of the temple are being reconstructed or renovated. You can climb up the temple and look at the parts above. The sculptures are very beautiful with the local god's face on them. Definitely a good place to go. Totally recommended!
Best Temple to Visit. Nice carvings around the temple. Very scenic. Perfect temple to take photos. Visited at noon time, it got really really warm.

Must Visit!. This is one of the most iconic temples that one must visit in Siem Reap. Walking around Bayon is breathtaking, as one admires the melancholy of beautiful stonework and architecture, set atop a backdrop of clear blue skies.

temples etched with happy faces : in a labyrinth.  Bayon temple has less visitors than the other bigger Angkor Wat. A few minutes ride from the Ankor Wat . There are labyrinthine pathways inside. The happy faces are etched and carved in stone . They are seen better from afar. Elephant rides around the Bayon temple can be had for US 15 dollars per person

Beautiful but Busy. The Banyon Temple, while large, is smaller than some of the other sites and it can get congested (both inside, and outside where there are a huge number of vendors, tuk tuk drivers, etc.). There is no water surrounding it, so if one must choose where to visit first thing in the morning, this one can be photographed and visited later in the day. Because of the bustle in the area, there are some interesting photo opportunities (such as the tuk tuk drivers "working" with the temple in the background).

Hide and seek at Bayon. This temple is located at the heart of Angkor Thom. Bayon's maze-like quality makes it a pleasure for hide-and-seek; that's why our tour guide's always excited about this place, his favorite of all the Angkors as this used to be his playground during his childhood days. Temple has narrow and perplexing chambers and corridors with so many faces virtually smiling at you (think of the enigmatic Mona Lisas everywhere looking at you), scary.
A temple with 54 faces. Aside seeing the very beautiful temple on foot, we also went around it on an elephant! A unique and fun experience!
Bayon. I really liked this temple. You can take a picture with the smiling Buddha and place your nose at the proper place so it looks like your nose is touching the Buddha's nose.
They're looking at you. Loved this temple even though we spent a relatively short time hereSo many towers with amazing faces

Amazing!. Loved that so much conservation activities are taking place. Makes me feel assured the Temple will have many more years ahead of it.
Didnt like the hordes of loud tourists disrespecting the place.
Amazing. Amazing Place to visit. Pay $20 and you have admission to all 3 temples. Bayon was the last temple to be built in Angkor with 216 gigantic faces carved in to stone.

Amazing. Bayon temple was just like I imagined it would be but 100 times better.To stand there and to look at the carved stone faces looking at you was truly amazing.We were there early so not a lot of people about, it seemed when we were walking around the temple we were the only people there, This was my favourite temple.Wear good walking shoes as there is a lot of walking to do
Cambodia Temples. Very cool. You won't be disappointed.You will never look at other temples like this one. Be sure to visit.

wonderfull!. wonderfull old temple, one of the best temple in the world, well is my opinion!ticket is 20 $ for one admission, and 60$ for 7 admission. Best time for visit is a early morning (7am). Highly recomended.

We went twice to this temple!. This temple is very amazing and it just stole our heart, we actually decided to come back to Bayon on the 3rd day just because we want to see it again and capture more pictures of it.

Lots of Face sculptures. Not much view from outside, but beautiful face sculptures once inside. Quite a few structures have crumbled and you can see restoration work being carried out. Not too big an area and you can walk and explore this within an hour.

Interesting for the carved faces. Did this one as last of a circuit, - 4th in the day. It is getting pretty warm by lunchtime, and you get a bit "templed out" Be aware that the passageways inside can be a bit narrow in places.This may hit some people who get calustrophbic, though you always have light within 10 metres, so can exit quickly.Less easy to avoid in these passages, the Japanese tour groups with guides who on our day were going the reverse direction to the arrows, and stopping every few metres for everyone to take a picture of everyone else and every group combination by every doorway.... sigh (my pet peeve world-wide)So a 5 minute walk through 2 passageways took half an hour, and we spent most of it being blocked and or shouldered aside by various VERY self-absorbed people.This was low season (June), it must be near impossible to negotiate during peak season.
Not all temples are the same. It can be said that all temples look the same but each has a different story to tell, have you walking shoes on and make sure you have insect repellant just in case
Very nice!. Nice temple, different from Angkor Wat. Make sure you wear good shoes and maybe bring a raincoat. We did not need a guide, as the sites are impressive enough on their own.
A must see. Simply amazing. This is one you must see when in Siem Reap. I would go with a guide to have the explanation to go wight he beautiful ruins you will see.

"Where's Indiana Jones??". If you like photographing old temples, then Bayan is a dream come true. Covered in vines and more recently nearly as ancient scaffold and sprouting enormous fig trees, this truly is a beautiful temple complex. To beat the crowds that flock there, make this temple your first stop off for the day, arriving as early as you can get yourself out there. You wont be disappointed!!!!
The best one. The best one from all temples here (we saw almost all). It our number 1. In the april-may there is not so much tourist in Cambodia.
Lovely!. My group and I loved our visit here. That is about all I can say about this site since there were so many wonderful places here!
You will FACE amazing architecture. Quite amazing how clearly visible those faces are, great work! Very busy over here, but well worth a visit!

Breathtaking!. It is one of the must see sites in Angkor Thom. We had hired a guide for the entire day to accompany us to all sites and it was money well spent. We got to learn so much history and details about the restoration work that is in progress. Definitely recommend hiring one of the official government guides for the day.

Beautiful Bayon. You can't help but smile as you walk around Bayon. Beautiful smiling faces looking down at you.It's amazing to photograph so get there early in the morning to avoid the crowds - it's busy even in low season. So good I went twice!

The best temple. My favorite time visiting Bayon Temple. it is value time and fun with lovely smiling face of Buddha and the fresh views around temple. When I saw the faces, I feel I was at the time of building the temple - the Khmer Empire. You should take more time to do it in early morning to get away from the crowded tourists.

No review can describe the Experience...!. One of my top three picks in Angkor wat. One can spend hours in this complex just admiring the beauty of the Bayon faces, architecture, and changing moods during the day. It comes right after the Angkor wat. A quick visit will take one hour, but one can spend a whole day here. This can be visited any time of the day. Sun rise, Sun set or noon. Each smiling face look different from different angles. If I visit again, I would definitely spend more time here. Hope you too enjoy it.
My favorite!. Do not miss Banyon!! I personally thought it was even more beautiful than Angkor Wat.. We went to it last in our temple tour, and I'm glad we did! Save the best for last..

Truly unique Temple. Coming from India, temples need to be truly unique to make an impression on you, and this one certainly fits the bill. Large faces unlike anything you have seen before, each representing a province of Cambodia at that time, is a truly unique experience.A must visit on your trip. Plan to spend some time there rather than making it a quick stop.
Amazing arcitecture. 3 faced large statues On top of temples. So many of them close by over awe you. The entrance to this complex is also very inspiring. A must visit

Good Place to relax. I like this temple as it has many statue made me feel like amazing!But you need to becarefull as some part is under renovation!Would recommend it to others guest to visit here after Angkor Wat.
Great. Pne of my favorites, id say to go early but aløways crowed... like out of Lara Croft movie... very cool
Amazing. This site can be descibed in one world - amazing.all thoses faces, all details, very impressed. The nature around the temple is oovely,

Intricate temple with 100s of Buddha faces. One of the highlights of Angkor Wat where you can observe transition from Hinduism to Buddhism in historical context of Khmer empire.Definitely must see during Angkor Wat visit.

The Faces. I went to see Angkor Wat and found myself in awe of Bayon Temple. The hundreds of faces carved into the temple were breathtaking. You haven't visited Siem Reap without seeing this monument in Angkor Thom :-)
Good place to visit. This place is very fantastic place i like to see. Would recommend it to others. Feeling very comfortable!

Majestic. I couldn't help but be in awe of the structure and imagine what must have taken place centuries ago in this very site. The architecture is something to behold and it's hard to fathom how this was built. We planned to spend a few minutes here but ended up taking in every part of the temple for a long while.

Come early to avoid the crowds. We visited Bayon immediately after Angkor Wat without going back for breakfast, at about 7 am.We nearly had the whole temple to ourselves to soak in the atmosphere.Compared to the much hyped, commercialized, and crowded Angkor Wat experience, Bayon and the whole Angkor Thom allowed us to get up close and personal with the architecture of that time.Just beware the unofficial guides who will cozy up to you at the entrance to try to get you to hire their services; their English is not all that good, and you may find yourselves trying to interpret meaning than enjoy the attraction.

Great Buhdas. See this before Angkor Wat. It is different, less overpowering, but a must see in my book. All the statues have Buhda's faces on 4 sides-North, South, East and West. Hot, wear hat, take umbrella, sunscreen, comfortable shoes for walking.
Amazing!. Don't miss this temple! It's smaller to walk through than Angkor Wat & Ta Prohm, but the faces on the pillars are not to be forgotten.
Mt. Rushmore, eat your heart out. Ancient carvings of Buddha's faintly smiling face; narrow, mysterious passageways. You can wander around it all.
Very cool!. Really enjoyed this temple. Although it is in worse shape than Angkor Wat, it has a very "Indiana Jones" feel and had fewer people. I would definitely recommend visiting this one.

A must see!. We were so tired coming in from the tour of Angkor Wat but we were still amazed by this temple complex. The carvings of the 4 Buddha faces are stunning.
Make sure you wear sunscreen as there is very little shade in the area. But the hike up the stairs and the scorching sun are all worth it.

amazing construction and unique. the architecture is impressive, all those 4 headed statues, it is a must for all visiting Siem Reap. I spent a lot of time watching the sculptures , passing to different chambers. It was not at all crowded when I arrived and being independent traveler, not with some organised group, I could take my time admiring the details.
Great cultural landscapes. This is the most amazing landscape of Angkor Wat areas ,with unique architecture made by Cambodia people,you will never it at anywhere else in the world !

Absolutely fascinating and other worldly..... How can anyone miss this absolutely iconic site as it is a total masterpiece in stone masonry. Each buddha face is different and unique and it is quite a sizeable complex.
Can only echo the words and sentiments of the other reviewers here who found Bayon a truly awesome and monumental site.

Don’t miss it if you get a chance. Lovely!. They are all amazing but this one is so unique... It was THE stand out. The others kinda blurred into each other, but those faces, I just couldn't get enough of them…

Another Great temple. loved every minute - make sure you have plenty of time to visit the whole temple it has loads of great picture opportunities make the most of it. Go early before the rush, wear sensible shoes and appropriate dress-

Wonderful structures. Superb visit; this is my favourite temple in Siem Reap, due to the prominence of the many multi-faced stone towers. This is reasonably central, and the site is easy to navigate and explore on foot.

Breathtaking. Absolutely amazing experience! If you go to Cambodia and don't see the Angkor Wat complex you are missing out! We went to Angkor Wat early to see sunrise and then came back mid-day to tour the other temples in the area. Bring A LOT of water, it's ridiculously hot!

My favourite temple!!. A must see and my number 1 temple!! Great for photography! Make sure you come to this temple early before the large tour groups arrive - we got here around 7am - the tour groups started to arrive at 8am.

Must - Visit - This - Temple. every single yuk yuk driver, bus driver, Tour Guide has this temple of their route.
stunning, breathtaking and well worth it way before the sun starts to set in so you can take the time to truly enjoy this wonder
Bayon. too many groups with their guides but overall a beautiful place. dont forget to bring plenty of water! and a hat! go there before heading to Angkor Wat. that way you avoid the crowds.
Simply magical. What can one say that has not already been said. I truely wonderful place and well worth a visit. So many things to look at.
Mystic. History comes alive at Byon temple. Try to visit early in the morning to avoid sun, ensure that you have a good guide and plenty of water.
Breathtaking and unusual. What can I say? You really need to see it for yourself. I have always wanted to visit and now I have, I suggest you do the same. A life changing experience
Beautiful. Wonderful temple, its great for pictures and a good look at history. Easy to get to all the temples with a tuk tuk.
Left the temples smiling. This is one of my favourite temples in Siem Reap. There is something calming about walking around the smiling faces. A must see for visitors to the park.

A "Must See" Temple. One of the stops on our private tour with the Angkor Helping Tour, was this beautiful temple! The huge Angkor Wat Temple is more famous but travelers who stop at this temple will want to go back again and again! We took more photos at the Bayon Temple than any other location on our 4 day trip to Cambodia. This temple is a very short drive from Angkor Wat and should not be missed if you have the time!
Awesome. One of the top 3 temples. Atmospheric, and nicer than Anchor Wat. Timing is critical, so make sure you have a guide to advise when to miss the hoards.

Awesome!. Just stunning to see. I loved it so much, I visited twice. Really beautiful and mysterious and the Bas Reliefs on the outer walls depicting the cambodians ancient history are incredible. Do not miss this if you go to Angkor!

The highlight of any visit to Angkor. Whilst Angkor Wat may be the biggest Bayon is the best, in my opinion. It may not strike you immediately, but give it time as you climb up from below and emerge to a forest of faces said to resemble the once great God King Jayavarman VII. Of all the temples of Angkor it is said that Bayon is the most romantic. It's also one of the closest to Angkor Wat. If your time is limited and there are only so many temples you can visit, do yourself a favour and get yourself down to the Bayon!
Worth a see. Worth the visit and so interesting to see. Amazing what was done and now the renovations. Had a pleasant walk around and some shade to rest away from the heat. Must see

Just incredible.. Angkor Wat is great, but the Bayon is unlike any of the other temples. The sheer number of Budda sculptures is simply astounding. Be careful of young kids trying to scam you for school supplies - they all have a similar story about how they lost their parents and that they need money for school.
If you have to pick one, this is it!. Of all the temples, this is by far the most magnificent…from the entrance/draw bridge to all the faces!
My favorite. Something different, my favorite temple overall! Great interaction w the jungle. Thought I saw Indiana Jones in one section!

Loved it!. The Bayon should definitely be on your go-to list when visiting the temples of Angkor. We really enjoyed our visit, despite the heat ...and all the other people there!! Great photo ops, I probably took my nicest shots around the Bayon Temple close to sunset. Highly recommend this place.
Amazing !!!!!!!!!!!!!!1. My wife and I watched sunrise from here at 5:30 am. There was no one else there. We had the place to ourselves for 2 hours. Kind of like being Indiana Jones and Lara Croft.
lets get templed. one of the many temples at the site. Well worth a trip around and you get receive a blessing while you are there...

Majestic Khmer Era. Actually I visited SRP wayback 2011, month of May. Everytime I heard Cambodia the first thing/place that pops up in my mind is the Angkor Wat but hey there are actually lots of temples to visit around the area not only Angkor Wat.Visiting Bayon Temple is an opportunity to travel the ancient era of Khmer Kingdom. The temple is made up of blocks of stone and where you can also spot the gigantic faces of Buddha. No perfect word/s to define the beauty of Bayon Temple with amazing architecture that every block of stone has its own story. Kudos for the ancient khmers who made this amazing temple and for all cambodians at present time who are one in hand in preserving all temples around SRP.

Worth Visiting. For people interested architecture and archaeology, this place is definitely awe inspiring. For others, please reach Bayon when you fresh in the morning or when towards the end of your day to sit back and soak the majestic feel of Bayon.

Temple of faces. We went to Bayon twice. The 1st time our camera batteries went dead so we couldn't take any photos. We went back a couple of days later after seeing the sunrise at Angkor Wat. Because most people go back to town for breakfast after the sunrise or stay there to look around for a couple of hours we were able to enjoy some peace and quiet at several temples before the crowds caught up. Well worth visiting as early as you can, for us this was at about 7-00 am after enjoying the sunrise for a while.
Must see. the beautiful four visage carvings, its a small temple but very beautiful. it gets crowded with tourist group but i was lucky to visit first thing in the morning
must see. one of the must see site near Angkor. all tuk tuk will service tourist sit but need bargaining. Most are quite honest with mark up to one or two US dollars.
Impressive. The most impressive temple from the Angkor area. the Buddha faces on the towers are gigantic and it is a great start to your walking trip in the temple area

Must see. A part of the city Angkor Thom with impressive statues. The heads are wonderful and its unbelievable they could build these statues such a long time ago. There was contsructions going on but definatly a must see when you are there. Was there in afternoon, not that crowdy but it was hot.

Magical place. Well over any Maya temples, this place is simply magic.It is recommended to come several times in the day, since the color and the expression of the Bouddha/Jayavarman VII face change during the day
Lovely to do in the morning. You get some lovely pictures and having a guide explain all the history is amazing. There are often locals dressed in cultural clothes you can take a photo of.

Great place to go!. Very nice, I enjoy the scene a lot.
We had a very passionate and friendly guide, thanks to him, we have a better understanding our the whole history.

Amazing to see!. This temple is a must see if you are in Siem Reap. The faces everywhere are a sight to see. So many photo ops everywhere. Try to make sure you go as early as possible to avoid the hundreds or thousands of tourists that may be there. We preferred this temple to Angkor Wat.
My favourite of the temples. This temple has large faces of Buddhas on all walls- it is quite say broken up and ruined but still very mystical and interesting temple. preferred it to Ankor Wat.

Must do in Siem Reap but swarming with tourists. It's a beautiful and interesting temple but the experience was slightly ruined by the hundreds of other people milling about. Suggest going early in the morning or later in the afternoon to avoid the crowds and heat (as mush as is possible in Cambodia).
Love it. I am just so fascinated by this temple. I took so many photos that I am going to enlarge one for my house, so that I can always see it.
Must see!. Definitely a must see if you are in Siem Reap! The faces carved in stone are a photographer's delight. About a 10 min drive from Angkor Wat.
Hundreds of Buddha heads. Excellent temple with plenty of photo opportunities with the Buddha heads around this temple. Nice bas relief of daily cambodia life which are still very well maintained.
amazing. make the completre round at the firstlevel to see the 'bas relief' some are describing the life of the people during the XII century.

Favorite Temple - Go Early!. This was my favorite temple, and my wife's second favorite. Everything everyone says about it is true; amazon faces, detailed bas relief walls, and open temple that you can climb around and explore. My tip is to come early. We started at 4:30a, so we could watch the sunrise at Angkor Wat. However, we only stayed at Angkor Wat long enough to see the sun come up (we then came back in the late afternoon, around 4p when the sun and the light really highlight the beauty of Angkor Wat). Then, at the advise of our tour guide, we went into the Bayon Temple. Since we were there about 6a it was still very quiet and we had the entire temple to ourselves. Time to explore, take photos, and to finish watching the sun come up. Enjoy! It's a beautiful temple.

Come for the bas-relief alone. We knew this was one of the places to see while we were in Siem Reap, but didn't quite know why until we saw it for ourselves.Bayon Temple, inside Angkor Thom, is a work of art and one created out of shear magic. The artwork on the outside walls (known as bas-relief) was something at which to marvel. How carving such intricate scenes of Buddhist tales over 1,000 years ago is possible I'll never know. Seeing the faces and, of course, getting a photo with you nose to nose with one of them is cute, but you should certainly go to see stonework on the outside.
One of the best. One of the top two for sure. Climbing around is fun! Bring proper clothes (no shorts, dresses, short sleeves).

A Thousand faces to see. The most distinctive feature of this temple is the multitude serene faces which they call 'thousand faces of buddha' that jut out from all around the peaks of the temple. We were not able to climb this temple because it was quite high and steep and we were all very tired as it was really very hot. So we just decided to take a lot of pictures as the panoramic scene was magnificent. It is truly a work of art. I asked our tour guide, Noun Chan Sarak who incidentally is very fluent in English, educated and very kind and I was told that the best time of the year to visit Siem Reap is in November when the climate is cooler. I suggest you get a tourist guide to be able to appreciate their history. Tourists are brought to a centralized site where we hAve to pay fees for all the sites and temples you would like to see.

A real WOW kind of place. This was the very first place my driver from the FCC says I should go to. Of course I listened since this is my first time in Angkor. What a sight!!! Everywhere you looked there is a face looking at YOU. Makes you think actually. I am here for 4 days so I know I didn't want to get temple out so this was just perfect place to chill and take in the whole Angkor Wat thing. You never should miss this place if you are in Siem Reap.
awe-inspiring. The temple makes for really memorable pictures which more than make up for the heat and the difficulty of climbing up and down its steps.

Awesome. One of the best three. Our 2 year old grand daughter loved the elephant ride. The Bayon's most distinctive feature is the multitude of serene and massive stone faces on the many towers which jut out from the upper terrace and cluster around its central peak

magnificient!. To me its rhe most beautiful of all wats... the carving are superb, not as big as angkor wat but big enough... u cn see everyday daily activities of the ppl carved all around the temple... superb restoration work..

Temples Galore. Our family thoroughly enjoyed exploring the temple ruins in Seim Reap...we chose to bicycle from town and throughout the temple grounds...in hindsight we were exhausted by the end of the day and a tuk-tuk would be the wiser choice,

Smiling Buddha. Loved the faces of smiling Buddha and the crumbling ruins of Bayon. Wish I had more time to explore it, but we had to move on. Plus the heat and humidity were overbearing. Winter should be a good time to visit the temples.

Best of the lot. We found Bayon the best temple we have visited in SEA. The only problem being all the people trying to get you to give donations to the monks via purchasing incense sticks. Don't be scammed by this, not only is it disrespectful if you are not a follower of the religion but it also does not go in the pockets of the monks. Make sure you explore the surrounding areas and not just the main Bayon Temple in Angkor Thom.
great way to learn history. the carvings tell us the great epics from India and the way the guide took us was also fine. The climb up and down was also good.

big temple. this is the 2th big tempe after angkor wat
this is different with angkor temple
this temple want to tell us how people living and many army

Magnificent, detailed. Bayon temple is situated at the start of the Light Circuit tour of Angkor Thom... The temple is much more in ruin than Angkor Wat, but itself is magnificent... Most of the temple towers have the distinct design of four faces on each wall, ranging from small to huge! Must visit. Recommended time to visit Bayon is in the morning, as the sunlight is perfect during that time for a great view and photos.

Bayon: The Gem of Angkor. Due to some communication issues with our Tuk Tuk driver, we had some trouble finding Bayon on our walk from the royal temple but the minute we saw it, we knew it was worth the trek!Bayon is immediately memorable and breathtaking because of the different faces on the towers. The temple is relatively well preserved and the detailed carvings are some of the best on any of the temples we saw. It was the perfect way to end our first day of temple touring! Don't miss this one!

Amazing place. Though not that big compared to some, we absolutely loved this temple. Faces smiling down on you from all angles and easy to navigate around. Our guide talked us through the carvings on the walls, fascinating stories of the lives of the people of the country. Well worth having a guide,as they really bring the history and religion of the temples to life for you. This was my second favourite place, next only to Ta Prohm. Definitely worth a visit.
Must visit this wonderful site in Siem Reap. Must visit this awesome ancient site once in a lifetime, we had great time in Siem Reap and would like to visit once again

Must visit. Bayon is a more compact temple you don't need to walk a lot to cover like Angkor Wat, especially under the sun. The facial expression from caving is amazing and you just need to turn your head to appreciate many of them without walking around. The terrace is friendly too even elderly can climb up and down without much problem.
Nice Ancient Architect.. Very nice Temple. Must visit. Unique architecture. Simply loved it. Don't forget to take your camera.Highly recommended.

a must see while in Angkor. Bayon is a really cool temple as it looks like it's falling down and has unique elements (like the large faces). We went early in the morning and were the only ones there (as opposed to the crowds at Angkor Wat at sunrise).

Beautiful Sculptured Faces of Buddha Facing All Four Directions. The only reason to come to Siem Reap is to see the temples. Angkor Wat is the biggest of the temple complexes, after this what we found fascinating was the Bayon Temple. Bayon Temple is a smaller complex then Angkor Wat, what is fascinating is the view of the large Buddha faces carved on the many domes on the roof of the temple. They are carved on all four sides of the domes looking out at all directions. There are multiple such domes and you have large Buddha faces looking towards you with serenity every way you turn. It is a wonderful experience. There is one vantage point from where you can photograph three faces in a line. It makes a good rememberance
must see!. one of the must-see temples of Angkor. some active restoration was in progress that was nice to see and also have cool carvings. highly recommend the elephant ride there as well.

The fairest of them all!!!. It is like stepping back in time.I like this more than the other temples because it's not too huge to go take a look around every inch but at the same time, not too small to get bored. Somehow Bayon is more personalized in such a way that you get to explore tunnels and be surrounded by huge smiling heads that are just breathtakingly spectacular. You are up close and being just next to them - words cannot explain. The visitors here are not as packed as Angkor Wat, hence you get more time for yourself. :)Choosing a great tuktuk driver as well can either enhance or make your trip really bad. I recommend Pech Vanny. Search for him in facebook :)))

Angkor - Bayon Temple - The faces are amazing and the temple a maze. This was the first smaller temple we visited after moving on from Angkor Wat and is a superb 12 th century Khmer design built for the buddhist faith. The main temple has four faces each watching over the four points of the compass whilst each of the 51 smaller peaks have their own face sculptures. Basically everywhere you go you seem to be being watched over. The faces themselves, although many worn, are beautifully carved and one or two have kept a superb degree of detail. Indeed the temple below is a wash with historical events carved into the walls and you could spend hours wandering around admiring every one that still exists. This is a fairly compact temple and one which is just beautiful. The faces are surreal. Loved this one and took some time to rest here from the heat ( good shaded areas ) and just admire what was built over nine hundred years ago. Different from Angkor Wat but it has a delight all of its own.
Bayon. Love the Architecture. Saw a monk meditating in on of the pocket holes. Everywhere you go, there is a face staring at you =)

Don't Miss Taking a Nose to Nose Photo with one of the Smiling Statues. Interesting temple with all the smiling statues :-) It gets pretty crowded so go early or later in the day if you can. Sometimes, there are some locals dressed in their dance costumes, ready to take photos with you, with a cost of course :-)
A spectacular Kingdom in history. You will be surprised how is this possible to build this temple with so many statures are both vivid and lively in ancient era. You will get impressive !!

Beautiful faces. Visited here during our third day in Siem Reap. We got a three day pass to split up our temple-visits a bit and did only 2 a day. This proved to be quite a good strategy as it is very hot and dusty. This temple was probably the one of the busiest temple we visited during our entire stay. It is huge and takes a long time to walk through. I would recommend a guide to tell you about the temple and its history as it will increase your experience. The face carvings are amazing and plentiful, they are everywhere you turn. This is what differs the Bayon Temple from the others in the complex and it is very well worth the visit.

Angkor Thom highlight!. I recommend you hire a personal tour guide for this temple. It would have looked like a bunch of old rocks and some statues without the storytelling, history and context the guide provided me and my friend. The Elephant terrance is adjacent to Bayon, and inside of Angkor Thom. Beautiful old city! You can ride an elephant within the grounds if you like!

Must Visit. Beautiful temple with loads of character.We did this temple as part of a half day tour which incorporated another 2 temples.Due to the heat, I highly recommend organising a tour with an air conditioned car rather than TukTuk as it does get hot and it's worth the extra money

Relaxing Place. Bayon Temple was so amazing and unforgettable. The first time that I saw the four faces, I was very surprise because it had very nice decoration and showed me about the hard work of ancient people in Cambodia. If you arrive there, you will relax and understand how calm it is. You can see the beautiful green grass around the temple and face with fresh air which can gain more happiness. I had no word to say because it was so great. I would like to recommend others to see Bayon Temple when they visit Cambodia. Let travel together. Thanks.

Could spend days here. Angkor Wat is beautiful and impressive, but I found Bayon Temple and the other nearby temples to be the most beautiful and impressive. If you are the type who likes to explore on your own, off the beaten path, without being led from place to place, you could easily spend a week in just the Bayon Temple area. Renting a bike may make exploring easy, or hire a tuk tuk. The driver will wait for you at each stop.

Deep and mysterious. If I was forced to choose just one temple in the Siem Reap area, Bayon would have to be the one. It does not have the massive scale of Angkor Wat or the ornate charm of Neak Poan but Bayon has the mysterious maze like qualities (mental as well as physical) that defines the enigma of a vanished civilization. It's a relatively small but do not rush through it. I would recommend a whole afternoon to admire the effect if the changing lights. Also do not forget to check out the base reliefs on both the first and second levels as well.
Beautiful temple!. One of the beautiful temples in Sieam Reap! It worth a lot a visit! Deserves at least 1 hour of exploration!
Best temple in Angkor Wat area. This is my most favorite temple. With all the smiling Buddhas, there's loads of charm to it & great for photo taking.
not like all. this temple was the umpleaseant one than i visited in angkor area.other places are more nice .angkor wat is far away so more nicer.
Smiling Buddha!. Bayon Temple is a massive stone faces on many towers. A lot of walking and climbing but we really enjoy the nice ambience.
The temple of faces. Excellent.. I liked this temple the best. Great faces and of course, great architecture. You must visit this one, alone with Angkor Wat, and Tombraider.

Wonderful. This is yet another must see in the Angkor Wat complex. The beautiful smiling faces on the statues and the whole place are just wonderful. It doesn't take long to look through but it is certainly and absolutely worth it.

Amazing structure and history!. Fantastic pice of architecture and preserved history!!! The I would love to have seen how this structure looked back in the 13th century.Remember to stock up on snacks and beverage on this visit, and wear comfortable shoes or sandals, so you can walk and clamp around without trouble. Elephant rides are available outside the temple and will take you around the structure for a fair price.A must see if you are in Siem Reap!
Carving were lovely. Loved the beautiful serene faces in the temple walls and the carvings depicting everyday life of the Khmer.
Fantastic....a must see temple. Amazing four sided faces on top of the peaks. Easy to get around and well worth the short tuk tuk ride for.
incredible temple. such a mysterious & fascinating temple. It was definitely my top 3 for the Angkor area and definitely not to be missed.
Beautiful temple.... But it does get busy! go early or later to avoid the crowds. It is on the must see list in the Angkor park!

The Bayon Temple .... Bayon is at the top of my list of temples to visit when visiting Siem Reap. Unfortunately, I was one a short trip and could not spend as much time as I wanted. Typically I have heard that one needs at least 4-5 days to visit the major temples and perhaps longer depending on one's personal interest in the history of each temple, etc. Bayon of course is very interesting due to all the faces that are found everywhere throughout the grounds.
Awesome faces. We enjoyed Bayon, I would say it was our 4th favorite out of 5. We liked all the faces and how some of the temples had been taken over by trees

great carvings, telling a story.... The bass relief was so detailed, much better and extensive than that in Angkor Wat.Massive stone faces make up the towers. This was one of the latest of the Angkor period

Must see. This is the second of the 3 must sees (Ankor Wat, Ta Prohm and Bayon). You need about 1 hour. For me the 2nd best, after Ankow Wat and before Ta Prohm due to the "faces". One could look at these for hours.

Smiles everywhere. Smiling buddhas everywhere...it's hard not to smile too. As with all the temple grounds these days, it can be quite overwhelming with the crowds of tourists in the heat. So make sure you have lots of water and a nice hat and sunglasses.
Loved it. One of the first temples my family visited and we all loved it. We will definitely not forget this one!

Wow !!!!. This Temple is not to be missed !!! Our Siem Reap journey would not have been complete without this stop. Just about everywhere is a gorgeous picture !!! Having our guide there to explain its history made it so much more interesting. Do not go it alone. Stay well hydrated and eat lightly as there is plenty of walking and climbing. Socks and comfortable shoes are highly recommended !!! Wear sunscreen of bring a hat with a brim.

Amazing. The iconic faces in stone that have been there for centuries are amazing. It's horrendously busy even though we were there in the hot season with everyone trying to snap the perfect profile picture but it's not to be missed.

Really good hotel and great view.. An excellent site to visit. The various temples and the Elephant and Leper King terraces are superb. An elephant ride around Baphoun temple is a must. Plenty of monkeys to be seen, but they can be a little demanding. Beware!!t.
My favourite temple. An amazing temple, my favourite of them all. The stone faces were incredible and made for some excellent photos!
Wow.... A must visit place. The sculptures are so peaceful. You can feel the serenity around the temple. Will definitely come back again in future. ....

Great Temple - Lots of Smiles. All the temples are great on most day and three day tours. Make sure Bayon is on your itinerary. The smiling faces are unique, great photo opportunities. It gets hot in April/ May but a little less crowded.
Busy but interesting. No guides needed. Interesting layout and walking around the rest of Angkor Thomas put things into perspective.

Nice, but not my favorite. It's in the top 3, but I prefer Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm. All of the temples are incredible though. But spread it out over a couple of days. After 3-4 temples they all start looking alike.

Overwhelming feelings. Just immagine how a XII century peasant would perceive this Majestic presence. All these huge faces looking at you from above. An Amazing masterpice I liked more than Angkor wat

definitely a must go, but not my personal favorite. not my personal favorite, but definitely a must go for touring so definitely pay it a visit and spend some time walking through it. I would recommend walking around that whole area and spend more time around that area to look around and enjoy in the atmosphere.

Truly Amazing!. My favourite temple out of all in Siem Reap. I had a tour guide to explain the back history of the stone carvings. I enjoyed it so much I went back the next day after I had done the sunrise tour at Angkor Wat.
Absolutely blew me away! Stunning.
Bayon a remarkable place. loved it, the trees growing in the temple, the ruins, the work being done to painstakingly put the jib saw pieces of stone back together

A place to visit after Angkor Wat. After Angkor Wat, Bayon would be the temple that you should not miss. Get a guide to walk you through the story of the place, especially the story on the bas relief. The place is smaller than Angkor Wat but I felt there are a lot more to climb. The temple is also much crowded due to the small walkways. Great place to take pictures, especially with the buddha faces.

Very difficult to understand. If you aren't in a tour group, definitely still go to this temple as it looks amazing. However there is a lot of art and architecture with no explanation which makes it hard to understand the meanings of why they are there.
Absolutely stunning. This is one of the great temples of Angkor Wat and a real treasure. Wonderful experience wandering around and marveling at the beautiful sculptured faces.

Face of Cambodia. A relatively small temple with lots of character. It is an easy climb and is a delight to photograph... if only i had my camera. Ahahaha. Anyway, my friends had a wonderful time capturing these faces of Cambodia
Beautiful temple. Its one of the more beautiful temples in Siem Reap. The head carvings which dot the entire temple is mesmerizing. Its a must see and not to be missed
Natural power. I just say that you have to see it. You can find the natural power to break the stone castle.

Include this in your tour package. Beautiful temple, with many bust sculptures. A bit crowded because its popular with tourists. Dont forget to include this in your tour package and segregate at least an hour to discover the temple. Inside there are few worshippers wh are praying. I hope you get to catch a glimpse.

My fav!. This was my favourite temple out of them all. I spent ages there. I went about 2pm so it was a lot quieter and there was hardly any people there. I never felt like I was alone with all those faces there and I met a lovely monk who I spend ages talking to :) defo a must see!

My favorite temple!. We left this temple last because everybody seemed to favorite Ta Prohm or Angkor but visiting it was a pleasant surprise. It really felt like heaven here. We spent nearly 3 hours visiting and taking photos of the place and didn't want to leave....seriously breath-taking!

beautiful face carvings. Part of the Angkor Thom complex, the face carvings of Bayon stands out. As I mentioned, our guide seems to be photo savvy as he has some nose to nose photo tricks up his sleeve. I also saw a real live monk sleeping on his side a la lying buddha style in one of the door entrances in the tower temple. It was a unique sight. However, I can give only a 4 star rating as I enjoy Beng Melea and Ta Prohm more. However, it is still a great temple to visit, among all the temples I got bombarded with during my stay in Siem Reap.
Beautiful, majestic - our favourite!. What an amazing place - absolutely loved it - 100% recommend! After two full days of looking at temples, we agreed that this was our favourite!

Very magnificent but not as expected. Many of my friends may over-describe it, therefore, I come there with a very high expectation that it would be huge, amazingly artful and fascinating. Well, it's true, but not as expected. May be because there is an under-construction going on, there is dusty and messy around the place we go, new things mix with old things, not feeling so well. But by the way, their doing is very careful and professional since the new ones still look as it was made from ancient time, not someplace in Vietnam where they build the whole new things instead.Detail, yes, very detail, I wonder how can people to be so exact and detail like that in this many years before, without supporting from modern technology.One thing is bad, there are a lot of people who selling incense to customers, which is bad, since the place show the holy atmosphere it self. Selling these things rude all the mood and destroy the feeling.

one of my favourite temple in the area. i loved the buddha faces, and all the carvings at the bottom. Arriving there is impressive, although I wish I could have done it by walk (our tour guide had decided it was too hot and too long to walk). We were there on a very busy day as it was Khmer new year, but very interesting to see that even today the temple is one of the major attractions amongst locals and that they come and pray in and around the temple during that period.
Beautiful temple. Well worth a visit to see this amazing piece of workmanship remarkably well preserved in many parts.
