Stupendous sculptures. The Bayon Temple was extremely crowded when we visited; however this was just bad luck as others from our hotel went a little later the same day and it was almost empty. It's not easy to enjoy the wonderful character of the carvings when you're surrounded by people taking photos of each other pulling silly faces next to some amazing masterpiece of stone sculpture! If you can be there without hundreds of others at the same time, it's a wonderful place.
BEST TEMPLE. The temple was amazing. Best for picture taking. Go there in the morning to avoid the scorching afternoon sun

Most impressive. Well worth a visit to see this amazing piece of workmanship remarkably well preserved in many parts. The friezes are amazing in their extent and detail. Access is good for close-up viewing.
Beautiful temple. our second temple for the day - the faces of this temple are absolutely beautiful - i could look at them for hours! really enjoyed our visit to this temple (despite construction)

Better than Angkor Wat. This is more intimate and somehow more accessible that its more famous neighbour. But it really feels more real. The carving is great and easier to see and there are less people. This was one of the highlights of our stay in Siem Reap and anyone who is there should go and spend the time to explore and enjoy.

My favorite temple in Angkor. You can find many temples in Asia. I have seen about 100 temples in 5 countries... But Angkor wat and temples of Angkor Thom it's something special. Bayon templeis really amazing, giant budda faces is spectacular and monumental and they can make you buddist, be careful ;) The best way to visit it is to have one day trip between Angkor wat and Angkor Thom temples by tooktook: you have your time, you can set priorities and visit that places, what would you like to visit... Also it's cheaper then group trip if you have some friends, normal price for one day trip on tooktook is about $20. But very important to have a good driver, because there is a lot of drivers who don't speak english, or they too lazy to drive some routes, or they don't know Angkor Thom well... In this reason i want to recommend the very nice khmer guy, who can help you to have the best experience in Angkor and Siem Reap. (his english is better then mine))) His name is Phirom, here is his contacts https://www.facebook.com/phirom.kakso (+855)81836396 He will give you a cellphone with khmer sim card, and you will never get lost. And he can recommend you best places to visit not only in Angkor ;) You can trust him. Have a nice trip in Angkor!
Nice temple!. The best time to visit should be in early morning. We have 3 day visits and always leave early and return back in early afternoon as it was hot in April.

Breath taking. A must see! The massive stone faces on all the towers is striking! There was restoration works happening while we were there but that didn't put us off. It's such a large place that you need an hour at least to explore. Was good to watch some of the restoration take place and see the care they are taking. Worth putting up with the heat. Take heaps of water and a fully charged camera with you!

stunning temple but busy. this is one of the most incredible temples and is full of amazing heads and faces - but be warned this is also a very busy temple and is best to try and avoid the times when the coach parties arrive as they swarm all over it...
Awesome. Great Temple. Beautiful smiling Buddha faces on the towers.Do not miss this one. One of our favorites. Also great for kids.

Bayon Temples. The temple is known as "the one with the faces." It is so much more than that. It is extraordinary. I loved the detail and the size of the faces carved into the stone. One of the better temples to explore.

Awesome. Its awesome,did not expect such hindu-buddhism heritage sites outside India.Must Visit..But be careful of the heat,do take lot of with with you if you are visiting in Apr-June.Temp'll be around 35-40 degrees in afternoon.

Amazing!!. When I entered the gate, my first impression was "Wow" and it never disappoints me. The temple is very amazing compared to angkor wat! Though there are reconstruction going on. Because of many tourist, try to find a place where you can have a best spot for photography.
I'm in love. I could have stayed all day gazing at those faces.. I felt at peace there, I felt like I'd found something that touched my heart. I know I'll be back.

Fantastic photo ops. Angkor wat is fantastic but it's too crowded unlike bayon temple wherein you literally can have shots without anyone accidentally photo bombing. Come in a bik and you won't be trapped in the traffic of tuktuks and cars. That is if you know your way around. We took to the road from our hotel to the unesco heritage site armed with just our bikes, a tourist map and bottles of water.

Don't Miss. Loved it. It was a lot shadier to walk around underneath the trees. Angkor Wat is very open and sunnier. Go here in the afternoon, if it's hot. Reserve a guide through your hotel there is so much interesting information that they can tell you about this place and you won't be able to pick one up on the grounds. If you do have kids try and get a guide that understands he can't stop every 5 minutes and needs to talk while walking :)
best of the temple days. Despite the heat wave, this is probably the best of the big temple complexes to visit - the photo opportunities are fantastic!

Amazing Experience. The Temple is located within Angkor Thom, great walking around it - very hot mid April hence I would suggest starting very early (6am) and going till lunch-time if your traveling at that time of year. We were at Bayon around 10am and it was quite busy, would suggest getting a guide for Bayon through your hotel etc as they assist with avoiding the crowds.

An architectural marvel, must see!. This breathtakingly beautiful piece of architecture is the best temple in Angkor. We planned to see it as the sun rose and I've no words to explain how beautiful this temple was. There are a few places in the temple where you come in close contact with the 'head-shaped' constructions and the intricacy of those carvings are mind boggling.

Impressive temple with all the faces!. Loved this temple, recommend you do in the morning with a guide, so much more interesting to be listening and looking rather than reading as you go. The top has an amazing view, we beat the crowds. Steep steps, kids under 12 not allowed to climb, can understand why coming down!
Wow, oh wow. Amazing carvings of 4 sided Buddhas. This is a great temple. One of the "must see temples" of Angkor.
Impressive. Still cannot imagine how the people can create such a nice temple. Less crowded due to low season. Exciting place to go!

Spiritual focal point. The Bayon Temple is second largest temple in the Angkor area. Tuk tuk drivers sometimes refer to this as the Four Faces Temple. It lies at the centre of the ancient walled city of Angkor Thom, people are still unsure of the significance of parts of the building. Scenes of everyday life on the Tonle Sap are shown in reliefs on the lower levels. The upper level has the famous towers adorned with huge faces on each side. At the very heart of the temple is a slightly mysterious circular building. When you go inside there is a small Buddhist shrine, incense and a Nun who will bless you.The temple can be crowded, I was here late afternoon and managed to grab a few peaceful moments.

Just amazing!. This temple was incredible. It's just amazing to think about how this place was constructed all those years ago. All the faces are different and each have their own personality. This is a great place to explore and take tons of amazing pictures. It is a place you can see without a guide but I highly recommend a tour guide to get the most out of your visit.

The Bayon. This temple is enigmatic with it's myriad of faces. Learn something about king Jayavarman the VII, who our guide described as the "super king" with all he did. Look at the faces in the top galleries, but take the time t look at the carvings on the lower galleries that give an insight into the daily routine for people living there at the time.
Majestic. Interesting temple with lots of carvings. This temple should be on your list if you only have one day to visit the Angkor Complex. This is also the main temple in Angkor Thom.

A Good Two Hours!!!. We really enjoyed the architecture and picturesque Bayon Temple. Bayon Temple is sufficiently compact to encourage any order of visit, particularly as the absence of a surrounding wall makes it easy to enter at any point. Not only that, but one of the special pleasures of this unique temple is to immerse yourself in its maze-like qualities.The confusion of the inner enclosure, with its narrow chambers, corridors and stairways, giving occasional surprise glimpses of the enigmatic faces, is in itself a fascinating experience.How much time you spend with the bas-reliefs will depend on your level of interest. I though the S section of the E Gallery and the E section of the S Gallery were the most interesting.Bayon Temple was one of the top five temples we visited.
Awesome. This temple was a great place to visit. We had a local tour guide for the day so he has able to tell us about the significance of this temple.
Highlight of Angkor Thom. Must see of the temples.Lots of photo opportunities.Can get busy with lots of tourists but a good guide will avoid the worst of it.Reasonably accessible complex.
Amazing!! my second best. you have to go and check all the different faces sculptured in the rocks. I really liked this temple!

Outside the main temple complex, this is one of the most evocative spots. The haunting faces facing the four directions at Bayon Temple really are evocative of the grandeur of the old Khmer Empire. It is easy to imagine how powerful it would make a Khmer general returning from some duty to walk up the approaches to this. History and archaeology buffs will be enraptured by it and while some of the local hawkers can be persistent and annoying it may be useful to get some form of guide to show you around (negotiate at the start of the tour!).This is one of the real highlights outside the main temple that you'll want to see.

Amazing and Historic. A must visit temple. We visited in the morning to avoid the crowds. The faces were huge and amazing. There are many small complicated carvings on the walls. Don’t forget to take water bottles and your camera, do your research about the temple before the visit so you don’t need a guide.
A unique temple worth visiting.... Apart from Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm, I think this should be another must-visit temples in Siem Reap, given its unique character and structures.

Jennie and Elliot Cambodian Tour. Banyan temple is great loved it try to take comfortable shoes as there is some climbing, it can be very hot so make your visit early morning before it gets too hot. Do not forget your camera.
Unique temple. Bayon is a must see temple while in Siem Reap, it is one of a kind, and top notch. You will get great pictures at the temples. .

Elephants a great way to see. We skipped the first place to do the elephant walk as our driver told us it was not as good as the second and he was so right. It was a lovely cool place to pause amongst temples. We took the elephant ride around the outside which gave a picture of what it must have been like thousands of years ago before it was surrounded by tuk tuks Awesome to see at different height

One of the most impressive temples for its stone faces of Buddha. Incredible sanctuary with 37 towers. Each one with the four faces of Bouddha, facing you everywhere.
Beautiful reliefs in stone representing the battles of the Khmer kings (official art) but also very funny and narrative scenes from the daily life: hunters, fisher- men, merchants, women and children at home.
Wonderful carvings depicting everyday life. For me the great sandstone carvings of everyday Angkorian life were a real highlight of the many wonders I saw over 3 days. So well preserved too.
Just spectacular. There are a few temples around Angkor that you are not going to want to miss. This is one of them. You can google it, and you've got to walk around the property.

Beware. It is a must see if you appreciate a good temple, but be aware if a local starts showing you around he will expect some cash at the end. Probably best just to say to him is 2$ ok, its worth 2-3 for someone to emplane the area and its easier to negotiate at the start, you will enjoy the temple much more.
Wow. not something that can be explained. it is just amazing. That any structure can last this long is amazing. The history of Cambodia is so incredible.

Superb. I thought this temple was simply superb. Its as if you are welcomed with lots of Smiley faces from the stone sculptors. Its not too big that you can not get round it quite comfortably. There are simply 100's of great photo opportunities here. There are also a few places to hide away and sit in the shade from the soaring heat. Like most of the temples you do need to be careful when walking and climbing the many stone steps. We were there during the new year celebrations and was quite busy with locals as well as tourists but this did not spoil our visit just made it a bit all the more special ( if that is possible ). One of the main temples that is a must visit.
Wooow !. The second most beautiful temple in the complex. The faces were to good , and each every one , was hilariously perfect.
Special treat. Next to Angkor Wat, this is the second phenonemal attraction.For sure a must-visit.The four-face Bayon really makes this more then amazing

216 faces staring down at you!!. This one is inside the Angkor Thom complex. Suggest do this at any time morining or afternoon. well preserved state - 216 faces which seem to simply stare down at you. Worth a visit. other major notables inside Angkor Thom include Baphuaon, Terrace of the Elephants andthe Leper king.
Super love. Super love, our tuktuk follow us because this is the only temple he can easily park his tuktuk, so he became our photographer! Hhahaha lol

One of a kind, truly magnificent. I was here 15 years ago and thought how magnificent it was then.
Fifteen years after to see it again with more time to inspect every angle was mind blowing.
One must imagine how it was possible to have built this with just human hands and simple tools.
incredible. all of Angkor that we saw was incredible. It's really hot right now, but completely worth the sweat.
One of the Must See Temples. With all the temples around Siem Reap this is one you need to make sure to visit. It is huge and has some really cool features like stone faces in the towers.

Beautiful and Historic.. The a really nice to place to take picture if u are the one who like photographing. Simply press your camera button and you can get a very picture and back ground . But , its very very hot out there.

My Favourite!. By far my favourite site to visit at Angkor. Absolutely fascinating to wander round and wonder what the faces are saying. It's a fairly large site when you get inside and you can spend a good bit of time here but it can get busy as it is one of the main attractions to visit. Take some good shoes and some water, we visited in early afternoon in March and it was very warm but still fantastic. Don't miss it!
Another amazing temple. Although not my favourite, it's still truly amazing and definitely one of the must see temples if you only have a 1 day ticket.
My favourite. Great temple of many faces - this is a special place. Make sure you have plenty of time to explore the different levels.

Provide drinking water facilities. The location is a 'must see' for those interested in History, Architecture, and Indian Cultural influence on Cambodia.But, drinking water facility must be provided at different points in this wast area. Presently tourists are forced to purchase water at costly rates,from private vendors. Water facility is a humane need that must be courteously made by all governments. But, both Thailand and Combodian governments are not paying attention to this
Amazing. I had no concept of The antiquity and history of the temple. It is. mind boggling to see what was created without any technology -- with only human labor.

Love the faces!. The faces on this temple are amazing! There seem to be hundreds of them, and most of them are fairly well preserved. This is, however, one of the most popular temples, and even though we were there in the morning, it was already packed with visitors.
Nice temple with huge buddha faces. The temple is grand with a lot of huge Buddha faces, which make the temple unique to other temples. A must see in Siem Reap!

Our family's favorite temple in Siem Reap!. This was an amazing place to explore. The overall feel was so exotic and exciting. Overall, my kids liked this place more than the uber-popular Angkor Wat and I heard the same feedback fro other families who have visited Siem Reap. Don't miss this one!

Bayon temples. This place is just awesome, well worth the visit, the majesty of the sculptures is unbelievable.
Take the time and really have a look around and you wont believe how it was all built so long ago.
It was hot when we were there so take a lot of water and snacks.

Just what you expect. A must see for all visitors amazing place. Bit pricey to get in! Climbing to the top up all the stairs is very exhausting especially if you are a bit old and overweight like me! Its double exhausting if it is a really hot day like when we went! BUT well worth the climb! The views are very impressive.

Stunning!. Brilliant! One of my favourite temples to visit. Take some proper walking shoes as stairs can be quite steep & some loose rocks around - but I suppose this applies to all temples really. The faces are quite simply stunning & you could spend hours wandering around even though it isn't the largest temple site here.

Most interesting of the Siem Reap temples. The detail of this temple, especially the enigmatic faces carved on the pillars were different and fascinating. There was a great deal of detail that hadn't been pillaged or worn away so one could really spend quite a bit of time there. However, when we were there in February, it was extremely crowded. Fortunately, our fabulous guide had us go in the exit and it was easier to navigate.

Exciting Approach. The north gate approach to the Bayon temple is simply fantastic! We rode elephants which was a fun way for our children to experience the processional way. We saw monkey's which just added to the atmosphere. The bridge is lined with incredible statues representing god's and devils and along with the 4 headed gate make for a dramatic entrance to the temple complex. We hit the temple at around 8am and it was already teeming with tourists-large tourist groups mean you have to wait to climb the stairs and make it more difficult to get the the perfect shot, but overall the site is amazing. There is some excavation being done onsite.

Great. I actually liked this temple better than the main temple, and thought it was more serene. Try and go at off peak hours like right after sunrise or early afternoon when you can more of the place to yourself.

The many amazing faces of Bayon. I visited Bayon on my first full day in Siem Reap, albeit after I had first explored Angkor Wat itself. I arrived at Bayon via Tuktuk and almost immediately saw a large monkey prowling around the road and the entrance to the temple. I was very wary of this monkey as it seemed to be stalking me. I put my camera away zipped into my pocket in case the monkey tried to snatch it from me, although when I was through the first doorway into the temple itself I was able to begin taking some cool photos. After the monkey, my next encounter was with a young Khmer man, who was waiting inside the temple, and he advised me that if I stood in a certain exact spot near him I could get a brilliant photo of the temple architecture above. I said I would come back later to take these photos, as I think he may have tried to charge me for the privilege.Probably even more so than at Angkor Wat, I found myself to be intrigued by the architecture here at Bayon, and I don’t mean just the faces. There are many little intricate carvings on the walls, both on the lower levels and up above. I also liked the fact that, unlike Ta Prohm and Preah Khan whose majesties have been somewhat claimed by the power of the jungle, Bayon still has a comprehendible design that can be explored logically. This certainly makes me feel Bayon is a true temple (albeit decrepit), rather than needing to refer to it merely as “ruins”.

Must see in Cambodia. Impressive and well worth a visit, along with Angkor Wat and Ta Phrom, the 3 'must sees'. The approach to Bayon from Angkor takes you over the bridge where ther are statues of 53 Gods and 53 Demons, a lot have replacement heads that compliment the original stonework as the originals were either destroyed or sold during the civil war. We were not too bad with crowds as started at Bayon about 9. Then Ta Phrom approx 1 o clock when crowds heading for lunch, then into Angkor Wat around 2.30 from the east gate and out by the west. Travel was by hire car and driver Mr Samreth Leang, known as Sam, was excellent. He had cold water and cold towels waiting for us on our return to the car and acted as a great source of information, would strongly recommend his services,(Samrethleang@yahoo.com (855)978667664).
One of my favourites. The temples of Siem Reap don't really need a review - they are all amazing. This temple is especially beautiful when it it lit up for celebrating new year.
honeymoon. calm and serene, you can feel the history as you walk around, shame so many things have been stolen and defaced, we enjoyed visiting all the temples
Cultural experience. Amazing to see something so ancient and culturally important. No wonder it's as busy as it is! One of my favourite Angkor temples.

Nice.. NIce to have seen, but felt templed out after Angor Wat. So if I was going to choose only one more to see that would have been Ta Prohm over this. But if seeing all the temples, this one is gorgeous.
An intriguing interesting complex. The history, architecture,and emotive site with trees and shrubs is wonderful. We enjoyed the whole experience
ok but very crowded. crowded with people. shouldn't be high up on your list. focus on temples further away from the town and get a private guide.

Sunrise trip to the Temples by Tuk Tuk. While in Seim Reap Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom are must see! At first we booked a private tour to take us but he cancelled on us at 5am on the day if the tour because of Khmer New Year. Our hearts dropped but luckily one of the amazing tuk tuk drivers jumped in to save the day (Mobe). He asked where wanted to see. Having never been we didn't really know. He said he would take us to Angkor Wat for sunrise and then to the other temples he thought we would want to see. We asked how much... $25 he says. Amazed by the price which was a third of what it would have cost for one of us on the organised tour we agreed. Sunset was beautiful but busy. Not sure if this was just because of new year though. Then we walked around having bought a info book for $15 outside. Be warned they are cheaper inside!!! After this we went back to meet Mobe and went to Angkor Thom. Again looked round for a few hours, had an elephant ride and saw monkeys playing in the trees. The place had an almost magical feel. From we visited four other temples before Mobe dropped us back at our hotel door. The man was a life saver and gave us an amazing trip for practically nothing. Never underestimate the knowledge of the mighty tuk tuk driver, and see angkor wat though the eyes of the locals.

Stunning. This was my favourite of all of the temple complexes. Just stunning. Very steep stairs though. This complex is not very big and can be seen in half an hour. So that was good. It really gave you a good idea of how the temple was made as a lot of the base layers of the temple is visible
It is definitely worth a visit. Bayon temple was one of the temples we visited on our one day tour while at Siem Reap. It is different from Angkor Wat as it has many more trees in and around it.

Amazing Enigmatic Faces and stone carvings. I was there early in the morning (after a not happening sunrise at Angkor Wat) and was really lucky as we were only about 6 people there, which was just fabulous. The huge Enigmatic faces are a must see. Make great photo subjects. And the stone carvings on the walls are out of this world. Aaaamazing work!!!
A must see when visiting Siem Reap. One of the 3 main temples that you can not miss, really does speak for itself. You just have to visit and see for yourself.

Temple history. the Bayon Temple was beautiful with so many smiling faces that have been so well restored. Don't stop there thoughm the history and temples all around this region are well worth a vist with so many variations as you pass through the various periods of history. The Bayon Temple is one you will remember to compliment your trip to Siem Reap.

Faces of Architectural Extravaganza. I think Bayon is the most visiting temple structure after Ankorwat in Seim Reap, aprt from a temple its like a marvelous creation in stones. Usually sculptures find in single huge rocks but the every faces built here is the interconnection of 100s of granite blocks with different expressions. Its one of the most clicked sculptures in the world. you would take nearly 30 to 1 hour to finish the sight seeing here and can get down and walk towards the terrace of elephants ...

Awesome. The ruins are majestic. Be prepared for a long walk in the temple. And do not accept incense sticks from anyone in the temple - they expect money in return. It's a scam. Just explore the ruins on your own - it's an experience

Amazing. I think the great thing about this temple is that as you twist and turn down narrow corridors you emerge with a different view of the enigmatic faces which in itself is a fascinating experience.
Used to love it. I used to love this temple - my favourite but now with so many restoration works and tourists, it loses its natural authentic touch =(
Wonderful History. Although it was hot and humid, this site is a must see for it's beauty and historical value. The building construction and restorations are amazing.
Just Fab. Probably the best temple complex within Angkor village. Spend a good 2 hours to fully explore as there is much to see

The architecture and the carvings are striking. It is amazing to imagine these structures were built over 1000 years ago. A guide who know the history and background of the place adds value to the overall experience.

I like this temple more than Angkor Wat. I think that this is my favorite temple in Siem Reap, it just has a different feel to all the other temples and you can feel an ancient vibe to it. It has lots of Buddha faces carved into the sides of many towers. If you have a guide, than you'll be able to understand the designs in the temple and how it is unique to the others. I think this is the nicest temple, you have to see this if you are in Siem Reap.
Trees engulfing the ancient temple. It was an interesting experience seeing these mighty trees engulfing this ancient temple. We enjoyed hearing about the history of this ancient civilization.

Amazing. It was amazing to see the temple and the astounding carvings on the wall, all of which was done over 1000 years ago. The builders were so talented in the way that they constructed such an amazing structure. The carvings tell the story of that time and their beliefs in fantastic detail.

Most exciting thing i have ever seen. You must see Angkor - if you like Indiana Jones movies from your childhood - you will be shocked of this. This is the part of the true, giant ancient city sorrounded by the jungle. Its fantastic. You must see before you die

Temples - Bayon. Spectacular sight - pictures do not do justice to the magnificence and awe inspiring temples that dot this landscape. If you have a bucket list this is a must for you! Yes it will be crowded and yes it's hot so be prepared and just go with the flow, enjoy and soak in the ambience - you will get alone times to sit and enjoy the temples by yourself !

Worth a visit. As with all the temples there is a lot to see and involves a lot of walking so take suitable walking shoes and remember, shoulders and knees must be covered.The face carvings into the rocks are amazing and although its large its not as big as the Wat temple but still worth a visit

Great experience. We visited this temple as "curtain raiser" for our afternoon visit to the famous Angkor Wat. We enjoyed the visit here and were quite fascinated by the carvings. By the time we arrived (around 07:30), there was a significant build-up of visitors. However, there was not too much crowding - we could get some photos unimpeded by visitors.

One of the must see Wat complexes. As with most Angkor Wat areas, this is another amazing example, but can be very busy with tourist groups. Choose a good guide and he should be able to make a day trip where you miss out on the "swell" of tourists at certain times of the day.Some excellent photo opportunities throughout, if it's not too busy.One of the must see areas of Angkor Wat - which leads onto Elephant Terraces / Leper King etc.

Really fun and interesting to climb. Climbing up will give you a larger perspective on the place. Well worth it! We left our two younger kids with the guide as kids 10 and under can't go inside due to safety. You also must wear something over your shoulders and below your knees to enter. They have cool clothes to buy outside so no worries about wearing winter clothes and sweating to death! The Cambodians know how to dress for hot weather even in pants and shirts!

One of the best temples. It has about 216 face carve onto the stones, ruins are still under renovation some parts of the temple is block off to the tourist ,it is defintely smaller then ang kor war but worth to visit

Again outstanding ancient ruins. This temple needs to be visited 6-7 am to see its beauty before the Bus loads of tourists start climbing all over it.  There are great photo opportunities all over and so interesting. A must do while visiting.
The most amazing one. Bayon temple and its two hundred sixteen faces carved in the stone was the temple I preferred among the others.

Great Sight. Rode here on bicycle as part of the 30k Temple circuit. All the Temples were amazing. It surprises me that people still clamber over everything - it's a historic relic and needs to be treated with respect.

Bayon Temple Experience. Some of the areas of the temple are under renovation/restoration by JASA. But the experience is very good, we just took some pictures and observe the details of the ruins. The temple is quite small as to compare with the Angkor Wat but it is a must place to visit.
Top 3. This temple is AMAZING. It was one of our top three. The carved faces are beautiful and everywhere. There is a lot of opportunity for some great photos here.

A must-see in Angkor Wat. Although on first sighting it looks like a pile of rubble, you'll see faces and more faces cut into the rock the more you look. Also, don't miss the bas reliefs around the perimeter base--possibly more interesting than those at Angkor Wat.

One of the best. Fascinating place dominated by the numerous four sided towers with a face on each side. Just wandering through the maze of corridors, rooms and temples was wonderful. I'd rate this as better than Angkor Wat itself - much smaller, true, but also much more intimate and probably gives you a better idea of what life might have been like when it was built than Angkor Wat.

Beautiful and unique. We had a great visit to Bayon Temple. I recommend going in the early morning as it gets very crowded and the area atop the temple can be quite narrow in places. We did the elephant ride and had a magnificent view of the temple as well.

Tomb Raider. You have seen it on Tomb Raider now see it in for real. Trees growing through every nook and crannie, awesome in their own right. Temples with every square inch carved....such a honour to have the opportunity to see these wonders of the world.

Great. After you have been round most of the temples they begin to merge into one, but if you look closely you can see they are built differently. They are so interesting you can't go to Siem Reap without doing the temples.

Must visit historical site!. The oldest temple in Siem Reap! It's a must visit with its heritage and the archeology of this temple. It is an astounding historical site that is a must visit whenever you are in Angkor Wat. You can't find it anywhere else in the world.
one of a must to visit. The Bayon is one of incredible and a must to visit place in Siem Reap even smaller than Angkor Wat. Four different faces image is the symbolic here.
Wonderful. An amazing place.. must visit. Can be done in one day tour together with the Angkor Wat n few others.

Another must see in Siem Reap. Have to see this if you are in Siem Reap - what more is there to say - fabulous complex and interesting story. You need to read up thoroughly or hire a qualified local guide to appreciate the temples.

The many faces of Buddha. We really enjoyed this temple. It wasn't too crowded when we went, around 10 am, and our guide pointed out some really interesting features that I'm sure we would have missed otherwise.
Faces in Stone. We loved this temple as so many good photos were taken here. Could have spent more time here but with only 3 days in Siem Reap and lots more to do and see it was rushed.

Our favourite temple. Outstanding, amazing, superb. We visited the temples yesterday. Mr Mean, our tuk tuk driver, recommended we started at the Bayon temple. We arrived at Bayon temple around 10:30am and finished at Angkor Wat around 3pm. The Bayon was definitely our favourite temple. The face carvings are amazing and the access through the temples is very easy -you can roam as you like. To my pleasant surprise the temples were not so crowded and we had lots of time to look around at our leisure and take photos as long as we wanted at each temple. This is definitely the best way to see the temples, especially with 3 teenagers. Wha you miss not having a guide, you gain by being independent and being able to wander as you like. We'll be going back on Thursday before we leave.
One of the best!. I think Bayon temple is one of the best temple out of all. The best time to visit this temple is in the morning.
A must see. Very unique architecture especially those smiling faces. Try to take a photo glancing at one of the statues.

Breathtaking temple!. This temple is located in Angkor Thom. Its a must visit temple with lots of amazing sculptures. I was there at around 11 am which was not too crowded. My cousin and I hired a driver with an english tour guide via the hotel to visit this location. We called around for private tour guides to compare prices and the hotel does offer competitive pricing so we just booked via the hotel. I stayed at Lotus Blanc. The price of an English translator was US$30 and the car rental US$35. This does not include the admission pass which is US$40 and tip for the driver and translator. Also you may want to make sure you have US$1 bills on you as there are a lot of kids wandering the streets trying to sell tourists post cards, bracelets, etc. They are really too cute to turn away. $1 can go along way for them.
Do not Miss. Another incredible site and so lucky to have seen it. Amazing restoration work ( ongoing) and original buildings basically held up by trees that have rooted and grown over the centuries

Stunning. Loved the fact that the time of day when you visit does not seem to matter here at all, it looks good at any time. I really enjoyed discovering all the carvings with my guide. He took a great picture of me touching noses with one of the statues, (bit like the hand on the Leaning Tower if Pisa). Without him I would not have known this possibility existed. The faces were incredible, i loved this more that Angkor Wat, the complex is much more intricate, there are, so I was told, 216 faces here, all slightly different. Put this one on your list.

Spectacular. One year later after my first visit, this remains my favourite temple. I visited it between 10.30 and noon, and it was a good choice, not so overcrowded as usual. The big faces overlooking at the visitors are stunning in their majesty. The bas reliefs around first level are terrific, and well deserve a good guide explaining all the details. Do not miss it, ever.
After Angkor Wat this was our next temple. The beginning of lots and lots of steps. Plan ahead and do a fitness course. I loved it, some didn't. You have to see to believe.

Beautiful Temple. This temple is the most beautiful temple inside Angkor Thom. There are a lot of sculptures and i was able to take a lot of beautiful pictures. A must visit place and a heaven for photographers.

Approach by Elephant!. We entered this last capital by way of the southern gate. The stone causeways portraying the gods and demons lead majestically into the complex. This is at the centre of Angkor Thom.The giant heads of Buddha and relief decoration is stunning

Angkor 2014. This reminds me of skull island (King Kong movie). On a serious note, even with all the stone faces everywhere you turned there's a sense of tranquility when looking at it. Not much shelter here so it's advisable to visit early in the morning to beat the noon heat.
The First Place Most Visit at Angkor Wat. Stunning, amazing. This is why you came to Siem Reap. Yes, there will be a gazillion others tourists at this location. As the day goes on, the crowds thin.
Must see in Siem Reap. I actually enjoyed Bayon more than Angkor Wat itself. The 4 faced signature shrines inside the temples are so unique to Cambodia.
Faces. those mysterious faces and intricate passages at Bayon Temple are truly enchanting plus there's that scent of incense that adds even more sense of mystery .. you have to see them yourself...

Our Favorite Temple. This temple was the favorite of our trip- in fact we went back a second day to take more pictures.Go earlier in the morning or late in the day, mid-day it is very hot and there is no shade at this temple.
A beauty. Don t miss this temple, it s a must see. Start your visit of the Angkor temples with this one, most of the tours are at the Angkor Wat temple.
Beautiful temple. Loved all of the faces carved on it. Arrived in style on an elephant. Easy to maneuver your way not too many steps. Arrive early to avoid crowds.

Second best temple after Angkor Wat. This temple is a must go! I was overwhelmed seeing the faces in real life, it was surreal. What a feat to build such a beauty. Don't forget to take photo of your face next to the temple's faces ;P
Nose to nose. The happy faces made me feel good. Our guide took some great photos of us , which appeared to be nose to nose with the statues. I will remember to keep smiling after this iconic visit

its amazing!..really gives us something to reminisce bout the good old day and customs of Cambodian folks..... the place, people, food....The room was both quiet and very clean with fans and a big window. The staff is extremely nice and helpful and they all speak very good English.
i dislike the hot of summer! but its tolirable! :)
My fav temple in Siem Reap. Each temple has its unique points. But bayon is by far my fav because of the faces on the temple tours. Filled with history and fascinating towers.
For me nices temple in this place. 54 towers each having 4 faces. Lots of nice places inside. Different angles gives you unexpected pictures of this faces.

Bayon Temple. We visited the Bayon Temple one late afternoon in March and after visiting several others, found we enjoyed this temple the most. Carved, four faced heads adorned the hights of the structure. What I found most interesting was comparing the sharpness or weathering of the head features. Some were beautifully precise and serene, while others bore the marks of time. Positioning of heads to capture two in a photograph made for an interesting afternoon of observation.
Not to be missed. Spent a fantastic hour exploring this and discovering more and more faces. Best to go early in the morning to miss the crowds

Amazing. So much to see and usually very little time so absorb what you can.The amount of photographs you will take is immense so make sure you have your batteries topped up and sufficient memory on your cards.When at the top of the Temple - not for the faint hearted - have your single shot side head photo taken with your nose appearing to touch the nose of one of the statues - amazing.The film 'Tomb Raider' will now look completely different.One big hint - if visiting in the morning, try to enter from the East so the sun is behind you.

The most unique "face"t of Angkor Archaeological Park. The Bayon Temple was my favorite on the park's many temples. It was well kept and the faces are fascinating to look at. Additionally, the temple has many levels and pathways so it is really fun to climb and explore.

Unbelievable Temple. Such a beautiful place, you get to experience reliefs on the walls depicting Hindu as well as Buddhist stories. You see so many amazingly sculpted walls and carvings into the stone ...it's simply a must do and must see temple.

My fav out of Angkor Wat. This was was so detailed! It was covered in Bayon heads, which I don't even have a clue how they built them so many years ago. It was big with many places to walk, so even though there were tons of people it didn't feel too crowded. Not a lot of shade though.

Amazing. You have to see this temple ! Go early as there is a big crowed.
Aside from all the other temples we loved this one and did not regret going.

Another highligh in the small curcuit.. Many different faces of Buddha in the temple. Take care in the darkness of the corridors. Nice people will offer you joss sticks.
We have seen a film shooting. Very interesting.
My Fave. All the faces, it doesnt look as good as angkor wat, but it was cooler in my opinion. If you do a temple tour, you wont miss it!
magical. love the sceneries here but be prepared there will always be hundreds of other tourists just like you but nevertheless the place is big for everyone.
Great. Very nice and meaningful! The best temple at that area worth the time. For those photographers, a must-go place

one of the best temples. I think the Bayon Temple was one of the best temples of the Angkor complex. Very picturesque as there are all these faces where you can get some awesome shots. Maybe not too big but it's about the details here.
Don't miss it. We took a tuk-tuk and explored on our own. Great views and faces looking in every direction. Definitely a 'must see'.

Very good close to the mountain to watch sunset. Very good, a must see if only seeing temples for one day, along with Angkor wat and ya prohm. Booked as a small tour with hotel paid $15 for Tuk Tuk that took us around the three sites

amazing history. I loved the oldness of the temple and the trees surrounding. I loved being able to wander through the temple and I found it popular but not too overcrowded to be able to get around and take photos.

Not just another temple. Bayon temple, along with Ta Prohm and Angkor Wat, are The Big Three with respect to the marvellous temples to be seen just outside Siem Reap. Each is unique in its own way, and each deserves attention.
Serenity Contemplated. I love the experience of climbing all the way to the top of the temple. It's the best! It is indeed undoubtedly the Angkor's most impressive temple.

Still impressive. The Bayon temple group were built later than many the other structures and while still impressive, are not of the same quality as most of the older structures.
Still well work seeing, especially in the context of the older, less mass produced temples
Extraordinary History. This world heritage site is well worth a visit. The temples and reliefs are wonderful and restoration is ongoing.
Must see. This temple is a must on your trip to Angkor. Great carvings. I recommend a guide to see all of the temples.
My favourite. I got completely bewitched by this amazing temple. Really beautiful especially in the afternoon light.
Not to be missed. Absolutely incredible, a must see if you are in the area, indeed worth travelling to Cambodia just for this and the other Angkor temples.

Good, not great.. Every temple is fascinating to see and walk around but Bayon wasn;t as spectacular as the others!!
If you need to cut a temple out.. choose Bayon

Amazing place, worth to visit. Amazing to see this temple with giant tree age more than hundreds year, i could imagine what was there in the past, the building the access the paint on the wall everything about Bayon and Angkor Tomb really amaze me. I enjoyed my time at that 2 places than Angkor Wat, something about that 2 places is magically for me would happy if could visit that place again someday

Incredible, a don't miss if you are short on time. Some people arrive with only one day at the temples! Bayon is part of the Angkor Thom complex and this is a "don't miss". See Angkor Wat as the other don't miss.
A 12th century masterpiece. Even the heat and high humidity could not dampen our enthusiasm for this amazing place. The Terrace of the Elephants seemed to go on for ever!
Warm welcome with smile faces.. This temple is so nice with the smile faces, this temple, it seems have a life and showcase that they welcome always.

do not miss this. this place well deserves all the positive comments that it gets. The crowds are there for the same reasons as you are so it is hard to want to be on your own but do keep an eye open for the bats inside the very innermost part.

subliiiiiiime. 37 faces looking in every directions. A unbelievable architecture. Mysteries, intimacy, "The Magical Montain". All the heads with 4 faces are supposed to represent the 4 virtues of the Buddha.

very beautifull temple. it was really nice temple with a great smiling face and if you go there early in the morning it is very quiet place and very peace .this is a great temple that i saw it few time in a day never getting boring with it.don't miss this temple

Favorite temple. It might have been the fact that it was our last stop of the day and nearing sunset so tourist volume was low but this was definitely the most peaceful of the temples we visited. The Buddha faces were beautiful.

It opens up as you walk in. From outside the temple does not look grand even though the faces are made very well. but as you walk in and explore one door after another, the temple's grandness keeps on expanding....and you can very well appreciate the beauty and construction of the temple, from the innermost portion of the temple.

Amazing. Very fascinating temple, the view is breathtaking!It is best to be there early in the morning or late in the afternoon,if possible with a tourguide, to avoid big touristic groups.We were here two years ago. It was busy then but the crowd seemed to have almost doubled this time.
Incredible. Unmissable when you are in Siem Reap! There have been so many reviews so I don't anything particular to add except for the fact that the Angkor temples are just MAGICAL!

fascinating. This is a popular temple that many people visit every day. At our tuk-tuk driver's suggestion, we hit it at the end of the day. The crowds were nearly all gone and we could roam through its levels and take striking pictures in the soft light of twilight.
Best temple in Angkor Wat Temple Area. Go see this. Period. It is the best temple in the area, can't get much better. Detail and carvings are incredible.
Beautiful Bayon. The striking face of Buddha, the reflection in the pool of water at the entrance, smaller and more intimate feel than the larger temples, quiet and tranquil atmosphere.

Be there early !. Instead of beginning your tour in Angkor Wat as every tourists do, arrive here early in the morning (just after having seen the sunrise if you're one of those brave people :P).
Thus you'll avoid meeting BIG touristic groups and be able to admire in silence lights games on stone faces... Impressive !
Good but in ruins. The temple would have been a grand structure but it is now fallen apart. The shiva temole himagiri close by is more intact

out of this world. on our first day temple hopping our guide drove us straight past Angkor Wat and i had a little freak out wondering why?! a few minutes down the road and and you see why. Bayon is extraordinary, the sheer amount of smiling faces that surround you in any one place is awe inspiring. Brilliant to photograph at almost any time of the day, place this temple high on your list!
Magnificent!!!. The stone faces are amazing!!!! The wall carvings are very intricate. This is the best among the temples in Siem Reap.

Jaw dropping!. This temple was full of beautiful carvings... Even better than Angkor Wat, in my opinion, in fact the faces of Buddha which I though through research were in Angkor Wat, were actually in the Banyon Temple.

One of the best temples in the area. We visited this temple on the first day after Angkor Wat and although we've seen many other temples in the area since, this remains as one of my favourites. It's fascinating to walk through something so old, you really do have to stop for a moment and remind yourself to appreciate being in it's presence. There are 54 towers, each with 4 smiling faces (216 all up) said to be in the image of the Buddha of Compassion. Although still a ruin, it's in better nick than many other temples in the area and you can spend an age here walking around and taking photos. The crowds here can get crazy, especially when a tourist bus or two arrives which although understandable, it's sad as it takes away some of the beauty and tranquility of the place.

If you only have time to see one temple this is it. Having had time to visit 15 temples during my visit I only visited 2 twice Anghor Wat and Banyon with Banyon the most stunning with its multi, multi faceted construct giving an awe inspiring appearance that has more to offer with every step you take into the interior.There are also 2 further temples adjacent to Banyon , Baphuon and Phimeanakas which can only add to the fascination the site of Angkor Thom provides

The best temple in Siem Reap, not to be missed. Of all the temples we visited, this one was the nicest. The big stone carvings inside the temple were still intact, and the intricate designs on the walls were truly beautiful. A must visit when you're in Siem Reap.

Prasat Bayon. After exploring angkor wat , Bayon is another one of the great temple, described as one of "the most striking baroque style" of Khmer architecture... You can't help asking yourself and wonder what the architect must be thinking when planning and building the 4 gigantic faces... Certainly rivals the great sphinx and the Nubian Monument at Abu Simbel

This is what you are here for.... Loved the sense of history and the vastness/scale of the complex. It is mind-bending to know that there was so much sophistication in the world so long ago, and that it is still visible to us today. Hated the crowds. Was here three years ago and it was busy then but numbers seem to have almost doubled this time. I would advise getting to the large temples early or late in the day when most of the tour buses and groups are not there. I would definitely recommend hiring a tuktuk for the day as this gives much more freedom and autonomy to move around and choose your route. You can hire a bike and cycle, but this gives you safety on the road while still being able to see the surroundings.

Our guide saved the best till last!. So many smiling faces, storiesof the the tourists as well as the stone carvings.To fully appreciate the intricacies of the bas-reliefs, but well worth it.TIP: avoid the heat of the early afternoon!
Nice smiles!. It was magical! The faces seem to be looking at you while providing a positive vibe. Make sure you are comfortable with heat and walking up many stairs.

Amazing Ruins. Bayon certainly doesn't compare with Angkor Wat on scale but it has a different magic about it. While archaeologists continue to work at this site, the temple is in a much worse state than the others. The ruins though provide enough signs of how amazing this temple might have been in the past. The pillars with the multiple faces of Buddha all around the temple gives it a very different feel when compared to Angkor Wat. The majestic depiction of the churning of the ocean for nectar at the entrance of the Angkor Thom complex shows that the complex along with all its temples must've been as marvelous a feat as Angkor Wat itself. The only issue with this place is that given its smaller size, crowds are more difficult to navigate.
Very spiritual experience. The thousands of years of history in a Temple that was relatively well preserved. This temple survived wars and landmines . It is truly an amazing experience to visit it.

Buddha, Buddha everywhere. Another fascinating temple in Angkor Thom. The structure was created by Jayavarman VII in an attempt to unify his people under his preferred system of Buddhism. The temple is oriented to the East, which is unusual in and of itself. Then numerous pillars are adorned with the serene face of the Buddha on all four sides. Some speculate that these were modeled after Jayavarman himself. There is a Mona Lisa quality to the expression of the Buddhas as they gaze across the landscape. A great place to sit and meditate or just relax and soak in the serenity.
Temple with Four Faces. After Ta Prohm, we walked to the Bayon Temple and from afar, the view is breathtaking. The temple has stone faces of four sides which represents four good values.

A temple that stood out (:. After going around the entire city since 5am (started with chasing the sunrise at Ang Kor Wat), I was definitely suffering from a serious case of temple fatigue. However, upon arriving at the Bayon temple, I was so intrigued by the facade. Reading on the important and significance of the temple's location in Ang Kor Thom definitely impressed me. Probably one of the more unique temples in Siem Reap and you must go there (:
Nice smiley faces. The only temple with the smiley faces on the towers (the king is watching over and protecting the town and its people). Lovely forest view from the top.

Beautiful temple complex. The Buddha face, looking toward the South Gate is serene and calming, though massive. The temple shows more Buddhist and less Hindu influence. There are many well executed bas-relief carvings depicting battles and telling stories. This area is fairly spread out and has more shade than Angkor Wat, but still gets a lot of traffic. Definitely try to go early to avoid the worst of the crowds.

Faces Everywhere You Look. This ended up being my favourite site. Bayon has many towers all adorned with faces. It was really a special place! There are some great spots to sit and look at all the faces around you.
Must see.. Go with a guide if for nothing else than having someone who knows where and when to take great pictures.

Bayon temple. Bayon temple is the 1st temple of choice it has a lot of history within the stonework & a very big area to walk around for picture taking.. A lot of forests nearby gives it the natural feeling of its beauty also...

Distinctive!. A very well preserved monument. Really can see the carved Buddha face clearly! Worth it to visit even if you are already very tired for the day of walking and climbing around the Angkor Archaeological Sites.

Astonishing!. Breathtaking! This temple is one of the best temples I've visited during my trip in Siem Reap. A must go! Do note that there is a high traffic of tourist groups going around the temple. Hence, visiting this temple during odd hours is recommended.

Worth a visit. Very interesting with plenty of very old stone carvings. The surrounding area is surrounded by trees with monkeys running around ~ good photo opportunities.Very busy and very hot, so take plenty of drinking water with you.

My favourite temple. Beautiful and tranquil...the carved faces were amazing. Almost everywhere we looked there were these smiling faces. The atmosphere was one of peace. Although it was busy, it was not obtrusive and you could spend time contemplating the serenity of the place.

God's own temple. Amazing place, great experience. A place of ancient worship, that is a testament to faith.
And ofcourse an amazing place for multiple photo-ops.
Our favourite. This temple has quite an effect architecturally and we spent the most time here. It also felt less busy - plan to spend time here!
Awesome but way overcrowded. Definitely a lot of history and a lot of work that has gone into this temple. Its so interesting to see, but there are people everywhere - especially at the top.
If short of time. This is the one not to miss ... Those faces !! Very precarious footpaths and exceedingly scary steps, but well worth iy.
Stunning portrait of the king. Eerie in a good way, beautiful, haunting. this is a wonderful temple for photography. Make sure you check out the dramatic bridge leading to the temple.

Ancient, Haunting, Mystical!. There are plenty of temples to go around in Siem Ream, Bayon in particular stands out. The whole experience of the temple is mystical and is well worth the journey. The smiling buddha faces are haunting and leave you with the a sense of awe. This is, in my view, the most amazing temple in Siem Reap.
Visited Jan'11.

Favorite Temple of Angkor Trip!. We rented a tuk-tuk for the day for $30. The driver picked us up at 5 a.m. from our hotel in Siem Reap, and it was about a 15-minute ride to Angkor Wat for breakfast and the morning-sunrise experience, then maybe another 10-minute ride to the Bayon Temple in Angkor Thom. You'll easily send a couple of hours walking around and photographing this incredible site. This was the highlight of our Cambodian trip!
Bayon temple. I found Bayon temple more interesting than Angkor Wat as there was much more detail to see. It is an amazing piece of ancient architecture and well worth a visit.
I see You. It is very interesting temple. It has most of the parts carved in head shaped rocks. It is quite small in area which is nice, because You can enjoy it without hectolitres of sweat.

1 of the big 3. Along with Angkor Wat for its size and Bantei Sreay for its intricate carvings, Bayon Temple is one of the must see temples of Siem Riap. You'll take lots of amazing photos and wish you were alive when it was finished so you could see it being used in its prime. We went early in the morning before most of the tourists descended upon it because we biked out and saw Angkor Wat at 5pm the day before (which is a great time to see that temple after most of the tourists have left and the sun is starting to set).

Bayon Temple, Siem Reap (Cambodia). It was beyond imagination. The giant stone pieces are set in such a nice way to create decorated human heads and all this was done a thousand years back. Even after ten decades, the temple is in nice good condition. When the rays of the Sun falls on the temple, it glitters and it appears that the Sun is also praising and appreciating the human workmanship and architecture. Our salute to Cambodia, its culture, its history and civilization.
Fantastic. Bayon temple is also a must see temple if you are in siem reap. Interesting to see so many faces of Buddha.
100% Must See!. By far my favourite temple out of all the ones we visited around Angkor Wat. Definitely worth the visit for the picture opportunities alone!
Beautiful. My favorite temple among all the others. The beauty of it needs no words to describe. How the build such a magnificent temple is beyond my imagination.

Bayon at Angkor Thom . utterly unbelievable and fantastic ! makes u feel like a real life Indiana Jones !!! the faces of buddha shine diwn on u magnificently . there r two kinds of faces ... one is the budhha face with the blunt nose and the other is the kings face with the sharp nose ! try to visit in the late afternoon about 30 min before the sunset . it is the best at that time .

The "Must-See" of Angkor Thom. The whole of the vast Angkor Thom site is interesting, but this is the jewel. It is difficult to find the words to express the magic of this place, even when there are crowds of people (as is the case most of the time). Because of time restraints we were only able to spend about 30 minutes here, but we could easily have spent an hour or more here alone in view of the extent of the carvings and fascination of the architecture.
Great Little Temple. The Bayon is in the Angkor Tom area which has 3 main temples and this is the best. Very impressive carving of heads and great to photo either early morning or late afternoon.
Went early. Go early before groups come... Is great fun and if you go to south side can ride elephants around temple..

Immersive!. Great trip and one of my highlights on my stay in Cambodia. Came here around mid morning with family visiting and everyone was really enthralled with the temple and the complex.Lots of crowds, but hey, its the #1 attraction, so what do you expect?!
4 faces temple.. Great temple with 4 faces, amazing temple and big but a bit old. Very very wonderful. How's can they build?
Don't miss this.. The smiley faces are intriguing. That is all you need to know about this site! Get there when the late afternoon light is upon the site and you will get some great photo ops.

Greeted by warm smiles. My favourite temple in Angkor city. The history is rich, and to be greeted by so many smiling faces! Every details of the carvings in the temple should be appreciated, how meticulously hand carved they were, and yet looked so uniform. We were lucky when we were there, not too many people. We had time to walk around and prayed as well. A small photography opportunity came up when a little monk appeared :)
The best. Of the major Angkor temples, we liked Bayon the most for its collection of smiling Buddhas that look out from every direction
amazing faces. too crowded... but since it's one of the three main temples in the area it's to be expected. An amazing experience anyway.

Best place to view Angkor Wat. Bayon can be found inside the Angkor Wat. In order for you to enjoy the Angkor experience I recommend for you to climb 50 steps ladder in the east part of the Bayon. Remember not to wear shorts, skirts, hat and sleeveless clothes. You don't have to worry if you don't have cover ups.. the officers will let you borrow a SARONG to cover your skin.

Amazing. The temples in Siem Reap are quite different and the Bayon Temple is no different . Be well prepared with walking shoes and carry plenty of water with you as it can be quite hot. We visited in March.

Many Faces.. Spectacular,yes,but just to over crowded with the tour groups,almost becomes a scrum.Work is being carried out near the site,so I presume some of it was off limits,maybe this made it busier,couldnt apply my 10 minute rule either.One to tick off the list,but preferred Angkor Wat itself.

Keep all the walking and steps in mind. Very interesting, amazing but wear suitable attire (especially footwear) in mind and don't bite off more than you can chew.This advice is for the not so young as touring all these sites is very hard work

My Favorite. I was really amazed on the stone faces with different facial expression. In fact, it was our first destination of our tour. Make sure you come here at around 7 am to avoid too much people. You wont enjoy the scene if its too crowded. We even came back on our last day so we can see it on a less crowded hour.
Must see. We love this temple even more than angkor Wat. It is an amazing example of the great work of khmer architecture, very intricate.

Do not Miss this place!. Personally, apart from Ta Phrom (Tomb Raider), this is another one of my favorite temple. The architecture is beautiful, to think that this is completed hundred years ago without modern technology. Beautiful. try to go early for this temple, as it get really crowded after 10am.

cooltempels. this is one of the better of the many temples in angkor wat
this one and the one with all the tree growing over it are the best
Fantastic experience. It's the most interesting of all the temples when you enters it. Faces everywhere with this rather disdainful smile of a long dead king.

The climb to the top is well worth it. Fascinating as are the other temple complexes. The detail that has survived all this time since 12th century is astounding. if you can, visit early in the morning to avoid crowds. the sites get very busy with tourists and Cambodians alike visiting them.

Not even a tenth as grand as Angkor Wat.. Bayon Temple is the focus of so many good reviews but I really find it chaotic and disorderly. The faces yes, they are great and add a great deal of character.
Amazing Temple. We visited this place last February 2014. The place is amazing. One of the places that people must see in their life.

The most amazing temple there is!. I was lucky enough to spend 3 glorious days int this country and without a doubt the Bayon Temple is just fascinating. I was besotted with Angkor Wat for years but was very surprised by the splendour of the Bayon Temple.The number of faces in the temple is amazing, you just keep seeing new ones everywhere you look. I cannot stress how wonderful this temple is. It may be not the most preserved but the sheer size of the ruins and the detail of the faces will blow you away!

Absolutely can not miss Bayon. This is an absolutely beautiful temple that can not be missed. It was definitely one of our top 5.When we were there, it was extremely full. It was around 9 AM on a weekday (after going to Angkor Wat for the sunrise), and when on the top, it was just too many people. I would recommend anyone who goes to try to make it either really early, or later in the afternoon, it will make the experience much better, and let you take in the beautiful site.The guides have a somewhat preset itinerary so they seem to tend to push to having this at around morning. Ask for a better timing!
Fantastic. Impossible to describe. Visit it. Very, very good. Especially at sunset. I feel time in every stone of this temple
Amazing place. This temple is amazing , all the towers decorated with 4 stone smiling faces and it is very good preserve

Smiling Faces temple. The center of the Angkor Thom Complex of temples.
This is the one with all the smiling and serene stone Buddha faces. You are surrounded by them on the top terrace. Loved it.

Great to photograph, but very busy. This temple had a lot of interest factor because of the faces, but it was so crowded it was hard to get uninterrupted shots.
There were a lot of wild monkeys in this area and right opposite the elephant rides.

History and sculptures are smiling at you!. It was a marvelous experience. We went in after 5:30pm, which you don’t have to pay but in two days we could see Angkor Wat and Bayon. If you really want to experience this area you need all day or more day than that.
Incredible. The Bayon Temples were breathtaking and a defiante must see when visit Siem Reap. The faces you see over the temples are truly amazing!
facinating. taking a guide to point out what you might otherwise miss and to explain the stories behind everything.

Ruins that awe. Amazing to view ruins and history of a place we had never been to. The cooperative venture of UNESCO and other countries helping to restore the ruins was great to read about and see in progress.
Truly amazing. This was our favorite temple. Angkor Wat gets all the press but Bayon is just breathtaking. The faces on the stone are just amazing. Don't miss this one.
Part of the Complex of Angkor Thom. It hasn't weathered as well as Angkor Wat, but it is still a phenomenal experience. the hundreds of stone faces staring out into the distance is quite eerie.

Favourite temple. Bayon Temple was my favourite of all the temples we visited in Siem Reap. To me, the temple felt peaceful. From a tourist's point of view, it was perhaps less crowded when we visited, and the light from the morning sun did help bring out the colours of the many faces of the temple.

Feels like being watched by many faces all at once!. Bayon is an architectural feat! Built in the late 12th or early 13th century in the center of Angkor Thom. It's most distinctive feature is the multitude of serene and massive stone faces on the many towers which jut out from the upper terrace and cluster around its central peak. It is unique and freaky at the same time. Feels like one is being watched by multiple faces all the the same time. Any direction one turns towards, there will be a face or a cluster looking back at you.
my favorite. I actually liked Bayon Temple the best. Maybe it was all the smiling faces, but it sure put me in a good mood.

Wondrous. It is surely the most surprising site of Angkor.
The towers with smiling faces impress with its architectural design and dimension. You can not go to Angkor and not visit Bayon

Loved Siem Reap. We spent four full days there and saw all the major temples, shopped, wandered around Pub Street and went on a bird walk with the Sam Veasna Center for Wildlife Conservation - highly recommended!
get really upclose with the sculpture. Liked it the best of all the temples we saw, able to get really close to the amazing sculpture. The smell of bat poo was my only complaint.
You'd be a fool if you don't visit Bayon. Stunning architecture with stunningly beautiful details. MUST GO. Top of the Siem Reap MUST-SEE List.
Historically interesting. This is one of the many interesting temples in Siem Reap area. Easy to walk around and a very pleasant area

Temple of many faces. This temple is stunning, for the many faces that was carved into its columns. It's interesting architecture and different from the structure and symmetry of the other temples in the compound. It was overrun with tourists when we visited, which was a shame.

OMG!!!. I went here twice, once on our first day looking at Angkor etc, the second time on my own at sunrise (you can give it about 30-45 mins after the crack of dawn) in order to avoid the many tour groups. I got there at about 0630, there were about 4 other people there and it was just stunning and somewhat mystical. It is impossible not to think you are the worlds best photo-journalist but.... words simply cannot do it justiceTo get the most from it you have to have the time otherwise you will be left with a sense of 'two religions? funny building, 4 faces, steep steps, next please...' therefore if you have the time get a multi-day pass (we each had the one week pass)After about an hour and a quarter/half the groups were beginning to come in and spoil what I had so I went around the outside. I was lost in my own thoughts when I caught sight of the north side as I came through the trees....lump in throat time, hanky to eye and a quick look over my shoulder to make sure no one could see me!***TIP*** get your ticket for the following day from approx. 1645 the night before - it is an accepted practice and does not eat into the validity of your pass; you can then get to wherever you want to first thing in the morning with little hassle beyond having to get your pass verified

This is another must-see when visiting Cambodia. We thought Angkor Thom gates were impressive, but this site is far better. The temple's carved faces are amazing and in very good conditions for photos. Give yourself plenty time to explore this site thoroughly.

giant heads. as per Lara croft tomb raider this temple has the giant faces looking down upon you.this is my favourite temple.... I was here 7 years ago and the influx of tourists has not diminished the spectacle.best seen at sunrise.

Enjoyable. There is a little trail before the main gate that you can go up and be almost face to face with one of them. The distressed look of the stone was beautiful and added to the carvings. And there is also one area within before you get to the people dressed in traditional Apsara costumes that contain bats. Be aware of the health risks associated with contact.
Impressive temple with lots of faces.. It's one of the more impressive temples with multiple towers and faces mostly intact. It's beautiful in the evening.
Must see. Loved the many carved faces that survive on this temple! You could imagine the glory of what it would have looked like long ago.

Was this made almost 1000 years ago?. Amazing and breathtaking location with all the faces there!!!You should go there in the morning, right after the sunrise tour at Angkor Wat, then you can skip the crowd later the day.

This temple a must see along with three (3) others!. If you have limited time in a Siem Reap for temple visits, I suggest you see this one and three others: TaProhm, Angkor Wat & Angkor Thom. These temples will give you four (4) different perspectives of content, design & style of the artisans and cultures at the time. They are truly works of art. There are excellent opportunities for photos and sightseeing of theses unique structures. Well worth seeing and spending the limited time that might be available. I would suggest at least 3/4 of the day with lunch set aside for viewing and really enjoying the experience in the daylight hours. A must see all four (4) if possible.

Faces.. This to my mind was the stand out complex after Angkor Wat,the temple is stunning,from the moment you cross the causeway your eyes can never take in everything in front of you .The faces are quite haunting,everywhere you look there is another one smiling at you.the photo opportunities are endless and our guide Pheng showed us the best angles to include multiple faces in our pictures.I was impressed with the care that is being taken of this complex and the ongoing restoration of this place in such a poor country is impressive,I realise this is probably with world funds but at least work is being carried out with great results.Don't miss Bayon,it is stunning.

Beautiful. In the Angkor Thom area which takes a couple of hours to walk around and see everything - Bapuon, Elephants Terrace, Leper King Terrace, and nearly a dozen other much smaller little temples. Bayon is huge with beautiful face carvings on its towers. On the day were were there, there were monkeys climbing in the trees around Bayon.

Our favourite temple. We really loved the Bayon temple, it was definitely our favourite of all the Angkor temples. While it is not quite as magnificent as Angkor Wat, it was so beautiful with the incredible faces carved all around. It gave it a really eerie feeling, and there are beautiful wall carvings all around it as well. For me this would be my "don't miss it" temple.
Fascinating building. One of the essential temples to visit in the park - although possibly the busiest after Angkor Wat. Beautiful and good for pretending to be Lara Croft :-)

Must see attraction !!!. We hired a guide for our three day visit and if you are planning to be there that long, buy the three day pass that can be used for any three days within a 7 day period.Nov /Dec best time due to cooler weather (70s) and with over 98 different temples to see this one has to be one of the top 5. Also since its bigger than most, there are a lot to see and explore.Easy hiking , and great scenery for amazing pictures.
Bayon Temple. This is a must see- best with a guide who can tell you the history and the finer points of historical and artistic interest

Magical attraction. Atmospheric and not too crowded.
The spot were Angelina Jolie 'disappeared' in the Tomb Raider movie was particularly popular.
Weird but wonderful. This was an incredible temple. Exactly as I had read about it. It was a weird structure but just so eerie and wonderful.

very photogenic. Beautiful it lots of Buddha faces to look at, really enjoyed it even though it was the last of day, 4 temples in one day is not easy and can get boring but luckily our guide was excellent and really made us a perfect day.

Amazing, just amazing. This is one of the greatest world site. Visit to Bayon is lifetime experience, it is must see atraction
..
Impressive

Beautiful mysterious smiles. The Bayon, with its enigmatic smiles is one of my favorite temples. Do not miss this one.
Come early morning or late afternoon. We came midday and it was really crowded, too many people and rather noisy.
Also, there are really dark portions (even some rooms) in the inside the temple.

go for sunrise. go here for sunrise and avoid all the people at ankor wat! keep one step ahead of the crowd for the surrounding temples too. Really magical with bats all around as the sun rises. no tuktuk noise and smoke!
Trees take over. Was crowded late morning. Just where Angelina Jolie was !! An eery site with trees taking over the temples.

Beautiful Place.... This Temple is simple AMAZING.... the peace and magic can be felted all around it. Its a place to relax, breathe it, enjoy it and above all, feel the good energy that surrounds Bayon Temple.

Mesmerizing Faces make up the temple domes. This temple is inside the ancient city of Angkor Thom. Go early or late to avoid the crowds and you can spend a lot of quiet time admiring the carvings. Just how all the stones were lined up and carved into faces is mindboggling. For me Angkor Wat and Bantai Srei came before Angkor Thom in artistry and beauty, but I enjoyed Angkor Thom as well.
Amazing and impressive temple. 54 towers representing the former capitals of Angkor. The large buddha heads facing the four directions of the compass are friendly and extremely beautiful

Stunning. Don't miss this - the smiling faces are quite beautiful, and the views from the temple are terrific. As with the whole area, the temple can be very busy at certain times of the day, and is seen at its best when quiet, so worth some careful planning, and an early start.
Recommended. Loved this temple,definitely take a camera and some water,as there wasn't anywhere at the temple to buy drinks. Very crowded at midday and lunchtime so either go early or late

Angkor Wat and surrounds. The shear scale of these temples is so impressive. A complete city complex with massive walls. The carvings in Bas Relief are still fresh,and tell wonderful stories - but you need a good guide!

Bayon heart of Jayavarman's empire. The Bayon is one of the jewels of Angkor, located at the heart of Angkor Thom the great city of Jayavarman VII. If you choose to visit the temple solo you can now download an iPad iBook that will guide you through with audio that explains all the bas reliefs (also in text) with interactive maps so you don't get lost and included is the latest information on archaeological research at Angkor, written by an archaeologist and narrated by Prof. Charles Higham who has been working in the region for decades. The iBook also includes a temple map with times that are best to visit various monuments so you can avoid the crowds. Find it at http://interactiveangkor.com or search the title "An Interactive Guide to Angkor" on iTunes. Happy temple-ing!

Nicest Temple by Far!. We love this temple and the beautiful smiling faces that adorn the temple sides. Simple stunning and well worth the visit. get there early or later in the day to avoid the growing number of Chinese / Japanese tourists group that can make it very busy!
