The smiles. Was told there were 39 smily faces but didn't count myself. Do come in early before groups of people storm in. Another steel stairs leading you to the top of the temple. Another amazing piece of art.
One of the many temples you just have to see. It is usually included in any guided tour, and we started at this one, giving us a taste of what was to come
Faces!. Faces everywhere. Make sure to visit this temple. Very close to Angkor Wat. One of the popular temple in Angkor Thom.

A sight for sore eyes. Nothing prepares you for the vastness of this place. Would recommend going to the Angkor museum in Siem Reap first though to find out the history as there are no signs at all at the site.

Spectacular - make sure you see it!. I had not read any information on the Bayon Temple before visiting, so was totally blown away by all the faces carved into the stone - truly amazing!! This temple is very close to Angkor Wat , so can be visited on the same day and is a must see!

great temple. We came here around 9am and it was getting hot.bring lots of water. This is an iconic temple and not one to miss. Get a guide or guidebook that tells you the history, many of the carvings depict daily life which is fascinating.
Faces. Serene stone faces make a great photo opportunity. A must visit site but getting there early is recommended.
Beautiful and amazing temple. Part of a 3 day trip around Siem Reap. Loved this temple. The carved faces were just stunning. Very beautiful despite being pretty crowded.

Don't miss this one. When Lara Croft is dropped off in Cambodia, she's standing on this temple with some binoculars by one of the iconic Buddha faces - of which there are many. It's impossible to resist taking hundreds of photos of this hypnotizing location. There are lots of different angles where faces line up, framed through stone windows that on a good day, are caught by slices of sunlight that cast shadows and patterns which constantly change. At points you will find you're level with the faces so you can stand next to them - but be prepared to wait your turn as the occasional aggressive idiot armed to the teeth with an arsenal of photography equipment is never less than six feet away. The significant thing about Bayon are the carvings on the outer wall that are some of the only recorded depictions of urban life in Angkor. If my memory serves me correctly, some show the pulley systems they used to lift the stones that built the many temples. You don't need a guide, but one can be helpful to take you through the carvings which are actually really good. If you only do Angkor Wat and one other temple, make this that one other temple. This temple is included in the Angkor pass, no extra charges. As with all the temples, how long you need is a piece of string - but at least an hour if not 2. Don't forget to check out the carvings.

See How Life Was Lived. Of all the temples we visited I got a particular kick out of this because of the bas relief showing all aspects of life during the Khmer period. It was really riveting if you love history
Best one.... Don't miss... this was the most interesting temple for me... the Buddha faces are just fascinating, and if you go right at dusk it will not be crowded
Amazing! . This was by far my favourite archeological site in Siem Reap. It is truly breathtaking how much work goes into this type of work, even in this day in age.
go and see. Misterious and so beautiful. What a culture and so much to see. Even more impressing than Angor Wat. You hardley believe your eyes. It took us 2 hours to see almost evrything.
Amazing!!!!. From the outside we don't get how amazing this temple is. We must go up and see the fabulous Buddha smiles. Superbe!!!!

Breath taking. stunning temple with eerie faces that seem to follow you round.
The only negative is the elephants with metal seats carrying tourists round please avoid these we didnt like the look of them but having been to an elephant sancturay in thailand these seats seriously harm the animals.

Less Popular Than Angkor Wat but Every Bit As Impressive. Without a doubt the most popular temple in Siem Reap is Angkor Wat. Although many people may never have heard of the name Bayon Temple prior to their trip, they will still enjoy a visit there. The temple is relatively small and is easily recognized by the numerous towers with faces. #1 Our group visited just after lunch, which I thought was a great time to see the ruins. The sun wasn't too high in the sky so it wasn't hot and the crowd of people was very manageable. #2 You will have to do a little bit of climbing to get to the main area of Bayon. #3 There are lots of doorways that weave here and there and it can become somewhat overwhelming. #4 Speaking honestly, it's easy to explore Bayon between 60-90 minutes. There truly isn't very much to see and once you see one tower with faces you've pretty much seen all. #5 If you're traveling with a group, be very specific about the time and point out the exact place where you will meet. Our guide simply told us to meet at the east entrance. Unfortunately that doesn't mean much when you're in a country where you have no idea where the cardinal points lie. We couldn't find someone in our group because she got confused on exactly where the east entrance was located. Fortunately she remembered the name of the hotel but the rest of the group left without her.

Fantastic. Bayon is a bit less crowded than Angkor Wat but the architecture is fantastic. One of my favorite temples on the Angkor complex. The massive stone faces are impressive. Would definitely return!

Be sure to wear comfortable shoes to climb and see wonderful structures.. We spent a wonderful morning visiting the Bayon Temple. I was amazed how many tourist had flip flops on and were sitting rubbing their feet. Be sure to wear a good pair of tennis shoes. The guides really know their stuff. Be sure to have an extra image card as you will take hundreds of pictures. The site is so large that you need a great deal of time so see it all and to understand what you are seeing. Be sure to go in the morning as it gets very hot.

Other worldly. Lucky enough to visit when most people / tour groups were at lunch so we had the luxury of it being less crowded. The fact that nature had taken over this one made it much more appealing to us.
Beautiful. Not much to say other than it's one of the more impressive temples in the Angkor Complex. Visit early morning or late afternoon/sunset.
Beautiful Carvings. The carvings are without a doubt the highlight of the Bayon complex without detracting from the numerous towers

Crowded but love those faces. Driving up the road towards the southern gate I was awed by the sculpted head atop of the gate and the demons and gods doing a tug of war on the bridge. Once inside, it gets even better as there are heads with four faces everywhere. Whose face was it?
Very impressive. Faces, faces, and more faces, but never enough...... Very nice, try to visit in the morning or evening.

Best temple in Cambodia. Loved, loved, loved Bayon! I feel that this is the best temple to visit in Cambodia, and it certainly doesn't disappoint. The Buddha faces all over really make his place magical, especially the smiling ones! If you want to get a real touristy photo, get someone to take a photo of you 'kissing' one of the smiling faces! :)
Better than Angkor Wat.. Yes, you read it here. This was just gorgeous and so up close and personal. You MUST go and see for yourself. Experience this now.

One of the best temples. Quieter than Angkor Wat but just as magical. Visitors should be able to handle steps. This temple is very close to lots of other places to visit- Terrace of the Elephants and others. There are nice toilet facilities on one end. There is also a market area with choices of food and tourist items for sale.

A must on your sightseeing list. An evocative structure which conveys the feeling that you are in a truly unique environment. There is little more to add that you cannot find in one of numerous guidebooks.

It doesn't disappoint!. Was there today, sadly with too many other people but nevertheless, an amazingly beautiful place that gives you goosebumps! So many amazing carvings and enticing doorways that reveal another secret as you enter. A MUST do when in Siem Reap. You will want to return!! Bicycle or tuk-tuk to get there from town, it's really not far at all.

Speechless!. Ok it is bloody amazing, however tourist filled the place was - it is still a must see. AMAZING.
We did a half day bike tour - and the guide took us thru the back path which was away from all the tourist. A great experience.

Breathtaking....Bayon Temple. One of the favorite temples to include in your visit to Siem Reap. Bayon a mysterious temple mountain is located in the center of Angkor Thom. Notice the artistic creativity and see the 54 towers that show the smiling stone carved faces. Take your time and feel the magic and see this amazing site.

My favorite of the Siem Reap temples. I am certainly happy that I saw Angkor Wat, but it seemed relatively "sterile" compared to the other 14 temples I visited in the Angkor Archaeological Park -- all vegetation has been removed and there were MANY visitors. On the other hand, I really enjoyed Bayon Temple -- built in the late 12th C. There are 54 towers each with 4 faces (for a total of 216), and apparently there is no definitive answer as to who is depicted in those faces. Our guide was Nu Tat. He speaks English very well, is well educated, and his commentaries are interesting and meaningful. Another of Tat's good qualities is that he doesn't follow the conventional itinerary so his clients tend to see the temples at less-visited times. Tat can be reached at nutarth@yahoo.com
Awesome!. Could spend all day there! Worth a visit, take a camera and water :) The area is clean, well kept. Lots to see.

Magical. You're entering in a diferent world/ time when discovering this temples... Go by bike or tuktuk, for great interaction with the sorroundings. This will be one of the most beautiful things that you'll ever see.
Lost in the ruins. So busy I actually lost my group.But reunited later.Be careful it's easy to get lost in the awe of it all.

Forget the Wat. If you on a time limitation this is the temple to pick out. Much smaller than its nearby big brother but far more interesting and although busy is not absolutely crawling with queuing Chinese and shouting Japanese tourists like Ankor is. Some of the carvings are fabulous and can be viewed at ease without being pushed and deafened by rude visitors.

Well worth the 5am tuk tuk ride to have this magical place to ourselves!. Bayon with its many faces full of mysterious contentment was an early morning treat! We had the run of the place when we arrived and happily explored the temple, admiring the many enigmatic faces and peeking into the many nooks and crannies. Some of the passageways are rather dark, so you may considered bringing a small flashlight to better see the details.From the Bayon, it is a short walk to explore several other nearby Angkor sites including the Elephant Terrace.

Such grand scale. The Bayon Temple or Four faces temple is just lovely. Although many of the spires have fallen down, our guide said that mabye one day they will try to rebuild them. I think it makes it better, it reminds you that these temples are old and are to be admired. We were lucky enough to be blessed in a ceremony that we accidently walked in on at the top teir. Worth adding to your list of must see things in the temple complex.
very cool. We couldn't get enough time visiting this temple and others in the area. full of great history, architecture and imagination.

Striking Architecture. Highlight were the beautiful 12 the century carvings around the temple and the striking face-towers. So much to see you need to read up about it before you visit or employ a guide and you will have a much greater appreciation of what you are looking at.

Amazing!. The sheer scale of this temple is its most impressive feature, and the many heads and bas-reliefs provide something to look at up close.Angkor Wat is the one everyone comes too see, but don't miss Bayon Temple; it's worth the visit!
Stunning. Fantastc temple. So beautiful. A must see whilst in Siem Riep. It's best to have a guide to explain everything to you.

Great place to visit. Family of 4: 2 adults/2 late teenagers. We went on a guided tour with 'Beyond Unique Tours' (see my separate review of them)... and this was a fantastic temple. However, you could still arrange a visit on your own by hiring a Tuk-Tuk driver from your hotel or in town. We started early arriving at 07.45am at the official Temple Ticket Office. 1-day all-temple visit ticket US$20, 3-day US$40. You need a photo-ID ticket to enter the temples and the staff DO check your ticket. I had a foot-cast & walking stick, but still managed to walk around this temple. The 'smiling faces' are something I still remember. We would recommend this temple.

My favourite of all temples. Mesmerised by this temple and all the detailed faces peering at you and the world that have been carefully carved into the stone. I took loads of photos as really is a picture everywhere you turn even though the area isn't that big. Can also ride elephants in the morning and support local villages (although not sure it's ideal for elephant so I didn't).

My Favourite Angkor Temple!!. Angkor Wat is the grandest, but the Bayon is simply amazing. My tip for keen photographers, get there at dawn and beat the crowds. It's a small temple, and the upper terrace gets very crowded, but if you get there as the sun comes up armed with a torch, you'll get the opportunity to photograph the Bayon's many faces in spectacular lighting.
Fabulous. One of our favourites. The huge face carvings looking out at different angles were so impressive. So glad we visited this temple.
mindblowing. The second most important temple (after Angkor). It takes a few hours to take all these fantastic reliefs in. Don good shoes!
Beautiful. I liked it a lot! i enjoyed that you can walk to the top and take nice photos without a lot of tourist in every single one of them. Small stairs and cozy atmosphere.
Amazing.... So many faces at so many angles. Very interesting architecture. A must to visit in Siem Reap. Should not be missed

Awe Inspiring. I found this temple better than Angkor Wat as its carvings displayed the life of Khymer People in the 11 the century , and the faces staring at you were excitingly frightning!! a must visit for all
Awesome!. I rented a bicycle and spent 3 hours walking through this temple complex. The advantage of having a bicycle was that I could cycle right up to the many temples. Fantastic!
Angor thom - timeless beauty.. this temple is open has a lot of sculptures from the ages past, and all the history to lose yourself in. Simply amazing
Cool Temple. Really interesting temple with lot wonderful architecture. There's lot of information related to Hinduism. Hindus should visit this awesome temple.
Amazing place. I am impressed by these huge architect and i have to spent 2 times for this place to make sure i get the detail i want to see
Bayon Temple. The Iconography is wonderful. We found it really helpful to have a guide who could explain the nuances of the statues and all of the carvings. The Buddha is everywhere!
Great set of carved faces. Nice an quiet in the morning with not a lot of tourists. Sun lights up some of the faces. These things are massive.
Happy and Film Making Too. Great happy atmosphere at this special Wat near Angkor Wat Complex. Elephant riding and a film being made was also exciting.

get a guide for here. Fantastic temple. definately get a guide for this temple. there is a lot of history and little quirks at this temple that you would easy miss without the experience of a guide showing you around.

Impressive. The stone carvings here are unique and whisper to you the stories of many hundred years...despite the fact that it is also way too full of the tourist kind, Bayon is still enjoyable and a must see....

Stunning, go later in the day. Most tourists start with Bayon directly after sunrise and breakfast around Angkor Wat. We did our tour the opposite way around so by the time we reached Bayon around 3pm there were hardly any other people and the light was fantastic.
Amazing. This is my favourite Angkor temple. The towers with stone faces are just amazing. This temple has lots of tourists so it is quite noisy.

Quite stunning. This place stands out, even against all the other amazing things to see in Siem Reap's glories. Yes there are huge crowds (some of whom are noisy to the extent of being rude), but this temple is an absolute 'must see'.

Character & Childhood. Bayon was the last temple of the day for us to explore and what a great way to end a long hot day. With the sunsetting most visitors were scurrying to the published sunset hotspots and the temple was practically empty. Empty temple = Bliss! As we roamed through the nooks and crannies of this beautiful ruin we were envisioning ourselves playing hide and seek as children. The real life facial carvings were unlike any we had seen and allowed us to feel connected to the temple on a human level. This was by far my favorite temple of the day.
Favorite of all the Angkor temples!. This was my favorite of all the Angkor temples! Beautiful and well-preserved. Ride an elephant here at sunset!

wonderful. One of the best temple experiences in Siem Reap, a great place for photo taking. As with all other temples, go early and beat the crowds, specially those ever present ever noisy tour groups!!! If you decide to skip some temples DO NOT SKIP THIS ONE!!!

loved. Have wanted to see this temple since the tomb raider game on playstation! The faces are all well preserved and they are currently working on restoration of the fallen walls. Only problem was the groups of tourists make it a little harder to move around the small space inside the temple.
Budha heads everywhere. All these heads were incredible!Took best pictures ever! Very crowded though with people from tour buses.

liked this one the best. This is the temple with the big faces and it was just as amazing as the photos. What I liked best is that it is kind of a maze inside which means there were lots of little nooks and crannies that you'd find yourself in without any other tourists - which is almost impossible anywhere in Angkor!

Bayon is the Best!. I would highly recommend visiting Bayon Temple. Unlike Angkor Wat, Bayon has not received as much renovation over the years and still looks authentic. It's a beautiful place to visit. My favourite temple in Siem Reap!

Fantastic !. We were on a bicycle tour and have visited this temple via the 'backyard' ; not too many people.
It is just marvelous - the faces in the temple everywhere. Very nice photographs. Amazing how this must have been built in the old times . Not to be missed in your visit of the Angkor Wat domain

Great ruins, hot weather! . These ruins are great, Buddha faces everywhere you look. Less crowded than the main Angkor Wat site but one of the must-see group of temples when you visit. You can also do the "face to face" photo so poplar with tourists but the sheer scale of this place is what you will remember.

Scary faces!. I'm surprised this was listed on Trip Advisor as the number 1 attraction in Siem Reap. Bayon was impressive but there wasnt much to look at aside from the giant faces which I'll admit as impressive both in size and craftsmanship. The temple is rather small so I agree with all the reviews that you need to go early to get the full experience. We didn't go early and so the temple was crammed with loud / disrespectful Asian tour groups (which consume Siem Reap all year round apparently). We felt rushed in seeing the temple because the herd of tourists were scrambling to get a photo opp.If you're like is abs don't like living behind your camera lense and instead prefer slowly seeing and absorbing the temple as you're there then go early!Overall the time temple gets a 3. Angkor Wat and Ta Prom were WAY better.

Second time round, still in awe. The trip was in 2005, it rained everyday and hot and humid. It was still hot but the air was pure around the temple, though tooo many visitors. The smiles on the stones faces will linger on forever.

spectacular. We visited many temples during our visit to Cambodia & Vietnam including Angkor Wat and this was one of my favourites. If I was pushed for time and could only choose one, it would be Bayon. It's smaller, less crowded and not so tiring as say Angkor Wat (which is also awesome). The faces are amazing as are the overgrown trees. Like any ancient site, you need to watch your footing and be very careful on the narrow steps - but there is always someone willing to lend a helping hand - if necessary. A must see.
Bucket list. Wear comfortable shoes, carry bottled water and take your camera! Go early in the day to avoid crowds.
Try first. Start here and do Angkor Wat second, as this one, although impressive, isn't a patch on the main sight!
Magical Place. Do not visit just Angkor Wat. Many other temples offer special features and ofter fewer tourists. Bayon is one of them.
Worth the trip. Great as part of a cycle trip around the Angkor Wat complex! Beautiful architecture and history. Perfect for photographers.

beautiful place. This was my first temple to visit in Siem Reap, so I think that is why I liked it so much. I do have difficulties getting around, but still was able to do all the climbs on this temple, with some hand holding on the way down. It is a crowded place, mostly because of the one-way trip through, but I was still able to enjoy the beautiful smiling faces that are around each corner. Even though it is not gigantic like Angkor Wat, it felt more personable and tangible

Spellbinding!!. Just the way we had imagined! It was picture postcard. Despite the fact that its such a photographed place, there wasn't much crowd early after sunrise (which we saw at Angkor). We spent nearly an hour clicking photographs and soaking in the atmosphere!! Some of those faces actually make u wonder how the people could have imagined and ultimately carve out such figures on stone!!

Beautiful temple . Beautiful temple, to bad about the crowds. Not sure when is a good time to visit this site. Some say early afternoon. When ever we drove by it was packed. We still got some good pictures of the faces. Head up to the second level and you are face to face with some nice examples. The best views and pictures we had of this site was from the top of the elephant that made its route around the temple. Go in the morning and early evening come back for a drive around the temple in the nice light. Too bad for all the tourists.
216 Smiling Faces. A charming temple with smiling faces. Bayon Temple is a smaller area to cover so it felt much more manageable and thus memorable.

The faces make this my favorite. You'll be able to get up close to the mysterious faces covering this temple site. Part Buddha, part king, the faces look out in all directions. The site has extensive carvings, like others in the area. It was a favorite of ours!

One in the Angkor series not to be missed.. You have to see this in addition to Angkor Wat. If you feel you have seen them all and missed this one, you have wasted your travel time! The faces are intriguing!

Overgrown. the temple is in sad disrepair, trees have taken over and there are no signs of poisoning them, in a few years it will be unsafe to visit, they are doing work on the front but I think it is too little too late. Had I known it was that bad I would have gone to another temple

Worth visiting with a guide. That was one of the few things you could do in Cambodia but visiting with a guide would make it more meaningful as they could direct you to some of the attractions and explain in details.

Beautiful Temple. Voted best in Trip advisor, I love the smiling faces of the buddha so much...!!
Great place to visit
Great. Not as grand as Angkor Wat itself, it was still a great place to visit and see a fully restored temple.
Wooooow. My favorite! The sight can get really busy so try to visit either early in the morning or late in the afternoon to avoid the crowd.
Wonderful Temple.. The whole area is also in unspoilt forests. Temples everywhere! Unbelievable how they built so many years ago.

Gopurams or temple towers with smiling buddha faces on four sides are mystical. If visiting in the mid morning/afternoon, climbing the innumerable stairs can be tiresome. There is no provision for food stalls/ drinks in the vicinity. So please carry drinking water and a cap. It is best to hire a guide from the ticket counter itself before you enter the angkor wat temple complex.

Beautiful proportions. This is one of the loveliest temples in the Angkor Wat area with beautiful carvings and over 200 huge faces on all four sides of all the towers. Despite being made of stone, it has a lightness and grace to its lines that the huge Angkor Wat Temple lacks.
Well preserved temple. Very interesting stone carvings at this temple and relatively easy to access. There are quite a few steps so you need to be fairly fit for this visit.

Angkor Thom site. Lots of elephants about if you fancy a ride! Very busy at the temple - unavoidable I imagine if you are going as part of a tour. Even though we arrived at 8.30am it was very busy. Might be an idea to hire your own guide at your hotel and make a 5.30am start. Would be worth it as the temples are magical. Apparently day-guides cost about $50, so you could do Bayon, Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm at your pace.

Beautiful Temple, Too Many Tourists. This is an incredible temple that you absolutely have to see if you go to Angor. There are so many intricately carved faces and ornate little windows that make for absolutely amazing photos.However, we went during the Chinese New Year, which meant that the place was not only crawling with tourists (as I understand it is generally) but crawling with groups of travelling Chinese, which made the day a little more difficult. If you can, avoid going during this time of year!

Beautiful temple, but try to find out a way to ditch the Chinese tourgroups. We loved all temples at Angkor, Bayon was one of the greatest, very compact but beautiful. Best advice I can provide for all temples at Angkor is, try to find out a way to ditch the tour groups. The appear to be only interested in making great portrait photos...

Elephant rides!. All the temples in Siem Reap are beautiful. But at this one an elephant can take you around before you walk the path! You can feed them first, too. Also a few pagodas there if you're like me and need all the blessings you can get.

Awesome. To see to be believe it, this temple filled with beautiful carving, need to take time to admire. One to understand the history behind and well lay out planned temple. Heaps of walking up and down.

Mysterious Mahayana Monument in Unexpected Location. It was a completely unexpected surprise for me to encounter the faces of Bodhisattva Avalokitesvara ( kwan in Ch.) and (Kwanon Ja.) Those who studied zen are familiar with this deity in the beginning of Prajna Paramita Sutra ( Heart sutra)Supposedly one of the kings was converted to mahayana buddhism or others say the faces are king's. Just like Angkor Wat, Bayon temple is a 3 dimensional mandala with upper terrace surrounded by the towers of Bodhisattvas. Lower gallery surrounding the temple is also interesting with a single lingam at crossing. For photographers it is a good place to use your tripod even during the day light if you carried one all the way. I imagine the experience of walking through the temple it self was planned as a mystical experience. Those who are interested in Buddhism Hinduism or the power of symbols should visit this place alone and quietly.

So cool!. Amazingly beautiful! Gorgeous area, rode an elephant, so much detail on every service and majestic overall. Beware of people offering to guide or take pictures. Consider booking a tour before hand (do not do it there!) or just explore on your own. I didn't do a tour as I think it wouldve been too slow pace for me. There are things I wouldve like to know what they were but couldnt have handled a set routine.

Staircases, staircases and more staircases...LOL!!. Bayon Temple bring a lot of histories of the passed by its own. The bullet marks on the rock during the world war still can be seen clearly. If your knee wasn't that strong, i won't recommend you to go up the temple. Maybe a view from the ground will do.

Excellent architecture of old era and well maintained facility. The architecture and the carvings are striking. It is amazing to imagine these structures were built over 1000 years ago.A guide who know the history and background of the place adds value to the overall experience.
Amazing. It needs to be visited to be believed, one can spend a few hours just admiring the artisan's ability to shape rock into beautiful faces.
Amazing building. Trees shadow together old cool stone are perfect view i've ever seen. I would be much nicer if the area is a bit quiet from tourists.

Out of this World. Amazing - a highlight of the Angkor temples. Serene. It has left a lasting imprint on my mind. To sit and reflect the operation of this glorious temple in ancient times is almost beyond comprehension. It is beyond words - if you have a chance to visit do it.

Beautiful But Getting Overcrowded. We visited 11 years ago. Coming back now, we were concerned how these magnificent ruins would be holding up. The ruins are fine, but the number of tourists is almost overwhelming. It is difficult to walk around and appreciate the sights due to the large number of (often) discourteous tourists.
Not saying you shouldn't go, but be prepared for crowds.

Amazing. Bought 3days pasess and visited most of the temple.
But Bayon is one of my favorite. U may find any flat and okay rock to seat on and take a minute rest.

Imposing Buddhist temple. Situated in the middle of the Angkor Thom complex, the two hundred or so faces beam beatifically from the towers. You can find places to eat within a few hundred metres on the grounds opposite the Terrace of the Elephants.
excellent visit. excellent visit mainly for people passionnated by ancient history. Not to many visitors at end of day.

Amazing.. Very unique compared to many of the other temples. Get here a little after sunrise or before sunset to see the faces bathed in warm, pleasing light when you can see more detail and definition.

Smiling Faces. Lucky for us, we did not encounter many tour groups when we visited. We got there early in the morning so maybe we arrived before everyone else. It is not sprawling like many of the other temples. This temple is very different from many of the other ones we visited. Bayon should be on the top of your must-see list.

Well worth the trip. Seeing the faces in the temple is worth the trip. We went with a guide and I would recommend doing some sort of a guided tour. Seeing the architecture and the friezes in addition to the large faces made it a very special experience
Out of this world. We wanted to visit this place for long time. We were not disappointed. Best to do it in the AM for good photos.

One of the most interesting temples. We really liked Bayon, with all its faces. It was teeming with tourists though and there was even a traffic jam getting there. We did it after Angkor Wat, around 8:45am as we had been there for sunrise. Try and go at a non-peak time, as having people everywhere was really annoying and we didn't stay as long as we would have liked.

Originator of Face time ;). Disliked: too many Chinese tourists..I say Chinese because they were everywhere and took away the magic of the place...maybe Jan is not such a good Time to visit or it may be this way often...anyway, we liked the Bayon and I know it would have been good if not over run by tour groups.

Expect to be part of a crowd. Crawling with tourists, but you're one of them so can't really hold it against everyone else! The temple is amazing, along with the rest of Angkor Thom. Absolute must see when in Siem Reap!
For all templas at Angkor - Am amazed. Every temple is great and every temple is worth visiting. A definite place off my bucket list! From Angkor Wat to Bayon, the place just amazes you
Trick Pics with the Bayon Faces. I liked this temple better as it looked more interesting and we enjoyed taking trick pictures kissing the faces.
Cheerful. One of our favorites from the temples. Really interesting, as there are 200-something faces (of the same God, who happens to resemble the king who erected the temple) all around.

Astounding. This is the classic temple with the faces -- but try to get there early because the Horrible Hoards make this hard to photograph. Rumor is they may close the place as it is being overrun by tourists.

The Temple That Smiles at You - Bayon Temple. Temple ruins around Siem Reap abound but one that really caught my attention the most was Bayon Temple. It smiled at me....many times. This temple ruin has over 200 smiling faces. They are huge and everywhere you look. I felt surrounded by happy people the entire time we were there. Our guide, Rany, was very knowledgeable about these ruins. Bayon temple is fun to explore but you really need a good English speaking guide with a lot of knowledge to help you understand its history and significance. I took tons of pictures and my daughter and I had to try the picture trick of smiling profile in the distance, daughter's profile up close, and the resulting nose to nose picture. This was by far my favorite temple.

Astonishing. Amazing how a mixture of narcotics and self-grandeur could lead a king to install his face repeatedly and with an identical stone-hewn stoned countenance throughout this masterpiece of art.Breathtaking. You'll be sharing the experience with half of Shanghai at the same time but even that won't dull the edge.
Which Temple to ensure you see.. Temple overload is always a risk at Angkar Wat. We loved the Bayon which is different to the others and we would say you must see this one, whatever else you go for.
Amazing. This temple is one of the best. It can get really busy but is still worthwhile. An amazing experience and one of the most photogenic temples.

The giant faces of this Bayon temple are unbelievable.. The Khmer architecture and art to shape the four faces on 37 standing towers is probably the pinnacle of their building campaign. It takes a lot of time to cover the whole building and there are lots of steps. It can be very warm seeing the temples, take precautions when you visit the temples in the dry season.
Stunning faces. My favorite temple, or wat, in SIem Reap. The faces are stunning and forceful and my imagination ran wild imaging what it felt like for people to see these in the 1200's.
History behind Statues. This is the signature temple in all the temples in Ankor Wat. The carvings are vivid and we're amazed at how those stones were piled up to make such delicate masterpieces.
Amazing. Busy busy with lots of tourists. Your guide may choose here first to avoid other crowds. Need a guide to have some sense of history.

Spectacular. The scale and proportion is an architectural wonder. Make sure to visit early morning or late afternoon for best photo taking opportunities. And make sure to have a proper English speaking guide to appreciate the interesting facts of this temple

Fantastic Carvings. After visiting Angkor Wat & Ta Prohm, we finally arrived at Bayon Temple & for both my wife & I this was the most amazing & interesting of the archeological sites to visit. Fantastic carvings in quite a small area & nowhere near as crowded as the other two sites. Our hotel organised a Tour Guide for us, which I would highly recommend having, as it makes the visits a lot more informative.

invated by monkey style tourist. Don't get me wrong Angkhor Wat and surounded temples are a must to visit.But tourist are to free to do what they like to do.They are allowed to climb on every statue, sit in every window frame ect.It feels like beiing in a zoo with monkeys.They damage the place and within 100 years there is nothing to see any more for future generation.This world herritage side is unprotected against the invasion of monkey styled tourist.A real shame.

Amazing place! Not to be missed.. This is the most spectacular structure by far.The buildings are covered with breathtaking sculptures and the walls with intricate engravings that you can spend hours looking at them.We were very lucky as the day we visited it was not too crowded and not too hot, it was around lunch time, so we had plenty of space to see things and take pictures.Our local guide was extremely good with great knowledge and excellent English.We also felt that this was the best of all the temples we visited and we will be back to spend more time exploring.

What a treasure! . I fell in love with this place the first time I visited and even more so the second time around. I loved Bayon during sunset... Just majestic! I loved wading through the rocks and just spend a little time relaxing before heading to the terrace and Baphoun.

Amazing. What an amazing place. Everywhere you go the four faces of Buddha look down on you. There is quite a bit of uneven pathway so it is worth wearing sensible footwear but the temple is a must on a visit to Cambodia.

Great place. Had a good time on tours except for the whole industry in Cambodia is such a scam. Tour guides buy their jobs and this day our English tour guide barely spoke English. Ridiculous. Was ok with it until he insisted I stayed at a hotel and tried to put me out somewhere else at the end. By then I had kind of had it.

Majestic Bayon. This was one of our favourite Wat's in the park. The scale and proportion is and architectural wonder. We spent at least 2 hours here in a cool, quiet corner and people watched, sketched and took in the beauty. TIP - if you want great pictures wear brighter shades of clothing as it pops against the muted tones of the temple! Remember to pack clothing that covers your arms and legsI will most definitely visit this temple again!
A national treasure. Best to go to Angkor Wat and the other temples with a guide who can give you a historical overview. We took two days to see all the temples and we needed that much time.
Breathtaking!. You can't not see this in your lifetime. It is human history frozen in time. Best time to visit is early morning/late afternoon or during lunch hours to beat the tour hordes
How did they do that?. They built this when? They got all this stuff here how? Just incredible. Imagine what it must have been like.
Faces every where- Must see. This is a good temple and you can easily spend couple of hours if not more. We visited this on our 1st day after Angkore thom and liked it.

You will be amazed. We all know about Angkor Wat but nothing had prepared us for this beautiful temple which to my mind is the most beautiful with it's carvings of faces and it's state of preservation. My favourite.

Bayon is one to visit. There are so many temples around Siem Reap in Cambodia, but don't miss this one. It really is one of the best and very unusual with all the distinctive faces. We had no problems with crowds. We hired a guide for the day, which was very affordable by western standards. He knew exactly when to be at each site to avoid the crowds and got us here while almost everyone else had gone off for lunch. As we left, huge crowds were on the road in.My advice is to definitely visit Bayon while you are at the Angkor Wat complex.
Not just another….. Go early, by bicycle. You'll be glad you did! I found it very peaceful, and even thought provoking...

Great Temple. One of the best for photography, the faces, the walls, the arches. As January is peak tourist season for Siem Reap, it is hard to get a great shot without a tourist in it.Amazing craftsmanship. A must visit if visiting the temples.
serene. it's a good spot to sit and enjoy the view. being part of the ankor thom, it's a good stop to take pictures
Another Khmer temple. After a while all the temples seem to be the same. This is no different. Not a bad place to go, but after Ankhor Wat and Thom, this was not the best place to go.

Cool temple over Crowded. Its a fantastic temple one of the best sights of the temple complex however it is very touristy if you want to really experience these temples with some piece and quite head there at dawn and leave as the hordes of Angkor Wat sunrises begin to turn up.

In a sea of faces, truly majestic. This is one of the best of the temples. You can walk amongst the multitude of faces like the ancient monks did, and it is a terrific experience to do so. Save this best for last!
Best of the temples. This one has it all and perhaps easier to explore than some of the others. All the temple complexes are great but this one is quite unique.

Faces of ancient stone. This is why we come, of course - to see the ancient temples. The Bayon was built between 1175-1240 and while slowly crumbling, it is still magnificent ... and haunting. Every tower has huge stone faces representing Buddha (in the likeness of the king). Bas-relief carvings show the battles between the Champa kingdom and the Khmer; there are 'frozen' Apsara dancers on every other wall. Nearby are the Elephant and Leper King terraces. It is a photographer's delight. While others in our tour group had seen enough by the third visit, I could have stayed at the Angkor complex for a week! Do wear good walking or gym shoes - the steps and uneven surfaces are a challenge at times. A 3-day ticket will cost $40 - and while you may want to avoid the heat of the day, you can come back as often as you wish.

Best of the lot. Bayon is such a beautiful temple, Angkor Wat is spectacular but I think Bayon is even more scenic as there is just so much to see there, the faces are incredible and the history is amazing.

something new to visit. It was really interesting to be there. when you spot faces made of rocks everywhere in the place was a unique feeling. Not much activities to do other than taking foto with a group wearing the cambodian traditional costumes.
huge faces staring at you. the temple is awesome: hundreds of faces are looking at you from everywhere you turn. i suggest to go there late in the afternoon when the light is perfect for the pictures

magnificent sights, first class tourguide. An ideal way to start your Angkor adventure is to see the Bayon Temple first. Its many towers with smiling faces makes it one of the most unique and grand temples in Angkor. My mom and I were fortunate enough to have a very wise tour guide with us. I highly recommend you get a guide too because Siem Reap is huge and it's always better to be in the company of someone who knows where the important places are, and when best to go there. We were there in November 2013 where the place is at its peak, and so we really appreciated that Cheak Chuom (our guide) fixed our itinerary in a way that we were at the right places at the right time where the sun perfectly hit the magnificent towers of its temples. Here's a link to his blog where you'll find his contact details: www.angkorenglishtourguide.wordpress.com (email: chuomcheak@ymail.com) The trip was extraordinary, the services outstanding! I encourage everyone to go there at least once in their lifetime.

Breathtaking. Let the crowds swarm around Angkor Wat while you explore the immense Bayon. It was the first temple I visited so I have a soft spot for it but I think anyone would appreciate how special it is.

Under-rated!. No doubt that Angkor Wat is the national symbol of Cambodia but Bayon has it's own unique beauty. In fact, this is my personal favourite spot in Siem Reap. Do make sure that you visit this place when you are in Siem Reap.

My favorite temple in AW. I really love Bayon Temple the most of the popular temples in Angkor Wat. The many sides of the temples all with smiling faces is just a really lovely delight. You can spend more time there as there are fewer tourists than at Angkor Wat itself. There are quiet pockets amid all the tourist chaos at Bayon.

Impressive architecture. Walked/climbed the ruins, impress by the details still visible on the facades. There were many other visitors, which was to be expected but that didn't diminish the experience.

Many faces.... Although it takes several steps to reach the top and be with the smiling faces of their god,one can't help but be amazed of how each of these faces was curved and looked perfectly the same.

Temple with the faces!. This temple is a must go to if you are visiting the Angkor Archaeological Park. This is the temple with all the smiling faces. You can climb up to the top terrace and get a closer look at the faces. This temple is fantastic because after a while all the other temples start to look the same but this one stands out for sure!

Great Temple. Totally agree with the previous review ! Nothing else to add it sums up my experience perfectly, i spent longer here than any other temple i saw over a 2 day period great for photos and lots of shady places.

Nice views. The view from the top of the temple is pretty nice though it does take going some steep steps in order to get there.Once up you're in a different world. You can not see any of the other temples in the area but it helps realize how grand the whole construction was when it was not in ruin.

Best temple at Angkor. This is actually the best temple at Angkor. Yes, Angkor Wat is more 'in tact' but you kind of expect that to be amazing. This has no expectations so exceeds them. Definitely worth a visit.

My favorite temple! . After a day of temple-hopping they are each quite a blur, but I loved Bayon. First off, there isn't the tour group irritation factor you get at Ankor Wat. It's way more low-key and you're not being pushed out of the way constantly. That part of Ankor Wat really ruined it for me. Second, the face carvings are enormous and gorgeous. There are lots of them, and it's fun to peek around a new corner and find a new one. It's also a bit more worn down, which makes it feel like you're in a movie (hello Lara Croft), climbing around, exploring the unknown. Lastly, no begging children! Win.
Smiling Faces. very nice structure, seems a bit different from the other temples and the smiling faces just give you a nice feeling!

Go early in the morning to avoid the crowds. We really enjoyed our Bayon temple visit. The relief carvings and scenes were incredible and we were able to see a lot of the artwork up close- an opportunity you probably wouldn't get in another country as it would be protected from touching etc. Early in the morning seems to be a better time to visit as crowds are more minimal. We also rode an elephant around the temple ($15) which gave us a great vantage point for photos. If you are wanting it, it's a good idea to book the ride, as there are often big tour groups booked. The easiest way is to go to the booking table near the elephant stand and make a time with the staff.
Don't miss it. Bayon Temple (the whole area) is well worth visiting.Expect crowd. Don't miss Baphuon. Climbing up to the top for really rewarding, don't miss it.
Superb. It's an Angkor tour de force! The temple was absolutely breathtaking especially at sunset. One of my favorite temples for sure and the best place to have a photo shoot. Haha
Just amazing. Kids loved it. Go before they close it and just have designated walkway (much needed) as you can climb all over the place now.

Great temple, even better with a guide. Amazing temple, well worth a visit. Our guide Chuom Cheak (Jack) gave us a great overview of the history of this temple, an insight into the local customs and stories as well as explaining the conservation works. We went during lunch as it was less busy at this time, avoiding the crowds is key to enjoying Angkor.We got so much more out of our visit to Angkor thanks to our guide Jack. I recommend a guide for a visit to any temple. An added bonus was he knew the best photo spots at all the temples!http://angkorenglishtourguide.wordpress.com/

Brilliant!!. This is the most amazing temple out of all of them, according to me. The faces of the Buddha was huge and beautiful. It makes one gape is wonder as to how men in those times might have used such huge stones and carved them with minimal tools.Don't mind the smell of the bats though!!
Amazing!. Don't miss this one...wear good walking shoes! We thought we were done seeing sites but our guide book with great description of history of Bayon Temple kept us going.

Must see. The second temple in good condition. Please use a guide. We did learn a lot from our guide. He also took good pictures for us. It does get hot there. I was there in the afternoon. Amazing structure and makes you wonder how they built it?

A romantic trip to the past. One can see the temple and what is being done to conserve it. As you walk through the many nooks and crannies of Bayon, you should also be able to see the conservation work being done by a team of locals and Japanese. There is also an information center nearby, albeit seemingly abandoned, that helps explain the work being carried out to stabilize the temple.
Best to visit in the morning.. Explore every corner of the temple. Surely, you will be captivated with its amazing structure. Best to visit in the morning.

A must go!. Avoid lunch time, get there very early or late afternoon due to hot weather.
Just beautiful, can not leave Siem Reap without visiting Bayon temple.
Buy the temples package, USD 20 person/day. I found a bit pricey specially when I learnet who keeps the money but its still worth it.

Mesmerizing temple. Of all the temples I visited at the Angkor Wat complex, I ended visiting Bayon Temple twice. Take an elephant ride around the temple before your visit and just marvel in the wonderment of this temple. Not to be missed.

One of the must see temples. Probably one of my favorite temples there. Love all the faces and intricate art work. Also is generally less crowded if you leave the early morning rush of anchor wat a bit early.

Simply amazing ruin. The huge face will stare at you from centuries past and make you feel both scrutinized and welcome. Easy to get around in. Take your time, and the faces keep appearing wherever you look, one as awesome as the last.

Faces. This place is just amazing. One can spend hours looking at the carvings of Khmer common life in the gallery, looking at the Buddha faces, and climbing up and down the stairs to find another splendid view to take a picture of. And yes, even though the place is crowded, it's not that difficult to find good spots for taking pictures, given many levels, balconies, and steps of the temple. Don't believe tuk-tuk drivers that say two hours is enough for the whole Angkor Thom. We've spent 1.5 hours only in Bayon, and could've spent twice as much, if we didn't have so many other things to squeeze into the day.

There is no Angkor thom ... its Bayon. what make people confused is that they look for the temple "angkor thom" ....angkor thom is a group of temples.... in this group BAYON is the bestthe stone faces is a mixed of the King and Buddha.....Along with Angkor Wat, Bayon is the second best temple of Siem Reap
WOW. One of the nicest temple in the area....simply MAGIC! Staying there and looking at all those tower with the Buddha face gives you a kind of mystical feeling.
amazing all those faces. everything about all the temples was wort all the travel and early morning wake up call to get there on time and to appreciate these special world sites
Amazinng. Brilliant temples with extraordinary carvings -lots of tourists of course so ducking out of the way people taking pics - but didn't detract from the experience

Bayon Temple. This was one of the very first temples I visited and despite all the reading before arrival, I was totally unprepared and just blown away. You have to see it to believe it. One cannot but become a little absorbed and carried away while wondering around this site...

Brilliant temple with very large stone carved faces.. One of the better maintained temples, steep steps and very large stone carved faces. Most of the temples including this one need significant restoration and repairs to stop the destruction of these historical sites sadly Cambodia is not a wealthy country and all the temples need urgent repairs. The scale of these temples are just amazing, the number of skilled stone masons required must have been extraordinary and many unskilled people just to supply the stone and put in place must have been an amazing sight without any mechanical support. Fantastic carvings all over the walls, some temples have evidence of colour on the walls, it would be great if CGI could bring these places back to life! they must have been an awesome sight to those approaching and those who lived
Stone Faces. This temple was different from the others we visited because of the many carved heads. The wall carvings tell the amazing story of life in the 9th century and are very well preserved

Must see!. My husband and I loved this temple! The faces were incredible. Hire a tour guide (www.angkordriverguide.com) to inform you of all the history. It gets really busy so I recommend going early.
The best of all. The Bayon Temple for us was the best of all. Grabs your tickets and head for here, as others go straight to Angkor Wat.

Favourite Temple. All the temples have something a little different from each other but this one has beautiful faces on the heads of the statues .They are all different and some are smiling and unique .It is so good to see the restorations going on ,if not this place would be lost to the elements .The tree roots have already caused considerable damage but alot of work is going on now to preserve this beautiful man made wonder of the world

Our favourite of the temples. Another stunning temple - and our favourite, because of the hundreds of carved faces. Amazing to think how it was all constructed all those years ago. Just wonderful to wander amongst them all and look out for the elephants sauntering past with paying customers aboard. Brilliant.

one of my favorite temples. Second trip to Siem Reap & the Angkor temples. There is something about the many faces of Buddha, apparently created in the likeness of King Jayavarman VII, that is really special. On my first trip I paid for the elephant ride around the temple and parts of Angkor Thom, I recommend it at least once (the elephants don't seem to be abused like the ones in Thailand). This trip we saw wild monkeys mingling with the visitors. It's tempting to walk right into the middle of the temple and focus on the faces, but take the time to walk around the outer gallery. The bas-reliefs depict events of Jayavarman VII's rule, and are beautifully done.
Beautiful and stunning. Bayon is not to be missed! The best temple on our trip. Unbelievable how this mountain was constructed in ancient times.

Real-life Minecraft. Though not as refined as Banteay Srei or as majestic as the Angkor Wat, the Bayon Temple is easily the most memorable with Jayavarman VII's face incorporated in every tower. From afar, it looks like something out of Minecraft, something the kids would find impressive. There are plenty of photo opportunities in this area, so make sure you have enough space in your memory card.Bayon is a short walk from the back of Baphuon Temple.
Great temple ribs amongst a whole lot of other temples.. Loved the enormity of this temple. The Buddha faces were amazing as were the rest of the ruins. A great place to visit despite the crowds.

A good place to start visiting. I've been here 2 times and any time I've enjoyed visiting this place.
54 towers and a lot of stairs to go up and down around the towers! very suggestive and amazing

Simply Awesome. This is the most awesome temple in the Angkor Temple Complex. The 216 gigantic Buddha faces, each made out of about sixteen carved blocks of stone, are placed in in 54 clusters of four each to make a marvelous viewing experience. How they managed, some 800 years ago, to carve these massive stones and then accurately place them to form each face is a tribute to the skill and methods of the builders. The outer wall features bas reliefs detailing wars the Khmers fought in the past as well as everyday life of the royals and ordinary and people.Our guide Sayon made the trip memorable with his explanations.The steps are high or steep or both. Senior citizens need to take care.This magnificent temple is worth another visit.
beautiful temple. a beautiful temple with hundred of budda faces looking down on you, very different from Ankor Wat, but well worth it

Brilliant. The temple is maybe 4 kms north of Ankhor Wat. It has loads of massive stone faces on the towers. Built in the 12th Century, it is a must see along with Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm, all Unesco sites. You ticket is good for all sites. You need to hire a tuk tuk or a bicycle to get to see them all. You can buy a ticket which is good for all sites the day before your visit and it is valid from 5pm the day before the ticket is issued for, so you can go watch the sunset and get your bearings the evening before.

Overgrown and under construction. This is an historical site the traveler can learn to appreciate the ongoing work to preserve and prepare for the public to visit. Trees are growing out of on over the temple walls..sections are roped off because of the tenuous condition of the structure. There are many tourists and all are there to see a very small portion of the site, so it is crowded.

My favorite of Angkor temples. Truly stunning with all the carved faces. Give yourself time to explore - take a walk around and beyond. Find nice photo spots, and strike a conversation with guards and police folks (whether real or fake ones).

amazing. the temple is in a great position, and busy - go early to see it before the hoardes. OR, late in the day. We went twice as it was so spectacular. Don't pay for the elephant rides (cruel) and don't feed the monkeys (and be careful of the touts). Wear sturdy shoes - the stones are rough and uneven.

Bird sanctuary tour. Amazing experience! One of the best trips we've done! We saw floating villages, went on the top of the tree platform and observed the rare birds and then were smelling local herbs in a floating garden. Oh, ya, and food served for lunch was absolutely amazing! These guys are working for a great cause! The experience TOTALLY worth the price!

Amazing experience!. Simply amazing to visit this site with all the giant faces carved in stone. This was one of the highlights of our visit to Siem Reap. Photos are better when the sun is a little lower, rather than bright morning. This is a must see!
Enjoyable. Yes, there are lots of tourist, but having a guide really did help knowing when to look at what temples/places when. All the temples etc are wonderful to look at. You take so many photos.

Mind Blowing. Highly recommended , when I visited there wasn't too many people around so it was more pleasant to just take your time and actually enjoy the full details of this wonderful temple, try and see it early to beat the crowds.

Fascinating Place. A must see. The central temple area is a fun place to go. Lots of faces carved into the rocks. Some of them huge. Ancient site that has many photo opportunities. Take water. Wear a hat. Wear sunscreen. Sturdy shoes are important, especially if you are older. Expect lots of people. Having a local guide adds a lot to the experience, as they have lots of information to impart.
Beautiful but much too crowded. Only problem was the number of tourists. would definitely NOT recommend going during the Christmas period.

my favorite temple. This was the favorite as the faces are captivating and make for fantastic photos (a bonus). We were there at the end of the afternoon (pre-sunset) and it was lovely. Apparently its even more crowded in the morning.
One of our favourites. The Buddha faces are simply beautiful. Even though it was very crowded we managed to find lonely spots. Just step a few meters away from the crowd ;)
Lots of heads. This temple isn't too big but quite a world away from its neighbours, it features a very different style and when we went had locals dressed up in the Khmer outfits posing for photos.

Most interesting of them all. This was the most impressive temple of them all. Not as vast as the Angkor wat but very different and unique. If you can make it early morning the crowds are less. The faces are quite haunting. It's definitely a must see.
great place. its one of the best temples in the place, beside angkor, so i recomend it to you to go!!!!! and the shooting range its nice too... but expensive
Beats the other ruins hands down!. Best place to let your camera click and watch the stone faces at different times of the day! If you are pressed for time, make this your highest priority stop.
Stunning. A must visit destination. One of our favourites of the many temples we visited. There are a lot of people here but you need to accept that and just soak up the history.
My favorite at Angkor. Bayon symbolizes all of the best of J7's remarkable reign. All of the smiling faces make the visitor instantly feel at peace.

A must in Siem Reap. I have seen so many temples in some places, but none has unique shape as I saw in Bayon Temple, i.e. the smiling faces on the top of the temples. This is a msut for those who visit Siem Reap and Angkor Wat complex.

Bucket list experience. This is the best temple in Siem Reap. It's also the most crowded. We arrived around 10 am and it was packed. That only slightly diminished the awe aspect of this amazing temple. You can climb and crawl around every nook and crevice of the Bayon temple. There are many little passages and archways and so many faces formed into the stone walls that you could spend all day looking and photographing every one of them. Unfortunately, my wife is too impatient for that and we spent a good 90 minutes there soaking up the ambience before heading off to the next one.
This is my favorite site at Angkor. Bayon is my favorite site at Angkor. Am returning this year to explore explore other sites on the Angkor campus but Bayon will be revisited!
Amazing. The smiling faces on the about fifty tall towers are truly amazing. Why are they smiling, what do they know what we don't? Restoration by German Government and a university in Cologne.

A Sacred Place- Home of the Gods. The Bayon is unique in all the world, nothing can match its complexity and the art that surrounds it. The Face Tower protect the holy space.The only problem is noisy and disrespectful visitors. Go early in the morning 7am or a noon when the tourist who come to check the box are not there.
it is a must-see place to visit during your trip to Siem Reap. In ancient Ankgor, Bayon is easily the pick of the lot with it's massively impressive stone faces on its numerous towers.
The best temple. Complete with monkeys at the gate and a snake on the path this was just brilliant. The kids enjoyed this one the most.
Greaat view. You'll be amazed with the super amazing view. How can they built such amazing figures with rock at that time?! Goosebumppps!!

A must see in the Angkor temple area.... This was the first temple we went to in Seam Reap, and it was fantastic to begin with smiling buddhas! It's fun to climb up and take great pictures. I will never forget it.
Bayon Temple. Amazing cravings of faces look at you from every angle...I felt a real feeling of happiness here with all the smiles staring down at me
Most interesting temple!. Very interesting temple with lots of history! Must go to the top to get the full experience. It was pretty warm while we were there so bring water!

Happy Faces in the Stone, Lots of People. This temple was great, with 50 some heads starring at you from the tops of towers. There were a ton of people around this temple, making it difficult to get the perfect shot. I recommend instead of doing sunrise at Angkor Wat heading over here to get pictures with out people in them. The temple is maintained really well. I wish they had more signs on the history of it, though you can buy guide books everywhere. I find the guide books to be really dry. The carvings are great and really detailed.

Bayon is the best next to Angkor Wat. Wow, it is beautiful.. you should see it to believe it! The faces cut out are magnificent, wonder how the craftsmen made it so many years (centuries) ago with very little technology & facilities. Please take a good guide & book.

Second only to Angkor Wat. This is a fascinating temple with the mystical heads second only to Angkor Wat. The best time of the day to visit is straight after sunrise, especially when the tour buses go back to town and there is no many people around. There are some really good photo opportunities and chance to have elephant ride.

Excellent temple to visit. Amazing statues and carvings which give tourists an understanding of the history of Cambodia. Great pictures to take with statues in the background and best to go in the early morning just after watching sunrise in Angkor Wat as it has less tourists and it is easier to take nice pictures with no crowds in the picture.

Just Amazing. Get there early because it gets hot. But just incredible. Totally worth the time. I wouldn't say it is vigorous, and I am going to assume that if you visiting Cambodia, you are prepared for the heat and the walking.
Stunning details. Go early - lovely small temple to start with.....and amazing details on the carvings....try to bat the bus loads who come along after 10am....

Favourite. This was my favourite the relief work was a highlight for me after being taught about then and their significance by my archaeology lecturers. They are significant because they depict 'the everyday': scenes of women and children following the soldiers off to war, Chinese envoys visiting the city and people preparing a feast. Such a gorgeous temple.

Strange but Compelling. Of all the Angkor temples this is certainly the strangest with its 216 smiling but unnerving faces staring down or across at you from every angle. Great to just wander around: see how many faces you can get in one picture. Walk round the outside when there is a lot of standing water and there are great reflections.

Overwhelming. After Angkor Wat this was our next temple. The beginning of lots and lots of steps. Plan ahead and do a fitness course. I loved it, some didn't. It was also the beginning of the incense sticks and the donations. You have to see to believe.

One of the best temples.. It is a curious temple with big smiling faces located on quite big ground to demand a significant amount of time to explore.To avoid the massive crowds that visit it, go really early in the day. I went there right after the sunrise at Angkor Wat and got to enjoy the place for myself for enough time (10-15min) to get good photos of the upper level in all its glory.If I were to go back, I would go even earlier (you won't see the sunrise itself from there, but aim to be there right at the moment there is some light). Head to the upper level first and when people start to gather, find a corner to have a small breakfast overlooking the grounds. Then take time to explore the lower levels.Amazing sight and should not be missed.

Unlike most buildings you'll ever seen. Go early.. Like many people, I knew about "that temple with the faces" and it delivers.If you like photography or hate crowds, go early in the morning around 7 or in the afternoon around 4:30. It will look fantastic with the soft light and you will be able to stroll around with very few people. It really adds to the atmosphere if you go early or late, like all Angkor temples.Once I was there, I spent the first hour staring at the towers high up from one of the internal buildings commonly called "libraries". Great shots with a long lens.It's not only about the faces: the entire perimeter is covered in carvings. Take your time to look at them from up close and discover miniatures of daily life 800 years ago.
Stunning. Absolute stunning temple in the Angkor Thom complex. Stunning giant statues of Buddas. The smiling Buddas seem to welcome you to the temple.

More to see than we expected. We were a bit overwhelmed by the extent of what we thought was "Angkor Wat", the potential number of sites to see was staggering. We only had two days in Siem Reap and fortunately had a guide that was flexible and knew his way around the sites, many times taking us to less travelled aspects so that we could great photos.
.. It was an amazing place with a special kind of energy. After three days of visiting temples, I think this was my favorite

Absolutely one of the best temples. The relics, the faces, atmosphere, everything are perfect. If you joined the sunrise tour in Angkor Wat, get here as soon as you're done with your sunrise shot. It's amazing in here when there's less people around.
The best one I like in angkor. A very nice place, need to prepare much time for that. Better go there earlier as most of the people go around 9 am.
The best!!!. For me was the highlight of my temples visit, what a great place and full of magic! Though high season was pretty uncrowded when all the other major ones were full of chinese tourists...

Probably the best hide and seek in the world….. Had two young boys in tow (4 & 5) so temple viewing isn't top priority for them. We'd visited Ankor Wat the day before and they had lasted about two hours in the heat. Bayon was a different experience - they loved playing hide and seek around the ruins - a lot of fun. Absolutely stunning place to visit. We went relatively early, around 7.30/8am which was worth it as managed to avoid the worst of the crowds and tour bus loads.

Very Busy but Totally Worth It. This site was busy but with good reason; this place is amazing. It was such a beautiful temple with many faces and exquisite and mesmerising carvings. From afar is is intriguing to look at as it looks so different to the other temples. We we able to climb quite high and explore a lot of the towers and enjoyed the sights surrounding it. If you are in the Angkor region, make this one of the top ones to see on your list.

Magical temple. Great temple to wander around, relax and listen to the jungle noises. Beautiful how the faces of Buddha are molded into the rocks. Go early in the morning or late before sunset to not have to walk in the crowds

Angkor Thom A Gem. A must stop in Siem Reap and Angkor Wat. The reliefs are incredible and the crowds, even in high season in January, were manageable. I worried about taking photographs free from throngs of tourists, but found it possible to do so. Be sure to recommend that your tour guide allow you to visit during lunch, as you will find it much easier to navigate the temple complex when everyone else is having lunch.
Wow - don't miss. Do not miss this one, for me this was my favourite temple in the Angkor Thom area.Doesn't have the size of Angkor Wat but it's so unique!
Just breath-taking!. The setting of the nature wonders just took my breath away! Never knew such places exist on earth, truly a world's wonder!
I loved them all but this was my favorite. The 54 Buddah heads were great, it was memorable temple to visit. There was some climbing of steps but it was not too difficult. Great photo oppurtunity!

The Face Temple...Go Early or After 3:30 and you'll have it to yourself!. We loved this temple. The faces are magical!! We went around 4pm and almost had it to ourselves as everyone was heading to the crazy sunset spots! Got some great photos!

Magnificent!. Went only to Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm and Bayon.Of the three, all of us in the family agreed that the Bayon is the best.It may not be the biggest, but it is the most intriguing and enjoyable to visit.
Gorgeous. This was my first temple and it was a great way to start. At first it looks like a pile of rock and then you start to see all of the faces - lovely

Worth a Visit. The Angkor Thom is a Khmer complex with several temples, towers, pyramid-like structures, and important historical monuments inside. The most visited among them is the Bayon Temple (Prasat Bayon) which is situated at the center of the complex.Bayon features four-faced crowns and towers, which, according to historians, resembles a lot with King Jayavarman VII
Mind blowing Place. One of the most amazing temples that I have ever seen. Truly amazing and highly recommended for visiting!

My fave temple!. Bayon was my favorite temple by far!
We took an elephant ride around the temple, then toured the site. It was busy, but AMAZING!

Face to Face with history. This was the highlight of our time in Cambodia. We visited Angkor Wat earlier in the day which was stunning but Bayon was even more impressive. The weather was perfect for some stunning pictures - the faces are quite errie from some angles. When built the city must haver been absolutely incredible. The whole site is very accessible but there are lots of steps to climb and it can be very hot, as it was when we went. The best view of the overall site it from the least accessible side but it is worth walking all the way round to pick out the best view. There were a fair few people there but they weren't a big problem. If you ever get the chance to visit, even for a short while, do not miss this wonderf0ul site (sight!).
Favorite Temple. I really loved this temple with the faces carved into the stone. It was my favorite of all the temples in the area!
amazing.. The buddha faces on all the towers, all four sides were amazing. as were the bas motifs along all the outer walls, telling a full story. One of the best temples in Angkor Thom

See the 216 faces. A tourist had recently fallen and been killed so part of the area was closed for the time being. As you approach the river runs through the jungle- the waters come from the mountains, the bridge is 10th century and on your way to the entrance you will find a small temple to the right and another to your left.The Victory Gate is fabulous- we got out of our vehicle and our guide took us up the hillside so that we could get a perfect profile of the faces on the gate. You even see bits of crumbling original ancient pottery in the grass.Within you see 54 columns which represent the 54 provinces of the Khmer Empire which spanned all the way from what is today called Thailand and all the way across to the shoreline of what is today called Vietnam- yes THAT huge- the largest in SE Asia. Only the Royal family, the high officials and their servants lived in this complex. Each of the 54 towers has four heads of the Buddha- facing the cardinal points. You can wander through the complex and view more of the heads which are astonishing. The South Gate showed reconstructed heads being put onto the ruins which I thought was a great idea and I hope that tourism helps to pay for this reconstruction. At this temple you see scenes of everyday life depicted in the sculptures- which is unusual as most of the temples show the story of the Ramayana- here you can see people eating finger food, a woman giving birth,someone drinking palm alcohol, the wars with the Chams- the moslims who tried to invade in the 12th century etc. The whole place is fascinating and a lovely reflection of how life was for some people at that time...fabulous. I agree with comments re tourists- there are always hoards- but we are all tourists and I guess we at least can be helping with the economy of Cambodia by visiting the area- despite all the crowds we had a good time- we were just one couple with our guide and he took us here for about 10.30am, we didn't see that many folk really- its just when you want to take a photo I guess and someone's head inevitably pops up or a shoulder etc...that's life !
Do NOT miss this. Absolutely stunning, picturesque and most interesting of all temples at Angkor. Do NOT miss this and dont forget to get a picture "kissing" one of them ;)
200+ faces!. Must visit! Crowded but worth it. Be sure to go inside and get a blessing. Liked walking around. For pictures, be sure you get right angles with sunlight --- gorgeous,
Amazing even when crowded. You'll share your visit with a LOT of other tourists but this temple is stunning and the faces are captivating. Well worth visiting.

Didnt have enough time to do it justice. We did this temple at the end of our day just before sunset and so were rushing to make it to the next temple for the sunset photos and to be honest we were all tired by then. The grandeur of it was amazing and we really wanted to see more of it but were too tired to climb any more stairs. Worth doing early so you have time, and less heat, to do it justice.

You just need to see it in person. Wow! Hard to describe how amazing it is, but you will not be disappointed when you get there. It was not too distant from the other great sites at Angkor Wat, and the crowds did not overwhelm you. BUT, the sheer beauty and craftsmanship of carvings that are ancient will do that for you.

Multiple headed wonder. This is a stunning temple with great carvings at every turn. The 4 headed sculptures are amazing to see, the smiles are different and the sheer size of them awe inspiring. BUT there are hundreds of tourists at every turn and so getting the best photo shots without the crowds is difficult. This is a large complex with many steps so comfortable walking shoes should be worn.
Awesome. Another great place to visit in Cambodia.The only downside to visiting at this time of year is that it was packed with tourists

Atmospheric marvel. It is impossible to miss visiting the trio of Angkor Wat's temples. The number of sculpted faces is dizzying. Best seen when there are few tourists but I have not quite figured out when that might be!

Unique Temple with many faces. One of the more memorable temples I visited. The temple has been restored to relatively good condition. And the unique structure means that it is one temple you will remember. Take your time to enjoy this temple, as it's structure is very unique from the rest
Spectacular. The Bayon temple and nearby Elephant terrace are spectacular. There is a lot of climbing and walking so be sure to wear good shoes.

My favorite temple in Siem Reap. What's so amazing about this temple is not only the most famous faces, but also the bas-reliefs - which most of the visitors neglect but is truly BREATHTAKING!!! I even prefer the bas-reliefs here to Angkor Wat. Because there are many interesting scenes related to Cambodian people's daily lives - like hunting, fishing, cutting pineapples, grabbing coconuts, giving birth… so vivid! Not only the eternal theme of fightings between the gods and devils...

Wonderful Experience though crowded.. One of the places I have always wanted to visit, it was a dream come true. Most serious detractors were the large number of fellow tourists being hearded through by tour groups yelling to their groups in a variety of languages and he rude local staff. At times I felt as if I were going to be trampled and getting a quiet moment for good photos was a challenge.
Best of the lot. 5 days and 20+ temples but this is the best? Can also get away from the crowds who follow 1 route. Also don't miss banteay kdei or beng mealea
