My favorite temple in Siem Reap region. This temple, right in the middle of Angkor Thom is a great photo spot, the smiling Buddhas are looking at you all the time and temple has been preserved quite well, unmissable.
Don't miss this one.. Along with Angkor Wat and Beng Melea, Bayon is a highlight of a trip to Cambodia. Very accessible and has none of the 'disneyland' characteristics of many tourist sites.

The best of them all!. The serenity of all the faces of the Lokesvara was a monumental experience for me, they overshadowed all the other interesting things to see in the Bayon, but it is still worth the time seeing it all. I would go back immediately if I could, and this time I would stay at the bayon as long as possible!
Highly recommendable!!!!!!

Definitely my favourite. Angkor Wat is a massive complex and in the heat it can get tiresome and testing. We arrived early at the complex to see sunrise over Angkor Wat and then spent the day going through the temples - hire a tuk-tuk driver for $15 a day it's really worth it! The Bayon Temple was my favourite, the place was stunning and the architecture was incredible. do not miss this one!
Incredible place. Stunning temple, very atmospheric and haunting. We would love to visit again but were luck with the relatively cool weather that twice might be to tempt fate. Very photogenic.

Great temple to wander about in. If you get there when there isn't too many other tourist there is plenty to explore. From the library of house of fire to the carvings on the stone depicting the daily life of the Khmer. There's many levels and great photo spots so make sure you have enough battery life. We explored Bayon slowly and steadily and really enjoyed climbing the stairways. This was the first temple we stopped of at and with the help of the guide we got to see the carvings.

Very unique presence. The place is not like the usual temples that you will find around Asia. The whole place is very popular for the eerie and unusual surroundings. The temple gets its popularity and charm from the jungle that is currently dominating the entire structure. The sheer sizes of the roots that cling on the walls of these temples are amazing. I visited the temple with couple of my friends and we were really amazed by the entire complex with so much to see and experience. The major attraction of the place is the smiling faces of the Buddha which as per my guide was part of a very majestic palace once and what is left of the ruins, The smiling faces takes the most appreciation. As with many other places in Cambodia, this place is also not without the huge crowds and the vendors and self acclaimed tour guides. Though in places like these a tour guide ensures that you get to see and experience everything that is to the place. Bayon temple remains my favorite in Siem reap

Classic photo opportunity. Classic face structures make this a must do - you can get some of the very best pictures here. Be aware it now gets very busy - so early is best - sunset (5pm-ish) gets you a red aura - well worth the effort. In addition the complexity makes for some divine photo compositions.. Stunning - Enjoy!
One of the great architectural miracles.. We came here for this and it was simply brilliant, crowded but superb. The lakes were superb and the complex huge, much bigger than expected.
Get there early. Its probably the highlight of any visit to the Angkor Wat complex. Today it was getting fairly crowded at 9am. Its high season. Still an amazing iconic experience
Amazing!. Loved this temple and the many faces! UNESCO is there doing renovation work right. Very cool to see it up close and personal

One of the first temples we went to. Lots of steps, but worth it. We then walked through the Angkor Thom area ending at the elephant terrace, not crowded, and the walk goes through forest paths, so shady, give yourself at least half a day day
Amazing!. Beautiful temple, a definite must see!! We visited mid morning in November was not too busy. Would recommend a guide for the visit.

Iconic Angkor Smiles - come early/late to avoid crowds. A very popular temple that features the iconic angkor smiles. Not so large, but very photogenic... we lingered for a solid hour taking photos. We visited twice, in the morning and late afternoon, and would recommend the latter both in terms of crowds and lighting. To avoid crowds, visit before 8 or after 330.
better than Angkor Wat. I only had heard about Angkor Wat but after seeing 15+ temples here, I can easily say Bayon is my favorite hands-down. Don't miss it under any circumstances.
Bayon Temple. This is a very interesting temple. This temple has faces carved into the stone and we were able to go up to that level to see these faces up close.
not far from angkor wat. just 2km from angkor wat. not so big, but a lot of the tower was ruined. When i am visiting Bayon temple, construction work still in progress to preserve the temple.

Great temple but watch out for crowds. This is now one of the most popular temples in the Angkor complex but the crowds get worse each year. Follow the track away into the forest for a bit of respite from the heat and noise but watch out for young lads scamming for money. They will tell you that it is for a school. It isn't. Notify the tourist police if you get hassled.
Worth the visit. magnificent temple, need to take time to immerse within the compound. Need a guide to walk through the temple.
wow. We loved exploring this temple late in the afternoon , we were almost alone and felt an amazing energy.
Lovely...... Put this on your top 5 in Siem Reap. Just to the North of Angor Thom. Huge stone faces that keep watch. So impressive!

After Angkor, see Bayon. You may think you will see/watch more of same ruins, but Bayon actually worth a visit.
Trees among the walls are amazing!

Temple of a Thousand Faces. We thoroughly enjoyed exploring this temple with its many Buddah faces. Our guide was able to point out the Hindu influences which predated the conversion of the temple and to find the places where pictures can be taken of the multiple visages. A large, but more manageable temple to explore than Angkor Wat with interesting bas relief carvings on the lower level.
Big stunning faces. I like the smiling faces and the reflection of the temple at the front door. it is one of the temples where the recovery is done pretty well.
Buddhas everywhere!. Excellent temple, incredible stone carvings depicting everyday life .absolutely amazing. Well worth a visit

Magic temple. Enjoyed it alone during sunrise. Bayon was on the top of our list of temples to visit in Angkor, so we decided to go there at 5:30am for the sunrise.As you cannot see the sun rising, this is not a popular place at this hour. As a result, we were the only one: arrived when it was still dark with loud sounds of jungle. And waited for the sun to rise and to slightly, step by step, enlighten the tens of carved faces on Bayon towers. Amazing and moving sights and visit.We then enjoyed the temple, almost alone for 2 hours, until 7:30am. Breathtaking

Awesome. This temple is amazing, but you definitely need a guide for the whole complex so you can understand the history. Be prepared to walk,explore and absorb the history. A must see when in Siem Reap....it's awesome!

wow!. If you enjoy adventure with history then you will not be disappointed, Bayon Temple is amazing...have your camera at the ready, so many photo opportunites, minimum time required two hours, a guide is a must unless you have a travel guide (book) look out for the roots growing (above ground)
Beautiful Buddha faces. My favorite today. 54 pillars with 4 smiling Buddhas on each pillar. Amazing is what I can say. Nothing to unlike
A part of the tour for Angkor Vat. First a bit of reading so you know a little of what you, advisable. Then go there and be amazed. Everybody knows the "Buddha" faces looking tree ways.
Very impressive. I think this was the best temple of all temples we visited. We took a tour with Angkor Shuttle Tour group and it was great.
angkor wat ruins. As beautiful as the main temple. But amazing how this survived time for us to experience. All those trees growing on the ruins. ASmazing
Siem Reapdec2013. Amazing locale and very well looked after. The access is well appointed and some wooden stair climbing is needed but all the same pleasurable.

The Best temple experience. The most picturesque and the least crowds allowing more time to savour the site. The hawkers at each of the gates are a bit overwhelming but remember the goods they are selling are hand made and this is usually the only income these people have. The most you will pay is a couple of USD.
Must see. we visited this temple in Angkor Thom twice during our visit to Cambodia, a must see if you're visiting siem reap
Amazing. the whole temple complex is truly amazing, but you definitely need a guide to explain about each temple as you go.

Totally awesome! Just need heaps of walking but everything else is perfect!!. Great great experience! Angkor wat is such a must see wonder in this world!! I love it! But dislike the little long walk due to my laziness:P
better than Angkor watt. Fantastic trip with a good tuk tuk driver...you can't go wrong amazing photo opportunity...just keep going round the different temples.

Amazing experience. Bayon is amazing and fabulous! It may have some tourists, but they don't get in the way of a good picture. This unique temple has every buddha looking at you! Its almost run-down state makes it look extraordinary and more interesting to see than any other temple. it has food around the corner and more temples to enjoy if that one wasn't enough. It has towers to climb and lean out of and so much history. Great for a day out and follow it with an elephant ride!
Beautiful!. Bayon temple is amazing! A temple of faces... one has to appreciate the details of this temple once there.
Magical Temple. its huge stone face carvings – 216 in total will make you feel amazed. After Angkor Wat, this is a must place to visit.
My favorite temple. The faces at Bayon Temple are fabulous and the bas reliefs, especially of daily life give you a wonderful view into life so long ago.

Trees like you've never seen before!. The trees amongst the ruins were extremely interesting! It's hard to believe how the roots could have grown so much through the ruins without TOTALLY uprooting everything.

Wonderful- Mind Boggling. This is the site for "Lara Croft - Tomb Raider". The trashy movie does absolutely no justice to this extraordinary monument. It is unique, even in Siem Reap. The temple consists of a number of very large heads of gods of the Hindu Pantheon. All intertwined with massive trees, which have become part of the architecture - DO NOT MISS IT - and take a good guide along - mine was lousy
See as many temples as you can. Another important temple to be visited. History, engravings, relief work, construction feats and the combination of Hinduism and Buddhism.
Faces. Bayon Temple is a temple of faces and is unlike the other temples of Angor. The carvings are intricate and amazing to see. I preferred this temple to Angor Wat.

Iconic Ankor Wat Temple. I visited this Temple Ruin at 4:30 until 6 pm closing. The late hour made for an unforgettable experience as I watched the faces on the ruin transform under the fading evening light. An additional benefit of a sunset visit is that this temple is not a common sunset destination, so crowds were at a minimum and I was able to wander the ruins with carved Khmer faces as my only company…..

The best `small temple`. The place is amazing! This temple is in excellent condition, you can visit several levels, cravings, etc. The view is astonishing. The indise is really exciting, packed with statues and cravings. Make sure you don`t miss this one!

Great temples, and interesting relief - shouldn't miss this. Though this is not the Angkor Wat but the relief is actually telling your more history of Angkorean Civilization than any other temples. The conflict between Cham, Siemese, Cambodian or even Chinese have been told through the relief at this temple. The temple reflects the devout of the king to Buddhism.

Amazing must see!. Beautiful temples, simple stunning. You can get an elephant ride from south gate to Bayon, and around. The Bayon temples itself and easy to walk round and you can get quite close to the faces for excellent photos. Simply breathtaking to see.

Bayon temple.. The stone faces on the towers are imposing and in good shape.This temple was built in the late 12th or early 13th century by the Mahayana Buddhist King Jayavarman V11. It was the official State temple.Tourists can explore the interiors of this temple and is on ground level with no stairs climbing involved.This temple is situated in the Angkor Thom vicinity of the Angkor Wat archaeological park.There is quite a lot of physical walking involved in seeing the ruins, tiresome.
Buddha faces. Its quite an experience to have all the Buddha faces looking at you. Its not as well kept as before. Nevertheless a must visit

Very Large Temple. This temple was the first we visited in Angkor Thom complex. It was very impressive with all the faces incorporated in the design. There were some impressive views from the upper part of the interior that are not to be missed. The stairs are rather steep but with good handrails.

have to see when in angkor. When in angkor than you have to visit the Bayon Temple also. Located near angkor wat you can plan a trip to this site also. also great architecture and carvings..... you have to see it when in angkor. Be sure to have a "brain overload" after some time and be sure other tourists are with you. but thats the price you pay when you are a tourist visiting a tourist site, right :-)!Therefore check it out by yourselve!!!!!

Magical reflection off the water. If you want to capture the moment where the Angkor temples reflect off the water below, escape the crowds, come face to face with the Angkor world (literally) then head to Bayon. The complex has excellent symmetry and due to its position can be well photographed at any time as you can head to the favourable side for appropriate light. Much less crowded than Angkor wat and Ta Phrom and arguably more beautiful than the former. Magical place

Must Visit in Siem Reap. Amazing carvings and beautiful temple grounds make it one of the must visit temples when you are in Siem Reap. Best ways to get there include renting a bicycle, or a full/half day car booking which costs around USD25. Entrace is included in the Angkor Heritage Pass - USD20 for one day and USD40 for up to 3days. I recommend the 3day pass as it is not possible to visit all in a single day. Hire a guide if you must for more elaborate understanding of the temples but I went temple hopping alone. Take a book for quiet time alone, bring along a trusty camera to wait for the best sunlight for pictures. Bayon, featuring stone faces of the four-face Buddha and other inscriptions, is largely different from other temples. Take care while climbing the steep steps. Dress code recommended for temple visit include sleeved tops, knee length pants at least and comfy shoes.
Must visit. I like every thing , try to be there early morning. The temple and surrounding is amazing. Only thing you need to be there early to avoid rush

Must see. Love the serene faces.. Went with a group and a guide. This is a must see when in Cambodia or Siem Reap. All the stone faces have such serene expression that you just feel peaceful even surrounded by tourists and the heat. Do not miss this one.
don'tmiss it!. one of the best places to visit very near from ankor watreally diferent.feel the place, feel the happiness from the peoplecabodians are so sweet and friendly!
Beautiful place to relax. The grounds for the temple complex is extensive, this is one of the temples, not in as good a shape as others but great to see and walk about.
Beautiful. Another beautiful temple. do yourself a favor a hire a guide for the day. You will get around quicker and have a greater understanding of the area.
Enigmatic smiles, serene atmosphere. This is my favorite place. The enigmatic smiles of the gigantic statues in a serene atmosphere is a wonderful experience.

Outstanding. This has to be one of the best temples in the area. The Buddha faces are amazing. There are so many. Each one is slightly different and the expressions are wonderful. The temple is in excellent condition for something so old. Would recommend this one as a must visit.

Face temple. Whilst you are in Siem Reap you will see many paintings, t-shirts, artefacts baring a smiling face. This is the face that is carved in stone on all 4 sides of the 49 towers of the Bayon temple which falls on the smaller circuit. Whilst the temple isn't as grand as Angkor Wat, nor as decrepit as Ta Prohm, it should surely be assigned some time on your tour. Do try to capture a picture of your/companion's nose aligned with the nose of one of the carvings. This is easily done on the higher floors of the temple.
Many, Many Faces Temple!. Whether you have a day or a week, you must go to Bayon on your temple tour. It is famous for the faces carved everywhere into the rock. GO!
Good renovation. The Temple was very impressive an Nice to Look at. We watsched a Mariage ceremonie. Very impressiv indeed.

Unique. Visiting Angkor Wat and surrounding temples might be too tiring (considering the ampunt of walking and climbing you'll have to do), but the diversity of the temples makes it worth your while. Face to face with Bayon Temple (literally) is an amazing experience, I would say one of my top three temples in Siem Reap. Try to go around late afternoon rather tha straight away after Angkor Wat in the morning (as everyone seems to do), the grandness of Bayon willbe more rewarding when less crowds are present.
A must see in Angkor. It was our first stop, there is a lot of stairs but it worth the visit, try to go early morning to avoid the heat.

Beautiful Temple!. One of the major temples in the Angkor Archaeological complex which is really really good!It is better to get here later in the afternoon because this temple is flocked by tourists.
Sublime. Loved the early morning quiet and atmosphere. A wonderful temple to reflect on things. Likes the views, the faces (of course) and the really condensed nature of the temple

Beautiful. Bayon Temple is a beautiful place. Make you time here a little more special by taking an elephant ride around the temples just make sure to buy your elephant some bananas or the small pineapples. One thing I did notice about most of the temples we visited is that there are vendor inside that will have you light a incense and then want an offering. I do recommend leaving a dollar or a few coins for them.
Awesome. Awesome, One of A Must thing to visit in Siem Reap. Only thing that I disliked is it's hard to find the toilet.

More charming than Angkor Wat. So Angkor Wat is a must when visiting the temples in Siem Reap but we found Bayon Temple much nicer. It is certainly smaller but the carvings of the stone, the lay out and the location are simply wonderful. Around every corner you walk there is a surprise, a small window for a great photo, a carving that can wow you.We finished a long day walking and touring with this temple and were still blown away with the beauty. A must see!!

FASCINATING FACES. At Bayon Temple you will encounter uneven walkways and some climbing. This temple in the Angkor Thom area will capture you, because even though the many large faces are similar, they are not the same. Take time to look for the face that “speaks” to you. If you like to take photographs, search for the images that capture your experience. Unlike any other wat (temple) this wat gives the feeling of being not just from another time, but also from another world. It is in every way larger-than-life.
A must for a tourist. The tour guide took us here at some point during the day! It is worth the walk. Beautiful places to take pictures! I recommend it!

My Favourite. Although there are a lot of tourists here, this temple is absolutely breathtaking and my favourite by far. I would highly recommend trying to go before it gets too hot and bring a camera because this temple is worth taking photos of!!!
nice. Loved all the smiling Buddhas, great stone work. Could hear bats screeching in the temples. Great experience. very busy!

Part of Angker Tom, this Temple is like an amazing film set.. We saved this one 'til last. A really amazing extravaganza, so deliciously theatrical, and unique. I think we preferred this to even Angker Wat, which is of course much larger, but Angker Tom is somehow still more imaginative, if that is possible!
A must see. This is a great temple to go visit. While there was a crowd there was plenty of room to take photos without having strangers in the frame - and there is a lot to take photos of!

Crowded. Bayon is less crowded than the main Angkor temple, but it is still infested with tourists bused in to look at it and take a photo. Rather than just taking the basic "temple tour" with everyone else, put the time and effort into getting to the more remote ruins and outer temples. The remote and outer ruins aren't in as good shape as the main temples like Bayon, but they're not crowded and allow you to actually enjoy and experience this piece of Khmer history. We looked at Bayon as we passed by it, but decided not to stop and fight the crowds after we had already had a magical experience at the ruins we found.

my favorite by a mile. ankor wat is infested with people going to watch the dawn and it's badly in need of a good scrub...but this temple is magical. There's something gloriously dotty about someone creating quite so many images of themselves...it is wonderfully over the top .
Great Temple. I love this temple so much. This is one of the must-visit temples in Siem Reap. I had really great time there with a professional tour guide. Fantastic!
spectacular. it,s the one we liked most with the four faces columns. we couldn´t be there, but at sunset should be spectacular
Take your time. Have been for a temple tour three times. Better get a private guide and do it at your own time. Amazing piece of architecture, bring your camera and go early to beat the crowds.
Amazing. The most amazing temple in the whole Angkor complex. I loved it. I was greatly impressed when I saw it.
Fanastic. Like all the temples, amazing. Head here right after sunrise at Angkor Wat and beat the crowds! Spend some time at the murals, they tell such a great story.
Worth a visit. The faces on the Bayon are incredible. I went here around 7:30am and it was cool and not many others here which was great to explore.

Awe-inspiring Bayon. The Bayon inspired contemplation. t's the type of place you'd want to be quiet in, just looking at all the wonderfully detailed carvings around you. Try to stay away from the bus loads of tourists who can be very noisy and disrespectful. I found the dress "code" to be less strict at the Bayon.

Must go.. Amazing. Must go period. Imagine being in a museum, a wonderful place with some of the greatest antiquities the world has ever seen. Now imagine you can walk into the exhibits and be a part of that museum.

The most awesome architectural treasure in Asia. I've been an architect for 17 years and this temple built 1000 years ago puts everything else I've ever seen to shame. A must see in your lifetime. Enough said.
Educational temple. Love the story on the wall. The guide was fabulous. Able to tell us the history. It is sad that there are so many ruins.

Best one. In our opinion we enjoyed this temple as the jungle had overtaking it and merged in with the ruins. It was magical to see how the trees had adapted and spread their roots out - good ophoto points for us. |We thought this was a lovely inimate temple (compared to Angkor Wat) and enjoyed it even though the temperature was very hot
excellent place to take beautiful Pictures. Lot to see and a lot to walk, but an excellent place to learn and take pictures, must send a good day over here.
Heritage world. Fantastic and Great Heritage place & Building. I dislike is the weather is too hot and make the traveller up side down.

Simply the Best. Everyone has their favourite, and this just happens to be mine - the scale, the majestic buildings, the carvings and the stories behind them - the beauty of the location. Fantastic place to wander and suddenly you feel transported to another time - yes it really does get to you. Beautiful to visit late in the afternoon it seems to take on an even more mystical quality.
Tranquil. We joined a group with a guide which was very helpful. Very interesting history. Lots of opportunities for great photos

Faces of Heaven. This was my favorite temple in Angkor Wat. If you can, contact JAPA - the Japanese Architectural society and ask for Bob McArthur who is an American archeologist who gives private tours. Made our trip there 10x special.
Do NOT miss this!!!. Early in the morning the crowds are at Angkor Wat and one can browse and photo Bayon at leisure. A photo guide knew where to find the truly unique perspectives.

One of my favorite temples. Hundreds of bodhisattva faces surround you as you ascend the levels and look over the jungle. Try to avoid the crowds, go wet season, early in the day or midday when everyone goes for lunch. a place to sit and be quiet.

Definitely belongs in the #1 spot. The giant faces are just awesome. I enjoyed this temple better than the "main attraction" in this area, Angkor Wat. Bayon has so much personality! I listed "fee for this attraction - yes" due to the $20 (for a one-day pass) charge for ANY temple in Angkor Archaeological Park.
simply extraordinary. the whole archeological park was outstanding, this is the first temple that u come across. its a wonder how this this temple was built.

a must see. A great temple complex. First time I came was 10 years ago, and had good time to wander around and see everything. must admit now it getting busier, and I would recommend that you go asap, before it gets even more crowded.

Prepare to be fascinated!. The Bayon Temple was built around 100 years after Angkor Wat and stands at the exact center of the massive Angkor Thom complex. It does not have an enclosing wall although it is protected by the wall surrounding Angkor Thom.It is characterised by over 2000 large, smiling, serene and silent faces carved on its majestic towers. It is generally accepted that the four faces on each of the towers are images of the bodhisattva Avalokitesvara and that they signify the omnipresence of the king. The characteristics of these faces - a broad forehead, downcast eyes, wide nostrils, thick lips that curl upwards slightly at the ends-combine to reflect the famous 'Smile of Angkor'.The basic plan of the Bayon is a simple one comprising three levels . The first and second levels are square galleries featuring bas-reliefs. It is possible and well worth it to climb almost to the very top of the Central Sanctuary -- the third level.Despite this seemingly simple plan, the arrangement of the Bayon is complex, with a maze of galleries, passages and steps connected in a way that make the levels practically indistinguishable and creates dim lighting, narrow walkways, and low ceilings. The architectural scale and composition of the Bayon exude grandness. I was fascinated by it. This was definitely one of the highlights of my visit.
Worth visiting. Bayon temple is really amazing, the architecture is really wonderful plus the carving was so unique. Worth going for Bayon temple.

Smiling faces everywhere. I have nothing new to contribute. The numerous reviews have spelled it out clearly. This is one "Must Visit". This being my third visit I have yet to find a day/time/season when it is possible to relax and take thought out photo angles. Too many tourists but so am I.

Fascinating Temple. Bayon Temple sits smack dab in the center of Angkor Thom; I believe it is one of the most popular temples on the circuit. It is perhaps most famous for its multitude of towers with benignly smiling faces adorning each one that overlook the temple in every direction. In addition, along the outer wall is a series of very well preserved bas-reliefs, featuring elephants and Khmer fighting troops. All in all it's a glorious and fascinating temple not to be missed!

Truly a wonder of the world!. The whole temple complex is amazing and, I would imagine, is why folks come to Siem Reap. The Bayon Temple is a good place to start. It's part of the larger temple complex of Angkor Thom. Love those enigmatic smiling faces! Bring water, hat, sun screen and lots of energy! Also be prepared for many locals to ask if you'll buy something (bracelet, shirt, pants, book etc) - so bring your patience and compassion (plus lots of $1 bills if you want to buy something).
A must for everybody!. This is my favourite archeological site in the world. You have to see this stunning tempel!! I have seen many places during my travels but this one is the best!!

My favorite area of all the temples. I really enjoyed our tour around Bayon. It was the first complex we visited and maybe that was part of the enjoyment since it was new to us. The head carvings were fabulous to see in person. There were so many things to see in the Angkor Thom complex and this is only a small part. We thought having a guide to explain everything was important here. I was not sure if we would want a guide but I think it made the visit better.
Archeological Wonder!. I really liked this temple, I went right after sunrise at Angkor Wat when Bayon was still very empty. The head carvings are beautiful and a great photography spot!

Fantastic Culture and History. Arrive early if you can ..our guide took us to the site at 5 am...we had a personal guie so only the 2 of us .... sat listening to the animals around us ..in the trees mainly waiting or the sun to come up on the temple ..Its the best time to get there as there were not crowds at that time and we walked around undisturbed able to hear what our guide was telling us about its history and take pictures with out having other unwanted bodies in the way and it was still fairly cool temperature

Find the smiling face. Not to be missed. The temple is very busy but worth being with the crowds. You can take an elephant ride to get perspective, the temple is huge. The faces are on every level.You need to search for the smiling face.

Great Temple!. I have been in Bayon Temple 3 times, in 1999, 2003 and 2007. Always a great experience! One advice, try to visit very early in the morning. There is more and more people visiting the is temple! In 1999 is was the best experience ever... they was at the time mabye 100 visitor per day for the hole temple!

amazing. Perfected preserved faces of buddha in an amazing arrangement. A must visit in the angkor complex. take some time sitting and relaxing in this magnificent structure and see the wonder that it gives. :-)

Peaceful early morning visit. We got up very early in the morning to visit this temple, arriving not long after sunrise, and it was well worth it as it is an extraordinary and exquisite place. The visitor numbers were starting to build up as we left but we did manage a good chunk of time of having it almost to ourselves. Possibly everyone else had been watching the sunrise at Angkor Wat but whatever the reason I was grateful for the serenity and space to contemplate the marvels of the amazing relic. An absolute must to see but do try to go early in the day. My top tip for temple visits is to hire a bicycle if you are physically up to it. We rented our bikes through our hotel and cycled from central Siem Reap. All up I estimate we bicycled around 40-45 easy kilometres. The whole complex is very flat and easy to navigate around and with your own transport you are not at the mercy of over helpful tuk-tuk drivers. Cycling around was such a pleasant experience I would be very happy to repeat it. Do remember to carry water although it is also available to purchase.

Fascinating temple!. We came here around 8am and it was not too crowded (lots of people but not overly crowded). Really enjoyed seeing the faces and walking through the gateway. Look out for the little plants whose leaves curl up when you touch them, my kids thought they were great! Beautiful carvings and interesting to see the different stages of restoration on the road to the gateway.
Just amazing . This was a goal to visit since years. Just unbelievable how such a big temple can be built hundred years ago. Definitly a must seen before die!

Spectacular creation. After a sumptuous breakfast, we left for the gargantuan Angkor Thom complex which houses one of the most popular temples, The Bayon, Phimeanakas, The Elephant Terrace, Terrace of the Leper king and other smaller structures.Upon reaching The Bayon we were completely awestruck at the majesty of this Temple, the highest peak of the temple was surrounded by numerous shorter peaks with huge serene faces carved onto the sides of each peak-looking at North, South, East and West sides. Rumour has it that King Jayavarman the VII, who wanted his people to follow Buddhism, made these huge faces on the pillars with his likeness to depict that he is watching over his kingdom.The Bayon was an engaging, enchanting and haunting experience. The temple literally had - expressions ! We had to climb up to the terrace to enjoy the view from up there and also to get a closer look at the enormous carvings and the shrine within. Such was the magic of this temple that we ended up staying here for more than 2 hours! We took some of the best photographs there. Needless to say as this was one of the most popular temples and tourists thronged the area. Soon, after getting a feel of the temple and absorbing the spectacular ambience all around, we decided to leave. But we were not yet done with Bayon, we knew we had to come back, sooner than later.

Only saw from distance. By the time i reached Bayon my body had given out. My husband went in but I only saw from a distance.. If you are limited as I am at 76, decide your priority. I wanted Angkor Wat and hoped to do both but couldn't.

I see you.. This temple is on my top 3! This was the first temple we visited after the sunrise watching in Angkor Wat and my mind was blown with everything on this temple. The faces staring on all directions, the stones, the pillars, this is really one of a kind. Never leave Siem Reap without visiting Bayon. Actually, if you only have a few hours in SR, make sure to choose this and Angkor.
Beautiful. Pictures of these temples are beautiful, but one really needs to visit and see these places in person! Breathtaking! Bayon Temple was the least crowded of all the temples we visited.
Fantastic but overrun with tourists. One of the more intact temples, but you need to go at a time when no one else goes, as it's very difficult to see it when there are hoards there.

Just beautiful. Although you do tend to get over temple's in SE Asia, this one was lovely. It's a different style to others in the area. Price of entry is included in the $20USD you pay before heading to angkor wat. Also another temple in the same area and the elephant wall. Be sure to ask your driver to stop at one of the entrances for some pictures.

My favorite of the temple complexes. Fascinating as are the other temple complexes. The detail that has survived all this time since 12th century is astounding. if you can, visit early in the morning to avoid crowds. the sites get very busy with tourists and Cambodians alike visiting them. THe climb to the top is well worth it and the photographic opportunities are endless

Worth a visit. Just around the corner from Angkor Wat and worth a visit as the "temple of faces" is very different from Angkor Wat. Be sure to climb up and you'll be rewarded with closer views of the multiple towers.
best there. VERY crowded, ask a guide when the best time to go there is, otherwise, this temple is the best in Angkor Wat

superb Temple, totally different architecture to Angkor Wat. This temple is different to the rest of Angkor Wat, it tends not to be as busy either we went early in the morning, and the views from the top are amazing (like you are on the top of jungle)! The sculptures are out of this world, and even on a dull day, you get terrific photos. Definitely a must visit site.

Happiest temple in the world. One of the "Big Three" temples in the Angkor Wat Archeological Park, it is certainly an experience worth having, and definitely unique! Every smile, they tell us, is slightly different. Did you find the happiest one? It can be crowded, so you may want to try and go either slightly later in the day, as everyone tends to try & get here first. There is no fee, as it's covered by the entrance to the Archeological Park, but there are plenty of stairs, some fairly steep, so you don't want to be doing this if you aren't reasonably comfortable with walking. It isn't hard, just there's lots of them. Many thanks to our guide, who was EXCELLENT at finding the quiet spots for good photos!
Met all expectations; came back for a 2d look. Just like Angkor Wat a great visit and worth a second visit to take it in and notice things missed on the first visit

Magnificent Faces. On our 2nd trip to Cambodia this was one of the temples we couldn't miss. All the faces on the towers, when you're inside the temple looking up its almost impossible to take a bad shot. If you get a chance to visit when it's raining, as we did in 2009, don't miss it. You'll eventually dry out, but the memories will last a lifetime.

Breathtaking & fascinating. One would be simply amazed with the detail and architecture and so much history of this temple. (as with all the other temples). The fact alone that this was built centuries ago is reason enough for one to go.We were so dismayed that our entire Angkor trip was shortened due to our trip being canceled as at least 2 hrs I think should be spent here. If you haven't read up on the Angkor temples, getting a guide would be great.

Smiling Buddha. Bayon temple, standing center of the city of Angkor Thom, is normally the first monument that people will pay a visit when arriving Siem Reap. Therefore, Bayon is always crowded, very hard to take good photos. However, this place is definitely worth to visit, the top towers are just like a maze, full of smiling Buddha faces. These 4 faces smile mysterious face of the Buddha, has witnessed the impermanence of human affairs for thousands of years.屹立吴哥大城正中央的巴扬寺(Bayon)，顶层满布佛面塔群。面露神秘笑容的4面佛陀，千百年来看尽世间无常。

One of our favorite temples. Plenty of temples blend together when you're traveling around SE Asia, but the Bayon Temple at Angkor Wat was one of the best. The temple is known for its columns, which feature faces on all four sides. It's a great photo op!

Amazing. Another fabulous temple and fascinating how it was built. Make sure you go early to miss the crowds as it gets really busy quick (i.e. impossible to get a picture without having somebody else in it).
Favourite. It is my favouritee temple in Siem Reap. It's not restored like Ankor Wat but seems more charming the way it is.

Have a guided tour. To get the best out of any of the Angkor temples you do need a guide. Arrive as early as you can, some open at 5.30am for sunrise. The temples get very crowded by 10am and so very hot

Another Fantastic Temple. This is another must-see when visiting Cambodia. We thought Angkor Thom gates were impressive, but this site is far better. The temple's carved faces are amazing and in very good conditions for photos. Give yourself plenty time to explore this site thoroughly.

Superb. One of the most interesting temples in Angkor. Massive faces stare at you from every corner taking you back to another time but let you 'feel' the surrounding jungle at the same time. The carvings are a masterpiece and offer unlimited opportunities for great pictures. The place is relatively small in comparison with Angkor Wat or Ta Phrom but it was very busy and people elbowing or pushing you sometimes made me feel not very safe (I'm not easily scared, but the place was really packed!!): positively worth it though. I wouldn't have missed that airy feeling for the world.
Nice temple to wander around. Not as busy as others so nice to wander. Beware of 'friendly' locals telling you about the temple, dont respond as all they want is money

The best temple in the Angkor complex. This is in my opinion the most interesting temple in Angkor. The stone heads are fascinating. The carvings are among the best. Some great pictures from here. A bit less crowded than some of the other temples like Angkor Wat an Ta Phrom. Chose your time of visit wisely though or risk being swamped with large tour groups
Tempio Bayon. It is breath taking al the faces are suprising. I highly reccomende this visit. In one day I visited . Angkor Wat-Bayon -Ta prohm- Angkor Thom

Must See in Angkor Archeological Park. Along with Angkor Wat and Ta Phrom, Bayon is the other must see for the casual visitor to the Angkor ruins. That being said, it is also one of the more popular temples and you will be sharing the space with more fellow tourists. If you tour the temples in a counterclockwise pattern and arrive at Bayon in the later afternoon you can enjoy it without nearly the crowds that are here during the rest of the day. Located at the center of Angkor Thom, this temple is known for the four faces on each of the towers. It is quite expansive and certainly unique in comparison in the other temples in the area. Once you are at Bayon, make sure you check out the other ruins in the Angkor Thom complex.

Great Temple. This is one of the crowd favorite and rightly so. It is visually stunning because of the 37 towers still standing today. Most of the towers are carved with four faces on each cardinal point. A small number have three or two faces. The giant faces make for good background and there is always a long queue taking pictures. The temple itself is quite compact and so very easy to access from various directions. Besides the attention grabbing faces, there are also very interesting and intricate base reliefs. You need at least two hours to really appreciate this temple and all it's intricacies. It is quieter if you visit in the afternoon and the evening light makes the carved faces stand out.

Bayon Temple. Great place. Other than the all popular Angkor Wat, Bayon is another great temple. People tend to walk straight in when they arrive. Our great tour guide brought us for the Money shot! just walk off the beaten path to the small lake beside it. Catch the reflection of the temple with great afternoon sun on it. Also a great place sit and relax.Climbing up you can take many photos with the buddha faces(initially designed to be Buddhist temple but was converted by Hindu King later on). Many of the carvings are still intact even after hundreds of years of erosions!Great place for photos! A must see!

Interesting place,,,!. This is a special place, but was a bit spoiled for me by the huge number of tourists. Access to Angkor Wat itself was restricted for religious reasons, so many of the tours decided to visit Bayon instead. Because of this congestion we had to walk from the Smiling Heads gate all the way to the temple itself and it was very very hot!! Once inside, ease of movement was restricted due to the large numbers of visitors. It was also difficult to appreciate the majesty of the architecture because of the behaviour of some tourists wanting to take funny/silly pictures. It's a place I would like to visit again, so that I can appreciate it more. Tip:- avoid this place if access to Angkor Wat is restricted, or at least be aware that you will be joining a few thousand more!

Bayon Temple, a great place to start!. Impressive Temple site with numerous carvings and reliefs. Would suggest to tourists to go here first. You will spend a lot of time here.Recommend a guide to explain the carvings and significance to the Buddhist and Hindu religions.

Amazing Faces. This was one of our favorite temples. The giant stone faces and the bas-reliefs of the historical sea battle, everyday life, chess games, childbirth, etc. are not to be missed. If you have to pick and choose where to spend your time, do not miss this one.
Love this place. Angkor Wat is amazing but Bayon has to be my favourite of the temples. One tip though is to go without a guide, that way you can just sit there for as and soak in the atmosphere.
Best Time for Bayon. Love to visit the temple at evenings near closing time. Fewer people, no groups, very quiet to allow a peaceful visit.

MUST TO SEE. Beautiful semi-restored temple in the expansive Angkor Thom complex. Lot of dramatic shots to be taken. Not as crowded as Angkor Wat and just as beautiful in its own way. A must see when in Siem Reap!

Cultural heritage. This is stunning and incredible with four faces in different directions. The temple is magnificent. I have enjoyed a lot. The time recommended for visit is morning and sunset because it is hot in daytime and you should bring water,handkerchief and will sweeten a lot.
Mysterious. Words cant describe what we saw. Awesome , mysterious and a dream come true to see. These great large smiles looking down on us. I didnt want to leave.

Inspiring place. The Bauon Temple & Angkor Wat go hand in hand and are exactly what Cambodia is all about. Inspiring history of this amazing country is easily seen just make sure you ave a knowledgable guide to share the history with you.

VietnamBamboo Travel - Private Tours. VietnamBamboo Travel arranged the most fantastic private tour of Vietnam and Cambodia for us. We first found them on the internet and were bit unsure how it would all turn out but our fears were groundless. The accommodations throughout the trip were top notch, the guides were all excellent, the drivers/cars were great and the many tours/adventures/sites visited were awesome. We would highly recommend VietnamBamboo Travel and Jennifer Nguyen in particular when considering a trip to Vietnam and/or Cambodia. We took the 20 day tour and were able to really get a good feeling for the countries, the history, food and the people. It was truly a trip of a lifetime and VietnamBamboo Travel made it unforgettable.

A mystical, magical place. All of the people on our tour agreed that the Bayon Temple was absolutely beautiful because it has not been restored. Therefore, this temple provides a wonderful contrast to the other temples. Parts of it reminded us of an Indiana Jones movie. The trees, roots and moss are beautiful and one can only imagine how the other temples would have looked had they not been restored.The only negative of our experience occurred as we returned to our bus when we were besieged by people trying to sell us scarves, trinkets, and other souvenirs. They just wouldn't take NO for an answer, even pounding on our bus windows! This was most unfortunate, as the trip through the Temple area is a must see when you visit Siem Reap. Some of my favourite photos from our trip are from this temple!

WOW. If I had to choose where to spend the most time, it would be here and La Prohm over Angkor Wat. Angkor Wat is the best for the silhouette pictures especially at sunrise and sunset. But Bayon and La Prohm is where you explore and continue to be fascinated with every turn. It is a play land with around 200 faces greeting you at every turn. I am amazed that you can be that up close to ancient treasures. Enjoy and let your imagination go wild.Don't forget to reserve time to explore the rest of the Angkor Thom complex, including The majestic Baphoun, and interesting Elephants Terrace and LIon KIng Terrace.
My favorite. This is one of my favorite temple in Siem Reap. May be because it is the first one I visited but the magic feeling of it is something that it is still with me after many months.
Faces faces everywhere. The temple with all the faces, a must see in the temple complex. One of the more popular ones for sure. Getting a guide for the temples is well worth it.

wonderful !. this temple is smaller than Angkor Wat - it has an eerie charm with large beautiful heads watching you ! the passage ways are tight and a bit overwhelming if busy in the heat but it is an exceptional temple not to be missed - other temples in easy walking distance through the trees so take time ( and plenty of water!) and enjoy exploring the forest is quite beautiful.

Bayon is unforgettable. The front side of Bayon doesn't look impressive from afar. But as we slowly approached the walkway, a three-dimensional world comes alive before my eyes. Bayon is made up of multi-level stairs (though not as high as Angkor Wat's), a maze of sculptures and features humongous intricate face carvings that is simply a sight to behold. I am entranced by Bayon's complexity of design and left me wondering how these Khmers were able to create this with very ancient tools. Just amazing and memorable. I will definitely bring my daughter here in a few years, so she can be in awe of it just like her Minecraft world, but way way better!It's the next best temple to visit, after Angkor Wat.
Angkor Archaeological Park. Beautiful and haunting but the crowd can be a major annoyance. Must see temples - Bayon, Ta Prohm and Angkor Wat for those with only a day to spare.

A must see!. Bayon temple was one of the temples we visited on our one day tour while at Siem Reap. It is different from Angkor Wat as it has many more trees in and around it. It is definitely worth a visit.

Don't miss the Bayon. The temple has 54 towers, each with 4 facets, and each facet features the smiling face of Buddha. That makes 54x4 faces. Some of the towers have collapsed, while some are still in excellent condition. It is the only major temple with so many faces of the smiling Buddha.Impressive master piece and good to start the journey in Angkor and don't be afraid to climb up and down the tiny stairs as it's where you'll find some great hidden treasures!

got soaked but worth it. very busy temple but one of tge mist interesting. It rained heavilly when we were there. Our guide positioned under a gallery area but I guess 1000 years plus has taken its toll. It leaked like a sieve. Beautiful temple though

They're watching you.... I don't know why but this place had more presence then Angkor Wat. It had interesting towers with almost imposable steps, mix-match of walls that have fallen and been re-stacked in the wrong order, and each face was ever so slightly different.side note: Don't forget to take WATER and a little map so you can walk over to the other temples/palaces near by.
Incredible architecture. not as huge as Angkor Wat, but the architecture here is not less appealing and incredible, with the carvings in the stone. Not to be missed
Faces everywhere. One of the more interesting sites with a multitude of faces.Also like the murals depicting day to day life (giving birth, grooming hair, etc.)

" Truly Amazing". It is a truly amazing temple to see in Siem Reap and one of a kind. This is definitely one of the temples not to be missed. The view is truly breath-taking from the time you approach the temple. It is unbelievable how something so magnificent could have been built so long ago. It is truly unique.

get here early. This place is best enjoyed on your own and in the early morning, without the large tour groups that come through later in the day. It's passages are great to get lost in. Really take your time with it if you can.

Cultural heritage. When you are in SR, you must visit this place. This is stunning and incredible with four faces in different directions. The temple is magnificent. I have enjoyed a lot. The time recommended for visit is morning and sunset because it is hot in daytime and you should bring water, handkerchief and will sweeten a lot. But it is worthy a try and you would amazed at what old people did.I would come in sunset in another occasion as returning SR.

Amazing work. The most beautiful temple in Angkor-typical spot in Khmer culture. Ancient empire here built surprising masterpieces of architecture. It’s just amazing that people at that long time ago can reach high level of building and carving on the stone like this. It may be taken a day to explore many Buddha face and building which are impressive and photogenic. There are so many faces and towers to explore. The view at sun rise or sun set is passionate.
Must see!. We visited twice at sun set n morning.Beautiful temple with towers having four faces on four direction.

My favorite. Until you get to it it is hard to imagine the beauty and awe that one feels up close to this temple. The Buddha faces on the towers and entrance are magnificent.
A wonder of the world indeed!

Amazing. The first view when you are approaching Bayon Temple is simply breathtaking. It sounds unbelievable that there was a civilization which was able to build something like this while in Europe the civilization was just entering its early medieval period. It is worth looking at all those different Buddha faces in those towers representing all provinces of Khmer empire as each of them express a different mood. Bayon Temple is definitely one of jewels of the ancient architecture.

Amazing place. Go at lunchtime to avoid crowds. As good as angkor wat. Don't miss taking pictures at the gate of the city. Climb upside to left of gate for best photos of your traveling companions. Go at lunchtime when others are avoiding the heat and eating. Only thing that was underwhelming was elephant but great reliefs in maze at the end of the elephant wall

Architectural Wonder. At a time when there were no cement or other fixatives were available these master craftsmen build this mammoth structures without cranes or mechanical aid, they used their brain in a different way. Each piece were made at ground level by rubbing stone to stone so that sides fit to perfection and lifted and placed into position, just amazing when one think how they might have worked to construct these beautiful temple for us to see and admire, thank you the great architect and his workers in thousands, we salute you all.

Archaeological treasure in a downpour. Our enjoyment of our visit to Bayon was somewhat dampened - by the last real downpour of the rainy season. Although impressive, reclaimed from the forest, and very different from Angkor Wat, it is still largely a ruin, and everywhere leaks - there is simply no escape from the rain! My overall impression was one of sadness; how even before the troubles of the last few decades, all that devotion and toil had been abandoned, and counted for nothing, until the archaeologists arrived.

Wonderful!. There is not much to say. If you go to Cambodia, you have to see the Angkor Wat complex. Just because its something unbelievably impressive created by our own species a thousand years ago. Bayon is one of the most impressive temples in the complex. Just don`t forget your water and tissues and be prepared for plenty sweating.

Temple with so much History. Bayon Temple is one of my favourite temple. Angkor Wat is a must see because of its status. But if we focus on the culture, the sculpture and wall caving, I will place Bayon as a MUST see. Get a guide that can explain the temple well and you will be able to understand more about what happened during those days. There are many good camera location to take fantastic picture too.
my favorite temple in Angkor. Situated at the centre of Angkor Thom, the Bayon is the most impressive temple at Angkor Thom in the whole Angkor complex.
Spectacular. When the hordes are tourist are at Angkor wat for sunrise, you get over to Bayon and enjoy. Thank me later :)
Love the Faces!. This and Ta Prohm were my two favorite temples to visit on this trip. The faces are just incredible to look at.
mindblower. had totally underestimated the scale of these temples - feel very privileged to have spent several days exploring

Stunning. Once again when in Siem Reap we just had to visit Bayon, which is our favourite temple. It could only be described as awesome and we are most fortunate that this wonderful place is still here after so very many years for us to visit and enjoy.
Wonderful!. While visiting this temple, walk around inside the lower section- there are so many interesting nooks and crannies and virtually NO other tourists.

THE TEMPLE. the temple was amazing and i loved it.it was so good to see and it had soo many amaing things that i have never seen in life it was the most wonderful time of my life i would love to go again with my familly or friends or partner it was the best intersening thing in my life and i wish to go again one day maybe soon and love seeing new stuff thses days

Happy faces. Bayon is a beautiful temple and we loved exploring all the different moss covered nooks and crannies. We went in October, but it was still quite crowded - Go during offpeak times of day for sure to get the best possible experience!

Must See. Me and my husband stayed in Siem Reap for five nights and toured many temples. We rate Bayon as one of the best temples to visit in the Angkor area. Highly recommend the elephant ride around the temple and feeding the elephants too!

First on your list for a three day visit!. Ease into the Angkor experience by visiting this enigmatic temple first. A good fitness level, and excellent shoes--don't bother with bringing flip flops to any of these venues--is important. Morning is a great time to view these haunting faces and introduce yourself to the architecture of Angkor. Bring lots of water and an umbrella for protection from the blazing sun.There are a large number of temples in the Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, and outlying areas as well. Don't feel you have to see them all. Three full days of touring are important to do this world-class venue justice but these are the Don't Miss sites, in this order of priority: Angkor Wat, of course, the stellar, Number One site; Bayon; Terrace of the Elephants and Terrace of the Leper King; Ta Prohm; Bandrey Srei; Preah Kahn; Pre Rup; Neak Prean.Give yourself time to visit your three favorites a second time within your three day itinerary. Many are so overwhelming in their interest, architecture, and artistry that you must see them at least twice to begin to appreciate them. We had to see the Churning of the River of Milk at Angkor Wat three times, as it was so artistically stunning, and is comparable to the greatest carvings anywhere in the World.

Bayon was the most beautiful temple.. We just returned from Ankor Wat and the Bayon temple was stunning. There is something about all the faces looking down upon you that is amazing. We would definitely put this temple at the top of the heap! The weather in early November was great.

the best carvings you will find at angkor. bayon is very nice, not as big as Angkor wat for example but worth a lengthy visit. take your time on the lower level to see the wall carvings, it would be better if you have a book explaining what you are seeing coz that makes it twice as interesting. the upper level when i visited was very busy with all sorts of photo happy tourists so ddnt really enjoy it much. you can combine bayon with baphuon and the terrace of the lepper king and the terrace of the elephants and phimeanakas on foot and then end up for lunch and rest at the many restaurants facing the the terrace of teh lepper king entrance for a full morning

Amazing. This ancient landmark is just so amazing. Centuries old ancient landmarks that is still there and tells a lot of stories, in its walls, in its architectural design is something we only ready in history books. Being able to look and touch them is indeed a privilege.

Simply amazing. Today I visited Ta Prohm, Angkor thom, bayon and Angkor wat. All are interesting and must sees but for me the bayon temple is the most beautiful, interesting and photogenic. There are so many faces and towers to explore. As we walked around one lady reflected 'you could so easily spend a day at this one temple taking photos' - I agree entirely. You can climb up to different levels where the views and 'faces' can be explored from all angles/levels. A wonderful place and an absolute must see!

Awe inspired. Just spent the day at Angkor Tom Angor Wat complexes. We were and still are awe struck. It is simply amazing that these structures were built during the 12th Century and are still around for the world to enjoy and treasure. We are only here for the day but you could spent a month here and not see it all. We will be back

it feels like the world smiles with you. The place is calming. All around you see smiling faces carved. It feels like someone is watching you and is pleased at you and what you do. A good place to visit. Not to be missed, along with Angkor Wat.

It's awesome!. The fact that this was built in the 12th century and can rival the pyramids of Egypt, the cathedrals in Europe, the Parthenon in Greece as what archaeologists say is worth seeing. Truly magnificent and it's history is mysterious and spiritually uplifting.
Beautiful Bayon. wow...this is a must go temple with it beautiful and amazing stonework. It was crowded with many tour and noisy during my trip to this temple.

Spectacular. Seeing this temple shows the indian influence in the cambodian culture. Our driver took us in the afternoon as it was not so busy. Take in the sites and relax seeing the spectacular workmanship. Breathtaking

Giant Heads. Beautiful semi-restored temple in the expansive Angkor Thom complex. Lot of dramatic shots to be taken. Not as crowded as Angkor Wat and just as beautiful in its own way.A must see when in Siem Reap!
A must see. What can I say ? Everyone is here for the famous khmer smile. It really wowed me. Hopefully, I will get to see it again.

A little rough around the edges but absolutely beautiful.. This was my absolute favourite temple by far. The traditional name for Bayon meaning magic. This temple had 54 towers. Up near the top of each tower on each of the four sides facing North, South, East and West are a big face. The temple was rushed and made in only 10 years (some temples took 50 years to build). Because of rush, the pieces of stone making up the structure are smaller and thus not as stable - basically it's a beautiful structure but a little rough around the edges. On one wall is the story of the king who built the temple. He was a man of the people and wanted harmony. He made his temple to support both Hindu and Buddhist beliefs. He wanted to move his entire forward and not create a civil war by creating a temple to worship and honour the gods of only one religion - smart man. There is just something so peaceful and beautiful about this temple - a must see!

Definitely my favorite. I fell in love with this temple. The first time we visited, it was jammed with people since it is one of the more popular temples. We loved it but wanted to see it again. We went back later on that afternoon and it was a totally different experience. There was hardly anyone there. We wandered around for a long time marveling at the many different faces. This was one of those places that I couldn't get enough of. I have to admit, I actually went back a third time. It was just after sunrise and we sat and admired the beauty before the crowds descended. You definitely don't want to miss this one.
Must See~. Other than Angkor Wat, this is another temple that you must visit when u're in Cambodia~ Go early so that you can avoid the crowd and also it gets very hot in the afternoon.

Too many visitors. This most popular temple in Angkor looses its charme due to the over population of tourists. Better visit the Preah Vihear Temple 1.5 hours away. you can get the real spirite without millions of visitors

Totally blown away!. This place was amazing, what made it more special was the history behind it. Would definitely recommend you do your research before going or hire a tour guide. Most tours start at this temple so best to go in afternoon when is less busy (as advised by our tour guide). Got loads of unobstructed pics. If you need a good tour guide we found a great guy through a recommendation from our friends in Bangkok, would be happy to share details just message me.

Bayon beauty. Incredible stonework, unbelievable history and legend, a feeling of wonder and enlightenment. So much to see with so many temples but the Bayon is the pick of the bunch after Ankor Wat. Go early to avoid the heat and crowds and sunrise or sunset for the best light for photos
Crowded. A must see. To avoid crowds try visit very early in the morning. They open at 5:30. Didn't like the elephant ride.
Fabulous. A beautiful unique temple, pity about the crowds but to be expected I spose. Definitely one of my favourites. Don't rush it,just enjoy!!
A must see. This temple is the one that you see everywhere in pictures with faces carved into the walls. It's beautiful.
Awesome, but packed. Probably my favorite temple, very tight with lots of detail, but too damn crowded. Lots of rude people make it difficult to get an unobstructed shot.

Too busy to enjoy. We hit the Bayon at the wrong time of day, which was a mistake. It was so crowded it was difficult to find a spot to enjoy the incredible architecture.If I could describe the Bayon in a word it would be FANTASTIC. It truly is stunning, very engaging and visually stimulating.Top tip?Talk with your guide/driver about quietest times to visit.
Bayon. Amazing temple a must see could spend hours here its incredible how they built it and the history is just really amazing. Incredible architecture for the day it really is WOW
Big Buddha heads. Beautiful temple with big Buddha heads carved into the roofs of the towers. Very serene and spiritual place.
Fantastic temple. Newer seen sonething like angkor bayon. Unbekievable beauty, unique architecture and 1000 years old story make this temple unique in the world . Best thing I ever seen in my life!

Worth the sunset exploring. Good;
less crowds
different design to other temples
preserved headstones
easy access
surrounding communities
picture opportunities
No so good;
neglected relics, base relief, moat, walls
congregation of tourists on top levels
loud Chinese and Korean tourists
lack of information about Temple on site

Deflinitely the second best temple to visit. This temple is part of the Angkor Thom complex and is built exactly in the middle. Bayon is known for its huge stone faces of the bodhisattva Avalokiteshvara, with one facing outward and keeping watch at each compass point. This temple to me, was second only to its famous counterpart. Angkor Wat Temple.A HINT.... organise an English speaking guide to take you to the temples, its certainly worth the smal amount of money you pay, however it will make the visit much more worthwhile
Amazing sculptures!. This was the second temple we visited and it was close to lunch (around noon) so it had far less tourists than expected which was a good thing.

Are you looking at me?. Surrounded by warm, smiling faces from so long ago - Bayon Temple connects us all. Take the climb for close up views and come face to face - literally - with history. Our guide, Chong Sang, from Indochina Odyssey Tours provided so much insight and history on this magical place - I would absolutely recommend taking a tour with him. His knowledge gave us a greater understanding of the beauty and background of this wonder of the world. Bayon Temple is not to be missed if you are anywhere near Cambodia.
Unforgettable. Less well known than Angkor Wat but very much worth visiting, mainly because the collection of mysteriously smiling faces looking from everywhere
Faces everywhere!. Beautiful temple, with the charming faces. Good to walk around up and down the stairs and gaze at the faces...

Touring the Temples. Amazing places. Covers a vast area. Were there for 3 days and really only covered 4 of the 60 temples. Advise anybody to make the effort and get up early to do the visits. The tour buses come crowding in by 8.30am and it can get quite frantic! everybody wanting the same photos. The heat and humidity can get unbearable by 12 midday so allow yourself the afternoon off!
Really great experience. All of the old temples around Siem Reap are great, and I highly recommend. Also amazing how different this one is to Ankor Wat. It was fun climbing all around Bayon Temple

lost for words. this is one of those places that you end up speechless, you just run out of words to describe it beauty, serenity, age, carvings, peace, well i hope you get the picture, and the 43 mt tower!!! wow oh wow

My favourite temple!. This temple is astonishing with the buddah faces in every corner that you look. The temple is so unique - it can't be missed.A friend told me that it is possible to see the temple at night - she had done this for pictures. If I go again, I would try to make a trip after sunset to the Bayon Temple.

Better than Angor Wat. This Temple was really impressive. Both my wife and I agreed this was better than Angor Wat. It is actually difficult to say why. This temple is large and it has innumerable faces of Buddha and Jayavaraman VII. It is an 'open temple' (no roof), so you can see many different parts of it from any given spot. This creates a seemingly infinite number of angles to view and photograph. In addition, since it is open you see the beautiful backdrop of the surrounding jungle as you view the temple. Not to be overlooked is the imposing entrance with a walkway lined with soldiers (good and evil) surrounded on either side by water and jungle. There is also a large entrance gate that is impressive. This grandeur of this place can really not be described in words. It is best to go here early or late because it is very crowded. I think it would be better to visit Angkor Wat before going to Bayon given that Bayon is more impressive. I found Angkor Wat to be a bit of a letdown having gone to Bayon first.
Wonderful. This was one of my favourite sites in my entire trip!! Actually found it more beautiful then ankor wat...in my opinion

Bayon - Really Grand. Bayon temple is a must-see attraction in the Angkor Archaeological Park. Though in a very dilapidated state it still proclaims its grandeur of the past. The carvings on the structures are really dense as are the sculptures. Only second to Angkor Wat, Bayon leaves you awestruck.
entrance. the moment we enter the temple area, salesgirl straightly go to towards us to sell souvenir. It's not very comfortable as some of us feel scared of them.

One of my favorites!. There is something about this temple that made it one of my favorites. For one, I loved the carved faces all around the temple. Another thing is that it's so much detail into such a "small" area. There are carvings everywhere, in the different hallways and junctions, on the outer and inner walls, on the various levels and up at the top. We walked around at our own pace and climbed some of the small buildings in the courtyard surrounding the main temple. From there, you can take some interesting pictures, just be careful with the steep stairs as always. The hallways once you enter the temple building are quite dark and with some condensation, also quite slippery at times. We eventually found the stairs which take you to the upper level and from there, got some amazing views of the carved faces. Be aware that at the top level, there were a group of children asking for money - one of them asked for candy - it's obviously your choice to give or not; we had no candy...
Look out for the smiles. A wonderful temple but busy with mainland Chinese who seem too busy taking photographs to actually look at the ruins.
Buddha Images beautiful.. The Bayon is the temple famous for the images of the Buddha built into the structure. Each structure has four faces of the Buddha, facing NESW. It is inspiring.

Bayon was the highlight of our trip. I think there is something about coming up to one of the gates to enter Angkor Thom that takes your breath away. No matter how many photos you have seen of the Faces, you are not prepared for the real thing. The size is enormous and adds to the grandeur of the entire site.

Great Temple I ever seen. This is very big temple and I could not imagine how they built. There are a lot of big tree surround the area. I spend almost 3 hours in this temple. it just stand on the main road from Angkor Wat.

Really incredible carvings. This temple is mostly ruins but its being put back together - for better or worse. There are supposedly 54 faces on the huge towers but scholars can't seem to agree and who wants to spend their day counting them?Watch out for friendly people offering to take your photo - they will eventually try to herd you out of the temple after you've given them a hefty tip for their help. However the guy who pulled this on me ended up taking some pretty nice shots of me for the equivalent of 4 quid and since I was on my own I would have had no one to take them for me. This, rather than Angkor Wat is the postcard picture temple for Siem Reap and is only one in the huge complex of Angkor Thom. I loved clambering down the steep health and safety-free steps and through the long dark tunnel but it's a real shame anyone with mobility problems has to stare from a distance. Thoroughly recommended to the able of body.

The best temple to visit. It's probably worth getting a guide for this - there are a few photo opps that would be otherwise missed. Also, make sure you have an umbrella - it gets really, really hot there and you'll be grateful for the shade

One of the highlights. A joint favourite (together with Ta Prohm) and the highlight of Angkor Thom. It wasn’t crowded when we visited (around 8.30am) and although one or 2 tour groups arrived just after us we could easily skirt round them. There’s lots of little areas to explore and this was the one temple I wanted to return to. After visiting the Bayon you can easily walk to the other buildings in the Angkor Thom complex – Baphuon, Phimeanakas (beautiful) and elephant terrace, amongst others. We loved the surrounding forested area.

Bayon Temple. This was situated very close to Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom and must be visited at the same time. I am sure most people have seen the photos of the temple where the trees are growing through the structure of the temple. Seeing this site in real life leaves any photo in the shade. This is a must see experience if you are ever in this part of the world.

Almost better than Angkor itself!. The Bayon temple was breathtaking. The large smiling faces created from stone smiling at you from nearly every direction. I would suggest visiting the temple with a tour guide as ours explained to us what the significance of the temple was along with tons of other great information. He also encouraged us to go where we wouldnt have gone without a guide there - he got us to climb up the very steep stairs of a library which had an amazing veiw of the temple. Don’t forget to bring your camera and extra batteries there are tons of photo opportunities here!

Spooky faces and great atmosphere. This was our favourite place - the faces are mesmerising and everywhere! We went late afternoon for the first time, which was great, it was just after a rainstorm and so we had the place practically to ourselves, the atmosphere at that time of day was amazing.
Amazing. It was amazing place, should be there before noon because it so hot and a huge of tourist.No toilet or rest room, you have to prepare your self.
One of the Must Sees. Really impressive! One of the big three--Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom and the Bayon. Banteay Srei outside of town is also definitely worth a visit.
Mystical Bayon. Bayon Temple is most known for the gigantic Buddha faces that seem moulded in stone. It is safe to enter and climb. They have installed wooden walkways over the rougher areas.
Bayon Temple. Great, well worth a visit and a not to be missed experience if you are staying in Siem Reap. This should be tied in with Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom

Huge and marvellous. Extensive, picturesque but busy at times so choose your timings if possible. Gates are impressive and just the sheer size of the grounds and terraces is mind blowing with only elephants and slave labour.
good to see. Enjoyed this trip and well worth the time spent, try to go on a cooler day as shelter is limited. As part of an overall temple trip you'd only need half an hour or so here

Amazing. It's definitely one of the finest temples of angkor, with magnificent towers revealing 4 faces.. Try not to visit it to early in the morning or late in the afternoon, so it has enough light, as the temple is surrounded by jungle.

Breathtaking awe. Amazing temple of magnificent proportions. The many different faces of Buddha as well as the outer wall glyphs were amazing! The victory bridge approach with the churning of the milk portrayed on the bridge was surprise since I had associated this tail with anchor wat. A favourite temple
Happy. Well worth the time. The faces are so unique. Our guide Sopheap Breem was excellent!!!! He was so knowledgeable and gave us much information. He also guided us away from the large tour groups.
Wow. Wonderful to wander around, Asian elephants where for $15 you can have a 20 min ride. All added to the magical atmosphere. Amazing buildings well worth the visit.
outstanding. up there with the 7 wonders of world. marvelous place and not to be missed during your visit to the region. you'll not forget it ever.

Majestic! My favorite.. I just had a great feeling visiting this temple. Each temple exuded a different feeling and impression, and Bayon along with Bantay Srei were my favorites. Where Bantay Srei had that magic-mystical appeal, Bayon was majestic specially when I saw all the towers in line as I approached Bayon. I thought I'd find it in Angkor Wat but no, I found it here. Beautiful.

Love the Bayon. We thoroughly enjoyed the Bayon Temple and the experience was greatly enhanced by our guide Piseth who had such excellent knowledge of the history of this temple and where it fit within Angkor society. We were in awe with every step.

first temple visited but still rates. beautiful temple and tastefully restored. so many different features to see. It was really busy but I still managed to find spaces on my own . I hired a tuk tuk who gave me great directions on how to best explore Angkor Thomas and went thru without a guide so manged to move away from others. Only temple where you are forced to walk an additional loop past vendors in order to which is a shame as it was one of my favourite temples visited
Spellbinding. Loved Bayon temple! It's probably my favourite at Angkor Wat. The faces are incredible and the surroundings are fantastic too. Would definitely return

Magnificent. This was on our list of must see temples and though there were hoardes of other tourists there it was still magnificent. A few steps to climb but nothing on Angkor Wat or some of the other temples - just take your time if it's wet as I nearly slipped a couple of times due to the impatience of other tourists in the vicinity. I think best to go early to Bayon as the amount of tourists was just too many around 11am.No hawkers at this temple which was a welcome change.There are four entrance/exit points so try to remember which way you went in as we ended up doing the full walk around however this was nice because of the lack of other tourists and we got to take some photo shots from a relative distance.
