Must visit. The carvings are perfect and represent an interesting historical period of deep Hindu influence in Cambodia.

Worth a visit. All the temples have a story to tell. We had a guide and were so pleased we did. The guide can explain things to you and show you the best things to see. We bought a 2 day pass which gets you into all the temples. It works out more expensive it you buy a ticket at every temple.

such a peaceful place. despite the throngs of visitors it is easy to imagine the original grandeur and intent of this special place. so many amazing details emerge when you have an experienced, knowledgeable guide to bring it to life. early morning is best, but do not miss it even if you need to be there at another hour. good shoes and a bottle of water, your camera, and your imagination - what a wonderful memory !

Majestic Buddhas. This was one of my favourite temples. The lying Buddha and the faces of 1,000 Buddhas. There is a good work out up sections of stairs and you can get a brilliant view from the top. Surrounded by beautiful rainforest.

My favourite temple in Siem Reap. Bayon is simply beautiful - head there immediately after getting your Angkor Wat sunrise shot to capture this beautiful temple without any other tourists ruining your shot.
200 faces. Stunning! so impressive to see the variety of faces - all of the king as protector of his people. Take flat shoes - naturally at this age the stone is rather worn

My favorite temple in siem reap. I loved angkor wat but the bayon temple for me was even more amazing! You could easily spent 2 hours just wandering slowly to admire this wonderful place. Take your time. Would recommend to visit this place either early in the morning or late evening when it's not so hot

awesome. came to siem reap to see the temples and I was not disappointed to say the least. Bayon temple is simply gorgeous. It is a huge complex but it can still get crowded with tourists. I was there in October and it was extremely hot so make sure you are in comfortable clothing and bring water and sunscreen! They have a ticket center right outside ($20/day for the entire complex). I just got the day pass thinking I would be done in a day. But after 5 hours of walking (bayon, ta prohm and part of angkor wat) I was too exhausted to enjoy it. Getting the 3 day pass for $40 may have been better so you can take in the temples a little at a time esp since the heat is unforgiving. But all in all, just seeing bayon, ta prohm and angkor wat (there are so many other temples within the complex that you can visit) is worth the $20 and even the trip to siem reap.
Awesome. This place and the faces are simply awesome - gotta see and be on everyone's bucket list. Awesome for photography too!

Wonderful compact ruins without too much commercial pressure. The Bayon Temple is a short drive from the main Angkor ruins. When we arrived we were not greeted by any sellers of anything hitch which was a pleasant change. The ruins here are quite compact which makes it easy to explore. The faces are absolutely amazing and many of them are mesmerising. I found myself captivated and cannot comprehend how such beauty was created so long ago. These ruins are well worth a visit and are a great place for any budding photographer. Enjoy!!
Amazing. Angkor Wat is the reason I came out here, but Bayon was the temple that I found to be really fascinating. The large faces were so different compared to the other temples, it was neat to see.

Don't miss it! Amazing place!. Ladies, get your sunscreen and sunglasses and running/hiking shoes ready. Bring water and towel too! This place is not something to be missed in Siem Reap. The temples and the architecture is really nice. Great photo op as well.

On the short circuit. If you meet a good tuk tuk driver stick with him. We went with a friends suggestion, wish we had taken the one we took the night before.Bayon is pretty. I think its the second on on the tour, sadly it blended into one temple. Sorry this is a terrible review!

The most interesting of the temples.. The story and the archaeology surrounding the Bayon Temple make it a must do when in Siem Reap. You can get some amazing photos here. Make sure you bring drinks with you though as there's not many places to hide from the sweltering heat!

Bayon Brilliance. Go early to enjoy some peace and tranquility. A beautiful temple. Unfortunately you will have to share the temple with crowds regardless. I was also very annoyed when I found out all of the entry fee money for all of the temples in the Angkar Wat area goes directly to Vietnam. Apparently after they intervened during Pol Pots genocidal reign of the country this is what they took in thanks. Personally I think Cambodia desperately needs that money to develop.

This temple made me come again!. This was my second trip to Siem Reap and I came this time to have more time in Bayon, Angor Wat, Preah Khan and Ta Prohm. I have fallen in love with Siem Reap and these beautiful and majestic temples.Comparing with my last trip in July and this one in September, I prefer to come during early monsoon when the places will be less damp with out much moss on the temples and yet not very dry like in the peak season.
Temple with faces. Must do -you get to Bayon through South Gate which itself is impressive -has a Wow Factor -If you only have one day In Siem Riep This is must do!

Best Temple. I visited this temple with a family of four and it was the best temple in the Angkor Temple Complex...... but ssssh don't tell. It had no crowds of people, very few hawkers and it was so very very quiet. I got some amazing pictures, and the overall feel of this place, is like it is something special...... This is a MUST see temple.

This is the temple with the Giant Stone Faces. Fascinating mysterious temple. Beautifully preserved bas-reliefs. We were fortunate to be on a Gate 1 tour. They engaged Hoy Pheakdey as our local guide and we would certainly recommend his services. We also read the novel Temple of a 1000 Faces by John Shors prior to going which helps understand the context. Plan to reread now that we are home.

Great architecture. Lovely architecture. Majestic and truly awesome! And it's great that everything is so close by. Travelling from one temple to another within the city of Angkor was really easy and saved us a lot of "lost" travelling time.
Wonder full temple with history. With rich in history of Buddhism philosophy , Bayon temple show up with warmly welcome of many smiling face of Buddha deeply impressive.

Travelling back in time. Bayon Temple is an absolute must to visit! When we arrive, we were pretty amaze with the whole structure. Furthermore, we were thinking how could rocks of different sizes able to come together making such a wonderful structure. Taking a closer look to the rocks, you will definitely see carvings of the past and if you place your hands on the rocks, you will find it cold even the sun is shining brightly above your head. It is a wonderful visit to the place and we are still amaze how people in the past are able to build this place.

Beautiful. I think one of the finest temple in the complex. Our first stop and introduction to Angkor Temples. The atmosphere in the area is one of solemnity. Ancient ruins, the faces, the gate everything is great. Get a good guide that can tell you the history of the place. Take your time and soak it all in.
Loved It. Enjoyed this Temple even more than Angkor Wat - is that allowed? We saw it in the late afternoon where the reflections on the surrounding ponds just made it magical.

The Jewel in the Angkor Thom Crown. Second only to Angkor Wat for popularity and importance the main temple complex of the Angkor Thom area is a must visit. Amazingly it was built after Angkor Wat but seems somehow less sophisticated. The guide books reveal that consequent rulers kept remodelling Bayon rather than build a new temple complex elsewhere and the scale of Angkor Thom (inside which is located Bayon) suggests that a very major city must have been located there at that time.Bayon is, of course, famous for the diversity and multitude of faces carved into the walls and towers of this temple.
Stunning. My favourite temple. If you can only visit one temple then make it this one. Easy to reach within Siem Reap with wonderful monkeys dotting the way.

Best of the temples in Angkor Wat! Need to go before 2015!. Bayon is absolutely one of the best temples in Angkor Wat. The relics, the faces, atmosphere, everything are perfect. If you joined the sunrise tour in Angkor Wat, get here as soon as you're done with your sunrise shot. It's amazing in here when there're a lot of less people around.
Hotel tour guide was excellent.. Mr. Chet.. The hotel set up our tour guide. He was excellent! Private tour for my husband and I by Tuk-Tuk.. by choice!
My favorite temple with Ta Prohm. Take the time to walk in the surroundings: the nature is incredible. Also, go at the end of the day for the best pictures

Stone faces. I found this to be the best of the Temples I visited. The faces are a lot clearer than those on the others. The restoration is ongoing but already it has created a magnificient attraction. it was also not as crowded and less beggars and people trying to sell you crap souvenirs.

The Highlight of Angkor Wat. This is the smallest temple but by far my favourite. We went early and the light was beautiful it it was quiet and serene. I truly found this place mesmerising. It has a lot of soul and is right in the middle of the jungle. There are elephant rides nearby and the elephants appear to be well looked after and happy (I did a sneaky look at where they live after hours and they are chained by the foot but appear well fed and happy as they do like to work).

Loved this temple!. We visited this temple during a downpour so we pretty much had the place to ourselves. The grounds were flooded which added to the mysterious atmosphere in the temple and added a lot of color to the buildings. We really disliked all the extremely aggressive children shoving their wares in our face relentlessly and then making you feel bad when you couldn't possibly buy from all of them. This was the same at every temple.

One of the very best!. If you have just one or two days in Siem Reap, Bayon should be at the top of your temple list. The faces and architecture are incredible. Try to see it when it's raining for the best effect--bring an umbrella to cover your camera though!

Buddha, Buddha, Buddha & Buddha. Amazing temple with multiple smiling faces of Buddha. Can get very busy with tourists but with the Elephant Terrace and other temples around you don't feel to crowded in. A must see if you are only in Siem Reap for a short time!

The many faces of Bayon. Like almost all major temples in the Angkor precinct, the temple is undergoing restoration work and in my mind is in the top 3 in the area. The feature is the many handcarved faces. This temple must have been magnificent in its heyday 900 years ago and is a tribute to the tradesmen.Restoration will take many years and I would like to return when it is finished

Fascinating. Bayon temple is just awesome. If you are in Siem Reap and therefore probably visiting Angkor Wat, you must see Bayon as well. Why? Well, it is different in character to the other temples. The huge timeless stone faces stare out at you as you try to travel back in time to imagine life in such an advanced society so long long ago. You can view he faces front on of course, but you'll find lines of faces at different angles just staring, smiling . You can have a travel,buddy take shots of you 'kissing' their lips in perspective. Don' t be embarrassed everyone does it. We found there less people here compared to Angkor Wat. The Angkor Wat fee of $20 USD covers Bayon.
Lovely temple. This is a really beautiful temple just like all the other amazing temples near Siem Reap. All of them are a must see as each are different.

Beautiful. If you are short on time, make sure you put this one on your list. Stunning! I had read many reviews that suggested the faces carved in rock are breathtaking, haunting etc. All true, make sure you see it.

Bayon Temple. such a beautiful place. wonder how they can build such a beautiful place without modern tools.
I still can remember this today the angkor beautiful site and the cambodian ppl they very polite

amazing temple. This temple in the angkor area surely is amazing...you can enter this temple en be surrounded by more than hunderds faces carved into stones watching at different directions...the place is not as big as " angkor wat " but surely amazing to see...

go early to this temple. Beautiful and unique...Best seen early if possible...I try and get out to my favorite temples at 6AM!...Few (and in some cases no people) cool weather...Great shots with a rising sun...and in some cases amazing wildlife (before the crowds)
Great temple. actually it makes me wonder, a beautiful old and historically valued monument in the middle of no where
Best temple. From the distance it seems like a pile of rocks but when you get there, you will see lots of faces. Great to get awesome shots. This is a must see in Angkor Tom

Just as good as Ankor!. Don't let Ankor Wat overshadow this gem! This was by far one of my favorite temples. Such a fun happy place. I loved that you can still climb all over everything although I don't think that is really ideal for the preservation of such an amazing place. Once back home it's not pictures of Ankor Wat that are hanging in my office, it's pictures of Bayon.

The pride of Angkor Thom & top 3 overall. Incredible effort went into the construction and detailing of Bayon judging by the gorgeous results. Literally a different photo op with every step. This is not one to be missed as it is distinctly different from the others. See it in the early morning light for best effect and unfettered access.
Amazing. Very beautiful and serene close to sunset. We came back to visit this temple again. Took some wonderful photographs with the many faces
Excellent Temple. This is a large temple with some lovely carvings. One of the must-see temples close to Siem Reap. Allow some time to see this temple as it extends over quite a distance.

Beautiful Park, Great Ruins, Impressive Scenery. Easy place to visit with a lot of history and beauty. Lovely grounds, fascinating carvings. One of the easiest places to enjoy and appreciate. Go with a good tour guide like the English speaker we used as our guide and driver. Makes a huge difference.

The best temple in Siem Reap. We loved this temple, definitely the best in Siem Reap, a must see! We went in the afternoon, it was warm and sunny with few people which was great to really enjoy the the atmosphere and get some great photographs. An hour is enough time to walk around this temple which is part of the Angkor Wat complex.

Very Unique, Mysterious& Beautiful. Very different from the other temples with the massive stone faces on many towers of the temple. You find smiling faces staring down at you from all around. Great photo opportunity. I am still in awe of the temple even though it was my second visit. A must see.

If only I could score it 9 :). Bayon is definietly my most favorite temple in siem so far. After seeing many ancient temples in india,to me this temple almost close to their origin back there.it reminds me of hampi a bit.Its nice to see shesha (7 headed snake) also here. wherever I go I witness many beautiful temples,and most of them are from hindu-indian.the indian shud be proud abt this :) and for bayon,u can just roam around everywhere,each spot has its own detail. I went there with my tuktuk driver who s also a good photographer kimleng sang (u can google him),he showed me good spots in bayon to take pic and none of my pic has other people in it.we never encountered crowd except at the entrance. Good place, good guide is wat u need actually. This temple to me is even more beautiful than the angkor vat itself. Enjoy :)

One of the best sites. This complex is huge with an amazing story behind it. Don't miss the Royal Palace at the extreme left of the Angkor Thom site. It does get a lot of tourists but because the whole site is so large there is lots to see. A guide will really help in explaining the history behind the site.

I love it. All the archeological site is beautiful, go there early morning to better enjoy this magnificent place.It's so hot during the SE Asian summer( april-may) but it's liveable, if you avoid the hottest day time.

A must See. My favourite building in a really amazing area.Visited Angkor in November, enjoyed the special mood of few visitors and the perfect climate.I recommend the sunrise visit even if the crowd is there too.

Absolutely stunning temple ruins. This is part of the Angkor Wat complex, and even if you don't have time to "do" much of this huge area, you should go there for the fabulous heads of Buddha and the richness of the decorated stone - It was a Buddhist temple from day one. Even if you are not Buddhist or even religious, you will be moved by its beauty.

Extraordinary. Has to be seen to be believed! Enormous carved faces at every angle you turn.The best time to see it and photograph it, is probably towards the end of the day or very early,. A serene place.. and very accessible compared to some of the other larger temples.

Amazing temple, go early to avoid lots of other tourists. This is amazing and beautiful, but go very early in the morning, say straight after sunrise at Angkor Wat to get there before the rush of tourist buses! It would be worth the early morning wake up. We went in the morning, but not early enough & there were way too many people there, but it was awesome all the same.

The many faces of Jayavarman VII. This temple is one of the most heavily visited, and justifiably so; it is wonderful. To see it a whole different way, I recommend a sunrise visit. I had the place mostly to myself, honestly only 1 or 2 other people around. Really gives you the chance to experience the temple in a special way.

Unbelievable temple. This is another must see. It is not that big, but achieves an extreme degree of fascination. It's the most interesting and creative temple in the whole area of Angkor Thom, and hosts hundreds of smiling faces of King Jayavarman VII, the King Builder. Wherever you walk you are assured that several faces look down on you with their enigmatic appearance. The only downside is the astonishing number of visitors that flow along the corridors and walls and stairs. Simply unbelievable, likewise the temple itself, nonetheless the visit is an absolute MUST, no stay at the archaeological park would be complete without a visit to Bayon.And the bas-reliefs are simply extraordinary.
Smiling Bayon Temple. That is what I personally call this temple. Smiling faces all around the place. Magnificent! One of my favorite. I hope these temple stays longer for generations to see.

The Jewell in the crown.. In a park absolutely full of magnificent temples this for me is the best. The work that has gone into the faces is just wonderful and after all these years they have taken on an almost haunting beauty. Definitely an absolute must see in Angkor.

This temple is amazing. The Bayon and all of Anchor Tom is an absolute must for all visitors to the area. Try to avoid arriving early morning as we did as this is when all the bus tours arrive. We hung around for a few hours, sitting and contemplating what it must have been like when it was built and also watching all the different people visiting, and by 11.30 almost everyone had left.

Our favorite. One of our favorite temples. The faces are so impressive and well preserved. It was not too busy when we were there so it was comfortable and you could explore without dodging people and cameras, unlike Angkor Thom.

Bayon Temple. Built in the late 12 and 13 centuries AD, the temple is one of the largest Mahayana Buddhist temples in the Angkor complex. The distinctive feature is the serene stone faces of the towers.
It is dream come true for me. Wow....how are the temples surviving with hundred feet long trees on them...i liked it ...If it was not so humid, i would have spent more time here.
Nice walk thru the past. The Elephant Trace at the Bayon Temple was on my favorite attraction. Impressive statues and designs.

Sublime!. This was probably our favorite of the temples at Angkor with its great atmosphere and haunting faces looking in every direction. The only downside to the whole experience is the sheer numbers of visitors, especially large tour groups who each want to have their photo taken in front of every photo opportunity! truly beautiful.

OMG!!. it's so nice and i keep wondering how the ancient people built them throughout my visit to Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom. Bayon temple is a must-visit temple, there are 208 faces of the King Jayavarman VII, with different facial expressions. Although i'm not sure i've found the face with the greatest smile, but i love it very much!The off-side is too crowded! Should plan a different time to visit to avoid the crowd, i can't really enjoy to see the carvings since so many tourists taking photos.
magnificient. A truly awe-inspiring piece of architecture. Carry a good guide book or hire a tour guide to get to know all the stories about the place...
Famous smiling faces and towers. The 4-face Buddha representing the four sublime states in Buddhism. Compassion. Sympathy. Equanimity. Charity.They are magnificent, fascinating and mystical
Very nicely preserved. Definitely worth seeing. Lots of serene faces in the stonework. It is within the Angkor Thom complex.
Impressive. The faces sculpted in Bayon Temple are unique! They look like real faces emerging from the rock. I loved it!

Faces are all around in Bayon. Yes, i like Bayon temple! a temple which full of miracles!Although some of the stones and parts of the huge faces were dropped off, but it's still looks amazing and beautiful! Love the massive smiling on the huge faces.A MUST GO TEMPLE in Siem Reap!! will definitely be back!!!

Awesome Temple. The trees growing amaong the temple gave spectacular photo opportunities. The guide we had for the day was also ver knowledgable about the temple. They have started to restore this temple also and would love to return in about 10 years to see the end results

Must see, very busy though. Definitely number two on the "must see" temple list in Siem Reap. Don't expect to be able to move though, as it's not very big in relation to the number of tourists that visit it.

Hauntingly beautiful. I actually enjoyed Bayon Temple more than Angkor Wat. There were too many repairs at Angkor Wat at that time. The faces etched on the walls are haunting and beautiful at the same time. Must-visit!

One of the most elaborate temples.. This one is a gem of the temples. There was a little construction going on, but there are many carved faces and very detailed wall carvings at this one.
If you're trying to plan a short trip and can only see certain temples, make sure this is one of them.
one of the most beautiful temple in the Angkor Wat complex.. the most interesting part is a big tree stand on the temple. The road condition is bad and it was raining which is difficult to walk

I liked this temple the best... I liked this temple the best because I thought it was the most beautiful. It was like a maze, but that was kind of awesome.. Recommend doing this on a Temple Tour of some kind. We had a car, so we didn't have a guide. You have to pay to get into the national park area.

Unbelievable. Could have wandered for hours. Wear suitable clothing and be careful, younger children are not permitted in some places. Were there at end of rainy season which might have helped limit the number of tourists as it never felt over crowded.

love the base relief depicting daily life.. If you only see two temples,Angkor Wat and Bayon should be the ones. The giant stone faces of Bayon have become one of the most recognizable images connected to classic Khmer art and architecture. There are 37 standing towers,most but not all sporting four carved faces oriented towards the cardinal points. Who the faces represent is a matter of debate.... The best of Bayon are the base-relief on the exterior walls where the stone faces reside. The realism of the southern wall base-relief is uncanny....a sea battle between Khmer and the cham. Even more interesting are extensive carvings depicting everyday life that are interspersed among the battle scenes,including market scenes,cockfighting,chess games and child birth. The surrounding tall jungle makes Bayon a bit dark and flat for the photographic purists who gather here every sunrise and sunset. Spectacular

Must See. This is one of the must see temples. The picture op with the people in cultural costumes is worth the $US2. Nice contrast of the colourful costumes again the grey/black background of the temple
Very Interesting. This temple is one of the smaller temples but has a great history. They are repairing it at the moment so you do have to be careful were you step at times.

One of the most amazing temples. The best way to enjoy this amazing temple is to skip the sunrise in Angkor Wat and go directly to Bayon, if you do so, it basically will be for yourself and that becomes really fantastic, with all the Hugh faces, and the solitude is just amazing!

Vast Temple Complex. This is a must visit temple of Siem Reap. We were guided by one of the English speaking guides and it made a difference as he pointed out many things to us, described the history and also took pictures of us and showed us where unique pictures could be taken. The Bayon style depicts a 4 faced Buddha each looking at the 4 points of the compass. There will be quite a bit to see and more importantly be ready to walk around and climb about to see the many faces at Bayon.

massive smiling stone faces. The temple with the massive smiling stone faces is personally my favorite among all the temples. Expect walking and climbing steep stairways and lots of photo opportunities too. There is a part in the temple where you can portray as kissing the stone 'face' if taken at a certain angle! A personal tour guide is recommended while going around as they know more stories, history and whereabouts. The temple does not only show these huge stone faces but as well as interesting wall gallery showing a bit of Khmer history. Outside the temple one can also enjoy an elephant ride, around $15 usd pp to go around the temple (which we skipped btw). Although renovations/conservations were going on in some areas it is very much worth going to!
Faces every where.. Giant stone faces every where . A must see . This was my favorite temple of them all the others had to much renovation going on.

amazing tour. Brilliant tour loved it, i would recomend steeped in history should be on everyones list.
we organised an independant tour guide who was very experienced and knowledgeable in the history of the temples

Many Faces. This is one of the better temples to go to, especially if you have kids, they love counting the faces and there is the added bonus of a possible elephant ride around the temple, if the parents let them. Make sure you have a guide, not just to this temple but to all the temples as they give you little pieces of interesting information.

Faces! Everywhere!. It makes me scared because all of those faces, but it's really amazed me that people in 12th century can built such of those details! Anyway, it was really fun hanging out here, spent 30-60 minutes is enough.

If possible get a good guide. It's a very beautiful temple with 216 faces. The ticket price that u pay to get in Angkor will cover these temples as well. Out of all the 216 faces there is only one face which is mailing the most.. Remember to take a click of it!

One step closer to heaven. Yes, I took one step closer to the stairs where it leads to heaven...or supposedly that's what I was told by the tour guide. Either way, it was a wonderful experience checking out the Bayon Temple and learned how it was built. Even with today's technology, I don't think we could build it as perfectly as it was built back then. Makes you wonder, doesn't it????

There are faces everywhere!. This place is also amazing like Angkor Wat, and it was fun trying to count how many faces are there in this temple. It just gets a bit crowded with all the tourists roaming so it was a bit difficult to move around.
What an amazing temple. You have to see this to believe it. What strangler figs can do. This place gets many photos I sure. Just wander around the temple and see the tree root pattern

My favorite. Better than Angkor Wat. The temple with the four-sided faces was the best and not to be missed! The character at some of the temples here was excellent, with moss growing in just the right places, stones cracking in interesting ways, and overall a less touristy and more authentic feel than Angkor Wat.Go for the "Small Tour" with a tuk-tuk driver or tour guide and make sure to budget enough time (3-4 hours) at Bayon.

Magnificent Temple. This temple is so beautiful! My favorite among the temples that we visited. It's small compared to the Angkor Wat but I enjoyed exploring it. The walls say a lot about their history, war, their kings and beautiful women. The Buddha heads are spectacular and you would wonder how these were done so many years ago with just bare hands. Just dont go to this place at around 11am because it is soooo hot!
rainy day. beautiful temple!! i went on a rainy day and that did not prevent me from exploring its grounds. the four faces on the temple pillars make this a really unique building

An historical gem in a city full of wonders. When you go to Siem Reap, all you think of is seeing the famous Angkor Wat. The splendor of the place really overshadows nearly everything else there, which is a shame. Bayon Temple is much smaller, but no less spectacular and no less historically significant.Our group spent a good 2 hours at the site, where we were given in-depth knowledge of its history by a very professional Cambodian guide. The temple is a photographer's dream come true. Shots from every angle came out amazing. I thoroughly enjoyed learning about the sculptures and the wall bas-relief. Being a Thai, it was enlightening to learn of the ancient connection between the Siamese and Khmer civilizations that Thai history books neglected or forgot to tell you.One of the most pleasant things about visiting Bayon is the absence of massive crowds you find at Angkor Wat. There are still a number of visitors there, but you can still do your own search for hidden corners and photo ops in relative peace. There will, of course, be the occasional noisy groups, but overall Bayon Temple offers a true learning experience. It is definitely a must visit in Siem Reap.

Their eyes are everywhere. We came here just after the sunset view of Angkor Wat. The place had a very eerie feel at dawn- it felt like you were being watched from every angle- very mysterious temple with oodles of character.

The temple of many faces. The giant stone faces of Bayon have become one of the most recognizable images connected to classic Khmer art and architecture. There are 37 standing towers and most have four carved faces oriented toward the cardinal points.  There is a statue of Buddha called the Happy Home Buddha - a seated figure with an umbrella behind the back. The flowers are real as is some of the fruit put their by devotees. The incense was lit when I was there. There was a linga or lingum which s a religious phallic symbol symbolic of the Hindu god Shiva and of creative power. The linga is implanted in a flat square base called a yoni, symbolic of the womb.There are over 200 carved faces at Bayon and they evoke a feeling of peace as you look at the sightless eyes. One of the towers of the temple is depicted on the 200 Riel banknote.

nice photo taking site. Just back from cambodia after visiting Bayon temple on the 8/9.Great for photo taking but careful when you walk around some rock carving is a bit slippery.Just like other temple around here please take care of the elderly as there is some climbing which is a bit steep.
Simply breathtaking. Details of the structures were amazing. Nice place to take pictures too. Would be nice if there are more descriptions of the temple for self-guided tours.
Amazing. The Bayon temple was absolutely amazing, the face carvings were out of this world. Great photo opportunities here if you have a guide to advise you where to take your pictures.
Most impressive temple. A MUST GO when go to Siam Reap! Amazing rocks with a lot of faces in a superb huge size..Can't believe it was all hand crafted by people from old ancient..

FAVOURITE besides Angkor Wat!. Fascinating, breath taking, we were in awe the whole 3 days that we explored ALL the major temples......! What a site! HIghly recommendable, do not only go to see Angkor Wat, certainly the largest and maybe the most impressive one ? but Bayon is very special too............cannot recommend it enough!

Unique Faces. Its part of the Angkor Thom visit...this is one of the best sites to visit even if you were to be tired of Wats...for this is the place of those Uniquely designed and intriguingly alluring faces that invites the tourists
Lost in Nother world.. I loved this place, I got so carried away exploring I lost my husband for close to an hour!! Go get yourself lost in another world here....

Easy to Get Lost. Like most of our days at the temples we had a late morning start however this was to our advantage as by mid afternoon the temples are quieter and the hawkers have gone for a rest.So much so apart from another half dozen or so people wandering around our family got separated and I had a peaceful 10 minutes alone going around and around as the upper level can be quite disorientating.
Bayon temple. walking in Bayon Temple and watching the smiling of Cambodia, you will feel every smiling is different and very smiling is unik. Amazing, really amazing.

The architecture was superb. Went there and amazed with the architecture and felt proud that I am able to visit here before reaching 25 years old. Nice place, however, the cambodian gov or the NGO's involved in conservating this beautiful place must create a time limit and tourist limit to enter this temple. Did you guys know that constant foot step and human body weight do effect the structure of the building? Thus, allowing people with no limit to enter the temple at certain time must be avoided to save this place from any negative impact.

Smiles all Round. the temple complex was crowded (as expected) but the guide arranged for time alone and time to find a niche space to relfect.this a once in a lifetime place to come and it is definitely something that is as awesome as the Taj, Great Wall or the Burobudor.
Awesome. The Bayon temple was absolutely amazing, the face carvings were out of this world, of all the temples we visited, this was my favourite. Definitely not one to be missed.
I love this temple most!. This is the temple which I love most in Angkor. The smile buddha, the building, the texture..and everything..

Probably the coolest place I've ever seen. I know it's saying a lot, but Bayon Temple may just be the most awesome place I've ever been. I could hardly drag myself out of the temple again - I just wanted to keep exploring and look for good photo opportunities!

Fascinating faces. It's really impressive to stand in front of the tens of faces carved into the marble in this temple which is one of my favourite in Angkor Wat. Walking around, entering the dark cells, staring at the faces is a kind of enchantind ancestral experience
Amazing!. Along with all of the other temples that we visited, nothing more can be said than AMAZING!When we think how old these structures, one can only be amazed at the workmanship etc.
Great temple. I believe this is the one that was in the Angelina Jolie movie. It's a great temple, very busy- so show up early and bring a camera- so many opps for beautiful pics!

Old Soldier. I truly think this was the best of the temples. I also got to check one more thing off my bucket list. I rode a elephant. I also got another thing off my bucket list I have always wanted to see Angkor Wat. The palace is pretty impressive. TO be truthful you need more than one day to see everything.
Unbelievable. Bayon Temple as well as the rest of Angkor Archaelogical Site is unbelievable. Spend at least two days in Siem Reap in order to fathom this incredible world heritage site.

Beautiful. My favourite. Tell a parasol brolly (available in all market stalls) to shade you from the sun, and drink plenty of water. Keep your camera charged because you are guaranteed to be snapping away at this beauty!
Nice Temple. The Bayon temple was very big, however there were busloads of tourists continuously arriving. My advice would be to arrive early in the morning before the swarms of people arrive.
Amazing Faces. Loved this temple. The faces are incredible and the photos don't do it justice. Amazing to see in person. What incredible smiles.

Delicate beauty.. This is a smaller temple in the Siem Reap area. Its delicate beauty is very appealing after being so overwhelmed by the grandeur of Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom. I felt I could relate to the statues and carvings more intimately and really enjoyed my brief visit there.
Nice temple. Bayon temple is also nice but i guess we just have favorites to compare to, Ta Phrom, Angkor wat, Pre Rup and Bantay Srei which are remarkably beautiful than Bayon temple.

Favorite Temple!. If you grew up in the '90's you might be familiar with the show Legends of the Hidden Temple, Bayon looks just like that temple! It was a blast wandering through it and reminiscing about that show. The temple was gorgeous. I recommend grabbing a book on the temples from one of the book vendors ($5-7) or hiring a guide.

Do it!!!. Do it, just do it!!
You won't be disappointed!!
This place will blow your mind.
The way nature inter-twines with heritage is something not to be missed!!
Beautiful 216 face statues. There are 216 face statues in the Bayon temple. Enjoy taking picture with kissing style with the statue is the best place in the world.
A Wonder. Mystical charm with many faces of Buddha looking onto you, a site not to be missed. You will be in awe of its architecture with the myriad of wall carvings telling its stories.

Doing Time in the Universal Mind. This was one of my favorite temples on this trip. All the faces were so interesting and it felt like a very interactive temple.
Loads of tourists but you can't do anything about that!
Cannot believe I was there!. Just perfect and amazing! Seemed like I was in angelina jolie movie! For sure a must visit site! The most amazing temple I visited during my journey!

Bayon Temple. This is 'Angkor Thom' you need at least one day to explore this area and temples around, mostly over shadowed by famous Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom is much bigger than Wat, This was once the capital of Khmer Empire and surrendered by walls.
Best time to visit is during cool season, you can not bare the heat otherwise.
Excellent history. I liked every thing. So much about the culture and rich Hindu history linked with India.lots of fun and enjoyment.good weather.very friendly people.lots of walking place.

My favourite temple!. With 37 towers (remaining) and the distinctive massive stone faces on each tower, The Bayon is the most enigmatic and powerful Khmer temple. The towers jut out from the upper terrace and cluster around the centre peak. Walk along the outer wall, and there is a massive stone craving that depicts Khmer lifestyle at that time
Temple of huge faces of the Buddha. All around the temple the huge serene faces of the Buddha on the towers stand out, compared to Angkor wat, this is a smaller temple, but definitely worth visiting.

lovely stone faces!. Its absolutely breath-taking! The intricate details on each of the carvings all around the temple and the stone faces is a reflection of the hard labor and dedication made by Khmer people during the 12th century. Carvings on the wall tell lots of story about ancient Khmer people, their history and their way of life. Bayon temple is found inside the Angkor Thom. Watch your step on stairs though, you might trip and fall.

Amazing ancient architecture. It is really hot and exposed out there so take a hat, sunscreen and water. Oh, and a good camera as you will feel like you are the first to discover ancient relics of the past
Bayan Rocks - Heads rule.. Bayan is my favorite temple in Cambodia. Go late to enjoy this temple and others when the crowds have gone back to their hotels.
Magical!. Amazing temple ruins to walk around and learn about Cambodia's Buddhist history. I really enjoyed our visit to the Bayon temple and it's history.

awesome.... the whole city of angkor is just awesome....the city is beyond your imagination n i thank god it was kept safe from the civil war...
the guides were great. they knew their history well n shared their knowledge with such pride n humbility too. cambodians truly fulfill graciousness to the t

Not as impressive as Angkor wat but still amazing. All of these temples are simply amazing make sure you have a look at the carved panels in the outer walls that have a story in it. read it from left to right. PAY FOR A GUIDE, you will get so much more out of it
Temples. We saw many temples, and like churches, there can be overload as you don't remember everything that is said.
Amazing Architecture. Such an amazing atmosphere that can not be described or understood unless you have experienced it yourself.
Amazing temple. Amazing temple that actually build thousands of years ago. Please bring along camera and water with you cause lots of beautiful scene and walking here.
Such a special place. Go, wait until the busses of tourists leave and just be quiet there. A very unusual place. Just feel it.

Awesome. A temple well worth visiting, but a hot tip, do it after 1430, as this is the time when most of the tours have been completed. We had it almost to ourselves, and we explored it like we were Indiana Jones. The architecture is magnificent, and you could just stand there for hours wondering at the people who built it.

Beat the busloads!. It's definitely a beautiful temple, the downside is that it's where almost ALL the tourist buses go and stop, so you have so many people around here, you just have to make sure you beat a tourist bus if you want photographs that aren't too rushed and full of people wearing different colored clothing!
Almost surreal. A beautiful temple. Maybe a bit of a climb, but once you;re up there, it's worth it.Take the time also to walk through the lower levels.

Breathtaking Temple views. Approach from the south gate and begin the tour with stunning views. The site is slightly smaller than Angkor Wat, but also with fewer tourists. Circum-ambulate the site from the outside, and you'll get a great view of the entire temple.

Marvellous. What a beautiful place to spend and evening and while the sun sets. There are loads of faces around the temples made in stone. So unique and authentic and it makes you appreciate what all the workers thousands of years have done without the tools we have now. Amazing.
A happy gem.. We were hot and tired, so we just drove by this temple. In hindsight I wish we would have walked around. So many pictures to take of the smiling faces.
My Favourite temple. The serene faces are truly amazing. If you only pick a few to look at make sure you include this one. It's easy to access.

BAYON TEMPLE. If you love historical places than this will be the place. I am from Singapore. I also see this place in the web. When I visit this place , wow! I fall in love with the temple. Which ever angle you look at it, faces you see Lord Vishnu or four face Buddha.

awesome. we came on a tour, to Bayon temple, it was just amazing, just awesome to see. The faces are huge, it is just so beautiful, and just think about how old the are,
a must when you go to Siem Reap. doent miss it!
Eerily beautiful!. This is the temple with the faces carved into the stones--part of the Angkor Thom complex. Fascinating!
Simply awesome and a must visit. One of our big four for the day. Simply awesome and a must visit. A word of warning - lots of stairs, but well worth it.

Well-preserved turrets. Get the 3-day pass. Best to see in the morning when the sun's not too harsh. Walk back from the temple through the dry side of the marsh so you can walk to the small bridge that leads to the Terrace of the Leper King
WOW!!. Go as early as possible to avoid the crowds. The sunset rise was amazing but getting up at 4,45 for a 5am start although hard, worth it!

A place you have to visit before you die, if you like ancient civilizations.. For practical outstanding purposes, there a small difference between the main Angkor Wat and other temples. For short, the place is a must if you are an enthusiast of ancient civilization. Be aware of Chinese tours. They take dominion of the place because usually they are many people not respecting other persons’ in terms of space and sound. Anyway, only for this reason try to go now instead of tomorrow.

Cute faces. Don't think anyone would use e word cute to describe a temple but I really thought this was one of the more interesting temples to visit even if you do no have interest in history. You can take nose to nose profile pictures with the faces. I especially like the face with a great big smile, the same one found on souvenir magnets.

The Faces Temple. Very popular temple at Angkor Wat-- this is the one with all the faces! This one was very crowded, but definitely worth walking through. Every once in a while, I'd become accustomed to everything that surrounded me and I needed to just stop and remind myself how old all of this is... and then I'd be amazed all over again!
Probably the Best of all at Angkor Wat. There are a lot of temples within Angkor Wat. It's personal taste of course, but this was the best of the ones we visited (and we saw quite a few!)

Awesome. Fourth time around and still as awesome! The architecture and faces never fail to amaze. Loads of photo ops at doorways and windows with intricate carvings and best of all with faces all around.Try to go very early before the crowds arrive for best views.

Another Classic Temple. This is another of the main temples visited by all tourists. But there is a reason for that. The amazing architecture and the smiling heads give this an interesting difference to other temples in the Angkor Thom complex.

Stunning Place to wander around. Just loved the architecture of this place. From the outside it looks amazing but its beauty is seen from inside with all the different faces you see. Excellent for photos too.
the faithful face. i loved this temple coz its so unique with all those massive faces and only one of them on the top has a smiling face!!! mythical and mundane

Stunning!. Amazing place to visit! Would recommend doing it early in the morning, around 530am. That way you get to see the sunrise at Angkor Wat then beat everyone to the other temples. Barely anyone was at bayan at this time.
Coolest place to see. Out of all the temples, this one was definitely one of my favourites. It was just so cool to see the structure of it and the area in general. It had the "wow" factor for sure.
Fantastic. One of the magic temples in Angkor. Close to 40 4-faced Buddha statues towering over you. Just walk around and let yourself be inspired

Faces!. The temple is often missed or skipped because of Angkor Wat, but it is impressive. The faces and restoration of the temple are impressive, and the hundreds of faces are very cool! A must see when checking out the temples in the area.
One of the best in Angkor... This temple is situated inside Angkor Thom. Very good for taking pictures. This is one of the temples where the smiling buddha's face is intact.
Best of all temples. Bayon was like walking into a video game. There's a lot to see! It gets hot during the day but it's worth the trip! Make sure to take plenty of water!
a must. If you go to Angkor Wat, you must visit this temple too. The faces are fascinating and you can have great fun trying to take the perfect picture
Amazing place!. the best for pictures are 7:00a.m.-9:00a.m. and 16:00p.m.-18:00p.m. the shadow on the 216 smiling faces is changable and mysterious!

Unbelievably amazing.. I am obsessed with this temple. I went 4 times during my 5 day stay! You have to go either at 6 am-8 am or from 4:30-closing. Otherwise, it's too crowded. Wherever you look, you will see the faces of Bayon looking at you. It was one of the best experiences of my life!

Thousand Faces. A must go! It's amazing to see faces everywhere you look! Definitely worth going to. Inside the temple is a great place to have a photoshoot! It's also easy to get lost inside the huge temple, so always be alert on where you went up because you must go down via that route as well.

One of my favourites!. A beautiful temple, see it later in the day when the rush of tourists has gone home! And prepare for beautiful children to convince you to give them your money, they are gifted swindlers but I loved them anyway! The whole Bayon complex is beautiful, give yourself some time to enjoy it and experience it!
Best in Angkor. This was the temple I most enjoyed in the Angkor complex - the ruins are well preserved with the carvings still visible, and it is overall very impressive
Nice Temple. People's favorite, and it is expected, the design in this temple is one of the most complicated of all, the four faces relief was really nice

Truly amazing. I love this temple compared to the rest. The architecture work and carving is simple majestic. I was truly amazed that back in the 12th Century such artistic work can be produced. I would love to see the actual temple then when it was running. I would definitely go back for a second visit to be mesmerized by the natural beauty of this temple.
Must visit. Yes i love it which It is the main attractive point to know about the culture and history of Cambodia

Our Favourite temple. Our guide described it to us as the faces temple... Angkor Wat was impressive but this was our favourite. The details that went into carving the faces from stones is spectacular, lots of great spots to take pics our guide had us standing in a specific place and the pics looked like where up close to the face when is reality we were standing far away.If you don't have a guide don't worry just look at where people are standing waiting to take individual shots and you have figured out the locations of the photo spot.
Amazing.... this place is an exceptional architectural heritage! was an extremely unique experience and a pleasure to photograph

Peaceful, cooler, temple top views.. One of my favourite temples in the Angkor Archeological Park but each & every one has a special something. Try and climb to the top tier of this particular temple where you'll find great views of the tree canopy & some bird spotting.

Great!. My most favorite temple besides Angkor Wat. Amazing stone carvings all around... great piece of ancient history... amazing!

amazing. what use to be more towers has now crumbled thru the passage of time... workers were seen restoring this beautiful architecture and i must say.. parts of it looks like the athens city but i call it the Asian Athens... faces of Buddhas are everywhere and see if you can find the smiliest one. Top 3 temple to visit in Siam Reap if you are on a short trip..

favourite temple. This was our most favourite temple. The many faces carved into the stone, and the actual size was fantastic. We wondered around for ages looking at the different rooms and admiring the stonework, doorways and the wonderful faces. Will be coming back to this one next time.
Nice temple. Love the many manysmiling budhha in this Temple. It's so peaceful and quiet...Captured a lot of nice pictures in there.

Budha peaceful faces.... I really like this temple..
As part of the Angkor Archaeological Park, Bayon has been famous for its amazing collection of Budha faces...
Unique indeed and many to see..
There are several famous spot for photos with perfect frame of Budha face :D..
Don't miss it...
Something you need to see. Can't write about it, it's something you need to see by yourself and will not be sorry. It's worth a couple of days in Cambodia just for the temples.

under reconstruction.. They are reconstructing the place and most of it is reconstructed but it doesnt fail to amaze visitors just by the sheer size!
Things the Bayon was loved by us was its size, the panels and the huge faces that is all over the Ruins.

The best temple in Siem Reap. For me this is the best temple in Siem Reap. The faces engraved in each temple are just amazing and beautiful. Despite the scorching sun, I can't help but take the picture of each faces in the temple. Each one is unique. Truly fascinating.

More awe-inspiring than Angkor Wat. The Bayon appears from the trees as you enter Angkor Thom, it rises majestically and the faces add mystery. Angkor Thom was obviously built by a different king and hence has an entirely different style to Angkor Wat.
Although it is more compact, you can still find a quiet spot to take it all in. Well worth the effort.

Bayon. It was serene and beautiful! A lot of walking, but worth it if you like archaeological sites. If you are lucky you may see monkeys. The one thing I did not like was the selling of goods by the locals.

Serene and tranquil place. It looked out of this world! There were many giant Buddha faces smiling serenely at you, but not too obviously - apparently there are 216 of them but it is probably impossible to spot all of them. However, the tranquility of the place was destroyed by the numerous tourists visiting. Try to visit early in the morning when there are less people

Buddha galore!. Beautiful temple with the face of buddha on all four sides of every pillar and there are 96 pillars (if im not wrong!). There are works of restoration in progress but much of the old stones still remain and is a must see! Its very close to Bapon temple and elephant temple, so you could actually see all 3 in one visit!
Gotta see Temple from Angkor Thom.. In the center of Angkor Thom, this is a must see when visiting Siem Reap. Go early or late, because it gets very crowded in the hot afternoon.

Great Temple. We went straight to Bayon after sunrise at Angkor Wat and nearly had it to ourselves - loved the individual style of the temple with all the faces... one of our favourites along with Ta Prohm.
Faces Galour. A great temple, big crowds but plenty of room to move around. Too many great photo opportunities to list. The smiling faces are quite eerie when you get a quiet area to yourself.

Great temple. I was been visit Cambodia in July. I went to Bayon temple it is amazing whole the building made by stone all point. So many temple in Siem Reap are but best and maint point only Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom and Ta Prom temple. But other was amazing as well as. I will be back again if i have holiday and will plan to Siem Reap again.

A must-see!. A stunning Temple and stone carvings which make one wonder how such relics were built so long ago.Definitely to be visited between sunrise and 10 am before huge crowds arrive. Also include Royal Palace and Terrace of Elephants nearby.Ensure pants cover your knees if you want to go inside Royal Palace as clothing rule applies

Too many people in this temple. There were too many tour group in this temple in the morning arond 9:00 - 11:00, therefore I suggest you 'd better avoid such rush four to visit this famous temple. Then you may have better experience with Khmer Smile.
Stunning. Loved everything about this temple. We visited in late July so there was the usual afternoon rains to deal with, so make sure you have an umbrella or poncho.

Many Faces. A very interesting temple complex with many multi faced towers. Can easily get congested when a tour bus unloads. If you can do a little wall climbing, you can get some fantastic pictures.
Prettiest temple around!. Most beautiful temple to visit in the Angkor Archaeological park. Worth a longer visit then all the other temples.

My favourite temple by far. Do not miss this one out.. There are so many wonderful temples to see in Siem Reap but do not miss this one out. 54 columns 216 smiling Buddhas. To me this was my favourite. Gets very busy and suggest you go mid morning as if can be packed first thing as all tours seem to start the same way.

Not that eerie. The many 'faces' were cool rather than eerie imo. Spectacular views whether at the bottom or at the top of the temple. Advisable to head there first instead of Angkor Wat, right after sunrise, to avoid the crowds

The Famous Faces. We have all seen these faces all too often in books, magazines, documentaries and travel paraphernalia but to be here among these most astonishing smiling faces carved out of massive pieces of stone is one great hard-to-explain feeling.Prasat Bayon or The Bayon Temple was built by King Jayavarman VII of the Khmer Empire and sits in the very centre of Angkor Thom, which was the capital city of the Khmer Empire and fortified by a 3.0 km by 3.0 km wall all around. It is said that the distance from any of the five tower gates to the Bayon temple measures 1.5km. It is even said that the walls of the Bayon temple were constructed to run north-south and also east-west and that the four faces that adorn every single tower structure had also been amazingly designed to face the four cardinal points (the four main points of the compass).There are countless towers with the serene faces, some people even calling them smiling faces and it’s really hard to imagine the arduous tasks and unparalleled skills of the artisans of that era who have actually immortalized these stone sculptures, which were not carved out of one single piece of rock but a combination of a number of big rocks put together to create each face. They are said to depict the face of Bodhisattva Avalokiteshvara but there are some who say that among these faces are some which depicts King Jayavarman VII’s face as well. Apart from the faces, there were so many bas-reliefs on the walls of the lower and also the upper levels of the temple depicting everyday folk lore, battle scenes and even the Apsara dances, and these carvings on the walls are still so sharp and crisp, considering the age of the building. The craftsmanship is really intriguing.Everywhere you turn you see these huge smiling faces and this exudes a calming effect on most people visiting the Bayon, which is one of my two favourite temples in the Angkor Archaeological Park area, the other being Ta Prohm Temple. Bayon is a fascinating temple and is a must-visit site in Cambodia.

Friendly Faces. This temple was perhaps the most enjoyable for me. I got many nice photos with the smiling faces. I went at mid day and the crowds were mangeable and not too annoying but would be great early morning.
Ruined Temples. What you see are the ruined temples and have to be careful when you go round them. It is one of the biggest temple in Angkor Thom.

One of the Must See Place in Siem Reap. Bayon impreesed us since arriving till leaving. Found the only open-eyed and wide smiling one is fantastic. But once u can do the nose-to-nose make it even better.

Our preferred temple. This was the second temple that we visited.Those figures are really impressive and you can feel that something is happening hereThe temple was far less crowded than Angkor Wat and this was maybe why it was our preferred temple.A must to be seen.

Perhaps my favourite temple. Because I am a real keen photographer, I think this temple was the best photo opportunity. But mostly, to stand outside and wonder at how this was sculpted and built all those years ago is pretty mind blowing

A happy place to be. I could have spent all day here with the happy faces and beautiful architecture. Big enough so the the large crowds aren't a problem- you can always find an area to sit and admire the beauty without the large bus full of tourists arriving along with you.

Excellent temple, different from the others. Everything about the temple impressed us, the style, the building technique and the photo poses. You better see this if you have limited time. This is our favourite temples after 2 days
316 smilling faces. How could you miss these Angkor smiling faces? Go to Siem Reap and "zap" Bayon, it will be really sad !

don't miss. The detailed art on virtually every wall, the architecture, and, of course, the faces of the king looking everywhere are not to be missed. Get your guide to describe the meaning of the wall art on the outer walls.
One for the bucket list. Go for sun rise and beat the crowds. Hire a monk to make your pictures more interesting. Make photo magic.

Enough to name your kid after it. One of the most magical places you might ever get the chance to visit in your entire life. Do not rush it. If you managed to visit during the golden light of the afternoon soon then it could possibly be the MOST magical.

The many faces of serenity.. Ta Prohm and Bayon come top on my list of must-visit places at Siem Reap. I would assume that the temple would look even more magnificent early in the morning. It is a treat to the eyes.
B-E-A-UTIFUL!. amazing architecture, got a lot of great photos. Tons and tons of stairs (uneven & narrow), so not for the faint hearted (or big footed ;p)

different stand alone. Among the Angkor Thom temples, I liked the way this temple is tucked into a corner but still looks very imposing with the giant faces on the facade. It's truly unique and looks grand even without the size of Angkor Wat. And of course everyone has to take their obligatory face to face photo shots.

Newest archaeological site to explore. A good way to see how the temples are catalogue and restored. Half the temple is restored and will offer you plenty of picture opportunities. Don't miss the tree roots in the ruins, they make for some good photography.

Beautiful Smiling Faces. I'm finally there! After looking through books and magazines for the longest time, I set foot on this beautiful temple. This was the first temple we went within the whole Angkor area. Although it was raining season in Siem Riep, the weather was kind to us that day. The temple is so serene, peaceful and the smiling faces made me feel calm. I can only wonder how those sculptures were formed those days. Truly amazing and worth the visit.
Four face temple. A must-see attraction in Siem Reap. The French did an excellent job restoring a major temple built during the height of the Khmer Empire's power
Best smile temple. When I arrive this temple,the weather is good and I feel surprise what I could see. This temple is amazing with its 54 tower of 4 faces smile.

Loved this temple. Not sure why but I think this was one of my favourites. A series of about 54 "towers" with 4 faces on each side - about 34 are still standing. I really liked walking around here the faces were odd but happy!

Worth the trip. Best to go earlier in the morning, due to less crowds. Better to see this before heading to Angkor- its smaller and easier to finish. Also, Angkor is crowded anyways, so you might as well see the smaller temples first.
Beautiful. Stunning sculptures. Photogenic. Rather quiet in July. Check out the info area nearby to see how these monstrosities are made.

The Temple of Faces. What an amazing architectural feat! Really really beautiful, but sadly sooooo many other tourists. I don't know what time of year one should go, or even what time of day, but it wasn't the day we went.
peaceful and beautiful. Honestly almost more impressive than Angkor Wat itself! a Buddhist temple vs the Hindu / Buddhist inspired Angkor Wat and you can literally feel the difference!
Experience of a lifetime!. Like the title, not to be missed! Only thing please remember to wear over the knees pants/skirts and clothes that cover the shoulders!

Great detail, but choose your guide wisely. We had a great time looking around this temple, but the guide we had was too keen to go into nauseating detail on mosaics so we found ourselves breaking off and "exploring" the temple for ourselves. This was enjoyable for our 9 year old daughter in particular!

Breathtaking!. We visited the Bayon Temple early in the morning and so there wasn't much of a crowd which is a good thing because there's not a lot of space to walk around within the temple grounds. It really is an astounding place to visit and to think of how people managed to build such a complex structure and the carvings at that time is amazing. It's a lot more rough in design as compared to Angkor Wat and other temple ruins, but is still worth the visit.

Must See!. Awesome - definitely worth hiring a tour guide though to help explain the history, identify carvings and to know the best photo opportunities of the various temples. If you have limited time definately include Bayon in your itinerary
Wat is very beautiful. You are strongly advised to visit the Bayon, with the look of a dazzling Wat at Angkor Thom. You must take photos in this area.Dislike: there are restoration projects

Awesome!. The stone carving of the stone heads were amazing. Angkor, Ta Prom and Bayon are the top 3 temples to see in the area if you are running short on time. Book a highly motivated and knowledgeable Tuk Tuk driver,this will make all the difference in enjoying the temples, the night markets and Pub Street. There is nothing like having your personal Tuk Tuk driver for your entire stay in Siam Reap. He will recommend what time to start sightseeing at the many temples, which temples to see and at what time to avoid the many tour buses and hoards of tourists. He will also recommend the time your will need at each temple and where he will pick up up. I really hate seeing such wonderful sights when they are so packed with tourists. Nothing like seeing the temples at your own pace. Your Tuk Tuk driver can take you to any of the restaurants in your guide books and give you a personal tour around Siam Reap to see some of the modern Buddha Temples and night markets. Our driver was great! He had cold bottles of water ready for us when we needed it in the hot day and cool moist clothes; scented with lemon grass. He dropped off our dirty laundry to a place he recommended and picked it up for us latter that day so we would not have to pay those high hotels rates for doing laundry.Our Tuk Tuk Drivers Name was Mr. Mao Da. He English was good and he was very professional and easy going. His E- Mail Address is maoda@live.com. He has a facebook page at Da Angkor wat driver and you can look at his website at: www.experienceanglor.com. His Phone number is: 097 96 440 66 & 855 97 96 440 66. I would recommend you try to book him by sending him am E- mail so he can meet you either at the airport if you give him all your information or if your hotel already has free transfer service from the Airport to the hotel; have him meet you outside your hotel at a specific time; leaving him you name and number of people in your party. The Tuk Tuk will hold 4 normal people comfortably.Since he was a great Driver; when he dropped us off at our restaurant for dinner I would give him $5 so he could have dinner with his friends. You pay him each day for his services and if you value his service; you give him one extra day pay as a thank you on the last day of service.

incredible!!. My favourite temple because of the stone face carvings. It is actually very pretty! Temple tour can be done on elephants at usd$15, but we did not do so. Bayon is rather small compared to Angkor Wat but the faces make it very interesting.
Take your time, look closely.. Get there as early as possible. Very hot and very busy. The carvings are very intricate and our guide Seepah was very good at pointing out the many different stories.

Head to Angkor Wat or Ta Phromn instead. Rather small temple, and we climbed right to the top of the temple, which isn't particularly high. Average views of the surrounding trees. (wasn't high enough to see anything else)Temple itself was abit repetitive and too symmetrical.
Awe inspiring. This is probably one of my favourite temples because, of all the carved heads. I found it completley surreal.
second more awesome place in Angkor. Really awesome place, not to miss it out together with Ta phrom and Angkow wat. I recommend to visit during the sunrise or sunet
Beautiful Temple. I like the design of this temple better than that of Angkor Wat. Lovely lovely place! Be careful however, my husband saw a green snake. This temple is really great for photo ops.

Amazing detail. This temple is different to others mainly due to the multitude of carved heads atop each tower. The incredible detail in each face and in the surrounding temple is simply amazing.The crowds here are a bit of an issue as the temple is not as large as others. It is very rare you can get a clear photo without other people in the shot.Definitely worth a visit.
Mystical place.... I just loved the Bayon Temple. The huge heads, carved in stone and dating back all those years is really amazing to see and truly mystical.
Faces. Ask your guide about spot to take pictures that allow your face to match up with the profile of the statues...it's fun.

One of my fave temples. the guide book tells you to start with the smaller temples - I disagree - go with the biggies and stop when you've had enough. There is no shame in not needing to spend a week exploring the temples. The best I think are Bayon, Baphuon, Angkor Wat with Ta Phrom the very best.

Best temple at Angkor. I really enjoyed visiting this temple. All of the smiling faces at every angle, were really a site to see. It was quite a hot day when I went and still had a great time even though I was dripping sweat. If you're going to go see any temple, this is the one to see (in my opinion).

The BEST in Siem Reap - DO NOT MISS!!. The Bayon Temple is number 1 for a reason - this temple is unlike absolutely any other temple that I've seen in my SE Asia visits. There are thousands of smiling faces that are contagious, you end up smiling too! It's a beautiful temple and I'd recommend spending at least 30 minutes there to walk around and take good as well as funny (kissing the statues) pictures.

The Bayon Temple. Date: From the late twelfth century. the late twelfth century. Probable starting 1200United: by Jayavarman VIII Jayavarman VIIVisit: Two hours (more than one visit is recommended)Already at the time it was made ​​was a unique work. Represents the summation betweenthe creative genius and the huge ego of the Sovereign Jayavarman VIII; rich in tastesloping to steep flights of stairs but above 54 spiers "gothic"decorated with 216 giant faces of "Avalokiteshvara" from cold smile than tocase resemble the famous Sovereign. They give the visitor a sense ofpower and control, but not without a touch of humanity. From any point youlook, you can always see a dozen faces, in front or in profile, almostat eye level or facing down.Exceptional.

My Favorite of the Temples We Visited. We visited four temples during our visit of the temples in Siem Reap. My husband and I both thought this was the best temple to walk through and explore. The mystic of this temple as the roots of the trees wound around some of the areas created this feeling of having been sent back in time in a time capsule. The beautiful carvings in the stone, the detail, the ability to have created something so magnificent so many years ago is just mind boggling. I could have spent a lot more time here, but knowing that we wanted to see the other temples and having just gone to Angkor Wat, we only allowed ourselves the luxury of closely examining the artwork on just a couple of the entrances to the rooms. This Temple deserves ample time to explore, so if planning a trip here allow at least three or four hours. If you don't have that much time, then please stop and admire the beautiful detail of a couple of the areas. To walk through this maze of temple room and paths without taking the time to closely look at some of the detailed work would be such a waste.

Stunning. Its smaller compared to angkor wat and is also quite damaged due to bombing from khmer rouge and the various wars and also due to the length of time it has been standingIT is currently being restored so do take note that there will be scafolding around this is being done to make sure that people in the future can see what it is like. There are three levels to look around and it is beautiful with all the ornate stone carvings especially the heads on the spires. It is included in the ticket price and also is 2nd on the small circuit trip.One thing to take note on is that there are rouge guides who roam the temple and start guiding you round and then ask for a tip. Yes they have lots of information however if you plan to budget and not have a guide they do catch you out.
Worth the visit. Was one of the three temples we chose to visit and I would recommend that you see it. Could get very crowded if busy.
One of the Big Three of Angkor. Don't miss it. the photo opportunities are amazing. Get there at the time of day to avoid the tourist hordes - mid afternoon seems to work.

Beautiful temple. This was our first temple visit when we were in Siem Reap. As we arrived quite early, the temple. The grounds was already full of tourists. We were amazed and left speechless at the various towers which had the many faces of Buddha. It is amazing that the people back then could build such beautiful structures without the use of modern equipment and yet, these structures can stand the test of time.

Probably the most amazing temple out of all. After seeing the main 5 temples in the complex, for me this stood out the most. From the outside to the inside, detail, size, little tiny labyrinth like paths from one room to another, dark rooms with narrow corridors leading to the pockets of light just made me feel like taking part in some adventure movie... Great place to visit and a must see when in Siem Reap!!!

WOW!. Being here is like getting to the Moon for the first time. It's truly magnificent. Yes, there are hordes of tourists everywhere but do make time to soak in the moment that you are in one of the greatest monuments ever made by humans!
Magnificent. Please allow enough time! Be careful not to get lost in the maze and make sure to go all the way to the top as the view is stunning.
Great Budha Temple!. You can't miss it in your visit to Siem Reap it is amazing how they played with the number 9 for everything!

Just speechless. Actually i went there in 2010..If you are about to see the creativity and ability of 13th century era, just try to visit these angkor wat complex.. It is really amazing, how they do the craft on the rocks.. And also how they worship their king that day.. From what i read about angkor, bayon is a temple, it is the place where the king pray..If you love to ride a bike, try to rent it and ride it to the temple..really cheap, approx. $1 per day.. Fyi, you can combine Cambodian Riel and USD on a payment of something.. $1 = 4000 riel..Don't forget to bring your water resistance bag, because when the rain comes, it is really hard to find a place to take shelter besides usually we have to chase the time, because after after the sun is out, there are no single light in angkor wat complex..
Awesome. We rode elephants! Lol that's all that really can be said ,,, it was great though so many interesting facts, history and photo opportunities!

WOW!. Have you ever carried a hundred kilogram weight up five flight of stairs? How could then one reason out the marvelous huge expressive Gods ,looking at you with admiration, each weighing tons ,& one has to stretch one's neck to look at the awe inspiring sculptures of Bayon Temple? Technology got developed by even artists & sculptures,in this, almost a thousand years ago built Temple.It's a unique experience to spend a few hours in the presence of enigmatic sculptures trying to convey the continuity & eternal beauty of human civilization of whatever hue!I enjoyed being there a lotTechnical details are available in numerous books sold by young kids near the temple.

Beautiful Bayon.. Amazing faces. An absolute delight. We visited at the end of the day when it was starting to cool. It was a joy to wander around with our wonderful Guide Veasna and hear all the history of Angkor Thom.

Amazing. This was a very impressive temple, but go early to avoid the crowds. We were here in the late afternoon and ran into lots of tour groups. This was the favorite among the temples for our family.

Visit with music. You can't escape from noisy tourist, try plug your ears with some music that you think it suits angkor , then jump into your own world of angkor and feel it....By bike is also a good way, tour or by yourself is easy as long as you got off road bike(more safe), Rain cloth(sudden rain every afternoon) offline google map,
Amazing!!. Small temple but really lovely. Many other temples and places of interest around as well. Rent your own tuk tuk for the day (for families), or bicycles (beware of the heat!).
So amazing temple with many faces. This great template called Bayon are looking around you, and so unique template with smiling so many faces.
Staggering. Again quite staggering - I have a large oil painting of the Bayon faces on my office wall - guarding my empire!

The fabulous Bayon Temple is one of the best places to get a sense of the grand scheme of the Angkor complex. Bayon held more atmosphere than the major Angkor complex, it 'felt' as though the past was still in the present.
Amazing. easily one of my favourite temples - 4 huge towers with intricate faces surrounding a large middle tower with 8 faces! amazing detail and architecture

Hauntingly Beautiful!. The Bayon is part of the Angkor Thom temple complex and while many people will say that Angkor Wat is their favorite temple to visit in Siem Reap, this was mine. It ‘s a lot less crowded than Angkor Wat, takes less time to see, and has more character as a result of the many large smiling stone faces and bas-reliefs scattered throughout the complex. Once you leave the complex on the far side and turn around, you will never forget the view of this hauntingly beautiful temple. The Bayon was built by King Jayavarman VII (some say the smiling faces resemble his face) about 900 years ago and was originally a Hindu temple but was later converted to a Buddhist temple. If you’re in Siem Reap, you should definitely see Angkor Wat but Angkor Thom is a must-see as well.
Best temple there. Beautiful. Spectacular. Magic. Not enough words to describe this wonderful place. Certainly one of the wonders of the world. Visited twice in my 4 days there.
Good temple. The Bayon Temple is a good temple, with an interesting and unique design. Worth a visit in my opinion.

Just wonderful.. Its away from the tourist Mecca that is Angkor and I believe is looks and feels better than Angkor as well. If you don't come here to see it then you have missed the best temple in the entire complex. Remember to wear clothes that go below the knee and over the shoulder, otherwise you wont get into all the temples.

Beautiful - but very touristy. Beautiful - but very touristy. Lots of people there, and lots of cars parked around (drivers for visitors) which spoiled the views somewhat.
