The only temple where there was a group of traditionally dressed people wanting you to have your photo taken with them - for a few dollars.I wish we could have spent more time there, and gone back when the sun was setting.

Beautiful Bayon Temple. If your traveling to Siem Reap to visit the temples, Bayon Temple is a must on your list of places to see. This temple was first used around 1200 AD and abandoned around 1600 AD; its truly amazing how well preserved it is considering the environment of SE Asia.The stairs used to access the various levels can be difficult on younger and elderly visitors; they are very steep and there are non landings where to take a break.Unfortunately the reconstruction taking place in areas of the temple can detract from some of the pictures, but its reassuring to know this wonderful world heritage site will be around for future generations.Remember to bring water for drinking and sun block.

Mysterious Faces. An awesome place that still hold the secrets of the past glories of the great Khmer Empire. Never has such a place existed anywhere in the world and yet so little is know of the site.A pleasure to visit early morning or at mid day when there is less tourists. A visit to the Bayon Information Center and Hut is helpful in understanding the Khmer Empire.
Wonderful Ancient Temple. I had long heard about Bayon prior to my visit. However, I was still impressed by the amazing architectural, craving and dignified atmosphere when I first saw it.

Awe inspiring. Not as big as the other complexes but from the point of view of being able to get up close and personal it seems much grander. You marvel at the people who created these wonders. It is a great place to lose yourself, not as crowded as the other sites.

Angkor Complex. Just about everything in the Angkor complex of temples is awesome. Angkor Wat is the most intact of the temples but, is also the most visited. It's best to get there early -- before the tour buses start to arrive. After that, it's competing with some pretty rude and inconsiderate tourists crowding for a look at, well, whatever.
Beautiful faces. Amazing carvings. It wasn't crowded when we were there and was able to take many close up pictures. I like the nose to nose picture with one of the Buddha.
Beautiful place. Walking through this relatively small (compared to Ankor Wat) area is highly recommended. We felt if was underrated, because parts were so beautiful and the crowds were much less.

A world wonder worth the visit. The entire world Heritage site is spectacular, but this is one of the most impressive. It is a photographers dream location. The Bas Relief carvings are so realistic the stone carved faces are life like. The construction methods which have survived since the 12 centrum put modern builds to shame. Try to visit either real early when it is not so hot, but as a photographer the location of the sun plays a big part in the appeal

My absolute favorite of the temples. Who can resist a smiling face? We absolutely enjoyed our visit to Bayon temple. We had an excellent guide who gave us the highlights of this amazing temple. The unusual layout, the changes made throughout its occupancy and the wonderful faces on the temple towers were all fascinating. I'm an amateur photographer at best but some of the photographs from our visit to Bayon were simply spectacular.
Beautiful. Beautiful temple but way too crowded with tourists - struggled to look around parts of it too many people.

One of my fav temples. Interesting and less crowded than Angkor Wat. Interesting mix of Hinduism/Buffhism bas reliefs here. Check out my photo of what appears to be some kind of drainage or sewage system. 200 faces make you feel like Indiana jones ; )
Faces everywhere. Check out the many faces of the Buddha and get a picture facing one too. Worth a visit, part of the Angkor Thom complex

Soul Enriching!. There are many big trees surround this place.
I have lunch at food shop where is the owner can speak Thai.

very impressive. What’s unique about Bayon temple is that there are over 200 large faces carved on the stone towers at the third level. I love how the faces all look serene. The temple also has nooks and crannies and endless passageways which is fun to explore. This is one of my favorite temples...Visited this temple twice. It was crawling with tourists on a Saturday afternoon and practically empty on a Sunday afternoon. :)

Amazing. Our tuk tuk driver/guide brought us in via the South Gate and when we saw the stone guardians along the connecting bridge and the 4-faced edifice looming over the entrance, it was definitely a 'Wow' moment for us. And this was before we were dropped off at Bayon Temple itself. It was amazing to be allowed to wander all over this park and see these wonderful structures and carvings up close.

Best is Bayon. This was our favorite. Angkor Wat is the biggest but we really liked the character of Bayon. The face on the towers made it feel like you were in an Indiana Jones movie. It was quite busy when we got to this temple at around 10am but that didnt matter. There is a maze of doorways so you don't have to go far to feel like your far from the crowd.

Our favourite temple - so few poeple. Bayon is worth the small side trip from the main Angkor Wat. While it is not as majestic the lack of people and vendors makes the experience much more enjoyable. There is also shade under trees to sit in and picnic and a constant flow of monks contrasting with the stone surrounds. Very aesthetically pleasing!

Great sight!. 216 faces to see. So many photo-ops for camera lovers. It can be pretty hot during the day so plan for an early morning or early afternoon visit. Not for elderly people because of so many stairs. A unique kind of temple in Angkor Wat.

Stunning temple - go at lunchtime for fewer tour groups. This is definitely one of the best temples to visit, but of course everyone knows that and so it is often overrun with tourists and massive groups. I happened to visit one Saturday at lunchtime, arriving around 1pm, and the temple was practically deserted. Most of the large tour groups head back for lunch around this time, so for an hour or so around noon/early afternoon this amazing ruin is actually quite peaceful and quiet. Do not leave Angkor without visiting this temple, and for the best experience try to visit when there are fewer people.
Nice big temple to explore. Lots and lots of tourists in the morning - but one of the main temples to see, so it needs to be done.

History with many faces. This is 1 of my favorite temples in Siem Reap. Every wall and corner captures the history of the place. This also has the most number of face carvings as compared with the others. I have great respect for the ancient Khemer people for their diligence in building and carving the rocks.
Wow. Takes your breath away. The minds that constructed this place must have been something else. Takes extra batteries for your camera when visiting

The temple is exquisite and very beautiful. The temple is exquisite and very beautiful. a must see when you visit the angkor temples. its ironic that people visit siem reap to see the beautiful ruined temples but the government is trying to restore it.

Bayon Temple. I always visited Bayon temple as it is so attractive for my heart even I went with my clients (tourists) + tour guide for many times but I still visit as well I really like looking the faces of Bayon Temple and big trees and more with best personal regards from James

Marvelous. History and sculptures are smiling at you. Especially under rain it was a marvelous experience. We went in after 5:30pm, which you don’t have to pay but in two days we could see Angkor Wat and Bayon. If you really want to experience this area you need all day or more day than that. You should bring your picnic equipments to sit next to canal and enjoy nature.

One-of-a-kind!. Bayon is truly magnificent with the numerous smiling Buddha engraved on the walls of the temple. Definitely one-of-a-kind. Along the compound, there are some tall tower which is pretty scary to scale and to come down from. From Bayon temple, you can follow along the trail to some other smaller lesser known temple and the elephant terrace. The tuktuk that you hire will be waiting there and it will take approximately 2 hrs to leisurely finish this entire trail.
nice temple in Siem Reap City of Cambodia. Good guide from Indochina Line Travel Ltd. Offer high quality of services with the best price. very friendly and happywww.indochinalinetravel.com
Historical and amazing. So much History can be gathered from this tour of Bayon. Thedirections to move around was very clear and helpful for thetourists.

So good we came back three times!!. Bayon is truly magnificant and I just didnt want to leave. So many parts of the temple to explore at your own free will - a fabulous morning out. There are monkeys just before you reach the temple so if you wish come prepared with banana's (0.75c for a bunch from market stall) too feed the monkeys. They are very tame and take them out of your hand. My four year old loved it. There is also a elephant ride around the temple for $15 each. My Daughter was free and she enjoyed it. I would only recommend this if you are desperate for a ride or have kids hassling you for one! Elephants seemed well treated but I found it expensive and also not the most comfortable of rides!!

second most tourist in angkor. i also visit this temple because my guide tell this is what i will like/. the four faces buddha means so many angle to find. then you can buy the t shirt with this iconic temple picture.

Bayon Temple, Siem Reap, Cambodia. Who doesn't love this temple? If you think it is cool now, you should have seen it in 1970 when I first caught a glimpse of it as I was cycling thru the jungle - it suddenly appeared like an apparition out of Lord Jim - pure magic!
Fantastic. That is why we come to Siem Reap it is just magic to be there and be a part of ancient history but very hot so you need to protect yourself

Enrinching expierance !. A part of the Angkor Archaelogical Site, Bayon Temple is like a dream came true. The faces on the pillars of the temples are what you had seen all your childhood in games shows, video games, lara croft and everything about Angkor !I loved the place and spent a lot of time there. Very clean and beautifullu preserved. Very well maintained !Must go !
Amazing. We were lucky to have a great guide Mr San who had a wealth of knowledge. This is the 'faces' temple and there were many. Just breathtaking.
Beautiful - worth a visit. Make sure you stop and take an Eskimo kiss picture with one of the faces. Shorter visit here than many of the other temples but wouldn't miss this one.

Best Temple in Angkor. The awesomeness that is Bayon. Such detail and size made this the most impressive temple that we saw while in Siem Reap. All the faces carved following you as you walk through the ruins leaves you in amazement of what the folks achieved so many years ago. Great photo opportunities exist here even with the multitudes of tourists clambering over every inch of the structure. Even if this is not your favourite, its close proximity to so many other temples make it a must see while your here. Access is fairly good for this temple, if you not into climbing steep stairs and walking for miles this one should still be okay to tackle.

The 200+ faces of Buddha. An outstanding visit where you are able to clamber amongst the many stone towers each showing 4 faces of Buddha.It is worth hiring a guide who will be able to highlight some great photo opportunities including kissing a Buddha, becoming one of the 4 faces of Buddha and sharing a quiet moment with your partner/friend and Buddha. Possibly the most memorable site we have ever visited.

Get a guide. I think you really need a good guide for this temple. There are all sorts of little secrets you can learn about and great photo oportunities ...I wouldn't of got such great photos ..such as the nose touching nose photos and faces thru the window frames if we hand had a guide.
The temple with the faces. Less crowded than Angkor Wat, and quite different from the other temples.When visiting the temples, make sure you include this one.

Spectacular temple. Romping around this magnificent temple was like playing in an adult-sized fort. Unlike historical sites in the US, there are very few "Do Not Cross" lines at Angkor temples making you feel like you are truly engulfed by your surroundings. This temple is a must see!

If you are looking for something "different", then this is it. If you are looking for something "different", then this is it. The faces speak to you. There are so many and so much time goes away in looking at them and understanding what they are trying to tell you. It is not a very huge complex. It is relatively smaller (than Angkor Wat), but it is magnificent. Definitely worth the visit. The architecture is a bit confusing. You will see pathways leading to nothing but a wall. And many walls put together - making no structure. It will fascinate you when you try to figure what is going on.
Wow. Loved the Bayon Temple the best of all others at Ankor Thom. We got there early to ride an elephant around the complex for an even better view!
Spectacular. This was our favorite temple. Angkor Wat gets all the press but Bayon is just breathtaking. The faces on the stone are just amazing. Don't miss this one.

Many heads. Head there in the morning.. If you have the chance to go see the sun rises at Angkor Wat, then be sure to visit Bayon right after that as there will be less tourists and more chance for you to enjoy the magnificent huge faces all over the temple. Be sure to enter from the South entrance and take nice close ups of the statues of the stoic giants who did the "churning of the ocean's milk". This is one of my favorite temples, and no words could describe how magnificent the statues and carvings are. The lower part of the walls depicted the scenes of battles and folklores, in intricate and breathtaking details. This temple definitely deserve a chunk of your time to explore!
Nice trip. I visited here in July and had a guide. Id definitely recommend getting a guide because there is much to learn about the friezes around the place.

Gigantic Faces of Bayon at Angkor Thom. Larger than life faces carved in stone, each face unique in its expression. Just magnificent. You need to see them to be in awe of how this temple was constructed. One of the highlights of the Angkor temples.
Being part of every action film filmed here. I loved the energy of the place, where else do you find ancient trees growing out of the walls of ancient temples with monkey guards watching.
Nice. It's like the other Temple the architectures are really nice and very much detailed. The only problem is when we went here its like their having some renovations

Amazing Temple. Bayon for me is the best of the temples at Angkor. The faces surrounding you create a really spiritual vibe. I got here very early before 7 AM well before the crowd builds up. Bring lots of water as it can be hot and humid. Take time to explore the walls around e temple which has some remarkable detailed carvings.

One my favs. This was one of my favorite temples, did this in the mid morning, was starting to get busy. Taking a guide is really useful as they are helpful with not only information on the temples but working around known peak times.
Incredibel site. Part of the main Angkor Wat complex and truly a must see. Allow yourself plenty of time and bring lots of water
Temple of faces. Temple of faces, which is quite different from the other temples - very fascinating. Should definitely incorporate in your tour.

number 1 place in the list. It is the paramount attraction, may be Angkor Wat Temple can compete with it! In fcat, we were amazed by this and we visited this place twice, once with the guide and another time by ourselves! It will be easier and fun if you have read all about this prior to visiting this place
Beautiful. This temple has 54 towers and over 200 smiling faces. It's just amazing, every were you tour there is a face. It so much history here that is hard to imagine how they did it.

Brilliant !. We were melting by the time we got to this temple, but it was amazing to see all the faces in the temple itself.There is a really good photography studio by the royal palace gardens by a photographer called john mcdermott who sold really good prints of the bayon temple and especially the heads, which will be hanging on our wall when we get back :).

Carry some water with you!. The major temple at Angkor Thom. Walk around the temple complex to get an overview before diving in to admire the many faces. On recommendation of my guide I did also climb the Baphuon temple. but I don't think the view is worth it and you can save some energy for other climbs.

Best Temple for me ...Too Crowded. This was definitely the best temple for me, I just loved it, a little too crowded with tourists taking pictures everywhere so It's a little bit difficult to walk around and take pictures but definitely worth it. Cambodia is really hot and you will sweat a lot so be prepared but it's worth a visit, The must see temples, Bayon, Ta Prohm and Angkor Wat, the other ones you can skip, explore these 3 temples in the morning, less crowded and you still have your energy, if you finish and have more time go and visit the other smaller temples. Do Hire a tuk tuk for the day so he can take you to all the temples and just drop you off at the entrance, our driver also carried cold water so it was pretty convenient. Beautiful Temple !!!

Breathtaking!. I visited in early morning & late afternoon to try to avoid the crowds...kind of worked too!Although the July heat & humidity is stifling it is well worth the sweat for the experience and photos!

My fav site. Tip: 3 days pass is very convenient. It's impossible to visit it in just 1 day. And there is no 2 days pass. $20/ day.Tip2: keep your ticket easy to reach. you will have to show it several times during the visit. I saw that tours provide a waterproof multi purpose pouch. Maybe you can get one on Target or Amazon.com. They are cheap.This is my fav site in AW. The enigmatic smile of Avalokiteshvara makes it a magical place. And it's even more incredible when you see it from the road. One of the sides has a small lake. It's gorgeous!Always crowded.

Highlight of Khmer Architecture. We visited Bayon very early in the morning before the crowd stampede and managed to get some spectacular shots of this magnificent temple. We also had a guide with us who can help telling the history of Khmer culture and architecture. We spent about 3 hours exploring the temple until it's very crowded with tourist. Definitely the highlight of our one week trip to Siem Reap.

just amazing. you will not regret. the intricacy of the temple layout and the multiple figures of heads that represent the merging of buddha and one of the khmer kings features is just amazing! i loved it and couldnt help snap away at my camera at every turn. Just to think these temples are a couple of hundred years old, almost reaching a 1000 just takes your breath away! do not forget to take a picture at the entrace of the inner gallery, where the four-faced head figure greets you
Winner. Like all of the ruins in this area it was magnificent to see and the scale has to be seen to be believed

Fascinating Archaeology. This is a wonderful example of the archaeology of the area. If you are a unsteady on you feet you need to take extra care as it is quite uneven walking, but should not be missed on your trip to Siem Reap

Very atmospheric, different to all others. Loved the multitude of faces. Calm temple. Visited early in the morning to avoid the crowds. The man in the centre by the Buddhist shrine will give you a joss stick and will expect money for the shrine.
Beautiful. This temple is very much underrated, it is absolutely magnificent! Even though it was hot and humid, we still enjoyed our visit. This is a must see!
Take a guide. Having a local guide with us gave us more information about the structure and history of the place but there are information boards around to help you make the most of your visit.

A mysterious and magnificent temple, I was frightened by the statues around. I got scared by surprise with so many faces around, its like every turn there is a person smilling at you, be it a hole where inside is Buddha statue, I was frightened.
Love this temple! Definitely the best temple ever, so creative and so grand of the temple.
Best temple in the area. We liked Bayon Temple much better than Angkor Wat. Get there early (before 8:00 am) to avoid the hordes of tourists who arrive in buses mid-morning.

My camera couldn't stop clicking. Just cant stop using my camera. Everything was just picturesque. And oh, this is way better than the Anchor Wat which is a bit disappoing for i did have high expectations with Anchor. Anyway, we (my friend Mat) did enjoy the sights amongst all the temples. Very intricate designs too. Love it!

A very nice temple with unique faces. The temple is beautiful. We enjoyed it.
Very unique
- things you need
- a tour guide
- a hat
- good hiking shoes
- water

Elephant ride to a beautiful temple. We were very excited to see Bayon temple and we were not let down. We got an elephant ride from the South gate of Angkor Thom up to Bayon temple. The elephant ride was one of the highlights of our trip and it was good to see how well the elephants were treated. Even though it is quiet hot and busy, the temple itself more than makes up for it. This is definitely a must see when visiting Siem Reap.
Many Faces of Bayon.. Immerse yourself in the history of the ancients. Ensure you have a good guide to get the best of the site.
Fantastic!!!. To see is to believe that this kind of temple really exist.... Just seen it in movies and now I can see it w/ my own eyes...
One of the interesting place. This is one of the Temples in the Angkor Temples complex. Very interesting temple. Must be visited when in Siem Reap :-)
Interesting temple. This temple will be a suitable place for those who'd like to take pictures, as the many faces of the temple makes a great shot.

A Beautiful Little Khmer Temple.. This temple is quite unlike all other temples that I saw in Cambodia, with an Indonesian appearance. Although quite busy, it is definitely a look for it,s unique architecture.

Beautiful Bayon. Angkor Wat is so well known as the largest temple in the ancient world. But equally worth visiting and one of the most beautiful temples in my experience is Bayon.Upon climbing up, I was so amazed to be in the middle of so many serene faces. Said to be based on Hindu numerology, each tower has 4 faces facing the cardinal directions North, South, East, and West. Faces that are said to be either of King Jayavarman the 7th (their most compassionate king), the Lord Gautama Buddha (the enlightened one), or Avalokiteshvara (a great spirit). I say, they are all beautiful. Each one having a positively mysterious Mona Lisa smile. I easily connected with the presence of the place and felt so at home, at peace. The soulful energy made me feel like sitting down and meditating... for hours. I vow to visit again - and just really be there to feel the enigmatic Angkor Smile of Bayon. :)

Angkor Wat seemed a little Houso after Banyon. After you visit Banyon and its amazing stone faces, Angkor was a let down. If I ever return to Siem Reap, I would spend the day at Banyon rather than the draw card.

Awesome Place, A Must See. I actually liked this better then the Angkor Wat temple simply because of the different faces on the temple. It is amazing how this can be built so many years ago and have faces built in. You can spend hours here going though the temple and looking at all the faces. Great for photos and walking around. When you step out of your tuk tuk or van you are in shock of how cool the faces are in stone. I loved the Bayon Temple and would go see it again in a heart beat. A Must See.

Enchanting visit. Hot, but well worth it. This temple is the most impressive, in my opinion. The faces gazing at you from all directions are subjects to great photos. At the sire, you cannot take it all in. When we got to the hotel, and looked at the pictures, we were stunned at all the details we missed while at the site, rubbing elbows with the huge crowds. Bring your camer, and take lots of pictures.

Fantastic place. It may sound wierd, but I liked Bayon more than Angkor Wat. This place is mystical. It is more in ruins than Angkor Wat and has a lot more wild growth around. The sculpture here is very different from the mother temples in the region.

Must to go in your life. I wish I stay here long enough. The smile of the Budha is very mystery. And if you are photographer, you should spend more time in here. Best lights in the 7-9h AM and 4-6h PM. At that time, the weather not too hot, so you could take some lovely shot. Bring a fresh water bottle, you should need it.
We loved all the faces. We loved all the faces and found the history fascinating. Good angles made for interesting photos. Since much smaller than Angkor Wat, only need 2 hours onsite.

Try not to go here first - build up to it!. My driver brought me here first. I don't think that was a good idea as it's all too new at that point. I'd suggest building up to it in order to get used to the style and really appreciate its glory.

stunning. The most distinctive feature of this temple is the multitude of serene and massive stone faces on the many towers which jut out from the upper terrace and cluster around its central peak.
Try to go there early to avoid crowds and carry plenty of water.
Well worth a visit. Go early in the morning so it is not to hot. Well worth taking a tuk tuk as a day trip. Very worthwhile and one of the best historical sites / parks ever visited
Amazing. I have been fascinated to have seen the pictures of the faces of the sculptures at the Bayon temple. I am glad to have visited it to see them.

One of the best. This temple can be done in a small loop with Angkor Wat
So much detail it's fantastic
Pay the extra and get a guide

Wow. Striking, interesting. A must-see when visiting Siem Reap. You can do elephant rides around the temple for $15 but the elephants go home for a rest in the middle of the day which is lovely but get in early.
all eyes on you. Beware of the monkeys! Everything else was EXCELLENT! Beautiful, serene, erie. Travel in the afternoon to avoid the crowds and the heat.
Temple to see, a must.. I like visiting this temple more than Angkor Wat. All those faces. Wow! Elephant ride around the temple a great way to get some pictures and see all sides of the temple.
Well-restored. Bayon is a nicely restored wat, and has on-going reclamation work. Not exceptional, but worth a stop.
amazing temple. I really like Bayon temple because of its beautiful faces.it is my favorite one .and i would recomend to visit this temple at late afternoon it's less busy and perfect lighting .!

The temple with the towering faces is truly a marvelous site to visit. The temple with the towering faces is truly a marvelous site to visit. The four faces of Buddha on each temple is unique in its own way, and make it stand apart. A must visit in site in Siem Reap

The ONE temple you must visit if you need to choose. If you need to choose only one temple to visit in Angkor, this is the ONE. First, the design of the entire structure was overwhelming. And then, those giant faces that popped out of the temple facets was simply breathtaking.

Breathtaking. Everything about this place is amazing. The fact that they were able to carve cubes of rock into parts of faces, then setting everything up in perfect armony. Just amazing. What a wonderful place. Never miss it.
Visited february 2012

Stupendous. I knew nothing about Bayon before visiting and perhaps that is why I was so blown away. For me this was the highlight of the temples in the Angkor region, with the giant stone faces looking at you from every angle.

Bayon Temple. We found this temple architecture was different from other temples in the Angkor wat complex. One of the temple built at the Buddhism era and the latest one. It worthed to visit and took picture with buddha faces was fun. I had a great picture look like I kissing the buddha !

Faces! Faces!. It's smaller than you think (Angkor Thom is really huge, but the Bayon is a bit small). No matter. The person who designed it really took the idea and ran with it. Faces all over!In the temples, you'd realize that these stones were actually painted pretty thoroughly. So I imagine that these faces were also painted. It would have been really eery in their original forms...
Classic angkor wat. But It is all falling apart This is the site of the classic angkor shots, so you can't come without seeing it.

Now I get the 5 star review. Wonderful and all said before. Shockingly good in person. Great pictures to take. Very surreal. Light incense inside and the lady will give you luck. Who knows if true - just felt good. Try to go early when crowds are small. When we got there 8:00, no one was there, but when we left it was crowded.
beautiful and impessive. beautiful and impressive temple! it gets crowded, so you might get other people in your amazing pictures, but yes, people go there for a reason ))

WHAT A TEMPLE. This is one of the best temple in the area, we spent alot of time taking photo and enjoying the view and the relics. It's awesome... really awesome... i think, this is better then angkor wat it self (that's my oppinion) love this temple so much...

Magnifcient Temple. Majestic Buddhist temples built by King Jaya VIII, together with Angkow Wat, with 4 faced stone buddhas. Great architecture that lasts which showcased the great Khmer Empire in AD 1175-1240. Part of Angkor Thom, located at South Gate.

One the best temples I visited!. The moment I set my eyes on the temple, I immediately fell in love of this marvelous architecture. From a distance, you could see the many imposing Buddhas faces smiling and seeming to welcome us to it's holy ground.As we entered into the temple complex, I was captivated by more Buddhas' faces looking at us from different angles. According to our tour guide-Sothorn, this was the first and last mountain temple dedicated to Buddhism in Angkor. The rest of the mountain temples were actually built in the name of Hinduism. As an avid photographer, my camera never stop clicking in the temple compound. I realized I took more photos in Bayon than any other temples in Siem Reap. No wonder it is easily the most popular tourists' site after Angkor Wat. It's really hard to imagine how the people then could construct a temple with such complexity with bare hands and basic tools.
Statuesque!. Just stunning, So many carved heads in a relatively compact space (compared to Angkor Wat). What more can I say? Get there early to avoid the coachloads!
Amazing. Amazing buildings, and completely surrounded by jungle, woods.. When you climb the stairs you have amazing views. Be sure the battery of your camera is fully loaded and bring a handfan!
All part of the bigger experience. Great temple with a lot of walking and climbing to see the whole think. Lots of interesting wall inscriptions and carvings.
ANGKOR TEMPLES- Bucket list material.. Amazing temple . It is worth getting a guide from the Hotel . He gave us much more than what was in the books.

Buddhist Temple with many faces of Buddha. Many places to take great pictures. Don't fail to take a picture with your face facing one of the Buddha faces. We were wondering why the guide made my daughter face right. He seemed to be taking a shot of her side view. When we saw the picture, it was as if she was face to face with the face of Buddha!

Incredible. Incredible! .. I love it,.. everything in siem reap it's beautifull and magic. be prepared to the wheater it's really hot, but the combination with the nature , the temple, and the landview it's incredible!

Bayan Temple Angkor Wat, Siem Reap Cambodia. Angkor Thom was built as a square, the sides of which run exactly north to south and east to west. Standing in the exact center of the walled city, Bayon Temple represents the intersection of heaven and earth.Bayon is known for its huge stone faces of the bodhisattva Avalokiteshvara, with one facing outward and keeping watch at each compass point. The curious smiling image, thought by many to be a portrait of Jayavarman himself, has been dubbed by some the "Mona Lisa of Southeast Asia." There are 51 smaller towers surrounding Bayon, each with four faces of its own.Bayon Temple is surrounded by two long walls bearing an extraordinary collection of bas-relief scenes of legendary and historical events. In all, there are are total of more than 11,000 carved figures over 1.2km of wall. They were probably originally painted and gilded, but this has long since faded. I promise you things are extremely cheap in Cambodia, very safe, the food is excellet, and the people are amazing. They treat you like a aking!

Overshadowed by Angkor Wat but way better!. We went in November 2012. The Bayon Temple complex was, in my opinion the most beautifully restored/maintained of the temples. Angkor Wat was very large, but something about this amazing temple draws you to it. The design, the faces, the mystery... See it early in the day to help avoid crowds and get some good photo ops.

One of the 3 "must sees"!. This is one of the 3 "must sees" of the Angkor complex, along with Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm. A good guide will be able to show the exact spots from which to take some amazing photographs, as well as filling in all the history of the temple; if you state what you want at the outset the guide will also give you plenty of time to ramble around on your own.

Mysterious place. I really liked this temple. I had spent the past two days viewing many photos, paintings and performances concerning the faces at this Bayon temple (the face of the Buddha of compassion, my guide told me), so I could not wait to see it in real life. The temple has three levels like the Angkor Wat but is smaller, so the climb was not as tiring. Make sure to walk around slowly - at some points, the faces all line up so the view is really nice. There's something quite mystical about the place - soak in the atmosphere.

This is the place where you see all the carved faces. This is the place where you see all the carved faces. Lots of good walking through shady paths and, once inside the temple there are corridors after corridors of exhibits. We didn't bother with a guide and loved every minute.
Places with many faces!. Excellent structures with faces that are all almost identical!Magnificent structures with the size of it...

An excellent photo opp. Towards the back of the temple there is a window you can perch on sideways, have someone take your photo where your profile lines up nose to nose with the large stone face. This won't make sense unless you go there.

Too much to cram into a few hours. hot and humid day, did this group of temples reasonably early in the morning need a life time to appreciate the whole complex loads of interesting hidden spots, plenty of stairs, so not recommended for the unfit found it more intriguing than Ankor Wat complex take loads of liquids with you

one of the must-see temple. There's no good food inside the angkor wat area. our tuk-tuk brought us to small food place near Bayon, it's a rip-off food starts at $6 and it's not even good, probably not clean too.

Temple of 216 faces. It's a very beautiful temple with 216 faces. The ticket price that u pay to get in Angkor will cover these temples as well. Out of all the 216 faces there is only one face which is mailing the most.. Remember to take a click of it! And if possible get a good guide. They really know the tips and tricks..
Wonderful. Incredible decoration on the temples. Many of the temples had steps and very hot. Carry plenty of water.

Fantastic place to visit! Bayon is a must see!. In ancient Ankgor, Bayon is easily the pick of the lot! With it's massively impressive stone faces on its numerous towers, it is a must-see place to visit during your trip to Siem Reap. I went there with friends, & we started off the Angkor Thom tour with the Bayon, & spent the majority of the day admiring the splendour of the temple!

A really interesting temple. I felt like a kid in this temple wanting to explore every nook and cranny, and it sure has plenty of those! This amazing temple was different from Angkor Wat in that it consists of lots of columns and walls rather than long corridors, and there are lots of areas to explore. The climb to the top was rewarded with the sight of some amazing carvings.

The best of all the temples. By far my most favorite temples in the entire archaeological park and the highlight of my entire trip to Siem Reap. It's a sight you can not miss and will walk through the many faces just in awe. We hired the same tuk tuk driver who took us to the sunrise to come pick us up around sunset to view this temple.

The Jewel in the Crown!. This atmospheric temple is at the centre of Angkor Thom & has a very commanding presence. We went early in the morning when there weren't too many coach loads tourists & the light is better for taking pictures. The enigmatic faces stare at you from all over the complex - there are over 200 of them & they are all different! Good walking shoes are necessary as there is a lot of climbing!
Magnificent sight. Take hats, water and go early in the morning, it gets very hot and you don't want to miss out on absorbing the beauty of this place for becoming heat struck!
Out of the way and worth it!. Although this place is slightly out of the way, it was worth the trip. Bayon is gorgeous. There are a few too many people trying to sell you things.
Tomb Raiders sight!. Wear a pair of good walking shoes. You need it! This is one of 3 main sites to visit besides Angkor Wat and Ta Phrom.

Always good. 3 time I been in Angkor in for the last 13 years and again this here is one of my favorite temple, but it is always difficult to choice the no. 1 . It still find the face very Special like Mona Lisa
great temple. it so nice to be able to visit this place , so amazing site that i will come back again to explore more deep of its history
Fantastic temple!. This was our first stop in touring the temple complex and made a huge first impression! Very expansive grounds with beautiful architecture and history!!

A must see. One of the jewels of the Angkor Park. Not to be missed. The enigmatic faces are an incredible site. I think one could visit at any time of day, but may find the light best for photographs, like any other site, best in the morning or late afternoon. However, this is one you will want to take pictures of so you might consider arranging your touring itinerary around this idea.

Buddha smiling in every corner. Very beautiful and great place for a photo op. Try getting there early to avoid heavy tourist rush. You would need about an hour or 2 to truly do justice to this visit.
Great historical place. Ancient structured of building was amazing. The structured of building was very special and carved with features of different faces. Very nice scene for picture.
Breathtaking. A unique place ,I enjoyed the architecture of the facetted stones ,a surreal experience standing among the ancient structures .

Calm Faces. We are talking about Angkor Thom, it means we have to talk about Bayon temple, because it is in the center of Angkor Thom. When we are standing in front of it, we seem we don't believe this is as temple, it looks like mountain, which has many faces of Buddha.Unbelievable, thousands of sandstone blocks put together become amazing towers and all the faces look so calm, smiling and peaceful, it is full of compassion.....I can not believe even if those faces look different but all are smiling and full of Love, Compassion, Sympathy and Equanimity.The one you can't miss it, especially late in the afternoon.

Amazing Temple. Take a lot of time for this temple. It is very complex but the more you climb the better you will find this temple. Some areas don't have tourists as most don't bother to discover all parts of the temple which gives you a some peace to sit and enjoy this temple.
Beautiful to see. I loved visiting all the Temples and seeing the History of the area. Amazing Ruins. It was nice to come here in June as it was a lot cooler than in May.
One more temple in Angkor. One more temple in Angkor. Altogether it is marvellous and breath-taking. However, it could be better conservation and more information for the visitors
tour visit angkor wat. He very professional , courteous ,safe and reliable . we note him as best tour guide in siem reap angkor wat when we are here .

Amazing Experience, but not sure if historian found/stated all true facts there. It’s almost a year we went there. I have to say it was a lifetime experience. The structure would be great representation of peace, power, tolerance and wisdom.During 500BC to 1500AD many emperors promote Buddhism and their non-violence philosophy. Emperor Ashok would another example. Most of us may have seen example when we or our parents born as per one religious and married or influence by other religious. For them Brahmanism/Hinduism and Buddhism tied very closely.One things which seems to me little odd during our visit we have seen many statue of Brahma, the creator (member of Trimurti or trinity). But many places the descriptions were not in sync or saying same thing.Not sure if in different language they call it different.There are still lot to find about this temple, place and history.I am already asking all my friends to visit and have this spiritual experience.

Blew my mind away!. If you are looking for something "different", then this is it. The faces speak to you. There are so many and so much time goes away in looking at them and understanding what they are trying to tell you. It is not a very huge complex. It is relatively smaller (than Angkor Wat), but it is magnificent. Definitely worth the visit. The architecture is a bit confusing. You will see pathways leading to nothing but a wall. And many walls put together - making no structure. It will fascinate you when you try to figure what is going on.There is a huge Budha temple right in front of it. Must visit. He is so peaceful and smiling, it is really beautiful.It is a 2$ tuk tuk ride from the city. Have a great time!
MAGNIFICIENT. A magnificient work, truly amazing like all the other temples in the area; but nonetheless unique in its own way. So many smiling faces to smile at. ;-)

iconic experience. This temple has faces everywhere -- both the stone faces carved into the towers, and the tired and glistening faces of the many tourists. This is really one of the main sights within Angkor Thom, and shouldn't be missed.

breath taking. not too big and just peacefully awesome. My top fav of them all. If you ever go Siem Reap, this is one of it that you shouldn't miss, despite the temple sickness u gonna have, dont miss this one

another great temple of siam reap. after visiting siam reap, my helpful tuk tuk driver brought me to Bayun Temple, its smaler than siam reap, but seeing the character if its temple, again i just loves being there and explore the temple. it just amazing temple again and again. im glad to made this trip and might spent more time to learn about cambodian people. thank you again to keep the place worth to visit.
Amazing. It is so amazing that hundred years ago could build such temple. I would definite recommend anybody to visit
bucket list check off. what else can be said? it is amazing! unless you like competing with a million other tourists and being hassled by the sad looking locals trying to sell stuff.
Amazing Temples. All the temples are interesting in their own way. Each one is different and represents incredible people and cultures
Simply beautiful. Not to be missed! It as a great day to go, cool with blue skies. Definitely added a little something special to have a tour guide with us. And especially nice to see by elephant.
Nice temple. This temple is worth the extra bit of searching, if the itinerary stretches to extra archaeological sites. Precautions for the heat may be necessary.

Another 'must see' temple. This is yet another temple that is well worth seeing. It has faces carved into the obelisk and is quite something. All the ruins have something different to offer but this one is a bit more special.

Great temple - no crowds. We loved this spot - there were virtually no other visitors the day we were there. Beware that as you start to explore, someone will offer to be your guide - it's worth the price of a tip to be walked through all of the nooks and crannies. One of our favorite temples on this trip.
Unique!. Wonderful sight to be seen. Probably the most interesting one in Angkor park. The detail in the faces is incredible. Highly hightly recommended!

Excellent. Bayon Temple is a great introduction to the temples of Angkor Archaeological Park. It will be busy but the earlier you go the better (this will also ensure you stay out of the heat of the day). Everywhere you look in this temple you will find serene, smiling faces looking down at you. It is almost as if they are welcoming you to the park. There are lots of nooks and crannies and places to explore also, but be careful as the cobblestones are of course very old and uneven. My fiancé did his ankle even though he is normally sure-footed. Wear good footwear and be patient when taking photos as people will walk in and out of your shot without even realising it (there are just too many people to avoid that kind of thing, hence the earlier you go, the better).

Impressive. This was the second time Siem Reap, temple was once again amazing and not as many to tourists. After seeing the temples in a Tuk Tuk the first time would definitely recommend using a private guide and car with air conditioning.
Amazing stone work. Better in the mornings when cooler and less crowded. The afternoons can be hot with all the black stone work of the site
Faces everywhere. Very nice place to visit. There are faces everywhere once you step into the temple compound. Interesting to see that the faces are all smiling no matter from what angles. :)

Bayon was more outstanding than angkor wat. I actually enjoyed the Bayon a lot more than the Angkor Wat. Loved all the details still preserved. Too many tourists on the day and time we went but we enjoyed it anyway
V Good. Within the Angkor Wat complex and the smiley temple - took guide for the day with aircon car US$85 - worth doing
Better than Angkor Wat!. We have seen many temples like Angkor Wat in India (south india especially), but Bayon is one of a kind. It is a must see in the temple complex.
Amazing temple!. The ruins of the Khmer civilisation around Siem Reap are among the most amazing and spectacular in the world and a rear joy for anyone interested in history and human endeavour.
Excellent but get there early!. Super-hot during the day and crowded. The earlier you arrive, the better. It quite amazing. Really something to see.

4 face temple. This beautiful temple was built by king Jayavarman VII, he was a Budhist, so Bayon is a Budhist temple. The 4 faces on the top towers facing 4 different directions are said to be the faces of the bodhisattva, but some also says that it picture the face of the king Jayavarman VII. It is said that there are 216 stone faces carved in this temple, which means it has 54 towers.The carvings are magnificent on such scale, that each faces resembles each other but some has it's unique such as the widest smile etc and sometimes if we see it from a viewpoint we can see as if the statues are having a conversation with each other. It is said that Bayon was built in a hurry due to the war at the time, since it is using smaller stones so that the condition right now is not as good as Angkor Wat and some of the carving are not finished.
awesome temple. so amazing - you must go there - the carved head are so detailed and interesting.I advise getting a guide as the give you detailed history and interesting info about the whole site

nose to nose. you will see sculpture faces every where. small, medium, big and giant. You see the best of carving and wonder. The faces are all smiling from any angle. Even one place, if you stand, looking up and your guide can take your picture, it comes out like side face that you are with big face 'Nose to Nose'. We went in afternoon but because of the hot weather, no crowd was there and we could see this very nicely and guide has describe that perfectly. Afternoon sun gave shadow at some places of the faces and it is the right situation for pictures. The faces are carved in all 4 direction with just right proportions and right level with next faces. many towers of faces and Simply Amazing !!

Very cinematic. We may have lucked out and rode here at just the right time between tour busses, but the place was nearly empty. At about 2pm the sun was very hot but shone in just the right way past the statues through incense smoke.

Great Elephant ride. Quite hot so good to see temples in the morning and rest in the afternoon. Loved the history, good idea to hire a guide. It was invaluable the history, the towers with the four faces on each were incredible to view in itself and the stories and carvings of pictures on the walls are really amazing to witness.

My favourite temple in Angkor Park. There are a lot of temples in the. Angkor Archeological Park and all of them are beautiful and some of them are so breathtakingly magical and ancient that you will never forget them.Out of all these temples, Bayon was my favourite. Do not miss it.I biked out one late afternoon just to visit Bayon. Arriving about 3:30pm most of the day's crowds had already dissipated. Then the monsoon rains came and only the brave and devoted remained. Just a dozen visitors exploring the site in the warm, afternoon rain.I wandered about, staring into the knowing eyes of the staring stone faces and wondered how many times the rains had washed their faces and how many people they had watched pass by over the last thousand years or so.One of the greatest experiences of my life. Don't miss it!
great temple. go either very early or late is day as is very hot! Make sure and take some cold water wear a hat and ladies you must wear shirt that covers shoulders and pants/capris that cover knees.

Loved the Giant Faces. This temple is amazing... away from the hustle and bustle of the main Angkor temple.
The giant carved faces are so beautiful and intricate! Loved just staring at them.
Go early/late, it gets busy in the afternoon (like all the temples do).

Temple of Many Faces. It's a spectacular temple with its many intricate carvings, it's worth to stop by, ponder and wonder about. Best to go early, much lesser crowd and better photo shots. You'll bum into a few freelance photographers who will explain briefly about the many faces of Buddha and take photos of you and of those interested. You'll be surprised when he shows up at the exit for his finished photos. We bought our family photos from him. Great ones though.

In the Middle of a Lush Forest Awesome. THe fact that there are no modern structures surrounding this temple really helps transport you to the days when it was still intact. Unlike most historical structures with fast food and stores surrounding them this one has none of those to ruin the picture perfect site. I hope they keep it that way
Love it here!. The faces sculpted were fantastic. Could have spent days here but will be back again. Make sure you go in with a guide! They know so much!

The smaller version of Angkor Wat. Well, the Buddha faces on the towers are just amazing. There's also beautiful cravings on the walls. Nice sceneries, interesting history, made the visit all worth it.

Even better then Angkor Wat. Really mistical place. Visited it twice and could visit even more. Being a center of Angkor Thom it played the same role as Angkor Wat and is trully amazing pieace of human art. If you are visiting Angkor for just one day this should be your second stop after Angkor.

Beautifully rich in details. The temple was very intricate with many beautiful carvings, which made it my favourite temple. We hired a guide who was able to highlight unique features and helped us take photos in the best locations.

Start here!. It is one of those OMG, jaw dropping moments! It is a rich but compact complex with 37 towers and spectacular bas-reliefs. To get the best light on the sculptures, early mornings and late afternoons are best. Do both if you can as the light hits different sets of bas-reliefs, towers... Having a good guidebook is essential to see every nook and cranny.

Beyond my imagination!. The most magical place I've ever been. This temple of all of its most famous counterparts, is to me, a more fascinating historical and heritage reference than its older and more well known brother temple.

My fav temple!. The Bayon is my fav temple out of all the temples in Angkor Thom. It's located at the very center of the Angkor Thom and it was built by the God King, Jayavarman VII. Some say that the 216 giant heads decorating the temple, bear more than just a passing resembles to the great king himself! Definitely the epitome of the kings genius and giant ego.
So many faces. This is one of the most amazing things I have seen. Looking around this temple is both erie and mesmerising. Looking back at my photos of this I still think how amazing it is.

Simply Stunning. I loved this place so much, I had the temple tattooed on my arm! A wonderful experience and I hope to go back some day soon. The entrance fee was about $20 which is amazing value when you consider the significance of the site you are entering. I spent two great days here and covered pretty much the whole entire site.
Terrific Temple. One of our big four for the day. Simply awesome and a must visit. A word of warning - lots of stairs, but well worth it.
Amazing!. We thought this temple rivaled Angkor Wat in its splendor. Take an elephant ride around the temple to experience it differently

A must see !. One is humbled by the sheer size and construction of this Temple. It is hard to believe that this was all done by many hands. Worth every moment spent in the heat and humidity - take water with you and a cloth to wipe your face!

Well preserved. Bayon is one of those temples that you just must visit! It was our first stop and we spent there around 2 hours. Very beautiful and well preserved temple. The towers with stone faces are what makes Bayon so special. It was primarily dedicated to the Buddha but later altered to Hinduism and other religions.

Huge Wat; Lots to See. We spent the most time at this Wat. There is a lot to see inside so plan to allot +2 hrs for this one. Monkeys a cute but will try to take your bag if you don't keep an eye on it. Also there tends to be a lot of uniformed people that will give you pointers and expect some money. Don't fall for it. When they ask where you are from or start giving you some history nuggets, just ignore them and keep walking.
Must See. It is as impressive as the brochures say. We went early morning, avoided the crowds and therefore got some nice photos without tourists.

I love this temple.. Beautiful temple. My favourite in the Angkor complex. It's just wonderful. It can be crowded, but then that's Angkor these days. It's the only temple I always visit when I come to Siem Reap.

back at the bayon. I can not work the Bayon out, it is so much different from the other temples. it does not matter how many times i go round this temple, its got me baffled. it has more of a palace feel to it, were as the other temples are more for worship and celebration, maybe ime looking at it wrong, but I can spend hours deep in thought trying to figure it out. its a good job I have a understanding tuk tuk driver.

One of the best Temples to visit!. This temple in the middle of Angkor Thom is totally impressive! The 216 faces are amazing. Try to come either early morning or later in the afternoon when the light is better for photographs. If you can squeeze your visit in between tour groups, it's even better - but good luck with that!

Omg. The absolute standout of the 10 or so temples I visited, not counting Angkor Wat of course. Bayon should be on everyone's list to visit when doing Angkor. The architecture, the atmosphere, the views from the top of the ruins. My words will not do it justice.....
Amazing Temple. The faces were so huge and the facial features were slightly different on each 49 plus 5 others, walkways easy to manage once one negotiated the two small flights of stairs.

Amazingly stunning and mysteriously charming!. It's my favorite place in Angkor trip... you must not miss it! The "Bayon smile" is so charming with all the stone carving detail that would amazed everyone. Try to be there in the morning and spare at least 2-3 hours for visit as there 're so many detail to observe and admire.
MUST SEE TEMPLE AREA. We chose to see Angkor Wat first and then Bayon the following day. Go EARLY to beat the crowds and the heat. Partially restored and fabulous!!!!!

Nice addition to the other temples you'll see. One of the must see temples when you visit Siem Reap
Make a list of temples you want to see and include this one for teh diversity in look and feel getting a complete experience of all the differences there are in temples.
Don't miss. I can't imagine how did they bring so much huge blocks of granite and placed them correctly. It is really an engineering marvel of the by gone era.

legendary. If you have time to visit only one temple then make sure it is Bayon. It will blow your mind. the smiling Buddhas of Bayon are amongst the world heritage sites for good reason, they are a pure gem of Khmer architecture. The bas reliefs of the temple alone are worth the visit.

Amazing Smiles. From outside it looks like a pile of stones but once you are inside you almost get hypnotised by the smiles everywhere. Unfortunately the hordes of tourist make it pretty hard to enjoy it in peace (my first visit was 1995 - incredible then).

Great short visit. This temple is relatively compact and with no walls so easy to access. It is nice to wonder around the maze like construction, which also provides a great respite from the unforgiving Cambodian sun:-)

Faces Around. For whom likes old ruins it is great, full of history and makes you feel inside a movie.
Try to count how many faces are on the construction it is a funny exercise.
Amazing place to visit. Interesting temple to visit. Good photography study opportunity. Be sure that your battery is fully charged!
Must Go. It's like stepping back in time. Awesome and so worth the visit. You have to be there to realise how amazing it is. Magical.

Worth a visit. While at Angkor Wat it is well worthwhile to see the other temples. If you go early enough you will be able to avoid the worst heat in the middle of the day but prices are reasonable enough that you could spread your visit over a couple of days. Pack a raincoat or umbrella just in case.

Charming. beautiful temple. Go very early in the morning to avoid large touristic groups otherwise you will miss the beauty of the temple. Have both far and close look. As the guide to explain you the stories told by the walls.
There are many monks around, act respectful and dress properly (cover your shoulders and knees)

The most remarkable of all. For me, Bayon was the most remarkable temple e saw in the region. The smiling faces on all the towers are stunning and differentiate Bayon from all other temples. An absolute must see in theis region

Mystical. I liked Bayon Temple better than Angkor Wat! We visited in the late afternoon and the colors were gorgeous. This temple didn't seem as crowded as Angkor Wat - it was intimate, mystical, secluded and hauntingly beautiful.
The best temple. If you have time to see 1, go and see this one and I hope you be there without large groups at same time. A spiritual place with beautiful Buddha faces. One of the very best !

One of my favorite temples in Siem Reap. We started off our sightseeing of the temple with the Bayon Temple South Gate. It was a gate in the centre with the churning of the ocean depicted on either side by huge stone monuments of asuras and devas on either side. The Bayon temple was built around 1190 AD as the official state temple of Buddhist King Jayavarman VII, and, also known as a temple of beaming faces, it is in the centre of the ancient city of Angkor Thom (means great city). The Bayon Temple is a three-tiered pyramid consisting of 51 towers each, with a head facing each of the four directions. In all there are more than 11,000 carved figures over 1.2 kms of wall.Head on north from the Bayon and we reached the temple of Baphuon. No shorts or sleeveless allowed here. Continuing on north is the Terrace of the Elephants, a 300m-long terrace used originally as a royal reception pavilion, with its name derived from the carvings of elephants on the wall. Next to the Terrace of the Elephants is the Terrace of the Leper King. Walk along the 7m high wall with bands of bas-reliefs and intricate carvings. It is called Leper King because the stone was being eroded in parts of the ruins, giving it the leper effect. The entire area is stunning - the architecture of the carvings, the intricacy, the fact that it has lasted this long..make sure you take a hat or an umbrella though, or else you'd easily pass out from the heat!
Nice temple with many faces. Make sure you can go up and take the view with the faces. Be there early in the morning since majority of the touring are still in Angkor Wat :)
beautiful. These temples still feel untouched and unique. Take a camera! Go early morning to avoid the heat in May.

AMAZING TAMPLE!!!. We have stayed in Siem Reap for one week,which was really cool city,really like over there!We have visited Temples for 3 days,and I have to say that Angkor WAT was really nice to see,and people are like it the most,but for me BAYON TEMPLE was the most stunning one,just AMAZING with 216 Faces on Towers;)Well worth to visit!!!B.u.J.o (;)xxx

Beautiful Temple. The temple is exquisite and very beautiful. a must see when you visit the angkor temples. its ironic that people visit siem reap to see the beautiful ruined temples but the government is trying to restore it.
It's a wonder.. For us by far the best place in and around Angkor. One of those places that transports you to another level in life. Truly life changing and a place you will always remember.

Excellent - especially from an elephant. This is a great temple - we did it both walking and on elephant. If you are on the elephant you get a much better view and therefore photos, than when you are on the ground. well worth a visit.

Awesome!. It seems silly to review these amazing monuments...these temples that are the very reason we all visit Siem Reap. Bayon Temple is exquisite and you WILL see it. Make sure your camera battery is fully charged. Enjoy. This temple is included in your Angkor Pass. (We bought a three day pass that allowed us to see all the temples, without feeling rushed.)
magnifique. there's such character that makes you shiver when you stand on its doorway. that temple is too awesome you need to buy a t-shirt with bayon pictures on it..
The Giant faces of Bayon. This is one of the highlights within the Angkor Thom centre. Some of these carved stone faces appear to be smiling. Have a look at the attached photos.

A must!. Bayon is one of those temples that you just must visit! It was our first stop and we spent there around 2 hours. Very beautiful and well preserved temple. The towers with stone faces are what makes Bayon so special. It was primarily dedicated to the Buddha but later altered to Hinduism and other religions.

one of the most amazing temple ive ever seen. wonderful piece of art in the jungle, next to angk kor pi temples, dont miss bayon, early in the morning if you can, its just amazing, like being in a videogame or so. little entrance everywhere, possibility to climb on top, feeling is magical

Buddha faces. We visited the Bayon at around 11am and it wasn't too crowded. From afar the Bayon looks magnificent. Bayon is constructed from many smaller stones as compared to the other temples so there are many textures and sharp edges. Somehow this temple gave me a messy feeling maybe because of the sharp edges. Climb to the top for more upclose Buddha faces. I especially liked the top levels whereby the Buddha faces are big and clear and the pathways are slightly narrow. The entire atmosphere at the top is special. Recommended :)

Wow. Absolutely awe inspiring. Every temple I visited in siem reap was mind blowing. The most intricate carvings and large structures. I visited here Angkor wat and ta phrom all in one day and had the most amazing time the views were spectacular and the smiling Buddha faces are just something else.
Elephant Walk. The elephant ride INSIDE the temple was a lot of fun. Gives you a circle tour of the temple. Our elephant was the fast one, leaving the others in her dust.

Soo interesting. This was one of the temples our guide included in our trip. It was obviously his favourite and I could see why. It was so endearing to hear him talk about his ancestors when telling us about the temple.

Temple of the smiley faces. A stunning photo awaits if you don't look in front of you all the time. Not for the unfit, but well worth it. It was extremely hot and humid in April, and this was our 3rd and last temple of the day (couldn't take more than that in the hottest month of the year) - I skipped climbing the steps and just sat in a quiet corner with a beautiful view waiting for hubby. The smiley faces are still beautiful (restored?) after all these years
Smiles of the king. There are many different smiles carved on the stone and the moment you are there, it's like you're in one of the movie - Indiana Jones.
Worth a visit. The faces make for very interesting photos, the ruins are great for climbing up to get good views. Make sure you kiss the Buddah.
must see place. heritage treasure... one of the wonder world.amazed how the people can make it.... and our generation thankful to be able to see it.
Always my favourite. Small enough temple to visit within one hour and next to the Elephant Terrace (been there twice in four years).
Favorite Temple. I think every traveler I met in Siem Reap agreed that this is the most beautiful temple in Angkor Complex.

Majestic Bayon. It was a huge temple, lovely engravings everywhere to look at,
lots of art work, some very steep steps to climb.
my fav temple. Bayon was breathtaking - each tower had 4 faces and each face showed a different emotion..Its a great spot for taking pictures..and a must see on ones visit to Angkor
very interesting. Historical Place... a little bit dangerous, as the stone might fall down any times. Watch your step ... :)

Bring your camera. The sheer number of these hand carved stone figures is overwhelming and their placement in this temple is a wonder to behold. Bring your cameras as this has more than normal things to photograph. Hiring a guide is recommended, there are some young wanta be guides - not certified - that you can slip (10-20) to for the tour. This area can be seen best by climbing and negotiating some narrow steps - not for those with very limited mobility.
Seam Reap. The people are nice and friendly. the features are similar to any place in Africa. I just like to visit Seam Ream the second time

Simply Marvelous. This was my favorite stop of our time spent exploring the magnificent temples in Siem Reap. Definitely worth every drop of sweat endured on this day. Drink plenty of water and make sure your camera has a full battery charge because everywhere you look is a magnificent photo opportunity. We started our exploring early in the morning so as to avoid the peak sun and there didn't seem to be crazy crowds of people. We made it here towards the end of our temple tour so I was pretty tired by this point but so worth it, I highly recommend.
Amazing and Wonderful Trip !. The Bayon Temple so amazing upon in viewing with the unique. The places just so wonderful and nice for photo shooting too. Love the place so much.

Definitely on my top 2 of all the Angkor temples. Different from all the other temples. Faces on the towers were exquisite. Great workmanship. One of the most interesting temples. I like this even more than the great Angkor Wat

216 faces of Buddha. The temple pass for Ankor way includes Bayon Temple and Ankor Thom and is valid for 3 days. It includes the authority for your camera. Check with your tour guide/agent to see if video cameras covers. As on some sites/attractions an additional fee can apply. It is an interesting testament of both Hindu and Buddhist influences
Incredible. This is my favourite of all the temples don't miss this one. I highly recommend a visit, our photos looked just like the ones the kids try to sell you!

A master piece of Khmer architecture. Bayon Temple is a must visit when you travel to Cambodia. An amazing temple for its unique construction and this is truly a master piece of the Khmer architecture. A guide is mandatory if you are going to this place.

Well worth a visit. This temple is great to visit as it is a nice contrast to Angkor Wat with the many faces on the temple towers. It is quite accessible compared to Angkor Wat and not too many steps to negotiate compared with others.
Spectacular Temple. There has many giant stone faces inside the temple. You also can find 'The Smile of Angkor' among those faces. It's one of my favorite temple.

Our favourite temple!. This really was our favourite temple of 8 visited. There is no denying that Angkor Wat is magnificent, but this temple stole our hearts and I really cannot explain why. Many people we talked to that had visited the temples rated this as one of their top favourites. So if you are trying to decide on which temples to see, I would add this as a definite must!

Very interesting but hot and busy. On the main tourist run - gets inundated with tourist buses. In April it was very warm walking around.Enjoyed the elephant ride around the Bayon temple - cost $15 a person plus $1 to feed the elephant a pineapple - certainly not the most comfortable ride but a must do if you are in Asia.

Unique creation. This is the most amazing creation as it's more unique as compared with other Angkor temples. For some camera fun, you can tilt your photo angle and take some interesting 'nose to nose touching' photos with the budhha head!!

Bayon Early Morning. best to get to the south gate and visit the Bayon prior to the bus loads of people that enter in after the sunset viewing at Angkor Wat. To get ahead of the crowd get to the Bayon early 600am - 630. We prefer to visit Angkor Wat the first afternoon for sunset, this gives you plenty of time to see it before the next morning...you can then see the sun rise if its clear and then move along to Bayon Quickly.
Amazing. I liked this even more than Angkor Wat!! It was truley awe inspiring. Try to get there erly so you have a little time before it getsf too crowded. Don't miss it.

Never gets old. Third trip here in the past couple of years, and Bayon never gets old. The 214 makes you feel like they are looking straight at you and trying to tell you the secrets of life. This is one of my favorite temples in Angkor.
Awesome. This is an awesome temple - favourite in Angkor Wat - get there early to avoid hoards of tourists. In fact, get to all the temples as early as possible for that very reason

Cool heads. Angkor Wat gets all the hype, but the cool, 4-sided heads at Bayon are what I will probably remember most from the temples in Angkor.Bayon was a really impressive with the size and cool that you could explore the temple and get face to face with some of the large stone faces. Really a unique temple, and definitely one of the highlights of the visit.
Authentic. Beautiful and mystic. Try visiting that one in the morning to avoid crowds and enjoy privacy for you photos.

The beautiful carved faces are worth a look. This is another magnificent temple complex. The thing that sets it apart from others is that it has giant carved stone faces, each with a serene smile and countenance. You have to do a lot of climbing around, but it is worth it. Go early in the morning to beat the heat.

The most picturesque Temple of all!!. If you spend 2 days in the Angkor city, after a while all the temples start to look the same, but I can never get enough of the facade of the Bayon!!! Of all the temples, this temple looks the best standing 150ft away from the main entrance.
Sun block, water and a hat. Astonishing, impressive and so different to the constructions of other ancient cultures.The heat and the humidity are constant, as well as lots of visitors.
Magnificent!!. Must see!! One of the most beautiful temples I ever saw. Very Intricate Very detailed!! 10 times better and more beautiful than Angkor Wat. A must see!!!
Amazing. Words cannot describe this site. It is part of a massive world heritage park and you can't see it all in a day.

My favorite temple at Angkor. Bayon is famous for the large faces carved in the stone (according to our guide it's still disputed whether the faces are those of the Buddha or the king), and it didn't disappoint. There are multiple levels in the temple, allowing you to get up close and personal with the faces for some great photos. There's a shrine in the centre tower with a very spiritual feeling and a couple of locals tending the shrine (they'll show you how to make a prayer and give you a string bracelet for a small offering). Combine with Ta Prohm and Angkor Wat for almost the best day tour you'll ever experience.

Enchanting!. The serenity & peacefulness, the wonder & awe of the giant faces. This amazing temple has stayed with me & I have to say for me this sits at number 1 with Angkor Wat. We visited in the late afternoon and the Sun light on these amazing serene smiling faces was nothing short of breathtaking.This is really heaven on earth.
Amazing. I love the amazing architectural of this temple. Full of art and details of every part of it's segment.

Facing the Budha Face. A unique , grand statue of Budha Faces all around you with his smile facing your face and a tranquil eyes looking at you everywhere you look around . a magnificent peace of art.

My favourite temple. Spent a week in Nov 2012 for my second visit to Angkor, Bayon is my favorite temple.. It's also a magical place if it happens to rain. It's spectacular to walk around it immediately after rainfall.Personally I'm a fan of the "tuk tuk" experience around Angkor (don't worry, they're much different and less hassle than in Thailand!), my driver in 2006, and 2012 was Peach you can contact him directly at yimpheach@yahoo.com he's a great guy! People that want to take pictures shouldn't ride in an Aircon vehicle, unless you like condensation of course.

You can't miss Bayon!. Bayon gives you a clear history of the Hinduism and Buddhism influence in the civilization. The structure still stands strong with faces that are clearly visible in the amazing architecture of that time. It's almost unbelievable the way it was constructed and what has lasted until today. You cant go without visiting this temple. It's an obvious Must Do!

a Must See site. The size of Bayon within Angkor Thom is impressive. This is the state temple of Jayavarman VII and sits at the centre of Angkor Thom. Although there are only 37 of the original 54 towers still standing that is a lot - one can only wonder at what it must have looked like in its prime - they were decorated with 216 faces of Avalokiteshvara. Typical of this area visitors can get up close and when it comes to the Bas Reliefs that is good, a number of them showing scenes from day to day life such as stone cutters at work and people playing chess.

Simply awe inspiring. We probably preferred this marginally to Angkor Wat as the variety in the complex is jaw dropping and marginally easier to navigate in the heat. Be sure your camera batteries are charged.

Awksome & Mind Blowing. The construction was majestic and fantastic. The overall size was mammoth and big. The detailing and sculpture were extremely fine. It was equally impressive from the inside and ourside. It is worth the trip.
One of the most beautiful temple. Not to be missed! You can take amazing pics of this temple. If you are not a big fans of temple - this one should be on your list. Very well preserved.

Better than Angkok Wat. Preferred this to angkor wat. we got here around sunset which made it even more breathtaking. really amazing temple and carvings. be aware that this temple does not have the wooden steps provided like the other ones and going up and down stairs is pretty steep.

breathtaking bayon. the buddha face carvings make this temple extremely unique. next to angkor wat it is a must see. make sure you climb as far as you can as it is worth the trip and good exercise as well.
2nd time vist. 2nd time I have visited - there are still so many things that you miss - you will always fin something you missed time after time

Beautiful Bayon. Beautiful, intricate carvings and sculptures. Breathtaking size of the Temple overall and the massive size of the face sculptures on the towers. Great to see the restoration work in progress.
excellent budha face carvings. excellent budha face carvings. is a good place for photo taking. there were a little climbing but very safe.

Must see - great short tour. This is a must visit on your temple tour list. Great photo ops at the top of the temple near the iconic faces, and it's fascinating to see the current restoration work in action. There are some steep steps to the top - difficult with small children.
Most beautiful temple I have ever seen!. We loved this temple, definitely THE temple to see in ANgkor... Do not miss it! (and prefer the visit around 4-5pm)

Interesting temple. Interesting temple- lots of Avalokiteshvara faces-216? supposedly; you can make funny photos with them. People are helpful with explaining the temple carvings but expect a significant tip afterward

Watch out for the Chinese Tour Groups. Great historical temple. At the current moment they are doing a lot of restoration work but its still worth a visit.My only advice is to go very early in the morning to avoid the Chinese tour groups as they are completely overwhelming and have no sense of personal space, speaking in a normal tone - seemed like everyone, and I mean everyone was yelling. Even the Cambodians were having a hard time with them.
Fun!. Too bad it was so hot and humid - we hurried a bit through but were still in awe and couldn't take enough pictures!! Make sure your battery is freshly charged - the heat kills them fast!
The best. even if everyone goes to angkor wat I found this one the best. Try some Pictures in the afternoon, with warm light.
Must see. One of the "must see" in Angkor Wat. You'll be facing Buda all the time. Prepare to walk a little bit, also.

Another Great Temple. Further to Angkor Wat temple about 3km, there is another great temple we love on our visit in the afternoon.
