This temple looked bigger than Angkor Wat as there are many temples were build. We spend about 3 hours before we move back to Bakheng Mountain for the sunset. We did really enjoy our first day tour.
Loved all the smiling faces. Every tower had a smiling face. Smaller than Angkor Wat, but worth the visit also. Great exploring and admiring the huge stone statues.

bayon smile. One of must visit temple in angkor world heritage.. all of bayon faces as a tower are stunning..all of the walls are full of carving..
All of temple in angkor world are worth to see.. just dont miss them..

Very charming temple. How can you not be charmed when the temple itself smiles at you! With its 216 smiling faces, and its walls of colorful stones depicting images of Ancient Khmer every day life, Bayon temple is not only majestic and impressive, but endearing as well.

My wifes Favourite!!. Having seen the all the temples on Tv we were wondering which would be our favourites.There was something special about Bayon even though most of it was damaged just seeing those smiling stone statues was in credible.We really enjoyed our viist as it was crowded when we were there
Bayon Temple. The Bayon seem to be Temple is much smaller than Ankor Wat, but with the faces on every tower ! So i like to seeing Bayon temple!

world heritage. a must see while you are in Siem Reap
Not only the main temple Angkor Wat, but also many more silent or "hidden" places are worth a visit
Khmer smile. You can see a lot of Khmer smile with different face here. But i cant see the difference maybe for i dint take much notice on that. Yet, worth to go.

Simply breathtaking. Bayon Temple is like a giant maze with so many identical-looking small rooms and steps.
The temple itself is a stunning sight to behold, with more than 20 smiling Buddhas in the temple. You can easily catch a glimpse of the smiling Buddhas wherever you are in the temple.
Everyone visiting the Angkor must visit this temple.

A must see. The Bayon Temple is much smaller than Ankor Wat, but with the faces on every tower it is just a stunning experience. If only there weren't all these other people everywhere to have the same one.
amazing place. majestic..did my pre-wedding shoot there and the whole ambience was so captivating. Had the best time of my life

My guide's favorite. Bayon was my guide's favorite temple and I can see why. Bayon is located in Angkor Thom, second most famous temple in Angkor National Park (after Angkor Wat) but it is equally if not more beautiful. The relief sculpture carved into this master work of art and engineering is breathtaking and the entrance way graced by statuary could not be more dramatic. This temple is a must visit.
just great. It was really a wonderfull place. The faces in the stones make you feel good. It is quite large , so you can wonder around for a couple of hours. take a guide
Interesting temple with Buddha faces. This temple is interesting as it has over 200 faces of Buddha carved all over it. The wall carvings are beautiful and ornate.

The best. Loved Bayon, the best of all. Make sure to visit Bayon early morning to avoid the crowd and heat. I was amazed to see the beautiful carvings and details in this temple. Early morning is the best because there will be less crowd and you can get better pictures.

My favorite temple. This temple of smiling faces for me is the best. Very mysterious and beautiful, anywhere you look. It's fascinating to touch the carvings that are almost a century old. Take your time, you'll just be amazed how many faces there are to discover in unexpected angles and places.
Gorgeous!. Bring insect repellant! Beautiful place though, very mystical. Be careful of the children that try to sell you things.

Must visit. The very first temple we visited in Siem Reap. I was in awe watching those huge face like monument. make sure to get ready your feet before continuing visiting all the temples. A very nice experience.

The second biggest after Angkor Wat. If Angkor wat style is classical, the Bayon temple has baroque style of Khmer architecture. I came to this temple after finishing Angkor Wat. All the trip in Angkor complex is awesome except the weather. I dislike it because it so hot, burning my skin. I suggested you to visit in the morning because it starts open at 05.30 am to 05.30 pm
simply the best. Bayon for me was the best temple among all. I just loved the intricate carvings and the unique details on every corner. I wished I had more time and stayed longer.

Faces, Faces and more Faces..... Seeing the ruins at Bayon was so impressive. I agree with an earlier reviewer, pictures don't do justice to the gigantic faces constructed all around this temple. They are a sight to see ...so many different faces that seem to change in the changing light. When you visit, if possible avoid being here at midday...it is not only hot among the stone ruins but the early morning light or light late in the afternoon will be better for pictures. We made a game out of trying to get as many faces as possible in a picture.

The best temple along with angkor wat. I loved this temple complex the best along with angkor wat. The indian style temples are magnificient. Wear supportive shoes so you dont twist your ankle like i did at Tha Phrom. Hat, towel or neck protection is a must, as is having your shoulders covered.
Fabulous!. Unless you run through the complex, you will need half a day to see it and take the elephant ride around (great for the kids!). Awe-inspiring...
Smiling Buddha. Try climbing up the steep stairs to the top (next to the main structure) , it's a different view up there. but coming down is scary.

Cover up. Longish walk up a hill to the temple to be told you can't get in to the temple if you (FEMALES) are not wearing a long sleeved top! A scarf to cover your shoulders was not acceptable. Many others were left like myself sitting at the bottom of the temple having been told by guides/hotel staff and others that there was no dress code. ALWAYS, ALWAYS CARRY A LONG SLEEVED TOP EVERYWHERE YOU GO OR YOU WILL DEFINITELY REGRET ITi
Below expectation. Maybe too high expectation as it's rated high in almost all kinds of travelogue we read. The Khmer smile is nice.

Incredible. I think there is something about coming up to one of the gates to enter Angkor Thom that takes your breath away. No matter how many photos you have seen of the Faces, you are not prepared for the real thing. The size is enormous and adds to the grandeur of the entire site. Bayon was the highlight of our trip to Siem Reap. We came for Angkor Wat, but left with a camera full of photos of Bayon. Climbing and walking among the temple walls itself was awe-inspiring. Do go in the morning when the light hits the temple just right and the detail of the carvings is most distinct. Also, I recommend it for sunrise - much better than Angkor Wat - the sun coming up and hitting the temple faces is amazing and really lights up the beautiful color of the stone. We spent hours just touring inside the walls of Angkor Thom and most of that time was spent in Bayon. But don't miss the other temples and the terraces, it is all very worthwhile.
All the faces. Bayon Temple part of Angkor Thom is a geat temple with lots and lots of stone faces, great picture opportunity and heights to walk around. Highly recommended
Awesome. For my money , the 2nd best temple out there, Really enjoyed it, I was there for the new year which made it very very busy but is a definite Must see

Stunning sculptures and nice walks. This was my second favourite of the temple areas in the Ankor Wat complex. This is the place where you see all the carved faces. Lots of good walking through shady paths and, once inside the temple there are corridors after corridors of exhibits. We didn't bother with a guide and loved every minute.

Very beautiful. Bayon temple, although smaller than Angkor Wat, looks more outstanding than the latter. I suggest you go here after seeing Angkor Wat since the distance is not that far. Hiring a private car is a smart option as the weather is very hot and the road is dusty if you'd prefer to bike or take a tuktuk. Once inside, you will see different faces carved into stones. Too bad a lot of portion was under renovation when we went there last April 23, otherwise it would've been perfect! I prefer Bayon temple over Angkor Wat, just an honest opinion.
Stunning!. This temple is for me the stunning in Siem Reap - even more so than Angkor Wat! Tall and domineering, the faces carved into all the towers are breathtaking. Definitely worth a visit!

A well-restored masterpiece. I visited Angkor Wat in 1966, when some of the restoration was just beginning. The Bayon is one of several that are more accessible now, and one gets a better sense of what it all looked like before the jungle took over.

very hot work. lots of steps, take plenty of water with you.didnt like young kids every 10 feet stopping and asking you to buy things, i know they only trying to make a living, but they dont leave you alone.
nice to start off with!. this is a nice spot to start the adventure with in the morning after 9. this site is pretty and has its ancient uniqueness.
Being restored and interesting. As with most Cambodian ancient temples, they are in disrepair but being restored. This is a temple that is worth seeing for it's interesting design and size.

Loved it. Went here on my tour of Angkor Wat and all the other temples. I really enjoyed this area and wished I had more than one day to spend. It was amazing to see this temple and the all the hard work put in to build this place. Make sure you pack plenty of water, cause it is very hot here even when I went on the 1st of March. I really liked this temple just as much as the other 5 that I went to.

Captivating!. We visited Bayon after Angkor Wat and Ta Phrom and this is my favourite out of the 3! Bayon offered a sense of serenity and calm and it is simply captivating. It also helped that there wasn't a crowd when we visited at 11am. Like previous reviewers mentioned, you have to be there to experience its beauty. Not to be missed!

Just when you thought you were "templed out....". Another fantastic temple in the Angkor Thom complex. The faces are sublime. Like almost all of the temples in the area, completely overrun by enormous Chinese tour groups. Apparently it's common practice to combine a number of individual groups (keeps the cost down), thus only one guide needs to be hired. This arrangement, unfortunately, also requires the use of a loudhailer. It's a real pain in the backside to wait for the opportunity to photograph something - whilst 50 people take it in turn to pose in front of exactly the same thing. They also have yet to learn the concept of putting their litter in a bin! Angkor Thom was the only complex where we were persued by groups of children flogging 10 postcards for $1. Their English was, actualy, better than theiy initially let on...One persistent young lady, having listened to me say "no thank you" over and over again to the postcards then pulled a selection of trinkets (all $1) from her bag. Once again, I said "no ", to which she replied "how about yes". Couldn't fault her for trying!

My favourite temple of the 7 we experienced. Thanks to our guide, Mr Hang Borey we experienced Bayon on our first evening with hardly any other tourists. A spiritual experience if the any faces of Bayon.
Magical. Liked this temple more than Angkor Wat, really magical with all the smilling faces and quit large as well.Try to avoid the crowds by going early in the morning or late in the afternoon.

A Must-See Temple. Our next stop after Ta Prohm was Bayon. I enjoyed looking at the giant stone faces connected to Khmer art and architecture.According to our guide, there are 37 standing towers, most but not all sporting four carved faces. The temple provided great photo opportunities for us.

Nothing different. Too much like all the others--nothing new or different. After all, how much time do you want to spend climbing around these ruins. Stick to Angkor Wat and Banteay Srei--that will be enough for the average person.

Wonderful art!. The Bayon was one of my favorite temples over there.
It's simly amazingly pretty! The location is wonderful!
A MUST see!

Simply amazing. Can't write about it, it's something you need to see by yourself and will not be sorry.
It's worth a couple of days in Cambodia just for the temples.

Amazing temple of faces. Love the faces at this temple. Didn't take a long time. Look out for the ladies that sell you luck. Making u light incense and pray and they give you a lucky bracelet, then ask for a donation. $1 is ,ore than enough!

One of the top 3 to see. Several temples in the area and you may eventually get "templed out" s make sure you get to see this one and do not skip it.
It is one of the more interesting to visit and does not take too long to see. Love those faces all over this one.
Amazing. This is in the top 5 of temples to visit around Siem Reap. Make sure your guide takes a photo of you facing one of the faces then you have a symmetrical face silhouette photo!

Very special place. Very special place, the architecture is amazing, based on exact astronomical alignments and sacred geometry, I have been told the heads with 4 faces represent enlightened consciousness, and the pine cone tops representing the pineal gland ( crown chakra) also very intresting there are meditation chambers positioned directly underneath them. Amazing place. The people who built them must have held wisdom beyond they are given credit for. if your here visiting Angkor wat make sure you get at least a couple of days pass and see all tha amazing temples. They are all so magical. Some of the prymids are very simuler to the pyramids in south America! So intresting! Must visit.

Very pretty. One of our 'must do's and we weren't disappointed. Remember to cover your shoulders for this one, a few westerners were wandering around in singlets and got funny looks from the locals, though everyone was too polite to say...

Main temple in the Angkor complex. The Bayon is a must see if you're visiting the Angkor complex.If you have the time, come very early morning to avoid the crowds, although I didn't seem to get a respite in Angkor Wat, it's trampled by hoards of tourists like myself :)

Recommended. Is a place where the stone shows Buddha faces. Alot alot of Buddha faces almost everywhere. I really feel amazed by it.
:) must bring sun block and keep self hydrated. Food is available in Angkor wat but at more expensive rate. So we ate breakfast and had our lunch outside like in the old market which is much cheaper.
My Favorite Temple. This one was awesome. Amazing pictures, unbelievable setting, lots of shade. Take a guide if you can, lots to hear about Bayon.
Brilliant!. A great temple worth seeing. Absolutely amazing how they made everything and it is in a really good shape.

Best at dawn. Tuk tuk drivers might persist to see Angkor Wat at sunrise, when we arranged a private tuk tuk we said 5 times the day before and again on the day itself that we wanted to go to Bayon. On the grounds our driver asked some guards at Angkor and they gave permission. Our driver left us at Bayon and would meet with us later around the elephant terrace. At5:30 am we were on our own and for the next hour or so we only saw 2 other couples. It was very peaceful and we loved exploring the temple and climbing into it. When we returned later that day to ride an elephant, we noticed that they were doing restructering work on one of the sides, so we not only beat the crowds but also the builders!
Must visit. So much detail, you will find many interesting photo spots. I visited in the late afternoon and its not too overly crowded.
Wow!. Been there many times and still got amazed of the site! Love the trees, the ruins and all the stories. I actually love Bayon Temple more than the Angkor Wat!
Majestic. It was one of the most beautiful, mouth-dropping temples i've ever visited. Go in the afternoon for best lighting and less crowds.
Maybe the best temple in Siem Reap. This temple is amazing! You'll feel like Indiana Jones. Make sure you notice the differences in faces carved and the positions of the columns. All has meaning.

Has to be seen to be believed!. This temple site was the last on the agenda on our day tour of the Angkor area. Bayon is situated in the centre of Angkor Thom (an ancient city built in the 12 century), and has to be seen to be believed. It is an extremely decorative temple containing over 200 stone carvings of a variety of massively large faces that reportedly bear a strong resemblance to the King that ordered the temple to be built - King Jayavarman V11. The faces are fascinating to look at and no two seem alike! We found the temple itself to be small in size but jam packed with things to look at. 1 hour is enough to dedicate to this temple. The parking area is well shaded so take the opportunity as you just don't know when your next shady tree will be! We travelled in March and believe me every shady tree was a blessing!Bayon is a must see whilst visiting Siem Reap
it's where you must visit!. try to get a photo at the entrance , and go up to the top to have an observation at the bayon smile, that's the best place where you should get some photo :)
Cool faces. Doesn't take too long to visit, but the profiles of the faces around this temple are really beautiful
Gorgeous. What more can you say about this temple within Angkor Thom. It's multitude of faces are amazing. Not to be missed.

Better than imagined.. Amazing temple complex.It begins with the arch you pass under. Don't miss it. We went early in the morning and rode an elephant around the temple and the drivers played music with leaves as we rode. A stand-out experience, complete with sound track.
Even better that Angkor Wat. As a whole (part of Angkor Thom), it's even more satisfying than Angkor Wat. Sunrise or sunset, this place is beautiful and mysterious.

Fav temple. Out of all temples this one stands out as my favorite. It is quite different from the other temples as this one was a Buddhist temple, which also make it the favorite temple of most Cambodians.

a must.... i like everything about it. the architecture and the solemnity it gives despite the hundreds of people visiting the temple. We went there in the afternoon just before sunset, so it wasn't that hot but i suggest u bring water and make sure u are ready to climb up and down long stairs...

Loved the many smiling faces. This was one of my favourite temples with all the smiling faces. The guide explained to us that the 54 towers (including the gate towers for the complex) represented the 54 provinces of Cambodia. Got some great pictures and the climb wasn't too bad compared to some of the other temples. I wouldn't miss this temple.

Classic Khmer temple, a must see.. Situated within Angkor Thom, this is a magnificent building with more carvings and reliefs than you can imagine. The massive towers with faces on each of the 4 cardinal points dominate the structure, yet there is so much detail in almost every other stone gallery, passage and support.As with the classic Angkor Wat, the Bayon cannot be viewed as a seperate building but has to be seen within the context of its purpose and use as a state temple within the city of Angkor Thom.Buy the book, "Ancient Angkor" , $5 US from the vendors if you haggle enough. it has all the history and great pictures of many of the must see features.Quite a few narrow passages and steep stairs. the place get crowded so be prepared for queues, blocked photo opportunities and some rudeness. Got to be high on the list of must see temples.

Amazing. This temple will stand out in your memory as the carvings are very different from the other temples. It's certainly something to see all the faces as you approach the temple. Trivia alert: Out of all those carved faces, only one is truly smiling! Our tour guide challenged us to find it...not too difficult as lots of tourists queued to take photos with the smiling face!

Stunningly beautiful.. This temple is stunningly beautiful. Approaching the temple from afar, i could see the many, many faces. My friend and i then walked in, then up to a platform where the faces are next to us. The crowd was large, sometimes needing to queue to take photo with the faces. Entering the temple is free as long as you have the admission pass from the main entrance. Wear appropriately such as knee lengths, sleeved shirts and no hats as guards at entrance may be strict. Definitely one of my favourite of the temples visited.For more photographs, see blog site.

Such a happy place. We got to this amazing temple at 6:30ish am and it was magical we had the place almost to ourselves. To wander around in silence surrounded by all these smiling faces... Breathtaking.
Go early and get your happy on!!

Four faces temple. Beautiful scenery on the way to temples. Many murals on temple walls. Look closely you may see some animals on wall murals.
Loved the causeway and the sculptures.
Very hot. Watch how many temples you see in a day.
one of my favourites. impressive temple. try to get there when it's not too busy and soak up the atmosphere of this temple surrounded by jungle. don't expect much from sunset there

Bayon and nature recapture their space. Beautiful building that nature has reclaimed following the city's abandonment. Seeing the tree visible from the building's front was cool. Seeing that tree from the back, where it slowly pushes its way through the stone walls is amazing.

A beautiful temple, we actually enjoyed this as much as Angkhor Wat. The carvings were wonderful and it was very peaceful and easy to get around.
I would recommend going early in the morning to miss the crowds and the heat.

Great Temple Ihave never seen. Wow...this temple are great and big surrounded by 4 main gates, the gate is too small just a size of only one bus can come in. The temple were built with a very big piece of stone and it attract many tourist beside the Angkor Wat which is our first temple to visit. Don't forget to see this temple if you are here.

Our favorite temple...A must. Angor Wat is the famous one, Ta Prohm is the romantic one, but Bayon will stay with you. There is something about the faces carved in the temple everywhere you look, but this is the temple that somehow became our favorite.

Don't miss this one. If you're visiting Siem Reap and the temples, make sure to visit that one. The temple is spectacular with some very interesting carvings from everyday life. Try to find the one with crocodile attacking a man :)

Go Early Morning to Kiss the King. If you go early morning, a "guide" will magically appear and show you how you can kiss the king. Makes a fun photo op. There are lots of stairs here so be ready for vertiginous walking. Plus, the humidity will make the wood slippery.
Iconic Cambodian Temple. Rivaled only by Angkor Wat for the top spot in Siem Reps historical attractions. A pgotographers deam.

Impressive setup. Number of visitors to high and heat was breathtaking. Best time to travel after rainy season in November. It is not safe but fun for the kids to climb on the walls. Read upfront or get a guide to find the best kept reliefs.

Well preserve.... the temple was incredibly beautiful,you just have to know the story behind the structure to fully appreciate the place,taking your time and be not in a hurry to see the details.the tour entails a lot of walking is a very very hot weather, nut everyone does it and that what's make it more enjoyable...
The must see temple. A truly different temple, and worth a visit. Go in the late afternoon about 4,30 the light was lovely and much less crowded with only a handful of people there

Bayon Temple. This was one of our favourite complexes. We got there very early to make sure we could get an elephant ride - which was the highlight of the trip for the children. It was totally different to when i visited as a backpacker 20 years ago - there are actual roads now! (Think I preferred the jungle trek to the coaches). Good to walk around and we loved the Terrace of Elephants.
My favorite temple. I love this temple at any time of the day.The movement of the light bring shadow who trandforn and mke this temple alive.Amazing !

Beautiful!. I especially enjoyed hiking through this temple, and seeing all the unique large carved faces! There is one place where you can take a picture that looks like you're kissing a side view of one of the faces. See if you can find it!!

Interesting but lots and lots of people. At times there were so many tourist groups that you couldn't move and it was a little disappointing that they were very disrespectful, climbing on everything. Also, the amount of people/children constantly harassing you to buy things gets really old. However, all that said its a place with lots of history and good to see once in a lifetime.
My favourite. Bayon temple is my personal favourite. Smaller than Angkor Wat but still just as magical. The repeated heads and carvings are amazing. A truly special place.
Massive but beautiful. Bayon temple is beautiful! It was massive and it took us about 2 hours to walk around and explore it. It's located within the Angkor complex. Definitely a must see temple.
Bayon Temple. Known for the large carved faces on each tower. Also amazing bas-reliefs depicting battle are fantastic. Very impressive sight. Loved this temple.

amazing. My second favorite temple in Angkor (after beng melea).
It is majestic, mysterious and beautiful.
you came spend hours looking at the faces on the statues that are facing you from all directions.
The temple is very popular - so their are huge crowds at the place -
fantastic stone carvings. This temple is covered in stone carvings of faces, it is almost surreal. It is overrun with tourists, but all of the Angkor temples are.

One of the temples not to be missed. If you've seen pictures of temples with carved faces on them, this is where you'll actually see them. So if you are scarce with time, include this one in your checklist of to-go to temples. Smaller than Angkor Wat but equally interesting in a different way. There will be people giving out incenses inside temples, if you get it, they will light it for you and pray over you, and give a handmade bracelet, thereafter will ask you for donation. If you don't want this, do not receive. It was picturesque but I suggest you go early so you can have a souvenir photo without people walking by continuously.
Amazing. An amazing temple. Must do. Best in Angkor Thom. Very hot, but worth it. The Buddha's here are fantastic, and great for fun photos.
A MUST!. It's hard to imagine anyone saying anything bad about the angkor wat complex. this is another one of the most amazing sites. take the time to explore as much as you can.

Must-see!. At the centre of Angkor Thom is Bayon. With iits nearly 40 remaining towers and some 200 serene faces carved from stone and seeminly watching you from every angle, Bayon is a massively impressive series of structures. Some of it has been lost to the sands of time, but what's left is wonderous. Lots of rubble and ruin - much of it assembled neatly and numbered, ready to be pieced back together - but far more that's not in ruin. Climb to the Upper Terrace and you'll see that the highest sections of Bayon are, truly, breathtakingly beautiful. A magnificent structure and a must-see when visiting the Angkor.

FABULOUS temple, but a sun-magnet!. The many faces of Bayon are worth investigating, though probably better done in the morning, before the sun shows ITS face in full-force! Probably tied for first in my ranking of Cambodian temples!Bayon is simply amazing, though fully under the sun's glare (watch out---heat exhaustion is simply too easy to come by).Located on the shorts circuit ($10-13 for a tuk-tuk for the day), Bayon, this is the second temple you visit after Angkor Wat. You can also ride an elephant here (in a basket, not bareback), which looks neat. There are water vendors around there, so don't worry, and your tuk-tuk driver will likely bring some water for you.

Smiling Faces. This is a temple located in the centre of Angkor Thom,consisting of a multitude of towers adorned with 216 gigantic smiling faces. It makes you happy ust looking at them! Lots of steps and rooms to visit as well as the outdoor areas. Watch your footing and take care on the steps!

Breathtaking. Wow! one is humbled by the sheer size and construction of this Temple. It is hard to believe that this was all done by many hands. Worth every moment spent in the heat and humidity - take water with you and a cloth to wipe your face! Go early to avoid midday heat and crowds. A must see in your Temple visits. Lot of climbing up and down so not advisable for those that struggle to get around.

Unbelievable. It is hard to comprehend how these structures, on such a scale, could be built. The guide was able to bring to life the bas-reliefs with his stories and interpretation. Could spend hours examining the faces and galleries.
One of the best temples. This temple impressed me a bit more than Angkor Wat. You should first do this one and then go to sunset to Angkor Wat
Great!. Awe inspiring! A must see in Siem Reap! Go with a guide, as they can point out all the interesting facts about the place, and also give you great camera angles for memorable pictures!!
Beautiful but packed. Very beautiful temple, it would be perfect if they would allow less people to enter at the same time as it can get so crowded it is hard to fully enjoy it
Another excellent temple. Same as the other temples, a bit in awe of the design and construction of these temples back in the days of total manual labour

My favourite. My family, including a 10- and 12-year old absolutely loved visiting the temples in Siem Reap, and this was my favourite. A hauntingly beautiful place, and a superb one for picture taking.We will definitely visit again, but next time at a cooler time of year. My only regret in visiting at the end of March was that it was extremely hot, which meant that spending more time photographing or simply sitting and reflecting wasn't really an option! Having said that, I wouldn't have missed it, no matter what the temperature.

So much History. So much to see, so much History, architecture, carvings.Absolutely amazing. You defintely need a full day at Angkor Wat to do justice to Bayon Temple, Angkor Thom, Pra Thm and Angokr Wat.

A true wonder. Not to miss, this is the most spectacular of them all. It's not as big and monumental as Angkor Wat, not as magical and ruined as Ta Phrom, but from all temples, it stands out as a mountain of rocks, a monument for the ages.

Wow - my favourite - a must. This is an awesome temple. The faces are just mind blowing. spent a happy hour mesmerised. We self guided ourselves - with a lonely planet book. The large carved faces and other carvings make this very special. Treat yourself to a visit.

Khmer Smile!. We visited this temple in a late afternoon. The temple is simply amazing. I was impressed by the Khmer smiles around me. The light from the sunset made this place even more mysterious and beatiful. Strongly recommended !
AMAZING!!. Must visit once in your lifetime.... Tomb raider eat your heart out! Loved every second, Would recommend a guided tour so you hear the history. Truely amazing x

Archaelogical marvel. Amazing! So much to explore, I spent over an hour just on the friezes on the outer wall. The iconic faces on the towers were fantastic. Take lots of water, it will be hot and dusty.

Beyond Belief. This is the temple they used in the Tomb Raiders & seeing it in person is beyond belief. When you know how slowly trees grow and you see the roots of the trees growing over the ruins you can't help but be in awe.

One of my favorite Temples!. Bayon is one of my favorite places, it is in the centre of the city of Angkor Thom and was built in the late 12th century. There are over 200 large carved faces believed to be King Jayarvarman V11 on 54 towers. These beautiful faces reflect the famous "Smile of Angkor".The Bas reliefs on the southern walls contain real life scenes from the sea battle between the Khmers and the Cham, then there are carvings of every day life such as market scenes, chess games and child birth. If you can only visit one other temple beside Angkor Wat, then Bayon is the one you must see. Allow approximately an hour to see the Bayon Temple complex.
Best temple of all. This temple amazed/interested me the most. So many great angles for photographs. Go when everyone else on the big tours are at lunch, for a more enjoyable visit.

Bayon Temple Review. Beautiful - but very touristy. Lots of people there, and lots of cars parked around (drivers for visitors) which spoiled the views somewhat. The only temple where there was a group of traditionally dressed people wanting you to have your photo taken with them - for a few dollars.I wish we could have spent more time there, and gone back when the sun was setting.
beautiful bayon. Mysterious temple featuring beautifully carved faces of Hindu gods appear all over this temple. Both gentle and enduring, the subtle smiles of these gods have endured for millenia.
The faces are amazing. Definitely worth a visit to this temple -- extremely detailed carvings and a different look from the others!

the best of the temples. This is the place to go. It for me beats Angkor Wat though architecturally its less accomplished. The Buddha faces built into the temple spires are serene, you could spend all afternoon here and its quieter than Angkor Wat. It is quite spellbinding and I took far more photos here than at other temples (much to my wife's annoyance!

omg. If you see only a couple of temples Bayon should be definitely one of those. The giant stone faces are really amazing. The temple has been rebuilt several times during the centuries which makes the whole architecture very unique. Leave a couple of hours to stroll around the site: the bas-reliefs on the exterior walls of the lower level and the chambers inside are both well worth to discover. To avoid crowds and heat it is recommended to arrive early. The elephant ride around Bayon is also a very nice experience. It costs 15$ pp. Rides available daily between 08:00 to 10:30. You can also buy an ananas for 1$ to feed the animals.
What a treat!. This temple is part of the ankor thom temple complex. It is beautifully stunning. Highly recommend you visit it. You won't be disappointed. Enjoy!

Different wall carvings than Angkor Wat. We didn't climb to the top as we had 2 year old. Still fun. We also didn't hire a guide. Saw very interesting wall cravings. Very different than Angkor Wat. Guess it must has a story. Constructions were going on but still a lot interesting to see.
fascinating. amazing, we both enjoyed our visit very much and would recommend it if you have a keen eye it is photographers heaven

Well Worth The Trip. Bayon Temple is the central temple of the Angkor Tom complex just down the road from Angkor Wat. The entire 3 mile square complex is worth the trip to Sieam Reap, and the temple at its center is astonishing.We spent 2 and a half hours exploring the site and would have stayed longer had the heat that day not become oppressive by early afternoon. For that reason, we would plan future visits a little earlier in the year.

Outstanding human masterpiece, but unpolite tourists. A great marvel. Just the stone faces looking at you and the architecture. However, as in all the Angkor complex, I dislike how noisy and unrespectful tourists are. It Should be a place of respect and observation, but at the end is a noisy place were tourists repeat the same photo with mobile phone, one after the other.

Great faces. As this is one of the more popular temples it is a good idea to come early in the day. We had a private guide for our four days in Siem Reap and he suggested that we visit here straight after sunrise at Angkor Wat, and before eating our hotel breakfast box, to avoid the worst of the crowds. It is also not so hot then. He knew the spot to take the photos of the nose to nose shots with the stone faces. Having a guide is so much better as they can explain features, give historical information and know the best places for photos and what order to visit temples in. So many carvings are so well preserved and it is amazing to think how old they are. As with all temples wear clothing that covers knees and shoulders and good walking shoes. Don't forget hat and water.

Bayon temple. The details in the carvings and the work that must have been involved in creating this incredible temple is awe-inspiring, the faces, and the tunnels through are truly a sight to behold and not worth missing!

Well preserved view into history. The Bayon temple was a highlight of our day's tour. With the beautiful faces still well-preserved and towering above the ruins, at each glance, is a different view -- whether looking through a tower's window to see yet another stone face looking back or walking around the uneven grounds, and admiring the detailed craftwork in the doorways, walls, ceilings, and sculptures. It was not too crowded when we went, though I can see this being hard to manuever when there more people around to watch out for. The stairs up and down are fairly steep, but well worth the trek up (or down).

Highlight of the Angkor temples. Although not as large or as famous as Angkor Wat the temple of Bayon is a must see. Dozens of carved faces of Avalokiteśvara keep watch over the grounds with mysterious smiles. Carvings on the lower level depict legends and historical events. There is a lot of renovation currently underway but there's still plenty to see. The temple is on many levels and be sure to visit the chamber at the very top and have a rest with the Buddha within. The best time to visit is at dawn or a bit later when the sun climbs over the surrounding trees and casts a beautiful, warm light on the stones. Once the tour buses arrive the calm and mysterious ruins become a madhouse. I've visited Bayon (and all of Angkor) several times and never tire of it or cease to be amazed and astounded. I've always been there at dawn but I imagine sunset is just as beautiful.
Bayon temple. it was nice and exotic, and the faces were beautiful. i enjoyed myself very much, and i also loved the elephant ride around the temple
amazing!. what an amazing Temple, great spot to take photos in the morning. i recommend to go early or last as the bulk tours also have this temple on there program.

Best Architecture. A must see in Siem Reap apart from Anchor Wat. Since this place is just near to each other. I love the architecture of this place, most of the temples in Siem Reap is copied from this temple.

The Mother of Temples. Located in Angkor Thom, the Bayon temple is a must go for all visitors. It's big with several levels to walk around. Climb to the top level and you can get a scenic view of Angkor Thom. Our tour guide asked us to stand at a certain angle near one of the Buddha's statue and took a photo for us (individual photo). When we see the shots, it's as though each of us were face-to-face with Buddha, almost kissing. It's really interesting. Ask around for this, definitely worth taking a shot!

Picturesque. Was rather humid when we came, so be equipped with water, sunscreen, a fan, sunglasses and plaster a huge smile if you've survived it. Great views and wonderful l history.Prepare $1 paper bills for purchasing and don't forget to try the palm juice and coconut stands. ;)

Breathtaking!. Bayon is just breathtaking for the sheer size and number of giant faces. As it goes, the faces are those of Jayavarman who reclaimed the land from the Chams (Vietnamese/Champas). Breathtaking views of what man accomplished centuries ago! Walking around the place looking at all the giant faces staring at you is an experience in itself. You see the harmony where one section is dedicated to Lord Vishnu and another to Lord Shiva, not withstanding the Shiva Lingam in the Northern section.Its a different world and its simply amazing! I would definitely go back again!
Unique. Amazing and unique. Hire a guide to take the most of it. If you think that because you have seen Angkor Wat, you have seen all, think again.
Awesome. The extensive carvings and surviving areas were awe-inspiring. There was way too much to see in one visit.
Very interesting. Very different to the other temples. Well worth the visit. Take plenty of water. Take lots of short breaks as it gets very hot in March.

Were distinct faces were engraved in stones.... This temple is reflective of distinct faces of some important people in Cambodia. The expressions of these person captured and stilled in stones is truly a wonderful work of art and artistic skill.

now i know why God doesn't want men to carve or engrave Him. i am a Christian but i do appreciate that Cambodian people and fellow travelers have great respect for each other and all the other peoples in various colors and beliefs..one can sense the solidarity and brotherhood and serenity ...as we ascend ( and descend) the steps of the ruins and temples, wisps of essences from the smoke of lighted sticks gave me a sense of peace...now, i know why God doesn't want Him represented in stones, or metals or any other structures..works of men crumble in time even the best work of men ( pyramids, Bayon temples, pagodas etc ) how dare we , reduce our God to any common rock, cement, stone, wood or metal? ..

Smiley Faces Temple!. An amazing temple and a must see in the Angkor area- its mass of face towers ( (they look like smiley faces!) create a stone mountain of ascending peaks - effect is overnwhelming. Most towers have 4 faces ( i on each side) but sometimes there areco only 3 or even 2. This temple is extremely complex both in terms of its structure and meaning having passed thtrough different religious phases and its lovely to amble through its two galleried enclosures seeing glimpses of the enigmatic faces is a facinating experience . Bayon has two stunning sets of bas-reliefs with incredible carving skills.

Best Temple in Area. This was by far my favourite temple in the area, I went there three times, the bas reliefs are amazing I recommend hiring a guide or buying a guidebook (hawkers sell them every by the temple, don't pay more than $5 for them) to get a translation of what you are seeing. The world of the ancient Khmers just comes to life that way, and lets not forget also all the columns of faces, spectacular. Being there on three separate days the temple is busiest before 10:30 because that is when it gets bombarded by all the tour groups, anytime after that the crowd isn't so bad.
Don't Miss. Another amazing temple not to be missed. Very hot and crowded, but worth the effort. Recommend a guide to explain the history, and allow lots of time to wander and soak it all in.
Good. Really enjoyable great to see the heads very interesting good site to walk and enjoy the view part of tour but was very good

Don't miss this in Siem reap. If you spend the time here, you will realise that no two faces at this unique temple have the same expression. take your time and try to not to rush through the place. Think about how a few hundred years ago, the architect, even if s/he wasn't called that, conceived and built this place.It is among the many MUST SEE temples in Siem Reap and speaks of the glory that this place had acquired once upon a time.

Fantastic!. This temple, as many other in the whole Angkor Wat area, is amazing, there's faces everywhere and is surrounded by trees. So when you take photos is makes a truly special mark.Try to go before 10am, because it gets VERY hot.

Eerie Sense of Being Watched. The Bayon temple has partially collapsed, but you can walk on its various levels and see the multitude of smiling (or glowering? pr ...?) heads on the towers staring down at - you. Are they the repeating faces of King Jayavarman VII who built it? Or repeating images of Buddha? Anyway, there are towers with many repeating faces on all four sides. More than one hundred in total, I have read. This is not a huge structure and it has various levels that can be accessed. It certainly looks different from Angkor Wat and should be on the must-do list of all visitors to the area.Again, this is a marvel of design and construction. Lifting the locks of stone into their designated positions - well, this is an achievement even today, for all the temples.
Seeing is Believing. The striking structure... Looks more magnificent than pictures in books. Worth a visit. Best to visit earlier in the morning when you don't see too many other tourists.
amazing. you need to see it, we had the best tuk tuk driver in the world there who showed us all around. the temples are wonderful
fantastic wall relief. The relief on the outer walls tells a lot of the ancient Khmer empire - from history to military to daily life. Worth spending time to study in detail.
Awesome trees.. A great example of mother earth retrieving her own. Took some great pictures. Go early to miss the crowds and heat.
Much better than Angkor wat as better preserved.. Slightly smaller but better preserved than Angkor wat. Go before 8 am and you will see in beautiful light with few other visitors.

Best of all :). I really liked Bayon temple. It's just so amazing to be surrounded with so many faces! It's also nice to observe the tourists-- on how they creatively take pictures of the temple. Some were having nose to nose pic with one of the faces. For a better view of the facade, you can also opt to ride the elephant here. Very, very nice and amazing! Can't forget!

Very good. We visited TP and Bayon on the first morning of our two day temple tour. We had an english speaking guide - excellent and very inexpensive. We travelled by tuk tuk from SR and it was fascinating. Bayon was interesting - with the trees growing out of the ruins and clearly one to see
Nice :). tried the elephant ride going to the Bayon temple, :) it was a bit disappointing since some part of the temple was under repair when we visited it. Lots of people too.
How many faces?. Impossible to tell, but you will enjoy wandering around trying. Stunning in its own right, well worth the visit, we went in the late morning and it wasn't too crowded.

Nature meets man. Incredible - loved the way the trees are entwined with the stone walls. The size of their roots is incredible and really demonstrates the might and endurance of mother nature. It made me feel inconsequential. A really mystical place - my favourite.
beautiful. one can only describw this plce as beautiful the buildings are so articulate in the architecture siem rep is full of wondera and this is one of thwse wonders

Loved it!. It's my favorite of all.... Beautiful smiles of Buddhas and you can look yourself in here. Great to explore on your own and send sometime there, however my tour guide was great and has almost shared every piece of history with me. Must go!!!

Stunning. Include this in any tour you do. We started with sunrise at the west gate of Angkor Wat then had breakfast before heading to Angkor Thom and the Bayon Temple. We finished at Ta Prom and then back to Angkor Wat getting back to the hotel at 2.00pm. That was enough for us but well worth it.
Outstanding. What more can one say? This is a magnificant and astonishing temple that defies imagination. Definitely not to be missed. A must see.
Faces. In addition to all the faces of Buddha (actually an old king's profile), visit he Buddhist monks and nuns within and donate a dollar or two.
beautiful temple. A great temple, must to visit. Ensure you visit at the proper time of the day to enjoy the temple's view.

A lovely (cloudy) day in Bayon. Love to visit this temple in a "not so hot cloudy day". Didn't spend much time here since there are several temples we have to visit during the day. Bayon is very popular just like Angkor Wat, but I do love Ta Prohm the most with its jungle and fresh green landscape.

Amazing and Eerie. An intereting place to visit and a bit eerie with all the faces carved into the facades.
Interesting to watch the stonemasons working on restoration projects.
Astonishing. This temple with all its big stone faces impressed me even more than Angkor Wat. It was different. See for yourself!

Interesting temple, and very picturesque.. Came here after visiting the sunrise at angkor wat. This is defintely a must-go after angkor wat. the other temples generally look the same after that. highly recommended! do go with a guide as it will be more interesting learning about the history as you walk.
a must see in Siem Reap. Giant stone carvings of faces. You can realy take close up pictures of Bayon Faces here. Less crowded in the late afternoon.
Worth to see and experience. the many Buddha faces are fascinating. Go there in the afternoon hours to enjoy better sunlight view for photograping.
Beautiful. With a myriad of carved faces, this was one of my favourite temples to visit. Amazing design and architecture. A must see in Siem Reap.

magic. It can be great if you go there just after see the Sunrise in Ankor Wat, because precisely only at this time temple is almost empty, and then after 8am a groups of Chinese tourists arrive and it became terrible.

Amazing!. This temple is amazing! We liked it better that Angkor Wat. It is definitely in ruins, but the carvings and faces are so cool! On the last day of our 3-day pass, we decided to go back! It is on all of the tour itineraries, so you probably won't miss it.
Very nice. I like this temple the best of all the temple i visited. So magnificent! Words can't describe, you have to visit the place yourself.

do not miss. temple not to be missed... try to get there early, before crowds of tourists and heat. probably one of the most interesting. try to have a good guide (not expensive!) and your visit will be much more worthy...

Best "rock concert" in Siem Reap. The rock is more like a symphony. Powerful. Moving. The trees almost seem to have been planned to be part of it when it was built. Go early in the morning. There are far too many people by early afternoon when I was there. Even the heat was not enough to keep the numbers down.

I loved the Bayon complex. The Bayon is very different, in its modesty, as compared to Angkor Wat. The tall trees, the reliefs, the temples with hidden wells, with towers with Buddha faces. It is like being in an alien world. Truly marvellous. I salute the anicent builders.

Humbling. It was insanely humid when we went for the full day so this is something to keep in mind. Our brilliant driver was kind enough to point out that we should really examine each face because they aren't all the same which was an excellent tip for us photographers.Ask the employees of where you're staying or your driver for better times to visit to avoid the crowds.Have good walking shoes on. It's in a wetlands area and is humid with moss growing on stones and stairs that you're walking on so do watch your step.Stairs are steep and be respectful of the signs. I saw so many tourists just blatantly ignoring these signs; they don't realise that what they do in that instance could mean it's something someone may not be able to do in the future. The Cambodians and UNESCO are working hard to keep up with the ruins but when you get there you'll see it's not an easy task by any means. So make their jobs easier so you have more to enjoy and appreciate in the future.

Not to be missed. Probably the best temple after Angkor Wat. The most striking thing are the countless faces carved into the rock all with Mona Lisa smiles. There are 216 in all and no one knows for sure who they represent. Some say it is a combination of Buddha and the King Jayavarman VII who was responsible for its construction in the 12th century. Don't miss the bas reliefs that depict a naval battle between the Khmer and the Cham along with scenes of everyday life. They were once painted and gilded which would have made them even more impressive. Try to get there early as it got very busy around 11 when I visited.
Bayon. My personal favorite of the many wats. It was smaller in size than Angkor Wat, but to me, The Bayon was the most stunning.

Must see this temple - amazing. This is the first temple you come to after entering the Angkor Thom south gate. The multitude of smiling faces and the detail of the workmanship is simply astounding. Take your time to fully explore this temple, maybe 2 plus hours. Ask your guide to take your picture with your nose lined up to a nose on one of the faces. Your guide will know exactly where to place you for this unique picture. This truly one of the amazing temples in Angkor Thom. Enjoy. The fee for Bayon is included in your Angkor World Heritage pass fee. Simply show your laminated pass to the security personnel. A seven day fee is $60.00.
The temples with stone large faces on top. This ruins are so unique, that seem from other planet. They are one of the smallest temple, but it could be as interesting as Angkor Wat temple

Hard to describe it all. Trekking down the road towards the temple on an elephant had to be the best way to see Bayon for the first time. In the distance i could see the faces peaking out from the treeline and lit up by the early morning sunshine. The elephant ride starts early in the morning (ask your hotel) and is 15 dollars per person. We were the first to arrive through the victory gate and onto Bayon on Elephant so everyone was taking pictures of us. I'm not going to lie, we felt like royalty.  I wished we went earlier in the morning because by the time we entered the tour groups had arrived. YIKES! but whatever, you have to keep in mind that cambodia is not a secret anymore. You will be bumping into people trying to get the best picture, fighting for 2 inches of shade, and occasionally get a wif of Body odor. It happens but don't let other annoying tourists dictate your ability to get what you want out of the temple. Bring water, towel, camera, umbrella and the idea that this temple is not ALL YOURS. Share with Care. One day there will be so many restrictions because of so many more tourists that want to see the temple so make the best of it now.
Keep it natural. Effort should not be spared to restore these monuments to its past glory. The down side is litters are starting to 'ruin' the place.

One of three temples not to be missed!. Built around 1190 AD by King Jayavarman VII, Bayon is a Buddhist temple but it incorporates elements of Hindu cosmology.This temple is a richly decorated Khmer temple and was the last state temple to be built at Angkor. The 216 smiling faces are a striking expression of the baroque style of Khmer architecture, as contrasted with the classical style of Angkor Wat.This temple was considered by the Khmers to be the conjunction of heaven and earth, though the auspicious site was covered in jungle for centuries.In the first part of the 20th century, conservation efforts are restoring the temple in accordance with the technique of anastylosis.The outer walls of Bayou temple are so far removed as to seem nonexistent. From the outside, this gives the Bayon an open feel, but the interior of the temple is actually quite cramped.Wear supportive shoes as it is uneven walking surfaces and very dusty.

Temple of 216 smiling Buddhas. Our guide told us that there are 54 towers at Bayon Temple, each with 4 serene smiling images of Buddha facing the four points of the compass. An extraordinary temple visit - despite the hoards of other visitors. If you go to the Angkor complex be prepared for crowds. But don't miss Bayon Temple.

Magical.. It is quite difficult to describe: quite magical, like breathing history and centuries...We had a guide with us and that helped us a lot to appreciate the beauty of it. Our guide spoke very good english and his explanations and references to other temples were invaluable.
loved it. Unfortunatley hard to escape the crowds. Great in the afternoon sun when it gives the faces a warm glow. One of my favorite temples.

serene smiling faces. Visually impressive to see the huge faces at the top of the towers. The elephant gallery and the leper king gallery were worth seeing but it was harder to avoid all the tour groups
Our Favourite. Small enough to explore with relative ease. A very important temple and probably the only one we would return to see again.

Amazing. Again... an amazing experience so much to see and do and the same as Angkor Wat a day pass for $20 or a three day pass for $40. Get a tuk tuk though to take you round all day as they are all some distance apart.
Marvellous. One of the most important temples, make a huge impression. Worth visiting at the beginning. Not that popular as Angkor Wat is a bit less crowded.

must visit in Angkor. if you are only doing 2-3 temples, this must be one of them. the multi-faced sculptures are fantastic. make sure your guide tells you the best spots to snap the best pics. also, before getting to the temple, it's a really cool little 5 min hike to climb up the gate and get a great view!

Small Temple, Bayon. I think 30 minutes is enough to go around Bayon temple. There's very hot better you bring sun block to protect your skin. You only pay one time to visit all the temples in Angkor complex.

Just What You Think a Temple Should Look Like. This was one of the many temples I visited during my three day "temple-athon" In many ways, it was the most picturesque because of the huge faces. You'll have to work a bit to get photos without other people in it. This temple was very very crowded.
Bayon Temple. We loved the whole temple, so much to see and such great opportunities for fantastic photos. It was very hot and sticky so take lots of water with you.
Big buddha faces. I liked the Big Buddha faces in this temple.You should not miss this temple when you visit the angkor wat.

Amazing and beautiful. This is one of the highlights of Angkor Wat region and a centerpiece of Angkor Tom. The carvings of the faces are each and the dancing women have their own character and serenity. My first visit was not enjoyable as it was jammed with other bus loads of tourists. However took a tuk back around 4:30 and had the temple practically to myself ! Walking through the maze of passages and climbing to the top level was unforgettable..magestic!

One of the 4 must-see temples at SR. Located in the centre of Angkor Thom, this is the most inspiring thing to see there. It is beautiful and interesting. Like most reviews have noted, it is busy in the morning and hot during the lunch period (but less tourists). We persevered with the heat to get fewer tourists but came back again at 5.30pm and there was literally no one there. Stayed til 6pm all alone there- it was great! As with all the temples, in my opinion a guide is essential to get the most out of Angkor.

Wonderful carvings and setting. More compact and visually accessible than Angkor Wat temple. Make sure you allow enough time to examine the fine script carvings as well as the more obvious temple faces.
Best temple!. This temple was so much fun to explore! The faces on all the buildings were remarkable and amazing to see. The temples get monotonous so this one was cool!
A beautiful temple. Another temple in the Angkor Wat complex. Again a beautiful piece of architecture with faces carved into the pillars.

An easy walk. Easy to get up to the higher levels. There are several several shady areas to rest. Bayon can get a bit crowded if a large tour group is going through but just wait a few minutes and they are out of the way.

Incredible views, just brace for crowds. I went to this temple a few times in a weekend visit. It was always swamped with tourists. Definitely worth seeing, but you will either be in someone else's photo or struggling to get an open shot yourself much of the time.
Great. We found the Bayon a lot more inspiring than Angkor Wat, also a lot quieter which was nice. All the different faces and expressions were so interesting you could wander around for ages.
Worth seeing. This was the third temple we visited in this area but was worth seeing. Different to Angkor Wat and a lot of reconstruction. being done.

Temple of faces. Comparetively small temple, still under reconstruction, very complex design. evident south Indian architecture. not far from Angkor, not walkable if after a walk around Angkor. Famous bridge with Asuras & Devas is enroute Bayon from Angkor. Must see if around Siem Reap

Temple of the smiling faces!. One of the first temples we went to, with those classic faces. Lots of steps, but worth it. We then walked through the Angkor Thom area ending at the elephant terrace, not crowded, and the walk goes through forest paths, so shady, give yourself at least half a day day

Go late.... Go late in the afternoon and enjoy a more relaxed visit to the whole complex. Take some water to hydrate yourself, it can be very hot. If you've played Tomb Rider back in the late nineties, you've already been here. A guide will help you to skip the big groups.

Temple of many faces. This temple is in Angkor Thom complex and is one of the more memorable ones as it stands out due to the huge number of faces on the towers. We came here around 10 AM and it was absolutely packed with tourists but by 12 there were fewer people which made taking photos easier :)Next time I would have visited the Angkor Museum in Siam Reap before visiting the temples as it really gives you a good background about them.

Too many tourists to be enjoyed. Even though I managed to make some of the best photo's of my holiday here - it was busy to the extreem with asian tourist who were more interested of taking (silly) pictures of themselves by climbing on the stones than taking in the beauty and history of the temple. Unesco should consider closing parts or limiting the number of visiters per hour to conserve the temple for the future.

Beautiful faces. Surreal, awesome, inspiring, spiritual and sublime. The beauty of this place is something out of this world and had to be one of my favourite temples in Angkor. The faces are lifelike and surround you at every turn. I think I took two hundred shots here alone. My office wall is full of canvases that take me straight back to this magical kingdom that completely took my breath away.
Enjoyed but third to the others. Enjoyed this temple but felt is was a sad back runner to the others on offer in this area.do not do in the heat of the day you will fry. Tree is no shade.

Exceptional, larger than expected. Give yourself enough time to explore all of the smaller temples. Hard to do Angkor in one day. Check with your tour guide when the best time to visit during the day. Try and avoid the numerous tour buses by reversing the order in which you visit the sites.

Inspiration at every turn. We visited the "Magical Temple"/Bayon Temple on 4th March, and it was the most spectacular sight i have ever seen. The 4 Buddha Faced Towers were more and more inspiring at every turn. We exhausted two cameras and three batteries on the overwhelming scenery. The Bayon Temple is history, legend, mystery, culture and art all squeezed into 49 towers. Truly magical.

this one was my favorite. I enjoyed this temple the most... maybe because we went later in the day when it wasnt so extremely hot but i like the design much more. Right after we visited this temple we took a walk up the mountain to watch the sunset over Angkor Wat. Truly beautiful

amazing. Liked everything about Anka Wat & especially the Bayan Temple.To be able to walk around & see as temple which had been built so many years ago was amazing. The trees which have been left to grow through the temple. Glad it is being preserved.

Beautiful and exotic. This was among my favorite temples in the Angkor complex. You really need to go around - after the Angkor Watt - and see the other temples in the area. This is among the more beautiful.

close survelence. The numerous faces are everywhere you look and make great photo opportunities. We went there after Angkor Wat and to be honest enjoyed it more. Not as big as Angkor and also less tourists.

Beatifully Crowded. Nice architecture, nasty crowds.It's not that big, and it makes it even harder to move around, because there's too many people. This is early morning where there is supposed to be fewer people.

My favorite spot in Angkor Wat. I have visited Angkor Wat twice, and each time Bayon has taken my breath away. I like it better than any other of the many temples in the complex, it is really special.
Stunning Historical Remains. Very well preserved, full of fascinating historical content. Try and get there early to beat the crowds and the heat! Well worth a visit.

Absolutely Amazing. The huge stone carvings are amazing. You start wondering how they would have gone about it. We took our time to go around the place - there are some delicate carvings at the bottom of each of the huge heads that could go unnoticed if you try to zip through the place.Best time to go is early morning when the tour groups are at Angkor Wat. We noticed that it is very crowded in the afternoon.
Tourist Trap Extreme. tourist trap nightmare, should consider capping the number of visitors otherwise its just a zoo for tourists in old ruins. Severely disappointed.

Incredible. I wasn't extremely excited about seeing the temples and after a crowded sunrise at Angkor Wat this was mindblowing. I was speechless at the beauty of this temple. The faces are mesmerizing and the whole atmosphere is great. Climb around it and being able to escape the crowds in it's many hallways and hidden decks.
About face(s). The heads of the HIndu god immortalized here are huge and four-faced and simply amazing. Getting so close to them is such an incredible experience.
Spooky!. Beautiful, spooky and amazing to see faces structured in temple designs. Unbelievable to think how it was done in those times without the help of modern machinery. Don't miss it.

Angkor Thom and The Bayon temple. Remarkable temple complex, surrounded by forest, well worth the visit. There are several temples to visit. The main one (The Bayon) has 54 towers, each carved with 4 faces of Buddha. Many bas-reliefs carved with scenes of life in centuries gone by, including battles with invading armies, domestic scenes, and animals. Also stunning Elephants' Terrace, where the king would speak to his people and where the games would take place (like the Roman coliseum, but less gory). Treat yourself to a guide: it makes it all so much more interesting and easier to get around.

The Temple with the faces. It is called Bayon Temple and is said to be in the centre of the Angkor Thom (Capital City of Khmer people).The faces on the towers is not yet clarified to whom they belong (perhaps Vishnou perhaps Buddah depending on the religion). Each time a religion prevailed Hindu or Buddism they changed details of the statues. That's why many are destroyed lips or jaw.When you visit it ask your guide for details.Not too crowded as Angkor Wat but a must visit!
One of the most photographic sites. Get here early in the morning and you will have plenty of photo opportunities. One of the places we liked the most.

The jewel of the jungle. Well, it is definitely a must see. The smiling faces appear to have come from a film setting. Do not miss the incredible naval battle in the north section of the outer enclosure! The best time to visit is before 9:45, when tourists visiting Angkor Wat start arriving!
Bayon Temple. I really like the temples in Cambodia better than those in Bali, Indonesia. Been to Russia, Pompeii, Rome, Egypt, and Indonesia; Cambodia complements the sights we have viewed!
Another must see in Siem Reap. This is one of the biggest temple representing the 4 face buddha i reckon. There are many of such temples around but this is one with many of it in the same compound.

face off. expressive stone carvings. not all statues are alike. they have their own facial expression, and we're talking about 20 ft face carving. the road is a bit dusty giving you a taste of how it feels like in the old days.
Elephant ride. Just visited Bayon temple on the outside and saw all the magnificent smiling gods while riding on an elephant. 15min ride costs US$15. Worth the visit!
Favorite Temple. We skipped the early morning rush at Angkor Wat and went straight to Bayon. We loved it so much we went back twice!

A MUST SEE TEMPLE. This is one of the better temples in the ANGKOR GROUP OF TEMPLES.THE massive stone faces on the four sides of many towers makes this a unique temple.If you only have a day to visit the temples,include this one.PART the Angkor ticket price.
facinating, although spooky. all the faces. Bit freaky. But very photogenic. A guide would have been a big help to give some understanding of the background.
Possibly the best. Filled with faces, this temple stands out amongst the rest for its uniqueness. This was quite easily the highlight at Siem Reap as far as the temple circuit was concerned.

Absolutely stunning!. This is another great historic site that one should not missed! It's amazing to see the well decorated Khmer temple.The outer and inner gallery greatly reflects on Cambodia rich heritage which is simply incredible. I learn so much and really appreciate this great site.I got awesome tour guide who help us know more about their cultural background. And of course giving us good opportunities for great photo.Overall this is a MUST! after Angkor Wat of course :-)
nice. i like this place because it's so unique. and not many people come here. i suggest you to bring umbrella or hat if you would like around the temple

must see!. don't you ever miss this place when you visit siem reap. wear comfortable shoes-sneakers i should say as there's a lot of stairs. after the main bayon, there's more neighboring amazing temples that needs a lot of walking and stair climbing before you get to the parking where your tuk tuk driver is waiting. don't forget your water.

Almost the best. To wisit Bayon the best time is early in the morning! So early as You can! The temple is really interresting and beautifull, but too many turist is there. Interrestng, how many times tried to build more and more shrine in the building and become the whole place like a labirint. Of course the temple is famous about the faces and they make a really deep impression. If you want to ride on an elephant, it is the best place. You can ride around the temple, about 5-10 minutes. Short, and interresting.
Amazing old temple.. Loved this temple - half standing, half in ruins, but beautiful and interesting. One of the better temples at Angkor in my opinion.
Beautiful!. Get there early in the morning just after sunrise for most enjoyable experience. No matter what time you go, don't miss this stop

must see while visiting Angkor Wat. This is one of the top places to see while in Siem Reap. Each area dn temple is different and one need to see all the top ones to get an understanding of how much was done in the area.

Great site. This was my favorite of all the temples we visited. The face carvings are amazing and numerous. There was a small restoration project going on when we visited carried out by a Japanese organization I was told. This is a must see.

Beautiful, but crowded. Stunning design. The circular elements are if fervent than the typical square design of the other sites. Tour groups were overwhelming so do you best to avoid the busy times if you can.

A different kind of temple. We visited Bayon last December 2011. It was the first temple we visited early in the morning..since it was early morning, there were not many tourists yet at the site so we had our fill of photographing such a remarkable temple, it being a photogenic temple.this is a must see in siem reap!
Spectacular. Love all the detail of the temples, dislike that it was very busy because we were unlucky to go at the same time as the Vietnamese national holiday.

Very original temple, center of huge ancient city. Angkor Thom City area, which surrounds Bayon Temple, was a city with a million residents in 12th-13th century. Bayon Temple is very original temple with it's numerous towers and face carvings, and should be absolutely included in any temple complex tour program.

Busy!. This was the first temple that we visited and unfortunately it was very busy; It is very impressive but in between climbing up and down uneven steps and trying to dodge photographers we did not get the full effect. It is probably best visited early in the morning!

Absolutely amazing!. This place was unbelievable and by far my favourite of all the sites. The heads were breathtaking to look at and we have some fantastic photos. Once in a lifetime, unmissable place to visit.

It's All in the Guide. This was my favorite of the many sites in the Angkor complex -- we also saw Angkor Wat, Banteay Srei, Ta Prohm and Angkor Thom. But what made our two-day stay in Siem Reap so great was our guide -- Chandara Niev (nickname, Ing) -- chandarakh@yahoo.com. He was everything you'd expect in a good guide -- prompt, knowledgable, enthusiastic, really good English. But so much more. When we wanted to know about rice production, he pulled off the road, walked into a paddy field and introduced himself and us to a family who taught us how to harvest rice (very entertaining and informative for all!); he was happy to recommend a good restaurant for lunch, but also cajoled us into trying fried, crickets and frogs and sticky rice and raisins steamed in bamboo; when we toured Tonle Sap Lake he took us to a family who invited us onto their floating home. He was sophisticated (exchanging Facebook info and sharing flash drives and good photography tips), but also grew up in a village and knew what it meant to study without electricity. He was politically savvy and serious sharing his family's experience with the Khmer Rouge, but also had a great sense of humor and didn't seem to mind waiting around while we shopped for the perfect Cambodian scarf. He was great company. Highly, highly recommended.

Definitely a must-visit!. Aside from the majestic Angkor Wat, the Bayon temple at Angkor Thom is a personal fave of mine. The massive stone faces are very impressive, as well as the numerous intricate carvings on the wall.

fun and interstng. this was a fun temple to look at alitlle, different and quirky in the carvings and layout i thought, worth a quick stop. if your game you can climb up to the libay btu be cautiouse it is steep and no railing.

A Must See Despite The Hollywood Cliches. An amazing site, hands down easily one of the highlights in Siem Reap. Get here early before the other tourists mob the place and you can get good shots. Or in the middle of the day when it is too hot and other tourists are eating.

Better in person!. Mysterious, compact and wonderous. I liked Bayon more than I like Angkor Wat! Be sure to come here with a guide who can take you through the reliefs on a long wall on the right side of the main entrance. You can see scenes from life back. So beautiful and well preserved.

WHAT AN EXPERIENCE!!!!. Need more than a day, because you will be in constant aww!!! I suggest atleast 2-3 days maybe a month to take fully in. But then again it depends on what you're wanting to experience from it.

Impressive!. Simply beautiful. Most of it is pretty well preserved. The details in the carvings are incredible and inside the temple, don't forget to look up! From the inside you can see how it was constructed. Also, light some incense at one of the little sanctuaries.
Wow. walking in all these temples and remembering that it was once full of life and services and culture and tradition. Its just simply an amazing experience.

One of my favorites. Bayon is a temple in the Angkor Thom area, its not a huge temple but still it is exciting. Everywhere you will see faces of the King made like the Budhdha, and the details that are shown in each face is remarkable. One of my very favorites after Angkor Wat

Overwhelmed by .... Well ... only one description, Overwhelmed by jostling Chinese tourists. Maybe I chose the wrong moment to visit the place but it was packed to the brim with tourists from China smoking indiscriminately in the temples itself, even though "No Smoking"signs were all over. (Not that the dust kicked up by vehicles bad enough, but the puffing made it almost unbearable)
I enjoyed it for the ride. By going to this temple (beyond just going to Angkor), we were able to get a much better view of the Cambodian countryside.

awesome. def do this. But DON"T ride the elephants around it. SE asia is notoriously bad to their animals. def do see this and see all the smiling buddha faces. also ask about all the square things in all the rooms. there is a cool story about them

A personal favourite. Bayon, and indeed most of Angkor Thom, is absolutely stunning - but the best part about visiting it is the freedom to range around. Clamber up thousand-year-old temples, take in the view from the top of Buddha's head, or just enjoy the sheer variety. A wonderful place to be.

Famous temple with cardinal faces. This temple is inside the Angkor Thom complex. The place itself is huge and has lots of passages, stairs and hallways downstairs so its difficult to make sure you saw everything. The good news is that most of it is. The same and just duplicated. Go up the narrow, steep stairs to the top level to get the. Famous face photos. This top level goes around the main tower so it's easy to see everything.

Fascinating. This place is amazing. However, I was tempted to give it 4 stars because of the crowds. Who was this guy, anyway, that he has his face everywhere; it is interesting. After walking through we crossed over to buy a book of the various temples. My daughter who speaks Khmer asked if anyone was willing to sell the book for $5. There was a rush of people willing to sale it. This is the same book that was offered for $20 U.S. in the previous location. Really nice book with wonderful photos.
Very impressive. Definitely a must see. Beautiful temples and fascinating history. Only low point is that the heat and the crowds do dull the joy a bit.
Amazing. Everything in the Angkor complex is amazing, including the Bayon Temple. Try starting with this one instead of Angkor Wat, it's right next door, and one can get lost for hours!
a Must !. most beautiful temple. spent there few hours and liked it very much. Many children will try to sell you handmade goods for cheap - instead of going to school - think twice before buying.

Wonderful temple. This was the first temple we visited and was one of our favourites although they are all amazing. We particularly liked the faces on the pillars and the hidden passageways which are great to explore.

Great temple. This is the biggest temple in angkor wat. The place is so beautiful. There are hundreds of visitors when we went there so it is difficult to take photos of the temple without people passing by. Wear approriate and comfy clothes and shoes or scandals. And dont forget suncreens.

you have to see this. you have to see this. a great experience. amazing history, beautiful place, took lots of pictures. Really cant say enough about all the temples in Angkor Wat complex. If you go anywhere this is a must.

Beautiful Bayon. Visually, Bayon is absolutely stunning. The giant stone faces are phenomenal, and though they are so awesome there is a beautifully quiet serenity to them.
