Personally, Bayon is the most otherwordly temple to visit at Angkor Wat. It is spectacular. Unfortunately I was travelling with a group and didn't get the opportunity to explore Bayon's interior -- however I did get to ride a gorgeous asian elephant around the site. The price is quite steep at $15USD per person, though worth it for such an incredible experience! The mahout frequently stopped close to the temple in order for us to take quality photographs. You can also buy pineapples at $1 each to feed to the elephants. Beware, as they will feel you up looking for more!!
GO WITH A GUIDE. To really help understand this site-go with a private guide. This will help enlighten knowledge and enhance experience.
Wow. The details are amazing. I really enjoyed seeing that temple. Just don't forget to bring a lot of water , even in the shadow it's stille hot !!

How can you not be amazed?. The Bayon Temple was our introduction to the Temples around Siem Reap and we where not disappointed. We entered the Bayon Temple complex through the south gate on the back of an Asian elephant, what a way to start, and never looked back. Traveled with my wife and two young children, all of whom really enjoyed the experience.

Our favourite temple in the Angkor complex!. Whilst nothing can beat the view of Angkor Wat at sunrise, this was our favourite temple visit during our Siem Reap stay. The stone faces in the Bayon are absolutely fascinating and it's fun to get lost in this temple! You should definitely go there first thing in the morning as it does get very, very busy and as it's quite small, it can feel a little cramped and claustrophobic. We went back for a second visit as we enjoyed it so much.
The faces are everywhere. If you enjoy the temples of Angkor, you will also like this site with its many faces of Buddha...or perhaps the king?

make sure you visit there at early morning or at the evening. lot of tourists. i have visited there 3 times in the past 5 years. now, it is flooded with tourists which you really can't find a good spot for pictures. i enjoyed this place when it is peaceful (5 years ago it was. or make sure you visit there at early morning or at the evening)

Mona Lisa of SE Asia. Bayon is known for its huge stone faces, with one facing outward and keeping watch at each compass point. The curious smiling image, thought by many to be a portrait of Jayavarman himself, has been dubbed by some the "Mona Lisa of Southeast Asia." There are 51 smaller towers surrounding Bayon, each with four faces of its own. Bayon Temple boasts an extraordinary collection of bas-relief scenes.

Our favourite!. Bayon was our favourite temple. We first assumed that the faces there were that of Buddha or Brahma. But we later got to know it was the face of the king in the form of buddha, the different faces symbolised him watching over the kingdom. The chaotic art definitely catches the eye and weaves a spell of magic.
Fantastic. Easy to get to from Siemens reap. We rented a rickshaw for the day for 15 US for the whole day. This temple is a must see despite the crowds.

An Insight into Cambodian Life...800 years ago. With its stone reliefs depicting life. Bayon temple is a must and needs to be visited with a guide to get the most out of the engravings depicting social and historical events in ancient Cambodia.
Trip to Bayon Temple. This place is a must see in Cambodia. I saw it after spending a day at Angkor Wat, but it was well worth the trip. Don't miss the black buddah just around the corner.

Probably my favorite temple. As a tour leader, i have visited many temples many times in Angkor, and Bayon is definitely one of my favorites. It's the most for sure the most picturesque temple, especially for its enigmatic smiling faces you can approach very closely.

Really nice... go there by bike and go climb around.... Really nice... go there by bike and go climb around...
Less crowded than Angkor and really beautiful!
Extraordinary!. Nothing can prepare you for the detail and scale of this building which you are still allowed to get really up close to. Go before it gets roped off!

Massive yet peaceful faces. We visited Bayon late in the afternoon - the crowds by then had huddled in Bekong for the sunset. We got the place all for ourselves. Faces and more faces and each face though massive had a peaceful intent to it. There is only one face with a smile - do take photographs here. We just cannot rate or compare this temple against others because each of them is unique and so is this. We loved it !

Amazing. Beautiful Temple with the famous faces of Buddha - not too many people were there when we were so that was nice. They have people dressed in traditional Cambodian outfits and if you pay them you can take a picture
Temples. Beautiful temple a bit away from the chaos of Angkor Wat. I recommend a vist. We went in the morning and it was relatively quiet.

Bayon temple. Fantastic site - not to be missed. Arrived fairly early but still quite busy - the friezes are superb, but the structure is confusing to navigate at times. Good views and great photo opportunities
something special. Adds to the overall feel of Ankor... quite enjoyed this more than Ankor Wat though smaller.... just need to be mindful that it can get crowded during the mornings and mid evenings.

Well worth your time. Bayon is probably the best known temple in the Angkor area.Each of the numberous towers has four faces of Buddha.What makes Bayon unique and recognizable from the other temples is the faces carved into the pillars.Pretty unique and interesting temple which is well worth your time.

A Place of Pilgramage. Beautiful, amazing multiple four faces of Avalokiteshvara..serenity, humility, happiness,...assention,..cool haven and a never ending well, with water deemed to have the power of blessing,..definately blessed as it was a rather hot day.
Outstanding. Part of the Anngor Thom complex not as well know as Angor Wat but the site is quite special and very different than the others so worth seeing.

Elephants. We visit Siem Reap every year, so we have walked and toured the temples many times. This year we went to Bayon just to take our favourite 20 minute elephant ride. The cost is $15 per person but worth every penny. You can also buy food and feed the elephant for an extra $1. We always do!

Not to be Missed. Beautiful historic site - but steep steep steps are not for the mobility challenged or someone afraid of heights - esp on way down - having a walking pike helps a lot. Uneven surfaces abound. Packed with Chinese and Japanese tourists "posing" - so go early....

Stunning temple.. This was our second visit to Angkor, the first being on a rushed, horrid bus tour a few years back. We were pushed along and didn't really get to appreciate the site.This, along with Ta Prohm, was my favourite temple in the Angkor complex. My 10yr old daughter and I on this occasion hired a local tuktuk and driver for the one day ticket, which included the sunset tour and 'killing fields' the evening before, plus a full second day starting at about 4am for sunrise, for £12 (though, obviously we tipped him at the end and bought his food and drink during the tour as well). Because we were able to dictate the speed of the tour, we had the luxury of waiting until the crowds dissipated and managed to get the temple to ourselves at times. I have amazing photos, which do not contain a single person, and also give the impression that we had it to ourselves the entire time! My daughter enjoyed playing 'where's wally' with the various Buddha heads carved into the structure. I preferred this temple to Angkor Wat, which was being restored at the time of travel. There were also 'police' at angkor wat who closed down public access to the central tower, unless you were happy to pay an several dollar entrance fee (which we weren't)!

Spend at least an hour there!. It is a beautiful temple with many enigmatic faces staring out at you. It is well worth spending time exploring Bayon temple. It's probably easier to do so as soon in the morning as possible, as it can get quite packed with tourists as the day goes by.
One of the best. This temple is amazing and a little different from the others. While it can be busy we found it quiet in the afternoon. Must visit!

The best Angkor Wat temple for me. Visiting this temple left me awe. I can just imagine the effort and creativity of ancient Khmers to be able to fashion smiling faces out of the rocks. Luckily, there was a tour guide who led me to some photo effects, like slightly tilting my head up- in one spot so that it would appear that am nose-to-nose with the huge statue of the king. In the end, after touring me through the nooks and crannies of Bayon - even though he was unsolicited, the guide asked for a tip and I happily gave some. Go to the top of this temple, it's very much worth it. There will be very good angles you will not be able to appreciate otherwise. Some of the steps going up can be very steep so be prepared.

Crazy crowds among the ruins!. Liked: The many beautiful Aspara dancer faces and statues around the temples and the jungle environment are simply stunning. Favorite was the Elephant statues at the tail end of the temple circuit. Dislikes: Crowds, tour buses and motorbikes definitely took away any peaceful vibes one could experience from this exotic sanctuary. How can they regulate the number of people to visit to make it more manageable? Sad to see a lack of staff to ensure that impolite tourists are reprimanded for doing things like littering their water bottles everywhere (there was a mountain of water bottles at the top of one temple!) or climbing over statues and ruins where they shouldn't be doing so. Suggestion: go very very early to avoid the crowds which by 10-11am was almost intolerable.
Smile from Cambodia. Amazing place. You can miss other ruin sites of Angkor but must visit this one. This is the smile from Cambodia!
Amazing. The history and the condition is a must see. You do have to be careful walking around as it is very rocky

breathtaking. large carved faces in impressive rock structures. this was my favorite part of angkor wat! i'd recommend a guide or book who could tell you about the images in the carvings... there are a lot of intricate details in there!
Amazing. We loved this temple the most, amazing!!!Make sure you have plenty of water and sunscreenNext time i would like to have a quide with us
Cool photo ops!. So cool to get up close to the carvings. Just amazing given the age and condition of the temple. Just watch your step!

My favourite. It is so hard to put this experience Into words. No pictures can do it justice.........excellent photo ops towards the late afternoon when the light is perfect and the crowds have left for the day.
Face it - Bayon is Beautiful. The faces are exceptional. We took many photos - some Abba poses with our profiles lining up the stone carvings etc... A bit of fun...It's really awesome.

Don't miss it!. It's one of my favorite throughout the whole historical sites. There are amazing carving on the wall around the temple. Bought an English colored guide book from the local kid, "Ancient Angkor" written by Micheal Freeman (the price is around $5-$10) The book explain the story of the temple and also carving around the temple. The face towers is just phenomenal. I reckon at least 1.5hrs of visit at this site. Please just don't miss this one!

Must see. We visited the Bayon Temple after Angkor Wat. It's not as grand and the condition of the building isn't as well-preserved. For that reason, we liked its character almost more than Angkor Wat. The Buddha faces are amazing and there's a feeling of peace. We arrived shortly before lunch and it was much less packed than usual.

A must-see!. Second time to visit Bayon and it still left me breathless! Tourists must not miss this temple complex in their visits as it's an unforgettable scene looking at those faces carved out of the temple walls.

Stunning. We visited the Bayon after Angkor Wat and were amazed by the differences between the two. We arrived at the Bayon at around 10am and it was busy already - recommend getting there earlier if possible. Still very enjoyable though - look out for the photo opportunity on the top level where you can duck behind one of the pillars and take a photo of the three faces in a row. Any of the guides should be able to point it out to you.
Great historical site. Touring this old historical temple is a great experience. We really enjoyed it. Quite a bit of renovation going - happy to see that.
amazing. Don t miss it it the best best best temple in siem reap, you will never forget it. A most do in angkor

Awe-inspiring. I felt so privileged to be able to wander around the ancient towers, gallieries, carvings. Cannot really add anything original to previous reviews, suffice to say make sure your camera has plenty of battery life as there are photo opportunities at every turn.

Best thing around Siem Reap. Angkor Thom and the Bayon Temple - this was the single most amazing thing we visited during our holiday, even including Angkor Wat itself. Try and go in the afternoon when it is less crowded - as the sun goes down, the interplay of shadow and sunlight on the giant faces is exquisite.

Amazing place!. So near to angkor wat so i decided to go to Bayon Temple.It's just simply amazing to see all those curvings,must have taken a long time to make this temples.The temple have big faces curved into it. A must visit place if you go to Seam reap.Highly recommended.

Just amazing!!!. Bayon was part of our second day visit. Spellbinding architecture which gives you lots of photo opportunities. Will definitely recommend to go because it's different. The giant carved smiling faces are worth seeing as well as the Angkor Wat.

More impressive than Angkor Wat. It is smaller and less famous than Angkor Wat. But I found its carving and faces more inspiring. The guide says there are 54 towers, each with carvings of 4 faces. The faces are aligned north, south, east and west. There are wall carvings as well.

Must visit place in Siem Reap. This place needs no introduction since there are numerous TA reviews and pictures of giant faces (still do not know whether those faces represented the famous king Jayavarman VII or Buddha. Excellent photo opportunities and may be a bit less crowded compared to famous Angkor Wat (since they are pretty close, you could modify your daily trip a bit and stop by first here if it is too overcrowded, especially at Angkor Wat).Bayon Temple is located inside big Angkor Thom city wall and as for a first time visitor, you should stop by at the entrance "naga" bridge: with smily Bayon like faces on the left side and angry looking demons/guards on the right side.Notes: 1) Excellent literature can be found on wikipedia if you are not a book person. 2) Entrance fee is required and consider 2-3 days temple pass (40 $), a minimum to explore all those temples. 3) I do not know why people are picking on small children and poor vendors selling food and stuff in all temples. If they have too much spare time to decide what is going wrong in Cambodia or any other part of the world (as if they do not have to manage their own affairs), why don't they go ahead and explore who got your temple pass money-- All entrance fees from tourists go to a private company (read as cronies making money with corrupted government) and do you know how much money Cambodia government/ordinary people eventually receive to improve their daily lives of their citizens and how little money go to temple renovation? Anyway, selling food or souvenir is not a crime and some children do go to school (they have either morning or afternoon classes to choose). Do not think that the world is uniform and flat and every school in the world is whole day. If they do not make any money and have nothing to eat, they will starve to death before thinking whether they should go to school or not. By buying food or stuff from them, your precious money (as wealthy tourists from developed countries think) go directly to ordinary Cambodian people and they could eventually buy rice to eat. I think it is more unethical if you haggle down a lot to those poor vendors because you think you are superior and you can do whatever you want (of course some vendors inflate the price a lot)!

Amazing. How can anyone not find this place amazing. Yes it is busy so try to visit really early or brave the midday heat when all the Korean tourists go back to town for lunch. Take your time to walk through and enjoy.
Another beautiful temple. Temple is stunning while not as big as Angkor Wat, its still worth a quick stop, Its one of the more popular temples for a reason.
One of the top 3 to see. Fascinating architecture - very different from the other temples - well worth seeing if you only have a short time in Siem Reap

Go to as well as Angkor. Great photo opps. Go here as well as Angkor; it's a different type of temple. Take water with you and do NOT buy frm the little kids. Locals are trying to get them out of labor and into schools.
Amazing place. THe temples are Angkor Wat are something to see. IT is worth the trip. Be great if not so many people were there as it is a bit overcrowded.

Someone is watching you. Within the Angkor archaeological historical park (entrance fee 20 USD / day) is an amazing piece of architecture. Wherever you are a face looking at you. Too many tourists but wonderful memories.
The Many Faces of Buddha. Bayon is a unique temple because of the many different facial expressions of Buddha. It's quite a stunning spectacle to behold that should be seen and experienced.

Beautiful temple. After 2 whole days of temple-ing, almost all the temples started to look the same. The Bayon however is truely look different from the other temples. The faces carved into the rock is so magnificent and detailed.

Buddha Faces Everywhere!. Apron arrival at the temple we were greeted by some friendly geese who showed us the way to the Buddha faces. Really quite beautiful! There isn't anywhere here that isn't a photo oppurtunity. Definitely worth a visit!
First Visit.... Part of my first day visit. Had a guide that let me explore on my own, and was not on my heals all the time. Very nice place.

Interesting but less commonly visited. The stone is more worn and not as well preserved as the other temples. It was built 1175-1240 and shows it's age. The colorful Hindu is minimal at this temple. Still worth a visit, but if you had to do only a couple, I wouldn't choose this one.

Favourite Angkor Temple. This is my favourite angkor temple, the 200+ smiling faces of budha/king looking at you from above is the most hard to forget image of angkor. Go during morning or evening so that the sun illuminates the faces from one side.
The best temple of all. Everywhere you turn at Bayon there is another photo to take, you can't help but be amazed by the faces on nearly every surface.
Awesome Stone Faces. How these faces were carved in the ancient days are something to behold. You cannot miss Bayon Temple.
Wonderful.. a must. Bayon has the classical temple images - with faces shaped into the temple. It's the one used in the photos and paintings. Less busy and great photo opportunities..

Lots of smiling faces, the temple dedicated to Shiva. And that’s not just because of the 216 gigantic smiling faces in this temple but also the people who are taking advantage of the wonderful photo opportunity beside the ruins of Bayon. There are certain angles where you can find 3 faces on 3 different towers aligned to each other. Use the windows as your “photo frames”!
Must Go. Go experience the Bayon Temple and it is sure to intrigue your mind to try and understand why the temples are designed in the way they were.
Incredible. Loved it - really huge - not until you get there that you can appreciate the scale of these temples and monuments. Definitely worth the visit.
Majestic but could get crowded. The giant faces, facing various directions are somewhat haunting, nostalgic and a slice of time travel from an opulent era. It's just a surreal experience altogether.

Not just another temple, just a different temple. It's hard to forget the first impressions as you approach this unbelievable structure. The multiple faces make a lasting impression among the grandeur of the Angkor Thom complex. The masons and sculptors really surpassed themselves here, so much so I had to stop myself taking too many photos.
Well worth a visit even if you are over temples and pagodas.

A must visit. We enjoyed visiting this temple as we had heard so much and seen so many photos. It did not disappoint. It's very cool to visit. But watch out, at several of the sites there are unofficial 'guides' who will just start talking to you about the temples and explaining things and then expecting a hefty tip for an unsolicited tour - one guy expected $10 - $15 for 10 minutes and was angry that we didn't give it to him! They can be quite persistent so just walk away and don't respond.

Wonderful carvings!!. Despite the size of Angkor Thom, that houses several wonderful temples, your car or tuk tuk can drive right up to most of these temples so don't be put off by the thought of having to walk miles to see everything.Bayon was one of my favourites - wonderful atmosphere and fantastic carvings, both at Bayon and also the entrance to Angkor Tom

Another different temple. Totally different than Angkor Wat, for me more interesting and not so crowded.Take your time to wander and stop to contemplate what motivated the people to design and build such huge edifices.The time, efort and money that must have bee expended has to be huge. The workmanship is amazing when one considers what tools and machinery the was available to the artisans.Incredible.

The Most Beautiful Temple!. The giant stone faces of Bayon have become the unofficial symbol of the Angkor Wat temples. This Buddhist temple was my favorite temple of all the temples in Angkor and is in the Angkor Thom ruins. The eerie beauty of Bayon is unforgettable and I had to return here several times, just to stand in it's majestic splendor. We visited Bayon in the late morning, when the sun is in a good position for photos. I also returned in the late afternoon, and there was a dramatic change in the color of the stones with the late afternoon light. Bayon was built by Jayavarnam VII during the end of the 12th century and was his state temple. Guide books differ on whose face is said to be carved into the towers. The bas-reliefs on the lower walls are fascinating, and should be viewed with a knowledgable guide. As in most of the other temples, there are many war scenes, but the most interesting were the scenes of everyday life during the 12th century.
Magnificent. Although Angkor is famous and the biggest of all temples. Bayon temple looks more interesting with most of its originality still intact. Its worth the visit.

Awe Inspiring. As I step up the platform leading to the entrance of the Temple, my heart skipped a beat. I felt like I was transported to another place where only beauty and peace reigns. The Faces of bodhisattva Avalokiteshvara are simply stunning. In addition, the bas reliefs which depicts a combination of both legendary and historical events can be seen surrounding the temple. Everything about this place is simply breathtaking! Really worth visiting!

"Better the Angkor". "Better the Angkor"!at least that's what my daughters said.I don't agree as it is a completely difference experience. But it is really really enjoyable. It is well worth visiting and no where near is clouded as Angkor which of course is 100 times bigger.

My Favorite. Sunset is THE time..... Some say "a ruin is a ruin"...if you have seen Angor Wat you've seen 'em all. I disagree. Bayon felt more intimate - less traveled and was just so breathtakingly beautiful words don't do it justice. The wafting smell of incense and soft chants, held by the sun setting and the whispers of tourists knowing that this is perfection came together for a perfect experience. Don't leave this off of your itenerary.

WOW! WOW! WOW!. This is one of the busiest temples but that doesn't matter here as the building and the many giant heads will stun you all the same. Look out for the wall of carvings showing the day to day activities of the ordinary people - incredible detail and still relevant today.

Interesting. Difficult to say which temples are the best, this one is one of the better ones. Another temple on the "small" circuit, that chould not be missed. The Buddha carvings are interesting to see.
My favorite. Wonderful. Beautiful bas relief, intricate and interesting inside. Do not pass this by even if there are crowds.
Highlight of Angkor.. The site of a thousand Buddha faces carved in stone was out of this world. Explore in the morning when crowds are thinner, and find the Buddha shrines within the temple.

I'd imagine most people find this more interesting that Angkor Way. First, you have the bridge over the moat, which is a series of ancient lovely Khmer carved figures lined up like so many Rockettes.Then, you have the entrance gate, which is lovely, but grab your camera as you may soon see an elephant stroll through, tourists perched precariously atop in a little sedan chair.Lastly, the temple itself. When it was built, each city-state was asked to contribute a statue to one of the 59 temples in the complex. Each temple has faces on four sides, a bit Maori-like. The phrase "cut your nose off to spit your face" supposedly comes to the defacing of such temples by conquerors throughout history.You could spend hours here looking at all the faces. Lovely setting too.

Fabulous Temple with those amazing Faces - don't miss this. The four faced structures of Bayon are one of my favourite and lasting memories of my trip to Angkor. The faces are fantastic and have to be seen to be appreciated. The place has a magical atmosphere and although it is far smaller than the building area of Angkor Wat I would have to say I preferred this. There are lots of tourists and at times this can be a pain. However, you might be able to get a quieter area where you can enjoy the various perspectives of the many faces and just spend time in awe of the beauty of this place. We also took the chance to have a n elephant ride around the Bayon. Again we really enjoyed this although it is not the most comfortable transport you will experience. I am so glad that we visited and spent time at the Bayon and the faces of stone will be in my memory for a long time to come.
Beautiful faces. This is the temple with buddha profiles carved everywhere and it is quite stunning. The trick is t try and avoid the coach parties if you can...

Should be shutdown. My rating and review here is based primarily on its present status and condition. There were hordes of tourists running all over the place who seemed to care for nothing except to click away their pictures to glory coming primarily from a country that starts with a capital C. These irresponsible tourists were trampling all over the structures, climbing up and down the precarious stones, and generally making a nuisance of themselves. I doubt if even one of them appreciated the beauty and grandeur that could still be seen in the highly damaged sculptures.I also blame the authorities for not shutting down this historical and cultural treasure until it is fully restored, and even then restricting the movement of these crazy tourists. It desperately calls for better management. Based on what I saw here and at Banteay Srei and some of the other temples, these structures are unlikely to survive this onslaught for very long. Angkor Wat itself is in better shape and is far better managed and controlled. The mad and crazy tourists do not trample overit the way they do elsewhere. Please stop them before thes ebeautiful tempples are lost forever.
Better than Angkor wat. I personally preferred this temple to Angkor wat. It was a little bit quieter and the towers with the face carved in them were spectacular.
The design is amazing. This one is a must see in Angkor. All the giant face carvings are amazing & all the detail is just unbelievable. Hard to even fathom how an ancient civilisation could do this.

Fantastic to explore. My girlfriend and I visited Bayon temple first out of the Angor complex of temples....and for us it beat Angor Wat. There weren't as many tourists wandering around which meant you got to really take in the temple and appreciate it, and it is very much something to appreciate.The different faces were quite spectacular to see and it is impressive that this place is still standing today. Definitely worth a visit....we really enjoyed hiring bikes and exploring the temples at our own pace without being made to move on my tour guides.

Face about... ...and you'll see another face. Good to explore and take in the ambience. Wear appropriate shoes for rough surfaces and steep stairs. Dress rules apply, depending on person at entry and some woman may get turned away from some temples in shorts, even of you offer to cover with a sarong.
little gem. Bayon Temple is like a little gem. It is in such great condition and its beautiful. A little bit out of town, but totally worth it.
Incredible. I really liked this temple, the 54 different faces, all with a different expression, carefully detailed, quite incredible how it stands all these centuries later, rescued from the jungle

Amazing!. Another fantastic ancient temple in the Siem Reap area of Cambodia. There are thousands of temples, I am told, in Cambodia; I could spend a lifetime expoloring and photographing them. If you only have time for a few temple visits this has to be one!
Much quieter than Angkor Watt. An excellent temple in good condition with much less crowds and no tourist groups. Got some great photos of this one
Awe-inspiring.. This is a not to be missed part of the temple complex. Make sure you have lots of space one our SIM card!

Amazing structure. Cheap food.. One more temple in Angkor. Altogether it is marvellous and breath-taking. However, it could be better conservation and more information for the visitors.
TIP: Always bargain for cheaper food. Sellers have hidden menus of 1.5$ any dish.

the shadiest temple of all. This was our third temple of our tour and frankly, I was getting bored so we told our guide we wanted to skip it. But he insisted we take a peek. Oh man I'm so glad we didn't skip it. It's the tomb raider temple! and it's different because it is covered by trees. Which makes visiting it bareable in the heat.
Hard to get a good photo. Of course this is an awesome sight, but photographers should choose their timing carefully as it's standing room only here.
Most interesting site of angkor. Not angkor wat but the bayon was for me the highlight of angkor. All the faces and carvings, just amazing and much more peacefukl then angkor wat.

my favourite temple. this was my first visit to the temples in Cambodia and for this reason it is my favourite. it seemed less touristy that the other temples with fewer hawkers and more monkeys!! I was able to get a blessing for $1 which was an interesting experience for me.
Nice setting. With trees all around this is a calm and peaceful place to visit in the afternoon. Coach parties have all gone by then! This is the one with the faces!

Mysterious faces. All those faces carved in stone mosaics created, you look enigmatic, with a smile, they seem to want you to talk. Bayon is an incredible place, a magical atmosphere pervades those who venture between the various towers.
Worth to visit. The carvings and dimentions are amazing, take your time and pace yourself. Be sure to seat down and enjoy the visit.

Awesome!. We went there first - it is awesome! Spoke to a Japanese team who are busy with restoration work - that is the amazing thing about Angkor - all the nations involved with restoration, finding what rocks belong where and repairing the carved friezes, etc Wear good walking shoes because you will be be clambering over and up and down many rocks and steps! Came across a small group of apsara dancers - unexpected colour beneath Buddha's smiling faces. More colour in the Buddhist shrines inside.

Beautiful. This was one of our favourite temples! It is absolutely beautiful. Plenty to see and explore. We only spent about 2 hours here which may seem short to some, but it was enough time for us. It gets very hot and crowded to go early (just after sunrise) if you can. MUST NOT MISS.

Favorite Temple. The Bayon Temple is easily my favorite of those in the Angkor park. All of those faces of Jayavarman VII, staring out of the jungle, with that enigmatic smile -- captivating. It is a delight for the photographer because there a opportunities for great photos at almost any time of day.

Coolest temple ever. Our tour guide told us that this was his favorite temple and after two hours climbing all around we agreed. The history, intricate carvings and its layout are all truly amazing, especially when you realize there were no power tools just man and elephant power. a must see.
like a movie.... Get to Bayon temple early in the morning, before the tourist's flood. Enjoy the scenic view and think about the Jungle Story or Tomb Rider...

Majestic!. Bayon Temple is my favorite temple in Siem Reap and simply spectacular. It helps too that the sky was exceptionally blue the day we visited and that we arrived about 8am in the morning where there was hardly anyone around. The place was packed to the brim by 9!The many large stone faces spread out across the entire temple, 52 in total as we were told, was a breath-taking sight. Though many had worn off quite a bit over time, a few of the stone faces were still in pretty good condition. Definitely worth a visit and only a short ride away from Angkor Wat.

1000 faces. The major temple at Angkor Thom. Walk around the temple complex to get an overview before diving in to admire the many faces.
On recommendation of my guide I did also climb the Baphuon temple. but I don't think the view is worth it and you can save some energy for other climbs.
Less crowded than Angkor Wat. Enjoyed this beautiful temple with the faced of Buddha on the towers. Very few visitors late in the afternoon, so peaceful. Does not take long to visit the area.
Atmospheric and enigmatic. One of the best, if not the best temples. Therefore, reserve for it a good time slot. Probably more rewarding that Angkor Watt.
Bayon Temple. Liked the very beautiful structure of the temple with towers of 4-faced buddha. Too bad most of the statues were gone. Restoration effort is very good.
Part of the whole Angkor Wat experience. You can't see Angkor Wat without seeing Bayon, it would be a terrible thing to do so. It is part of Angkor Wat and located very close to it, in the same park.
Better than Angkor Wat. Bayon is quieter with more original parts and less renovation. There are also less hawkers which leaves you to mooch around at your own pace with out the hassle
Amazing experience. The entrance gives you a feeling of going back in time. The skills , design and architecture are admirable which words can not describe.
My favourite.. Go early (just after sunrise) to avoid the que. gets very busy and very hot. My favourite of all the temples very impressive.
Another must do temple. Great photography, get there early in the morning to best appreciate this one as you will be able to take photos and sit in peace, 4 a while anyway
Lots to see. See not just the famous faces of Bayon, but the Elephant Terrace and the tucked away Terrace of the Leper King. wonderful bas relief.

Lovely temple. You must visit this place, it is wonderful. Go with an English speaking guide, they only charge you 20-30 usd a day.
Go in the morning when most of the people ar at Angkot wat.
Bayon Temple. This is an amazing piece of architecture and restoration work. We felt that it was among the most beautiful places that we saw.
Bayon Temple - Siem Reap. Visited on a 3 day temple pass $40. Went at our own pace - I would recommend visiting here after seeing Angkor Wat - following the history time line. Well worth a visit.
Our favourite. Is our favourite temple in Angkor: we went there 2 times in 2 different hours. The late afternoon is the best choice.
Interesting. Entrance gate is really impressive with the alignment of statues and the surrounding moat. Rest of the temple is less so.

Very unique temple - one of a kind that has face carvings. The crowds at this temple & the scale of the complex make it more interesting to explore, compared to Angkor Wat. The reliefs on the wall convey lot of stories & the transition of spaces with varying levels of volume & light make exploration of the temple very interesting.
The many smiling faces of Bayon. The faces were extraordinary - we virtually had it to ourselves around sunrise, and we could feel the peaceful serenity of this place.

Great Experience. We visited Bayon in the afternoon (after visiting Angkor Wat in the morning). Though it was really hot & humid and the crowds were a bit much, experiencing the Bayon was one of the highlights of our trip. Definitely try visiting early morning when the weather and the crowds are agreeable.

Amazing. Ariive early in day (7am) or late afternoon to beat the mid-day sun and crowds around this amazing site. Amazing enormous statue faces everywhere, and an easy walk to scenic Terrace of Leper King, Terrace of Elephants via Phimeanakas. Lots of photo opportunties.

Great temple. Wonderful temple much bigger than I thought only down side is the climbing
It's helpful to have a guide

Beautiful, and less mobbed than angkor wat. We may have lucked out and rode here at just the right time between tour busses, but the place was nearly empty. At about 2pm the sun was very hot but shone in just the right way past the statues through incense smoke. Very cinematic. If you don't like a ton of chatter and just want to experience for yourself, I recommend renting a bike and going by yourself. A great experience.
Our favourite Siem Reap Temple. Angkor Wat may be bigger and more famous, but Bayon was our favourite - those huge faces are just amazing!
Nature at its best. Leaves one awed and mystified with the wonders of the past and heritage for the future.do enjoy the place and soak in the reality of the ages.
Photogenic. Pay for a guide to tell you about the place, it is worth it!!! They help you take memorable photos too.

Avalokiteshvaras all the way round. Although splendidly ruined, the wonder of the Bayon are the faces of Avalokiteshvara, modeled on the King's who had them built, that beam out benignly from its intricate towers. The acme of egotism - yet you know he knows.
Loved it!. OMG this place was amazing!! Loved all the faces DO NOT MISS this place on your trip to the Temples of angkor!
My favorite.. Such a sense of peace here despite the crowds. Love the serene smiles -- especially in late afternoon sunlight.

Loved the Bayon Temple. I loved the Bayon Temple. It's not as famous as Angkor Wat but I very much enjoyed walking around its corridors and checking out the little carvings and smiling budhha faces everywhere.However just like Angkor Wat I think visits can be better managed to prevent the damage to the temples, I can see tourists trying to scrape the surface of some of the rock carvings and also not taking care when going up and down the stairs. I don't claim to have a solution but I do hope Cambodian tourism finds one soon.
Another great temple. This was another great temple to see while visiting Siem Reap. While there are many temples to see I would make sure to add this one to the list.
Good to see.. Part of Angkor Thom...faces were interesting. We spotted monkeys near the temples so that was fun. No elephants available to ride however. ;-((

Amazing. The place was packed to capacity but it was still worth it. Although time and the elements have taken their toll, the carvings of Buddha were exquisite. There is a mystical aura about the place. A must see!

A beautiful building, still well maintained. Traveling half way around the world to see the Angkor complex, this was a big deal for me, and I did my research in advance. Unfortunately, I did not have enough time to see all of Angkor Thom but couldn't leave Cambodia without seeing Bayon, which we did just after sunrise (before the tour buses started to cycle through). Bayon is a lot smaller than I thought it would be. It is still very interesting and the faces are plentiful and well maintained, but for some reason I thought it would be bigger, almost like Angkor Wat. It is still substantial, though, and worth seeing.

A Temple With A Face. Angkor Wat is larger and receives most of the press. Bayon, however, is remarkable, because it has spectacular carvings of faces in the rocks at the top of the temple.It is small, but very worthwhile to visit. If you are in Siam Reap, you probably have the time.

My favorite!. One of my favorite temples in Siem Reap. It's simply fascinating and you can tell that a LOT of work has gone into building such a magnificent place. There are faces carved everywhere! You must not miss seeing this temple, you will be amazed. It's better to visit this temple during the morning.
Stunning. What a marvel. The place was very busy which was to be expected and it did not detract from the experience.The heads are amazing. The Temple was much better than I expected.
brilliant. The whole area is just amazing, it helped to have a good enthusiastic guide to bring to life what you were seeing.

Invest in good guiding!. known as the face temple, its pretty cool- the angles for good shots are endless, but it also has very interesting history and the carving on the walls are impressive especially when presented well by a certified guide.

Stunning visuals from one 4 faced entrance to the other. The carved heads are really cool to look at and they are abundant. The temple itself is not easy to navigate because of all the different levels of the ground. Be wary with little ones or if you have difficulty walking.

Buddha heads. This is the temple known for the big Buddha heads. Take your time walking around, and enjoy! Plenty of picture opportunities. If you are unsteady on your feet, please watch where you step. Though that is the truth with most of the park.
The best temple!. Such a fascinating place! Liked it best of all! Would recommend it to all, even in high season. Fabulous with all the stone faces!
Do not skip. Dozens of faces have been preserved despite terrible destruction of so much of the area. And beautiful wall carvings tell stories.
Also Amazing. Another very impressive part of the Angkor complex. The upper levels showed us some more of the detail of this historical wonder.

A unique perspective. The temple with the towering faces is truly a marvelous site to visit. The four faces of Buddha on each temple is unique in its own way, and make it stand apart. A must visit in site in Siem Reap.

Beautiful temple. We brought our 5 and 2yo. It was fun climbing the steps and exploring the temple. My kids totally dig the place!
Some steps are a little steep thus a toddler carrier came in useful for my 2yo.

Amazing - not sure who had the bigger smiles, the Bayon or me!. Visited in Nov 2009. Part of the huge Angkor Archaeological Park, the Bayon temple from a distance seems like a jumble of huge rocks, but as you get closer you begin to make out the huge, peaceful faces looking to all four directions.There are 37 standing towers, most but not all sporting four serene carved faces.This temple, for me, was even better than Angkor Wat, it is incredible. As with all the sites, it gets very busy.
Ultimate beauty. An excellent exemple of beauty and high culture. In times when the Western world lived in the Middle Ages.

Mysterious. This temple is unique . We walked around the quiet ruins marveling at the huge four headed faces and tiny passages. I've been to many temples but have not seen this type of architecture anywhere else. We visited at twilight and the surrounding greenery and bird sounds added to the serene scene.Definitely a must see. There are several temples, and "templing" can get tiring in Cambodia. Bayon should not be missed.
new years day 2012. visited on new years day 2012 after a night of drinking and was very impressed with this temple of the many visited that day.

Too many tourists. Not that I am complaining but I think Bayon, and the other Wats could really use some more planning in terms of the volume of visitors entering the premises. Bayon is way much better a few years ago when I visited the place since many of the structures have already gone down but reconstruction is also underway in the place.

I founf it to be the most impressive temple. I loved the faces carved into the 4 sides of the pillars, all of the carvings into the rocks and just the immensity of Angkor Thom, but Bayon in particular.

In pure awe. We visited the Bayon in late afternoon and the hue made the Great face looked more mystical and
stunning. I stood there in pure awe and peace for minutes, feeling like I was talking with people from the past. An incredible experience!

The center of the site. Bayon is the center of the complex of Ankor Wat. you can find many of budha faces around of this site. Unfortunately, this site is really need a reconstruction, so many damage in some sculptures and statues. But overall, this site is really has historical & cultural magic. :)
-
M!

Our favourite temple in Siem Reap. This temple was our favourite Temple in Siem Reap with all the faces and different places to check out. We did the Elephant ride around the temple and felt like rock stars, it was great. A must see in Siem Reap

One of the best sites at Angkor. The many, mysterious faces are haunting and beautiful. Get there early morning or late afternoon to avoid the worst heat of the day and the worst crowds. The lighting is better then too. Get a guide and have him/her show you the kissing face and get a picture.

Beautiful Temple but Pick Your Time of Visit Wisely. Bayon Temple ranks among the top five of most special temples/sites of the Angor Area. It's very famous for the carved out faces that have become symbolic for the Angor are itself. Do note, however, that this is one temple that is on every tour group's itinerary and thus almost always very crowded. Lunch hour is a pretty good time to avoid the crowds though. Towards sunset this place is best avoided.

Words don't do it justice. Angkor Wat etc you just have to see to believe, and appreciate. Recommended if you are into cultural sites and history. Bring sunscreen and mosquito repellant. Respect the people and their extreme poverty. Watch out for scammers. Bayon Temple is another great site to view on offer in Siem Reap.

Definitely a must see in Angkor!. We visited the temple as part of our Grasshopper Adventures tour (see other review).This is one of the most prominent temples in Angkor National Park, aside from Angkor Wat.We were there is November 2012 and it wasn't too busy.Its quite hard to imagine these temples are almost 1,000 years old and how much majesty they would have had in their prime. A must see for sure!The fee is included in the Angkor Pass, which is $20 for 1 day and $40 for 3.

The faces, the faces!. If only spending two days at Angkor (As I did), Bayon is probably the one I will remember the best alongside Ta Prohm and Angkor Wat. The faces – the faces! Amazing carvings and like some guidebooks describe – impossible to count. But like everywhere else in Angkor – people trying to “give” you incense will expect to be paid afterwards.

Definitely worth a visit!. One of our favourites and the surrounding temples are also lovely with lots of monkeys in the surrounding trees - although watch your bags around them! Mine was emptied by one of the monkeys!

My favorite temple!!. I absolutely love this temple. Probably even more than Angkor Wat itself. If you only get to see three temples, see Angkor Wat, this one (the face temple), and Ta Phrom (the one in the Tomb Rainder movies).

Happy stone faces everywhere. It's just amazing to see the massive works involved in the construction of these huge stones faces at a period of time when modern tools were not yet available.
An amazing piece of massive architectural work not to be missed.
See it. Saw a history of Khmer life 1000 years ago written on a wall . Step back into serious history. Tis is a must see
Indescribable. Words fail when trying to explain Angkor's temples. Try and go at times when the big package tour buses aren't around or it gets crowded

Very nice.. You kan make reservation true a travelagency but better is to do it with Tsoi. He speaks English, has a car for 4 passengers, airco and cool water. His phonenumber: 01/7976308. You can also "rent"him for other trips. I used him as a private driver for 12 days (1.200 km). He's not expensive and reliable.
Almost beats Angkor Wat. A magnificent site, well restored and much less crowded than Angkor Wat. It's a just see when there.

Faces smiling from stone. Every tower in this remarkable temple (and there are many) has a unique face of Buddha carved into all four sides. And they are not just little statues, these are massive, taller than an average human. Stained by the weather of centuries, the Bayon Temple's extraordinary faces are serene and beautiful. Officially there is only one "smiling" face, but all feature a calm beauty. This is so unique it must rate highly on anyone's itinerary to Cambodia.
Wonderful. This is the temple with the faces. I loved it. Much smaller than Angkor Wat but it had a really nice atmosphere about it.
Interesting temple to visit. I liked the towers with the smiling faces . Much smaller temple than Amgkor Vat and definitely worth a visit .
How was it possible?. 1000 years back, with no modern technology, kings from far off lands made these marvelous temples - beats our imagination.

Sunset visit a must. Bayon, built in 800 AD has great atmosphere especially if you arrive around 5pm when the monks are praying in the working temple set within the precincts of the ruins. Climb to the top of the ruins to watch the sunset but beware that the stone steps leading up can be a tad treacherous for those not too fond of heights or find difficulty maneuvering steep steps.
Fascinating. We loved all the faces and found the history fascinating. Good angles made for interesting photos. Since much smaller than Angkor Wat, only need 2 hours onsite.
Beautiful faces and monkeys. What a temple... this was just as fascinating to me and my lady thanks to the intricate faces and monkeys around this temple. Not to be missed!
Smiling faces temple. This temple is every bit as impressive as the mighty Angkor. You will recognise those smiling faces... And possibly start to see them In your dreams!

Must Visit. Visit only Angkor Wat and Bayon Temple and skip the rest of the temple if you need to.
Pay attention to the sculpture and religious history of the building
Unbelievable. Even more impressive than the mighty Angkor Wat - Bayon is truly my favourite temple in the area. And not as crowded as other parts of the complex.
Very, very fun. Faces everywhere - great to climb over and around. The kids loved it. We were pushing to see a lot, but could have spent more time there!

Get a guide to really see the Bayon!. Love this temple. I went twice! The light and the crow traffic are best around 3pm. I did not have a guide, and I wish I did. So, I booked one the next two days and was relived. There is so much information to take in that it helps to have a guide, an insider, to get you to the temples at the right times around the never-ending crowds. I used the amazing Mr. Ra. I booked him through La Niche D'Angkor hotel. His English was excellent and his knowledge superb. After two days he was equally a friends.

The Most Beuatiful Gem of the Area. It's hard to pull a favorite from the overall Angkor experience, but for me, it is Bayon Temple. The beauty, serenity, and complexity of this temple overwhelmed me. The many classic Buddha faces offer numerous opportunities for both great photo ops and personal introspection, but that will only come if you open yourself to it.

the most photographed Budhist face. Take time to walk around the terraces of the Bayon. Here you will find lots of nooks and crannies, places to sit and feel the peaceful atmosphere. It is also home to the most photographed Budhist face, so-called because it has the biggest smile of all the faces.

So much potential, crowds horrendous. It was definitely one of the best temples we visited, but find a time without tour groups. Massive groups of Chinese and Russian tourists somewhat ruin the serenity. Don't know when that time would be, but it isnt 11 am!

the best temple in my opinion. I really liked this place, smaller but more interesting than Angkor Vat. This is a personnel opinion. Anyway I know it would be part of your visit because it is a must !

Magnificent. After seeing Angkor Wat earlier in the day I really didnt think anything could be more impresive, I was wrong.Standing outside the south entrance I stood in amazment at the structure and the magnificent carved faces. The question in my mind was where to start with the photography.A favourite photo of mine is outside the south entrance, to the left in front of the water.I thought there would be a mass of people fighting for space but it was quite quiet. Take a moment to look into the carved faces and imagine how this Buddhist temple was built. Due to the tempurature we drank lots of water so ba aware that the toilet facilities are quite a distance from the Temple it's self.

majestic ancient wonder!. my brother was blown away by the magnificence of the angkor temples in siem reap that he decided to come back and bring me along. since he planned the trip, i just decided to relax and not research further about the place. i've seen the pictures, i've read the recommendations in travel blogs, but i was not expecting the temple to be this wondeful! i was in complete awe during the visit, and my trip became more colorful because i learned a lot about the history of the Angkor people through my guide Sopie.
My favorite temple of the trip. The carved stone faces are just amazing, and there are just so many of them to snap - we went at lunchtime and it was fairly quiet.

Great place to visit. Of course a fantastic place to go , plenty pictures that a must lol take a day at least , the architecture is different from the Angkor Wat each temples is different. Hire a bicycle to visit the site save you walking and stop when you wanted.

Beware the ravages of time. This was one of the 3 major sites we visited in the vicinity of Siem Reap, and it offered a dramatic return to the glorious 12th Century of Khmer architecture, as well as an object lesson in how little this great heritage has been respected by succeeding generations. Its proportions are massive and the workmanship lavished upon it is remarkable. The grey stone-work gives it a gothic texture, out of which are carved a range of images, the most celebrated being a series of 4 grotesque faces wearing different demeanours. The walls of the inner and outer sanctuaries are decorated with bas relief carvings relating tales of Khmer mythology or of true historical events, and the craftsmanship comes close to that of Angkor Wat itself. Although this impressive temple is not in good repair, and one has to tread carefully over piles of fallen rock, the fact that huge cranes hover over parts that are out of bounds signifies that someone is making a huge effort to restore this site to its original glory. I would love to return when the workmen have completed their job.

Amazing. For me this was much more impressive then Angkor Wat - and far more intimate without the hoardes of people swarming all over it. Although comparatively small the temple is fascinating with a labyrinth of passageways and the incredible carved heads on every tower. The elephant terrace with its intricate carvings was stunning. Unlike at Angkor Wat you can climb all over the place and it seems much more tactile and alive. Go!

Wonderful. I found this to be one of the most interesting temples. It looks like a temple would be in a cartoon or movie. Huge stone faces and lots of nooks and crannies to explore. It's fairly small so easy seen in an hour. I preferred this over Angkor Wat.

A very nice and unique one. Bayon is quite damaged but still is extremely nice to see because of its unique style. All the temples are squarish when Bayon is roundish. In addition the many towers and faces are a beauty.

The faces of Siem Reap. My kids traveled with us and this was one of our favorites! The faces are fun to see and made this site more interesting for them! I would recommend this site if you have the time!

By far the Pick of Temples for me.... Came ally his way and I'd not want to miss this beautiful temple. The carvings are beautiful and wonderful pictures can be taken from all angles. Take your time and enjoy the wonderful surrounds. We had a Tuk Tuk all day and they were great in leaving this one till last ad I is a memory we will not forget...just jaw dropping beautiful.

Loved it despite renovation all around!. One of our favorite temples, tho this time round we could not see enough as the place was being 'renovated' and 'upgraded. Good to see that but the throngs of tourist made it impossible to get a 'clean' shot ... lots of patience will pay off tho!
The best of the temples. Also a little packed with tourists, smaller, but exceptional with detail and uniqueness the others cannot offer.

More beautiful from Angkor. Beautiful temple. Fairly small so not too much wandering but there are lots of steps. It was so hot when we went but there are lots of parts of the temple in the shade so you have a bit of a break from the sun!

Beautiful carvings. You be able to see many stone carvings on the buildings. Is so amazing and unique. Can say 1 of the best over there. Better wear cover shoes while visiting all these temples as lots of walking and climbing stairs to do. Bring enough water along as the weather is super hot. Elephant rides are available outside the temple, USD15 per head. Can take 2 adults and walk round the temple.

Pics of a Lifetime. Siem Reap is a land of hundred temples, and you can't see all. Pretty soon all of them start to look the same; you feel jaded, blurr..start forgetting the names.....But not Bayon.Bayon, in my opinion, is among the top 3: together with Angkow Wat and Ta Prohm, in terms of "awe power" and depth etched in the mind. It is one of those things you'll remember forever. It is part of the Angkor Thom city, now an archaeological park. (Entrance fees covers all the temples inside.) Main entrance to the the city itself is grand, with an elaborate, tall arc and main gate, preceeded by row of stone guards lining the bridge towards the entrance. ). As you approach the Bayon temple, the jumble of towers resolve and start showing faces. Yes, the faces seen in all the pics of Cambodia. Haunting,impressive, sad, smiling, glorious, crumbling, awe-spiring, humbling, spell-binding,....you run out of adjectives to describe it. A masterpiece of ancient human spirit. [I wonder why and and what cost those kings built such edifices. Surely one reason why the country ended up being so poor?]Take your time; walk around, up and down, in and out, all nooks and corners, the compound and the roof. Staircases are steep and narrow, and stone blocks lying around in places.Careful with children around. It will be very hot in midday withour tree cover around, since the compound is covered by cobblestones.Bring a lot of water and hats. Most important, bring along a good camera...you'll be shooting pics of your lifetime.

The best. If you only have time for one in-depth site, make it this one. Catch the spires of Angor Wat on the fly, and walk through and around this site. The stone carvings, the encroaching vegetation, and the massive structures are incomparable.

Fantastic temple. These ancient stone faces are amazing. Hard to believe how this jewel was created. There was a policeman who offered to take " comedy" photos of each of our family as there is spot that looks like you are having a stand off with one of the faces. Would not have known this!! Great family experience.
這是微笑. 你今天微笑了嗎??從遠楚看到高高大大的微笑，我的嘴角也不自覺得揚起角度!!四面都有高棉微笑，是大大的微笑!smile is a action， need to do it!this temple is very beautiful. 每天都要微笑的巴戎寺~:P

Many faces. The attention to detail was amazing, with countless intricate designs and elaborate carvings. There were etches of people praying, images of warfare and other Khmer icons carved out of the rock surface. It was very impressive, to take note of the talents of the human race, even centuries before modern technology. We found it fascinating that regardless of the fact that the temples are in ruins, people from all over the community still go there to pray. That's defintely one way to keep the Temples of Bayon alive.

The quintessential image of Angkor. When you climb to the third floor of Bayon and look at the 54 towers (216 faces) you will recognize this image as one you have seen over the years that has been shown to the outside world. It is absolutely mind boggling that they were able to achieve this level of sophistication and skill. A must when visiting Angkor.
The Best. For me this is the most fantastic temple with its wonderful heads of the Buddha' also be very careful when exploring as it can be a little dangerous.

A photographers paradise.. Plenty to view and photograph here and the option of walking around the four sides or doing as we did and take the elephant ride. Having a local guide with us gave us more information about the structure and history of the place but there are information boards around to help you make the most of your visit.
Beautyfull. Marvelous site but don't go there with greater mekong travel and tour worst experience of our 2 1/2 month of travel
impressive.. this place is so impressive. you will keep wonderful memory is so big... this is my favorite temple.
Smiling faces!. Visited around midday.... good time to go, not too busy. Unique compared to other temples at Angkor.

Stunning. You must must must go see this...though if you are in Siem Reap its likely this is second after Angkor Wat on your tour anyway. I took a private car to see some of the smaller temples as well, but the faces in this temple blew me away. They are complex, unique, and stunning to look at. The temple is intricate and interesting in its design and layout, enjoy the libraries on either side, though the steps are even steeper than you'd expect so be careful climbing! See this temple!
those haunting faces. every tower with four faces, everywhere a tower, walking around the grounds of Bayone is overwhelming

Smiling Temple. I came to see this temple twice. Each tower has an image of a smiling face – this is so unusual in architecture. No one can say how many smiling faces there are.... but you can walk half a day along its terraces each time finding a new stunning something to look at. I personally loved the places of worship with Budda statues and quiet sweet smoke of the offerings
The best of them all. I loved this temple, it is beyond beautiful - don't miss it. I didn't read up too much before my trip and would have missed this if it wasn't for our excellent tour guide.

Fantastic. Visted as part of the three main sites, it's awesome. Hard walking at times with difficult stairs.
You need the services of a good guide, we can recommend Kiri travel, they were very good and kept us well supplied with water and cool towels.

Those big faces. This temple is one we have all seen in documentaries, but when stepping into it is absolutely fascinating. Those huge faces comming out of the stones seem to e watching over you as you strall through. Its the central temple in Angkor Thon and was built just after Angkor Wat.

My favorite temple in the Angkor complex!. Loved the faces! Arrive early to avoid the crowds for a better visit. If you have time, purchase a seven day pass to Angkor Wat Archeological Park, arrive early each day and enjoy the majesty of each temple before the crowds arrive and it gets hot. Take a break in the heat of the day the. return for a couple of hours during the late afternoon/early evening.

Smiling Faces. It's definetely the most interesting temple in Angkor site. From any corner you have a look at this temple you'll catch a smiling face looking at you. i made photos in mid-day and afternoon. the photos afternoon are so far better with naturel red coloured effects.
You just have to include this. Not just Angkor Wat but do the whole scene around the area is worth more than a day .. get a good tour guide .. we recommend Sophana Yous .. this was a fantastic tour !

Unforgettable. Absolutely incredible, one of the true archeological marvels of the world. The scale of Bayon is stunning-all those incredible massive sculptured faces will take your breath away. Found myself reminded of the giant visage of Ramses in Abu Simbel. an extraordinary temple, and a must see.

One of the most spectacular of the early temples!. This temple stands in the middle of & dominates the ancient walled city of Angkor Thom, dates back to the 12th century & is famous for its original 54 towers (37 still standing) which represented the 54 provinces of the Great Khmer Empire.
Another wonderful temple. Not as big as main temple but this one has it's charm. Must see. Need to spend enough time to enjoy this.

Would have been spectacular in its original condition. The temple has 54 towers, each with 4 facets, and each facet features the smiling face of Buddha. That makes 54x4 faces! In its original condition, these faces were all coated with gold. Some of the towers have collapsed, while some are still in excellent condition. It is the only major temple with so many faces of the smiling Buddha.Do climb to take great shots that can show a few towers in one photo.Tip: try finding an angle where you can take a photo of the tip of your nose touching the nose of the smiling Buddha's face.
Don't miss the Bayon face. The Bayon face is beautiful. Parts of the temple look like jigsaw puzzles made up of massive blocks of sandstone. Keep an hour to explore
Amazing!. The entrance into Angkor Thom itself is almost as spectacular as the Bayon. Visiting in the early morning gives great lighting.
Bayon is not to be skipped!. Bayon was the first temple we visited in Angkor Wat. We enjoyed the sheer size and huge faces. Make sure you walk up to all levels as the top is the best part.
Great face temple. Impressive master piece and good to start the journey in Angkor! great pictures also, you can visit it at different times of the day to play with the light, shadows, effects!
Mystique. It left us with so much question. How come those guys made this glorious one of a kind art, to think they dont have that much tools and technology before. Truly magnificient!
Beautiful faces. This temple has many beautiful carved faces. It sits in the middle of Angkor Thom and offers some great photo opportunities.
Don't miss it.. Take water, don't be afraid to climb up and down the tiny stairs as it's where you'll find some great hidden treasures!

Home of the Gods. The Bayon temple of Angkor Thom is truely magnificant and mysterious. The work that the Japan-APSARA Safeguarding Angkor team is doing in restoration is amazing. A Trip to the Bayon Information Center at the Japan-APSARA Project Office in Siem Reap is very educational and sets the stage for visits to all the temples in Cambodia...a wonderful museum and display with video in english and Japanese...staff is very good and the explainations understandable.

Weird but glorious. The other one you just have to visit at Angkor. Wander around and go to all the different levels and then just walk around the whole temple outside to see as many of the 216 faces as possible.

Temple of a hundred faces. This is one of the many gems of this area. Be prepared to climb! The stairs are steep but they are worth it. Each tower has 4 faces and you will start to see that each is a little different from the other.you will be thankful that we live in the age of digital cameras because you will be clicking away.

Mind-Bending. Do you remember the chaotic pictures, where all of a sudden a 3D shape emerged? That's a little what moving towards Bayon feels like. Definately see it, spend some time and preferably get a guide for the stone carvings (I had trouble finding what my travel book described).
Interesting carvings and images. Bayon Temple is a must see. The carvings and images depicting daily life was interesting and all the giant heads make this temple very different from the others.

Excellent architecture. A great place to visit showing the power of Angkor in the 9th to 13th centuries. Many tourists walking all over the structure and very hot and humid. I found one day was enough to see the Angkor complex as after a few hours all the stones and Buddhas seem to merge into one.

Super cool. I loved this temple. You see the photos but you have no idea until you are right there. There are sooooooooooooo many faces and in soooooooo many places.It's also much bigger in person than you can imagine from the photos. I loved this temple and you will too.I recommend getting yourself a guide as this truely does make all the difference and for only $25 a whole day, no excuse not to have one
Fabulous sight. really good with just so muchto see - hire a local guide to get te most out of your visit. Huge amount to photograph, Be ready for some steep woden stairs to climb
Simply Beautiful. This is one of the nicest I have seen in this region. Really a must see. Spectacular and genius craftmanship.
Amaging to see own eye. So many different face structure.Only down side was I didn't take any rain gear and nowhere to get shelter. I was soaked wet.

High expectations met.. I had extraordinarily high expectations for the Bayon temple. We were blown away. I would suggest, when setting an Angkor complex agenda, to see the smaller and more remote temples first. Save Angkor Wat and Bayon for last. They are worth the wait and will be all the more impressive and important after you have seen the other sites in the area.
A must see. Much smaller than Angkor, but much quieter as a result. It's great to be able to get into everywhere rather than viewing from the side of a roped off area too.
Simply stunning. The centre piece of Angkor Thom this temple is huge, with fabulous opportunites for great photos & exploration. Under going restoration so should be even more impressive in future!

A spiritual experience. The caveat is, make sure you get there before the hoards of North Asian tour groups descend. I stayed overnight in Siem Reap and made my way by motorbike to the temple. Early in the morning, it is blissfully serene. Amazing sculptures (of course). The best thing to do is explore the nooks and crannies and find a quiet spot to draw or to meditate.

Picture perfect temple. Bayon temple is not the usual Angkorian temple because of its face towers. This unique aspect makes it one of the top 3 temples you should visit when you are in Siem Reap. The other two are Angkor Wat (of course) and Ta Prohm. I visited this temple around noontime and I was pleasantly surprised that the temple wasn't filled with tourists so much so that I got many great shots of Bayon's well known face towers without much effort trying to find a spot without one or many tourists blocking the shot. And, if you want a great vantage point of Bayon, you just need to go to the other side of the moat surrounding Bayon and take a shot from there. Many tend to forget the other parts of the temple, like the maze of hallways at the lower level of the inner gallery and the bas reliefs at its outer gallery. Since I had about an hour or so to go explore Bayon, I ventured to the lower level of the inner gallery and found the temperature there to be way lower and it was welcomed coolness from the horrible heat in the upper level. Going through this maze, don't forget to look up when you see a collapsed ceiling. You may see a face tower or two peeking. But, if you only have a little over 30 minutes to spare in Bayon, go to the upper level of the inner gallery and have your fill of the face towers and take photos with them. Regardless of the time you have, Bayon is a temple NOT TO BE MISSED.

Great temple. A great temple among all those at Angkor. Famous for the buddha heads 'turrets'. Also central so easy to walk around to some of the other temples and buildings within Angkor Thom - always somewhere to get away from the mass tourists when they build up inside the temple.

Make sure you see the whole place back to front. Superb site to visit and really should not be missed and do make sure you walk the whole monument from front to rear. Great water photos at close to the moat. The sculptures and engraving through out are some of the most spectacular and interesting. One of the very top places to visit in the area.

Faces here and there. I can imagine the caloused hands who did the craft, with love for the labor that they did. A lot of restoration going on though i think it should be done faster as a lot of stones seem to have fallen to the wrong places already. A temple worth the visit!
Amazing. This looked amazing, unfortunately we were to pooped to look right through it as it was the last one on our tour - we went around the outside only
Temple History. Seeing the history of the temple and the carvings that have survived for centuries is breathe taking and enlightening.

One of the largest Buddhist temple in Angkor Thom, it has 49 towers. Bayon consist of 3 storwy. It is located in Angkor. I love all the smiling faces in this temple. One face and one tower but with four smiling faces. These are faces facing to the four directions.
Most WOW factor temple. This was the temple I was most in awe of at first site. Beautiful site, great adveture climbing and exploring.

how they carved those faces at Victory Gate???. entering one of the Gates to the temple amazes you to begin with! the temple itself has its magic, and you can rebuilt in you mind what its missing from the construction
Buddha Blessings!. A great structure to explore inside and out. Do not miss this place. A true testament to world heritage

Another mad temple. I liked taking in the culture and history of the place
I also liked that it was one more temple off the list, only a few to go

Quintessentially eerie beauty. This place is like a fun house of a temple with huge carved faces looking out into the jungle mounted to face each of the four cardinal directions on every tower in the temple. Awesome geometric design. Leaves me in awe everytime.
amazin!. You will feel like you so small in this world, this temple is impressive, better than Angkor wat to me.

Well worth seeing - take a guide.. The Bayon Temple was one of many fascinating sites i visited while in Siem Reap. I used a guide from Mr Tees Private Guided Tours. His name was Soly and he was informative and great company. At only $30 for the day I would highly recommend that you consider using a guide - he added great value to our visit.
Great bas reliefs. I really liked the carvings of everyday life one thousand years ago. You can pick out the Khmer, Chan (Vietnamese) and Chinese based on their hair and clothing.

Breathtaking. I'm running out of adjectives descibing the various temples in and around Siem Reap. This one with the 4 heads on its towers is almost as magnificent as Angkor Wat. The jungle setting only adds to the beauty and magnificence.

a MUST see temple in Siem Reap. One of my favorite temples visited in Siem Reap. The entrance gate is already impressive and seing inside Bayon added more excitement. The towers and stone faces are spectacular...

Beautiful faces and well received. The Bayon temple is really worth seeing and is characterized by impressive faces. The arrangement is very impressive and striking. The condition is good and the freedom of movement is quite good. Especially recommended as all stairs are easy to cross. Moreover, you have a good idea of the highest levels to be climbed. Highly recommended, and in any case an asset in terms of design.

Fabulous Temple. One of my favorite temples. Everywhere you look, you see a chiseled stone face looking back at you. Go early to avoid the crowds. For photographers, I'd recommend a visit in the morning or afternoon for interesting lighting/shadow effects.
Historical site. it's a temple that everyone who visits Cambodia should go. It's part of Angkor Thom. Quite an interesting site, combining Hinduism and Buddhism buildings.
Beauty. My unashamed favourite of all the temples, not as impressive as Angkor but an array of tiny corridors, fabulous light relfections, gothic towers and brilliant temples within.

Temple of many faces. Some of the most impressive carvings of the temples we visited. Located in the Angkor Thom complex it was very busy in the morning but largely deserted in the afternoon. A good temple to have a guide with you to explain the carvings.
historic. temple site locate around the more establish angkor wat. walking and enjoying the temples surrounding could take a day to a week

stunning -easily the best one !. A stunning large temple with the enigmatic faces staring at you. despite the crowds this was a world-class attraction and will remain in your memory for ever. If you can worth re-doing early in the morning (or dusk) to see this as quietly as possible,

Visit Early for Less People. This temple and Angkor Wat are the two best. If you visit in the morning, it is less crowded. You can even take an elephant ride to the temple too, which they only give in the mornings.

Serene....unforgettable.. If you love history and mystery combined you cannot better this. Most people will only ever come here once, but will never forget the experience. what stories those stones could tell.

Highlight of Angkor Thom, faces dreams are made of.... Banyon temple is my personal favorite in the Angkor Thom complex, and along with Ta Prohm (aka Tomb Raider Temple), my favorite in Cambodia. Smaller and more intimate than Angkor Wat, the iconic four faces of Buddha haunt me still... Do go with a good guide who can point you to the best photo ops after filling you in on all the history, mythology and religion. We had Mr. Phalley of IOT who was worth his weight in gold.
my favorite among the other wats. huge temples. lots of things to see here.. i'm glad the Japanese are helping in its restoration... :)

The awe inspiring faces will make you remember the place.. This is one of those places you will say " I always wanted to be here "! 200 stone faces will look at you back and one cannot help but imagine how fantastic this place had to be in its time of power and splendor. Every architectural detail is interesting. 54 towers and impressive galleries, reliefs and sculptures. This place is one of the symbols of the lost civilization. It gives you also a vibe of "adventure spirit" likely due to many movies and documentaries one recalls this impressive temple from. Interestingly Bayon also means late 12th and early 13th century architectural style of Khmer architecture. This only proves how important this temple once was.
