Incredible temple of Faces. I have visited the Angkor Temples many times and I am always amazed by the the structures and renovations that are ongoing. I usually only stay for a couple of hours as I know that I will come back again to discover new things.

This is better than Angkor Wat!. Personally we prefer this temple to Angkor Wat. It is part of Angkor Thom temple. It has 3 different levels and at the top you see very old head statues which will turn out really nice on your camera. Engage a guide to visit this place so that you can gain a better insights into the historical place. There are hoards of tourists and my fear is that the relics will be destroyed if they don't exercise better preservation. There are elephant rides that will let you circle the Bayon Temple but we didn't try the rides.My photos are located at my travelogue blog. http://sqtravel.blogspot.sg/2012/10/siem-reap-angkor-thom-bayon-temple.html

Amazing pics to be taken here!. I love this temple the best, out of so many at the Angkor Park.There were lots of smiling craved faces all around, and many made an excellent picture.The best picture taking opportunity i like is the nose to nose picture. Yes, you can actually take a picture of yourself and a far away smiling craving, with tips of the nose touching each other. Verdict: ought to come again!

worth a visit. As part of a one-day trip to the 3 main temples it was very good. I would not want more than One day!It was also very hot - the trip cost 62$ for my wife and I including a car/driver and guide.

worth a look. As part of a one-day trip to the 3 main temples it was very good. I would not want more than One day!It was also very hot - the trip cost 62$ for my wife and I including a car/driver and guide.

Beautiful. We arrived late afternoon with a storm about to descend which just added to the atmosphere. Just an amazing experience, steep steps in places but just get in amongst it and feel the history. Brilliant. Even if we got absolutely soaked.

One of our Faves. This temple was smaller and so unique. The faces were amazingly well preserved and it was only a short distance away from the place to see the sunset. If you have time, this is a quaint and tranquil temple not so overrun with people.

Amazing. Astonishing place it's amazing how they built this temple so so long ago and the precision that it is built and the amount of detail I the carvings are defiantly worth many photos.its funny to see that a crane, surveyors and machines being used to fix a few things that was built without any of the above
magnificient!!!. This is my favorite temple. try a good camera trick ...kissing the lips of the buddha stone... it's fun.

The highlight of Angkor Thom. This is a super temple. Famous for the towers with 4 heads on them. Not as busy as Angkor Wat and better for it. Adjacent toilets are western style.Take plenty of water with you and watch out for the heat.

Better than Angkor Wat. Went there with two friends, and we all agreed: Bayon is more interesting and impressive than the much better known Angkor Wat. Word of advice: Pay attention to your guide, who should explain the dramatic, mundane, and even funny slices of 12th/13th century life portrayed in the bas-relief sculptures. Bayon is absolutely not to be missed!
Trip back in time. Get there early or the crowds that arrive later can spoil the atmoshere - some fine carvings - take care when walking uneven ground - don't forget your camara.

more like disneyland .... This temple is beautiful but quite small, and there is so many tourist that you can not really enjoy the place. It's not peaceful anymore. A lot of big groups are coming all day long taking lots of pictures, and sometimes you feel more like in disneyland than in Angkor.

Aaron k. We did a quick walk through as we wanted to see the bigger temples as well, but we had a freelance tour guide ( local ) who gave us some explanation of the temple , we paid him approx $5 American , and he told us all about temple
My favourite!. Faces everywhere you look - this temple is fascinating and has to be seen to be believed - we went mid afternoon and it was very quiet

A True Treasure. The Bayon, while relatively small, is an incredible treasure trove of Asian antiquity! Even if you are not interested in this sort of thing it is a must! It is truly an ancient wonder!
The faces are amazing. This is probably one of the best temples of the area, if you have limited time: this is a must see. The faces on top of the temple are just amazing.

More than just Tomb Raider. Though the locals keep harping about this temple being the one used in Tomb Raider, it is the huge, ancient trees that are the real attraction in this place.It is impressive to remember that this temple was part of a citadel that was abandoned. The jungle overtook this temple and the French "resurrected" it by hacking through tropical jungle. If only these walls could talk.
Elephant riding at Bayon Temple. Had a fantastic time with the kids elephant riding, a great way to enjoy the temples with tired feet :)
Local guides are great. We hired a guide and tuk-tuks through hotel concierge. These Wats are a very different style and scale - interesting contracts.
See it!. Whilst Bayon Temple is not as well-known or as massive as Angkor Wat, it is just as amazing. The three-faced temples are icons.

The smiling serene Buddha's ooze serenity. This calming and serene temple which is still being restored has many smiling Buddha faces on the corner of walls and roof.
It is extremely peaceful early morning for a wander around and meditate.

Who is watching who?. This temple is covered by the Angkor Pass. Your pass will be checked before you can enter. We visited Bayon the first thing in the morning. It was a pleasant tuk tuk ride (Angkor Tuk Tuk) at that hour of the day. We passed several other temples along the way but did not stop. Bayon greets you on its western face. As you drive on past to the main northern entrance, you begin to feel insignificant looking at all the serene faces. They seem to have found peace. There is so much to see here that you need to be prepared to spend a good portion of a morning or afternoon here. Although there were a few busloads of tourists we found that we could wander around by ourselves without too much interference from the crowds. There were a few photo opportunity sites where it got very crowded, particularly with photographers taking endless photographs of large group tours. They seem to think the place belongs to them and do not like you trying to take a photograph. They will try to block you.There are some 216 faces - some of them better preserved than others. The corridors can be narrow and dark, so walk carefully and be mindful that in some cases you have to take large steps to go from "room" to room to cross over the doorways. If you are tall you will have to mind your head at all times. At the lower level there are some mossy corridors that can make for a good photograph at the right angle. Some of the faces have a third eye carved into them as an anti-Bhuddist campaign after the death of the King Jayavarman VII. Dont forget that there are lots of stairs getting up to each level.There are lots of interesting carvings all around the outer walls. We found one where there was a Sadhu (Hindu holy man) trying to climb a tree to escape a tiger - this is on the south side.One of the heads on the main upper terrace offers a trick photo opportunity. You can stand at a particular spot and looking towards a head a photograph can be taken that looks like you are rubbing noses with the head. There are also good opportunities through the windows. Professional photographers station themselves at these opportunities and you will have difficulty trying to get your own photograph at these places.If you walk around the outer wall you will find it peaceful. There is a moat running all around it and you can, if you do not want to or cannot walk through and up the monument itself, take an elephant ride around the moat. This will give you another perspective of the monument and you will also get reflections in the moat water. There is also a very large gilded Buddha in a shrine to the west. This is also a good place to prop yourself if you are walking around the monument, as it is generally quiet and shady and the vendors do not venture here and will not bother you.If you want more than just a casual look around the monument, then you will need a guide to explain the scenes. The east gallery depicts the Khmer army marching to war.There is a central tower where there is a statue of a Buddha. It said that the original was destroyed and then discovered in a well. When they put it back together, it would not fit through the door, so it must have been in place before the walls around it were built. The Buddha statue that you now see is much smaller. We would have liked to spent more time looking at the carvings around the galleries but it was getting very hot. There are photographers stationed at the south entrance and a few vendors too.Walk around the moat and see some beautiful reflections. There are a few ducks on the moat and they too become part of the photo opportunity.The vendors are kept away from inside the site and this is a good thing. You can buy whole coconuts and this is a must experience. When you have finished drinking the water they will cut the coconut open for you and you can also eat the soft flesh inside.This is definately a temple where you should spend a fair amount of time.
highly recommended. The smiling faces temple! It was beautiful. I liked this better than Angkor, because it was smaller and more intimate. Lots of people once again, but so beautiful.
Bayon's smiling faces. With its smiling faces one of the most impressive temples at Angkor Wat area we have visited. An absolute must see when visiting Cambodia.
Marvellous Temple. Unlike the Angkor Wat, the carvings at Bayon Temple describe how the Khmer lived their lives more than 900 years ago. It was Awesome to walk back in the past.

a great temple to visit. If time allows buy a monthly pass to enable you to visit all the temples. This temple is worthwhile to see it is a different style to other temples with a lot of photographic opportunities.

Stoneface. Amazing Tample!! Don't miss this one. Go first thing in the morning so it's not so hot! If you don't have time to go in, Just ask the driver of the tuck tuck to take you past the South gate so you can take a pic. you don't have to go in.

The Serenity is disappearing :(. The structure is degrading fast and it was tragic to see such a beautiful facade going to waste. The faces no longer have the serenity that they are world famous for. Cracks are appearing fast and thick. But, they structure complex still holds the mystical calm deep within and one cannot help but stare back at those faces trying to discern their mystery.

Four headed buddhas. Worth the trip to see another type of Khmer temple--this one buddhist. Angkor Wat is Hindu. Built by Jayavarman VII, who converted to buddhism. 34 towers of the original 49 remain, each with four buddha faces. Quite striking.
A must, as many other "wats" and places.. Slow discovery, imposing itlsef slowly .. walking, exploring, climbing up the terraces one after the other .. magnificent!
Small, but amazing. This temple is rather small compared to others, but the architecture is amazing and the huge stone faces are breathtaking!

Favorite Temple. Bayon was my favorite temple that we explored and you could easily spend hours trekking through it. It can get very busy so go early and be sure to look for monkeys along the road leading up to it from Angkor!! We stopped to feed them and it was a highlight for us.
Fascinating Temple. I really liked this Temple. There are 99 temples we are told. This was one of my favourites. Worth visiting.
Fantastic temple. This for me was the best part of the Angkor temple tour,,,,, the trees with their big buttress roots make spectacular photos,,,,,a must see if you are in Siem reap.

Indeed beautiful architecture. After Angkor Wat, make way to this temple with beautiful carving and architecture. They are not equipped with high technology machineries or equipment and yet they could built such beautiful temple. There are now in the midst of conserving the temple therefore there is construction going on but this place is worth visit and recommended.

Almost Miss This Out!. I almost miss out this temple because too tiring after long hot walked from Angkor Watt & few other temples. As i thought it was just another same temple i decided not to follow my other 2 travel buddies. Also due to weather condition, which very gloomy & not long after they go it start raining. So i thought lucky i never follow them. Guest what? I was wrong!! The picture the snap look so nice so i forced them to company me gain the next day just to snap the photo... So really, don't miss this temple out no matter how much tiring you are!

Mystical adventure!. We visited this place at 6am to beat the crowds and well worth it. Don't be late as the buses start rolling up around 7am! This place was spectacular and mystical all at the same time. It felt like we'd stepped into a movie set! It was amazing to see such a spiritual place with such history being taken over by nature...beautiful!

the smile of King Jayavarman. we arrived Siem Reap International Airport late in the evening , the following day got our pass and proceeded to Angkor Wat , we spent a half day tour and proceeded to Bayon Temple , really impressed by its mystic beauty maybe because of its four phase face of King Jayavarman as accdng to our guide. ,so impressive this must be for everyone who wants to experience the most unforgettable trips of a lifetime.

Awe inspiring. Incredible. We felt a guide to this complex was very helpful. The bas-reliefs were amazing and we would have missed them completely if it hadn't have been for the information he gave. Don't miss this one.
worth visiting!. this temple is very special, you have to visit it if you go to Angkor Wat, it is one of the most important!
Bayon. Probably my favorite site. Beautiful carved walls on the exterior and amazing carved faces on every spire inside. It is not quite as large as Angkor Wat, but very nice. A don't miss site.
My favorite temple.. There's nothing I disliked about this temple...it's totally amazing n beautiful. So much culture n history in one place.
How wonderful this temple is!. It's the wonderful, beautiful & interesting temple! You can spend a whole day to explore this temple without getting bored.

beautiful. try to go early because after lunch it is usually rainy bring a lot of water inside because after you climb you will need it
it is an amazing temple
Must see. I'm sure many travellers just visit 1 temple but visiting Bayon and Ta Prohm is also a must! You can do this all in one day!
Beautiful Site. Be sure to take a good look from a distance as well as close up (inside). The elephant trek starts off from just south of the site.

Beautiful. I love this temple, it is truly beautiful. I have been to Angkor three times now and it is getting busier each time as Siem Reap becomes more developed, so I would recommend going to view the temples as early as possibly, starting at 5.30am with sunrise. That way you get to see the temples in relative peace and are able to head out as the tour buses roll in. This is one of my favourite temples.
Amazing early morning!. You must be there at 5:30 to enjoy to walk through in absolute silence... But it is worth to get up early!!! Stop fo a while on the bridge before entering the main gate.

we left our heart in bayon temple. go visit angkor wat they said. it is the greatest temple they said. yes, indeed angkor wat is recognized for its greatness and its big sized temple. but looking through specifically on the detail, it is still below the mighty Bayon Temple. you might be visiting cambodia at that time but will also feel like exploring the ruin of Inca in Macchu Picchu. Go with proper pair of shoes and bag and dont forget to bring enough drinks. I would suggest you to climb the highest possible vantage point on this area to obtain finest experience and get your best picture shot!
very intriguing. excellent photo ops..a very strange and mystical place..worth spending 2 hours not to be missed in Siem Reap..along with Tha Prom and Angkor wat definitely the top 3
Amazing. I like this temples the most out of all the temples. The big faces are so beautifully carved. I wonder how did they stack all of the stones so perfectly to make the face.
Choose the right time to visit!. Amazing temple. If you get there at the right time you will almost be alone. Go late afternoon. Probably the most temple I ever saw.

Stunning bas-relief.. Like Ankgor Wat, we thought one of the most incredible features were the bas-relief around the whole exterior of the structure. Worth taking the time to read about them and then follow the story along the wall. Lots of great photo ops with the eerie faces too. Not to be missed.
Elephant rides. This is spread over a fair area so you'll need good shoes, a hat and water but it's worth it. There is also quite a few shady trees and good toilets.
The highlight of Angkor Thom. The Bayon Temple is the highlight of the huge Angkor Thom area. The statues near the top, featuring massive serene-looking faces, look great in the late afternoon light.

Must see in Angkor. We visited it during the rainy season, or how they call it, the green season. We got a rain during the visit to this temple, and it was great! Cool, quiet and lots of contrasts. Take some rain gear and a waterproof camera and enjoy this site in peace!
excellent beautiful place. place is very nice worth visiting, is hot, humid, but worth it, interesting to see the magnificence of those kings that built it
Giant Stone Faces. Angkor Wat and Bayon are the two must see amazing temples. The giant stones faces have four sides. There are extensive carvings of battle scenes.

Don't miss this. Get a 1, 3 or 5 day pass for the temples, depending on how long you are in Siem Reap, but don't just do Angkor Wat, as to me sme of the slightly lesser known temples are more atmospheric.

The temple with the heads. Seeing is believing and what a sight. All that I ever imagined this temple would be and more. Lots of picture now means I do not have to buy those posters depicting the heads.
Love it. Elephant ride lots of fun and then walking around Bayon that has been repaired so looks great. An amazing temple
variety of faces. Magical!! Variety of faces carvings of the stones. And the smiles look real too. Love the site!! A must visit place!

Fantastic. We had a great time here, very interesting temple... however we were here in the middle of the Chinese national holiday so the temples were all VERY VERY busy... make a note of this if travelling to Siem Reap in the first week of October or I believe the first week of April.
Bayon is as wonderful as Angkor. It's also well known and is situated close to Angkor. The temple is in the the Angkor Archaeological Park and well worth a visit carefully.

Amazing. The entrance to this temple is amazing, the fact that all of these temples were discovered under overgrown forest is even more amazing. The structure is fantastic, definitely go here but take your time, it is hard work

Favourite temple. Payed two visits here on this trip and second was most enjoyable as we went immediately after watching the sunrise at Ankor so were ahead of the tour groups with only a few visitors so could take picture without people walking in front of your camera so they could take their own pictures!
Wat's not to like!?. From a distance could be regarded as a pile of rubble but the closer you get the more you see. The faces in the towers seem unique to this temple and are very beautiful. Loved it

Smiling faces. The temple is smaller than Angkor Wat, but still of a good size. All the towers have smiling faces on them.
To make most of your visit, you need to be able to climb steps and make your way around a bit of rubble

A must see, but you need to be in good shape. The Bayon and associated sites are one of those "top 10 must-see before you die" places. However, the climate is very hot and humid, and and good deal fo walking and climbing is needed to really appreciate the sites... so do this while you are younger and reasonably fit. Also, adapt to the climate - do your sight-seeing very early in the morning, then head back to your hotel and take it easy for the rest of the day. Use the evenings to explore around town.

My favourite temple. If you are limited on time.. Make bay on temple one of your priorities..a beautiful temple..won't ruin it for you..photos will never do places like this justice..visit and soak it up..

FaceTime. Visitors flock to Bayon to see the 250+ faces of the Buddha(?) that are carved into this temple. No disappointments here, as the temple is impressive in its carvings. It is also of good size, so despite the crowds of visitors, it doesn't feel crowded. Lots of areas to explore. Not the type of temple where a guide is that helpful, but we did have one, and he was able to point out a few things, including giving suggestions on unique photo vantage points. Certainly one of the top 5 temples to visit during a tour of Angkor.
Breathtaking photos!. Unlike anything else, soooo Amazing to experience, especially when the sun is in the right place! Breathtaking photos!

The Faces of Siem Reap. My children loved this temple. The were intrigued by the many faces depicted in the sandstone. There was one photography opportunity where you could turn sideways and get a profile picture of your face that appeared to have your nose touching the nose of one of the carvings - great photo!
difficult to say why...but it was the best temple. Astonishing! And definitely less crowded than Angkor Wat. Get lost in this temple that seems one thing within the nature around

one of the better temples to visit. Elephant rides cost 15dollar per person. the elephant jsut went around the temple. great for pictures ! you can buy a pineapple for a dollar to feed the elephantsprepare for a sunny hike. bring hats, shades and water. lots of photo opportunities inside the temple so bring your best camera1 day visit to all the temples cost 20$. always bring your temples pass with you to prevent inconvenience

My favourite temple. This temple with the four faces of buddha carved on its remaining 37 towers is amazing. A lot of restoration work has been done already, with a lot more to go, however it is good to see how the stones have weathered over the years, depending on where they are facing.The intricate carvings on the stone are beautiful and the stories that they tell can be clearly seen.Didn't begrudge paying the $20 entrance fee to see this and all the other temples at all.

Must visit. This place will make you wonder who they built this perfect civilazation, so clever and spiritual. You must visit at least once in your life. Arrive early, spend the entire day there, walk a lot and keep a bottle of water, and keep on exploring.
My Favourite. Find a good guide who will point out to you why some statues with eyes closed, or open or half closed/open. Great place to take lots of great shots!
amazing. wonderful wonderful wonderful. Go to the top or you'll miss it. Get the blessed bracelet at the top.

Brave the masses and enjoy the beauty of Bayon. When I visited during the day it felt like this temple was being sacked by an invading Korean hordes. But it was still possible to take pictures without people in and to find a quiet spot to enjoy the beautifully engraved towers that feature large faces that watch your every move.
Takes Your Breath Away. To think that these temples are up to 1200 years old and everything is done by hand. The carvings are so intricate and detailed. It's just amazing.
Beautiful ruins. Part of the Angkor complex, well maintained, beautiful carvings, easy access, vendors in their own area
My favourite temple. this temple was less crowded thn angkor wat but in my opinion equally as beautiful, well worth a visit
The Faces temple. Whilst not as well preserved as Ankor Wat it is very different with all the faces and their profiles make for an interesting few hours

Iconic. This monument is fascinating. One of the temples to be built last, come visit this place specially when it is sunny so you can take good pictures. Glad that it is being restored and maintained.

Not too bad. After Angkor Wat, all else pale in comparison. Bayon was good for pictures as there were many carving and stone work with faces of Buddha through out the temple. Was very crowded when i was there so didn't explore it thoroughly.

Second important temple to visit in Siem Reap. At Angkor Thom, the Bayon Temple with its countless sculptural decorations. The Bayon's most distinctive feature is the multitude of serene and massive stone faces on the many towers which jut out from the upper terrace and cluster around its central peak.

Serene faces of Bayon. One of my absolute favourites of Siem Reap's many temples. I found the smaller temples even more stunning than Angkor Wat. This temple features many beautiful stone serene faces that can be seen on every one of the towers of the temple. We spent over an hour wandering around here. We visited around lunchtime and found the temple less crowded, as most of the tour-groups break for lunch around this time. As we were leaving, the crowds started pouring in. Also stunning at sunset, we went past this temple another evening and it was beautiful at this time of day.
Another fascinating temple. Do yourself a favour and visit this temple, get a three day pass so you can visit various temples in the area. Ore inspiring.
Equally impressive. Part of the tour, even if you only have one or two days, and worth it. The site, building and carvings are all extraordinary

Be informed before you go, but go!. Very impressive. You will never have enough valuable information unless you prepare your homework by yourself before you travel, and you keep guiding your guide. This is one of those places of "must go" where you have to be well prepared in advance.
Misterious smiling faces. Different temple in Angkor. More than 200 smiling faces are watching you while you are visiting the temple. Unbelievable

Smaller than Angkor Wat but "cuter". It's a smaller temple naturally but it's still very pretty. The designs of the four-faced cones and the carvings are amazing and very detailed. If you get dropped off here, you get to walk up all the way to the temple of the Leper King. The whole are is beautiful and worth the long walk.
Amazing!. Be prepared to do some climbing in the ruins around Bayon (Angkor Thom) and bring plenty of water (4 litres for a day is about right)
Beautiful. Faces everywhere this is what you go to see it is awe inspiring and makes you think about effort that went into creating it Great for photos go in the arvo

Smiling temple. It's very sweet smile temple. It's very great temple in Cambodia with fours smiling faces that hard to find in the world. I love this smiling face too much. I love Cambodia, Kingdom of wonderful !!

If only those faces could talk!. Bayon is actually part of the vast Angkor Thom complex, which is even bigger than Angkor Wat. What sets it apart are the faces - hundreds of them, I think. Every guidebook I picked up described them as enigmatic, & that's spot on. Each looks like it has a story to tell, a story that most likely has a surprise ending.Like all the other sites around Siem Reap, you're besieged at entry & exit by kids who want to sell you postcards, guidebooks, bracelets, etc. You can probably get the cheapest deals from them, but they should be in school, so save it for a shop in town.
All those buddhas..... Just a wow for this temple with all those carved Buddha faces. It's fantastic. You'll have to climb to discover even more of then. A must-see when in the area.
Best at the site. Maybe the coolest place in the Ankor Wat Area. There are so my things to see here and the longer you stay the more you will discover.
Our favorite temple!. So much to see - incredible. Our guide showed us the place to take the picture where it looks like you're kissing the buddha!
more impressive than Angkor Wat. this was the facility within the park that I thought was even more impressive than Angkor wat itself!
Great place to see the magnificent creation of mankin. We like the carving & how pieces of stones were put together to form such a magnificent structures. Worth to visit.
My favourite. I loved being at the Bayon with the hundreds of benevolent faces around me - a very peaceful experience.
Sheer Beauty. This is a stunning edifice which rises up majestically, with its many towers adorned with huge faces of a Buddhist god, but resembling the king who created it.
Simply Beautiful. A must see on your visit to the temples of Angkor. One of the major ones on the tours organized by the hotels and guesthouses.

They are smiling there every day!. Haha, people being there are looking for the smiley faces.
It is interesting. It is amazing.
Kids there are lovely and willing to be models for you (yes, bring some candies, pens or stationery to tempt them, if you feel money is not appropriate for little kids).
Loved it. Like all the temples, this is also being loved to death. Restrictions will have to be placed on entry etc sooner rather than later
Loved the faces. I thought this was the most interesting of the temples with the faces engraved in the stone. You can take a lot of interesting pictures here.

Amazing, but..... This temple is amazing, however there is a huge amount of reconstruction taking place which is wonderful as Bayon would be the most run down of the ruins we visited. By this. I do not mean visually, it is impressive, but mobility and safety would have to be questionable at this stage of its reconstruction with many stairways and arches etc being in a precarious state. Would be very difficult for those who are not very sure footed. Will be absolutely amazing when the work is further along, don't be put off, it is worth the short trip from Angkor Wat to see, even if you don't go too far inside.
my favorite!. from far away the temple looks boring - but once you're up close you'll see the faces and fall in love with them!
a beautiful temple. it is a smaller temple, a lot more personal, but equally beautiful, lots of "towers" and intricate, a dedication to the people of Cambodia, don't miss seeing this temple.
Beautiful temple. This temple was beautiful. Still being repaired but the location and the ruins were spectacular. Very easy to imagin yourself lost in the jungle here!

Lots of temples to explore. There are lots of temples in the Bayon area. The main temple has a lot of carvings which depict interesting stories and times in history. It was useful to have a guide to explain this. This was the busiest temple we went to.
Amazing. The temples were amazing to see. The stories written on the walls were great and done with so much detail. It is a must to see but be prepared to walk and climb stairs.

Faces of heaven. Possibly the most specatular of the temples. Certainly makes an impression that lasts. Highly recommend that you get to the NORTH gate which is less crowded than the south and offers beautiful photo ops.
Bayon. Not as spectacular as Angkor Wat but well worth a visit. We went towards the end of the day and it was a bit crowded
Amazing. It's a great place to walk around discovering all the Buddha faces. It's like taking Art History all over again.

Go on the off times to enjoy this popular site.. Dara from the Ponheary Ly foundation served as our guide. He was wonderful and we learned a great deal about the ancient and more recent history of Cambodia under his guidance. He is great with kids and has a quiet kind way of relating to others. He took us to half the sites in Ankor and surrounding areas opposite the typical "tourist" schedule so we avoided crowds and lines.

Many faces has been carved on the towers. You feel like you are watched by big brother. Many visitors during day time. Especillay Chinese people there and they can block your views in front of your camera. Early hours like 7 am is Recommended to visit
Major Temple Ankor Thom. Well worth the small climb a must when visiting Siem Reap need several hours to visit this and all surrounding sites but well worth the time.

truly intriguing. nothing to dislike except the effort you sometimes have to put in to climb for a better view. I was mildly familiar with the history and didn't hire a knowledgable guide.... but next time ..... definitely a go back to before you die place......... I think I would try and get an educated guide to explain the history in more detail...... goes for the whole complex ........ looking on your own and at your own pace is great ... but knowing is probably even better if you can get the right guide. Don't be bullied into taking just anyone as a guide and don't be rushed.....
Go for the bas-reliefs, stay for the Jayavarman heads. Don't miss the bas-relief on the south wall and then go up to the "roof" where you can see the 4-sided heads on a jungle background. Magic
a beautiful temple. a very memorable temple with beautiful carvings and temples . lots of history to read about it - cant wait to visit it again
Smiling faces of Buddha. The perfection of the faces and the expressions of peace and smile in stone after hundreds of years of ruins is to be seen to be believed.Do not miss it!
Unique Temple. Elephant ride was great, cost $15.00 for a 10-15min ride. Took us around the Bayon Temple, good way to see the different angles of the Temple.

the smiling buddha face. this temple is famous for the smiling faces of the Buddha, carved very beautifully in many numbers. one face has retained full shape and looks beautiful. others are ravaged ,in different degrees.these ruins gives an insight to the prosperous regimes that ruled the area in the past. then the sad period of neglect and destruction followed,which made these amazing edifices almost lost to the world
don't miss it... So much History, culture, I imagine how that civilization could shine during its time, very mystical..

Royal Ride Around Bayon. Loved the elephant ride, which gave us an awesome view of the temple. Bayon is simply awesome. Be on the lookout for many spots that would make great pictures and a very helpful temple guard who would give you tips on some interesting photography tricks you can do.

Lovely.. While there isn't THAT much to do in this rather small temple, you can enjoy exploring its numerous faces and walk/stumble inside its ruins for apx. an hour, easily.Each face is rather unique and the condition of some of the faces will leave you in awe.The site, however, is unfortunately rather neglected.
Bayon Temple. Brillant Temple probably would be our favorite Temple.A must is to hire a guide as this makes you appreciate the history much more.
It was awesome. For someone who enjoy the beach, when i visited the Bayon the place was rich with pictures telling the history.

Amazing.. Visited in September, early mornings would be better than midday as the humidity is overpowering and when you add the odd tropical downpour it becomes very clammy. The complex is a photographers dream and two photos from the same point, an hour apart, look totally different due to the changing light and shadows.

The smiley faces. You will notice your tour guides telling you stories from the ancient years. And here at Bayon, you will see different architectural, with all 49 Gods with their smilling faces. I would say, the craftings were just too awesome. I wonder how those people in the olden days has such a great mind for arts...

brilliant - take millions of photos - you feel like you're on a film set anyway. again, travel in morning - less heat and take tuk tuk rather than taxi - 3 day pass can be used over 7 days so it is best value

Unique. The statues at the entrances and carvings all over the temple are amazing. We've never seen such unique shapes of faces before. All the renovated sections are clearly recognizable. This is done on purpose, so visitors could distinguish between new and old. It took a while to get used to it (imagine old body of statue with completely new head). The most photogenic places are crowded with Chinese, Japanese, and Korean tour groups. There are even locals with costumes on posing for money. This temple is completely different from Angkor Wat, so don’t skip it.

Unbelieveable many faces of each tower. tourists can enjoy Elephants trekking through the Angkor Thom gate, and then reach Banyon Temple. Along khmer Story is depicted on the wall is represented the ancient khmer.
wow!. Another great temple around Siem Reap area, can be very crowded though!!Check with your tuk tuk driver and go when its quiet, not filled with 500 other happy snappers..
loved this one. this is the most beautiful temple - september is a great time to visit - less crowds so had the place almost to ourselves
Loved it. Hands down, this has to be my favorite temple in the area. It also seems to be a popular one with the locals. Just incredible
Impressive but so crowded. A gret temple but we found it so crowded and due to the steps and narrow passageways much harder to avoid the crowds.

So beautiful, I loved it.. Bayon Temple was my favourite temple from those I visited.
Our small family had a wonderful english speaking guide, Sun Same, and this certainly enhanced the experience.
You can ride an elephant around the site. Probably nicer early in the morning.

A wonderful experience. I loved the Bayon Temple - it had a great atmosphere with monks walking around and the multitude of towers in many directions. The photo opportunities abound! We also took the elephant ride around the Bayon which made for a picturesque ride. There were little things that added to the atmosphere such as our elephant handler playing a tune on a leaf as we progressed around the outskirts of the Bayon.

My experience with Seam Reap. Very good and nice. This time is most pleasing and wonderful to learn. Every individual trying to learn about history and heritage should visit the site in his/ her lifetime.

Loved it. Falling apart so we felt lucky to be able to step inside while it's still standing. Really interesting carvings and the faces are all so masterfully done... I loved it. Kids (daughter 9 and son 12) had a great time. Younger kids would not do as well with this one.
The faces of Bayon. Every face looks slightly different, but everything is so sophisticated. Absolutely worth to visit it!
Must seen place. Bayon is a must seen temple and you cannot miss that in Siem Reap. The temple located near to Bayon is also worth a visit.
Banyon Temple. At the time it was under construction so there was not much to see. If you had seen one from a distance then you can see you have been there

Really Old. If you are looking for really old carvings, temples and weathered stone, this is the place. The faces were nice and all, but the whole place feels really ancient. No internet access and zero electricity. Its high enough, I feel like if they added a dish on top they'd be able to get satellite internet and some decent channels. The lack of air conditioning and concessions once inside the ruins was also pretty lame. Halfway though I could have gone for an electric fan and a hotdog.

quite in good condition ..considering. quite well restored. it is easy 2 imagine d days gone past. when d guide told us that usually temple are build on top of treasures likes gems and gold to strengthen d foundation, really tempted to dig around....

Great Temple. It was amazing temple and worth to visit. I can feel the power of Kmare people in that period through this temple and made them created such a great temple like this. Keep wondering how they can make this temple in that time as all the rock and the art they had put into the construction was not easy.

Breathtaking!. Who would believe that those faces that we saw on Bayon temple were man. Bayon temples which have either Buddha faces or King's face on temples, are the most known and viewed temples in the world media. I have attached the pictures with this review. You can cover these temples with your visit to Angkor Wat main temples. These are close by and not massive in terms of area. These temples give you plenty of opportunity to gasp and shoot.
Amazing. Bayon temple was our one-of-three best temples in Angkor. It is amazing to see those faces especially in sunrise or sunset. Definitively place that should not be missed.

Conquer your fear!. Probably one of the highest temple in the small circle. At first, I did not want to climb as I was afraid of heights, but I did and I do not regret doing it. It was amazing and fulfilling.
Fascinating. Unbelievable giant stone faces in really good conditions. One of the most beautiful temples on the site.

Mind Blowing!. The Bayon temple is amazing, and perhaps one of my all time favorites. The faces peer out in such an eerie way, but I loved them so much I bought a little wooden replica (and I am so not a tchotchke buyer) to remind me of its magnificence.
nice place to see. its nice place if u wanna take pictures, it is hug place and u can see the faces of bayon and the architectural of Khmer era,, anyway you would love this place
Most impressive Herritage. This herritage is very impressive with Smiling Budda Faces.Budda faces ask me What to think and what to do.or You are good as you are.

Better than Angkor Wat!. I loved this temple, it felt like being in an adventure film! The passages are narrow and the stairs steep, it gives the temple a mysterious feel and the four-faced statues are fascinating. I suggest researching it before-hand or hiring a guide to fully appreciate the temple's reliefs.
A must see!. Memorable temple ruins that will leave you in awe! The countless different expression of the Buddha face around the temple will definitely amaze you.
52 beautiful faces. Beautiful Buddha carvings unfortunately destroyed/ modified by the next Hindu King Jayavarman VIII. Lots of picture opportunities here if you are a photography fan.

beaufiful maze. This place it a beaufiful maze! I was practically playing hide and seek with my travel companion! This place is known for its massive serene stone faces built around may towers. The impression I get is very gothic and mythological. It feels very surreal to be walking the grounds of Bayon.

My favorite. This temple stood out to me with all the faces. The first time I visited was during a downpour so my sight and vision was limited by my rain gear and everyone else's. I then went back to enjoy the splendor of this very temple commanding so much respect. It was striking.
Favorite Temple. This was my favorite temple and it was so close to town. We had to stop twice because we didn't have enough time to see it the first time.

Beautiful!. If you visit all the temples in Cambodia, the Bayon is the one you will never forget. You will remember all the towers with all the faces, and you will remember the beautiful monks dressed in orange that walk around the temple. The facilities near by are also great, you can have a meal, buy drinks and use clean toilets.
Amazing..... i truly love the experience we had on our temple visits, especially on Bayon Temple.... it amazed me!!!

vannas tour. bayon temple was probably my favourite temple the temple itself the age of it the way the vegetation married with the buildings and the ruins I did not see the film "the tomb raiders " but it has made me want to see the movie.

Just fantastic !!!. Antiquities at their best !!! Loved it all. The entire Angkor Archaelogical site was just amazing. To walk around and imagine what had gone on within those walls is just amazing. All of this makes European history look modern day

The Best of the Temples. Underrated - but one which to me, is the best of the lot. Unfortunately most of the tourists are disorderly, which makes for bad pictures - but this place is magnificent. The wall/fresco about the invasion and the carvings about cambodian life at the time is amazingly simple and distinctly understandable even though they're just carvings. Wonderful.

Bayon temple, Angkor Wat itself, Angkor Tom but especially Bantey Srei was my favourite. Banteay srei was a real piece of art. Very fine decoration, a bit further away so not overcrowded.
We also planned a trip on the Tonlé Sap Lake. Don't go to close from Angkor Wat, too touristic. Go at least 40 kms further. Authentic

Buddhas all around!. Great place with so many faces of Buddha in subtly different poses. The sky was not magnificent in September but Bayon was still superb. Temple is a bit congested due to several kings making new towers in Bayon, but this is a must do for any itinierary.
Must go. Absolutely must go. Must get a really good tour guide. Pay the money! otherwise you don't know what u are missing out

Worth Seeing. Banyon Temple, approx 1-1/2 km from Angkor Wat is a Hindu Temple built c1190.I wrote in my holiday diary - An intricate piece of work, everything confined with narrower entrances & rooms etc, in comparison to Angkor Wat. One can picture in minds eye, the glory of such a magnificant Temple back in that era.Don't rule this one out if you love temples.
Beautiful!. Definitely worth a visit if you love all things architecture and art - beautiful architecture, very, very detailed! wonder how they did the carving/structure..
beautiful. thoroughly enjoyed seeing all the faces of the temple and learning about the history. it wasn't too crowded when we went so very peaceful walking around and admiring everything.

Nice temple site in Angkor Thom area. When you go by Tuk Tuk to the Angkor Thom area, the Bayong Temple will probably the first complex you visit. Tickets are checked at the entrance. The temple was under construction, which means that it will even get better in the future. The works did not disturb our visit. Bayong is an impressive site, certainly a good call card of the Angkor Thom complex.
my favourite. my favoutie of the temples with loads of carvings still in good condition. easy to access and plenty of shady spots to get out of the sun
Best of the area. For me this temple is what i was hoping for in cambodia. Personally i think it is better than Angkor Wat... lovely place!
Bayon Temple. Beautiful temple, a wonderful exemple of khmer architecture and history. It is not as famous as Angkor Wat but well worth the visit
The best temple!. In terms of architecture i think this is the best temple in the area. It is smaller than Angkor Wat but it made a bigger impression on us. Definitely a must see!
great and beautiful, calm and very nice to walk around. Wear good shoes when visiting the temples. The stones can be slippery, cover yourself and watch out for mosquitoes.

Bayon Temple is unique. bayon temple is even more interesting than Angkor Wat. The specific huge stone faces are very beautiful and you may climb everywhere to take pictures with them. Go there, visit and you'll have an unforgetable experience!
No walls. The only temple I have been to with no walls. It seems so open and at the same time overwhelming. I was quite excited to see the central temple of Angkor Thom.
Probably the best in Angkor. Best temple in my eyes in Angkor where the presence of Buddha still can be felt. Statues are very beautiful.
Under repair but worth visiting. Well worth visiting even though it is under restoration. Don't be put off but go in the morning if you can.
Unbelievable. Everything you read.. and more. Try to go when few people around, you will feel it more. If you're a camera buff you will love it...

the best. even the main wat is more famous Bayon is the most attractive. Stunning! Usually is on the path of any Angkor visitor, but be sure it is on your one. It's very close to Siem so don't miss it you will be rewarded
Great architecture. Loved the architecture but too many tourist around made it difficult to really appreciate the temple.

Epic. Very unique among the temples that we visited because of the smiling stone faces. Should not be missed.This is located within Angkor Thom.We fed the elephants with bananas and got to ride on one for a picture. Would've been even better if we got to have pictures in front of the temple while we were on the elephant but we didn't have enough time anymore.

Serene & Calm at Bayon Temple. We visited in early September which is the low season for tourist as it is the start of the rainy season. We were almost by ourselves in this temple. So beautiful, serene and a sense of calmness. You don't get the crowd here as compare to Angkor Wat. This is one of my favorite place in Siem Reap.
1 of the 'must see' in angkor. Nice complex in the angkor thom area. Good to be in for 1 hour or so to make nice pics.Climb and walk through this complex. Also nice for children. Lot to discover.

Beautifully eerie.. Bayon temple is beautiful and eerie at the same time, despite the smiling faces. The carvings are less intricate as compared to the one in Angkor Wat. It is a medium sized temple, we took about an hour to explore this place. One of the must visit temple when you are in Siem Reap. Don't miss it.

Elephant ride around the temple. Definitely spend the $15 and take the elephant ride around Bayon Temple. It's worth it! You enjoy beautiful views and honestly this was some of the best pictures I took! You can fit 2-4 ppl on the elephant if atleast one is a kid.

Many Faces of Bayon. This is the temple of many faces. There are over 200 carved faces so it offers a great place to play around with pictures. If you stand just right you can get faces kissing or merging together. Up at the very top is a Buddha statue where you can offer up a donation and receive a blessing and a bracelet from the locals. While I was there we found a group of dancers dressed up in traditional garb offering to pose for a small donation. This donation goes towards their schooling to become professional dancers.
Impressive. It was very Impressive to walk around in the old temple, liked this better than Ankor Wat. It is amazing to walk around the temple and one Can easily spend sevaral hours here
A must see. If you have only a day to go, Bayon Temple is one of the two temples that you should not miss. Be awed by the magnificent structures and sculptures the Bayon offers. A must see!
Amazing. whats not to like in a temple thats more than a 1000 years old? The giant Faces are magnificent! pity its in such a state of destruction. even though tthe destruction also adds to its charm

a one not to miss. possibly the most impressive temple we saw as a lot of the stonework is still in fairly good condition and the place has a definate presence, there is a mass of things to see and do in this area and you could easily spend the whole day in this one area.We arrived at the end of our 2nd day and probably did not do it enough justice, would spend more time here if we ever go back and maybe less time at the smaller temples we went to.
So many Faces!. This temple is so great! I really enjoyed just sitting and relaxing while looking at the art. This place is really just cool! SO SO COOL!

Someones watching you..... So the king built the temple with faces to watch over his whole empire...spooky thought! Cool architecture, interesting story, lots of hidden sculpting into the rocks etc!Great spot for panoramic pictures

Gentle Faces. I love that each of the faces has its own unique characteristic and charm. It is amazing and I just cannot imagine how they were able to stack and carve the faces with the huge stones. This temple is a must see.
Not to miss!. Most photo genic temple in Angkor. After having visited all temples in two trips, this is till my favorite. Check it out in the early or late hours when it's nice and quiet!
Trapped in time. Uniquely amazing, worth doing the visit. Not far from Siem Reap, you can get a tuk tuk driver for the day for about $25USD and will take you to as many temples as you can fit in.
Smiling faces!!!. Great temple for huge smiling budda's. They are well preserved and are a must when you go to siem reap for your holidays.

Our preferred temple in Angkor. Simply, no words...
We will come there again again in the next years.
None can forget the experience in this very unique temple

Bayon cries. It was raining when I was there, but the experience was totally spectacular! I only prefer if it was more quiet without groups of big tourists and their guides talking so loudly like they are the big bosses around!!!!

Wow!. Aside from Banteay Srei, this is another site that you should not miss. I know more temples... but this one holds its own. Its beauty are in the faces sculpted on all four directions. Not huge but amazing!

Top 3 - don't miss it. I think the must-see temple list is Bayon, Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm. I loved the faces and walkways. Quite compact so you can get around easily and fast if you choose. Go early or late because it can get very hot. They are all very close to each other too.
Amazing Place. This temple is very beautiful plan to spend two hours walking on it and enjoying every single detail it has to offer.

awesome Bayon. brilliant- go. wander around, say hello to Dtoho who works checking tickets and his wife (and new mom) who sells/sold tickets for elephant rides - which looked like lots of fun! I recommend spending the morning/afternoon walking all around and to the other temples within Angkor Thom. Spectacular!

Stood out from the rest. This temple definitely stood out from the rest because of the Bayon style architecture. The four face tower is one of a kind and i have not seen temples with such tower anywhere else. Lots of picture opportunities here if you are a photography fan. Spend more time here if you are not in a rush.
Simply amazing. Breathtaking design and construction. We were blown away - try and avoid the tours and spend some time contemplating this incredible structure.

In the spirit of Jayavarman. Buddha Buddha everywhere~! Fantastic mandala of a temple~! Take some headphones and find a quiet spot, the lower levels provide some peace away from the hustle, bustle shouting tour guides. It was built for meditation, so try some~! Wonderful place, you can cruise by on an elephant for around $20 - Do change dollars into local $ to give away to the local kids and really get into Jayavarman's groove~!
Amazing!. amazing sight, we did this as part of a one day tour and it was plenty of time for us, amazing that these have been there so long yet cravings are so clear!

Beautiful Temple. We started at Angkor Wat early before moving to a much quieter Bayon. The place not being overcrowded really made the difference for us. Spend some time looking at all the intricate carvings before heading inside and make sure your camera is fully charged and you have a back up battery - beautiful photography made easy!!
Awesome temple. At least once in your life you should come and visit it. Really good place for photography. If possible try to avoid weekend tour as they will be too crowed.
The faces of Bayon. Serene mysterious stone looks out in all directions.the site could use some conservation but is very special even in the present state of relative disrepair
This place will blow you away. A "must visit" in Siem Reap especially if you like photography. This place will blow you away. Just go - I won't spoil it for you!

good spot. Lots of old faces everywhere, there's a particular spot you can sit on to get a picture...if camera is placed at a good angle, you could get a good of you face almost kissing another face statue that's pretty far away from you. Great history in Cambodia. Good times.

Amazing - My favourite. Loved Bayon for all the faces, different levls and the way that in late afternoon we virtually had the whole place to ourselves as the crowds moved to Angkor Wat. Spend plenty of time here and make sure the camera is fully charged.
excellent. A really excellent visit, a part of the larger ankor thom complex well worht a look. The kids enjoyed exploring around this whole place.

Avalokiteshvara's faces everywhere!. The last temple we visited on our day 1 petite circuit temples, and oh what a great climb to complete the day. Everywhere you look, you'll be drawn by the monalisa smile of these giant stone faces. Very interesting architecture!
Angkor Wat is Good Bayon is Better!. I think Bayon is the jewel of all the temples we visited. Make sure you hire a guide, it is well worth the money.
Do not miss..,. Top sight, not as famous as Agkor Wat, but huge and wonderful, we took an elephant ride around Bayon...

Simply Amazing....charge up your camera!. Breathtakingly beautiful an absolute must, preferred this to Angkor Wat...take an elephant ride around the temple and try and go first thing in the morning as less busy.
The Best of the Ankor temples. Don't miss this one it is amazing? I visited this one three times during my stay. Go early morning to avoid the crowds.

Being Re-Built. the site was under restoration and not many places inside the temple ruins were accessible. The surrounding fields were lush green and the area surrounding the ruins were very peaceful, quiet and picturesque.
Amazing!. An absolutely fascinating temple. The 4 faces on each of the 54 columns & the frescoes were amazing. My favourite temple!
Excellent site. It is amazing site with multi complex built within the area and wit magnificent arts of Buddha, Elephant and others

Bayon Temple. Make sure to take an elephant ride around the temple, $15USD and it's really fun. There is a platform which makes it easy and safe to get on and off. You can buy bunches of bananas to feed your ellie for $1 each.

Smile and Faces of Buddha. What I like the most about this temple is that, its less crowded compared to the others and the story of the temple is interesting too! One of my favorite temple definitely!

Incredible!. This was my favourite of all the temples in the Angkor complex. The size of the faces is incredible!
For a surreal experience arrive at or just after sunrise when it is deserted!
Larger than life. The hcamera is an essential piece of equipmentead carvings in this temple are huge and most interesting. A

Look for the Khmer guy with the military uniform with the American-sounding accent.... My third visit to the Angkor Wat complex in 2 years turned out to be the one where I learned the most! While wandering around, trying to work out how to get a photo of my face lined up with one of the faces of Avalokiteshvara, I noticed this guy talking with a couple of Scottish tourists. I thought, "He seems like a character", and went over to him and enquired about the photo. He laughed, held his hand out for my camera, and indicated for me to follow him. He proceeded to bring me around the Bayon, showing me some really amazing secrets hidden inside (I won't give them away here!), as well as giving insights into the carvings and the cosmology of Hinduism and Buddhism, which I am quite familiar with already, but it was nice to hear it anyway. He also told bits and pieces of his own story, and I could tell he was leaving a lot out... he was born in the 1960s, so I don't need to point out what he lived though...I can't remember the guy's name, but if you want some really interesting info about the construction, as well as some philosophical insights, as well as great entertainment and real friendliness, and you don't mind throwing a few extra dollars his way, definitely let this guy show you around. You won't regret it!
find the faces. Its a must see - those faces are too amazing for words! My favourite an its unique in the world ...Anywhere you look, they are watching you and each face sears a different expression

My Favorite Temple, By Far!. Bayon was my favorite temple. It wasn't too crowded. Loved the stories of Thai and Indian mercenaries joining up with the Khmers for war against the (eventual) Vietnamese. The faces are amazing and the fact that they still remain after all this time is inspiring. Go with a guide to make sure you get the intriguing history behind this awesome temple!
Great work of art!. Of all the temples in Angkor, Bayon is the one I liked the most. Such a masterpiece. I love how the faces are beautifully sculpted and done ages ago. Absolutely amazing!

One of the better temples inside Angkor Thom. Best known for its 49 carved stone towers with big faces looking out to the four cardinal points and with an enigmatic smile. It is quite nice and a must see when visiting Angkor Thom
Amazing. Bayon Temple - one of my favourite of all. We were here 11 years ago and hasn't changed that much except for more tourists. A must if you are going to visit the temples.

Fascinating View. A "must" visit temple when you are in Siem Reap. Totally enchanting and mesmerizing! No words can best describe this wonderful place. Fascinating!However, as this is one of the most famous temple in Siem Reap, be ready to fight off the huge crowds. You will need to know the best time to visit in order to avoid the big crowds. We have a great tour guide to help us through. Just in case anyone here might need his assistance, you may search for him here under the name, Mr. Teng Sreang (an English speaking guide).
Impressive. I chose to take my fotos in black and white mainly. The heads and other details are spectacular. I am glad to see renovation and restoration taking place.

Eyes!. Amazing temples. You feel like you are being watched. I can imagine what it might have been like thousands of years ago before the temples were worn down and destroyed. Faces looking in every direction. Pure ingenuity.

Truly awesome. First impressions: As you approach the temple, you are greeted by a multitude of bas-reliefs of Buddha's face -- all in smiles and from all angles. Wow! IMO, Bayon Temple has more charm and character than Angkor Wat. (Sorry, I wasn't bashing it.) Grade A.Pros: Close enough to AW and, because it is bigger, feels less crowded. There's this certain corner of the temple where you can see the Kissing Buddha. (No, not literally...) But if you sit at a certain spot to have your profile meet the Buddha's profile, the resulting optical illusion makes it look like the two of you are kissing in a photograph.Cons: A lot of "helpful" locals on-site who will "volunteer" to take your picture with the Kissing Buddha but then are expecting to be paid for this favor. And, of course, the crowded lineup to take pictures with the iconic profile.Verdict: A must see... Highly recommended. Be sure to purchase the multi-day entry pass. The Angkor Temple Complex is just too big to do in one day.
Faces were interesting. 54 towers of faces, apparently to watch over the 54 provinces at the time of building, very impressive!
amazing faces. loved seeing all the Buddha faces. amazing how large and lifelike they appear. it's like we were in a time capsule visiting long ago.

amazing. awe inspiring, spiritual place..wow wow wow. Try to avoid weekends as it gets very busy, its when the large tour buses arrive. We managed to go week days and wow, the site is amazingly well preserved and immense.
great temple. Fantastic - a must see, one of the most atmospheric temples...get there after the manic groups have been around first thing.
Bayon Temple. having a local guide is a must ,knew which way to go to get the best photo opportunity,and to avoid the crowds

bayon tempal. tempal is very much broken but what ever is their is excelent to see slepping budha statu is marvalas i had seen many historical tempalin india but this statueis something spacil the boundry wall is also eye catcher

Bayon heads will have your head turning.. Another site that definitely needs visiting. You will be stunned by the huge Bayon temple heads. What a view! If you stand a specific angle you will be able to take a pic of the three heads. Morever, there are traditional dancers that can take a photo with you in front of the Bayon heads for a $1.00. Definitely, worth a visit!

One of my favs in Angkor. You simply cannot miss the Bayon Temple, there are a few steep climbs which aren't so pleasant in the heat and if you get caught up there with a tourist group you may want to throw a few of them off the top, but it's an absolutely stunning temple and you'll love having all the smiling faces looking down at you and the detailed carvings.

Hauntingly Beautiful. Being surrounded by these enormous Buddha faces really was a phenomenal experience. I especially enjoyed that they were all smiling these serene peaceful smiles as if the devastation that had been wrought upon them by generations of warfare was ok because they were still there. If you only have the time for a few temples while in Siem Reap, don't miss this one.

No words for how spectacular. There are simply no words for how amazing this site is. Warning, very steep climbs and very hot. Also, short sleeves required for some temples, I wore a tank top and brought a shrug and was fine but my friend had a scarf tide around like a shawl and wasn't allowed

Dress appropriately. Be warned - for Bayon temple you need proper attire. a sleeveless t-shirt will not do, your shoulders need to be covered. Much to my surprise there was only a guard enforcing this, but no hawker selling t-shirts for the ones needing one.

Has to be seen to be believed!. The Bayon is an amazing temple complex with hundreds of four faced heads and extensive carved walls showing numerous battles that took place in Cambodia's ancient history. This was my favourite of all the Angkor monuments, because everywhere you turned there was something else to amaze and surprise you. Highly recommended!

History at its best. The site is best lended to enjoying with a guide. Make sure they wear an official guide badge pass. The story continues and it's really interesting how the sites evolves and are interlinked.

One of our favourites. The serenity. We visited Bayon Temple on our second day of touring temples and it was one of the highlights. There is something about this place that inspired peace and we left feeling grateful that we had the opportunity to see it.

Such a wonder!. Arriving there with the bike tour (KKO) with no tourists, and little by little discovering all the crowds visiting the área is a special feeling. We watched a 1 hour documentar y before the visit. Worth to google and do before. The experience is a dream.

Great faces. Very enjoyable. Loved the character in the old "faces". It really causes serious thought about the amount of work it must have involved to haul the materials, build it & finish the designs.

a major attraction. its very hot during april! lots of tourists..the temples are spectacular..if you have trouble climbing up the stairs then its too bad..definitely recommended to every one who has limited time like we did..
Pinnacles and smiling Buddhas. The most complete, beautiful and labyrinthine of the temples of Siem Reap. Enjoyed joining in with the local dancers at the top too!

Exciting Temple to Explore. Beautiful temple. Wish I have more time to explore the temple. Bring your own bottle as the weather could get very hot easily and at some parts of the temple was hard to find people selling water bottles.
Worth a visit. Mostly intact, worth getting a guide to tell you about the place. Various kings have left their mark on these temples whenever they change religion.

Work of art. It was the first temple we visited.
Each faces had slightly different smiles, and had sense of vulnerability. This place really makes you wonder what went on back in the day of khmer Empire...

Breathtaking!. We visited many temples during our trip to Cambodia. Bayon Temple was definitely our favourite. It was beautiful and our tour guide was able to show us many of the popular places to take photos. Very interesting and lots to see. While there, we also took an elephant ride around the temple. This was also lots of fun.

Just beautiful. We loved all the temples we visited & this was no exception.
They are so worth a visit You couldn't possibly visit Siem Reap & not see these amazing temples.
Great Temple. Go see it ...Just fabulous take an elephant ride Go by tuk tuk not taxi and wear good walking shoes- take water and a snack!

Get a guide. We got an official guide which really helped, the queue to the top was too long though and we didnt make the climb. Take your own water as there are not a lot of places to get cold drinks and it is exhausting but fascinating.
Interesting. History at the different temples at relatively different. Use a guide or read up about it. Use a guide to help with the job market there.
Amazing Buddha face. Its amazing how they built such a place by using stones. This is something you must visit in Siem Reap.
spectacular. it was worth the climbing and walking and sweating to see the kingdom of gods and legends..it was amazing..the image is exactly the same as the postcard
Memorable. Saw many temples and would have to say this was one of the favorites. Went around the temple on elephants which was special.

Faces everywhere!. A brilliant temple to visit, amazing with the faces all the way around it - a must see. Try to visit either first thing in the morning (7am) or in the evening for sunset when it is cooler.
Beautiful!. Liked the Bayon most! Must visit! It stands out from the rest due to the unique, beautiful 'face' sculptures.
Big and Beautiful. The atmosphere. Incredible! One of the most striking historical sites to visit in the world - apart from the Angkor Wat Temple itself, that is :)

What an incredible experience!. Experiencing being in something that old, and with such an incredible history was amazing. Knowing that I was walking the same path as those from so long ago blew me away
Bayon is packed with history and carvings. Among the many temples in Angkor, this is one of my favorites. The site is packed with history among the numerous carvings on the temple walls.
Enchanting. This was an interesting television because of the smaller scale and chance to take some great photos
One of many things to see in Angkor Park. This is the one of the famous temples - the one with the faces. Usually visited with Ta Prom, Angkor Tom, and Ankor Wat.

Excellent.. Buy a 3 day pass and use it ove 5 or 6 days. Get out of bed early,and be there at daylight and you will have the place to yourself, amazing! No noisey people and you will hear all the bird life and monkeys etc. Same for all the temples.
Temple. Enjoyed the site not the beggars and sorry for vendors with the same products at every site. Was lovely weather put on good footwear and enjoy. Bring sun tan lotion

Simply Amazing!. All of the temples at Angkor are amazing! To think that these structures were built 900 years ago and are still standing is breathtaking! What is our generation going to leave on the world? People come from miles to see this because it is classed as an unofficial wonder of the world. It is a must see just like the other temples. The architecture and detail is like something you will never see in this day and age. An absolute must visit. You only need 30 mins to walk around it and then move on to the next one. Go early in the morning to avoid the contest ion and the midday sun. It gets very hot walking around the complex. This was our second favourite temple after Ta Prohm which is the best in our opinion.
Bayon Temple. This was perhaps my favorite of the temples around Angkor Wat. It is the temple with the large carved stone faces - errie and yet brilliant - so recommend it

average.... i dont get it why people rate this as one of the best atraction in siem reap. i mean i get it that it was a big temple and an old one, but the other temple was much more interesting. but meybe it's just me..
Amazing !. A must see. The sheer magnitude of the structures is awe inspiring. One of my highlights. Try the elephant ride for a different dimension.

ramarkable experience. Good site to visit for those who are really interested in historical sites. Area was more than expected after hearing all kinds of stories before I experience it for the first time

Not to be missed!. One of the first temples we visited and one of our favorites overall. Seeing it with a guide really brings the history of the site to life. The different massive-sized faces and their slight variations are wonderful to look upon.

Interesting temple. Worth looking at take a guide they are $35 a day and well worth the cost. The temple has great carvings and a wonderful history. It helps to study the history about the area before traveling to south asia
Temple of smiling faces. Nice place for photography. Especially with the contrasting color of a monk's robe. One of the must visit temple.

One of my favorites!. This is one of the most impressive temples in Siem Rep and I recommend you hire a guide to show you the details on the walls and the meaning of the sculptures.He will be able to point out differences on the faces of the Budhas, which one is older or younger. Things I would not spot by myself.A guide should cost $ 25/day and a tuc tuc another $ 15. The hotels can organise it for you.

Good day but lots of tourists - Travelling with an infant. We travelled with a 15 month old. We had her in a back pack. We bought the 3 day pass, enabling us to use the ticket on any day within the week (from purchase). Cost $US40 each.In the 3 days we visited:Day 1: Angkor Wat and Banyon Temple (4 hours total from the point we left the Hotel to the point we returned)Day 2: Preah Kahn and Ta Prohm (4 hours total from the point we left the Hotel to the point we returned)Day 3: Banteay Srei, Butterfly Museum and Landmine Museum. (5 hours total from the point we left the Hotel to the point we returned)We hired a car to take us (Day 1 = $30, Day 2 = $30, Day 3 = $40)Banyon Temple was good. Given we were there around 11:30 it was getting quite hot so we were in and out within 30 mins.If I was doing it again I would have left the hotel each day at 6:30 to avoid the heat and tourists.

Invisible faces!!!. So you rock up to this temple and you wonder if you are in the right place - As you get closer you see these huge faces rise up above you carved in stone!! 49 towers with 4 faces each (196 altogether) are very interesting and amazing - some great pics to be had here.

Really Amazing!. Very wonderful temple - if you are in Siem Reap, you must see this gorgeous temple. Try to go there early in the morning as this site get packed by midday. Just be ready to climb the stairs to see all the faces etched in the stones. Very amazing to see.
Bayon Temple. This is another must see temple in the Angkor Wat Park. Again we took lots of photos and got a real insight into the history from what our guide told us.
Bayon Temple in the heat. A wonderful temple to visit. Still in pretty good condition despite its age. Go there and see the four faces.
Amazing!. Gorgeous temple- a must see out of the many in the park. Try to go early in the morning or in the early evening- these sites get packed in the middle of the day.
One of the best. This and Angkor were my favourite temples. This one is very unusual, lots of faces etched into the stones, amazing to see.If visiting Siem Reap, this is an absolute must do.

Creepy and Huge!. When I first saw the gates going to the Angkor Thom complex, I was filled with awe...and then I saw the Bayon Temple. It was so huge and mysterious! I kept on wondering who the faces were and how the early Khmers built such an enormous temple without the use of the modern machinery and equipment we have today.
Beautiful temple. It's a great temple. Go early so you can take time to snap the famous smiling/kissing face shot. Ask your tour guide for the best angle to take the picture. Not to be missed.

Bayon the temple that impressed me most. I had done a lot of home work before going to Siem Reap and I was surprised that many people rated Bayon over Angor Wat which is the most famous temple in Angor Archaeological Park. Bayon was the first temple I visited on the first day and it was really a mesmerizing one,. I just could not resist appreciating it from the out side for almost 30 minutes before I decided to enter. The fearsome beauty of this unbelievable temple really captured my heart.If you are a keen photographer it is advised to visit this temple in the morning so that you get full details of the temple in your photographs.The west side of the temple gives you some nice view for photographs. You will need a good camera with pretty high zoom to capture the details especially the "smile of Angor". My camera with 42X zoom was found to be very useful here,

Weird and wonderful. This temple looks like a heap of rubble from a distance but once you get up close you can see the multitude of huge faces that look out in all directions. There are some wonderful carved reliefs around the outside walls (ground level). Unsurprisingly it does attract crowds so it's difficult sometimes to see everything
Just beautiful. Probably my favorite of the temples. Not as crowded. Was very peaceful. Visit in the morning while it's still cool.

Impressive Visit. We did this temple as part of a full day with guide. Having a personal guide with transportation is absolutely worth the money. They know so much about these places that you would otherwise have to acquire before you visit.
Bayon. I loved this temple because it is small and unique. The faces are just beautiful and provide some wonderful photo opportunities.
Amazing. Unique temple in Angkor that is well worth a look. Great place to explore the nooks and crannies of the lower levels. Has a different feel to most of the other temples.
Mind blowing!!. Fantastic place to wander around, fantastic sights, feels like you entered another time!! (just try and avoid the Chinese tourists!!)
Angkor Thom area is great.. Peaceful, and breathtaking. Very interesstibg area. If you love Elefants, take a ride around the Baon, on elefant back.
Fantastic. Stunning temple, very impressive. Definitely worth a visit. Limited shade, so visit early (before 10AM) or late (after 3.30PM).
Amazing temple. It's an amazing temple, not to be missed. Its a huge site and take your time to admire the temples, and be amaze with the cravings and others.
Amazing. A must see in Ankor, loved all the smiling faces and beauty of the area. Definitly don't skip this one

Great Temple. We visited this temple 3-4 times in our entire in Siem Reap.
Took many photo & please take your time to admire this temple.
This is a must during your temple hopping in Siem Reap.

GREAT TEMPLE. For sure is a must visit! but do it later in the day, it will be a lot better as there will be no tourist at all.
You will find that if you go there late, you have it all just for you, you can take as many pictures as you want with no one to disturb you.

Amazing. This was amazing. So much detail but really busy. We had a driver through Mr Kriss (Alex) and a guide who he organised (Mr Chang) who showed us through the Bayon, we would have missed so much with out him. I think I guide is really good idea.

Nice temple. Worth a visit! That's why we all went to siem reap, didn't we? Fantastic temple! Go and see it.
Yes, yes and yes.

Bayon. Amazing temple with lots of nooks and crannies so you could escape the crowds and feel alone. The faces are wild and the drive through the gates with all the guard statues is surreal. This was our favorite temple out of 12 in Angkor.
