Beautiful smiling buddhas. Favourite temple of Angkow Wat! Very photogenic, especially in morning and evening light.
The smiling buddhas are very calming :-)
One of my favourite temple. Smaller than Angkor Wat less grandiose, but magnificent, smiling Buddha's every where you turn, having a fantastic guide helps you get the details on the temples!!

temple. this is a typical of the cambodian style of temple , somewhat similar in architecture as the other angkor temples... but neverthless, its a must see as each has its own uniqueness and history... the angkor wat temples are such a huge archeological sites , that at times you need to plan well if you wish to see the complete temples............. It is better off with a guide to know more about these and some of the temples are being restored as well.......

Fantastic!!. In whole Cambodia that is the temple to go. It is fantastic, magic, beautiful.......enjoy it. Ask your guide for some photo spots. Even though these guys are telling you a lot of stuff, there normally know the best spots for making pictures.
Temples and Trees. I like the way natural trees and man-made temples blend together to form wonderful creations.
A sight to see. Dont miss the opportunity to tour (with a guide). Awesome place!
one of the better ones to photograph. I loved the heights and steep stairs. Not a temple you need to spend too much time in though

Peaceful place. It is a nice and plasent destination for you and your family to relax and calm down . Bayon temple is not a big temple , it is medium size I would say. Together with my aunt's family , we visited this extra ordinary temple in the early morning , it is highly recommended to stay there for at least two hours . If you are lucky enough , there will be a guard to t funny pictures for you together with the four faces carvings on each dome or roof . this temple is covered with phenomenon and unbelievablely beautiful carvings . it is a must for every single tourist to pay a visit while you decide to have a stay at Cambodia .
Awe-inspiring, one of the highlights of the temples. Angkor Wat is known for the bas reliefs and the Bayon Temple inspires from the sheer number and size of the structures.

"Kissing the King". one of the best temple i've been, which ever direction you look you can see the king's face ad i was able to take a picture of me 'kissing the king', i think that's pretty cool.......
Beautiful places so much history. Like other temples in this area Bayon was spectacular
A happy place. I felt the faces on the temples are smiling warmly at us, some even looks grinning due to the chipped parts of the lips. Amazing place. Somehow felt calming.
My favourite. Surreal. Spiritual. Try and get here at or just after sun rise and you will find yourself alone with all those gorgeous smiling faces.
My favourite temple. This is a must to visit, it is truly a wonderfully charming temples with faces on all sides of the towers. Much smaller in comparison to Angkor Wat but charming

The haunting, enigmatic smiles in the faces of Bayon - unforgettable!. If the Louvre has the Mona Lisa and her mysterious smile, the Bayon Temple located in the centre of Angkor Thom, has 200 giant stone faces with equally enigmatic smiles. According to my tour guide, each of the 40+ towers has 4 faces that look out to the four directions on a compass. The faces are massive and the sheer size and number, make this place impressive. It will take your breath away. Take the time to wander around the temple to appreciate the beautiful and ornate carvings of Apsaras (celestial dancers) on the walls and arches. This is clearly up there on my list of favorite temples. If you are only in Siem Reap for a day, don't miss Bayon.

A multitude of massive serene stone faces watching your every move. Wonderful to see monks in and around this complex. They add so much colour. Try and photograph someone rubbing noses with a stone deity. Not so good was rubbing shoulders with the hundreds of tourists pouring out of buses. Go early to avoid the crush.
Better than Angkor Wat. Bayon temple was the best temple in the entire Angkor temple complex.
Fantastic faces!. This temple was fascinating. We loved the faces so much we went back for a second look.

WOW!. What a great place! Lots of amazing structures to see! Crowded this time of year, hard to get pics without anyone in them. Quite hot and humid so take water. But it is a great place to walk around and take it all in.
Impressive. It was the first temple we visited. All the faces and wall murals are just so impressive.

Don't wander alone. Bayon is a massive and interesting temple with all those faces looking at you. Almost all of them look similar, except for one - the only smiling face. It will be fun looking for it. My friend and I decided to go around the temple separately and ended up looking for each other for 2 hours. So if you are not hiring a guide, don't separate.The best time to go there is after taking pictures at Angkor Wat. Go ahead of the other tourists so you will have time alone admiring the statues and taking pictures.

One of the best temple to see.. I loved seeing this temple. It and the Ta Prohm temple were used in the Tomb Raider movie. Only thing, if you do not like the heat and humidity, then you may want to visit during the cooler months.
Overawed. One of the many amazing sites of Angkor, but this is intriguing with the many faces that smiled gently down on you.
Highlight of Angkor Thom. Personally my family enjoyed this more that Angkor Wat itself. Dont go early so you miss the crowds and an early cloud.

Majestic Bayon. If you only have time for 2 temples to visit, one of them should be Bayon. It is always astounding to see them in pictures. But to finally see the real thing up close is even more awe-inspiring. The 4-faced statues are majestic and yet at the same time scary. The phrase "we are watching you" from the movie Congo comes to mind. Makes you wonder why a temple need to be surrounded by so many gigantic stone faces. Still, great place for photo-ops. Oh and there are apsara dancers inside waiting to have your picture taken with them. Another memorable souvenir to take home with you!
Ride the elephants around this site. An incredible experience. Make sure you ride the elephants. $15 dollars each and well worth it. Importantly, it appears that the elephants were well treated.

Very Impressed!. Beyon is located at the centerof Angkor Tom.
Many faces greeted us.
The faces have some kind of a weird smile, but I thought that the person who made these statues is tremendous.
Each faces had slightly different smiles, and had sense of vulnerability.
I found my favorite from many of those ruins.
Magnificent. Seeing the faces carved on stone is eerie and magical at the same time! It feels like they're always watching you! This is one of my favorite temples! I can marvel here for hours!
You gotta go. Everybody talks about Angkor Wat, but this was my favorite. Less crowds, absolutely stunning.

Must See. Really beautiful temple, we have visited this twice and I can recommend to go either early or late because of the huge tourist groups that arrive by bus.We went there after a big shower so we were the only tourists there, which was even better.This is something you must visit when you're in Cambodia, because it is just amazing how this temple has been preserved.
One my favourites. This temple almost looks like made of lego. It has a very mystical feel to it when all those dozens of faces are looking at you from the towers and it some amazing bas reliefs too.

Jayavarman all around. While you walk-up to the zenith of the Bayon; you loose count of how many Jayavarman II statues have you witnessed. Its mystic .. whether its the statue of the king or Lord Buddhha or Vishnu ... What rules is the size and the vision.
Careful. Boardwalk hard to navigate, inside very dark.No signage.
It felt like you were discovering it for the first time. Nothing the weather was great and the number of tourists was tollerable
Unique temple. There's no way not to visit this temple during your visit to Angkor Wat. Very impressive and unique indeed.

Impressive !. Even if you have visited lots of other temples in the surroundings, Bayon is a must see. Don't be bothered by the crowds at the entrance, once your inside, there are great spots to see, without the hordes of fellow temple viewers!
Simply amazing. Bayon temple was our one-of-three best temples in Angkor. It is amazing to see those faces especially in sunrise or sunset. Definitively place that should not be missed

Mind blowing. If you are going to see only one temple in Siem Reap then it has to be this one. Absolutely unbelievable. We loved Angkor Wat but not even that came close to Bayon.
A must see.
Amazing!. Unbelievable giant stone faces in really good conditions. One of the most beautiful temples on the site.
Fascinating. The whole history of the place is amazing. Get there early and be prepared to climb and descend large steps.

Restoration almost complete. I like the historical value of the temple just like the other temples in Angkor Wat. The ancient architectural design and significance of each of the temple with the four faces are amazing.
Temple tour. Fantastic experience, so many temples to see, it was great,
A Photographers Delight. It is stunning and beautiful and if you enjoy photography the opportunities here are endless
Beautiful temple. Loved the temple itself & the one next to it & the novelty of the elephant ride. The complex containing Bayon I thought was one of the most beautiful in Siem Reap.
Beautiful place. Amazing place. Make it a priority if you only have a short time.

Less crowds. Amazing beauty.. The faces carved in every surface belie the significance of a temple complex that was Buddhist transformed to Hindu, back to Buddhist. Unlike most of the temples in the area that were originally Hindu, this one stands apart. It is being restored by the Japanese, who are quarrying authentic sandstone to recreate the original beauty of the site. Go early to see the sun rise on the beautiful visages. Have fun!
My fave temple. My favorite among the many temples we visited. Very picturesque and has a very interesting history as well
just brillant. you have to go its that good.................................

Distinctive amongst the temples. Perhaps the most distinctive amongst the many temples in Siem Reap, Bayon has huge faces carved on the temple walls, which are supposed to be either of the Buddha or the king. The faces do seem to have slightly differing nuances but they are mostly large and imposing. But don't just focus on the macros, because there are beautiful small bas reliefs on the lower walls as well. Do get your guide to advise you on the best angles to take photos since the number of faces gives you great opportunities to snap some really catchy pictures. Finally, do stop by the southern gate of the Angkor Thom complex, where Bayon is housed. The gate and the moat causeway lined with figureheads are quite spectacular and scenic as well.

Great feeling. Cannot say enought about it. Great feeling once you are in the temple. Make sure you have a good guide who can tell you the history as we had a great one. There are few places in temple where you can take some great pictures make sure you guide tells you ie one place where it looks Buddha is touching your face when you take a picture
try to count how many budda's face. amazing, it's located in the center of Angkor tom, don't miss the wall also
Big and unspoiled. Very big and impressive temple, part of it is unrestored with big tree growing on top. I think this is the most important temple you should visit in Siem Reap.
Temple Tours. All the temples are worth a visit. Bring a camera and lots of memory, the details are incredible

Great king built great temple. Bayon is the best temple in my trip at siem reap. The king build with 24 towers and more than 200 faces. It is fascinating and impressive with all smiling faces of this temple.
A marvel!. This is one of my favourite amongst all the Angkor temples because of its structural beauty.

Beautiful temple. Ancient building,beautiful sculptures and tranquil environments.
Dislike too many children selling items, harassing tourists. Children must be given education and not remain poor
Worth a visit. "Weirdest" - I would say the most unusual temple, worth a visit!
Beautiful temple.. Gorgeous temple. Interesting it kids too. The elephant ride around the temple was wroth it too!

Interesting, different from other temples. The faces incorporated in the architecture of this temple make it quite unique. We used a tour guide who was quite knowledgeable in the history of the area and the ruins and restoration processes.
Put Bayon on your must visit Temple list. Amazing. Loved this Temple complex . Incredible carved faces. Able to take some great photos.
beautiful. beautiful, gorgeous, what about things to see from siem reap you can go with the tuk tuk, 10 minutes from downtown.

Overcrowded but Amazing. Enjoyed it better than Angkor Wat. Loved the statues of the faces outside. Amazing that these great structures are so well in tact. Although elephant rides are available, I am personally against the mistreating of elephants as I've seen videos online of the way they are hurt in order to break them down and basically force them to do whatever one wants. Would recommend looking into it if you haven't already.Rainy season means lots of mud so be careful walking about.I would beware of the people handing out incense as it seems a bit suspicious to me they ask for money.
Smiling Faces. Gives you a happy feeling..... Love the contrasting smiling faces and the eerie feel to the place
Unmissable. The centre of Angkor thom, this is an epic temple. The towers with the four faces of Buddha are extraordinary.
Worth alook. Interesting to visit such an ancient sacred sight, too much to take in, our guide was very knowledgable,

Breathtaking. I recommend doing a bit of reading before visiting this temple. There are 54 tower type structures within the temple, each with a carving of a face on each of its 4 sides. The amount of work that would have gone into building this temple is mindboggling.There are traditional Khmer people living in and around the runis, they will attempt to ask you for monetary offerings at each of the temples. So if you want to share the love, don't start out with a big offering on the first chance you see this.
nice place. go in the morning, and try to read or learn something about before go.
Loved it. Loved everything, this was a real treat...Not really suitable for persons who have mobility problems
My Favorite Place to visit in Siem Reap. The magnificence of this place is beyond words that can be described, one has to be there to feel the magic and beauty.
really fascinating. My husband and I and our 2 teenage sons loved walking around Bayon. Our tour guide was knowledgeable and spoke good english
Awesome!. Great place... not too many people at certain times...
Temple visit. Different to other temples and worth a look. We spent 3 half day visits which was just enough.

One of our favorite!. Loved this temple! The faces are amazing. We had a guide who able to give us more info than we would have gotten if we walked around on our own.Tip - bring a towel to wipe your face, it gets very hot walking around the temples.

Amazing site. Situated in the heart at the heart of Angkor Thom this 12 centuary masterpiece the highlight being the faces more than 200 of them silent but with the famous half smile playing on trheir lips. P J de Beerski wrote of them ( godliness in the majesty and the size, mysteryin the expression )
Gorgeous!!. With so many serenely smiling faces looking down at you, you can't help but feel happy in this place!
Must see Bayon.. Our favorite of the 7 temples we visited. The trees growing out of the walls give you the feeling of how the jungle overtook these temples for 600 years,
Breathtaking!. Do not miss this when visiting Siem Reap!...Great for photography!

You can do it from north to south. What i realised today is that tourist buses bring people to south gate and take them from the north gate. So at the south gate, there is always a chaos. (Elephant riders; little girls selling water and trinkets etc..) But since I started from the north gate according to driver's advice, i had a pretty decent visit. At the exit i spend some time taking the pictures of elephants but i didn't have to deal with the rest of the crowd. Another tip: It was raining today so if you have a raincoat -which they sell for 1 usd everywhere when it is not raining- and rain doesn't bother you, you may visit all the places without getting disturbed by tourist groups. And trust me when these temples are crowded, it is difficult to take a decent picture. 3 temples (what they call here small tour) can be properly visited in half day, you don't need to buy a full day tour/rent a car or tuk tuk for full day. (depending how long you plan to stay in each one of course.). But if you rent a car for full day expect them to take you to one of the touristy places for lunch. If you are not going to tip the driver -you don't have to- you may as well eat at that place. you pay 2-3 dollars more but they get at least 1-1,5 usd from that. Companies pay really little to the drivers or guides. Or you can ask him to take you to one of the places where locals eat. Or to a street vendor where you can buy food for 1-1,5 dollars. (Restaurants around Angkor cost at least 7 usd per person.)
Loved this temple - its the one with all of the faces!!!. Part of a large complex of temples, this one stands out for me.
Wow. Just wow.. What is not to like . 54 towers. Stunning. Do not miss it.
Must See. Don't go to Siem Reap without a visit here it is a really interesting spot to see

We forgot to see the bas reliefs!. It's one of the defining points of the Angkor visit, but don;t just focus on the 4 faced statues, do remember there's also 1.4km of bas reliefs at the lower walls..which we completely forgot to view!! Only realised it after we got back and read our guide book..duh!
incredible. All these ruins are famous for a reason, look at the photos, then imagine being there!
Very cool. Keep it on the temple tour trip! You might think you will be temples out but everyone is unique. The faces of the Bayon are very cool!
bayon. dont miss this place since its has the most tower heads..great for photography
Breathtaking. My favorite of all of the temples. Faces carved all over the temple. Truly amazing and mind boggling.
WOW. Different face expressions if look closer. One of the nice temple in Siem Reap.

WHEN AT BAYON...SMILE AS THE DEVAS DO. Popularly known as the Temple of the Smiling Faces, I could see why it was called such. At almost every turn that I took around the temple I "bumped into" a carving of a smiling faced figure and as I wandered through the ruins there were the towers with the four heads looking down and smiling at me. I was told later on it was the face of the Bodhisattva Avalokiteshvara. For me,the place became a "fun" location for taking photos because you didn't have to encourage your subjects to smile...the statues did that for you! One place in particular became a popular picture spot because if you had a photograph taken of you at a certain angle, it looked like you were rubbing noses with one of the tower heads. Among the many temple ruins at Angkor that one must visit, Bayon Temple is a "must see." I would even say, that you've not seen Angkor if you've never seen Bayon.

Byon temple is a smilling temlpe in Siem - reap. The central tower of the Bayon once sheltered a Buddha seated on the Naga. Cast into the well of the central tower with the 13th-century return to Brahmanism, this statue was discovered and transported for worship and display at Vihear Prampil Loveng in 1935.
A plethora of temples to visit.... ...and this was one that I did, but any of them is worth the visit.
Temple. Nice and interesting temple. It is very warm in this temples. Good, quick dry clothes recommended

Fascinating temple. The huge Buddha faces on the temple. We did not like that there were many "so called" students studying history and was there to earn extra money for school and trying to blend in with you and start telling you the history of the temple and then said we could give him whatever we like for the lesson. When we said we will give him US$1 from each of us which was US$3, he said not enough as he had to give to someone else. This is a scam. Just ignore them. Dont even start with them.
Great place worths to go. We enjoyed all of our trip in cambodia and this temple is worth seeing,

Must see Temple. Everyone comes to Siem Reap for Anchor Wat. But be sure not to miss Bayon. The architecture is what you think of when you think of Khmer. It is plenty busy but there are moments when you can get great photos. The local actors add to the experience, be sure to tip them.
Impressive. As part of the whole 'Angkor' area, this temple is another stunning place to visit. Take water!

The faces temple. It is impressive this construction, and even though I learn that the rock they used wasn’t as good as the one in Angkor Wat, still and amazing creation and the history behind is even more amazing.

Very interesting temple with four buddhaheads. Very nice temple and very interesting.
You see many stones around and the amazing growing trees, some just like elephant
Photo-OP at Bayon. Best photo-op for travelers- take the elephant ride around Bayon temple only $15 pax, and have a photographer friend position himself so that Bayon temple will be the background!
Well preserved work of art. This would be the best temple to go if you can only choose 1 temple to visit in Siem Reap.

Bayon: Towers and Faces. We visited Bayon as part of a Small Circuit tour of Angkor Wat/Thom by tuk-tuk. After having gotten up at 4:30 am to reach Angkor Wat for sunrise, and wandering around its vastness, we had a somewhat mediocre breakfast in one of the many temple restaurants, and then rolled onward to Angkor Thom through a huge parkland area of grass and trees. Angkor Thom (Big Angkor 12th – 13th c ce Buddhist) is a three kilometer square walled and moated royal city and was the last capital of the Angkorian empire. King Jayavarman VII constructed his state-temple, Bayon, at the center of the city.Bayon (late 12th c ce Buddhist), a temple with thirty-seven standing towers, most but not all sporting four carved faces oriented toward the cardinal points. Apparently who the faces represent is a matter of debate but they may be Loksvara, Mahayana Buddhism’s compassionate Bodhisattva, or perhaps a combination of Buddha and Jayavarman VII. The bas-reliefs on the southern wall contain real-life scenes from the historical sea battle between the Khmer and the Cham, as well as scenes from everyday life. Bayon is a smallish temple and beautiful (although quite crowded). See more information and pictures of our temple tours here: http://lmaclean.ca/2012/01/temple-tour-two-small-circuit-of-angkor-wat-and-angkor-thom/ and here: http://lmaclean.ca/2012/01/grand-tour-of-temples-around-angkor-thom-cambodia/
Smiling faces. Unique for the serene smiling faces carved on the stone. The temple as a whole reflects both Hindu and Buddhist influences. It's a picturesque temple well worth a visit.
Excellent trip. This is a great temple, so much of it has been presrved well, considering the age of the place. We really enjoyed our visit.

Lots of smiling faces. My guide told me it was one of the "big 3" as it shows the friendliness of the Khmer people. The level of detail in the faces is just incredible, and walking around every corner there is another face to see. Incredible detail.

Picturesque part of the temple complex. The stone carvings and the huge stone faces are a sight to behold. My friends and I enjoying taking pictures of the different parts of the temple. When you pass by some parts of Bayon, you will see Buddha statues and there, you can light some incense sticks. For a small donation, a local will give you a string bracelet and whisper a prayer for your good luck. If you can, try to avoid the big groups of tourists so that you can take nicer pictures of yourself and the place without extra people being included in your shots. Some temple security person even taught us how to take a shot like we were kissing the temple faces. Bayon is one of my favorites in the temple complex!
Beautiful Bayon. Amazing temple to visit and get stuck in a rainstorm in! It was quite surreal. Well worth a visit.

Aesthetically inspiring. I was rather puzzled over why many preferred Bayon temple to the great Angkor Wat. Now that I've been to both places, I wholeheartedly concur that the Bayon is indeed unique. This is one place you must not miss when visiting Siem Reap.
Good Archeological Site. The short stretch of road leading to the hotel is not tarred
fascinating. spent a week visiting the nearby temples, all magnificent, all worth visiting.
Unbelievable. The detail and expressions of the carved faces. The incredible location and the elephant around the Bayon that gives you a great overview
Amazing Temple. It was really incredible construction with great job.

Picturesque!. This is absolutely my favorite temple among all the temples that I visited. The carvings on the walls were pretty amazing and you can take a lot of beautiful pictures here! This place really makes you wonder what went on back in the day in Cambodia with all its empires. You shouldn't skip this on your itineraries!
awestruck. you can't fail to be spellbound by this temple. very easy to navigate thanks to clear signs everywhere

Amazing Bayon. Amazing temple, huge with beautiful bas reliefs and the characteristic faces. Simply wonderful.
Even in June (low season), quite crowded.
Wow. Amazing place. To be in a place that is so busy, but feel at peace, which this place gives is truly worth a visit.

Mesmerized.. It was like living a dream. The place was a wreck - in a way that you would wonder how it was like during its glorious era.
The Legendary Bayon Face. You shouldnt miss this. No need to purchase separate ticket/pass for this one. Included in the Angkor Wat pass.
Amazing temple. Very impressive, have lots of beautiful pictures can't wait to frame, our guide explained so much history, we loved it

Most interesting temple at Angkor. Bayon is beautiful. Try to go at different times, so that you avoid crowds and catch the sun at different angles. Early morning is best. Be sure to walk around the entire complex and the nearby temples as well.

Touch the face. One of the nicest temples of the whole city of Agkor Thom.
The fact that makes it extra special is that you can actually touch the faces on the top floor.
Rich in History. I loved the history behind most of it. I loved hearing the stories of the legendary king who revolutionized Cambodia.

Favorite Temple in Siem Reap!. We LOVED Bayon Temple! We got rained out but our guides from Peace of Angkor Tours found us hiding out and rescued us with umbrellas for each of us! The pictures we got of the beautiful faces in the rain were great to print on canvas with a Groupon and now hang proudly in our guest room for all to see! Do not miss this temple and if you get caught in the rain, find a neat place to hunker down and take pictures!
super beautiful, smiling temple !. no dislike at all, this temple is just amazing ! I would have stayed longer if it was not so hot, and there are so many temples to see .... :)

Bayon Temple, a most see in Angkor Wat. I'm sure you won't miss it, it's one of the most beautiful temples in Angkor Wat, a mix of Buddhist and Hinduhism, the stone faces are spectacular and will take your breath away

Totally Woaw. to us this was the nicest. great temple, great vibe; we were there at the same time chinese officials were visiting. 5 VIP cars, all engine left running to polute the air so that these VIP's could get cold in their car after the climb. What a waste.
Bayon Temple Visit. The downside is that much of the temple has been destroyed but still remaining are many of the beautiful wall carvings describing the daily lives of the early inhabitants.
Excellent!. Well preserved - great place to visit. We went early to beat the crowds - 07:45 & wasn't too packed.

Breathtaking!. Something which you have to see for yourself. The craftsmen who built these will be remembered for centuries. But try to come after 2pm. Anything earlier will be either too hot or not bright enough to take photos unless you wants shadows all over the place

Bayon - Buddhist Temple fused with Hindu Cosmology. The temple is better to visit from the main entrance where one could see the sculptural depiction of the churning of the oceans. This is a Hindu mythology described as purification of the world once it was formed. The Gods on one side and the Demons on the other side used the great serpant as the rope and Mount Meru as the stirer to churn the oean to rid the poison to make this world safer for living. The Temple was built by king Jayavarman the VIIth. around 11th Century. It is also popularly known as the Temple of Mona Lisa of Southeast Asia. The Khmer architure with smiling faces on the temple towers are a magnificient depiction of Eastern religions. The medieval sculputurers makes one wonder about the depth of artistic imagination of our ancestors and their religious beliefs. Another place never to be missed whilst in Sieam Reap. This temple is only a short distance away from the main Angkor Wat temple.
Bayon Temple. You could cycle over to bayon temple. Its not that far away for angkor wat.
Wonderful!. This temple is a must-see when visiting Siem Reap!

Great place to start. We had two days so did what the locals call a "short circuit" that took in Angkor Thom and Ta Phram (sorry spelling won't be correct as I don't have the map in front of me). The second day saw us venture further from SR to complete a "long circuit".Both days were great and Angkor Thom and Bayon were an ideal start.We saw lots of people without guides and therefore missing things so I'd recommend engaging one to talk about what you would like to do. It would be a shame to travel all that way and not do it.
My favourite. The detail and the ability to get so close up to the structures and great photo opportunities

The only one fantastic building in the world.. As I visited Bayon temple first time in 1996, I am so proud of Khmers ancestors who built this temple, all the beautiful smiling faces of charity, compassion, sympathy, and composer..that those four are facing to the four cardinal point of the universe .
Not to be missed.. Whatever you see in pix, it is better in real life.
Great Faces, A Must See in Siem Reap. Unlike about anything else anywhere else. A definite must on your itinerary.

Budhdha or Brahma. You can at least 43 of these faces out of est100 originally built..the faces and stone structure must be admired for how they have built this huge monument without cement..only structure well laid out ..the architecture,like any other in Siem Reap,reveals the Varmans devotion for their religious faith..let it be Hindu Gods or Budhdhist philosophy

Unforgettable serene faces. Bayon temple is most unforgettable because of the its hugh serene smiling stone faces occupying many towers and bas-reliefs on its walls. It is a Buddhist temple and stands in the middle of the walled city of Angkor Thom. Truly amazing even after three visits!
Wonderful place. The Bayon Temple was my favourite of the big three sites in the area - this is really impressive and is just so full of questions ... just takes your breath away really
Beautiful. Amazing temple in Angkor Thom. Great photos to be had

mind blowing. we found the Bayon temple the most breathtaking of all sites and sights in siem reap.
tip : go early morning or after 1200 if you want to avoid the crowds.
Breathtaking and one of a kind. It's my favorite temple..so much to see..but lots of climbing up and down big stairs at this temple.

My favorite temple. Angkor Wat is magnificent, Ta Prohm was green, Bantay Srei was intricate. Bayon Temple is my favorite. in the lower levels there was a labyrinth of dark and dank corridors perfect for getting lost in, then there was a well with BATs inside! Then on the top level that is where the magic happens. 54 towers each with 4 smiling faces formed the canopy of the temple. Signifying 54 provinces of the Khmer Empire. Up here I felt humbled at the sheer size multitude of the buddhist faces. Great place to have fun with trick photography. Amazing architecture. Must see for all.
Been there, taken nice pics. Experience climbing the steep staircase to the library
Better than Angkor Wat??. This is a must visit temple. It is smaller than Angkor Wat and can therefore get a bit crowded, but it is well worth the visit.
Ankor Wat. Just great, as are all the temples in this amazing place. Go early in the morning.
magical. I visited Prasat Bayon 3 times on my 2nd visit to Siem Reap and I will never tire of the amazing architecture and carvings and the 100's of faces gazing down at you from every angle.
Our favourite!. Just our favourite! The monks also helped to create very fotogenic scenery.

happy temple. The Bayon Temple will seem smal if you go to Angkor Wat first. But is has its own charm. The temple is also called Happy Temple because is has a lot of smiling faces throughout the Temple. The Bayon Temple ticket is included in the ticket you buy for Angkor Wat. Worth the visit.
Amazing!!!. If you go to Cambodia you must visit the temples area is just amazing and magnificent. I just come back from Siem Riap and I've to say it worth every single penny you spend on it!
Truly amazing .... A must see. The sheer magnitude of the structures is awe inspiring. One of my highlights. Try the elephant ride for a different dimension.
amazing temples. It will be hot, it will be crowded, but it is incredible series of temples to visit. The attention to details makes this such a special site.
Very interesting. You will enjoy this on you own but it's amazing if you have a good guide.
Awe-inspiring. The faces and construction of this temple was truly awe-inspiring. A must visit when at the Angkor site.

Nice & unique temple, many good spots for taking pics. I was lucky to have Seila as tour guide, he knows what he's doing. Plus he's a good photographer too! He knows where to take good pics. He took some pics of me facing the one of the faces as if our nose touches, cool...This temple is unique comparing to any other temple in Angkor Archaeological Park. One statue has four faces in four different direction. Beautiful...

One of my Favorites!. How can you not be charmed by these giant, gently smiling faces!This is still my favorite temple in the Angkor Park. Each face with its unique smile, What have they seen and witnessed over these hundreds of years? All the beautifully carved windows make for wonderful photos as well.
52 beautiful faces!. beautiful buddha carvings unfortunately destroyed/ modified by the next Hindu King Jayavarman VIII.
Everything is huge. Go in sunset time and the carvings will be even more impressive because of the shades and will be much less crowded than during daytime.

wow!. It's an amazing temple,love the detailing.
I captured lots of photos here.
Must visit!!

One of Our Favorite Temples- Don't Miss It!. The Bayon is beautiful. Don't forget to take the famous "kissing Buddha" photo while you are there! It is incredible how you are permitted to walk all over and touch pretty much anything you want at the temples in Cambodia. An unparalleled experience. Our group of four liked this temple style a lot (you will see how the temples vary depending on when they were built). All of the faces are stunning and you can get some very creative photographs here.
Excellent. Well worth the trip around all Angkor Thom, sat for some time at the east side amongst the busts.

The best spot for photography. Was here in the morning and spend many hours to make amazing images of all the things around me. The feeling was amazing and al do it is very hot...the energy levels rise when you are here. Must see when visiting Cambodia. This temple is amazing. I could spend a long time in the great Temple.
Face to face. The magic of the huge faces of each side of the towers is unique. How fortunate we are to be witnesses to architecture and art over one thousand years old.
216 faces of mystery!. My favorite temple, hands down. I love how there are so many picture worthy spots.

My favourite!. Bayon is absolutely stunning! I suggest everyone spends some time at Bayon wandering around and checking out all the amazing carved faces! There is one spot in particular that allows you to view 4 faces at one time- apparently this is rare! And that same location will allow you to take a picture that makes it look like you are nose-to-nose with one of the carvings! It's on the Southern side of Bayon (I learned this information from an Angkor tour guide!). This temple is my favourite by far! I've been to Angkor 4 times now and each time I make sure to visit Bayon.
Amazing Place. Like all of the temples around the area - they must not be missed

The temple with lots of faces. Nice place...you have to be alert as there are corners that you could take great pictures that are not obvious if you are not paying attention to your surroundings....get Bunleat as your tour guide and he has a lot of tips in taking photographs here!

A must-see!. Bayon is the first temple you'll come across as you enter Angkor Thom. The rows and rows of magnificent towers of faces carved into the four cardinal points are mind-blowingly awesome. Happy photo-taking, as it'll be very hard to take a wrong photo in this complex. (However, be warned that you will come across flocks of gauche tourists taking kissy-faces pictures with the monuments). We took in the monuments without a tour guide, but we did have a guide book in hand and we unravelled the stories and history behind the temple as we walked through it. It was a pretty amazing experience. I suggest touring this temple (and the rest of Angkor Thom) as early in the day as possible, as it can get very hot and muggy from the middle of the day til sunset.-----------------NOTE: You will need to buy entry passes to visit ALL the temples in Siem Reap. These can be purchased from a central point (near Angkor Wat) and will be personal to holder (they'll take your picture for the pass and all passes are non-transferable.) Passes cost USD20/day, $40/3days or $60/7days. Pretty steep, but well worth the money.

Don't miss it. Ankor Wat is the big name in Siem Reap, and deservedly so. However, Bayon Temple is only a short distance away, and is extraordinary. It would be a mistake to travel all the way to Siem Reap and not see this one. It's easy to see them both in one day with the help of an experienced guide (which I highly recommend).

Great photo opportunities.. Amazing architecture of the temple with fantastic photo opportunities. Light for photo is very good just before dust. The ice cream man on the Tuk Tuk was a welcome relief from the heat of the day.
faces everywhere!. Such a cool temple, you have to see all the faces here!
Incredible. This is my favorite temple in the greater Angkor Wat area. The stone faces are really amazing. I love this place. Do not miss it.

Mind-boggling. An incredible temple, quixotic faces on all sides. Must have been spectacular when built. Take the time to talk to the heritage police man on top - he took the time to show us unique features and help us take some great photos.
Impressive. It is a wonderful visit, but very hot, of course. Prepare your hat and sun block.
The one with the faces. I loved the Bayon temple, the detail in this place was unbelievable i can't imagine what it must have looked like when it was first built in all it's glory
Weird and wonderful. Bizarre seeing many stone faces staring back at you. Try to go at sunrise while all the crowds of the people are at Angkor.
Best temple in Angkor Wat by far. This is one not to be missed. The faces and the architecture are really spectacular. Go early in the morning to avoid the heat....
Amazing carving etc., old old old!!. Everything most interesting, people super friendly & helpful

Amazing, alien-like. The Bayon Temple is one not to be missed in the Angkor temple complex. It is the most unique with its four face towers and has an interesting history about it, which I will not recount here. It is a popular temple, so as with all other temples, be sure to ask your driver to recommend the best time to visit. Lastly, be sure to have a picture taking facing one of the faces. There are several vintage points where you can do so with amazing optical illusion.
The temple with big faces. I love this temple because of its gigantic faces of Buddha, Lve to take photograph of this temple and will give very nice image with the tall trees in the background.
Amazing a must see. I think it was the best temple I visited and found it a highlight of the trip.
Unbelievable!. The architecture and the stone carved in detail show multiple faces of enlightenment. Quite a sight to behold.

all smiles!. The temple with the 54 towers, each with four faces, has a fascinating history and significance in Buddhism. Almost every corner photographs well! Best of all, there aren't as many precarious steps to ascend.
Happy Temple. Whoever built this temple must have been a really happy person...the smiling statues makes this temple my all time favorite.
Bayon Temple. A beautiful temple noted for its massive serene and tranquil carved faces on the four sided towers ahd pillars.....You can feel the religious significance here.
The lure of Bayon. Huge boulders forming the Buddha heads peacefully staring on the horizon. I was amazed at the wonder of how the ancient Khmer people have created such a work of art.
Amazing. Beautiful temple. Another jewel in the Angkor crown!
a great temple to see. We saw quite a few temples while in Cambodia. They are definitely for us the main reason to go to Cambodia. This is one of temples worth visiting.
Another temple. One you have been to a couple of temples they start to blend into each other. But it was still intereseting
huge - not as exciting as angkor wat. carvings in walls and huge faces make this not just a pile of old rocks
Kind of spooky, but again a must see. Not just another temple, this is unique due to the four faces on each column. Always a face looking down at you. Very intricate building and lovely to see.
Don't miss it.. The temple was being partly renovated when we were there, but still great photo opportunities and an amzing site to see the effects of nature on these buildings.

hot. go early early.. like all the temples in the complex, bayon is a masterpiece of art and engineering, and unmissable. much more compact than angkor wat, the stone pulses with searing heat that bounces around the courtyards and walls - even at 7am. you'll be wanting a hat, water, wet towel and decent shoes as the floor is uneven.
but go you must.

Best temple in Cambodia!. Loved it!
Best of all temples I've visited in Cambodia!

Worth several visits. The faces in Bayon are mesmerizing.
I was there a couple of times at noon and it wasnt too crowded but it gets a bit tiring with the intense sun. None the less, it has nooks and corners to sit down and enjoy the view.
bayon temple. a must see for travellers take the time to walk around the whole temple and take in all its glory, highly recommend.
Must see Bayon Temple!. This is the best temple I've visited in 2 days. Love the giant smiley stone faces. Ask the guide for the best location for photo opportunities.
Awesome. Beautiful and amazing. Hard to comprehend the magnitude of this creation
Such an amazing temple!. This temple ranked in my top 3 out of the 10 or 12 I saw during my trip to Siem Reap. Definitely worth the visit.

Best temple in Siem Reap. With the huge trees protruding from the ruins, this place will make you think you have stepped into an Indiana Jones' film. Part of Lara Croft: Tomb Raider was shot here. The place is beautiful with several photo opportunities so don't forget to charge up your batteries...pun intended. :)
great first stop. if you do bayon first instead of the way most tourists do it, with angkor wat at sunrise, you beat the crowds and get to enjoy this magical place without so many people
Most amazing place to be.... It is like going back thousand years in time. Huge complex runs miles and has some of the best stone carvings I have seen, only comparable place would be India.
Amazing - Full of faces. For me it was the best temple - guides use to know where to take the best pictures!
This was our favorite temple. Amazing place. Not even close to as big as Angkor but I think more impressive.
unbelievable. Fantastic..get there as early as possible, about 6am to avoid the crowds and have a magic experience as the sun comes up with the temple to yourself..a must visit..
How did the ancients do this?. Beautiful place to visit - marvel at the amazing carvings across the bayon and the lifelike sculptures. Real insight into the past.
It is a MUST SEE.. Atlhough we have difficulty climbing but this is an awesome temple.

Loved it, just wish you see it without being hassled. We loved walking around and looking in aww at the temple. I just wish that you could look in peace. I understand that every one needs to make money and I wish I could have bought from them all but it's just not possible and you must say no to so many, but I has followed and harrased for quite a long time by several teen girls who got quite mean with me. There are kids and old people alike selling just about everything at all of the temple not just Bayon and several no's usually is all that is needed to send them on to the next tourist.
The temple is amazing. Unique feeling if you visit late in the afternoon (even after closing time), when no tourists are around.

Bayon temple tour. When you first approach the Bayon Temple it looks like a pile of rubble and very different to Angkor Wat it is at the very center of Angkor ThomThere are lots of faces of Buddhas and hidden corners at time it is dark and musty the hallways of which there are many seem empty at times but the rooms have many people down on their knees praying to the Buddhist statues insideThe Bayon Temple has many towers close together unlike Angkor whose towers are more spread out The Bayon towers have 4 Buddhas faces on eachThe outer walls feature scenes of the marching Khmer army as well as market scenes land battles including elephants fightingThe central tower used to feature a huge Buddha but was taken down and destroyed it was apparently put back together and is on display somewhere

My favorite temple in Angkor. This was my favorite temple in Angkor (my husband's second favorite behind Ta Prohm). Definitely worth spending time here and if your in Angkor this is a can't miss temple.

buddhas everywhere!. one of my favourite temples... so many faces of buddha and we took lots of pictures...funny pictures like holding the buddha by the chin and kissing the buddha all taught to us by our super guide keo.
Up close with elephants. Temple was interesting but to get up close to the elephants was a treat. And the ride around the temple topped it off

True definition of awesome. As with many other reviewers, I rushed through Bayon after spending most of my day at Angkor Wat and other sites. Big Mistake! Bayon deserves at least as much time as Angkor Wat. The complexity of the architecture is simply unbelievable. In addition to a guide, I would suggest bringing a flashlight as hundreds of years of revisions have created some fairly dark areas in this maze-like structure. Many faces aside, there are just so many little gems tucked waiting for you to discover. Angkor Archaeological Park doesn't get much better than this.

Same Same But Different. After a morning in the heat visiting Angkor Wat the last thing we felt like was more temples. However, in many ways it is very different to Angkor Wat, in size and scope alone. Very imposing, large but quite different. Different colour stone, very steep steps and Bayon itself is in the centre of the larger complex of Angkor Thom. Do yourself a favour and don't try to do it all at once, we spread it in morning and later aafternoon visits but it would probably be better over two days, the heat is a killer. The Vietnamese operator of the complex has got it all sewn up and charges like the proverbial bull, but really doesn't put much back into it. A pity the Cambodian Government couldn't run it for themselves.

Impressive. Here in the ruins of Angkor is a Buddhist minority, four face Buddha is made with stones outside, and (temple) is a Buddhist flavor is different, such as Japan and China. There are many Buddha is (smile) has been a little bit different facial expressions. Impressive ruins.
Serene faces of stone. An absolute "must do" in my opinion. Get a guide you can understand and you will enjoy this amzing place even more. Take water.
Climbing and Exploring. Loved actually climbing around the temple and exploring all the different parts.
bayon temple. worth a visit along witht hte other temples in angkor wat
Not all temples are alike. Stunning architecture in an exotic setting. Love it and would like to return earlier in the day.
My favorite temple of the park. Bayon is smaller than some of the other temples, and the amazing carvings are everywhere you look. Easy to take it all in.
Incredible!. An incredible couple of hours spent here. fantastic that such a temple was ever built.
Just amazing!. The second of the main temples in the group but so different from Angkor Wat
Faces galore!. This temple is amazing. So many faces to see :) Don't miss this temple!!!

The temple with an attitude!. One of the best temples i've seen in the complex. The Bayon's most distinctive feature is the multitude of serene and massive stone faces on the many towers which jut out from the upper terrace and cluster around its central peak.
The scenes crafted on the stone wall are also a must thing to see.

Awesome!. Not as busy as the other temples and perhaps that was due to arriving around 8am in the morning for this. The template is well preserved and when you do come early bring a light sweater or jacket as it was a cool tuk tuk ride.

As good as Angkor. Bayon and Angkor Thom in many ways are better than Angkor Wat because more of the statues of Buddha have survived and much of the bas relief are in better condition,also much less crowded.See both .
everything and more. my best advise is to get there early to avoid the crowds. we went for the sunrise over angkor wat and still were the first ones at the temple.
one of the best temples. We went there before 8am and could enjoy it in peace while the jungle awakens. So go early and enjoy it all for yourself!
enjoyed this temple. I liked seeing all of the different sites in Siem Riep

Inspiring - a definite must see!. A temple like no other, filled with beautiful, massive facial stone structures which are awe-inspiring, to say the least. One of the places you visit which will leave an ever-lasting impression. (Visited May 2007)
Good place. I love Bayon. I want to come back as soon possible.
photographers delight. Amazing. Definitely go in the early morning when it is cooler.

A little crowded, still my favorite. Definitely one of the more crowded temples but this place is amazing. If you get off of the main level, you won't bump into any tour groups at all. This place has an amazing feel to it. I only wish I could see it without the tour groups. Still 5 stars in my book though.
The most amazing temple in the world. Better than Angkor wat!! B e a u t i f u l!!!! Go there!

Great Place. We went at 5.30am so theplace was absolutely deserted. It was quiet and peaceful. We went early thinling we'd catch the sunrise. Unfortunately the trees have grown so much that even at 7am the sun was hardly hitting the tops of the temples. So go around 8am if you want to take pictures of the sunrise hitting the statues' faces.
Bayon Temple. Very beautiful and magical. The Buddhas are fantastic. Just lovely.
must visit site. fantastic carvings of giant heads.Site very busy with tour groups in the mornings but quieter when we returned in the afternoon

simply amazing.. Absolutly amazing. Wish we could go back in time to see in all its splendour. The people of the time were very brilliant, beyond our understanding because not much we build today will stand the test of time this has. Love climbing around a corner to discover a archway framing an amazing site or another tower.

Angelina's temple. Everyone wants to see this temple after seeing the movie.
Take your camera to replica the movie shot.
Extraordinary.. Go there very early, before the crowds. It's worth it. My wife and I were amongst the first people just after sunrise, and it made the experience very special.
Great place to visit. Beautiful site but was rather concerned about the structural condition of the temple.
Bayon Experience. Really worth the trip to Cambodia. Felt we were in a different time in history.
Amazing. It was amazing , to see that a such a temple still exists.
Just like the Post Cards. Absolutely stunning as a photographer the sights and scenes are simply breathtaking.

Our favorite temple. We fell in love with this particular temple. As a result, we went back two more times. It is serene and mystical. Stone towers carved with giant massive Buddha faces, some with quixotic Mona Lisa smiles, look north, east, south west. If you try to take photos of each face, you'll easily shoot over 100 photos.
GREAT VISIT. When in the Siam Reep area this is a must but make sure you have a good guide to take you around

One of the best temples of the Angkor area. With its smiling faces staring at you all the time, this was one of the best temples of the Angkor area we have visited. Only drawback was that it was really crowded when we were there. So it is worth considering to avoid the peak moment just after 8.30 am.
Outstanding. Beautifully preserved and maintained. Very crowded we went in the middle of the day

Mysterious Faces. The Bayon is one of the well preserved temples in Angkor Thom. You can climb up to the second level and have a closer look of the more than 200 mysterious faces carved on the temple towers.
It is one of the most popular temples so the place was crowded during our visit.
Check my blog for Bayon photos: http://erickcamba.blogspot.com/

Big brother is watching you. The place looks like a jumble until you (with great explanations from our guide) start to really get into it - and have all those stone faces staring at you. Like the other sites, the detail is overwhelming and it's hard work to absorb it all. The live ladies in costume posing as temple dancers might have seemed a bit "naff" from one point of view - but accepted as a visual embellishment, they actually worked fine.

Stunning Faces. Bayon are temples with huge faces everywhere, it's thematic and beautiful - without realize sometimes you could just stunned to stare to those big faces in front of you and imagine "what would be the real face" of this stone.

Awe Inspiring. You may have heard a lot about Bayon, and you may have read about it in your guide book, but it's not the same as actually walking through the ruins and feeling the gaze of the silent faces looking down on you.

Worth while and great experience. As these are all ruins this is one that still shares it's history with you. Some quiet time here will reward you and your camara. It's large enough to wonder around and take it all in.
Magnificent. A great temple to spend time in. Don't miss this one..
Fantastic!. All of the temples of Angkor Wat were fantastic, but Bayon had an allure that was completely unique. I could have stayed there all day, it was especially beautiful at sunset.
I liked this temple the best!. The stone faces on the towers of the Bayon are amazing and the location is very close to the rest of the ruins.
Better than Angkor. Albeit we found Angkor to be amazing we preferred Bayon temple.

A must see!. A matter of opinion but this could be as good as its big brother Angkor Wat, a nice temple and a photographers dream.....the relaxed smiles on the temple reflect the smiles of the Khmer people, don't miss this temple.
Must visit highlight in angkor wat archeological park.... Make sure u climb all the way up to see the many faces at the top...everyone is unique.
amazing. beautiful temple, make sure you ride an elephant around the temple. its only $15 :)
Awesome!. Just wandering and wondering! Truley amazing-everywhere you look are stone smiley faces soaring upwards,on and on!
A must see. A must see if you are visiting Angkor Wat! Amazing! Only thing I can say that is bad is the constant hassling to buy something off the locals when you walk in and out of the temple.

Fascinating temple. This the temple with the four faces of buddha on each column, found in the Ankor Thom complex.
It is well worth a visit and this one in a good state of repair.
Great place - faces with different expressions. Very nice place in the forrests and very intersting to see the scuplured faces that all look similar but however still have different expressions
Beautiful. This was one of the best, if not the best, site in Angkor. Would definately not miss this one.

Interesting Temple. This was an interesting temple and worth a visit. It's worth paying for a guide to learn about the history and to point out lots of interesting details that might otherwise be missed.

Wow. Again, incredible and our guide took us on all the quiet routes as far as possible. I imagine this place gets VERY crowded sometimes though.
Next time we would do the elephant ride! Worth allowing a bit more time, it may be touristy but it looks fun!
Take a LOT of water, it is VERY hot here.
breathtaking. from a distance it looks like ruins but up close you can see the most amazing carvings of faces
Great!. So much beauty and history there. so worth it! Don't underestimate the heat, that is the only bad side.
excellent. Amazing place to visit - highly recommended. best to go early morning and avoid the crowds
Here's lookin' at ya. This was my favorite of the temples... everywhere you turn, a face! And not as crowded as the main temple...
The faces. This was such a cool visit, the faces are beautiful!

Beautiful temple. This temple was built in late 12th century and was the biggiest and the most beautiful temple of Angkor complex. It was amazing with beautiful designs and architectures. We got lovely photos of this temple. A truly memory in your trip!!!
So big. I think this is the one that is so high and covers a lot of ground but in more ruins than Angkor Wat. Still, we all stood in awe.
Fabulous. What can I say, as you start to realise just how many faces there are as the angles change, it really is a thrill.
Awesome. One of the best parts of the Angkor site. Love the heads coming out!
Do the elephant ride. It's cheesy but a great experience for the kids (and adults).

I love this place ,In the Buddhist temple located inside the Angkor Thom, Bayon Temple is famous Angkor was building to represent the Buddha as rumors surface 4,, Bayon was good enough may be said that even during a turn. Has been arranged so as to overlook all round the country of Cambodia 360 ℃, tetrahedral tower of Bodhisattva of various facial expressions,The Bayon is not nothing in the standings very far forward. A must... Amazing to go around and see this temple and all of its different face's.

Better than Angkor. We loved this temple. It has a great atmosphere and it just spectacular. We got a tuk tuk driver to do a day tour around the temples for $10. They take you to one, wait while you look round and then take you to the next. Best way to do it.Definitely make time to see this one.
Breath taking. truly incredible temple with amazing carvings, not to be missed

Beautiful ancient temple. The temple with many Buddha faces imprinted in the wall. A must see attraction.

Amazing!. After having seen Angkor Wat, this was really nice. Considerably smaller and more intimate, it was truly a wonder. The entrance was nice, and the temple was nice- much different than Angkor Wat. Worth the time to spend there.
Brilliant...better than Tomb raider one...... The heads of Buddha statue being chopped off was something to see
cool. the faces on the towers were very detailed and amazing. I would definitely recommend a visit.

Speechless. UNBELIEVABLEI've seen many beautiful things in my life, but Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom are apart.Miracles of human existence.Take time to study Khmer civilization before going and you'll be bewitched at the middle of these temples.We stayed quite late in Bayon (almost nobody around ...) until our tuk tuk arrived to pick us up.It was MAGIC.

one of the must see sites. One of the key sites to visit while in Siem Reap. Extraordinary history. Go early in the day
Nice. What cn I say really? It was a nice experience. Very good for the family especially my son.

Amazing day!. Just go and see...it's amazing! The whole area needs at least a whole day spent there, this was our second trip to enure we saw it all. Just make sure you have a large memory stick or plnty of film with you..you will need it
Excellent temple. An iconic site in Angkor. The intricate face carvings make this one of the best temples to pay a visit too.

Temple of many heads. One of the best sites in Angkor. This just feels different from the other sites, almost magical. There is a more peaceful and mystical feel to this place. I personally think it is because of the smiling faces carved everywhere.

Better than Ankor. I purchased my ticket for the Temple complex on the evening before the day I intended to visit at 4:45. I spent the time before sunset checking out Angkor Wat, which was cool. Stunning !. Took a great tour to visit Bayon early morning before over crowded by tour bus and tried again at the afternoon to see how color is changed.

wonderful!. great place, leaves you in awe!!! it's inside Angkor Thom so there are a lot to see there, including the terrace of the elephants. definitely get a 3 day pass to all of these places including angkor wat!

Great photos.

A definite must-see. Of all the temples in the Angkor area, if you are limited for time you must visit Ta Prohm (of "Tomb Raider" fame) and the Bayon. All the superlatives have been used. This day immediately went into our top-ten travel experiences of all time. Nuff said.

We were touring with a photography group under Nathan Horton who showed us some sweet spots to take interesting photos. We were fortunate to be there when there were fewer tourists visiting, so our photo taking was leisurely. A beautiful temple that you leave from feeling happy, Buddha has smiled upon you!
Gorgeous smiles!. The faces can't be missed. If you go late in the afternoon as the sun paints the faces gold the photos are amazing.
Must See Bayon. This temple is an ode to King Jayavarman himself. I have never been to a place so unique where you are watched by the king from all angles. Mesmerising !

Numerous temples and lots of walking. Bayon is very spread out, and requires a lot of walking. You could spend days here, but we crammed it into about 4 hours. Taking more time would be better. Definitely a must see.

Work in progress. This temple was not as intact as others and is been slowly restored. We felt there was less to see and appreciate. Those who dont like climbing to any height should give this one a miss. Because this is on the hit list for major tour groups with limited time it was very crowded. There are nice vistas at the top. Best Temple in SR. Much preferred to Angkor Wat. More striking -- the "temple of the faces." This and Preah Khan were my favorites.

Magnificient sculpture. So very different from the Angkor wat, but as wonderful as it is. The huge faces are unique. One must visit during the off season, to avoid the crowd. Thanks to the Japan government who has taken up the restoration work along with the Cambodian government. Worthy of visit time and again.
wonderful. Beautiful surroundings. Wonderful temple built for Bodhisattva.

Amazing faces. The faces in the walls at Bayon Temple are amazing and its well worth going there just to see them. The whole of Angkor Thom complex is interesting but if short of time just do Bayon Temple as that was the highlight for me.

Excellent. We saved Bayon for our second day rather than add it on to the end of our first temple day and I'm glad that we did. Exploring this great site when you are well rested and not "tempted out" is well worth it. Be ready for the crowds though!

Wonderful Bas Reliefs. A great stemple to visit in the early morning before the crowds arrive. Great rock carvings with typically Khmer faces. Interesting to see the small exhibit showing how the temple was built and also the carvings depicting that process.
Just amazing. Stand there and look up and see those huge faces looming down on you. Beautiful
Unmissable. Giant stone faces look at you from every angle as you wander about its maze like passages.
Pictures can't do it justice. One of my favorite temples in the Angkor complex-- I went back twice while I was in Siem Reap because I couldn't get enough! A must-see, even if you only have one day.
Stunning. Really amazing but the first time we went it was so so busy, need to get there early or it can be too busy to able to appreciate it.
Amazing. Take a look from far, you see the faces of the buddha. Go near it and see it again. What you see if the amazing effort that was put during the Angkorian period. Thumbs up!

nice place. It was hot but Bayon temple very intere3sting and memorable. i met khmer girl she works there and she told me amaizing story. I invited her for the dinner at the Viva mexican and khmer restaurant. She told me that Bayon is very khmer pray to get luck and birth of child.
wonderful. its a such a wonderful palace and lots of temples to see very a wonder of the world dont miss it its a woesome

Smiling Temple. Bayon is an integral part of any tour of the area around Angkor Wat. This large temple is famous for its eerily smiling faces shaped in to the very structure of the temple. Photo-ops abound! Do not miss it.

A must. This is a treat to see the number of faces on each of the towers of this temple. Each tower has four faces looking in the four directions with each tower representing a major city in the Angkor era. Perhaps one of the most crowded temples simply because there is limited space for the people to walk.

Simply breathtaking!. The history. The artistic beauty. The amazing architecture is jawdropping when you consider when it was built and that the builders had only manpower and elephants to create such a place.
Stunning carvings. The carved faces at Bayon are amazing - it's a beautiful temple, built to inspire awe, which it certainly does!
Bayon - wonderful. Do not miss - Angkor Wat will always be amazing, but second time around after gap of 5 years, Bayon has become the standout for me
Great place to visit. Was my first time there and just wished I would have found a better time to visit and it was crowd
Stunning Faces !. It must be a very experiences for our family had visited this temple. Beautiful temple and huge building decorated by its towers and Buddha faces.
Amazing. Our favourite temple of the Angkor complex, faces are amazing!
The temple with the faces. Loved it....worth visiting...!! Didn't like the usual harrassement by the beggars and little sellers but looks like it is unavoidable in Cambodia.
Stunning!. This unusual temple was my favourite - smiling faces make you feel very peaceful. Come in the later afternoon when it seems to glow with warm sunshine.
Angkor Thom. Impressive scale. Lot to see and great for photography.

Magical place. If you are there when the crowds have gone else where there is a magical quality to the place. The architecture is interesting it is in very good condition. It is one of the highlights of the park.
Amazing!. Incredible. The history is so rich. Our guide was a huge help in learning all this history.
So good. Probably my best temple, just so gret to look at the detail, really amazing.
amazing place. This place is not to be missed - a person with an enigmatic smile struck me the most

The faces stare at you and feel alive. We decided to explore the Angkorian site in three days and leave Angkor Wat, the largest and most popular in the world, for the last day.  Bayon was our first stop.  It’s one of the most unique structures with magnificent design elements throughout.  As we rode our bikes around all sides we encountered huge Gothic towers decorated with enormous smiling faces staring down at you while exuding this immense power.  Upon entering the three levels inside Bayon, we were mesmerized by the detailed carvings on the walls depicting important events that occurred during the Khmer empire.Read about our entire Angkor Temples experience at http://www.culturecats.com/2012/02/14/temples-of-angkor/

The very center of what was once the largest city in the world. The Bayon temple is right in the middle of Angkor Thom, the immense city built by Jayavarman VII. At first sight, it's shape is difficult to grasp, it is a very complex structure.Apart from the location and the historical meaning, two features make this temple absolutely extraordinary. First, the immense series of reliefs with rich and amazing detail (warfare with the Chams, daily life, ...) require a patient and diligent visit; second, the upper level with the towers where over 200 smiling faces look in the four cardinal directions. Strolling through these mysterious sculptures on the central plateau under a brilliant sun is an unforgettable experience. Take your time!Even in the 'cold', dry season, the place is quite hot in the middle of the day, there's almost no breeze. If possible, visit the temple in the early morning or late afternoon. That may, alas, also be the moments where massive groups of tourists invade the monument.
Awesome!. This is a must see if you are heading to Siem Reap. The history of this place is very interesting!

My favourite temple by far!. After spending the early morning seeing Angkor Wat, one may find it hard to imagine the even greater splendour awaiting you at the Bayon Temple.Firstly the drive / walk: you pass a river / stream with delicately carved stone elephants silently drinking only to be met by the real deal on arrival. I saw several tourists taking the unique opportunity to explore Bayon on elephant back and they really seemed to be enjoying the experience. We had a whistle-stop tour here so couldn't really take the time to indulge but even so took the opportunity to feed one resting in the shade and grab a few cheeky snaps for the family at home.Next the temple itself: wow!Its staggering to imagine that without the technology we have today, people performed the back breaking task of constructing such beauty. Despite the ever present Chinese tourist groups, I found the contrast of the benevolent faces, blue sky and green surroundings both peaceful and breathtaking. This is one not to be missed!!

Amazing. This is the first temple I visited and it was as impressive as any other temples in the area. The cravings and the statues are all very detailed. Definitely one of the must-see temple in Angkor.
Masterpiece of Angkor temples. The temple with the faces is just mindblowing!! For me the highlight of all temples we visited.
Amazing Structure!. built without any screws, bolts, nuts! make sure you come with a pair of comfortable shoes for some climbing.
Morning at Bayon. Make this your first stop in the morning and there'll be fewer or no people. When the morning light hits the faces on the east side, you'll get great pictures

Not to worthed. it's not good temple if you're compairing with Angkor Wat, Thom, etc. But if you already at Siem Reap, maybe you need to visit this temple for a while. Beware of local people who ask you to walk together. They'll ask for you money at the end of the walk.

authentic angkor experience. it doesn't feel as sterile as angkor way
it's slightly away from the tourist horde so you get mor time to wander
Impressive historical site. The statues and engravings in Bayon have been inspiration for the region for centuries.

WONDERFUL. This temple is really stunning as the Buddha faces on the top of the building structures are really haunting. This was the most busy temple to visit and there is much construction and repair going on.
Eye opener. Wonderful ruins and so much fine detail still in place. Try to go in at lunch time to avoid the tour bus loads of visitors.

Bayon........can sit here for days, it is captivating. The Bayon temple and the palace walls behind it are truly amazing. I could sit here and just gaze all day. The 4 heads on most of the structures are so similair from one pillar to another its hard to imagine how all this was done by hand with such precision. If your guide is good and shows you the best views, like through certain doorways and arches you have some of the most memorable photo opportunities ever.
nice. this temle is most interesting, and abit old but good for visiting and take care this
Just Beautiful. I am glad we went to this temple. It was amazing to see the hundreds of smiling faces carved into the towers. Beautiful temple - shouldn't miss.

Three levels of stone heads. Bayon is the major temple in the Angkor Thom complex and, to me, more interesting than the Angkor Wat temple. It is a bit of a climb to the top, but worth the effort. You walk through galleries of carved scenes of life at court in the 12th and 13th centuries and wars against various enemies. There are over 200 carved faces in the temple. It apparently began as a Buddhist temple. It was later turned into a Hindu temple before returning to being Buddhist. Each side of the base of Bayon is a bit over 600 feet across...twice the length of a football field. I hope to return here and spend more time just wandering through it. I did not realize the complexity of the temple and, because of time limitations, could not spend as much time as I would have liked. The book "Ancient Angkor' recommends a visit of 2 hours. 3 hours would be better because you could just sit and take it in at leisure. Unfortunately, I was there only about an hour. If I make it back to Siem Reap, I would do my sightseeing at a slower pace. I was here in early November 2011 and it was a bit hot. Take water with you as you go through the temples at this time of year. A friend was here in February 2012 and said the temperatures were in the 70s and quite comfortable.
Bayon temple - brilliant experience. a lot of carvings and faces carved in stone that makes you go WOW!

my favorite among the temples. this temple stood out among the others because the towers had the four faces of buddhas -- one each facing north, south, west and east. considering its age, the temple is in very good condition. the north and south gates were also good places for having your picture taken. overall, this is a temple you should not miss when you go to angkor.
smiling faces. impressive but very hot (was there in the afternoon)
Breathtaking!. From afar, the Bayon heads looked like lumps of rock but up close and up on the temple they were massive faces! It's my favourite site in the Angkor Archeaological Park.
excellent. With Ta Prohm, The best. this is one of the temples that is best preserved, and the faces make the experience special.
Amazing carvings. Get a guide who can explain the stories behind the carvings
Great Temple. Very busy in the mornings, great temple in the Angkor Thom complex. Many temples within walking distance of each other and sometimes monkeys that like to steal things from your bags.
One of the classic ruins of Angkor. Great place to spend several hours. Try to avoid the hoteest part of the day.
many faces. bas reliefs were fantastic & are at ground level-however because there are no directions we took some time to locate them
Wonderful place. This is an amazind site. The only problem is tourist groups, and it is difficult to plan in order to avoid them. The bas relief, the faces are incredible.

Bayon temple with 4 faces. I like Bayon temple of 4 faces of Avalokitesvara, Boddhisatva, the temple was built iin the center of Angkor Thom and it best view during rainy season when water come around the temple. Best photo of reflection all towers into water. The best time to visit is afternoon from 4:00PM some time before sunset.
Great in Angkor Thom area. the face of the temple represent Cambodian (Khmer) people.
The best. Don't miss it go early in the morning to avoid the crowds

Bayon is a must see. Bayon temple covers a large area; and with it's ancient ruins, small alleyways and incredible faces, this temple is not to be missed. One of the highlights of my temple visits. You may not be able to visit all the temples, but don't miss this one.

better than Angkor Wat. loved the unfinished look of it, the splendor of all the heads.
even liked it better than Angkor Wat
my favourite of all the temples: a must see!. go early to avoid the crowds...this is a most beautiful temple. Better than Angkor Wat in my opinion.
So many temples, so little time.... Most people wont get a chance to visit all of the temples of Angkor but Bayon is one not to miss!
great place to visit. nothing to dislike was all we expected it to be. the temples were old and the walks around the temples was breath taking

Go here for sunrise - remember a torch. Some people we met in Laos highly recommended going to Bayon for sunrise. It was rather eerie but beautiful. We stupidly forgot our torch to go into the temple but was still so amazing.

The Temple You Must See. .. .. ... The Bayon temple, in my opinion is the most incredible temple of the whole bunch. The many faces offer endless photo opportunities, and if you can get here early before the masses arrive, you can just chill out and enjoy the setting.

just another wonder of Angkor Wat. more treasures to be discovered and amazing reliefs and buildings. the discovery of an extraordinary culture, leaving a legacy like no other. Awe inspiring and in a beautiful surrounding.
amazing. I went two times to this place and really is a very good trip. You need take the driver two or three days and you ll enjoy the visit

amazing. Bayon Temple is a must for anyone traveling to Siem Reap. Although Angkor Wat is the main attraction ( and rightfully so) Bayon should not be missed by those with very limited time. It is simply amazing and breathtaking.

The Bayon is one of the most incredible photographic sites on the planet.. I have visited the Bayon many times over a number of years and I always look forward to my next visit. I know that I have not taken the best photo I can yet of the Bayon and probably never will. I also never tire of just sitting in the temple, contemplating life in general, marveling at the incredible faces,wondering what it was like a thousand years ago, and watching the new visitors absorb this incredible place.Put the Bayon on your list of things you must do and see (at least once, if not twice) in your life.
Just awesome. A great tranquil place not too crowded when i was there.the budas are amazing.
heads. loved all the heads . Wasn't too busy so we were able to soak in the atmosphere
