A lot of old Stones, very impressive. I was very surprised I was expecting to be surrounded by beggars in a crowded environment but it went very well. Weather was fine and people are very nice. L
I loved this temple. Beautiful temple with many faces - I could have spent hours walking around here. Definitely worth a visit
The best of the best. Suggest avoiding the crowds at dawn at Angkor Wat and head for this site and share it with a few people rather than crowds. It's spectacular in the early light.
King Jaya. An overwhelming sense of spirituality, the face of the the great King follows you everywhere.
My Favourite Temple. The style with the 54 towers each with a buddha's head facing the four compass points. Awe inspiring
Excellent.. Must have tour guide. Can pick one up at site. So much better when everything explained to you. Great spot for Xmas photos.
A Must!. Definitely needs to be one your list!
Faces of Buddha. It is still a beautiful temple despite the rain which is slowly washing the faces away. Go now!
Stunning!. This is a lovely temple to visit, smiling faces everywhere, and on a small enough scale that it is not as overwhelming as some of the other sites.

Bayon Temple. Fascinating;
Take headcover & plenty of water to keep hydrated
Beautiful temple. We went to this temple and loved it. The architecture was very unique. It's one of the more popular temples so there were many tourists here when we visited so expect some crowds.

A real effort is being made to keep the temple. I like Angkor during the rainy season.. the temples all look better to me wet..
Currently the 'ears' are undergoing repair

Great maze of faces. Wonderful site. Taking a guide definitely enhances the experience, but it would still be fun to explore on your own. We went at about 3pm. Even though it was the high season, it wasn't too crowded. Could be that late afternoon is the best time to go.

Beautiful ruins. I was in awe of this site. So much to take in between the bas-reliefs and the fantastic architecture. On par with Angkor Wat for sheer inspiration, but the smaller scale made for some crowded discomfort.

Mythological Bayon. This place it a beaufiful maze! I was practically playing hide and seek with my travel companion!This place is known for its massive serene stone faces built around may towers. The impression I get is very gothic and mythological. It feels very surreal to be walking the grounds of Bayon. This is definitely one of many thousands of Siem Reap's ancient temple to visit. You will see what I mean when you get there.

Faces all around. The hundred faces of Avalokitesvara sure were the main attraction of Bayon. You could also see an example of the tug-or-war statues at the gate. Oh, and the view from the backyard was good to take pics from, considering tourists flood the front.

Great elephant ride. Lovely temple. I managed to see most of the best bits even without having a guide. I learned about the elephant rides online (after having already done my visit). I went back early the following morning & managed to find where they started from & succeeded in getting a ride (all around the outside of Bayon Temple). I think I enjoyed Bayon more than Angkor Wat (which had lots of scaffolding which spoiled it a bit for me).
The Temple of Faces. A must see. The enigmatic stone faces make it even more interesting and cool than Angkor Wat!

Take your time, explore the whole place. Most people go right up to the top level of the temple, where the smiling faces rightfully become the main attraction of Bayon. This is great, but you will leave the place without fully appreciating it.Take the time to walk the whole temple, including the lower levels and the walls with bas relief carvings. I think that will complete your experience ...

Historical place. Very nature place, a lot of trees and historical architecture, don't miss out, must take a lot of photos, ask the tour guide and go through everything and their history, you will very enjoy.

Jayavarman VII's masterpiece. Bayon is the centerpiece of Angkor Thom. Wherever youare in this temple there are giant heads staring at you over200 in all. Bayon is unimpressive from the outside, but onceyou enter you'll be captivated. Be warned that there are verysteep stairways, but you should get to the highest level asthe rewards are great!
A Must See. If you have limited time for Angkor area then choose Bayon and Angkor Wat as a must see temples.
History. Fabulous old temple in very good condition. Worth a visit.
Not my favorite. Don't km\now why but this temple did not impress me. Go there in the evening.
My favorite temple at Angkor!. Bayon was fascinating and the experience was enhanced by having a great guide who helped us see the faces from different perspectives.

Best temple in Siem Reap complex. We saw many of the temples in Siem Reap, but Bayon is the one that will stay with me forever. There is something really awe inspiring about the gigantic smiling faces of Bayon. All the other temples have something special but when I think back of this place, Bayon is the first that comes to mind. I loved it and I am so happy to have seen it!You can do elephant tours of it for $25 but they seemed very very wobbly and a bit overpriced. There were some real apsara dancers there posing for photographs.

Great history. Be prepared to wear good walking shoes, light clothing & invest in sun protection.We, a group of 4 ladies, ages between early 40s to late 20s, visited it on 08th Feb. It was very hot & dusty - temperature 37 degrees. Lots of walking, climbing up/down the steep, narrow steps (not for the faint hearted). Also make sure your camera is fully charged - plenty of sights to capture!!!

Just Awesome!. Prasat Bayon is the lovely temple featuring more than 200 carved faces in the 54 spires of the temple, so this is the part most people go to see. The massive carvings are simply awesome. They're still so clearly detailed, even after more than a thousand years, and they really give the place a breathtaking appeal.Yet, the myriad of incredibly intricate carvings along the walls of the second and third levels are not to be missed. They depict some amazing parts of the Khmer history in stunning detail, showing battles being fought, and everyday life of hunting, cooking and even cock fighting. There's plenty to explore at this magnificent site, so wear comfortable walking shoes and take plenty of drinking water. Oh, and be sure your camera battery is fully charged. There are some brilliant photo opportunities here you don't want to miss.

Fantastic - Jaw Dropping.... Just a stunning example of a temple. Loved it. Got there early to avoid the crowds. Trust your tuk tuk driver and let him take you to some local places to eat off the beaten track.
Angkor Complex unforgettable. Excellent temple and complex, well worth the $20 entrance ticket!

Very interesting and you need good walking shoes and be prepared to climb a lot of steps. Great history and a guide is a must to get the best out of this place. There is a lot of walking and climbing of steps to see the various levels. Exhausting in the heat of the day.

THE JUNGLE BOOK!!. Amazing!! one of the most beautiful temples on this spectacular archeological park. Wonderful sunset from this spot. A paradise for photographers. It reminds me Mowgli, Baloo and Bagheera :)
Not to be missed. This site should be high on any sites to visit in Siem Reap. Do not miss.
Just as good as Angkor Wat...don't miss it. The faces will overwhelm you. I can't do it justice with words. Read about it on wikipedia and just get out there!

One of the most beautiful temples. If you have to pick just a few temples to see in Angkor, this is definitely one of them. What differs it from the others is the serenity of the stone faces which is actually well preserved. The stone faces are all over the place... amazing.
must see. no visit complete without a visit herewear comfortable shoes, bring lots of water

Someone watching over you?. My friends who have been to Siem Reap on tours to visit the temples often say that one can easily get an “over dose” of temples, and their conclusion is, that they ( meaning the temples) are all about the same! The truth is far from this.Unless you have a very special interest for ancient history, culture and architecture, it’s better with the limited time during a short visit to follow the advice of the Siem Reap’s Visitor’s Guide, “ Any itinerary should include the legendary Angkor Wat and Bayon.” This I did and added in the Ta Phrom made famous not only by the film Tomb Raiders, but is popular also by the massive fig and silk-cotton trees growing from the ruins.I visited the Bayon in the morning about 7.30 am with a Guide.The giant stone faces of the Bayon evoked a strange eerie feeling when I approached the site. More than 200 impassive faces on 54 towers appeared like sentinels guarding mysterious secrets of past events. Some researchers think that these are the faces of the bodhisattva Avalokitshvara, while others think they represent the king Jayavarman.The Bayon is built on three levels. The bas-reliefs on the exterior walls of both the first and second levels are worth spending some time looking at, as they depict the scenes from the historical battle between the Khmer and the Cham, and the scenes of everyday life. Scenes that can be clearly made out are naval battles, childbirth, hunting, marketing, cooking, men playing chess game, cock fighting, etc. View pictures attached.I went to the Bayon in the early morning to avoid the crowds, and noisy tourists. It’s cooler and the rising sun allows for more interesting photography with the light falling at an angle. I was fortunate I had a guide who knew many of the best angles to take pictures, and hence maximized the preciously short time I had. The previous day I visited Angkor Wat, and strangely did not expect the Bayon to be as, if not more, interesting than the former. Perhaps because the staring faces evoke some personal attention, the feeling of presence, that big brother is watching you! It's a photographer's dream to be there. Or simply sit and look, reflect, and imbibe the magic and mystery of the place.Tip: Go early morning when it’s cooler. Avoid the crowds. Bring walking shoes, a hat, and drinking water. Ensure that your camera battery is fully charged!

friendly faces. definitely my favorite temple of all, so many different face (52 if I'm not mistaken, representing the 52 provinces or something like that of Cambodia) and every face is facing in the direction of the province. Go early, skip the Angkor Wat and make this one your first visit - you'll have an amazing time there if you can wander around on your own!

MY FAVOURITE. This is the best temple in the whole Angkor Wat precinct, in my opinion. I was there early morning and there was a very ethereal feel to the place. Very 'picnic at hanging rock' if you know that Australian movie. The carvings were wonderful - the faces are amazing. A very peaceful place.
Good. Yes i had good time but difficult walkking.. Too much sun. Tuk tuk man was not smiling and left us and we were upset. Good view and too much sign

The second most photographed site in Siem Reap. Great restoration and makes for a great photo opportunity. The way that the ruins have been put together and maintained is fantastic. The scale is quite amazing. It may be somewhat difficult for the elderly to negotiate since some of the climbing is difficult, but has its rewards. Even an amateur photogrpaher like me would feel that once has turned professional after seeing the results.

great bayon. they dont make temples like they used to.How did they transport these stones to this location and build this magnificiant temples.the mind boggles at just the matematics of it all.Where are these peepole where did they go .
Amazing Bayon Temple. We had a great guide (Mr Bunny) so found out about the background. Wear covered shoulders please or you may not be allowed entry to the main part.

One of my favorites. Angkor Wat is big, beautiful and well-restored, but in Bayon temple you can feel its age. Walking around and through it, with all of the faces staring at you from all directions, it feels like you've just found it.

Magical. There are 54 faces of Buddha all watching over you as you walk through tunnels, passages and stairs in this thousand-year-old Khmer temple. It is absolutely magical. It helps to have a tour guide to explain the history, structure and carvings.
Smiling Buddha everywhere. A temple where you can see face of Buddha EVERYWHERE! :) come early in the morning as place got crowded towards noon.
Wonderful. The light is beautiful here. Make sure you have your shoulders and knees covered.
Faces everywhere. mountain-like structure is topped by 54 towers, each sporting four faces like the city's entrance gates.
Amazing Ruin - must see even with the crowds. Go early to avoid the crowds. Must see temple - the towers with faces on 4 sides seem to surprise at every turn.

Lots of history on the walls. Excellent carvings of how life was in ancient days, on the walls of the temple. Get a tour guide if you can on this trip - extremely helpful in explaining what the carvings are and learn about the history of the Khmer Empire in its hey days.
The Bayon Temple. Another great place you should not miss. I used to read about this place when I was a kid. Now I am there. it was what I expected, amazing.
Smile like Bayon. You'll love the place, get your cameras ready for the most distinctive feature, the multitude of serene and massive stone faces on the many towers - 216 gigantic faces.

Next to Angkor Wat but another world. For some reasons the teeming crowds that visit Angkor Wat don't seem to drift the few kilometres down the right to Bayon. Yet, Bayon is any many ways more beautiful than its more famous neighbour. For one it is on a more human scale. The Human element is also evident in the architecture with Bayon dominated by the beautiful sculptured heads of the Khmer king who built it. And being a buddhist (as opposed to Hindu) structure, it has a very different style throughout.

Great...but timing is EVERYTHING!. This is one of those places at Angkor that gets crowded. REALLY REALLY REALLY crowded. So time it to see really early before the horrid tour buses get there or later in the day when they are all at one of the preferred sunset spots. We had this place virtually to ourselves around dusk one evening. Truly amazing the way the light hits the faces from the west as the sun is setting. Whatever you do avoid this place between the hours of 9 and around 1. It's utterly pointless with the throngs or package tour-goers clamoring all over it...
Beautiful Faces Stone Sculpture. I love this place. All i can tell all the travelers is to go there and witness for yourself. You will not be disappointed.
Bayon temple it was built by the king Jayavarman vii in the end of 12 centurry. I like this temple because the face of buddha has a gentle smile to everywhere .
Bayon Temple. Spectacular, a great experience. You can overdose on temples but this is worth it.
My favorite, specially before sunset. So strange, so beautiful, a treasure. With a guide it is even more interesting to understand all the scenes made all around the bottom of the temple.
Magic !. We spent hours at sunset waiting to be alone with the smiling faces. And when the sun light goes, the huge smiling faces totally disappear. It's umbelievable, but it's true.

beautiful. It can't be hyped enough, this place is wonderful. My first time I didn't get there till early afternoon, and it was very crowded. Next I went around 9am and there were far fewer people, so peaceful I decided to take out my book, read, and try and soak up as much of the essence as I could. Went twice and will go again on my next trip to Cambodia.
Unmissable. Even if you are not a temple person this place will still move you. This was my 2nd visit

Someone is watching!. This temple is incredible as there are 216 enormous faces smiling eerily over all comers. Although it is quite large there is a real sense of individual space as you move between the various levels.Although you spend most of your time looking up, don't miss the bas reliefs on the first level.This was probably one of our favourites of the Temples of Angkor as it was quieter than Angkor Wat and seemed less touristy.

Fab but don't use the elephants. A great site but don't use the elephants as we heard they are not treated well, be careful about using the bikes as Angkor is a huge area and it could be exhausting in the heat. Bayon sits in the middle and is quite an incredible site to go round.

Incredible place to visit. We visited this temple twice, once in the morning and again in the late afternoon. Late afternoon was best as the lighting was better for photography and also there were less people. The bas reliefs around the outside walls are amazing and I missed them the first time. My son and I had a competition to see who could get the most faces into one photo shot. I would allow at least an hour and a half for this temple and don't rush, also worth walking around the outside for good views of the whole temple. Also loved the Apsara carvings in the pillars.

Go for the elephant ride - fantastic. Great first temple on our itinerary on a full day trip of the Angokor temples. Make sure you get there before 1000 if you want to ride an elephant around the temple as they head off for a break t for a few hours at 1030.

My main reason for going.... ...to Cambodia, to the Angkor Wat Complex, was to see the gigantic faces carved in the rock. They are so beautiful, so majestic, so unbelievable. Awe-inspiring! They are worth the price of admission all by themselves.
Don't skip Bayon in your temple tour.. One of the more interesting temple sites. It was easy to walk around with the kids and a lot of fun.

Must-see stop on any tour of the Angkor temples. The faces are the thing you will remember the most from this temple and they really are fantastic. The scale, height, condition and decoration on this temple make it a must-see stop on any tour of the Angkor temples. Along with Ta Prohm and Beng Melea, it was a top favorite. The kids really enjoyed climbing up it and seeing all the Buddha faces as well.
Amazing khmer temple. We where lucky to visit this temple during lunchtime. There where only 2 groups of tourists. We lost ourselves in this giantic labirynth. The kids and us loved it !
Up there with the best of them!. Awesome! 2nd only to the mighty Angkor Wat , need at least a couple of hours to have a good look around

Best temple in the complex. The entire temple complex was nice, but Bayon temple was by far my favorite. It was smaller than some but absolutely beautiful. A pleasure to take in, I must have took most of my pictures there (none of which I can upload right now). My camera's battery died on me that day and I just continued with my cell phone cam. Don't leave the complex without seeing this one, I really enjoyed every minute spent in there.
Amazing. 2nd trip there and just as amazing as the first - get there early to avoid the crowds
More stunning than Angkor Wat?. Yes, I dare say. A striking temple. The Angkor smile on 216 faces. Stunning.

Favorite temple in Siem Reap!. Angkor Wat is spectacular, but Bayon was my favorite temple of our trip to Siem Reap because it was a little easier to take in (smaller than Angkor Wat) and the sculptural reliefs on the towers was really breathtaking. There is a face for each province of Cambodia, which is quite cool. A lot of the photos we saw in advertisements around Cambodia are from Bayon. It's definitely a must see if you are going to see Angkor Wat!
We will return!. We had no idea we would be so captured. It was a bit hot for us so we did not explore, as planned, by bicycle, but did rent a tuk tuk.,
Stunning, a gem in the world. Words can not describe the beauty of this site. It is absolutely breathtaking and in pretty good condition considering what the country has been through.
Speechless. Wow, what can I say. This is definitely a highlight of our trip and it shows the best of Angkor architecture. We loved it more than Angkor Wat
Amazing. This place is amazing. It is one of the best preserved sites in the complex.
Awesome!. The temple is a highlight of the whole Angkor Thom complex... beautiful and as well preserved as it can be...

On par with Angkor Wat. After a while, all the temples in Angkor look the same... Except for Bayon.
It's super easy to remember this temple, and looks the best in photographs as Bayon Temple has large faces on the architecture! It's like stepping into an adventure movie. Loved this place, and will probably remember it more than Angkor Wat.
Better than Angkor Wat. its smaller and so much more peaceful. Try to get there real early when there are less people

Favourite Temple. The 4 faces of Buddha looking benignly down upon you from the multiple towers at this temple are incredible - definitely my favorite temple in the Angkor complex. Could spend hours here.

My favorite. The Bayon is my favorite in the Angkor Archeological Park. Great place to just roam around taking pictures and admiring the handy work of the ancients. Not a lot of shade here so be careful. Stairs are also rather steep in places. I am usually there for a couple of hours minimum. Beautiful spot.
Don't miss it. Although Angkor Wat is the most well known attraction, it would be a waste of your trip if you missed this!
Enigmatic. Compact temple within the confines of Angkor Thom with enigmatic faces on many of the twoers

He's everywhere I look!. Bayon is amazing, just to see how many times the same face is repeated over and over again. Bring water and be prepared to climb a lot of stairs. Pay for a guide - you'll find each spot so much more meaningful
sensational. our second favourite - the three headed elephant, teh five headed horse - the fantastic carved story walls. A must see !
Best of the lot. Carvings are amazing and fairly well maintained and restored
13th Century Temple. Terrace of the elephants and Leper King all very interesting.
Inspirational Temple. Loved the Buddha heads silhoetted against the sky.
Beautiful!. Just amazing, a must see! A nice temple with lots of history!
Elephants. Take the elephant tour! The gorgeous animals take you round the circuit, and you get to feed them bananas!
great!. go early and avoid the loud tour groups take a private tour guide if you can.
My personal favourite. I found this temple the most interesting architecturally of all we visited. If you visit, allow time time to ride an elephant while you are there and watch out for the monekys.
Must see.. The haunting faces and detailed carvings provide a fascinating experience and some amazing photos.

Magic in the Temple!. Bayon Temple is magical, with faces looking around and the sunlight coming in. Visit in the early morning to enjoy the peaceful atmosphere and avoid crowds. After Bayon, visit Baphoun and the Elephant Terraces nearby.
Great Heritage. I have been dreaming to step on this place long ago. was told i can't go the day i plan to go due to heavy flood. At last, I made it. My dream comes true
Don't miss !. Like a 1000 year old Mad Max temple, small enough but varied to suit all tastes and expectations. Great.
Amazing. These temples are amazing to see and have a serenity about them.

Excellent & not to be missed-go in the afternoon to avoid the crowds!. Bayon temple is part of the amazing Angkor Thom complex, situated in the heart of Siem Reap. A short distance away from the main attraction, Angkor Wat temple, it is the first of 7 temples in the tourist complex, right after you are dropped off by your tuk-tuk driver. After Bayon, you continue walking on to several more temples(which includes the Elephant terrace), each progressively getting smaller & smaller, till you finally exit the gate where the tuk tuk drivers are waiting. Since there are already so many reviews & the pictures themselves say a thousand words, I will restrict my review to just a few tips that others might find useful:1.Enter at the East Gate & work your way to the other temples after viewing Bayon-as mentioned, Bayon is the best preserved one, the others getting progressively smaller in size. You could do it the other way, but after a couple of hours walking, you would probably be too exhausted to really appreciate the beauty of the temple. In this case, save the best for first!2. There is lots & lots of walking! And steep climbing too. At one point, in one of the temples, we saw a sign that said children under the age of 12 are not allowed to climb up the uppermost viewing platform. The climbs up are very steep & I think it’s a great idea to restrict children below a certain age, in case they fall. Both going up & coming down all those temples there are by incredibly narrow stairs. Definitely no place for a young child or anyone who needs help walking.3. Be dressed appropriately. These are temples & though there is no real dress code, there are signs that ask you to cover up. We actually saw the guard pull someone from the line because she had on a tank top & a tiny pair of shorts. Best attire would be a t-shirt, capris & sneakers- all the people dressed that way were let through, so I guess the length of the shorts & the tiny tank top she had on was the problem. Imagine making it all the way to Bayon & then not being able to climb up to get the magnificent views from the top.We really liked Bayon- its calm & serene & not the hub of activity that Angkor Wat is. Schedule at least 3-4 hours, get your hats & water, get ready for plenty of walking & enjoy. The beauty is simple breathtaking!One more tip- go in the early morning or late afternoon- we were there late afternoon after lunch & it was fairly devoid of tourists(as the pictures show!)
Beautiful. Lovely spot, part of the Seim Reap experience, go early, avoid crowds and heat
Beautiful!. This temple was stunning- really worth a visit, as it the whole Angkor Thom complex
Lost in your own world. Once you venture into these temples you get a sense of tranquillity and feel like you’re the only one there.....you forget about the outside world....
Definitely worth a visit!. The temples at Angkor were all different in style. Bayon has its own uniqueness and definitely worth the visit.

Smiles. This is a must see. There are elephants that will take you from just outside the S. Gate all way to the Bayan Temple for about $12. The elephants are a real treat and are a rare site in Cambodia in modern times.
Great place to visit!. One of the great temple areas to visit! I would not miss this temple on a visit to Angkor Wat!
Second best ruins to visit. Very detailed stone carvings. Entry for three days was $40 versus $20 for 1 day. You can not see the several major temples in 1 day.

A very interesting temple that everyone must see!. There were still some construction going on, to rebuild the destroyed ruins, but it is definitely worth to visit and take pics.
But on your way into the temple, be very careful of fine sands, if theres a wind, it might hurt your eyes, so bring your sunglasses and wear flip flops

I might like this even more than Angkor Wat. All the beauty, without all of the crowd. Definitely worth climbing to the top if your knees can bear it. The lovely trees and detail make this place a true piece of art. With all of the lovely temples Siem Reap has to offer, this one holds a special place in my art. Don't miss it.
Temple to see. this was the fist temple on our tour and a must see for Angkor
a must see. amazing temple, fascinating freezes and lots of smiling buddha faces! Great

Jaw-dropping. Purely a personal opinion, but edged it over Angkor Wat for me. The bad-:reliefs on the lower levels are absolutely stunning and the giant faces in the top, third level are phenomenal. Quite simply, this is a location to justly rank alongside the Great Pyramid, Petra, Ephesus and others. Allow yourself plenty of time to explore.
Evocative Plus. Wonderful site, even if the hordes ot tourists are pressing
Fantastique!!!. It is simply a visual feast!!! Nothing compares to the scope and magnitude of this magnificent architectural imposing piece of history.
croweded. there are dozens of tourist groups during the day. go early (6AM) or not.
Great site. Great Temple, lots to see and explore, and very easy to get to.
Bayon temple. The faces of Bayon are awe-inspiring and mesmorizing. Not to be missed on a tour of Angkor Wat area.

Stunning. Most travellers visit Siem Reap to visit the Angkor Complex, and this temple is a wonderful place to visit. It's fascinating and grand. At the moment (Jan 2012), there is some restoration in progress, with cranes and workers around - I personally think it would be better to see in its 'original' state before it has been rebuilt, so go quickly!
Temples. These temples are just indescribable, and must be seen to be beleived
Preferred to Ankor Wat. This was an impresive temple and not as busy as the main attraction. It isn't as intricately carved but is interesting to walk around.
Incredible!!!. This temple is known for it's many, many faces! It is an incredible sight and one of more intricate in it's construction. Some amazing photo opportunities!
Temples. Truly a World Heritage Site. This temples is one in a series of elaborate temples spread over a vast area.
Awesome temple ruined by the crowds. This temple is arguably the most impressive of the lot. However, it is ruined by the throngs of crowds. Get their early to fully appreciate its splendour
My favourite Angkor temple. It was such a surprise, so different to the Angkor Wat. Smaller but equally impresive
Visited every time in Siem Reap. Been there 5 times, still an amazing space every time.

So many faces that you can not hide from them. So many faces that you can not hide from them. Small yoke.A beautiful temple, and just can not say which is more beautiful than whom in the whole complex. They are all beautiful to me.
Historical Maze. Everything was great, it was a bit crowded and we kind of got lost but all in all it was really fun.
Towers sporting large faces in each cardinal direction. One of the deservedly famous temples. The 37 remaining towers each have 4 large carved faces looking out to the north, south, east and west.

Best of the temples!. This was my favorite temple in Siem Reap. The faces are amazing and there are a ton of amazing photo opportunities. We went early afternoon and there were definitely crowds at that time but still my favorite.
Amazing faces of serenity. The half smiling faces look great at sunrise. One of the most impressive temples with Giant buddhas nearby.

Must not miss!. If you have limited time in Siem Reap to visit the temples, then Bayon is one of the MUST SEE temples (others being Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm, and Bantaey Kdei). So much history carved on the walls and those faces...well, you won't see it anywhere else!
More of my review here: http://www.excursionista.net/2012/01/exploring-indochina-angkor-thom-bayon.html

Very good. I'm not really into ruins and temples and architecture - nature is my thing. But the Bayon Temple is really spectacular when you think that it was all built so long ago and without any modern machinery. The huge faces on all sides of the temples are well worth seeing.

Iconic. Loved the Avalokiteshvara visages on the different faces.
Best time to visit would be early morning
Becomes rather crowded with droves of tourists as the day progresses

Spiritual. This was one of my favourite temples in Siem Reap. Truly truly truly amazing.
Like nothing I had ever seen before - huge enigmatic stone faces hidden deep within a tropical forest..
For a more detailed account of my visit to Siem Reap, you can check out my travel blog at http://audreylovestotravel.blogspot.com/2011/12/sojourn-in-siem-reap.html
the trees are fantastic. The roots growing over the temples are amazing. There isn't a lot of shade here though...
Smiling Buddha. Just go there. The amazing Buddha faces and the smiling one as well. It is an out of this earth feeling

Our Favorite Site in Siem Reap Area. The Bayon is just awesome. We liked it so much we went to it twice. The first time it was in the morning, and it was so crowded with tourists that we didn't really get to take it all in. The second time we went back it was very late afternoon, and since the Bayon is not a "sunset hot spot" we practically had the place to ourselves. Worth skipping the craziness of trying to get a sunset picture in exchange for enjoying an ancient site almost to yourselves!
Amazing. You can easily spend hours here, particularly in the afternoon when the light is so wonderful. The faces are so spectacular. We were all entralled.

Intriguiging. This is the first temple we went to and thoroughly enjoyed our trip here. This temple has a lot of character and the towers are very interesting. We explored the entire temple during our visit and were aided by our Guide "Tiger" who did a good job of explaining the temple architecture and history.
Bayon Temple. This Bayon Temple is really amazing. It's smiling faces is really cute. and the trip is very worth it. best to go around 6-7am..
Morning temple. Great for photos early in the morning when most people are eating breakfast after the sunrise at Angkor wat.

Breathtaking. Had a tour guide the first time and was just amazed at how these structures were constructed. The second time I saw it was from an elephant ride around the temple and still blown away by these massive concrete faces.

Incredible!. The bas reliefs at Bayon are out of this world! Definitely buy a guide book which explains all the different features of the temple and tells the stories of the bas relief carvings. In my opinion, Bayon is better than Angkor Wat!

Among the met interesting temple with Ta Prohm. This temple is just amazing. Watever you look around, you can see mysterious faces. I advice you to go there between 12.30pm and 2pm. Less people than earlier or later during the day. All the groups get back to Siem Reap for having lunch. Au that moment this is peaceful and with a nice light for taking pictures

All Smiles on You. Very different from Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm, Banteau Srei. A must see. P.S. Don't forget to get a nose-to-nose pic with one of the faces. Precious! Ask your guide for the right "spot"!

A must see!. Words can not describe. Most gorgeous of the Buddhist temples in my opinion. If you are in Siem Reap, take the time to step into this wonder. Go early before the crowds....6am, the lighting is fantastic!
Bayon Temple. The site was fantastic and like the others nearby, just amazing in it's own way.
Outstanding. Visited early in the morning and was blown away by this place. My advice is get here before the crowds and enjoy the peace and quiet

We enjoyed Bayon more than Angkor Wat!. Lots of history- really go with a good legitimate Cambodian tour guide who can interpret the carvings for you. The carvings at Bayon depict real life in he Khmer empire not just Hindu lore.

Best Temple in Cambodia. I am sure many will challenge me, but I preferred the Bayon Temple to Angkor Wat. I visited Bayon first and found the symmetry of AW to be impressive, but preferred Bayon for its character and faces.

Subtle smile. This was the last temple for us to visit and having been in awe at Ta Prohm and the TREES I never thought that I will see something more intriguing...I realized how wrong I was from the moment I laid eyes on the towers of Bayon or from the moment the Tower laid eyes on me. The subtle smile on their faces is captivating.
Fabulous example of Khmer Ingenuity. Inevitably very crowded but an absolute must to visit.
Being watched from every angle. The number of towers and four sided faces looking out at you is a must to see.
Beautiful temple. Amazing carvings with so much details and history.
dawn at Bayon Temple. Lots of 3-dimensional carvings; quiet, peaceful setting.
AMAZING. well worth the vist, allow plenty of time, the zize, the history all overpowering.

stunning, monumental artistry. We travelled on elephants down the main boulevard of the temple complex to arrive at the Bayon Temple. It is surrounded by trees and jungle and is in the most beautiful location. The enormous blocks of masonry are carved into figures of four faceted heads. The best time to visit is early as the sun is coming up. I think this was my favourite temple in Angkor
Wow. Maybe our favorite temple - so cool! It's a bit crowded, but we loved it.
You wont be disappointed. If you are there chances you know what you came for, and it doesn't disappoint. Get there early and enjoy!
Mindblowing. Just go there and marvel at it! It is a beautful place and quite unique.
Amazing. Definitely worth the day trip there - try and go there during winter, it would be ridiculously hot out there during summer.
the fallen empire. This is one of my favourite temples - bantay srey is the other.
A Masterpiece. All the faces make this place seem unreal. An architectural work of art.

Loved it!. Intially from the pictures in guide books, the huge imposing faces looked rather eerie but it turned out to be my favourite temple in Siem Reap. Some parts of the ground are run down and need to be treaded on carefully but it is a beautiful temple with lovely carvings and the little nooks and cranies make it rather interesting to explore.

Wonderful photo opportunities and one of my favourites in Siem Reap. I really liked this smallish temple located in the complex Angkor Thom as it was really unique with the four faces on each of the "columns" . Though this was one of the newer temples, it is certainly one of the more interesting ones to photograph. There are several "cool photo spots" where one can be photographed "kissing the face or some other interesting pose. Look out for the interesting wall carvings that depict the history of the Khmer people including evidence of Chinese influence and invasion of the CHAM empire.
Great Handling Heritage. Selamat Buat pemerintah Kamboja yang telah begitu baik dalam mempertahankan dan merawat Temple2 di Kamboja
bayan temple. the faces! who are you? go and see for yourself, very popular so expect lots of tourists but still worth every minute.
Awesome Temple. Must see temple in a long list of must sees at Angkor Wat

My favourite temple. You will see many temples on your visit to Cambodia but this will definitely stand out in your memory. There are over 200 giant smiling faces beaming at you. When we visited we were met by some aspara dancers in beautiful costumes offering a photo opportunity for a contribution of course. Our visit was topped off with an elephant ride around the complex costing $15. The elephants seemed to be treated well we noticed they actually had regular breaks.
A place to see sunset. Maybe the most crowded place to see the sunset,but worth it.
Beautiful Bayon. This was a highlight for me rather than Angkor Wat
Angkor Thom's famous main temple. We enjoyed this very much - totally different and "genuine" compared to Angkor Wat. It's a small temple compared to Wat but the smiling faces was fantastic.
Outstanding! Nothing can describe!. Truely amazing! Very crowded but amazing. Try to get there early if possible to avoid the crods
Beautiful Temple. This was one of our first temples that we visited with our guide. It was so breathtaking.
The "face" of Angkor Thom. I really enjoyed the face-towers at the Bayon temple. This is the main attraction inside Angkor Thom so don't miss it!
Beautiful!!. The guys that built this thousands of years ago were fairly handy at the ol brickwork!!
It's the most beautiful of all.. Hard to describe. It is so unique, and very nice for pictures.

A little eerie, but amazing!. This is definitely one temple you shouldn't miss when visiting the Angkor Temples. You can even ride an elephant to the temple...although it's a quite a bumpy ride. The hundreds of faces make this temple fascinatingly eerie. A definite must see!
Lunchtime Photography. Fantastic temple, probably my favourite. Best photos to be had during the hours of lunch. A must see.
Not to miss. No trip to the Angkor temples would be complete without visiting Bayon. One of the highlights

Beautiful ruins. The Bayon Temple is a place to visit if you're in Siem Reap, besides Angkor Wat. Unlike Angkor Wat (which was built 100 years earlier), Bayon is in a worse shape than Angkor Wat (lots of fallen pillars and stone slabs). But that makes it a very beautiful opportunity for nice pictures too.

Its so beautiful but too busy. We came here 8 years ago and this place was amazing, breathtaking. Now crawling with people, mobile phones ringing constantly, loud tourist groups. Awful, ruined experience

Simply the best temple of all. This temple is simply amazing to me. One of the temple which I have vowed to come back here again the next time around to go through every corner and perhaps spend at least half a day here. Try climbing up the smaller 'rooms' to get an eye level view of the faces and you'll be amazed by how ancient people built all of these.
Great Temple.. Banypn trees grow within the temple walls. Like Tomb Raider style scenery. Awesome..
Astounding. Very different and quite awe inspiring - a real insight into how power can be used/abused
Lovely. I thought this was one of the nicest temples and it was great to visit

One thousand smiling faces welcome you here. I was in this temple in 2008. The temple is simply amazing and it could take about half day to see it slowly and enjoying it fully. You can take a guide to show you around, but you can do it yourself id you have a good guidebook (so you're sure to not miss places). I suggest to see it at early morning as at midday the stones are far too hot and you feel like being exloring an hoven.

Very cool temple, but really crowded. We visited Angkor with a group, and many people thought Bayon was their favorite temple of the bunch. It has a unique and interesting style, with dozens of towers topped by smiling Buddha faces (four per tower, one facing each of the cardinal directions). The effect of this design is very impressive and though there is a lot of work needed and ongoing, the temple is in a suitably good state of preservation to appreciate it. If you have time to see more than just Angkor Wat then Bayon should be next on your list.The downside is that this is a fairly small temple, especially compared to a place like Angkor Wat, and because of it's unique style it is a popular stop for tourists. This combination means that the place can be a zoo. This was one of the most crowded tourist attractions I've been to anywhere. We were there during the morning rush and it was extremely difficult to walk around or get a nice picture. I've heard that it can be less crowded at lunch time or late afternoon, but cannot confirm. Go in expecting the worst and you may be pleasantly surprised.
The Most tranquil of all temples. Both myself and daughter felt such peace at Bayon temple that we did not experience at the other temples

awesome. We had a private, local guide who took us to areas that were perfect for pictures. I loved this site. In one picture, I was framed in a doorway whereby my nose was touching (in the picture) the nose of the face on that tower.

Bayon - A Walk Thru Ancient Cambodian Life. The carvings which told the story of ancient Cambodian life was fantastic. We were amazed at the level of access available to the temple, and were delighted with being able to take our time to experience the history and culture of the place. I would have like the added safety of stair rails on the more of the modern stairs that have been added to provide visitor access.

The allure of a human gaze !. You can see pictures and read about Bayon. And after you've been there, you'll continue seeing more pictures - just to remind you of those wonderful moments - when you walked around those amazing - absolutely magical faces - jayavarman was on a trip when he conceived these - and so was I when I visited here. I would love to go back again some years down the road and see them again !!
Marvelous. This is a must see in Siem Peap. So beautifull. The towers have the face of a king on all sides. Such an invention at the time.
Interesting. The size and splendor of this temple is unlike anything i have ever seen. Must visit
ok, as temples go. you see one temple, you've seen the all. the only exceptional temple during my one day tour of angor wat was the one with all of the trees that have grown into the temple walls.
Amazing. The Bayon Temple in Angkor Thom was so mind blowing. It was one of my favorites besides Ta Prohm.

Amazing Temple. Bayon is one of the jewels of the Angkor complex. We were especially thrilled by the entranceway, which is flanked by 54 gods on one side and 54 demons on the other. It is truly a marvel.
Bayon. It was very interesting and has a great feel but is very busy!

Magnificient Awesome. The Bayon Temple is awe inspiring; it takes your breath away. If you manage to get there when there are few other travellers and have time to sit and take in the many huge carved faces, it is truly exceptional to observe.
Amazing sight. This is a must see for all tourists. an amazing look into tha past. Loved all of it
Magnificent temple. Intricate stone temple with beautiful carvings reclaimed from the jungle surroundings.
Fantastic. Temples in the Angkor Complex are a must see!!! Fantastic!
Beautiful. What to say, you can stay here for hours just looking every single corner or making pictures. Absolutely beautiful.
One of the most interesting sites. Simply amazing and worth the visit on its own. Besutiful masks

Exceeded my high expectations. Angkor Thom is the lesser known temple just past Angkor Wat and I actually liked it better than Angkor Wat. Lots of great photo opportunities inside the temple, and so much history. You may be tempted to just buy the book and wonder around on your own, but I definitely recommend a tour guide. They will show you the best spots for a picture and are excellent photographers. They will also give you a great history lesson and can answer just about any questions you have. I would not recommend that you book through a tour agency or hotel though. The packages are over priced. Just book a guide for $30 for the entire day, and travel buy tuk tuk. On top of that its $20 per person for one day at the temples ($40 for 3 days). If you book through an agency you end up having to pay for this temple passes anyway! Save the money and give your guide a bigger tip.
A must. Angkor wat is beautiful. Bayon is more impressive.
Great!. It's one of our favorites in siem reap. Besides bantrey srei, Angkor wat and TA phrom.
Can't get enough. Simply awesome. The place is so wholesome and feels like I am in heaven

The best of the best temple complex in the world.. The Angkor complex is a must-see, and Bayon is the best temple there. Try to count the unique faces carved into the stone. It's simply an amazing feat of architecture, design and human triumph.
Awesome. Great Adventure in Cambodia. We went at sunrise and it was everything we expceted.
Photogenic. Bayon is second only to Ta Prohm for great photo ops. And you can't help but smile back at all those big stone happy faces.

They're watching you...!!. The Bayon Temple is a wonderful piece of architecture, delicately arranged so there's a face around every corner.. everywhere you go you are being watched! The Khmer people have built some magnificent structures in their time and this is certainly one of them.
Four faces. This temple is very different from the other temples. It has the 4 faces statues and most distinctive feature is the serene and massive stone faces on the many towers. Worth a visit.

Beautiful temple for both size and detail. This would have to be the 2nd best temple behind Angkor Wat. I would recommend going to see Angkor Wat at sunrise and coming after so you can beat the armies of overenthusiastic Asian tourists with their cameras. This temple is beautiful. It has the size of Angkor Wat but the finer detail of Banteay Srey. Loved it.
great. I likeSmile of the Buddha. whatever we go ,we can see the smile.
Faces, faces, faces. One of our favorite temples around Angkor. Very popular so difficult to get one of the famous "nose to nose" shots. Still not to be missed.

enthousiastic for Photographer. Good opportunity to take pictures on the sunset
Too crowded by Tour from US and JAPAN
Nice view. Nice view from the lake outside. We took plenty of pictures from there. The smiling statues are amazing.
Great place to visit. If you look carefully, apparently all the faces are different. That was pretty cool and oddly peaceful.

The Bayon/Angkor Thom Temple is a must to visit. Visiting the Bayon/Angkor Thom Temple is a must even if you could only spare half a day. Snap a nice picture of you standing next to the smiling Bayon. It is worth your time and effort to climb up those uneven stairs to get up to the top floor.

Megalithic Stone Buddha Heads are Mind Blowing. Allow ample time to stay and contemplate these enormous benevolent stone jinga puzzle faces. It's extremely facinating, exhiliarating and calming all at the same time. Remember to breathe!

Amazing Place ! Must visit !. Certainly a mystical place...with all that faces carved in the temple walls. Some great angles where you can position your subjects "face to face, lip to lip" with the sculpture. I thought all temples are alike ...but each temple has it's unique characteristics to keep you entralled ...and Bayon is 1 of my fave !!
Unbelievable. Please make this a stop, if you are not in a group tour. A must see...
Don't miss!. Spectacular temple and our favourite. Not to be missed. Try go early to avoid major crowds, but worthwhile at any time of day.
Totally gorgeous. Fantastic, such impact from the multi-faced temples, absolute must see if you are in Siem Reap on the temple path.

Atmospheric temple with wonderful friezes. We went there in the late afternoon when the cicadas were deafening. There were hardly any other visitors there but we enjoyed seeing the elephants with their handlers on the approach road, obviously there to give rides to tourists. The outstanding feature of this temple is the dozens of versions of the smiling face of the king who built it, each smile different from the last, carved on the towers. I was also amused by the stories of everyday life depicted in the astonishing friezes, which bring the past very much closer to the present day for the viewer.
bayon temple takes your breath away.. they dont make them like they used to.there is no comparable mode like this anywhere else.
Looks just like the postcards.. We saw a lot of the,plea today and all were unique. Make sure you have a guide as it makes the day complete. Our guide was from buffalo tours and was awesome,
Wonderful Temple. Certainly its rich in architecture that no present architects are able to come up with something as close as the temples found in Bayon.
Super faces. This temple comples is full of huge faces. The central temple is great. Walk around it at least twice. Then go to the elephant terrace. Nice.

Truly Mesmerised.... A place of true wonder and enchantment, not to be missed if you're visiting Siem Reap. Life is truly cast in stone and i can't help but become mesmerised by the brilliance of an ancient culture. Unforgettable!
Excellent state. Try to count all the faces!!! And look at them properly, some are smiling, some smirking and some are almost scary...
A must visit site. The most impressive of the temples, just loved those faces!

Spooky and wonderful. If you ever wanted to stare into the face of Buddha or a godlike king, this must certainly be the place for it.
It's still an actively used temple, venerated by locals and visitors alike, leading to a sense of continuum through the centuries that only the most spiritual of locations can muster.
A MUST SEE!
The Best. An amazing experience, spend time there and soak up the history.
Breathtaking!. I could have spent many many more hours just walking around this temple and taking in the beautiful architecture!! :)
fantastic. everything was an experience to the eye. A magical place.
Good to see many faces of Jeyavarman VI. Good place to visit and to know the last Angkor dynasty

A sense of serenity and tranquility.. I am not such a religious person but while my friend decide to climb up to the top of this temple, I decided to find a quiet spot in the temple to rest my feet. Then I felt it...... A sense of peace and tranquility. Not sure why ..... Didn't felt it while I was on the temples visits in Bali nor even in Angkor Wat ....... Not sure whether you will have the same experience but I love it.

Worth a see.. Camdoia and surrounding nations are mainly Buddist now but it was not always so. This early temple is a must see along with mnay others in Cambodia to gain an understanding of the country
Fantastic. Loved them all! The temples were just an amazing experience and one I would not have missed.

Smile of Angkor. Faces, faces and more faces. Small faces, big faces, humongous faces. All with that wise, peaceful trademark smile. The steps can be tricky and the sunlight when directly above can be punishing. But time it right and it's an exhilarating experience to walk around the place. We had loads fun trying to guess the number of faces we could count from any one point.

SIMPLY EXTRAODINARY. I was amazed to see the temple. It had me wondering how the artisans of that era managed to create such a wonder. we had a photo shoot with nose touch- highlight of the place. is this s smiling Buddha or Jayavarman VII / Avolokiteswara

Fabulous.. The low light of the sun makes everything even more magical.Brutal Russian tourists asking everyone to move aside for a picture are extremely annoying in such a peaceful and beautiful place.
so nice. this temple is special with more than200 faces.small but amasing.
Amazing, beautiful temple. This temple is beautiful, with some sun, there is no doubt you will love it. It is just amazing how a temple like that has been built and it really worth it.
Fabulous. Each of the temples is beautiful in a different way. The steps can be tricky but it is well worth it.

good. its a temple jimall of angkor complex is stunning , but the hoards of tourists does make quite an unpleasant experience.chinese people have no ability not to shout , spit and ruin these temples. they come in a hoard and if you arrive after them , the experience is ruined .they push , get in the way and are repunant in their littering !!!!go early for sunrise to angkor wat and start moving on, because by 9 the hoards arrive ruining it

Beautiful Buddhist Temple with smiling faces !. This was my favourite of all the Angkor temples. They call it the temple of 1,000 faces. And they are not wrong. You cannot help but be overwhelmed by its beauty !

Happiness!. It gives immense happiness to see so many smiling Buddhas at one location. The site is magnificient to behold. I hope this brings lot of peace and happiness to the visitors as well as the inhabitants of Siem Reap!

Amazing- History comes to live. We're lucky they found these ruins/temples. What an amazing experience. There's a little bit of walking around, and it's packed with tourists but so so so worth the visit
Charming Bayon. Bayon Temple is so beautiful; It's a must see if you are in Angkor area. One of our favorites.
Go and visit it!. So interesting! Great time of the year to see it not too hot. We had a guide which was very worth while

My favourite temple in the Siem Reap region. Well, I think the title says it all. The sight of the multi faces is something to experience, despite the crowds. Try to visit at different time of the days to see the temple under different lights. The best is when the surrounding moats are still full and the temple is reflected in the water.

perhaps the second most significant temple. after Angkor Wat, only a couple of kilometers further, great at the end of the day, half an hour to 2 hours is the right amount of time, less than other temples

Like nothing else you've seen. We spent the whole day at the Angkor temples and Bayon was the only one we returned to a couple of days later. The temple is one of the biggest in Angkor Thom and has numerous peaks which all convey a 4-sided face of Shiva. Impossibly photogenic and great for just wandering about in through the dark corridors at the base and the wider areas at the top.
Be stunning by greetings with mystic smile faces of Avalokitesavara. It is a must-see in Angkor Thom compound. Walking up to the top of Prasat and enjoy a pool with young geese family
amazing structure. blown away by the whole temple and can't really begin to imagine how it was built so long ago with no modern implements
One of my favourite places on the planet. Go before dawn, with a torch, and simply stand, listen and wait...
Mind boggling. Do have a guide - there is so much to be explained
Amazing faces. Amazing faces all over the temple complex. Nice carvings. A lot to climb on.

Every face tells a story. Nothing to dislike here. Wonderful temple to visit with those incredible faces gazing out offering so many photo opportunities. The look on some of the faces is simply enchanting and bewitching, the slight upward curve of the lips as though they are smiling gently at some private joke.Lovely setting amongst the trees and from every angle it seems you are guaranteed a good picture. Could have happily spent longer there.
absolutely wonderful. bring your camera and water and comfortable shoesWe used a tuktuk for the day about $15 and he took us around a few temples
Must See. One of the top three at the Angkor site. Here you'll see the iconic four faces of Buddha.

Angkor. The individual sites are quite different but just as interesting. Be selective as to which sites you plan to visit as one can easily be 'Ruined out' so be sure to do your research before you go or get yourself a good (certified) guide. The Cambodian Government has done an excellent job in training qualified Guides.
My Favourite Temple. Angkor Wat's awesome but Bayan was my favourite. Much more personality.
BREATHTAKING. THe best place on earth. The people are amazing and the temples are something out of a story book.
A must visit!. Angkor Wot is the big and fancy temple. Bayon however....wow.
One of the Must See near Angkor Wat. Only thing i disliked....to many people are visiting the sites same time, really overrunned, so makeing "THE PICTURE" is almost impossible.
breath taking. We actually enjoyed this temple better than Angkor Wat. The carvings were beautiful and told lots of stories.
Nice, but other temples are nicer. Nice temple, but in comparison to some others only scored as average with me.

Monumental history. On the drive to this temple you get to see the many many monkeys that interact and live alongside humans. This was my second time at the Bayon and it has changed dramatically. The upkeep of this site is lacking but you can still get a sense of the beauty and labor. It is a must see sight when visiting the temples. There is nothing else like it.
Impressive. Work done originally to construct these magnificent buildings must have been labour intensive and an architect's nightmore! Fancy being the Foreman.No dislikes.
Most beauiful temple. Amazing! Even though it was really hot and we were so tired, it was worth it! Beautiful temple.
A Good Introduction to Angkor Wat.. Started there so it was "all new" , Strongly advise using a car rather thanh a Tuk Tuk and a Guide is essential - unless you are very well 'read' and observant.
You have to be there if you go to Angkor!. Photos just don't do justice to the beauty of the Bayon. I even liked it better than Angkor Wat.
A smaller less crowded temple. Liked the causeway but hated the flow of traffic over it. Felt less overwhelming than Angkor Wat.
Enigmatic towers of faces. Enigmatic towers of faces (of the Bodhisattva of Compassion with the king's face) looking out in the four cardinal directions.
Lovely faces. My favourite temple with such beautiful faces. 54 different smiles :)
Breathtaking. To see in the flesh something only ever viewed on travelogues is quite overwhelming.
Every Wat is different.. Bayon is very beautiful. Quite different from the big name Wats. See them all. Bayon is part of the overall picture that should not be passed by.

Absolutely the highlight of all the temples!. This place is stunningly gorgeous. We went back a second time late in the day to see the sunset. The late afternoon lighting is beautiful for pictures, and one side the temple is perfectly reflected in a small pool.

Beautiful!!. Going at sunrise and seeing the huge faces coming into light from shadows is stunning! worth waking up early to beat the crowds as to see this temple in the eerie stillness makes it even more hauntingly beautiful!
Extraordinary temple, the best !. To be seen at 5:00pm to have the rigth ligth for the photos
,magic site. not so many tourists , very beatuful feeling about it

Definitely should make your temple shortlist!. Just amazing temple - very busy so best to go really early, or really late in the day - or just be prepared to wait for a photograph without someone else in it. Worth battling the hoards though.
Beautiful Temple. Amazing experience, really worth it to see...our tour guide and driver was wonderful.

a must see. when you visit Siem Reap, this place should also be included in your must see. a giant smile is a bit creepy but looking at it makes you feel that he is trying to say something. very wonderful.
Absolute favorite of all the temples. The faces are spectacular, and if you can catch a moment between the giant tour groups, this temple still manages to be mystical and brilliant.
One of the great wonders of the world. We were in awe just being here, totally breath-taking
Another amazing temple. Love this peace and quiet of sunrise but were glad to escape before the bulk of the tourists!
One of my favorites. This temple is amazing. The stories on the south wall and the faces are truly stunning!!
My favorite. I found the Bayon the most beautiful of the temple complexes we visited. The faces seemed to follow me ala Mona Lisa! A more managable size to Ankor wat.
Magical. Amazing get a pic of you nose to nose with one of the heads!

One of my favourites!. We spent a month filming a documentary in Cambodia, visiting many temples, numerous times. This one is simply stunning - so unique, with the smiling faces! Very pretty. We were lucky enough to go in the low season, with the rain, so the place was sometimes completely abandoned! It's especially special then, when you are there alone. A magic place. A must see.

must see. The faces of Bayon are so well preserved and you are allowed to walk around and in the temple itself, so you can get close to carvings. It's much more interesting than just standing outside behind barricades.
Visit in the Early Evening. For the best photos, make this the last visit of the day or at least before you return to Angkor Wat to see the sunset.

....Another World Wonder. .....After Angkor Wat on the first day we visited the Bayon Temple on the second day,and it keeps me astonished as well.Buy a book about the temple complexes and their history from the local kids which are offering you to buy one.Just try to understand they need to make a living and stay polite,I bought on for $5 in the end......

Eerily Amazing.... The Bayon Temple is about a 10 min. tuk-tuk ride from the main Angkor temples. Better if you'd drive by and enter through the South Entrance which happens to be the most restored of all the entries leading to the temple, an hour to an hour 1/2 would be a good time to explore the place especially of you want to go to the top of the temple....great place to spend your sunset/sunrise to avoid the large tourist crowds. It could get a bit eerie as you can get lost in one of the courtyard mazes inside the huge faces looking down at you from all sides!
My favorite. Out of all the temples, definitely my favorite! One not to miss; don't miss the Victory Gate as well!

must visit. Bayon is one of the must see sites within the Angkor complex. The faces are amazing, where ever you look one of the faces is looking back at you. This is one of the temples that's just great to explore, lots of hidden little places. It gets a little crowded in certain areas of the temple (like the stairs), especially if there's tour groups, but just make sure you have enough time to let the tour groups do their thing and then once they pass you'll be able to enjoy and get pictures on your own terms.
Stunning. I went back to Cambodia just to go to Bayon again. If you cannot get a great photo and feel the wonder of Cambodia at Bayon then you need to reevaluate why you travel at all.

Every angle is a stunning picture. This was my favourite temple of the Angkor Wat or Thom Wat area. All you want to do it take a picture after picture. If you are a camera nut, plan to spend time here!
Bayon Temple - ancient marvel. Fascinating relic of Cambodia's past. We spent hours exploring !
Fair.. I am not a temple fan and after Angkor Wat a bit of a disappointment. Too much of the same face to be seen all over
Elephant Ride was cool. Just for kicks you can be extra touristy and ride the elephants around the temple. great way to get awesome pics of the temple and surround area!
You can´t get enough of Bayon. I felt I could look at it for ages, Bayon temples is really impressive.
A must see. Very crowded even in the rain. Got a sore neck from trying to take it all in! There is so much going on here.
Truly Amazing!. The scale and the jungle location make this a truly amazing site!
Must see!. Amazing to just be in this place, incredible carvings, awesome.
All those smiling faces. As you would expect one of the most beautiful temples in Ankor

One of the better ruins to visit. very interesting ruin, but no shade so take an umbrella/parasol otherwise you may get heat stroke.
Now they have women in ethnic dress on the second floor trying to get you to have tacky photos taken with them.

So many faces.... so little time. It's a photographer's dream! We went during the late evening light and it was great. Another good time to go is early morning - especially to beat the large crowds that gather here.
Majestic. Loved the architecture , i simply didn't expect to see such a wonder. The pictures did not prepare me for the real thing

Breathtaking. All I can say is go as early as you can because it is breathtaking before the tour groups arrive.
Only down fall is that they still have Elephant rides in 2011 and they worst part is seeing tourist encourage it?

Amazing. This temple is amazing. It is so badly damaged from the roots on the ficus trees growing up between the stone slabs and pushing them apart yet alot of it is still together. The roots are whats really incredible - how they have taken over the whole temple and in some parts totally destroyed it into a crumbled heap on the ground yet in other parts these roots have grown over the stone walls and encased them. Its so wonderful to see that they are trying to rebuild the temples in the area.
The many faces of Bayon. It's overshadowed by the reputation of Angkor Wat, but would be a great destination if AW did not exist.
Beautiful!!!. the carvings are phenomenal.. beautiful stone faces are still intact. Wonderful experience and I'm sure you'll take lots of great pictures!
A dream come true. Bayon is a must since most of the architecture are intact and full-restored.

Surreal, and awe-inspiring. The Bayon is breathtaking...the multitude of carved Buddha faces is well known from the pictures, but is nothing compared to actually being there. The sheer scale of the place, the quality of the carvings, the condition of the carvings, the Naga balustrades, and the Apsaras are amazing.

My favourite.... Most tourists to Cambodia make a point of going to see Angkor Wat. On this, my second visit, Angkor Wat is a distant second (or maybe fifth) to Bayon. You have to experience the magic yourself to truly appreciate the magic of the upper tier, with the many faces of Buddha (a photographers dream location) and the adventure-inspiring passages beneath. Bayon is especially inspiring early in the morning (6:00) or late in the afternoon (after 4:00).
Amazing!. he highlight out of all the temples. It is incredible!
Fantastic. Great experience. Enjoyed the many faces all over the temple complex.
In a class of its own. While part of Angkor Tom, Bay is beautiful on its own.The faces of the temple states are really quite spectacular.
My favorite of all the temples. I must have taken 100 pictures at this temple. My favorite of them all.

Awesome temple for photography. Fun to wander but even better to photograph. This place lends itself to great evening photography with soft light, nice skies and classic Angkor lines. Come early and set up for late light.
Smiling Faces. This is by far my favorite Temple! the smiling faces are such a wonderful work of art!
My favorite temple. This is an amazing temple to visit and should not be missed. More than 200 faces look out in all directions and the rest of the temple is just as amazing. Do not miss this one!
The best work. Spend time in this temple as in the paradise. We recommend to hire a guide to reveal the history

Spectecular. Amazing after Angkor Wat. I enjoyed taking photographs here. The structure, the build up keep me in awe. I wish I had a tour guide or a guide book with me to tell me more about Bayon. Will definitely be back here and I make sure I read up about Bayon before I come.
Awesome experience. It was very surreal to be walking through this temple. The big faces watching over the temple are truly awesome. Don't miss it.

eerie. The giant faces all over this temple seemed almost like spirits pressing out of the walls. The atmosphere here, especially towards the end of the day when we arrived with fewer crowds and a darkening sky overhead, was mysterious and eerie. Of all the temples we visited, this one made me feel the presence of the ancient Angkor peoples the most.Another must-see, alongside Angkor Wat at sunrise, Ta Prohm, Beng Mealea, and Banteay Srei.
amazing temple made of rocks. I was amazed how the ancient people built this with stones or rocks and formed them into human faces, etc

Stunning.. Coming from the west part of the world, this culture is very interesting. Siem Reap treasures a very peculiar cultura that shows Buddhism and Hinduism together. Place is very big with a lot of very well maintained ruins. But be prepare to walk, a lot, and it is general very hot.

Spine-tinglingly stunning!. The Bayon which is situated right in the centre of Angor Thom was one of our favourite temples in the Angkor complex. We visited it twice; once in the morning and once in the afternoon. Take your time and have a good look around the outside; the views with the towers reflected in the water that surrounds it (if you're there near to the rainy season) are stunning. To avoid the crowds go early; right after seeing sunrise at Angkor Wat is a great time.The enigmatice faces that gaze over your every step with whistful smiles are captivating and very, very atmospheric. How many individual faces can you capture in the same photograph? Don't forget to keep an eye out for the frequent elephant rides that pass by and the same faces on the towers that stand over the gates of Angkor Thom.
one of the better temples. We were only at Angkor for one day. We saw many temples but this one was high on the list and we were glad we made it there, a must-see!!

Must see ruins.... Pros:
-Amazing piece of history and well preserved ruins. Tour
-Tour guides are very knowledgeable and polite
Cons:
-Not fault of site, but very hot - come prepared to sweat!

Another Magnificent Masterpiece. Other than Angkor Wat, Bayon is another magnificent structure that it worth visiting. I just couldn't help but watch in awe as my mind wandered off and imagined how they could have constructed a magnificent structure like this without the aid of modern technology.But the fact remains. Even without modern building technologies, the Bayon temple, which was said to have been built in the 12th century, has survived the ravages of time and today standing as a testimony of the great civilization which had built it.Due to the sheer size of the temple, you need to spend quite some time wandering around and taking in the sights in order for you to understand the sheer enormity of this wonderful structure. Do ensure your have your camera with you as there many wonderful sights to capture. Also do make sure you are dressed lightly as the weather can be rather hot and stuffy. And one more thing...do watch your steps as the stairs here can be quite steep.

A Wonderful tribute to probably the most Vain man!. Stupendous! Find out how the stone was brought there - its fascinating.Look for for the tourist policeman - Larry - he is very interesting , informative and makes a quick buck on the side. I would recommend him over any tour guide to Bayon.
So many tourists. This temple we visited with a guide, so he could tell us more about it, but it was so full with people, that was not nice. Maybe visit this better very early in the morning.

An architectural masterpiece. This is a 900 year old temple that provides a view of the past and how advanced the ancient Angkor civilization at that time.The whole temple is stunningly amazing. Every turn of the corner is a must photo opportunity for visitors.The temple is surrounded by bas-relief that narrates the daily activities in and around the temple. The four-face tower was one of the most photograph site in this temple.

Stunning. This was one of the highlights of my whole trip. Give yourself plenty of time to wander around and take in the atmosphere and make sure your camera is charged as there are great views all over the temple.
awesome. amazed with all the scrupture of Buddha's faces. the buildings, scriptures on the walls and steps
Amazing bas reliefs. View the bas reliefs and imagine the background painted red, the foreground painted gold and the changing light during the day. It would create an old style moving picture show.
TA PROM. The sculpting of the ancient ruler was great. The tour guide was wonderful at explaining the history and the architecture of Bayon Temple.

Stunning Face Towers All Over!. This stunning Buddhist temple was under some renovation when I visited in July. There were some wooden planks and some scaffolds. Still a must-visit attraction here in Siem Reap, beside Angkor Wat.Even from afar, I was amazed by the view of this temple; with the stunning face towers all over. It was said to have 37 towers all in all. This place was very crowded, and everyone was busy taking photographs! Bayon is just full of photo opportunities. The best would be when the monks visit; and they are normally very friendly and obliging to pose for photos if you ask.Bayon is definitely famous for the faces; but the reliefs on the surrounding walls are quite an amazement too. Some are still in high details, good conditions. If you have time, go along the surrounding walls and enjoy the reliefs.Wear a hat, and bring water as it can be very hot in the open.

WOW !!!. Now thats what I would doff my hat to. What vision and what execution. A 900 yr old temple with 54 towers and 4 massive faces on each tower makes the whole structure look extremely impressive. One of the top must-dos at Siem Reap.

Temple visits. Best of all the Temples. We went to the Siem Reap Museum the day before and we were able to identify with this temple in particular with the carved faces, door lintels and carved colums within this temple.
Amazing. The faces of Bayon temple are so amazing. Wonderful carvings!
Get ready to be stunned!. An amazing building - on a grand scale. just go, look and wonder at the sheer size and beauty.

amazing. We visited this temple on a full day tour which included ta prom, bayon, ta prom, angkor wat ..and.. we overdid it!Next morning after sunrise at Angkor, we decided to get another perspective of the Bayon.. so elephant ride it was. ..this was great. Certainly saw things I had not noticed the day before when we were clamboring all over.. highly recommend this extra cost.
A step back in time. I enjoyed the entire complex, something I would highly recommend. Best to get a Tuk Tuk around. No shortage of opputunities to buy food and water.
even better than Angkor !. everybody knows Angkor but this place is even more impressive
Really Cool. you'll dig the big faced buddha and get to kiss the nose of one

Worth seeing this one first. A magical introduction into the 'Angkor' temples......Built to honour the fabled king Jayavaman VII........ Take a guide, try for dawn or dusk - (the best time to visit ALL the temples) and take your time. The Bayon is not as restored as Ankor Wat and (much smaller as are all the other temples) yet these are not negatives.
Best site to see!. This was my absolute favorite site in all of Angkor park. Probably the most amazing thing I've ever seen, was so cool I went back twice more to see it again!
Enigmatic temple. Feel stunned, and strange. A must visit attraction
More history. not as big as Angkor Wat but equally impressive, you will need an umbrella should it rain.

Breath takingly beautiful. This temple is absolutely exquisite. Take your time to have a thorough look at the architecture, you will see just how much detail and hard work went into building the structure. Will never forget my time there!!!

Awesome. Great temple, if you ony visit two or three temples in this are, this has to be one of them. Compact and stunning, loads to see and great photo opportunities.Be aware there are some very steep steps to get to the central walkway, they are only short but quite steep.Watch out for pickpockets but generally once you are in the hawkers have gone.
AMAZING. A different perspective by elephant - MUST hire a guide, it's amazing, they know all the tidbits. Fantastic place.
Mysterious Faces. Bayon is a surreal experience. Especially enjoyed in the early hours of morning

Maybe more impressive than Angkor. After Angkor we didn't expect anything else to knock our socks off. Well Bayon Temple is as impressive, if not more. Don't miss it! If you're on a bike it's just a 5 minute ride to Bayon from Angkor.

A great place, don't miss it!. Take your time and walk around the temple. We had great luck that we were more or less the only tourists there and we felt as if we were right in a movie set. Angkor Wat is the most famous temple of Angkor but you should mot miss the smaller ones. You get a better feeling of former times there.

For a great Bayon experience, get there early. Bayon is by far the most interesting temple in the Angkor Wat small loop, but for a truly special experience, get to the park early at about 5:30am right when it opens. After you watch the sunrise from in front of Angkor Wat, make your way to Bayon in Angkor Thom (while everyone else enters Angkor Wat instead) and experience the strange feeling of being in a giant shrine all alone, without anything but the morning light and the giant faces to accompany you. If you want to know more, I also wrote a lesson about it on my blog: http://traversary.posterous.com/lesson-get-up-early-to-really-experience-bayo

Wonderful, Amazing, Beautiful.
