This was the first temple we saw on our 8 day stay in Siem Reap, and it was a fantastic starting point, the Beautiful Smiling faces against the clear blue skies, stunning.We had our guide who added so much value to the temple, providing us insights into the history and mythology behind the building its statues and carvings.
Don't miss this!! Beautiful Pictures!. This temple looks amazing.. we were there for several hours!!

Favorite ruin in all of Angkor!. The Bayon is by far my favorite temple in the entire Angkor Complex. It is a lot less crowded than Angkor Wat and I find the giant faces to be absolutely fascinating! I have been to Angkor twice and both times the rest of my group is practically dragging me out of this temple. I'm sure all tour will include this temple, but make sure you really take time to explore this and take in the wonder of the construction.
WOW !!! what a temple !!! A must visit. Its a temple with towers in the form of smiling Buddhas !!!!!

The temple of the faces, interesting and a must see. Located within Angkor Thom. Highly recommend to visit. This is on par with Angkor Wat, a must see. The Bayon temple was built in the late 12th to 13th centuries. You will need quite a bit of time to go through here especially if you are into photography. It is quite extensive and there are lots of photo opportunities.This temple is famous because it is the temple of the faces so to speak. You can see faces on many of the stone structures. And in some cases you can go nose to nose or face to face with the statues for picture opportunities.If you need a guide, I would highly recommend this one, he was fantastic! See information and my review here: http://www.tripadvisor.com/Attraction_Review-g297390-d2178241-Reviews-Thoeunson_Private_Tour-Siem_Reap.htmlThe Bayon temple cannot be missed, it is located within Angkor Thom. Angkor Thom has many temples but this one is one of the best of the bunch in this area simply because of the architecture and photographic opportunities. You will need at least one hour here depending on your interest.Use your Angkor pass that you bought to get into here.
Awesome. Bayon is not to be missed, an almost magical surreal experience that I will never forget.

Best of the Cambodian Temples. I spent a week in Siem Reap and visited all the temples, well almost all, but I have to say the temple that left the biggest impression was Bayon. It felt "less restored" which means you got the feeling you were seeing the actual temple, not someone's reconstruction of it. There was lots to see. It was very picturesque. If you are viewing the temples in chronological order, you will probably want to start with this one as it is the last one built, then work backwards through time. Doing it this way allows you to see the changes in religious beliefs of the area, and small architectural changes. It's all so overwhelming so if you pick a theme, such as chronological, it can help bring order to it all making it more enjoyable.

Don't miss. One of our favorite temples. Part of the Angkor Thom complex, this temple is quite unique and within walking distance of several other temples (Baphuon, Phimeanakas, Preah Palilay) and Terrace of the Leper King and the Elephant Terrace. We loved the many smiling faces. If if you're not too exhausted/hot/templed-out, check out the other temples. We thought they were worth the extra effort.
Breath taking. Beautiful and very underrated. Make sure you don't miss out while visiting the Angkor Wat. Enter the gates on the back of the elephant for the ultimate cultural experience.
Favourite temple of all. Best Buddhist temple with intricate wall carvings and sculptures. Took tons of photos there and very well preserved.

4 head temple. A must see.. This budist temple is a must see. The towers with the four faces are very beautiful and you can take awesome photos playing with their position. We recommend this beautiful temple.
My preferred!. Just get the chance to be there at a different time than the crowd, and you will enjoy the specific touch of the place!
Smile that will never forget. The smile of Bayon is amazing just like that of Khmer kids, pure and peaceful. Another icon of Cambodia except the Angkor Wat.

Ride an Elephant into Bayon Temples!!!!. My favorite temple! I highly recommend getting an elephant ride to the Bayon Temple. What a fantasic way to enter this temple! You can also buy bananas to feed the elephants. This is the most unique tempe I have seen. A must see in Cambodia! On your way back there are monkeys on the side of the road to feed too! (on a side note, there is a nice bathroom at the elephant ride stop)
Cool faces. This has the most elaborate and interesting faces. It is worth seeing. Have a guide to point you in the right direction and explain the various things.

Definitely worth the visit. Bayon is another good temple to visit, it may be one of the main ones, but isn't anywhere near as busy as Angkor Wat. Its inside walls at Angkor Thom (in the centre) surrounding by lots of forest. What I like a lot of the temples in Angkor is that you can go and explore on your own and pretty much go where you please, of course sticking to paths and not going beyond any sealed access areas. But you are pretty much free. There is a multitude of stone faces carved and many towers which surround a main tower, you can visit varying levels, although the stairs are steep they are not as much so as some of the other temples. The place is in good condition considering it being 12th or 13th century.This place has plenty of photo opportunities. We felt we didn't need a guide and stuck to our book, we could take our time and enjoy our visit. from Bayon you can pretty much go to the other temples near by on foot and meet your tuk tuk driver somewhere else. There are plenty of people selling drinks so you won't go thirsty and places to get food.

Serene smiling faces .... The best time to visit this temple is not in the middle of the day - it gets very hot and also extremely crowded. We went between eight and nine in the morning when it's a bit cooler and the light is nice. At this time of day you can even hear the bats twittering where they roost in the holes in some of the giant towers!The faces are beautiful and serene in the forest setting. Very photogenic - I changed many of my photos to sepia as it seemed to lend them even more atmosphere!

The faces of Bayon. Bayon is one of the earlier temples if you're entering from the back of the Angkor Archeological Complex, and is absolutely beautiful, and thankfully not much of a climb compared to the other temples. The huge faces of Bayon are on the towers and are pretty impressive up close. There are also a troupe of apsara dancers that you can take photos with for a dollar or two on top of the temple. Bayon is also the closest temple to the elephants rides as well, for those who are interested in catching an elephant ride.

The most beautiful temple in Angkor. Just incredible with many towers and the smiling faces. There also many carvings on the walls and if you have a guide you will get the most from the visit. But the faces on the towers are the best part of this temple. I think that this was the most beautiful temple in Angkor area.They even have elephants close by so you can ride a tour around the temple if you like.

My FAVORITE temple of them all!. Bayon is in my opinion the most beautiful temple in all of Angkor Kingdom. The attention to detail that was put into this temple is amazing. It's more complex than most of the other temples and will test your leg muscles if you intend to scale up every single set of stairs (though you don't have to). What makes Bayon unique and recognizable from the other temples is the faces carved into the pillars. It's beautiful and I'm amazed that after all these centuries, most of the faces are still perfect. We spent about two hours roaming this temple in the heat of October (I can't imagine how unbearably hot it'd be mid-summer) but still had a blast. Pack a lot of water and nothing else...you'll regret lugging around anything else!

a must place to visit for ancient lovers. besides Angkor Wat.... Angkor Thom's Bagan temple is a must see item.... we would enjoy the engineering work during the time where technology is a question/ might also wonder what happen to the civilazation.... Cambodian people had a good attitude towards preserving the past for our future to see and fell...USD is widely use.... but pls. keep small change... as the balance payment mostly paid in cambodian money

Bayon 49 towers only!. Many guide books mention that Bayon got 54 towers, but in fact there are only 49 towers. 37 of them got 4 faces, two of them 2 faces and ten 3 faces....and now you can only see 137 faces.... If you stand in the east and count the towers from there...first tower is with four faces, second with four faces too, third with three faces and the last one with two faces only.....

Greatest Temple in Angkor Thom. Bayon is beautiful, with its special feature- a lot of faces, of the king Jayavarman VII. With 54 towers and more than 200 faces, and the center prasat as high as 14 stories building, the temple is simple magnificent (of course, magnitud wise less than Angkor Wat). Bayon is around 2 km northward from Angkor Wat. We will passby the great south gate of Angkor Thom in between. My advice, avoid putting in Bayon together with Angkor Wat in a same itinerary, unless you have a very strong feet (as it was too much for most of my family members). The temple is much more exposed than Angkor Wat. So, sufficient sunscreen/sunblock or an umbrella might help. Try to climb to the top of the temple to see the faces closely. The feeling is very different from just watching them afar down the entrance. I am quite agree with the reviewer saying that an pre-visit enrichment of knowledge about this place is essential, or else, we might just inteprete the whole Angkor Archeological Park as a pile of stones in ruins.Pay a little bit of attention to the bas-reliefs on Bayon, as the stories told are more focused on daily life, instead of more religion-liked at Angkor Wat. The bas-relief inscribed how Khmer Empire built all the great ancient temples as well. For more of my experience in Siem Reap and Angkor Archaeological Park, pls visit my blog at:http://bettyandlingshing.blogspot.com/2010/12/bayon-and-surrounding-area.html

“Smiling face”. The Bayon is incredibly beautiful. It has 216 huge smiling faces of the King Jayavarman VII as the Buddha's reincarnation, faces one of the four directions. Fifty-one smaller towers surrounded the central tower. The faces are carved with lips, eyes and each tower has four massive heads carved into its top. I loved the layout of the temple and this temple is one of my favourite temple. I took many pictures here.

Unforgettable. This temple is one of my favourite, not to mention Angkor Wat. It is famous of its giant stone faces. There is 216 faces in the whole temple ( 54 towers/ 4faces each). Probably Faces represent Buddha or Bodhisattwa Avalokiteshvara. Built in the late 12th century or early 13th century by Jayavarman VII, first floors are a pantheon dedicated to the gods Khmers of the beginning of its construction, in a time of transition between the Hinduism and the Buddhism. The superior floor is dedicated to Buddha. Fabulous low reliefs of 1200m of length and representing more than 11000 sculptured persons, very long frescoes telling the fights and the naval battles between the Khmers and the Chams, as well as the daily life..

Love it!. For all those who want to visit this complex be sure have a good guide book or book yourself a tour guide because if you don't know anything about Bayon Temple then all that you will see there are just pile of stones carved with faces. Do your own research before arriving in Siem Reap so you could appreciate the temples. I will not recommend any guide but all hotels and guest houses in Siem Reap could arrange that for you. This complex is mostly open air so it is best if you wear light clothes and bring an umbrella to protect you from the midday sun and the rain.This is also where you can ride on top of an elephant and have a tour around the surrounds of Bayon.
My favourite temple so far... This is my favourite temple so far, I couldnot get over the amount of faces on the towers.
Lots of faces. Cool temple with lots of faces and good fun for perspective shots!

Whadya Staring At????. Pretty unique and interesting temple which is well worth your time!Bayon is avery well restored temple considering its age. You don't really realise the number of faces it has till you actually step closer. The carvings on the walls on the lower levels tell you a good history of the place.One of the temples you shouldn't omit on your Angkor tour!

Buddhas, Buddhas everywhere!. After Angkor Wat itself, Bayon is probably the best known temple in the Angkor area. Each of the numberous towers has four faces of Buddha, one facing each cardinal point. Anywhere you are in this temple, there are numerous Buddhas smilely down upon you. The layout of the temple itslef is also interesting. It is built on more of a circular plan than the other tempples in the area.This temple is a definate must-see.
